title: 'ORDINARY PEOPLE' WINS THE ACADEMY AWARD FOR BEST PICTURE
description: ''Ordinary People,'' the story of a family shattered by a catastrophe, was named the best picture of 1980 tonight at an Academy Award ceremony delayed for 24 hours by the assassination attempt on President Reagan.

title: AROUND THE WORLD
description: The Israeli state-controlled radio said today that one guerrilla and seven Lebanese civilians were killed in the seaborne Israeli raid on the southern coast of Lebanon early today.

title: MUDDY WATERS A BIG 66
description: SEEING Muddy Waters at the Beacon Theater on Saturday, it was hard to believe that the great blues master will be 66 years old on Saturday. Both vocally and instrumentally, he completely dominated his six-piece band and outshone his special guest, the Texan guitar virtuoso Johnny Winter, who produced Mr. Waters's recent albums.

title: It's Spring for Trout Fans
description: Lured by the knowledge that New York State's trout streams, lakes and ponds are in unusually good condition for angling, thousands of fishermen will be testing their skill and luck today, the opening of the trout season.

title: Advertising; Magazine Departure For Rodale
description: FEW if any magazine publishing companies have quite as strong a philosophy as Rodale Press. Through its chairman, Robert D. Ro@dale, who has been described as ''guru of the organic movement'' (as was the late I.J. Rodale, his father, before him), the privately held company has a commitment not only to the organic field, but also to natural life styles and self-sufficiency. The only trouble is that the readership of most of its four publications - Organic Gardening, Prevention, Bicycling and New Shelter - tend to be on the high side of middle-aged.

title: ELDERLY SHOPPERS LEAVE FEARS AT HOME
description: ''This is wonderful,'' said Charles Alekel as he stood in the bright spring sunshine yesterday, surrounded by friends and protected by the police.

title: Wine Calendar
description: Christie's, the auction house, has temporarily abandoned its effort to hold a wine auction in New York and has scheduled its first wine sale in this country for April 25 in Chicago. Three wine shops in New York had sued to block the sale that Christie's had scheduled for last Dec. 9 at its Park Avenue offices.

title: REDISCOVERING ITALY'S FAMOUS RICE DISH
description: ''RISOTTO alla Milanese is a forgotten treasure,'' says Gianni Minale of the Alfredo restaurant, 240 Central Park South. Italy's most famous rice dish has been displaced by the current craze for pasta. But people are beginning to discover it again.

title: Welch to Go on Trial Wednesday
description: Bernard C. Welch is scheduled to go on trial Wednesday for the slaying of Dr. Michael Halberstam, whom Mr. Welch allegedly shot on Dec. 5 when Dr. Halberstam surprised him in the course of a burglary of the Halberstam home.

title: BEST BUYS
description: The average weekly cost of feeding a family of four went up 19 percent to $102.88 during the two-week period March 16 to March 27, according to the New York City Department of Consumer Affairs. Shoppers paid 11 percent more than during the same period a year ago, when the market basket cost an average of $92.57.

title: The Region; Agencies Working To Keep Trains Cool
description: WHITE PLAINS (UPI) - Metropolitan Transportation Authority and Conrail officials said they have made important strides in efforts to keep air-conditioners working on trains this summer. They would not guarantee, however, that the units would always work.

title: Carter Declares Danger To Presidents Is Routine
description: Former President Jimmy Carter said today that he was shocked by the attempted assassination of President Reagan but that any President knew that danger went with the job.

title: U.S. Spy Planes Going to Britain
description: The United States will station new spy planes in Britain beginning in 1983, Geoffrey Pattie, Britain's Under Secretary for Defense, said today.

title: Market Place; Upward Trend Is Foreseen
description: HALF an hour before trading began yesterday morning on the New York Stock Exchange, Martin D. Sass was asked how he thought prices would open. ''I expect the market will be rejoicing because of relief,'' he replied. He heads M.D. Sass Investor Services Inc., which manages $350 million in client money.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: IT is a well-known fact that chefs and professional cooks in the kitchen have a language - some people call it a code - that is all their own. Various names are given to some dishes - sauces, for example -and if you mention one dish (they run into the thousands), it is unnecessary to go into detail as to how that dish is prepared. There is a word for it.

title: ONE COUNTRY'S DUMP IS ANOTHER'S BASKET
description: To the Editor:

title: 'ARE WE A SICK PEOPLE?'
description: Within moments of the shootings of President Reagan, his press secretary, and two law-enforcement officers, the nation was informed, and immediately the terrible scene was enacted again and again on television screens. There could have been few mature viewers who did not respond with a despairing sense of deja vu, emotionally and visually recalling the slaying of John F. Kennedy.

title: JONES, LEFEBVRE TRADED TO PADRES
description: Just 24 hours before the interleague trading deadline, the Yankees tonight traded four players, including Ruppert Jones, to the San Diego Padres for Jerry Mumphrey, a center fielder, and John Pacella, a right-handed pitcher formerly with the Mets.

title: ARMS CONTROL'S AGENCY
description: When rumors started to fly in November that members of the Reagan transition team were considering a recommendation to dismantle the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, most experienced observers dismissed the possibility.

title: COMBINATION OF FACTORS IS FOUND TO BE CONDUCIVE TO ASSASSINATIONS IN AMERICA
description: A national emphasis on civil liberties for the mentally ill, the lack of cultural restraints upon expressions of hostility and the ready availability of pistols are combining to make assassination an increasingly common American event, according to psychiatrists who have examined the problem.

title: The City; The Police Blotter
description: David John Lao, a 20-year-old security guard who lives at 1038 Lowell Street, the Bronx, was arrested and charged with setting a fire Sunday at the Vista International New York Hotel in the World Trade Center. ... Six men wearing ski masks escaped with $100,000 in furs and animal skins from the 18th-floor offices of Creation by Diorr Furriers at 330 Seventh Avenue. The robbers, armed with two handguns, handcuffed seven employees and locked them in a bathroom as they arrived for work at 8 A.M. ... A man suspected of breaking into a car parked on West 35th Street near Fifth Avenue was shot once in the right shoulder by Police Officer Joseph Campbell when the man allegedly drew a knife on the officer during a struggle. The suspect, Juan Francisco Montilla, 26, of 1350 Amsterdam Avenue was reported in good condition at Bellevue Hospital.

title: John Harms, Concert Impresario And Organist in Bergen County
description: John Harms, concert impresario in Bergen County and an organist and choral director, died at Englewood (N.J.) Hospital on Monday at the age of 74.

title: SIXERS DEFEAT PACERS
description: Julius Erving scored 32 points and Bobby Jones and Darryl Dawkins added 20 apiece tonight to lead the Philadelphia 76ers to a 124-108 victory over the Indiana Pacers in the opener of their two-of-three game National Basketball Association playoff series.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: FIFTEEN years ago, the Rolling Stones and the Who were rock's angriest, most outspoken groups. The Rolling Stones demanded ''Satisfaction,'' and in ''My Generation,'' the Who sang defiantly, ''Hope I die before I get old.'' One might have expected both groups to fall to pieces after their first moments of glory; many of their contemporaries did.

title: FOR NANCY REAGAN, A TIME OF CONCERN AND SMALL TALK
description: Nancy Reagan's home away from the White House today was a small, sterile hospital room in the intensive care unit of George Washington University Hospital, one door away from where her husband lay recovering from a gunshot wound.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We did not gain anything. Walesa has made bungled decisions. We can compromise on the supply of onions, but not when blood has been spilled.''

title: NOW Convocation on 'New Leadership'
description: More than 400 representatives of business, women's groups and the public sector were told this week that the women's movement has come to the ''end of the beginning,'' and that it must now enter a second stage. Betty Friedan, a founder of the National Organization for Women, called for a coalition of interests of ''not women alone, and certainly not women against men,'' in working for the larger interests of the country, ''and doing what we did for ourselves 20 years ago.'' ''There is too much organization in special-interest and singleinterest groups,'' she said. ''We must have new activism, new voluntarism and a new transcendency of polarization.''

title: MAYO CLINIC: THE HOMETOWN BUSINESS
description: When the city of Rochester was debating whether to fluoridate the public water, the City Council asked the Mayo Clinic for its advice. The clinic, three blocks from City Hall, received the request via telegram.

title: Indian Students Fight Policemen In a Conflict Over Untouchables
description: University students fought with policemen today in the second day of riots in Baroda, in Gujarat state, and the authorities imposed an indefinite curfew on the western city, the United Press of India said.

title: ISAIAH TRUNK, AUTHOR OF A HISTORY OF JEWS DURING THE NAZI ERA
description: Isaiah Trunk, chief archivist of YIVO, the Jewish Research Institute, died Saturday. He was 75 years old. Mr. Trunk was one of the leading historians in the United States on the destruction of European Jewry during the Nazi era.

title: BODY OF YET ANOTHER BLACK FOUND AS 21ST IS IDENTIFIED
description: The body of a young black male was found today in the Chattahoochee River, about four miles from the spot where the 21st slain Atlanta child was found yesterday.

title: ENID BAGNOLD, 91, BRITISH PLAYWRIGHT
description: Enid Bagnold, the British playwright and novelist whose works included ''National Velvet,'' died today at her apartment in St. John's Wood in north London. She was 91 years old.

title: AMID THE DARKEST MOMENTS, A LEAVEN OF PRESIDENTIAL WIT
description: When President Reagan awoke this morning, an aide reported to him, ''You'll be happy to know that the Government is running normally.''

title: FULFILLING AMBITIONS IN THEIR AFTER HOURS
description: WHEN Helene Gurfein was growing up in Brooklyn, she dreamed about becoming a musical comedy star a la Jane Powell or Kathryn Grayson. ''My main claim to fame,'' she said, ''was that when I was 7 or 8, I could hit the same high note that Kate Smith hit when she sang 'God Bless America.' ''

title: New Light on Ghostwriting Case
description: Dennis King, the first writer arrested under New York State's law against ghostwriting research papers for college students, won an ''adjournment in contemplation of dismissal'' yesterday when the State Attorney General's office said in Criminal Court in Manhattan that its informant had been motivated by ''a political organization.''

title: ENGELHARD TO DIVIDE OPERATIONS
description: The Engelhard Minerals and Chemicals Corporation yesterday announced a plan for splitting up the two sides of its business - commodity trading and industrial operations - into two independent, publicly held companies.

title: West Germans' Iraq Job
description: Estel Hoesch Werke announced today that a subsidiary, Estel Tecna, heads a consortium that has won a $10 million order to enlarge a steel pipe plant near Basra, Iraq. Other members of the consortium are Estel Rohr and Maschinenfabrik Deutschland.

title: Massey Plans Cut In Capital Outlays
description: In what was termed ''largely a bookkeeping matter,'' Massey-Ferguson Ltd., a major international producer and marketer of agricultural and industrial equipment, announced plans for a capital reduction to be submitted for shareholder approval at the financially troubled company's annual meeting April 21.

title:
RED SMITH;
He Forgot to Duck
description: WHEN John F. Kennedy was President, he attended an Army-Navy football game in Philadelphia and, as protocol dictates, watched one half from Navy's side of the field and the other from Army's. Between halves, cadets and midshipmen in uniform lined up in twin files flanking the 50-yard line to form an honor guard. The President walked between the ranks, hatless and without an overcoat.

title: MANDATORY CURB ON USE OF WATER ORDERED BY KOCH
description: Mayor Koch yesterday announced tighter water restrictions that will be mandatory for homes and businesses in New York City. But the Westchester County Executive, Alfred B. DelBello, called instead for voluntary reductions in the county's water consumption.

title: EXCERPTS FROM HOSPITAL BRIEFING ABOUT VICTIMS
description: Following are excerpts from a news briefing at George Washington University Hospital yesterday morning conducted by Dr. Dennis S. O'Leary of the hospital staff and Lawrence Speakes of the White House press office, as recorded by The New York Times: STATEMENT BY O'LEARY

title: A Big Homecoming
description: Indiana's basketball champions were welcomed home today by thousands of cheering students and fans already looking forward to the Hoosiers' title defense next year.

title: Sports News Briefs; Testimony at Kush Trial Alleges Pattern of Abuse
description: Bob Owens, a former Arizona State University assistant football coach, testified today that he knew of at least 15 players who quit the team after physical and verbal mistreatment by the former Sun Devil head coach, Frank Kush.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Anatole Broyard IN SHELLY'S LEG. By Sara Vogan. 248 pages. Knopf. $10.95.

title: CONVERSIONS SHRANK RENTAL MARKET BY 5%, SAYS JERSEY TENANT LEADER
description: An officer of a New Jersey tenants' organization told a Congressional subcommittee today that in just two years the number of rental apartments in the state had shrunk by 5 percent because of conversion to condominiums.

title: Sherman Edwards, 61, Composer And Lyricist for '1776,' Is Dead
description: Sherman Edwards, composer and lyricist for ''1776,'' which won the New York Drama Critics Circle and Tony Awards in 1969, died Monday at a friend's home in Manhattan.

title: Economic Scene; Specter of Crisis In Global Debt
description: THE shock wave from the attempt on the life of President Reagan spread through the world financial system within minutes. Panic was forestalled by the quick closing of the New York Stock Exchange and by the news that, following surgery to remove the bullet from his lung, the President was not in danger.

title: BACK-DOOR AID ABROAD
description: While controversy swirls around the Reagan Administration's proposal to send an additional $25 million in military aid to El Salvador in fiscal 1981, various aid offices around Washington are quietly assembling a total financial- and military-aid package that could reach $523 million.

title: VALIDITY OF MARCOS'S '73 CONSTITUTION IS CHALLENGED
description: The validity of the 1973 Philippine Constitution under which the Government of President Ferdinand E. Marcos has ruled was challenged today by 130 of the 311 members of the body that drafted it.

title: SADAT DISCLOSES ACCORD TO SELL IRAQ AMMUNITION FOR SOVIET MADE ARMS
description: President Anwar el-Sadat announced today that Egypt was selling ammunition to Iraq even though, he said, he still believed the Iraqis should not have invaded Iran last September.

title: No Headline
description: Elliott Maddox, in the Yankee spring camp for a tryout after having been released by the Mets, forced Michael to make a decision about his status Monday night and the manager told the outfielder-third baseman there was no place for him on the roster.

title: A LIFE THAT STARTED OUT WITH MUCH PROMISE TOOK RECLUSIVE AND HOSTILE PATH
description: For John Warnock Hinckley Jr., the youngest of the three children of a prosperous oilman, life had begun full of promise. He had grown up in a luxurious home and attended perhaps the most elite public high school in Dallas. He was a quiet boy, many friends recall, not particularly memorable, perhaps, but certainly not unfriendly or hostile.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Advanced Patent Technology Inc. securities were suspended from trading through April 19 by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: BSN to Sell Units to Asahi
description: BSN-Gervais Danone S.A. said today that it would sell 80 percent of its Belgian subsidiary, Glavebel S.A., and 80 percent of its Dutch Unitglasfabriek de Maas B.V. to the Asahi Glass Company of Japan for 290 million French francs, or about $58 million.

title: OPERA: ARIEL BYBEE IN 'MAHAGONNY'
description: WHEN Teresa Stratas took ill before the Monday performance of Kurt Weill's ''Rise and Fall of the City of Mahagonny,'' the Metropolitan Opera turned to Ariel Bybee to take the role of Jenny. Miss Bybee, a regular performer at the Met since 1977, had sung the part previously in San Francisco.

title: Emissions Test Method Approved
description: The Environmental Protection Agency yesterday gave the Armco Steel Corporation approval to begin using the controversial ''bubble'' method to measure emissions from its plant in Middletown, Ohio.

title: McDonnell, Airline In Air Crash Accord
description: American Airlines and the McDonnell Douglas Corporation have reached an out-of-court agreement to share the liability for the 1979 crash that killed 273 people at Chicago's O'Hare International Airport, it was announced today in Federal District Court in Chicago.

title: Careers; Needed: Experts on Fire Safety
description: TOWERING infernos in Las Vegas, the nursing home fires in New Jersey and a motel disaster in Westchester County, with their high death tolls, have focused attention on fire protection as an important career opportunity. About two years ago the Society of Fire Protection Engineers estimated that at least 5,000 fire protection experts would be needed in the next five years, but only about 50 graduated that year with B.S. degrees.

title: CITIBANK IN EL SALVADOR IS BOMBED
description: A bomb destroyed Citibank's offices in an 18-story office building today and knocked out windows across the street in the Camino Real Hotel.

title: PROFESSOR WROTE WIDELY IN FIELD
description: Dr. Jacob Swartz, a psychiatrist and psychoanalyst who was a professor of psychiatry at the Boston University School of Medicine, died Saturday at University Hospital in Boston after surgery. He was 59 years old and lived in Newton, Mass.

title: AROUND THE NATION
description: Mayor Jane M. Byrne tonight moved into an apartment in the crime-ridden Cabrini-Green housing project. Mrs. Byrne and her husband, Jay McMullen, moved into their fourthfloor apartment after dark, said the Mayor's press secretary, Ray McCarthy.

title: FLUOR PLANS TO ACQUIRE ST. JOE
description: The Fluor Corporation, one of the world's biggest engineering and construction companies, has agreed to buy the St. Joe Minerals Corporation for $60 a share, totaling nearly $2.9 billion, the two companies announced yesterday. The terms call for payment in cash and stock.

title: AGENCY OVERSEEING CONRAIL BACKS AID
description: The agency created by Congress to oversee the operations of Conrail, differing sharply with the Reagan Administration, called yesterday for continued Federal aid for the financially troubled rail system that spans the Northeast and reaches into the Middle West.

title: SOME FIND FRESH HOPE FOR ECONOMIC PROGRAM
description: Business and corporate leaders expressed relief yesterday that President Reagan had survived the assassination attempt in such remarkably good shape, and some said the episode - in particular the President's manifest calmness under stress -may even heighten chances of Congressional enactment of his economic program.

title: 2 BROTHERS OF CHARLES TO SERVE HIM AT RITES INSTEAD OF A BEST MAN
description: Prince Charles will have two official ''supporters'' rather than a best man at his wedding on July 29 to Lady Diana Spencer, Buckingham Palace announced today.

title: 'MOST UNDERRATED AND UNREWARDED JOB'
description: To the Editor:

title: New Roles at Time
description: Kelso Sutton, the new group vice president for magazines at Time Inc., has created a Financial and Development Group to handle various functions of the magazine division that had been taken care of by the corporate comptroller's department. And he has put Lawrence M. Crutcher, 38-year-old corporate circulation director in charge, with the title vice president-magazines, replacing him with S. Christo@pher Meigher 3d, 34, who was president of Time Distribution Services. Stepping into that vacancy will be Donald M. El@liman Jr., 36, who was circulation director of Time International.

title: Q. I am in junior high school. In reading ''Little Women'' I noted that the youngest girl and her schoolmates like the taste of pickled limes. Can you tell me how they are made?
description: A. There are many recipes for pickled lemons and limes. In each you can substitute one for the other. The commonest recipes call for making slits in the fruit without cutting them through. You add salt, which dissolves as it stands. The lemons or limes are left to stand for a considerable period before serving. In India, where pickled lemons and limes - called achar - are served sweet or hot, various spices are added, including cumin, chili pods, mustard seeds, fenugreek and so on.

title: DEWITT WALLACE, FOUNDER OF READER'S DIGEST, IS DEAD
description: DeWitt Wallace, who conceived and edited a pocket-sized magazine that as Reader's Digest became the most widely read magazine in the world, died of pneumonia at his home in Mount Kisco, N.Y., on Monday night at the age of 91.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: EVE MERRIAM is intrigued by the most mannerly of the recent graffiti efforts that she has observed. "This," she reports, "appeared in red capital letters on a building at the corner of Bleecker and Thompson Streets in the West Village": HI DO YOU MIND IF I TALK TO YOU FOR A WHILE? . . .

title: Japan Exports Still Strong
description: Japan's exports continued strong last month, the Finance Ministry and the Bank of Japan reported today, leading to a trade surplus for February of $1.38 billion.

title: THREE STARS, TRADITION AND, OUI, A HELIPAD
description: that the young chef can hold his own with the superstars in Paris and Lyons.

title: * To the Editor:$
description: Sorrow became outrage as I read the March 25 story about the millions of navel oranges left to rot in the sun to keep prices stable.

title: THAI GENERALS, CITING DICTATORSHIP THREAT, STAGE COUP
description: Thai army generals overthrew the year-old government of Gen. Prem Tinsulanonda today and established a revolutionary committee, the Thailand radio announced.

title: NAMIBIA REBELS IN ANGOLA TRAIN 10,000 CHIDREN
description: At a bend in the road, 40 boys and girls in blue shorts and red-peaked caps stand solemnly, holding handlettered placards in English reading, ''Reagan is a racist war monger but victory is certain,'' and ''Swapo condemns USA collaboration with South Africa and its puppets.''

title: BANK BOARD BACKS PLAN TO HELP SAVINGS UNITS
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board has given preliminary approval to a plan that would pump private capital into hard-pressed savings and loan associations, increase the income of the associations and provide new money for home mortgages.

title: Dillingham Weighs Hawaii Liquidations
description: The Dillingham Corporation, which recently announced a plan of partial liquidation, said that its directors expected to recommend that virtually all of its Hawaii real estate holdings be involved in its plan. Proceeds would be distributed to Dillingham shareholders.

title: M.D.'S HAD NO HIDDEN AGENDA'
description: To the Editor:

title: ALLERGIES OF SPRING: TO GET SHOTS OR NOT?
description: WHEN the buds of spring first appear on trees and shrubs, the thoughts of many a summertime wheezer and sneezer turn to allergy shots. Recalling how they suffered in previous years, many visit an allergist asking for injections to desensitize them to the causes of their recurrent misery. Some six million Americans choose shots as the solution to their allergies.

title: RAUL JULIA TO BE PROSPERO IN 'THE TEMPEST' IN PARK
description: SHAKESPEARE, conspicuously absent from Central Park last summer, is making a twofold return. Joseph Papp's annual presentation of free Shakespeare in the Park, replaced last summer by the hit revival of Gilbert and Sullivan's ''The Pirates of Penzance,'' will open with ''The Tempest,'' starring Raul Julia as Prospero. The first performance will be June 26. The second production of the summer will be ''Henry IV, Part I,'' to open at a date to be set.

title: The U.N. Today; April 1, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Special Committee on Enhancing the Nonuse of Force in International Rela- tions - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: GUNS TRACED IN 16 MINUTES TO PAWN SHOP IN DALLAS
description: The revolver used to shoot President Reagan was traced to Rocky's Pawn Shop in Dallas within 16 minutes of the time the gun's serial number was given to agents of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms yesterday afternoon, an official of the firearms agency said today.

title: CASTING NEW-SEASON FASHION VOTES
description: DESIGNERS have had their say. Designers are right now having their say. Designers will have their say again. But it all comes down to what women actually buy and wear.

title: MARKET AND BUSINESS RELIEVED
description: Buoyed by news that President Reagan was making an exceptionally strong recovery from the bullet wound he suffered Monday afternoon, the stock market rallied sharply yesterday.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: There are any number of occasions when binoculars would be useful - horse races, of course, or boat races in summer and football in the fall. But if they are powerful enough, they are often heavy and a nuisance to lug around. Nikon has come up with a practical solution. The company's new model - the 8-by-20 roof prism binoculars are small enough to fit into the palm of the hand and weigh only eight ounces. They're powerful enough to give clear images even if one is sitting up high in the bleachers. Another feature is adjustable rubber eye cups which make the binoculars comfortable even if one wears glasses. They come in black and silver metal and are attractive enough to have been accepted for the Museum of Modern Art's design collection. The Olden Camera Company, at 1265 Broadway (32d Street) has the binoculars priced at $159.95.

title: White Motor Bid
description: The Canadian Government said it would permit the TIC Investment Corporation of Dallas and Linamar Machine Ltd. of Ariss, Ontario, to acquire the farm equipment division of the White Motor Corporation of Canada Ltd., a wholly owned subsidiary of the White Motor Corporation of the United States, which is operating under bankruptcy laws. Terms of the transaction were not released. The Canadian Government said TIC, a privately held company, and Linamar would immediately reactivate White's combine manufacturing facilities at Brantford, Ontario, which have been closed since August.

title: Real Estate; Medical Offices in Manhattan
description: IN the last few years physicians practicing in rented quarters in cooperative apartment houses on the Upper East Side have been making an interesting discovery when their leases come due: The cooperative wants to sell them their space.

title: MATHEBULA: FALLEN CHAMPION
description: He was called Terror, and for the heady 15 weeks he reigned as the first black South African to hold a world championship, virtually all sides in this starkly divided country, with the exception of a fringe of black political activists, were ready to claim him proudly as their own.

title: FOR APRIL FOOL'S DAY, A DEN OF SERENDIPITY
description: It was a few days before April Fool's Day and Bob Fields, with thoughts of mischief in his head, had stopped off at his favorite den of serendipity, the Circle Magic Shop at 52rd Street and Broadway. Sy Sussman, also known as Sy Sands, was behind the counter laughing uproariously because he had just squirted a glob of blue ink on the white shirt front of another customer and the customer was stuttering with anger.

title: STAEMENT ISSUED BY PHYSICIAN
description: Dr. Daniel Ruge, the White House physician, issued the following statement today at 5 P.M.: The President continues on the road to recovery. He is doing extremely well.

title: Agent's Family Learns On TV He Is Wounded
description: Elizabeth McCarthy and her daughter Karen were watching the attack on President Reagan on television. ''Suddenly, as we watched, we saw where he was hit and fell,'' Karen McCarthy said.

title: Bond Prices Increase Slightly; 7-Year Notes Yield 13.34%
description: Bond prices rose slightly yesterday as dealers and speculators were encouraged by stability in overnight interest rates. ''Wall Street's sigh of relief that the President's injury was not more serious carried prices higher,'' one government securities dealer commented. He added that ''outright investor buying of new issues remains light, though many firms are willing to accumulate some inventory.''

title: CHINESE CLEAVERS
description: IT comes as a wearying surpise to some student cooks: The heat is the least part of cooking; the preparation is far more important. That's why cooks of the Western world developed such an elaborate system of knives. The Chinese, whose cuisine is also extremely reliant on preparation, arrived at the same place by a different route.

title: Notes On People; Eagle Scouting Award Honors Hospital Patient
description: ''Scouting has been my life since I was 8 years old, when I became a Cub Scout, and my greatest ambition has been to be an Eagle Scout,'' John Huneke said yesterday. ''It's scouting's highest honor.''

title: BLOCK ASKS PARING OF FARM AID
description: Agriculture Secretary John R. Block today proposed a new farm program that could halt any further increases in milk price supports this year and eliminate payments of subsidies to grain and cotton farmers in the future.

title: ISLANDERS BEATEN BY MONTREAL
description: Nothing lasts forever, the Montreal Canadiens finally proved tonight by defeating the New York Islanders, 3-1, at the Forum. Ended were the Islanders' 13-game unbeaten streak and their nine-game nonlosing record against the Canadiens that stemmed from Dec. 10, 1978.

title: TEXT OF THE 25TH AMMENDMENT
description: Following is the text of the 25th Amendment to the Constitution, which deals with Presidential succession. A White House official said that aides to the President had considered, and rejected, invoking its provisions.

title: MOON'S SECT LOSES LIBEL SUIT IN LONDON
description: In a case that could have wide international repercussions, the Unification Church of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon lost a major libel suit today against a London newspaper.

title: G.M. Joins Units
description: The automobile marketing organizations of Vauxhall Motors Ltd. and Adam Opel A.G. in Britain will be combined immediately, Vauxhall announced today.

title: Lucas of Nets Is Fined $2,000 for Misconduct
description: Maurice Lucas of the Nets has been fined $2,000 by the National Basketball Association for an altercation in Detroit two weeks ago.

title: He Was Checked, O'Neill Says
description: The Speaker of the House, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., said today that he received no extra protection after President Reagan was shot, but that he did get a call from the Federal Emergency Management Agency within minutes asking where he was and if he was safe. Representative O'Neill said he then received a call from Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. at 3:55 P.M. to brief him on the situation.

title: REAGAN, MAKING GOOD RECOVERY, SIGNS A BILL; WHITE HOUSE WORKING, BUSH ASSURES SENATE
description: Behind the Reagan Administration's approach to affairs of state today was a calculated strategy not only to reassure the outside world of its stability but also to protect the diplomatic effectiveness of Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr.

title: BULLS TOP KNICKS IN PLAYOFF OPENER
description: The Knicks collapsed in the final three periods last night, scoring only 56 points, and lost to the Chicago Bulls, 90-80, at Madison Square Garden in the opening game of their National Basketball Association playoff series.

title: The City; Defense Rests Case In Goody Tapes Trial
description: The defense rested its case at the tape-pirating trial of Sam Goody Inc. and a company vice president without calling a single witness. Judge Thomas C. Platt directed that summations begin today in Federal District Court in Brooklyn.

title: Gilmore Helps Slow Fast-Starting Knicks
description: At first, it was like the glory days. A little more than 10 minutes into the game last night, the Knicks led the Chicago Bulls, 22-8, in their National Basketball Association playoff opener. Madison Square Garden was rocking.

title: Chrysler Makes Payment on Loan
description: The Chrysler Corporation said it had made a $71 million payment due to its bankers as the first installment in a plan to retire $650 million in debt.

title: SHORT-TERM GAINS SEEN FOR G.O.P. BY POLITICIANS
description: Ever since President Reagan's election, Republicans have been talking of their opportunity to build on that landslide to become the nation's dominant political party, and in recent weeks they have been finding nuggets of confirmation in public opinion polls.

title: China Hopeful on '81 Grain Crop
description: China should reach its 1981 goal of 332.5 million metric tons of grain if bad weather does not damage the crop, Du Runsheng, deputy minister of the State Agricultural Commission, said at a news conference today. Production last year slumped to 315 million tons from 1979's record 330 million tons because of drought in the north and flooding in the south, he said.

title: Tribune Adds Cable
description: The Tribune Company, which publishes The Chicago Tribune, The Daily News in New York and newspapers in Florida, said it had completed its acquisition of the Douglas Communications Corporation, which owns and operates cable television systems serving communities in New York, Maryland, Tennessee and Louisiana. The cable firms all will be assigned to Tribune Company Cable Inc., a newly created subsidiary of the Chicago-based communications company.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bank Leumi Trust Company of New York has appointed Dennis H. Stein executive vice president in charge of operations.

title: G.M. MAY CUT SALARIED STAFF
description: The General Motors Corporation confirmed today that it was studying cutbacks of its salaried employees as part of an effort to trim costs after a year in which it lost $763 million.

title: Wrong and Right Reasons to Limit Guns
description: Would a tough national gun-control law have prevented Monday's attempt on President Reagan's life? Would it bring any relief from the street crime now routinely acknowledged, if not accepted, as a fact of everyday urban life?

title: MAN WHO TACKLED SUSPECT IS ILL
description: Alfred Antonucci, an Ohio labor official who was apparently among the first people to tackle John W. Hinckley Jr., the man charged with the attack on President Reagan, was hospitalized with severe chest pains two hours after the incident.

title: WHEN PARENT SEES TEACHER, ANXIETIES RISE
description: The parent-teacher conference, a 10-minute session that has brought generations of parents face to face with the other adults in their children's lives, can be an uneasy encounter.

title: Kidder, Peabody In T.V.A. Gas Deal
description: Kidder, Peabody and Company, the brokerage and investment firm, said it had drawn up a $2.8 billion plan to finance a coal gasification project being developed by the Tennessee Valley Authority at Murphy Hill, Ala.

title: 3 COMMITTEES INVESTIGATING CONDUCT OF SECURITY SERVICES
description: Three Congressional committees and the Secret Service opened investigations today into the conduct of the Federal security forces in yesterday's attempt on the life of President Reagan.

title: Relocation Plan Announced In Town With Fire in Mine
description: Gov. Dick Thornburgh announced a plan today for the permanent relocation of Centralia families who believe their health and safety are threatened by a 19-year-old underground mine fire.

title: LETTERS HINT SUSPECT ACTED OUT FANTASY
description: Federal investigators have found evidence that they believe suggests that John W. Hinckley Jr., accused of the attack on President Reagan yesterday, was seeking to impress Jodie Foster, a teen-age actress whom he had apparently never met.

title: Treasurer Says Zinc Penny May Save $50 Million a Year
description: Pennies made of zinc instead of copper may save up to $50 million a year, the Treasurer of the United States, Angela Marie Buchanan, said today.

title: STATE TO MONITOR NURSING HOMES IF STRIKE OCCURS
description: The State Health Commissioner, David Axelrod, warned yesterday that the state would monitor care in any proprietary nursing homes that were struck today under a 6 A.M. union deadline.

title: BLUES AND FOLK: TAJ MAHAL SINGS
description: TAJ MAHAL, the New York born folk blues artist with 16 albums to his credit, has experimented with all manner of styles over the years. Besides the blues, he has delved into jazz, rock-and-roll, and more recently Caribbean music. Mr. Mahal has a wonderful, husky growl that is stylistically very adaptable.

title: Sports News Briefs; Seales Flattens NeSmith In 5th and Captures Title
description: Sugar Ray Seales weakened Sammy NeSmith with a barrage of punches in the third round, then knocked him out with a right hook to the head a minute into the fifth and captured the North American Boxing Federation middleweight title tonight.

title: The Region; Yates Won't Run For Jersey Senate
description: TRENTON (AP) - State Senator Charles B. Yates, head of the Joint Appropriations Committee, announced he would not seek re-election to the Senate, where he has served for four years.

title: Lockheed-Peru Pact
description: The Lockheed-Georgia Company said it had sold two stretched L-100-20 Hercules transport planes to the Government of Peru.

title: KNIGHT'S DICTUM UPHELD: PRACTICE PAYS OFF
description: Winning in Philadelphia was the most obvious similarity between the Indiana team that took the National Collegiate basketball championship in 1976 and the Indiana team that captured the title at the Spectrum last night.

title: NOW CONVOCATION ON 'NEW LEADERSHIP'
description: More than 400 representatives of business, women's groups and the public sector were told this week that the women's movement has come to the ''end of the beginning,'' and that it must now enter a second stage.

title: Sports News Briefs; Miss Woodward of Kansas Named Player of Year
description: Lynette Woodard of Kansas, who established a women's intercollegiate career scoring record this season, received the Wade Trophy yesterday as college basketball player of the year.

title: THERE'LL ALWAYS BE A CRISIS
description: To the Editor:

title: METS SEND BERENGUER TO ROYALS
description: Tim Leary finally gave up some runs today as the New York Mets intensified their auditions for the one job open on the pitching staff. But the front office reduced the long line of candidates by trading Juan Berenguer and his wayward fastball to the Kansas City Royals.

title: Notes on People; Dr. Rabi Receives Pupin Medal for Service to Nation
description: As a graduate student in physics at Columbia University in the 1920's, I. I. Rabi went to the Norfolk, Conn., home of Michael I. Pupin for a birthday celebration.

title: MUSIC: AMERICAN BRASS QUINTET
description: The American Brass Quintet is celebrating its 20th anniversary season, and to reaffirm its committment to new music, the group presented a "retrospective of premieres" Monday night at Carnegie Recital Hall-three premieres it had offered in earlier years and a New York premiere and a world premiere of works composed just last year. The totality made for an attractively diverse overview of new music for brass of the past two decades.

title: CHARLES J. KLYDE
description: Charles J. Klyde, an administrative law judge for the Department of Defense, died Saturday at New York Hospital.

title: PIANO: ANN SCHEIN'S CHOPIN
description: ANN SCHEIN concluded her six-concert Chopin marathon on Monday night in Alice Tully Hall with a program devoted to the composer's most challenging collection for the keyboard, the 24 etudes. This assignment alone would be enough to content any pianist in search of a Mount Everest to conquer, but Miss Schein warmed to the task by prefacing the etudes with two nocturnes, in F (Op, 15, No. 1) and in E flat (Op. 55, No. 2).

title: Leader of Catholic Bishops Urges A Time of Prayer and Reflection
description: Archbishop John R. Roach, president of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops, said today that the wounding of President Reagan should bring the country to prayer and reflection.

title: VIOLENT CRIME ROSE BY 13% IN 1980
description: uf814WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP) - Violent crime rose 13 percent last year, the largest increase in a dozen years, the Federal Bureau of Investigation reported today.

title: NBC-TV CONTINUES TO LAG IN 3D PLACE
description: ''Judge us on our performance during the next 60 to 90 days'' Fred Silverman, president of NBC, said three months ago, at Christmas. ''Our objective is to move into second place, ahead of ABC.''

title: U.S. FAVORS NEW PROPOSAL FOR THE INDEPENDENCE OF NAMIBIA
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that the United States was prepared to discuss a modification of the United Nations plan for South-West African independence that might be acceptable to South Africa and to black African states.

title: The Presidency Under Glass
description: In July 1864 a Confederate force attacked Fort Stevens near Washington. Abraham Lincoln rode out to watch the fighting. As he stood erect and exposed in his silk hat, an officer three feet away fell, prompting a 23-year-old captain, Oliver Wendell Holmes, to shout at the President, ''Get down, you fool.''

title: Index; Reagan Shooting
description: Reagan Shooting

title: TRUDEAU SET BACK ON CONSTITUTION
description: The Newfoundland Court of Appeal handed the Federal Government a major judicial defeat today by unanimously declaring illegal Ottawa's proposals to effect constitutional change without overall provincial consent.

title: OPENING STATEMENTS HEARD IN WILLIAMS'S ABSCAM TRIAL
description: Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. of New Jersey was portrayed yesterday both as a ''corrupt public official'' who schemed to make $12 million illegally and as a ''trusting, easygoing, forgiving man'' victimized by self-interested, ''immoral'' Government agents.

title: Edith Wilson, Actress And Jazz Vocalist, 84
description: Edith Wilson, a singer, actress and vaudeville performer for more than six decades, died yesterday at the age of 84.

title: by Terry Robards
description: THE bottle was wrapped in a brown bag to conceal its shape and label, and it was uncorked for an impromptu tasting in a Manhattan restaurant. The wine was dark red, almost black, and rich with the fruit of the cabernet sauvignon grape, conveying a flavor intensity characteristic of the best Bordeaux or perhaps one of the great California estates where the cabernet also achieves superb quality.

title: OPEC SEEKS TO HEAL RIFT
description: Indonesian oil officials said today that representatives of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries were trying to resolve sharp differences among members over Saudi Arabia's proposals for a long-term pricing strategy.

title: GOULETAS CONCERN BUYING IN MANHATTAN
description: American Invsco, a real estate conglomerate partly owned and managed by Evangeline Gouletas, is buying one of Manhattan's largest apartment buildings, Continental Towers, at 301 East 79th Street at Second Avenue.

title: Once Again
description: This began as an amiable, tongue-in-cheek piece about the Reagan Administration's decision to bring back the battleship, but a friend burst into the room. Somebody had shot at the President. The bulletins tumbled out of him: The President's press secretary shot in the head. Policeman shot. Secret Service agent shot.

title: Bridge: Mrs. Moss's Team Is Victor In Detroit Knockout Event
description: The American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals ended here in the early hours of this morning with a victory in the women's knockout team championship for a sextet headed by Jo Morse of Silver Spring, Md. Teamed with Evelyn Levitt of Wilmington, Del., Helen Utegaard of Carmichael, Calif., Pat Lapides of San Diego, Calif., June Deutsch and Sandi Leavitt of Chicago, Mrs. Morse won by 19 international match points.

title: Papers to Discuss Wages With Key Unions Today
description: Negotiators for two key newspaper unions and The Daily News and The New York Times made plans yesterday to address differences on the critical wage issue in bargaining talks scheduled for today.

title: THE CRISIS MANAGER TAKES THE EMPTY CHAIR
description: With President Reagan sidelined for a time - nobody quite knows for how long - the issue of ''crisis management'' in Washington now takes on a new significance.

title: TENNECO'S CORPORATE FARMING
description: From a helicopter, the flat and fertile San Joaquin Valley looks quilted with the specialty crops of a few huge irrigated farming operations. Pink-blooming nectarines, whiteflowered almonds, delicate strawberries and asparagus, citrus of all varieties, grapes and pistachios stretch in gargantuan parcels from the Coast Range toward the hazy Sierra Nevada in the east.

title: Sons of Ireland
description: If there was ever a paradigm for the emergence of the Irish in America, it is in the names of the four people injured Monday by the bullets of a would-be assassin. Reagan, Brady, McCarthy, Delahanty - it sounds like the guest list for the annual dinner of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick.

title: Asbestos Corp.  Talks Proposed
description: The General Dynamics Corporation indicated today that it was prepared to negotiate the sale of the Asbestos Corporation and avoid expropriation of its majority interest in the company by the government of Quebec province.

title: MX Missile System Viewed As Devastating to Nevada
description: The proposed MX missile system is like a ''modern-day gold rush'' that could devastate the Nevada desert, a longtime resident of the area charged at the first public hearing on the Air Force's draft environmental impact statement.

title: PRICES PAID FARMERS DOWN 1.9% IN MARCH
description: The prices that farmers receive for their raw products dropped 1.9 percent in March from February, the fourth consecutive monthly decline, but still were an average of 10 percent higher than those of a year ago, the Agriculture Department said today. Officials said that lower prices for hogs, cattle, soybeans, wheat, cotton and corn led the decline.

title: People
description: * George Russo named senior vice president-media director at Creamer Inc., New York.

title: A BAN ON GUN PARTS IS URGED IN CONGRESS
description: In the aftermath of the attack yesterday on President Reagan, members of Congress expressed bipartisan support today for legislation that would ban the importing of unassembled gun parts involved in the manufacture of cheap pistols often used by criminals.

title: JURY DECIDED NOT TO QUERY ADVISOR TO SCHOOL'S PAPER
description: A Cumberland County grand jury withdrew a subpoena yesterday for a high school teacher whose testimony might have led authorities to a campus drug dealer who sold drugs to elementary and high school students in Millville, N.J.

title: STATE STARTS NEW FISCAL YEAR WITHOUT ACCORD ON BUDGET
description: The Republican-controlled State Senate passed one budget today, and the Democratic leaders here agreed on an entirely different version. That left New York State adrift, without a revenue and spending plan for the new fiscal year beginning at midnight.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Citibank said an average rate of 13.436 percent was set at yesterday's weekly auction of 91-day Citicorp auction commercial paper, compared with a 13.663 percent average rate late last week.

title: Teletype Chief Appointed
description: John J. Pappas, 48, has been appointed president and chief executive officer of the Teletype Corporation, a subsidiary of the Western Electric Company. He succeeds Lloyd C. Boswell, 63, who retired as head of the Skokie, Ill., manufacturer of data terminals.

title: JERSEY UTILITY'S RATE OVERREACH
description: To the Editor:

title: DOCTOR SAYS PRESIDENT'S LIFE WAS IN DANGER AT FIRST
description: Contrary to earlier impressions of his condition, when President Reagan walked into the emergency room of George Washington University Hospital yesterday, minutes after being shot, he was having serious breathing problems and was experiencing chest pain, his blood pressure was low and falling, and he had been spitting up blood from the wound in his lung.

title: LET THE GUN MAKERS PROPOSE CONTROLS
description: To the Editor:

title: WEDNESDAY, APRIL 1, 1981; Companies
description: Fluor agreed to buy St. Joe Minerals for $60 a share, or nearly $2.9 billion in cash and stock. Seagram, which had sought to buy St. Joe for $45 a share, was ''evaluating'' the offer, but had no further comment. Sources friendly to Seagram, however, questioned whether Fluor had sufficient capital of its own for the acquisition. (Page D1.)

title: SIGNS ARE UNEXPECTEDLY ENCOURAGING FOR PRESS SECRETARY
description: James S. Brady, the White House press secretary, who was the most gravely injured of the four men wounded in yesterday's attempt to assassinate the President, showed signs today of recovering unexpectedly well from the bullet that had pierced his brain.

title: TURKEY OPENS CAMPAIGN AGAINST KURDISH REBELS
description: Turkish authorities have sought to prepare the public for the opening of a large trial of Kurdish militants next month with a 90-minute television program featuring denunciations of them.

title: LONG STRIKE FEARED
description: The leadership of the United Mine Workers conceded tonight that more than two-thirds of the union's rank-andfile members had rejected a proposed contract settlement that would have brought an early end to a strike of 160,000 coal miners in the East and the Middle West.

title: Who's Minding the Store?
description: Ronald Reagan himself raised the crucial question of state as they wheeled him toward the operating room. ''Who's minding the store?'' he wondered at the sight of all his top aides. But the question answered itself. With his engaging quips, he proved his alertness and punctured the anxious speculation about whether he had to be judged temporarily incapacitated.

title: Thailand Lists Gas Deposits
description: Thailand has proven deposits of natural gas in the Gulf of Thailand of more than 10 trillion cubic feet, an official of the natural resources department said today.

title: MOVING AHEAD ON HEAD START
description: To the Editor:

title: Kellogg Strategy Change Is Hinted
description: On the surface it seems a small matter: Kellogg assigning a ''new cereal product under development'' to the J. Walter Thompson Company in Chicago. But think, the Leo Burnett Company, Chicago, traditionally handles all cereal assignments in the United States for the country's leading marketer of dry cereals, while Thompson has been doing most of it overseas.

title: NEW YORK APPEALS COURT LIMITS BASIS FOR SEVERING LIFE SUPPORTS
description: New York State's highest court yesterday sharply narrowed the circumstances under which a patient can be removed from life-sustaining equipment.

title: WHITE HOUSE WORKING, BUSH ASSURES SENATE
description: President Reagan's doctors said he was making a good recovery today from a bullet wound in the chest, and Vice President Bush filled in for Mr. Reagan at the White House. The Administration sought to demonstrate that the Government was running smoothly despite the attempt yesterday to assassinate the President.

title: Beaulieu of France
description: Beaulieu, the French movie camera and projector manufacturer, suffering financially from the arrival of home video equipment and stiff competition from Japan, has declared itself bankrupt.

title: TV: 'COPLAND CELEBRATION' AND WINTER OLYMPICS
description: BY scheduling chance, tonight's ''A Copland Celebration,'' on WNET-TV, Channel 13, at 9 o'clock, could hardly be presented at a more fortuitous time. After Monday's violent events in Washington, the nation could undoubtedly use some moments of reassurance. Nothing could be more appropriate than the internationally celebrated music of Aaron Copland, music described on this 90-minute program as ''devoid of politics, without sectionalism, with just the ideals.'' The program ends, stirringly, with ''Lincoln Portrait,'' narrated by Mr. Copland and conducted by Leonard Bernstein.

title: The Region; Interest-Rate Limits Ended in Jersey
description: TRENTON (UPI) - Governor Byrne signed a bill eliminating ceilings on interest rates for most types of consumer loans offered by New Jersey's lending institutions. In an effort to protect consumers, Mr. Byrne also signed a measure lowering from 50 to 30 percent the criminal usury rate.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: LEONARDO'S PEERERS

title: MARGIOTTA JURORS TOLD OF SPLIT FEES FOR LITTLE WORK
description: Testifying at the trial here of the Nassau County Republican chairman, the Mayor of Freeport said today that he had received $10,000 in split insurance commissions even though ''I really didn't do too much'' for the money.

title: Dispute Over Direction Leads to Resignation
description: Terry E. Valeski, 33-year-old vice president and director of marketing, who had been heading the search committee that was to bring a new ad agency to Teledyne Water Pik, has resigned from the company two weeks before the decision was to be announced on the $5 million account.

title: The Region; JERSEY OPENS DEBATE ON GUN CONTROL BILL
description: More than 500 people, most of them members of sportsmen's and gun clubs, crowded the Assembly chambers today to debate the merits of a bill that would ban the sale or importation of handguns in New Jersey.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, APRIL 1, 1981
description: After the Shooting President Reagan was recovering from surgery after Monday's assassination attempt as Vice President Bush filled his place at the White House to demonstrate that the Government was running smoothly. Mr. Reagan met with senior aides and signed a bill that was brought in on his breakfast tray at George Washington University Hospital. (Page A1, Column 6.) The President's initial condition minutes after he was shot Monday was much more serious than previously acknowledged. A surgical intern who first treated Mr. Reagan said that he was having serious trouble in breathing and was experiencing chest pain, his blood pressure was low and falling, and he had been spitting up blood from the wound in his left lung. (A18:3-6.)

title: OUTLINE OF FILM CITED IN INQUIRY
description: In the 1976 move "Taxi Driver," written by Paul Schrader, Robert De Niro plays the role of an alienated former Marine named Travis Bickle who plans the assassination of a United States Senator and befriends a 12-year-old prostitute named Iris, played by Jodie Foster.

title: Argentine Bank Sale
description: The Bank of America, the nation's largest, said the Argentine Government had given final approval to its purchase of the Banco Internacional S.A. of Argentina for $145 million. Bank of America said that Banco Internacional is Argentina's 16th-largest bank, having deposits of $337 million and 60 branches, most of them in the metropolitan Buenos Aires area.

title: Belgian Bank Lifts Key Interest Rates
description: The Belgian National Bank raised its discount rate by three percentage points today, to an unprecedented 16 percent, in an effort to ease the pressure on the Belgian franc.

title: FACTORY ORDERS OFF IN FEBRUARY
description: New orders for manufactured goods fell by five-tenths of 1 percent in February, the Commerce Department reported today, indicating a slowing of the economy.

title: Nordiques 5, Penguins 1
description: Anton Stastny scored a pair of goals and Jacques Richard scored his 51st of the season last night to power the Nordiques to a 5-1 triumph over the Pittsburgh Penguins at Quebec.

title: Popovic of Arrows Named M.I.S.L. Coach of the Year
description: Don Popovic, who has guided the New York Arrows to three Major Indoor Soccer League championships in the league's three years, has been voted coach of the year for the first time.

title: JAZZ: GROVER MITCHELL LEADS HIS OWN BAND AT SWEET BASIL
description: THE 12-piece jazz band that Grover Mitchell, a trombonist, is leading Monday evenings at Sweet Basil, has a close relationship to Count Basie's orchestra. Mr. Mitchell has been a Basie trombonist on and off for 19 years. Five of the regular members of his band, including Mr. Mitchell, are in the Basie band. Mr. Mitchell's group plays only when the Basie ensemble is taking time off, which happens frequently now that Mr. Basie is 77 years old.

title: NEW KODAK COLOR DARKROOM
description: The Eastman Kodak Company yesterday introduced a system that it said would make it easy for darkroom hobbyists to make color enlargements from either negatives or slides.

title: Stuffed Zucchini Florentine
description: 2 pounds fresh spinach or two 10-ounce packages spinach in plastic 4 medium-size zucchini 1 1/2 teaspoons herb seasoning (see recipe), optional 1 1/2 teaspoons dried oregano 1/2 pound chopped fresh mushrooms, about 3 cups 1 clove garlic, finely minced 2 tablespoons finely chopped shallots 1/4 teaspoon freshly grated nutmeg 1/4 teaspoon freshly ground pepper 6 ounces Monterey Jack cheese, grated 1/2 cup cooked brown rice (see recipe).

title: Israeli Budget Approved Despite Rift on Subsidies
description: Parliament gave approval today to the Government's 1981-82 budget and defeated attempts to limit official spending before the June 30 general election.

title: Coors Adds an Ale To Its Product Line
description: The Adolph Coors brewery, which went from 1873 to 1978 with but a single product, Coors Beer, yesterday announced the addition of a fourth label to its line. This time it is an ale, George Gillian's Irish Red, which it will brew under a licensing agreement with the Pelforth Brewery of Lille, France, and from G.H. Lett & Company of County Wexford, Ireland, which licensed Pel@forth but does not brew anything itself.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 17.00-17.50** Current rate excludes 3 percentage-point surcharge on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers. Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: U.S. ASSURES ALLIES IT SEEKS ARMS TALKS
description: Officials of the Reagan Administration met for the first time with the NATO allies as a unit today, and expressed interest in arms control but no commitment on a date for resuming talks with the Soviet Union.

title: BONN, WORRIED, SOLICITS AID FOR POLAND
description: West Germany, the country most acutely threatened economically and politically by the labor crisis in Poland, is taking the lead in rallying Western aid for its troubled neighbor.

title: SPA'S GARDEN OF LOW-CALORIE DELIGHTS
description: ESCONDIDO, Calif. THE Golden Door here is the sort of establishment where, when guests arrive by air, you expect it to be in their own private plane. Some of those who've spent time at this health spa are Natalie Wood, Robert Wagner, Cliff Robertson, Bill Blass, Paul Anka and Barbra Streisand. During my own week's stay recently, guests included Ilias Lalaounis, the New York jeweler, several highly placed executives in publishing and oil, a geologist who is a board member of the Los Angeles Rams, a Washingtonian who owns 57 movie houses and a Wall Street broker.

title: SURGEONS TO THE PRESIDENT
description: As President Reagan was wheeled into the operating room yesterday afternoon, he looked up at his surgeons and said: ''Please tell me you're Republicans.''

title: SENATE REJECTS BID TO RESTORE WELFARE FUNDS
description: Moderate Republican Senators failed today in their bid to restore nearly $1 billion in social welfare programs to the budget for the fiscal year 1982 because of the opposition of conservative Democrats who joined most Republicans in supporting President Reagan's program.

title: Annual Award and Meet To Honor Jesse Owens Set
description: An annual award for an amateur athlete, and an annual indoor track meet to raise funds for cancer research have been created. Both honor the memory of Jesse Owens and were announced at a luncheon yesterday, a year to the day after Owens died of lung cancer.

title: NO SIGNS THE RUSSIANS WILL EXPLOIT REAGAN SHOOTING TO ENTER POLAND
description: There was no suggestion here today that the Soviet Union would seek to take advantage of the assassination attempt against President Reagan by intervening in Poland.

title: TAX COLLECTORS IN RIO PUTTING A LION TO WORK
description: Revenue authorities here have resorted to a computer, some dirty tricks and the public relations image of a lion to combat an age-old reluctance among Brazilians to pay their taxes.

title: PHYSICIAN PROVIDES A REASSURING VOICE
description: The calm, authoritative voice of Dennis S. O'Leary greeted the nation on television this morning with a report on President Reagan that constituents could appreciate.

title: The City; Injunction Delays Hospital Shutdown
description: A temporary restraining order yesterday halted Cabrini Medical Center's plan to close St. Elizabeth's Hospital in the Washington Heights-Inwood section of Manhattan on the eve of its scheduled shutdown, United Press International reported.

title: SULLAIR STIRS INTEREST WITH STEAM PROCESS TO PUMP HEAVY OIL
description: The Sullair Corporation, a 15-year-old manufacturer of air compressors, has been stirring investor interest with its new oil-drilling technology.

title: GENERAL MOTORS URGES REVAMPING OF CLEAN AIR ACT
description: The General Motors Corporation proposed sweeping changes today in requirements of the Clean Air Act that affect motor vehicles, including the elimination of the requirement that individual automobiles and trucks comply with antipollution standards.

title: Satellite Network Planned For Music Shows on Radio
description: An Atlanta radio consultant is organizing a national satellite network for 24-hour-a-day music programming.

title: BREZHNEV IS AMONG WORLD'S WELL-WISHERS
description: For a second day, messages of shock and sympathy over the attempt to assassinate President Reagan poured into the White House yesterday from around the world, among them messages from leaders of the Soviet Union and China.

title: DAVID L. DEXTER
description: David L. Dexter, professor of physics at the University of Rochester whose research was concerned with the optical and electronic properties of solid materials, died Sunday in Rochester of lung cancer.

title: POLISH UNION APPROVES AGREEMENT AND CALLS OFF A THREATENED STRIKE
description: The national commission of Poland's independent labor movement, despite heavy attacks on its agreement with the Government, voted here tonight to abandon a general strike that had been threatened for today.

title: U.S. ALLOWS RAILS 11.7% RETURN
description: In a ruling hailed today by the railroad industry, the Interstate Commerce Commission has decided that the nation's railroads can raise rates, if they wish, so that they can earn a return on their investment equal to the current cost of capital.

title: Maxwell House Has a New President
description: Robert L. Seelert, 39 years old, has been named president of Maxwell House, the coffee-making division of the General Foods Corporation. He succeeds Ervin R. Shames, 40, who was appointed president of General Foods Europe.

title: WHITE HOUSE AIDES ASSERT WEINBERGER WAS UPSET WHEN HAIG TOOK CHARGE
description: White House officials said today that a difference of opinion arose yesterday between Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. and Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger over their respective responsibilities in the crucial hours after the shooting of President Reagan.

title: STAGE: 'GREEN CARD BLUES, ' A COMEDY
description: LARRY PINE and Tom Costello, two graduates of Andre Gregory's troupe, the Manhattan Project, are cavorting on stage at La Mama in a farce about illegal aliens in America. The play, ''Green Card Blues'' by Annalita Alexander, is a slight, ramshackle affair, buoyed by the presence of the two clowns. Imagine, if you will, the two as a comedy team, the Off Off Broadway equivalent of Abbott and Costello - call them Pine and Costello - with the heavier-set partner, in both cases, the one named Costello, playing a female role.

title: Rating the Chickens
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: The article ''Rating Roasting Chickens: A Guide for Buyers'' (March 4) testing and rating chickens was exhaustive, impressive and informative. It also has practical results. When I, a long-standing customer of a West Side meat market, went into the store with the article in my hand, asking what happened, I didn't get a very good answer, but I sure got a better chicken than I'd seen in years. Thank you. EDITH LEONIAN Manhattan TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: The City; New School Opens Under Old Principal
description: The 2,900 students of Eastern District High School in Brooklyn's Williamsburg section will open their new building today under their current principal, David Dicker, with the approval of several hundred community leaders and students, who had protested a plan to transfer him.

title: Q & A
description: Q. Because the bricks in our chimney had been flaking, we recently had many of them replaced with new ones. Now the new ones are covered with a white powdery substance. Can you tell me how to correct this, and whether I should spray the rest of the old bricks with silicone to prevent further flaking of them? - F.B. Fairfax, Va.

title: CONSTRUCTION SPENDING DOWN 3.6% IN FEBRUARY
description: Spending for new construction dropped 3.6 percent in February, the Commerce Department reported today. It was the first monthly decline since last summer and the latest in a series of signs that the national economy is slowing,

title: Lois Pitts Gershon Chosen
description: Inc., the Boston publisher, which will be bringing out High Technology and Technology Illustrated magazines in the fall, yesterday named Lois Pitts Gershon as the agency for the two consumer books.

title: A KEY TAPE IS SHOWN IN TRIAL OF WILLIAMS
description: A videotape played yesterday at the bribery trial of Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. of New Jersey shows him discussing a mining venture with Abscam undercover agents and agreeing to have a concealed interest in it.

title: ARMS AND INFLATION
description: -When Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger made his pitch on Capitol Hill for the Reagan defense budget, he promised to use "innovative managerial techniques" to make the most efficient use of defense funds. He certainly will have his work cut out for him, for despite all the Administration's talk of efficiency savings, the tab for its defense plans may exceed the $1.5 trillion in outlays projected over the next six years. One result of such unanticipated costs may be the "stretch-out" of a number of major weapon-procurement programs, raising the ultimate cost of purchasing these weapons by billions of dollars.

title: LAPOINTE OFF THE HOOK
description: -The Montreal Canadiens' managing director, Irving Grundman, said today that no disciplinary action would be taken against Guy Lapointe for remarks the defenseman made against Coach Claude Ruel. "There is no need to carry this any further, Guy will continue to be part of this team for the balance of the season and the playoffs," Grundman said after he met with Lapointe for two hours. Lapointe had publicly criticized Ruel after the team's 4-0 loss to Quebec Saturday night in Quebec City.

title: U.S. HALTS ECONOMIC AID TO NICARAGUA
description: Washington, April 1 -The United States today terminated the remaining $15 million in economic aid for Nicaragua because of that country's assistance to guerrillas in El Salvador, but held out the possibility of an early resumption of aid if the Nicaraguans continued their recent efforts to avoid involvement in the Salvadoran situation.

title: ASSURING U.S. SEALIFT, AND MARITIME IDENTITY
description: To the Editor:

title: INVSCO'S ADVERTISING QUESTIONED BY REP. ROSENTHAL AT A HEARING
description: Representative Benjamin S. Rosenthal of Queens said today that the American Invsco Corporation, the counrty's largest developer of condominium apartments, appeared to be engaging in false advertising and violations of securities laws.

title: HOTEL IN THE TRADE CENTER GREETS ITS FIRST 100 GUESTS
description: The Vista International New York, the first major hotel built south of Canal Street since 1836, opened at 3 World Trade Center yesterday with 100 of its 825 rooms ready.

title: Advertising; Science Magazines Taking Off
description: SOCIAL changes frequently help create new magazine categories. The movement of women into the work force has certainly brought with it a string of new titles of service magazines intended to help those women cope, and, of course, make money for the publishers. The running craze has brought with it a proliferation of publications on the subject, and video and high technology have combined to cause a flood of trade and consumer magazines on every aspect of video and cable television.

title: Helpful Hardware; GETTING THE TOOLS ORGANIZED
description: If you are sick oftools jumbled in a box, there are some tool organizers that can be used to sort out the situation.Tool Boy is a large heavy plastic carrier with small drawers for nails and screws and various slots and compartments for screwdrivers and hammers.

title: NORWAY EXPELS SOVIET OFFICIAL
description: Norway has ordered a Soviet trade official to leave the country, accusing him of activities incompatible with his status, the Foreign Ministry said today.

title: BEATING SWORDS INTO SAUSAGE FOR POLAND
description: That was no mere strike for wages and benefits that Poland's labor movement canceled this week. It shied from civil war, a conflict bound to become a Polish-Soviet war, with grave consequences for the economies and diplomacies of East and West. No sane person could have wished for anything but retreat.

title: LONG-TERM COMPANY BONDS UP
description: Short- and long-term interest rates were little changed yesterday as securities dealers focused on the distribution of a large amount of new issues.

title: ARGENTINA CHANGES ECONOMIC POLICIES
description: The Argentine military Government moved today to halt an escalating economic crisis by announcing a series of policy readjustments, including a nearly 30 percent devaluation of the peso.

title: LOVE FOR SALE
description: Children are very expensive. Aside from food, clothes, shelter and basic medical care, a lot need orthodontists, some need psychiatrists and almost all of them want bicycles. No longer apt to be fellers of forests (if they are sons), or angels in the house (if they are daughters), and equally unlikely to follow in one's footsteps, they are a high-risk investment that guarantees neither financial reward nor ego amplification. Why, then, are so many people so eager to produce what is patently a luxury item? The answer is simple: they're taking a chance on love.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: TRAVELING HOME

title: KENNEDY SET TO COMPROMISE TO OBTAIN GUN CONTROL BILL
description: In an effort to draw a lesson from the shooting of President Reagan, Senator Edward M. Kennedy announced today that he would support a package of limited gun-control measures. The measure is also gaining support among conservative Republicans, raising the possibility some compromise legislation might be adopted by Congress.

title: LEBANESE SOLDIER IS KILLED IN A CLASH WITH ISRAELIS
description: United Nations forces and Lebanese troop clashed with Israeli forces in southern Lebanon last night. One Lebanese soldier was killed and another wounded, according to accounts by the Lebanese radio and a spokesman for the United Nations peacekeeping force.

title: BAN ON CITY WATER FOR OUTDOOR POOLS
description: As of Tuesday, the estimated 50,000 public and private outdoor pools in New York City are prohibited from receiving city water. Under new conservation measures announced by Mayor Koch, owners who violate the ruling risk being fined $50 for the first offense and up to $500 for the second offense.

title: 8 NEW YORK AREA MILK DISTRIBUTORS INDICTED ON PRICE FIXING
description: Eight major milk distributors and 20 individuals were indicted yesterday on criminal charges of conspiring to fix wholesale and retail milk prices in the metropolitan New York area.

title: Key Rates
description: Current rate excludes 3 percentage-point surcharge on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers. Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: TO ADD FLAVOR TO AN ANNUAL REPORT, SPRINKLE WITH LATIN
description: The annual report of New York City's chief archivist is only VI pages long and each of its XVI sections, written in English, are preceded by epigraphs in Latin.

title: TEEN-AGE ACTRESS SAYS NOTES SENT BY SUSPECT DID NOT HINT VIOLENCT
description: The actress Jodie Foster said today that she received ''several pieces of unsolicited correspondence'' last fall from the suspect in the shooting of President Reagan and that she had thrown them away. But when she received ''three or four more notes'' at the beginning of March, the 18-year-old Yale freshman said, she gave them to her dean.

title: Technology; Defining Terms In Growth Area
description: WHAT is high technology? The casual observer of the business scene might easily be forgiven for concluding that any technology is high technology. These days, most executives -and virtually all of those in public relations - refer to their enterprises' technology as high technology, if they refer to it at all.

title: A LONELY CROWD
description: -When Robert Kennedy was assassinated in June 1968, President Johnson appointed a commission on violence in America.Its report pointed to a distinctive characteristic of assassinations in this country.

title: Nixdorf Offers 25% Of Its Stock; Earnings Rise at Computer Maker
description: Nixdorf Computer A.G. disclosed plans today to offer publicly 25 percent of its common stock, now held by Deutsche Bank, in the next three years.

title: R. H. IVES GAMMELL
description: R. H. Ives Gammell, a muralist, portrait painter and art teacher, died Monday at his home in Boston.

title: RAMS GIVE UP FIGHT TO SIGN FERRAGAMO
description: -The Los Angeles Rams acknowledged today that they had lost Vince Ferragamo to Canada and indicated that, as a result, Pat Haden would be the No. 1 quarterback next season.

title: KEY G.O.P. SENATORS SEEK CUTS IN UNTOUCHED MEDICARE PROGRAM
description: Influential Senate Republicans are quietly moving to seek cuts in Medicare, a rapidly growing assistance program for the elderly that President Reagan has left virtually untouched in his budget proposals.

title: Calendar of Events; ANTIQUES IN SUBURBS
description: Morristown Antiques Fair, National Guard Armory, Western Avenue, Morristown, N.J.

title: MISS GOULETAS AND THE GOVERNOR TO WED IN NEW YORK ON APRIL 11
description: Ending weeks of speculation, Governor Carey and Evangeline Gouletas, the Chicago real-estate developer, announced tonight that they planned to be married April 11, the Governor's birthday.

title: WEINBERGER ORDERS POWER IN PLANNING DELEGATED TO AIDES
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger has ordered his first extensive reorganization in the Pentagon. He is delegating greater planning authority to the service secretaries and to the Joint Chiefs of Staff in an effort to free himself to focus on policy.

title: Hers
description: Kay, my mother, has a manila folder of articles I've written - an addemdum, of sorts, to the burgeoning collection of a committed scrapbook enthusiast. She saves these clippings, partly because she's still consumed by a mother's passion to see all of her children's papers. But in the complicated, evolving adult relationship we have, there's another reason for the file folder. We want to understand each other's ideas.

title: Options Case Judge Drops Bear, Stearns
description: Bear, Stearns & Company has been dropped as a defendant in a suit filed by three Chicago Board Options Exchange market makers charging that some of the firm's clients profited from inside information on the trading of Kennecott Corporation call options. Removal of the brokerage house from the list of defendants was ordered by Federal Judge Stanley Roszkowski in Chicago after attorneys for the marketers conceded that they did not have evidence against Bear, Stearns.

title: FORMER MARINE IN LINE TO BE CHOSEN AS HEAD OF VETERANS' AGENCY
description: James Webb, a much-decorated former marine who wrote a novel about the Vietnam War, is the leading candidate to head the Veterans Administration, high officials said today.

title: U.S. SELLS GHANA WHEAT AND RICE
description: Ghana will get $12.7 million worth of American wheat and rice under a new Food for Peace agreement, the Agriculture Department said today. Under a credit arrangement, Ghana will be able to buy $5.5 million worth of wheat and $7.2 worth of rice.

title: Saudi-Taiwan Road Deal
description: The Saudi Arabian Communications Ministry awarded a $124 million contract to build a 37-mile road to the Ret-Ser Engineering Agency of Taiwan, company officials said today. The road, in the mountains of western Saudi Arabia near Taif, will take about three and a half years to build and will include about one and a quarter miles of tunnels and more than 20 bridges, the company said.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A dispatch from London yesterday about a libel suit involving the Unification Church incorrectly identified a man who had written an article about his son's joining and leaving the church.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "A writer's real material comes from his sufferings. The truest memory is the kind that leaves scars on the heart.

title: A DEPUTY PREMIER OF POLAND FLIES TO U.S. IN QUEST FOR ASSISTANCE
description: Mieczyslaw Jagielski, a Polish Deputy Prime Minister, who has already received assurances of economic aid from West Germany and France, flew to the United States today to continue his quest for assistance.

title: MAN WITH 2 GUNS SEIZED IN SUBWAY
