description: A transit policeman won a standoff in a Queens subway with a man who was wielding two loaded shotguns and carrying more than 100 shells, authorities said.

title: RANGERS TO START ROOKIE GOALIE
description: -Steve Weeks, a 22-year-old rookie who has never played in a National Hockey League game, is scheduled to be the goalie for the Rangers tonorrow night when they face the Islanders at Nassau Coliseum in a game both teams are eager to win.

title: RIO POLITICIAN'S HOME BOMBED
description: A bomb exploded today in the home of Marcelo Cerqueira, an opposition Congressman, the police said. No injuries were reported.

title: FLUOR'S ROAD TO DIVERSIFICATION
description: J Robert Fluor's bow tie and folksy manner disguise his flair for the dramatic gesture. When his fast-growing Fluor Corporation arranged last November to invest $12 million in Genentech Inc., he explained the genetic engineering company's relationship to what Fluor does in energy: ''The idea is, we turn some bugs loose in coal and then they chew like hell and turn out oil.''

title: G.&W. Tire Stake
description: Gulf and Western Industries Inc. reported to the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had increased its ownership of the General Tire and Rubber Company to 3,082,400 shares, or 12.8 percent. Of the total amount, 392,800 shares were purchased on the open market between Feb. 27 and March 20 for about $7.8 million. Gulf and Western said the purchase was financed by general corporate funds for the purpose of investment, adding that it plans to increase its ownership of General Tire to more than 15 percent.

title: QUEBEC NATIONALISTS UNEXPECTEDLY SEEM TO BE LEADING IN PROVINCIAL RACE
description: Parti Quebecois, fighting to hold power despite the defeat in a referendum last year of its goal of independence, showed a surprising lead over the weekend in two polls. And from the underdog position it has generally been thought to occupy, it has now suddenly begun to look like a possible winner in the provincial election April 13.

title: U.S. STEEL TO REBUILD IN CHICAGO
description: The United States Steel Corporation announced today that it would spend ''several hundred million dollars'' to rehabilitate its 100-year-old plant on the city's industrial South Side. Some steel experts said that the announcement signaled a change in strategy at Big Steel, which has been trading some of its natural-resource properties for cash lately.

title: HARBURG MEMORIAL TUESDAY
description: A memorial service will be held next Tuesday for E.Y. (Yip) Harburg, the lyricist who died March 5 in an automobile crash in Los Angeles at the age of 84. Among those scheduled to participate in the service, which will be held at 4:30 P.M. in the Shubert Theater, 225 West 44th Street, will be Jack Guilford, Fred Hellerman, Celeste Holm and Jule Styne. The service will be open to the public.

title: Mobil Predicting Quarterly Earnings
description: The Mobil Corporation said it expects to report first-quarter operating earnings ''significantly lower'' than the $845.6 million reported for the quarter a year ago, but ''significantly higher'' than the $565 million reported for the 1980 fourth quarter.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Blount Inc., Montgomery, Ala., has named Robert E. Heaton president and chief executive officer of two wholly owned subsidiaries, the Washington Steel Corporation and the Calstrip Steel Corporation.

title: DEMOCRATS, EYING ELECTIONS, MANEUVER ON BUDGET CUTS
description: Dispirited Democrats made a dozen foredoomed efforts to restore social welfare funds for the fiscal year 1982 on the Senate floor today in a strategy aimed at next year's Congressional elections.

title: BRIDGE
description: Winning a major national title with a brand-new partner is a relatively rare occurrence. To do so in the men's teams, a board-a-match event that places a premium on absoulute accuracy deal after deal is very rare. This was achieved last week in the Spring Nationals in Detroit.

title: Wells, Rich, Greene Gets More Chase Business
description: Wells, Rich, Greene, already the agency for the Chase Manhattan corporate advertising account, has now been assigned its community banking business, with billings of around $6 million. Dancer Fitzgerald Sample had the business for a few years.

title: DRIVERS UNION REJECTS TWO NEW WAGE OFFERS FROM TIMES AND NEWS
description: The Daily News and The New York Times made two new wage proposals to the Newspaper Deliverers Union last night, but neither was accepted.

title: Telefunken Wins Contract
description: AEG-Telefunken A.G. said today that it had received a contract worth about $37.5 million to supply electrical equipment for a rolling mill in Ilsenburg, East Germany.

title: Natomas Sues Magma Power
description: The Natomas Company of San Francisco announced it had filed suit against the Magma Power Company and B.C. McCabe, who is Magma's chairman, chief executive officer and principal stockholder, to restrain them from making what it called false and misleading statements in connection with a Natomas $42-a-share cash tender offer for all of Magma's outstanding common. There are about 9.9 million Magma shares outstanding.

title: A President's Apology To Secret Service Agent
description: When President Reagan awoke yesterday morning after surgery for removal of an assailant's bullet, one of his first requests was to see Jerry Parr, a Secret Service agent.

title: HABASH BACK IN BEIRUT AFTER SURGERY ON BRAIN
description: George Habash, leader of the Marxist-oriented Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine, reappeared in public today after several months of treatment abroad following brain surgery.

title: RISE OF 10.27 LIFTS DOW TO 1,014.14
description: Heavy institutional buying pushed the Dow Jones industrial average up 10.27 points yesterday, to 1,014.14, close to the eight-year high of 1,015.22 that was reached last Wednesday.

title: Around the Nation; Suburban Transit Workers Begin Strike in Philadelphia
description: Suburban bus and trolley drivers went on strike tonight, halting service for thousands of commuters already affected by a city transit walkout that began March 15.

title: AIDES SAY KOCH PLANS TO REPLACE APPEALS OFFICIAL
description: Mayor Koch will replace the chairman of the Board of Standards and Appeals next week, according to sources in his administration. The agency has broad powers to exempt builders and developers from the city's zoning laws.

title: THE LIBERIAN COUP, AND OTHERS, SEEN THROUGH 'BIFOCALS'
description: Except for some reservations about the bloodshed when the Liberian Government was overthrown last April, a cross-section of informed public opinion in the United States expressed support for the coup. It was seen as a harbinger, if not of prosperity, then at least of long overdue liberty for the indigenous Liberian people from an "Americo-Liberian oligarchy." But a year, and at least $27 million in United States military and humanitarian aid later, not only is prosperity eluding the people of that small West African country, but so is liberty, in whose name so many inglorious acts have been committed.

title: ISLAMIC PEACE MISSION ENDS SECOND ATTEMPT TO HALT IRAN-IRAQ WAR
description: A second attempt by nine Islamic leaders to arrange a cease-fire in the Iraqi-Iranian war appeared today to have ended in failure. Iran's Prime Minister announced plans to deal with another Islamic group.

title: Draft Officials Proposing to Start Screening Ahead of Any Call-Up
description: Selective Service officials want to start screening potential draftees to eliminate men with permanent physical or mental disabilities, the agency's director said today.

title: Companies
description: Fox said it had accepted in principle a reinstated takeover bid by Marvin Davis, days after the Denver oilman withdrew his $700 million offer for the entertainment company. The terms of the deal, to be presented to Fox shareholders by June 25, are nearly the same as those proposed by Mr. Davis in February. (Page D1.)

title: Cincinnati Concern Set to Go Private
description: The American Financial Corporation, a Cincinnati-based diversified financial service concern, said it had settled the last of several lawsuits that had been filed in response to its bid to convert into a privately held company. The proposal is to be voted on by shareholders next Monday.

title: U.S. AIDES IN SYRIA ARE REPORTED TO SEIZE FORMER PLANE HOSTAGES
description: Newport Beach,Calif., April 1 (AP) Craig Clymore, the hostage in the hijacking of a Pakustani airliner who had been indicted in the United States on drug-smuggling charges, has been taken into custody again in Syria by State Department officials, according to Ron Kreber, his lawyer. A spokesman for Mr. Kreber said yesterday that Mr. Clymore, 24 years old, of Laguna Beach, had been seized shortly before he was to board a flight home with Mr. Kreber.

title: TV: 'NURSE' BACK AS 6-PART SERIES, WITH SAME STARS
description: "NURSE" began several months ago as a two-hour movie starring Michael Learned and Robert Reed. With Miss Learned, longtime matriarch of the television's Walton family, as a widowed mother returning to the nursing profession, the production captured what seemed to be an authentic slice of New York City hospital life. What's more, it did well in the audience ratings.

title: WEAKEST QUINTUPLET IS OFF RESPIRATOR
description: ROCHESTER (AP) - The weakest of the quintuplets born here in St. Patrick's Day was off the respirator and breathing on her own, hospital officials said.

title: TV: OSCAR PRESENTATIONS REGAIN SOME OF THEIR BYGONE LUSTER
description: PERHAPS because the cameramen outside the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion i n Los Angeles were dressed in black tie - or perhaps because, once t hey got inside the building, they photographed Robert Redford at e very conceivable opportunity - the Academy Awards telecast regained s omething of its former luster this year. To be sure, the awards t hemselves offered few surprises. And the first hour of the program, i n accordance with academy tradition, was as close to uneventful as l ive television can be. Nevertheless, last year's show was longer andd uller by far, and this year's marked a noticeable improvement.

title: FOUR EX-PLAYERS TESTIFY ON ABUSE TACTICS BY KUSH
description: -Four former Arizona State football players testified today that Frank Kush, while he was coach, had subjected players to physical abuse that subsequently forced them to quit the team.

title: TRIAL DELAY DENIED IN HALBERSTAM CASE
description: A judge today denied motions to postpone, move or close to the press the trial of Bernard C. Welch Jr., who has been charged with murdering Dr. Michael J. Halberstam, a prominent cardiologist and author.

title: Mormons Announce Plans To Build Nine New Temples
description: The Mormon Church announced today that it planned to build nine temples at sites in the United States, Latin America, Europe, Asia and Africa.

title: U.P.I. RELEASES PHOTOS SAID TO SHOW HINCKLEY OUTSIDE WHITE HOUSE
description: The news agency United Press International yesterday released to its subscribers two photographs it had acquired, described as showing John W. Hinckley Jr. in front of the White House, apparently in the last year.

title: NAVY DROPS A CONTRACT TO BUILD 9TH TRIDENT SUBMARINE AT GROTON
description: The Navy dealt a further setback to the Electric Boat Division today, announcing that it had withdrawn an optional contract with the shipyard in Groton, Conn., for the construction of another submarine in the troubled Trident program.

title: Court Voids Union Rule On Funds to Candidates
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia has struck down a rule by the United Steelworkers of America prohibiting candidates for major union offices from accepting any money or services from nonunion members.

title: BIG DAY FOR TROUT ANGLERS
description: -Fishing on the first day of the trout season in any Northeast state is like beginning a romance in which the ritual alone will probably be the reward.

title: ROME MAGISTRATE ORDERS THE TRIAL OF 70 ON CHARGE OF INSURRECTION
description: A Rome investigating magistrate today ordered the trial of more than 70 people on charges of insurrection and forming an armed band.

title: Kobe Steel to Buy Harnischfeger Stock
description: Japan's Kobe Steel Ltd. will buy one million shares of the common stock of the Harnischfeger Corporation, giving it 10 percent ownership in the Milwaukee-based construction and mining equipment manufacturer, Harnischfeger announced yesterday.

title: U.S. BANKI DAMAGED IN SALVADOR
description: US Bank damaged in Salvador: A soldier standing guard outside offices of CItibank in San Salvador, wrecked when a bomb exploded Tuesday night. Three people were hurt. Thr bombing is believed to be the work of lefitists.

title: UNION AGREES TO DELAY NURSING HOME STRIKE DEADLINE
description: A strike threatened against 81 proprietary nursing homes was postponed at least until Saturday as a union official reported last night that all major issues were "substantially resolved."

title: U.S. SENDING AUTO GROUP TO JAPAN
description: The United States, responding to a Japanese request made last Friday, is preparing to send a relatively low-level ''briefing team'' to Tokyo in the next week to discuss measures the Reagan Administration will take to aid America's auto industry, Administration officials said today.

title: Market Place; Niagara Share's Foreign Focus
description: THE Wing Lung Bank Ltd. and Sime Darby Holdings Ltd. are not exactly household names even to institutional investors, but these stocks are among the holdings of the Niagara Share Corporation. The Wing Lung Bank, as it turns out, is a major bank in Hong Kong, while Sime Darby Holdings operates plantations and conducts diversified trading activities in Malaysia.

title: WHERE TO GARAGE AND PARK YOUR CAR
description: Keeping a car in New York City is viewed by many as a form of folly or masochism, particularly in Manhattan, where the automobile density sometimes causes prodigious traffic jams that one day, the experts say, will result in the ultimate stoppage known as gridlock.

title: PHYSICIANS MOVE REAGAN OUT OF INTENSIVE CARE UNIT
description: President Reagan, recovering painfully but apparently uneventfully from chest surgery to remove a bullet from his left lung, was moved today from an intensive care unit to a private room at George Washington University Hospital.

title: 15,000 Seek 20 Postal Jobs
description: The hope of working for the United States Postal Service at more than $17,000 a year drew 15,000 people to pick up applications for perhaps 20 positions.

title: DON'T SHORTCHANGE HYDROPOWER PROJECTS
description: To the Editor:$

title: FOR THE KNICKS, IT'S WIN OR ELSE
description: If the Knicks don't win tomorrow night in Chicago, they will be out of the National Basketball Association playoffs before they realize they were in them.

title: Abitibi, Reed Raise Price of Newsprint
description: Abitibi-Price Inc., the world's largest producer of newsprint, and Reed Paper Ltd. said yesterday that they would raise the Canadian and American price of newsprint by $30 a metric ton, to $500.

title: HELP FOR REFUGEES FROM INDOCHINA CUT
description: Federal support was cut back today for special welfare programs for destitute Indochinese refugees. The reduction will be costly for California, where 40 percent of the nation's 450,000 Indochinese refugees live, and it will be devastating for some refugees who will not be eligible for help under other programs.

title: News Analysis
description: Behind the messages of sympathy from heads of state and government - perhaps even the ''shock'' expressed by the Chinese Prime Minister and the ''indignation'' of the Soviet leader, Leonid I. Brezhnev - a quieter, troubled strain can be sensed in the international reaction to the attempted assassination of President Reagan.

title: Credit Markets Producing Losses
description: Gyrating interest rates during the first quarter played havoc with the profits of securities firms that participate in the credit markets, the companies are beginning to report.

title: STARRETT LOST $8.7 MILLION IN 1980
description: The Starrett Housing Corporation, the beleaguered builder with substantial assets in Iran, announced yesterday that its losses in the fourth quarter of 1980 widened to $7.9 million from $270,000 in the fourth quarter of 1979.

title: CITY PLANS MAJOR RENOVATION OF VAN CORTLANDT PARK
description: New York City will spend $15 million to $20 million in the next 10 years to renovate Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx, Parks Commissioner Gordon J. Davis announced yesterday.

title: DESIGN NOTEBOOK
description: It is hard not to believe that a certain sense of gloom descended upon every breakfast table in the nation on the morning not long ago when news reports of the annual meeting of the National Association of Home Builders were published. The home builders are as aware of the cost of housing as any of us, and they understand fully how difficult it is to produce new housing at an affordable price.

title: MEDICAID COST TAKEOVER VOTED BY STATE ASSEMBLY
description: After objections by some upstate legislators that New York City was getting "the bacon" while their districts were getting "crumbs," the Assembly tonight overwhelmingly approved the state takeover of the annual billion-dollar local costs of Medicaid.

title: ELECTRICIAN AWARDED $1.5 MILLION BY JURY
description: JERSEY CITY (AP) - An electrician who fell 31 feet from scaffolding at a Secaucus construction site in 1977 has been awarded nearly $1.5 million by a Hudson County jury in Superior Court.

title: IN DIVISION OVER POLISH AGREEMENT, UNION DISMISSES CHIEF SPOKESMAN
description: A leading member of the independent labor union Solidarity was dismissed and another resigned today as moderates and militants in the union continued a dispute over the terms of a compromise agreement reached with the Government.

title: A Return to Cornelius
description: Jeno F. Paulucci, the 62-year-old founder of the Chun King Corporation and Jeno's Inc., has returned to a more active role at the Cornelius Company, an Anoka, Minn., food- and beverage-dispensing equipment manufacturer.

title: PENNEY'S SHIFTS TOP EXECUTIVES
description: The J.C. Penney Company, the nation's third-largest retailer, paved the way yesterday for a succession of top management three years hence by creating an ''office of the chairman'' and electing William R. Howell, a senior vice president, as executive vice president and a director.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: THE GARDENER'S TALE
description: The droghte of March hath perced to the rootes of New York City's lawns. The month produced an inch of rain, less than a third the normal amount.

title: STATE STUDY CITES VALUE OF CHILD RESTRAINT SEAT
description: The Department of Motor Vehicles estimated today that 3,200 children were injured in automobile accidents last year because they failed to wear approved restraint systems.

title: Waste Contract Bids
description: Waste Management Inc. of Oak Brook, Ill., announced that separate joint ventures in which it is a principal appeared to be the low bidders for five-year city cleaning contracts in Jeddah, Saudi Arabia, and Cordoba, Argentina.

title: JERSEY MAYOR SEES EDGE IN HIS RACE FOR GOVERNOR
description: -Although changes in the New Jersey election law tripped up his campaign for the gubernatorial nomination after a promising start, Lawrence F. Kramer believes his record as four-term Mayor of this industrial city will still give him the edge in the June 2 Republican primary.

title: NASA SETS APRIL 10 LIFTOFF DATE FOR ORBITAL TEST OF SPACE SHUTTLE
description: The official launching date for the first orbital test flight of the space shuttle Columbia was set today for Friday, April 10, by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

title: CROSS & TRECKER'S ANTITRUST SUIT ENDS; Cross & Trecker's Antitrust Suit Ends
description: The Department of Justice has dropped antitrust charges against the Cross & Trecker Corporation in return for an agreement that the company divest itself of certain assets.

title: A DECADE OF GROWTH, BUT NOT YET PROFITS, FOR PORT OF ALBANY
description: Lining the bustling pier and warehouse sections of the Port of Albany are receiving areas for Volkswagen autos and United Brands bananas, and export facilities for Cargill Inc., the grain company.

title: 'YEAR OF THE SQUASH,' WITH GOOD REASON
description: The seed trade is so enthralled with squash that it has designated 1981 as the "Year of the Squash." Squash plants are prolific; harvest starts in midsummer and, with proper storage, the shell types will last through the winter.

title: FIDRYCH IS SENT DOWN; CAREER MAY BE OVER
description: -The Detroit Tigers optioned Mark (The Bird) Fidrych to the minors for the third time today, in all likelihood signaling the end of his major league pitching career.

title: WRITTEN N.B.A. PROPOSALS ARE SOUGHT FOR SAMPSON
description: -Virginia's coach, Terry Holland, plans to ask Dallas and Detroit of the National Basketball Association to submit written contract proposals to Ralph Sampson, the Cavaliers' 7-foot-4-inch sophomore, it was reported today.

title: Home Beat; A NEW CONVERGENCE OF TALENTS
description: THEY thought it was simply the right time - and they found the right SoHo space. So, Don Thomas, above left, a jewelry designer, and Jorge Cao, a store planner, opened Convergence, a crafts emporium.

title: AMERICAN CAN, SET TO DIVERSIFY, PLANS SALE OF PAPER UNITS
description: The American Can Company announced yesterday that it planned to sell its paper and forest-product operations in an effort to raise cash for new business ventures.

title: WHAT TO DO THIS MONTH; THE CITY GARDENER/ Linda Yang
description: SPRING CLEANING Remove evergreen bough mulches from tubs and yards. Pick up fallen branches and large undecayed leaves and clean debris form street tree pits. On terraces, sweep up leaves and twigs that have collected. Clean roof drains and replace decayed screening material to insure good drainage. Use a detergent and water bath to sponge off winter soot from broad-leaved evergreens such as laurel or rhododendron.

title: THE TESTING SERVICE'S PYRAMID QUESTION WAS A BIT TOO CRYPTIC
description: To the Editor:

title: MGM Hotels' Profit Up
description: Despite a sharp drop in revenues because the fire-ravaged MGM Grand Hotel in Las Vegas has been closed since Nov. 21, MGM Grand Hotels Inc. said today that earnings in the second fiscal quarter edged up to $6.95 million, or 22 cents a share, from $6.81 million, or 21 cents a share, in the comparable period a year earlier. Revenues fell to $43.8 million in the period, ended Feb. 28, from $73.5 million a year earlier.

title: THE TROUBLE WITH LOCAL GOVERNMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: PETER BROOK'S 'CHERRY ORCHARD' CAPTIVATES PARIS
description: TEARS are scarce in the modern theater. Among other things to be remarked about Peter Brook's new production of "The Cherry Orchard" is the wet faces of a Paris audience for whom childmurder would scarcely be more shocking than sentimentality.

title: ART CATALOGUES: THICKER BY THE DOZEN
description: One thing about being an art critic is that you never go short of mail. Everyone on a newspaper gets mail, of course, but the art critic's mail has a torrential quality that carries all before it. Leonardo da Vinci, that great student of mass in motion, should be here to chart its flow and thrust.

title: A BROKER SAYS $10,000 FEE WAS SHARED WITH MARGIOTTA
description: -An insurance broker testified today that he had split a $10,000 insurance commission with Joseph M. Margiotta, the Nassau county Republican chairman, after being informed by Mr. Margiotta that he would receive the check.

title: CSX Earnings Up 59.3% in Quarter
description: The CSX Corporation, created Nov. 1, 1980, by the merger of the Chessie System Inc. and Seaboard Coast Line Industries Inc., reported yesterday that earnings in the first quarter of 1981 increased 59.3 percent over the combined results of the two companies in the 1980 first quarter.

title: JAKOB ACKERET, 83, AN AUTHORITY ON AERONAUTICS AND GAS TURBINES
description: -Jakob Ackeret, who was one of the world's foremost aeronautics experts, died here after a long illness, it was announced today.

title: BASEBALL TRADES
description: -Acquired Jason Thompson, first baseman, from Pirates for Jim Spencer, first baseman; Greg Cochran and Freddie Tolliver, pitchers, and an undisclosed amount of cash. Tuesday, the Yankees obtained Jerry Mumphrey, center fielder, and John Pacella, right-handed pitcher, from Padres for Ruppert Jones and Joe Lefebvre, outfielders, and Tim Lollar and Chris Welsh, pitchers.

title: YANKEES ACQUIRE JASON THOMPSON
description: -In their second major trade within 16 hours, this one a three-team deal involving the California Angels and the Pittsburgh Pirates, the Yankees today acquired Jason Thompson, a power-hitting first baseman, for Jim Spencer, two minor league pitchers and cash.

title: Lewis Sees U.S. Ending Conrail Ownership by '83
description: Transportation Secretary Drew Lewis, providing details of the Reagan Administration's plans for Conrail, said today that he intended to end Federal ownership of the deficit-ridden rail system in the next two years by selling freight operations and turning passenger operations over to local transit systems.

title: 77 TAX PREPARERS FACE CITY CHARGES
description: Almost 80 percent of New York City tax preparers checked in a recent enforcement sweep were charged with violations of city law, the Department of Consumer Affairs said.

title: SOVIET PHYSICIST AND A DISSIDENT
description: -Mikhail A. Leontovich, a leading nuclear physicist, has died at the age of 78 after a long illness, the Soviet press agency Tass reported today.

title: New Head of Levi's Not in the Family
description: Robert T. Grohman, 56 years old, has been elected president and chief executive officer of Levi Strauss & Company, the nation's largest apparel manufacturer, effective Nov. 29, the end of its current fiscal year. He will become the first person unrelated to the founding family to head Levi Strauss, which has annual sales of $2.8 billion.

title: Saudi Gas Pipeline
description: A 730-mile natural gas pipeline across Saudi Arabia has been tested and preliminary operation has begun, the Arabian American Oil Company, known as Aramco, said today. The pipeline, an important part of Saudi Arabia's gas-gathering program, is expected by late this year to be carrying up to 270,000 barrels of gas liquids a day.

title: Three Whites Plead Not Guilty In Slaying of Black in Alabama
description: Three white men have pleaded not guilty to charges that they killed a black teen-ager whose body was found hanging from a tree limb in a racially mixed neighborhood.

title: CAREY TOXIC WASTE PLAN ASSAILED AS 'PREMATURE'
description: Governor Carey's proposal to construct a plant to dispose of toxic waste on state land ran into new difficulties today. A key legislator charged that plans for such a plant were "premature" because the safety of the project could not be guaranteed.

title: MUSIC: EVALYN STEINBECK, CELLIST
description: DEPENDING on what music was being played by Evalyn Steinbock at the Abraham Goodman House on Monday night, the cellist, with fervent strainings at vocalization, either sang with a deep sound and intlelligently shaped phrases or with a ragged energy, sacrificing intonation and character.

title: HART LOSES CANADIAN TITLE FOR FAILURE TO DEFEND
description: -Gaeten Hart has been stripped of his Canadian lightweight title. Murray Sleep, president of the Canadian Professional Boxing Federation, said today.

title: KHOMEINI CALLS FOR PURGE OF JUDICIARY AND THE REVOLUATIONARY GUARDS
description: Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini marked the second anniversary of the Islamic republic today by calling for purges of two of its principal institutions, the judiciary and the Islamic Revolutionary Guards.

title: AWARDS FOR DESIGN
description: The President's Fellows awards of the Rhode Island School of Design will be presented tonight at a dinner at the Whitney Museum of American Art.

title: Around the Nation; Patient Sets Longevity Mark For Heart-Lung Transplant
description: Mary D. Gohlke today became the longest-surviving heart-lung transplant patient in medical history, and her surgeon announced that her prospects were now the best since her operation March 9.

title: FAIRNESS ON CHANNELS
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. DROPS CHARGES AGAINST MAN SEIZED IN COPTER JAILBREAK ATTEMPT
description: All charges were dismissed yesterday against Thomas H. McCreary, a Legal Aid Society employee who was held in jail for six weeks after being accused of hijacking a helicopter to assist an attempted jailbreak in Manhattan.

title: CITY TO TRY NEW LITTER BASKETS
description: Hoping that it has finally found a solution to a source of chronic frustration on New York City sidewalks, the Koch administration will soon install newly designed litter baskets that are supposed to be theftproof.

title: FACULTY MEMBERS PICKET AT WAGNER
description: Members of the Wagner College faculty picketed the seven entrances to its Grymes Hill campus on Staten Island.

title: DANCE FILM AT THE KITCHEN
description: "Making Dances," Michael Blackwood's new film on post-modern dance, will be presented on April 21 at 8 P.M. and 10 P.M. at the Kitchen, 484 Broome Street.

title: Spot Oil Prices Drop in Week
description: Prices for spot oil products eased in the last week amid generally weak demand and adequate supplies, but hardly any activity took place, traders said today.

title: Gas Project Cut In North Sea
description: Organizers of a proposed $5.6 billion gas-gathering project in the British sector of the North Sea have scaled down their plan in a bid to raise financing, oil industry sources said today.

title: Thursday, April 2, 1981
description: After the Shooting

title: Chrysler Asks Recovery Act
description: The Chrysler Corporation's top two executives, Lee A. Iacocca, chairman, and J. Paul Bergmoser, president, today renewed their call for a national automotive recovery act in the auto maker's annual report to shareholders.

title: Chromalloy Sells Consumer Units
description: The Chromalloy American Corporation of St. Louis said it had sold a large part of its consumer products group to the Dyson-Kissner-Moran Corporation, a privately owned New York organization, for about $61.5 million.

title: FLUOR'S STOCK FALLS AS TRADERS STUDY BID TO TAKE OVER ST. JOE
description: The Fluor Corporation's stock fell $4.50 a share in heavy trading yesterday as sharp differences developed over whether the huge engineering and construction company's $2.9 billion offer to acquire the St. Joe Minerals Corporation was really a good deal for Fluor.

title: WATER LEAK DEFIES REPAIR IN JERSEY CITY
description: JERSEY CITY (AP) - A damaged water valve near the Journal Square PATH station has been leaking a gallon of water an hour for more than a year because no one knows how to fix it, a Water Department official said.

title: JONES IS DISAPPOINTED, MUMPHREY ELATED
description: -When Ruppert Jones called his wife in New Jersey to tell her he had been traded to the San Diego Padres, he kept the conversation brief because he was not yet ready to articulate his churning emotions.

title: U.S. AND LIBERIA PLAN JOINT MILITARY EXERCISES
description: The Reagan Administration has ordered a company of Special Forces, also known as Green Berets, and a naval destroyer to Liberia next week to show support for the Government of Master Sgt. Samuel K. Doe, who came to power in a coup a year ago, Pentagon officials said today.

title: Youths Earn Too Little to Survive but Feel They Can't Return to Their Farming Villages
description: Hasan would like to go back to his village but cannot because it would bring dishonor to the family.

title: COACH PLEAU ADDS DUTIES AS WHALERS DROP KELLEY
description: -Jack Kelley, director of hockey operations for the Hartford Whalers, was dismissed today and replaced by the team's head coach, Larry Pleau.

title: WHOM THE COAL STRIKE WILL HURT
description: It sounded like an April Fool's joke at first. How could there be a serious coal strike after the high hopes expressed last week for the new contract just signed by union leaders and industry?

title: BRADY, RECOVERING,BREATHES WITHOUT AID AND CAN SPEAK
description: Continuing what appeared to be an extraordinarily rapid recovery from a gunshot wound in the head, James S. Brady, President Reagan's press secretary, was able to speak today and breathe without the aid of a respirator, the White House said.

title: BOOMING MARKETS SPUR FLOOD OF NEW BROKERS
description: Ronald M. Schwartz, vice president at Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith in charge of training and development, remembers ''when you had to shoot a cannon down Wall Street'' to find a prospective stock broker.

title: 61 Synthetic Fuel Plans Seek Aid
description: Sixty-one projects in 24 states have petitioned the Government for $17.5 billion in subsidies that it has to hand out to spur development of synthetic fuels, officials said today.

title: Flink Resigns From Dancer Fitzgerald
description: Lawrence J. Flink, the 47-year-old executive vice president of Dancer Fitzgerald Sample, has resigned because, the agency said, ''he cannot achieve his long-term personal goals here.''

title: Around the Nation; Boston Jury Finds 7 Persons Guilty in Pornography Trial
description: Seven persons, including a reputed key figure in nationwide pornography trade, were found guilty today of distributing obscene films, magazines and books in New England, New York and Canada.

title: IMORU EGALA, GHANAIAN POLITICIAN AND FOUNDER OF GOVERNING PARTY
description: Imoru Egala, a leading Ghanaian politician, died here today after a heart attack, the Ghana News Agency reported. He was 67 years old.

title: POTHOLE LAW LIMITS CLAIMS AGAINST CITY
description: The city's so-called pothole law, which requires prior notice of of a street problem before a claim for damages can be filed, has turned back claims in about 1,100of 1,200 or more cases, a City Council committee was told.

title: DAF GETS BIG ORDER
description: ton trucks will begin in mid-1983, the company said.

title: CHIHULY GLASS SHOW FEATURES SEA FORMS
description: Although Dale Chihuly has exhibited his glass in 100 shows since 1967 and is represented in 30 public collections in the United States and abroad, the exhibition opening Saturday at the Charles Cowles Gallery is his first one man show in New York City.

title: Around the Nation; Tornado Hits in Alabama, Killing Two and Injuring 23
description: A tornado killed two persons and injured 23 more early today, leaving 300 people homeless in this agricultural community.

title: BURTON TO UNDERGO SURGERY TO EASE SPINAL PAIN
description: Richard Burton will have to undergo neurosurgery to relieve severe spinal pain in "seven to 10 days," his manager, Valerie Douglas, said yesterday in Santa Monica, Calif. The operation is necessary because the actor has a deteriorating cervical disc between his neck and shoulder.

title: JUDGE DEFENDS IT
description: Mayor Koch resumed his criticism of the judiciary yesterday by labeling as "unduly lenient" and "unsatisfactory" a sentence by a State Supreme Court justice.

title: ROSIE RUIZ: IT'S BEEN THE LONGEST YEAR
description: Almost one year after she became a household word, Rosie Ruiz still insists that she ran the Boston Marathon from start to finish. But the publicity generated by her alleged fraud in that race, she says, has made the ensuing months almost unbearable.

title: Canada's Real Estate Giant; A.E. LePage Is Focusing on Deals Abroad
description: Canada's largest real estate company, A.E. LePage Ltd., has moved into international real estate management with an agreement to manage 10 luxury apartment buildings in Saudi Arabia.

title: SICILY PRISON AGREES TO TRANSFER THREE INMATES HOLDING HOSTAGES
description: Penal authorities agreed to transfer three rebellious inmates from Gazzi prison today in return for the release of 15 people held hostage for nearly 10 hours.

title: A FORMER BOARD CHIEF FOR ALLEGHENY POWER
description: Earle S. Thompson, a former president and board chairman of Allegheny Power System Inc., died Monday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 89 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Atari Inc. opened a new manufacturing plant in Fajardo, P.R.

title: COUP IN PORTUGAL CALLED 'IMPOSSIBLE'
description: Prime Minister Francisco Pinto Balsemao ruled out as "impossible" today a military coup here like that recently attempted in Spain.

title: FOR THE GROUPERS, SANDS OF SUMMER BECKON IN SPRING
description: In spring, many New Yorkers turn anxiously to thoughts of summer.

title: ONE FELL SHORT; by William Safire
description: -In this week's test of the ability of the executive branch to respond to an emergency, how did the top officials of the Reagan Administration perform?

title: CHICAGO'S MAYOR SPENDS 'LOVELY' NIGHT AT PROJECT
description: Mayor Jane M. Byrne emerged this morning from her new home away from home in the Cabrini-Green public housing project here and announced that she and her husband, Jay McMullen, had spent a ''lovely'' and ''very quiet'' first night at the violence-torn, predominantly black complex.

title: Air California Sale Planned by Parent
description: the trustees of the Westgate-California Corporation have tentatively agreed to sell its Air California subsidiary for $34.9 million to a newly formed company, Aircal Investments Inc.

title: Fred Meyer Chain To Reconsider Bid
description: Fred Meyer Inc., the largest retail chain in the Pacific Northwest, said today that it would reconsider a bid from Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, the New York investment firm, to purchase all its outstanding shares of common stock for $310 million.

title: GILMORE BLOCKING KNICKS' PATH
description: Coach Jerry Sloan of the Chicago Bulls calls Artis Gilmore a presence. And, with nine victories in a row and 14 in their last 16 games, the Bulls have relied heavily on that presence in their sudden emergence as a team to be feared.

title: SCOTT: A NO. 1 EFFORT FROM NO. 4
description: -The New York Mets got their longest and best pitching of the spring today from Mike Scott, the junior man in the starting rotation, who worked seven scoreless innings while the Mets were edging the Toronto Blue Jays, 2-0.

title: IMPROVISING A SERENE RURAL LIFE
description: IN the best arrangement of life and desire, we never know what we will do next. When I taught at a university, I lived a Tu-Thu schedule with office hours and special appointments. Few hours were fixed; even so, I took leave in order to write full time, and lived as I do now, and developed a taste for it. In 1975 I jettisoned tenure to live the improvised day, rising early each morning without an alarm clock, filling a long day with work, never sure what I will do next.

title: WINEGROWERS CLOSE FRENCH PORT IN A PROTEST OVER ITALIAN IMPORTS
description: Some 5,000 French winegrowers protesting imports of Italian wine sealed off this Mediterranean port today.

title: South Korea's Shoe Industry Seeking a Comeback; Other Nations Cut Into Sales
description: Beginning in the early 1970's, foreign buyers and manufacturers flocked to South Korean shoe factories, attracted mainly by the low wholesale cost of footwear and the factories' high production.

title: BELGIUM FREEZES ALL PRICES DURING CABINET CRISIS
description: The Belgian Government froze all prices today for a month in an effort tokeep a tight grip on the economic situation while the country is in a cabinet crisis.

title: Nontraditional Image At Galli, DeSola & Fiore
description: Galli, DeSola & Fiore is a new advertising and public relations firm in town, and it has something other than the traditional heritage.

title: ASSURING U.S. SEALIFT, AND MARITIME IDENTITY
description: To the Editor:$

title: DRUG SMUGGLERS MAKE A POINT
description: To the Editor:

title: BRZEZINSKI RENEWS HIS COLUMBIA TIES
description: Zbigniew Brzezinski thinks that you can go home again - and he tried it for the day yesterday. The former Assistant for National Security Affairs under President Jimmy Carter returned to the Columbia University campus, where he has been a professor for the better part of the last 20 years. He had lunch with 30 of his colleagues at the School of International Affairs and spoke to students, who packed an auditorium by the hundreds to question him about American foreign policy.

title: People of Reagan Boyhood Home Pose for a Get-Well Photograph
description: Citizens in Ronald Reagan's boyhood home gathered under Memorial Arch today for a group portrait they hope will cheer the President as he recuperates from his wound.

title: THE WINNERS OF THE OSCAR COMPETITIONS
description: Following are the Academy Awards winners: BEST PICTURE - "Ordinary People," Ronald L. Schwary, producer. ACTOR - Robert De Niro, "Raging Bull." ACTRESS - Sissy Spacek, "Coal Miner's Daughter."

title: ALLEGED WORLD SWINDLER GUILTY IN MANHATTAN CASE
description: After a lifetime of alleged international swindles and two convictions in absentia, Eduardo Rabi was present in a courtroom yesterday to hear himself found guilty of grand larceny and fraud. He faces a prison term of up to 14 years.

title: TEXT OF LETTER IN SUSPECT'S ROOM
description: Following is the text of a letter found in the Washington hotel room of John W. Hinckley Jr., charged with the attack on President Reagan. Law-enforcement sources have confirmed its accuracy. The Federal Bureau of Investigation, which is investigating the shooting, declined any official comment on the letter's contents.

title: BASEBALL
description: ATLANTA (NL)--Sent Larry McWilliams, left-handed pitcher, to Richmond.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: MEMORANDUM FOR THE PRESIDENT. A strategic Approach to Domestic Affairs in te 1980's. By Ben W. Heineman Jr. and Curtis A. Hessler. 404 pages. Random House $17.50.

title: FIRE AND ICE
description: We are forced again to think about assassins. There are several prominent theories about what drives such people. Many psychological theses are plausible, but there are so many of them we wonder if any conclusion will ever be reached.

title: Sears Foresees Improved Profits
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company expects a ''substantial'' improvement in the profit of its merchandising group this fiscal year after a ''poor'' performance last year, Richard Jones, its vice chairman, told security analysts in New York yesterday.

title: FOOTNOTE IN THE ANNALS OF THE AMERICAN MUSICAL THEATER
description: Who is the only actress in the history of Broadway to have played the lead in two hit musicals on the same day? It happened on Sept. 15, 1945, the shows were "Carousel" and "Oklahoma!" and it was Iva Winters.

title: SUSPECT GOT IDEA SOME TIME AGO, INVESTIGATORS SAY
description: John W. Hinckley Jr., accused of shooting President Reagan, underwent psychiatric examination today as Federal investigators collected more evidence that they said suggested he had been planning for some time to attack the President.

title: INDUSTRIAL BONDS USE SOARING
description: In what officials said was the first comprehensive tally, the Congressional Budget Office reported today that the volume of tax-exempt industrial revenue bonds sold in the United States soared to $8.4 billion in 1980, from $1.3 billion in 1975.

title: Cubans Who Left Plane in Miami Won't Be Given Political Asylum
description: Immigration officials refused to offer political asylum and instead ordered deportation hearings today for 41 Cubans who got to the United States by posing as tourists and then left a Spain-to-Mexico flight on a Miami layover.

title: ROCKETS DEFEAT LAKERS
description: Moses Malone scored 38 points and grabbed 23 rebounds last night in Inglewood, Calif., to lead the Houston Rockets to a 111-107 victory over the Los Angeles Lakers in the first game of their two-of-three National Basketball Association playoff series.

title: LEAFS, HAWKS PLAY 2-2 TIE
description: The Black Hawks' Reg Kerr scored his 29th and 30th goals of the season last night as Chicago gained a 2-2 tie with the Maple Leafs in Toronto.

title: BRITISH COLUMBIAN UNIT RAISES ITS OFFER FOR MACMILLAN BLOEDEL
description: The British Columbia Resources Investment Corporation has raised its bid for MacMillan Bloedel Ltd. of Vancouver, Canada's largest forest products company, to $347.2 million in response to a competing bid by Noranda Mines of Toronto.

title: General Assembly
description: Special Committee on Enhancing the Nonuse of Force in International Relations-10:30 a.m. and 3P.M. Preparatory Committee for the Energy Conference-10:30 A.M. and 3P.M.

title: Delbert Oberteuffer, 79, Is Dead; Professor of Physical Education
description: Delbert Oberteuffer, professor emeritus of physical education at Ohio State University, died last Thursday in Hyannis, Mass. Dr. Oberteuffer, a resident of East Orleans, Mass., was 79 years old.

title: CONTINUES TO GAIN
description: President Reagan today continued what associates called an ''amazing'' recovery from the chest wound he suffered Monday in an assassination attempt. But the White House limited Mr. Reagan's schedule to avoid tiring him and because he was expected to be in increasing physical pain.

title: U.S. DENIES RUSSIAN EXTENSION OF VISA
description: The Reagan Administration has denied a visa extension to the Soviet Union's leading expert on the United States to keep him from participating in a televised debate, State Department officials said today.

title: FOX AGREES TO NEW BID FROM DAVIS
description: Marvin Davis, the multimillionaire Denver oil man, has reinstated his offer to buy the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation for nearly $700 million in cash and Fox executives have accepted the proposal in principle, both parties disclosed last night.

title: SOVIET PAPER SAYS GOOD WEATHER SPEEDS SPRING SOWING IN SOUTH
description: Good weather in the south of the Soviet Union's European areas has enabled farmers to begin sowing grain earlier than usual, raising hopes for a good crop, the Government newspaper Izvestia said today.

title: NO TALKS ARE SET IN COAL WALKOUT AFTER PACT'S LOSS
description: The chief negotiator for the Bituminous Coal Operators Association said today that the association had ''no plans to resume negotiations'' with the United Mine Workers in the aftermath of the rank and file's unexpectedly sharp rejection of the proposed contract that would have ended a six-day-old nationwide strike.

title: Home Improvement; CESSPOOLS AND SEPTIC SYSTEMS NEED CHECKING
description: MANY homes in long-established suburban communities, as well as most houses in rural areas, still must depend on their own private waste disposal systems to get rid of their sewage, withthe most widely used - and most widely accepted - method being a septic tank combined with a drainage field. The other widely used type of disposal installation is a cesspool.

title: WATCHING PEOPLE WATCHING THE ACADEMY AWARDS
description: It was the second annual Lester Persky Academy Awards television party Tuesday and, like the first, it was something of a hurry-up affair. "I call it my Rolodex party," said Mr. Persky, a producer who had both Gina Lollobrigida and Truman Capote ("I haven't seen a single picture that's up for an award") to serve as guests of honor.

title: 3-YEAR STUDY FINDS A HEART DRUG CUTTING DEATH RATE AFTER ATTACKS
description: A large-scale study has found a sharp reduction in the risk of death for patients taking a drug called timolol after suffering heart attacks, according to a report published yesterday.

title: SHANGHAI TELLS STORY OF CHINA'S BREAK WITH ITS PAST
description: Nowhere is the break between the old China and the new more palpable than in this great city, China's largest, because nowhere are there mor graphic reminders of the old.

title: BONN OFFICIAL IS DUE IN SOVIET FOR TALKS
description: Hans-Dietrich Genscher, the West German Foreign Minister, arrives here tomorrow for talks with Soviet leaders that could shed new light on Soviet intentions in Poland and in East-West arms control talks.

title: ATLANTA TASK FORCE ASSIGNED TO BLACK MAN'S DEATH
description: The body of a 21-year-old black man was found last night in a river, and Public Safety Commissioner Lee Brown said today that the case would be investigated by the police task force that has been looking into the deaths and disappearances of 23 black children.

title: STUDY URGES G.O.P. STRATEGY FOR U.S. POWER
description: The Republican Party can dominate American polities for a generation if it seizes on new technology and new ideas, concentrates on the South and encourages volunteer efforts to replace canceled Federal programs, according to a closely held party planning document.

title: DETROIT MAYOR IS WARNED THAT BANKRUPTCY IS NEAR
description: A special committee studying Detroit's deepening financial crisis said today that unless city taxes were raised and municipal wages were cut the city would be bankrupt by June 30.

title: A SCHOOL FOR ASPIRING CONDUCTORS
description: THE aspiring American conductor has not fared very well in his native land, judging from the many foreign conductors leading major American orchestras. Five years ago, Harold Farberman founded the Conductor's Guild as part of the American Symphony Orchestra League to help alleviate the situation. This summer the group, which publishes a journal and regularly organizes conducting workshops, will sponsor an Institute for American Conductors. From Aug. 3 to Aug. 20 at West Virginia University, master classes will be led by Maurice Abravanel, Sergiu Comissiona, Otto-Werner Mueller and Mr. Farberman.

title: CHINA'S COAL OUTPUT
description: PEKING, April 1 (UPI) China's coal mines produced 78.3 million tons of coal in the first quarter, slightly above their quota, the official New China News Agency said today.

title: AFTER ACADEMY AWARDS, A GREAT SCRAMBLE IN THE BALLROOM
description: At 10:15 last night, B.H. (Buddy) Goldberg, executive director of the American Film Market, blew a loud blast on the solid gold whistle around his neck. Instantly, 1,175 persons rose from their seats in the Beverly Hilton Hotel's International Ballroom and were escorted by 50 Beverly Hills policemen and security guards to a smaller ballroom 100 yards away.

title: ASSISTS MARK TO GRETZKY
description: The Edmonton Oilers' Wayne Gretsky tonight broke Bobby Orr's record for assists in a National Hockey League season, getting his 103d in the first period against the Colorado Rockies. Gretzky, a 20-year-old center, set up Jari Kurri's power-play goal at 1 minute 33 seconds. He added to his mark in the second period of a 4-4 tie by getting his 104th assist on another goal by Kurri.

title: PASSOVER DECORATION IN FLORAL WORKSHOP
description: Strolling through the New York Botanical Garden next week will be a group of Passover celebrants getting into a festive mood early by admiring the garden's collection of purple crocuses, yellow daffodils and other spring flowers just in bloom.

title: A STALINIST PURGE VICTIM RECALLED AT MOSCOW FUNERAL FOR HIS SON
description: Yuri Trifonov, the Soviet writer, was buried today 50 yards from the grave of his father, a high Bolshevik official who fell victim to Stalin's purges in the 1930's.

title: Oil Output Up, Soviet Reports
description: The Soviet Union said today that its oil output for the first two months of this year exceeded the planned level by more than 75,000 barrels a day.

title: Firestone Tire Sells Closed Coast Plant
description: The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company said it had sold a 51-acre manufacturing complex that it closed here last year to an Iowa office furniture manufacturer.

title: Around the Nation; 16 Are Injured in Las Vegas In Caesars Palace Hotel Fire
description: A fire in a luxury suite on the fifth floor of Caesars Palace Hotel today forced hundreds of people to flee the hotel's 12-story central tower, and 16 were injured, authorities said.

title: RIGHTIST EXILES PLAN INVASION OF NICARAGUA
description: Tegucigalpa, Honduras Right wing Nicaraguan exiles here, confident of the support of some sectors of Honduran Army and hoping for a "green light" from Washington, are preparing to invade their homeland to overthrow the 20-month-old Sandinist Government.

title: Main Hurdman Selects a New Chief Executive
description: John A. Thompson, 46 years old, has been named managing partner and chief executive officer of Main Hurdman & Cranstoun, the big New York-based certified public accounting firm. The firm, ninth largest in the United States, has 3,500 accountants and 500 partners in 81 offices.

title: THAI GENERAL, SAYING COUP FAILS, ASSERTS HE HAS KING'S SUPPORT
description: The Thai general whose Government was declared ousted in a coup early yesterday broadcast from central Thailand later that he was still Prime Minister and had the support of King Phumiphol Aduldet and most leaders of the armed forces.

title: FORMER AIDE OF PEOPLE'S TEMPLE CONFESSED 5 KILLINGS AT GUYANA AIRSTRIP
description: A written statement in which Larry D. Layton assumed ''full responsibility'' for the slayings of Representative Leo J. Ryan and four other persons in Guyana in 1978 was produced by the prosecution in a pretrial hearing here today.

title: NEW COSMOS ROLE A DELIGHT TO IARUSCI
description: -The last thing Robert Iarusci expected in December, when he became the first player ever to be reacquired by the Cosmos, was that he would be playing soccer's most glamorous position.

title: EGYPTIANS, AWAITING HAIG, DON'T WANT G.I.'S IN SINAI
description: Cairo, April 1-Three days before the arrival here of Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., ranking Egyptian officials said today that Egypt remained strongly opposed to inclusion of American troops in a multinational Sinai peace-keeping force.

title: American Tobacco
description: The American Tobacco Company said it will close its Richmond plant, where cigarettes have been manufactured for 50 years, by Oct. 1, but said it plans to continue operating several other major facilities in the Richmond area. A company spokesman said the closing of the 600-employee factory, known as the Virginia Branch, should be completed within six months. The company blamed ''changes in cigarette manufacturing requirements'' and increased operating costs.

title: FREEZE ON GRANTS FOR COLLEGE STUDENTS NEARING END
description: The Reagan Administration's freeze on processing Federal education grants for about 1.5 million college students is expected to be lifted next week under the terms of a compromise reached today by the Department of Education and key members of Congress.

title: U.S. MAY SELL SAUDIS RADAR, FUEL PLANES
description: The Reagan Administration was reported today to have tentatively decided on enlarging its program of arms sales to Saudi Arabia by including five Awacs electronic surveillance planes and seven KC-135 aerial tankers.

title: ROMANCE BLOOMS IN BRITISH FASHION
description: The princess and the pirates have given a welcome lift to the fashion scene here which, just six months ago, was preoccupied with bankruptcies and a sense of doom.

title: SETTLEMENT IN PHILADELPHIA STRIKE STARTS BUSES ROLLING
description: A 19-day transit strike that halted buses, trolleys and subway trains for 400,000 Philadelphia commuters ended today with a tentative contract agreement, and the transit union's president ordered his men back to work.

title: Russian Side Withdraws From Television Debate
description: Bill Moyers, the television commentator, said today that the Soviet side had withdrawn from a planned Soviet-American debate in protest against American refusal to extend the visa of a Soviet participant.

title: Ricoh Entering U.S. Market
description: Ricoh Company Ltd., the Japanese company that has been making copiers sold by the Savin Corporation, said yesterday that it would enter the United States market under its own name.

title: Zimbabwe Refinery
description: The Central African Petroleum Refineries, owner of Zimbabwe's only oil refinery, which has been closed for more than 15 years, said today that it would take 18 months and $95 million to reopen it. The company said in a statement that the refinery, which has a capacity of a million tons a year, was in reasonably good condition but a great deal of work would be necessary to put it back in working order. The refinery was closed in 1965 in the wake of international trade sanctions against Rhodesia, as the country was formerly known.

title: TRW Inc. Predicts Flat First Quarter
description: TRW Inc., a diverse automotive, electronics and energy-systems manufacturer, expects this year's first-quarter results to be about the same as last year's, with sales of $1.2 billion, net earnings of $47.9 million and per share profits of $1.30, its chairman, R.H. Mettler, told analysts today.

title: Playing Kremlin
description: There is something profoundly wrong with a State Department that can dream up only one limp harassment of Soviet officials every eight weeks. From election to inauguration, it could think of no fiercer thrust than to require Ambassador Dobrynin to use the public rather than private elevator when visiting the Secretary of State.

title: ISLANDERS TOP RANGERS, 2-1, AND REMAIN IN FIRST PLACE
description: In an erratic contest that neither team appeared capable of winning tonight, the Islanders woke up long enough to post a 2-1 victory over the Rangers at Nassau Coliseum. The victory kept the Islanders in first place in the National Hockey overall standing and was a setback to the Rangers' hopes of clinching a playoff spot.

title: Moving Both Ways on Africa
description: So the Reagan Administration does not, after all, want to swap black Africa for some mineral-rich South African pottage. It will do business even with African Marxists and, like the Carter Administration, press for a negotiated deal on Namibia. Welcome signs. But what mars this shift from ideology to realism is an inconsistent kicking at Angola. If the Administration persists in moving both ways at once, it will neither appease conservative Americans nor befriend a wary black Africa.

title: Copter Suspect Indicted
description: A Federal indictment yesterday charged Jasper A. Banks with assisting a jailbreak attempt and air piracy involving the use of a helicopter in an unsuccessful effort to free a prisoner from the Metropolitan Correctional Center in lower Manhattan on Jan. 25. He was arrested in Boston last week.

title: AGENT SAYS HE KNEW REAGAN HAD A LUNG WOUND
description: Jerry S. Parr, the agent who directed the Secret Service detail protecting President Reagan on Monday, said today that he was aware that the chief executive had been shot through the lung as their armored limousine sped to the hospital.

title: Marcos Foes Shun Debate In Dispute Over Format
description: Opposition politicians failed to appear tonight for a scheduled televised debate with President Ferdinand E. Marcos, and instead Mr. Marcos spoke for two and a half hours by himself, explaining the issues before the public in the plebiscite April 7.

title: JERRY LEWIS IS HIS 'HARDLY WORKING'
description: JERRY LEWIS now there's a name to make a child or a Frenchman smile. For the benefit of the rest of us, Mr. Lewis begins ''Hardly Working,'' which he directed and stars in, with a series of clips from his earlier movies. The purpose of this must be to remind the audience that Mr. Lewis has laurels to rest on. Instead, it prematurely raises the question of why the new film can't stand on its own.

title: NEW ODD-COUPLE MOVIES ARE ODDLY CONVENTIONAL
description: WHEN oddballs fall in love, they seek out others of a similarly weird stripe. Maybe that's why movies right now seem to be devoting most of their imaginative energy to dreaming up, then pairing up, unlikely lovers. Do an out-of-work boxer and a chirpy prostitute (in ''Back Roads'') make an odd couple? Not beside a television newswoman and a janitor (''Eyewitness''), or a voluptuous housewife and the manager of an all-night drugstore (''All Night Long''), not to mention Albert Brooks plus anyone (''Modern Romance''). By comparison with these pairs, the hot-blooded killers of ''The Postman Always Rings Twice'' and the homosexual marrieds of ''La Cage aux Folles II'' look like the homiest of homebodies.

title: by Mimi Sheraton; Lincoln Center rustic and a bit of Havana.
description: IN the six years since it opened, the Milestone, a pleasantly informal and countrified restaurant on West 68th Street, has been a welcome oasis of good, reasonably priced food within walking distance of Lincoln Center. Recently moved to larger quarters, just across the street from its original home, this kitchen now turns out food that does not seem to be quite so good as it was a few years back, but the Milestone remains more than a cut above average and a boon in this area. Prices, though still comparatively moderate, are higher than they were, and service remains friendly and helpful, but the house runs out of many dishes early in the evening, limiting the choice considerably.

title: U.S. AGENCY ASSERTS VOLKSWAGEN FAILED TO DISCLOSE ENGINE DEFECT
description: The Federal Trade Commission today charged Volkswagen with failing to disclose potential engine problems in more than one million of its cars.

title: Economic Scene; Budget Cuts And Economics
description: THE economics profession is in shock over what it sees as a vendetta against it by the Administration's Office of Management and Budget. The Economics and Social Science Directorate of the National Science Foundation has been told to take a 25 percent cut in what remains of the current fiscal year and a 75 percent cut in the fiscal year 1982.

title: THE CIRCUS IS BACK, THRILLS, CHILLS AND ALL
description: IN a splash of chromatic overstatement that makes spring blooms seem pallid, that nomadic tribe called the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus opened for a nine-week stay at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday with a 26-act, two-hour-and-57-minute extravaganza, the ususal dizzying panopoly of pyrotechnics designed to numb the brain and unfocus the eye.

title: JUDGE ORDERS MORE EXTENSIVE TESTS
description: A court-appointed psychiatrist has found John W. Hinckley Jr. competent to stand trial in the shooting of President Reagan, but a Federal judge today ordered a more extensive mental examination, which could take from 30 to 90 days.

title: Credit Markets; RATES UP ON INVENTORY WORRIES
description: Short- and long-term interest rates rose modestly yesterday, when a lack of investor demand for securities encouraged some firms to reduce their inventories before the weekend.

title: Company News; COMPANY IS 'RECYCLING' BUSINESSMEN
description: Four years ago, Myron Sperber reached a career dead end as the senior executive in a family-owned retail business in Pennsylvania. Today, the 58-year-old businessman owns one-third of a six-store retail chain in Chicago, the Clothing Clearance Centers, with sales of about $8 million.

title: HOUSE PANEL FINDS WIDESPREAD AND GROWING ABUSE OF THE ELDERLY
description: The physical, psychological, sexual and financial abuse of elderly Americans is ''widespread, serious and growing,'' according to a report by the House Select Committee on Aging that will be issued today. One million older Americans, most of whom are more than 75 years old, are the victims of such abuse, the report found.

title: EASTERN IS SPREADING OUT IN NEW SHUTTLE TERMINAL
description: ''It's like being liberated,'' Coralee Forte said as she waved a hurrying commuter into the security check at Eastern Airlines' new shuttle terminal at La Guardia Airport.

title: The U.N. Today; April 3, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Special Committee on Enhancing Non-Use of Force in International Relations - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: BRAZIL'S BUSY FACTORIES FORGE A LABOR FIREBRAND
description: Sao Bernardo do Campo, a grimy suburb of Sao Paulo, is now the largest industrial park in Brazil, a symbol of what this country has done in two decades of seeking to become a major power.

title: JURORS HEAR MEXICAN TELL OF BEING CHAINED BY ARIZONA EMPLOYER
description: A Mexican laborer has testified in court here that Bo W.M.Burris, his employer, padlocked a heavy logging chain around his neck for almost 24 hours after some ranching tools were discovered missing.

title: F.B.I. NOTICE ON HINCKLEY ARREST AT ISSUE
description: Secret Service officials told Congressional investigating committees today that the Federal Bureau of Investigation had not given them details of the arrest in Nashville last fall of John W. Hinckley Jr., who has been accused of shooting President Reagan.

title: SCHMIDT SAYS BONN WILL SEEK DROP IN E.E.C. BUDGET COSTS
description: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany said today that Bonn, the biggest contributor to the Common Market budget, would seek a cut in its 1982 share. He added that the decision had received French support.

title: CUT OF $36.9 BILLION IN SOCIAL PROGRAMS IS VOTED BY SENATE
description: The Republican-dominated Senate approved a $36.9 billion package of spending reductions by a vote of 88 to 10 tonight, thereby ordering an extensive retrenchment in social welfare programs and a change in the direction of government.

title: Business People; OILMAN TO BE NAMED SYNTHETIC FUEL CHIEF
description: Edward E. Noble, a 53-year-old Oklahoma oilman and real estate developer, is to be nominated as chairman of the Government-sponsored Synthetic Fuels Corporation, the White House announced yesterday.

title: WEEKEND JAILING BY SECOND JUDGE IGNORED BY KOCH
description: A judge appointed by Mayor Koch and once warmly praised by him has given a jail sentence identical to one that earned another judge criticism from the Mayor. This time Mr. Koch declined to comment.

title: MARGIOTTA'S ROLE IN FEE SPLITTING IS DETAILED
description: An insurance broker described by the defense as ''the critical witness in this case'' testified today in the extortion and mail fraud trial of Joseph M. Margiotta, the Nassau County Republican chairman.

title: Company News; White Plans to Sell Its Australian Unit
description: The financially troubled White Motor Corporation, which filed for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act last September, said it had signed an agreement to sell its Australian subsidiary to Silchester Holdings of Brisbane for an undisclosed price.

title: Advertising; Isuzu Opens Diesel Car Campaign
description: AMERICA has gotten another Japanese car, the Isuzu. (The what?) And, what sets it apart is that it is a diesel car from Japan's oldest car maker and the world's second-largest maker of diesel engines.

title: DOCUMENTED KEY WARS ON FILM
description: Norman William Alley, whose motion pictures brought the Spanish Civil War, the Ethiopian War, and World Wars I and II to the American public, died Wednesday of heart failure at the Motion Picture and Television Home in Woodland Hills, Calif. He was 86 years old and had lived in the home for several years.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard THE TESTAMENT. By Elie Wiesel. 346 pages. Summit Books. $13.95.

title: Prompter Changes In Certificate Rates
description: Effective Tuesday, banks and savings institutions will change the rate they pay on new six-month money market savings certificates on Tuesdays instead of Thursdays. The maximum rate on the certificates will continue to be set one quarter of a percentage point above the average discount rate for six-month Treasury bills, which are sold every Monday.

title: TEXACO ALBERTA FIND
description: - Texaco Canada Inc. reported that a well in Alberta yielded high-quality crude oil at the rate of 1,121 barrels a day. The company's Texaco Canada Resources Ltd. subsidiary is full owner of the wildcat well, in west-central Alberta, Texaco said. The company said it had full control of 14,560 leased acres in the area of the find and plans additional wildcat drilling and development there this year.

title: Hines at Tully Hall
description: Gregory Hines, of the Broadway show ''Sophisticated Ladies,'' will join Debbie Allen, Marlo Thomas, Leon Bibb and others in a tribute to Rosa Parks at 8:30 P.M. on Sunday at Avery Fisher Hall. Mrs. Parks, the seamstress whose refusal to give up her seat sparked a bus boycott in Montgomery, Ala., 25 years ago and led to civil-rights reforms, will also be present.

title: 2.9% G.N.P. Rise Seen in Canada
description: Canadian real gross national product is expected to grow by 2.9 percent this year, compared with a onetenth of 1 percent rise in 1980, the Conference Board of Canada said today.

title: BOSTON SYMPHONY PLANS 100TH ANNIVERSARY TOUR
description: The Boston Symphony Orchestra will make an eight-city world tour and present three world premiers next fall to mark its 100th anniversary, orchestra officials announced yesterday.

title: DANCE: VIOLA FARBER BEGINS UMBRELLA SERIES
description: WITH Wednesday night's performance by the Viola Farber Dance Company, a new Dance Umbrella has opened for some choreographic April showers. Sponsored by the TAG Foundation Ltd., the Dance Umbrella has been providing technical and administrative services to dancers for several years, although because of the lack of suitable facilities, there has not been a Dance Umbrella series since 1979.

title: Company News; Braniff to Expand
description: Braniff International plans a 10 percent expansion of its operations at the Dallas-Fort Worth Regional Airport at the end of April, Braniff officials said.

title: OKC SELLING 5 UNITS
description: The OKC Corporation of Dallas said it had agreed to sell the capital stock of five subsidiaries that hold all of its oil and gas properties to the GMW Oil Company of Midland, Tex., for $20 million in cash and a note. The sale, part of the complete liquidation and dissolution of OKC, is subject to regulatory approval and acceptance by the directors of both companies. OKC said its shareholders would retain royalty rights to any oil and gas produced by GMW after the Midland company recovers drilling and production costs.

title: 'Smile,' '75 movie on beauty contest, to be a stage musical.
description: ALOT of people have talked about turning the 1975 film ''Smile,'' a satirical look at a teen-age beauty pageant, into a Broadway show, but now there is a group that is actually doing something about it. Thomas Meehan, best known as the author of ''Annie,'' is writing the book; Marvin Hamlisch, composer of ''A Chorus Line'' and ''They're Playing Our Song,'' is writing the music, and Carolyn Leigh, whose credits include ''Peter Pan,'' is doing the lyrics. The producers are Howard Feuer, Jeremy Ritzer and Lawrence Gordon, all making their debuts as Broadway impresarios. They are looking to raise $2 million and to open next season.

title: SID L. HYDEMAN
description: Sid L. Hydeman, a retired magazine art editor and graphic artist who specialized in portraits of authors and theatrical and public figures, died Wednesday in Danbury (Conn.) Hospital.

title: energywatch
description: MARCH 27 Crude oil imports fell, but supplies jumped to 391.1 million barrels.

title: CARNEGIE HEAD ASSAILS 'MYTHS' IN REAGAN PLAN
description: President Reagan's plan for achieving economic recovery through budget cuts, deregulation and tax cuts is based on ''myths'' and ''turns a blind eye to some compelling realities,'' Alan Pifer, head of the Carnegie Corporation of New York, declared yesterday.

title: 31 ARE CHARGED IN ALLEGED WESTCHESTER CRIME SYNDICATE
description: Thirty-one reputed members of an organizedcrime network in Westchester County were arrested today and charged with conspiracy in an alleged multimillion dollar operation involving gambling, loan sharking and drug trafficking.

title: G.E. TO SELLA ROBOT FOR USE IN FACTORIES
description: The General Electric Company said yesterday that it would manufacture and sell an industrial robot developed by an Italian company as part of its strategy to become a major supplier of equipment for factory automation.

title: Smoky Subway Fire Delays 72,000 Riders
description: A smoky electrical fire trapped 700 passengers in a No. 7 Flushing subway train yesterday morning and halted all service on the line for 90 minutes, United Press International reported.

title: CUTS COMPARED
description: The following table compares the budget cuts proposed by the Reagan Administration for fiscal year 1982 with cuts approved yesterday by the Senate. Except for those lines marked by an asterisk, the cuts approved by the full Senate are exactly those recommended by the Senate Budget Committee.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, APRIL 3, 1981
description: International New American food aid to Poland was pledged by Vice President Bush. He told a high Polish official visiting Washington that the United States would provide $70 million worth of surplus butter and dried milk to help ease Warsaw's deepening economic crisis. (Page A1, Column 1.) Bonn urged Soviet moderation in international affairs. At a wideranging meeting in Moscow, Hans-Dietrich Genscher, the West German Foreign Minister, said that Bonn would consider Soviet intervention in Poland a flagrant violation of the 1975 Helsinki accord on human rights and East-West relations in Europe. (A3:1-3.)

title: EXCERPTS ON PRESIDENT'S CONDITION
description: Following are excerpts from an exchange at George Washington University Hospital today between Dr. Dennis S. O'Leary of the hospital staff and reporters concerning President Reagan's condition when he was brought to the hospital's emergency room Monday after having suffered a gunshot wound in the chest:

title: Company News; Last Large Chryslers
description: The Chrysler Corporation will permanently close its 53-year-old Lynch Road assembly plant in Detroit tomorrow and will lay off 2,160 employees, marking the end of production of full-sized cars by the nation's No.3 auto maker. The shutdown will mark the fifth Chrysler factory to be closed since 1978 and will leave Chrysler with 22,600 hourly employees in the Detroit area - fewer than half the 1978 average. The plant, which produced the fullsized New Yorker and Cordoba, was originally scheduled to close a year ago.

title: PACERS OUSTED BY 76ERS
description: Julius Erving scored 23 points tonight as the Philadelphia 76ers, holding Indiana to 20 points in the fourth quarter, beat the Pacers by 96-85 for a two-game sweep of their first-round playoff series.

title: CAREY AND MISS GOULETAS SET GREEK ORTHODOX RITE
description: Governor Carey and Evangeline Gouletas, the Chicago condominium developer, announced today that only their families would attend their wedding ceremony next week.

title: YANKS, PIRATES MODIFYING CASH PART OF DEAL
description: While Bowie Kuhn, the baseball commissioner, was reviewing yesterday's trade that sent Jim Spencer to Pittsburgh for Jason Thompson, the Yankees and the Pirates today continued their attempts to modify the cash portion of the deal in order to satisfy Kuhn's guidelines.

title: Money Funds Up By $3.2 Billion
description: Assets of the nation's money market funds rose $3.2 billion in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

title: KENNEDY, SCHWEIKER SPAR ON AID TO POOR
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy, sparring with Richard S. Schweiker, Secretary of Health and Human Services, over the Reagan Administration's proposed budget cuts, said today that the transfer of federally supported health programs to state and local governments would leave the ''poor and the underserved'' competing for scarce funds.

title: THEATER: STRINDBERG AT CIRCLE
description: IN a great production, August Strindberg's ''The Father'' should take the audience on an almost Lear-like descent into madness. The play's hero, a cavalry captain and a free-thinker, is so alienated from life's supposed meaning that he has taken to studying other planets to search for a reason to exist. His scientific research doesn't pay off; he ends up in a straitjacket, slithering into the silence of the universe. By then, the audience should feel, as he does, that ''all thoughts dissolve and our brains grind emptiness.''

title: News Analysis
description: Had they been alive, the state's highest court would have allowed Brother Joseph Charles Fox of Mineola, L.I., to die this week at the age of 84, while it would have required John Storar, 52, of Newark, N.Y., to go on living.

title: FREEMANS, FATHER AND SON, ON SAXAPHONE
description: JAZZ has evolved at such a rapid pace that father-and-son teams have been something of a rarity; all too often, the generation gap cannot be bridged. But the tenor saxophone team of Von Freeman and his son Chico is unique. The father often improvises as freely and adventurously as an avant-gardist half his age, and the son tempers his own exploratory inclinations with warm, melodious ballad playing. Their affinity for each other renders generational boundaries irrelevant, and at the Public Theater this weekend they will be supported by a rhythm section that should be able to follow them anywhere - Kenny Barron on piano, Cecil McBee on bass and Jack DeJohnette on drums.

title: S.E.C.'s Stock Monitor
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission told Congress today that the agency's computerized system to detect violations in stock trading currently covered only 10 percent of all stocks traded but that it would be expanded to include all stocks later this year.

title: THE STAGE WORLDS OF BORIS ARONSON
description: WHEN Harold Clurman was preparing to direct William Inge's ''Bus Stop,'' he asked Boris Aronson to make the set look like an Edward Hopper painting. Mr. Aronson, who was not a man to waste words or to shortchange his own identity, said, ''Why not 'like a Boris Aronson?' '' As it turned out, the set, a roadside diner, did have a touch of Hopper, but as filtered through the designer's sensibility.

title: MEDICAL PROFESSOR AT PENNSYLVANIA STATE IS NOMINATED TO HEAD FOOD AND DRUG AGENCY
description: Dr. Arthur Hull Hayes Jr., chief of the division of clinical pharmacology at Pennsylvania State University College of Medicine, yesterday was nominated by the Reagan Administration as Commissioner of Food and Drugs.

title: DOW EASES BACK 5.13, TO 1,009.01
description: The stock market finished moderately lower yesterday. It had opened higher but turned mixed as investors began cashing in the substantial profits made during what Wall Street is calling the ''Reagan recovery rally.''

title:
RED SMITH;
A Tale of the Two-Headed Trout
description: THE word ''enthusiasm'' comes from the Greek ''entheos,'' meaning inspired or referring to the power of one who is divinely inspired. Inasmuch as there is no living creature more enthusiastic than the dedicated trout fisherman, it follows that he and his breed are godlike.

title: Transactions; AUTO RACING
description: Mario Andretti has signed a one-year con- t ract with the STP Corporation to drive for t he Patrick Racing Team on the circuit for I ndianapolis-type cars.
