BASEBALL CHICAGO (AL) - Sent Mike Colbern, c atcher, to Edmonton of Pacific Coast L eague. CHICAGO (NL) - Sent Carlos Lezcano, o utfielder, to Iowa of American Association. D esignated Willie Hernandez, pitcher, and T y Waller, infielder-outfielder, for minor l eague assignment. HOUSTON (NL) - Placed J.R. Richard, p itcher, on 60-day disabled list. Traded Mike F ischlin, infielder, to Cleveland for a player t o be named. Sent Gordie Pladson and Bert R oberge, pitchers, to Tucson of Pacific C oast League. Designated Alan Knicely, c atcher, and Joe Pittman, infielder, for m inor league assignment. KANSAS CITY (AL) - Sent Onix Concep- c ion and Tim Ireland, infielders; Jerry T witty and Gary Christenson, pitchers; Jim G audet, catcher, and Dan Garcia, outfield- e r, to Omaha of American Association. D esignated Dave Wehrmeister, pitcher, for m inor league assignment. Waived Jerry T errell, infielder, for purpose of giving him h is unconditional release. METS (NL) - Sent Dan Norman, out- f ielder, and Ray Searage, pitcher, to Tide- w ater of International League. Sent Billy S mith, pitcher, who had been drafted out of t he Houston organization, back to Houston. MINNESOTA (AL) - Placed Darrell J ackson, pitcher, on the disabled list. SAN FRANCISCO (NL) - Sent Rich Mur- r ay, first baseman, and Dennis Littlejohn, c atcher, to Phoenix of Pacific Coast League.

title: 40 TO READ POETRY OF THE CITY IN 10-HOUR MARATHON
description: Consider Manhattan, in verse: Hard-edged buildings; cloudless blue enamel; Lapidary hours - and that numerous woman, Put-together, in many a smashing Suit or dress is somehow what it's, well, All about. A city designed by

title: RALPH M. BILBY
description: Ralph M. Bilby, former board chairman of the Arizona Public Service Company and a longtime civic leader in the state, died Wednesday of cancer in Phoenix. He was 63 years old.

title: The talk of Houston
description: THE recent appointment of Barbara Rose, the art historian and critic, as curator of exhibitions and collections at the Museum of Fine Arts in Houston, has set off a little controversy in that upand-coming culture center. It's not only that Miss Rose will retain her job in New York as art editor of Vogue, touching down in Houston for one week every month. It's also that last week, a story in The Houston Post by Mimi Crossley, art critic for the paper, reported that a month before Miss Rose's hiring, the museum acquired five paintings from her husband, the songwriter Jerry Leiber, for an unconfirmed purchase price of $80,000.

title: Three Die in Newark In North Ward Fire
description: Three people died in a fire in the north ward of Newark last night, the Fire Department said. The fire, which was discovered at 10:17 P.M. and was declared under control 22 minutes later, was in an apartment above a store at 239 Bloomfield Avenue.

title: As a Barrymore Saw It
description: It was a tribute to the Barrymores, but it was Myrna Loy who brought down the house the other night when 500 people gathered at the Regency Theater to celebrate the publication of ''The Barrymores: The Royal Family in Hollywood'' by James Kotsilibas-Davis.

title: G.P.U. GETS RATE RISE
description: The General Public Utilities Corporation, facing possible bankruptcy because of the Three Mile Island accident, won permission yesterday to increase substantially rates charged by its two Pennsylvania subsidiaries.

title: 2 BROOKLYN BANKS PLAN MERGER
description: The Metropolitan Savings Bank and the Brooklyn Savings Bank, both based in Brooklyn, announced yesterday that they had agreed to merge into the fourth-largest mutual savings bank in the United States. Their action is part of a trend toward consolidation of savings institutions.

title: Crew is Rescued From Ship Periled by Natural Gas Leak
description: Nineteen crew members were trapped for more than five hours aboard a survey ship today as natural gas from the bottom of the Gulf of Mexico bubbled up around them, the Coast Guard said.

title: A FOUNTAINHEAD OF ROCK
description: and-rollers, will pay a rare visit to New York this weekend, appearing for two concerts at the Bottom Line on Sunday, backed by the brassy nine-man band Roomful of Blues.

title: Yippies Evicted
description: The Youth International Party and allied groups were evicted from an East Village building. William M. Kunstler, the groups' lawyer, said that they had a lease for the building, at 10 Bleecker Street, that would extend for another two years, but that the lease also had a provision that allowed the landlord to evict them virtually at will.

title: INTEL AND MATRA-HARRIS AGREE TO FRENCH VENTURE
description: In a move that may give it access to a large part of the French electronics market, the Intel Corporation said today that it had agreed to form a joint venture with Matra-Harris Semiconducteurs, a French concern.

title: U.S. DOCTOR ESCAPES IRAN ON FOOT AFTER BEING STRIPPED OF PASSPORT
description: An American physician who fled from Iran to Turkey by bus and on foot flew to Rome today on her way back to the United States. She was described as hopeful that she could return to Iran some day.

title: ENRICO MACIAS WILL SING
description: ENRICO MACIAS sings in French, Hebrew, Arabic, Spanish and Italian. But, he says, language is only a small part of what he has to offer. ''It is the music, the atmosphere, the communication that is important.''

title: Inquiry Asked On Coal Rates
description: The United States Coal Exporters Association is seeking a Government investigation of coal-export rates charged by the Norfolk & Western Railway and the competing Chessie System, contending that the rates are excessive.

title: TRAUMA PROGRAM THAT AIDED REAGAN IS IMPERILED BY HIS PLAN TO CUT BUDGET
description: The Federal program that helped organize the sophisticated emergency treatment system into which President Reagan and three others wounded in Monday's assassination attempt were channeled would be terminated under the President's budget-cutting proposals.

title: A NEWS DISTRIBUTOR GUILTY OF PAYOFFS
description: A major distributor of magazines and newspapers pleaded guilty in Manhattan to Federal charges of giving $37,000 in payoffs to officials of the Newspaper and Mail deliveres Union between 1976 and 1979.

title: News Analysis
description: When two adversaries struggle against each other long enough and hard enough, the axiom goes, they begin to resemble each other. The independent union organization Solidarity and the Polish Communist Party are a long way from being mirror images, but a number of striking similarities did emerge during the latest crisis. Both organizations responded to the crisis in the same way: hard-line factions geared up for a confrontation and were overruled and repudiated. In both cases the moderate leaders - Stanislaw Kania in the party and Lech Walesa in the union - were strong enough to carry the day, but only because their positions received strong support from the majority of the rank and file.

title: Friday; JAN DE GAETANI IN ROCKLAND
description: Jan De Gaetani, the mezzo-soprano, has a reputation for versatility. Tonight at 8:30, she will sing music spanning the centuries, from Handel and Brahms to Vaughan Williams and Arnold Black, at the Rockland Center for the Arts, 27 Greenbush Road, West Nyack, N.Y. Assisting artists will be Philip West, oboist; Abba Bogin, pianist and harpsichordist, and Frederick Zlotkin, cellist, who will also perform the Poulenc Sonata for Oboe and Piano and Beethoven's Seven Variations on a Theme by Mozart for cello and piano. Tickets are $5.50 ($4.50 for students and the elderly). Reservations are suggested: (914) 358-0877. SATIRE ON THE WEST SIDE

title: Phil Mahre Outraces Field In Giant Slalom in Alaska
description: Regaining the form he lost with his bindings the day before, Phil Mahre won the United States Alpine Championship giant slalom yesterday at the Alyeska ski resort.

title: Hinckley Family Says That Man Shown in Nazi Uniform Isn't Son
description: The family of John W. Hinckley Jr., the man accused of shooting President Reagan, says that a man in a Nazi uniform appearing in a photograph made public Wednesday is not their son.

title: MODERN ART OF 1100'S AT THE CLOISTERS
description: DRIVING northward from Paris toward Chantilly on the new expressway, you can't miss the Cathedral of St.-Denis, though it lies quite some way from the road. And if it's conspicuous now, with its high-backed silhouette and its look of a great ship that has somehow drifted inland, we may be sure that it was even more conspicuous in the year 1144, when it was inaugurated with all possible pomp in the presence of Louis VII, King of France, his queen, Eleanor of Aquitaine, and everyone who counted in France. Seen in the context of that plainest and flattest of countrysides, it must have stood out like a diamond on a dungheap.

title: Springtime in Albany
description: A few days ago Governor Carey explained that the juices of spring had turned his graying hair a color more often associated with maple leaves in October. Today it is clear that vernal power has had an even stronger and, one hopes, a more lasting effect. Mr. Carey and Evangeline Gouletas have announced that they will be married on April 11. The Governor will meet this deadline, even if it is beyond his power to produce a state budget agreement on time.

title: 'HOLY TERROR'
description: ''Holy Terror,'' the 1977 horror film that opens today at the Astor Plaza and other theaters, will go into the record books as the movie in which Brooke Shields made her screen debut, though the film itself is a creditable example of its genre and Miss Shields is in the picture for an extremely short time.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Arizona Public Service Co. awarded two contracts valued at about $75 million to the Babcock & Wilcox unit of McDermott Inc.

title: Index; International
description: Egyptians say they oppose U.S. role in Sinai force A2 U.S. terminates economic aid to Nicaragua A3 Around the World A6 For Istanbul youth, return to farm is not a way out A7 In Shanghai, mute reminders of China's break with the past A8 Khomeini seeks purges of judici- ary and revolutionary guards A9 Polish union ousts official A10 West German Foreign Minister due in Moscow today A11 Second Islamic peace effort in Gulf seems to end in failure A11 Yuri Trifonov, writer, given offi- cial funeral in Moscow A12 Quebec nationalists take unex- pected lead in poll A16 Reagan Shooting President is moved to private hos- pital room A22 Sen.
