title: TURKEY ENJOY'S THE NATION'S 'FULL SUPPORT'
description: To the Editor:

title: HAIG'S WRONG SIGNALS
description: Less than two hours after President Reagan was shot, a trembling Secretary of State grasped the lectern in the White House briefing room and announced in quavering voice: ''I am in control.'' If General Haig had not visibly had the shakes, it could have been a terrifying moment.

title: Zimbabwe Rebels Attack Town
description: Anti-Marxist guerrillas attacked the Mozambique garrison town of Espungabera near the Zimbabwe border and killed a child, security sources said today. They said the guerrillas struck yesterday with light artillery and machine guns.

title: STAGE: THE ELLINGTONIANS RING TRUE IN 'LADIES'
description: WHEN ''Sophisticated Ladies,'' the musical based on Duke Ellington songs, was floundering through its out-of-town tryouts in Philadelphia, Wilmington and Washington, the jinx that hovered over Mr. Ellington's efforts to do a Broadway show while he was alive seemed to be pursuing him even after his death.

title: ART: NARRATIVE PAINTING STRUGGLES FOR A REBIRTH
description: TO tell a story, to describe an action, to create memorable characters and recall legendary events was once for painters - as it was for poets - one of the fundamental tasks to which the artistic imagination addressed itself. But just as narrative ceased to be a central concern for the great modernist poets, so did storytelling all but disappear from modernist painting. What had long been the province of poetry and painting was now left to prose and the movies. For the high culture of the modernist era, there was something suspect about straightforward narrative - to such an extent, indeed, that storytelling was often dismissed as a lowbrow interest. It was certainly not something with which an ambitious pictorial talent was any longer expected to be concerned.

title: AT ODDS OVER A-BOMB, U.S. AND PAKISTAN MAKING UP
description: Longstanding differences between the United States and Pakistan over Pakistan's nuclear energy program should pose no barrier to improved relations between the two nations and to increased economic and military aid, according to Western diplomats as well as Pakistani and American sources here.

title: A Study of British Drunk-Driving
description: One person in 10 breaks the drunk-driving laws each week in Britain, according to a report published today by the Office of Health Economics, a research group financed by the pharmaceutical industry. The report said that Britain has 750,000 or more ''problem drinkers'' in its 56 million population.

title: Business People; MacMillan Ex-President Fighting to Take It Over
description: Less than six months after resigning as president of MacMillan Bloedel Ltd. of Vancouver, Canada's largest forest products company, Bruce Howe is engaged in a takeover battle for MacMillan as president and chief executive officer of the British Columbia Resources Investment Corporation.

title: A CHANCE TO HEAR OPERA'S NEWCOMERS
description: year-old soprano from Urbana, Ill., scooped three bent nails from a backstage floor - traditional tokens of good fortune. Gail Dubinbaum, 25, a mezzo from Northridge, Calif., did not dare think of winning for fear of invoking a jinx. And Rebecca Cook, 28, a soprano from San Francisco, battled a thought that intruded on her concentration as she sang ''Dove sono'' from ''The Marriage of Figaro'' on stage. ''Dear God,'' Miss Cook kept thinking, ''I'm at the Met!''

title: WEINBERGER AND HOLLINGS CLASH OVER MILITARY BUDGET
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger encountered the first critical Congressional scrutiny of President Reagan's proposed military budget today when Senator Ernest F. Hollings of South Carolina questioned the Administration's long-range planning.

title: BAD MANAGEMENT MAYBE, BUT NOT CHANGING
description: To the Editor:

title: A State of Emergency Is Declared in Belize
description: The British Governor of this Caribbean colony declared a state of emergency today after riots and strikes by workers and political opponents that have shut down most businesses and government services for three days.

title: MARXIST GROUP CHARGES CONSPIRACY AS $40 MILLION SUIT GOES TO TRIAL
description: A lawyer accused the Federal Government of waging a 40-year ''campaign of disruption and defamation'' against the Socialist Workers Party as the trial of the party's lawsuit seeking $40 million in damages opened yesterday in Manhattan.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Armco Inc., Middletown, Ohio, has elected Howard T. Cusic chairman, president and chief executive officer of its Oregon Metallurgical Corporation unit.

title: Company News; Airline Choses Pratt
description: Pratt & Whitney Aircraft of Canada, a unit of the United Technologies Corporation, said TransBrasil Airlines had selected its PW2037 turbofan engines to power six Boeing 757 aircraft. Pratt said the engine order, the first from a foreign carrier for use on the 757, is valued at $53 million. The company said production of the new fuel-efficient engine is to begin in 1984 and that deliveries of the aircraft to the private Brazilian airline would begin in 1985.

title: CITY 'HEART LAW' UPHELD BY COURT IN A 5-2 DECISION
description: New York State's highest court today upheld lower-court rulings that a New York City police officer or firefighter who is disabled or dies because of a heart ailment during his employment is entitled to special benefits unless city officials can prove the ailment did not stem from his work.

title: Belgian Official Is Asked To Form a New Regime
description: King Baudouin of Belgium today accepted the resignation of Prime Minister Wilfried Martens and asked Finance Minister Marc Eyskens, a Flemish Social Christian, to form a new government, an official statement said.

title: F.T.C. STAFF URGES END TO CHILD-TV AD STUDY
description: After three years of controversy, the staff of the Federal Trade Commission has recommended that the agency drop its investigation into regulating children's advertising on television.

title: SWARTHMORE ELATED BY A $6 MILLION GIFT
description: Swarthmore College announced today that Eugene M. Lang, a New York City entrepreneur, had given the college $6 million, the largest gift in the school's 117-year history.

title: CORPSE IN MAUSOLEUM DESCRATED BY VANDALS
description: Teen-age vandals broke through the heavy metal doors of a Queens mausoleum yesterday afternoon, smashed open a coffin and desecrated the corpse inside, according to a spokesman for John Santucci, Queens District Attorney.

title: Nicaraguan Officials Assail Cutoff in American Aid
description: Nicaraguan officials today assailed the Reagan Administration's decision to halt economic aid to the two-year-old junta here.

title: KHEEL UPSTAGED ON A VISIT TO CITY HALL
description: Theodore W. Kheel, the labor mediator, went to City Hall yesterday in search of a dialogue with the man whose stewardship of municipal government he finds seriously flawed. In the process, he later said, he found out firsthand why Edward I. Koch may be hard to displace as New York City's Mayor this election year.

title: WHY FEAR A STATES'
description: CONVENTION To the Editor:

title: Find by Mobil Near Hibernia
description: A new oil and gas discovery off the coast of Newfoundland was announced today by Mobil Oil Canada Ltd., but it was not immediately clear whether the find was large enough for commercial development.

title: BONN AIDE, IN SOVIET, CALLS FOR MODERATION
description: Hans-Dietrich Genscher, the West German Foreign Minister, urged the Soviet Union today to act with moderation in international affairs, especially in regard to Poland and Afghanistan.

title: SERIOUSLY, THERE'S NO REASON TO WAVE GOODBYE ON PUBLIC
description: TV To the Editor:

title: George Goodman Dies; Educator and Journalist
description: George W. Goodman, a social worker, journalist and educator who was an official of the National Urban League and a dean at Fisk University, died Wednesday at St. Francis Hospital in Hartford. He was 80 years old and lived in Hartford.

title: DISASTROUS MINUTES
description: High White House officials, in their present circumstances, have little choice but to put the best possible face on Secretary of State Haig's performance the day President Reagan was shot. But Mr. Haig's few minutes on national television, at the height of the crisis, may have irreparably damaged him.

title: 37 REPORTED KILLED IN BATTLES IN BEIRUT
description: Intense shooting erupted here and in eastern Lebanon today in the worst violence since the civil war ended in a cease-fire in 1976.

title: U.S. TO AID POLAND WITH SURPLUS FOOD WORTH $70 MILLION
description: As the Administration expressed new concern about Soviet troop movements near Poland, Vice President Bush announced today that the United States would provide Warsaw with $70 million in surplus butter and dried milk to help ease its economic crisis.

title: No Headline
description: ''It's like running a small town or like a county board of commissioners,'' said John M. McCabe, legislative director of the National Conference of Commissioners on Uniform State Laws in Chicago, as he tried to describe how condominium communities are governed.

title: MUSIC: KUBELIK'S 'ORPHIKON'
description: EVERY conductor who composes learns to live with the epithet "conductor's music." Musicians use the term slightingly to describe compositions that may be crafted well -- often brilliantly -- but that betray at every turn of the page how difficult it is for experienced conductors to empty their minds of the music they have spent many years learning and to compose something with a recognizably individual voice. However, there is conductor's music and there is conductor's music. At the New York Philharmonic last night, we heard an unusually ambitious example of the genre, when Rafael Kubelik, the orchestra's current guest, conducted the world premiere of his "Orphikon."

title: Company News; Posner Expanding Simplicity Stake
description: Victor Posner, the financier who is chairman of the Southeastern Public Service Company of Miami, said that Southeastern intends to expand its stake in the Simplicity Pattern Company to 25 percent, buying an additional 1.9 million shares before May 2.

title: Appeals Court Refuses ABC-TV Bid to Bar Wolf
description: The State Court of Appeals refused today to grant a request by the American Broadcasting Companies to bar Warner Wolf, the sportscaster, from appearing on a rival station, WCBS-TV, because of a contract dispute.

title: Mets Fail in Effort to Get Oliver of Rangers
description: Craig Swan tested his shoulder successfully for the fourth and final time in an exhibition game tonight. But his comeback to the Mets was upstaged by a rush of traffic that sent Joel Youngblood back to the outfield and Dan Norman back to Tidewater.

title: COURT RESERVES DECISION IN NEW YORK OIL-TAX FIGHT
description: Decision was reserved yesterday after oral arguments on the constitutionality of New York State's 2 percent tax on the gross receipts of oil companies doing business in the state. The case was heard in the Temporary Emergency Court of Appeals of the United States.

title: Company News; Standard of Indiana Encouraged by Find
description: The Standard Oil Company (Indiana), the sixth-largest United States oil company, said that natural gas production from the United Arab Emirates sheikdom of Sharja could begin in 1982 if the company's second well there confirms a major find.

title: Two Firsts for the State University of New York
description: The State University of New York will break two traditions in Albany today when it confers an honorary degree on Elisabeth Luce Moore.

title: A REPLACEMENT FOR PATANE
description: William Harwood will replace Giuseppe Patane as conductor of the American Symphony Orchestra concert to be given at Carnegie Hall on April 12. Mr. Patane has been hospitalized in Italy after being injured in an automobile accident. Mr. Harwood will take over the program announced for Mr. Patane.

title: Bridge: On Occasion, a Safety Play; Will Give Virtue Its Reward
description: Among the large group of New Yorkers in the Detroit Spring Nationals were Rita and Al Rand, Gail Moss, Jim Becker and Matt Granovetter. In March they won the Long Island Swiss Team Championship, in part because of the diagramed deal.

title: Lee Morgan Gammill Dies at 81; Former New York Life Executive
description: Lee Morgan Gammill, a retired vice president and general counsel of the New York Life Insurance Company, died Tuesday at his home in Scarsdale, N.Y. He was 81 years old.

title: Noranda Increases Bid for MacMillan
description: The battle for control of MacMillan Bloedel Ltd. of Vancouver, Canada's largest forest products company, intensified today as Toronto-based Noranda Mines Ltd. raised its cash-and-shares offer for the company to the equivalent of $62 a share, or $626 million (Canadian).

title: 200 books from 15th century
description: ERIC SEXTON was a collector who spent more than half a century assembling books that document the spread of printing across Europe in the 15th century. His collection will be auctioned at 10 A.M. on Wednesday at Christie's, Park Avenue at 59th Street. Mr. Sexton, who died last year at the age of 78, was a bibliophile who began shopping in London and on the Continent in 1921 and continued through the mid-60's.

title: ASSEMBLY BACKS FUNDS FOR ABORTIONS
description: An effort to end state Medicaid financing for most abortions was turned aside by the Assembly late tonight, but not before seven Republican legislators normally in favor of the financing walked out just before thr crucial vote.

title: Britain's Opening To Center
description: The impressive thing about Shirley Williams in this day of sloganeering, table-pounding, image-grooming, is that she makes so little effort to impress.

title: WEEKS STANDS UP WELL IN RANGER DEBUT
description: Steve Weeks, the Rangers' rookie goaltender make his National Hockey League debut against the Islanders tonight and stopped the first shot aimed at him with the game only 22 seconds old.

title: Company News; DEVELOPERS OF OPTICAL PRINTER WIN OSCAR FOR SPECIAL EFFECTS
description: The people who made possible the feats of Superman, King Kong and the Incredible Shrinking Woman have been quietly prospering in Hollywood for the past four decades, producing and putting to work an amazing machine that creates special effects for motion pictures.

title: Antuofermo Triumphs
description: Vito Antuofermo, his forehead covered with blood, scored a unanimous 10-round decision tonight over Mauricio Aldana.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: EVERYONE will be thinking pink at the wedding April 11 of Evangeline Gouletas and Governor Carey. Miss Gouletas will be wearing a lowwaisted pink satin gown with full skirt, chiffon bodice and sleeves, and it's being feverishly stitched together this very minute by the New York couturier Stavropoulos.

title: Key Rates
description: * Current rate excludes 3 percentage-point surcharge on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Cosmos Put Restrictions On Carlos Alberto's Role
description: Krikor Yepremian, the general manager of the Cosmos, met briefly yesterday with the team's disenchanted star from Brazil, Carlos Alberto, and presented options concerning his future. The options did not include the possibility of Carlos Alberto's playing regularly.

title: Miss Van Hoose Shots a 66 and Leads by 3
description: Myra Van Hoose shot a sixunder-par 66 today to take a three-stroke lead after the first-round of the $250,000 Colgate-Dinah Shore golf tournament.

title: DOCTOR SAYS PRESIDENT LOST MORE BLOOD THAN DISCLOSED
description: A review yesterday of President Reagan's emergency medical care at George Washington University Hospital confirmed that the President lost more blood in the initial critical period than was previously acknowledged, according to Dr. Dennis S. O'Leary, the hospital's director for clinical affairs.

title: REVOLT IN THAILAND ENDS AS REBELS FLEE
description: A military rebellion that began early Wednesday ended today as thousands of troops loyal to the Prime Minister moved unopposed into Bangkok, seizing army and Government headquarters, the airport and all radio and television stations.

title: Company News; G.&W. Raises Stake In Three Companies
description: Gulf and Western Industries Inc. said in filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had increased its stake in the Libbey-Owens-Ford Company, Munsingwear Inc. and the Mohasco Corporation.

title: Business People; Caesars World And Jersey Unit Pick President
description: J. Terrence Lanni has been elected president and chief operating officer of both Caesars World and its Caesars New Jersey subsidiary, it was announced by the two companies.

title: Would Everyone Please Talk at the Same Time?
description: Why did the ballet dancer and choreographer Jacques d'Amboise convene a mini-United Nations in a private office in the United Nations press center Wednesday?

title: END TO WEEKLY MONEY REPORT STUDIED
description: The Federal Reserve Board announced today that it was considering ending the practice of reporting money supply data each Friday. The move could reduce pressure on the Fed to adjust interest rates weekly in response to short-term changes in the money supply.

title: HOME IS FOR LIVING NOT FOR SPECULATING
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: The names of two recently discovered victims were officially added to a special task force's list of missing and murdered children here today at a news briefing that included a tour of the investigation headquarters.

title: ZALE'S GERMAN STAKE
description: The Zale Corporation of Dallas, operator of jewelry and other retail outlets, said it had acquired for an undisclosed amount of cash an 85 percent interest in Keller-Christ, a jewelry retailer with 77 units based in Frankfurt, West Germany. Zale said the acquisition included jewelry stores and leased jewelry departments in West Germany. Keller-Christ, which also manufactures jewelry, operates additional units in Switzerland and France and has a sales volume of about $44 million, Zale said.

title: The Police Blotter
description: Two plainclothes police officers were injured when a motorist they had stopped on Fifth Avenue at 31st Street in Manhattan struck them with his car and sped away.

title: by Chris Chase; For 'Thief' role, James Caan got first-hand data.
description: JAMES CAAN is in New York to do publicity for his new United Artists movie, ''Thief,'' because he really likes it. ''It's unusual for me to come and speak nicely about a picture,'' he says. ''Usually, I tell them, 'You better not send me.' ''

title: SCREEN: 'ATLANTIC CITY,' LOUIS MALLE GHOST STORY
description: ''ATLANTIC CITY,'' Louis Malle's fine new movie, may be one of the most romantic and perverse ghost stories ever filmed, set not in a haunted castle but in a haunted city, the contemporary Atlantic City, a point of transit where the dead and the living meet briefly, sometimes even make love, and then continue on their individual ways.

title: U.S. IS RESISTING GREEK DEMANDS SETTING CONDITIONS ON ARMS AID
description: Negotiations with the United States over a military and economic cooperation accord are stumbling over Greek demands that Washington appears unwilling to satisfy.

title: ARCHITECTURE TO PLEASE THE PALATE
description: It is a rare building that tastes good, even at Cooper Union, where architecture students are noted for the refinement of their designs. Even the best of Cooper projects normally has rather more concrete, wood and glass than satisfies the taste buds.

title: REAGAN EAGER TO RETURN TO WORK ON FISCAL PLANS
description: On the fourth day after he was shot in the chest, President Reagan strolled around his hospital suite, ate heartily and told key aides that he was apprehensive that his economic recovery program might falter unless he returned to work quickly, according to a White House spokesman.

title: Interco Profits Up 15.3% in Quarter
description: Interco Inc., a major maker of footwear, apparel and furniture, reported yesterday that net income for the fiscal fourth quarter was up 15.3 percent, to $38.5 million, or $2.36 a share, from $33.4 million, or $2.24 a share, for the comparable quarter the year before.

title: TESTING PRISON FOR HINCKLEY IS FOCUS OF STRIFE
description: The Federal prison where the accused assassin John W. Hinckley Jr. has been transferred for pyschiatric diagnosis has a troubled history of its own.

title: NASA Test of Atmosphere Is Startling to Early Risers
description: Spectacular red and bluishyellow clouds created by a scientific rocket test painted the winds and startled early risers along the Eastern Seaboard today.

title: Two Biographies Win $4,000 Bancroft Prize; Two Biographers Win $4,000 Bancroft Prizes
description: Ronald Steel, author of ''Walter Lippmann and the American Century'' (Atlantic-Little, Brown), and Jean Strouse, author of ''Alice James: A Biography'' (Houghton Mifflin), are the winners of the 1981 Bancroft Prizes - the first time two biographies won the prizes.

title: The Man at the Wheel Has to Steer
description: It's the stuff of bad melodrama. Special Trade Representative Bill Brock says he is in charge of negotiating limits on Japanese auto imports. Wrong, asserts Secretary of State Haig: this is my show. Both are telling Japan it must ''voluntarily'' cut auto shipments. But in order to sell restraint at home, the Japanese say, they must have a formal request and a public show of diplomatic arm-twisting.

title: INFLATION RELIEF
description: To the Editor:

title: DANCE: LAR LUBOVITCH OFFERS NEW WORKS
description: The first thing you notice about the Lar Lubovitch Dance Company, which opened Wednesday night for a run through Sunday at the City Center, is the fantastic dancing.

title: Alabama Town Digging Out After Tornado That Killed 2
description: The homeless of Hurtsboro dug through rubble today, salvaging what they could after a tornado yesterday killed two persons and destroyed much of the small farming town.

title: Toshiba's British Output
description: Toshiba Consumer Products said today that it planned to restart full production of its range of Britishmade color television sets in Plymouth, England, on May 4. Toshiba Consumer Products, a new company operating through Toshiba U.K., which is a subsidiary of the Toshiba Corporation of Japan, takes over production following the closing on March 20 of Rank Toshiba, the former operators of the plant. Toshiba U.K. said the first year's production would be around 100,000 sets, with the majority destined for the British market.

title: 2D SHUTTLE WORKER DIES FROM ACCIDENT
description: A worker injured in the launchingpad accident at the Kennedy Space Center last month died late last night as preparations continued for the first orbital test mission of the space shuttle Columbia, scheduled to begin April 10.

title: Bauman Charges Are Dismissed
description: The Government has formally dropped charges against Robert E. Bauman, a former Republican Congressman from Maryland who was accused of soliciting sex from a 16-year-old boy. Justice Department officials said Mr. Bauman had avoided prosecution by agreeing to undergo six months of counseling and publicly stating that he was an alcoholic and had ''homosexual tendencies.''

title: PCB PATROL GUARDS HUDSON 14SUB FISH
description: ''They were right off here,'' said Steve Cook, a New York State conservation officer, jabbing a forefinger at X's and O's on a map of the Hudson River. But when he bounced his 14-foot aluminum motorboat over the waves to the spot on the map downriver from here, the fishing nets he was looking for were gone.

title: Company News; Textron Plans to Sell 2 Units With Losses
description: Textron Inc. said it had agreed in principle to sell two subsidiaries for about $66 million to Nucon Holding Inc., a recently formed private company.

title: TAPE SHOWS WILLIAMS VOWING TO GIVE 'SHEIK' AID WITH IMMIGRATION
description: A videotape played yesterday at the bribery trial of Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. of New Jersey shows him giving an F.B.I. agent posing as an Arab sheik assurances of help in seeking permanent residency in the United States.

title: LONG STRIKE PREDICTED
description: A United Mine Workers official, saying that union politics figured in the rejection Tuesday of a tentative settlement, yesterday predicted a long strike by 160,000 of the nation's soft-coal miners.

title: NURSING HOMES WARNED WALKOUT IS STILL POSSIBLE
description: The head of the union representing 12,000 workers at 81 metropolitan-area proprietary nursing homes said late yesterday that an agreement appeared close with one large group of homes but not with another, and that a strike was still possible at 6 A.M. tomorrow.

title: Unlikely Rookie Making Good
description: When Kevin Hickey learned that the White Sox equipment truck was leaving Chicago early for spring training camp, he quickly hitched a ride. Hickey, a 24-year-old rookie pitcher, arrived here Feb. 8, among the trunks of bats and balls, two weeks before camp officially opened.

title: Investment Up In Slurry Line
description: The five partners in the proposed 1,500-mile ETSI coal slurry pipeline said today that they had committed an additional $70 million to the project and planned to begin construction by early 1983. ETSI hopes to complete the line by 1985.

title: EXPLOSIVE BULLET STRUCK REAGAN, F.B.I. DISCOVERS
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has determined that special explosive bullets, called Devastators, were fired at President Reagan on Monday. Doctors who removed the bullet from the President's lung did not know at the time that it could explode at any second, officials said.

title: EX-ASTRONAUTS AS SALESMEN
description: The boyish grin of Charles Conrad Jr., the former astronaut, now adorns magazine advertisements for his company's jetliners. The intrepid gaze of Frank Borman, who circled the moon as commander of the Apollo 8 mission, looks out from television commercials plugging the airline he runs. The confident charm of Eugene A. Cernan, the 11th man on the moon, is used on foreign oilmen on behalf of his Houston petroleum company.

title: MISS HELLMAN, 'MASADA,' SEA FISHING AND 'UXB'
description: PRODUCED as a series of five half hours by the Dallas-Fort Worth station KERA-TV, ''Lillian Hellman: A Profile'' begins a weekly run tomorrow at 8:30 P.M. on WNYC-Channel 31. Miss Hellman is interviewed by Marilyn Berger, the television journalist. The conversations are supplemented with private photographs and glimpses of the writer's New York apartment.

title: Burger Won't Bar Removal Of 3 Bullets From a Suspect
description: Warren E. Burger, Chief Justice of the United States, refused today to block a court-ordered removal of three bullets from the body of a man wanted for murder. The bullets were allegedly fired in self-defense by the murder victim.

title: Market Place; Kind Words For Con Edison
description: IN April 1974, directors of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York made a decision that had a devastating impact on their company's stock and simultaneously sent shock waves rippling through shares of other electric utilities. For the first time since 1885, Consolidated Edison omitted its quarterly dividend.

title: SELF-INTEREST AND TAKEOVERS
description: A Federal judge recently blasted the St. Joe Minerals Corporation, accusing its management of following a ''scorched earth'' policy for vowing to liquidate before accepting a takeover bid from Joseph E. Seagram & Sons.

title: ART:OPENING OF THE WEST AS VIEWED BY THE PIONEERS
description: The Katonah Gallery at 28 Bedford Road in Katonah, N.Y., will surely not mind being described as an oddity. It is, after all, a ''museum without a collection'' that doubles as a gallery displaying local lesser-knowns as well as major reputations. A nonprofit organization with a standing army of guide-lecturers, the Katonah regularly serves Westchester with exhibitions of educational interest that, in the last year alone, have run the gamut from Islamic ornament to ''sound'' sculpture. The museum is assisted in this endeavor by county, state and, sometimes, Federal funds, not to mention the labors of its volunteers.

title: Business Digest; FRIDAY, APRIL 3, 1981; The Economy
description: The Republican-controlled Senate approved spending cuts of $36.9 billion, $2.8 billion more than recommended by the President. The cuts, passed by an 88-10 vote, would mean a major retrenchment in social welfare programs and a change in how the Government operates. The measure now goes to the Democratic-controlled House, whose leaders have predicted passage of 75 percent of the legislation sought by the President. (Page A1.)

title: The Budget Targets First of a series on key programs; that President Reagan wants to cut.
description: By proposing sharp slashes in Federal aid to education, President Reagan has run head on into the collective wrath of what former Representative Edith Green once called ''the educational-industrial complex.''

title: ISLAMIC GROUP PREPARES TO SEND MEDIATORS TO IRAQ AND IRAN AGAIN
description: An Islamic peace mission that visited Iran and Iraq this week announced plans today to send two of its members back to the two capitals within 48 hours to discuss a revised plan for settling the Iraqi-I@ranian war.

title: REYNOLDS BID SEEN FOR ROTHMANS
description: R.J. Reynolds Industries, the leading tobacco company in the United States and the third largest worldwide, indicated yesterday that it was discussing a possible acquisition of Rothmans International, a British company that is the fourth-largest cigarette manufacturer in the world.

title: ON HAZARDOUS WASTES
description: Hazardous chemical wastes pose major health and environmental threats across the country. To deal with some of the threats facing New York State, its Department of Environmental Conservation is urging that private industry establish a large, regional high-technology hazardous-waste-disposal facility on a parcel of state land.

title: JULIUS WILDSTEIN, 72, A CIVIL-RIGHTS LAWYER AND OFFICIAL IN JERSEY
description: Julius Wildstein, a civil-rights lawyer who broke new ground in antidiscrimination cases, died of a heart ailment Wednesday at his home in Brick Township, N.J. He was 72 years old.

title: Garner Undergoes Surgery
description: Phil Garner, the Pittsburgh Pirates' second baseman, will miss an estimated 30 games after undergoing surgery today on his injured shoulder. Garner, who had a shoulder injury that bothered him much of last year, was placed on the 21-day disabled list.

title: BENN STARTS NEW LABOR PARTY FIGHT WITH A CHALLENGE FOR THE NO. 2 POST
description: The Labor Party was struck by a new round of bitter internal wrangling today with the announcement that Tony Benn, the hero of its radical left, had decided to seek the party's deputy leadership.

title: Turkish Diplomat Is Wounded
description: Turkish diplomats said early today that one of their colleagues, whom they declined to identify, was shot and wounded last night at his home here by a group calling itself Justice for the Armenian People.

title: Soviet Rights Activist Gets A Five-Year Prison Term
description: Tatyana Osipova, a 32-year-old human rights activist, was convicted today of anti-Soviet agitation and sentenced to five years' imprisonment to be followed by five years of exile within the Soviet Union.

title: Miss Burnett Flooded With Requests to Share Award
description: Since being awarded a $1.6 million judgment against The National Enquirer last week, Carol Burnett has been ''inundated'' by requests from charities for some of the award, her spokesman said yesterday.

title: SERVING EL SALVADOR BY COLLECTIVE ACTION
description: To the Editor:

title: Olympic Airways' Credit
description: Olympic Airways, the Greek national airline, has signed a $140 million credit package, including a $112 million export credit, for three Airbus Industrie A300-b4 planes, the agent, Midland Bank International, said today. The credit is the third finance package from British, French and West German banks for Airbus purchases signed this week, Midland said.

title: G.M. RAISING PRICES AVERAGE OF 3.5%
description: The General Motors Corporation announced yesterday that it was increasing prices on its 1981 cars by an average of 3.5 percent, or $351, despite considerable weakness in the automobile market in the last 10 days of March.

title: REAGAN'S CONSUMER CHIEF NOTES POLICY SHIFT
description: A new emphasis on consumer education and information and a reduction in Federal activism appear to characterize the consumer policy evolving under President Reagan.

title: THE BENEFITS OF JOUSTING IN OUTER SPACE
description: To the Editor:

title: Knicks Beaten in Overtime; Bulls Sweep Series, 115-114
description: The Knicks' season ended in frustration tonight. The Chicago Bulls, with a second-half surge, forced an overtime and eliminated New York from the playoffs, 115-114, before a noisy crowd of 19,901 at Chicago Stadium.

title: Canada Ford Reopening
description: Ford of Canada Ltd. said today that its Windsor, Ontario, casting plant, temporarily closed last July as a result of unfavorable economic conditions, would reopen this month. The company said the move resulted from revised operating plans of the engine division of Ford's North American automotive operations and the casting division of its diversified products operations. The first 100 employees will be recalled this month and full production could be reached by December, it added.

title: Response to the Gunmen
description: A civilized society, says Senator Edward Kennedy in the wake of the attempt on the life of President Reagan, cannot avoid the issue of gun control. And soon, Mr. Kennedy will introduce a new proposal to stiffen the Federal handgun law. Even conservative Senator Strom Thurmond, Republican of South Carolina and chairman of the Judiciary Committee, appears willing to go along, at least partway. There are also signs that public support for handgun control is mounting. But given experience with the gun lobby, optimism had best be tempered nonetheless.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SONGS FROM THE UKRAINE

title: Pole Says Warsaw Drops 49 Big Investment Plans
description: Poland has scrapped 49 large-scale investment projects because of the ''considerable'' economic difficulties it has encountered, a Polish state planner said here today.

title: A BIRTHDAY BASH FOR CHARLOTTE FORD, TURNING 40The It's-Later-Than-You-Think Department
description: It seems only yesterday that Henry Ford 2d made international headlines by spending more than $250,000 on his older daughter Charlotte Ford's now-legendary debutante party at the Fords' Georgian mansion in a Detroit suburb.

title: Xerox Cuts Fees On Copier Rentals
description: The Xerox Corporation said it had reduced rental and lease prices for major users of six of its lower-priced copiers that compete directly with Japanese machines.

title: Blazers 124, Kings 119
description: Calvin Natt and Kelvin Ransey combined for 9 points in overtime and Mychal Thompson scored a careerhigh 40 points tonight to give the Portland Trail Blazers a 124-119 victory over the Kansas City Kings. The Blazers' victory evened their playoff series at one victory each.

title: HERMAN YABLOKOFF, YIDDISH ACTOR
description: Herman Yablokoff, an actor, composer, playwright, director and producer in the American Yiddish theater for more than 55 years, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived in the Coney Island area of Brooklyn.

title: CABARET: 'TROOPERS,' A REVUE
description: The three young singing musicians who, as the Manhattan Rhythm Kings, have built a repertory around the styles of the Boswell Sisters, the Rhythm Boys and other singing groups and songs of the 1920's and 30's, have put together a miniature musical revue called ''Troopers,'' which is being booked around town separately from their appearances as the Manhattan Rhythm Kings.

title: BIRTH DEFECTS TENTATIVELY LINKED TO SPERMICIDE USE
description: The use of spermicides for contraception may increase the risk of birth defects or spontaneous abortion, according to a study published today in The Journal of the American Medical Association.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I'm feeling fine.'' - James S. Brady, President Reagan's press secretary. (8:5.)

title: 22 on Coast-to-Coast Plane Are Hurt in Rough Weather
description: A woman suffered a broken hip and at least 21 other people were injured today when a United Airlines jetliner hit a severe downdraft in clear weather and dropped 2,000 feet, airline officials said.

title: FOTOMAT CUTS DEFICIT
description: The Fotomat Corporation cut its loss for its final quarter ended Jan. 31 to $1.79 million from $4.68 million in the comparable period of the previous year as sales rose 6.4 percent, to $58.2 million, from $54.7 million. For the year, Fotomat earned $734,000, or 8 cents a share, in contrast to a loss of $4.69 million the previous year.

title: Chrysler Sees No Motor Fault
description: A spokesman for the Chrysler Corporation said today that ''there is nothing to indicate we have a problem'' with excessive oil consumption in the engines of its Plymouth Omni and Dodge Horizon cars, despite their similarity to the water-cooled Volkswagen engines cited yesterday by the Federal Trade Commission.

title: VANDERBILT RECOVERS FROM SHOCK OF LINK TO REGAN SHOOTING
description: A small, successful oil and gas exploration company, coincidentally thrust into the limelight because of the assassination attempt on President Reagan on Monday, says now that it has returned to ''business as usual,'' despite the temporary departure of its founder and leader.

title: Securities Groups Gets Hanseatic
description: The Securities Groups, a newcomer among firms trading money market instruments and Government securities, joined the elite club of primary Government securities dealers this week when it acquired New York Hanseatic, founded more than 40 years ago.

title: THE BOWERY SCENE
description: 1. Recently, a cousin of mine stopped over on his way from Beirut, a city which now has most of its politics in the street, but almost no sanitation services. Standing outside my door, he looked up and down the Bowery and marveled, ''They keep it so clean!''

title: DISABLING OF REAGAN PROVOKES A DEBATE OVER NUCLEAR AUTHORITY IN SUCH CASES
description: The shooting of President Reagan has prompted renewed discussions within the Government over who should have authority to order the use of nuclear weapons or direct other military action if a crisis arises while the President is disabled or cut off from defense communications.

title: Four Fire Departments But None to Fight Fire
description: Four departments argued over jurisdiction while a junkyard fire in ''a no-man's land'' burned out of control for three hours. A judge finally ordered one of the departments to respond.

title: CITY FAILING TO DRAW PUPILS TO SCHOOL MEAL PROGRAM
description: Schools throughout New York City are failing - and in some cases refusing - to carry out Federal and state programs to provide students with free or low-cost breakfasts and lunches, even though the city could reduce its share of the cost of such programs if more meals were served.

title: BONN SEEKS SAUDI LOAN
description: West Germany and France are negotiating a major sale of securities to member governments of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to finance measures to cut energy use and spur their economies, a Bonn Government spokesman said today.

title: Turk in Critical Condition After Attack in Copenhagen
description: A Turkish diplomat shot by Armenian terrorists was said to be in critical condition today after eight hours of surgery.

title: CRITIC OF FILMS WHO WROTE FOR VARIETY AND PM
description: Cecelia Ager, a film critic and commentator on the foibles and personalities of the entertainment business, died yesterday after suffering a stroke in Los Angeles. In a career that spanned the golden age of the movie industry, she wrote for Variety, PM, Harper's Bazaar, Vogue and The New York Times Magazine and Arts and Leisure Section. She was 79 years old.

title: A SUBWAY REVIVAL MUST INCLUDE SAFETY
description: To the Editor:

title: ERODING IMMIGRATION POLICY
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Candy Man' Went Thataway
description: Grumpily but wisely, the prosecutor for Cumberland County in South Jersey has abandoned his pursuit of a high school teacher who persists in honoring a pledge of confidentiality to a student journalist. Prosecutor Kenneth Pagliughi had threatened to jail Richard Lee, the faculty adviser to The Tattler, a student newspaper, for refusing to identify the reporter whose interview with a pusher named ''Candy Man'' blew the whistle on drug traffic at Millville High School.

title: MORE HELP WANTED
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. AVIATION PIONEER
description: Juan Trippe, a pioneer in international aviation and jet passenger travel for American airlines, died yesterday in his apartment on Fifth Avenue. He was 81 years old.

title: Lon Nol's Wife and Son Fined in Child-Abuse Case
description: The wife of Lon Nol, the former Cambodian Prime Minister, and their teen-age son have been been fined and placed on probation after pleading guilty to child endangering, and two of the four children involved have been returned to their home.

title: JOHN A. LUNN
description: John A. Lunn, a manufacturing executive, died Monday at his home in Cambridge, Mass.

title: Prediction of Shooting Disputed by TV Aides
description: Tamara Rand's prediction of an attempt on President Reagan's life was recorded the day after Mr. Reagan was shot, and she was not in the studio on the day in January when she contends the show was taped, television crew members said today.

title: Saudi Seeks to Buy Out Hyatt International
description: Ghaith R. Pharaon, a Saudi Arabian entrepreneur, announced yesterday that he had made an offer to acquire all the outstanding common stock of Hyatt International, challenging a bid by the Pritzker family to make the Chicago-based hotel chain private.

title: WORKERS CRITICIZE POLISH PARTY CHIEF
description: Polish workers sharply criticized the Communist Party leader and other officials today for a lack of leadership, information and food during a round of face-to-face factory meetings, the Polish press reported.

title: ISRAEL ASKS U.S. FOR GIFT OF JETS, CITING SAUDI SALE
description: Israel has asked the United States for an outright gift of an additional 15 F-15 fighters as well as access to an American spy satellite to compensate for the Reagan Administration's planned sale of advanced military equipment to Saudi Arabia, Administration and Israeli sources said today.

title: Slip of 1.90 Trims Dow To 1,007.11; Polish Situation Worries Traders
description: The stock market showed little vitality yesterday as traders remained apprehensive over the course of political events in Eastern Europe.

title: Some Flxible Buses May Roll by April 30
description: The Grumman Corporation said it hoped to have the first small group of New York City's fleet of 637 Flxible buses repaired and ready for service by the end of April, about two weeks later than the time initially targeted for their return.

title: Says a Photo Of U.S. Nazi Was Not Hinckley
description: A man in a Nazi uniform appearing in a photograph that was distributed this week was incorrectly identified as John W. Hinckley Jr., the man accused of shooting President Reagan, The Associated Press said yesterday.

title: SCHOMBURG BLACK CULTURE CENTER NAMES WENDELL WRAY AS CHIEF
description: Wendell L. Wray, professor of library science at the University of Pittsburgh, has been named chief of the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture. He has worked for 14 years with the New York Public Library's branch libraries.

title: U.S. Teen-Ager Sentenced For Bomb Hoax on Airliner
description: A 17-year-old American returning from a tour of Middle East religious sites was sentenced to three months in jail today for a bomb hoax on a New York-bound jet with 382 people aboard.

title: CHICAGO ANNOUNCES PLANS TO DESEGREGATE SCHOOLS
description: The Chicago Board of Education today announced a preliminary plan for desegregating the city's public schools that calls for the transfer of 41,706 of the system's 463,278 pupils in the next school year.

title: Jersey Utility Asks 8% Electric Rate Rise
description: NEWARK (AP) - The Public Service Electric and Gas Company asked the New Jersey Board of Public Utilities to increase its customers' electric bills by 8 percent to pay for what it says are rising energy costs.

title: PARENTS OF SUSPECT VISIT HIM AT PRISON
description: Chauffeured by plainclothes agents in speeding cars, Joann and J.W. Hinckley Sr. spent three hours today at the Federal Correctional Institution at Butner, where their son, John W. Hinckley Jr., the accused assailant of President Reagan, has been held since yesterday.

title: Citibank Lifts Broker Rate
description: Citibank raised its broker loan rate to 16 percent from 15 1/2 percent, effective immediately, a spokesman said yesterday.

title: KOCH NOW ASSAILS 2D JUDGE FOR WEEKEND JAIL SENTENCE
description: Mayor Koch criticized another judge yesterday for what he considered lenient sentencing. His target this time was Acting Justice Irving Lang of State Supreme Court, whom he had appointed and once warmly praised.

title: PLAYBOY CASINO GRANTED PERMIT BY JERSEY PANEL
description: The Casino Control Commission gave the Playboy Hotel and Casino a temporary permit today after four Playboy executives agreed to resign pending investigation of two Playboy casinos in London.

title: U.S. SECURITY ADVISER IS ASSAILED FOR REMARK ON RAIDS ON LEBANON
description: Arab-Americans yesterday denounced Richard V. Allen, President Reagan's national security adviser, for saying that Israeli raids into southern Lebanon could be ''justified'' as ''hot pursuit.'' They called for his resignation and for a repudiation of his statement.

title: COURT HEARS TAPES ON LETTER FAKED TO IMPLICATE WILLIAMS
description: Attorneys for Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. of New Jersey played tape recordings at his trial for bribery and conspiracy yesterday in which an alleged co-conspirator is asked to produce a letter from the Senator that would have him promising continued involvement in a mining venture.

title: TRUCE IS REPORTED IN LEBANESE TOWN
description: A cease-fire was reported tonight in the eastern Lebanese Christian town of Zahle after two days of artillery duels between Syrian troops and Christian militiamen.

title: No Headline
description: A Company News item in Business Day on Thursday incorrectly reported the date by which Southeastern Public Service Company of Miami plans to expand its stake in the Simplicity Pattern Company to 25 percent. It is May 2, 1982.

title: RANGERS DEFEAT CHICAGO, 3-1, AND GAIN PLAYOFF BERTH
description: The New York Rangers qualified for the Stanley Cup playoffs last night, coming from behind with three third-period goals to defeat the Chicago Black Hawks, 3-1, in their final regular-season game at Madison Square Garden.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 15. 1. Rocky's Pawn Shop in Dallas is where the gun used in the attack on the President was bought last October. 2. The study showed that in every state the disposable income of workers who also get welfare would be reduced so much by the budget cuts that the workers' families would hardly be better off than those who relied entirely on public assistance.

title: PANORAMA WILL HALT PUBLICATION
description: Panorama, a monthly magazine about television aimed at the affluent reader concerned with the quality and impact of the medium, will cease publication with its June issue, it was announced yesterday by Triangle Publications, its parent and publisher of TV Guide.

title: TRIDENT WOES PUT MILITARY-INDUSTRIAL SYSTEM IN DOUBT
description: Five years ago, when construction of the Ohio, the first of the Navy's planned fleet of Trident ballistic missile submarines, began here at the Electric Boat Division of the General Dynamics Corporation, the new vessel was the pride of the Navy's future.

title: TAKING THE OBFUSCATION OUT OF RESTAURANT MENUS
description: Although responsible restaurateurs are well aware of the need for what has become known as truth-in-menus, all too few are equally concerned with clarity. A menu is an advertisement and as such is an offer to sell. It would seem to be in the owner's best interests, therefore, to make that offer as clear as possible, so that prospective buyers will know exactly what to expect, thereby avoiding disappointment and dissatisfaction.

title: Flexi-Van Takeover
description: The Flexi-Van Corporation, a New York-based transportation-leasing concern, said its directors had approved an offer made last week by a group of British institutional investors to acquire Flexi-Van for $35 cash per share, or about $300 million.

title: SPACE SHUTTLE PROBLEM OVERCOME
description: Preflight preparations of the space shuttle Columbia ran four hours behind schedule today, but officials of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said that the countdown should still begin Sunday night, aiming toward a launching next Friday.

title: CAREY AGAIN VETOES A BILL TO RESTORE DEATH PENALTY
description: Governor Carey, as he promised he would, today vetoed legislation that would reinstate the death penalty for some cases of murder. He insisted that the state could protect its citizens from the fear and the act of crime without resorting to ''the ultimate act of violence.''

title: Alcoa Brazil Grows
description: Alcoa Aluminio S.A., the Brazilian unit of the Aluminum Company of America, has announced the acquisition of an aluminum fabricating plant on Brazil's coast.

title: CHAMBER: PARNASSUS' 'HA-SHIRIM'
description: The slow-breathing images of the biblical ''Song of Songs'' create their own erotic world, abundant with fragrance and pulsing life. It is a world rich in allegory, resonating with surrounding texts, telling of dramatic yearnings of a religious culture.

title: Heavy Rains Flood Uzbekistan
description: The Republic of Uzbekistan has had as much rain in two days as sometimes falls in a whole year and floods have killed three people, the newspaper Izvestia said today.

title: Islamic Group in Teheran For More Cease-Fire Talks
description: Habib Chatti, Secretary General of the Islamic Conference Organization, arrived here today for further talks on ending the war between Iran and Iraq, the Iranian state radio reported.

title: Fed Decisions On M-1B's Rise
description: Monetary policy makers at the Federal Reserve decided in late February to accept a slower money supply growth than they had wanted for the first quarter.

title: A 'MUDDY TRACK' IN HEALTH ADMINISTRATION
description: To the Editor:

title: THAI PREMIER PROMISES LENIENCY FOR REBELS
description: With a two-day coup attempt crushed, Prime Minister Prem Tinsulanonda pledged today to give ''a fair judgment'' to the rebels. He called on them and all the Thai people to ''forget what happened'' and to get on with serving the nation.

title: News Summary; SATURDAY, APRIL 4, 1981
description: International Moscow is poised for intervention in Poland, according to the United States, which issued another warning against such ''unjustified action.'' Informed sources said that the Soviet Union had begun airlifting helicopters into the Soviet military district in southwest Poland, in a move that appeared to be on a small scale to avoid attracting attention and generating alarm among the Poles. (Page 1, Column 6.) Moscow urged Polish Communists to be vigilant. For the second consecutive day, the Soviet Communist Party newspaper Pravda implied strong Kremlin disapproval of the willingness of the Polish leadership to make concessions to the independent union. (5:1-3.)

title: Computer Loan Pact
description: Computer Communications Inc. said that an $18 million financing package, announced on Thursday, would provide $10 million for the company's lease financing subsidiary, C.C. Systems Inc. In addition, the West Coast producer of computers said it would replace the Wells Fargo Bank as its major lender with a new loan agreement that would provide more than $5 million minimum credit. As a result of the financing agreement, the company said, a number of new contracts have been signed. The financing will enable Computer Communications, which has been operating under Chapter 11 protection of the Federal bankruptcy laws, to discharge creditor debt and provide operating capital, it said. PU COMPNEWS FOLOS

title: BELIZE IS QUIET AFTER RIOTING OVER INDEPENDENCE PACT
description: With a state of emergency and a dusk-to-dawn curfew in force, police and army patrols restored order in the tiny Central American colony of Belize today after several days of violent protests against Britain's plan to grant it independence later this year.

title: HOW BANKERS VIEW WORLD CAPITAL MARKETS
description: To the Editor:

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 25.

title: G.M. Heir Joins the Battle Against G.M. Plant
description: Inasmuch as he is a multimillionaire heir to a General Motors-based fortune, when Stewart R. Mott gives money to an organization fighting General Motors, people can be expected to sit up and take notice.

title: BELGRADE SENDS TANKS TO REBELLIOUS REGION
description: Yugoslav tanks and troops took up positions today in a province in the south to put down anti-Government riots by Albanian separatists.

title: Another Derby for Luro at 80
description: The horse came galloping toward the barn, slowing only a bit. His rider threw a leg over the top, rode sidesaddle for a few jumps, then hopped off, grabbing the reins and stopping the animal in a single fluid motion.

title: COACH BILL GLEASON AND HIS LAWYERS
description: BILL GLEASON knew what he was doing when he raised three of his daughters to be lawyers. When the Chicago Hustle of the Women's Pro Basketball League tried to dismiss Gleason as coach last weekend, he had a phalanx of legal help that was as incensed as he was.

title: The Budget Targets
description: The food stamp program is one of the largest and is probably the most visible of all Government support programs. It is also one of the most popular targets of troubled taxpayers and politicians aiming to reduce the size of Government.

title: Cigarette Blamed in Hotel Fire
description: A smoldering cigarette in a bed caused the fire at Caesars Palace hotel Wednesday that injured 16 persons and forced evacuation of part of the hotel, fire officials said today.

title: U.S. TALKS TOO MUCH ABOUT POLAND, RUSSIAN INSISTS
description: American officials talk too much about Poland, according to Oleg A. Troyanovsky, the chief Soviet delegate to the United Nations, who returned to New York recently after extensive consultations in Moscow.

title: U.S. ASSERTS SOVIET STEPS UP READINESS TO MOVE ON POLAND
description: The United States said today that Soviet forces around Poland had made new preparations that would enable them to go into action at a moment's notice and again warned Moscow that such ''unjustified action would have the gravest consequences for East-West relations.''

title: A Honeymoon Tip
description: One of the first metropolitan-areapolitical figures to congratulate Governor Carey of New York on his impending marriage was Governor Byrne of New Jersey, and he couldn't resist putting in a plug for his state.

title: MENTAL TESTS ON HINCKLEY MAY TAKE UP TO 3 MONTHS
description: Psychiatrists examining John W. Hinckley Jr. at a Federal prison in North Carolina will probably try to discover every possible detail about his personal, social, criminal and psychiatric history, from the moment he was born to the present.

title: West Germans Arrest Squatters
description: The police arrested 200 squatters today who refused to leave a vacant building they occupied yesterday. The squatters put up passive resistance and the police carried them out of the building, a police spokesman said.

title: RECITAL: BESS WELSH, FLUTIST
description: Besse Welsh, the flutist, brought some new music to play Tuesday evening at Carnegie Recital Hall. Donald Martino's ''Quodlibets II'' had its first performance anywhere; new to New York was Klaus Huber's ''Ein Hauch von Unzeit.''

title: THEATER WING WILL PRESENT SEMINAR SERIES
description: Performers, playwrights, directors, producers and press agents - the whole panoply of a Broadway production - will participate in the American Theater Wing's 12th series of seminars, ''Working in the Theater.''

title: Carmen Mastren, Jazz Guitarist With the Dorsey and Miller Bands
description: Carmen Mastren, a jazz guitarist who played with Tommy Dorsey and Glenn Miller, died of a heart attack Tuesday at his home in Valley Stream, L.I. He was 68 years old.

title: A NEW AIR OF CONFIDENCE PERVADES HARPER & ROWE
description: For almost two centuries Harper & Row has been an American publishing tradition, but these last several years must have seemed like the longest in that company's lengthy history.

title: BRADY TELLS PHYSICIAN HE FEELS FINE
description: James S. Brady, the White House press secretary, today told his doctor ''I'm feeling fine,'' according to a White House announcement.

title: COURT UPHOLDS SUSPENSION OF DELANEY IN WESTCHESTER
description: The authority of the Westchester County Executive, Alfred B. DelBello, to suspend the county's Commissioner/ Sheriff was upheld yesterday by the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court.

title: 2 MISSING IN TANKER FIRE IN RIO
description: A 13,000-ton oil tanker, the Jari, exploded and caught fire while at anchor in Rio's Guanabara Bay last night, severely burning one man on a nearby barge, authorities said. Two deckhands from the barge were reported missing today. The cause of the fire was under investigation.

title: JOBLESS RATE 10.5% FOR NEW YORK CITY
description: New York City's unemployment rate reached double digits last month for the first time since late 1978, except for summer months, Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, Regional Commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, reported yesterday.

title: AUTO SALES DOWN 16.4% AT BIG THREE
description: New car sales by the Big Three domestic producers fell 16.4 percent in the March 21-31 reporting period from a year earlier, as customer cash rebates were scaled down throughout the period.

title: ST. JOE OFFICERS BACK MERGER WITH FLUOR
description: Directors of the St. Joe Minerals Corporation, one of the nation's leading producers of lead and zinc, yesterday approved a $2.6 billion cash-and-stock merger agreement with the Fluor Corporation. Meanwhile, directors of Fluor, a California-based construction and engineering concern, scheduled a meeting for today to consider the merger agreement.

title: Priests to Decide Status Of Governor's Wedding
description: Governor Carey's wedding to Evangeline Gouletas at the Holy Trinity Greek Archdiocesan Cathedral in Manhattan next Saturday will not be recognized by the Roman Catholic Church until a panel of priests can rule on Miss Gouletas's two previous marriages, New York State's eight Catholic Bishops said in a statement yesterday.

title: COMMERCE DEPT. OFFICIAL FORECASTS ECONOMIC LAG
description: William A. Cox, acting chief economist for the Commerce Department, told Congress today that, after the first quarter's rise, the American economy would slow down significantly for the rest of the year.

title: F.B.I. CONFIRMS MALFUNCTIONING OF EXPLOSIVE BULLET THAT STRUCK REAGAN
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation confirmed today that the special explosive bullets that struck President Reagan, a Secret Service agent and a District of Columbia police officer malfunctioned and did not detonate on impact.

title: WELFARE CUTS AIMED AT PREGNANT WOMEN
description: The Reagan Administration's budget includes welfare cuts for pregnant women and those who get aid under the program for the aged, the blind and the disabled, Government officials said today.

title: CHROME SLUMP HITS SOUTH AFRICA
description: Rand Mines Ltd, the mining subsidiary of Barlow Rand Ltd, is well poised for any upturn in the chrome market, but at present it is containing expansion plans because of the depressed state of the world market, senior company executives said in an interview today.

title: 8 CANADA PREMIERS PLANNING A PARLEY
description: Eight of Canada's 10 provincial premiers will meet in Ottawa April 16 in their strongest bid yet to defeat Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau's constitutional proposals, but Mr. Trudeau, speaking yesterday in New York, said he was ''not impressed.''

title: UNMASKING DEATH; Books Of The Times
description: By Anatole Broyard LIVING WITH DEATH AND DYING. By Elisabeth Kubler-Ross. Illustrated. 181 pages. Macmillan. $10.95.

title: A Cook, 27, Is Held In West Side Rapes
description: A short-order cook was arrested early yesterday and charged with the rape of three women near Central Park on Manhattan's West Side, the police said.

title: S.& P. Reduces Kraft Bond Rating
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation, the financial services publisher and debt-rating agency, said it had reduced the bond ratings of Kraft Inc., a major dairy products and food processor, to Double-A from Triple-A.

title: VIDEOTAPES OF BEATINGS FIGURE IN FEDERAL INQUIRY OF POLICE FORCE IN
description: TEXAS

title: U.S. Will Withdraw Case In World Court Against Iran
description: The United States has authorized the withdrawal of its claim in the International Court of Justice for damages from Iran for its 444-day holding of the American hostages, sources close to the case said today.

title: HEALTHY U.S. PROGRAMS
description: Overlooked in most discussions of foreign affairs these days - discussions that tend to center on economic concerns and defense priorities - are the quiet, effective programs of the Office of International Health in the Public Health Service. The programs cost little to operate but pay substantial dividends in our relationships with other countries and our commitment to improve health and health care around the globe. The relationships are genuinely reciprocal: While helping others, we reap benefits that would not, otherwise, be ours.

title: SECRETARY OF AGRICULTURE IS 'FURIOUS' AT HAIG ABOUT WHEAT SALES ISSUE
description: Agriculture Secretary John R. Block said he was ''furious'' with Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. over a discussion Mr. Haig had with the French Ambassador about a possible wheat sale to the Soviet Union.

title: UNIVERSAL MILITARY MOTION
description: The idea behind the MX system is sound enough: Stack a supply of Hbombs on railroad trains and keep them moving constantly so enemy targeters will not know where to aim. To confuse things further, run decoy trains so the enemy cannot distinguish between false bomb carriers and the real thing.

title: ADMINISTRATION PLANS TO END VISTA
description: The Reagan Administration has decided to eliminate the Vista program by the end of the 1983 fiscal year, sources said today.

title: Miss Nilsson Returns To Sing Strauss at the Met
description: Birgit Nilsson will return to the Metropolitan Opera during the 1981-82 season to sing the Dyer's Wife in a revival of Richard Strauss's ''Die Frau ohne Schatten,'' Anthony A. Bliss, the Metropolitan's general manager, announced yesterday.

title: UNION AND NURSING HOME SETTLE, AVERTING WALKOUT SET FOR TODAY
description: A strike this morning against a majority of nursing homes in the New York metropolitan area was averted last night when employees ratified a new contract. Meanwhile, union talks with a second group of homes continued.

title: PRESIDENT PICKS ACTOR FOR MEXICO POST
description: President Reagan has selected the actor John Gavin to be Ambassador to Mexico, the White House announced today.

title: No Headline
description: Dan Graham and John Lowenstein hit run-scoring, pinch-hit singles with two out in the last of the ninth inning tonight to give the Baltimore Orioles a 4-3 victory over the Yankees.

title: SOVIET WARNS WARSAW AGAIN ABOUT UNREST
description: Amid signs that Moscow is losing confidence in the ability of the Government in Warsaw to contain the labor crisis, the Soviet Communist Party newspaper Pravda called today on Polish Communists for vigilance.

title: Leasco to Buy Reliance Stock
description: The Leasco Corporation, a computer leasing concern, said it will exercise an option agreement next Monday with Warner Communications Inc., a diversified entertainment company, to purchase for $76.50 a share 270,500 common shares of the Reliance Group Inc., an insurance, property and liability holding company.

title: Your Money; Late Payments On Income Tax
description: ''A TAXPAYER should file a return on time, and there's no excuse for not filing,'' says Wilson Fadely, a spokesman for the Internal Revenue Service. With April 15 less than two weeks away, Mr. Fadely's advice is probably not very comforting for many taxpayers who, because of personal troubles or poor financial planning, either will fail to file on time or will be unable to pay what they owe.

title: OBOTE, LIKE AMIN, SAID TO RULE BY FEAR
description: The three-month-old Government of President Milton Obote is apparently responding to insurrection within the country with summary executions and repressive tactics in the style of Idi Amin, who was overthrown two years ago this month.

title: Bridge: Knockout Stage Scheduled In Grand National Contest
description: The knockout stage of the Grand National Team Championship begins today at the Vanderbilt Club, Manhasset, L.I., with 16 expert teams from New York City and 16 from Long Island to be reduced to a total of eight at the end of the day, after two 32-deal matches. In the quarterfinals tomorrow, the field will be cut to four after 64-deal matches.

title: DANCE: LAR LUBOVITCH
description: There seemed more reason than usual for the audience to yelp out the now-traditional curtain cry of ''Whooo!'' as it did Thursday at the City Center-55th Street Theater, where the Lar Lubovitch Dance Company is performing through tomorrow afternoon. Witty, inventive, and performed by a group of strikingly gifted and attractive dancers, Mr. Lubovitch's dance is an exhilarating trip for the senses. And ''Marimba,'' which surfaced in this second program of the Lubovitch engagement, is almost a signature piece.

title: ON THE POLICE BEAT, A GOLD CHAIN WARNING, A BUTCHER OFFERS BULLETPROOF
description: VESTS... By BARBARA BASLER

title: Restaurant Worker, 16, Slain in Bronx Robbery
description: A teen-age employee of a fast-food restaurant in the Bronx was killed and another was seriously wounded early this morning during a robbery, the police said.

title: Insanity Verdict In Slaying of Parents
description: A 21-year-old woman accused of killing her parents was declared not guilty by reason of insanity and committed to a state psychiatric hospital.

title: Philadelphia Transit Service Resumes With Fewer Riders
description: Philadelphia commuters were offered the first normal service in 19 days today as striking transit workers returned to their jobs, but officials said that the number of riders on some lines was only about half the normal total.

title: THRIVING ON DO-IT YOURSELFERS
description: When Neil Bradley, a retired Government worker from suburban Virginia, needed to make some repairs on his model HO train set, he knew of only one tool delicate enough to work with the miniature track and only one place where he could find it.

title: TROUBLE FROM WIND RIVER: INDIANS, OIL LEASES AND THE U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY
description: Since 1943 oil has been flowing regularly on the Wind River Indian Reservation, providing a steady income for the Shoshone and Arapahoe tribes, who lease part of their land to about 30 oil companies. Most Indians have been happy with the arrangement and some have even prospered.

title: HOUSE DEMOCRATS ARE SEEKING TO RESTORE SOME FUNDS CUT BY SENATE
description: Democrats on the House Budget Committee tentatively agreed at a caucus today to seek to restore funds for social welfare and environmental programs that were among the cuts in the $36.9 billion package of budget reductions approved yesterday by the Senate.

title: No Headline
description: The nation's unemployment rate remained unchanged last month as new workers continued to enter the labor force at the same pace that the economy produced new jobs.

title: KEEPING JEANS HONEST
description: It might be called the Counterfeit Spy Caper: On March 23 United States marshals raided a factory in Los Angeles to confiscate what were described as counterfeit Jordache jeans and discovered that the factory owner was Avri El-Ad, an Israeli agent in the 1950's.

title: Some Jerseyans to Face Loss of Jobless Benefits
description: Governor Byrne has signed a bill prohibiting people from refusing ''suitable work'' if they have exhausted regular state unemployment benefits and are in the 13-week extended-benefits period.

title: Yankees and Pirates Call Off Trade Effort
description: After more than 20 hours of telephone conversations, the New York Yankees and the Pittsburgh Pirates failed today to work out a restructured trade satisfactory to the teams and to Bowie Kuhn, the commissioner. As a result, Jim Spencer will remain a Yankee, and Jason Thompson becomes a Pirate.

title: METS RAP SEAVER FOR 9 HITS AND WIN 5TH STRAIGHT, 6-5
description: The New York Mets defeated the Cincinnati Reds again today, 6-5, for their fifth straight victory and they even prevailed over Tom Seaver. In his final tuneup for opening day next Wednesday, Seaver pitched seven innings against his former team.

title: Article 069929 -- No Title
description: The Banca Commerciale Italiana, a major Government-owned Italian bank, has offered $93 million to purchase the Litco Bancorporation of New York, the largest domestically owned bank on Long Island, it was announced yesterday.

title: New Head of Picker Dismisses 8 Aides
description: Eight of the top twelve executives of the Picker Corporation, a leading maker of medical equipment, were discharged Thursday, a day after the parent concern, the RCA Corporation, sold Picker to the General Electric Company of Britain for more than 150 million in cash.

title: Connally Nominee For Ford Board
description: John B. Connally, a former United States Secretary of the Treasury, has been nominated for a seat on the Ford Motor Company's board of directors, Ford officials announced yesterday.

title: MONEY SUPPLY IS UP SLIGHTLY
description: Short-term interest rates rose more than half a percentage point, and the yield on 30-year Treasury bonds climbed to nearly 13 percent yesterday as higher-than-expected overnight interest rates in the Federal funds market caused traders to cut prices and offer higher yields to attract buyers.

title: FUNDS BEING RAISED TO RESTORE 2 BUILDINGS LINKED TO STUYVESANT
description: Historians seem agreed that Peter Stuyvesant was harsh and intolerant in governing the Dutch colony of Nieuw Amsterdam more than 300 years ago.

title: DIVORCE LAW AND WOMEN
description: ''U NDER New York's new divorce law, marriage is viewed as an economic partnership and, when it is dissolved, the assets of the marriage are equitably distributed. But equitable does not mean equal: ''You get out what you put in,'' Margaret Tyre, a matrimonial lawyer, told 25 women at a seminar on the economic implications of New York's 10-month-old divorce law.

title: HIS CONDITION TERMED SATISFACTORY
description: President Reagan had a fever of 102 degrees this morning, but by afternoon it had dropped to near the normal 98.6 degrees in what his doctors called ''a bit of a setback'' in an otherwise uneventful, rather ''remarkable'' recovery from a bullet wound in his left lung.

title: Indian Point 3 Plant Resumes Operation
description: The New York State Power Authority's Indian Point 3 nuclear power plant resumed operation after being shut down since Jan. 31 because of a damaged turbine blade.

title: LEGISLATURE CALLED FOR SPECIAL SESSION TO WORK ON BUDGET
description: Under pressure from Assembly Speaker Stanley Fink, Governor Carey today called a special session of the State Legislature for noon tomorrow to attempt to pass a budget for the fiscal year that began Wednesday.

title: SATURDAY, APRIL 4, 1981; The Economy
description: The Producer Price Index jumped 1.3 percent in March, a 16.8 percent annual rate, largely because of soaring oil prices, the Bureau of Labor Statistics said. The first rise in food prices since November contributed to the increase. (Page 1.)

title: U.S. Urges That U.N. Labor Body Ask the South Africans to Rejoin
description: The United States has suggested that the International Labor Organization invite South Africa to rejoin the organization after a 17-year boycott by South Africa over criticism of its racial segregation policies.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of incorrect information from a company spokesman, the ad- vertising agency for Killian's Irish Red ale was incorrectly identified in Busi- ness Day on Wednesday. The agency is Foote, Cone & Belding, Chicago.

title: Myra Van Hoose Leads Golf by Shot
description: Myra Van Hoose shot a scrambling one-over-par 73 today to keep her lead in the $250,000 Colgate-Dinah Shore tournament, but Carolyn Hill moved within a stroke with her second consecutive 70.

title: Jersey Water Rate Rise Averaging 57% Sought
description: New Jersey's largest water company filed today for a rate increase that would raise the average customer's bill 57 percent above what it is now.

title: MARCH PRODUCER PRICES UP 1.3%, WITH OIL COST RISES A KEY FACTOR
description: Large increases in the prices of oil products were the key factors in pushing up the Producer Price Index last month by 1.3 percent, to an annual rate of 16.8 percent, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

title: JOHN W. SIMMONS
description: John W. Simmons, chairman emeritus of Morton-Norwich Products Inc., the Chicago-based manufacturer of salt, specialty chemical, pharmaceutical and household products, died Wednesday of cancer at his home in Chicago.

title: Slicing Through 'Soft' Science
description: Pity the social and behavioral sciences. They are scorned by natural scientists as ''soft'' and full of hot air. They are lampooned by yahoos in Congress. And they are tempting targets of candidates for high office. Candidate Reagan, for instance, once criticized a Government-supported social science textbook for being ''morally neutral'' about some Eskimo customs he thought repugnant.

title: OFFICER 1325, WHERE IS YOUR HAT?
description: One day in June 1979, Fred Catalano, a police officer for Nassau County on Long Island, left his hat on top of his car while he made a telephone call, then forgot about it and drove away.

title: THE CONQUEST OF DISEASE
description: Richard S. Schweiker, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, and Senator Harrison H. Schmitt, Republican of New Mexico and Chairman of the Appropriations Subcommittee on Labor, Health and Human Services, and Education, recently stated publicly that Federal funds should be channeled into research on prevention of disease. Their views raise the question, How does a nation go about preventing disease?

title: I.R.A. Kills Ulster Constable, 23; First Full-Time Officer Slain in '81
description: A car bomb planted by the Irish Republican Army killed a 23-year-old Northern Ireland policeman last night.

title: Harvester Creditor Demands Payment
description: The International Harvester Company said one of its more than 200 creditor banks, the First National Bank of Commerce of New Orleans, had demanded payment of its $3.5 million loan and has filed suit in Federal court in New Orleans to recover the amount.

title: AWARD RECALLS A BITTER MEMORY FOR BUSH
description: It was with poignant memories yesterday that Vice President Bush presented Karen Anderson of Lutherville, Md., with the 1981 American Cancer Society Courage Award.

title: HOBART TAYLOR JR., 60, PAST TRADE BANK HEAD AND LAW FIRM PARTNER
description: Hobart Taylor Jr., director of the Export-Import Bank under President Johnson and a director on the boards of several corporations, died yesterday in the Bahamas. He was 60 years old.

title: EXCERPTS FROM TRUDEAU'S TALK ON REAGAN AND WORLD PROBLEMS
description: Following are excerpts from remarks by Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau of Canada at a meeting yesterday with editors and reporters at The New York Times:

title: EBERSOL CONSULTS THE OLD GANG AT SATURDAY NIGHT
description: The latest scenario to save NBC-TV's beleaguered ''Saturday Night Live'' is to consult with the old gang, bring back some of the original writers and give the newly constituted cast a big opening bang.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Allied Bancshares Inc. agreed to acquire First Continental Bank of Dallas in an exchange of stock valued at more than $6.3 million.

title: American Values In Food Chain Link
description: The purchase of 3 million shares representing a 20 percent interest in the financially ailing Victoria Station Inc., a restaurant chain based in Larkspur, Calif., has been made by American Values N.V., an investment group, according to filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Edmonton Gains Playoffs
description: The Edmonton Oilers clinched a playoff berth tonight as Wayne Gretzky picked up a goal and an assist in a 7-2 rout of the Vancouver Canucks.
