title: Nelson Takes 2-Shot Lead
description: Larry Nelson, with one of the few sub-par rounds of the day over the windswept Forest Oaks course, posted a four-under-par 68 today to take a two-stroke lead after the two rounds of the $300,000 Greater Greensboro open.

title: TIME HAS BYPASSED LAW OF THE SEA TALKS
description: To the Editor:

title:
Patents;
Creating Life Forms In the Lab
description: WASHINGTON THE invention on which the Supreme Court based its decision authorizing patents on forms of life created in the laboratory was officially patented this week. Patent 4,259,444, granted Ananda M. Chakrabarty for a microbe, is assigned to the General Electric Company.

title: DELOREAN'S AUTOS START TO ROLL
description: After eight years of planning and an investment of $200 million, the much-publicized DeLorean sports car is finally in production. But the car's price tag will be much higher than was at first planned and, according to industry analysts, the design has been substantially modified.

title: MARGIOTTA JURY IS TOLD OF BROKER'S FEAR
description: The key witness in the trial of Joseph M. Margiotta testified today that he feared losing the Nassau County and Town of Hempstead insurance business if he did not split commissions with politicians designated by Mr. Margiotta, the Nassau and Hempstead Republican leader.

title: GUY J. COFFEY
description: Guy J. Coffey, president and board chairman of the Chicago Pneumatic Tool Company from 1954 until his retirement in 1963, died Wednesday at his home in Malibu, Calif.

title: ROMANS IN SCOTLAND
description: The region surrounding our loch cottage in the Scottish hill country was intriguingly dotted, on the ordnance map, with Roman roads, Roman signal stations, Roman forts. We knew that the Romans had occupied Britain for the first three or four centuries A.D., and were stirred by the proximity of such ancient history to our own annual summer occupation of the glen; in New York, where we live the rest of the year, there is a definite dearth of the ghosts of antiquity.

title: No Headline
description: Benjamin Britten's ''Noah's Flood'' will open the Pepsico Summerfare '81 festival July 11. The festival will run for five weeks at the State University of New York College at Purchase. To be performed outdoors, ''Noah's Flood'' will be directed by Brooks Jones and choreographed by Carmen de Lavallade. The setting will be designed by Antonio Frasconi and David Durst. The Britten opera, in which professional and amateur community performers of all ages will take part, will begin with a parade, ''The Gathering Storm,'' which will begin in the Pepsico Sculpture Garden and wind its way to the grounds of the Center for the Arts on the university campus.

title: LAKERS TRIUMPH
description: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar scored 27 points and Earvin (Magic) Johnson grabbed 18 rebounds tonight to help the Los Angeles Lakers beat the Houston Rockets, 111-106, and tie their twoof-three-game playoff series at one game each.

title: OPERA: RONALD BENTLEY'S 'TOSCA'
description: The New York City Opera's ultrarealistic, ultratraditional production of ''Tosca'' dates back to 1966, when Tito Capobianco directed the action in the decor of Donald Oenslager. That production wandered in and out of the repertory until the fall of 1979, with Mr. Capobianco always credited with the onstage proceedings. Wednesday night it returned, this time with entirely new stage direction by Ronald Bentley, who has been on the company's staff but who was making his debut as a director in his own right.

title: Tax Evasion
description: To the Business Editor: I read ''How Tax Evasion Has Grown'' (March 15) with some interest and agree with its conclusions with some reservations. The implication that accountants are willing participants in tax evasion schemes is a disservice to the profession.

title: THE ELDERLY POOR WOULD BENEFIT FROM NEW PROPOSALS ON TAXATION
description: To the Editor:

title: AN ATHLETE REMEMBERS HIS COACH, JUMBO ELLIOT
description: James F. (Jumbo) Elliott the longtime track coach at Villanova University, died on March 22 at the age of 66. The following article was written by Dick Buerkle, who competed for Villanova and Coach Elliott from 1965 to 1970.

title: Correction
description: In the Arts and Leisure section, a picture and caption on the Theater page and a listing in The Guide announce the opening of the musical ''A Reel American Hero.'' The show closed in previews after both sections went to press.

title: REAGAN, T.R. AND THREAT OF AN 'ELECTRONIC' PRESIDENT
description: To the Editor:

title: At Home
description: FOR her 53d birthday, my friend Carol received a framed ''Certificate of Martyrdom'' from her husband, Sam. Offered by the Church of World Peace, it reads: ''The suffering you have had to endure at the hands of life has been almost more than any person can bear. Rarely has such a noble soul been forced to put up with such undeserved agony.'' To qualify for listing in the Official Archives as a Church Martyr, the applicant must have endured three tragic events in his or her lifetime. Carol's ''tragic events'' are, in order of reappearance, the return home of Michael, 24, Sam Jr., 26, and Anne, 28.

title: TRIAL STAKES HIGH FOR MARGIOTTA AND NASSAU G.O.P.
description: WESTBURY IT is normal for indicted politicians to express confidence that they will be vindicated. But Joseph M. Margiotta, the Nassau County Republican Party chairman, is acting like a man who is almost certain he will be exonerated.

title: Home Clinic; DIVERTING WATER ON A SLOPING SITE
description: HOUSES on sloping ground often have problems with water after every heavy rain, or even when a neighbor lets his lawn sprinkler run too long. Not only does this water soak into the ground on the uphill side of the house, causing muddy areas and washouts of shrubbery or grass, but it also saturates the soil next to the foundation walls to such an extent that hydrostatic pressure forces moisture in through every opening in the masonry.

title: BUDGET CUTS WOULD HURT CITY'S ELDERLY, REPORT SAYS
description: Despite the Reagan Administration's pledge of a ''safety net'' for people who truly need Government social programs, the President's proposed spending cuts fall especially hard on the estimated 940,000 New Yorkers who are 65 years or older, according to a report prepared by the city's Department for the Aging.

title: COSMOS PLAN A TEAM TO COUNTER M.I.S.L.
description: Since the Major Indoor Soccer League is definitely expanding into the new Meadowlands arena next season, the Cosmos are on the verge of making a commitment to field a team for the indoor season of the North American Soccer League.

title: CRAFTS
description: NEWARK TEXTILE enthusiasts can revel in the fact that close to a quarter of the 200-plus objects in ''Tibet: A Lost World,'' an exhibition now at the Newark Museum, are made of cloth.

title: Housing Bias Victims Urged to Seek Help
description: Although we are in complete agreement with the conclusions expressed in the article, ''Resegregation Is Found to Persist'' (Feb. 8) - namely, that resegregation is occurring in New Jersey's suburbs - the article fails to include the state's Division on Civil Rights as a resource for victims of housing discrimination.

title: MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: IS IT A BIRD? A BELL? NO, IT'S A FROG CHOIR
description: PRODDED by slowly rising temperatures, New Jersey's 15 native species of frogs and toads, which spent the winter under muddy pond bottoms or in burrows, are awakening these days, breaking the silence of the woodlands with peeps, chirps, clicks and croaks.

title: EAST SIDE NURSING HOME, STRUCK BRIEFLY, JOINS OTHERS IN CONTRACT ACCORD
description: Employees of the largest nursing home in the city went on strike for 12 hours yesterday, then agreed to return to work after the owner said he would sign a contract reached earlier in the day by the association representing his home and 17 others.

title: A BORDER TRADE ZONE
description: If Ronald Reagan is able to confer with Jose Lopez Portillo at the border, in San Diego, Calif., and Tijuana, later this month, as planned, the Presidents will have a unique vantage point - this would be their second meeting - from which to view the complex relationship between the United States and Mexico.

title: APPALACHIAN REGIONAL STUDY FINDS ABSENTEE OWNERSHIP OF 43% OF LAND
description: Absentee owners, primarily coal, timber and petroleum companies, hold title to nearly half the surface area in 80 counties of the impoverished Appalachian Mountain region, according to a Government-financed study.

title: Rolls-Royce: Top of the Class
description: ''NOW don't laugh,'' said Reg Abbiss, ''but Rolls-Royce has become socially conscious.'' As he said it, more than half a million dollars' worth of that new social consciousness was lined up outside Tavern on the Green in Central Park, making the restaurant's parking area look Sheikly chic. Inside, though, there was scarcely a prince to be found. What there were, mostly, were automobile writers, trying to look their scruffy best for the introduction of two new Rollses - the company's first new four-door sedans in 15 years.

title: Clout
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. PRESSURES FORCE A CHOICE ON NICARAGUA
description: When Salvadoran guerrillas launched their ''final'' offensive in January, they were enthusiastically cheered on by Nicaragua's Sandinist rulers who thought they saw their July 1979 revolution about to be emulated. But when the fiesta was over and the Salvadoran rebels were still far from power, Nicaragua was left holding the check.

title: COLLEGE EATING: FOOD FOR THOUGHT
description: STONY BROOK ''WHAT'LL it be tonight -turbot with fruit sauce or veal Parmesan?'' asked Arlene Nekrutman, the effeverscent manager of the Roth Cafeteria, one of the three main dormitory dining rooms at the State University at Stony Brook. The student, who wasn't familiar with turbot, a firm-fleshed white fish, was offered a taste. ''Not bad,'' he said, ''but I think I'll have the veal.''

title: Nancy Newberry Is Wed To Christopher Kristoff
description: At St. Michael Roman Catholic Church in Greenwich, Conn., yesterday, Nancy Newberry, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph R. Newberry of Riverside, Conn., was married to Christopher A. Kristoff, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Kristoff of Greenwich. The Rev. Vincent O'Connor performed the ceremony.

title: Camera; SHOOTING PICTURES THAT THE EYE CANNOT SEE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Jack Manning is a staff photographer with this newspaper, and the author of several books on photography.

title: Diane Landis, Student, Fiancee
description: Mr. and Mrs. Wilson A. Landis of Orchard Park, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Diane Landis, to Edward W. Duffy Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Duffy of East Aurora, N.Y. and New York.

title: SITE SOLD, 87 UNITS TO BE BUILT ON 49TH ST.
description: The former Midtown Hospital site at 309 East 49th Street has been sold by Roberto Riva and Giorgio Laurenti, principals of the OTIC Development Corporation, to Bruce Berger Realty Inc. for more than $5 million.

title: SHOPS FEATURING EXOTIC FOODS
description: CULINARY adventure for Westchester residents is not limited, as some may think, to trying out unusual new restaurants or dependent on forays into Manhattan. Without traveling beyond the bounds of the county, an inspired cook can venture into markets of foreign lands to secure ingredients for truly different meals. The variety of ethnic, exotic and specialty stores in Westchester - beyond the ubiquitous cheese, health-food and gourmet shops - is sufficient to keep the most creative chef happy.

title: Theodore Gramkow to Wed Elizabeth Reed
description: Mr. and Mrs. H. Mason Reed Jr. of New Canaan, Conn., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Clarke Reed, to Theodore William Gramkow, son of Col. Edwin Warfield Gramkow, U.S.A.F., retired, and Mrs. Gramkow of Woodbine, Md.

title: Living With Diabetes
description: As the parent of a diabetic child, I feel that the plight of the juvenile diabetic and the complications associated with this disease have been kept in the closet for too many years (''New Hope for Diabetics,'' by Pat Covelli, March 8). The funds required for meaningful research programs aimed at curing the disease and the complications associated with it can be raised only when the public is made aware of this awesome health problem. Pat Covelli's article helps accomplish that objective. BARRY N. COOPER, New York City

title: A Correction
description: An article on book piracy in the March 29 issue of The Week in Review incorrectly stated the terms of United States copyright law. As of Jan. 1, 1978, the law provides protection for the lifetime of the author plus 50 years after the author's death. Works published before 1978 and still protected by copyright are now covered for 75 years.

title: FALLING ENERGY RESERVES
description: While the large American oil companies accumulated heady profits last year, most of them ate into their proven United States oil and gas reserves and became more dependent on foreign sources, according to Energy User News' tabulation of annual reserves estimates filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: CRITICS OF KOCH MAY BE LOSING LIBERAL SUPPORT
description: There are signs that the Liberal Party might be moving away from the citizens' coalition that is trying to consolidate the opposition to the re-election of Mayor Koch.

title: A PRESIDENTIAL ASSAIN FAILS--JUST BARELY
description: IN= the end, the familiarity of it all was the most dreadful. The shots, the shock, the screams, the Secret Service scramble to pack the stunned President into the limousine readying to rocket away, the affably serious doctors addressing anxious reporters in a makeshift hospital press room, the videotape over and over again that night, the columns in the next days on the when, why and how of American assassins - but above all, the fact that such a fact no longer astonishes. On Monday, March 30, at 2:25 P.M., John W. Hinckley Jr., a 25-year-old well-off dropout, tried to kill Ronald Reagan.

title:
The Careful Shopper;
Display of Fashions At Norwalk Outlet
description: Next Saturday at the Norwalk Factory Outlet Center in Connecticut, spring will be welcomed with fashion shows at noon, and 2 and 4 P.M.; on Sunday more fashions at noon and 4 P.M. There are nine discount outlets are open at the ground level; on the second floor, the Quoddy Moccasin Factory Outlet, Clothes Works and the Old Mill have opened.

description: We pleaded, we reasoned, we shouted. But no. Washington is so busy setting back the clock of Soviet policy it just let the Kremlin seize another precious advantage.

title: SHIPPING: RESURGENT BARNACLES
description: Until the early 70's, the gooseneck barnacle spent most of its time on the backs and heads of whales. No one in the shipping industry objected to this arrangement: Everyone in the shipping industry hates the gooseneck barnacle.

title: Earthquake Felt in Two States
description: A minor earthquake, registering 2.7 on the Richter scale, awakened residents in southeastern Massachusetts and parts of Rhode Island early today, officials said. The quake was recorded at 4:24 A.M. by the Boston College Observatory here, which put the center of the earthquake in Portsmouth, R.I. There was no damage reported.

title: WHY BROADWAY'S FASTEST WRITER CANNOT SLOW DOWN
description: Consider the playwright cursed by the burden of memory, wounded by the pain of the past. Think, for example, of Eugene O'Neill. Old ghosts coursed his brain - scuttling up a synapse, running down a neuron, and hurling themselves onto the stage. Ah, misery! Oh, art! It is how we defined O'Neill. Now consider Neil Simon, who also dredges around his past. He exorcises old ghosts; sometimes he wrestles with demons, but for him they come out funny. For him they make us laugh. Him we define by the calcium deposit in his neck. It is an accretion built up by sitting hunched up over a typewriter, five hours a day for 30 years. Is this fair? Is this just? Where is the artistry and anguish in a calcium deposit? No matter; Neil Simon defines himself by the calcium deposit, too.

title: CATHERINE SHEEHY FIANCEE
description: Dr. and Mrs. Alfred M. Sheehy of Belhaven, N.C., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Catherine Mary Sheehy, to Richard Peter Crean, son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony E. Crean of Somers, N.Y. The wedding is planned for Aug. 1 at Our Lady of Mercy Roman Catholic Church in Washington, N.C. Miss Sheehy and her fiance graduated from Holy Cross College. The prospective bridge teaches English at Pungo Christian Academy in Belhaven. Mr. Crean is a field representative for Prentice-Hall Inc, in Columbia.

title: AROUND THE NATION
description: Councilman Henry G. Cisneros beat seven other mayoral candidates in balloting here today to become the first Mexican-American Mayor since 1842.

title: CONFRONTING THE CUBAN NEMESIS
description: In the deep, postmidnight darkness of Monday, April 17, 1961, a dozen frogmen silently slid ashore on the southern coast of Cuba, closely followed by landing craft from five troop-laden freighters. Soon, more than 1,500 Cuban exiles - secretly trained, armed and directed by the United States Central Intelligence Agency - were moving along the Giron and Larga beaches on the Bay of Pigs. The C.I.A. had assumed that the people of Cuba would rise up against Fidel Castro the moment the exile brigade hit the beaches. In fact, they did nothing of the sort. Within 72 hours, the ships were sunk by a handful of Castro's all-but-obsolete aircraft and the members of the brigade captured or killed. The bearded revolutionary and his tiny island, just 90 miles from Florida, had defied the mighty Uncle Sam and lived to tell the tale.

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, APRIL 5, 1981
description: International Defense Secretary Caspar Weinberger said that the Soviet Union was continuing its military buildup in and around Poland and that the response of the United States and its allies would include ''far more effective'' trade sanctions against the Soviet Union and possibly the sale of weapons to China. ''There's still a lot of activity that we wish weren't going on,'' he said during a flight to Europe for a meeting in Bonn Tuesday of defense ministers of the NATO countries. (Page 1, Column 6.) Diplomatic sources in Moscow said that the Soviet leadership refused to discuss the issue of Poland with Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher of West Germany, who spent three days in Moscow for talks. ''Their refusal is consistent, but ominous, especially when they were talking to a man of high rank,'' a senior Western diplomat observed. (1:5.)

Although it was startling news, a Michelin executive said, even more startling was Milltown's plea for $20,000 to light the field.

The menu essentially follows the lines of the typical neighborhood Chinese restaurant with a great many special and combination dinners, column A and column B selections and food that might be called Cantonese but is interpreted according to American tastes.

title: ADDING TO THE ZIP CODE

Those requesting the new 18-cent stamps have been sold what the Postal Service calls the non-denominational B stamp, which has no price on it. According to Thomas V. Falvey, a spokesman in the Northeast Region of the United States Postal Service in New York, the new stamp has no price because the Postal Service, convinced that 18 cents will not cover the cost of mailing a first-class letter, plans to raise prices again soon, to 20 cents.

title: PRODUCER PRICES JUMP 1.3 PERCENT IN MONTH
description: Volkswagen was charged by the Federal Trade Commission last week with failing to tell customers that engines manufactured from 1974 to 1979 could leak oil because of problems with valve seals. The complaint, which will be examined by an F.T.C. judge, is without ''factual or legal support,'' VW said. The charge, the first case of its type against a foreign manufacturer, comes at a time when United States car makers are increasingly concerned over competition from the imports. Health or safety is not involved, the F.T.C. said, but the pocketbook is. Extensive repairs can result from an engine running without enough oil. VW Rabbits, Dashers, Siroccos and Audis are involved, the F.T.C said, adding that it had received 800 complaints from consumers.

WALKER EVANS- ROBERT FRANK

However, Tod Papageorge, the curator of this exhibition, seems to be saying that Robert Frank was really little more than a puppet of Walker Evans.

description: The Beatles. By Geoffrey Stokes. (Times Books. Cloth, $19.95. Paper, $12.95.) With a jacket by Andy Warhol, a perfunctory introduction by Leonard Bernstein and countless photographs beautifully art-directed by Bea Feitler, this is the ultimate coffee-table book on the Beatles. The text is a brisk and cogent narrative account of their career. Strawberry Fields Forever: John Lennon Remembered. By Vic Garbarini and Brian Cullman with Barbara Graustark. (Bantam. Paper, $2.95.) A respectful narrative of Lennon's life, illustrated with photographs, the book includes a Newsweek interview with Lennon and Yoko Ono conducted just before Lennon's death. One of the better examples of the ''instant'' paperback. Lennon Remembers: The Rolling Stone Interviews. By Jann Wenner. (Rolling Stone Press/ Fa wcett. Paper, $2.50.) Generously illustrated with photographs, these 1970 interviews now seem dated. But aficionados will appreciate them for their informative candor. The Writings of John Lennon: In His Own Write and A Spaniard in the Works. (Simon and Schuster. Cloth, $10.95; New American Library.

description: GREELEY, Colo. Four years ago, Kenneth Monfort relinquished the top job at Monfort of Colorado Inc., the country's biggest feedlot operator, citing ''a lack of challenge.''

title: Emmie Hill Is Married to Michael K. Minter
description: Emma Willis Hill and Michael Kent Minter, both of New York, were married yesterday in Washington. The Rev. Thomas E. Hill, the bride's uncle, performed the ceremony in St. Alban's Episcopal Church.

title: WASHINGTON
description: SINCE= the founding of the Secret Service three months after the slaying of Abraham Lincoln, all but one of the attempts on the lives of six Presidents have been made by lone assassins who had virtually no chance of escape after firing a pistol at close range. Such was the case in the attempt last week, and the Secret Service conceded that it was impossible to guarantee that other lone guns won't pose a threat in the future.

title: Ziegler Foresees Bright Future
description: Another regular season has ended for John Ziegler, the beleaguered but unflappable president of the National Hockey League - another season in which he has had to defend his views on violence, on network television, on the 80-game season played to eliminate five of 21 teams.

title: WOODBURY RESIDENTS FIGHT DEVELOPMENT
description: WOODBURY WOODBURY residents -afraid that as the shopping center goes, so goes the neighborhood - have combined forces and finances to try to halt the spread of commercialism in this hamlet of expensive homes and large open spaces.

title: Westchester Journal
description: FOR months, community leaders and politicans have been criticizing an Elmsford manufacturer of luminous signs for the level of radioactive emissions it has allowed to enter air and water. Public hearings have been held by the state's Department of Environmental Conservation, and calls for a shutdown of the company, Self-Powered Lighting Inc., have been made by Elmsford, Tarrytown, Yonkers and the town of Greenburgh.

title: SMALLER HOUSEHOLDS FOUND IN L.I. CENSUS
description: WASHINGTON SUFFOLK COUNTY, one of the few in the state with a substantial population increase during the 1970's, also had a 29 percent increase in its housing stock, a shade better than the national average.

title:
Gardening;
SPRING IS FOR PRUNING, SEEDING, FERTILIZING
description: AT this time of year, the urge to get outdoors on warm, sunny days is almost irresistible -especially among gardeners. The many tasks at hand provide additional incentives.

title: INDIANA IN HOLIDAY FESTIVAL
description: Indiana will join Villanova, St. John's and Kansas in the 30th annual Eastern College Athletic Conference Holiday Festival at Madison Square Garden Dec. 28 and 29.

title: MUSIC: CHAMBER SOCIETY
description: The Chamber Music Society unfurled an even more diverse program than is its norm Friday in Alice Tully Hall. Along with standard repertory - Beethoven's Violin Sonata in C minor (Op. 30, No. 2) and Mozart's String Quintet in C (K. 515) - there was the expected deft novelty in Fran,caix's ''Divertissement'' for bassoon and string quintet, along with the first appearance with the society of a topflight young violinist, Cho-Liang Lin, and, to top it all, a commissioned world premiere, Joseph Schwantner's ''Through Interior Worlds.''

title: THE NO. 1 INVESTOR'S PRUDENT PORTFOLIO
description: NEWARK T HERE are no computer terminals, no Dow Jones ticker, no stockquote machines in the spacious office of Frank J. Hoenemeyer in the Prudential Insurance Company of America's headquarters here. Behind his desk, however, there is a boxy sculpture laden with numbers and words - sense, nonsense, yes, no -that he jokingly refers to as his dart board.

title: WALLACE LEFT MARK ON COUNTY
description: THE publishing innovations of DeWitt Wallace, the Reader's Digest founder who died last week at the age of 91, are widely known: luring readers from fiction to non-fiction, condensing articles and books in a mass-circulation magazine, putting a table of contents on the cover, developing the ''how to'' form of service article.

title: On the Bronx
description: To the Editor:

title: usic: Debuts in Review; Yong Hi Moon Performs Schubert Piano Sonata
description: When Yong Hi Moon played Schubert's A Major Sonata (D. 959) at her Carnegie Recital Hall debut Wednesday night, she showed how sensitive a pianist she could be. Some finely shaped phrases passed between her hands.

title: Suzanne E. Carr and Carl Gordon Shepherd Are Married
description: Suzanne E. Carr, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. E. Edgar Carr of Short Hills, N.J., and Carl Gordon Shepherd, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Shepherd of Dallas, were married yesterday. The Rev. Robert Nunn performed the ceremony at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: SQUIBB: A NEW LOOK AT A PHOTOGRAPHER
description: LAWRENCE TWP. MOST older Americans might not recognize Ernst Haas's name, but they would certainly recognize some of his pictures. As a photographer for Magnum, the internationally known picture agency, Mr. Haas snapped memorable views that frequently appeared in Life magazine and other publications, as well as in galleries and museums. However, in recent years, his work has not been seen here with as much frequency as many of us would like.

title: Recordings; VOCALISTS ON DISPLAY
description: Guide By PETER G. DAVIS

title: BASEBALL 1981: SOME BIG MONEY QUESTIONS TO ANSWER
description: set with 3 line initial and ruled byline By MURRAY CHASS

title: RISING COSTS, REGULATORY CHANGE PROMPT BANK MERGERS
description: WATERBURY FACED with a rising cost of doing business and with changes in banking regulations, Connecticut financial institutions are beginning what some observers believe will be a fundamental reorganization.

title: Connecticut Journal
description: THE Connecticut State Register and Manual, better known as the ''Blue Book,'' has become the latest casualty of state budget constraints. Secretary of the State Barbara B. Kennelly announced last week that the supply of the 1980 edition of the manual has been exhausted in part because the press run was held down to try to save money.

title: Apke Leaving Creighton To Coach Colorado Five
description: Dan Offenburger, the athletic director at Creighton University, said today the school would start a search immediately for a successor to Tom Apke as the Bluejays' head basketball coach.

title: ENGLISH POLO FIELDS: A TOP-CLASS OUTING
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- SUSAN HELLER ANDERSON writes frequently from England. By SUSAN HELLER ANDERSON

title:
Food;
THEY SELL FISH WITH AN EDUCATION
description: OCEANSIDE ''THEY all look so young,'' remarked a woman as she bought two pounds of gray sole the other day at the Seafood Terrace at 217 Merrick Road.

title: Miss King Fiancee Of Robert O'Connor
description: Noelle Warden King and Robert J. O'Connor, who are with the Metropolitan Museum of Art, plan to be married in June in Southport, Conn.

title: Italians Arrest a Suspect In 1978 Slaying of Moro
description: Mario Moretti, a suspected Red Brigades guerrilla wanted in connection with the kidnapping and murder of former Prime Minister Aldo Moro in 1978 was arrested in northern Italy today with a group of other guerrilla suspects, the police reported.

title: Gotham Is Next Test For Cure the Blues
description: When Jose Martin plummeted from Air Force planes near Fort Bragg as a paratrooper in the mid-1960's, he said he never knew exactly where he would land or what the simulated enemy would look like. ''We just prayed that the chute would open,'' he said.

title: Long Islanders; HE LOSES NOTHING IN TRANSLATION
description: WHEN the weather is nice, Gregory Rabassa sits on the porch of his home in Hampton Bays and practices the art that has won him prizes and eminence.

title: Critics' Choices
description: DANCE Daniel Nagrin describes his new ''Poems Off the Wall,'' to be seen Tuesday, Thursday and Saturday at the Studio Theater, as ''a mesh of movement and words, music and visuals.'' The movement should be gutsy, pointed and highly dramatic, if his 39 years of work--much of it solo dancing--are a guide. The music for this suite of solos will be a miscellany, the visuals slides by Pablo Orrego and costumes by Sally Ann Parsons. And the words? ''I might quote Woodrow Wilson,'' Mr. Nagrin says. ''I might paraphrase J.P. Morgan: 'If you have to understand dance you can't afford it.' ''

title: WHEN MERCHANDISERS GUIDE THE ANIMATOR'S HAND
description: Awinsome moppet named Strawberry Shortcake will encounter a comical villain called the Purple Pieman in Big Apple City this Friday evening at 7 on 101 stations around the country including WPIX/Channel 11. But have no fear: Everyone will live happily ever after. The syndicated show's producer and sponsor, Kenner Toys - which last year sold nearly $50 million worth of Strawberry Shortcake dolls and other related playthings -wouldn't have it any other way.

title:
DEATH PENALTY: ITS PROSPECTS HAVE IMPROVED;
TRENTON
description: ALTHOUGH there will not be a statewide referendum on capital punishment this year, New Jersey voters will have a chance to make their feelings known about a reinstatement of the death penalty by the way they cast ballots in the coming elections for Governor and the Legislature.

title: THEATER: HERMAN WOUK'S 'CAINE MUTINY' AT THE Y
description: A tall, businesslike fellow dressed as a Marine directs audiences down the stairs to the American Jewish Theater at the 92d Street Y, and a two-striper takes tickets, allowing you to sit in the spectator section and witness a dramatically gripping production of ''The Caine Mutiny Court-Martial.''

title: LURING BIG EXECUTIVES
description: T HE front-end bonus - the big bait, no-strings payment in addition to salary and performance incentives - is designed to lure corporate executives into top-level jobs, and more and more companies are using it. Some executives, before accepting a contract, now even demand that the company provide luxury cars, country club memberships, free air travel for family members and even haircuts.

title: Pamela Rogers Is Bride Of William W. Harmon
description: Pamela Anne Rogers, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Courtney Rogers of Houston and New York, was married yesterday in Houston to William Walter Harmon, son of Mrs. Dorothy Harmon and Harvey L. Harmon both of Oklahoma City. The Rev. Sam W. Lanham performed the ceremony in St. Philip Presbyterian Church.

title: SLAYING RENEWS FEARS OF A KILLER IN CALIFORNIA PARKS
description: Just as spring is attracting more people to secluded hiking trails and beaches, the fatal shooting last Sunday of a young woman and the wounding of her companion have renewed fears that a killer stalks northern California parks in search of victims.

title: Barbara L. Lewis Fiancee of Lawyer
description: Dr. and Mrs. John S. Lewis of Pelham, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Logan Lewis, to John Andrew Buchman, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Frederick Buchman of Canton, Ohio.

title: FARRELL TAKES 2 EVENTS
description: Monsignor Farrell and Cardinal Spellman won two events apiece in the New York sectional Catholic High School Athletic Association relays at Randalls Island Saturday.

title: IT'S THE LITTLE THINGS THAT DEFINE A TIME
description: THERE are people who feel that it is the mundane things that provide us with the best insights into the mores, values and daily way of life of a given period. Believers in the evocative powers of the concrete object and the significance of the seemingly insignificant garbage-bound scrap speak of ephemera - material that is transitory, produced for short-term use and meant to be thrown away.

title: BUDGET CUTS MAY FORCE THE CLOSING OF BOSTON'S 25 BRANCH LIBRARIES
description: The Boston Public Library may close all 25 of its neighborhood branch libraries on May 1 in an effort to keep the central library open despite deep budget cuts.

title: Article on Pensions Is Held Misleading
description: The method of calculating retirement benefits not only applies to the Public Employees Retirement System, as mentioned in an article on March 22, but also to most state-administered programs both in New Jersey and throughout the country.

title: At Home
description: FOR her 53d birthday, my friend Carol received a framed ''Certificate of Martyrdom'' from her husband, Sam. Offered by the Church of World Peace, it reads: ''The suffering you have had to endure at the hands of life has been almost more than any person can bear. Rarely has such a noble soul been forced to put up with such undeserved agony.'' To qualify for listing in the Official Archives as a Church Martyr, the applicant must have endured three tragic events in his or her lifetime. Carol's ''tragic events'' are, in order of reappearance, the return home of Michael, 24, Sam Jr., 26, and Anne, 28.

title: THE LOVE THEY TAKE AND MAKE
description: SHOUT! The Beatles in Their Generation. By Philip Norman. 414 pp. New York: Fireside/Simon and Schuster. Cloth, $19.95. Paper, $9.95.

title: By Sports of The Times; Steinbrenner Setback
description: IN maintaining his reputation as baseball's least-loved bully, George Steinbrenner thought he could insult Bowie Kuhn's intelligence and Harding (Pete) Peterson's integrity. When both the commissioner and the Pittsburgh Pirate general manager challenged the Yankees' principal owner, the deal for Jason Thompson collapsed. George Steinbrenner has only himself to blame.

title: Warren Green to Marry Marsha Salamoff in Fall
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert G. Salamoff of Newton, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marsha Anne Salamoff, to Warren I. Green, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Green of North Miami Beach, Fla.

title: Japan Moves to Increase Rights of Korean Minority
description: After 30 years, Japan is moving to eliminate one of its most blatant forms of official discrimination against 280,000 Korean and 8,000 Taiwanese residents. Many of them were brought to Japan for forced labor before World War II or were born here.

title: WITH NEW SOVIET MOVES, POLAND MAY BE RUNNING OUT OF STRING
description: ''MANY people today are asking with extreme fearfulness: What next?'' The comment was not the latest worried word from the West, but Izvestia's claim that Poles fear ''creeping counterrevolution.'' What the Poles really fear is a Soviet invasion.

title: MAN IN MOTION AT NOTRE DAME
description: the perpetual motion of their new head football coach, Gerry Faust.

title: LEGISLATURE ASKED BY CAREY TO TAKE UP PLAN TO AID TRANSIT
description: Governor Carey convened the Legislature in special session here today with an order that the Assembly and Senate consider not only the state budget but also his five-year, $5.85 billion program of new equipment and improvements for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority system.

title: Beware the New Park Ranger
description: Interior Secretary James Watt promises dramatic and disturbing changes in the way national parks are run. He recently told park concessionaires that he would change ''fifty years of bad government'' and had begun by firing other Presidents' appointees from Interior. More heads will roll, he vowed.

title: Toting Bags to Tortola
description: To the Editor:

title: GUN USE IN CRIMES IS HIGH, BUT NOT RISING
description: WASHINGTON

title: Tiant Sent to Minors
description: The Pittsburgh Pirates have shipped Luis Tiant to the minor leagues. The 40-year-old right-handed pitcher, who has won 225 games in 16 seasons in the American League, will start the season with Portland, Ore., of the AAA Pacific Coast League.

title: WHO KILLED MR. BRODIE?
description: I KNEW I was in trouble the minute I saw the box on the kitchen table. It moved. Ribbon and all - the box moved. I looked at the girls and they had big smiles on their faces, and their Dad was standing there trying to hold back his eagerness for me to open the birthday present.

title: New Yorkers Excel At Kearny Relays
description: Relay teams from New York City's public high schools crossed the Hudson River today and found gold. Competing in the fifth annual Kearny Relays on the high school field, Public Schools Athletic League representatives, led by Boys and Girls and Thomas Jefferson, won six gold medals in boys' Division II and four more in the girls' section. And Nigel Gabriel of Boys and Girls was named the most valuable athlete in the meet and went back to Brooklyn with a gold trophy.

title: Counterfeit Couture
description: Isn't there some kind of poetic justice in ''The Big Couture Rip-Off'' (by Susan Heller Anderson, March 1)? Shouldn't the designers feel good knowing that now not only rich people can enjoy the ''image'' and not only rich people can feel the inner security of wearing outer price tags of well-known prestigious logos, but that now almost anyone can pretend that he found the ''real thing''? KATE SELAN Chicago

title: U.S. PULLS A SWITCH ON HIGH COURT
description: WASHINGTON ON the morning after President Reagan's inauguration, the Supreme Court returned from its one-day holiday to hear arguments in one of the term's most important regulatory cases, a challenge by the textile industry to the three-year-old Federal standard limiting worker exposure to cotton dust.

title: Correction
description: In last week's Investing column, stock prices for the Aspen Exploration Corporation were misstated because of erroneous information supplied by Going Public: The Initial Public Offering Reporter.

title: FICTION
description: 1 1 24 THE COVENANT, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $17.95.) Fifteen thousand years of South African history. 2 4 12 MASQUERADE, by Kit Williams. (Schocken Books, $9.95.) A fantastic tale about the Sun, the Moon and a lost treasure. 3 3 7 CENTURY, by Fred Mustard Stewart. (Morrow, $13.95.) Saga of an Italian-American family. 4 2 8 BRAIN, by Robin Cook. (Putnam's, $11.95.) A young physician copes with a conspiracy of medical researchers who steal young women's brains to create an artificial intelligence. 5 5 4 THE COMPANY OF WOMEN, by Mary Gordon. (Random House, $12.95.) One modern young woman's experience with the manners and mores of Roman Catholicism. 6 6 15 ANSWER AS A MAN, by Taylor Caldwell. (Putnam's, $12.95.) A man who has made it big in early 20th-century America struggles against the corruption that engulfs his life. 7 7 28 THE KEY TO REBECCA, by Ken Follett. (Morrow, $12.95.) German espionage in Cairo during the desert campaigns of 1942.

title: TRUCE BREAKS DOWN IN EASTERN LEBANON
description: A cease-fire in the Christian town of Zahle in eastern Lebanon collapsed today while fighting here intensified and spread.

title: TRANSIT DECLINE POSES A THREAT TO JOBS IN CITY
description: Delayed subway trips, commuter-train breakdowns and no-show buses are straining the commercial links that have made New York City, with its high density, a singular attraction as a place to do business.

title: QUOTATIONS
description: ''I don't know how it can get any worse. Everybody's kind of on their belly now.''

title: The Fire at Carey High: Another View
description: In regard to the fire at Carey High and the resulting outcry of letters, I want to say that Andy Edelstein (''Did a Spark From the 1960's Start the Fire at Carey High?,'' Opinion Page) is speaking not only of his neighborhood school but of a widespread phenomenon, and I consider his article perceptive and altogether quite wonderful.

title: Court Clarifies; The Right to Die
description: The moment of death must still come, miracles of technology notwithstanding; but whether to let it come quickly, or artificially to ward it off, has become a thorny question. The New York Court of Appeals last week narrowed the conditions under which such decisions can be made.

title: Miss Robbins, John R. Cissel Will Be Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Walter Spalding Robbins of Fairfield, Conn., and New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Brown Robbins, to John Rittenhouse Cissel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Wood Cissel of St. Louis and Little Compton, R.I.

title: ISLANDERS CLINCH FIRST WITH 4-1 VICTORY OVER CAPITALS
description: The Islanders clinched the No. 1 spot in the National Hockey League's regular season standing today when they defeated the Washington Capitals, 4-1, at Nassau Coliseum.

title: Iranian Jurist Questions Legality Of Ex-Deputy Premier's Spy Trial
description: A leading Iranian jurist today questioned the legality of the trial of former Deputy Prime Minister Abbas Amir Entezam on charges of spying for the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: CELLIST: PAMELA FRAME
description: Pamela Frame, a cellist who made her formal New York debut last season, appeared for another recital Thursday night in Carnegie Recital Hall, and acquitted herself admirably. Miss Frame does not have a big, assertively virtuosic tone, and thus sometimes - as at the very beginning of the slow movement of Beethoven's Sonata in D (Op. 102, No. 2) - her quiet playing took on an oddly lifeless character.

title: LAND OF ERIE, AT $69, WINNER OF WIDNER
description: Land of Eire, the longest betting choice in the field, moved strongly on the outside to catch the leaders in the stretch today and win the $155,750 44th running of the Widener Handicap at Hialeah.

title: Viola Starts With; His Hands Full
description: With spectators barely outnumbering security guards, one general succeeded another last week in Casa Rosada, Argentina's pink presidential palace. The ruling junta presented Gen. Roberto Eduardo Viola with the blue-and-white presidential sash and gold-knobbed baton, but, with the economy traumatized and politics stagnant, many of his countrymen hoped he would pass the baton to a civilian before his term ends in 1984.

title: REAGAN, T.R. AND THREAT OF AN 'ELECTRONIC' PRESIDENT
description: To the Editor:

title: Missing Student
description: All seemed normal last Dec. 9 when Juha Uronen, a 17-year-old exchange student from Finland, left the home of his host family in Scarsdale, N.Y., ostensibly headed for high school.

title: EXPLORING AFRICAN POLICY
description: The foreign policy of the Reagan Administration has been highly declamatory so far: lots of strong words and sharp gestures. That gives special interest to an effort, now under way, to rethink one area of policy cautiously and quietly - policy toward southern Africa.

title: SUING G.M.: IS CHEVROLET TRYING TO FORCE OUT ITS SMALL DEALERS
description: F ROM his Queens showroom, Robert L. Koop sold more Chevrolets in 1978 and 1979 than he had ever sold before. Poor sales were driving other new-car dealers out of business, but he felt he was doing well. He thought Chevrolet thought so, too - in the last few years the company had rewarded his performance with expense-paid trips to China, the Soviet Union, Italy, Hong Kong and Australia.

title: CRIME
description: English writer Reginald Hill began writing his series of procedurals starring Detective-Superintendent Dalziel and Sergeant Pascoe about 10 years ago, and by now their reputation is well established. These two cops, who operate out of Yorkshire, complement each other. Dalziel is a veteran: feet-on-the-ground, sceptical, confident in his normal routine. Pascoe is intelligent and sympathetic, a college graduate who sometimes works from flashes of intuition. At first there was a guarded suspicion between the two men. Now they are comfortable with each other and work well in tandem.

title: Alden A. Rockwell Is Betrothed
description: The engagement of Alden Appleton Rockwell to James B. Murphy 2d has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. H.P. Davis Rockwell of Olympia Fields, Ill., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Dr. James Slater Murphy of New York and Happy Rockefeller, widow of former Vice President Nelson A. Rockefeller.

title: Ragers and Fatalists
description: Unity: It was a week for Americans to draw together, first in shock, then in gratitude for miracles. The President seems speeding toward recovery; so do his brave defenders; and each day brings new hope for James Brady, his genial press secretary.

title: HEART PATIENTS ADD TO THEIR 'MILEAGE'
description: WEST ORANGE ''I'VE BEEN BYPASSED!'' exclaim the T-shirts worn by some of the adults who jog regularly in the gym at the Y.M.-Y.W.H.A. here. With these words appears a red heart plastered with a bandage.

title: Stage View; HALLELUJAHS FOR BACALL, HANDICAPS FOR 'ROSE'
description: Ithink what impresses me most about ''Woman of the Year'' is that the new musical promptly and even arrogantly sets itself challenges that it had damn well better live up to - and then somehow, sooner or later, makes good on the deal.

title: COUNTERFEIT COUTURE
description: The real couture rip-off is that designers dare charge so much for items no better than dozens of others, and no different except for the ''name'' label. They invite criminal copies. And isn't it revealing that so few people can tell the difference between the originals and the cheaper copies? J.M. THOMASON

title: Markets
description: To the Business Editor: Prof. Leonard A. Rapping in ''Supply Side's Bad Side'' (March 15) applauds ''the great Allied victory against fascism,'' but himself puts forth fascist principles: ''Investments must be coordinated by the adoption of stratetic planning, not by the confusion and chaos of the gladiatorial arena called the 'free' market.''

title: SPENCER READY TO PLAY
description: Jim Spencer, back with the Yankees after two days of head-spinning confusion, is prepared to resume his role here undeterred by the aborted trade that almost sent him to the Pittsburgh Pirates for Jason Thompson.

title: INMATE IS HELD
description: An inmate apparently drowned the warden of a state prison in a shallow ditch today after fatally shooting the manager of the prison's farm, a Texas Department of Corrections official said.

title: CONCERT: THE SONGS OF LYUN JOON KIM
description: A rather peculiar concert took place in Carnegie Hall on Friday night devoted to the songs of a 66-year-old South Korean composer named Lyun Joon Kim, whose music had never before been heard in New York. Evelyn Lear was to have been the principal soloist with a chamber orchestra conducted by Andrew Meltzer and piano accompaniments supplied by Jonathan Feldman.

title: RETIREES IN FLORIDA CAUGHT BY TIGHT MORTGAGE CREDIT
description: In retrospect, Arthur B. Fowler says, he should have known better. He and Mrs. Fowler bought a home in a mobile-home community before they sold their condominium at a lakeside development called Murry Hills in this pleasant community south of West Palm Beach along the coast of southeast Florida.

title: Girl, 16, Slain in Holdup At a Food Shop in Bronx
description: The 16-year-old daughter of a New York City police detective was killed early yesterday by a holdup man who opened fire with a shotgun on her and other employees of a Bronx fast-food shop for no apparent reason, the police said.

title: IT'S NOT ALL THAT EASY TO BE A HAWAIIAN IN NEW JERSEY
description: ''WHERE are you from?'' I am always asked. ''I live in Montclair,'' I reply, smiling innocently with my tropical white teeth, slanted Asian eyes and acquired Jersey logic.

title: STAGE: JAMES SAUNDERS'S 'BODIES' AT THE LONG WHARF
description: James Saunders's ''Bodies,'' a thought-provoking new British play in its American premiere at the Long Wharf Theater, operates on a double frequency, as an excoriating study of modern marriage and as a sardonic disputation on the price of emotional adjustment and on creativity as symptomatic of neurosis. The characters are a classic quadrangle. Two married couples, the oldest and closest of friends, have affairs with each other's spouses. They part, and meet nine years later, as they approach middle age. At a dinner party, they revisit their ''old selves'' and expose old battle scars.

title: CONGRESS HITS SNAG ON SOCIAL SECURITY
description: Congressional efforts to provide more financing for the hard-pressed Social Security System have run into serious obstacles in the early stages of drafting the complex and politically sensitive legislation.

title: Columbia Gets Ready and Set For Friday Go
description: For a vehicle designed to shape up and fly right for some 100 missions, America's space shuttle has spent a great deal of time shaking down and standing on launch pad 39-A at Cape Canaveral, Fla. But, after completing final tests and a review of flight readiness last week, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration set early Friday morning as Columbia's launch date.

title: Bullet Fired at Transit Policeman Is Deflected by Pen in His Jacket
description: A Transit Authority police officer escaped serious injury yesterday when a bullet fired by a suspected mugger bounced off a fountain pen in a jacket pocket over his heart, the police said.

title: HAIG OPENS TOUR WITH CAIRO TALKS, PLEDGES EFFORTS FOR A MIDEAST PEACE
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. opened his Middle East tour today by pledging the Reagan Administration's desire to promote security and peace efforts in the region, but his attention was distracted by the situation in Poland.

title: HOW CREATIVE SHOULD LITERARY CRITICISM BE?
description: IN the past few years, as if the literary scene were not confusing enough, a new battlefront has emerged. Critics, whether journalists or academics, send their wit and vocabularies charging against ''deconstruction,'' ''structuralism,'' ''revisionism'' and other foreign-sounding heresies. The sudden blaze of attention, as when a war first breaks out, has even reached America's favorite parlor game, ''The Dick Cavett Show,'' which devoted two of its recent sessions to literary criticism. Yet this warfare baffles the bystander, who wonders what the study of literature is all about. Do we have to fight over how literature should be read? Can't we just relax with a good or entertaining book?

title: Wayne Baker Weds Paula A. Mirabile
description: Paula Angela Mirabile, senior leasing officer for the New York State Office of General Services, was married yesterday to Connecticut State Senator Wayne A. Baker, Democrat of Danbury. State Supreme Court Justice Joan M. Durante performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents, State Supreme Court Justice Thomas J. Mirabile and Mrs. Mirabile, in Jamaica Estates, Queens.

title: RIFLE GROUP VIEWED AS KEY TO GUN LAW
description: In a speech Wednesday advocating stricter controls over pistols, Senator Edward M. Kennedy conceded, ''This is not an easy issue for any officeholder or candidate.''

title: THE BIG PUSH IS ABOUT TO BEGIN
description: IF YOU have been ignoring the campaign for Governor of New Jersey because of, or in spite of, the large number of candidates in each major party, chances are that it will be difficult to do so from now on.

title: ISLA MUJERES: A BUDGET ALTERNATIVE TO COZUMEL AND CANCUN
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- JOHN BRANNON ALBRIGHT is an editor on the staff of the Travel Section. By JOHN BRANNON ALBRIGHT

title: By A PAUSE, THEN GOVERNMENT MOVES AHEAD
description: WASHINGTON AROUND 4 P.M. on Monday, the Cabinet officers and other officials gathered in the White House Situation Room, which is the nerve center of the American Government, were doing what most of their fellow citizens were doing. They were watching television news reports of President Reagan's condition.

Mr. Bush slipped into the seat at the head of the table to hear their reports and recommendations. But he began with an admonition. ''The President is still President,'' he reportedly said. title: Future Events Names to Follow
description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:Hers and HisApril 9 -Irena Neumann Kirkland steps up first for her Freedom Award from the International Rescue Committee. Then her husband, Lane Kirkland, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., gets his. Both of their plaques show a map of the world with the places where the 48-yearold committee has relief and resettlement programs for refugees from totalitarian violence and oppression. Leo Cherne, chairman of the committee, will hand the plaques to the Kirklands at a dinner in the Sheraton Center, which starts with a reception at 6:15 and, after roast ribs of beef, goes on to speeches by leaders in labor, industry and government who are active in the committee. The nodais trend will be upheld with all guests seated on an equal level, which those to be honored will leave briefly for the speakers platform so everyone can see them better. Mrs. Kirkland, once a prisoner in Nazi concentration camps, later was imprisoned by the Communist regime in her native Czechoslovakia for her leadership in the Social Democratic youth movement. She fled to the United States by way of Israel. She and her husband, who became active in behalf of refugees when he joined the staff of the American Federation of Labor in 1948, thus join the ranks of Freedom Award recipients who include Winston Churchill, Hubert H. Humphrey, William B. Donovan, George Meany and Jacob K. Javits.

title: AN ITALIAN TREAT FOR EASTER
description: There is no easy answer to why so many holiday or feast-day breads and cakes are made with yeast, but it is certainly so. It is true of the Greek Easter bread known as lambropsomo, the Jewish hallah, the Russian kulich and the Italian panettone, which is a bread most closely associated with Milan. Actually panettone serves for two religious holidays in Italy, Christmas and Easter. There are numerous versions of this bread, some with and some without candied fruits and raisins. The variation outlined here is not only delicious, but also keeps well when wrapped in aluminum foil and kept airtight. The preparation of this panettone is slightly intricate, so on this page are step-by-step photographs showing how to go about it.

title: By THE SYMPTOMS SURROND US, BUT WHAT IS THE MALADY?
description: WASHINGTON PERHAPS the most shocking thing about last Monday afternoon was that many Americans were not really shocked. Angry, anxious, maybe even frightened, but not shocked. In a way it was like hearing that the corner grocery store had been held up again or that another neighborhood teen-ager had died from using drugs. We wonder what it is about our society, our national character, that makes such events so common. In time, we may turn to professionals, to sociologists and psychiatrists, but we find their judgments no more satisfying, no less contradictory than our own.

title: A MASTERPIECE OF MODERN DANCE
description: Vaslav Nijinsky's scandalous 1913 production in Paris of Igor Stravinsky's ''Le Sacre du Printemps'' signaled the beginning of dance as a modern art. In 1980, the American modern-dance choreographer Paul Taylor offered his own ''Le Sacre du Printemps (The Rehearsal)'' on Broadway, producing a very different kind of surprise. Taylor took the legendary avant-garde ballet and reduced it to a baffling, cartoon detective story about a young woman whose baby has been kidnapped by Chinatown thugs; intermingled are scenes of a dance rehearsal overseen by a grim Russian ballet mistress. ''The most talked-about dance work in recent years,'' as Anna Kisselgoff of The Times called it, will be repeated during the Paul Taylor Dance Company's three-week appearance at the New York City Center, opening April 14. For all its comic exuberance, Taylor's rites of spring neveretheless end on a disturbing note: the detective, the crooks and the police - even the baby (a doll) - become the victims of a methodical, silent-movie massacre. The corpses revive for a final dance rehearsal. Is this a demonic celebration of American violence or a final apotheosis of the dancer's art?

They had demanded $1.5 million and the release of 80 political prisoners.
