title: SONGS FROM STAR TEAMS AND SOLOISTS
description: With star excitement in opera on the wane these days, it apparently takes the appearance of two or more celebrated singers in tandem to raise the temperature of most opera fans. We recently heard the Sutherland-Horne-Pavarotti trio and the Caballe-Carreras duo concertizing in New York, and these events did indeed stir up some star dust. A pair of new recordings also operate on the principal that two big names are better than one, duet albums by Mirella Freni and Renata Scotto (London OS 26652) and Katia Ricciarelli and Jose Carreras (Philips 9500 750).

title: JODIE FOSTER SEEKS 'NORMAL LIFE' AT YALE
description: NEW HAVEN SHE says she plans to major in literature, but that that will ''probably change five times.'' She likes the lectures of the historian W. Gaddis Smith, but the class meets at 8:30 A.M., an hour when she says she would rather be sleeping, and by now, the second half of her freshman year, she feels confident enough to cut the class once in a while.

title: Former Iran Hostages Will Gather in Capital
description: A majority of the 53 Americans who were held hostage in Iran will be reunited later this month at a threeday gathering sponsored by the State Department.

title: No Headline
description: Iranian jet fighters struck today at four airbases deep inside Iraqi territory in what was described by Teheran Radio as a major effort to destroy the enemy's air force.

title: Short Fiction
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: OCEAN DUMPING ADVOCATES ENLIST NEW ALLIES
description: Twelve miles from where the Hudson River meets the Atlantic Ocean, in a triangle formed by tips of the Long Island and New Jersey shores, lies one of the largest underwater dumping grounds in the world. Every year for the last 50 it has absorbed up to 10 billion pounds of sludge, including vast quantities of bacteria and significant concentrations of heavy metals such as zinc, chromium and lead.

title: Tire Executive Is Killed in Crash
description: Willard P. Seiberling, the son of the founder of Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, was killed yesterday in a traffic accident near the Michigan-Ohio state line, the police said. Mr. Seiberling, who was 88 years old, was the son of Frank A. Seiberling, founder of the Akron-based tire company, and was elected as a director of the Seiberling Rubber Company in 1959.

title: MURDER IN MOSCOW, ARKADY RENKO ON THE CASE
description: GORKY PARK By Martin Cruz Smith. 365 pp. New York: Random House. $13.95.

title: Robin Ann Houlas, Designer, Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Houlas of Brecksville, Ohio, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Robin Ann Houlas, to Richard Brennan Thomas Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas of Old Greenwich, Conn.

title:
Art;
GEOMETRY DEFINES ITSELF
description: the mathematical definition of forms in space - is one of the great tools of art. It provides a basis for the analysis of structure, the building of compositions and the determination of balance and proportion. Nowadays it is commonly used as an end in itself, providing both a work structure and its subject.

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: JAMES HERRIOT'S YORKSHIRE, by James Herriot. (St. Martin's Press, $9.95.) The veterinarian who has been treating creatures great and small for 30 years and has written about them in three best sellers, here describes the wild rustic hills and dales of the English county that's his home. Derry Brabbs's 225 photographs capture the special charm of the land.

title: NEW NAMIBIA PLAN BACKED IN PRETORIA
description: South Africa can be expected to embrace the Reagan Administration's effort to revise a Western proposal for settlement of the dispute over the territory of South-West Africa, a senior official indicated today.

title: EDITORS' CHOICE
description: ELLIS ISLAND, by Mark Helprin. (Delacorte Press/Seymour Lawrence, $10.95.) A new collection of stories by the young American writer.

title: Dining Out; STONEHOUSE SERVES OLD-TIME DECOR
description: GREENWICH IN recent years, Greenwich has joined Westport as a Fairfield County town with a variety of interesting restaurants. New restaurants seem to open and thrive on a fairly regular basis. One of the recent additions is the Stonehouse, open since September.

title: Ellen E. Gomprecht To Be Wed June 20
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Irvin Gomprecht Jr. of Stevenson, Md., of the engagement of their daughter, Ellen Elizabeth Gomprecht, to William Jay Oppenheim Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Oppenheim of Greenwich, Conn.

title: EXPECTED CUTS TROUBLE THE ARTS
description: ARTISTS who depend upon grants from the state's Commission on the Arts may anticipate a 50 percent cutback this year, probably compounded by another 50 percent cut in subsidies from the National Endowment for the Arts.

title: Notes; STAYING IN BRITISH PRIVATE HOMES, STATELY AND OTHERWISE
description: The number of organizations offering opportunities to stay in private homes in Britain keeps growing. At least a half-dozen concerns now specialize in arranging for visitors to stay in stately homes and country estates in England and Scotland as paying guests of the owning families.

title: LEGISLATORS HURRY UP AND WAIT AT A SPECIAL SESSION
description: ''Rarely have I felt so silly in my legislative career,'' said Assemblyman Richard N. Gottfried, a Manhattan Democrat who was serving today by standing and waiting outside Assembly Speaker Stanley Fink's office.

title: NEW YORK DAIRY FARMERS BACK CUT IN PRICE SUPPORTS
description: Hans Schober sat in a rocking chair at his farmhouse here in northern Columbia County today before going out to the barn to milk his herd of 80 black and white Holstein cows.

title: British Seize 26 in Heroin Raids
description: The police arrested 26 people and seized five and a half pounds of heroin in a series of overnight drug raids in the London area, authorities said today. Two police officers were injured in a scuffle with suspects in one of the raids, the police reported.

title: Furniture
description: To the Business Editor: In ''High Point, N.C.: The Furniture Makers Are Coming Unglued'' (March 15), the This End Up Furniture Company was erroneously referred to as the End Up Furniture Company of Raleigh, N.C. This is of some importance since the name was derived from package crates that indicated which end was up. The wood used in first making the furniture for this company was obtained from these shipping crates, but now is of the strongest pine.

title: Music View; RUFFLES AND FLOURISHES ON AN OLD TUNE
description: When Zubin Mehta zoomed into town in his supermaestro suit to take charge of the Philharmonic in 1978, many skeptical New Yorkers worried out loud that he might not fit in. The former leader of the Los Angeles Philharmonic, the faint of heart feared, might want to import some West Coast flamboyance into Lincoln Center, that travertine-walled stronghold of musical conservatism. Other observers of the Philharmonic, of course, fervently hoped he would do just that. It was at least expected by almost everyone that Mr. Mehta would quickly insist on impressing his own personality on the orchestra itself, its repertory and on the city's musical life. After being exposed for several seasons to the brilliant but buttoned-up mind and impersonal musical interpretations of his predecessor, Pierre Boulez, some of us felt that any change might be a tonic. The change has been slow in coming.

title: Robert Harder Ryan Fiance of Shelley Beck
description: Shelley Ann Beck, a floral design consultant in New York, and Robert Harder Ryan of New York, co-founder and president of RBR Political Consultants Inc., which specializes in the management of political campaigns as well as issues research, plan to be married May 16 in Eagles Mere, Pa.

title: TUT SHOW WILL FINANCE MUSEUM PROJECT IN EGYP
description: The Tutankhamen collection that has been touring the world will be returning to Cairo soon, but disposition of the $16 million in profits realized by Egypt from the traveling exhibition is still largely undecided, although the money was to have been used to renovate the Egyptian Museum in Cairo.

title: Dance View; CUNNINGHAM'S FOLLOWERS
description: In many ways, Merce Cunningham is the Cubist of dance. Collage, an essential Cubist device is basic to his own method of nonlinear organization of movement. He has applied the Cubist principle of breaking up forms to show us a super-reality we would not have seen in a more literal structure. Similar to Cubism, his approach offers not only analysis but also the synthesis of dissociated (theatrical) elements.

title: OPERA: 'SALOME' AT MET
description: The Metropolitan Opera substituted ''Salome'' on Friday evening for what would have been the first of five ''Fidelios'' - all lamentably canceled for lack of a suitable Lenore. For 1981 audiences at least, the principals for this ''Salome'' were almost wholly new -an entirely new royal family, a new Jochanaan and a new conductor, Julius Rudel, to preside musically over the grisly proceedings on stage.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: AN AMBASSADOR'S WIFE IN IRAN By Cynthia Helms. Illustrated. 212 pp. New York: Dodd, Mead & Co. $12.95.

title: Cory Sea Is Fiance Of Maryanne Kentz
description: Judge Frederick C. Kentz Jr. of the Superior Court of New Jersey, Chancery Division, and Mrs. Kentz of Summit, N.J., and John's Island, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Maryanne Kentz, to Cory Sea, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert F. Mullen of Ann Arbor, Mich.

title:
Numismatics;
RARE CANADIAN SILVER DOLLAR BRINGS RECORD PRICE
description: American numismatists tend to be chauvinistic about their hobby, viewing United States coins as the ultimate in rarity and value. This type of smugness was jolted several weeks ago when two Michigan dealers announced that they had purchased a rare Canadian coin for $325,000, a price exceeded by few American issues.

title: THE SOVIET NAVAL THREAT
description: The Soviet Union has built a combat navy that jeopardizes our principal interests on the world oceans. The Reagan Administration must formulate a strategy to crimp this new dimension of Soviet imperialism.

title: PHOTOGRAPHERS CALL FOR WARNING ON AIRPORT X-RAY DAMAGE OF FILM
description: A group of photographers have formally asked the Federal Aviation Administration to post signs at airports warning air travelers that X-ray screening of their baggage may damage photographic film.

title: NEW BOAT ACCESSORIES
description: The shelves of marine hardware stores now are brimming with the myraid of supplies needed to care for an outfit a boat. And with seasonal regularity, new accessories appear on the market to help the boat man in his spring labors.

title: THE GULF COAST: BAYOUS, BEACHES, NATURE TRAILS AND FORTS
description: White sand beaches, barrier islands with alligator swamps and nature trails, old forts, bayous and reefs are among the attractions along the Gulf of Mexico coast in western Florida, Alabama and Mississippi.

title: WESTCHESTER AIRPORT: A SAFER COURSE
description: QUITE clearly, the medieval philosophers were not considering the proposed expansion of the Westchester County Airport when they wrote ''In medio stat virtus'' and ''Pars tutior preferendum est.'' However, our intellectual forefathers, while pondering less technological but equally extravagant extremes, did suggest quite humbly, but accurately, that there are times when ''strength and wisdom counsel the middle ground'' and ''the safer course should be the preferred course of action.''

title: Statehouse Game Goes into Overtime
description: After failing to pass a budget in time to start the new fiscal year, members of the New York State Legislature braced themselves for the penalty - a weekend in Albany.

title: FOR OPENING DAY THE 50 WAYS TO LOVE YOUR YANKEES
description: WITH the baseball season beginning this week thoughts of past seasons fly through the mind. A die-hard Yankee fan must be forgiven if his baseball thoughts are virtually totally Yankee thoughts. Herewith are offered 50 thoughts of what a super Yankee fan of a certain age would like to see (or hear) for the first time or again. Readers must realize that nostalgic thoughts of past Yankee glories are fairly sacred to a pinstripe worshipper, and those not so afflicted are asked to offer rebuttal at their own risk. 1. A doubleheader with the St. Louis Browns or Washington Senators; such unabashed pleasure was surely a perversion, a sin. 2. Mel Allen broadcasting an inning of a Yankee-Red Sox game, or a whole Yankee-Red Sox game, or a whole season for that matter. How about that? 3. Mickey Mantle batting right-handed with the bases loaded. Was Hornsby really a better hitter than Mantle batting right-handed? 4. Yogi Berri jumping on Vic Raschi or Allie Reynolds or Don Larsen after a World Series game victory. 5. Eddie Lopat staring at Bill Veeck's black cats in Cleveland's Municipal Stadium - and then pitching a shutout against the Indians. 6. The Yankees' winning five consecutive World Series. 7. Phil Rizzuto making only 14 errors in a full season playing on natural turf in every park, and wearing a glove only as big as - a glove. 8. Only 14 night games (Tuesdays and Fridays) with the first one not until the middle of May, and Sunday doubleheaders to spend six hours or more at Yankee Stadium. 9.

title: North Sea Oil Rig Disaster Tied to 'Abysmal' Security
description: Poor design, lack of stability and ''abysmal'' security precautions all contributed to the collapse of a North Sea oil rig in which 123 people died last year, according to a report by a Government-appointed board of inquiry published here yesterday.

title: A NEW LOOK IN AMERICAN DENTISTRY
description: Leonard A. Cole is a political scientist and a dentist. By Leonard A. Cole The patients sit in a spacious waiting room around a large fish tank that gently bubbles amidst plush, colorful furnishings. A mother chats with a visitor while waiting for her children to finish treatment. She has just made an appointment for herself because her youngsters have been so pleased. She has decided to leave her private dentist, who had treated her for 19 years, and come to the Family Dental Center in the Woodbridge, N.J., shopping mall. The center is open from 7 A.M. to 10 P.M., which makes it easier on her schedule, she says, and she was attracted by its advertisements of lower prices and personal attention.

title: CHASE IS NOW BILL BUTCHER'S BANK
description: WILLARD C. BUTCHER is a fist-thumper and a chain smoker, and when there are problems, he smothers them. The word he uses to describe himself is ''pro-active.'' When doing his New York State income tax returns last month, he says, ''I found I had less days not working than there are weekends in the year.'' Mr. Butcher relaxes on what he calls ''the Butcher yacht,'' a 15-foot sailboat. ''If you don't use it,'' he says, ''at least you don't have a lot of money sitting at the mooring.''

title: SCHOOL CLOSINGS A MAJOR ISSUE
description: AT this late stage of the campaign, school closings because of declining enrollments seem likely be a major issue in many of the 553 districts that will go to the polls Tuesday to elect school board members and decide on budgets.

title: WEST BENGAL HALTING TEACHING OF ENGLISH FOR PRIMARY STUDENTS
description: The Marxist government in India's eastern state of West Bengal has decided to drop English as a compulsory language for primary students despite protests from intellectuals.

title: AUSTRALIANS IN A BATTLE OVER A 35-HOUR WEEK
description: Australian trade unions campaigning for a 35-hour workweek have run into determined opposition from the Government, touching off a struggle that threatens to embroil the country's industrial relations for some time.

title:
Gardening;
SPRING IS FOR PRUNING, SEEDING, FERTILIZING
description: AT this time of year, the urge to get outdoors on warm, sunny days is almost irresistible -especially among gardeners. The many tasks at hand provide additional incentives.

title: EXPERTS REPORT HIGH RATE OF ALCOHOL ABUSE IN STATE
description: At least 40 percent of the hospital patients in New York State have alcohol-related medical problems, and a similar percentage of prison inmates are alcoholics, according to testimony at a state hearing on alcohol and heroin abuse.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: POP: JESSE WINCHESTER
description: The formulas of popular music can be cruelly restricting, even if they do sometimes serve to purge more eccentric artists of mannerism. Jesse Winchester, who was at Folk City last Thursday night, has appeared on record and in previous New York dates with a conventional folk-rock band.

title: STATE TO PROCESS PERMITS FOR STILLS
description: NEWARK ENDING what has been described as a ''year of bureaucratic nightmares,'' Sidney Glaser, director of the state's Division of Taxation, said last week that applications would be accepted in the next 10 days from people who wanted permission to produce alcohol fuel for their own use.

title: MAPLE SYRUP A GO-GO
description: Thanks to a succession of cold nights and warm days, the sap has been running out of New England's maple trees and into the boiling vats of maple syrup producers at prodigious rates.

title: IN AMERICA SUING SEEMS TO WORK
description: THE LITIGIOUS SOCIETY By Jethro K. Lieberman. 212 pp. New York: Basic Books, Inc. $13.95.

title: Headliners; Back to the U.S.S.R.
description: The studied insult has been a favorite device of the Reagan Administration in diplomatic dealings with the Soviet Union, and last week it was applied to Georgi A. Arbatov, Moscow's leading expert on the United States. Mr. Arbatov had been asked to join in a televised debate on the arms race on Friday, but the State Department refused to extend his visa, which expires today. The reason: Soviet spokesmen have access to American television, but the courtesy is not reciprocated in Russia.

title: CORRECTION
description: A listing today in section 2A, The Guide, for next Saturday's Metropolitan Opera radio broadcast is incorrect.

title: LET ME IN, LET ME IN!
description: NOT long ago, I traveled to Cambridge to give a reading from a novel I had just published. In the pub afterward, surrounded by pleasantly deferential students, I was asked about the London literary world. The students' preconceptions about London were, of course, as naive and fantastic as were mine about Cambridge: ''Is Clive James really a millionaire? Do you know Angus Wilson? Is Ian McEwan really having an affair with Princess Margaret?'' I exaggerate, but the questions all presupposed a febrile metropolis of vast monetary gain, blazing celebrity and keen socio-sexual selfbetterment.

title: NEW DRAG STRIP PLAN OPPOSED BY RACERS
description: AN effort by Southampton Town officials to impose more stringent safety regulations at a drag strip has mobilized amateur racers in the county. They say the requirements are unnecessary and might be undesirable if they were applied to all racing within the town.

title: La Ronde
description: The problem had puzzled New York's officials for years: How to design a litter basket people won't steal. Stumped, they ran a contest.

title: Randall Atcheson Plays On Organ and Piano
description: Randall Atcheson, who seems to be the only person ever allowed to pursue a double major while a student at the Juilliard School, made his New York debut at Alice Tully Hall on Tuesday night playing his two instruments of specialization - organ and piano.

title: A CAROLINA TOWN WITH A GRACEFUL ARCHITECTURAL HERITAGE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- SKIP ROZIN is a New York-based writer who specializes in sports. By SKIP ROZIN

title:
COMMENT;
TAX-FREE FINANCE
description: A N economic civil war appears to be brewing over the more widespread use of tax-free financing, a program used by states to aid development and generate employment. Objections primarily concern a liberal application of the program by Northern states. Seemingly unworthy projects, increased reduction of Federal tax revenues, creation of unfair competitive disadvantages, and the alleged benefiting of wealthy borrowers and lenders are being cited.

title: NINA E. COUGHLIN IS BETROTHED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Coughlin of Chestnut Hills, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nina Elizabeth Coughlin, to Stephen Bradford Cook, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bradford Cook of Haverford, Pa. A June wedding is planned.

title: Miss Hill Takes Lead on 70-210
description: Carolyn Hill shot her third straight two-under-par 70 today and took a one-stroke lead in the $250,000 Colgate-Dinah Shore tournament, the richest on the women's golf tour.

title: Ferragamo's Style May Alter in C.F.L.
description: Vince Ferragamo, who is on the verge of signing a contract with the Montreal Alouettes after spurning a new offer from the Los Angeles Rams, is probably going to have to alter his passing style because the Canadian Football League's playing field is so much larger than the field in the United States. That is the view of Ralph Sazio, the general manager of the Hamilton Tiger-Cats, who held the negotiating rights to Ferragamo before trading them to Montreal last week.

title: THE ROOTS OF TERRORISM
description: Claire Sterling's article begins with two terrorist incidents, one of which was the murder of the Unionist politicians, the Stronges, by the Irish Republican Army. Miss Sterling failed, however, even to mention the probable reason behind that contemptible act, that being the equally contemptible attempt to murder the political and social reformer Bernadette Devlin McAliskey and her husband, while they ate breakfast, with their children, in their own home. This assassination attempt was the work of the Ulster Defense Association, a Protestant terrorist organization. JOSEPH MURPHY Chairman Suffolk County Chapter

title: LAOTIANS TO CELEBRATE NEW YEAR TRADITION
description: WHEN Boonchoo Jaigla and his family arrived in Rye in November 1975, they constituted Westchester's entire Laotian refugee population. But today there are an estimated 500 Laotians in the county, and on Saturday night many of them will gather to celebrate the Laotian New Year.

title: About Long Island
description: THE outdoor season is coming in, and not a moment too soon. Lately, the automated world within has been pestering me with what I am pleased to call practical jokes of mechanization.

title: Fourth DanceAfrica In Brooklyn April 24-26
description: African-American dance companies from Boston, Chicago, Philadephia, Washington and New York will join in the Brooklyn Academy of Music's fourth DanceAfrica Festival, from April 24 through April 26 at the academy's Opera House.

title: LIVING WITH DIABETES
description: Some 10 million Americans have diabetes, 40 percent of whom are unaware of the condition or are not receiving treatment. Most in this latter group are over 40 years old, overweight and ignoring symptoms that seem minor but which in fact are signaling the onset of diabetes. The American Diabetes Association is concerned about these four million undiagnosed diabetics and offers information on the warnings signs and treatment of diabetes. DONALD I. BELL, M.D. President, American Diabetes Association

title: Smith, Times Columnist, To Receive Racing Award
description: Walter W. (Red) Smith, the sports columnist of The New York Times, and James B. Faulconer, executive vice president of the Thoroughbred Racing Association, have been named recipients of the Dean Eagle Memorial Award for 1981.

title: Around the Garden
description: This Week:

title: ON ROSA LUXEMBOURG
description: I wonder if our Polish brothers still remember Rosa Luxembourg. Sixty years ago, this brilliant Polish-Jewish Communist put her fingers on the evils against which Solidarity and its dissident allies in the Polish Communist Party have begun successfully to revolt.

title: LIVING WITH DIABETES
description: I am a user of the new insulin pump. I say ''new'' because an updated version is now being issued to diabetics.

Gardening;
SPRING IS FOR PRUNING, SEEDING, FERTILIZING
description: AT this time of year, the urge to get outdoors on warm, sunny days is almost irresistible -especially among gardeners. The many tasks at hand provide additional incentives.

title: IN A YEAR OF HIGH FUEL PRICES, SOME GUIDES TO CUTTING COSTS
description: Given the high cost of fuel, normal spring fitting-out routines, like painting the bottom of a boat and tuning the engine, are no longer enough. This year, boat owners must take additional steps to achieve the best fuel economy.

title: KEEPING A BOX SCORE ON U.S. PHILANTHROPY
description: To the Editor:

title: Westchester Housing; HOUSING PLANS REWARDED WITH AID
description: T HE county government has begun to carry out a promise made when its housing policy was enacted last year: to reward towns and villages that plan for new or rehabilitated housing and to withhold funds for improvements for those who do not cooperate. The policy calls for the construction, conversion or rehabilitation of 50,000 units by 1990. The county has asked communities to submit plans showing how many they would provide and said the communities that cooperated would receive help in local improvements. Thirty-four communities responded, with plans adding up to 41,000 units.

title:
NEW JERSEY HOUSING;
TEACHING SALESMEN THE ART OF SELLING
description: THERE'S a concern based in Scottsdale, Ariz., whose president, Tom Hopkins, has been called the ''Billy Graham of real estate.'' By whatever name, over the last few years Mr. Hopkins not only has developed a large following among those who take his sales-training messages as gospel, but also has built up a formidable corporate enterprise, Tom Hopkins Champions Unlimited.

title: DETERMINED NEIGHBORS AND BUSINESSES BRINGING NEW VITALITY TO QUEENS
description: PLAZA Twenty-three years ago, Stan Margolin first entered his red brick liquor store in Queens Plaza and felt happy to be in business in ''the suburbs.'' His customers were people who worked on the railroad - ''the backbone of the neighborhood,'' he said the other day -and the spread of the web of tracks behind his building was, he thought, as predictable as the appearance of lunch boxes on his counter.

title: HOLLYWOOD'S LONG-RUNNING ROMANCE WITH JAMES M. CAIN
description: James M. Cain is talking to us again - metaphorically, of course - and many filmmakers are listening. In fact, the newest version of ''The Postman Always Rings Twice,'' directed by Bob Rafelson, is only the first of what appear to be several serious attempts to raise Cain.

title: PRIVATE COLLEGES AND PUBLIC SOLUTIONS
description: The following is the text of an address by Dr. Leland Miles, president of the University of Bridgeport, to the General Assembly's Education Committee last Tuesday:

title: SUSPECT'S PARENTS ASK FOR PRAYERS
description: The parents of John W. Hinckley Jr., who has been accused of shooting President Reagan, issued a statement here today describing their son as a ''sick boy'' and asking people to pray for him.

title: 'STAR' PROFESSOR HIRED TO TEACH LAW AT N.Y.U.
description: Winning out in a heated contest among several of the country's top law schools, Manhattan's New York University School of Law has attracted to its faculty one of the legal profession's nationally recognized ''superstars,'' Anthony G. Amsterdam, a 45-year-old expert in constitutional and criminal law who has been teaching at the Stanford Law School in Palo Alto, Calif., since 1969. With the law schools at Columbia, Harvard and Yale - among others - competing for his services, Professor Amsterdam called Dean Norman Redlich at the N.Y.U. Law School to say ''yes'' to a job offer there. He will begin work Sept. 1 as director of clinical and advocacy programs.

title: Transit Plan Is Assailed At a Moynihan Session
description: A variety of state and local officials in New York gathered at the City University Graduate Center yesterday to express opposition to the Reagan Administration's proposal to phase out operating subsidies for mass transportation.

title: SCHOOL EDITORS FIND 'CANDY MAN' CASE OUT OF PROPORTION
description: MILLVILLE THE Orange and Blue Tattler, the Millville Senior High School newspaper that last month found itself in the midst of a battle over freedom of the press, is no stranger to controversy.

title: LIVING WITH DIABETES
description: While Pat Covelli's article focused on diabetes, there are numerous other applications for continuous infusion therapy.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Play ball! Next Wednesday afternoon, at Cincinnati's Riverfront Stadium, the Phillies will meet the Reds, and the 1981 baseball season will officially begin. From then until the World Series ends in early October, literally billions of words will be printed about America's most favorite sport. Many of them will be published in newspapers and magazines - but for the real fan, the sort who treasures legends and statistics, the best will be preserved within book covers. This spring, as every spring, bookstore shelves and newsstand racks are crowded with volumes to satisfy this nostalgia and curiosity. Herewith a quick look at what they have to offer.

title: At Home
description: FOR her 53d birthday, my friend Carol received a framed ''Certificate of Martyrdom'' from her husband, Sam. Offered by the Church of World Peace, it reads: ''The suffering you have had to endure at the hands of life has been almost more than any person can bear. Rarely has such a noble soul been forced to put up with such undeserved agony.'' To qualify for listing in the Official Archives as a Church Martyr, the applicant must have endured three tragic events in his or her lifetime. Carol's ''tragic events'' are, in order of reappearance, the return home of Michael, 24, Sam, Jr., 26, and Anne, 28.

title: OLD MILLS IN THE NORTHEAST TRANSFORMED INTO HOUSING
description: At a picturesque point along the Yantic River, an 1813 red-brick, 90,000-square-foot mill building, once a nail factory and later a textile plant, is nearing the end of its conversion into 121 apartments.

title: Early Birds in Spain
description: To the Editor:

title: ANDERSON TELLS CAREY WHY G.O.P. OPPOSES TAKEOVER OF MEDICAID COSTS
description: The Republican leader of the Senate told Governor Carey and his fellow legislative leaders privately today that his problem with the Governor's proposal to take over the state cost of Medicaid was not only a possible loss of Federal funds but also political reluctance among his Republican colleagues.

title: Pamela Lilly, Lawyer, Engaged to Surgeon
description: Pamela Vanessa Lilly, a tax lawyer for the Exxon International Company in New York, and Dr. Eleby Rudolph Washington 3d, a senior orthopedic surgical resident at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center, will be married May 24 in Detroit.

title: PENSIONS: TAKING IT ALL AT ONCE
description: O N March 1, four months after his 55th birthday, an executive at the Great Northern Nekoosa Corporation retired. Instead of taking the $14,156 a year for life that he was entitled to under the company's pension plan, he opted for a $104,237 lump sum.

title: FELLINI ON MEN, WOMEN, LOVE, LIFE, ART AND HIS NEW MOVIE
description: A&L pg 1 By MARY CANTWELL

title: A 'SHOW ME' ATITUDE FACES FIRST U.S. MISSION TO AFRICA
description: After more than two months of working out its foreign policies, the Reagan Administration has begun to try them out on the countries concerned. Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. was in Egypt and Israel this weekend, explaining what he means by a Middle Eastern ''strategic consensus.'' This week, Chester A. Crocker, the Assistant Secretary of State-designate for African Affairs, sets out on what may be an even more difficult mission - to seek backing for a new approach to southern Africa's complex troubles.

title: COMMUNITY THEATERS PLAYING A STRONG ROLE IN THE ARTS SCENE
description: T HE Chappaqua Drama Group took its production of David Manet's ''The Water Engine,'' which won three prizes at the 21st New York State Theater Festival Association's competition, to Wilmington, Del., last weekend, where it represented New York State in a regional competition with community theaters from Delaware, Pennsylvania, New Jersey and Washington.

description: Guide

title: Miss Russell, Glenn E. Davis Plan Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. A. David Russell of Wilton, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Martha Leslie Russell, to Glenn Edward Davis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Keith E. Davis of Glenview, Ky.

title: The Wooster Trio Plays Violin, Clarinet and Piano
description: The chamber literature for violin, clarinet and piano may be small, but its highly concentrated quality and sophistication seems to be attracting more and more groups like the Wooster Trio. The Wooster, making its New York debut last Saturday at Carnegie Recital Hall, brought with it most of the big pieces from the repertory - including the Mozart Trio in E flat (K.498) and Bartok's ''Contrasts.''

title: Dr. Robert Mendelsohn To Wed Robin Yarmark
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. Lorelle Saretsky and Dr. Ted Saretsky of Hewlett Neck, L.I., of the engagement of her daughter, Robin Wendy Yarmark, to Dr. Robert Mendelsohn, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ben Mendelsohn of Delray Beach, Fla.

title: BUSINESS OF CHARTERING BOATS GROWS IN LONG ISLAND SOUND
description: Although chartering boats is usually associated with Southern and Caribbean waters, local brokers report that it is currently becoming big business in Long Island Sound and Northeastern waters.

title: DENNIS WIPPER FIANCE OF MARGUERITE GIGNOUX
description: Regis Gignoux of Bedford, N.Y., and Jane Hughes Gignoux of New York, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marguerite Jay Gignoux to Dennis Paul Wipper, son of Mr. and Mrs. David C. Wipper of Cincinnati.

title: WOMEN WHO LOVE WOMEN
description: SURPASSING THE LOVE OF MEN Romantic Friendship and Love Between Women From the Renaissance to the Present. By Lillian Faderman. Illustrated. 496 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. Cloth, $18.95. Paper, 10.95.

title: Nine Is Better Than; One, Insists Marcos
description: Ferdinand E. Marcos likes to unfurl legal umbrellas over the many hats he wears as President, Prime Minister and Commander in Chief of the Philippines. On Tuesday, the country will vote (at peril of six months imprisonment for organized boycotting) on constitutional changes calculated to add at least six more years to Mr. Marcos' previous 16 as Numero Uno.

title: PROGRAMS FOR ELDERLY IN JEOPARDY
description: IT took years for our government to even begin to address the diverse needs of older Americans, and to write laws and institute programs that would reduce the collective fears and infirmities that have long beset the elderly.

title: NEW YORK URGES U.S. NOT TO END HOME LOAN PROGRAM
description: New York City officials are urging the Reagan Administration to rescind its plans to end a Federal housing rehabilitation loan program for poor and moderate-income homeowners. They say the program has been ''a vital tool'' in stabilizing one- and two-family housing in the city.

title: BOAT PLAN STIRS DEBATE ON REVENUE
description: THE sleek, stately pleasure boats that annually make their way north from winter berths are beginning to arrive in harbors along Long Island Sound from Greenwich to Groton. They will remain most of the summer, cruising in and out of port between trips to the Massachusetts islands or, perhaps, out into the ocean. Then, when the weather turns, they will head south again to warmer - and cheaper - climes.

title: TWO 'LITTLE BIG BANDS' OFFER NEW JAZZ
description: What do you call a jazz ensemble that consists of eight to 10 musicians and combines the loose agility of a small combo with the density and firepower of a bargain-basement big band? Jazz musicians and critics have never been sure, and they have usually fudged the issue by referring to such groups as octets, nonets, or tentets, or, more informally, as ''little big bands.''

title: Coal Miners Reject Agreement, Risking Long-Term Losses
description: ''You never know in these meetings what you are going to lose or gain,'' said union president Sam Church after a five-day, six-state flying tour to sell a proposed contract to the 160,000 striking members of his United Mine Workers. Last week, as two-thirds of them rejected it, he found out.

title: SPACE SHUTTLE COUNTDOWN TO BEGIN TONIGHT
description: Space agency officials said today that, barring last-minute hitches, the countdown for the first orbital flight of the space shuttle Columbia should begin late tomorrow night. The launching is scheduled for Friday morning.

title: NEWARK: ARE THE 80'S ON ITS SIDE
description: NEWARK IT WAS a cold day in early February when a crowd of about 250 mourners - mostly old and mostly white - filed solemnly into Sacred Heart Cathedral in this city's Vailsburg section to attend a funeral mass for former Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio.

title:
RED SMITH;
Rambling Willie, Bookseller
description: THE book is called ''Rambling Willie - The Horse That God Loved,'' and some may complain that the title implies that God can be bought. Rambling Willie is the 11-year-old pacer who is probably the largest single contributor to the collection plate in the Church of Christ in West Mansfield, Ohio. However, the authors, Donald P. Evans and Philip S. Pikelny, are God-fearing citizens who have no doubt that the Lord loves Willie for himself, not just his money.

title: Valerie Corning, Banker, to Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Mrs. Victor A. Colage of Palm Beach, Fla., and Nathan E. Corning of Manchester, Mass., of the engagement of their daughter, Valerie A. Corning, to Edson W. Spencer Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Spencer of Long Lake, Minn.

title: CHANGES AT PLAYLAND OUTLINED
description: AVASTLY refurbished but somewhat more expensive Playland will open its 1981 season under new management on May 9, the Board of Legislators learned last week, with the Marriott Corporation stamping its image on the half-century-old amusement park in Rye.

title: HE SEES AIDES AS FEVER GOES DOWN
description: President Reagan was described as in ''good condition'' today after a mild fever receded. Despite the fever, he conferred with aides last night and earlier today. His temperature slowly ebbed through the day and was reported as normal at 6 P.M.

title: BETTE DAVIS INSPIRES OFFSPRING OF STARS
description: Bette Davis drew her tiny frame up to its full 5 feet 3 inches, clapped her hands on the shoulders of a reedy, bespectacled boy and fixed him with a withering blue glare. ''CONCENTRATE!'' she barked. The cast of ''Family Reunion,'' bunched on the sloping lawn of a Long Island estate, had heard that word before. It was not just one of the most legendary superstars in Hollywood history giving a lesson in how to act - it was grandmother, telling a cherished grandson to shape up.

title: SPACE AND THE AMERICAN VISION
description: John Noble Wilford, science correspondent of The Times, has covered the space program since the early 1960's. By John Noble Wilford o much rides on the fires of Canaveral, the explosions of energy that overcome gravity and push tons of crafted metal high into the sky and out of sight into that infinite frontier known as space. The fires are a testing. A people are testing themselves in relation to their heritage of steamboats, Conestoga wagons, railroads and airplanes, seeking reassurance that over the years the old vigor and resourcefulness have not left them. A people are testing their resolve to reach beyond the ordinary and thereby, if history repeats, magnify the human spirit.

title: No Headline
description: Having read the letters in regard to the fire that ravaged Carey High School, I feel it necessary to present one other point of view.

title: A MOVIE FOR JUST UNDER $10,000? IT'S A MYSTERY
description: BALDWIN In this era of big-budget films, when a price tag of $10 million is considered modest, "The Way Some People Die," the current Carl Henry 3rd production, can hardly be called "typical." It cost a mere $10,000. But then, Mr. Henry, who prefers just plain Carl Henry for his credits as an actor, director and scenario writer, is not too typical, either. Two years ago, when he started the 60-minute mystery that will be given its premiere at the library here, he was only 19 years old. His collaborator, Rich Carter, was 17. When Mr. Henry and Mr. Carter dedided to transfer Ross McDonald's detective novel to film, they had already created "Chandler," a spoof they filmed in junior high school, and a 20-minute interview with Chuck Scarborough, the WNBC-TV newsman, that won a media contest in high school. Mr. Henry is a video engineer at NBC. When not attending the New York Institute of Technology, Mr. Carter is a cameraman at ABC. "The Way Some People Die" was to be their audition film, so to speak, that, according to Mr. Henry, they would show friends and acquaintances at their networks with an eye to getting a foothold on the creative end of the business. "I've wanted to make movies ever since I was 10," Mr. Henry said. "It was just a coincidence that I was born into a show-business-type family." His father and grandfather are members of television craft unions.

title:
Gardening;
SPRING IS FOR PRUNING, SEEDING, FERTILIZING
description: AT this time of year, the urge to get outdoors on warm, sunny days is almost irresistible -especially among gardeners. The many tasks at hand provide additional incentives.

title: CULLING GEMS FROM FLAWED MOVIES
description: Critics and reviewers make their livings in search of perfection, but because very few things are perfect there's frequently the impulse to see things as being better than they are, to compromise. Some do it out of laziness or optimism or perhaps to help the needy, and many do it out of a real conviction that the second-rate is, indeed, first-. Compromise is not a nice word. It suggests selling out. Sometimes, though, the critic/reviewer in his pursuit of the perfect object not only asks more from a work than was even intended but also leaves unrecognized the possibility that a work's imperfections are why it works so well. Something of this sort recently happened on the stage.

title: PAROCHIAL PUPIL RISE CAUSING DIFFICULTIES
description: WHILE some public school districts are facing the problem of what to do with surplus buildings caused by a dwindling student population, officials at parochial schools on the Island are reporting increases in student enrollments that, in some cases, are taxing the physical limits of small parish-run schools.

title: Airplane Passengers Are Warned Against Bringing Mace on Board
description: The Federal Aviation Administration has warned airline passengers that they face tough penalties if they try to bring Mace or other brands of incapacitating sprays aboard aircraft.

title: POLES PUT OFF SPECIAL SESSION OF PARLIAMENT
description: A special session of Parliament that was scheduled for Monday has been postponed until Friday because the Prime Minister, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, is ''indisposed,'' the Polish press agency said today.

title: Connecticut Guide; SEASONAL MUSIC
description: Observances of Easter and Passover, which fall on the same day this year, begin with some noteworthy musical events around the state this week.

title: Art View; THE CONTINUING DIALOGUE BETWEEN PAINTING AND SCULPTURE
description: ''Sculpture often starts on paper,'' writes Colin Eisler. ''Few workers go straight to wax, clay, plaster of stone without setting down their initial thoughts in brush, pencil, pen or crayon. So most sculptors first see the form that they will follow initiated on the page.'' Obviously, there is a freedom and velocity of expression to be found in drawing that can never be entirely equalled in the more protracted and inhibiting labors required for the realization of a sculpture. To a drawing an artist is free to confide every sort of flight or fancy of the imagination as well as corrections, afterthoughts and idle notations. In order to carve or model or construct a three-dimensional object in real space, however, the sculpture is obliged to submit the cherished spontaneity and inspired improvisations of drawing to the very different - and more slowly realized - disciplines imposed upon him by the nature of his sculptural materials and the technical challenges they entail.

title:
ANTIQUES;
CASTLE RECALLS PATERSON IN ITS PRIME
description: PATERSON LAMBERT CASTLE, a crenellated, terraced former showplace that Catholina Lambert, a Paterson silk magnate, built here in 1892, now houses on its first floor the small museum of the Passaic County Historical Society.

title: A GARDEN GROWS IN WASHINGTON
description: Marjorie Hunter is a correspondent in The New York Times's Washington bureau. By Marjorie Hunter On the slopes of Cryptomeria Valley, the camellias are in bloom, splashing bright reds and delicate pinks amid the stately cedar trees. Yellow sprays of forsythia float over the newly green grass, and shining black branches of the magnolia trees frame early blooms.

title: Toll Now 12 in India Strike Clash
description: Two more deaths from violence during an opposition-sponsored strike in India's Marxist-ruled West Bengal state were reported today by the Press Trust of India news agency. At least 12 people have died as a result of bomb attacks and police gunfire yesterday. The strike was intended to protest what was described as increasing lawlessness in West Bengal.

title: DANCE: BILL JONES AND ARNIE ZANE'S 'VALLEY COTTAGE'
description: ''Valley Cottage,'' a new collaborative dance piece by Bill T. Jones and Arnie Zane, began promisingly with the two men repeatedly crossing the stage diagonal formed by a row of flats. Mr. Jones slithered, and Mr. Zane bounced. They rolled. They jumped. They capered through some genuinely funny pratfalls, acting as acrobatic levers for each other. And round and round they went, at varying speeds, to children's voices and syncopated drumrolls.

title: Leisure; THE POSTCARD CAMPAIGN TO SAVE WILD FLOWERS
Republicans Dumur on New Plan for County to Take Over Con Ed
description: Two Democrats on the Board of Legislators are unwilling to let the idea of a publicly owned utility for Westchester die. But they are getting no aid or comfort from the Board's Republican majority.

title: London Literary Life
description: Not long ago, I traveled to Cambridge to give a reading from a novel I had just published. In the pub afterward, surrounded by pleasantly deferential students, I was asked about the London literary world. The students' preconceptions about London were, of course, as naive and fantastic as were mine about Cambridge: "Is Clive James really a millionaire? Do you know Angus Wilson? Is Ian McEwan really having and affair with Princess Margaret?" I exaggerate, but the questions all presupposed a febrile metropolis of vast monetary gain, blazing celebrity and keen socio-sexual self-betterment.

title: SADAT LEARNS TO COMPROMISE WITH HIS RELIGIOUS MILITANTS
description: Sadat is dealing with rising religious fervor by giving Islamic radicals much of what they want in the hope of containing them. He has made overtures to Islamic conservatives of the older generation who do not challenge the regime openly. Meanwhile, he has built up security forces and multiplied police surveillance of the more extreme Islamic groups, which are agitating in the universities and poor neighborhoods and are reported to be arming for possible street violence in the name of the Islamic revolution. ''He is soft on religion but tough on the street,'' said a student of Egyptian religious affairs.

title: THREE NOVELS
description: THE FURTHER ADVENTURES OF HALLEY'S COMET By John Calvin Batchelor. 508 pp. New York: Congdon & Lattes, Inc. Cloth, $17.95. Paper, $8.95. THE ANTS OF GOD By W.T. Tyler. 278 pp. New York: The Dial Press. $10.95. IDLE HANDS By William O'Rourke. 435 pp. New York: Delacorte Press. $12.95. By DAVID QUAMMEN

title: Gallery View; TERRA COTTAS- CHAMBER MUSIC FOR THE EYE
description: One of the most beautiful interior spaces in this country is the Blumenthal Patio in the Metropolitan Museum. As perfect in detail as it is in proportion, it was brought over piece by piece from Andalusia in Spain, where it was originally built by Italian workmen in the early 16th century. It makes everything and everyone look their best. At this moment and through Sept. 6 it harbors an anthology of European terra cottas from the Arthur M. Sackler collection, and I can think of few better ways to spend a spring or summer morning than in looking them over.

title: Margiotta's Side; Calls It Patronage
description: As Nassau County Republican chairman for the last decade, Joseph M. Margiotta has been credited by colleagues with using love and fear to build the best-financed, best-disciplined political organization east of Chicago. Last year a Federal indictment charged that he also used extortion and mail fraud, and last week he went to trial on those charges.

title: OTHER COUNTRIES ARE AS SMART AS WE ARE
description: T HERE is a widespread feeling that America needs to recapture economic pre-eminence. Economically, America used to be No. 1. America deserves to be No. 1. America should return to being No. 1. If America just returns to its ancient virtues, it will once again be No. 1.

title: A Prayer for President, Followed by Criticism
description: The New York State Democratic Committee prayed for President Reagan's quick recovery, then assailed his economic program and ended its meeting with a resolution of sympathy for the President, his press secretary, James S. Brady, and the two lawenforcement officers shot Monday.

title: Drought Conditions Found In 46 States in March
description: Drought conditions in the United States spread to 46 states in March, reflecting a flow in rivers and streams that was well below normal, the United States Geological Survey reported yesterday.

title: IT MAY BE WORSE THAN THE DISEASE
description: ATTACKS on Presidents and other prominent figures have prompted some observers to question the vast expansion of civil liberties for mentally disturbed people that has unfolded in recent years. It has been suggested in some quarters that if more of these ''loners, kooks, screwballs,'' as former President Gerald R. Ford described them last week, were confined in mental institutions or prisons, without regard to legal niceties, maybe Americans could feel a little bit safer.

title: LOW LIFE, HIGH LIFE
TENNSTEDT- A GERMAN SYMPHONIC SPECIALIST
description: Philadelphia's Academy of Music, with its genteel red plush and intimate horseshoe configuration, seems to breathe the solidity and traditionalism of the city's concert life. And the other day, the music filling that venerable hall breathed with traditionalism, as well. The occasion was the final rehearsal of Beethoven's Symphony No. 5 before the first subscription concert of the week that night by the Philadelphia Orchestra. The music purred with the sort of assured grandeur in which the Philadephians have specilalized for decades.

title:
Stamps;
NEW MAGAZINE ARRIVES
description: A new stamp magazine, the first new publication for collectors to come along in years, has just made its debut. In a philatelic ''first,'' it is to be sold at newstands alongside the mass-media monthlies, as well as by subscription.

title: Europeans Demonstrate Against NATO Missiles
description: About 15,000 people demonstrated peacefully today against North Atlantic Treaty Organization plans to deploy new nuclear missiles in Europe.

title: Drug Tips Scales For Heart Patients
description: Of the 1.5 million Americans who suffered heart attacks last year, about 40 percent died three or four weeks later. Among those who survived, 10 percent died of a subsequent attack sometime during the next two years of recovery.

title: Votes in Congress; Last Week's Tally for the Metropolitan Area
description: Senate

title: A Familiar Brand; Of Ugandan Terror
description: Idi Amin, the deposed dictator who liquidated 500,000 Ugandans during an eight-year reign of terror, was said last week to have learned his methods while serving Milton Obote, the President he ousted. Now Mr. Obote has returned to the presidency and the pattern of violence is being repeated.

title: NEW IMPETUS FOR CONRAIL TAKEOVER
description: THE possibility that Conrail will no longer be the operator of the New Haven-to-New York commuter railroad in July 1982 - a change that would come about if a proposal advanced last week by the United States Railway Association were to be adopted by Congress - has caused transportation agencies in Connecticut and New York to consider taking over the line.

title: DODGERS ARE STRONG TOO
description: This National League preview was prepared by Joseph Durso and appears in predicted order of finish with the Mets fighting the St. Louis Cardinals for fourth place in the east. EASTERN DIVISION Montreal Expos

title: Television Week
description: Guide

title: MEETING THE DEMAND FOR QUALITY IN DISKS
description: Pessimists looking for a patron saint might as well pick Sir Thomas Gresham, the 16th-century granddaddy of all economists, who worked out a theory that things invariably go from bad to worse. Specifically, Gresham argued that an inferior coinage (or commodity) tends to drive out the better. No doubt he would be confounded by current developments in the record business, where exactly the opposite seems to be happening. Record companies everywhere are upgrading production standards to meet rising demands for higher quality.

title: McGlynn Is Criticized For Silence on Energy
description: In an Opinion Page article on March 22, Richard McGlynn, a Republican candidate for Governor, made a number of observations about the economy of New Jersey. He listed a series of recommendations, all culled from reports, studies and articles initiated by other people.

title: Amy Wane Is Married
description: The marriage of Amy Wane, daughter of Seymour L. Wane of Short Hills, N.J., and the late Marion G. Wane, to Peter David Meltzer took place yesterday at Harkness House.

title: U.S. MILITARY LINKS WORRYING SPANIARDS
description: Almost every week, Fernando Tejedor Martin, the Socialist Mayor of this whitewashed seaside town, cordially receives newly arrived United States Navy personnel assigned to the big base at the end of Rota's main street.

title: IS SCHMIDT BORN AGAIN AS A COLD WARRIOR?
description: Note to Messrs. Richard V. Allen and Alexander M. Haig Jr.: There's a voice on the Rhine, muffled somewhat these days by river mists and the thickening haze of Bonn politics, that is offering a bit of intellectual fellowship.

title: JOSEPH P. SALERNO
description: Joseph P. Salerno, an architect, died of a heart attack Friday in Norwalk, Conn., Hospital. He was 66 years old and a resident of Weston, Conn.

title: 22 Food Establishments Fail Sanitary Inspection
description: The New York City Department of Health cited 22 food establishments as having violated the health code. It also named five others that had corrected earlier violations.

title: Critics' Choices
description: Opera Ordinarily, one would not think the Brecht-Weill ''Rise and Fall of the City of Mahagonny'' would need recommending in the first place. This was one of the most highly acclaimed productions last season at the Metropolitan Opera, after all, and its first viewing this year showed it to be as mordantly witty, astringent and, ultimately, impassioned as ever.

title: TREASURER SAID TO SIT ON WILDLIFE MEASURE
description: TRENTON A CONFRONTATION has developed between the Byrne administration and environmentalists over legislation that would provide some $500,000 a year for wildlife protection and management.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Confidence on the Rise

title: Public Housing Termed
description: In Grave Fiscal Danger

title: BELGRADE SEES PERIL OF MINORITY UNREST
description: Yugoslav Government and Communist Party leaders have voiced apprehension that other national minorities may stage anti-Government demonstrations following the rioting by Albanian nationalists in Kosovo Province.

title: A Fire Causes Damage IN PARK AVE. SKYSCRAPER; In Park Ave. Skyscraper
description: A two-alarm fire caused extensive smoke damage to the the upper floors of a Park Avenue skycraper early this morning, the Fire Department said.

title: Bridge: Most of the Seeded Teams Survive in Grand Nationals
description: The district quarterfinal stage of the Grand National team championship was played at the Vanderbilt Club, Manhasset, L.I., yesterday with almost all the top-ranked teams in contention.

title: ELLEN SEEHERMAN AND STUART SLOAME, LAWYERS, MARRIED
description: Ellen J. Seeherman and Stuart Charles Sloame, New York lawyers, were married yesterday at Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein performed the ceremony.

title: U.S. Pioneer Split Yields 2 Account Assignments
description: U.S. Pioneer Electronics has split into two companies, one for video products and the other for audio, and has decided to divide its agency assignments the same way.

title: 31 ON BALLOT TOMORROW FOR HOUSE SEAT IN MARYLAND
description: Until Gladys Noon Spellman fell ill five months ago, the energetic career politician seemed to have a lock on Maryland's Fifth Congressional District, the most politically turbid suburb of Washington.

title: CONVERTING FUEL, NOT REPLACING IT, IS FOCUS OF STUDY
description: A research group's findings that the United States could eliminate oil imports by improving energy efficiency have stirred considerable debate.

title: L.I. Man Found Slain
description: A 32-year-old man was found stabbed to death early yesterday on the walkway next to the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive at 63d Street, the police reported.

title: Iran Says It Destroyed Iraqi Bombers in Raid
description: Iran's Defense Minister, providing details on an announcement yesterday, said today that eight Iranian aircraft had destroyed a number of Soviet-built TU-22 long-range bombers and some long-range fighters at the Iraqi base of Haj Sen near the Jordanian border. He said the raid had been carried out to demonstrate that no part of Iraq was safe from Iran's air force.

title: New Florida Magazine To be Published in July
description: New Florida will be that sunny state's first magazine when it begins monthly publication in July, with Arthur R. Murphy, 65-yearold former publisher of McCall's and Sports Illustrated, publisher once again.

title: LEARY EARNS A PLACE ON METS ROSTER AND WILL FACE CUBS SUNDAY
description: Tim Leary, perhaps the most acclaimed rookie in spring training, won his first job in the big leagues today when the New York Mets promoted him and announced that he would pitch the third game of the season.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Art People column in Weekend on Friday incorrectly reported the time of a scheduled memorial service for the art dealer Julien Levy at the Cooper Union, Eighth Street and Astor Place. It will be held at 4 P.M. on Friday, April 24.

title: FOR BOB LANIER, A TOUGH SEASON
description: MILWAUKEE LINGERING near the foul line, Bob Lanier had vaguely heard his name being called. The Milwaukee Bucks' center - a striking, bearded man, 6 feet 11 inches tall, broad as Buddha - looked up.

title: Chloraseptic Assignment
description: Henderson Advertising has done it again. The pride of Greenville, S. C., which already had an unnamed assignment from Norwich-Eaton Pharmaceutical, has just picked up Chloraseptic mouthwash, gargle and lozenges, with billings of around $5 million.

title: PAPER ON THOMAS WOLFE STIRS DEBATE ON SCHOLARSHIP VS. PRIVACY
description: THE sedate world of academic research and publication has been rocked by a controversy growing out of an iconoclastic article about the novelist Thomas Wolfe in The Yale Review. The article was written by John Halberstadt, a Yale graduate who was subsequently barred from Harvard University's Houghton Library for publishing the article without permission of the library and the copyright owner of the Wolfe papers.

title: U.S. Mortgage Levels Decline
description: The value of new long-term mortgages originated in January fell 28 percent from the same month a year earlier, the Department of Housing and Urban Development reported Friday in a new measure of the nation's housing slump.

title: Canada Gas Reserves Fall
description: Canada's natural gas reserves declined in 1980 for the first time since 1972, a report by the Canadian Petroleum Association said Friday.

title: Marshall Fund Gets a New President
description: Frank H. Loy, a lawyer with wide experience in business and government, takes over today as president of the German Marshall Fund of the United States, an American-controlled foundation established in 1972 by the West German government in appreciation of American Marshall Plan aid to Europe after World War II.

title: Marchers Re-enact Start Of a 1965 Rights Effort
description: About 5,000 demonstrators singing ''We Shall Overcome'' marched across the Edmund Pettus Bridge today in a re-enactment of the beginning of the 1965 Selma-to-Montgomery march led by Martin Luther King Jr.

title: FIGHTING DECAY, AND EACH OTHER
description: An outsized mouthful of pearly white teeth gleams from the magazine page. ''Introducing Advanced Formula Crest,'' the advertisement declares. ''Now, get fewer cavities with Crest than you ever got before.''

title: BREZHNEV HAS TALKS IN PRAGUE AS CRISIS ON POLAND DEEPENS
description: Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, flew to Prague today amid intense speculation here and in Eastern Europe that a decision by Moscow on whether to intervene in Poland would come in the next few days.

title: Opening Day Then or Now
description: The good time is approaching, The season is at hand When the merry click of the two-base lick Will be heard throughout the land. The frost still lingers on the earth, and Budless are the trees. But the merry ring of the voice of spring Is borne upon the breeze. THE ode to opening day appeared in the original issue of The Sporting News in 1886, a yellowed copy of which has been unearthed by baseball anthropologists dedicated to the proposition that the more things change, the more they remain the same. As proof, consider this excerpt from the lead story:

title: Victory for Ocleppo
description: Unseeded Gianni Ocleppo of Italy won his first Grand Prix tournament by beating Mark Edmondson of Australia, 7-5, 6-1, in the final today.

title: JULY FARE RISE CALLED LIKELY BY AIDE, BUT KOCH RESISTS IT
description: A top City Hall official acknowledged for the first time yesterday that a fare increase on the city's subways and buses in July was virtually inevitable.

title: U.S. AND SOVIET STUDY COMPROMISE IN MADRID TALKS
description: A 30-page compromise document drafted by eight neutral European nations has been received with a cautious welcome from the United States and the Soviet Union at the Madrid conference on detente and human rights.

title: Patriarca Leaves Hospital
description: Raymond L.S. Patriarca, reputed to be a major figure in organized crime, was discharged from Miriam Hospital today, a week after he lay on a stretcher in a courtroom to plead not guilty to a charge of accessory to murder. The state police said that Mr. Patriarca, 73 years old, returned home after his release from the hospital, where he was treated for heart disease. He faces a hearing Thursday on his ability to stand trial.

title: PROUD APPEAL-CURE THE BLUES RIVALRY HEADS FOR WOOD MEMORIAL
description: Only moments after the official sign had been posted to certify Proud Appeal's nose victory over Cure the Blues in the Gotham Stakes yesterday at Aqueduct, connections for both colts were speculating about a rematch, and their supporters were bandying about the names of Affirmed and Alydar to characterize the opening episode of what promises to be a remarkable rivalry between two fast, evenly matched colts.

title: Panel Is Appointed On Yacht Inquiry
description: The Board of Directors of the United States Yacht Racing Union met yesterday and appointed a three-man panel to conduct an inquiry into alleged irregularities relating to the handicap ratings of Acadia and Williwaw, two of the country's foremost offshore racing yachts.

title: Mrs. Lloyd Triumphs in Coast Final, 6-4, 6-3
description: Chris Evert Lloyd broke Hana Mandlikova's service in the ninth game of the first set and went on to a 6-4, 6-3 victory today in the final of the $200,000 Clairol Crown tennis tournament at La Costa.

title: TV: 4-EPISODE 'PVT. BENJAMIN
description: EVEN without Goldie Hawn, ''Private Benjamin,'' the television show, looks and feels a lot like ''Private Benjamin,'' the movie. This television version, which will be shown tonight at 8 o'clock on NBC, features a couple of the film's key actors and duplicates much of its mood. The movie's wit was more offbeat, and its jokes seemed a good deal funnier. Still, this is a creditable imitation.

title: LESLEY A. KALMANS MARRIED TO ROBERT CHARLES BERNSTEIN
description: Lesley Ann Kalmans, daughter of Mrs. Robert Rothschild of Roslyn Heights, L.I., and Murray Kalmans of Rego Park, Queens, was married yesterday to Robert Charles Bernstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Bernstein also of Roslyn Heights.

title: VIVIAN JACOBS
description: Vivian Jacobs, a writer and poet, died Saturday at St. Barnabas Medical Center in Livingston, N.J. after a long illness.

title: DEBORAH PARNES, STORE BUYER, IS MARRIED TO LESLIE MARGULIES
description: Deborah Parnes, daughter of Abraham D. Parnes of Perth Amboy, N.J., and the late Frieda Parnes, was married yesterday at the Lincoln Square Synagogue to Leslie Margulies, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Manuel Margulies of Philadelphia.

title: CENSUS INDICATES A SHARP DECLINE IN WHITES IN CITY
description: The final 1980 Census Bureau figures for New York City show a sharp decline in the city's white population, a moderate rise in blacks and a substantial increase in Hispanic people.

title: THE CRAZY AMERICANS
description: From the time news broke about the shooting of President Reagan, people have been coming up to me and shaking their heads in sympathy. I happened to be in London on the day of the attack, and I've found reaction to the crime one thing the quarreling British and French agree on now.

title: 4McHale Impressive as Celtics Beat Bulls, 121-109, in Series Opener
description: Kevin McHale, playing more like a veteran than a rookie today in his first National Basketball Association playoff game, sparked the Celtics to a 121-109 victory over the Chicago Bulls at Boston Garden.

title: ALTERING MONEY DATA WILL NOT END DEBATE
description: Many credit market analysts say that interest rates might fluctuate less if the Federal Reserve adopts proposals to alter the way it discloses money supply data.

title: CYNTHIA MAC VICKER WED TO MICHAEL KENNETH WALL
description: Cynthia Ann Mac Vicker of Pembroke, Bermuda, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Warren Harding Mac Vicker of Warren, N.J., and Michael Kenneth Wall, also of Pembroke, son of Mrs. Peter Waterson of Bayleys Bay, Bermuda, were married yesterday in of Our Lady of the Mount Roman Catholic Church in Warren by Msgr. Richard Behl.

title: By Jim Benagh
description: Sports World Specials The Ultimate Musher

title: RANGERS BEAT FLYERS, WILL PLAY THE KINGS
description: The Rangers defeated the Flyers, 2-0, at The Spectrum tonight in their final game of the regular season. New York will face the Kings at Los Angeles for the first two games of the three-of-five-game opening round of the playoffs, beginning Wednesday. The third game, and a fourth if necessary, will be played at Madison Square Garden next Saturday and Sunday.

title: No Headline
description: Law enforcement officials here said early this morning that they had been seeking the former president of a New York City construction company and his woman companion, a dancer, who were found murdered in Kenosha, Wis., on March 18. The officials said that the murder victims, William Henry Callahan and Wendy McDade, were sought in connection with a million dollar embezzlement of the Arc Electrical Construction Company at 739 Second Avenue last year.

title: RUSH OF BORROWERS LEADS TO BUSY BOND SCHEDULE
description: The volume of new corporate bond issues is expected to increase to more than $1.6 billion this week from about $1 billion last week. At Salomon Brothers, analysts estimate that corporate debt issues this month, including about $400 million of convertible issues, might total $4 billion, the greatest volume since last July.

title: Mexico Cuts Oil Price
description: Mexico's national oil monopoly, Pemex, said Friday that it is cutting the price of its Maya-grade crude oil to $32 from $34.50 a barrel because of world surpluses and increased production by Iran and Iraq.

title: LILCO CUSTOMERS TO GET LOWER BILLS IN APRIL
description: Electricity customers are getting a reduction in their April bills from the Long Island Lighting Company, the utility said yesterday. This is attributable in part to the relatively mild weather last month, and also to Lilco's success in buying electricity that was not produced by burning oil.

title: Judicial Discretion, Mayoral Indiscretion
description: When he's talking about the judiciary, instead of berating some individual judge, New York's Mayor Koch often makes good sense. In now asking the Legislature to permit appeals of criminal sentences by the prosecution as well as the defense, Mr. Koch puts an important item on the state agenda.

title: MOST-WANTED TERRORIST FALLS INTO ITALIAN POLICE NET
description: The arrest of Mario Moretti, the most senior known leader of the Red Brigades terrorist organization and the one presumed to be the most dangerous, is regarded among the most important successes scored by the Italian police against the terrorists in several years.

title: EMOTIONAL INJURY IN ASSAULTS ASSESSED
description: Although no one can predict President Reagan's long-term psychological reaction to being wounded by an attacker's bullet, psychiatrists and psychologists say the emotional consequences of a shooting injury often linger.

title: Angolans Plan to Open An Embassy in London
description: Angola is opening an embassy in London for the first time, a Foreign Office spokesman said today.

title: Blacks in South Africa Town Riot Over Increase in Rent
description: Blacks in Tembisa township rioted today over a rent increase and the police broke up the disturbance with tear gas, authorities said.

title: PARIS FALL SHOW OPEN WITH THREE WINNERS
description: Three masterful collections over the weekend got the fall and winter fashion openings off to a strong start. Karl Lagerfeld of Chloe proved his superb command of the dressmaking craft with clothes that were the direct opposite of the sexy, skimpy shapes he had been toying with for the last few years.

title: A Would-Be New Yorker Tries to Settle In
description: Now that Harry Crosby has finally gotten settled in his Manhattan Plaza apartment, it's a good bet he'll be going away on a long trip. ''As soon as I signed the lease last June,'' he said the other day, ''I got two projects that took me away on location and it was months before I got any furniture.''

title: 11 REGIONAL FINALISTS GET CHANCE TO SING AT THE MET
description: Sometimes the prospect of hearing young, unknown singers display their talents can be as tantalizing as a concert given by established stars - there is always the promise of discovering an exceptional voice at the start of a big career. That possibility was held out at the Metropolitan Opera House yesterday afternoon when 11 aspiring young artists stepped onstage, surrounded by the lush second-act set of the Met's ''Manon Lescaut,'' to sing a concert of arias and duets.

title: Cubans in Miami Celebrate
description: About 300 Cuban immigrants, many of them recent arrivals, turned out last night to celebrate the first anniversary of the takeover of the Peruvian Embassy in Havana, a siege that led to the boatlift that carried 125,000 refugees to South Florida.

title: FOR TOYOTA, DETROIT AID IS U.S. JOB
description: The Toyota Motor Company wants the United States Government and Detroit to decide on specific ways to rejuvenate the American auto industry before asking the Japanese auto makers to take any steps to help, according to Shigenobu Yamamoto, executive vice president of Toyota.

title: NEW YORK CITY STILL STATE'S POWER SEAT
description: Despite New York City's loss of population and charges that its population had been undercounted in the recent census, the city continues to have a larger population than the 53 upstate counties, according to newly compiled census figures. And there also continue to be more people living in the city than there in all of suburban Westchester, Rockland, Nassau and Suffolk Counties, the figures showed.

title: Ski Lift Derails at Coast Resort; A Dozen People Are Hurt in Falls
description: A ski lift at a South Lake Tahoe resort derailed today, injuring a dozen people who fell to the snow from heights of 20 to 50 feet, El Dorado County authorities said.

title: Philipp Brothers Change
description: Hal H. Beretz, 45, who will become president and chief operating officer of the Philipp Brothers Corporation when the giant commodity trading and marketing company becomes an independent concern, anticipates that conditions in his field will improve before too long.

title: Mosconi Moving To Dickison Shop
description: Roger P. Mosconi, one of the people largely responsible for the Mean Joe Greene Coca-Cola commercial, the most honored TV spot last year, is moving from McCann-Erickson, where he was a senior vice president and associate creative director, to join Dickison & Rakaseder in Westport, Conn., as executive vice president, cocreative director and principal.

title: JIM KAAT PROVING HIS THEORIES ABOUT BASEBALL ARE TIMELESS
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. WHILE the other St. Louis Cardinal pitchers are in the outfield at Al Lang Stadium, toiling through their daily sprints, Jim Kaat calmly throws in the bullpen. Now, Jim Kaat isn't against running, especially when he's late for a bus, but he doesn't believe in running as a form of conditioning for pitchers.

title: Indian Leftists Fight Foes In 2 Marxist-Run States
description: Leftists battled opponents today in two Marxist-governed states in India. The press agency United News of India said one person was killed, raising the death toll during a week of clashes to 25.

title: New Orleans Backers Given Deadline for Fair Funds
description: The city must raise $12 million to $13 million by Wednesday or lose the 1984 World's Fair, Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige said.

title: Rockets Win, 89-86, and Eliminate Lakers in Playoffs
description: Magic Johnson reached into his bag of tricks and came up with air today - an ''air ball'' that never reached the basket with five seconds left - as his Los Angeles Lakers, the defending National Basketball Association champions, were eliminated by the Houston Rockets, 89-86.

title: HOW TO FIND SCHOOL PRINCIPALS
description: Amateur psychologist. Morale booster. Referee. And, yes, occasionally educator. To be the principal of an urban public school is now so taxing that the post can no longer be filled by conventional means. Yet a debate persists in New York City, and probably elsewhere, over whether to choose principals by merit examination or by some less formal method. Whatever methods worked in the past, clearly the key to success now is flexibility.

title: SPREAD OF POLLUTION FEARED IN WELLS AROUND NEW YORK
description: In the last three years, more than 600 ground water wells have been closed in the New York metropolitan area because of contamination by chemicals, and public health and environmental officials fear that thousands more may be jeopardized in coming years.

title: POLICE SEEK 2 GUNMEN WHO SHOT TEEN-AGERS IN A ROBBERY IN BRONX
description: Detectives said yesterday that they were still seeking suspects in the killing of one teen-age girl and the wounding of another during a robbery at a fast-food restaurant in the Bronx early Saturday.

title: CURE THE BLUES LOSES TO PROUD APPEAL
description: Proud Appeal outlasted Cure the Blues for a nose victory at Aqueduct yesterday in the $83,400 Gotham, ending the unbeaten streak of one of the early Kentucky Derby favorites.

title: TV: TWAIN'S CIVIL WAR
description: ''THE Private History of a Campaign That Failed,'' on WNET-TV, Channel 13, tonight at 8, continues a series of Mark Twain adaptations that began with ''Life on the Mississippi'' and, once again, the fiction has some autobiographical roots.

title: 21,000 SOLDIERS IN MOCK WARFARE ALONG TEXAS-NEW MEXICO BORDER
description: New Mexico border.

title: News Analysis
description: Why the Legislature was ordered back to Albany in special session to act on bills that did not exist - a question many legislators asked this weekend - has less to do with the Governor than with the Assembly

title: Greensboro Playoff to Nelson
description: Larry Nelson holed out from a bunker on the final hole of regulation play to force a playoff with Mark Hayes, then won the Greater Greensboro open golf tournament today with a birdie on the second hole of the sudden-death playoff.

title: REAGAN CUTS CALLED HARMFUL TO ELDERLY
description: Despite contrary assertions, Congressional experts on aging have concluded that President Reagan's budget proposals will ''dramatically'' reduce health, nutrition, housing, legal and social services now available to millions of older people.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt MAKING SCENES. A Personal History of the Turbulent Years at Yale, 1966-79. By Robert Brustein. 341 pages. Illustrated. Random House. $15.

title: 'TWO ADMIRALS FOR EVERY THREE SHIPS'
description: To the Editor:

title: FATHERS GET POSTPARTUM BLUES, TOO
description: For Long, it has been one of the less enchanting aspects of child birth - afterward, many women suffer from some form of postpartum blues or depression, ranging from a brief bout with what doctors have called ''the weepies,'' up to more serious episodes that can require clinical treatment. Now, however, new evidence shows that men, too, can suffer from postpartum depression.

title: LETTER IN BOTTLE RECALLS LOST CHAPTER IN ARCTIC EXPLORATION
description: Almost exactly a century ago, on Sept. 29, 1881, the U.S.S. Rodgers anchored at Herald Island, a rocky bit of Arctic land off northeast Siberia, and sent a landing party ashore.

title: ADDING FUEL TO THE GARBAGE-BURNING ISSUE
description: To the Editor:

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Peking Police Break Up A Protest by Dissidents
description: Outlawed activists threw free-speech leaflets into the air today as more than 2,000 people paid homage to revolutionary heroes on the traditional Chinese day for mourning the dead.

title: 26 IN STAGE HALL OF FAME
description: Twenty-six men and women ''who have contributed to the heritage of the American theater,'' were inducted into the Theater Hall of Fame last night at the Uris Theater in a program entitled, ''A Tribute to Broadway.''
