title: DANCE: A NEW SOKOLOW OPENS JULLIARD ANNUAL
description: THE Juilliard Dance Ensemble's annual performances are always an event to welcome, simply because of the high professional level of dancing and a varied repertory, which includes works by major choreographers.

title: MINERS SAY THEY REJECTED COAL PACT IN ORDER TO SAVE THEIR UNION
description: John Erazmus watched as a heavily laden coal barge struggled against the Ohio River's southbound current, and the sight seemed to take some of the boom out of his voice.

title: U.S. SAYS NORTH CAROLINA SEEKS BOXING FIGURE'S ARREST
description: A new mystery involving Harold J. Smith, the boxing promoter who disappeared in January amid charges that he had helped defraud Wells Fargo National Bank of $21.3 million, emerged today when Federal agents disclosed that North Carolina authorities had notified them that they want to arrest Mr. Smith.

title: Inmate Held in Two Killings Said to Have Feared Beating
description: A convict accused of drowning a state prison warden and fatally shooting the manager of the prison's farm apparently feared he was going to be beaten for breaking a rule, an unidentified deputy told The Dallas Morning News today.

title: WITH MASTER NEAR, WATSON IS WQORKING OVER THE ROUGH SPOTS
description: THE sixth fairway of the Harbour Town Golf Links in Hilton Head, S.C., is uncharacteristic of the course, being wide and hospitable. Yet in the final round of the Heritage Classic there last week, Tom Watson pushed his drive so far right, into a mess of brush, palmetto and pines, that it was presumed lost or out of bounds.

title: Chandler Keeps Title On 15-Round Draw
description: Jeff Chandler of Philadelphia retained his World Boxing Association bantamweight title today, fighting Eijiro Murata of Japan to a draw in a 15-round championship bout at the Kuramae Sumo Hall.

title: TALKING ABOUT LOVE, FOR THE RECORD
description: One day Wendy Clarke began talking to herself on television, ''mostly about love, my elation with it, my problems with it, using myself as an arts resource,'' she said. Soon she became obsessed by the notion of getting everyone in the world, if possible, talking about love on videotape.

title: Military Analysis
description: The Soviet military is believed to be concerned about Poland's increasing independence because of the country's central importance to overall Soviet strategy in Europe, according to Western military analysts. The analysts believe that Marshal Viktor G. Kulikov, the commander in chief of Warsaw Pact forces and the former Soviet chief of staff, supported by leaders of the navy and air force, has been leading the campaign to persuade Leonid I. Brezhnev, the party leader and President, to intervene in Poland.

title: Market Place; Putting Assets To Better Use
description: LAST Wednesday, when the American Can Company disclosed plans to sell its paper and forest-products operations to raise cash for new business ventures, the announcement proved a tonic for the company's long-languishing stock. As the day's most active issue on the New York Stock Exchange, American Can jumped 4 7/8 points, to 43 3/4.

title: Commission Weighs Ban of Diesel Taxis
description: Jay L. Turoff, the chairman of the city's Taxi and Limousine Commission, said the commission might have to ''call a moratorium'' on the use of diesel taxis, which, he said, yielded high gas mileage but polluted the air.

title: AFRICAN SCENES: 'GHOSTLY' RAIDS TO CHINESE AID
description: A dozen Angolan soldiers, AK-47 assault rifles at the ready, dogged every step taken last week by a group of reporters looking at a refugee camp in Angola's east central province of Moxico. The soldiers' presence belied an official myth.

title: SADAT SAID TO AGREE TO G.I.'S IN SINAI UNIT
description: President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt was reported today to have cleared the way for the presence of American troops in a contemplated peacekeeping force between Israel and Egypt.

title: Visiting Prince Keeps His Balance
description: Britain's most famous horseman managed to stay on his horse this weekend, something he has not been able to do in his last two public outings. This time it was polo, not steeplechasing, and Prince Charles not only kept his seat on Saturday, but even helped his team to a 9-4 victory in a special match at Auckland, New Zealand.

title: SHUTTLE COUNTDOWN STARTS ON TIME AFTER PROBLEM WITH VALVE IS SOLVED
description: A short-circuited valve wire threatened to interrupt work on the space shuttle Columbia today, but space agency engineers found a way to bypass the problem and the countdown for the first flight of the space shuttle Columbia began on schedule at 11:30 tonight.

title: Thais Put 100 Rebel Officers In 'Temporary Detention'
description: More than 100 officers involved in a 56-hour coup attempt against the Thai Government were under ''temporary detention,'' military sources said today.

title: GULLIKSON PULLS OUT
description: MILWAUKEE (AP) -- The professional tennis player Tim Gullikson, who had been seeded second in the South African open tennis tournament that began today, decided to pass it up.

title: SUSAN RICKA SREIN WED TO KENNETH S. ABRAHAM
description: The marriage of Susan RickaStein, curator of the prints and drawings collection at the American Instutute of Architects Foundation in Washington, to Kenneth Samuel Abraham, an associate professor of law at the University of Maryland, took place yesterday. Rabbi Howard Herman performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Alan S. Stein, parents of the bride, in Jenkintown, Pa.

title: Fair Grounds Ends Discordant Meeting
description: The Fair Grounds closed its 110th season today, but the aftermath of allegations of illegal medication and fixed races will probably continue to swirl.

title: Cutting the Wrong Health Care
description: Medicare provides the elderly with help in paying medical bills. Medicaid does the same for the poor. As a group, the elderly carry considerable political weight. The poor, as a group, do not. The Reagan Administration, ever clear about such matters, chooses in its budget-cutting drive to limit funds for Medicaid. It chooses to leave Medicare alone.

title: Tradition Reigns at Bittersweet Celebration
description: It was a celebration tinged with sadness last night when Melvyn Douglas and two dozen of his friends and relatives marked the actor's 80th birthday at a 12-course Chinese banquet at Manhattan's Flower Drum restaurant.

title: Navy Discloses Large PCB Spill At an Abandoned Missile Facility
description: The Navy has disclosed that up to one ton of the caustic chemical PCB leaked when thieves broke into an abandoned Atlas missile test facility.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''This is a switch.'' - Vernon E. Jordan Jr. of the National Urban League visiting Ronald Reagan, who had called on him when he was recuperating from a gunshot wound.

title: State to Hear Appeal On 2 School Closings
description: Community School Board 26 in northeastern Queens, ordered by Chancellor Frank J. Macchiarola to close two of its ''underutilized'' elementary schools in June, has appealed the decision to the State Commissioner of Education, according to Jack Como, chairman of the local board.

title: by T. H. Watkins
description: No one needs to be told that we are in a terrible mess, our economy in tatters, our international prestige dim, our diplomatic position vis-a-vis the Soviet Union a pitiful thing indeed. The situation is so bad, in fact, that there are those who say we may have problems for which there are no solutions.

title: Dollar Slips in Tokyo
description: The dollar declined slightly against the yen today, opening on the Tokyo exchange at 213.30 yen. It had closed at 213.65 Friday. Trading was quiet.

title: NEW GENERATION OF ASTRONAUTS POISED FOR SHUTTLE ERA
description: It is supposed to happen this way: Shortly before 1 P.M. next Sunday, 20 years to the day after Russia's Yuri Gagarin became the first human being to fly in space, the most technologically elegant spacecraft ever built will come hurtling down out of earth orbit.

title: No Headline
description: ''They never laid a glove on us,'' was William G. Hundley's chipper response when Richard A. Williams, the key witness in the mail fraud and extortion trial of Joseph M. Margiotta, finished his direct testimony Friday afternoon.

title: ANALYSTS WAITING TO SEE IF GENENTECH HOLDS LEAD
description: Nearly six months after Genentech Inc. jolted Wall Street with one of the most volatile public stock offerings in memory, the company is assessed cautiously by analysts of the emerging field of genetic engineering.

title: Mumphrey Cautious About Role as Yankee
description: Jerry Mumphrey has had a valuable introduction to life on George Steinbrenner's Yankees, arriving the day after the team tried to trade Jim Spencer to Pittsburgh for Jason Thompson and watching quietly as the deal fell through. ''That could have been me,'' Mumphrey said.

title: SURGE IN BUILDING OF OFFICES BRINGS 'MIXED BLESSING'
description: Forty thousand additional office workers - and thousands more who will vie to sell them everything from carnations to quiche - are expected to begin to pour into the east midtown area of New York City in the next two years as a result of the flurry of new construction in the area.

title: EDITORS TELL WHY VOTES ON BUDGET GOT LITTLE SPACE
description: In forcing roll-call votes Thursday on two dozen amendments in an unsuccessful effort to protect programs such as food stamps, education and unemployment benefits, Democratic senators said they were ''building a record'' that would encourage voters to protest the Reagan Administration's proposed budget cuts.

title: Baseball's Barnum
description: Ron Fraser has been the baseball coach at the University of Miami since 1963, but he became concerned in the past few years when his sport and the other so-called minor sports faced elimination for cost reasons at some colleges.

title: Mormon Church Elder Calls Homosexuality an Addiction
description: Homosexuality is ''an acquired addiction,'' like drugs and alcohol, and would not be so pervasive if children had happy home lives, a Mormon official said today.

title: M-G-M Film Net Rises 5.9%
description: The Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Film Company said Friday that its earnings rose 5.9 percent, to $3.6 million, in the second quarter of its current fiscal year as revenues climbed 54.3 percent, to $62.8 million, from $40.7 million in the similar period the previous year.

title: PHYSICIAN SAYS REPORTS ON REAGAN WERE OPTIMISTIC BUT HID NOTHING
description: Dr. Dennis S. O'Leary, who has been the principal medical spokesman about President Reagan's emergency surgery and recuperation since he was shot on Monday, said today that ''nothing of significance'' had been concealed from the public although his reports had been ''as upbeat as possible without damaging my credibility.''

title: Mother, 19, Slain, Infant Is Missing
description: The police were investigating the mysterious disappearance of a two-month-old girl and the murder of her 19-year-old mother. The mother, Yudelka Maldonado, was found strangled ''for no apparent reason'' in Brooklyn Saturday, about eight hours after her husband dropped her off at the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center in Manhattan with their sick child, the police said.

title: A Well-Dressed Badger With a Busy Schedule
description: Please don't bother the badger. It's only James Billings, the opera star, who plans to be wearing his bulky badger costume on the streets of New York today.

title: Rodgers Wins Again
description: Bill Rodgers won the 10-mile Cherry Blossom race for the fourth time today, completing the run against gusty winds in 47 minutes 14 seconds. Greg Fredericks, an Olympic team member, finished second in 47:24, followed by another Olympian, John Gregorek of Georgetown University, in 47:34. Winds blew up to 35 miles per hour, with the runners going into the gusts for the first seven miles and being pushed by them for the last three.

title: Squires Victor Again
description: Pete Squires of the New York Athletic Club won his second race in two days by capturing the 12th annual Scarsdale 15-kilometer run this afternoon in 47 minutes 31 seconds. Squires, a 30-year-old former all-American at Manhattan College, registered a 175-yard victory over Steve Heinbockel of the Westchester Road Runners, who was clocked in 47:59. Kathy McIntyre, unattached, of New York, captured the women's title in 56:30 over the 9.3-mile course.

title: January Tops Ford in Playoff
description: After Arnold Palmer's game collapsed on the back nine today, Don January went on to defeat Doug Ford on the first hole of sudden death to win the $125,000 Michelob Seniors Classic, the first event of the 1981 Professional Golfers' Association seniors tour.

title: Miss Kirkland and Bissell May Rejoin Ballet Theater
description: The possibility that Gelsey Kirkland and Patrick Bissell, who were dismissed last December by American Ballet Theater, might be rehired shortly by the company was confirmed yesterday by a Ballet Theater spokesman.

title: U.S. LIMIT ON MEDICAID WOULD SHIFT BURDEN TO STATES
description: At the close of a long Congressional debate in 1965 over a bill assuring medical care for the aged, a hastily written measure was tacked on to deal with health care for the poor. The legislative ''sleeper'' was quickly approved.

title: Walker of Georgia Will Listen to C.F.L.
description: Herschel Walker, the all-America tailback of national champion Georgia, says he's ''got to listen'' if the Canadian Football League's Montreal Alouettes make him an offer to turn professional.

title: Mrs. Kirkpatrick Says U.S. Seeks To 'Preserve' Options on Poland
description: The chief United States delegate to the United Nations, Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, said in a television interview today that the United States was ''trying to preserve our options'' in the Polish situation.

title: Oil Futures Market to Open
description: An oil futures market will open here tomorrow to offer protection to the oil trade against sharp price movements and to bring new business to London brokers.

title: MEXICO'S ECONOMIC IMBALANCES
description: A full-page advertisement for a jewelry sale in San Antonio looked strangely out of place in the pages of the Mexico City daily, Excelsior, a few days ago. But the Joske Department Store had made no mistake: its largest clientele is Mexican.

title: Byrd Sees a Need to Alter Rules On Succession to the Presidency
description: Robert C. Byrd, the Senate minority leader, said yesterday that the shooting of President Reagan showed that there were ''holes that need to be plugged'' in the constitutional amendment dealing with Presidential disability and succession.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, APRIL 6, 1981
description: International Leonid I. Brezhnev flew to Prague to attend a meeting of the Czechoslovak Communist Party. Soon after his arrival the Soviet leader and Gustav Husak, the Czechoslovak party chief, met for talks. Mr. Brezhnev's trip comes amid speculation in Moscow and Eastern Europe that a Soviet decision to move on Poland will be made in the next few days. Meanwhile, East Germany's official press agency reported that thousands of fresh troops had joined the extended Warsaw Pact maneuvers. (Page A1, Column 6.) President Reagan sent a message to Leonid I. Brezhnev, expressing extreme concern over the Soviet threat to Poland, according to an American official. The the President was said to have used ''strong language.'' (A10:1-2.)

title: WHAT ENTITLEMENT IS
description: To the Editor:

title: Wienerwald Entrepreneur's Empire Grows
description: Friedrich Jahn, a 57-year-old Austrian who opened his first restaurant in 1955, built a worldwide chain of Wienerwald restaurants over the next 25 years. Now his empire is about to get bigger, following an agreement last week by his Wienerwald Holding, a private Swiss company, to acquire the IHOP Corporation, the publicly owned parent of the International House of Pancakes, for $2.60 a share.

title: Iran Cites Need For Fuel Imports
description: Iran's production of refined oil products has been cut 60 to 65 percent because of the war with Iraq, and Iran now must import diesel and heating fuels in quantities that its ports were not equipped to handle, the Government spokesman, Behzad Nabavi, said Friday.

title: Index; International
description: The Talk of Warsaw: Poles suffer ''Weinberger rash'' A1 Italy seizes most-wanted terrorist suspect A2 Swiss reject proposal to improve lot of foreign workers A2 Yugoslav leaders express fear ethnic unrest will spread A3 Fighting subsides in Lebanon but truce remains ineffective A3 West German generals complain about cutbacks A3 New compromise is proposed at Madrid conference on detente A5 African scenes: ''ghostly'' raids and Chinese aid A7 Message in bottle recalls lost chapter in Arctic exploration A8 Iranian President warns of eco- nomic dangers A9 Weinberger calls Brezhnev trip a welcome sign A10 Government/Politics Emotional impact of an assualt assessed by experts B11 Plans to limit U.S. aid to Medicaid would shift burden to states B12 Outline of coverage on roll-call votes on Senate budget cuts B13 31 on ballot to succeed Represent- ative Spellman of Maryland B15 Young and 2 others are front-run- ners in Atlanta mayoral race B15 General Around the Nation A12 Perils of uranium boom to Indians in New Mexico depicted A12 New organization plannned by for- mer Jaycee chapters A13 New York City still the population center of the state B6 Industry/Labors United Mine Workers say they're striking to save their union A12 Health/Science Engineers on space shuttle solve a problem B10 SportsMonday Baseball: Mumphrey is cautious about his role as a Yankee C5

title: ROCKETS ARE OVERJOYED OVER OUSTING CHAMPIONS
description: Until Feb. 20, the Rockets had won only four games and lost 28 in the Forum, the home of the Los Angeles Lakers, since joining the National Basketball Association in 1967 as the San Diego Rockets and moving to Houston in 1971.

title: CHERYL BETH NEWMAN MARRIED TO JOSEF STERN
description: Cheryl Beth Newman and Josef Stern were married yesterday at the Jewish Center in New York by Rabbi Israel Miller, vice president of Yeshiva University.

title: Shoemaker, Borzoi In Santa Anita Upset
description: Borzoi, ridden by Bill Shoemaker, upset King Go Go and won the $109,700 San Bernardino Handicap today at Santa Anita.

title: TURKEY ENCOURAGES NEW OIL DRILLING, AND HUFFCO TAKES LEAD
description: If anybody can find oil in Turkey, it's Huffco. That has been the word in business circles here ever since Roy M. Huffington Inc., a Houston-based oil company, arrived last November, fresh from its successes in Indonesia.

title: Penguins 5, Whalers 4
description: Nick Libett's sixth goal of the season capped a four-goal burst in the third period that carried Pittsburgh to victory. Libett's game-winner came on 25-foot wrist shot from near the left face-off circle.

title: JAYCEE DISSIDENTS BEGIN NEW GROUP
description: Members of six chapters of the United States Jaycees who opposed the civic organization's ban on membership for women began a movement today to sponsor a new national organization.

title: The Draftnik Papers
description: What do you do if you are an 18-year-old junior college student with little interest in school but a lot in sports? Mel Kiper Jr. of Baltimore solved that problem by dropping out of college and going into the sports business. He began operating a service to provide inside information on college and pro football teams to bettors or anyone who wants to use it. Kiper extracted information from any source he could find, such as newspapers, games on television and contacts around the country. He began getting people to make videotape recordings from television of games in their areas. He then analyzed the games.

title: MAYOR-ELECT OF SAN ANTONIO HAILS VOTE AS A VICTORY OVER 'THE ETHNIC FACTOR'
description: At the high point of the evening, a grinning, excited Henry Cisneros shed the coat of his blue-pinstriped Ralph Lauren suit, grabbed a long stick and took aim at the pinata, a hollow, six-pointed star made of red, pink, turquoise, violet, white and yellow crepe paper that had been suspended above the speaker's platform.

title: The U.N. Today; April 6, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Special Committee on Enhancing the Non-Use of Force in International Relations - 10:30 A.M.

title: SWISS REJECT PLAN TO ENHANCE FOREIGN WORKERS' STATUS
description: Swiss voters rejected by a ratio of 5 to 1 today a proposed constitutional amendment that would have removed virtually all constraints on foreign workers here.

title: A REAGAN NOTE TO BREZHNEV TELLS OF CONCERN ON POLAND
description: President Reagan, using what an American official called ''strong language,'' has sent Leonid I. Brezhnev a message expressing the Administration's extreme concern over the situation in Poland.

title: Wisconsin Counties Pick Up After Killer Tornado
description: Tornado victims sifted through the remains of their shattered homes today as a state of emergency remained in effect after a weekend storm that left six dead and caused millions of dollars in damage.

title: PROGRESS REPORTED AS ALBANY LEADERS WORK ON A BUDGET
description: With the state still lacking a budget five days into the new fiscal year, legislative leaders and Governor Carey reported some progress today as the Governor temporarily removed from discussion the main sticking point - his proposed state takeover of local Medicaid costs.

title: The Talk of Warsaw
description: Being in Poland these days is like living on a roller coaster. It seems that the entire country swings from peaks of optimism to valleys of despair. Lately the peaks and valleys have been coming at breathtaking speed.

title: Volkswagen Is Found Not Liable In Girl's Death in Carolina Crash
description: Volkswagen of America is not liable for damages in the death of a 16-year-old girl who was thrown from the back seat into the dashboard in a collision, a jury has ruled.

title: Judith Bosek Married to Noah Engelberg
description: Judith Bosek, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Saul Bosek of Hillside, N.J., and Noah Engelberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Engelberg of Woodside, Queens, were married yesterday in Temple B'nai Israel in Elizabeth, N.J. Rabbi Gershon B. Chertoff and Cantor Morris Schorr officiated.

title: Helping the Wrong Veterans
description: In the name of sustaining the military, President Reagan has exempted every major program for older veterans from his budget cutting. But to reduce spending, he wants to kill every Federal program designed to help the youngest war veterans, those who served in Vietnam. We think he has it backwards.

title: STANLEE STAHL PH.D STUDENT, BRIDE OF GEORGE N. ACKERMAN
description: Stanlee Joyce Stahl, daughter of Mrs. A. Duey Stahl of Passaic, N.J., and the late Mr. Stahl, was married yesterday to George N. Ackerman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ben Ackerman of Hollywood, Fla. Rabbi Joseph Herman performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's sister, Mrs. Sharon Barash, in Montvale, N.J.

title: Bank Meeting in Spain
description: Bankers, finance ministers and economists from Latin America and major Western industrialized nations have gathered here for tomorrow's opening of the Inter-American Development Bank's annual meeting. The bank, established in 1959 by the United States and 19 Latin American countries, now has 43 members, including Japan and most of Western Europe, whose contributions support development in Latin America and the Caribbean. Debt in that region stands at about $200 billion, according to the bank, which said it plans to lend between $2.4 billion and $2.5 billion this year, a record sum.

title: JOINT PATROLS SEEK TO END FIGHTING IN BEIRUT
description: Clashes between Syrian troops and Christian militia forces gave way today to sporadic shooting here and in Zahle, but all efforts so far to maintain an effective cease-fire have failed.

title: GRAHAM GREENE DOUBTS HOLLIS WAS SOVIET AGENT
description: Graham Greene said today that he believed the world's secret services were riddled with traitors, but he discounted allegations that the late Sir Richard Hollis, Britain's counterintelligence chief, was a Soviet agent.

title: Mrs. Melton Wins by 2 on 64-277
description: Nancy Lopez-Melton pulled away from a logjam of players with a brilliant eight-under-par 64 today and won the $250,000 Colgate-Dinah Shore tournament by two strokes.

title: Reverse Play
description: When Joe Purzycki made a trip into Philadelphia to recruit football players recently, an assistant coach at Central High School kept correcting him when he said he was from Delaware State College.

title: PROBLEMS FROM URANIUM BOOM DEPICTED AT HEARING BY NAVAJOS
description: Navajo ranchers, pueblo leaders and social workers from this area told a United States Civil Rights Commission panel this weekend that energy development in the area was creating social problems and disrupting traditional ways without necessarily bringing promised wealth.

title: Purchases Announced For Three Magazines
description: Knapp Communications has acquired the ailing San Francisco magazine, and that is just the first of three purchases reported yesterday.

title: Red Smith; New Haven Steeplechase
description: AT the first fence, two horses fell, bringing with them from the bettors in cushioned theater seats a sound that was half a gasp, half a moan. The 37 steeds still in the race pounded on toward the second of 30 jumps on the Grand National course at Aintree near Liverpool, England. Three thousand miles away in New Haven, Conn., horseplayers in the elegant gambling hell called Teletrack had a far better view than those at Aintree, for the television camera was mounted on a van that stayed abreast of the field just across the inside rail.

title: BONN'S GENERALS FEAR AUSTERITY COULD UNDERMINE ROLE IN NATO
description: West German generals have protested against a series of planned cutbacks and delays in procurement that they say, according to published statements, affect the long-term West German role in NATO and endanger troops in some situations.

title: MODERNIZATION OF HOUSING MEANS FEWER HOMES FOR THE POOR
description: To the Editor:

title: ELLEN WURMAN IS BRIDE OF MARK D. BIRNBAUM
description: Ellen Wendy Wurman, daughter of Gustave Wurman of Long Beach, L.I., and the late Doris Wurman, was married yesterday to Mark David Birnbaum, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Birnbaum of Franklin Square, L.I. Rabbi Abraham Mann, assisted by Cantor Solomon Mendelson, performed the ceremony at Temple Israel in Long Beach.

title: Confidence Rises in March
description: Consumer confidence rose sharply in March as optimism increased over future business and employment prospects, the Conference Board said in a report scheduled to be released today.

title: Three Are Named by White House To Jobs in Two Federal Agencies
description: The White House has announced three appointments to Federal positions, two of them in the Department of Education.

title: POLICE OFFICERS NEVER REALLY FEEL OFF DUTY
description: To the Editor:

title: BANI-SADR EXPRESSES ALARM ON ECONOMY
description: President Abolhassan Bani-Sadr says Iran's economy is in acute difficulty, with production falling and the money supply increasing alarmingly.

title: S.E.C. TOLD OF TALK TO AMAX INSIDER
description: Thomas C. Reed, a former Air Force Secretary, has testified before the Securities and Exchange Commission that one of the persons he talked to in advance of a $4 billion takeover bid for Amax Inc., the giant mining company, was Ian MacGregor, a prominent Wall Street investment banker and a member of the Amax board of directors.

title: YOUNG AND 2 OTHERS EMERGING AS FRONT-RUNNERS IN ATLANTA MAYORAL RACE
description: When Andrew Young declares his candidacy for mayor of this city tomorrow, the race among nearly a dozen contestants is expected to move into high gear.

title: Prediction on Shooting Acknowledged as Hoax
description: A Hollywood psychic's prediction of the attempted assassination of President Reagan was a hoax, Dick Maurice, a local television talk show host, admitted today.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: TRIBUTE

title: DiBernardo to Sign
description: Angelo DiBernardo, who played under an amateur contract last year, has chosen to sign a professional contract with the Cosmos rather than become a free agent.

title: Newspaper Strike Gains Support
description: About 700 demonstrators, watched by police officers in riot gear, marched to the Terre Haute Tribune-Star Publishing Company yesterday and circled the building four times in a show of support for newspaper employees who have been on strike against the company since Feb. 21.

title: TAUGHT THE THEATER AT BROOKLYN COLLEGE
description: Joseph (Skipper) Davidson, who taught speech and theater at Brooklyn College for 44 years and then embarked upon a professional career in the theater, died of a heart attack in Maimonides Hospital in Brooklyn on Friday. He was 77 years old and lived in that borough.

title: MUSIC: ROSTROPOVICH MILESTONE
description: MSTISLAV ROSTROPOVICH returned to Carnegie Hall on Saturday night to celebrate a special anniversary. It was 25 years to the day since his United States debut in the same hall, and the Russian cellist appropriately decided to play the same program as on that notable occasion, this time with Samuel Sanders as his partner at the piano.

title: NEW HAVEN RIDERS FACING LONG DELAYS
description: Starting today and continuing indefinitely, all 40,000 commuters on Conrail's New Haven line face morning and evening delays of at least 30 minutes, and possibly an hour or more, as a result of a turbine breakdown at the railroad's Cos Cob, Conn., power station.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Canon U.S.A. Inc. has appointed Haruo Murase vice president and general manager of the copier division.

title: Treasury Bill Rate Could Drop Today
description: Treasury bill rates increased sharply late last week to about 13 percent for three months and 12.6 percent for six months, but dealers cautioned that rates may be lower at today's auction.

title: WEINBERGER, ON EUROPE TRIP, IS WARY OVER BREZHNEV ROLE
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger said today that he viewed as a welcome sign the arrival of Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, for the Czechoslovak Communist Party meeting in Prague.

title: Washington Watch; A Challenge To Canada
description: THE St. Joe Minerals Corporation has started what could be another altercation with Canada. This time it involves a little-known provision of the Mineral Lands Leasing Act of 1920, which the big mineral extraction corporation wants to use to fend off any new bid by the Seagram Company Ltd.

title: McEnroe Wins
description: John McEnroe won his second straight World Championship Tennis tournament today by defeating unseeded Tomas Smid of Czechoslovakia, 6-3, 6-2.

title: Air Time Inc. Seeking Chapter 11 Protection
description: Air Time Inc., a major media buying company that filed under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act Thursday, reported over $9 million in liabilities and $3.6 million in assets, which include $1.5 million in receivables.

title: JAZZ: VON AND CHICO FREEMAN
description: THE New Jazz series at the Public Theater, which was dropped five months ago, started up again over the weekend with three performances on Friday and Saturday by a father-and-son team of tenor saxophonists, 58-year-old Von Freeman and 31-year-old Chico, backed by Kenny Barron, piano; Cecil McBee, bass, and Jack De Johnette, drums.

title: An Old Friend Works on a New Form
description: Birgit Nilsson, who's in New York from her home in Sweden to prepare for a couple of concerts next weekend at the Metropolitan Opera House, went there the other night to see ''La Traviata.''

title: WILL OPPOSE LEAFS IN PLAYOFFS
description: Relaxed and aware that the final game of their regular season couldn't alter their first-place standing, the Islanders gave up three first-period goals to the Buffalo Sabres and then rallied for a 7-3 victory.

title: No Headline
DEPOSIT ON CLEANLINESS
description: To the Editor:

title: Haig Sees the Funny Side Of His Feud With Bush
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., who has been criticized in Washington for appearing to promote himself ahead of other Reagan Administration officials, jokingly referred to the matter tonight in a toast at a dinner given in his honor by Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir.

title: PETTY'S BUICK REGAL TAKES 140,000 RACE
description: Richard Petty proved his mastery at North Wilkesboro Speedway again today, outdueling Bobby Allison to win the $140,000 Northwestern Bank 400 Grand National stock car race.

title: Garrett Is Selected
description: John Garrett of the Hartford Whalers today became the first goaltender to be selected for Canada's entry at the 1981 world hockey championships in Sweden. John Ferguson, the Team Canada general manager, said he expected that the remaining five roster selections, one of which must be another goalie, would be announced tomorrow.

title: CLAUDIA CARMEL IS MARRIED
description: The marriage of Claudia Carmel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence H. Carmel of Harrison, N.Y., was married yesterday at her parent's home to Martin Weise, son of Mrs. David Weise of New Springville, Staten Island, and the late Mr. Weise. Cantor Bernard Dienstag of the Jewish Community Center of Harrison performed the ceremony. The bride is an interior designer and her husband is a real estate developer in Staten Island.

title: Commodities; Limited Liability An Issue
description: MEMORIES of ''Silver Thursday,'' March 27, 1980, may be fading, but the day that rocked the commodity futures industry and Wall Street has not been forgotten. Rather, the near-collapse of a major brokerage house and several commodity exchanges provoked protective moves.

title: BREZHNEV'S LAST STAND; by William Safire
description: He resembles Chicago's late Mayor Daley: jowly cheeks, bulbous nose, an expression of defiance on his face even in repose. He is 66, which is young for a full member of the 14-man Politburo, and has been Communist Party boss of the City of Moscow since 1967. Within the Kremlin, he is the man probably putting the most pressure on Leonid Brezhnev to crush the Polish counterrevolution or to step aside.

title: Advertising; Religious Radio Gets A Network
description: GOSPEL Music Month began last week, so it was very appropriate that the Gospel Radio Network and Radio Spot Sales Inc., should come into being during the observance.

title: A New President At Taylor Wine
description: Michael J. Doyle, 39 years old, has been named president of the Taylor Wine Company, a major American winery in Hammondsport, N.Y. Joseph L. Swarthout, 61, who had been president, will become a consultant until his retirement on Aug. 1 from Taylor, a unit of the Coca-Cola Company that produces Taylor, Great Western and Lake Country wines.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: During one of the games in the National Collegiate basketball tournament, Ralph Sampson of Virginia had one hand on the backboard as stuffed the ball into the basket. Was that legal? There seemed to be some difference of opinion among the television announcers.

title: FORD FOUNDATION TO STUDY CRIME IN NEW PROGRAM
description: The Ford Foundation, the country's wealthiest philanthropic organization, has adopted a program for the 1980's in foreign and domestic aid that has as one of its central concerns the widespread incidence of street crime, arson and violence across the country.

title: MONDAY, APRIL 6, 1981; The Economy
description: An optimistic forecast of the benefits of energy efficency is causing wide debate. The Mellon Institute's research unit said that imports could be eliminated by the year 2000 if equipment used to convert fuels into energy were improved. But some analysts say that reducing crude imports is just not that easy. (Page D1.)

title: State Approves Prudential Plan
description: New Jersey's Insurance Commissioner, James Sheeran, on Friday approved the proposed acquisition by the Prudential Insurance Company of America of the Bache Group Inc., a Wall Street stock brokerage. Mr. Sheeran had the power to block the purchase of Bache by Newark-based Prudential if he felt the move was not in the best interests of the insurance company's customers.

title: by Howard Singer
description: In Israel, they fly the flags at half mast on April 30. In the United States, they hold memorial meetings. It's Holocaust Day.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Edward H. Budd, the 47-year-old president of the Travelers Corporation, has been elected to the additional post of chief executive officer. He succeeds Morrison H. Beach, 64, who will continue as chairman of the Hartford-based company, parent of the Travelers Insurance Companies, until reaching the normal retirement age of 65.

title: MISSING MAN ADDED TO ATLANTA INQUIRY
description: A retarded man missing since March 30 was added today to the list of young blacks whose murders and disappearances are being investigated by a special police force. Today's addition raised the count of unsolved cases to 25.

title: California Inquiry Begun On Ski Resort Accident
description: State safety officers examined equipment and interviewed Sierra ski resort operators today in an investigation of a lift accident that injured 17 persons, three of them seriously.

title: Special Shuttle Issue; SCIENTISTS PREDICT GREAT DISCOVERIES ON FUTURE MISSIONS
description: WHILE observations during the Columbia's initial flight will be aimed chiefly at the craft's performance and its effect on nearby space, future missions are almost sure to produce revolutionary discoveries regarding the cosmos and the earth.

title: WEINBERGER SEES POLES THREATENED WITH SOVIET INVASION 'BY OSMOSIS'
description: The Soviet Union is coercing the Polish people with ''an invasion by osmosis,'' Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger said today as he continued a running commentary on Moscow's threat to Poland.

title: PROMOTER TIED TO BANK FRAUD ADMITS HE IS MAN SOUGHT ON FORGERY CHARGES
description: Harold J. Smith, the boxing promoter who disappeared last January amid allegations in a lawsuit that he helped steal $21.3 million from Wells Fargo National Bank, admitted today that his real name was Ross Fields, and Federal authorities said he was wanted in two states and the District of Columbia for forgery and other charges.

title: 2 Drug Dealers Executed in Iran
description: Two narcotics dealers have been executed in the southern Iranian town of Bandar Abbas, the state radio said today. It said the executions, which took place last night, were for buying, selling and distributing heroin.

title: Steel Output Drops 2.1%
description: Steel production fell to 2.615 million tons in the week ended last Saturday, a decline of 2.1 percent from the previous week's 2.671 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. The industry's production amounted to 87.4 percent of capacity during the week, compared with 89.2 percent in the previous week. Estimated figures for the year to date showed production at 33.654 million tons, an increase of 1.6 percent from the 33.131 million in the previous year.

title: SPAIN IS MAKING A NEW EFFORT TO GET PICASSO'S 'GUERNICA'
description: Spain sent a Government delegation to New York today to claim Pablo Picasso's famed 1937 painting ''Guernica,'' which the Spanish artist said in 1973 that he would never turn over to his homeland until democracy reigned.

title: Loans Announced For Latin America
description: The Inter-American Development Bank today announced a series of loans totaling $413 million for Mexico, Brazil, Argentina and Peru. The loan agreements were signed here before the opening of the bank's annual meeting.

title: FEAR ABOUT OUR OIL RESERVES IS HEALTHY
description: To the Editor:

title: AIDE REJECTS CHARGES THAT BUDGET PORTENDS A 'DISASTER' FOR ELDERLY
description: David A. Stockman defended President Reagan's budget today against Congressional charges that it constituted ''a blueprint for disaster'' for ''millions of low-income elderly people across this land.''

title: LAW COLLEGES ADD WOMEN AS STUDENTS
description: While the number of women enrolled in accredited law schools has nearly doubled in six years, the number of blacks in law school has increased only slightly and has actually decreased a bit as a proportion of all students, according to statistics released by the American Bar Association.

title: LAW OF SEA REVIEW WELCOMED
description: The five major industrial consortiums that stand poised to begin mining strategic minerals from the world's oceans see President Reagan's recent decision to review the draft treaty on the Law of the Sea, rather than immediately ratifying it, as a major victory for their interests.

title: METS DEAL BOMBACK, GLYNN AND BENTON
description: The New York Mets ended spring training today with 13 victories, 13 defeats and three painful choices that trimmed the roster to the legal limit of 25 players.

title: HAIG ACCUSES SYRIANS OF 'BRUTALITY' IN ATTACKS ON LEBANESE CHRISTIANS
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. assailed Syria today for ''the brutality'' of its attacks on the Lebanese Christian stronghold of Zahle and said that Syria's actions were unaccertable ''by any measure of appropriate international standards.''

title: U.S. PROPOSES EASED CAR STANDARDS
description: The Reagan Administration today proposed easing or eliminating 35 air quality or safety regulations as part of a program to help the domestic auto industry, now fighting to preserve its competitive position against Japanese imports.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Why do bats hang upside down?

title: Jamaica Tourist Board Account Landed by Y.& R.
description: Young & Rubicam has landed the Jamaica Tourist Board account for advertising in the United States, Canada, Britain and Europe and the domestic account alone bills $7 million, according to the agency.

title: Dances of India Coming To Asia Society April 24
description: Kathakali: South Indian Dance-Drama from the Kerala Kalamandalam will inaugurate the Lila Acheson Wallace Auditorium - the theater of the Asia Society's new headquarters at 725 Park Avenue - on April 24 at 8 o'clock.

title: Lockheed Dividend
description: The Lockheed Corporation said today that its directors had approved a dividend of $1.875 a share on its $11.25 convertible preferred stock, its first cash payout on any of its publicly traded securities since the last quarter of 1969.

title: CHIEF WILL QUIT CITY HEALTH POST EFFECTIVE IN FALL
description: New York City's Health Commissioner, Dr. Reinaldo A. Ferrer, submitted his resignation yesterday, saying that he and his ailing wife wished to return to Puerto Rico.

title: Oil Reserve's Progress Noted
description: The nation's Strategic Petroleum Reserve stands now at 121.5 million barrels, an amount equal to 18 days' worth of oil imports, Congress was told today.

title: MARK F. ETHRIDGE, JOURNALIST, DIES AT 84
description: Mark F. Ethridge, one of the most respected figures in American journalism, who helped build The Louisville Courier-Journal and The Louisville Times into nationally known newspapers, died Sunday in Moncure, N.C. He was 84 years old.

title: Coast Guard Copter Overturns in Bay
description: A Coast Guard helicopter crew practicing emergency maneuvers in Jamaica Bay got an unexpected live drill when the helicopter flipped over, spilling its crew into the water, United Press International reported.

title: KENZO'S CAREFREE STYLES AT AN OFFBEAT SHOWING
description: ''I've known Kenzo since he started his own shop, about 13 years,'' said Dewi Sukarno, settling into her seat in the tent called Saint Eustache, where Kenzo's show was being held late last night in the Forum des Halles. ''Sometimes I wear his things in Saint Tropez. But they're better for my daughter, Karina.''

title: Bridge: Teams Rated at Top Ended Grand Nationals as Losers
description: Winning a New York title is often harder than winning a national title. This seems to be the moral of the district Grand National Team Championship quarterfinals, in which an astonishing upset contributed to an equally astonishing overall result.

title: Chess: Easy Pickings for Korchnoi At Banco di Roma Tourney
description: Viktor Korchnoi romped to an easy victory in the Banco di Roma International Tournament in Rome, conceding only two draws while running up an 8-1 score. Istvan Csom, a Hungarian grandmaster, took second place, while Bruno Parma, a Yugoslav grandmaster, and Stefano Tatai, an Italian international master, shared third. FINAL STANDINGS Player W. L. D. Pts. Korchnoi 7 0 2 8 Csom 4 2 3 5 1/2 Tatai 2 1 6 5 Parma 1 0 8 5 Matanovic 1 1 7 4 1/2 Makropoulos 2 4 3 3 1/2 Mariotti 0 2 7 3 1/2 Rodriguez 1 3 5 3 1/2 Toth 2 4 3 3 1/2 Zichichi 0 3 6 3

title: U.S.-Japanese Factoring Tie
description: The BankAmerica Corporation and the Nippon Shinpan Company, one of Japan's largest consumer credit concerns, said today that they would begin a joint venture soon to provide financing services to small and medium-sized Japanese companies.

title: Ex-Reagan Aide Enlisted
description: John P. Sears, the Washington-based political consultant who ran Ronald Reagan's Presidential campaign until he resigned in a dispute, is joining the fray of New York politics.

title: AFRICA'S LEGIONS OF REFUGEES ASK THE WORLD FOR HELP
description: Africa's dismal army of refugees, millions of men, women and children driven across borders by wars between tribes, regions and countries, will seek help at a conference that opens here April 9.

title: Drag Racer Dies in Texas Crash
description: A drag racer whose car veered into a crowd in a race two years ago and killed four persons has been burned to death in an accident involving the same car. The police said that the car driven by D.C. Thompson, 30 years old, crashed into a wall at the Yello Belly Drag Strip, exploded and burned late yesterday.

title: Harvester Gets Reprieve on Debt
description: The International Harvester Company, the ailing farm-equipment maker that is trying to put together a $4.7 billion debt restructuring plan, said today that it had received a one-month reprieve from an overseas bank that had refused to cooperate in the company's refinancing program by demanding immediate repayment of its $10 million loan.

title: Conference on Belize Opens In London Despite Boycott
description: Constitutional talks on independence for the British colony of Belize began in London today despite a boycott by the main opposition party and a state of emergency in the country after riots.

title: Petrofina Unit Takeover
description: The Ontario Securities Commission today approved the previously announced $120-a-share takeover of Petrofina S.A.'s 71 percent owned Petrofina Canada Inc. by stateowned Petro-Canada. But approval for the approximately $1.46 billion (Canadian) takeover is also needed from regulatory commissions in other provinces and in Belgium and France before the offer can be mailed to shareholders in those jurisdictions. Under the agreement, Petro-Canada would take over the assets of Petrofina Canada but the Belgian parent may remain a minority shareholder.

title: BONN ARRANGING DATE FOR VISIT BY BREZHNEV THIS YEAR
description: A West German Government spokesman said today that talks were under way to arrange a date for a visit to Bonn by the Soviet leader, Leonid I. Brezhnev. The visit is expected before the end of the year, he said.

title: MASSACHUSETTS IS GIVEN MEDICAID PLAN APPROVAL
description: A three-year experiment in controlling Medicaid costs in Massachusetts has received preliminary Federal approval. State officials said today that the new system, which would be based on the use of a fixed annual budget and private health service contractors, would reduce the cost of health care for the state's 550,000 Medicaid recipients by 20 percent or more and yet result in improved care.

title: 4 Americans Attacked in Turkey
description: Gunmen opened fire today on a car carrying four American military specialists, according to United States Embassy sources. The Americans, identified only as employees of a defense-related organization, were not hurt.

title: Special Shuttle Issue; THE SHUTTLE: AMERICA POISED FOR A RETURN TO SPACE
description: 1, as the space shuttle's maiden flight is officially called, is to get the Columbia into orbit and back to a safe landing on Earth. If the astronauts John W. Young and Capt. Robert L. Crippen manage to accomplish more than that, possibly the completion of 36 scheduled orbits, space agency officials will consider it a bonus.

title: Plankton, Mare, Is Retired Because of an Ankle Injury
description: Joseph Allen's Plankton, a 5-year-old mare who has earned $546,497 in her career, was retired at Aqueduct yesterday because of an ankle injury.

title: Household Cable Up
description: A. C. Nielsen, always measuring, has released its latest estimate of household penetration of cable TV. It puts it as of February at 25.3 percent. Last November it estimated 22.6 percent.

title: Russian Arrives for Austria Visit
description: Prime Minister Nikolai A. Tikhonov of the Soviet Union arrived for a five-day visit to Austria today. It was his first trip to the West since taking office last year. During the visit Chancellor Bruno Kreisky is expected to invite the Soviet Union to attend a North-South summit meeting on world development issues to be held in Mexico in October.

title: An Unidentified Youth Is Killed After Dispute on Brooklyn D Train
description: An unidentified youth was stabbed to death on a subway train in Brooklyn last night after he and a friend were involved in what the police described as an altercation with three youths.

title: Heroin Cases Double At Hospitals in City
description: The number of New York City hospital emergency patients with heroinrelated problems has more than doubled in the last two years, according to the director of the State Division of Substance Abuse Services.

title: MOYNIHAN AND BRADLEY VOTED FOR REAGAN BUDGET BILL
description: Two Democratic members of the Senate from the New York area - Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York and Bill Bradley of New Jersey - voted in favor of the 1982 budget limitation sought last week by President Reagan. They did so after having supported Democratic amendments aimed at restoring funds to certain programs, mostly social measures.

title: NOT EVEN THE RICH PAY THEIR WAY
description: ''I paid for it. Now you want to take it back.'' That sums up the feelings of many current and potential Social Security recipients. Any proposal to rein in spending - taxing benefits, capping cost-ofliving increases - is seen as a betrayal. They think of Social Security as a private pension: those who contribute have as much right to their benefits as someone with an annuity from Metropolitan Life.

title: Career Officer Is Picked For Post in El Salvador
description: President Reagan will nominate Deane R. Hinton, a Foreign Service officer who is now an Assistant Secretary of State, to be ambassador to El Salvador, the White House said today.

title: DEMOCRATS BUDGET TOPS REAGAN FIGURE ON SOCIAL PROGRAMS
description: House Democrats today proposed a $713.5 billion budget for the fiscal year 1982 and recommended more funds than the Administration sought for social programs and what would seem to be more money for military needs as well, although the Democrats said it was actually less than the Administration has proposed.

title: Key Rates
description: * Current rate excludes 3 percentage-point surcharge on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Fox Merger Approved
description: The 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation said today that its directors had approved an agreement to merge into a company owned principally by Marvin Davis, a Denver oilman. Fox said all directors at the meeting had voted for the merger, valued at about $700 million. A formal merger agreement will be signed on Monday, the company said.

title: POLISHHARD-LINER SEEN IN WARSAW AS AN APT CHOICE TO GO TO PRAGUE
description: Western diplomats and Polish sources regard it as significant that Stefan Olszowski, the leading hard-liner in the party leadership, was chosen to head the Polish delegation to the Czechoslovak party congress that opened today in Prague.

title: 50-CENT RISE IN DONATION ASKED BY MET MUSEUM
description: Citing an increase in operating costs because of inflation, the Metropolitan Museum of Art will raise its suggested contribution for adult admission from $3 to $3.50 today.

title: Article 073170 -- No Title
description: A consortium of West German and Austrian companies has won a $350 million order from the Libyan Ministry of Heavy Industry to build a turnkey plant to produce sponge iron, a consortium member, Korf Engineering G.m.b.H,, said here today. Other consortium members include Voest Alpine A.G., Bilfinger & Berger, Maschinenfabrik Augsburg-Nuernberg A.G. and Siemens A.G., Korf said.

title: TV's Tough Problem
description: Dr. Dennis O'Leary, the articulate doctor who has been the principal medical spokesman for Ronald Reagan, says that in his reports right after the President was shot he tried to be ''as upbeat as possible without damaging my credibility.''

title: MEZZO: FREDERICA VON STADE OFFERS 4 SONGS BY MAHLER
description: LIKE all intelligent singers, Frederica von Stade knows exactly what her voice can do best, and now that she is famous enough to sing precisely what she wishes, her recitals are almost always deeply satisfying and presented on her own artistic terms. And because those terms are very special in themselves, each song on the mezzosoprano's Alice Tully Hall program Sunday night had a glowing patina of vocal beauty all its own.

title: TURNING STUDENTS INTO VOLUNTEERS?
description: To the Editor:

title: JERSEY BEMUSED BY ITS MULTITUDE OF CANDIDATES
description: Last year it was disco roller-skating and riding mechanical bulls; this year it seems to be running for Governor of New Jersey. The Garden State is offering up to $600,000 in public funds to help finance the campaign of anyone who wants to run in the June 2 gubernatorial primary election, and a record number of candidates are taking advantage of the offer.

title: Crowd in Manila Protests Vote on New Marcos Term
description: Hundreds of policemen and militiamen dispersed a crowd that gathered here tonight for a noisy protest of tomorrow's plebiscite on a new six-year term for President Ferdinand E. Marcos with no limit on re-election. The nation's 26 million voters are required under threat of arrest to cast ballots.

title: PROBLEMS ON BUDGET FELT IN THE CORNER DRUGSTORE
description: Last Thursday, David Shulman expected to find two checks - for $10.9 million and $5.5 million - on his desk in the Westchester County Office Building. He is Commissioner of Finance, and the money would have represented the Federal and State advance payments for Medicaid costs in the county in the second quarter.

title: Gaines Works Hard On Comeback Route
description: Clark Gaines's pro football career, a study in struggle and determination, is in jeopardy, and he strains his body every day in an attempt to return to the Jets.

title: ICKO WAKMANN
description: Icko Wakmann, retired president of the Relide Clock Company in Manhattan and founder of the Wakmann Watch Company, died Saturday at his home in Miami Beach.

title: BLOC MEANS TO BACK POLISH COMMUNISM, CZECH LEADER SAYS
description: Gustav Husak, the leader of the Czechoslovak Communist Party, warned today that the Soviet bloc would not watch passively while the Communist system in Poland was undermined.

title: Advertising; Newsweek Gets Tough In Ad Drive
description: traditionally the weapon of No.2 - is being embraced by Newsweek in its war with an unnamed news magazine referred to as ''our competition.''

title: KUWAITI OIL-FEE DISPUTE CUTS OUTPUT
description: A bitter dispute has erupted between three major Western oil companies and the Kuwaiti Government over terms of their crude-oil contracts, authoritative Western sources here reported today. As a result Kuwait's daily crude production since March 31 has dropped about 400,000 barrels, to 900,000 barrels from 1.3 million barrels.

title: PARADOX OF THE REAGAN BUDGET BLITZ
description: To the Editor:

title: SCIENCE LIBRARY
description: Other Worlds: A Portrait of Nature in Rebellion - Space, Superspace and the Quantum Universe By Paul Davies. 207 pages, illustrated. Simon and Schuster, New York.

title: JACKSON'S INJURY WILL SIDELINE HIM AT LEAST 5 GAMES
description: Manager Gene Michael's task in cutting the roster down to 25 was made easier today when the Yankees decided to place Reggie Jackson on the 15-day disabled list, retroactive to April 2. The first game Jackson will be eligible to play will be at Texas on April 17.

title: WITNESS AGAINST MARGIOTTA SAYS LEADER DID NO WRONG
description: The key prosecution witness in the trial of Joseph M. Margiotta testified today that he did not believe the defendant or he had done anything wrong in splitting municipal insurance commissions with politicians designated by Mr. Margiotta.

title: ROBERT HITE
description: Robert Hite, lead singer of the rock group Canned Heat, died today in the back of his van after becoming ill at a performance in North Hollywood.

title: Defense Motions Denied In Halberstam Murder Trial
description: A Superior Court judge today denied several defense motions and ordered testimony to begin in the trial of Bernard Welch, who is accused of killing Dr. Michael Halberstam in a burglary last December.

title: ALASKA ENCOURAGES EFFORTS TO FARM THE PERMAFROST
description: With the toe of his boot, Greg Engellant scuffed away the top two inches of dirt and then hit the deep band of permafrost, the frozen soil that lies beneath his land.

title: Split-Stock Prices: New Method Used
description: Beginning today, a new method is used in the stock market tables to show the historical range of prices of stocks that have been split within the last year. The New York Stock Exchange and American Stock Exchange tables are affected.

title: IN POST-AMIN UGANDA, DREAMS KEEP DYING
description: In a week, it will have been two years since one of the more murderous regimes in modern Africa, the eightyear Government of Idi Amin, was brought down. For foreigners, two years is pretty much the limit in a hardship post like Uganda, and so they are leaving in droves, depressed and carrying broken dreams of reconstruction.

title: YUGOSLAV OFFICIAL CALLS RIOTS A SURPRISE
description: Yugoslavia's leaders were caught off guard by the extent and the intensity of last week's rioting by ethnic Albanians in which 11 people were killed and 57 wounded, it was acknowledged today.

title: Reagan Aide Questioned Before His Trip to Africa
description: Chester Crocker, Assistant Secretary of State-designate for African Affairs, appeared at a Senate Foreign Relations Committee confirmation hearing today and then left on a 17-day trip to southern Africa.

title: NEW HAVEN LINE HAS FEW DELAYS, YET COMMUTERS HAVE ROUGH TRIP
description: Commuters on Conrail's New Haven line this morning did not experience the long delays that had been expected because of a generator breakdown, but there was plenty of discomfort nevertheless.

title: Special Shuttle Issue; VOYAGE OF THE SPACESHIP COLUMBIA: AN OVERVIEW OF THE SHUTTLE'S MAIDEN FLIGHT
description: MILITARY SIGNIFICANCE Many Defense Department analysts and military strategists, who will be keenly watching the first shuttle flight, believe the re-usable spacecraft will give the nation military superiority in space, especially strengthening its position with respect to the Soviet Union. Futuristic military scenarios for the shuttle include its use in the construction of manned orbital posts for vehicles that can warn of missile attacks; it might also be used in the assembly of unmanned space stations armed with lasers and other sophisticated weapons. The space shuttle would carry satellites into orbit for various purposes, including reconnaissance and navigation. An apparatus known as the ''inertial upper stage'' would be used to boost many satellites to a ''geosynchronous'' or stationary, orbit, 22,300 miles above Earth. Military use of the shuttle is advocated by a civilian group, the Alliance for Peace Through Strength, headed by Daniel O. Graham, a retired general, and a Congressional group headed by Senator Malcolm Wallop, Republican of Wyoming. There is opposition from some scientists and academics, many of whom fear an arms race in space. Indeed, many opponents, including Dr. James Van Allen of the University of Iowa and Dr. Eric Chaisson of Harvard University, fear the shuttle will be mainly used as a weapon. Last year, Harold R. Brown, then Secretary of Defense, told the Senate Committee on Commerce, Science and Transportation that the space shuttle was essential to the nation's future military planning. The shuttle's military potential contributed to President Carter's decision to increase its funding.

title: Dina Ehrenhalt, M.A. Student, Is Married to Abraham Levy
description: The marriage of Dina Ehrenhalt, who is studying for a master's degree at the Fordham University School of Social Work, to Abraham Levy, a law student, took place yesterday.

title: Japanese Find Oil Off China
description: Japanese developers said today that they had found a large and promising offshore oilfield in China's Bohai Bay. The Japan-China Oil Development Corporation of Tokyo said that a test well sunk last December had struck oil in southern Bohai at a point about 118 miles southeast of Tianjin, the port city in northeast China.

title: Continental Phone, Thomson Venture
description: The Continental Telephone Corporation and Thomson-CSF, an affiliate of the Thomson-Brandt group of France, have agreed to form a joint venture to design, manufacture and market business communications equipment in the United States.

title: HOW SOLICITOUS OF US ARE YOU MR. KOCH?
description: To the Editor:

title: HOSPITAL CARE NEEDS NO 'STONEWALLING'
description: To the Editor:

title: TALKING BUSINESS
description: Talking Businesswith Hardy of McKinsey & Company Role of Inflation In U.S. Industry

title: Warner Amex Pact
description: Warner Amex Cable Communications Inc. said it would begin immediate construction of a $100 million cable television system in Dallas following approval by city voters on Saturday of an earlier City Council decision to award the franchise to Warner Amex.

title: Brief Outburst at Prison Facility In Deer Island Being Investigated
description: The authorities are investigating today a short-lived, but violent, outburst by inmates at the Deer Island House of Correction in which eight guards and seven prisoners were injured.

title: Honda Plan for Colombia
description: The Honda Motor Company said today that it would sign a technical assistance agreement with a Colombian bus-body maker to manufacture motorcycles in the South American country. The contract, scheduled to be concluded this month, will empower Fabrica Nacional de Autotartes Nanalca S.A. to produce Honda-designed motorcycles starting in the mid-1980's, company officials said. Initially put at 16,000 units annually, the output of 100-cubiccentimeter motorcycles will be increased to 30,000 units later in the decade, the officials said.

title: Coca-Cola Merger
description: The Coca-Cola Company said it had been given an additional 90 days to seek financing for its bid to acquire the Coca-Cola Bottling Company of New York, the country's biggest independent bottler of Coca-Cola products. Officials of both concerns predicted the cash transaction would be completed. The original agreement, signed Jan. 7, gave Coca-Cola until April 7 to obtain the money needed to pay stockholders of the bottling company $10.375 a share.

title: HIGH COURT BACKS SUIT OF WORKERS
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that a worker retained the right to sue his employer for violations of the minimum wage law even after arbitration had resolved the dispute in management's favor.

title: Article 072934 -- No Title
description: Another record here for a slot machine jackpot has fallen, this time to an Elizabeth postal worker who won $24,422.20.

title: CABARET: RICHARD IANNI SINGS POP
description: LITTLE ITALY is known more for its food than as an entertainment center. But a step has been taken in that direction by S.P.Q.R., a large restaurant at 113 Mulberry Street, which has just opened a cabaret room upstairs where Richard Ianni is singing.

title: Posner Sells Again - At a Profit
description: Victor Posner, the Miami businessman who seems to pick one takeover stock after another, sold off two more at a profit yesterday - the Simplicity Pattern Company and the Bundy Corporation.

title: Three Canadiens Share Vezina
description: The Vezina Trophy, which goes to goaltenders appearing in at least 25 games for the National Hockey League team surrendering the fewest goals in the regular season, will be shared by the Montreal Canadiens' three main goalies. It is the first time that more than two have split the award.

title: New Belgian Government Is Sworn In by the King
description: King Baudouin today swore in a new Belgian Cabinet headed by Prime Minister Mark Eyskens. The new Government, the fifth since 1979, is virtually identical with the coalition of Christian Democrats and Socialists headed by former Prime Minister Wilfried Martens that resigned last Tuesday over a proposal for a wage freeze. Mr. Eyskens was Finance Minister in the Martens Government.

title: JOBLESS PAY UPHELD IN RELIGIOUS DISPUTE
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that a worker who quits a job that conflicts with the worker's religious beliefs may not be denied state unemployment benefits and that payment of such benefits does not constitute establishment of religion.

title: ECONOMIC 'FORECASTING'
description: The optimistic growth forecasts in President Reagan's program for economic recovery have been criticized because they are not based on any econometric ''model.'' In fact, the Administration made some use of a model provided by John Rutledge, president of the Claremont Economics Institute, consultants. The Administration has also drawn upon a model by Norman B. Ture, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for Tax Policy. The Administration has not adopted one of these, and is reportedly working on its own model. Meanwhile, the ''big three'' forecasting firms -Chase Econometrics, Data Resources Inc., and Wharton Economic Forecasting Associates - are using their models to challenge the Administration's forecasts. Apparently an economist without his model is like a cowboy without his gun.

title: A Real Theater Family
description: The family of Barnard Hughes, the actor who won a Tony Award for ''Da,'' seems to have taken over the Manhattan Theater Club, where Mr. Hughes, his wife and son have simultaneous professional engagements.

title: ORCHESTRA BOARD REJECTS REHIRING LANDAU DESPITE POLL
description: In an effort to reinstate Siegfried Landau as music director of the White Plains Symphony Orchestra following his resignation over programming differences with the orchestra's board, several of Mr. Landau's supporters conducted a ballot poll of the audience at his final subscription concert in Westchester on Saturday night.

title: OFFICIAL SAYS THE NAVY IS THINKING OF BUYING SUBMARINES OVERSEAS
description: The Navy is thinking of buying submarines abroad and will decide by the end of the year whether to do so, John F. Lehman Jr., Secretary of the Navy, said today.

title: Pro Basketball Notebook; Loughery Still Leads Chase for Hawk Job
description: Every day the mail brings additional candidates for the Atlanta Hawks' coaching job. General Manager Stan Kasten even received an application yesterday from an assistant high school coach.

title: Austria Cites Doubling in Number Of Polish Refugees in Last Year
description: Nearly 1,400 Polish refugees arrived in Austria in the first three months of the year to seek asylum in the West, according to a survey made public today.

title: MUSIC NOTED IN BRIEF
description: Eugenia Zukerman Plays Beethoven Flute Concert

title: Dart Hails Oil Strike
description: the Dart Energy Corporation, a fiveyear-old Michigan-based drilling concern, said its Missaukee County well in the northern part of lower Michigan could hold up to 60 billion cubic feet of natural gas and seemed to indicate the existence of a deep reservoir of oil and gas. The 11,000-foot well, the deepest one producing oil or natural gas in Michigan, could pump 12.3 million cubic feet a day, worth $1.1 million a year at current prices, Dart Energy estimated. Dart and PPG Industries, which previously reported a strike in the same area, are drilling a second deep well in Missaukee County that has already reached 10,600 feet and may go as deep as 17,000 feet, the company said.

title: SCIENCE LIBRARY
description: Biological Aspects of Mental Disorder. By Solomon H. Snyder. 260 pages. Paperback. Oxford University Press. New York/ Oxford. $6.95.

title: Magma Bids Holders Reject Natomas
description: The Magma Power Company, a California energy concern with interests in producing geothermal wells, said it had recommended to shareholders that they reject a $42-ashare tender offer from the Natomas Company for the 9.3 million shares of Magma that it does not already own.

title: People
description: * Jonah Gitlitz has joined the Direct Mail Marketing Association as senior vice president, public affairs in the Washington office.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: NEW YORK YANKEES (AL) - Placed R eggie Jackson, outfielder, on 15-day dis- a bled list, retroactive to April 2. Optioned G reg Cochran, right-handed pitcher, to Co- l umbus, International League farm team. NEW YORK METS (NL) - Traded Mark B omback, right-handed pitcher, for player t o be named, to Toronto Blue Jays for their S yracuse farm team in International L eague. Sent Butch Benton, catcher, to Des M oines, American Association farm club of C hicago Cubs, and Ed Glynn, left-handed re- l ief pitcher, to Cleveland Indians' Charles- t on affiliate in the International League, b oth for cash or a player to be named. Pur- c hased Dan Boitano, right-handed relief p itcher, from Milwaukee and assigned him t o Tidewater farm team in International L eague. BOSTON (AL) - Waived Skip Lockwood, r ight-handed relief pitcher. CHICAGO (AL) - Optioned two pitchers, D ewey Robinson, right-hander, and Guy H offman, left-hander, to Edmonton in Pa- c ific Coast League. CINCINNATI (NL) - Sent Geoff Combe a nd Jeff Lahti, pitchers, to Indianapolis in A merican Association. CLEVELAND (AL) - Sent Chris Bando, c atcher, Gordy Glaser, pitcher, and Karl P agel, outfielder-first baseman, to Charles- t on in International League. DETROIT (AL) - Sent four players to E vansville affiliate in American Associa- t ion: Tim Corcoran, first baseman, and t hree pitchers, Jerry Ujdur, Dennis Kinney, a nd George Cappuzzello; recalled Darrell B rown, rookie outfielder, from Evansville. HOUSTON (NL) - Placed Kiko Garcia, i nfielder, on 15-day disabled list.

title: TUESDAY, APRIL 7, 1981; The Economy
description: The Administration proposed easing or eliminating 35 auto regulations governing air quality or safety in an effort to help the U.S. auto industry compete with Japanese imports. A Cabinet-level auto task force had considered tax and import relief as well but took no specific actions because of disagreements. The industry immediately hailed the regulatory changes. (Page A1.)

title: DEEP SOUTH SCHOOLS FOUND TO LAG STILL
description: Public schools in the so-called Black Belt of the Deep South remain ''inferior'' to most schools in the South and the nation despite a decade of school desegregation aimed at relieving such conditions, according to a study by the Southern Regional Council. The study concludes that local resistance to desegregation has been transformed into ''local neglect.''

title: Amtrak Plans Move Of Reservations Unit
description: Amtrak has decided to go ahead with plans to move its central reservations operation from Pennsylvania Station to Nassau County, despite a concerted effort by the Koch administration to persuade the company to stay in the city.

title: Brazil Jet Engine Order
description: Transbrasil Airlines of Brazil said it would order Rolls-Royce engines to power three Boeing 757 passenger jetliners on domestic routes, a Rolls-Royce Ltd. spokesman said today.

title: By Sports of The Times; The Islanders' Swagger
description: IF a team is to dominate its sport over a span of years, its best players must develop a sense of swagger, a belief that they are indeed the best. Swagger has come in all styles - noisily for the Yankees, muscularly for the Pittsburgh Steelers, calmly for the Boston Celtics, majestically for the Montreal Canadiens. And now, as the Islanders prepare to defend the Stanley Cup, they appear to have developed their own sense of swagger. Testily.

title: DOCTORS FOR THE PRESIDENT
description: What if Ronald Reagan had been standing in James S. Brady's place? The 25th Amendment, which provides for the transfer of power from a disabled President, is adequate only when a President knows he is going to be incapacitated - for example, before an operation; or when it is obvious to everyone that he will be disabled indefinitely - for example, because of physical injury. The President, or the Vice President and the principal officers of the executive department, simply indicate to the President pro tempore of the Senate and the Speaker of the House that the President is unable to carry out his duties, and the Vice President immediately becomes Acting President. After recovery, the President resumes his office on his own demand.

title: Drive a Bargain With the Saudis
description: By persuading President Sadat to let a thousand American troops join a peacekeeping force in the Sinai Peninsula, Secretary of State Haig has assured the survival of the Camp David accords and reaffirmed American sponsorship of the Israeli-Egyptian entente. Thus he reaches Saudi Arabia this morning as a protector of Israel as well as a suitor for oil. It is time to insist that the Saudis end their scornful treatment of Camp David as part of a wider diplomatic bargain that justifies their purchase of ever more sophisticated American weapons.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard THE MEN'S CLUB. By Leonard Michaels. 181 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $10.95.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, APRIL 7, 1981
description: International The Soviet bloc will not sit by and allow the Communist system in Poland to be undermined, the Czechoslovak party leader, Gustav Husak, said in Prague. He likened the present situation in Poland to those in East Germany in 1953, in Hungary in 1956 and in Czechoslovakia in 1968, when Soviet troops suppressed dissidents. Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, sat behind him, giving his warning further authority. (Page A1, Column 6.) Poland's leading hard-liner was chosen to head the country's delegation to the Czechoslovak Communist Party Congress in Prague. The chief delegate, Stefan Olszowski, has long been a protege of the Kremlin. (A10:1-2.)

title: Special Shuttle Issue; VOYAGE OF THE SPACESHIP COLUMBIA: AN OVERVIEW OF THE SHUTTLE'S MAIDEN VOYAGE
description: THE SETTLEMENT OF SPACE

title: SUITS TO RECOUP LOSSES FROM TRANSIT WALKOUT UPHELD BY STATE COURT
description: A State Supreme Court justice has ruled that businesses or professionals that suffered economic losses as a result of last April's 11-day transit strike may sue the unions involved for damages.

title: Energy Aide's Income Queried
description: A top Energy Department official who is leaving his job has disclosed more than $100,000 in income from energy-related companies after House investigators questioned a Government ethics form on which he failed to list the income.

title: TV: 'MONSTERS' TO VISIT CHILDREN THIS AFTERNOON
description: ''MISUNDERSTOOD Monsters,'' on CBS-TV today at 4 P.M., consists of three animated shorts linked by a ''live action'' narrative. Meeno Peluce plays Stanley, a 10-year-old piano player who is always being told he is too short to play ball with the other guys. Stanley is so resentful that he becomes a bit monstrous, knocking over a little girl's sandcastle and teasing a neighborhood dog. Fleeing from the angry animal, he runs into a shed and finds a disembodied mouth, animated in more ways than one, that insists on introducing Stanley to some helpful books.

title: Don't Punish the Economic Messenger
description: In a 200-year-old nation, the roots of a 7-year-old Federal agency don't run very deep. That is why the Congressional Budget Office, one of Washington's abler institutions, needs some timely defense against a nasty conservative assault.

title: Special Shuttle Issue; NOTHING LIKE IT HAS EVER FLOWN BEFORE
description: THE space shuttle is unlike any other space vehicle ever constructed, the differences being chiefly rooted in its technical sophistication, the novelty of its many roles and its design for reuse on at least 100 missions.

title: U.S. Asks World Court To End Suit Against Iran
description: The United States asked the International Court of Justice today to dismiss the American claim against Iran for damages resulting from the seizing and holding of American hostages.

title: U.S. SEES NO LETUP IN RUSSIAN ACTIVITIES
description: A State Department spokesman said today that although there had been no letup in Soviet military activities in and around Poland, the Administration did not believe that Soviet intervention in Poland was imminent.

title: ADVERTISING
description: William Scott Miller, 35 years old, who was senior vice president and creative director of the Coca-Cola USA account at McCann-Erickson, has been named executive vice president, and will fill the post of creative director of the New York office, a slot really vacant since William M. Backer, now president of Backer & Spielvogel, left.

title: KING DAVID HOTEL IN JERUSALEM FACES INVASION BY U.S. CHAINS
description: The King David Hotel, in ochre Jerusalem stone, stands majestically over this city. But its position as the pre-eminent hotel here appears threatened by the influx of American hotel chains, in Jerusalem and other Israeli cities, particularly as the uncertain international economy and foreign-currency fluctuations curb tourism.

title: Ray Hunt Buying Sport Magazine
description: A company controlled by Ray L. Hunt, president of the Hunt Oil Company, agreed to purchase Sport magazine from the Charter Publishing Company for an undisclosed price.

title: HINCKLEY INQUIRY CENTERS ON DETOUR TO LOS ANGLES
description: Federal investigators are trying to reconstruct the movements of John W. Hinckley Jr. in 20 hours he spent here in the hope that it will shed light on the motives behind his alleged attempt three days later to assassinate President Reagan.

title: 4 New Works by Ailey To Be Danced Next Month
