description: Four new works and a revival will be highlights of the spring season of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater at the City Center-55th Street Theater from May 5 to 24. Among the new works are Billy Wilson's ''Concerto in F,'' set to a Gershwin score, and ''Places,'' a male solo by William Chaison to an interpretation of a Bach score by Jacques Loussier.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Allied Bancshares Inc. of Houston agreed to merge with People's State Bank of Marshall, Tex., in a share exchange valued at about $4.9 million.

title: Westchester Airport Gets Bermuda Link
description: Air Florida received the approval of the Westchester County Board of Legislators to operate daily round-trip service between Bermuda and the county airport, near Purchase.

title: THEATER: 'FOOLS' BY SIMON
description: SAY what you will about Neil Simon, but there's no denying that he has a real nose for jokes; he doesn't go looking for laughs where they can't be found. So how can one account for ''Fools,'' the almost total misfire that he brought to the Eugene O'Neill last night? This peculiar endeavor was destined to be fruitless from the moment the playwright dreamed it up. Why the shrewd Mr. Simon plunged ahead anyway is one of the minor mysteries of the Broadway season.

title: DEMOCRAT IN BUDGET ROLE
description: After that 1972 election, Mr. Jones was charged with having failed to report a campaign contribution from the Gulf Oil Company. Today Mr. Jones calls it ''an innocent mistake,'' but he pleaded guilty to a misdemeanor and paid a small fine.

title: Market Place; Storer's Growth And the Costs
description: THE Storer Broadcasting Company's additions to its cable television business have pleased Wall Street. But the heavy burden that the program places on future earnings may cool enthusiasm for the shares.

title: No Headline
description: Steve Baker, the New York Rangers' goalie, has been named National Hockey League player of the week for the period ending April 4. Baker, 23, posted a 2-0-1 record for the week, including a pair of shutouts against the Philadelphia Flyers. Baker stopped 83 of 84 shots during the week.

title: KOCH SEES TRANSIT FARE RISE EVEN WITH NO BETTER SERVICE
description: Mayor Koch, who has repeatedly opposed a rise in the transit fare unless service gets ''demonstrably'' better on New York City's subways and buses, said yesterday that an increase was likely in coming months even without such improvements.

title: LAUNCHING PREPARATIONS STILL ON SCHEDULE, DESPITE SETBACKS
description: The countdown for launching the space shuttle Columbia, the world's first re-usable winged spaceship, continued around the clock with technicians struggling to make up time lost because of frayed wires and a leaky valve.

title: F.C.C. LETTING BELL RAISE LONG-DISTANCE RATES 16%
description: The Federal Communications Commission voted today to authorize a new profit margin for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company that would mean an increase in interstate long-distance telephone rates of as much as 16 percent, perhaps in the next few weeks.

title: Fluor Begins Offer for St. Joe Shares
description: The Fluor Corporation began its $60-a-share tender offer for up to 20.41 million shares of the St. Joe Minerals Corporation following the signing of a merger agreement by the two companies.

title: NEW COLEMAN STUDY ADDS TO CONTROVERSY OVER TUITION CREDIT
description: JAMES S. COLEMAN, the educational sociologist, concludes in a new Federally financed study that private high schools provide a better education than public high schools. These findings are expected to strengthen the support of tuition tax credits for parents whose children attend parochial or other private schools.

title: James L. Townsend, in Atlanta; Founder of Three City Magazines
description: James L. Townsend, founder of magazines in three cities, died yesterday after a long battle with cancer. He was 48 years old.

title: Brookwood Backs New Merger Offer
description: Brookwood Health Services Inc., which has been fighting a takeover attempt by Humana Inc., yesterday announced it has accepted an offer to merge with American Medical International Inc. through an exchange of stock valued at about $120 million.

title: Crewman Dies as Ship Sinks
description: Lashed by high winds, a 54-foot inter-island cargo ship, the Lady Merline of Dominica, sank Saturday in waters of the United States Virgin Islands, Coast Guard officials said today. One crewman drowned, but three others swam to shore on the island of St. Croix.

title: KOCH SEEKS CURBS ON TAX ABATEMENTS
description: The Koch administration, in a change of position, has proposed restrictions that would prohibit developers from claiming tax abatements for the renovation and rehabilitation of buildings in some luxury residential areas in Manhattan.

title: Bar-Illan, at Y, Performs Mussorgsky's 'Pictures'
description: When the pianist David Bar-Illan evoked the images from Mussorgsky's ''Pictures at an Exhibition'' at the 92d Street Y on Saturday night, he seemed to be using thick jabs of paint, coming at the work from above. As in the rest of his piano recital, the music was sounded with an impulse that often drew attention away from internal shapes and rhythms, toward the external, physical act of playing.

title: DANES BRACE FOR INFLUX OF 'BOAT PEOPLE' IF RUSSIA TAKES OVER POLAND
description: Danish naval officers said today that the Soviet Union and its Warsaw Pact allies have enough high-speed naval craft poised along Poland's Baltic Coast to close off the area within a few hours, making it very difficult for Poles fleeing by boat from Soviet invaders to reach this small Danish island, their nearest point of refuge in the West.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: P ERHAPS because it's spring, or because there's a new moon, things are percolating all over town, and many of them delight the eye. At Victoria Falls, an odd sort of clothing shop at 147 Spring Street, Wendy Gell, a sculptor and jewelry designer, has mounted a show called ''Funny Babies and Other Objects,'' a collection of whimsical assemblages that can be worn or just gazed upon.

title: Canadian Disposal
description: The Consolidated Natural Gas Company said it had signed a formal agreement to dispose of virtually all its Canadian gas and oil holdings in a transaction valued at $52 million. The sale, to Merland Explorations Ltd. of Calgary, Alberta, will add approximately 75 cents to 1981 per share earnings, the company said.

title: ARGENTINE COURTS ARE ALWAYS OPEN
description: To the Editor:

title: Soon Hee-Lee, Soprano, Presents Song Program
description: It took the traversal of several works by Rameau, Mozart and Brahms before Soon-Hee Lee's soprano voice settled into the music with convincing intonation on Sunday night at the Abraham Goodman House. Once the singer was more relaxed, she suggested impassioned energy in Brahms's ''Meine Liebe ist grun'' with accurate high tones, and created a refined delicacy in Rachmaninoff's ''The Lilacs,'' accompanied by the pianist Ryan Edwards.

title: Welles Named to Defense Post
description: Benjamin Welles, a former correspondent for The New York Times, has been selected by Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger to be Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense for public affairs. Mr. Welles, 64 years old, retired from The Times in 1972.

title: College Students' 'News Blackout' Put to Severe Test
description: The point of the weeklong ''news blackout'' Gilbert Stinger imposed on his 30 students in a mass communications class at St. Bonaventure University, in Olean, N.Y., was to teach them the value of a free press. They were to learn how it is to be without newspapers, magazines, radios or television sets.

title: Miners' Bargaining Council Summoned to Washington
description: By United Press International The bargaining council of the striking United Mine Workers has been summoned to Washington in what may be the first step toward renewed negotiations to end the 11-day-old walkout by 160,000 soft-coal miners, a union spokesman said yesterday.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * AM International Inc., Los Angeles, has elected to its board Gary E. MacDougal, chairman and chief executive officer of the Mark Controls Co.; Jean Allard, partner in the Chicago law firm of Sonnenschein, Carlin, Nath & Rosenthal, and Putnam L. Crafts, vice president of the Madison Fund, a closed-end investment fund.

title: Stouffer's Inn Opens 122 Days After Fire
description: Stouffer's Inn reopened yesterday, 122 days after a fire in its conference center proved fatal to 26 business executives.

title: DOUBLE TAX BREAKS ON LEASES
description: It goes by an odd name - double dip - and, as interest rates remain near record levels, it is one of the more creative new ways to finance plant and equipment.

title: Prisoner Slain in New Mexico
description: Jesus Jose Antunez, 29 years old, an inmate accused of burning another prisoner to death in the February 1980 riot at the state prison here, was stabbed to death today in a recreation yard outside a maximum security cellblock. Two inmates were taken into custody and held for questioning. The authorities said they had recovered two ''icepick-like homemade weapons.''

title: DANCE: ROYAL BALLET OF FLANDERS IN 'LA CATHEDRALE ENGLOUTIE'
description: BROOKLYN is becoming the place to go if you want to see ballet from all over. Brooklyn College and the Brooklyn Academy of Music have been featuring American ballet companies. And Saturday night the Royal Ballet of Flanders came to Kingsborough Community College.

title: READER'S DIGEST AFTER WALLACE
description: The Reader's Digest, which has made a name for independence in the publishing business, says it has no intention of departing from that tradition following the death of its founder, DeWitt Wallace.

title: WILIAMS DESCRIBED IN RECORDING AS 'THRILLED' BY TALK WITH SHEIK
description: The prosecution at the bribery trial of Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. played tape recordings yesterday in which his codefendant says that the Senator was ''thrilled'' when he was told he had favorably impressed an undercover agent posing as an Arab sheik.

title: SLAIN EXECUTIVE CALLED SUSPECT IN EMBEZZLING OF COMPANY MILLIONS
description: A high-living New York executive who, with his female companion, was found murdered in a Wisconsin nature preserve on March 18, was a suspect in a multimillion-dollar embezzlement scheme, the Manhattan District Attorney's office said yesterday.

title: Australian Energy Setback
description: Australia's promising Rundle oil shale project received a major setback today when its partners - Esso Australia, Southern Pacific Petroleum and Central Pacific Minerals - announced the scrapping of a pilot plant because estimated costs trebled during the past year. Esso owns a 50 percent stake in the project and the other two partners each have 25 percent ownership.

title: IN THIRD GRADE, VIOLENCE IS PUT IN PERSPECTIVE
description: The words ''brain damage,'' ''collapsed lung'' and ''assassination'' have become routine vocabulary in the third grade at the Birch Wathen School on the Upper East Side of Manhattan.

title: Cement Plant for Egypt
description: The Polysius Corporation, the United States subsidiary of Krupp Polysius A.G., has won an order worth more than $100 million to build a cement plant in Quattamia, Egypt, the parent company, Fried. Krupp G.m.b.H., said today. The company said that construction of the plant would begin in September 1982.

title: RANGERS, ISLANDERS ARE UP FOR PLAYOFFS
description: The Rangers have played ''playoff hockey for 10 games,'' according to their coach, Craig Patrick, and it has instilled in them a striking confidence as they prepared for their first-round series of the Stanley Cup playoffs against the Los Angeles Kings.

title: Engineer Declines Reagan Science Post
description: The White House has apparently lost its first choice for a Presidential science adviser.

title: Hockey Squad Chosen
description: Seven 1980 Olympians were among 22 players named to the 1981 United States national hockey team, General Manager Dick Meredith announced today. Bob Johnson of Wisconsin, the National Collegiate champion team, has been named as coach. The gold-medal winning Olympians are Neal Broten, John Harrington, Mark Pavelich, Phil Verchota, Dave Christian, Bill Baker and Bob Suter.

title: THOMAS FULTON CONDUCTS 'MANON' IN DEBUT AT MET
description: There were glamorous doings at the Metropolitan Opera Saturday evening, but even the presence of Canada's Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau and a small army of tailcoated diplomats didn't quite deflect attention from another event of importance going on in the Met's orchestra pit.

title: Rijsbergen Pact Extended
description: The Cosmos have, at their initiative, renegotiated and extended the contract of Wim Rijsbergen, their rugged and most consistent defender the last two years.

title: Ceausescu Tells Unions Party Will Keep Control
description: President Nicolae Ceausescu asked Rumania's unionists today to work harder and warned them that the Communist Party would retain firm control over domestic policies.

title: Accounts
description: * Cuisine magazine to Pesin, Sydney & Bernard Advertising. * WINS Radio to Slater, Hanft, Martin.

title: Index; International
description: Africa's dismal army of refugees appeals for help A2 Two years after Amin, Uganda is again trapped in despair A3 Riots caught Yugoslavia off guard, official admits A3 Around the World A5 Madrid is angered by bishops' letter A7 Bonn reports talks on date for visit by Brezhnev A9 Danes prepare to help refugees if Soviet bloc invades Poland. A10 Invasion of Poland is not imminent, U.S. officials say A11 Government/Politics Secretary says Navy may buy submarines abroad A13 Supreme Court Roundup A14 Reagan's choice for Surgeon General is opposed in Congress A16 Witness against Margiotta says leader did no wrong B2 Koch refines position on increase in transit fare B3 In a recording, Williams is called ''thrilled'' at meeting sheik B4 Dr. Ferrer resigning as New York City Health Commissioner B4 Some pharmacists in difficulty over delay in 1981 budget B7 Federal budget limits supported by Moynihan and Bradley B20 Energy Geological Survey says it cannot police oil lands against theft A12 General Around the Nation A12 Another retarded man added to Atlanta list A13 Women law students increase as blacks show mininal gain A14 Schools in South's ''Black Belt'' still found lagging A16 Hinckley's moves in Los Angeles still a mystery B11 Dead executive suspect in multi-million-dollar embezzlement B20 Science Times The Space Shuttle A mission of perils and hopes C1

title: MADRID IS ANGERED BY BISHOP'S LETTER
description: A dispute between the Government and the Roman Catholic Church over a pastoral letter by three Basque bishops has underlined the sensitivity and nervousness toward the military that has taken hold in Spain since the attempted coup six weeks ago.

title: SCIENCE WATCH
description: Custom-Made Pollution

title: IF SOCIAL SECURITY WERE FUNDED
description: To the Editor:

title: ALBANY BUDGET IMPASSE TIES UP SCHOOL AID
description: Governor Carey, charging that the Republicans were being ''irresponsible,'' said today that the state would not be able to meet an April 15 payment of $925 million to school districts because there was still no state budget for the fiscal year that began April 1. The Republicans, in turn, blamed the Governor for the impasse.

title: Poland Increases Prices Paid for Farm Products
description: Increases of up to 55 percent in the prices paid to farmers for their products were announced tonight by the state radio.

title: REAGAN NOW TAKING 2 ANTIBIOTICS, CONTINUES TO REGISTER SLIGHT FEVER
description: President Reagan continued to run a mild fever today even though he was getting additional antibiotics, including penicillin, that his doctors ordered yesterday to increase Mr. Reagan's protection against a possible infection.

title: EDWARD'S IMAGINED MANDATE
description: A potentially new crisis is looming in our energy picture, but not one of inadequate supply. Rather, we are facing an overabundance of myth. The question is: In electing President Reagan, what energy-policy message did the electorate also send?

title: SCIENCE LIBRARY
description: Earthly Pleasures By Roger B. Swain. 198 pages. Charles Scribner's Sons, New York. $10.95.

title: No Headline
description: A Company Briefs item in Business Day on March 31 misidentified a company that makes vending machines, electronic devices and shipboard equipment. The company was UMC Industries Inc.

title: Boxing Antitrust Lawsuit Goes to Trial Here Today
description: Trial of an antitrust suit against the World Boxing Council opens today in United States District Court in Manhattan. The suit was filed last year by Teddy Brenner, former head of Madison Square Garden boxing, against the W.B.C. and its president, Jose Sulaiman, a Mexican lawyer.

title: STUDENT 16, IS CHARGED IN DEATH OF TEACHER TRYING TO HALT A FIGHT
description: A 16-year-old freshman at Bushwick High School in Brooklyn was arrested yesterday and charged with first-degree manslaughter in the death of his homeroom teacher, who died shortly after breaking up a fight between the youth and another student on March 19.

title: Wing Drives 2 Winners As Yonkers Meet Opens
description: Ted Wing, a 32-year-old driver from Secaucus, N.J., started the 63-night program at Yonkers Raceway tonight by bringing home the first two winners.

title: REAGAN NOMINEE FOR SURGEON GENERAL RUNS INTO OBSTACLES ON CAPITOL HILL
description: The Reagan Administration's plan to appoint as Surgeon General a Philadelphia physician who has spoken out forcefully against abortions has run into Congressional opposition and stirred criticism from several medical groups, unions and feminist organizations.

title: Special Shuttle Issue; VOYAGE OF THE SPACESHIP COLUMBIA: AN OVERVIEW OF THE COLUMBIA'S MAIDEN FLIGHT
description: OBJECTIVES & BENEFITS

title: RATES SOAR AS TRADERS SHIFT VIEW
description: Short- and long-term interest rates rose sharply yesterday as traders in the credit markets realized that, contrary to their previous belief, the Federal Reserve did not encourage lower interest levels in March.

title: DOW PLUNGES BY 12.87, TO 994.24
description: Stock prices retreated along a broad front yesterday in response to rising interest rates and continued concern over the possibility of Soviet military intervention in Poland. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 12.87 points, to 994.24.

title: Frazier Out to ProveHe Can Take Punch
description: The punch was a solid one and it felt good, even though Marvis Frazier was on the receiving end. Only last Sunday, Smokin' Joe's 20-year-old son was ordained as a deacon in the Greater Harvest Baptist Church in Philadelphia, so he knows it is better to give than to receive, especially in his chosen profession. But this one time, in a sparring session last December, Marvis Frazier wanted to get hit, wanted to find out if boxing could indeed be his chosen profession. He had to find out if he could take a punch without becoming paralyzed because of a pinched nerve in his neck.

title: Public TV Needs Its Heat Shield
description: More evidence that it's not only fat that David Stockman's fiscal surgeons propose to cut from the Federal budget: In urging a 25 percent reduction in support for public broadcasting, they are also proposing an end to advance funding, a change that would remove the ''heat shield'' that protects a vulnerable activity from political meddling and reprisal. Properly, this dubious recommendation has been unanimously rejected by the Senate Budget Committee.

title: Shirley Majors of Football Family In Tennessee, a Longtime Coach
description: Shirley Majors, patriarch of a football family and for 21 years coach at the University of the South in Sewanee, died of a heart attack yesterday.

title: Lockridge an Easy Victor In Featherweight Fight
description: Rocky Lockridge of Paterson registered three knockdowns and retained his New Jersey featherweight boxing championship with a unanimous 12-round decision over Luis Edwin Rivera of Hoboken tonight.

title: D.D.B. Sweden Agency
description: On an incursion into Sweden, Doyle Dane Bernbach has acquired Falk & Pihl, an eight-year-old, $12 million agency, with offices in Stockholm and Goteborg. Falk & Pihl now adds a Doyle Dane Bernbach to its name. Just like getting married.

title: HARVARD SCHOOL OF EDUCATION REBOUNDS AFTER PAINFUL PERIOD
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. IN the early 1970's, when many education schools went into a tailspin, few appeared more disoriented than Harvard's Graduate School of Education. An oversupply of teachers and administrators, and an undersupply of Federal support for master's and doctoral students, created little demand for its graduates.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Beehive International is offering 551,000 shares of common stock at $14.875 a share today through a Shearson Loeb Rhoades group.

title: New President Appointed at United Jersey
description: T.Joseph Semrod, 44 years old, has been appointed president and chief executive officer of United Jersey Banks, a banking company based in Princeton. Edward A. Jesser Jr., who will be 65 in November and who had been chief executive, continues as chairman.

title: ISRAELI BOOK FAIR HONORS GREENE, AMID PROTESTS
description: The Jerusalem International Book Fair opened today with the presentation of a prize in literature to Graham Greene, the British author. The award, known as the Jerusalem Prize, is given every other year for writing on the theme of the freedom of the individual in society.

title: BANI-SADAR CRITICIZES TRUCE PROPOSAL OF ISLAMIC GROUP, CALLING IT VAGUE
description: President Abolhassan Bani-Sadr of Iran tonight characterized the latest proposal by an Islamic peace mission for a cease-fire in the Iraqi-Iranian war as vague and reiterated that there could be no truce while Iraqi troops remained on Iranian territory.

title: SHAD: EASE REGULATIONS
description: John S.R. Shad, President Reagan's choice to head the Securities and Exchange Commission, told the Senate Banking Committee at his confirmation hearing today that he favored easing regulatory requirements for business, including the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act of 1977.

title: Koch Changes Stand On Filling City Pools
description: In a departure from the drought regulations announced last week, Mayor Koch told children at Public School 250 in Brooklyn's Williamsburg section that the city would fill its outdoor pools this summer.

title: Dissident Says War Is Unlikely
description: The Soviet dissident Alexander Ginzburg says he does not believe the Soviet Union will risk a war over the crisis in Poland. He said in a speech at LeMoyne College last night that before beginning a major conflict, Soviet leaders ''would have to be convinced they have absolute superiority and they aren't convinced of that.''

title: GUESS WHO HAD A REUNION
description: Question: What happens when 500 high school quiz kids grow up and get together for the first time in years? Answer: They discover they can still fire off answers to the triviapacked, tightly worded questions that tested their wits when they were on television, way back when.

title: CORRECTION
description: In a review of the four-part television series ''Private Benjamin'' yesterday, the network on which it is shown was given incorrectly. It is on CBS.

title: The Budget Targets Fourth in a series on key programs; that President Reagan wants to cut.
description: In what is one of its most expensive welfare programs, the Federal Government will pay more than $25 billion this year to 10 million disabled American workers and their dependents.

title: Baseball Notebook; Littell on Disabled List, Lockwood Cut
description: With most of major-league baseball's season openers only 72 hours away, the teams continued trimming yesterday in efforts to reduce to the 25-man limit. Two of the victims were former star relief pitchers troubled recently by arm problems.

title: Frank C. Emmick Dead; Jailed 14 Years in Cuba
description: Frank C. Emmick, a businessman who spent 14 years in Cuban prisons on charges that he was a spy for the Central Intelligence Agency, died yesterday at a hospital here after collapsing at a dance. He was 65 years old.

title: Sun Weighs Sale Of Texas Refinery
description: The Sun Company said it was considering disposing of its Corpus Christi, Tex., refinery and petrochemical plants for an undisclosed target price.

title: Schuler, Coach at Rice, Says He'll Be Nets Aide
description: Mike Schuler resigned as the Rice basketball coach tonight and said he would join the New Jersey Nets as an assistant coach.

title: Conoco-Mitsubishi
description: The Conoco Corporation's Conoco Chemicals Company said it had signed a letter of intent to form a joint venture with Mitsubishi Petrochemical Company to sell and manufacture cresylic acids in the Far East.

title: GIANTS EXTEND PERKINS'S CONTRACT AS COACH
description: Just as Ray Perkins was embarkingon the lame-duck year of his three-year contract, the Giants announced yesterday the extension of that contract, but they would not say for how long, at least officially,

title: Lakme' Coincidences
description: She insists it's all just coincidental, but Eve Queler said yesterday that she was fascinated by the scheduling of an Opera Orchestra of New York performance of Delibes's exotic opera, ''Lakme,'' which she will conduct at Carnegie Hall next Monday. The 65-piece orchestra will perform with nine soloists and the 139-voice Coast Guard Academy Chorale.

title: SPECIAL SHUTTLE ISSUE
description: WORTHY PROJECTS SUFFER BECAUSE OF THE SHUTTLE, CRITICS OF NASA CHARGE

title: Ex-Jersey Official Guilty in Funds Case
description: George W. Lee, a former assistant secretary of state and former Burlington County Democratic chairman, pleaded guilty to breaking election laws during Governor Byrne's 1977 re-election campaign. Mr. Lee had been charged with one count each of laundering contributions to Mr. Byrne's re-election bid and collecting $7,500 in unreported contributions.

title: U.S. GIVEN ESTIMATE ON OIL THEFTS
description: A Government official said today that the United States Geological Survey could not serve as a police force to halt what he said was as much as $400 million in annual losses from theft and fraud at oil wells on Federal and Indian lands in the West.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The protection of the socialist system is the concern of each socialist state but also the joint concern of the states of the socialist community, which are determined to defend their interests and the socialist achievements of all their people.'' - Gustav Husak, the Czechoslovak Communist Party leader, at the party congress in Prague. (A10:1.)

title: WIESEL: NO ANSWERS, ONLY QUESTIONS
description: ''HE has the look of Lazarus about him,'' wrote Francois Mauriac of his friend Elie Wiesel, and Mr. Wiesel, a survivor of two Nazi concentration camps, has indeed returned from the dead with a story to tell, a story he has spent his adult life recounting. Like all writers, he is a witness, attempting to preserve history with his words. And yet in his case, the event was so horrific, the consequences so enormous that the author of ''The Testament,'' a novel that Summit Books will publish this month, says he is caught in a ''dialectical conflict'' between the need to recount and the futility of all explanation.

title: Kirklands to Get Awards
description: Since the first was given to West Germany's Willy Brandt in 1957, 14 persons have won the Freedom Award of the International Rescue Committee, and never have two persons been honored at the same time. That will change on Thursday when Lane Kirkland, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., and his wife, Irena, will receive awards at a dinner at New York's Sheraton Centre Hotel.

title: Officials Confirm Csonka Is Part of a Drug Inquiry
description: Federal officials have confirmed that the former Miami Dolphin fullback Larry Csonka is a subject in a marijuana smuggling investigation in Louisiana, but no charges are expected soon.

title: The Rev. Cappuccino Ilarino, 76; Delivered Sermons of Four Popes
description: The Rev. Cappuccino Ilarino, who served as a papal preacher for 20 years until his retirement last year, died today after suffering a heart attack, church officials reported.

title: The U.N. Today; April 7, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Special Committee on Enhancing Nonuse of Force in International Rela- tions - 10:30 A.M.

title: Special Shuttle Issue; VOYAGE OF THE COLUMBIA: AN OVERVIEW OF THE SHUTTLE'S MAIDEN FLIGHT
description: COSTS The cost of the program through the first mission was originally set at $5.2 billion, but inflation and technical delays have raised the cost to at least $10 billion. Since the end of the Apollo program, NASA has increasingly focused on the shuttle, with the program now taking about a third of the agency's $6 billion budget as against less than 3 percent of its $3.3 billion budget in the fiscal year 1971.

title: New N.L.R.B. Regional Director
description: Daniel Silverman has been appointed regional director for the National Labor Relations Board in New York, officials announced yesterday. Mr. Silverman, 39 years old, of Jersey City, has been an assistant general counsel in the Division of Operations Management.

title: Goodyear Expects Growth Abroad
description: Foreign operations, which bolstered 1980 earnings for the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, are expected to account for up to 65 percent of all sales by 1985, the nation's largest rubber company said today.

title: Diebold Names President
description: Earl F. Wearstler, 56 years old, who was named president and chief operating officer of Diebold Inc. early yesterday, had a quick hamburger and soft drink for lunch near his Canton, Ohio, headquarters - and then was on his way to Europe to attend the Hanover Fair in West Germany, where some of his company's equipment for the banking industry is now on display.

title: DR. LEO KANNER, 86, CHILD PSYCHOLOGIST
description: Dr. Leo Kanner, a leader in child psychology who urged common sense rather than a rigid following of guidebooks or fads in rearing children, died Friday of heart failure at his home in Sykesville, Md. He was 86 years old.

title: Addenda
description: * Bernard Hodes Advertising Inc., a subsidiary of Doyle Dane Bernbach International, acquiring the Florida offices of CM&B Advertising, the recruitment advertising subsidiary of Campbell-Mithun Inc.

title: FOUNDATION URGES EFFORTS FOR GENERAL EDUCATION
description: A private foundation is urging the revival of general education in American colleges, saying the pendulum has swung too far toward specialized studies that feed ''self-preoccupation and social isolation.''

title: General Instrument Up 30.3% in 4th Quarter
description: The General Instrument Corporation, a leading producer and distributor of automated wagering systems, reported yesterday that earnings in the fourth quarter of the fiscal year 1980 that ended Feb. 28, increased 30.3 percent while revenues edged up nine-tenths of 1 percent.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: A POET SPEAKS

title: Shterna Sarah Garelik Bride Of Rabbi Hillel David Krinsky
description: Shterna Sarah Garelik, daughter of Rabbi and Mrs. Gershon M. Garelik of Milan, Italy, was married last night to Rabbi Hillel David Krinsky, son of Rabbi and Mrs. Yehuda Krinsky of Brooklyn.

title: Invesco Settlement
description: The Invesco International Corporation said that a Federal judge had approved a $1.1 million judgment as settlement of a suit contending that the company had mined Government-owned coal.

title: COUNTDOWN ON LIFTOFF FOR SHUTTLE RESUMES AS PROBLEMS ARE SOLVED
description: Technicians caught up with a backlog of problem-solving work today and resumed the interrupted countdown for the first launching of the space shuttle Columbia.

title: Bridge: Second-Seeded Team Gains In Grand Nationals Contest
description: Grand National knockout team play during the weekend proved almost as difficult for the top-ranked teams in the New Jersey-Westchester County section as it did in New York City and Long Island. One of the top four seeded teams survived in Montvale, N.J., and Teaneck, N.J., as against none in Manhasset, L.I.

title: Mexican Meal; Guacamole
description: 3 tomatoes 2 fresh green chilies 2 avocados 1/2 small onion, minced 2 tablespoons fresh coriander, chopped Coarse salt and freshly ground pepper Juice 1 lemon.

title: Communications Unit Set by Abell Co.
description: The A.S. Abell Company, publisher of The Baltimore Sun and Evening Sun, said it had formed an electronic communications subsidiary.

title: Bloedel Tug-of-War May Not Be at End
description: A dispute yesterday over corporate takeover rules could indicate that the tug-of-war for control of MacMillan Bloedel Ltd. may not be about to end, despite a recommendation from MacMillan directors that shareholders accept the $62 cash and shares offer of Noranda Mines Ltd. of Toronto.

title: EAST SIDER URGES A DRY CITY TO LET HIM WATER TREES
description: J. Langdon Sullivan was getting ready to water the trees in front of his town house on 80th Street between Park and Lexington Avenues the other day. Then, he said, ''this thing hit us between the eyes.''

title: SENATOR HELMS OFFERS A FARM BILL AT ODDS WITH REAGAN PROPOSALS
description: Senator Jesse Helms, chairman of the Agriculture Committee, today introduced a farm bill that sharply differed from the Reagan Administration's proposals for supporting the prices of peanuts, milk and grains.

title: G.M. Sees Talk on Labor Costs
description: The president of the General Motors Corporation, F. James McDonald, said today that he expected G.M. and the United Automobile Workers union to ''get conversations started'' within a few weeks on ways to reduce the company's labor costs.

title: 3 DEAD IN GRAIN ELEVATOR EXPOLSION
description: A 14-story concrete public grain elevator exploded in flames 20 minutes before the 3:30 P.M. shift change today, killing at least three workers and injuring more than 30 others, including seven Federal inspectors.

title: CASEY SUGGESTS REAGAN BACKS LAWS TO IMPROVE SECRECY
description: The Director of Central Intelligence, William J. Casey, told a House subcommittee today that he believed President Reagan would give his ''full cooperation'' to measures to improve procedures to provide false identities for covert intelligence agents.

title: CITY MOVES TO SHUT UN LICENSED ARCADES
description: New York City's Commissioner of Consumer Affairs led a band of assistants into an electronic-games arcade in midtown Manhattan yesterday and announced that the establishment was unlicensed and should close.

title: N.F.L.
description: The 1981 National Football League Schedule. Saturday, Sept. 5 Minnesota at Tampa Bay, 8 P.M. Sunday, Sept. 6 Baltimore at New England, 1 P.M. Dallas at Washington, 1 P.M. Green Bay at Chicago, 1 P.M. Houston at Los Angeles, 1 P.M. Kansas City at Pittsburgh, 1 P.M. Miami at St. Louis, 12 noon. New Orleans at Atlanta, 1 P.M. Jets at Buffalo, 4 P.M. Oakland at Denver, 2 P.M. Philadelphia at Giants, 1 P.M. San Francisco at Detroit, 1 P.M. Seattle at Cincinnati, 1 P.M. Monday, Sept. 7 San Diego at Cleveland, 9 P.M. Thursday, Sept. 10 Pittsburgh at Miami, 8:30 P.M. Sunday, Sept. 13 Atlanta at Green Bay, 12 noon. Buffalo at Baltimore, 2 P.M. Chicago at San Francisco, 1 P.M. Cincinnati at Jets, 4 P.M. Denver at Seattle, 1 P.M. Detroit at San Diego, 1 P.M. Houston at Cleveland, 1 P.M. Los Angeles at New Orleans, 12 noon. New England at Philadelphia, 4 P.M. Giants at Washington, 1 P.M. St. Louis at Dallas, 3 P.M. Tampa Bay at Kansas City, 12 noon.

title: President Chosen At American Can
description: Frank J. Connor, 50 years old, has been named president and chief operating officer of the American Can Company. He will succeed William S. Wood@side, 59, who will continue as chairman and chief executive officer of the Greenwich, Conn., corporation.

title: PUERTO RICO IS CONSIDERING A BILL TO LICENSE JOURNALISTS
description: The compulsory licensing of journalists, enforced by law in seven Latin American countries but considered unconstitutional in the United States, is being considered in Puerto Rico.

title: BEST BUYS
description: SPRING fruits and vegetables are coming in at lower prices, with those items that were affected by the Florida freeze considerably cheaper as the new crop arrives. Squash, string beans, tomatoes and cucumbers are down in price and expected to decline further, as are asparagus and strawberries.

title: FLORIO OPENS JERSEY DRIVE WITH A PLEA TO MODERATES
description: With old-fashioned political razzmatazz - two bands blaring, balloons bobbing and bursting, straw hats and emblazoned T-shirts, flowing beer and roaring cheers - Representative James J. Florio began his campaign for the Democratic nomination for Governor last night.

title: 5 at Oscar Mayer To Get $6.8 Million
description: The five top executives at Oscar Mayer & Company will get at least $6.8 million in cash, salaries and bonuses during the next five years under terms for the proposed $465 million sale of the Madison-based concern to the General Foods Corporation. The terms were made public today.

title: Administration Wins Two Tests In Effort to Reactivate Old Ships
description: Reagan Administration proposals to resurrect World War II warships survived twin challenges in Congress today, with opponents charging that the vessels would be a waste of money but backers saying they were needed to bolster a sagging United States fleet.

title: EAST GERMANS DIVIDED ON INTERVENTION
description: Three of the most influential members of the Politburo of the East German Communist Party have argued for military intervention by the Warsaw Pact as the only certain means of resolving the Polish crisis, a Western official said here today.

title: Cornelis Verolme Dies; Was Dutch Shipbuilder
description: Cornelis Verolme, a marine engineer who became one of the Netherlands' principal shipbuilders, died Sunday at a hospital in Rotterdam at the age of 80. He lived in Ridderkerk, a Rotterdam suburb.

title: EX-FRIEND TESTIFIES AGAINST WILLIAMS
description: An alleged co-conspirator who turned Government witness testified yesterday that Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. was willing to accept $20,000 in ''expense money'' from Abscam undercover agents if the witness could receive the money for him. The payment was not made because the agents insisted on giving the money to the Senator himself, the witness said at the New Jersey Democrat's bribery and conspiracy trial in Federal District Court in Brooklyn.

title: Selling a State's Cement
description: The South Dakota State Cement Company, the only cement company owned by a state, has appointed Robert G. McAlister, 47, president and chief executive officer. The company in Rapid City has a plant capacity of more than a million tons.

title: ON THE SCENT OF WHAT SELLS A PERFUME
description: WHY does one new fragrance soar while another sinks? Is it the name, the price, the packaging, the promotion, or could it possibly be what the consumer is actually supposed to be buying - the fragrance itself?

title: PRUDENTIAL IS BRANCHING OUT
description: Tucked away in the heart of this New Jersey city, the Prudential Insurance Company of America is somewhat removed from the competitive fervor of Wall Street.

title: SOVIET INTENTIONS IN POLAND
description: The Reagan Administration publicly took the position today that despite all the worrisome signs, a Soviet invasion of Poland is neither imminent or inevitable. Others with long experience of Moscow's policies expressed serious caution about the outlook.

title:
Baseball Notebook; 
Busby Gives Up Comeback Bid
description: Steve Busby, who was once the star pitcher of the Kansas City Royals but who struggled with shoulder problems the last five years after tearing a rotator cuff, announced his retirement yesterday.

title: The Police Blotter
description: Two small firebombs exploded in a building on Manhattan's Lower East Side that houses a branch office of the Israeli-based Bank Leumi Trust Company. Three men were seen running from the scene of the explosion, a stairwell of the three-story building at 85 Delancey Street. ... A 14-year-old Brooklyn youth, William Ojeda, and his 18-year-old brother, Angel, were charged with murder in the stabbing of another teen-ager on a southbound D train Monday night. The victim was identified as Steven Best, 18, of 4169 Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: SUPERMARKET STRATEGIES: HOW TO SAVE MONEY
description: SHOP for specials and redeem coupons: These are obvious methods of stretching grocery dollars. By applying a number of other commonsense strategies, the budget-conscious food shopper - and who isn't? - can further alleviate the pain at the supermarket checkout counter.

title: Q.  I have heard of - but never tasted - a dessert called Mississippi mud pies or simply mud pies, and wonder if there is actually such a dish. Is it a regional dish and have you heard of it?
description: A. I suspect it is a new gimmick and cannot be classified as regional or traditional. It consists, I am told, of a chocolate cookie crust filled with chocolate or coffee-brandy ice cream. It may or may not be garnished on top with shaved chocolate or chocolate curls.

title: The Worth of a Korean Promise
description: The Reagan Administration correctly insists that its low-key human rights policy should be judged by its fruits. They have ripened in South Korea, and the taste is bitter.

title: Alitalia Mechanics Call a Strike
description: Italy's national airline Alitalia canceled most international flights originating at Rome's Leonardo da Vinci airport today as flight mechanics seeking higher pay began a threeday strike. A three-hour walkout by luggage handlers delayed some domestic flights as well.

title: DOCTORS SAY REAGAN SHOWS NO INFECTION
description: Eight days after suffering a chest wound in an assassination attempt, President Reagan was up and about in his hospital room in ''excellent spirits,'' with no sign of any bacterial infection that might slow his recovery, his doctors reported today.

title: Exxon Office Unit Plans Price Cuts
description: The Exxon Office Systems Company said yesterday that it was cutting prices on two models of its Vydec word processors by $1,500 and offering volume discounts on its complete line of Qyx electronic typewriters.

title: International Bank Battle
description: In a rare battle among international banks, the Hongkong and Shanghai Bank has made a bid to acquire the Royal Bank of Scotland, the fifth largest in Britain.

title: DINNER FOR EIGHT FOR LESS THAN $25
description: ONCE most of us have filed our tax returns, we feel too poor and depressed to entertain. But take heart. If you've invited friends for dinner it is possible, even these days, to serve a delicious dinner to eight guests for less than $25.

title: Advertising; Tums Goes To a New Agency
description: THAYER of Tuckahoe, N.Y., a subsidiary of Revlon, has switched its Tums antacid tablets with billings of about $7 million to Jordan, Case & McGrath.

title: THJE LITERATI'S APPRECIATION FOR BASEBALL
description: Ernest Hemingway wrote to Lillian Ross in 1948 that she was quite right to run rather than slide while playing softball. ''Sliding actually is a threat to cut the man at the bag so he will be out of the game,'' he said. ''It also raises dust and if you can really come in, you can avoid the tag as far as possible.''

title: A NIGHT SURCHARGE FOR CABS EXPECTED
description: The New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission is expected today to impose a 50-cent surcharge for night and Sunday taxi rides in what it says is an effort to get more cabs on the city's streets.

title: Two Win Nominations To Succeed Mrs. Spellman
description: Steny Hoyer, a Democrat, and Audrey Scott, the Republican Mayor of Bowie, Md., today won their parties' nominations for the Congressional seat vacated by Representative Gladys Noon Spellman, who has been comatose since suffering a heart attack last October.

title: DR. MORROE BERGER, 63, A SOCIOLOGY PROFESSOR AND NEAR EAST EXPERT
description: Dr. Morroe Berger, a professor of sociology at Princeton University who was an authority on the Near East, died today, apparently of a heart attack, at his home in Princeton. He was 63 years old.

title: Antonowsky Moves Up At Columbia Pictures
description: Marvin Antonowsky, former agency research chief and NBC-TV vice president-programming, has been promoted to president of marketing and research at Columbia Pictures, which seems to like the title president more than most.

title: Police Chief Is Shot In Little Falls Bank
description: The Police Chief of this Passaic County community was shot three times by a man who had entered the Broadway Bank and Trust Company wearing a ski mask, the police said.

title: SHUTTLE JET IS DAMAGED IN COLLISION WITH BIRDS
description: A Boeing 727 jet carrying about 40 passengers was slightly damaged last night when it struck a flock of large birds 3,000 feet over the Hudson River near 34th Street, and sucked them into two engines.

title: HUSSEIN TELLS HAIG ISRAEL DISRUPTS AREA
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. was told by King Hussein of Jordan today that Israel was responsible for Middle East turmoil and instability.

title: TAXIS, TAXES: A VERITABLE HAIL OF COLLECTIBLES
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 LEADING DEMOCRATS JOIN DRIVE AGAINST REAGAN ECONOMIC PLAN
description: Democrats took the offensive against President Reagan's economic program today as House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. and Charles T. Manatt, the party's national chairman, charged that the program would fight inflation less than it would harm the poor.

title: Moscow's War Of Nerves
description: If Leonid Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, went to the Czechoslovak Communist Party conference in Prague to confuse the Reagan Administration about his handling of the crisis in Poland he succeeded, at least in part.

title: Chrysler Revives $50 Test-Drive Offer
description: the Chrysler Corporation announced the revival of an offer to pay $50 to customers who test-drive a new Chrysler car or truck and then buy a comparable vehicle from either Chrysler or a competitor.

title: Winburn Thomas, 75, Missionary In the Far East and Asia 30 Years
description: The Rev. Dr. Winburn T. Thomas, a missionary for the Presbyterian Church in the Far East and Asia for more than three decades, died of a heart attack on April 1 in Dacca, Bangladesh. He was 75 years old and had formerly lived in Larchmont, N. Y.

title: Suns 102, Kings 80
description: Walter Davis and Dennis Johnson scored 16 points each, and Len (Truck) Robinson led a third-period scoring flurry as Phoenix beat Kansas City in the opener of their four-of-seven-game Western Conference seminfinal playoff.

title: CITY STRUGGLING IN ATTEMPTS TO SELL TAX-DELINQUENT APARTMENT BUILDINGS
description: New York City has spent about $285 million in the last three years under its program to take over tax-delinquent apartment buildings, rehabilitate them and restore them to the tax rolls, but it has sold only 200 of the more than 10,000 it has acquired.

title: CONGRESS BEGINS FIGHT OVER EXTENSION OF VOTING RIGHTS ACT
description: The struggle over renewal of the Voting Rights Act began in earnest today as members of Congress from both parties introduced a bill to extend all the major provisions of the law to 1992.

title: EXXON CONFIRMS GAS PRICE CUTS
description: The Exxon Corporation cut wholesale gasoline prices in several states today by one-half cent to two cents a gallon, joining the parade of major companies that have reduced prices as a result of slack demand.

title: ABOUT WASHINGTON
description: A week after the awful event, as it might have been termed in Lincoln's day, capital life is indomitable. The trees are flowering pink and white around the grave of John F. Kennedy, working their way once again into a vista that looks idyllically across the Potomac upon the Government.

title: NEW ARRIVALS HEARLD SPRING AT BRONX ZOO
description: The New York Times/Edward Hausner Venturing out into the Polar Bear Moat yesterday at the Bronx Zoo, Russia stayed close to her cub, Snowflake, born last Nov. 23. In the rocky retreat of a herd of Sardinian wild sheep, a lamb nestled close to its mother. Mother was nowhere in sight at the Bird House, but John Wilhelm, a keeper, offered comforting words to a newly hatched tawny frog-mouth bird, which was quite at home sitting in a basket.

title: AMF'S NEW FOCUS: THE ENERGY MARKET
description: After the Arab oil embargo and the recession several years ago, AMF Inc. found itself with an amalgam of unprofitable leisure companies, a ballooning debt and a consumer less than eager for such corporate trademarks as Head skis, Harley-Davidson motorcycles and Hatteras yachts.

title: IN UNEMPLOYMENT' EMPLOY
description: To the Editor:

title: Super Valu Chief's Goals
description: Michael W. Wright, the 42-year-old president of Super Valu Stores, the nation's largest grocery wholesaler, has been elected to the additional post of chief executive officer, effective after the company's annual meeting on June 26. He will succeed Jack J. Crocker, 56, who will continue as chairman of the Minneapolis company.

title: Stars Come Out for Opening Night of 'Fools'
description: Jacqueline Onassis didn't make her expected appearance, but her friend, Mike Nichols, had no reason to complain. There were enough celebrities at Monday's opening night party for Neil Simon's ''Fools'' to keep the flash units flashing long into the night.

title: Real Estate; Restaurants And Lease Subletting
description: NOWADAYS, say the store brokers, the owners of commercial buildings in Manhattan are likely to put severe restrictions on subletting in their leases. ''They see to it that no one will make a profit off their lease except themselves,'' as one broker put it.

title: Lillian Gish: a Winner Before and a Winner Again
description: While Lillian Gish, the legendary film actress, was serving as guest preacher at St. Andrew's Episcopal Church in Murray Hill, N.J., last Sunday, Lillian Gish, a 3-year old chestnut mare, was winning her first race.

title: Seized Prison Guards Freed
description: Three Federal prison inmates, one armed with a pistol, held eight guards hostage briefly yesterday, then ended their apparent escape attempt because more guards were rushed to the scene, a prison spokesman said. No one was hurt.

title: Mt. Sinai Walkout Goes On for 2d Day
description: Several hundred employees at the Mount Sinai Medical Center struck for the second day yesterday to protest the center's absenteeism policy, which they charge is too strict.

title: AROUND THE NATION
description: A week after her move to a crime-ridden housing project, Mayor Jane M. Byrne says she will continue to keep her part-time project residence but will spend more time at her luxury North Side apartment, beginning at the end of the week.

title: A GUIDE TO SEASONAL DIFFERENCES IN FOOD
description: Improved methods of cultivation, shipping and storage have made many fruits and vegetables available all year. But there are seasonal differences in quality and price.

title: Squibb Set To Sell its New Drug; Analysts Split on Capoten Market
description: E.R. Squibb & Sons Inc. announced yesterday that Capoten, a drug for the treatment of serious forms of high blood pressure, had been approved by the Federal Drug Administration and supplies would be available to hospitals and pharmacies within a few days.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Archer Group Inc. agreed with a group headed by the John W. Mecom Co. of Houston to buy 3 percent of the Mecom group's interest in a 62,000-acre gas and oil exploratory property in southern Louisiana.

title: BREXHNEV EXPRESSES VIEW THAT POLAND CAN SOLVE ITS CRISIS
description: Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, said today that he thought Polish Communists would be able to end the country's crisis by themselves.

title: WHAT MAY KEEP CARTER DOWN ON THE FARM
description: To the Editor:

title: ABC 'MASADA' SCORES HIGH IN RATINGS
description: Will ABC-TV's enormous investment in the eight-hour version of ''Masada'' prove profitable, or will the series simply prove to be a prestigious loss leader?

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Campbell Soup Company, Camden, N.J., has elected Zoe Coulson to the new position of vice president-consumer services.

title: Accounts
description: * The New York Hilton and Old Tyme Jamaican Style Products Inc., for its Jamaican Ginger Beer and assorted line of soft drinks, to Fearon/O'Leary Associates Ltd.

title: Index; International
description: Reaction to hijacking points up stability of Pakistani regime A2 Afghan rebels are said to win major victory A2 U.N. officials uncertain on peace- keeping role in Lebanon A3 Filipino voters give big margin to Marcos on charter revisions A4 Around the World A5 Iran closes largest opposition newspaper A6 3 East German leaders said to favor intervention in Poland A8 Excerpts from Brezhnev's ad- dress A9 Government/Politics Fight begins over Voting Rights Act extension A10 U.S. reports says households vic- timized by crime have declined A10 Puerto Rico considers compulsory licensing of journalists A13 Reagan support indicated on se- crecy for covert agents A14 Reports find business gifts to top Congress leaders increase A15 Democrats join offensive against Reagan economic program A18 Food stamp battle on Capitol is joined but is already half over A25 Florio announces candidacy for gubernatorial nomination B2 City shutting down unlicensed electronic arcades B3 Former prosecutor testifies about retainer at Margiotta trial B6 Energy No flooding damage found to Rec- tor No. 2 at Indian Point B2 General Around the Nation A11 Car identified in Halberstam mur- der trial A22 New York getting Miss Universe contest first time B2 Relative questions identity of a murder victim B4 East Side tree lover seeks exemp- tion on watering ban B4 The Living Section Food Supermarket strategies: How to save money C1

title: Cummins Engine Expects Record Net
description: The Cummins Engine Company, a diversified manufacturer of heavy-duty trucks and diesel engines, said it expects its profits for the first quarter ended April 5 to top the record $22.5 million, or $2.66 a share, earned in the comparable 1979 quarter.

title: IN PARIS, FASHION INCURSIONS FROM ABROAD
description: The French are not particularly receptive to foreigners on their fashion turf. But since they are convinced that they are the leaders, they will tolerate some incursions from outsiders who want to take advantage of the huge audience of buyers from throughout the world that the French fashion shows attract. The operating rule, however, is that visitors maintain a low profile and do not try to seize center stage.

title: Crime Control, Cost Control
description: A society traumatized by violent crime should be willing to pay what it costs to make the streets safer. And signs from Albany are that New York's criminal justice system will soon be fortified with extra police officers, prosecutors, judges and prison cells.

title: CRIME SAID TO TOUCH 30% OF HOUSEHOLDS
description: A Justice Department report said today that the number of crimes has increased over the last six years but that the percentage of Americans victimized by crime has slightly declined.

title: REAGAN'S MAIN AIDES ASSAIL RIVAL BUDGET AS 'SAME OLD TUNE'
description: Senior aides to President Reagan, increasingly concerned that his hospital stay might rob his economic program of momentum in Congress, began a counterattack today against the alternative proposals put forward this week by the Democrats.

title: Red Brigades Kill Warden In Show of Power in Rome
description: -Gunmen of the Red Brigades terrorist group killed a prison warden today in Rome, then called the press to say that this was their way of proving that they were able to continue terrorist attacks despite the arrest of Mario Moretti, their military commander, on Saturday.

title: U.N. UNCERTAIN ON LEBANON ROLE
description: High United Nations officials suggested today that an expansion of the United Nations peacekeeping force in Lebanon would offer the best prospect for restoring a measure of peace to that country. But they have concluded that there is virtually no chance such a plan would be accepted by Arab countries or the Soviet Union.

title: ABBIE HOFFMAN GETS PRISON TERM OF UP TO THREE YEARS FOR COCAINE SALE
description: Abbie Hoffman, the counterculture leader of the 1960's who surrendered in 1980 after six years in hiding, was sentenced yesterday to up to three years in prison. Last January he pleaded guilty to selling $36,000 worth of cocaine to undercover policemen in 1973.

title: Memories of Leafs Painful to Islanders
description: Pavlov never played in the National Hockey League, but his conditioning theory might have some bearing on the outcome of the three-of-five-game first-round playoff between the Islanders and the Toronto Maple Leafs, which starts at 8:05 tonight at Nassau Coliseum in Uniondale, L.I.

title: TO MEET WITH CAREY TODAY
description: The special session of the Legislature called by Governor Carey to resolve what he called ''critical'' budget issues was halted today when the Senate majority leader sent the members of his house off on vacation until April 28. However, the majority leader, Warren M. Anderson of Binghamton, a Republican, agreed to meet with the Governor and other legislative leaders tomorrow morning on the subject of the 1981-82 budget.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: 1. Six-Sided Puzzle

title: Karoly, Coach Of Miss Comaneci, Defects to U.S.
description: Three Rumanian gymnastics experts, including the coach of Nadia Comaneci, defected to the United States in a meeting with State Department officials today, according to State Department sources.

title: Back Into the Frying Pan
description: Anxious Poland watchers can start breathing again, but they will need to keep watching as well. The Soviet leader, Leonid Brezhnev, turned down the heat yesterday by affirming that Poland's own Communist leaders could defend ''the honor and security of their country,'' presumably without any immediate need for fraternal assistance from Warsaw Pact troops. The extended maneuvers of Soviet, East German and Czechoslovak forces in and around Poland have at last ended, and the armies are ''returning to the places of their permanent stationing.''

title: 2 South African Buildings Are Burned in Rent Protest
description: Demonstrators burned a Government building and a beer hall today in violence touched off by Government-ordered 70 percent rent increases in black townships near here.

title: BALTIMORE'S JUNE FESTIVAL
description: BRITAIN has the Edinburgh Festival, Italy has Spoleto and the United States has Baltimore. Baltimore? That city plans to put itself on the global theater map in June with the ambitious Baltimore International Theater Festival. At least 12 major companies from around the world are expected to participate in the three-week event, from June 6 to 27.

title: BILL TO IMPROVE ECONOMIC RIGHTS OF WOMEN PROPOSED IN CONGRESS
description: Three Republican Senators and 17 members of the House of Representatives today proposed legislation that is intended to improve the rights of women in pensions, insurance, inheritances, child care and military service.

title: AFGHAN REBELS SAID TO WIN BATTLE
description: Moslem rebels battling the Sovietinstalled regime of President Babrak Karmal in Afghanistan have won a major victory by killing or wounding hundreds of Afghan troops and capturing a town in Nangarhar Province, an Afghan exile reported today.

title: Courthouse Cleared As Fire Breaks Out
description: More than 1,000 people were removed from the Essex County Courthouse after a fire broke out in the basement of the 12-story building. Four firemen were injured and a Superior Court judge, Charles E. Villanueva, was given oxygen at the scene.

title: by Terry Robards; ELMIRA HEIGHTS, N.Y.
description: THE wines of the 1980 vintage in New York State have just made their public debut here and lived up to their advance billing, showing great charm and balance. They are clearly the best wines made in the state since World War II and may be the best of the century.

title: The Budget Targets Fifth in a series on key programs; that President Reagan wants to cut.
description: The program designed to assist workers caught in long-term unemployment is scheduled for substantial shrinking under President Reagan's plans to reduce Federal spending.

title: FAILURES AT RECORD IN BRITAIN
description: - British businesses are going into liquidation at a record average rate of 174 a week, the Dun & Bradstreet credit rating agency reported today.

title: West Coast SSC&B Gets A New General Manager
description: The West Coast office of SSC&B has a new general manager - John H.A. Cross. The Los Angeles office, which used to be Erwin Wasey Inc., is billing in the neighborhood of $10 million these days since the bulk of the Carnation business was moved to New York.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: 'CITY OF WOMEN' A SPECTACLE BY FELLINI
description: BECAUSE ''City of Women,'' Federico Fellini's gigantic new motionpicture spectacle, is so closely connected in one way and another to all of the 17 Fellini films that precede it, and because it is as much a culmination as a continuation, it's impossible to look at this latest work with the objectivity you might bring to a film by any other major director you can name.

title: Argentine Phone Contract
description: The Compagnie Generale de Constructions Telephoniques and a subsidiary of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, Standard Electric of Argentina, have won a contract from Entel, the Argentine telephone company, for a 150,000-line telephone network, the French company said today. The network will be installed by the end of 1984, it added, but no financial details were given. The network is part of a 600,000-line system that will also involve other companies.

title: Lobbying 'Progress' Reported by Mayor
description: Mayor Koch returned from a day of lobbying in Washington yesterday and said he believed his efforts had paid off to some degree.

title: WEINBERGER EXHORTS ALLIES TO SHARE BURDEN OF DEFENSE
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger turned a routine meeting today with Western Europe's Defense Ministers into a strong advertisement for the Reagan Administration's military policy, and he made it clear that the Europeans were expected to do their full share.

title: Woman Gives Birth to Boy In Disputed Surrogate Case
description: A woman who agreed to bear a baby by artificial insemination for a childless New York couple and then decided to keep the child herself has given birth to a boy.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, APRIL 8, 1981
description: International An end of the Warsaw Pact maneuvers was announced by Moscow. It said that all troops, including those who joined the three-week-long exercises over the weekend, were speedily returning to their bases. Earlier, Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, said he believed that Poland's Communist leaders could resolve the country's crisis by themselves. (Page A1, Column 6.) The State Department reacted warily to the Soviet statements about Poland, calling Moscow's intentions unclear and describing military activity by the Warsaw Pact countries as continuing at ''unusual levels.'' (A1:5.)

title: U.S. Studies Steel Imports
description: The Government has detected surges in specialty steel imports from five nations and has begun considering imposing countervailing duties or antidumping steps, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: FILIPINO VOTERS GIVE A BIG MARGIN TO MARCOS ON CHARTER REVISIONS
description: Filipinos voted today on a complex set of constitutional amendments that would in effect allow President Ferdinand E. Marcos to run for a new six-year term.

title: BUSINESS GIFTS TO TOP CONGRESSMEN TERMED HEAVY
description: The top leaders of Congress received $6.5 million from political action committees in their most recent election campaigns, almost two-thirds of it from business interests, Common Cause said today.

title: KINGS' RICK MARTIN IN GOOD COMPANY
description: He has played only one game with the Los Angeles Kings since a controversial trade, but tomorrow night Rick Martin will open the playoffs in one of hockey's most explosive positions - left wing on a line with Marcel Dionne and Dave Taylor.

title: BREZHNEV TALK EXCERPTED
description: Following are excerpts from the speech yesterday by Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, to the Czechoslovak party congress in Prague as distributed in English by Tass, the Soviet press agency:

title: INDIAN PT. REACTOR NEAR REOPENING
description: The technical staff of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said today that Consolidated Edison's No. 2 nuclear reactor at Indian Point, N.Y., apparently suffered no damage from a flooding accident last October. The decision left the way clear for the unit to be restarted soon, perhaps later this month.

title: Reorganization Proceeds At Wells, Rich, Greene
description: The four members of the board of directors of Wells, Rich, Greene will be voting on a broad reorganization plan when they meet April 20 to plan ahead to 1982 when the agency cracks through the $500 million-in-billings mark.

title: Emanuele Ronzoni Jr., Led Macaroni Concern
description: Emanuele Ronzoni Jr., chairman of the board of the Ronzoni Macaroni Company of Long Island City, Queens, died Monday at St. Francis Hospital in Roslyn, L.I. He was 77 years old and lived in Port Washington, L.I.

title: DANCE: A SURPRISING HOUSTON BALLET
description: THE Houston Ballet made its New York debut last night with a program that conceivably could have been described in advance but suddenly burst forth with surprises.

title: CITY DISCOVERS WEAKNESS IN FRAME OF NEW 2-MAN SANITATION TRUCKS
description: The two-man trucks recently purchased by New York City's Sanitation Department to increase productivity contain welding weaknesses in their frames that could lead to breakdowns, Koch administration officials said yesterday.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Aztec Energy Corporation filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission an intial offering of five million common shares to be sold through underwriters headed by Rocky Mountain Securities and Investment.

title: United Brands Loan
description: The United Brands Company said it had arranged a $250 million, 27-month revolving credit and term loan plan with a group of 11 banks led by the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company.

title: A Dozen Tips
description: 1. Pay attention to sales. 2. Use price-off coupons. 3. Plan meals in advance. 4.

title: IDENTITY OF MURDERED MAN IS QUESTIONED BY LAWYER
description: Doubts about whether a New York man who was murdered in Wisconsin was William H. Callahan, the subject of inquiries into a multimillion-dollar embezzlement scheme, were raised yesterday by a cousin of Mr. Callahan's wife.

title: Market Place; Raising Money For Oil and Gas
description: WALL STREET has been devising new ways to raise money for oil and natural gas programs at a time when drilling needs have outpaced capital development. The latest approach is a novel one that permits individual investors to convert unmarketable oil and gas interests into a new company's marketable common shares.

title: Air Staff Fights Bid
description: Employees of Continental Air Lines today announced a plan intended to keep Texas International Airlines from gaining control of Continental. Details of the plan, involving the issuance of new stock, are to be announced tomorrow by the newly formed Continental Employees Association.

title: MAKING NONWHEAT BREAD BEFORE PASSOVER
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Rebecca Boroson is a freelance writer and editor. By REBECCA BOROSON

title: CHANGE IN SCHOOLS' READING TEST WEIGHED
description: New York City public school pupils were squirming in their seats and scratching their heads yesterday as they once again endured the annual reading test.

title: AROUND THE NATION
description: Vincent Schoemehl Jr., a 34-year-old city alderman, won a 2-to-1 election victory today to become the youngest mayor of St. Louis in more than a century.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: WHEN I began my apprenticeship as a chef in Paris a good many years ago, almost every dish that was created in the kitchen of the Restaurant Drousant where I worked was prepared by ''the book.'' And the book was Escoffier.

title: Careers; Old People: A Viable Market
description: THE apparent quick recovery of 70-year-old President Reagan from his bullet wound has focused new interest on aging. Professional organizations have also been conducting research into the impact of older persons on the nation's economy.

title: PARTS MAKERS RESIST U.A.W.
description: The United Automobile Workers union, which has recently won key organizing showdowns with General Motors in the South, has had considerably less success in unionizing the companies that make auto parts, which now account for most of the auto jobs in the region.

title: Sexual-Assault Bill Signed by O'Neill
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill signed into law a bill allowing married persons or ''cohabitors'' to charge each other with rape.

title: CHILD-ABUSE PARLEY DEPLORES FUND CUTS
description: One of every four American girls is sexually abused before the age of 18. More than 500,000 cases of child abuse are reported every year and it is estimated that 1.5 million other cases go unreported. Since abused children are inclined to become abusive adults, the syndrome of child abuse and neglect is passed from one generation to the next unless it is overcome by treatment or prevention.

title: TAXIS, TAXES: A VERITABLE HAIL OF COLLECTIBLES
description: To the Editor:

title: CONSUMER DEBT SOARS $2 BILLION
description: Consumer borrowing surged by $2 billion in February, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. It was the largest increase since February 1980, when a $2.9 billion rise contributed to President Carter's decision to impose credit controls throughout the economy. The annual rate of increase spurted to 8 percent in February from 3 percent in January and 1 percent for all of 1980.

title: DETAILS OF LIFE UNDER ALIAS EMERGE
description: Ross Eugene Fields, the boxing promoter who for years used the name Harold J. Smith, failed today to gain the release from the Los Angeles County jail that his attorneys predicted yesterday. The $200,000 bail that was to have been posted by his friends ran into paperwork snags, according to his attorney, Robert Michaels, Later, a judge doubled the bail in response to a North Carolina warrant served today that charged Mr. Fields with ''theft by deception.''

title: NOTES ON PEOPLE;
description: John McGarry, a 47-year-old former New York City policeman who is retired on a disability, is to collect $25,000 from the Federal Government for injuries he received in 1976 when he was struck by a State Department security vehicle escorting Nancy Kissinger to the Muhammad Ali-Ken Norton championship fight in Yankee Stadium.

title: Judge in Boston School Case To Appoint a Special Master
description: A Superior Court judge said today that he would appoint a special master to determine how much money was available in Boston's treasury to keep schools open for the full school year.

title:
RED SMITH;
Happy New Year
description: THERE was a time when this would have been New Year's Day. Caesar designated Jan. 1 as the start of the calendar year, but Big Julie doesn't have his old clout anymore. Until recently, the roundball and hockey players would stow their playthings about the time the ice went out of the rivers, and the new sports year would begin on opening day of the baseball season. Now the indoor playoffs go on past Memorial Day, and there's no longer a clear line marking the end of winter and the arrival of spring.

title: RATES DIP AS TRADERS MANEUVER
description: Short-term and long-term interest rates declined yesterday, reversing most of the previous day's sharp increases. While interest rates fluctuated widely over the last two days, securities dealers said most of the changes stemmed from short-term trading strategies and had little to do with investor demand for securities.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Friday incorrectly characterized the appointment of Dr. Arthur Hull Hayes Jr. as Commissioner of Food and Drugs. The position does not require Senate confirmation.

title: Jets Run Test Patterns
description: In their first plays yesterday under the new offensive plan, in which the backfield is in motion on every snap in an effort to confuse the defense, it was the Jets who looked confused. The backs ran to the wrong side, or did not move at all.

title: Young Pro Changes His Style for Masters S02.3-
description: Without being pushed into the sport, John Cook became a golfer capable enough to win the United States Amateur championship at age 20 and polished enough to win a tournament in his second year on the PGA Tour. In fact, in a sense, he came up via motor racing.

title: IRAN'S LARGEST OPPOSITION NEWSPAPER ORDERED CLOSED
description: Iran's revolutionary prosecutor general today ordered the country's largest opposition newspaper to cease publication.

title: COAL STRIKE EFFECT SEEN AS MINOR
description: A prolonged coal strike could cause American producers to lose some future long-term contracts with foreign customers, analysts say, but the amounts involved are not expected to be large.

title: Salvadorans Say 37 Rebels Were Killed in Single Clash
description: At least 37 leftist guerrillas were killed in a clash with El Salvador's security forces early today in the foothills of the San Jacinto range three miles east of here, a military spokesman said.

title: Kendall Oil Moves To Al Paul Lefton Inc.
description: Kendall Motor Oil has just moved to Al Paul Lefton Inc., New York office.

title: TAXIS, TAXES: A VERITABLE HAIL OF COLLECTIBLES
description: To the Editor:

title: HOW STATE INSURANCE OPENED UP THE 'UNION GRAB BAG'
description: To the Editor:

title: Conrail to Ask 6% Rate Rise
description: The Consolidated Rail Corporation announced today that it would seek a 6 percent freight rate increase, to begin July 1. It would expand revenues about $240 million a year.

title: SAVE LEGAL SERVICES
description: Despite bar association efforts here and elsewhere in support of the endangered Legal Services Corporation, among individual lawyers ominous lines are drawn between those who want the Corporation to exist and those who agree with the Reagan Administration's recommendation that it be abolished in fiscal 1982.

title: NEW COLEMAN STUDY IS DEFENDED AND CRITICIZED BY 500 EDUCATORS
description: A new study that concludes that private high schools provide a better education than public high schools encountered sharp criticism today at a seminar attended by nearly 500 educators.

title: Running the M.T.A. Into the Ground
description: While all New Yorkers agree that the city and suburban transit systems are falling apart, the state's leaders disagree on how to help. And while they palaver in Albany, rank-and-file legislators are turning a relatively simple legal remedy into something as complicated as the rules for choosing wild-card teams for pro football playoffs.

title: N.F.L. Announces Schedule
description: The National Football League has announced its schedule for the 1981 season. The listings for all the teams appear on page B12.

title: U.S. OFFICIALS BRIEF TOKYO ON CAR WOES
description: Visiting American officials briefed the Japanese Government today on the ''parlous condition'' of the American auto industry but made no request for Japanese voluntary restraint on car exports that took close to a quarter of the American market in 1980, according to a spokesman.

title: Voters in Emporia, Kan., Reject A Move to Back Pistol Controls
description: Eight days after President Reagan was shot, Emporia residents voted today against recommending that the Legislature impose stronger pistol controls. The final but unofficial results were 3,537 against controls and 1,407 in favor.

title: Multinationals: U.S. Slipping
description: American-based companies still outnumber foreign multinationals among the world's largest corporations, but the United States' domination of the roster of multinationals has slipped, a new report indicates.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: CLASSIC OUTLOOK

title: 100 Back House Protest On Arms Sales to Saudis
description: About 100 Republicans and Democrats in the House of Representatives supported a protest today against the Reagan Administration's plans to sell advanced weapons and equipment to Saudi Arabia.

title: TAYLOR: AFTER THE TURMOIL AND WANDERLUST
description: WEARING weathered jeans and a flapping khaki overcoat, James Taylor passed unrecognized recently when he ambled down an Upper West Side street on the way to his apartment. The 34-year-old singersongwriter's face looked leaner and more angular than it did in l970, when his song ''Fire and Rain'' and album ''Sweet Baby James'' were No. 1 hits. That song and album launched a new era in rock, the era of the sensitive, introverted singer-songwriter and of soft-rock. Mr. Taylor's music, which was widely imitated, combined the lilting melodies and acoustic guitars of folk music with an understated rockand-roll beat.

title: Players Request Mediation
description: On the eve of the opening of the strike-threatened baseball season, the Players Association submitted two proposals to the owners' labor representatives yesterday, then asked the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service to enter the negotiations.

title: SYRIANS AND LEBANESE BATTLING FOR HILLS
description: Fighting for control of the Lebanese Christian town of Zahle and its surroundings intensified today as Syrian troops moved to drive Christian militamen out of hill positions.

title: STATE DEPT. SAYS SOVIET INTENTIONS REMAIN UNCLEAR
description: The State Department, reacting warily to President Leonid I. Brezhnev's remarks on Poland, said today that Soviet intentions remained unclear and that military activity by Warsaw Pact countries continued at ''unusual levels.''

title: Simplicity Pattern To Add 3 to Board
description: Harold Cooper, chairman of the Simplicity Pattern Company, said that his company intended to add three representatives of NCC Energy Ltd., a London-based energy and minerals company, to its board.

title: PAKISTAN REACTION TO HIJACKING SHOWS ZIA'S STRENGTH
description: ''Before the hijacking,'' a senior Pakistani official said the other day, ''every Westerner stepped off the plane here and asked: 'Will the regime fall this week or next?' I think that's all over now.''

title: IN A PRICE WAR, REAL WINE BARGAINS
