description: THE retail wine market in the New York metropolitan area is in turmoil, and consumers are the beneficiaries. Bargains abound, for a fierce competitive battle is being waged by numerous stores offering wines at deep discounts, sometimes at wholesale cost.

title: The Cactus Submarine
description: Strategic thinkers at the Institute of High Dudgeon are beside themselves about what they construe as our attack on the MX missile system. ''So, wise guy, you think our plan for putting H-bombs on railroad trains and running them around the Southwestern deserts is dimwitted, eh?'' their letter begins.

title: The Della Femina Typewriter Caper
description: Not much surprises a person who has worked awhile at Della Femina, Travisano & Partners. But finding out that a typewriter stolen from the New York office has turned up in Alaska, well that's something to talk about.

title: U.S. MILITARY WOOING ARGENTINA, BUT RIGHTS ISSUE COULD INTERFERE
description: The Reagan Administration is sending a number of American military leaders to court Argentina, but the human rights situation that marred relations in the past remains unpredictable.

title: Key Rates
description: * Current rate excludes 3 percentage-point surcharge on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: WEDNESDAY, APRIL 8, 1981; The Economy
description: Consumer installment debt rose by $2 billion in February, the Federal Reserve Board said. The increase was the largest since a $2.9 billion rise last February, just before the Government ordered credit controls. About half of the broad-based expansion of debt resulted from auto loans, which were spurred by manufacturer rebates on car purchases. While the increase may reflect consumer confidence, it also brought the possibility of heightened inflationary pressures, some economists said. (D1.)

title: Economic Scene; Energy Supply And Strategies
description: WASHINGTON THE winter heating season is behind us, petroleum imports are down sharply, the industry is awash in gasoline and there is now talk of a peace treaty between Iraq and Iran, two major OPEC producers that have been engaged in undeclared war since September.

title: Supreme Court Refuses Appeal From Woman Who Shot at Ford
description: The Supreme Court, acting one week after President Reagan was shot, refused yesterday to hear an appeal by Sara Jane Moore, who is serving a life sentence for trying to assassinate President Ford.

title: MIXED MARKET DROPS 1.35 POINTS
description: An easing of short-term interest rates and lessening tensions in Poland permitted the stock market to register a small advance yesterday until the final hour of trading. The Dow Jones industrial average, ahead by nearly 3 points at 3 P.M., finished at 992.89, down 1.35 points.

title: MAN, 22, IS ARRESTED IN MANHATTAN FOR THREATENING THE PRESIDENT'S LIFE
description: A 22-year-old unemployed man armed with a .32-caliber revolver was arrested yesterday afternoon in the Port Authority bus terminal in midtown Manhattan on charges of threatening the life of President Reagan.

title: CONGRESSIONAL BATTLE ON FOOD STAMPS IS JOINED AND IS ALREADY HALF OVER
description: In a Senate committee room yesterday, Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, was denouncing food stamps as a ''fiscal monster'' and calling for even deeper cuts than those proposed by President Reagan. Today Mr. Helms introduced his own farm bill that would trim about $1 billion more from food stamps than the Reagan package would.

title: IN GUATEMALA, UNDER FOOT
description: When I saw Mateo not long ago, standing beside a smooth post on his veranda, he said, ''I had no idea this would happen when I started.'' Twelve years ago, Mateo's life was different. The black beans and maize corn he produced on his acre and a half in the Guatemalan highlands did not last his family, all young, until the next harvest. So each November he left his home for two months, migrating to work on a plantation on the humid southern coast.

title: G.A.O. SEEKS TO CUT DEFENSE CONSULTANTS
description: The Defense Department is weakening its ability to perform its essential tasks by relying too heavily on outside consultants, the General Accounting Office said in a report to Congress released today.

title: SEAGRAM WITHDRAWS ST. JOE BID
description: Joseph E. Seagram & Sons, the large wine and liquor company, said yesterday that it was withdrawing its $45-a-share offer to buy the St. Joe Minerals Corporation, making the Fluor Corporation the apparent winner in the bidding contest to take over St. Joe.

title: Tracing Food Stamps Through the Congress
description: This is one of a series of occasional articles tracing the progress of one program, food stamps, through the budget process.

title: BUCKS DEFEAT SIXERS
description: Julius Erving and Bobby Jones shut down Marques Johnson tonight in the first half. They were not that lucky in the second half.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt THE MODELMAKER'S HANDBOOK. By Albert Jackson and David Day. 352 pages. Illustrated. Knopf. $19.95.

title: FOCUS IS ON PITCHING FOR METS AND YANKS
description: Joe Torre headed the New York Mets toward Chicago today to open the baseball season and predicted that their summer's success would depend on the health of the pitching staff, despite the arrival of new punch at bat.

title: Buffalo Warned On Niagara Pollution
description: The Buffalo Sewer Authority has been warned that it will face action by the Department of Justice if it does not curb its pollution of the Niagara River.

title: THREE COMMAND CENTERS, FOCUSING ATTENTION ON EXPECTED SPACE SHUTTLE
description: California

title: Easter Pets Warning
description: City Health Department officials warned that Easter rabbits, ducklings and baby chicks are common hosts for salmonella bacteria, which can be transmitted to children who receive such pets as holiday gifts.

title: Brenner's Lawyer Lays Conspiracy to Sulaiman
description: A jury of four women and two men, all of whom, under questioning, said they had never heard of Floyd Patterson, Ken Norton or Don King and did not care about boxing, was chosen yesterday to hear Teddy Brenner's antitrust suit against the World Boxing Council and its president, Jose Sulaiman of Mexico.

title: ALFRED JENSEN, PAINTER OF PATTERNED ABSTRACTS, DIES
description: Alfred Jensen, a painter who used numerical systems as the basis for his art, died of cancer Saturday at a nursing home in Livingston, N.J. He was 77 years old and lived in Glen Ridge, N.J.

title: CITY GETS MISS UNIVERSE EVENT
description: New York City has been selected as the site of the 1981 Miss Universe Pageant, Karen Gerard, the Deputy Mayor for Economic Development, announced yesterday.

title: Linda Ronstadt To Record Special Album
description: Linda Ronstadt is planning to record an album of songs associated with such artists as Billie Holiday, Ella Fitzgerald and Sarah Vaughan. The album will be produced by Jerry Wexler and backed in a spare idiom using veteran jazz musicians.

title: UPSETS MARK WOMEN'S TENNIS
description: Their names are too far down on the Women's Tennis Association player computer to be noticed. But for today, Susan Rollinson, Joyce Portman, Kim Steinmetz and Nerida Gregory enjoyed an afternoon to remember in the Family Circle Cup tournament.

title: The U.N. Today; April 8, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Special Committee on Enhancing the Nonuse of Force in International Rela- tions - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: MUSIC: THE PHILADELPHIA AND MAHLER'S TWO SIDES
description: THE musical personality of Gustav Mahler shows two starkly contrasting sides, both of which had light shined on them last night when Klaus Tennstedt conducted the Philadelphia Orchestra's final Carnegie Hall program of the season.

title: ?Quotati?n?of the Day
description: ''But the Polish Communists, with the support of all genuine patriots of Poland, will be able, one should believe, to give a fitting rebuff to the designs of the enemies of the socialist system who are at the same time the enemies of Poland's independence, will be able to uphold the cause of socialism, the genuine interests of the Polish people, the honor and security of their motherland.'' - Leonid I. Brezhnev. (A9:1.)

title: ZABAGLIONE POTS
description: A DESSERT that would nicely follow any graceful, well-prepared meal is zabaglione, an eggs-and-wine mixture that takes barely minutes to cook. Frothy and rich, zabaglione has the best chance of success when the appropriate equipment is used in its preparation.

title: Homestake Mining Buys Out Partner
description: the Homestake Mining Company said it had bought out its partner, the United Nuclear Corporation, for $23 million and would assume operation of the partnership's four uranium mines and one mill.

title: Group Protests in U.N. Building Over Syrian Attacks in Lebanon
description: About a dozen Lebanese and American protesters conducted a brief protest in the Security Council chamber here today over attacks by Syrian troops in Lebanon.

title: Theaters Are Her Children
description: She's known as the ''Queen of Off Broadway,'' and some 300 of her admirers came to pay her court Monday night when the Museum of the City of New York opened its new Lucille Lortel gallery with an exhibition covering the actress-turned-angel's remarkable career.

title: NEW RULES DRAFTED FOR SOCIAL SECURITY
description: A House subcommittee reached tentative agreement today on a package of major changes in the Social Security System, including postponement of the age for full retirement from 65 years to 68.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARYTECH TEST HOLD FOR ROBERTS
description: AS Mari S. Gold was leaving the 92d Street Y one night after a recent concert, her eyes were drawn to a frenzy of movement across the street. A man was frantically pasting up flyers on the boxlike pedestal of a street light. ''He was working at a furious pace,'' she says, ''rolling on glue, slapping the flyer on all four sides of the box, and then running down the street to the next lamppost.''

title: Turkish Weekly Seized for Assailing Regime
description: The weekly magazine of former Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit was confiscated today for ''discrediting the security forces'' in an editorial in its last issue.

title: Dow Jones Profit Increases 26.1%
description: Dow Jones & Company, publisher of The Wall Street Journal, reported yesterday that its net income in the first quarter of 1981 increased 26.1 percent, to $15 million, or 96 cents a share, from $11.9 million, or 77 cents a share, a year before.

title: EX-PROSECUTOR TELLS OF A RETAINER THAT WAS ARRANGED BY MARGIOTTA
description: William Cahn, the former Nassau County District Attorney, testified today that Joseph M. Margiotta helped arrange for him to receive a $2,000-a-month retainer from an insurance agency after he was defeated for re-election. Mr. Margiotta is the Republican chairman of Nassau County and the Town of Hempstead.

title: Payments Gap Wider for Bonn
description: West Germany had a balance-of-payments deficit of $2.84 billion in February, the Bundesbank said today. This was the biggest deficit since last April's $3.45 billion, the nation's central bank added.

title: SUBTERRANEAN REACH OF NUCLEAR BLASTS
description: To the Editor:

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: IF there is such a thing as ''the perfect exercise,'' swimming may come close to being it. It can be done by persons of all ages - from 3 to 103, and beyond - and in almost any physical shape.

title: HAIG ENDS MIDEAST TOUR SAYING RESULTS PLEASE HIM
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. ended his Middle East trip today saying that his mission had laid the groundwork for stronger ties with all countries in the region.

title: REDS TAKE OPENER, 3-2, ON WALK IN NINTH
description: The first game of the baseball season began without a baseball today. The traditional first ball, which was supposed to have been thrown by President Reagan before the Cincinnati Reds opened the major league season against the World Series champion Philadelphia Phillies, was replaced by a moment of thankful silence for the President's recovery from last week's assassination attempt.

title: Technology; Robot's Future As a Servant
description: FOR those who can afford to spend several thousand dollars on a somewhat clumsy, dimwitted and near-useless servant, the age of the personal robot is at hand. Industrial robots, which cost from $5,000 to $200,000, are playing a vital role in automating factories, performing such tasks as welding and assembling. Experts envision that robots will eventually move from industry to the home, as the computer is doing.

title: Times Co. Sells 66th St. Plant
description: The New York Times Company has sold a seven-story building at 66th Street and West End Avenue to Harry B. Helmsley and Irving Schneider, president and executive vice president of Helmsley-Spear Inc.

title: 'VOYAGE EN DOUCE,' 2 FRENCHWOMEN ON A JOURNEY
description: ''Voyage en Douce'' is a prettily overripe French film that appears, for quite a while, to be headed in a novel and interesting direction. Two beautiful women, evidently unhappy with the men in their lives, embark impetuously on a journey in the country, traveling over lush landscapes, sharing jokes and meals and erotic daydreams. This has the makings of a bawdy, spirited film about women and friendship, almost a women's ''Going Places.'' It turns out to be something else again.

title: DEBATE ON DEFENSE IS WIDENED IN JAPAN
description: For the first time since the post-World War II period, the Japanese are seriously debating some of the fundamental tenets of their postwar defense doctrine.

title: MORGENTHAU SAYS DATA LINK A THIRD OF CRIMES TO THE CAREER CRIMINAL
description: While career criminals make up only 6 percent of all those arrested in Manhattan for muggings, robberies, assaults, burglaries and rapes, they are responsible for nearly one-third of all the reported crimes, District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau, said yesterday.

title: Suit Says U.S. Illegally Stopped Plan to Provide Drug Safety Data
description: Three public interest groups filed suit in Federal District Court today charging that the Reagan Administration had illegally suspended a plan to provide patients with printed safety and health data when they buy many popular prescription drugs.

title: Advertising; by Philip Dougherty; Warriner Mandelbaum Adds Tony Palladino
description: The new ad agency at 555 Madison Avenue is Warriner Mandelbaum Palladino. The Palladino is the new part. Tony Palladino is a 51-year-old creative product from East Harlem, who went to the High School of Music and Art with George Lois and later worked for him in New York and London.

title: Fay's Drug Sells Units
description: The Fay's Drug Company has sold its 31 drugstores in North Carolina and South Carolina to the Rite Aid Corporation for an undisclosed amount after losing money in its first venture outside New York and Pennsylvania, the company said today.

title: BOSTON COUNCIL BACKS SCHOOL AID
description: The financial crisis threatening to send 65,000 public school students home for the summer on April 16 eased today with City Council approval of a plan to borrow enough cash to keep classes going through June.

title: NEWS GROUPS AGREE NOT TO PUBLISH BUSH SCHEDULE
description: In response to a White House request designed to improve security for Vice President Bush, the two major national news services and Washington's two major newspapers have said they will stop publishing Mr. Bush's full schedule of daily activities, at least temporarily.

title: Belgrade Lifts Night Curfew In Province Struck by Riots
description: Yugoslav authorities lifted a curfew tonight in the southeastern province of Kosovo, where 11 people have been killed and 57 injured in a series of riots by ethnic Albanians since March 11. The authorities imposed the curfew last week after protests by ethnic Albanians seeking more autonomy for this province on the Albanian border.

title: Bridge: Justifying a Grand Slam Bid Varies With Type of Game
description: A deceptively simple question that few could answer accurately is this: How good a percentage chance is needed to justify a grand slam attempt?

title: PARLEY SHOWS RIFTS OVER FOOD SAFETY LAWS
description: Fundamental philosophical differences over food safety laws among consumer activists, Government officials and representatives of the food industry marked a two-day conference that ended here today.

title:
Baseball Notebook;
Drago Dealt Again And Doesn't Like It
description: Dick Drago, the relief pitcher involved in a much-publicized freeagent signing three years ago, was traded again yesterday as the Boston Red Sox trimmed to the 25-player limit.

title: MANY USED AND REMODLELED GRAND PIANOS FAIL TO SATISFY EXPERT
description: OLD grand pianos never die -they are reborn with new strings, felts, sound boards, pin blocks, hammers, bushings, keys and furniture finishes.

title: DEMOCRAT LEADS FOES OF PARTY'S BUDGET
description: Representative Phil Gramm is preaching party revolt in the ranks of conservative Democrats on Capitol Hill. If he succeeds, the Texas Democrat could significantly alter, or even defeat, the Democrats' budget proposals and insure passage of President Reagan's sweeping cuts in social programs.

title: Newmont Estimates Higher Gold Yield
description: The Newmont Mining Corporation announced that further drilling at its gold quarry in Carlin, Nev., indicated estimated probable reserves of 4.1 million ounces, compared with an estimate in December of 1 million ounces.

title: JET MAKES SAFE NO-WHEELS LANDING
description: A Boeing 727 jetliner with 72 people aboard landed on its belly and skid more than 5,000 feet down a runway at Kennedy International Airport last night before coming safely to rest. The no-wheels landing was made after the left landing gear failed to lower automatically and the crew was unable to lower it manually.

title: BAKER AND RANGERS TURN BACK KINGS, 3-1
description: Steve Baker survived a furious final period tonight to win his first National Hockey League playoff game as the New York Rangers beat the Los Angeles Kings, 3-1, in the opening game of their three-of-five series.

title: Hers; by Mary Kay Blakely
description: THE priest and I are having lunch together, to plan a program in which I'm to be the main speaker. He is telling me, as tactfully as possible, to be prepared for some hostility in the audience.

title: MOBILES ADRIFT
description: SHE thought of clouds because ''she wanted to get the sensation of the wind inside a space.'' Or, at least, that's what got Diana Carulli, who learned to work with fabrics when she lived in California, started on her mobiles.

title: Intel Profit Down 91.3% in Quarter
description: The Intel Corporation reported today the profits declined 91.3 percent, to $2.1 million, in the first quarter, from $24.1 million in the comparable period last year, and said the first three-month period should be its low point for the year.

title: AFGHANS TELL WEST THAT SOVIET HAS SENT MORE TROOPS
description: A Western diplomatic source said today that large numbers of Soviet soldiers had arrived in Afghanistan in recent weeks to buttress Soviet units trying for the last 15 months to subdue guerrilla resistance.

title: Bold 'N Determined Wins Apple Blossom by Nose
description: Bold 'N Determined captured the $219,700 Apple Blossom Handicap at Oaklawn Park today, beating La Bonzo by a nose.

title: Company News; CELANESE NET UNCHANGED
description: The Celanese Corporation, one of the world's largest producers of man-made fibers, announced yesterday that net income in the first quarter of 1981 remained at the level of the corresponding quarter a year earlier while sales increased 30.2 percent.

title: STAGE: RICHARD THOMAS SPARKS 'FIFTH OF JULY'
description: IF there were any doubts about the merits of Lanford Wilson's ''Fifth of July,'' they can at last be put to rest. Thanks to a major casting change, which was officially unveiled to the press this week, the full beauty of this comedy has finally been uncorked. And how much beauty there is! Mr. Wilson's powerful play seems infinitely wise about love and family, about America's past, present and future. When this show opened at the New Apollo last November, one could see its broad outlines and its woolly humor, but were audiences sobbing for much of Act II? They are now.

title: Company News; A.& P. Discussing Niagara Takeover
description: The Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Company, which has been operating at a loss, and Niagara Frontier Services, a Buffalo food retailer and franchiser, jointly announced that they were negotiating for A.& P. to acquire Niagara but said that no agreement had yet been reached. They also refused to disclose terms.

title: Rural Serenity
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: ''Improving a Serene Rural Life'' (April 2) paints a deceptively appealing word picture of a freelance writer's unstructured existence. I suspect it merely touches upon one aspect of a less than uncomplicated matter.

title: TIMES NAMES PUBLIC AFFAIRS CHIEF
description: Marjorie W. Longley has been named director of public affairs for The New York Times Company, Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, the company's chairman, announced yesterday.

title: KINGS,88, SUNS 83
description: PHOENIX (AP)-Reggie King and Scott Wedman combined for 44 points, including 21 in the fourth period, as Kansas City defeated Pheonix and tied their playoff series at one game each.

title: Norway Seeks Gas Pipeline
description: The Norwegian Government will ask Parliament to approve a project proposed by the Statfjord Group for a pipeline system that would bring North Sea natural gas to Kaarstoe, in western Norway, Arvid Johanson, the Minister for Petroleum and Energy, said today.

title: Cutting Home Prices
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: Paul Goldberger's article ''Developers Return to the Basics to Cut New Home Prices'' (Design Notebook, April 2) was a refreshing, relevant, high point.

title: 17 Lost as British Vessel Sinks
description: Seventeen people were missing and eight were rescued after a small British freighter headed for Ecuador with a load of cement sank in the Pacific about 300 miles off Costa Rica, port officials said today. They said that an engine-room explosion Saturday broke the 5,860-ton freighter Barbara B in two, sinking it within minutes.

title: IN SUNRISE RITE, JEWS RECALL CREATION
description: At dawn yesterday Rabbi Zalman Schachter stood on the observation deck of the Empire State Building and watched the sun's rays flash across Long Island Sound and glint off the windows of Brooklyn. As the sunlight brightened the East River and streamed into Manhattan, he sounded the shofar - a ram's horn trumpet - and led several hundred worshipers in the Birkat ha-Hamah, the Jewish blessing of the sun, which takes place only once every 28 years.

title: CREIGHTON, REED TO MEET
description: Willis Reed, former player and coach for the New York Knicks, has been added to the list of candidates for the vacant head coaching job at Creighton University.

title: ARTS ENDOWMENT SLASHES BUDGET
description: The National Endowment for the Arts, struggling to meet the Reagan Administration's demand that it reduce spending by about 50 percent, has sent to Congress a revised budget for fiscal 1982 that would cut the challenge-grant program by more than 80 percent and eliminate several other programs.

title: Bowater Paper Price Up
description: The Bowater Sales Company said yesterday that it was raising the price of newsprint 7.1 percent, to $490 a metric ton, effective June 1. The move followed announcements by three other newsprint producers that have increased prices 6.4 percent, to $500 a ton, effective later in the year.

title: Is the Shuttle Worth Rooting For?
description: At dawn tomorrow the space shuttle Columbia, three years behind schedule and way over budget, is due to blast off on the riskiest, most technologically challenging space mission yet. Though this radically new venture is even more demanding than the landing on the moon, the mood of the public is subdued, and many Americans are mystified. Will a successful flight mark a milestone in man's conquest of space - or the evolution of a technological white elephant?

title: CASO TELLS COURT HE KNEW NOTHING OF INSURANCE-COMMISSION SPLITTING
description: Ralph G. Caso testified today that he knew nothing about municipal insurance commission-splitting with Nassau Republican politicians while he was the Presiding Supervisor of the Town of Hempstead and County Executive from 1965 through 1977.

title: Two Boys, 13, Killed In Elevator Accident
description: Two 13-year-old boys were killed in a high-rise Brooklyn housing project when they fell four stories down an elevator shaft and the car on which they had been playing then dropped on them, the police said.

title: German Recovery Seen
description: There are clear signs that the weakening trend in the West German economy has eased, the country's Economics Minister, Count Otto Lambsdorff, said today. Speaking after a Cabinet meeting, he said that the Government sees evidence of recovery.

title: KHEEL SAYS HE'LL OPPOSE KOCH IF NO ONE ELSE DOES
description: Theodore W. Kheel said yesterday that he would run against Mayor Koch if no other candidate turned up. Without telling any of his associates in the anti-Koch coalition, the lawyer and labor mediator telephoned news services with his announcement, which he said was in response to a challenge by the Mayor and a Daily News editorial.

title: 61 Vietnamese Reach Malaysia
description: A boatload of 61 Vietnamese refugees landed on the northeast coast of Malaysia and those aboard complained of raping and looting by Thai pirates, police officials said here today.

title: Company News
description: The Joseph Dixon Crucible Company said its directors had agreed in principle to be acquired by a newly formed corporation to be owned by Wolsey & Company, a New York investment banking firm, and other investors. One of Wolsey's general partners is Maurice Valente, the 52-year-old executive who was dismissed by the RCA Corporation as president and chief operating officer last June.

title: Dental Charts Asked In Slaying Inquiry
description: Dental records will be used to determine if a man slain in Wisconsin on March 18 with his female companion was William H. Callahan, the subject of Manhattan embezzlement inquiries, the Kenosha County, Wis., Coroner said.

title: ADOLPH OCHS OF TIMES PICKED FOR OHIO HONOR
description: Adolph S. Ochs, publisher of The New York Times for 39 years until his death in 1935, and Anne O'Hare McCormick, a foreign correspondent and member of the editorial board of The Times who died in 1954, will be installed in the Ohio Journalism Hall of Fame on April 29.

title: Advertising; by Philip Dougherty; Wilkens, Eurocom Form A European Network
description: From across the Atlantic comes news that Wilkens, the largest independent agency in West Germany, and Eurocom, the largest agency holding company in France, have joined forces to form a European agency network through a financial holding company called Satel G.m.b.H. in Hamburg, Germany.

title: RECITAL: WATTS OFFERS 4 BRAHMS PIECES
description: ANDRE WATTS gave a puzzling piano recital last night in Carnegie Hall. It was puzzling because of its inconsistencies - just when one felt one had figured out how Mr. Watts was playing, he turned around in the next piece and confounded one's expectations.

title: DANCE: DANNY GROSSMAN COMPANY
description: ON Tuesday night the Danny Grossman Dance Company opened the second week of the Dance Umbrella season at the new Space at City Center. The group from Toronto offered two premieres by Mr. Grossman: one grim, the other blithe. Yet Mr. Grossman's jests contained their own serious implications.

title: News of Music; COMPLEX DEAL GETS VIOLINIST A STRADIVARIUS
description: ONE of the more interesting financial deals transacted in music circles recently involves a small young man and an even smaller object. The man is Daniel Phillips, an active and respected violinist around New York, and the object is a 1702 Stradivarius.

title: OWNERS STILL GAMBLE ON ESQUIRE
description: When Christopher Whittle and Phillip Moffitt bought languishing Esquire magazine two years ago, one of the last decrees of the outgoing regime was that its offices be moved to 2 Park Avenue. Thus the day the jaunty young Tennesseans (they were barely into their 30's) took charge, Esquire was literally a maze of unpacked boxes.

title: P.T.A. RATES TV'S 'BEST' AND 'WORST'
description: The national Parent-Teacher Association yesterday revealed its annual list of the best and worst prime-time television programs for family viewing. It also announced plans to form a full-time television review panel that will determine whether to give the P.T.A.'s endorsement to individual programs.

title: PARTY CHIEFS IN ALBANY: POWERS BEHIND VOTING
description: It was one of those moments a legislative leader dreads: Warren M. Anderson, leader of the Senate's Republican majority, was committed to passing his version of a bill to aid mass transit, and the bill was going down to defeat.

title: Lane Bryant Withdraws Suit
description: Lane Bryant Inc., the apparel retailer specializing in large sizes, has withdrawn its suit against its former chairman, Raphael Malsin, and his wife, Elaine.

title: 'Railroad Bill' Begins Tour for Labor Theater
description: The story of Morris Slater, a black Alabama turpentine worker who turned train robber between 1893 and 1897, is the subject of the musical folk tale, ''Railroad Bill,'' that began a 35-city tour on Tuesday.

title: RCA to Issue Cast Album Of 'Sophisticated Ladies'
description: An original cast album of ''Sophisticated Ladies,'' the Broadway musical based on compositions of Duke Ellington, will be produced by RCA Records.

title: CONTINENTAL EMPLOYEES SEEK STAKE
description: The employees of Continental Air Lines announced a proposal today to purchase 51 percent of Continental's stock to prevent a takeover of the carrier by Texas International Airlines. The employees would pay about $185 million.

title: Parish Stays With Celtics
description: Robert Parish, the 7-foot center who found a home with Boston this season but could have become a free agent after the playoffs, agreed to a multiyear contract with the Celtics today. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Business Digest; THURSDAY, APRIL 9, 1981; The Economy
description: A bipartisan alternative to the Administration tax bill was outlined by Dan Rostenkowski, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee. The proposal suggested a cut in the top tax rate to 50 percent from 70 percent, an increase in the standard deduction and relief from the so-called marriage penalty. (Page A1.)

title: UNLOCKING OLD FURNITURE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Michael Varese restores antiques for dealers and collectors. By MICHAEL VARESE

title: RAPID RISE IN STUDENTS OF ASIAN ORIGIN CAUSING PROBLEMS AT BERKELEY CAMPUS
description: In 15 years the number of Asian students has quadrupled at the University of California campus here, leaving administrators worried about the future if the trend continues and leaving students frequently frustrated by language and culture problems.

title: Uganda Blast Hurts 2 Passersby
description: A grenade explosion today wounded two passersby on the street and caused minor damage to the building housing the Indian High Commission, according to Government officials.

title: Jersey Utility Loses Rate Rise Appeal
description: TRENTON (UPI) - The State Supreme Court upheld a state order barring Jersey Central Power and Light Company from charging its customers for an inoperative but undamaged nuclear plant at Three Mile Island.

title: Arab Emirates' Oil Net Up
description: The United Arab Emirates earned $18.5 billion in 1980 from oil exports, nearly 50 percent more than 1979's $12.5 billion, central bank figures show. A bank report quoted by the official Emirates news agency said revenues rose despite a fall in oil exports to 1.71 million barrels a day in 1980, from 1.82 million in 1979, presumably as a result of crude oil price increases. The United Arab Emirates' current-account surplus at the end of 1980 totaled $5 billion, up from $2.5 billion at the end of 1979, the report said.

title: Affecting Soviet Intentions
description: In the view of just about every student of Soviet attitudes, the threat to Poland is not over. Moscow continues to send strong signals of discontent, using language reminiscent of what was said before the crushing of Czechoslovakia in 1968. Armed intervention could still come at any time.

title: Fannie Mae Posts $21.6 Million Loss
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association announced yesterday a record operating loss of $21.6 million for the first quarter. Oakley Hunter, chairman, attributed the loss to high interest rates and a decline in fees as a result of a sharp decline in mortgage lending.

title: Going Out Guide
description: PUTTING ON THE DOG

title: Sports News Briefs; RUMANIAN DEFECTORS CITE INTERFERENCE AS REASON
description: Three leading Rumanian gymnastic trainers, including Nadia Comaneci's coach, have defected to the United States, the State Department confirmed today.

title: LONG-RANGE POSTURE OF ADMINISTRATION ON SPACE PROGRAM REMAINS UNCERTAIN
description: If the skies over Florida are clear Friday, America's long-stalled manned space flight program will resume, but the space shuttle Columbia will be flying through clouds of political uncertainty.

title: PET SITTERS DO MORE THAN WALK THE DOG
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Marcelle Sussman is a freelance writer. By MARCELLE SUSSMAN

title: Former Hostage Welcomes a Year at Harvard
description: She spent 444 days as a hostage with other Americans in Teheran, and now Elizabeth Ann Swift is going to get a year in a more amicable setting. She has been selected as one of 20 fellows at Harvard's Center for International Affairs.

title: Heart and Lung Recipient Is Taken Off the Critical List
description: The world's longest-surviving heart-lung transplant recipient has been taken off the critical list at the Stanford Medical Center.

title: ANDERSON REBUFFS CAREY ON MEDICAID FUNDS
description: The State Senate majority leader, Warren M. Anderson, today rejected an emergency appropriation of $75 million sought by Governor Carey for nursing homes, hospitals, clinics, doctors and pharmacies serving Medicaid patients as the state entered its second week without a budget.

title: COAST BANK GOING INTERSTATE
description: In early June, the Western Bancorporation will change its name to the First Interstate Bancorporation. And its 21 banks in 11 Western states will officially become units of the First Interstate Bank, part of a $32 billion financial organization with nearly 900 offices in 450 communities in the West.

title: Company News; G.E. CLIMBED 5% IN 1ST QUARTER; CATERPILLAR TRACTOR DOWN BY 1%
description: The General Electric Corporation, the country's largest manufacturer of electrical equipment and a leading producer of consumer goods, reported yesterday that net income in the first fiscal quarter of 1981 increased 5 percent while sales rose 3.6 percent.

title: TEXT OF STATEMENT ON POLAND
description: Following is the text of a statement on the Polish situation by the Secretary General of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, Joseph M.A.H. Luns, which he read today at the end of a meeting of allied defense ministers in Bonn: Special to the New York Times

title: A LIFELONG TASTE FOR GOOD TASTE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Jane Geniesse is a journalist and novelist. BY JANE GENIESSE

title: Home Improvement; FLOOR PROBLEMS IN CONVERTING UNFINISHED AREA
description: FOR most do-it-yourselfers the easiest flooring to put down when converting a basement or garage to living quarters is vinyl that comes in self-adhesive squares. (There is also a surprisingly realistic new self-adhesive ''wood plank'' vinyl in strips that closely resemble real planks; called Woodstock, it is made by Armstrong.)

title: Morgan Library Receives A $1 Million Astor Grant
description: The Pierpont Morgan Library has been given a $1 million grant by the Vincent Astor Foundation to help the work of its department of printed books and bindings. This is the largest single grant that the library has received since it was endowed as a public institution in 1924.

title: I.R.A. MAN'S RACE FOR COMMONS UNCOVERS OLD PAIN
description: A convicted Irish Republican Army leader is waging a strong campaign here for a seat in the British Parliament.

title: TESTS SET FOR MAN CHARGED IN THREAT
description: A Federal judge yesterday ordered a psychiatric examination for the 22-year-old unemployed man who was charged in Manhattan Tuesday with threatening to kill President Reagan. Other authorities said the man had indicated he was motivated to commit violence by a ''prophetic dream.''

title: Wesleyan Students Seek Greater Voice
description: Nearly 60 Wesleyan University students jammed the office of a college vice president for nearly an hour yesterday afternoon, demanding a greater voice in educational planning.

title: JUDGE WON'T ORDER CONTINUATION OF BUSING OF LOS ANGELES PUPILS
description: An attempt by civil rights groups and a teachers' union to preserve a mandatory busing program in Los Angeles public schools through the end of this school year was rejected tonight by the presiding judge of Superior Court.

title: Market Place; Ad Agency Stocks Favored
description: AS a service industry, advertising agencies rarely rank as great favorites on Wall Street. Currently, the price-earnings ratio of the six largest publicly held agencies is 7.3. This compares with the 9.1 ratio for Standard & Poor's index of 400 industrial stocks, which, in turn, is well below the even more generous earnings multiples of service industries.

title: S.E.C. SAYS IT OPPOSES CURBS ON MONEY FUNDS
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission, throwing its full weight behind defenders of the popular money market funds in their battle with the nation's banks, told a House subcommittee today that it would oppose any legislative proposals to curb the growth of the funds.

title: A Judge Bars Jail For Fear of Attack
description: A Manhattan Criminal Court judge refused to sentence David Ross, 23 years old, of Manhattan to jail yesterday because ''the State of New York could not guarantee his safety in prison surroundings.''

title: The Budget Targets Sixth in a series on key programs; that President Reagan wants to cut.
description: The Reagan Administration says it wants to see the people who use transportation services pay a greater share of the cost, reducing the demand for assistance from the Federal Government.

title: 3 KILLED AND 6 HURT IN A QUEENS BLAZE
description: A woman and two children were killed and six other persons were injured last night when fire raced through a three-story private house in Richmond Hill, Queens, authorities said.

title: MISS GOULETAS PLANS TO GIVE ROLE OF FIRST LADY FULL TIME
description: Evangeline Gouletas, the Chicago real-estate executive who will be married to Governor Carey Saturday, said yesterday that she planned to relinquish her ''personal career'' to devote herself full time to her role as ''First Lady of the State of New York.''

title: Debut of 'J' Cars Set Back a Week
description: The General Motors Corporation will postpone the introduction of its new subcompact 'J' cars by one week because production delays have limited the number of cars available to dealers, the auto maker said.

title: CALENDAR: FLOWERING OF 34TH & BROADWAY
description: Macy's Flower Show, 34th Street and Broadway.

title: Finance Group Buys Penn Central Shares
description: American Financial Enterprises Inc. said yesterday that it had purchased 650,000 convertible preferred shares of the Penn Central Corporation, raising its stake in Penn Central's common stock to about 13.4 percent, assuming conversion of the shares. It had owned about 1.5 million common shares.

title: To the Last Lebanese
description: Lebanon's unremitting agony conveys what Virgil meant by the tears of things. Left to themselves, the Moslem majority and Christian minority might long ago have ended a ruinous conflict and begun to rebuild a shattered republic. But every peacemaking effort has been thwarted by outsiders - Syrians, Israelis and Palestinians. Lebanon's soil has been borrowed in a battle between armies whose foreign patrons seem ready to fight to the last Lebanese.

title: BACKSTROKE TO MISS CAULKINS
description: Tracy Caulkins of Nashville and Rick Carey of Mount Kisco, N.Y., 18-year-old high school seniors, won their first national titles tonight in backstroke swimming.

title: Key Rates
description: Previous Year In percent Yesterday Day Ago PRIME RATE 17.00 17.00 20.00 DISCOUNT RATE* 13.00 13.00 13.00 FEDERAL FUNDS 14.75 15.60 15.65 3-MO. TREASURY BILLS 13.64 13.25 14.40 6-MO. Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Article 077604 -- No Title
description: The establishment of an annual choreographic award of $25,000 was announced yesterday by the American Dance Festival. The award, the gift of Samuel H. Scripps, will honor choreographers who have made a significant lifetime contribution to American modern dance.

title: One Way to Get to the Top Is to Start on the Roof
description: Mark L. Bohn of Morristown, N.J., a recent graduate of the University of Arizona, wants to work in marketing in the recording industry. It took him six weeks to write his resume, but yesterday it seemed worth it, for one of the first persons to respond was Bruce Lundvall, president of CBS Records.

title: Dr. Unqualified
description: Although Dr. C. Everett Koop deserves his reputation as a fine pediatric surgeon, he is not deserving of the role in which the Reagan Administration hopes to place him - Surgeon General.

title: SALVADOR OFFICIALS ARE CALLED TARGETS OF ASSASSINS
description: Leftist insurgents and right-wing forces in El Salvador have committed a series of assassinations aimed at destabilizing the Government, according to American intelligence and State Department officials.

title: by James C. Goodale
description: No one seemed more surprised than the actress Carol Burnett when she heard that she had won a $1.6 million libel award against The National Enquirer for a gossip-column item that wrongly implied that she had been inebriated in an encounter with Henry A. Kissinger in a Washington, D.C., restaurant. She said she would have been happy with a dollar and planned to give the windfall award away to charities. Indeed, the Los Angeles jury awarded her $100,000 more than she had demanded.

title: REAGAN'S WORKLOAD UP TO 2 HOURS A DAY
description: Nine days after being shot in the chest, President Reagan spends about two hours a day doing work brought from the White House to the hospital and the remaining time resting, reading and undergoing sometimes painful exercises and physical therapy for his wounds, White House officials say.

title: NATO DEFENSE AIDES ISSUE JOINT WARNING TO SOVIET ON POLAND
description: Defense ministers of the North Atlantic alliance warned the Soviet Union today that military intervention in Poland ''would have profound implications for all aspects of East-West relations.''

title: MET CATCHER HURT AND MAY NOT PLAY
description: The Mets worked out today in the Chicago Cubs' home, where they will open their 20th season tomorrow, and they promptly suffered another injury: John Stearns stepped on a baseball in the outfield and twisted his left ankle.

title: The U.N. Today; April 9, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Special Committee on Enhancing the Nonuse of Force in International Rela- tions - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Support Given Conrail Moves
description: The Reagan Administration's proposed changes would make Conrail a more viable freight carrier even if the Government cannott sell off the system's assets to other railroads, Transportation Secretary Drew Lewis said today.

title: POP: DONNIE IRIS AND EVE MOON
description: NOWADAYS, the level of technical expertise among rock musicians is so high that what would have sounded impressive 10 years ago sounds merely competent today. The main problem facing mainstream rock acts is no longer one of mastering technology but, given the limited vocabulary of mainstream rock, how to avoid sounding like a cliche.

title: CAPTION
description: The New York Times/Don Hogan Charles Wallenda Grandson to Inaugurate Mets Season on a High Note Tino Walenda Zoppe, a grandson of the late high-wire artist, Karl Wallenda, using a balancing pole as he practiced yesterday on a tightrope strung between home plate and the upper deck in right field at Shea Stadium. Mr. Zoppe plans to walk the 500-foot-long wire to throw out the first ball next Tuesday when the Mets are scheduled to play their opening home game of the season.

title: Mine Owners Say Talks May Not Resume for Weeks
description: By the Associated Press Several coal mine owners said yesterday that it could be weeks before bargaining resumed with the striking United Mine Workers.

title: CITY PANEL VOTES NIGHT SURCHARGE OF 50 FOR TAXIS
description: Over the objections of the taxi driver's union, the New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission yesterday approved, as expected, a 50-cent surcharge for evening and Sunday taxi rides.

title: MINISTER HELD OVER FUND-RAISING IN ATLANTA SLAYINGS
description: The Rev. Earl Carroll, a local minister who has been involved in fund-raising efforts in the case of Atlanta's missing and murdered children, was arrested here today on charges connected to his fund-raising activities.

title: BLOCKING SETTLEMENT OF INDIAN LAND CLAIMS
description: To the Editor:

title: DANCE: 'POEMS OFF THE WALL' BY DANIEL NAGRIN AT STUDIO
description: AMY LOWELL is not recited. The walls are not especially oppressive. Daniel Nagrin's new ''Poems Off the Wall,'' a mixed-media solo seen Tuesday at the Studio, is simply an evening with Mr. Nagrin, veteran choreographer, teacher and consummate actor-dancer. At the age of 63, Mr. Nagrin hasn't the body or energy of today's pyrotechnical whiz kids. And his mad, glittering eyes, teeth and fringe of black hair have the messy vitality of an animal's pumping heart beneath a citydweller's fingers. But this is an hour of dance and theater that has more to say about the art of performing than most weeks' worth of performances.

title: MYTHS THAT DO A DISSERVICE TO THE POOR
description: To the Editor:

title: BATHROOM SPAS: A HEALTHY HEDONISM
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Norma Skurka is a freelance writer in the design field. By NORMA SKURKA

title: Books of the Times; Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard BANDITS. By Eric Hobsbawm. Illustrated.181 pages. Pantheon. Paper, $4.95.

title: AM General Wins Big Army Contract
description: The AM General Corporation, a subsidiary of the American Motors Corporation, has won a $600 million contract from the United States Army to build 11,394 five-ton trucks over a five-year period.

title: The Police Blotter
description: Morris Kleinman of Brooklyn, a 61-year-old former New York City consumer affairs inspector, was arrested and charged with taking $500 in bribes from Queens supermarkets to overlook short-weighting and other violations. ... Kenneth Ortiz, 17, of 167 Milford Street, Brooklyn, was found shot to death at Glenmore and Fountain Avenues in Brooklyn's East New York section.

title: TO GUARD AGAINST THE MISUSE OF ADOLESCENCE
description: To the Editor:

title: The New York Times/Keith Meyers Martin Bell of the British Broadcasting Corporation taping a report from Cape Canaveral, Fla.
description: All three major television networks and the Cable News Network have planned live coverage of the launching, re-entry and landing of the space shuttle.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Apache Corporation said its first 1981 oil and gas partnership program was fully subscribed as of April 4 at $20 million.

title: Advertising; by Philip Dougherty; Ladies' Home Journal Estimates Its Power
description: A new black-and-white print campaign for Ladies' Home Journal, to break this week, represents the magazine's back-to-basics approach.

title: BUSINESSMEN OFFER PLAN TO CURE NEW YORK'S CHRONIC TRANSIT ILLS
description: A team of former corporate executives from a business group founded by David Rockefeller produced a plan yesterday listing major New York City Transit Authority problems. It offered to recruit 20 executives to begin solving them.

title: Baker Urges the Senate To Permit TV Coverage
description: The Senate majority leader, Howard H. Baker Jr., today urged his colleagues to allow television coverage of the Senate as a step toward modernizing proceedings and toward regaining some power from the Presidency.

title: Law-and-Arts Symposium Saturday at New York Law
description: The New York Law School's Media Law Project, contending that ''legal problems faced by performing artists and performance companies have grown in complexity,'' is sponsoring a daylong symposium on ''Law and the Performing Arts.''

title: Where There's Smoke, There's a Train Delay
description: A fire fueled by trash produced so much smoke in an IRT subway tunnel in Brooklyn yesterday that four Manhattan-to-Brooklyn express lines were delayed 20 minutes. No one was reported injured.

title: TREASURY AIDE CRITICAL OF FED
description: Beryl W. Sprinkel, Under Secretary of the Treasury for Monetary Affairs, said today that, in trying to peg interest rates, the Federal Reserve System ''interferes'' with the steady slowing of money supply growth, which is one of the key economic policy objectives of the Reagan Administration.

title: Spain Requests Transfer Of 'Guernica' by Museum
description: A Spanish Government delegation in New York has presented a formal request to representatives of the Museum of Modern Art in an effort to get the museum to transfer Picasso's ''Guernica'' and its related works to Spain.

title: PAYING INVESTORS FOR TIME, RISK AND INFLATION
description: To the Editor:

title: STATE DEPT. SAYS SOVIET KEEPS UP PRESSURE ON POLES
description: The State Department said today that the Soviet Union was continuing military and political pressure on Poland despite yesterday's announcement that the Warsaw Pact military maneuvers had ended.

title: Planting Trees
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: Thanks to Linda Yang for her informative and accurate article (''How to Get a Tree Planted on Your Street,'' March 5) on the challenges and joys of planting and caring for a street tree in New York City. The Parks Council would like to add an extra note of caution: We are warning all prospective tree planters that the drought may give them some special problems.

title: Rejoining Control Data
description: For eight years before 1970, when he joined the Scan-Data Corporation, maker of optical character recognition devices, as chairman and chief executive officer, Robert R. Burns was a manager at the Control Data Corporation. Now Mr. Burns, 49, is returning to Control Data - which owns a major portion of Scan-Data in Norristown, Pa.

title: On the Menu for Saturday? There's Shark Mousse ...
description: When members of the Explorers Club, those hearty souls with hearty appetites and apparently cast-iron stomachs, get together for the club's annual dinner, they smack their lips over exotic victuals.

title: DEMOCRATS IN HOUSE PRESS ATTACKS ON PRESIDENT'S ECONOMIC PROPOSALS
description: House Democrats today intensified their attack on President Reagan's economic package, criticizing what they called the Administration's ''bunker mentality'' and adopting a statement of principles that called the Administration's tax proposal ''the fiscal equivalent of faith in a free lunch.''

title: Gretzky's 5 Assists Lead Upset by Oilers
description: Wayne Gretzky, the National Hockey league's leading scorer, set up five goals tonight to lead the Edmonton Oilers to a 6-3 upset over the Montreal Canadiens in the first game of their preliminary-round Stanley Cup playoff series.

title: OFFICER AND 2D MAN SHOT IN STORE
description: An off-duty New York City police officer and another man were wounded last night when bullets were fired into a small grocery store in Brooklyn. The police said the shooting may have been in retaliation for another shooting at the store the night before.

title: WEINBERGER DEFENDS A.T.&.T.
description: The Secretary of Defense, Caspar W. Weinberger, has recommended that the Justice Department drop its suit to break up the American Telephone and Telegraph Company because doing so could weaken a communications network that the nation's strategic systems rely on.

title: ROSTENKOWSKI PROPOSING A ONE-YEAR ALTERNATIVE ON REDUCTION IN LEVIES
description: Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, outlined to fellow Democrats today a one-year tax relief bill that he presented as a potential bipartisan alternative to the Reagan Administration's proposed three-year tax cut bill.

title: Venezuelan Plan on Debt
description: Venezuela plans to restructure its $8.6 billion short-term debt into medium-term credits over the next three years, the Planning Minister, Ricardo Martinez, said today.

title: YORK FINALLY DOES IT
description: The York College baseball team ended a 50-game losing streak yesterday by defeating Baruch, 7-4, in a Division III game called after seven and a half innings because of darkness. Eduardo Vasquez pitched a seven-hitting and picked up the victory, the first for York since 1977, when the Nomads beat Queensboro Community, 7-2.

title: FABRIC CARE HANDBOOK PUBLISHED BY MUSEUM
description: DON'T just stuff a Victorian crazy quilt into a trunk or drape an antique dress on a wire hanger. Don't even hang a Navajo rug in direct sunlight or keep a label stapled onto fine Irish lace.

title: New Defect Delays Indian Point's Start
description: The resumption of service by Consolidated Edison's Indian Point 2 nuclear reactor has been postponed to at least the end of April while technicians try to determine why a coolant pump is vibrating, officials said yesterday.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, APRIL 9, 1981
description: International The NATO allies warned Moscow that military intervention in Poland ''would have profound implications for all aspects of East-West relations.'' The Western defense ministers also expressed concern about what they said was an ''unrelenting buildup and improvement'' in Soviet nuclear arms. (Page A1, Column 6.) The United States accused the Kremlin of continuing military and political pressure on Poland despite Tuesday's announcement that the Warsaw Pact maneuvers had ended. (A10:4-6.)

title: Dr. Live-Again
description: Dr. Howard Rusk is 80 years old today, making it a fit day to honor the father of rehabilitation medicine. He has won professional and civic awards around the world, plus such admiring nicknames as ''Dr. Live-Again'' and ''Dr. Warmth,'' and he's still at it.

title: GARBAGE TRUCK FLAWS CALLED DANGER TO PRODUCTIVITY GAIN
description: Because of hydraulic problems, many of New York City's new two-man sanitation trucks cannot carry nearly as much garbage as they were supposed to, according to an engineering analysis by the City Comptroller's office.

title: Company News; Du Pont Sues Toray
description: E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company said it had filed suit in London against Toray Industries of Japan for patent infringement. The company said the suit charged that Toray had violated Du Pont patents in Britain for texturing polyester yarn. Du Pont said it had patent applications for the process in other countries, but did not name them.

title: LEBANON PRESIDENT ORDERS A CEASE-FIRE
description: After a day of fierce fighting between Syrian troops and Lebanese Christian militia forces, President Elias Sarkis ordered a cease-fire here and in the Christian town of Zahle, 30 miles to the east. But the truce was only partly observed.

title: News Analysis
description: The war of nerves over Poland is entering a new stage, Western analysts here believe, and Stanislaw Kania, the leader of the Polish Communist Party, may not survive. Already, according to Soviet and Eastern European informants, the Kremlin has decided to bypass him in attempting to curb the influence of Solidarity, the independent trade union, and its more vocal political allies.

title: POP: T.S. MONK IN SHOWCASE LED BY THELONIUS MONK JR.
description: THE Bottom Line showcase Monday of the New York pop-funk group T.S. Monk pointed up a significant difference between East and West Coast styles of black mainstream pop. Generally speaking, West Coast popfunk bands have choreographed stage acts, and their material sticks to one of several proven commercial formulas.

title: Sports News Briefs; Packers Fined for Failing To Report Marcol Injury
description: The National Football League has fined the Green Bay Packers for not reporting an injury to the place-kicker Chester Marcol before a 1979 game, it was disclosed today.

title: Q&A
description: Q. During the winter my house is plagued with mold. I am constantly scrubbing the bedroom walls and ceiling with a disinfectant, but the mold keeps coming back. Is there a solution to this problem? - J.M., San Francisco.

title: LAST OF ARMY'S FIVE-STAR GENERALS
description: General of the Army Omar N. Bradley, a World War II hero who was the last of the nation's five-star generals, died yesterday in Manhattan. He was 88 years old.

title: AUTO MAKERS VIEW U.S. PLAN AS MODEST
description: The Reagan Administration's plan to assist the automobile industry by easing or eliminating no fewer than 35 regulations is apparently being viewed within the industry as a rather modest effort.

title: Canada Legislators End Filibuster Over Charter
description: An agreement among the three parties in the House of Commons today ended nearly two weeks of filibustering against Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau's proposals for a new Canadian constitution.

title: 300 in Indonesia Flee a Volcano
description: Renewed volcanic activity on Mount Semeru in East Java has forced the evacuation of 300 villagers, the Meteorology Institute said today. The mountain, 500 miles east of here, began spouting lava and rocks last week.

title: BRENNER TELLS OF BAN BY W.B.C.
description: Teddy Brenner testified yesterday that his troubles with the World Boxing Council began when Don King ''over-reached'' their agreement by telling the sanctioning body that Brenner had waived promotional rights to Alexis Arguello, then the W.B.C.'s super-featherweight champion.

title: Advertising; by Philip Dougherty; Modern Photography, In the Air and on Campus
description: ''Up in the Air . . .'' and ''On the Campus . . .'' - both followed by ''With the Editors of Modern Photography'' - are two inserts being planned over at ABC Leisure Magazines to run in airline magazines and campus newspapers.

title: Critic's Notebook; THE UNSOLVED MYSTERIES THAT BAFFLE A THEATERGOER
description: I TRY to be an understanding person, but there are some things about the theater I just don't understand and they keep me from sleeping well after 11 in the morning. Of course, I know that many very odd things manage to get into plays and Playbills, and on stage by way of the sets and props, that don't precisely belong there. It's perfectly possible for an author to insist that the stage decor include a six-foot rubber plant because it will serve as a set-up for a joke about rubber plants, and then cut the joke -when it bombs out of town - and quite forget to remove the rubber plant.

title: Olin Officer Picked To Head New Unit
description: Ben E. Foster, 53 years old, has been appointed president of the newly established consumer products group of the Olin Corporation. The group, which will be the sixth major component at the big Stamford, Conn., company, produces skis, carpet underlay, flares and chemical products for swimming pools.

title: Advertising; Challenge Of Policing Oneself
description: With a new emphasis in Washington on less Government regulation, the advertising industry may be facing the challenge of initiating complete self-regulation, Don Johnston, the newly elected chairman of the American Association of Advertising Agencies, told the membership here today.

title: Food Supplies for Poles Will Fall in 2d Quarter
description: Supplies of eggs, flour and fats in Poland will shrink in the second quarter of 1981 from the levels of the first three months, the official Polish press agency P.A.P. said tonight.

title: Praise for One Plimpton, Self-Effacement by Another
description: The legal fraternity was out in force Tuesday night when Francis T. P. Plimpton received the Legal Aid Society's annual Servant of Justice Award at the New York Hilton.

title: Spurs Beat Rockets, Tie Series
description: Mark Olberding, the Spurs' power forward, scored a career-high 34 points and played strong defense against the Houston Rockets' center, Moses Malone, to help San Antonio to a 125-113 victory tonight that evened their National Basketball Association Western Conference semifinal series at a game each.

title: Volkswagen's Orders Rise
description: Volkswagenwerk A.G. reported an increase of orders in the first two months of this year from declining levels in late 1980, but did not give any figures. Siegfried Ehlers, the auto company's chairman, told a meeting of workers in West Germany on Tuesday night that orders were especially high for diesel-powered models and that production was not keeping up with demand.

title: PAM CASALE TO FACE HER TOUGHEST TEST
description: Two weeks after she became a tennis professional, Pam Casale of Fairfield, N.J., has joined Chris Evert Lloyd, Pam Shriver and Virginia Ruzici in the round of 16 of the $150,000 Family Circle Cup tournament.

title: By Sports of The Times; No Nameplate and a Blue Bat
description: WEARING an open-necked beige shirt, a brown suit and beige shoes, Dave Winfield strolled into the home clubhouse at Yankee Stadium yesterday and looked around for a locker with his name on it. But he could not find one.

title: ISRAELI TRADE UNION VOTE INDICATES CLOSE ELECTION IN JUNE
description: Returns from the trade union federation's elections showed today that, despite gains by the opposition Labor Party, the Likud bloc of Prime Minister Menachem Begin had held its important base of support among the non-European working class, raising the likelihood of a close general election in June.

title: Suspension at South St. Seaport
description: Leads to Training Program Inquiry

title: INCREASE THE LIMITS ON I.R.A. AND KEOGH
description: To the Editor:

title: Futures Trading Jumps 130%
description: The New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday announced a record 130 percent increase in its first-quarter trading volume. The exchange said that in the three months ended March 31 a record 450,322 commodity futures contracts were traded, compared with 196,006 in the similar period last year.

title: Advertising; Ad Revenues Up 12.1%
description: According to preliminary estimates from the Newspaper Advertising Bureau, revenues in February increased 12.1 percent, to $1.21 billion, from the comparable month of 1980. For the first two months of 1981, revenues totaled $2.4 billion, up 11.5 percent. National advertising led the month's gains, rising 24.3 percent, to $226.6 million, while retail advertising rose 11.9 percent, to $621.2 million, and classified 5.8 percent, to $360.7 million.

title: MAN MISTAKEN FOR REAGAN ATTACKER ASSERTS HE NOW FEARS FOR HIS LIFE
description: James Whittom of Shreveport, La., says he is frightened when he walks in the street since a photograph of him in a Nazi uniform was incorrectly identified as that of the man accused of trying to assassinate President Reagan.

title: U.S. Moves Due In Cobalt, Silver
description: The Reagan Administration said today it would buy up to 5.2 million pounds of cobalt for national defense and sell all of the Government's surplus silver.

title: Company News; Italian Bank Offer Accepted by Litco
description: The Litco Bancorporation of New York said it had signed an agreement in principle to be acquired by Banca Commerciale Italiana after Litco's board approved the proposal.

title: Gardening; TURNING AN EMPTY TERRACE INTO AN OASIS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Linda Yang is a regular contributor of garden articles to The Home Section. By LINDA YANG

title: Sudanese Economy Grapples With Debt, Inflation, Shortages
description: A textile factory north of Khartoum lies idle. The railroad track that was supposed to supply it with cotton was never built. In Shendy, a small town, $36 million of equipment rusts in the open because the contractor did not have enough cement to erect a planned building.

title: Islanders Beat Leafs By 9-2; Trottier Gets 2 Goals and 3 Assists
description: The Islanders opened defense of their Stanley Cup championship by beating the Toronto Maple Leafs, 9-2, tonight at Nassau Coliseum and taking a 1-0 lead in their three-offive-game playoff series.

title: Mead's Earnings Drop
description: The Mead Corporation, the paper and lumber company, yesterday reported a drop in first-quarter profits to $29.9 million, or $1.12 a share, from $31.3 million, or $1.19 a share, a year ago, despite a rise in sales to $672.3 million from $650.4 million. C. Greene Garner, the company's chief executive officer, said that demand for housing and automotive castings was the main cause of the earnings decline.

title: IRAN OFFERS RECOGNITION IF ETHNIC REBELS YIELD ARMS
description: Iran's Islamic Government issued a directive today aimed at tightening control over political activity but offering legal recognition to ethnic groups opposed to it if they would lay down their arms.

title: Helpful Hardware; OLD-FASHIONED DOORBELLS; by Barbara L. Isenberg and Mary Smith
description: MECHANICAL doorbells, Victorian inventions, are alive and well. They are useful either in a restoration in which authenticity is desired, or if the wiring for an electric bell is difficult or expensive.

title: Hutton to Add Canadian Stake
description: E.F. Hutton & Company, the investment and brokerage firm, said yesterday that it had reached an agreement to acquire a 10 percent equity interest in Greenhold Inc., a Montreal-based holding company that is the parent of Greenshields Inc., a leading Canadian investment firm. The purchase price was not disclosed.

title: Atomic Plant Holds An Emergency Drill
description: New Jersey, Delaware and the Public Service Electric and Gas Company conducted an elaborate all-day drill of new procedures to be used in the event of an accident at the utility's Salem nuclear plant that would require the public to be removed from the area.

title: HOLLYWOOD WRITERS TO VOTE TOMORROW ON A STRIKE
description: The threat of a strike by Hollywood's television and movie writers, which has been lurking in the wings since last October, moves to center stage this week.

title: Colombian Mining Town Raided
description: Leftist guerrillas attacked the Colombian gold mining town of Segovia today, wounding 10 people, including five policemen, according to radio news reports. The reports said guerrillas had escaped with more than $20,000 worth of gold. There was no immediate confirmation of the report by the authorities.

title: TV: 'DIAL M FOR MURDER' IN REMAKE
description: ''DIAL M FOR MURDER'' wasn't one of Alfred Hitchcock's favorite Hitchcock films; he dismissed it as being too talky in his famous interview with Francois Truffaut. The material, adapted by John Gay from the play by Frederick Knott, is talky, no matter how it's treated. But in tonight's television-movie remake (on NBC at 9), ''Dial M for Murder'' is deftly staged in a style that makes the most of its narrow scope. The small screen becomes the ideal place for this circuitous detective drama to unfold.

title: TV: GEOGRAPHIC SPECIAL FOCUSES ON GREAT APES
description: ''GORILLA, the National Geographic special on WNET-TV, Channel 13, last evening (it will be repeated Saturday at 1 P.M.), profiled the largest of the great apes in its natural African habitat and at a number of zoos, public and private, around the world. As might be expected, the animals are thoroughly fascinating in closeup. What's more, this particular National Geographic edition is outstanding, blessedly free of the inflated prose and soaring musictracks that can often mar the series. Written, produced and directed by Barbara Jampel, ''Gorilla'' makes its environmental points simply and eloquently.

title: Company News; E.D.S. Seeks Right To Pursue Iran Suit
description: A Federal judge has scheduled a hearing for Friday on a request by the Electronic Data Systems Corporation for a permanent injunction to prevent the United States Government from interfering with the $19 million judgment the Dallas company won last May against Iran.

title: Sports News Briefs; Walker Says He'll Decide Soon on Alouettes' Offer
description: Herschel Walker, the star Georgia freshman, says he will meet within a week with Montreal Alouette officials who want to sign him for the Canadian Football League team.

title: NEW ORLEANS REACHES ITS GOAL OF $26 MILLION FOR 1984 WORLD'S FAIR
description: Louisiana businessmen, civic leaders and politicians said today they had collected at least $14.4 million in pledges over the past four days in an effort to keep New Orleans from losing the 1984 World's Fair.

title: TEXT OF STATEMENT ON ECONOMIC MATTERS ADOPTED BY HOUSE DEMOCRATIC CAUCUS
description: Following is the text of the statement of Democratic Economic Principles adopted today by the House Democratic Caucus:

title: The Starting Lineups
description: RANGERS YANKEES Wills, 2b Randolph, 2b Rivers, cf Mumphrey, cf Oliver, dh Winfield, lf Bell, 3b Watson, 1b Sample, lf Piniella, rf Grubb, rf Cerone, c Putnam, 1b Nettles, 3b Sundberg, c Werth, dh Mendoza, ss Dent, ss Matlack, p John, p

title: FOR A LIFT IN SPIRIT, CHIRAC GOES BACK TO DEEP FRANCE
description: The Limousin is to the Auvergne as the Auvergne is to the rest of France. If the Auvergnat farmer, working his beautiful and stubborn hills, stands for conservative and hardbitten solidity, the Limousin farmer works even more stubborn hills, and is harder bitten.

title: STAGE: LARRY KETRON'S 'TRADING POST'
description: THE theatrical world of Larry Ketron is filled with cracker-barrel characters and country humor. In a neighborhood liquor store, a boarding house, an electrical repair shop or, in the case of his new play, ''The Trading Post,'' a resale shop in eastern Tennessee, rustic provincials swap memories as they meander through indolent days. Mr. Ketron's plays - this is the fifth that I have seen in five years - can seem uneventful, but underneath the surface, lives are changing.

title: Company News; Brookwood Reviews Merger Agreement
description: Brookwood Health Services Inc. said that a recent increase in Humana Inc.'s cash tender offer, to $42 a share for each Brookwood share, had prompted Brookwood and American Medical International Inc. to hold further discussions concerning their previously announced merger agreement.

title: HOUSE UNIT OPPOSES A NEW PEANUT PLAN
description: Representatives from Southern states, where most of the nation's peanuts are grown, voted today to scuttle the Reagan Administration's proposals for a new peanut program and instead substituted price support loan levels 30 percent higher than those the Administration wanted.

title: Sports News Briefs; Proud Appeal to Ship Out
description: Malcolm Winfield announced yesterday at Aqueduct that his 3-yearold, Proud Appeal, winner by a nose over Cure the Blues in Sunday's Gotham Stakes, will be shipped to Keeneland in Kentucky for the Blue Grass Stakes April 23. He thus will pass up a rematch with Cure the Blues in the Wood Memorial at Aqueduct April 18.

title: DISSIDENT'S WIFE CHARGES SOVIET OFFERED DEAL FOR HER TESTIMONY
description: The wife of an imprisoned Soviet Jewish activist charged today that the authorities would not let her accept a foreign gift of warm clothes for her husband unless she testified in the case.

title: WINFIELD, STEARNS FOCUS FOR OPENERS
description: Reggie Jackson, the focus of any crowd, will not be at Yankee Stadium today for the season opener against the Texas Rangers. That means the 50,000 fans who are expected will be able to focus more carefully on Dave Winfield.

title: Marcos Picks Prime Minister Under Amended Charter
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos today named his Finance Minister, Cesar Virta, to become the Philippines' first Prime Minister under a modified parliamentary system overwhelmingly approved in a plebiscite yesterday.

title: National Ban On Lasix Sought
description: In a move it said was designed to forestall Federal intervention, the National Association of State Racing Commissioners today passed a resolution recommending for the first time a national ban on the use of Lasix for horses 24 hours before races.

title: Greece Will Stop Servicing Ships From Soviet Fleet
description: Greece has formally terminated an agreement with the Soviet Union to repair the support vessels of its Mediterranean fleet. The agreement has long been criticized by the NATO alliance.

title: BONN AND PARIS PLAN $6 BILLION BOND ISSUE
description: West Germany and France announced plans today for a major international bond issue totaling almost $6 billion. The money will be used to reduce energy use and to stimulate long-term industrial investment in both countries.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The delegation of responsibilities and authorities appears to be fractionalized and there is evidence of different organizations performing the same duties.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Amerace Corporation has named David L. Nighbert a group vice president responsible for the Swan Hose division and the Anchor Coupling Company subsidiary.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on March 20 misidentified the forum for a speech by Peter G. Peterson, former Secretary of Commerce, on President Reagan's economic policy. He spoke before the Women's Economic Round Table.

title: Soviet Sharply Cuts Back On Exit Visas for Jews
description: The number of exit visas granted to Jews seeking to emigrate from the Soviet Union fell by nearly 50 percent in March after a sudden surge in February, figures obtained today show.

title: New York Air Begins A Service to Cleveland
description: New York Air, the city's newest airline, inaugurated flights yesterday between La Guardia Airport and Cleveland.

title: SENATE COMMITTEE SUBPOENAS FILES ON TEAMSTERS HELD BY LABOR DEPT.
description: A Senate committee investigating the alleged influence of organized crime over the International Brotherhood of Teamsters and other trade unions took the unusual step today of subpoenaing records and files from the Department of Labor.

title: Witness Places Defendant At Site of Doctor's Slaying
description: A witness at the trial of Bernard C. Welch Jr., who is accused of the murder of Dr. Michael J. Halberstam, testified today that she saw him near the physician's home twice on the day of the fatal shooting.

title: PRAGUE DENOUNCES POLISH LABOR UNION
description: Soviet and Czechoslovak officials charged the Polish independent labor federation Solidarity today with ''counterrevolution'' and ''anti-socialism.''

title: MEXICO AND VENEZUELA TRY TO EASE TENSIONS IN CARIBBEAN
description: President Luis Herrera Campins of Venezuela today ended a three-day visit here during which Mexico and Venezuela decided to harmonize their policies to prevent the Caribbean basin from becoming a focus of East-West tensions.

title: Company News; CHINA'S HUGE STEEL PROJECT IS DORMANT
description: The Baoshan iron and steel project, China's most ambitious industrial undertaking since the establishment of the Communist regime, lies dormant. Few workers are in sight, and hardly a hammer blow is heard throughout the huge site on the banks of the Yangtze River about an hour's drive from Shanghai.

title: Index; International
description: For a lift in spirit, Chirac goes home to Deep France A2 Israeli union elections indicate a close election in June A3 I.R.A. man's race for the Com- mons revives old fears A3 Soviet dissident's wife says offi- cials tried to manipulate her A4 Possibility of revising charter now discussed in Japan A5 Around the World A6 Iran offers recognition to ethnic rebels that lay down arms A8 Soviet and Czech officials renew attack on Polish union A10 Text of statement on Poland by the Secretary General of NATO A11 Lebanese President orders cease- fire after intense fighting A13 Government/Politics Conference shows division on food safety laws A16 Caso testifies he knew nothing about insurance fee splitting B2 Taxi panel, as expected, approves 50-cent night surcharge B3 Kheel says he'll run against Koch if no one else does B4 Anderson rejects emergency ap- propriation sought by Carey B10 House panel rejects Reagan plan on peanut price supports B15 General Around the Nation A16 Harvard panel backs female pro- fessor's complaint of sex bias A16 News groups will temporarily not publish Bush schedule A17 Tests ordered for man charged with threatening President A19 Man mistaken for Hinckley fears for his life A20 Off-duty officer and another man shot in Brooklyn store B6 Times names director of public af- fairs B8 Religion Jewish rite recalling creation is observed B3 The Home Section Home The spa bathroom: A luxury for the 1980's C1

title: AN ATTORNEY FOR BOXING PROMOTER CHARGED WITH OBSTRUCTING JUSTICE
description: An attorney for the jailed boxing promotor Ross Fields, also known as Harold Smith, was indicted today on charges of obstructing justice and giving false testimony to a Federal grand jury. The four-count indictment against the attorney, Jennifer King, said she had been called to testify in an investigation involving Mr. Fields's Muhammad Ali Professional Sports Inc. and an alleged $21.3 million embezzlement from Wells Fargo Bank.

title: Mrs. Thatcher Sees Hussein
description: King Hussein of Jordan, fresh from conversations with Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. in Amman, had a one-hour meeting today with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher.

title: HARVARD PANEL SAYS SEX BIAS LED TO DENIAL OF TENURE FOR A WOMAN
description: A Harvard University grievance committee has concluded that an associate professor of sociology was denied a tenure appointment last fall as a result of sexual discrimination.

title: New Greens and Longer Holes at Masters
description: The Masters, first of the season's four major golf tournaments, will begin tomorrow with two questions that cannot be answered until the last putt drops Sunday afternoon on the undulating 18th green of the Augusta National Golf Club.

title: NEWS MEDIA SWARM TO SITE FOR THE SHUTTLE'S LAUNCHING
