description: The launching of the space shuttle is a full-scale event for the news media, and as bleachers, trailers and tents here fill with news people, there is a hint of carnival in the air.

title: HARPSICHORDIST: JUDITH NORELL
description: JUDITH NORELL'S harpsichord recital Tuesday night at the Abraham Goodman House was a distinguished affair for three reasons. First, Miss Norell is a fine artist, seemingly able to invest almost any music with freshness, and sensitive both to modern musicology and to traditional musicality.

title: History On Its Head
description: Fantasize along with me: imagine a six-hour television docudrama about Watergate, produced by H.R. Haldeman, directed by John Mitchell, written by John Ehrlichman.

title: Victim in 1975 Crash Awarded $1 Million
description: A 24-year-old Greek sailor burned in the 1975 crash of a jet at Kennedy International Airport has been awarded $1 million in damages, according to United Press International.

title: Algeria to Get More for Gas
description: Algeria and Belgium today signed an accord that raises almost fourfold the price of Algerian natural gas exports to Belgium.

title: Cowboys' White Testifies About Kush's Discipline
description: Danny White, the Dallas Cowboy quarterback, testified today that Frank Kush slapped him once on the helmet during his freshman season at Arizona State in 1970 ''and told me that I'd never be a good quarterback.''

title: Feminists Protest
description: About 30 people staged a ''mock stockholders meeting'' in front of Federal Hall National Memorial on Wall Street to protest alleged discrimination by the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company against its women office workers. Across the street, the bank's stockholders met and rejected a proposal that job openings be posted. The resolution was defeated by a ratio of about 19 to 1.

title: Company News; B.C. Resources Asks New Stock Offering
description: The British Columbia Resources Investment Corporation, which is competing with Noranda Mines of Toronto in a takeover bid for MacMillan Bloedel, a major forest products concern, has proposed an increase of its current authorized capital to 200 million common shares and 100 million preferred shares. It now has 100 million authorized common and 96.2 million issued common shares and no authorized preferred shares.

title: Company News; Morgan's Operating Net Up 12%
description: J.P. Morgan & Company reported yesterday a 12 percent increase in its first-quarter net operating earnings over the similar period of 1980. The company is the corporate parent of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, the nation's fifth-largest banking organization.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: TV: 'PARK PLACE,' NEW CBS COMEDY
description: TV is apparently determined to stuff most of its new series into a New York City setting. On the drama front, ''Nurse'' does its Thursday night rounds at a fictional New York hospital. As for situation comedies, Monday's ''The Two of Us'' offers the host of a Manhattan television talk show coping with her new English butler, and tonight's two new entries -''Checking In'' at 8 P.M. (which wasn't available for previewing) and ''Park Place'' at 8:30 P.M. (which was) -have Big Apple addresses. William S. Paley might justifiably expect a thank-you note from Mayor Koch.

title: COPING WITH REJECTIONS FROM COLLEGES
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Arlene Fischer is a freelance writer. By ARLENE FISCHER

title: SHUTTLE POISED FOR LIFTOFF TOMORROW AS CREW ARRIVES IN CAPE CANAVERAL
description: The astronauts who will fly the space shuttle Columbia arrived here today as work on the new craft proceeded smoothly, and even the weather showed signs of cooperating with plans to launch the first mission of the shuttle Friday morning.

title: Company News; Chrysler to Increase 'K' Car Production
description: The Chrysler Corporation said that it would begin increasing production of its ''K'' cars at the Jefferson Avenue assembly plant in Detroit next week to meet continuing high demand.

title: I.R.S. WITHDRAWS DISPUTED BANK RULE
description: The Internal Revenue Service today withdrew a controversial ruling that could have increased borrowing costs for state and local governments while subjecting banks to millions of dollars of liability for back taxes.

title: SAINT LAURENT: QUIET CLASSICS AND GLITTER
description: Yves Saint Laurent brought this week's fall and winter fashion shows here to a sober conclusion today with clothes that were straightforward, quiet and chic. It was, in fact, one of his classic collections, the kind he shows when he is not making waves and when he feels the world needs a breather from histrionic costumes.

title: WITNESS ACCUSES DEFENSE LAWYER IN WILLIAMS CASE
description: A key prosecution witness in the bribery trial of Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr., yesterday accused the Senator's attorney of telling the witness to ''forget about'' possible evidence against the Senator. The attorney heatedly denied the accusation. Earlier he had sought to destroy the credibility of the witness.

title: Credit Markets; BONDS FALL IN VOLATILE TRADING
description: Institutional investors, who must become heavy buyers of bonds before there can be a sustained drop in long-term interest rates, still have strong doubts about the Reagan Administration's plans to stimulate the economy and reduce inflation.

title: BIDDING GROWS HEATED FOR BIG SCOTTISH BANK
description: The Standard Chartered Bank indicated today it would fight to acquire the Royal Bank of Scotland Group. The result could be a bitter public battle with its rival, the Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corporation, which yesterday topped Standard Chartered's $704 million offer with a bid of $1.1 billion - believed to be the biggest such bid in British financial history.

title: by Irwin M. Stelzer
description: Every time that a New Yorker pays $5 for a taxicab ride, he pays 60 cents toward the preservation of monopoly power. The trial night and Sunday surcharge approved yesterday cannot change that fact. The Taxi and Limousine Commission's latest tinkering cannot provide adequate service and reasonable fares. More cabs can.

title: MET SLAYING SUSPECT'S REMARKS ADMISSIBLE
description: Statements made by Craig S. Crimmins to the police can be used at his trial for the murder of a violinist at the Metropolitan Opera House last summer, a judge ruled yesterday in State Supreme Court.

title:
ADVERTISING;
Attenzione to Increase Newsst
description: Until now, Attenzione magazine, which made its debut in 1979, has been sold primarily through subscriptions, with only a sparse presence at newsstands.

title: Investment in Japan Stocks
description: Net foreign investment in Japanese stocks may exceed $1 billion this month, an increase of $400 million over March, analysts at the Daiwa Securities Company said today. They said the situation was reminiscent of the mid-1980 boom on the Japanese stock market, when net foreign investment reached $1.07 billion in August and $1.14 billion in September. Foreign investors are mainly interested in steel, auto, shipbuilding and electronics issues, they said.

title: REAGAN PROPOSAL SEEKS DATA BANK ON 25 MILLION WELFARE RECIPIENTS
description: The Reagan Administration, in an effort to reduce welfare cheating, is proposing the creation of a data bank that would identify the estimated 25 million people on public assistance in a single national list for the first time.

title: Corco Expects End Of Chapter 11 Status
description: Judge Joseph C. Elliott of the United States Bankruptcy Court in San Antonio authorized the Commonwealth Oil Company to solicit creditor and shareholder acceptances of its plan for emergence from bankruptcy.

title: NEW PLAN DRAWN UP FOR EXCHANGE OF LAND IN TUDOR CITY CONTROVERSY
description: The New York City Board of Estimate agreed yesterday to obtain the required appraisals for a new land-exchange proposal that could resolve the longstanding controversy over the parks in the Tudor City apartment complex.

title: U.S. PLEDGE AFRICAN REFUGEE AID
description: The United States pledged at a United Nations conference here today to give $285 million to aid African refugees in 1981 and 1982.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt LOVE, DAD. By Evan Hunter. 407 pages. Crown. $12.95.

title: CONCANNON IN PLEA
description: CHICAGO, April 9, UPI) Jack Concannon, former Chicago Bears quarterback, pleaded not guilty today to drug charges at his Criminal Court arraignment. He was arrested March 18 in suburban Schaumburg on charges of selling to undercover agents 2.2 pounds of cocaine, worth $400,000 on the street. A hearing was set for April 24.

title: New PhotoQuick Chief Cites Industry 'Disarray'
description: Kenneth L. Horstmyer, 59 years old, has been named president and chief executive officer of PhotoQuick of America, a chain of 34 franchised and company-owned photo processing stores.

title: RODINO OFFERS A BILL TO CURB PISTOLS
description: Legislation to ban the sale of socalled Saturday night specials and tighten controls on the sale of other pistols has been introduced by Representative Peter Rodino Jr., Democrat of New Jersey.

title: Witness Can't Identify Contract
description: The financial adviser of Alfredo Escalera, formerly the World Boxing Council's superfeatherweight champion, testified that he had never before seen a purported contract between him and the promoter Don King that was presented to him in court yesterday.

title: An Appreciation
description: Omar N. Bradley was a peculiarly American military hero. There was about him some of the salt tang of the nation's youth, a faint echo of the frontier. That tall, lank figure would not have been out of place in one of Mathew

title: Assets Rise Again For Money Funds
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds rose $3.4 billion in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

title: The City; Daughter Identifies Slain Businessman
description: The formal identification of a man slain in Wisconsin on March 18 as William H. Callahan, the subject of embezzlement inquiries, was made in Kenosha, Wis., by his daughter, Eleanor Callahan of New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: A Platform Extension For L.I.R.R. Unveiled
description: Long Island Rail Road officials yesterday unveiled a $1.067 million extension for the railroad's busiest Penn Station platform, the first project completed with funds from the state's $500 million 1979 bond issue.

title: Black Indiana Police Allege Bias In Federal Lawsuit for $3 Million
description: Black state policemen filed a $3 million class-action lawsuit against the State Police Department yesterday, charging it with racial harassment and bias in hiring, promotion and evaluation practices.

title: An African Statesman
description: So far, Senegal is unique in Africa for making a peaceful transfer of power after its first President, Leopold Senghor, retired. Now the new President, Abdou Diouf, seeks to extend the record by legitimizing all political parties and expunging all past convictions on political or press control grounds.

title: CARLOS ALBERTO QUITS COSMOS
description: Carlos Alberto, the Brazilian sweeper who established order every time it appeared that the Cosmos' defense might become chaotic over the last four years, announced yesterday that he was leaving the team as a result of difficulties with Coach Hennes Weisweiler.

title: DEFECTORS' ARTISTRY
description: When one talks with an American about contemporary Russian art and culture, the conversation turns inevitably to defectors. One hears many rapturous words about their creative accomplishments. But there are also some unpleasant remarks.

title: Shoe Import Proposals
description: The International Trade Commission, which investigates trade problems for the Government, recommended today that President Reagan lift curbs on shoe imports from South Korea but continue restrictions for two years on imports from Taiwan. The footwear industry and two unions had asked the I.T.C. to extend for three years a voluntary agreement, expiring June 30, with the two countries. The accord limits their shipments of shoes to the United States.

title: BROWN ASKS WATT TO DROP 4 OFFSHORE OIL-LEASE AREAS
description: Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California urged Interior Secretary James G. Watt today to drop four disputed areas off the northern California shore from a proposed lease sale for oil and gas drilling rights.

title: Salvador Asked to Shield People on a 'Death List'
description: Amnesty International called on the Government of El Salvador today to protect people on ''an apparent death list'' of 138 names published by the army.

title: IMPROVE ITS DRAFT
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. IS STILL CONCERNED ON POLAND BUT SLIGHTLY RELIEVED, HAIG SAYS
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said today that the United States ''was somewhat relieved'' by the latest developments concerning Poland but that the continued high level of readiness of Soviet soldiers in the region was still a cause of concern.

title: MICHAEL ENJOYS HIS GRITS
description: The winning manager marched triumphantly into his office yesterday carrying the game ball and wearing a wide smile. On his desk was a stack of telegrams and a gift-wrapped three-foot plant that skimmed the ceiling. The ball was a gift from Bucky Dent, who had three hits, including a three-run home run in the Yankees' 10-3 victory over the Texas Rangers. The plant was a gift from Gene Michael's children, Sandy, Mark and Mathew.

title: Noranda Leading For Bloedel Control
description: Only 1,174 shares of MacMillan Bloedel Ltd. stock were tendered to the the British Columbia Resources Investment Corporation, in an offer that expired at 9:30 A.M. on the floors of the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stock exchanges. As a result, Noranda Mines Ltd. of Toronto appeared to be heading for control of Canada's largest forest products company.

title: ELECTRIC CONCERN'S NET CLIMBS
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation, the nation's second-largest manufacturer of electrical equipment after the General Electric Company, announced yesterday that earnings in the first quarter of 1981 rose 17.8 percent on an increase in sales of 6.9 percent.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: FED PURCHASES HELP PRICES A BIT; KEY U.S. BOND STILL AT 13% LEVEL By MICHAEL QUINT

title: Dick Seay, 2d Baseman, Black Baseball All-Star
description: Dick Seay, a star second baseman of the Negro National League in the 1930's and 1940's, died at his home in Jersey City Monday. He was 75 years old.

title: by Mimi Sheraton; North Italian and South Chinese.
description: JUST about one year old, Il Galletto on 34th Street, between Park and Lexington Avenues, is a convenient and convivial North Italian restaurant worth remembering when visiting in the neighborhood. Just four blocks from Madison Square Garden, it is jammed at lunch, but only moderately crowded at dinner.

title: OKC Mailing Out Liquidation Details
description: Stockholders of the OKC Corporation, Dallas, have been mailed final details of the company's liquidation plan, which involves distribution to the shareholders of money received from the sale of most of its oil and natural gas properties to the GMW Oil Company, Midland, Tex.

title: Noel Wins an Early Shot At the Lightweight Crown
description: The World Boxing Association agreed in United States District Court today to give Claude Noel of Trinidad an early shot at the lightweight championship.

title: STAGE: 'AAAH OUI GENTY' FRANCH PUPPETS AT BIJOU
description: ''AAAH OUI GENTY!'' which opened at the Bijou last night, is a puppet show -hand puppets, string puppets, puppets on steel rods, and puppets manipulated I don't know how, but not the way you dangled Punch and Judy. Obviously, there is invention here; there is amusement, charm and surrealism, too. How favorably you respond to this will be in direct proportion to how favorably you respond to puppets in general, and if you feel that when you have seen one puppet show you have seen them all, then that is a perfectly honorable position. If you love puppets, of course, you will be enchanted by ''Aaah Oui Genty!''

title: Arizona's Ex-Coach Suing School Over His Dismissal
description: Tony Mason, former University of Arizona football coach, has sued the school, officials, regents and unnamed others, alleging improper dismissal and defamation, his attorney said today.

title: SALVADOR BLAMES LEFT FOR SLAYINGS
description: The Government blamed leftist guerrillas today for the killing of 24 civilians here two days ago, saying the victims had been bound, tortured and shot ''in order to defame the police.''

title: ROCK CLUBS A GROWTH INDUSTRY
description: A LINE stretched down West 44th Street this week from the entrance to the Savoy, New York's newest rock club. Tickets for an eight-night engagement by the popular singer-songwriter James Taylor had just gone on sale, and teen-agers, young mothers and middle-aged men in tailored suits were waiting to buy them - at $15, $17.50 and $20 each.

title: FICKLE CUB FANS JEER KINGMAN
description: A divorce was made final today. Dave Kingman, who went to high school and started college near here, and who became an instant Cub hero in 1978 as a home-run hitter in a park that homerun hitters live for, paid a visit in a gray visitor's uniform. The masses were waiting.

title: The City; Jetliner Impounded After Belly Landing
description: Federal inspectors have impounded the Eastern Airlines 727 jet that had to be landed on its belly Wednesday night at Kennedy International Airport after its landing gear failed to function.

title: Aetna Link to I.B.M.
description: Aetna Life and Casualty announced yesterday it had signed an agreement with the International Business Machines Corporation to market more than 1,000 mini-computers to independent agents throughout the country by 1985. The contract commits Aetna to buy as much as $70 million in specially tailored equipment from I.B.M. over the next four years.

title: AMERICAN ETHNIC
description: To the Editor:

title: CITY OPERA: JANACEK'S 'LITTLE VIXEN'
description: WHAT might any opera company be expected to make of a work that alternately suggests Aesop, "L'Enfant et less Sortileges," Disney, Orwell's "Animal Farm," "lulu," Mother Goose, "Die Meistersinger" and Pogo? What, indeed, but one of the season's most charming and affecting evenings in the musical theater. The foregoing improbable catalogue rather fairly circumscribes Leos Janacek's "The Cunning Little Vixen," which the New York City Opera presented last night in a new production whose sets and costumes were realized from designs by the children's book illustrator Maurice Sendak.

title: Islanders Lead, 2-0, As Trottier Scores 3; Islanders Win Again As Trottier Scores 3
description: Bryan Trottier continued his scoring rampage tonight with three goals, leading the Islanders to a 5-1 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs at Nassau Coliseum. The triumph gave New York a 2-0 lead in the National Hockey League playoff, with the three-of-five-game series moving to Toronto Saturday night for the third contest.

title: by Peter G. Davis
description: THE Metropolitan Opera's new production of "La Traviata" on Monday night had a new Violetta, and Catherine Malfitano seized on the part as if it were a prize, which of course it is. Miss Malfitano has been seen and heard to advantage in other roles at the Met during the last two seasons, but this was her most prominent and demanding assignment to date.

title: EASTER MUSIC BEGINS WEEK OF SOLEMNITY AND JOY
description: EW YORK'S sacred music coexists with its lavishly publicized secular concert life, yet remains unnoticed by most people. The reason is partly the wordliness of our time and partly that most people who listen to music in a church do so in their own churches, and don't wander in search of esthetic experiences in the same way that secular concertgoers routinely do.

title: REFUSING TO JAIL A WHITE IS CALLED RACIST BY KOCH
description: A decision by a Criminal Court judge that a 23-year-old white man should not go to jail ''because the State of New York could not guarantee his safety in prison surroundings'' was criticized yesterday by Mayor Koch and other officials as racist.

title: Louis Bloch, 90, an Economist; Held Manpower Position in War
description: Louis Bloch, an economist who served on the War Manpower Commission in World War II, died March 31 in San Francisco, where he lived. He was 90 years old.

title: 'LA DROLESSE, ' ECCENTRIC LOVE STORY
description: ''LA DROLESSE,'' the 1978 French film that opens today at the Lincoln Plaza 3, is a sweet, eccentric love story about Mado, a lonely 11-year-old country girl, and Francois, a possibly psychotic 20-year-old fellow who kidnaps Mado and hides her in the attic of his parents' farmhouse. As soon as Fran-,cois has the willing Mado in his clutches, however, he abandons all thoughts of lust. Instead, each finds in the other the love and companionship that's been missing from life.

title: Around the Nation; High School Will Require Counseling Against Draft
description: The Berkeley Board of Education will require high school students to take instruction that includes counseling on how to avoid the draft.

title: PRODUCTIVITY FACTOR IN RETIREMENT PROGRAMS
description: To the Editor:

title: Jersey Asks to Void Caesars Stock Sale
description: The Attorney General of New Jersey asked a state court today to nullify the sale of more than $5 million in Caesars World Inc. stock to the gambling company's founders.

title: DELAY IN THE MAIL IN NASSAU LEADS TO VOTE RECOUNT
description: A State Supreme Court justice yesterday ordered a recount in a special State Assembly election after Democratic leaders charged ''deliberate sabotage'' was the reason that a Democratic campaign mailing of 10,600 postcards had been held up in the Hempstead post office for four days.

title: BUSINESS PANEL SAYS TRADE CENTER SHOULD BE SOLD BY PORT AUTHORITY
description: The World Trade Center, which includes New York City's two tallest buildings, should be sold to private investors, a panel of businessmen appointed by Governor Carey recommended yesterday.

title: COMPUTERS TO HAVE THE LAST WORD ON SHUTTLE FLIGHT
description: The space shuttle Columbia will be ruled by majority vote - not of its astronauts and ground crews but of its computers. Four on-board computers will control and navigate the Columbia in a system that many scientists consider the most advanced yet developed for the space program. The four computers will make all critical decisions, and a fifth will be on standby, ready to take over if three or four of the primary computers fail. In addition, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration recently decided to put a sixth computer on board as an extra precaution.

title: Notes on People; Reagans Bring a New Touch to an Old Tradition
description: Franklin D. Roosevelt was the first President to accept the position, Jimmy Carter declined it as a matter of policy, and now Ronald Reagan is resuming the tradition and adding a bonus. He and his wife, Nancy, will become the first husband-and-wife team to serve as honorary chairmen of the annual observance of National Bible Week.

title: Around the Nation; Valve Break Releases Acid In Detroit, Injuring 19
description: A safety valve ruptured in a chemical plant here today, severely burning four persons, injuring 15 others and spraying a cloud of acid over several city blocks.

title: A.&P. Merger Talks
description: Niagara Frontier Services Inc. told the American Stock Exchange that a possible merger into Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Company would involve cash and secured A.&P. debt obligations, but that no further announcements about negotiations would be made for about 10 days. Earlier in the week the Buffalo-area supermarket chain and A.&P. had disclosed they were talking about a merger. A.&P., one of the nation's largest surpermarket chains, does not now operate in the Buffalo area.

title: COLUMBIA FRATERNITIES REVIVE A RITE OF SPRING
description: Today, for the first time in 14 years, the fraternities at Columbia University will celebrate a modest, but nevertheless symbolic, return to their fabled days of beer and roses.

title: The Region; Navy Chief Defends Submarine Decision
description: The Secretary of the Navy, John F. Lehman Jr., yesterday defended his decision to assign the construction of three submarines to a boatyard in Newport News, Va., although the Electric Boat Company in Groton, Conn., was the low bidder.

title: 'NIGHTHAWKS' WITH SYLVESTER STALLONE
description: WE'VE seen movies like ''Nighthawks'' before, but we haven't seen one in a while. That may be why this police film, with an international cast and a plot about international terrorism, has so much punch. All of it is standard stuff, and yet ''Nighthawks'' has been assembled with enough pep to make it feel fresh. It is particularly helped by the performances of Rutger Hauer, a Dutch actor who makes a startling impression as a cold-blooded fiend, and Sylvester Stallone, from whom less is definitely more.

title: PUBLISHING: KEEPING UP WITH THE SUPPLY SIDE
description: WHEN George Gilder's ''Wealth and Poverty'' rolled off the presses in November, the first printing consisted of 5,000 copies for the trade and 3,000 for the Conservative Book Club. Today the book is appearing on best-seller lists. It has gone through eight printings, 125,000 copies are in print, and for Basic Books it is the first best seller in 10 years.

title: SHUTTLE PROPULSION: AN OLD-NEW BLEND
description: While many features of the space shuttle are brand new, some of the practical rocket technology underlying its propulsion systems was already known six centuries ago.

title: Topics; INHUMANITY JUSTICE; Again, Corpses in Uganda
description: It is premature to speak of a rerun of the ghastly regime of Idi Amin, but it is none too soon to recognize, just two years after his overthrow, that Uganda's hopes are being betrayed.

title: JUDGE HALTS STATE SPENDING OF UNAPPROPRIATED U.S. AID
description: Governor Carey must halt New York State's longstanding practice of spending Federal funds from the State Treasury without the Legislature's approval, a State Supreme Court justice ruled today.

title: SOME GUNFIRE ERUPTS IN LEBANON BUT THE CEASE-FIRE SEEMS TO BE HOLDING
description: Despite occasional gunshots and a brief exchange of shelling late tonight at Zahle between Syrian forces and Christian militia units, a cease-fire ordered yesterday by President Elias Sarkis appeared to be holding.

title: MISS CAULKINS SETS U.S. MARK IN MEDLEY
description: The rules for the United States short-course swimming championships limit each man and woman to four individual events over the four days.

title: Motorola In Deal On Memory Devices
description: Motorola Inc. has signed an agreement with the National Semiconductor Corporation under which Motorola will manufacture and market magnetic bubble memory devices and bubble memory controllers, which are used in computers.

title: Key Rates
description: * Current rate excludes 3 percentage-point surcharge on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Around the World; Barbados Judge Rules Biggs Must Be Returned to Britain
description: A Barbados judge ruled today that Ronald Biggs should be extradited to Britain to serve the rest of a 30-year-sentence for his role in the $7.3 million Great Train Robbery.

title: Genuine Risk to Race Tomorrow
description: Genuine Risk, who last year became the first filly to win the Kentucky Derby since Regret did it in 1915, is scheduled to make her 1981 debut in a $32,000 seven-furlong allowance race at Aqueduct tomorrow.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''For me one of the worst things would be if I woke up one day and said to people, 'I think apartheid is not so bad.'

title: BEGINNING AT HOME
description: To the Editor:

title: OIL PRICES SLIPPING AMID TALK OF GLUT
description: World oil conditions have returned to the buyer's market that existed before the Iran-Iraq war broke out last September, oil analysts say.

title: DONOVAN HOPES TO ACCOMMODATE SENATE ON SUBPOENA
description: Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan said today that he was not willing ''to send nine trailer trucks'' full of documents on alleged union criminal activity to Capitol Hill, but that he would still try to accommodate a Senate committee investigation.

title: PUNK'S 'D.O.A.'
description: SID VICIOUS, the closest thing to a star ''D.O.A.'' has, is dead now and was halfway there when the film was made. Interviewed with his girlfriend manager, Nancy Spungen, whom he later killed, Mr. Vicious affects the audience in ways most horror movies only dream of. Lying on a bed, which he nearly sets on fire several times during the course of a minute or two, Mr. Vicious languishes in a doze while Miss Spungen nags him impatiently to wake up. She also explains what a good influence she has been on him - ''We have good fun, we help each other out'' - and berates him about his career.

title: U.S. Says Moscow Puts New Aircraft in Poland
description: The Soviet Union has sent about 100 more transport helicopters, 50 to 100 transport planes and 500 to 1,000 pilots and technicians into Poland in the last week, officials here said today.

title: energywatch
description: APRIL 3 Crude oil stocks jumped to 395.4 million barrels. Experts say the increase reflects a decline in refinery output and a rise in crude oil imports.

title: SENATE PANEL, 12-8, REJECTS OWN PLAN FOR BUDGET IN 1982
description: The Republican-dominated Senate Budget Committee tonight rejected the austere budget that it had drafted for the fiscal year 1982, creating a delay that Reagan Administration officials feared could halt the budget-cutting momentum.

title: Market Place; Inflation: A Tax That Bites Deep
description: THE chairman of Berkshire Hathaway Inc., Warren E. Buffett, always reflects on the world of business in his company's annual report. This year his subject is the impact of inflation on corporate earnings, and he paints a grim picture. As always, his remarks have relevance for the nation's shareholders generally.

title: Notes on People; Trying for a Third Time to Make a Met Debut
description: Finally it's going to happen for Simon Estes. The Iowa-born bassbaritone is going to make his debut Sunday night at the Metropolitan Opera House, after having had it postponed twice, which may be some kind of a record.

title: MINE LEADER SEEKS TO REOPEN TALKS
description: The United Mine Workers president, Sam M. Church Jr., buoyed by a vote of confidence from his executive board, yesterday proposed immediate resumption of negotiations with the soft-coal industry to end a 14-day strike by 160,000 miners.

title: Dollar Drain At Polish Bank
description: Western banks are believed to have withdrawn over the past month $400 million to $500 million in shortterm dollar deposits at Poland's foreign trade bank in Warsaw, banking sources said today.

title: BANKERS NOW FAVORING BRAZIL
description: In an abrupt departure from the warning signals it was putting out regularly only months ago, the international banking community is expressing favor with the economy of Brazil and lending the Government money at a rate that is outstripping national leaders' programmed goals.

title: PROFILE OF AVERAGE OTB BETTOR
description: A study by New York City's Offtrack Betting Corporation has found that the average customer earns less than $18,000 a year, has a bluecollar job, wagers $18 on the days he gambles and rarely goes to race tracks.

title: U.S. Steel in Sohio Deal
description: The United States Steel Corporation announced yesterday that it had agreed to sell 28 percent of its coal reserves and two of its mines for about $700 million to the Standard Oil Company (Ohio).

title: BRIEFS
description: * Alcolac Inc, said its merger into a wholly owned subsidiary of Tunnel Holdings Ltd. had been completed.

title:
RED SMITH;
Another Opening And Another Show
description: IT was the start of Don Zimmer's 23d baseball season, and the question was meant facetiously: Was he nervous? ''I'd be lying if I said no,'' the manager of the Texas Rangers said. ''Well, maybe not nervous exactly, but that opening-day feeling. It's next to the World Series, except for the playoff game in 1978.'' That was the year the Yankees tied the Red Sox in the American League East, and Bucky Dent won the single playoff game for New York with a home run.

title: Bank To Help Pay Lance's Fees
description: Stockholders of the National Bank of Georgia ratified an agreement yesterday to pay Bert Lance $477,790.91 for legal fees he incurred in his trial on bank fraud charges. Mr. Lance, the bank's former president, who resigned as former President Carter's budget director to fight the charges, had asked the bank for $1.07 million.

title: CHEMICAL, MARINE MIDLAND UP SHARPLY
description: Two large New York banks yesterday reported sharp increases in first-quarter net operating earnings. The Chemical New York Corporation, the nation's seventh-largest banking organization, said its earnings, before securities transactions, rose 54.3 percent, to $50.2 million in the first quarter from $32.5 million in the comparable period of 1980. Earnings per common share rose to $3.12 from $2.06.

title: POLLUTION COALITION URGES RETAINING CLEAN-AIR LAWS
description: The National Clean Air Coalition, representing environmental, public health and other citizens' groups, today called for preserving the Clean Air Act of 1970 basically unchanged except for adding provisions to deal with so-called acid rain and toxic air pollution.

title: Index; International
description: For a principle, a father in Argen- tina is persecuted A2 U.S. pledges $285 million to help African refugees A3 Peres says Eban will be Foreign Minister if Labor Party wins A4 Around the World A5 Ebullient Bishop Tutu returns to South Africa A6 Weinberger says Polish invasion is still possible A8 Haig ends visit to Spain express- ing support for its democracy A9 Government/Politics Donovan voices concern about subpoenaed records A10 Recount ordered of ballots in As- sembly election in Nassau B2 Connecticut Senate votes for higher parkway tolls B2 Court tells state to stop spending unappropriated funds B2 Prosecution rests in Margiotta ex Decision not to jail white criti- cized as racist by Koch B3 Energy Proposed offshore leases at issue in California A10 General Around the Nation A10 Gray sues the Government over its break-in case against him A15 Goody company convicted of deal- ing in bogus tapes B2 Health/Science Space shuttle fuels: a blend of old and new technology A16 Contingencies drawn for aborting journey into space A16 Multicomputer system to make all vital decisions on shuttle A17 Education/Welfare Bell urges stiff tests for students to be promoted A10 Weekend Weekender Guide C1

title: Writers' Talks Wind Up Tonight at New School
description: The writers Toni Morrison and Toni Cade Bambara and the poet Audre Lorde will take part tonight in final program of the ''Conversations With Writers'' series at the New School.

title: ART: MANIERRE DAWSON, AN AMERICAN KANDINSKY
description: THE name of Manierre Dawson, though no longer so obscure as it was 12 years ago, when the first New York exhibition of his work was mounted at the Robert Schoelkopf Gallery, even today remains better known to specialists in early American modernism than to the art public at large. Even among the casualties of his artistic generation -the first generation of American modernists - Dawson's was a strange and poignant case. For a period of four crucial years, 1910-14, he produced some of the most remarkable avant-garde paintings being created in the United States. Then - nothing. He changed his life and for all practical purposes gave up on his artistic vocation. When he died in 1969, at the age of 82, he was found to have produced nothing of interest since 1914.

title: DANCE: 2 NEW WORKS BY TRISLER TROUPE
description: FROM the moment pretty young Elizabeth Roxas oozed across the stage, all extravagant curves and cinches in her red leotard and tights, and young Eugene Roscoe sassed his jubilant way through a jitterbug, you knew you were in the presence of a likable and welltrained modern dance company. Not that it was a surprise. The late Joyce Trisler, whose Danscompany performed on Wednesday in the Dance Umbrella festival at The Space at City Center, was a demanding teacher who enjoyed a bit of comeback from her dancers. Unfortunately, the Umbrella repertory seemed for the most part but a limp rejoinder.

title: Private Schools, Public Duty
description: Advocates of tuition tax credits for parochial and private schools now find new ammunition in yet another ''Coleman Report.''

title: RADIOACTIVE WATER LEAKS AT INDIAN PT.
description: An undetermined amount of ''slightly'' radioactive water accidentally leaked from the shutdown Indian Point 2 nuclear plant at Buchanan, and some of it drained into the nearby Hudson River, officials of the Consolidated Edison Company said today.

title: JURY INDICTS FIRM IN SEWER PROJECT ON BRIBE COUNTS
description: The principal engineering firm involved in Suffolk County's $1.2 billion Southwest Sewer District project was indicted yesterday on charges of bribing public officials and political figures in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut in order to obtain contracts.

title: Miller Among 4 Tied at 69 Miller Among 4 Tied at 69
description: The Masters got off to a brisk start today on a new set of bent-grass greens and with swirling winds that played tricks with the scores.

title: MISS CASALE SCORES ANOTHER TENNIS UPSET
description: Pam Casale phoned her family in Fairfield, N.J., today with more good news after upsetting Dianne Fromholtz for a berth in the quarterfinals of the $150,000 Family Circle Cup tennis tournament.

title: SSS/Obit Page; Charles Schnurmacher, 75, Dies;
description: A Car Dealer and Philanthropist

title: BLACK CLERIC BACK IN SOUTH AFRICA BUT BOTHA IS FIRM OVER PASSPORT
description: Bishop Desmond Tutu returned here today from a 10-nation tour and declared, in a manner that was too ebullient to be described merely as unrepentant, that he regretted none of the remarks that provoked Prime Minister P.W. Botha to threaten to confiscate his passport.

title: New Orleans Endorsed for Fair
description: Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige today endorsed a proposal to hold the 1984 World's Fair in New Orleans after sponsors came up with more than $30 million in loan guarantees. ''I will recommend favorably on this project to the President based on the sponsors' assurance that the full $37.5 million in guarantees will be in hand by May 15,'' Mr. Baldrige said.

title: Volkswagen Plans To Cut Dividend
description: Volkswagen, the West German auto maker, will cut its annual 1980 dividend to shareholders because of a slump in net earnings last year, the company said today. the supervisory board, the group that forms company policy, voted to recommend to a July 2 shareholders meeting to reduce the dividend to 8 marks, or $3.73, per $22.50 share. In 1979, the company paid 10 marks.

title: Oratorios and Choral Concerts; Today; Carnegie Hall. Salieri's Mass No. 1 in D major and Mozart's Mass in C minor, ''The Great,'' (K. 427); St.  Cecilia Chorus and Orchestra conducted by David Randolph. At 8 P.M.  Tickets $4-11. Information: 247-7459.; Tomorrow; Second Presbyterian Church, 6 West
description: 96th Street. ''Surrexit Pastor Bonus'' by Mendelssohn, ''Ave Maria'' by Brahms, Five Motets by Distler, Five Hungarian Folk Songs by Bartok, ''Petites Voix'' by Poulenc and other music; Radcliffe Choral Society conducted by Beverly Taylor. At 8 P.M. Suggested donation: $2. Palm Sunday Church of St. Ignatius Loyola (Roman

title: DOW CLIMBS BY 5.40 IN HEAVY TRADING
description: The stock market finished moderately higher yesterday in heavier trading with the glamour, blue chips and airlines issues posting the largest gains.

title: METS DEFEAT CUBS, 2-0 IN SEASON OPENER
description: For the seventh straight year, the Mets won their opening game when they defeated the Chicago Cubs today, 2-0, on a kind of gang effort.

title: FORD WON'T MATCH G.M. PRICE RISE
description: The Ford Motor Company said today that it would not increase its car and light truck prices at least through the end of this month, in an apparent bid to increase sales at the expense of the General Motors Corporation.

title: End of Counseling Units For Veterans Criticized
description: The Veterans Administration was involved in a dispute today over its a decision to close storefront counseling centers for Vietnam veterans despite agency concerns, disclosed yesterday, that up to a million of the veterans might still suffer stress, depression and other psychological trauma from combat.

title: Japanese Unconvinced After U.S. Auto Talks
description: A United States Government delegation concluded today a mission here to explain President Reagan's relief measures for the American auto industry. But the Japa@nese side remained unconvinced of the effectiveness of the United States program, Japanese officials reported.

title: OILERS JOLT CANADIENS FOR 2-0 PLAYOFF LEAD
description: Risto Siltanen scored the deciding goal and Andy Moog, Edmonton's rookie goalie, stopped 40 shots as the Oilers beat the Montreal Canadiens, 3-1, tonight and took a 2-0 lead in their preliminary Stanley Cup playoff series.

title: WEINBERGER SAYS INVASION IS STILL A 'REAL POSSIBLITY'
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger asserted today that a Soviet invasion of Poland ''is still a very real possibility'' despite what he described as a ''more conciliatory'' tone in Moscow's recent statements.

title: KILLINGS IN SALVADOR DEPLORED BY U.S.
description: The killing of unarmed civilians that has been attributed to El Salvador's security forces was deplored by the Reagan Administration today as a threat to the Government of Jose Napoleon Duarte.

title: BELL URGES STIFF TESTS TO DECIDE IF STUDENTS GO ON TO NEXT GRADE
description: Schools should require students to pass tough comprehensive examinations as a means of ''quality control'' before promoting them from key grades and allowing them to graduate from high school, Education Secretary T.H. Bell said today.

title: REAGAN IS TAKEN OFF A DRUG AND FOUND IN 'GOOD SHAPE'
description: President Reagan's physicians today discontinued one of the two antibiotics he had been receiving to prevent infection in the bullet wound in his left lung, and the painful physical therapy to dislodge congestion in Mr. Reagan's lung was ended as well.

title: Good Friday; All Saints Church (Episcopal), 230 East 60th
description: Street. Miserere by Gregorio Allegri, ''Drop, Drop Slow Tears'' by Kenneth Leighton, Victoria's ''Improperia,'' ''Adoramus Te, Christe'' by Antonio Lotti and Claudio Monteverdi, Gregorian psalms and antiphons. At 12:30 P.M. Information: PL 8-0447. Calvary Episcopal Church, Park Avenue South, at 21st Street. ''God So Loved the World'' by Stainer, ''O Sacrum Convivium'' by Messiaen, ''Ave Verum Corpus'' by Byrd. Noon. Information: 475-0830. Christ and St. Stephen's Church (Episcopal),

title: The City; Transit Unions Face Loss of Checkoff
description: The three unions that struck the Transit Authority for 11 days last April face the possible loss of their right to the automatic checkoff of membership dues as a result of a decision by Harvey Milowe, a hearing officer of the State Public Employment Relations Board.

title: Man Dies in Elizabeth House Fire
description: A man was killed and five firemen received minor injuries early today in a blaze that swept through a frame house in the city's industrial section, officials said. The dead man was identified as Eugene Thomas, 57 years old.

title: Home Resales May Increase
description: Resale of existing single-family homes this year is expected to total 3.2 million units, for a gain of 11 percent over the depressed level of these sales in 1980, according to a forecast released yesterday by Multi-List/ McGraw Hill, the real estate arm of the McGraw-Hill Information Systems Company. The average sales price was forecast at $80,900, also an 11 percent rise from last year.

title: Advertising; Television 'Censors' Criticized
description: In two areas, at least, the heads of the three major television networks see eye-to-eye - they are generally unconcerned about the inroads being made by new technology but fearful about what they see as the new wave of self-appointed censors.

title: 50'S TEENS IN 'CRAZY TIMES,' ZOLA'S 'THERESE' AND PAUL
description: IN ''Crazy Times,'' tonight's movie on ABC-TV at 9 o'clock, the year is 1955. That much is immediately apparent because the woman crying along with Johnny (Ray Liotta) in a theater showing James Dean in ''Rebel Without a Cause'' is not his girlfriend, but his mother. Later, at the local ice-cream parlor, they agree they hadn't had such a good sniffle since ''Dumbo.''

title: Around the World; Iran Orders Printing Curb On Some Newspapers
description: Iran's Information Ministry today ordered printing companies not to print newspapers that lack a valid Government license.

title: MOBILE-RADIO 'CELLS' APPROVED BY F.C.C.
description: The Federal Communications Commission agreed today to begin licensing a new type of radio system that promises broad changes in mobile communications. At the same time, the F.C.C. also rejected pleas to restrict tightly the entry by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company into the new industry.

title: The Dirty Secret of Journalism
description: There's an ill, unconstitutional wind blowing from Latin America that has driven some of our colleagues in Puerto Rico's news business astray. We almost said ''professional'' colleagues, but their desire for such exalted designation, and the higher wages it might bring, is precisely the problem.

title: ISRAEL RAIDS SITE IN SOUTH LEBANON
description: Israeli paratroopers struck eight miles across the Lebanese border last night and destroyed a ''terrorist base'' northeast of Nabatiye, according to the military command.

title: New Advocate for Disabled
description: Governor Carey today named a new state advocate for the disabled. His appointee, Frances G. Berko, 61 years old, has been serving as coordinator of the State Commission on the International Year of Disabled Persons. Miss Berko, who has been on leave from the Suffolk Developmental Center, will assume her new $48,600-a-year post next Wednesday.

title: Around the Nation; Police Tie-In Is Alleged In Kidnappings in Florida
description: A recently honored policeman and and a former policeman have been charged with kidnapping for their alleged part in abductions involving $1 million ransom demands, the police announced yesterday.

title: Chemical Bank Selling Building
description: The Chemical Bank said today that it had signed a contract with Jack Resnick and Sons Inc., a New York real estate developer, to sell its headquarters building at 20 Pine Street in lower Manhattan for $45 million. The bank already has begun to move its headquarters to 277 Park Avenue.

title: 7 Die in French Road Crashes
description: Seven persons were killed and 55 injured today in several crashes of speeding cars on a fog-bound northern French highway.

title: Relief, but Not Leadership, for Detroit
description: President Reagan's new plan to help the ailing auto industry is carefully fashioned to offend as few interests as possible and to stave off independent action by Congress to reduce imports. But it isn't going to change much. Far bolder action by Washington is needed to turn the industry around - more specifically, a willingness to press Big Auto for major organizational reforms.

title: STAR-STUDDED CAST FOR CAREY WEDDING
description: There are some politicians, industrialists and show-business personalities who have not been invited to the wedding tomorrow morning of Evangeline Gouletas and Governor Carey, but not many.

title: U.S. SEXTET WINS, 5-0
description: 0 in a final warmup for the world championship tournament in Sweden next week. Last night the teams drew, 3-3, in Tuopio.

title: AGENTS CHECK LETTER TO EVANGELIST IN REAGAN THREAT
description: The Secret Service said here today that it was looking for a possible connection between a letter mailed to a Louisiana evangelist before President Reagan was shot and threats against the President that Edward Michael Richardson allegedly made several days after the attempted assassination of Mr. Reagan.

title: BOORMAN'S 'EXCALIBUR'
description: THE Arthurian legends will not die for good reason. They are essential myths. Yet some films made of them are funnier (''Monty Python and the Holy Grail'') and more stimulating (Robert Bresson's ''Lancelot of the Lake'' and Eric Rohmer's ''Perceval'') than others, including the foolish screen version of the musical ''Camelot'' and now John Boorman's big, solemn, grandiose ''Excalibur.''

title: CONCERT: THE FOLGER CONSORT
description: THE music of medieval Czechoslovakia, 16th-century Dalmatia and early 17th-century Poland shared an important characteristic on Wednesday night in the Abraham Goodman House - it was played with uncommon sensitivity and nuance by the Folger Consort, the resident ensemble for early music at the Folger Shakespeare Library.

title: ART: HUMANIZED STARFISH OF ALAN SIEGEL AT PLAY
description: MIDWAY between art and the theater, storytelling and dexterous illusion, the ''starfish constructions'' of Alan Siegel at the Cordier & Ekstrom Gallery, 417 East 75th Street, will endear themselves to anyone who wants a new and curious experience at this particularly agreeable moment in the year.

title: FRIENDS MOURN A MURDER VICTIM, 16
description: Last Friday, Karen Marsh, a 16-year-old Bronx high school student, told several of her close friends that she often worried about her father because he was a city policeman in a city full of crime and violence.

title: MEMOREX SEEKS NEW RECOVERY
description: Eight years after a sudden turnaround saved it from the brink of bankruptcy, the Memorex Corporation has encountered sluggish sales, mounting competition and deep losses.

title: BALLET COMPETITION SET FOR JUNE
description: The second American International Ballet Competition will be held in Jackson, Miss., from June 20 through July 4, 1982. ''Jackson has now become the official home for the competition in the United States,'' Gov. William F. Winter of Mississippi said in announcing the dates.

title: Around the Nation; Prosecution Rests Case In Slaying of Halberstam
description: Prosecutors completed their case today against Bernard Welch in the murder in December of Dr. Michael Halberstam, the cardiologist. Final arguments were expected tomorrow.

title: BENJAMIN SLADE
description: Benjamin Slade, a retired engineer and member of the technical staff of Bell Laboratories for 43 years, died yesterday of a heart ailment at Wayne County Memorial Hospital in Goldsboro, N.C., where he lived.

title: CITY APPROVES PLAN ON LOFT CONVERSION FOR RESIDENTIAL USE
description: New York City yesterday enacted the first major program in more than a decade to regulate the conversion of industrial and commercial lofts in Manhattan to residential use.

title: No Headline
description: Following is a list of some of the special musical presentations and other events planned for the Easter season at churches and concert halls in the metropolitan area. Palm Sunday All Saints Church (Episcopal), 230 East 60th Street. Music by Victoria, Monteverdi and ''L'Hora Passa'' Mass by Viadana; choir led by the Rev. Dennis G. Michno. At 11 A.M. Information: 758-0447. All Souls Unitarian Church, Lexington Avenue and 80th Street. ''The Fawns'' from Respighi's ''Deita Silvane,'' Psalm 24 by Boulanger; Walter Klauss, music director. At 11 A.M. Information: 535-5530.

title: House Panel Acts to Bar $130 Million to Syrians
description: A House Foreign Affairs subcommittee, in an effort to show disapproval of Syria's role in recent fighting in Lebanon, voted today to block $130 million in undistributed economic aid to Damascus.

title: EARL F. AIKEN
description: Earl F. Aiken, corporate treasurer of the Morrison-Knudson Company, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home in Boise, Idaho.

title: NEW ANTITRUST LEADER VOWS TO BREAK UP A.T.&T.
description: The Justice Department's new antitrust chief said today that the department would aggressively pursue its lawsuit to break up the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, despite objections raised by Defense Department officials.

title: FORMER F.B.I. CHIEF SUES JUSTICE DEPT.
description: L. Patrick Gray, Acting Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation in the Nixon Administration, filed a $5.5 million lawsuit today against the Justice Department, charging that department attorneys had presented distorted evidence against him to a grand jury.

title: DODGERS BEAT ASTROS ON ROOKIE'S 5-HITTER
description: Fernando Valenzuela, a rookie making his first start for Los Angeles, pitched a five-hitter, and Steve Garvey scored twice to lead the Dodgers to a 2-0 victory over the Houston Astros today before a crowd of 50,511.

title: 'Supporting Cast,' comedy about kin of notables, due in July.
description: ''IT'S a mean, vicious, gossipy play - and I love it.'' Thus, Gene Saks has gleefully signed to direct George Furth's new comedy, ''The Supporting Cast.'' The play, by the man who wrote the book for Stephen Sondheim's musical ''Company,'' as well as the straight play ''Twigs,'' which starred Sada Thompson in 1971, will go into rehearsal next month. The comedy will try out at the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington on June 26 and open on Broadway in late July.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * All-Steel Inc., Aurora, Ill., has elected Mason D. Feisel president and chief executive officer.

title: News Analysis
description: The space shuttle Columbia is such a complex piece of machinery that its first flight is necessarily a risky proposition. But the shuttle's constituency finds it unsettling to believe in anything other than success, for the future of the nation's space programs, military, scientific and commercial, hinges on this re-usable winged spaceship.

title: STAGE: 'HALF-LIFE,' STORY OF A CRUSTY HEDONIST
description: THE second best way to appreciate the acting artistry of Sir John Gielgud is to see someone else play his role. Several seasons ago in London, Sir John took Julian Mitchell's ''Half-Life,'' a modestly thoughtful play, and turned it into a richly textured character sketch. In the National Theater production, the actor personified Sir Noel Cunliffe, a crusty 75-year-old archeologist with impeccable taste and unswerving conceit, an impossible man facing a late-in-life crisis.

title: The Budget Targets Seventh in a series on key programs; that President Reagan wants to cut.
description: In a particularly heated session in David A. Stockman's office, Mr. Stockman, Secretary of Agriculture John R. Block, and Deputy Secretary Richard E. Lyng were debating Mr. Stockman's proposed cuts in the farm budget. At one point in a discussion of dairy price supports, Mr. Stockman, the young director of the Office of Management and Budget, pointed to the wall and said: ''See that picture? That's a farm where I milked cows for 15 years. Don't talk to me about farming.''

title: Notes on People; Words of Thanks and Words of Modesty
description: When he was released from the hospital the other day, Timothy J. McCarthy, the Secret Service agent wounded in the attack on President Reagan, said he wanted to thank the stranger who helped him as he lay bleeding in front of the Washington Hilton Hotel.

title: WORKERS' RIGHTS AND THE PUBLIC INTEREST IN LABOR ELECTIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: FAMILY PERSECUTED IN ARGENTINA FOR STAND ON RIGHTS
description: A physicist and his wife, a chemist, talk quietly in their apartment as sunlight filters through the white chiffon curtains. The light dapples the hardwood floors and the books stacked on corner tables.

title: ARIZONAN GUILTY IN CHAINING OF WORKER
description: A state court jury here has found a former rancher guilty of unlawful imprisonment and aggravated assault in the chaining of a Mexican farmworker he had employed.

title: Around the Nation; Teacher's Suspension Urged Over Aristotle Assignment
description: A high school English teacher should be suspended for one semester without pay for teaching Aristotle and Machiavelli to his 10th grade students, a Montgomery County Board of Education hearing examiner says. Cyril Lang was guilty of a ''willful and deliberate act of insubordination'' by assigning reading from the two authors, according to a report by examiner Joseph Sickles.

title: PERAHIA COMES HOME FOR A PIANISTIC VISIT
description: Murray Perahia, the pianist, passed through New York not long ago, alighting briefly at one of those drab but expensive hotel rooms along the Upper West Side and then flying quickly off again for two concert performances in Florida.

title: DANCE: HOUSTON BALLET'S 'PAPILLON'
description: THE theme of boy loves butterfly has its limitations, but the Houston Ballet does wonders with just this subject in an absolutely delightful comic ballet that is on view this weekend at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Go see it.

title: JUDGE WEIGHS MOTION TO DROP CASE
description: The prosecution rested its case against Joseph M. Margiotta today, and Federal Judge Charles Sifton reserved decision on a defense motion to dismiss the case.

title: The U.N. Today; April 10, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Special Committee on Enhancing Nonuse of Force in International Relations - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: A SCENT OF SPRING AT PUBLIC GARDENS
description: SPRINGTIME has come to New York, with flowers of sunny yellow, sky blue and creamy white. To see them, head first for the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, where the magnificent collection of magnolias is in full bloom. The garden boasts one of the oldest and largest collections of these magnificent trees in the metropolitan area. Some of the 80 trees in the courtyard around the entrance plaza were planted in 1914; the main collection dates back to 1932. The years have sculptured these trees beautifully, and they are particularly wonderful to look at just now, with sunlight filtering through the waxy white flowers and no leaves to get in the way.

title: AILEY DANCE GROUP GETS COSTUMES BACK
description: A stolen truck containing $50,000 in costumes and equipment belonging to the Alvin Ailey Repertory Company was returned to the dance company, minus $6,000 worth of rented sound equipment and the truck's battery. The police discovered the abandoned truck Wednesday night at Sayers Avenue and New York Boulevard in Queens, about two miles from where it was stolen from a driveway Tuesday night or Wednesday morning, the company's stage manager said.

title: DOCTORS-TO-BE PONDER ABORTION
description: In other classes they learn about anatomy and biochemistry, physiology and histology. But when first-year medical students at the Mount Sinai School of Medicine meet each week for their Introduction to Medicine course, the issues discussed are more elusive: an individual's moral responsibility to act according to his or her own conscience versus a doctor's professional responsibility to serve his patient; honesty in the name of truth versus dishonesty in the name of compassion; patients' rights versus doctors' rights.

title: HAIG, ON A VISIT TO SPAIN, ATTEMPTS TO ASSURE REGIME OF U.S. SUPPORT
description: After meeting with King Juan Carlos, Prime Minister Leopoldo Calvo Sotelo and other Spanish leaders, Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. today ended a one-day visit to Spain expressing support for its democratic institutions.

title: RULING TO EASE CURB ON EX-HOSTAGES' EARNINGS IS BONANZA FOR POLITICIANS
description: The Federal Election Commission eased a restriction today to help the Americans who were held hostage in Iran, but the action also opened the way for politicians to receive almost unlimited sums of money from speeches and articles.

title: SCHMIDT, IN STERNER TONE, BLAMES SOVIET FOR WORLD ILLS
description: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt, giving new emphasis to his increasingly critical portrayal of the Soviet Union, said today that its military and political expansionism were the essential causes of the ''world's darkened political horizon.''

title: SHUTTLE'S MISHAPS LAID TO ITS BUDGET AND NEW TECHNOLOGY
description: The maiden flight of the space shuttle Columbia scheduled for today was delayed three years by a procession of mishaps not entirely unexpected in the production of a craft whose requirements originally went far beyond existing technology.

title: Noranda's Diplomatic Executive
description: Adam H. Zimmerman, 54, has to be as much of a diplomat as a businessman as the leader of the $626 million (Canadian) attempt by Noranda Mines Ltd. of Toronto to raise its 8 percent interest in MacMillan Bloedel Ltd. of Vancouver to a commanding 49 percent.

title: GRAFT IS SUGGESTED
description: A former Polish Prime Minister is under investigation by the state prosecutor for decisions made while in office, and a similar case may be prepared against the former party leader, Edward Gierek, a newspaper reported today.

title: GOODY COMPANY AND AN EXECUTIVE CONVICTED IN BOGUS TAPES SCHEME
description: Sam Goody Inc., one of the oldest and largest chains of recordedmusic stores in the country, and a company vice president were convicted yesterday of knowingly dealing in counterfeit cassette and eight-track tapes of popular music.

title: SMALL BUSINESS GETS ITS OWN CONSULTANTS
description: When Carl Ernst opened a management consulting concern in Albany in 1973, he did not have to fight for business in a cutthroat market. ''To find outside expertise at the time, a businessman had to go to New York or Boston,'' he recalls. ''There was no one to speak to in the area.''

title: KINGS TOP RANGERS, 5-4 AFTER BRAWL ENDS FIRST PERIOD
description: Dean Hopkins scored with 2 minutes 44 seconds remaining to give the Kings a 5-4 playoff victory over the Rangers in a game that was marred by 267 minutes of penalties and a knee injury to New York's Dave Maloney.

title: Kaiser Aluminum: Profit Down 7.1%
description: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation yesterday reported that first-quarter earnings fell 7.1 percent, to $68.1 million, or $1.60 a share, from $73.5 million, or $1.77 a share, in the first three months of 1980.

title: MacAndrews Names President
description: Bruce Slovin, 45, has been appointed president of the MacAndrews and Forbes Group, a flavorings processor based in New York. Ronald O. Perelman, 38, continues as chairman and chief executive officer.

title: Around the World; Turnout Is Heavy In Ulster Voting
description: Voters turned out in large numbers today in a by-election to decide whether a 27-year-old jailed Roman Catholic guerrilla or a 63-year-old Protestant hardliner will represent them in the British Parliament.

title: New Orleans Opening Is Brisk
description: The South's only commodity exchange market opened here today with brisk trading in milled rice futures. Trading in open rough rice and milled rice will begin tomorrow, activity in short staple cotton will start in May, with soybean trading following a few weeks later at the newest of the nation's 12 commodity markets, according to Tom Webber, president of the fledgling New Orleans Commodity Exchange.

title: BODY OF 23RD VICTIM IS FOUND IN ATLANTA found
description: The case of Atlanta's slain children took another turn today when the body of a young black man was discovered in an abandoned apartment building about six blocks from his home in the northwest section of the city.

title: Around the World; Mrs. Gandhi Backs Brezhnev On Call for Summit Talks
description: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, alluding to President Leonid I. Brezhnev's call for a summit meeting with President Reagan, said today that ''no opportunity for a dialogue should be missed.''

title: Notes on People
description: ? Diana Trilling to Get $1 Million for Movie on Harris Case

title: CHRYSLER NAMES 2 TO JOBS AS IACOCCA'S CHIEF AIDES
description: Two younger executives were named to top positions at the Chrysler Corporation today just under Lee A. Iacocca, the chairman, as the president and vice chairman of the company announced their retirements.

title: 'THIS ULTIMATE THREAT'
description: Following are excerpts from a talk that General of the Army Omar N. Bradley, who died Wednesday at 88, gave at a convocation at St. Alban's School, in Washington, on Nov. 5, 1957. It is reprinted from the Nov. 18, 1957, issue of I.F. Stone's Weekly.

title: Drama, Dance, Verse and Jazz; Tomorrow; The Cloisters, Fort Tyron Park.
description: ''Noah's Flood,'' 14th-century drama adapted from the Chester cycle, performed by the Actors Guild. At noon, 1:30 and 3 P.M. Free with admission (suggested contribution of $3.50). Information: 879-5500. Palm Sunday

title: NATION'S OLDEST MAGIC SHOW POPS UP AT HUNTER
description: KEN ALAN is 24 years old, but the magician has already beheaded 2,173 women with his scimitar, and he will do it again tomorrow night at 8 o'clock at Hunter College. Rollan Rochelle has been producing striped umbrellas, canes, bouquets of flowers and streamers of silk out of thin air for 38 of his 52 years, and he will do it again tomorrow night, too.

title: F.C.C. Halts Applications For Weak TV Stations
description: The Federal Communications Commission voted today to halt the acceptance of any more applications for lowpower television stations.

title: ESCAPE PLANS DRAWN UP IF LAUNCHING GOES AWRY
description: Space agency officials here, proud that no astronauts have been lost on any previous space launchings, appeared confident today that they had done everything reasonable to minimize the dangers of the shuttle mission.

title: SHUTTLE MEETS NEED FOR RE-USABLE CRAFT THAT COULD ALSO SERVE MILITARY'S
description: ENDS By RICHARD L. WITKIN

title: Notes on People; '53d Hostage' Hospitalized
description: Cynthia Dwyer, the freelance journalist who spent nine months in an Iranian prison until her release earlier this year, has been hospitalized suffering from what her husband described as ''fatigue and delayed stress.''

title: About Real Estate; A BUILDER'S SHIFT AWAY FROM HOUSING IN NEW YORK CITY
description: In the early 1950's Jack Parker was in the lumber business. He owned two mills on the West Coast. He sold that business in 1954, but he remained in construction, moving to the East Coast.

title: Ellis M. Haller, 66, a Top Editor At U.S. News and World Report
description: Ellis M. Haller, an assistant managing editor of U.S. News & World Report, died Tuesday night of a heart attack in Orlando, Fla. He was 66 years old.

title: AUSTIN SCOTT, HARVARD PROFESSOR AND AN AUTHORITY ON TRUST LAWS
description: Austin W. Scott, one of the best-known professors at the Harvard Law School, and for more than four decades one of the nation's foremost authorities on the law of trusts, died yesterday at Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston after a brief illness. He was 96 years old.

title: CONNECTICUT ASSEMBLY VOTES A 10-CENT RISE IN ROAD TOLLS
description: The Connecticut State Senate gave final legislative approval tonight to a 10-cent increase in parkway and bridge tolls as part of an array of tax and fee increases that has begun moving through the General Assembly.

title: by Chris Chase; Jessica Tandy shuttles from stage to screen.
description: blue eyes, has done it again. Two scenes - not even very long ones - as Glenda Jackson's mother in ''Rose,'' and theater critics are hurling themselves at her feet, calling her ''that most ravishing actress'' and ''the most plausible reason'' to see the play.

title: 2 Conventions Remember Old Rock and the Comics
description: Those with a penchant for rock-and-roll memorabilia or vintage comic books can add to their collections this weekend at conventions in the New York Statler Hotel, Seventh Avenue at 33d Street.

title: REPUBLICANS CALL TAX BILL INSUFFICIENT
description: The White House and the senior Republican tax writer in the Senate, Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, gave qualified praise today to a one-year tax relief bill proposed by Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee.

title: LORD RUSSELL, WROTE 'SCOURGE OF SWASTIKA,' ANTI-NAZI BOOK, IN '54
description: Lord Russell of Liverpool, a former British military jurist who resigned his legal post in 1954 amid a controversy over a book he wrote on German war crimes, died here today. He would have been 86 years old on Saturday.

title: YANKEES AND METS START THE SEASON WITH VICTORIES
description: Dave Winfield, beginning his New York career, gave the largest opening-day crowd in Yankee Stadium's 59-year history some reasons to cheer yesterday. But it was Bobby Murcer, a 34-year-old outfielder fighting to prolong his career, who got the most enthusiastic reception - first when he emerged from the dugout to pinch-hit in the seventh inning, then a minute later when he hit a grand-slam that sealed a 10-3 Yankee victory.

title: PERES SAYS EBAN IS HIS CHOICE FOR FOREIGN MINISTER
description: Shimon Peres, chairman of the opposition Labor Party, said today that he would name Abba Eban as Foreign Minister and Haim Bar Lev, a retired general, as Defense Minister if his party won the June 30 elections.

title: Ambush Reported in Guatemala
description: Leftist guerrillas said today that they had killed 34 soldiers and wounded several others in an ambush of a military truck in western Guatemala. The Government declined to comment. The Organization of People in Arms, in a statement sent to newspapers here, said the attack took place last Friday on the Pan American Highway 61 miles west of the capital.

title: WORKERS' RIGHTS AND THE PUBLIC INTEREST IN LABOR ELECTIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: The Evening Hours
description: W HAT are the New York Yankees like when they step out of their pinstripes and go to a party? Well, there were some clues Wednesday night at a cocktail reception that preceded the annual ''New York Welcomes the Yankees'' dinner at the New York Hilton, the proceeds of which went to charity.

title: REAGAN TEAM SLOW IN FILLING 43 ENVOY POSTS
description: The Reagan Administration, now almost three months old, is moving slowly to fill an unusually large number of vacancies in ambassadorial posts.

title: S.E.C. Revokes Adviser Registration
description: In an administrative proceeding, the Securities and Exchange Commission today revoked the registration of a Texas-based investment adviser, National Counselor Reports Inc. and its owner, David Magee, for violating antifraud provisions of the Federal securities laws.

title: News Analysis
description: In a series of speeches and statements this week, Democratic leaders have been trying to set forth a new political identity for their party, themes that could guide them through the budget and tax battles of this year, and the Congressional elections of next year.

title: Accounts
description: * The Chubb Group of Insurance Companies to Herman Associates for the United States and Canada.

title: FUTURE PROSPERITY OF OFFTRACK BETTING QUESTIONED
description: New York City's Offtrack Betting Corporation opened for business with its first $2 bet 10 years ago this week. Since then more than $7 billion has been wagered with the OTB, but city officials and racing experts say that without major changes its most prosperous days may be over.

title: Bridge: A Select Group of Winners Joined by New York Player
description: Only a handful of players in the history of the game have won three major national titles within a space of five months. Those who have achieved this feat have normally done so by capturing two or three team championships.

title: 102 New Products Introduced in March
description: The New Product News published by Dancer Fitzgerald Sample reports that 102 new products were introduced in March, compared with 78 in February.

title: The Region; Boy, 8, Survives Ride On Outside of Train
description: TRENTON (AP) - An 8-year-old Jersey City boy survived a a 48-mile ride on the outside of a locomotive at speeds of up to 110 miles an hour, Amtrak officials said.

title: Jewels fit for an empress
description: AN extraordinary 18th-century emerald necklace, which may have once adorned Napoleon's Josephine, is among the hundreds of glittering gems that will be offered next week at Sotheby Parke Bernet's Madison Avenue galleries, at 76th Street, and at Christie's, Park Avenue and 59th Street. The gaveling begins next Tuesday at 10:15 A.M. at Sotheby's with two auctions - the first single-owner sale of jewelry at this house in five years - to be followed immediately by four sessions of diamonds, rubies, emeralds, sapphires and other gems from different owners.

title: Bendix Asks F.T.C.  About Divestiture
description: The Bendix Corporation asked the Federal Trade Commission for approval of its proposed divestiture of a subsidiary's rotating-toolholder business, the F.T.C. said.

title: Times Retail Ad Director
description: The New York Times has named Erich G. Linker Jr. as director of retail advertising. Mr. Linker, who joined The Times in 1977, had been advertising manager for national and retail accounts.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDEFriday; SALIERI MEETS MOZART
description: Antonio Salieri, the 18th-century composer, has been having a rough time on Broadway competing with Mozart in ''Amadeus,'' but he'll finally get a hearing tonight at 8, when the St. Cecilia Chorus and Orchestra, directed by David Randolph, presents the American premiere of his Mass No. 1 in D major in Carnegie Hall. Mozart will be represented, too - his ''Great'' Mass in C minor (K. 427) and his ''Regina Coeli'' (K. 276) are on the program. Tickets are $4 to $11. Carnegie Charge: 247-7459. WESTCHESTER DANCE SATIRE

title: Economic Scene; Game Theory On G.O.P. Plan
description: ONE of the greatest intellectual achievements of the 20th century is game theory, developed by the mathematician John von Neumann in 1928 and extended to economics by Dr. von Neumann and the economist Oskar Morgenstern in their classic, ''The Theory of Games and Economic Behavior'' (1944).

title: TEXT OF MESSAGE TO ASTRONAUTS
description: Following is the text of a message from President Reagan to John W. Young and Capt. Robert L. Crippen of the Navy, the astronauts of the spaceship Columbia:

title: STAGE: 'MARCH OF FALSETTOS, ' A MUSICAL FIND
description: WHEN the best two musicals of the season (''The Pirates of Penzance,'' ''Sophisticated Ladies'') are both the work of dead songwriters, you know that the American musical theater is in trouble. Indeed, I can't even remember the last time I attended a musical - on Broadway or off - that introduced a new composer or lyricist of serious promise. And that's why I had trouble believing my ears at a new show with the unlikely title of ''March of the Falsettos.'' This one-hour, musical, which is now running in the small upstairs space at Playwrights Horizons, tells its story through 20 songs by William Finn. The songs are so fresh that the show is only a few bars old before one feels the unmistakable, revivifying charge of pure talent.

title: HEINZ HOLLIGER REFUTES THESIS THAT THE OBOE IS AN ILL WIND
description: If the oboe ever manages to rival the flute as a popular solo instrument, Heinz Holliger will probably be reagrded as the musician who started it all. The 41-year-old Swiss oboist, in New York for a recital at the Metropolitan Museum of Art tomorrow night at 8, has been acclaimed all over the world for his virtuosity and compelling musicianship on this cinderella of instruments. His many recordings, mostly on the Philips label, explore every corner of the oboe's Baroque repertory, while more than 60 composers have dedicated new works to him.

title: JERSEY CAR INSURERS ORDERED TO END 'SOCIAL' RATE SYSTEM
description: New Jersey's Commissioner of Insurance ordered insurance companies today to stop using age, sex, marital status and scholastic standing as factors in computing auto insurance rates.

title: Palace Theater Performer Injured By Object Falling From the Roof
description: A 44-year-old performer at the Palace Theater was slightly injured at 8:30 P.M. last night when a cinder block fell or was thrown from the top of the Broadway theater and struck him on the head, the police said.

title: WINNER OF AN OSCAR FOR 'SKIPPY'
description: Norman Taurog, the film director who won an Academy Award for ''Skippy,'' died yesterday at Eisenhower Medical Center, near his retirement home in Palm Desert. He was 82 years old.

title: FRIDAY, APRIL 10, 1981; The Economy
description: The Justice Department will press its suit against Bell, the new antitrust chief pledged, despite Defense Department requests that the suit be dropped on grounds that A.T.& T.'s communications net is vital to national defense. Rejecting a settlement with A.T.& T. that the Carter Administration had negotiated, William F. Baxter vowed to ''litigate it to the eyeballs.'' His strong stand may portend a dramatic clash within the Administration. (Page A1.)

title: Stockman Defends Slash in Aid For Home Heating for the Elderly
description: President Reagan's proposed reduction of $500 million in Federal assistance for home heating costs of the elderly was defended today by David A. Stockman, director of the Office of Management and Budget.

title: 'An Artful Package'
description: Even David Stockman called it ''a very artful package.'' More than that, the 1982 budget proposed by the House Budget Committee Chairman, Jim Jones of Oklahoma, is the first effective Democratic counterattack on the Reagan Administration's controversial economics.

title: WHEELCHAIR DOESN'T GET IN THE WAY OF HER SINGING
description: WESLIA WHITFIELD, who has sung with the San Francisco Opera Company, the San Francisco Cathedral Choir and in cabarets and musical shows, has always preferred to do her nightclub performances sitting down because, she said, ''you don't have to worry about where your feet are.''

title: Topics; INHUMANITY JUSTICE; End of an Era
description: Abbie Hoffman used to be the master of the media event, turning adversity to advantage by going outra-geously public. It worked in his salad days, the glory days of the counterculture.

title: SHUTTLE TEAM SET TO ORBIT EARTH IN HISTORIC TEST
description: The world's first reusable spaceship, the Columbia, was reported ready early today to embark on its maiden voyage in earth orbit, a test flight culminating a development program that has cost almost $10 billion over the last decade.

title: ART: HENRY GLINTENKAMP, STUDENT OF ROBERT HENRI
description: PAINTINGS and drawings by Henry Glintenkamp make up the latest in a series of revivals at the Graham Gallery (1014 Madison Avenue at East 78th Street). Glintenkamp, who died in 1946 at the age of 58, was a student of Robert Henri from 1906 to 1908, which places him at the very heart of the New York scene of those days.

title: The Region
description: PLEASE USE White Plains Settles Police Hiring Suit
