title: GAUGING THE BURNETT LIBEL SUIT AWARD
description: To the Editor:

title: Federal Judge Rejects Motions On Acquittal of Arizona Rancher
description: A Federal district judge today denied motions to acquit or grant a new trial to Patrick W. Hanigan, convicted of obstructing interstate commerce by torturing and robbing three illegal aliens nearly five years ago.

title: DODGERS PLACE STANHOUSE, RELIEVER, ON ASSIGNMENT
description: LOS ANGELES, April 9 (UPI) The Los Angeles Dodgers placed the relief pitcher Don Stanhjouse on assignment last night, sent Rudy Law and Jack Perconte to the minors and put the pitcher Joe Beckwith on the 21 day disabled list

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, APRIL 10, 1981
description: International An inquiry by the Polish prosecutor against Piotr Jaroszewicz, a former Prime Minister, is under way, and a similar case may be prepared against Edward Gierek, the former Communist Party leader, according to a Warsaw newspaper. No specific charges were mentioned, but many party members have demanded a trial for what they regard as Mr. Jaroszewicz's mismanagement of the nation's economy. (Page A1, Column 5.) Bonn stepped up criticism of Moscow. Chancellor Helmut Schmidt said that the Soviet Union's military and political expansionism and its buildup of missiles represented ''a massive'' danger and constituted a potential source of blackmail. (A7:1-3.)

title: NEWSPAPER UNIONS ACT TO INTENSIFY TALKS AS PUBLISHERS VOICE OPTIMISM
description: Leaders of New York City's newspaper unions said yesterday that they planned to intensify their efforts next week to negotiate new agreements with The Daily News and The New York Times that would avert a possible strike.

title: G.& W. Lifts Stake In Collins & Aikman
description: Gulf and Western Industries Inc. announced it had increased its stake in the Collins & Aikman Corporation and sold all of its holdings in the Salant Corporation, a diversified apparel manufacturer.

title: BRITAIN'S SOCIAL DEMOCRATS
description: Several developments in Britain have compelled former members of the Labor Party like myself to join the new Social Democratic Party. The extreme monetarist dogma of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher is threatening to polarize politics more dangerously, precipitating left-wing demands for more nationalization and protection. The labor unions are exerting more control over the Labor Party, while Trotskyists and left-wing activists are infiltrating the parties at the local level.

title: LEBANESE CONFLICT RAGES ON TWO FRONTS
description: Violence in Lebanon increased today as Syrian and Lebanese Christian artillerymen exchanged intense fire around the eastern town of Zahle and Israel staged an air and ground attack on Palestinian guerrilla positions in the south.

title: WITNESS CALLS MINING STOCK IN WILLIAMS CASE WORTHLESS
description: An accountant called as a witness in the bribery trial of Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. said yesterday that stocks the Senator allegedly accepted in a titanium-mining venture were worthless.

title: News Summary; SATURDAY, APRIL 11, 1981
description: International Poland's Prime Minister will resign, he said, if Parliament does not adopt a law he has requested to suspend strikes for the next two months. In a tough and despondent nationally televised address to Parliament, Prime Minister Wojciech Jaruzelski said the strike ban was necessary because of the country's political upheaval and its poor economic situation. A strike suspension would ''bring social peace and douse the flames of new conflicts,'' he said. (Page 1, Column 1.) A leader of the Irish Republican Army who is serving a 14-year prison sentence in Northern Ireland for firearms violations was elected to the British Parliament. Robert Sands, a 27-year-old Catholic, defeated Harold West, a 63-year-old Protestant Unionist, in a by-election in a largely Catholic rural district in Northern Ireland that includes County Fermanagh and part of County Tyrone. Mr. Sands, on a hunger strike to enforce demands for status as a political prisoner, is in a prison hospital ward. (1:1.)

title: PRICING BY ITEM AT ISSUE; WASHINGTON
description: L AST week, Giant Food Inc., a supermarket chain in Washington, Maryland and Virginia, provoked a stir among consumers when it announced that it would no longer mark prices on individual grocery items.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Dome Petroleum directors approved a 5-for-1 stock split, subject to approval at a shareholder meeting May 8.

title: OBJECTS HURLED FROM ROOFS IN 4 ASSAULTS ON 47TH ST., POLICE SAY
description: An assault on a Broadway actor who was hit on the head by a heavy concrete block apparently thrown from a roof has been linked by the police to three similar incidents last year on the south side of West 47th Street.

title: Gould Symphony Salute's Artist's 'Visual Music'
description: Houurs before the Cleveland Orchestra, directed by Lorin Maazel, was to perform the premiere of a new symphonic work by Morton Gould Thursday night, the composer talked about how he went about his work.

title: U.S. SPEEDS OIL LEASING OFFSHORE
description: The Reagan Administration today outlined a plan to step up substantially the pace at which the Government leases offshore oil and gas properties.

title: FORD SAYS IT REJECTED CHRYSLER TIE
description: The Ford Motor Company said today that it had rejected a proposal to merge with the Chrysler Corporation, a course of action that some Government officials and others consider necessary to insure Chrysler's long-term survival.

title: Ricardo Mestres, Official
description: Of Princeton University

title: Mortgage Rate 14.5% at F.H.A.
description: The ceiling on interest rates for Government-backed, fixed-rate home loans will be raised to a record 14.5 percent on Monday, Federal officials said today.

title: William Yates, Real-Estate Agent And Bank Official in Westchester
description: William J. Yates, a Westchester County real-estate agent who sold large tracts to many major corporations, died Wednesday at the Phelps Memorial Hospital Center in North Tarrytown, N.Y. He was 87 years old and lived in Ossining.

title: OPERA: JANACEK'S 'VIXEN WITH DESIGN BY SENDAK
description: What might any opera company be expected to make of a work that alternately suggests Aesop, ''L'Enfant et les Sortileges,'' Disney, Orwell's ''Animal Farm,'' ''Lulu,'' Mother Goose, ''Die Meistersinger'' and Pogo? What, indeed, but one of the season's most charming and affecting evenings in the musical theater. The foregoing improbable catalogue rather fairly circumscribes Leos Janacek's ''The Cunning Little Vixen,'' which the New York City Opera presented Thursday night in a new production whose sets and costumes were realized from designs by the children's book illustrator Maurice Sendak.

title: B.P. Denies Reports Of Kuwait Oil Cutoff
description: The British Petroleum Company denied news reports that Kuwait had cut off its crude shipments because of a pricing dispute and said the company was still buying oil from the OPEC nation.

title: THE CITY IS RUNNING OUT OF TIME
description: To the Editor:

title: DANES KEEP WARY EYE ON SOVIET-BLOC SHIPS IN BALTIC
description: Capt. Erling H. Jensen peers across the misty Baltic Sea through a pair of battered gray binoculars, then quietly gives the orders in Danish. The hunter has spotted his quarry.

title: Padres 4, Giants 2
description: SAN FRANCISCO (AP) - San Diego was held hitless through five innings but rallied for the victory, helped by a tie-breaking, pinchhit single by Dave Edwards in the eighth inning.

title: DeLorean's Riding High
description: In what is believed to be the most expensive residential realestate deal ever made in New Jersey, John Z. DeLorean, the independent automobile manufacturer, has bought a 430-acre estate in Bedminster, N.J., from the John Cowperthwaite family for $3.5 million.

title: International Paper Cites 1981 Outlay
description: The International Paper Company said it plans capital spending of about $900 million for 1981, about the same as in 1980, and a total of $1.1 billion for 1982 and 1983.

title: A.T.&T. FILES DETAILS ON HIGHER RATES
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company today filed with the Federal Communications Commission new phone rates it hopes to charge for long-distance calls. The changes, which would generally raise the rates 16 percent, follow the commission's authorization Monday of new profit margins for the company.

title: REAGAN'S RETURN TO WHITE HOUSE EXPECTED TODAY
description: President Reagan's doctors announced today that he would probably leave the hospital for the White House tomorrow but that he probably would not have the stamina to return to work in the Oval Office for another week.

title: Biggs Plans to Appeal Extradition To Britain for Great Train Robbery
description: Ronald Biggs, the fugitive British train robber, will fight an extradition order granted by a Barbados court, his lawyers said today.

title: MARONITES' DILEMMA ON PALM SUNDAY
description: To the Editor:

title: Shearson Loeb Net Up 41.2% in Period
description: Shearson Loeb Rhoades Inc., benefiting from its diversification, reported yesterday that earnings in the third fiscal quarter, ended March 31, rose 41.2 percent, to $27.4 milllion, or $1.75 a share, from $19.4 million, or $1.55 a share, in the similar 1980 period.

title: NASA OFFICIALS WERE APPREHENSIVE ABOUT POSSIBILITY OF A COMPUTER LAPSE
description: The possibility of an error in the space shuttle's computer programs had long been a fear of both NASA officials and independent scientists. Such an error apparently cropped up yesterday, and the shuttle's launching was delayed for at least two days.

title: EUROPEANS REPORT ADVANCE IN ANTIMATTER EXPERIMENTS
description: The first collisions between beams of normal protons and their antimatter twins have been achieved by the European Center for Nuclear Research, a 12-nation research organization near Geneva, according to news reports yesterday.

title: MISS SHRIVER ADVANCES
description: Patience has its rewards on clay courts, Pam Shriver learned again today in scoring a 6-2, 6-4 victory over Pam Casale in the quarterfinals of the $150,000 Family Circle Cup tennis tournament.

title: THE REGION;
description: NEWARK (UPI) - Governor Byrne signed legislation allowing the New Jersey Transit Corporation to spend $10 million for the rehabilitation of state-owned buses.

title: American Financial
description: The American Financial Corporation, a diversified financial concern that recently went private, said it had raised its interest in the Gulf United Corporation to 22.9 percent by purchasing 665,000 Gulf United shares in the last two months for about $15.3 million. American Financial said it had acquired the interest in Gulf United as an investment but, because of the size of its investment, ''it might be in a position to influence Gulf United.'' Under a December 1979 agreement, American Financial has a right to acquire up to 24 percent of Gulf United, an insurance holding company.

title: CONKAREE CONKAREE CONKAREE
description: On a nippy dawn not long ago, I gathered up my maul and wedges, and walked down the field behind our small farm to the place beside the river where the maple tree lay. I had felled it the day before and cut it up into stove-length sections. Now, as the sun inched up behind the bare-branched trees like an orange balloon, I began to split the wood and stack the gleaming white slabs. The whack of my hammer rang out sharply. The maple smelled sour when it split but the brisk west wind blowing across the river was fresh and clean and full of the promise of spring.

title: JUDGE IN COPLON SPY TRIAL
description: Sylvester J. Ryan, who as a Federal judge presided over some of New York's biggest cases, died yesterday at the Mary Manning Walsh Home in Manhattan, where he had been confined for several years because of ill health. He was 84 years old.

title: HAIG AND CARRINGTON DIFFER ON THE MIDEAST
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. and Lord Carrington, the British Foreign Secretary, disagreed today on the priorities that should be given efforts to seek both peace and security in the Middle East, British and American officials said.

title: GARBAGE TRUCKS FOUND TO HAVE ADDED PROBLEMS
description: Two days after troubles were disclosed with its two-man trucks, New York City's Sanitation Department said yesterday that another new truck introduced a few months ago also could not carry nearly so much garbage as it was supposed to because of mechanical problems.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL CLEVELAND (AL) - Placed Ross Grimsley, pitcher, on 21-day disabled list with rib injury.; COLLEGES MICHIGAN TECH - Named Ron Marciel head football coach.; FOOTBALL NEW ORLEANS (NFC) - Signed Jerry Copeny and Rickie Williams, running backs.
description: SEATTLE (AFC) - Signed John Sawyer, t ight end. SOCCER COSMOS (MISL) - Signed Angelo DiBer- nardo, midfielder, and Bob Iarusci, defend- er, to three-year contracts.

title: Comedy by Tally to Continue
description: 'Coming Attractions,' the comedy by Ted Tally that had announced it would close this weekend, won a reprieve as business improved. The play, directed by Andrew Ernotte.

title: Miss Caulkins Excels
description: Another day, another swim, and Tracy Caulkins made history tonight. For the third time in three nights, the 18-year-old prep-school senior from Nashville won a title in the national short-course swimming championships and broke an American record.

title: Eleanor M. Montgomery Wed To Dr. N.O. Atuk, Professor
description: Mrs. Eleanor Morgan Montgomery of Charlottesville, Va., Savannah and Atlanta, was married in New York yesterday to Dr. Nuzhet O. Atuk, professor of internal medicine at the University of Virginia School of Medicine.

title: ISLANDERS DETERMINED TO PROVE THEIR QUALITY
description: The Islanders, the defending Stanley Cup champions, are seeking both a sweep and respect in tonight's third game of their National Hockey League playoff series with the Toronto Maple Leafs.

title: SATURDAY, APRIL 11, 1981; The Economy
description: The Federal Reserve reported a $3.2 billion increase in the money supply, causing prices to fall sharply in the bond and money markets. Adding to the pressure on interest rates, Chase Manhattan and Manufacturers Hanover Trust raised their prime rates to 17 1/2 percent from 17 percent. Some economists foresaw further rises of one to one-and-a-half percentage points and predicted the Federal Reserve would tighten credit. (Page 29.)

title: Marathon Wins Wheelchair Ban
description: The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court ruled Thursday that wheelchair-bound competitors need not be admitted to the New York City Marathon.

title: WE ALL STARTED LOW
description: To the Editor:

title: Mets' Swan To Return On Monday
description: The Mets moved today to recover their No. 1 pitcher when they ordered Craig Swan to leave Florida on Sunday and rejoin the team Monday in Shea Stadium.

title: Connecticut Permits More Sulfur in Oil
description: Connecticut utilities will be allowed to burn oil containing 1 percent sulfur instead of the current 0.5 percent, the State Department of Environmental Protection announced.

title: INSURANCE GAIN FOR NONSMOKER
description: EIGHTEEN months after a landmark study on the life expectancy of cigarette smokers and nonsmokers, the rush to offer discounts for nonsmokers in newly issued life insurance policies is gaining momentum.

title: NEW YORK'S HEALTH SYSTEM NEEDS MAJOR ORGANIZATIONAL SURGERY
description: To the Editor:

title:
PATENTS;
Self-Contained System To Cool Outboard Motors
description: A new cooling system for outboard motors is designed to avoid damage said to be caused to motors by the use of water through which the boat is passing.

title: Lend Me Your Romans
description: How would you like to be the ABC television network if Julius Caesar were still around, friends? Or maybe you didn't see ''Masada,'' the eight-hour opus that ABC televised for four consecutive nights this week.

title: DAWKINS HELPS 76ERS TO 2-1 LEAD IN SERIES
description: Darryl Dawkins's mood after a game depends not only on whether the Philadelphia 76ers won or lost, but also how he played the game. In victory he has named his repertoire of dunk shots. But he has been known to sulk in victory and defeat.

title: 'GATEWAY IS MY CHILDREN'S YOSEMITE'
description: To the Editor:

title: Flight From Law and Honor
description: Precisely because it is legally difficult and politically hazardous, enforcement of the Federal laws against discrimination in education belongs to the Federal Government. In this area, above all, the Reagan Administration's decentralizing urge goes too far.

title: 5th Body Found at Grain Elevator
description: The death toll rose to five today from Tuesday's explosion at a grain elevator. Searchers found the body of Gilbert Garcia, 19 years old, in a ship channel that serves the Corpus Christi Public Grain Elevator. One man remains missing.

title: NEW HEARING IS ORDERED ON 'FROZEN' IRAN ASSETS
description: A Federal appeals court decided yesterday to require a new court hearing to consider the constitutionality of financial conditions negotiated by the Carter Administration in the agreement that freed the American hostages in Iran.

title: THE TRADITIONAL HAIRCUT AT AN OLD-FASHIONED PRICE
description: It is not news to men who want a plain ordinary 1950's haircut, but it may be to those who have their hair styled: A professionally administered haircut is still available at a number of Manhattan barbershops for $2 to $3.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Campeau Corp. said it had agreed to sell its Harbor Castle Hotel, in Toronto, for $95 million.

title: HDLFATE OF SCENIC UPSTATE LAKE RESORT HINGES ON A JUDGE'S OPINION
description: After hearing eight months of argument, an administrative law judge is deciding the future of Lake Minnewaska, one of New York State's scenic treasures and the site, for nearly a century, of two grand, old mountain-house hotels.

title: THE CARE REAGAN WAS GIVEN
description: A major reason behind the successful treatment of President Reagan's gunshot wound was that the medical care he received at The George Washington University Medical Center was routine. This is remarkable since the incident was extraordinary.

title: YUGOSLAVS DOUBT AN INVASION OF POLAND
description: Senior Yugoslav officials believe that if the Soviet Union felt a need to intervene militarily in Poland it would have done so much earlier.

title: Rotten Oranges, Crude Pricing
description: The scene evokes memories of the Great Depression: tens of millions of navel oranges rotting in the sun, abandoned so that growers can get a higher price for the fruit they do send to market.

title: U.S. Hears Police Version Of 23 Salvadoran Killings
description: Salvadoran officials have told the State Department that 23 people killed earlier this week in a San Salvador suburb died in an hourlong firefight between leftist guerrillas and the Government police, a department official said today.

title: FORMER HOSTAGE SAYS HIS FILMED CONFESSION WAS FAKED BY CAPTORS
description: Staff Sgt. Joseph Subic Jr., in his first substantive interview since he was freed as a hostage, has said that Iranian films released last April in which he allegedly confessed to spying were ''faked.''

title: Berbick's Ring PoiseCame the Hard Way
description: Unless Larry Holmes should happen to show up in a Marine uniform at the Caesars Palace Sports Pavilion tomorrow night, he will be the overwhelming favorite to retain the World Boxing Council's heavyweight title against Trevor Berbick.

title: U.S., AT MADRID PARLEY, DEMANDS STRONG RIGHTS STAND
description: The Madrid conference on security and cooperation in Europe started a three-week Easter break today after a strong warning from the United States that the contentious issue of human rights would have to be included in a final document.

title: RANGERS AND KINGS FINALLY COOLING OFF
description: Both the Rangers and the Los Angeles Kings were expecting no recurrence of Thursday night's brawling when their playoff series resumes at Madison Square Garden tonight.

title: Tyler to Acquire Reliance Universal
description: The Tyler Corporation said it had agreed to acquire Reliance Universal Inc., a leading maker of specialty chemical coatings, through a tender offer at $37 a share. Based on Reliance's 1.95 million shares outstanding, the indicated value of the transaction is about $72 million.

title: ARCHITECTURE: ASIA SOCIETY BUILDING, A DESIGN FULL OF CIVILIZED
description: INTENTIONS By PAUL GOLDBERGER

title: MONEY SUPPLY UP $3.2 BILLION
description: The Federal Reserve yesterday reported a $3.2 billion spurt in the money supply, reinforcing an upward movement in interest rates that began last week.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 47. 1. The Reagan Administration is sending military leaders to a foreign country, despite a Congressional ban on military assistance to that nation, imposed because of human rights abuses. What country is it?

title: THRONGS ARE FRUSTRATED BY LIFTOFF POSTPONMENT
description: Frank Briolat fought traffic jams miles long and competed with a half-million other people for a chance to witness the launching of the spaceship Columbia.

title: YANKEES STILL PONDER IDENTITY OF 5TH STARTER
description: It is six months and two interleague trading periods since the Yankees decided they needed a couple of right-handed starting pitchers. They found one they had not figured on in spring training, but the season has started and they are still debating their options for the other.

title: Appellate Court in Italy Upholds Sentences of 4 in Red Brigades
description: An appeals court today upheld the sentences of a founder of the Red Brigades leftist guerrilla group and three followers who helped him escape from prison in 1975.

title: NEW YORK BANKS IN COAST BID
description: New York's biggest banks, including Citibank and Chase Manhattan, have been particularly visible in California in the past few weeks. Over lavish dinners and cocktails and in meetings with California businessmen, they have expressed the hope that they will soon have full-service banks in the growing California market.

title: Fisk's 3-Run Homer Helps Beat Red Sox
description: Carlton Fisk, the former Boston catcher, hit a three-run homer in the eighth inning today to lead the Chicago White Sox to a 5-3 victory over the Red Sox in their American League opener.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Washington Watch column in Business Day on Monday identified Herve de Carmoy with the wrong bank. He is general manager of the Midland Bank of Britain.

title: Board Faults Ship's Pilot In Tampa Bay Accident
description: A freighter pilot's decision to attempt to cross under a bridge in Tampa Bay after his ship lost navigational references in a storm led to the accident in which 35 persons were killed, investigators said today.

title: Top Chinese Leaders Make A Rare Joint Appearance
description: In an apparent show of unity, the Communist Party chairman, Hua Guofeng, appeared in public today with the deputy chairman, Deng Xiaoping, for the first time in almost five months.

title: Mount St. Helens Erupts, Sending Ash to 15,500 Feet
description: Mount St. Helens erupted today, propelling a plume of light steam and ash 15,500 feet above sea level before subsiding. Scientists for the United States Geological Survey said seismic vibrations were continuing beneath the volcano.

title: DISEASE CAN'T WAIT FOR A CURE
description: To the Editor:

title: CAREY GATHERS SUPPORT ON MEDICAID AS DEADLOCK CONTINUES
description: Governor Carey announced an agreement today with four county executives on a revised program to have the state assume local Medicaid costs over the next seven years.

title: EMPLOYEE WELFARE FUNDS ARE PRIVATE
description: To the Editor:

title: Censored in Israel
description: ''The Battle for Peace,'' a book by Ezer Weizman, former Israeli Minister of Defense in Prime Minister Menachen Begin's Government, has run into censorship difficulties. Censored sections of the book, which is Mr. Weizman's account of the Israeli-Egyptian peace negotiations, were published this week in The Jerusalem Post. ,

title: Record $1.2 Million Paid For 'Wild Men' Tapestry
description: A medieval tapestry woven in northern Switzerland was sold at auction today to a Swiss museum for $1.2 million, more than four times the previous record price for a tapestry.

title: U.S. Plans to Sell Turks 15 F-4 Jets With Spares
description: The Pentagon has notified Congress that it plans to sell Turkey 15 F-4E jets, along with spare parts and support equipment, for about $78 million, officials said today.

title: Cable-TV Network Plans Italian-Produced Fare
description: A commercial cable-television network devoted solely to Italianproduced programs will begin operating throughout the United States on May 2.

title: Bridge: Weird Hands Usually Mean Wild Bidding and Dull Play
description: Most players go through a lifetime without ever picking up a hand with 9-4-0-0 distribution, which they can expect 10 times in a million deals.

title: JAPANESE SHIP SINKS IN COLLISION WITH U.S. ATOM SUB
description: A Japanese freighter and an American nuclear-powered submarine running just below the surface collided yesterday in the East China Sea. The cargo ship sank.

title: Books of The Times
description: Doorknobs to Tragedies By ANATOLE BROYARD PLEASURE AND PRIVILEGE: LIFE IN FRANCE, NAPLES AND AMERICA, 1770-90. By Olivier Bernier. Foreword by Louis Auchincloss. Illustrated. 290 pages. Doubleday. $14.95.

title: 100 Green Berets in Liberia For Joint Training Exercises
description: About 100 members of the United States Special Forces, known as the Green Berets, arrived in Liberia today for joint military exercises with the Liberian army.

title:
PATENTS;
INVENTOR'S EXPOSITION SET IN MAY
description: WASHINGTON MORE than 175 American and foreign inventors will display and explain their creations at the Fifth Annual International Inventor's Exposition, to be held at the New York Statler Hilton Hotel from May 14 through May 17.

title: News Analysis
description: The conflict between ideological purists and those who bear the responsibility for moving legislation through Congress was demonstrated anew last night when three Republican Senators helped to sidetrack an austere budget proposed by a Republican President.

title: U.S. PROSECUTOR FINDS NO CRIME IN GIBSON TAXES
description: The Justice Department has notified Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson of Newark that it is closing its investigation into whether he violated income-tax laws and has decided not to bring criminal charges against him.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Our backs are against the wall. We have to get out of this.

title: Gains Seen In Talks on Polish Debt
description: United States and other Western creditor governments have made ''good progress'' in talks with Polish officials in Paris on the refinancing of Poland's heavy foreign debt, State Department officials said here today.

title: I.B.M. Up by 7.1% in Quarter; Increase Below Expectations
description: The International Business Machines Corporation reported yesterday that its net income rose by 7.1 percent in 1981's first quarter, an increase that analysts described as less than expected.

title: TWO CLOWNS AS 'PRIVATE EYES'
description: Tim Conway and Don Knotts wear the same clothes throughout ''The Private Eyes,'' the new film that opened at Cinerama and other theaters yesterday, and no matter what the publicity release says (it says the movie took two months to shoot), I think that Mr. Conway and Mr. Knotts started work after breakfast, broke for lunch and had the movie in the can in time for dinner. ''The Private Eyes'' wastes two good clowns.

title: BELEAGUERED BOSTON CLOSES 10 FIRE AND POLICE STATIONS
description: Boston closed 13 fire companies and all of its neighborhood police substations today as efforts to solve the city's two separate but equally complex financial crises made headway in the courts, the City Council and the State Legislature.

title: BALLOONS FLOWER IN THE GLOW OF SPRING
description: in Just-spring when the world is mud-luscious the little lame balloonman whistles far and wee

title: Inquiry Is Reported Into Big 8 Basketball
description: A Federal investigation into the possibility that at least two Big Eight Conference basketball games were fixed late this season is under way in Kansas City, according to sources familiar with the inquiry.

title: POLISH PARLIMENT VOTES A STRIKE BAN TO LAST TWO MONTHS
description: Acting after Prime Minister Wojciech Jaruzelski threatened to resign if it did not move to prevent new strikes, the Polish Parliament approved a resolution tonight for a two-month suspension of strikes and threats to strike.

title: COMPUTER PROBLEM WILL DELAY SHUTTLE AT LEAST TWO DAYS
description: A mysterious computer breakdown caused postponement of the launching of the space shuttle Columbia today, and space agency officials pressed to reschedule it for Sunday morning.

title: Sun Debentures Sold In Becton Accord
description: The Sun Company said it had successfully sold, for $389.1 million, 25-year subordinated debentures exchangeable into Becton, Dickinson and Company stock.

title: HECLA REVIVES OFFER TO BUY DAY MINES
description: The Hecla Mining Company today again offered to acquire Day Mines Inc. through a $156 million stock swap in which Day shareholders would get 1.65 shares of Hecla stock for each Day share they own. Hecla has been pursuing a takeover of Day Mines for weeks but has met a chilly reception.

title: RUDOLF SCHRAMM
description: Rudolf Schramm, composer, conductor and arranger, died last Monday in Westwood, N.J., at the age of 78, after a long illness. Former music director of the United States Office of Education and a cofounder of the National Symphony in Washington, Professor Schramm also taught rhythm training and songwriting for many years at New York University.

title: NASA BLAMES A TIMING FLAW IN INSTRUCTIONS
description: The space agency said tonight that it had identified the problem that had caused the computers aboard the space shuttle Columbia to refuse to ''talk to each other'' properly this morning. The computers balked just before the Columbia's scheduled launching, causing at least a two-day postponement of the spaceship's shakedown cruise.

title: OWENS-ILLINOIS AND OWENS-CORNING OFF
description: Owens-Illinois Inc., the country's largest producer of glass containers, reported yesterday that earnings in the first quarter of 1981 dropped 9.4 percent as sales improved by 2.7 percent.

title:
PATENTS;
Mimicking the Aroma Of Cocaine for Police Use
description: Law enforcement officers may want to familiarize themselves with the distinctive odors of narcotics. Patent 4,260,517, granted this week to Warren J. Woodford of Atlanta, offers a way to reproduce the aroma of cocaine, using readily available and noncontrolled substances.

title: Monthly Housing Completions Up
description: Privately owned housing units were completed in February at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.4 million units, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: VALVE IS BLAMED FOR WATER LEAK AT INDIAN POINT
description: An official of Consolidated Edison said today that it was a faulty check valve that had caused a small amount of radioactive water to drain into the Hudson River Wednesday from the company's Indian Point 2 nuclear plant.

title: DOW, UP 1.44 POINTS, PASSES 1,000 AGAIN
description: Stock prices edged higher in continued heavy trading yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average finished above the 1,000 mark for the first time this week. Mustering some strength in the final hour, the Dow closed at 1,000.27, up 1.44 points.

title: SAMUEL KALISH, SERVED IN EXECUTIVE POSITIONS IN COSMETICS INDUSTRY
description: Samuel Kalish, former president and chief executive officer of Max Factor & Company, died Thursday of cancer at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 53 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: E.P.A. SAYS IT WOULD NOW BACK EFFORT TO EXTEND DUMPING AT SEA
description: The Environmental Protection Agency said today that it was willing to endorse efforts by municipalities in New York and New Jersey to seek court permission to continue dumping sewage sludge at sea.

title: SOUTH BRONX RESIDENTS TRY TO CHANGE THE ODDS
description: In the mid-1970's, when many of their neighbors in the 1600 block of Vyse Avenue fled the approaching blight that had already ravaged much of the South Bronx, Samuel and Nerenaida Cruz Mereno stayed.

title: ESCAPED FELON IS CONVICTED OF MURDERING DR. HALBERSTAM, A NOTED WASHINGTON CARDIOLOGIST
description: Bernard C. Welch Jr., whom the authorities have described as ''a one-man crime cell'' specializing in burglary,, was convicted today of murdering Dr. Michael J. Halberstam, a noted cardiologist and author, while burglarizing the doctor's home last December.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: BROOKLYN BOUND

title: Vatican Weighing Risks of a Trip By Pope to Basque Region in Fall
description: Arrangements for a tour of Spain in October by Pope John Paul II are being delayed by uncertainty over whether he should risk a visit to the Basque country, Vatican sources said today.

title: ABC'S ARTS CABLE STARTS TOMORROW
description: ABC Inc. will introduce tomorrow the first full-time cabletelevision service devoted to the performing and visual arts. The Alpha Repertory Television Service, ARTS, will be sent by satellite between 9 P.M. and midnight each evening to three and a half million subscribers.

title: SOUTH AFRICA GIANT SHUNS LIMELIGHT
description: The Rupert Group may be South Africa's biggest multinational company and the world's fifth-largest tobacco concern, but it likes to keep a low profile. Even shareholders are privy to only the barest of corporate financial data.

title: Gutierrez Cancels Concert
description: Horacio Gutierrez, the pianist, has canceled his Carnegie Hall concert tomorrow night because of illness. Refunds can be obtained at the box office or at the place of purchase.

title: JERSEY UTILITY MOVES TO TAKE RATIONING VIOLATORS TO COURT
description: New Jersey's largest water utility initiated action today that could lead to the first court prosecutions in the state for violations of its six-and-a-halfmonth-old water-rationing plan.

title: Tax Cut Called Spending Spur
description: A study of 441 major corporations, released today, says that the Reagan Administration's proposed business tax cuts could produce an estimated $14.7 billion in corporate spending for capital improvements.

title: COUNCILMAN RICCIO GOES ON TRIAL IN LARCENY CASE
description: Councilman Vincent A. Riccio of New York City arranged state ''no show'' jobs for several people so he could use at least part of their salaries to continue to support a mistress, the prosecution charged today at the opening of the Brooklyn Conservative's trial today.

title: MORGAN SEEKS TO SET UP A BANK IN DELAWARE
description: J.P. Morgan & Company formally filed an application yesterday with the Delaware Bank Commissioner for permission to establish a new bank in Wilmington, Morgan announced.

title: JAILED I.R.A. MEMBER WINS COMMONS SEAT
description: In a stunning blow to the Protestant establishment in Northern Ireland, Robert Sands, an imprisoned member of the Irish Republican Army, has been elected to the British Parliament.

title: Kings, Rockets Take 2-1 Leads
description: Scott Wedman scored on a 10-foot shot with five seconds left and Kansas City defeated Phoenix, 93-92, tonight to take a 2-1 lead in their National Basketball Association Western Conference semifinal series.

title: CORPORATE REPORTS

title: Owens-Corning Fiberglas
description: The Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corporation, a leading producer of glass fiber products and other construction and industrial products, announced that net income in the first quarter fell 33.9 percent, to $12.5 million, or 41 cents a share, from $18.9 million, or 62 cents a share, in the first three months of 1980. Sales dropped 6.9 percent, to $539.5 million, from $579.3 million.

title: Noranda Wins Bid For Bloedel Stock
description: Noranda Mines Ltd. of Toronto has won the bidding war for Canada's largest forest products company, MacMillan Bloedel Ltd. of Vancouver, following the formal withdrawal of the British Columbia Resources Investment Corporation.

title: A Historic Compact Betrayed
description: Does the Reagan Administration consider the American heritage expendable? Its proposed reduction in the Historic Preservation Fund, from $35 million to $5 million, would not cut fat. It would cut out the heart of the national preservation program - and sever its lifeline by giving the token $5 million to the National Trust for Historic Preservation rather than to state preservation offices.

title: 2 in Store Wounded by Grenade, Ugandan Guerrilla Group Reports
description: A grenade injured two people in a major store in the capital's commercial area today, witnesses and a guerrilla group reported.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 17.00-17.50 ** Current rate excludes 3 percentage-point surcharge on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: NAP IN THE BROOKLYN HEIGHTS SUN
description: A mother and child on the promenade quietly enjoying yesterday's 70-degree temperature. Today may prove to be a different story - the metropolitan forecast calls for a chance of thunderstorms.

title: N.A.S.L. Alters Two Rules
description: The North American Soccer League reverted to the 35-yard line as its offside marker and restored its three-substitutions rule last night after the United States Soccer Federation received permission from F.I.F.A., the international federation.

title: The Budget Targets Last of eight articles on key pro- grams the President wants to cut.
description: The programs under the seven-year-old Comprehensive Employment and Training Act, like well-traveled suitcases, have acquired quite a collection of scratches, baggage tickets and unsightly bulges.

title: Cuban's Hijacking Attempt Fails and He Then Dies
description: A Cuban refugee grabbed a stewardess and started a fire in an attempt to hijack a jetliner to Havana today, but he was overpowered by an airline employee and a passenger and died minutes after the scuffle, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 16. 1. Argentina. 2. She steered Oxford to victory as the first woman coxswain in the 152-year-old Oxford-Cambridge regatta. 3.

title: Russian in Visa Case Says U.S. Stirs World Tensions
description: A Soviet journalist and author who was refused an extension of his visa to the United States so he could appear on an American television program charged today that the Reagan Administration was deliberately creating tension with the Soviet Union.

title: 2 NEWSPAPER UNIONS ABANDON MERGER DISCUSSIONS
description: The Newspaper Guild and the International Typographical Union, saying they could not resolve all their differences, broke off merger negotiations today after more than three years of formal talks.

title: INDSUSTRY ACCEPTS UNION BID TO RENEW COAL STRIKE TALKS
description: The chief negotiator for the soft-coal industry agreed tonight to resume negotiations with representatives of the United Mine Workers on a contract to end a strike by 160,000 miners.

title: Correction
description: An article last Monday incorrectly reported New York City's Hispanic population for 1970. The City Planning Commission says the correct figure is 1,202,281.

title: FRAZIER WINS EASILY AFTER 6-MONTH LAYOFF
description: Marvis Frazier, the first fighter in his family to make a comeback, returned to the ring last night, and the only pain in his neck, he was glad to learn, came from his opponent's holding and not his punches.

title: By Sports of The Times; Jack's Masterly 65
description: IN the locker room at the Augusta National Golf Club, the voice on the TV set was explaining that the space shot at Cape Canaveral had been delayed. Hubert Green smiled.

title: As a Seismologist, He's a Good Stock Analyst
description: When Joseph Granville, the Wall Street analyst, told the 3,000 subscribers to his Granville Market Letter to ''sell everything,'' they had enough faith in him to trigger the Dow Jones industrial Average into tumbling 23.8 points Jan. 8. It was the heaviest trading day in the history of the New York Stock Exchange.

title:
PATENTS;
Chin-Steering Mechanism For Motorized Wheelchair
description: The handicapped occupant of a motorized wheelchair can steer it and control its speed by chin movements, using a system that was patented this week by two staff members at the Johns Hopkins University Applied Physics Laboratory, Laurel, Md.

title: IN SOME QUESTIONS OF TASTE THE DISPUTES CAN BE FUN
description: Anyone who really believes that there is no disputing taste should take a look at the mail that comes into this department after almost every column headed ''De Gustibus.'' One look would show that there is indeed room for arguing over taste and that such arguments can be endlessly diverting, informative and rewarding.

title: SCHOOL BELLS RING AMID CRIES OF 'SCAB' IN OHIO TOWN
description: ''Look,'' the woman said hurriedly as she left the junior high school, ''they had the job and didn't want it. I can't say no to a chance to work. And they can afford to go on strike, that's their business - but they shouldn't blame me for having to go to work.''

title: Temperence Hill Wins
description: Temperence Hill took the lead on the final turn and scored a two-length victory in the $200,000-added Oaklawn Handicap at Oaklawn Park today. Ridden by Eddie Maple, Temperence Hill finished the mile-and-a-sixteenth event in 1:43 2/5.

title: U.S. GOOD WILL VISIT BRINGS TRAGEDY TO DOMINICANS
description: A series of student demonstrations set off by a good-will visit of two United States naval vessels and fueled by labor strife and charges of police brutality ended this week with four dead, dozens injured and several hundred arrested.

title: Bus Line in Jersey Is Hit by a Strike
description: Bus drivers and maintenance workers for the Short Line Bus Company, which serves 10,000 commuters daily in northern New Jersey, New York and Pennsylvania, went on strike last night at midnight.

title: Braves 5, Reds 3
description: ATLANTA (AP) - Chris Chambliss hit a two-run double, and Dale Murphy had a two-run homer as the Braves scored four times in the eighth inning and defeated Cincinnati before a crowd of 34,929. The Braves ended a streak of nine straight losses in their season openers.

title: WHERE THE TAXIS ARE
description: To the Editor:

title: Arum Testifies in Brenner Trial
description: Bob Arum, one of boxing's leading promoters, testified yesterday that he had received preferential treatment from the World Boxing Council for three years until the middle of 1978, when, he said, Don King became the W.B.C.'s favored promoter.

title: Busing Litigation Judge Removed in Los Angeles
description: The judge appointed Wednesday to hear the school desegregation case in Los Angeles was removed today because of his membership in the American Civil Liberties Union and the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

title: HARVARD WILL GIVE TENURE HEARING IN SEX BIAS CASE
description: Harvard University officials announced today that they would grant a tenure hearing to an associate professor of sociology who a university grievance committee concluded had been denied opportunity for tenure as a result of sex discrimination.

title: Djibouti's Leader Visits Somalia
description: President Gouled Aptidon Hassan of Djibouti, which is situated between Ethiopia and Somalia on the Red Sea, arrived here today for an eight-day visit after stopping in Southern Yemen. Somali officials say Southern Yemen is supplying troops to Ethiopia for the Somali-Ethiopian conflict over the Ogaden Desert. The conflict, along with a drought, has sent refugees pouring into Djibouti.

title: Crippled Polish Ship Is Sunk
description: A Polish freighter with explosive gas filling its forward holds was scuttled in the North Sea today after its owners were unable to find a country or port willing to accept it for repairs, Dutch authorities said. The Stanislaw Dubois, crippled last week in a collision with a Sudanese vessel, was carrying calcium carbide.

title: CABARET: 'PIANO MAN,' REVUE
description: Franklin Roosevelt Underwood, who has been playing piano around New York for two decades, has written a little musical revue called ''Piano Man,'' in which he performs the title role on Tuesdays at Mickey's, 44 West 54th Street. Seated at a piano, wearing a black derby and a shirt of fireman's red and surrounded by the other members of the cast - Cindy Benson, Claiborne Cary and Kurt Lauer - Mr. Underwood starts his revue with a seemingly autographical bent in his hometown, Gilman, Ill., but it soon branches out into songs that are more generalized and, presumably, less personal.

title: U.N. MEMBERS SIGN TREATY ON NAPALM AND LAND MINES
description: A treaty to protect civilians from napalm, land mines and booby traps was signed here today by 35 nations.

title: NICKLAUS FORGES 4-SHOT LEAD ON 65
description: Jack Nicklaus, whose five Masters championships make him the most successful golfer in the tournament's long history, took a four-stroke lead today after the second round with a 65, seven under par for the Augusta National Golf Club and one shy of the course record.

title: TRAUMA OF UNSOLVED MURDERS SHADOWS ATLANTA MAYORAL CAMPAIGN
description: The toll in this city's seemingly endless tragedy rose again last week as authorities identified the 23d young black victim, Larry Rogers, a retarded 21-year-old. They said that, like 10 others, he had been strangled to death. Officials said there were clues, but little hope for an immediate breakthrough. ''We've got all kinds of fingerprints,'' said Larry Howard, director of the state crime lab. ''But the question is, who do they belong to?''

title: U.S. PUBLISHERS TO MOUNT FAIR IN CHINA
description: With the strong encouragement and cooperation of Chinese publishing officials, the Association of American Publishers will mount in six cities in China from May 12 to 25 the biggest international exhibition it has ever assembled anywhere of English-language books. Six hundred publishers as well as the Government Printing Office are participating, and 20,000 titles in every field will be shown.

title: Practical Traveler; SAVING TIME, MILEAGE AND MONEY ON WEEKEND CAR RENTALS
description: If you are planning to rent a car over weekends this spring or summer, be prepared to face a miasma of complexities when searching for the most advantageous rates. You may, despite efforts of the rental agencies to make their peak-season operations more efficient, face long delays in picking up your car. You may end up with a car substantially different in size, features and fuel consumption - an important consideration because you will be paying for the gas - from the one you had reserved. You will certainly face rate structures that are confusing and subject to sudden change.

title: Page Beats Monroe By Knockout in 6th
description: Undefeated Greg Page stopped Marty Monroe in six rounds today in a scheduled 10-round heavyweight fight. Page, from Louisville, Ky., is 16-0, with 15 knockouts.

title: BRAIN-SIZE THEORY GETTING SCHOOL TEST
description: SHOREHAM BECAUSE of a controversial theory linking brain growth to how and when a child learns - a theory developed by a Brandeis University biophysicist that is being tested in the school district here - Ross Burkhardt's teaching of the American Revolution may undergo a revolution of its own.

title: Yank Homers Rout Rangers, 5-1
description: Gene Michael, the Yankees' rookie manager, didn't waste any time finding the home run button at Yankee Stadium. On opening day Thursday, Michael professed to be nervous, but he managed to keep his finger on the button long enough for Bucky Dent to hit a three-run homer and for Bobby Murcer to hit a pinch-hit grand slam. Obviously calmer yesterday, the manager pushed the button three times in the first three innings, and Graig Nettles, Willie Randolph and Oscar Gamble responded with homers that powered the Yankees past the Texas Rangers, 5-1.

title: AFTER 39 PLAYS IN 44 STATES...
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- John Houseman, the director, actor and author, is one of the founders of The Acting Company. By JOHN HOUSEMAN

title: M.P. Goldsmith Weds Ellen Josem, Lawyer
description: Ellen Debra Josem, a lawyer and executive assistant with the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services in New York, and Michael Philip Goldsmith, a candidate for a J.D. degree at the Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law of Yeshiva University, were married yesterday in Wilton, Conn. Rabbi Jonas Goldberg performed the ceremony at the Rolling Hills Country Club.

title: WHY GASOLINE IS GETTING CHEAPER
description: IT may not be like the glorious 60's, when a driver could buy a half tank of gasoline for pocket money, with balloons, beer mugs or soda pop thrown in. But for the long suffering American motorist, his psyche scarred in recent years by periodic shortages and relentless price increases, it's welcome relief indeed.

title: 2 BARS IN DISPUTES
description: AN application to increase the occupancy limit of the Mad Hatter, a bar in Stony Brook, from 286 to 888 patrons is being opposed by the Brookhaven Town Public Safety Commissioner and civic leaders who say the building is not large enough to accommodate all those customers at the popular tavern.

title: GRADUAL END URGED TO AID FOR STUDENTS
description: A new Democratic alternative to a Reagan Administration budget-cutting proposal seeks a more gradual elimination of a program that provides about 800,000 young Americans with special education payments from the Social Security System.

title:
Antiques;
LETTERS REVEAL YANKEE ROLE IN OHIO
description: HARTFORD ''HEZEKIAH BULL expects shortly to leave this State for Ohio and requests all persons indebted to him to make payment. He wishes to engage some young enterprising men to go with him, to settle on New Lands, on advantageous terms, House and other carpenters, blacksmiths, good Axe men, etc. He wants to purchase three yoke of likely working cattle (oxen).''

title: IT'S ONE STEP FORWARD AND TWO STEPS BACK FOR SOUTH AFRICA'S BLACK UNIONS
description: South Africa's qualified attempts to upgrade the economic rights of blacks without imperiling white political dominance are being resisted by some officials who view any improvement in blacks' status as likely to weaken whites. The result is a politics of contradiction.

title: NATIONAL DEBT
description: To the Business Editor: "The National Debt: A Primer" (Feb. 22) stopped short of completing the elementary lesson. It mentioned the effect of inflation on the debt ("$1 trillion is not what it used to be") but neglected to relate it to that other issue of great topical interest: the Federal budget deficit.

title: No Headline
description: One person was injured and at least nine were arrested today when about 100 young supporters of Robert Sands tried to stage a rally and clashed with the police. The youths fought the police with bricks and bottles, and the police fired back with rubber bullets.

title: Miss Woleslagle Is Married to Pilot
description: Christine Ann Woleslagle, daughter of Harry R. Woleslagle of Bethel Park, Pa., and the late Catherine Long Woleslagle, was married yesterday to James Hooker Hamersley, son of Mrs. Robert C. L. Timpson of Southampton, L.I., and the late Louis Gordon Hamersley. The Rev. Ralph R. Warren Jr. performed the ceremony in St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Mount Lebanon, Pa.

title: On Destruction
description: To the Editor:

title: GALILEO'S LATEST MEMO
description: TO: Charles Darwin FROM: Galileo Galilei SUBJECT: Your current troubles Since I once had to deal with the science vs. Bible problem, maybe I can cheer you up by reminding you of what I had to go through to establish the sun as the center of the solar system.

title: A Right to Quit As an Act of Faith
description: How to maintain church-state separation while giving religion its due can be a tricky constitutional question. Last week, balancing the freedom of religion against the First Amendment clause prohibiting its ''establishment,'' the Supreme Court ruled that a state should not withhold unemployment benefits from a worker who quit a job for religious reasons.

title: Numismatics; LAST ACT IN GARRETT SALE; by Ed Reiter
description: Even the biggest Broadway hit shows must close eventually, and the same thing is true of long-running auctions such as the four-part Garrett Sale, the ''My Fair Lady'' of numismatic auctions. The final curtain fell on March 26, but, like Broadway's greatest hits, this ''Sale of the Century'' has left an enduring legacy.

title:
ANTIQUES;
ON THE BANKS OF THE RARITAN
description: NEW BRUNSWICK IN THE early 1700's, this town was an important link in the journey between Philadelphia and New York City. Travelers would go by sloop up the Delaware River to Trenton, than by stage from Trenton to New Brunswick. Another sloop would take them to New York via the Raritan River.

title: BRAVO, MR. BECKER
description: Bridge and chess are among the few recreational activities in which it is possible, though admittedly most unusual, to be a worldclass performer for half a century. Chess-players can point to the great Samuel Reshevsky, while bridge-players can point to, among others, B. Jay Becker. Both men, in their own fields, are the epitome of remorseless efficiency, grinding down their opponents by solid accuracy without any artificial striving for brilliance.

title: Tracy Caulkins Sets Mark in Swim Titles
description: The United States short-course swimming championships ended tonight the way they had begun four days ago. Eighteen-year-old Tracy Caulkins of Nashville won her fourth title in four races, each in American-record time, and gained her 31st national title, the most by a woman in the history of American swimming.

title: Murder Strikes From Both Sides In El Salvador
description: They count the days in deaths in El Salvador, where 15,000 people have been killed in the last 18 months. In December, the victims included three American nuns and a colleague, murdered reportedly by right-wing security men. In January, leftist guerrillas launched a ''final offensive'' that claimed 1,100 lives before it failed. Last month the United States Embassy's weekly ''violence reports'' tallied 30 assassinations a week, including four attempts on President Jose Napoleon Duarte and killings of half a dozen mayors and other local officials.

title: No Headline
description: James Lieber fails to mention the alienation many men feel by incarceration so far from their homes and families that visits on a regular basis are impossible.

title: THE REGION
description: N.J. Tries to Insure Fair Auto Rates Though there were questions as to whether his order would stand up, New Jersey State Insurance Commissioner James J. Sheeran last week did for the the state's motorists what Governor Byrne had been unable to get the Legislature to do.

title: A SEDER THAT LETS HUNDREDS SHARE
description: THE Passover seder, a feast commemorating the exodus of the Jews from Egypt to Israel, traditionally combines a solemn religious observance with a joyful gathering of family and friends. It should be a time of celebration. But for those who have neither the relationships nor the means to arrange for a place at a seder table on the first or second nights of the holiday - this year, on Saturday and next Sunday - it can be lonely.

title: Geraldine Kriaris, Nurse, Bride of Alan W. Messer
description: Geraldine Edith Kriaris, a hospice nurse with Visiting Health Services of Passaic Valley in Little Falls, N.J., was married yesterday in Upper Montclair, N.J., to Alan Williams Messer, president of Data Counsel Inc. The Rev. Shannon Bernard, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony at the home of the couple.

title: The Problems In Prisons
description: My employment takes me each month to Florida State Prison, the state's main maximum-security institution (''The American Prison: A Tinderbox,'' by James Lieber, March 8). I was literally ill after my first thorough visit to the institution.

title: FAIR ASSESSMENT IS WITHIN GRASP
description: MANY homeowners are up in arms over the prospect of full-value assessment. Their fears are probably needless. The fact is, of all the bills to reform the present haphazard system of property taxation being considered by the State Legislature, not one proposes assessing and taxing real property on the basis of 100 percent of value.

title: ANOTHER TRY
description: ''IN the case of the shuttle, you don't fly without the computer system,'' an official of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said recently. That is perhaps the simplest explanation of what happened last week. To the chagrin of NASA technicians wary of failures in machinery, it was a computer glitch that kept the space shuttle Columbia's 4.5-million-pound, 184-foottall bulk firmly earthbound on Friday.

title: Managing Big Business
description: Douglas Bauer's article ''Why Big Business Is Firing the Boss'' (March 8) should be read with care both by big business and by President Reagan and his team.

title: DANCE: 'THE PHI PROJECT' FROM KENNETH KING
description: Kenneth King's choreographic career has taken many odd twists and turns. His satiric early dances resembled Pop Art. Then he devoted himself to cryptic spectacles about a variety of explicitly philosophical, scientific and semantic issues. And he invented eccentric alter egos to exemplify his ideas.

title: HORSE POWER
description: GUITING POWER, England Charles Pinney is a small businessman with entrepreneurial impulses who operates out of this tiny village in England's serene Cotswold country. Mr. Pinney's business is the Cart Horse Company Ltd.

title: Paris Museum Guards Strike
description: A strike by guards seeking higher pay shut some of Paris's most famous museums and monuments today. The strikers, who are also seeking a guaranteed promotion schedule, plan to return to work Sunday night.

title: A BRITON WHO SPECIALIZES IN THE CLASSICS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Michael Billington, who is London theater critic for The Guardian, also maintains an interest in television. By MICHAEL BILLINGTON LONDON

title: DONNA CAPONI YOUNG SHOOTS A 65 FOR 2-STROKE LEAD
description: Donna Caponi shot a seven-under-par 65, including a 150-foot eagle on the last hole, to take a two-stroke lead today after the second round of the $125,000 Ladies' Professional Golf Association American Defender Classic.

title:
The Careful Shopper;
Inventory Sale Is Sight For Sore Eyes
description: The Canal Street Plastic Supply Company in New Rochelle is hard to miss. Located south of the I-95 toll booth and painted purple and an orange-now-faded-to-salmon, it has a sign within saying ''We Don't Like the Color of Your House Either.''

title: HOLMES KEEPS TITLE ON DECISION
description: Larry Holmes's streak of eight straight knockout victories came to an end tonight, but he retained his World Boxing Council championship with a unanimous 15-round decision over Trevor Berbick. It was Holmes's 37th straight victory as a professional.

title: BARBARA CARTLAND'S TOUCH OF ROYALTY
description: Barbara Cartland, the flamboyant queen of the romantic novel, is about to acquire a genuine royal connection. But with a reticence that has seldom been a feature of her long and remarkable career, Miss Cartland has resolved to say nothing about the coming marriage of her stepgranddaughter, Lady Diana Spencer, to Prince Charles.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
THE AVERAGE CRIMINAL IS AN AMATEUR
description: IN MARCH 1974, tens of thousands of American youths playfully removed their clothes and ran, jogged, pranced and bicycled through streets, libraries, schools and other public places.

title: JAMAICAN HIGHLIGHTS: A GREAT HOUSE, A GRUELING TREK
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- DEIRDRE FRANK, a writer who lives in New York, grew up in Jamaica. By DEIRDRE FRANK

title: Music; ORCHESTRAL THEME IS PURSUED TODAY IN FOUR AREA CONCERTS
description: THE orchestral theme continues to be pursued throughout the county; there are three concerts today alone, and a fourth if you're willing to go a few miles across the Bronx border.

title: Playing Politics; With Refugee Aid
description: Arab delegates at first refused to enter because Israel's delegate arrived first, and the Soviet bloc didn't come at all, arguing that the matter at hand was all the fault of Western colonialism. But despite the shadow-boxing and absentees, a United Nations conference in Geneva last week raised $560 million to aid an estimated 5 million African political refugees.

title: POLAND'S NEXT MOST IMPORTANT ELECTION IS FOR PARTY CHIEF
description: Barring Soviet military intervention, the likely next phase in the workers' revolution in Poland will not be a struggle against the Communist Party but a struggle within the party itself. The outcome will be crucial -probably more important than anything that has happened so far - in determining how far Poland will go in its remarkable dash for more freedom and democracy.

title: Leslie G. Rowland, Editor, to Be Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Robert Rowland of Weston, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Leslie Gail Rowland, to William Edward Jacques, son of Stanley Webster Jacques Jr. of Elkins Park, Pa., and Eileen Link Lawless of Huntington Valley Pa.

title: DANCE: FRANK HOLDER COMPANY AT PACE
description: If the Frank Holder Dance Company had a slogan, it would probably be ''dance is fun.'' In its New York debut Thursday at Pace University's Schimmel Center, the Greensboro, N.C.-based modern-dance group offered a smorgasbord of dance entertainments performed by eight bright, pleasantly slick young dancers.

title: EAST GERMAN FEELS POLISH CRISIS EASES
description: In a cautiously worded statement on Poland, the East German leader, Erich Honecker, said today that serious difficulties continued in the neighboring country, but he indicated that the Soviet bloc was not pressing for immediate intervention to end the crisis.

title:
ART;
WHAT IS AN ORIGINAL PRINT? SHOW GIVES SOME ANSWERS
description: GREAT NECK ALTHOUGH printmaking is perhaps the most widely known form of art, there is a certain mystery about it. What is an original print? How can it be an original if there are more than one of each image? These are questions that both puzzle the layman and vex the artists who choose printmaking as a primary medium of expression.

title: MELODRAMATIC BETI WORK MIRES ACTORS IN APHORISMS; BY ALVIN KLEIN; EAST FARMINGDALE
description: LEAVE it to Frederic De Feis, producer-director of Arena Players Repertory Theater, to dig up an obscure play and seek contemporary meaning in it. Ugo Betti's ''The Queen and the Rebels,'' which plays through next Sunday, is rife with up-to-the-minute political implications. You can read what you will into it, but it isn't likely that you will get an illuminating evening out of it.

title: Academy-Institute to Give Awards to 16
description: Sixteen writers will receive awards from the American Academy and Institute of Arts and Letters at the organization's annual ceremonial on May 20, it was announced by John Updike, chairman of the literary committee.

title: TO SPICE UP A LONG RUN, ADD A DASH OF MICKEY ROONEY
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- George Howe Colt is a freelance writer with a special interest in theater. By GEORGE HOWE COLT

title: ART SAMPLER
description: SO MUCH painting has become painfully self-conscious these days, fastidious in its attitude and pinched in its philosophy. It looks as if it survives on artificial blood, if it survives at all, generated mechanically and unnaturally in an artistic hothouse.

title: THE ODDS TURN AGAINST THE TRACKS
description: L AST Monday, on a cool gin-clear night, the Muzak trailed off just before 8 o'clock and 8,916 fans, sprinkled throughout the lime-green grandstands, turned their attention to the trotters vying for position out of the starting gate. The spring meeting, in horseracing parlance, had begun at Yonkers Raceway.

title: 2 UNIONS IN BATTLE
description: WHEN 110 civil servants employed by the Village of Mineola in November of 1979 turned down the contract negotiated for them by their union, the Civil Service Employees Association, and accepted instead the representation of Local 808 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, it seemed as if the teamsters' local had made a healthy start in its bid to win over some of C.S.E.A. units in Nassau and Suffolk Counties.

title: JERSEY CITY BETTING ON THE FUTURE sectors
description: JERSEY CITY

title:
The Careful Shopper;
Furniture Bargains At Canal Street Plastic
description: This week only, there is a sale at 35 to 40 percent off suggested retail prices at Canal Street Plastic Supply Company in Stamford. It is also sale time at the Manhattan branch and at the New Rochelle factory (painted purple and orange-now-faded-to-salmon), south of the I-95 toll booth in Westchester.

title: ANTHONY TAKES L.I. BOWLING
description: Earl Anthony of Dublin, Calif., who was elected to the Bowling Hall of Fame six weeks ago, won the $100,000 Long Island open today at the Garden City Bowl.

title: AVON RINGS A BELL FOR COLLECTORS' CLUBS
description: SPOTSWOOD JUST about everyone knows an Avon lady, but less familiar are the growing number of collectors now scrounging around in their quest for unusual old Avon bottles, jars or other products manufactured by the cosmetic company.

title: FOUR DIVERS PLAN AN ATTACK ON ANDREA DORIA'S RICHES
description: PRINCETON SUNDAY, July 26, will be the 25th anniversary of the sinking of the liner Andrea Doria off Nantucket. The luxurious Italian ship, carrying 1,134 passengers from Genoa and Gibraltar to New York, was struck amidships in dense fog by an eastbound liner, the Stockholm, at 11:10 P.M.

title: THE PEN IS A HEAVY OAR
description: THE protagonist of the recent French film ''Like A Turtle on Its Back'' is a novelist in his mid-30's who, since the publication of a successful first novel six years before, has been afflicted with writing's most insidious occupational hazard: writer's block. Any movie that takes this malady as its central theme and principal action is certainly testing the limits of plot; writer's block is so excruciating for the sufferer and tedious for those in the immediate vicinity that one can hardly imagine people paying to watch such an ordeal. The novelist's condition is conveyed in agonizing and evocative detail: He toys endlessly with his new manuscript, fondles his fountain pen, buys a new chair, pursues women at cafes, takes on a degrading ghostwriting assignment, and finally - by his childish petulance and self-indulgence -leaves his wife no choice but to kick him out. Still, however believable the portrait, my temptation is to agree with Edna Ferber, who insisted that ''writers should be read but not seen.'' Especially not on a movie screen and in the throes of idle capacity.

title: Lost & Found Dept., Maritime Division
description: History sometimes begins as news and ends in scholarship. In its spring issue, the quarterly journal Polar Geography, will publish, with the sponsorship of the American Geographical Society of New York, a translation of a forgotten Soviet report which had moldered in the archives of the Soviet Hydrographic Office in Leningrad for 17 years.

title: TRYING AGAIN IN CONSUMER ELECTRONICS

In earlier eras, for example, much of the original work on the jet engine, the computer, radar and the early work on semiconductors was done in Britain. But the money on them was made elsewhere.

description: The American Film Institute's ninth Life Achievement Award was given to Fred Astaire at a dinner here last night.

title: Monica Griffiths Married
description: Monica Griffiths, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harley M. Griffiths of Larchmont, N.Y., was married there yesterday in St. Augustine's Roman Catholic Church to Timothy Blair Brenton, son of Mr. and Mrs. C. Bowman Brenton of Towson, Md. The Rev. Paul Maher, superior of Innisfada, a Jesuit retreat house in Manhasset, L.I., and a cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony.

title: Film View; STAND BACK! HERE COMES THE 'ORDINARY' AVALANCHE
description: Now that ''Ordinary People'' has won its Oscar as the year's best picture, can there be any doubt about which way we're headed? In the wake of this and ''Kramer vs. Kramer,'' ordinary is in. Humdrum is hot. Normal is big news. The movies, so accustomed to offering glamour, will now be turning to real life for their inspiration. Why set a story in Monte Carlo when you can just as well leave it in Michigan? Why profile suave jewel thieves and international spies when every grocer has a tale to tell? For months to come, Hollywood's most daring thinkers will be asking themselves such questions. Herewith, some scenarios that may well be on their way:

description: WILLIAM ROBBINS is a correspondent for The Times based in Philadelphia. His wife, Helen, participated in the preparation of this article. By WILLIAM ROBBINS

description: TRENTON A PANEL of Republican state legislators, saying that a lack of ''affordable'' housing in New Jersey is becoming the major issue of the 1980's, has been conducting public hearings to gather information for a legislative initiative.

description: Jones, an 18th-century feminist, tells ''the true history'' of her service with a coven of witches, a house of doxies, a slave-ship crew and a pirate flotilla in a style reminiscent of John Cleland's ''Fanny Hill.'' ''The beauty of the language,'' said our reviewer Alan Friedman, ''turns the pornographic narrative into a prodigious work of fiction.''

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, APRIL 12, 1981
description: International Solidarity and the Polish Government will begin talks toward a mutual understanding Thursday and they will be nationally televised, leaders of the independent union said. Issues will include the union's access to mass media, release of political prisoners, an independent union for private farmers, police violence in Bydgoszcz and strike pay. A Solidarity official said approval of the televised negotiations has been confirmed Mieczyslaw Rakowski, Deputy Prime Minister and chief Government negotiator with the union. (Page 1, Columns 4-5.) The Soviet threat to Poland appears to have eased, Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said at news conference in Bonn at the end of his nine-day trip in the Middle East and Western Europe. He said the mililtary situation appeared ''somewhat improved,'' despite the readiness of Warsaw Pact troops on Poland's borders. His optimisim was based largely on a recent statement by Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, that ''reflected greater moderation.'' (1:1-2.)

title: GREEN BERETS STAGE A PARACHUTE SHOW FOR LIBERIANS
description: About 100 United States Special Forces troops, who arrived in Liberia yesterday for joint maneuvers, held a parachute show today on the eve of the first anniversary of Master Sgt. Samuel K. Doe's coup.

title: Laurie Susan Engel Married
description: Laurie Susan Engel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey John Engel of New York and Boca Raton, Fla., was married yesterday to Mark Lawrence Jr., son of Mrs. Nan Lutor of Honolulu and Mr. Lawrence of Boston. Michael Grupp, a leader of the Ethical Culture Society, performed the ceremony at the Regency Hotel. Mr. Lawrence is a grandson of the late David Lawrence, the syndicated newspaper columnist and founder, editor and board chairman of U.S. News and World Report, a weekly news magazine.

title: A TALK WITH LEONARD MICHAELS
description: ON a sunny Thursday afternoon in Berkeley, inside a white house protected by pale green shutters, a faded picket fence and a tangle of California plants, Leonard Michaels helps his 16-month-old daughter down the stairs.

description: Julianne Joy Williams, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alan Williams of Los Angeles, was married yesterday in San Francisco to Dr. John Harrington Donohue. The Rev. Thomas Connellan performed the ceremony in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church.

title: KINGS, ROCKETS ARE THE SURPRISES OF N.B.A. PLAYOFFS
description: Before the Kings' practice this morning in Kansas City, Reggie King was saying: ''Nobody thought we would get into the playoffs. Nobody thought we could beat Portland. Nobody thought we had a chance against Phoenix, and we're up 2-1 against them.''

title: No Headline
description: Curiously, no attention was given to the factor which is omnipresent in criminal activity: alcohol abuse.

title: Regan Begins London Visit
description: Donald T. Regan, making his first trip abroad since becoming President Reagan's Treasury Secretary, arrived here today for talks with finance ministers and central bank chiefs from Britain, West Germany, Japan and France. The meeting is one of a series of private conferences bringing together the leaders of major non-Communist industrial nations.

title:
GARDENING;
LANDSCAPING TO MEET CHALLENGING INTERESTS
description: NOTHING appears quite so desolate as a newly built house devoid of planting, except, of course, an entire development of such houses. But once plantings are in place, a slow transition begins and in 15 to 20 years most houses take on a more inviting and habitable appearance.

title: STAGE: WORLD PREMIERE OF SAMUEL BECKETT'S 'ROCKABY' AT STATE U.
description: The central image is spellbinding in Samuel Beckett's new play, ''Rockaby,'' which had its world premiere last week at the Center for Theater Research. The play, directed by Alan Schneider, was presented by the State University of New York, in celebration of Beckett's 75th birthday. In ''Rockaby,'' an old woman, played by Billie Whitelaw, dressed in a black sequined gown, sits in a spotlight in a rocking chair and rocks herself back into memory. Memory is life, and when the river of the woman's subconscious runs dry, the chair stops, her eyes close and she expires. Contradicting a last spasm of rage against futility, an almost beatific, childlike innocence floods the woman's face. It is a moment of transfiguration.

title: Bruins Eliminated By the North Stars
description: Steve Payne scored two goals, including one into an empty net with 1 minute 26 seconds left, to lead Minnesota to a 6-3 victory tonight and a three-game sweep of its preliminary National Hockey League playoff series with Boston.

title: FROM A FOREST AND A STREAM
description: CENTERPORT WHAT'S in a name? That depends. If you're Lothlorien, a chamber ensemble that plays ''third stream'' music, not necessarily too much. ''We were on our way to our first booking in a library and we realized we didn't have a name,'' recalled Jim Palmer, who with Rebecca Dunnell founded the group in 1975. ''Well, our piano player then was heavily into Tolkien and he came up with 'Lothlorien,' which I think is the name of a nebulous, peaceful forest. Because we couldn't think of anything else, we used it and it kind of stuck.''

title: FOOD AND WINES FROM DOWN UNDER
description: WITH its yabbies from the Billabong, mimi birds, bundled chooks and carpetbag, merely reading the menu at the Australian Country Inn and Gardens in Northport is a vocabulary lesson. Some knowledge of Australian geography would be helpful, but translations are provided for those who do not speak the language.

title: BOAT SALES STEADY DESPITE RISING COSTS
description: MAMARONECK THIS is ''fitting out'' time, and for the next few weeks Westchester's boaters will be up to their elbows in paint, canvas, cordage and rigging, getting their craft ready. They have no intention of being caught with their anchors down when the weather becomes fit for running with the winds and putt-putting with the tides.

title: TRACKING FAMILY INCOME
description: To get a clearer picture of earnings among working families, the Bureau of Labor Statistics has developed a new demographically based survey of wages and salaries that is gaining popularity among economists.

title: About Westchester
description: MAMARONECK NATALIE HIRSCH had her opponent locked in the Zugswang. Zugswang is that situation in chess in which any move a player makes will be to his or her detriment. Now Beth Hisle sat hunched over the board, pulling on a strand of blond hair, intent on extricating herself from the threatening predicament.

title: STUDY FINDS 111 OF 670 JERSEY WELLS CONTAMINATED
description: A three-year state study of ground water in 670 wells throughout New Jersey has found that 111 of them, or 16.6 percent, contained elevated levels of toxic organic chemicals.
