description: IN every other golf tournament of importance around the world, Tom Watson and Jack Nicklaus would be paired together in the final round

title: No Headline
description: Assemblyman I. William Bianchi Jr. persists in declaring that a Bayville-Rye bridge would pay for itself.

title: 'PATIENCE' DESERVES TO BE POPULAR
description: On April 23, 1881, Gilbert and Sullivan's ''Patience'' received its world premiere at the Opera Comique Theater in London. This Wednesday ''Patience'' settles in for a short run - through April 26 - at the East Side Playhouse on East 74th Street. Which means that the Light Opera of Manhattan, known to the world as LOOM, will be staging ''Patience'' exactly on the centennial, to the joy of the town's Savoyards, and also to the joy of those who might be encountering this enchanting operetta for the first time. But LOOM is not the only G&S group honoring the centenary. At Symphony Space, 95th Street and Broadway, the New York Gilbert and Sullivan Players are currently giving eleven performances of ''Patience,'' ending on May 3.

title: But the Enemy Is Inflation
description: During his first months in office, Ronald Reagan had the field to himself. He unveiled a bold economic plan and sent aides to clear the way for its journey through Congress. Only now have the Democrats gotten themselves onto the field, helmets in place, ready finally with their own economic program. This plan, prepared by Democrats on the House Budget Committee, is a sensible and decent document, more cautious about inflation than the President's, and more humane in its spending reductions.

title: Robin Greenberg Betrothed To Kenneth Michael Kramer
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Greenberg of Hamden, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Robin Joy Greenberg, to Kenneth Michael Kramer, son of Dr. and Mrs. Albert S. Kramer of Huntington, L.I. A September wedding is planned.

title: SAYS HE FEELS 'GREAT'
description: Twelve days after he was shot in the chest in an assassination attempt, President Reagan returned to the White House this morning.

title: Villane's Quarrel Held To Be With New York
description: An Opinion article by Assemblyman Anthony M. Villane Jr. on Feb. 8 that discussed the disposal of sewage from the World Trade Center requires comment. Sewage discharged from the center and all buildings in lower Manhattan has always been handled by the New York City sewer system.

title: Alison Blackman, Editor, Is Bride of Dr. Frank Weiss
description: Alison Wendy Blackman, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Norman S. Blackman of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to Dr. Frank Weiss, son of Mr. and Mrs. Barney Weiss, also of Brooklyn. Rabbi Solomon Kahane performed the ceremony at the Sutton Place Synagogue in Manhattan.

title: STUDENTS OF ARCHITECTURE GIVEN HIGH-FLYING TEST
description: In intermittent rain and variable winds, as a brass band played ''the best music of the last 600 years,'' dozens of kites flew high, flew low, flew into trees, into the ground and not at all at the City College of New York School of Architecture's first kite festival yesterday in Central Park.

title: POLICE EXPECTING MORE THAN A MILLION AT LAUNCHING
description: The police braced today for more than a million spectators for tomorrow's second try at launching the space shuttle Columbia.

title: Beckenbauer's Life Back in Europe
description: He is far too polite, too genuinely gracious, too instinctively diplomatic to suggest that the Americans did not fully appreciate him when he played for the Cosmos, did not really understand what he was up to. But when the man sitting on the opposite side of the coffee table in his Hamburg brownstone starts insinuating as much, Franz Beckenbauer just smiles a bit. In his courtly, indeed princely way, the look is pure assent.

title: Dining Out; OLD BARN HOLDS PLEASANT SURPRISE
description: SOUTH WOODSTOCK COMING upon Bald Hill Restaurant in the wooded, somewhat underpopulated terrain of northeastern Connecticut is a little like stumbling upon a feast in the middle of the desert. Sparkling glassware, a pot of begonias on each table, comfortable rattan chairs, softly modulated lighting, nicely set tables covered with glass over red-and-green-patterned fabric, repeated in the draperies - all make the restored barn in which the restaurant is located an inviting, comfortable place to dine.

title: MANCHESTER: AN ISSUE OF AUTHORITY
description: MANCHESTER PINNED to the bulletin board on the first floor of the Manchester Town Hall is a proclamation by Governor O'Neill on the state's observance of Good Friday this week. ''The American people have never been islands unto themselves,'' it states.

title: IN SOUTH AFRICA, BLACKS DISDAIN WHITE ELECTION
description: It is the nature of the South African system that blacks are excluded from any kind of participation in so-called ''general'' elections. It is the nature of the system, too, that the blacks, who account for about 71 percent of the population, can never be displaced as the central issue of white politics.

title: Recordings; DISKS DEVOTED TO AMERICAN MUSIC
description: In 1978, New World Records completed its project to present a comprehensive overview of American music on 100 disks - a magnificent collection, as it turned out, that explored virtually every phase of our varied musical life from the past 300 years. The company has been less active of late but by no means idle. A year ago four records were released documenting music by Cecil Taylor (NW 300), San Pueblo Indian chants (NW 301), string quartets by Walter Piston and Roger Sessions (NW 302) and a recital of contemporary piano music played by Bradford Gowen (NW 303). Presently at hand are five new issues with the promise of more to come in the near future.

title: Headliners; After the Surrender
description: It was, said the defendant, ''an act of stupidity and an act of insanity.'' It was, said his lawyer, ''the aberration in this man's life.'' It was, said dozens of the defendant's prominent friends and supporters, an occasion for judicial leniency. But Acting Justice Brenda Soloff of New York State Supreme Court said none of that was relevant to the defendant's crimes: selling cocaine to undercover policemen and jumping bail. So she sentenced Abbie Hoffman, the former Yippie leader who surrendered recently after having lived six years underground, to up to three years in prison. He is to begin his term on April 21 and must serve a year before becoming eligible for parole.

title: A.C.L.U. WILL SEEK TO VOID COLLEGE TEST
description: PATERSON THE American Civil Liberties Union has taken up the case of seniors at Passaic County Community College, who charge that the administration did not give them time to prepare for an examination that was required for graduation.

title: THE PIED PIPER OF DANCE
description: Barbara Gelb is a regular contributor to The New York Times Magazine. By Barbara Gelb Dancing transformed his life, and that is why Jacques d'Amboise, a big American boy with an aristocratic French name and a ballet technique that is elegantly and peculiarly Russian, has become, in his mid-40's, a missionary of the dance. A symbol of virile grace for the New York City Ballet for more than 30 years, the audacious partner of many of the world's most ravishing ballerinas, d'Amboise now dreams of sweeping into rhythmic self-expression all the youth of America - for dancing, he believes, is every child's cultural birthright.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Spreading the word. Along Publishers Row, a neighborhood whose residents seldom all agree about anything, there's one matter about which opinion is unanimous - nothing sells a book like ''word-ofmouth.'' Favorable reviews, advertisements in the press, on television and radio, book-club adoptions, attractive cover designs and elaborate displays in bookstores help launch a book, but to become a true popular success, it must possess a magic quality that impels readers to recommend it to others.

title: Benefit for Collegiate Chorale

The concert, featuring works by Bach, Berg, Beethoven, Brahms and Rachmaninoff, will be in the WQXR Auditorium of the New York Times Building, 229 West 43d Street, at 7:30 P.M. Admission is $5.

description: For a fleeting moment, Vice President Bush recalls, he thought he might have to assume the Presidency on the day President Reagan was shot. But he quickly quelled the thought and for the past 12 days has striven to project the continuity of the Reagan Administration without appearing to be a surrogate President.

title: Victoria Flournoy, Teacher, Engaged
description: The engagement of Victoria Fox Flournoy to Kevin Edward McCarthy has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Richard C. Flournoy, parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. John F. McCarthy Jr.

title: Greek Tragedy and Our Athletes
description: To the Sports Editor: Bruce Ogilvie's article, ''Athletes Deserve Human Frailty Like the Rest of Us,'' (The New York Times, March 29) contains, I think, a flawed definition and a consequently serious error of application and interpretation. When Professor Ogilvie writes of Greek hubris as ''the sin of (false) pride, which was a universal human response when awed or threatened by perfection,'' he misconstrues the nature of hubris. To the Greeks, hubris was not the audience's response to dramatic heroes, as Professor Ogilvie suggests, but rather the tragic character's own impiously lofty conception of himself as godlike. Indeed, Greek tragedy was a kind of cautionary tale for the demos, whose responses, according to Aristotle, were pity and fear, and not as Professor Ogilvie seems to imply, the hubris of vindictive rage.

title: D COPPER DON'T MIX
description: T HE ancient saw is that one can't mix oil and water. How about oil and copper? The question is especially relevant now. Standard Oil of Ohio plans to merge with the Kennecott Corporation. Standard Oil of California seeks to acquire the 80 percent of Amax shares it does not now own. These huge acquisitions involve billions of dollars and also billions of tons of mineral reserves containing many millions of tons of metal.

title: CAREY'S MARRIAGE CALLED A POLITICAL AND PERSONAL PLUS
description: ''In politics,'' Governor Carey said as he prepared for his marriage to Evangeline Gouletas, ''two can live better than one.'' It may also turn out that in politics, two can survive longer than one. Mrs. Gouletas-Carey quickly demonstrated last week that in her new role as New York State's First Lady she intended to be a valuable political asset to the Governor. For one thing, Mr. Carey, who has suffered his share of political reversals lately, seems to be stifling his remaining doubts about running for re-election next year.

description: The world's newest cultural center, the Centro de Bellas Artes, opened last night before an audience headed by Carlos Romero, the Governor of Puerto Rico, and with an obbligato of about 2,000 chanting picketers along Ponce de Leon Avenue. Until Wednesday, it was not even a certainty that the concert would go on.

title: Solutions Offered For Jail Overcrowding
description: The recent article ''Overcrowding Plagues Nassau Jail'' highlights a problem that Nassau shares with numerous counties nationwide. The Nassau Coalition for Safety and Justice has extensively researched the issue of the overcrowded jail, and we are convinced that the county needs to approach solutions from a systemwide level rather than leaping to quick-fix, short-range, expensive decisions.

description: To the Editor:

description: A special judicial committee plans to submit legislation to Congress in a concerted effort to increase the salary and benefits of Federal judges throughout the country.

title: Westchester Journal
description: early enough to be the first to check in at the refurbished hotel that has recovered from the fatal fire of Dec. 4.

title: ANTI-SEMITIC ACTS ON THE INCREASE
description: NO ONE thought it would ever happen in Closter - but it did. One weekend last month, vandals sprayed obscenities in red paint on St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church on High Street, then moved on to Schraalenburgh Road, where they spread garbage in front of Temple Beth El and scrawled a swastika on its walls.

title: CONSOLIDATION A GROWING TREND IN FARMING
description: FRANKLIN ALL over Connecticut, spring transforms suburbanites into backyard farmers, grooming lawns and planning gardens. In rural parts of the state, a still substantial agricultural industry operates year-round, without regard for the cycle of planting flowers and killing crabgrass.

title: IS FRONT RUNNING RISKY? PERES AWAITS THE ANSWER
description: It is often a great handicap to be the solid favorite in an election campaign. The aura of invincibility must be maintained. A political faux pas or dip in the polls runs the risk of being magnified into a major reverse, testimony to the candidate's sudden vulnerability.

title: Taylor Shapes Up as the Giants' Top Pick
description: ''A blue chip, a No. 1 all the way ...'' Tom Boisture, Director of Player Personnel, the Giants. ''As good as any I've seen. He may even have an S emblazoned on his chest ...'' Mike Hickey, Director of Player Personnel, New York Jets. ''The best athlete I've ever coached ...'' Mel Foels, assistant coach, North Carolina. ''A great, great player. We called him Godzilla ...'' Barry Switzer, head coach, Oklahoma. CHAPEL HILL, N.C. THE player is Lawrence Taylor from North Carolina. Taylor, George Rogers of South Carolina and Pittsburgh's Hugh Green are the three most desirable athletes in the forthcoming draft of 336 college athletes by the National Football League's 28 teams. Taylor, who played at end in college but is projected as an outside linebacker, stands 6 feet 3 inches, weighs 245 pounds and runs 40 yards in 4.7 seconds, sometimes 4.6. That is fast, fast for a flanker or a running back, and incredible for a linebacker.

description: To the Editor:

title: QUESTIONED TO DEATH
description: STORE UP THE ANGER By Wessel Ebersohn. 299 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $12.95.

description: While doing a good turn last week for the Americans who were held hostage in Iran, the Federal Election Commission gave several hundred politicians a shot at big bucks.

description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Harlow Robinson teaches in the Slavic Department at SUNY-Albany and is writing a book about Prokofiev. By HARLOW ROBINSON

title: Ada Greenbaum Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Paul Greenbaum have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ada Susan Greenbaum, to Seth Ira Alpert, son of Mr. and Mrs. Al Alpert. Both families are of Manhattan. A June wedding is planned.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Condor Chase
description: Only about 30 California condors were left in the entire state, the Federal Fish and Wildlife Service estimated in June 1979 when it proposed to save the vultures from extinction by trapping at least four and trying to breed them in captivity. By the end of 1979, Congress had granted $500,000 for the work, and the next year the appropriation was increased to $1 million.

title: TWO FROM HUBERTH 'INGENIOUS' PRIZE
description: The bankers, lawyers and brokers, along with the buyer and seller, had all gathered in the board room of East New York Savings Bank last June to sign the final agreement.

description: To the Editor:

title: POLISH POET ARRIVES AT HARVARD AFTER YEARS OF WAITING FOR VISA
description: Stanislaw Barantzak has spent the last few days fulfilling a three-year-old dream -walking around Harvard Yard, talking to students and dining in the Faculty Club with colleagues.

title: WELFARE
description: To the Business Editor: Mr. Penner concedes that many families who receive Aid to Families with Dependent Children "will be net losers for a long period of time." A look at economic reality shows that welfare cutbacks will have a disastrous impact.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: IN A MOVE designed to reduce costs and increase efficiency, four Hudson County municipalities will consolidate their fire-protection services. Weehawken, West New York, Union City and North Bergen have approved a communications network to speed response to fires in this urban area of 250,000 people. The communities, served by paid Fire Departments, also approved an authority to oversee the consolidation.

title: BURGLARY SUSPECT, 17, IS KILLED IN BAY RIDGE BY CORRECTION OFFICER
description: An off-duty New York City correction officer shot and killed a teen-age burglary suspect last night in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn, the police said.

title: SUSPECT IN COLOMBIA DRUG CASE EXPECTED TO TESTIFY
description: William A. Spradley has been tight-lipped about the details of his unpleasant adventure into Colombian marijuana territory since his return here almost two years ago, except to say he may have been duped into co-piloting a small plane for a drug mission.

title: PRESIDENTIAL PANEL HOLDS HEARINGS ON 'RIGHT TO DIE'
description: After two days of hearings conducted by a Presidential commission here, a consensus emerged among witnesses that terminally ill patients should have the right to forgo lifesustaining therapy.

title: CAREY'S RECEPTION: PANOPLY, POMP AND BAGPIPES
description: ''It's like chicken soup,'' said David Garth, the political consultant. ''Governor Carey's marriage to Evangeline Gouletas has got to help him.''

title: Braniff Officials Get Raises
description: Braniff International, whose union employees last month agreed to a 10 percent pay cut, has given an 11.4 percent average raise to about 1,000 management officials. The salary increases were necessary to keep management employees from quitting, airline officials said yesterday.

title: Pakistan Bus Plunge Kills 42
description: A bus carrying pilgrims from a religious shrine ran off the road and plunged into a canal about 200 miles north of Karachi, killing 42 people, the Government said today.

title: Peggy Levere Wed To Russell DaSilva
description: Peggy Ann Levere, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Levere of Teaneck, N.J., was married last evening at the Waldorf-Astoria to Russell Jay DaSilva, son of Mr.and Mrs. Albert I. DaSilva of Kings Point, L.I. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Charles Simon.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: ANTHONY J. MONTE looked over what the visitor had brought him. He turned one shoe over, then the other, an expression of curious distaste on his face. ''What do you expect me to do with these?'' he asked.

title: HEALTH-CARE DEBATE OVER MEDICAL CENTER
description: I WOULD like to take issue with some of the assumptions and implications in the recent affirmation of the Westchester County Medical Center's role as a regional center for specialized health services.

title: RANGERS BEAT KNIGS FOR 2-1 LEAD
description: The Rangers came within one victory of clinching their preliminary-round Stanley Cup playoff last night by defeating the Los Angeles Kings, 10-3, at Madison Square Garden.

title: FARM BUREAU SEEKS 'RIGHT-TO-FARM' BILL
description: WHEN an apple grower in Bethel flew a helicopter over his 60-acre orchard last May in a late-night attempt to save his crop from frost, his neighbors complained about the noise the next day. In Manchester, neighbors of a pig farmer were so offended by the habits of the litter that they obtained a court order requring the farmer to move the animals another 300 feet from their homes.

title: THE DISMAL SCIENCE MEETS THE LIVELY ART OF POLITICS
description: As Congress continued to dissect President Reagan's proposals to cut Federal spending, the top of the budget news was once again the debate over how much, and from what, to slice. Under the surface, however, another argument was going on, over which assumptions about the future course of the economy should be used in calculating the cuts and their effects.

title: RISE OF POVERTY LANE
description: IT doesn't really sound all that upwardly mobile to edge from poverty into grayness, but for a grateful few in Clinton, that shift was sufficient.

title: SOUNDS OF EASTER: TRADITON PREVAILS
description: TRADITION and solemnity prevail in music programs throughout Westchester for this Easter season, dominated by the performances of three major oratorios.

title: On Language; ON 'EARLY ON' AND ON AND ON; by William Safire
description: On 'Early On' and On and On Kimble Mead

title: TWO NOVELS
description: HOME GROUND By Cecelia Holland. 371 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $13.95. THE OFFICERS' WIVES By Thomas Fleming. 645 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $15.95. By JANE LARKIN CRAIN

title: Dodgers 7, Astros 4
description: AT LOS ANGELES (AP) - Steve Garvey and Ron Cey got three hits each in a 12-hit Los Angeles attack that sent Houston to defeat. Burt Hooton, a right-hander, scattered 10 hits before leaving in the ninth in favor of Bobby Castillo. The relief pitcher gave up a two-run double to Jeff Leonard and a run-scoring single to Craig Reynolds before nailing down the Dodgers' second straight victory over the Astros.

title: IMPROVING IN TENNIS: IT'S NOT HOW YOU PLAY BUT WHOM YOU PLAY
description: MUCH as I hate to admit it, since I enjoy the game so much, tennis has a ''Catch 22'' that is frustrating to a great many players. And the unfortunate thing about it is that there really doesn't seem to be an easy solution.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY IN WORDS AND PICTURES
description: PHOTOGRAPHY: ESSAYS & IMAGES Illustrated Readings in the History of Photography. Edited by Beaumont Newhall. Illustrated. 327 pp. New York: The Museum of Modern Art. Distributed by New York Graphic Society. Cloth, $29.95. Paper, $14.95.

title: HARD TIMES FOR NUCLEAR POWER
description: Anthony J. Parisi, former energy correspondent of The New York Times, is now an editor with Petroleum Intelligence Weekly. By Anthony J. Parisi

title: A VOTE AGAINST STATE RACING CONTROL
description: I doubt that many among the millions of fans who have stood with a roaring crowd as some of the world's finest thoroughbreds rushed to the finish line at Aqueduct, Belmont or Saratoga have contemplated the fact that the racing they went to see and bet on has generated more than $1.2 billion in state and local tax revenue over the last 10 years.

title:
INVESTING;
THE REAL MONEY IN PAPER MONEY
description: W HILE inflation-obsessed investors have been jamming the exits to get out of currency, a small band of unusual souls has been doing the opposite -investing in paper money. They are not the ultimate contrary opinionists; they are aficionados of antique bills and rare notes. The objects of their affections beguile the eye with elaborate engravings and beautiful colors, odd shapes (hexagonal) and even odder denominations (6 1/4 cents), fascinating adjuncts to history that serve to remind just how multifarious and provisional the notion of money has been.

title: REYNOLDS: SMOKING STILL PAYS
description: SALEM, N.C. - Except for the smell of shredded tobacco wafting from the factory across the road, the mirror-faced, artlined headquarters building here could be the home of any modern conglomerate. It is a long way from the small factory, making plug chewing tobacco, that Richard Joshua Reynolds built 106 years ago.

title: Thorne G. Butler To Wed Miss Allin
description: The Right Rev. John Maury Allin, Presiding Bishop of the Episcopal Church, and Mrs. Allin of New York and Sewanee, Tenn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kelly Ann Allin, to Thorne Gordon Butler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Gordon Butler of Oyster Bay, L.I. The wedding is planned for late next month.

title: SAUSAGE FOR ALL TASTES
description: EUROPEANS have been making sausages for centuries, the spicy links apparently evolving as a way to use up precious leftover bits of beef, pork and veal. The result was a variety of international sausages flavored with native-grown herbs and spices - oregano and cumin in Greece, fennel and garlic in Italy, hot peppers in Portugal.

title: JUNIOR TENNIS TOURNEY SET TO GO
description: EDGEWATER GOVERNOR BYRNE will be swinging a racquet in support of the annual Easter Bowl junior tennis championships, which begin tomorrow at the Binghamton Racquet Club.

title: Television Week
description: And Then There Were Seven

title: JEWS UNDER STALIN
description: THE TESTAMENT By Elie Wiesel. Translated by Marion Wiesel. 346 pp. New York: Summit Books. $13.95.

title: Connecticut Housing; CONDOMINIUMS WIN TAX REBATES
description: A FEW weeks ago Richard Hamlin, who lives in the Harbor View condominiums in Stamford, received word from the tax assessor's office that made him smile. So did John V. Murray, who recently moved out of a condominium at Rowayton Woods in Norwalk.

title: DEDICATED TO DOPE
description: HIGH IN AMERICA The True Story Behind NORML and the Politics of Marijuana. By Patrick Anderson. 328 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $13.95.

title: NEW SCHOOL DISPUTE STIRRED BY COLEMAN
description: A prominent sociologist, James S. Coleman, has touched off a new round of debate over Federal educational priorities by asserting that private and parochial high schools come closer to the democratic ideal of a ''common school'' than public schools do.

title: WOMEN AND HEALTH: 'FALSE STEROTYPES' CHALLENGED FOR AGED
description: STONY BROOK IT was the kind of telephone call for help that Jane Porcino gets virtually every day. A woman whose husband had developed Alzheimer's disease - a kind of senility - wanted information, and support for her decision to keep her husband at home rather than in an institution.

title: New York to Give $200,000 For Community Arts
description: The City Department of Cultural Affairs has $200,000 available for nonprofit community-based arts organizations in low- and moderateincome neighborhoods under the federally financed Community Arts Development Program.

description: To the Editor:

title: WAY CLEAR FOR TEST
description: Space agency officials announced today that they had resolved a computer problem on the space shuttle Columbia, clearing the way for another launching attempt tomorrow morning.

title: STRONGER FOES STRUGGLE OVER LEBANON
description: Glimpsed through the smoke of battles that last week pushed this country to the brink of another civil war were clashing Syrian and Israeli interests.

title: A DANCER'S RISE FROM FLOOR TO STAGE
description: WHEN the curtain goes up Tuesday on the Paul Taylor Dance Company, a 27-year-old dancer who started her career in a Sea Cliff basement will join such guests as Mikhail Baryishnikov, Rudolf Nureyev, Hermione Gingold, Adolph Green, Betty Comden and Gwen Verdon on the stage of New York's City Center.

title: Outdoors; ALEWIVES AND SHAD KNOW ITS SPRING
description: Watching trout rising for tiny aquatic insects emerging in Cairn's Pool on New York State's Beaverkill River April 1, a vague sense of spring's arrival moved in me.

title: COSTA RICA MOVING AGAINST FOREIGN POLIITICAL EXILES
description: The Costa Rican Government, after the explosion of two terrorist bombs in San Jose last month, has begun a campaign against foreign political exiles, who have traditionally sought refuge in this tiny Central American democracy.

title:
ART;
55 YEARS OF REDFIELD AT RUTGERS GALLERY
description: NEW BRUNSWICK AN EXHIBITION that implicitly asks how long Impressionism can last as a viable style will be on view at the Rutgers University Art Gallery through next Saturday. Entitled ''Edward Redfield (1869-1965),'' the show presents a representative sampling of the artist's work over some 55 years.

title: ARMS TO CHINA: DUBIOUS MOVE
description: Warnings by American officials that the United States might sell weapons to China if the Soviet Union invades Poland raise questions whether such a threat has any serious validity. The dominant view among intelligence officials of the United

title: CALLOUS LOGIC ON THE MX MISSILE PROPOSAL
description: To the Editor:

title: POP: DEBRA BARSHA AT O'NEAL'S
description: Debra Barsha, a 22-year-old singer, songwriter and pianist who has been playing in Chelsea, has moved uptown to the New Room at O'Neal's, on the Avenue of the Americas at 57th Street, where she is using a vivid, energetic performing style to try to carry a program of songs that stay within a relatively narrow musical area.

title: Escaped Prisoner in Florida Kills Two Before Recapture
description: One of three convicted murderers who escaped from the Union Correctional Institution early today killed two persons, including a state trooper, and held a mother and her baby hostage before he was apprehended, prison officials said.

title: Critics' Choices; ART
description: It is difficult to spend time in Venice and not notice sooner or later the strange highbacked building on the Giudecca that is the headquarters of the house of Fortuny. It is like no other building in Venice, and it ought to look like an excrescence, but Venice has a way of making even the oddest buildings look perfectly at home.

title: 2 BIG FOLK FESTIVALS SCHEDULED
description: NEW BRUNSWICK TWO major celebrations of folk-life tradition, both sponsored by the New Jersey Folk Festival, will be held here next Saturday and April 25.

title: Two-Man Trucks In Double Trouble
description: Mayor Koch seemed certain last year that with the purchase of 220 two-man garbage trucks, the Sanitation Department was poised for a great leap forward in productivity. Last week, however, the City Comptroller's office reported that engineering flaws in the $71,000 vehicles were slowing sanitation workers and cutting into the productivity gains that were supposed to result from replacing threeman trucks.

title: Chess; SHORT AND TO THE POINT: AH, VICTORY, AH, YOUTH
description: Nigel Short was the surprising winner of the BBC International Tournament in London. The 15-year-old British international master won the playoff game against his compatriot, Grandmaster Anthony Miles, after he had won his qualifying section by defeating Grandmaster Svetozar Gligoric of Yugoslavia and drawing with Vlastimil Hort, a Czech grandmaster, and with me.

title: COMPUTER SLIP IS TERMED RESULT OF SIMPLE CHANCE
description: Engineers at the Johnson Space Center said yesterday that they believed they had resolved the space shuttle Columbia's computer problems by not actually solving them. If they do essentially nothing, they said, if they merely repeat yesterday's abortive launching procedure tomorrow, the spaceship's primary and backup computers should start talking to each other again on their own.

title: Natural History Museum Plans Shakespeare Festival
description: Shakespeare is coming to the American Museum of Natural History. ''Shakespeare Summerfest,'' which the museum describes as a ''threemonth cultural extravaganza,'' will be on display from June 18 to Sept. 20.

title: A Judge and His Judge
description: Judge Stanley Gartenstein of New York's Criminal Court thinks that David Ross, a 23-year-old white man, ''richly earned'' a prison sentence for berating a black policeman when the officer cited him for walking his unleashed dog in a city park. But the judge didn't give him one, saying he feared that because of the defendant's ''slight build, his mannerisms, dress, color and ethnic background,'' he would be subject to attack or sexual abuse by black prisoners.

title: A DO-IT-YOURSELF GUIDE TO REPAIRING A FLAT ROOF
description: REPAIRING leaks is much simpler on a flat roof covered with roll roofing than on a steeply sloping, shingled roof, and in most cases the do-it-yourselfer can safely and easily tackle the job.

title: The Budget Begins To Cut Both Ways
description: In the two months since Ronald Reagan went before Congress to present his version of the Federal budget, there has been much talk about, and even some votes on, his proposal to perform radical surgery on Federal spending and the tax rates at the same time. Last week, the lawmakers finally started to consider both proposals at the same time, and the Federal deficit too. That is turning out to be a painfully complicated process.

title: by Don Langer
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Don Langer is a freelance writer and instructor in photography. The architects may not have realized it, but in designing the United Nations building complex they created one of the more photogenic sites in this city. The huge, glass-fronted Secretariat building that dominates the group is unique in several aspects.

title: A SURVIVOR'S DESIGNS
description: Tommy Hilfiger is a survivor. When he started his juniorsportswear company a year ago the Western look was the rage, so he called his line Rodeo.

title: TURKISH JUNTA PLANS CHANGES FAR WIDER THAN INITIAL AIMS
description: Turkey's military rulers are planning broad changes that go far beyond the aims they stated when they seized power last Sept. 12, raising the question of how long the generals intend to stay in power.

title: City Council Units List Meetings for the Week
description: The following City Council meetings have been scheduled for this week: MONDAY - Committee on Finance, City Hall, 9 A.M.; Committee on Public Safety, City Hall, 10 A.M.; Committee on Housing and Buildings, City Hall, 12:30 P.M.

title: IN CINNCINNATI, LAST DOESN'T MEAN LEAST
description: ''If the world comes to an end, I want to be in Cincinnati,'' Mark Twain is said to have said, ''because everything happens there 10 years later.''

title: British Firm on Terrorists Despite I.R.A. Man's Victory
description: A British Government spokesman in Northern Ireland said today that Thursday's election to Parliament of an imprisoned Irish Republican Army member would not move Britain to grant inmates convicted of terrorism the status of political prisoners.

title: BROKERS SEEK HELP ON FEES
description: Concern is rising among residential real-estate brokers in New York State over the collection of fees, brokers' representative report. They tell of sellers who refuse to pay the broker a commission at closing, or who pay only a percentage of the commission, even though the broker possesses a signed contract from the seller stating that a commission is due and what the amount is to be.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: IT'S still a year away from opening officially, but that's not stopping Nassau County's Cradle of Aviation Museum from doing business in two hangars at Mitchel Field. With 13 planes already acquired and in place, professional museum personnel are supervising the work of 120 volunteers who are building from scratch copies of three more historic planes.

title: Music; SIMBURY TROUPE'S 'PIRATES OF PENZANCE'
description: WHEN the Simsbury Light Opera Company selected ''The Pirates of Penzance'' for its spring production, it ''did not anticipate the New York version,'' said Ann Kendall, the company's publicity chairman. ''It is our hope, of course, that we can benefit from the current popularity of the show rather than be obscured by it.''

title: Connecticut Guide; GOOD OLD EGG
description: Although not the kind usually associated with Easter, 14 troodon's eggs that are 70 million years old, cracked at the ends and minus their yolks, are worth seeing.

title: RUNNING, LOSING AND LEARNING
description: LAST year, I ran as a Democratic candidate for the State Legislature against an intrenched incumbent. I was decidedly the underdog, but felt I had nothing to lose and had the opportunity to raise some important issues, which I did. I lost by a substantial margin, but made many friends and, for a new political face, did not do badly. I also enjoyed myself thoroughly and learned a lot about the political system that is not found in books.

title: And More About Women and Men
description: In response to the responses evoked by Jane Lee Anderson's Opinion piece that asked ''Why Can't a Woman Be More Like a Man?'' (Jan. 25), and to the lady from Metuchen who ended with ''I am not amused,'' I would like to say that some women, myself included, were amused. And to quote Plutarch: ''He who is serious about ridiculous matters is apt to be ridiculous about serious matters.'' CLAIRE GERBER Port Republic

title: Cabinet Lifts Some Rules of the Road For Auto Makers
description: The Reagan Administration may be sharply divided on limiting imports on Japanese cars, but last week it cheerfully gave the domestic automobile industry something else Detroit dearly wants. A Cabinet-level task force proposed to ease or eliminate 35 air quality and safety regulations.

title: Ford Foundation Issues an Agenda
description: Given its financial resources of $2.8 billion, Ford Foundation's pronouncements are to some worth their weight in gold. In the latest, issued after a 9-month review of its policy and structure, the country's wealthiest philanthropic organization has come out with a broad agenda for the next decade.

title: Fashion; SUMMER GOLD
description: SUMMER GOLD Once, gold clothes were worn for formal evening events. But this summer, fabrics ranging from metallic leathers to silks shot with gold thread have turned up in simple shapes for daytime wear.

title: A DIP IN U.S. EXPORTS
description: While American's decline in world markets has been well chronicled, The United States nonetheless remains the world's most important exporter.

title: JAZZ: DON GROLNICK RELAXES
description: One of the more talented and inventive of New York's session musicians, Don Grolnick, the keyboard player, has assembled a band and is displaying it through today at that home of session musicians relaxing with jazz, Seventh Avenue South.

title: SUPPORT HAS FADED FOR JOBS PROGRAM
description: Three years ago, when the Federal Government was spending almost $10 billion a year on public service employment, any suggestion that the program be abolished was met with spirited protests from elected officials around the country.

title: by Hans Fantel
description: When Charles Darwin put apes in our pedigree -along with reptiles and other slinky creatures -mankind suffered an identity crisis from which it has not yet recovered. Hoping to tell us who we are, anthropologists have been looking for some mark unique to humanity, and the current fashion in some academic circles is to define man as a myth-making animal. As far as anyone can tell, we are singular in our habit of interpreting reality through fiction.

title: PARMA AND ITS SPECIALTIES
description: My husband and I had packed the usual guidebooks for Rome, Florence and Venice, intending our trip to be an introduction to the art, history and culture of Italy. But we had also brought a list of restaurants, gathered from friends who had eaten their way around the country. We had included Parma, midway between Florence and Venice, on our itinerary because we had been told that there we could eat the finest examples of two of Italy's most distinctive contributions to world cuisine - prosciutto and Parmesan cheese.

title: Editor in Iran Denounces Closure Of Paper as Unjustifiable in Law
description: An editor of the leading Teheran newspaper Mizan, shut down last week by the Government after its managing editor was arrested, declared today that the action was unjustifed and pledged to fight for a free press in Iran.

title: Big Eight Pledges Help in Inquiry
description: The commissioner of the Big Eight, Carl James, said yesterday that the conference would ''cooperate fully'' with a Federal investigation of allegations that three conference basketball games late this season were fixed, according to a report by The Associated Press.

title: A CAPITAL MUSEUM THAT INVITES KIDS TO PARTICIPATE
description: A small, dark-haired girl in a construction worker's hard hat popped her head out of an open manhole and shouted in joyful discovery: ''Hey, there's a car up here!''

title: POOR-AREA DOCTORS TO RECEIVE SUBSIDIES
description: The Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center has announced plans to place family physicians in subsidized neighborhood practices in Washington Heights on condition they provide a specified amount of free care to the poor.

title: TENNIS PLAYER, 86, IN UNCROWDED FIELD
description: BRISTOL RALPH STRONG would be the first to admit that he has lost a few steps through the years and that he no longer strokes a tennis ball as hard as he once did. But Mr. Strong has compensated for a loss of speed and power by becoming a more guileful player, relying more on chips, slices and drop shots as he did in winning the North American clay-courts title for his age group in Charlottesville, Va., last September.

title: A CONTRASTING WEDDING IN '63
description: The last weeding of a sitting Governor of New York took place on a spring Saturday nearly 18 years ago, when Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller and Margaretta Filter Murphy were married in a ceremony very different from yesterday's wedding of Governor Carey and Evangeline Gouletas.

title: PEKING SAYS MAO'S MERITS OUTWEIGH HIS MISTAKES
description: A long article by a senior Communist Party official evaluating the pros and cons of Mao Zedong's role in Chinese history appeared in all national newspapers today. The publication was regarded here as a sign that the party leadership, after long debate, might have reached a consensus on how to fit the late party Chairman's powerful shadow into the present political scene.

title: WATERFRONT REVIVAL IN NEW ROCHELLE
description: NEW ROCHELLE AS the signs of spring awaken yearnings in mariners and landlubbers to ''go down to the seas again,'' the New Rochelle Municipal Marina, with its vistas of ships, seagulls and its own refurbished image, beckons.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Ensemble Instrumental, French String Players
description: The Ensemble Instrumental de France, which made its New York debut Monday night at Carnegie Hall, was founded in 1968 by Jean-Pierre Wallez, a violinist. For its current tour, it consists of 12 string players plus a harpsichordist.

title: A Mayoral 'First,'; And Room to Spare
description: Maybe it shouldn't have been all that startling that City Councilman Henry Cisneros was elected mayor of San Antonio. He's photogenic and young - only 33 - a Harvard graduate who has close ties to the business community and who did a tour in Washington back when that was a respectable thing to do.

title: Jerome Raymond Weds Miss Ruiz
description: Marisabel Ruiz and Jerome Edward Raymond, both of New York, were married here yesterday in the Village Temple by Rabbi Dennis Math. The bride, a member of the department of special education of Kean College in Union, N.J., is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Atahualpa Ruiz of Quito, Ecuador.

title: Notes; EXCURSIONS AND EVENTS ON SPRING WEEKENDS
description: Spring signals new signs of life in the world of tourism as well as in the countryside and gardens. As the flowers begin to bloom and the days lengthen, more and more travelers set out on weekend trips, and the options available to them multiply.

title: AMERICA THE VARIOUS
description: THE ETHNIC MYTH Race, Ethnicity and Class in America. By Stephen Steinberg. 277 pp. New York: Atheneum. $14.95.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Water-Fueled Car
description: To some people, Sam Leslie Leach's idea for a car in the 1970's seemed about as practical as a scheme for a wooden engine. Mr. Leach, a multimillionaire inventor in southern California, proposed to run his car on water instead of gasoline.

title: RANGERS BEAT KINGS FOR 2-1 LEAD
description: The New York Islanders advanced to the quarterfinals of the National Hockey League playoffs tonight when they beat the Toronto Maple Leafs, 6-1, for a three-game sweep of their preliminary-round series. Their opponent for the next round, which starts Thursday night at Nassau Coliseum in Uniondale, L.I., will be either the Pittsburgh Penguins or the Edmonton Oilers.

title: INQUIRY INTO JORDAN ASSAULT FINDING NEW LINKS TO RACIST
description: Federal investigators say they are continuing to develop evidence connecting Joseph Paul Franklin, an avowed racist who was recently convicted in the slayings of two black men in Salt Lake City, with the sniper shooting here last May 29 of Vernon E. Jordan Jr., the civil rights leader.

title: APPRAISING A BENEFIT CONCERT ALBUM
description: From Bangladesh to No Nukes, rock has had a noble history of starstudded benefit concerts. A series that attracted relatively little attention in this country when it occurred was the Concerts for the People of Kampuchea -Kampuchea being Cambodia, whose travails in recent years could certainly use help from any source. These concerts took place on Dec. 26, 27, 28 and 29, 1979 in London's Hammersmith Odeon. They were organized by Paul McCartney and stocked entirely by British artists - well, Chrissie Hynde is an American, but she lives in Britain and her band, the Pretenders, is British. The proceedings were recorded and filmed, and now the album, ''Concerts for the People of Kampuchea,'' has been released in this country (Atlantic SD 2-7005, two disks).

title: Homefinders
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I walked in here - I'm going to walk out.'' - President Reagan, leaving the hospital. (1:6.)

title: Who Are Tellers for Welfare Data Bank?
description: Having proposed a reduction in the size of the Federal Government's figurative safety net - the social service programs that would be left in place to help the certifiably poor - the Administration now wants to shake deadbeats out of the net with the help of a nationwide central data bank.

title: VIEWS FROM TWO SIDES ON HOW TO VAULT THE COLOR BAR
description: THE election of a conservative President and the apparent disillusionment of many voters with traditional modes of liberalism have recently brought unaccustomed attention to black conservatives. Academics and businessmen for the most part, they are dissenters from what some call the ''liberal orthodoxy'' of established civil rights leaders. In many respects, their views coincide with Ronald Reagan's and they are likely to be heard from in coming months on issues such as tax credits for private school tuition, a proposal that gained support last week from a new study by Dr. James S. Coleman, the sociologist, who concluded that private high schools provide a better education than public schools. To explore the ideas of the black conservatives and how they contrast with those of the traditional black leadership, Don Wycliff, an editor of The Week in Review, interviewed separately Dr. Walter E. Williams, a professor of economics at George Mason University in Fairfax, Va., and a leading exponent of black conservative views, and Benjamin L. Hooks, the president of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. Excerpts from the interviews follow:

title: Mimi Dolph to Be Wed to Steven M. Adkins
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas P. Ford of New York and Madison, Conn., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Ford's daughter, Mary Early Dolph, to Steven Michael Adkins, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Steven Adkins Jr. of Easton, Conn., and Madison.

title: Reggae Star Said to Have Cancer
description: Bob Marley, the Jamaican reggae singer, is suffering from cancer of the brain, his wife, Rita, said today. She said that Mr. Marley, 36 years old, was at a clinic in Munich for treatment.

title: HOW THE THREE NETWORKS TREAT BREAKING NEWS
description: The story was real, frighteningly real. Yet, in the course of a full week, television's coverage began to take on the dimensions of an elaborate scenario. The production could have been called ''The Shooting of the President,'' complete with vivid on-the-spot news footage and inevitable entertainment values. As usual in any major news story, from assassination plots to moon landings to returning hostages, television became a significant part of the event itself. On a fairly quiet Monday afternoon, ABC was the first to telephone my office about the attempt on Ronald Reagan's life, naturally anxious to announce that it had beat its network competitors to the air. Television had begun its peculiar job of informing and reassuring, of startling and lulling. Before 3 o'clock, all three networks were maintaining a national vigil that would remain unbroken for several hours.

title: Millions For Tribute
description: A curious phenomenon of the Reagan Administration, little noticed as yet, is its energy policy. Or rather its two policies. For on the crucial question of imported oil the Administration speaks with two conflicting voices.

title: AFGHAN GROUP SEES TRADITIONS MELTING AWAY
description: Eight men sat cross-legged on the carpeted floor of the army-style tent. The tent itself stood roughly in the center of Kachigarhi I, a vast, sprawling camp on the outskirts of this old British military garrison town.

title: NEW RELEASES FROM A COMPANY DEVOTED TO AMERICAN MUSIC
description: In 1978, New World Records completed its project to present a comprehensive overview of American music on 100 disks - a magnificent collection, as it turned out, that explored virtually every phase of our varied musical life from the past 300 years. The company has been less active of late but by no means idle. A year ago four records were released documenting music by Cecil Taylor (NW 300), San Pueblo Indian chants (NW 301), string quartets by Walter Piston and Roger Sessions (NW 302) and a recital of contemporary piano music played by Bradford Gowen (NW 303). Presently at hand are five new issues with the promise of more to come in the near future.

title: THE DISTURBED CHILD CHALLENGES A FAMILY
description: SHE arrives home from the day hospital center at 5 P.M. and goes to her room, where she watches television or takes a nap. And generally, things are all right, except on those days when she hears voices that tell her what to do. ''There's a good voice and a bad voice and they have names,'' her father said, speaking about the personal demons of his adult daughter, who, many years ago, was diagnosed as schizophrenic.

title: Alison D. Keller, Aide of Chemical Bank, Is the Bride of Charles Coe Townsend 3d
description: Alison Dixon Keller and Charles Coe Townsend 3d were married yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest by the Rev. Alan Houghton. Louisa D. Keller was her sister's maid of honor and James P. Snedeker was best man.

title: ON THE DECLINE OF PUBLIC TELEVISION
description: To the Editor:

title: WELFARE
description: To the Business Editor: I was disappointed in Rudolph Penner's "How Fair is Welfare?" (March 29). The issues are not "how much?" or "for whom?" The issue is what are we expecting this system to accomplish.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Here Comes the Taxman

title: CANADIAN BANK SIGNS MIDTOWN LEASE
description: The Bank of Montreal has purchased the leasehold of 430 Park Avenue, the 18-story office building that occupies the entire west blockfront between 55th and 56th Street.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
MAKING A MOCKERY OF HOLIDAYS
description: THERE was a time when Washington - Washington, D.C., that is - was described by sports-minded patriots as ''First in war, first in peace and last in the American League.''

title: Flames 5, Black Hawks 4
description: CHICAGO (AP) - Willi Plett of Calgary scored the winning goal on a 40-foot slap shot at 15 minutes 17 seconds of the second sudden-death overtime period.

title: 'THE DEMENTED VICE OF A PRIZED VIRTUE'
description: To the Editor:

title: WINGING IT TO WASHINGTON
description: Francis X. Clines is a reporter for The Times's Washington bureau. By Francis X. Clines uring an awful day of delays at New York City's La Guardia Airport, a planeload of Eastern Air Lines shuttle passengers were kept strapped and wondering in their narrowly packed seats and, as precious business time slipped by, some of them tried to rebel creatively. At the instigation of Carl Bernstein, Washington bureau chief of ABC News, they composed a group letter of complaint to Frank Borman, Eastern's chief executive.

title: NEW STUDY IS PESSIMISTIC ON NATION'S OIL POTENTIAL
description: A two-year study for the Federal Government has concluded that the prospects of finding more oil and gas in the United States are severely limited. Future discoveries will be considerably smaller than most analysts have predicted, the study says, and output will fall faster than expected.

title: James R. Stewart Fiance of Carla Call
description: Mr. and Mrs. Norman L. Campbell of South Burlington, Vt., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Campell's daughter, Carla Call, to James Randall Stewart, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leslie Stewart of Wetumpka, Ala.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Michael Soloway Offers Wide-Ranging Guitar Bill
description: A young guitarist, Michael Soloway, made an impressive debut at Carnegie Recital Hall last Sunday. Debut concerts such as these tend often to be lonely affairs; but on this occasion, the hall was virtually packed with friends and admirers, and indeed there was much for them to admire.

title: Camera; PINHOLE CAMERAS CAN GIVE SURPRISING RESULTS; by Bruce Habegger
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Bruce Habegger teaches photography at City College and at the Educational Alliance.

title: Best Sellers; FICTION
description: 1 1 25 THE COVENANT, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $17.95.) Fifteen thousand years of South African history. 2 2 13 MASQUERADE, by Kit Williams. (Schocken Books, $9.95.) A fantastic tale about the Sun, the Moon and a lost treasure. 3 3 8 CENTURY, by Fred Mustard Stewart. (Morrow, $13.95.) Saga of an Italian-American family. 4 4 9 BRAIN, by Robin Cook. (Putnam's, $11.95.) A young physician copes with a conspiracy of medical researchers who steal young women's brains to create an artificial intelligence. 5 5 5 THE COMPANY OF WOMEN, by Mary Gordon. (Random House, $12.95.) One modern young woman's experience with the manners and mores of Roman Catholicism. 6 6 16 ANSWER AS A MAN, by Taylor Caldwell. (Putnam's, $12.95.) A man who has made it big in early 20th-century America struggles against the corruption that engulfs his life. 7 8 3 THE DELTA DECISION, by Wilbur Smith. (Doubleday, $12.95.) A plot to unite international terrorist groups into one global organization. 8 1 REFLEX, by Dick Francis. (Putnam's,

title: AMONG FALLEN INNOCENTS
description: LIFETIME By Scott Sommer. 208 pp. New York: Random House. $9.95.

title: Enquirer Seeking a New Trial
description: The National Enquirer filed motions in Superior Court yesterday seeking to overturn a $1.6 million libel judgment for publishing an item about Carol Burnett. The motions asked the court to void a jury's verdict for lack of evidence and grant a new trial. Judge Peter Smith is expected to rule on the motions by May 27.

title: Dr. Claire Flanagan Wed to David Duhaime
description: Dr. Claire Marie Flanagan, a pediatric resident at the Children's Hospital in Philadelphia, was married yesterday to David Edmund Duhaime, a psychologist. The Rev. William V. Reynolds performed the ceremony in St. Augustine's Roman Catholic Church in Larchmont, N.Y.

title: CONNECTICUT CURBS ON WATER ASSAILED
description: PORT CHESTER THIS village and two other Westchester municipalities that get their water from Connecticut are chafing under drought-induced restrictions while the Connecticut reservoirs have recovered to more than 80 percent of capacity.

title: RECITAL: DANIEL WAITZMAN, FLUTIST
description: Daniel Waitzman played six 18th-century pieces with flutes from three eras at the Abraham Goodman House on Thursday and still neatly avoided giving his audience a history lesson. Mr. Waitzman seemed less interested in niceties of authenticity than in how his instruments blended with the particular textures of each piece. Especially attractive was the conical Boehm instrument - a sweet-sounding compromise between its husky Baroque predecessor and the modern flute.

title: Critics' Choices; DANCE
description: DANCE Elisa Monte is indisputably one of the most striking dancers in the Martha Graham Dance Company. Anyone who has seen her Electra tearing around the stage with vengeful fury in Miss Graham's ''Clytemnestra'' can testify to the dramatic presence Miss Monte conveys through energy alone.

title: 'Doing' the City
description: While still a student at Texas A & M, Henry Cisneros, the son of Mexican immigrants, attended a public policy conference in West Point, N.Y. In his words, ''I was totally outclassed by students from Williams, Harvard and Stanford.'' But pride took hold. Mr. Cisneros decided that ''the city is what I want to do.''

title: THE 'WHITE CASTLE OF LOUISIANA' IS OPENED TO THE PUBLIC
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- BOB SUMMER writes a column about books and publishing for the Baton Rouge Sunday Advocate Magazine. By BOB SUMMER

title: NOMADIC LIFE TOOK A DRAMATIC TURN
description: THE young Richard X. France would hardly have been considered ''the most likely to succeed.'' His mother died when he was about 6 years old. He grew up as the son of an Army officer in postwar Japan, and in Australia and West Germany. By the age of 17, he had flunked out of high school and was drifting.

title:
DINING OUT;
A TOUCH OF ELEGANCE IN CHATHAM
description: RELOCATING The Tarragon Tree from Meyersville to Chatham has enabled Dennis Foy, its chef-owner, to add the elegance that was missing before. The new dining room is decorated in the soft colors found in a Fragonard painting, and the pristine napery, gleaming silver, pretty flowered china, flower-filled bud vases and comfortable seats add to the pleasure of dining here.

title: Clouds Gathering In Congress Over Voting Rights Act
description: The Voting Rights Act of 1965, a product of the turbulent times when civil rights had a higher priority than a balanced budget, has been renewed twice before, in 1970 and 1975.

title: CONCERT: BARTOK'S 'KOSSUTH'
description: Taken together, all the performances of this year's Bartok centennial celebration form a composite of one composer's life in music; and certainly no biography is complete without a few sins of youth to add to it. Friday evening at Alice Tully Hall, the Juilliard Orchestra helped fill in our portrait of Bartok as a very young artist with a performance of his ''Kossuth,'' a symphonic poem written in 1903 - five years before the first string quartets -but only now receiving its New York premiere.

title: BARYSHNIKOV EXPLAINS REHIRING OF MISS KIRKLAND
description: Mikhail Baryshnikov, the artistic director of the American Ballet Theater, said he had rehired Gelsey Kirkland, who is scheduled to rejoin the company tonight in its final performance at the Kennedy Center in Washington, because ''I respect her enormously as an artist even though she does not seem to return that feeling.''

title: HABITAT SAID TO IMPERIL BLUE HERONS
description: TRENTON THE great blue heron, a large, long-legged wading bird, continues to be threatened by loss of its habitat, according to a state biologist.

title: FIRST PERSON SINGULAR
description: IN a way, it's a stage with a horrendous play in continuous performance. In a way, it's a fishing expedition. It's sad. It's forced gaiety. It's purchasing a few hours of superficial gibberish along with the drinks and the Latin music. It's the singles bar, whose clientele seems to have become amply diluted with cheaters along the way.

title: Irish Prisoner Wins an Election
description: Robert Sands, a young leader of the Irish Republican Army Provisionals, insists that the 14-year prison sentence he received for possessing a gun and some ammunition was really political punishment. Last week he achieved a political impact of his own through more traditional means, winning a British parliamentary byelection without leaving his bed at Maze prison near Belfast, where he has been on hunger strike since March 1.

title: 2 OLD DISCUS THROWERS HAVE A REUNION AT MEET
description: Al Oerter, who returned to discusthrowing competition in 1977 after having been an Olympian four times, made his annual appearance at the C.W. Post Relays today, looking toward the 1984 Games.

title: Returnable Bottles: A Little Arithmetic
description: The recent article ''Wide Impact Seen in Deposit-Bottle Bill'' states that one of the arguments against returnable bottles is that they will make ''prices go up on all beverages, perhaps as much as $4 or $5 a case.''

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
TUNING IN TO THE EMBROIDERED ALLIGATOR'S SUBTLE CALL
description: A RECENT newspaper article presented a composite profile of one of President Reagan's top White House aides. His dress was described as follows: ''At work, he wears dark, conservative suits; at play, khakis, Lacoste shirts and tasseled loafers.''

title: Miss McWhirter And Brian Hughes Will Wed Aug. 29
description: Dr. and Mrs. William Robert McWhirter of Greenville, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cynthia Rae McWhirter, to Brian Blake Hughes, son of Mr. and Mrs. Blake Hughes of Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y.

title: Session on Power-Boat Safety
description: In the aftermath of a recent collision in which a driver was killed, the Offshore Commission of the American Power Boat Association has scheduled an emergency session for Wednesday in Freeport, the Bahamas, to tighten safety procedures.

title: Klansmen Stoned in San Jose
description: Some 20 white-robed members of the Ku Klux Klan broke off a rally today as demonstrators hurled stones and cans and chanted ''Death, death, death to the Klan!'' At least 15 protesters were arrested. The authorities said that several people were treated at hospitals for minor injuries.

title: REWRITING REGULATION; BY STEPHEN J. FRIEDMAN
description: E VOLUTION in the financial markets has outpaced our regulatory structure in form and content. Banks, savings institutions, securities firms, investment managers and others have responded to the economic and institutional changes produced by dizzying inflation, the growth of pension funds and other forms of institutionalized savings, with imagination and vigor.

title: Douglas Burger to Wed Nancy McClelland
description: Nancy Marie McClelland, manager of the juniors and nouvelle clothing departments at Neiman Marcus in White Plains, and Douglas Hyatt Burger, who is with Combine of Fairfield Inc., restaurant owners in Connecticut and Westchester County, plan to be married June 13 in New York.

title: ASSAD ASSAILS AN 'IMPERIALIST, ZIONIST' PLOT IN LEBANON
description: President Hafez al-Assad of Syria said in a speech in Damascus tonight that the fighting in Lebanon was part of an ''imperialist, Zionist'' plot to fragment Lebanon and use its territory for strikes against Syria.

title:
GARDENING;
LANDSCAPING TO MEET CHALLENGING INTERESTS
description: NOTHING appears quite so desolate as a newly built house devoid of planting, except, of course, an entire development of such houses. But once plantings are in place, a slow transition begins and in 15 to 20 years most houses take on a more inviting and habitable appearance.

title: THE RETURN OF THE RADIO NETWORK
description: S OMEWHERE back in the murky days of yesteryear, decades before the advent of Laverne and Shirley and Archie and Edith, network radio ruled the air waves. Now, while much of the media world stands agog at the upheavals to be wrought by new video technologies, a curious radio revolution is occurring. The old radio networks are storming back, and new ones are being formed at an astonishing pace.

title: RECENT HOME SALES
description: Bloomingdale 32 Bogue Drive 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath split-level $72,000 Patio, one-car garage.

title: SOME CONCERN TRY TO KEEP OLDER WORKERS ON JOB
description: After three days of discussing and debating with one another, 70 representatives of industry, labor, government and education have concluded that older workers are a wasted resource and have drawn up a set of recommendations for keeping them on the job longer.

title: Dr. Drucy Borowitz Bride of a Surgeon
description: Dr. Drucy Sarette B. Borowitz and Dr. Philip Leon Glick were married yesterday at the Community Synagogue in Sands Point, L.I. Rabbi Eugene B. Borowitz, the bride's father who became president of the American Theological Society yesterday, performed the ceremony.

title: CATHOLIC BISHOP URGES A HALT TO MX MISSILE SYSTEM
description: Less than five months ago, the Rev. William K. Weigand was a parish priest in Homedale, Idaho, population 2,078, on the banks of the Snake River near the Oregon border. He had recently learned he would become Bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Salt Lake City, and he said he wanted to make his church, in Mormon Utah, ''as visible as possible.'' Yesterday he took on the Pentagon.

title: No Headline
description: Someone must be kidding to have brought the case of Rhodes v. Chapman to the Supreme Court. I'll bet that many of the inmates complaining of overcrowding not only slept two to a room at home, but probably slept two or more to a bed.

title: Turkey's Turquoise Coast
description: To the Editor:

title: Antitrust Chief Starting Out Big
description: If Ronald Reagan didn't want William F. Baxter's job just to be a ''caretaker,'' neither, apparently, did Mr. Baxter, the new chief of the antitrust division in the Justice Department. Last week, over the objections of the Defense Department, Mr. Baxter rejected a Carter Administration proposal for settlement of the Government's longstanding suit against American Telephone & Telegraph Company and said he would ''litigate it to the eyeballs.''

title: TOXIC WASTE'S TIES TO CRIME SOUGHT BY STATE AND U.S.
description: FOR six months, law enforcement authorities have been gathering evidence that they hope soon will show an organized conspiracy to dispose of hazardous wastes illegally in at least three counties in northern New Jersey.
