title: ROACHES EAT BEDBUGS, TOADS EAT ROACHES
description: THE LIVING AMERICAN HOUSE The 350-Year Story of a Home - An Ecological History. By George Ordish. Illustrated. 320 pp. New York: William Morrow & Co. $12.95. By NOEL PERRIN

title: WATSON LEADS NICKLAUS BY ONE
description: Tom Watson overtook Jack Nicklaus in the third round of the 45th Masters today, wiping out Nicklaus's fourstroke lead, and even moving ahead by four, before finishing with a one-shot advantage.

title: New Assembly in Seoul Holds Its Opening Session
description: South Korea's new National Assembly, working under a new Constitution and dominated by President Chun Doo Hwan's Democratic Justice Party, held its first session today.

title: SHORT STORIES
description: DESIRES By John L'Heureux 180 pp. New York: Holt, Rinehart and Winston. $12.95. NOTHING TO DO WITH LOVE By Joyce Reiser Kornblatt. 208 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $11.95. By JOHANNA KAPLAN

title: Music View; IT WAS A SHORT BUT LUCKY MET SEASON
description: You remember the old joke: no matter how late you get to ''Tristan'' there are always two acts left. That, in retrospect, is how the Metropolitan Opera's 1980-81 season has seemed. The season, on which the curtain comes down this week, actually was more than a third over before it began, thanks to that needlessly long and needlessly wounding labor dispute. But what about the two acts that were left? It is time to make some appraisals.

title: EXPERIMENT FOR URBAN AREAS: 'ENTERPRISE ZONE'
description: OUR country was founded on the idea of free enterprise. Two hundred years later another idea, enterprise zones, is helping to revitalize the country.

title: BUYING A COUNTRY HOME
description: I N spring, a family's fancy often turns to thoughts of fields and streams, and a house nearby to enjoy them. This spring may be the best time in years to set out in quest of such a second home, provided the family has plenty of cash to ease the pain of high mortgage rates.

title: LATE SURVEY SHOWS WIDE LEAD FOR LEVESQUE
description: The last polls in Quebec's election campaign continued today to show a surprising lead for Premier Rene Levesque and his nationalist Parti Quebecois in Monday's election of a provincial legislature.

title: Defector-Coach May Face Problems Here
description: Bela Karolyi has found a new roof over his head, but he has not necessarily found a new home, at least as a gymnastics coach. The Rumanian defector, who rose to international fame as the coach and discoverer of the Olympic champion Nadia Comaneci, will run into problems as a coach in America that he did not encounter in Eastern Europe, according to United States gymnastics officials.

title: DEDEAUX OF SOUTHERN CAL: HE MAKES MAJOR LEAGUERS
description: LOS ANGELES TWO things a baseball player knows when he enrolls at the University of Southern California: he has a good chance of playing in the major leagues and an even better chance at wearing a garish red wig in an airport lobby.

title: RED SMITH
description: AS Dave Winfield finished his last turn in the batting cage and walked to the bench with his long, loose stride, a boy just behind the dugout said, ''Hello, Dave.'' Winfield looked up and smiled. It was a warm smile, unforced, and it showed gleaming teeth. Then the richest Yankee went on about his business.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: Reagan's First 3 Months
description: The Congress will be in recess for the next couple of weeks, so for all practical purposes of legislation, President Reagan's first hundred days in office are over.

title: FUND URGED AS GUARD AGAINST DISHONEST LAWYERS
description: Acknowledging a problem that few lawyers discuss publicly, the State Bar Association adopted a resolution today asking the Legislature to set up a fund to reimburse victims of their own lawyers' financial dishonesty.

title: RADIOACTIVE CENTER BARRED BY LYNBROOK
description: LYNBROOK AFTER impassioned warnings from residents, the Board of Trustees has made Lynbrook the first village on the Island to ban the processing, storing and distribution of radioactive materials. Representatives of a company that sought to establish a regional radioisotope center here say the ban will be injurious to the public health, but would not say whether they would take legal action to try to overcome it.

title: REACHING THE SOVIET PEOPLE
description: Whatever differences of opinion there may be about President Reagan's policies, there is near-unanimous agreement that he has mastered the use of the electronic media to communicate with the people.

title: JUST A REGULATED DAY IN THE LIFE OF AN ORDINARY CITIZEN
description: At 6:45 A.M. on Friday, the low murmur of a digital clock woke Patricia Mathews, resident of an apartment building on upper Connecticut Avenue. Eyes closed, she reached out from the warmth of her down comforter, pressed off the alarm and, after stretching herself fully awake, got out of bed and headed for the kitchen, pausing first to flick on a television news program.

title: MRS. HARRIS BEGINS AS PRISON TEACHER'S AIDE
description: JEAN S. HARRIS, sentenced last month to 15 years to life for the murder of Dr. Herman Tarnower, started work as a teacher's aide at the Bedford Hills Correctional Facility last week, and she has already received praise from at least one fellow inmate.

title: POLITICS AN POEMS
description: COMING ALIVE China After Mao. By Roger Garside. Illustrated. 458 pp. New York: McGraw-Hill Book Company. $12.95.

title: New York Schoolboy Stars Defeat Long Island, 100-96
description: Dwayne Johnson, a 6-foot-7-inch forward from Mater Christi in Astoria, Queens, scored 27 points to lead the New York City team to a 100-96 victory over Long Island today in a high school basketball all-star game at Nassau Coliseum.

title: THE SUBTLE ARTISTRY OF THE MISSION FURNITURE OF HARVEY ELLIS
description: Master designers are rare in any period. And the turn-of-thecentury was no exception. The spare, squarish Mission furniture that emerged from the late 1890's until World War I was the work of several extremely gifted designer-architects -Charles Rennie Mackintosh in Glasgow, Josef Hoffmann in Vienna and Frank Lloyd Wright in Buffalo and Chicago.

title: Patricia Simon Is Bride Of Henry M. Bretherton
description: Patricia Leigh Simon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Simon of Sarasota, Fla., and Henry Montgomery Bretherton, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Ord Bretherton of Philadelphia, were married yesterday at St. James Epsicopal Church in New York. The Rev Ann B. Jones performed the ceremony.

title: Nancy C. Weymouth Married
description: Nancy Clayton Weymouth, a broadcast business manager at Wells Rich Greene, a New York advertising agency, was married yesterday in Bronxville, N. Y., to Harold George Mercer of Bronxville, national sales manager in New York for Bloomsburg Mills. The Rev. James Zwernemann performed the ceremony in the Village Lutheran Church. Mr. and Mrs. E. Grayson Weymouth Jr. of Hancock, N.H., are the parents of the bride. Mr. Mercer, whose former marriage ended in divorce, is the son of Mrs. William Ludlum Mercer of Bronxville and the late Mr. Mercer.

title: A Better Idea
description: A fare increase wasn't the only thing on the minds of transit officials last week. After two months of study, a team of former corporate executives found that conditions at the Transit Authority's headquarters were nearly as bad as those on the IRT.

title: BAXTER ON A.T.&T.
description: A split appeared in the Reagan Administration last week over the Government's pursuit of the antitrust case against A.T.&T.

title: FRENCH ELECTION POLLS PAINT BLURRED PICTURE
description: The first round of the presidential election, which pares down about 10 contenders to two finalists, is two weeks away. The official campaign, according to law, begins at the end of this week, but intensive campaigning has been going on for more than a month, with the four major candidates swinging regularly around the country and blitzing the television screens to the point of snowblindness.

title: THE HANDICAPPED: SCHOOL ROLE DEBATED
description: A NEW Federal law requiring schools to assume responsibility for searching out and evaluating handicapped children from birth through the age of 21 is creating consternation among some Connecticut doctors and clinical psychologists.

title: PHILHARMONIC: KUBELIK
description: For this round of New York Philharmonic subscription concerts at Avery Fisher Hall, Rafael Kubelik is conducting Beethoven's Symphony No. 9, all 72 minutes' worth - minus one repeat in the second movement. Because we hear continuously and rightly about the danger of overexposure to the classics, one must wonder about a presentation of this particular masterpiece when there seems no compelling reason to hear it now, under these circumstances, with this conductor.

title: 'Big Brother' Lives In Briarcliff Manor
description: In regard to '' 'Big Brother' Is Racing '1984' Deadline'' by Charles E. Rodgers Jr. (March 22), I note that Mr. Rodgers is a resident of Briarcliff Manor.

title: MUSIC: COMBINED TALENTS
description: It only takes a drop of the proverbial hat for solo musicians to join forces in a concert of chamber music these days. When the chemistry is right, no matter how ad hoc the instrumental combination might seem, the musical results can be stimulating for all concerned if the performers are evenly matched and temperamentally in tune.

title: Quake Jolts Southern Japan City
description: A fairly strong earthquake shook this southern Japanese city today with an intensity of four on the Japanese scale of seven. The police said there were no reports of casualties or damage.

title:
GARDENING;
LANDSCAPING TO MEET CHALLENGING INTERESTS
description: NOTHING appears quite so desolate as a newly built house devoid of planting, except, of course, an entire development of such houses. But once plantings are in place, a slow transition begins and in 15 to 20 years most houses take on a more inviting and habitable appearance.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; 3 Established Players Form Chamber Ensemble
description: New York's chamber-music establishment took on a distinguished new member last Sunday afternoon with the debut of the Stoltzman-Trampler-Luvisi Trio at the New School. Richard Stoltzman was the clarinetist, Walter Trampler the violist, and Lee Luvisi the pianist.

title: Insurance Institute Separate From A.A.A.
description: A short article (''Safety Group Faults Red-Light Regulation,'' March 22) identified the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety as ''a unit of the Automobile Association of America.''

title: UNIVERSITY COPES WITH 'INVASIONS'
description: NEW HAVEN A LIGHT rain fell on the Yale campus last Sunday, cleansing the thick spring air and bringing a welcome calm to a student body that had spent the week before defending one of its own against intruders with notebooks and cameras.

title: No Headline
description: James Lieber mentions some promising solutions. There are others that change the system without great expenditure.

title: IN JAPAN, CRIME IS RARE AND REACTION SWIFT
description: Just after he had taken office in 1978, Japanese Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira was the target of an assassination attempt by a man who mixed with reporters outside the Prime Minister's office, and managed to get very close to his intended victim. The assassin had only a knife. Given Japan's gun control - it's illegal to own a pistol, and buying sporting rifles and shotguns involves complicated registration and permit procedures - anything else would have been very hard to obtain.

title: It's No Time to Revive Plea for Bridge on Sound
description: In a recent letter to the editor, I. William Bianchi Jr.'s attempt to propagandize for a Rye-Bayville bridge across Long Island Sound appears to be a semiannual revival of the gobbledygook translated from public-relations handouts of the Long Island industrial community. It is an attempt to give the impression that the future of Long Island depends on this $2 billion ripoff that ''industry'' is trying to push through at taxpayers' expense.

title: Politics; TINKER, TAILOR, SOLDIER, LEGISLATOR
description: IT is not true that the folks who make your state laws here at the Capitol are all a bunch of lawyers with briefcases. Take, for example, State Senator Gerald Labriola, Republican of Naugatuck. He sometimes has a stethoscope sticking out of his jacket pocket.

title: MARCOS AND TIES TO U.S. DENOUNCED AT MANILA RALLY
description: As President Ferdinand E. Marcos set up the machinery for his re-election in June, an alliance of students and workers today denounced his dictatorship and the support given to it by American groups.

title: Some Added Notes On 'Workfare'
description: In the article on Bordentown's ''workfare'' program (March 22), Mayor Joseph Malone is quoted as saying the program can be successful ''because it does not give an incentive to go on welfare. It gives an incentive to keep from going on it.''

title: HAIG CAUTIONED BY ALLIES ABOUT WARNINGS ON POLAND
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. returned here tonight after having been told by some European allies that they were concerned about the repetitiveness of the Reagan Administration's warnings that the Soviet Union might be preparing to intervene in Poland.

title: No Headline
description: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee today called Syrian attacks on the Lebanese Christian community outrageous and said the Syrians had changed their role in Lebanon from peacekeeper to occupier.

title: FOUR DAYS OF DANCE AT MANHATTANVILLE
description: ASPECIAL four-day program by the company Dancemoves will open tomorrow at Manhattanville College in Purchase to students, the county's dance community and the public, according to Greta Levart, dance director at the college. Irene Feigenheimer, a dancer and choreographer who is now an artist in residence, is to participate in the program, which continues through Thursday.

title: TAXIS IN NEW YORK: 850 PEUGEOTS
description: Will Peugeot do to the taxi market what Cuisinart did to the kitchen? Since the French auto maker, the largest in Europe, entered the American market three years ago, the number of diesel-powered Peugeot taxis has jumped from 50 during its first year in New York City to a current total of 850. Peugeot's sales manager for the United States, Anthony J. Aldarelli, predicts that by the end of the year 1,200 cars, or 10 percent of the 12,000 taxis servicing New York, will be Peugeots.

title: BIGGER SPACE STATIONS ARE SOVIET GOAL
description: As the American space shuttle Columbia stands on its Cape Canaveral launch pad, the shadows of events 20 years past hover about its 184-foot-tall metal structure. It was at Cape Canaveral on April 12, 1961, that a Redstone rocket waited to lift what the United States hoped would be the first man in space. That day, the Soviet Union boosted Major Yuri A. Gagarin into a 108-minute single orbit of Earth.

title: Sabres 5, Canucks 3
description: Danny Gare and Tony McKegney each scored two goals as the Sabres swept the playoff series in three games.

title: Poland's Leaders Seem to Be Getting A Second Chance
description: After nursing an illness that may have been diplomatic, Prime Minister Wojciech Jaruzelski put on his general's uniform and medals and went before Parliament last week. It was his second try at reviving central authority and after Poland's edgiest week in recent history, the message was grim. ''Our backs are against the wall,'' he said, ticking off Warsaw's political and economic dangers. He threatened to resign unless he received Parliament's backing for a two-month suspension of strikes. The 440 deputies overwhelmingly acquiesed.

title: Brewers 5, Indians 3
description: CLEVELAND (AP) - Larry Hisle and Gorman Thomas hit consecutive sixth-inning home runs to lead Milwaukee before a crowd of 71,067. Hisle hit a two-run homer over the left-center field fence off Bert Blyleven to break a 1-1 tie. On the next pitch, Thomas hit a drive into the left-field stands for a 4-1 lead. Jim Gantner's triple drove in the Brewers' final run in the ninth.

title: Soviet Paper Attacks Falwell
description: A Soviet Communist Party newspaper published a lengthy attack today on the Rev. Jerry Falwell, denouncing the conservative American minister as a slick businessman and an enemy of detente. The article in Sovetskaya Rossiya, a widely circulated daily, said that Mr. Falwell, the leader of the Moral Majority movement, ''is a religious businessman who transforms disappointment with the present and fear of the future, as well as the unsettled and perplexed state of many Americans, into clinking coins.''

title:
GARDENING;
LANDSCAPING TO MEET CHALLENGING INTERESTS
description: NOTHING appears quite so desolate as a newly built house devoid of planting, except, of course, an entire development of such houses. But once plantings are in place, a slow transition begins and in 15 to 20 years most houses take on a more inviting and habitable appearance.

title: WOUNDED LEBANESE VOWS SHE'LL RETURN TO ZAHLE
description: Saaba Yeshuah saw three of her friends killed in the Lebanese Christian town of Zahle this week as Christian militiamen exchanged artillery fire with Syrian troops. Then she was struck by shell fragments.

title: Linda M. Hofford Is Wed To Robert Frick, Teacher
description: Linda Marion Hofford, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James M. Hofford of Middletown, N.J., and Robert William Frick, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Frick of Cherry Hill, N.J., were married yesterday at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in New Monmouth, N.J. Deacon Jay C. Harbeck, a cousin of the bride, assisted by the Rev. Henry Kreutzer, a Presbyterian minister of Red Bank, N.J., performed the ceremony.

title: A Reunion Was the Aim, But We Remembered Al
description: When the committee for the Oceanside High School Class of 1970 reunion held its first meeting, eight individuals who had never before worked together labored to form a cohesive group. One point was unanimously agreed upon: our primary responsibility was to locate and reunite 863 persons after 10 years.

title: Margaret Feeney Married
description: Margaret Feeney and Neale M. Albert, a lawyer, were married yesterday at their home in Manhattan by State Supreme Court Justice Samuel J. Silverman. The bride, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerard Feeney of Watford, England, is a flight attendant for Trans World Airways. Mr. Albert, a partner in the New York law firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison, is a son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Louis Albert of New York. His previous marriage ended in divorce.

title: Edward Vogel, Brooklyn Lawyer; Served 20 Years on City Council
description: Edward Vogel, a Brooklyn lawyer who served on the New York City Council from 1940 to 1960, died yesterday at New York University Hospital. He was 78 years old and a lifelong resident of Brooklyn.

title: Missing the Monarchy
description: Lots of Americans would give their eyeteeth to live under a monarchy, especially one as engagingly classy as the British (''Royal Romance and Princely Duty,'' by William Borders, March 22).

title: Metaphysical Clarification
description: The caption under a photo with an article about the North Jersey Metaphysical Center on March 29 incorrectly described the gathering, which was a meditation.

title: THE POLITICIANS' TURN AT MARGIOTTA TRIAL
description: WESTBURY TOMORROW, it will be the defense's turn to present its case in the trial of Joseph M. Margiotta, the Republican leader of Nassau County, on charges involving a system of dispensing thousands of dollars in insurance commissions to favored political associates. So far, the testimony elicited by the prosecution has provided an unaccustomed glimpse at some of Nassau's top political figures.

title: Ex-Klansmen Sentenced in Jersey
description: Two former members of the Ku Klux Klan have been sentenced to six months for firing shots into the home of a black family in Barnegat Township last year. Judge Mark Addision of Superior Court permitted the two - Aaron Morrison, 19 years old, and Karl C. Hand, 30 - to go free yesterday on $15,000 bail, pending an appeal.

title: SHEIL HOLDS A KEY
description: LIKE his predecessors in the job, State Senator Walter N. Sheil, the enigmatic chairman of the Hudson County Democratic organization, could hold the key to who wins the Democratic nomination for Governor in the June 2 primary.

title: No Headline
description: It would appear that William Borders presumes that Prince Charles ''seems to show signs of having a good mind.

title: Connecticut Journal
description: FOR the next four weeks, hotels, motels and tourist attractions in Connecticut will be advertising heavily to encourage visitors to take advantage of the good things in the state. The joint effort, sponsored by the Department of Economic Development, is expected to cost $90,000.

title:
NEW JERSEY HOUSING;
ALMOST-NO-FRILLS HOMES IN HOWELL
description: AS the song says, ''everything old is new again.'' The New Jersey division of the U.S. Home Corporation, perceiving a great demand for housing stymied by high interest rates, rising energy costs and stiff down-payment requirements, has decided to address itself to these problems. In short, the answer that this large building concern has come up with is a small house on a small lot.

title:
Dining Out;
FOOD AS WORTHY AS THE ATMOSPHERE
description: IT is always pleasant to return to what was once a potentially good restaurant to find that it is fulfilling that potential. In our review of Damiano's in Granite Springs more than a year ago, we lamented that it had everything a restaurant-goer could want, except good food. We can report that such is no longer the case; under the guidance of the new chef, Nicola Brunetti, the kitchen has at last become worthy of Damiano's atmosphere.

title: SQUEEZE ON MAGAZINES
description: After a period of unprecedented growth between 1975 and 1979, when revenues more than doubled, to $2.7 billion, and the number of pages increased more than 45 percent, a sagging economy made 1980 a disappointing year for magazine advertising. Revenues rose by 4 percent, to $2.8 billion, a negative rate after inflation is taken into account.

title: Sunday Observer; FACING HUMILIATION; by Russell Baker
description: Baker Headline to Come Patrick McDonnell

title: THAT INEVITABLE TIME OF YEAR IS NIGH
description: IT'S the time of year to count the blessings of the year before. In short, it's W-2's and 1099's - that perennial and debilitating exercise, the income tax return.

title: NATIONAL DEBT
description: To the Business Editor:

title: NATO Ministers Get the Hard Sell
description: Echoing a refrain made familiar by every United States Defense Secretary, Caspar W. Weinberger flew to Bonn last week to urge North Atlantic Treaty allies to try harder.

title: EX-SCARSDALE MAYOR IN FILM ON POLAND
description: AMONG the stars of ''Image Before My Eyes,'' a documentary film about Jews in pre-Nazi Poland that was released last month and has received considerable attention, is a former Mayor of Scarsdale, whose family once owned the largest cigarette factory in Eastern Europe.

title: JAMES HAGERTY, EISENHOWER AIDE, DEAD
description: James C. Hagerty, the White House press secretary under President Dwight D. Eisenhower, died yesterday afternoon at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville, N.Y. He was 72 years old.

title: Dance View; 'HAMLET' AND ROBERT HELPMANN
description: The glut of new dance books, mostly mediocre, on the market hides some whose usefulness should not go unobserved. One is a biography of Robert Helpmann, its timeliness tied to the Royal Ballet's revival of his ''Hamlet'' this month with Anthony Dowell in London.

title: Balancing Books; Ounce by Ounce
description: While Republicans jeered their ''pickpocket approach to state money matters,'' Connecticut Assembly Democrats moved last week to increase more than a half-dozen state taxes in an effort to balance the state budget without an income tax.

title: Michele Erica Mooberry Wed To Gerard Potier, Executive
description: Michele Erica Mooberry, daughter of Mrs. Leo William Farland, was married at her mother's home in Manhattan yesterday to Gerard Hubert Potier.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Fines on Credit
description: With parking fines at $25 to $35, plus $65 more if the violator's car was towed away, the New York City Council approved on Sept. 18, 1979, the use of credit cards to pay the fees. The legislation, which became Local Law 63, stipulated that the Department of Finance work out the details with credit providers.

title: RECITAL: JUXTAPOSITION BY NEW MUSIC CONSORT
description: For all its internal variety, the music of this century has evolved into such a large quantity of self-contained repertory that it makes up a tradition all by itself. And so it has become possible to pick and choose ''traditional'' 20th-century works and mix them with newer pieces and assemble a program full of contrast and historical links. That is what the New Music Consort has done this season, with three programs at Carnegie Recital Hall, juxtaposing works by well-known composers of the century with pieces by younger Americans.

title: Paperback Best Sellers; MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: BEHIND THE BEST SELLERS
description: How do you cook up a cookbook? In the case of Maida Heatter, whose ''Book of Great Chocolate Desserts'' was recently on the best-seller list, the basic ingredients were a love of cooking and dumb luck. Mrs. Heatter had been an avid cook for years and ran her own cooking school, but she might never have written a book if it weren't for her chance meeting with Craig Claiborne of The New York Times.

title: AGE OF SPACE TRAVEL OPENED 20 YEARS AGO TODAY
description: It was 20 years ago today that a man was hurled for the first time into space, propelling mankind into the age of space travel. The man was a Russian, Maj. Yuri A. Gagarin, who on April 12, 1961 took a 108-minute spin around the earth at a speed of more than 17,000 miles an hour, six times faster than man had ever traveled before, and at a height of 187 miles. He returned to earth safe and an international hero. Some called him ''the Columbus of the Interplanetary Age.''

title: LIGHTS GO UP ON THE EXPRESSWAY
description: ONE by one, the lights are going up on the Long Island Expressway, turning night into day along a heavily traveled 37-mile stretch from the Queens-Nassau border to Exit 58 at Nicolls Road in Suffolk County.

title: THE MAN BEHIND MANHATTAN'S ART THEATER BOOM
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Dan Yakir is a New York-based freelance writer who specializes in film. By DAN YAKIR

title: Alice M. Ehrenclou Will Be the Bride Of Wallace Cole 3d
description: Announcement has been made by Mrs. David M. Irwin of Essex, N.Y., and Alfred M. Ehrenclou of Singer Island, Fla., of the engagement of their daughter, Alice Morris Ehrenclou, to Wallace Hasbrouck Cole 3d of Malibu, Calif., son of Mr. and Mrs. Cole Jr. of Miami.

title: Around the Garden
description: This Week:

title: Loughlin Trackman Take Crown at Nanuet Relays
description: Bishop Loughlin High School of Brooklyn has opened its outdoor season where it left off indoors - with victories.

title: CRAFTS
description: IN the current thrust toward the expressive potential of handmade paper, two galleries in the northern part of the state are running simultaneous exhibitions in that medium.

title: TOXIC SMOKE CHOKES MEXICO CITY
description: Mexico City has been inundated by acrid smoke carrying twice as many poisonous substances as a human being can safely withstand, environmental officials said yesterday.

title: DIGGING UP OUR URBAN PAST
description: Claudia Lorber is a freelance writer based in New York City. By Claudia Lorber In a muddy hole 10 feet deep and half a block wide, across Pearl Street from Fraunces Tavern in the heart of Manhattan's financial district, 18 archeologists recently made a remarkable discovery. They uncovered what they believe to be the remains of the Stadt Huys, New York's first city hall, dating to Peter Stuyvesant's time. Next to it, they found the remains of a tavern built in 1670 by the English Governor, Francis Lovelace, and in the cellar, a storage barrel brimming with empty wine and rum bottles and one perfect, unbroken clay pipe.

title: THE QUIET CAMPAIGN TO CUT CAPITAL GAINS TAXES-- TO ZERO
description: WASHINGTON S TILL savoring the 1978 reduction of the capital gains tax, business has begun a new campaign, though so far low key, to abolish this levy altogether, or at least to whittle it down further.

title: Gretzky's 3 Goals Leads Oilers' Sweep
description: Disorganized and dispirited, the Montreal Canadiens tonight suffered the completion of a humiliation that was as quick as it was shocking.

title: Miss Bickel To Be Bride
description: Caroline Croft Bickel, a legislative paralegal in the Washington office of the Philadelphia law firm of Ballard, Shahr, Andrews & Ingersoll, plans to be married June 13 in Chattanooga, Tenn., to Hollis Samuel McLoughlin, an assistant account executive with the Benton & Bowles advertising agency in New York.

title: L.I.'S MUSIC FOR EASTER
description: WITH Easter Sunday near, churches throughout the Island are offering music to mark the occasion. In some churches, the special musical offerings are today, Palm Sunday.

title: Arum: Was Conned Twice
description: Bob Arum, the boxing promoter who was doing business with another promoter known as Harold J. Smith, says he was twice conned by Ross Fields, Smith's real name.

title:
ON THE ISLE;
ALL THAT JAZZ
description: Libraries do not live by chamber music alone. Frequently, more contemporary refrains invade the premises. Such as today at 2:30 P.M., when Stanley Free, a pianist and composer, visits the Great Neck Library to perform some jazz. The composer in residence for Manhattan's West End Symphony, Mr. Free has conducted such Broadway productions as ''Shenandoah'' and ''The Magic Show'' and has a gold record to his credit for ''Popcorn.'' He is appearing under the auspices of the Meet the Composer program and will offer his latest jazz compositions. The library is on Bayview Avenue, and Mr. Free's appearance is free.RENAISSANCE DANCE

title: Supporting Local Representatives
description: ''County Uncertain of Reagan Budget's Impact'' is the lead story of the March 15 Westchester Weekly. The text spells out in two dozen paragraphs one uncertainty after another, while between the lines we see the picture of an oncoming likelihood in our local life -an increase in local taxes.

title: Marianne Loughran Bride of C. J. Walsh
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of the Immaculate Heart of Mary in Scarsdale, N.Y., yesterday, Marianne Loughran, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John B. Loughran of Scarsdale, was married to Christopher James Walsh, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas M. Walsh of Yonkers. Msgr. Daniel V. Flynn performed the ceremony and concelebrated the nuptial mass with Msgr.

title: Nancy Bodine To Be a Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard Phillips Bodine of Easton, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Conant Bodine, to Gregory Scot Wolcott, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ezra Rowley Wolcott of Big Flats, N. Y.

title: DR. STANLEY PLASTRIK, 66, EDITOR OF DISSENT MAGAZINE
description: Dr. Stanley Plastrik, a co-founder and editor of Dissent, the Socialist quarterly, died yesterday at Roosevelt Hospital after a long illness. He was 66 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: ECONOMIC AFFAIRS
description: UTILITIES: WHY THEIR SERVICE IS SLIPPING OIL AND COPPER DON'T MIX By Paul W. MacAvoy

title: Correction
description: In a review last Sunday of a double bill presented on April 2 by the New York Light Opera, the piano accompanist was incorrectly identified. He was Nathan Matthews.

title: Asphyxiation Ruled Cause Of Death of Cuban on Plane
description: A Cuban exile who attempted to hijack an Eastern Airlines jet died of asphyxiation from injuries suffered when he was subdued by passengers and flight attendants, according to an autopsy report today.

title: CENSUS SHOWS MAJOR SHIFT IN REGION'S DEMOGRAPHICS
description: The statistics on the racial composition of the population, which are just becoming available from the 1980 census, will probably provide enough information for debate and analysis to keep demographers, sociologists and politicians busy until the 1990 census is taken. But some trends in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut already are clearly identifiable, even allowing for some nuances in interpretation.

title: MOZART AND STRAVINSKY
description: Stravinsky, who is reported to have felt that he and Mozart had a great deal in common, will be paired with the earlier master in the seventh annual New Music Festival on Monday nights at William Paterson College in Wayne. The works of more more recent composers also will be played.

title: COMMUNITY INVOLVED IN EDUCATION OF DEAF
description: WINSTED WHILE driving to Northwestern Connecticut Community College to visit his son, a deaf man was pulled over by a Winsted police officer. After gesturing that he could not hear, the driver was astounded when the officer repeated the charge - in sign language - and presented him with a speeding ticket.

title: STRIP USED FOR TRAINING ASTRONAUTS IS PREPARED FOR EMERGENCY LANDING
description: If the astronauts flying the Columbia were forced to land at the Northrup Strip here after one orbit around the earth, they would aim for a huge white target visible from far out in space.

title: Still No Budget But the Scrapping Goes on in Albany
description: Both Governor Carey and his Statehouse adversary, Warren M. Anderson, leader of the Senate's Republican majority, won budgetary skirmishes last week, but their fiscal war continued and the casualties began to mount as the state's inability to pay its bills meant that others couldn't either.

title: Protecting the Most Basic Right
description: Five thousand voting-rights demonstrators marched across the Edmund Pettus Bridge in Selma, Ala., last week, and nothing happened. State troopers and posse men were not waiting on the other side to mow down the crowd with tear gas, clubs and whips. It was a notable contrast with the day the demonstrators were commemorating - the ''Bloody Sunday'' of March 7, 1965, that helped goad a conscience-stricken nation into enacting the Voting Rights Act.

title: Westchester Guide; ALL ALONG THE RIVER
description: The Hudson River Museum has scheduled a series of events about the body of water for which it was named. The first, taking place at 2 P.M. today, concerns what is acknowledged to be the first truly American school of painting, The Hudson River School. Made up of artists who spurned dominant European influences and subject matter, focusing their attention instead on an indigenous American source of inspiration, the school flourished in the 1830's. Its best known practitioner was Thomas Cole.

title: SUSPECT FLEES FROM HOLDING CELL AT COURT BUILDING IN MANHATTAN
description: A man accused of possessing burglar's tools walked out of New York City Criminal Court at 100 Centre Street yesterday and escaped, the police said.

title: Fairfield Alumnus Welcomes Haig
description: As an alumnus of Fairfield University, I was deeply concerned to read of the protest regarding Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig's planned commencement address this May (''Haig Invitation to Fairfield Commencement Sparks a Protest,'' April 5).

title: Design Food; MAKING THE DESERT BLOOM ON FIRE ISLAND; by Mimi Sheraton
description: Making a difficult task look easy always has been the mark of the true professional, whether the performer is a writer, a painter, a musician, a gymnast or, as in this case, a gardener and a cook. Even under the most ideal growing conditions, enormous effort and knowledge are required to create and maintain new gardens that flourish, that look uncontrived and so naturally opulent one might believe they are almost as old as Eden.

title: HE MADE 'SOPHISTICATED LADIES' JUMP TO THE RHYTHM OF TAPS
description: The three small, cheerfully battered studios are far noisier than the rush-hour Broadway they overlook, on a Theater District block crammed with discount electronic stores and pornographic movie houses. In one studio, a rehearsal is in progress, with voices raised in humming, slightly uncertain song. In another, a performer is posing for a newspaper layout. And dancers' feet chatter companionably through some complicated tap routines in the third, sliding easily into barrel turns and butterfly steps as a short, rotund man named Henry LeTang pounds out a flow of easy jazz rhythms on the piano.

title: SPRING WEEKENDS, WITH HISTORY, IN HADLEY
description: JOAN COOK is a reporter for The Times. By JOAN COOK

title: Art; TAPESTRIES, INGE MORATH PHOTOS EXHIBITED
description: NEW MILFORD THE Silo should consider bottling the delicious smells that waft from its cookery school. A recent visit to this handsome group of wood buildings, previously a farm, was enhanced as much by the scent of cakes baking in its kitchen as by the signs of spring on its grounds. Located on Upland Road, which joins Route 202 north of New Milford, just past the paddock of riding horses, the Silo has inaugurated the seventh season of its barn-gallery with photographs by Inge Morath and tapestries by Susan Kimber. They will be shown through Apr. 26.

title: Enlivened By Torts
description: As a first-year student at Columbia Law School, I take exception to Russell Baker's article ''The Legal Pitch'' (Sunday Observer, March 1). His claim that law-firm commercials are ''duller than a lecture on torts'' does a great disservice to the subject of torts.

title: NBONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: WE DIDN'T HAVE MUCH, BUT WE SURE HAD PLENTY Stories of Rural Women. By Sherry Thomas. Illustrated. 185 pp. New York: Anchor Press/Doubleday. $7.95.

title: Taking the Plunge On Social Security
description: As America has grown grayer, politicians have turned paler when forced to contemplate cuts in Social Security. No matter how necessary changes might be to keep the nation's old age insurance fund afloat, proposing them was tantatmount to committing suicide in a polling booth. But then so was proposing still another tax increase to pay for the mounting costs of benefits that now go 35 million elderly people.

title: U.S. AND JAPANESE DISAGREE IN ACCOUNT OF SHIP DISASTER
description: The United States Navy and survivors of the sinking of a Japanese freighter after it and an American nuclear submarine collided close to Japanese territorial waters gave opposing accounts today of the accident, in which two Japanese apparently drowned.

title: Ellyn Golder to Be the Bride Of Stephen R. Saft in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert B. Golder of Glenside, Pa., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Ellyn Golder, to Stephen R. Saft, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert Saft of Narberth, Pa.

title: Editors' Choice
description: 1961. GEORGE ORWELL, by Bernard Crick. (Atlantic-Little, Brown, $17.95.) The first full biography of the writer.

title: Neil Barrocas, an Executive, Fiance of Barbara Bleetsein
description: Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Bleetstein of Great Neck, L.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Bleetstein, to Neil Barrocas, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Barrocas of Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

title: NURSE HELD IN DEATH OF 4 BABIES AT TORONTO HOSPITAL
description: Police, medical and legal investigators have joined forces here in recent days to examine the mysterious deaths of at least four infants, all in the same ward of Toronto's Hospital for Sick Children, and to reconstruct the deaths of three dozen others there.

title: Arts High Founded By Franklin J. Keller
description: Jill Silverman's article about the Rondo Dance Theater's 10th anniversary celebration at the State University of New York at Purchase (''Dance Theater Plans Birthday Celebration,'' March 15) incorrectly credits the Rondo's director with also founding and directing the High School of Performing Arts in Manhattan.

title: LITERARY FIGURES TALK ON WRITING
description: WHEN the Westport-Weston Arts Council asked Carol Plaine Fisher to plan a forum about writing and writers, using local talent, she knew it couldn't be one of those ''You, Too, Can Be a Writer'' evenings.

title: SALE TERMS IN ASSISTED CO-OPS AS VALUES RISE
description: ''I want to live here the rest of my life,'' said Irving Zuckerman, a public-school teacher and a resident of the Chatham Green cooperative since it was built 18 years ago.

title: WORK IS THERAPY FOR HANDICAPPED YOUTH
description: HANDICAPABLE Inc., a private, nonprofit employment training program for retarded youth was begun last August by Ron Sands and Dave Lindsey, two special-education teachers in the Norwalk school system who believed in their idea enough to undertake it without government aid.

title: VARIETY MARKS A NEW RECORDING LABEL
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Allan Kozinn writes frequently about recordings. By ALLAN KOZINN

title: OLD INN STIRS A NEW DISPUTE
description: MONTCLAIR ARECENT application for a liquor license by the Marlboro Inn may renew a heated battle that began four years ago in this Essex County community. The three-story landmark hotel recently reopened under new ownership after being vacant for nearly two years.

title: PRUDENTI BACKS A WINNER
description: ANEWCOMER to state Republican politics, Anthony Prudenti, the Suffolk County party leader, proved to be a better politician than two more experienced Nassau neighbors in the lengthy and often tricky maneuvering over the state chairmanship.

title: PANEL TO GRADE NUCLEAR DRILL
description: LOWER ALLOWAYS CREEK TOWNSHIP

title: AFTER 10 YEARS, CENTRAL PARK ZOO CAFETERIA TAKES A NEW DIRECTION
description: After 10 years of operation by Nedick's, the cafeteria at the Central Park Zoo has a new concessionaire, and that makes the elephant keeper happy.

title: HOW ART MAKES US FEEL AT HOME IN THE WORLD
description: It is fundamental to the white magic of art that it does away with the nightmare of disorientation. Not only does art tell us who we are, but it tells us - or it used to tell us -where we are. And ''Where am I?'' is, after all, one of the most poignant of human formulations. It speaks for an anxiety that is intense, recurrent and all but unbearable. Not to know where we are is torment, and not to have a sense of place is a most sinister deprivation.

title: Deborah L. Machemehl Is Married to Daniel G. McGinn
description: Deborah Lea Machemehl, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert C. Machemehl of Belville, Tex., was married yesterday in Washington to Daniel Glenn McGinn, son of Mr. and Mrs. James McGinn of Nitro, W. Va. The Rev. James David Ford, chaplain of the House of Representatives, performed the Lutheran ceremony in his office.

title: Genuine Risk Romps in Return
description: Genuine Risk, the champion 3-year-old filly of 1980, made a belated but sparkling debut as a 4-year-old with a 9 1/2-length victory at Aqueduct yesterday. She beat an undistinguished field in an allowance race in her first outing since last September, when she won the Ruffian Handicap.

title: RURAL TRANSIT OFFERS FREE RIDES
description: PUTNAM THE bright yellow van pulled up to the Finast grocery store and no one got on. It was St. Patrick's Day, last month's free bus day in Putnam, part of a new strategy by the Northeastern Connecticut Transit District to get people to ride the bus. They will try again this Tuesday, when any riders of fixed-route service between Danielson and Plainfield, and between Putnam and Thompson, will ride free.

title: Bernstein Concert on TV
description: FM and WNEW-TV will present a simulcast of Leonard Bernstein conducting the London Symphony Orchestra's performance of Mahler's Symphony No. 2 in C minor, ''Resurrection,'' tomorrow at 8 P.M. Dame Janet Baker, the mezzo-soprano, will be the soloist in the taped presentation.

title: WHITE HOUSE STAFF SEES REAGAN RETURN AS BEST RX FOR PROGRAM
description: Before President Reagan checked out of George Washington University Hospital and returned to the White House yesterday, the First Lady received a letter from someone who has experience with convalescing chief executives. ''Lady Bird Johnson wrote Mrs. Reagan,'' a White House aide recalled, ''that she should remember that after Lyndon Johnson had his gall bladder out, he took basically a month off.''

title: Politics; DEMOCRATS IN NORTH REGROUPING
description: DEMOCRATS in northern Westchester, occasional winners in local contests but consistently outregistered by Republicans, have decided to ''regroup,'' as Thomas F. Carty, the County Democratic Chairman, put it, ''to breathe new life into their political organization.''

title: BUILDERS COMPETE FOR BIG PROJECTS
description: Requests for development proposals for the second phases of two major residential projects in Manhattan - Battery Park City in lower Manhattan and the Ruppert urban renewal site in Yorkville - have been issued for almost 3,000 units of housing.

title: Art View; AVERY-'OUR GREATEST COLORIST'; by Hilton Kramer
description: For the inauguration of its spacious new quarters at 724 Fifth Avenue, just below 57th Street, the Grace Borgenicht Gallery has organized an important exhibition of the work of its most illustrious artist, the American painter Milton Avery (1893-1965). Consisting of 14 major canvases, including loans from outstanding museum collections, and a selection of gouaches, this splendid exhibition also marks two other events: the 30th anniversary of the founding of the gallery, and the publication of a handsome new book on Avery's work. The show opens on Wednesday, and remains on view through May 9. I doubt if there is a more beautiful exhibition of a modern painter to be seen here just now.

title: ATTEMPTING TO RECOUP, HAIG WORKS HARD TO SCORE POINTS ABROAD
description: As Alexander M. Haig Jr. flew from Washington nine days ago on his first overseas mission as Secretary of State, he told reporters accompanying him he was convinced that the measure of his effectiveness would not be who was in charge of crisis management or his behavior the day President Reagan was shot, but what he would accomplish. When the report card was rendered, it would be rendered on substance, he said.

title: Stage View; NEIL SIMON ON FOREIGN GROUND
description: Neil Simon, blithely turning out comedy after comedy year after year, has undoubtedly entertained us more often than any of his contemporaries, and I salute him for it. I'm also willing to salute him as a certain kind of folklorist. He's a New York folklorist, that's what he is, a nosily observant and sometimes flesh-pricking recorder of the fancies and fetishes by which our urban dwellers live, quarrel, procreate. (The California plays aren't really California plays; they're full of transplated New Yorkers, plus a couple of palm trees.) The embattled cave men of ''The Odd Couple'' are already mythic figures for our time, and expensive Plaza Suite weddings may go down into our book of fables, too. But now let us pause. What, in the name of Aesop and Hans Christian Andersen, is a New York folklorist doing in the completely made-up and therefore achingly nonexistent cuckoo-clock world of Kulyenchikov?

title: No Headline
description: Most of the executives mentioned in Douglas Bauer's article are ''one man, one decision'' style managers. Today, the trend is toward the team player.

title: New-Look Cosmos Shun Star System
description: The Cosmos have given up on the star system, and tomorrow the home fans get their first look at the changed team. Franz Beckenbauer is playing in West Germany, Carlos Alberto is waiting to have his contract reassigned and Johan Neeskens has been banished.

title: BUBBLY STUFF AT THE MCCARTER
description: PRINCETON IN P. G. Wodehouse's adaptation, Ferenc Molnar's ''The Play's the Thing'' is a low-calorie entertainment. It's weightless, a dandy concoction for adults, with carbonation that fizzes buoyantly for two hours and a nonnutritive sweetness that should please anyone's taste buds.

title: JAPANESE PREPPIES
description: SCHOOLDAYS IN IMPERIAL JAPAN A Study in the Culture of a Student Elite. By Donald T. Roden. Illustrated. 300 pp. Berkeley: The University of California Press. $24.50.

title: FATHER WAS LOVING AND SILENT
description: HIS SON A Child of the Fifties. By Bill Henderson. 144 pp. New York: W.W. Norton & Company. $10.95. By LARRY McMURTRY

title: SKY IS THE LIMIT FOR CITIZEN'S BACKYARD ROCKET SHIP
description: Bob's Space Program lags behind that of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. As NASA's Columbia waits to streak into orbit 173 miles above earth, Bob's ''space shuttle'' is still unfinished, sitting in his driveway next to a can of grass clippings in Saratoga, Calif.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Tax Break on Rents
description: If homeowners can claim property taxes as a deduction on their Federal income tax, why not give apartment renters a comparable break? Why not, the New York State Legislature and Governor Carey agreed. In 1978 they approved a law to let the renters take their share of a building's property taxes as a personal tax deduction.

description: To the Editor:

title: Thieves Steal Fine French Wine
description: DU-PAPE, France, April 11 (AP) - Thieves with a taste for fine red wine broke into the cellars of the Amouroux wine-growing estate and made off with 1,000 bottles of Chateauneuf-du-Pape ''Grand Cru,'' police sources said today. They estimated the loss at about $10,000 and said the bottles, which carried the highest classification for French wine, were stolen late Thursday or early yesterday.

title: Greece Charges Turkey With Airspace Violations
description: A Greek Government spokesman said today that his country had protested to Turkey about repeated violations of its airspace by Turkish military aircraft this week.

title: Jean Hayden Is the Fiancee Of Physician
description: The engagement of Jean Nikander Hayden to Dr. Eugenio DeMarchis has been announced by Mrs. William J. McCart of Maplewood, N.J., mother of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Mrs. Luigi DeMarchis of Rome and the late Mr. DeMarchis.

title: A TEST FOR CONFLICT OF INTERSET
description: WHAT creates a financial conflict of interest for municipal employees? The outcome of a Montauk real-estate broker's suit in New York Supreme Court against East Hampton's Town Board and Board of Ethics may provide the answer.

title: A ROYAL DEFENDER OF DEMOCRACY
description: THIS FOOTNOTE GROWS OUT OF THE FIRST PARAGRAPH OF STORY: *The royal dynastic family imported by Spain from France in the 18th century. The repetition of the Spanish spelling in Juan Carlos's name reflects the lineage of his father, Don Juan Borbon y Battenberg, and mother, Dona Maria de las Mercedes de Borbon y Orleans. James M. Markham is chief of The Times's bureau in Madrid. By James M. Markham rivately, Juan Carlos de Borbon y Borbon confides that he would like to be the kind of constitutional monarch Britain's Queen Elizabeth is: high above the fray of politics, an ultimate but rarely appealedto referee, a living symbol of the unity of the nation. History, however, has cast him in a more exacting and perilous role, and recent events thrust him center stage. On the night of Feb. 23, with the Government and Parliament held hostage by a band of rebel Civil Guards, Juan Carlos I almost single-handedly halted a surprise golpe de estado, a coup against the state, its aim nothing less than reimposing the reactionary conditions that existed under the late Francisco Franco and the destruction of the frail democracy instituted by his successor, Juan Carlos, to insure the survival of the restored Bourbon* dynasty.

title: Theater; 'FIDDLER': TOUCHING ON BASICS
description: ''FIDDLER ON THE ROOF,'' which opened on Broadway in September 1964, is one of the great musical successes of the American theater. Though based on the stories of Sholom Aleichem, it cannot attribute its popularity simply to the fact that it tells the story of Jews in a small Russian village. That might explain its popularity with one part of society, but ''Fiddler'' went on to become an international success, as popular in Japan as it was in the United States. The reason lies in the show's opening number, ''Tradition,'' which states the theme.

title: Critics' Choices; by Gene Thornton
description: PHOTOGRAPHY Just when it seems that the last undiscovered photographer of merit has been found and shown, another one turns up. She - or in this instance, he - may not require that the history of photography be rewritten.

title: GOVERNOR AND MISS GOULETAS ARE WED IN ORTHODOX RITES
description: With smiles and kisses and the mingling of two large families, Governor Carey was married yesterday to Evangeline Gouletas of Chicago in a celebration that stretched from Manhattan to Albany.

title: EASTER CELEBRATED IN MUSIC
description: EIGHT major musical works for the Easter season will be performed in Connecticut over the next few weeks, and Mendelssohn's ''Elijah'' will be presented at the State University of New York, College at Purchase, by the Greenwich Choral Society. Richard Vogt will conduct the 150-voice chorus, a 53-piece orchestra and four soloists at 7:30 P.M. April 25.

title: Johns Hopkins Trounces Cornell in Lacrosse, 17-6
description: Johns Hopkins, three-time national champion, scored four straight goals at the end of the first half, including three by Jeff Cooke, and went on to rout Cornell, 17-6, in college lacrosse today.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
THE JARGON OF BILINGUALISM OBSCURES THE TRUTH
description: BILINGUAL education is in serious trouble throughout our country. Mismanagement on all levels, coupled with indecisive and everchanging guidelines within the Federal bureaucracy, have created an unhealthy environment within which students attempt to learn and teachers to teach.

title: Swiss Hospitality Has Certain Limits
description: The Swiss have perfected a revolving door for foreign workers that works almost as efficiently as their precision watches. A few citizens think the system is cruel and reflects badly on the industrious nation, but most Swiss disagree and last week, they voted 5-to-1 to keep the revolving door spinning smoothly.

title: STATE'S BUDGET DISPUTE PUTS 150 COMMISSION EMPLOYEES OUT OF JOBS
description: New York State has been without a budget since April 1, and while most state employees have been paid anyway, the dispute over state spending fight has made the jobs of 150 employees quite literally disappear.

title: WELFARE
description: To the Business Editor: Mr. Penner is obviously at home among the "many Americans" who do not believe that this country should be striving to establish a more egalitarian society. His sense of elitism is apparent.

title: CONTINENTAL PLAZA SOLD FOR $58 MILLION
description: WINNING office complex in this Bergen County community has been sold in one of the largest real estate transactions in North Jersey in recent years. The three-building Continental Plaza project on Hackensack Avenue and Route 4 here has been acquired from J.D. Construction Enterprises for $58 million by Rreef USA Fund 1, a partnership that serves as investment adviser for major corporation pension funds.

title: ISLIP WITHDRAWS FROM 3-TOWN PROJECT TO BUILD A REFUSE PLANT ON L.I.
description: The Town of Islip on Long Island has withdrawn from the Multi-Town Solid Waste Management Authority, delaying by at least a year the proposed construction of a centralized refuse disposal plant planned for Islip, Huntington and Babylon, and possibly jeopardizing the future of the project.

title: Koch Acts to Abate Hefty Tax Breaks
description: There may not be many bargains left in New York City real estate, but it hasn't been hard for some developers to get a good break on the taxes. Since 1955, the city has forgiven millions of dollars in real estate taxes to encourage developers to rebuild housing.

description: GUIDE Page 26

title: DAMAGED OIL TANKER IS LEAKING OFF SOUTH AFRICA
description: A supertanker that was reportedly damaged by a wave Thursday has created a 60-mile-long oil slick in the Indian Ocean about 15 miles off South African resort beaches, the South African Press Association said today.

title: Booster Rockets Are Retrieved; Soviet Vessel Is Warned Away
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla. -- The Columbia spaceship's two solid-propellant booster rockets were retrieved today by two specially built ships. It was the first recovery ever made of space vehicles intended for re-use.

title: Bird Leads Celtic Sweep
description: Larry Bird scored 35 points, including the field goal that put Boston ahead to stay with 39 seconds left, to help the Celtics to a 109-103 victory over the Chicago Bulls today and a sweep of their Eastern Conference semifinal series.

title: INCENTIVES FOR IDEAS
description: The key economic-policy word in Washington these days is ''incentives.'' To an economist, this comes as a breath of fresh air. The Reagan Administration is correct in stressing the important connections between lagging growth in productivity and the effect of our complex tax system on the incentives people have to work and to save money. It is unfortunate and ironic, then, that the Administration is about to make a serious policy blunder on an issue involving the incentive to accumulate a centrally important kind of capital.

title: Linda Sartorius, 35,Bridge Player Who Won Several Regional Titles
description: Linda Sartorius, a high-ranked contract bridge player, died in her sleep in Cedar Grove, N.J., Saturday. She was 35 years old, and an autopsy is being conducted to determine the cause of death.

title: BARBARA JAFFE MARRIED TO LAURENS SCHWARTZ
description: Barbara Ellen Jaffe of Brooklyn, who is on the staff of Madison Galleries Ltd. in Manhattan, was married yesterday to Laurens R. Schwartz, who expects to receive a law degree in June from New York University. Rabbi Morton Green performed the ceremony at the Woodcrest Country Club in Syosset, L.I.

title: Vermont College Ends Its Search for a New President
description: Roderick M. Gander, chief of correspondents at Newsweek magazine, has been named president of Marlboro College in Marlboro, Vt., ending a yearlong search for a successor to Thomas B. Ragle, who has headed the small liberal arts college since 1958.

title: THEATER: 'DAMIEN,' THE LEPER-PRIEST
description: ''= DAMIEN'' is a one-man show in more than one sense. The play, now at the Theater of the Open Eye, is a vehicle for that fine actor Eugene Troobnick. It is also a portrait in depth of Joseph Damien De Veuster, Belgian missionary to the lepers on the Hawaiian island of Molokai from 1871 to 1889, when he himself died of leprosy.

title: Cemetery Workers Ending Walkout in San Francisco
description: Cemetery workers voted today to end a 26-day strike and return to work tomorrow to begin burying several hundred bodies of people who died in the course of the walkout.

title: Mrs. Lloyd Beats Miss Shriver in Final, Extends Streak on Clay
description: Chris Evert Lloyd's 6-3, 6-2 victory over Pam Shriver today in the final of the Family Circle Cup tennis tournament was hardly a surprise.

title: RANGERS ELIMINATE KINGS, 6-3
description: The Rangers gained a place in the Stanley Cup quarterfinals last night by defeating the Los Angeles Kings, 6-3, at Madison Square Garden. They took the three-of-five-game preliminary playoff, three games to one.

title: Penguins Top Blues, Even Series at 2-2
description: Mike Bullard, a rookie, and the defenseman Randy Carlyle scored two goals each tonight as the Pittsburgh Penguins defeated the St. Louis Blues, 6-3, and evened their playoff series at two victories apiece.

title: Sports World Specials; One for the Book
description: By the time Ty Cobb retired from baseball in 1928, his exploits had led to major revisions in the record book. The Sporting News, in a cover story this week by Paul Mac Farlane, has revised the book on Cobb. And major league baseball is not too pleased.

title: SOME TILES FALL OFF, BUT NASA SEES NO DANGER
description: The space shuttle Columbia, its rockets spewing orange fire and a long trail of white vapor, blasted its way into earth orbit today, carrying two American astronauts on a daring journey to test the world's first re-usable spaceship.

title: WILLIAM STONE LUCKETT
description: William Stone Luckett, a vice president of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York who had been in charge of its office at 40 Rockefeller Plaza, died yesterday of cancer at his home in Larchmont, N.Y. He was 49 years old.

description: Sean O'Grady won the World Boxing Association lightweight championship today after battering Hilmer Kenty for most of 15 rounds in a fast-paced fight at Bally's Park Place Hotel.

description: Paul R. Eckel, the chairman of the Continental Employees Association, a workers group at Continental Airlines that is seeking control of the Los Angeles-based carrier, speaks like a man with a mission.

description: SAN FRANCISCO (UPI) - Mike Ivie singled in Larry Herndon from second base with two out in the 14th inning to beat San Diego.

description: A wind-driven fire that already has burned an estimated 27,000 acres of the Everglades jumped a fire line today, and officials said they expected it to ravage 1,000 acres more before it was brought under control again.

title: SHUTTLE'S SOPHISTICATION TO ALTER ROLE OF MISSION CONTROL
description: It is a tableau familiar to millions of television viewers, both today and in years past. Men in shirtsleeves, some with cigarettes in hand, some with Styrofoam coffee cups at the elbow, sit behind four ranks of control consoles, gazing at screens and switches and lights and buttons. Up front, the expansive master trajectory display board glows in contrasting black and turquoise.

title: Syrians and Christians Clash in Eastern Lebanon
description: Syrian forces and Lebanese Christian militiamen clashed today in the hills outside the predominantly Christian city of Zahle in eastern Lebanon, the police reported.

title: SHARON FASS, EDITOR, WED TO SAMUEL YATES
description: Sharon Abramowitz Fass, an associate editor with the general books division of the Reader's Digest Association in New York, was married yesterday to Samuel Langdon Yates of New York, director of financial planning for the television stations division of the National Broadcasting Company. The ceremony in the chapel of the Church Center for the United Nations was performed jointly by Rabbi Roy Rosenberg and the Rev. Eileen Lindner, a Presbyterian minister.

title: ANGELS 8, MARINERS 6
description: - Rod Carew, who had three hits and drove in two runs, stole home for the 17th time in his career with two out in the ninth inning as California ralled for four runs.

description: - The chairman of the International Harvester Company, Archie McCardell, has called union officials to a meeting this week to discuss the financial future of the struggiling company.

description: The organization of the Masters golf tournament is as impeccable as those green jackets the club members wear at the Augusta National course. So it is appropriate that when the Masters ends, the champion is impeccable in his green coat, too.

title: ETHEL BROWN FOERDERER
description: Ethel Brown Foerderer, a philanthropist and the widow of Percival E. Foerderer, head of a leather manufacturing business, died Thursday at her home in Haverford, Pa.

description: Yes, they've had requests for ''Melancholy Baby,'' but when one patron asked for Bach, they were able to oblige. If the ''Siciliano'' sonata is not the usual hotel bar fare, Margaret Chiurazzi and Betty Corpier are not the usual cocktail-hour musicians.

description: Charter Publishing Company to the Richards Group of Dallas for circulation advertising.

description: E. B. Long, a Civil War scholar and author and a professor of American Studies at the University of Wyoming, died March 31 of a heart attack while in Chicago on a speaking engagement. Mr. Long, who lived in Laramie, Wyo., was 61 years old.

description: Rochelle Gail Lefkowitz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Lefkowitz of Long Beach, L.I., was married yesterday to Lawrence Felix Kramer, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Kramer of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbis Bonnie Steinberg and Robert Goldenburg performed the ceremony at the Faculty House of Columbia University.

description: After 75 years of voyages that rocketed to the moon and plumbed the depths of the oceans, the men of the Explorers Club crossed a new frontier yesterday and agreed to admit women into their ranks.

title: Taxicabs After Dark
description: Come evenings next month, when the clock strikes eight, taxi fares will go up. New York's Taxi Commission has decided to tack an experimental 50-cent surcharge on nighttime and Sunday rides. Added incentives are needed, it says, to keep taxis on the street after the pre-theater rush.

KYOTO, Japan

title: KINGS CONQUER SUNS, NEED ONE TO CLINCH
description: Ernie Grunfeld poured in a gamehigh 27 points and Scott Wedman and Reggie King added 21 apiece to lead the surprising Kansas City Kings to a 102-95 victory over the Phoenix Suns and a 3-1 lead in their National Basketball Association playoff series.

description: Splendid Spruce, a 15-1 shot who had never won a stakes race, waited patiently on the rail for a mile, then rushed through an opening to win the $270,600 Santa Anita Derby today and earn himself a trip to the Kentucky Derby.

description: If the third turbine failed at Cos Cob, cutting off the plant's power entirely, all rail traffic east of Stamford to New Haven would halt, while a minimal power supply for the rest of the line could be maintained from a Consolidated Edison plant in the Bronx.

description: I T has been called the hidden handicap because it is not obvious, yet dyslexia can have corrosive effects on the ties that bind families together.

description: To the Editor:

title: ROBERT L. CRIPPEN
description: While John Young was establishing himself in the last two decades as one of the premier astronauts of the early space age, Bob Crippen was waiting. For 15 years he waited. That is how long he was an astronaut before he made his first trip into space.

title: ROBYN ELLEEN IS BRIDE OF ROBERT M. FIELDS, A LAWYER
description: Robyn Gail Elleen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Elleen of Morristown, N.J., and Robert Meddin Fields, son of Dr. and Mrs. Maurice Fields of Savannah, were married yesterday at the Manor in West Orange, N.J., by Rabbi Z. David Levy.

title: Officer Is Charged In Youth's Shooting
description: An officer of the Warwick Village Police Department in New York's Orange County has been charged with the reckless use of a weapon in the shooting of a teen-ager during a car chase that spilled into New Jersey Saturday night.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Chromalloy American Corp. signed a letter of intent to sell its Los Angeles water treatment division to Erie Manifacturing Inc., a private multinational company based in Milwaukee, for about $10.3 million.

title: PALM PROCESSION IN TROUBLED AREA
description: An Episcopal church here took its Palm Sunday procession to the streets today, stopping at neighborhood trouble spots for prayers asking deliverance ''from hopelessness and despair, from empty political promises'' and from the ravages of urban blight.

title: WITH STATE BUDGET OVERDUE, CAREY POSTPONES HONEYMOON
description: The honeymoon had to wait for Governor Carey and his new bride, Evangeline Gouletas-Carey, as Mr. Carey returned to state business tonight, meeting briefly with legislative leaders in an unsuccessful effort to break the impasse over the 1981-82 budget, now 12 days overdue.

title: Dollar Up Again in Tokyo
description: The dollar rose again against the yen at the start of foreign exchange trading today in Tokyo. Initial quotes put the dollar at 215.80 yen, more than 1 yen above Friday's record close of 214.55.

title: Auto Racer Killed
description: Junior Taft was killed last night when his super-modified stock car collided with another car on the final lap of a race at Tulsa Speedway.

title: State Dept. Aide Meets With Iraqi Foreign Chief
description: Morris Draper, a Deputy Assistant Secretary of State, held talks today with Foreign Minister Saadun Hamadi of Iraq. Mr. Draper's visit was the first publicly announced trip to the Iraqi capital by a high American official since Baghdad severed diplomatic relations with Washington after the 1967 Arab-Israel war.

title: Holmes Is Pushed to the Limit
description: For two weeks, Larry Holmes had been calling Trevor Berbick ''awkward,'' and maybe Holmes knew something. At Don King's party that ended early this morning, Holmes danced smoothly with his wife, Diane, while Berbick never risked the perils of the disco dance floor.

title: RIOTING SWEEPS LONDON DISTRICT FOR SECOND SAY
description: Hundreds of youths, most of them black, rampaged through the Brixton section of south London this evening in a second night of clashes with the police.

title: Oilers' Goalie Allows His Victory to Linger
description: Long after the giddiest moments of celebration were over last night, Andy Moog of the Edmonton Oilers had still not removed his goaltender's pads. Together, they had just helped complete a three-game sweep of the Montreal Canadiens. The dirty, worn pads and the 21-year-old goaltender with the baby face had been through too much in the last year and a half to hurry this moment.

description: Top-seeded Guillermo Vilas defeated Sammy Giammalva, 6-2, 6-4, today in the final of the $175,000 Houston National Tennis Championship.

title: INSIDERS AND THE LAW
description: EVERYONE is looking for an edge. In the stock market, the edge that is sought is called insider information. Stanley S. Arkin, of of the law firm of Arkin & Arishon, knows a lot about this topic. He defends individuals who have been accused of white collar crime.

title: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., April 12 (UPI) - The roar of the space shuttle's rocket engines frightened two bald eagles into leaving their nest at the Kennedy Space Center Sunday morning, Government biologists said.
description: But environmentally endangered brown pelicans, nesting 10 miles farther away, continued their fish-gulping, undisturbed by the racket.

title: No Headline
description: A picture caption yesterday incorrectly identified the maker of a disk kite flown in Central Park. The kite was made by Margaret Watts.

title: DR. OSCAR CHARDIET
description: Dr. Oscar Chardiet, associate clinical professor of psychiatry at the Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn, died Thursday at his Manhattan home.

title: LONG TERM YIELDS CLIMBING
description: High and erratic interest rates caused corporate treasurers and investment bankers to cancel much of last week's new issue calendar, and some analysts expect the same thing to happen this week when more than $1 billion of new issues is scheduled.

title: YANKS BEATEN BY RANGERS, 6-4, AS GUIDRY FAILS IN FIRST START
description: Despite three home runs - by Jerry Mumphrey, Bucky Dent and Graig Nettles - the Yankees and Ron Guidry lost to the Rangers yesterday, 6-4, thus allowing Don Zimmer, the latest in a seemingly endless succession of Texas managers, to show up for the opening of the Rangers' 10th season in Texas with one victory in three games.

title: Piquet, in Brabham, Wins Grand Prix of Argentina
description: Nelson Piquet of Brazil drove his Brabham to an easy victory today in the Argentine Grand Prix auto race.

title: CITY'S RETAIL SALES UP BY 13.5% IN MONTH
description: Sales for March and early April among New York City's biggest retailers registered strong increases over the similar period in 1980, according to a spot-check last week. Retailers said the sales gain mainly reflected the adverse impact of the city's transit strike on business in the 1980 period.

title: PENTAGON PLANNING TEST OF A SUBMARINE SYSTEM
description: - On President Reagan's orders, the Defense Department will test and operate a limited version of a controversial underground submarine-communication system in Wisconsin pending Mr. Reagan's decision late this year on a permanent program, according to the Pentagon.

title: MISS CAPONI'S 208 WINS BY SHOT
description: - Donna Caponi sant a short birdie putt on the 17th hole today to beat Cathy Sherk by a stroke in the $125,000 American Defender golf tournament. Miss Caponi shot a par 72 and finished at 208. Mrs. Sherk, who was four shots behind at the start of the final round, had 71-209.

title: FOR LIV ULLMANN, A NEW ROLE ON BEHALF OF UNICEF
description: ''There are many different languages to talk about suffering,'' said Liv Ullmann, the actress, who for the last year has been traveling around the world as a good-will ambassador for the United Nations Children's Fund. ''There are so many people you can never forget. I try to take the faces and images that I've seen and share them with others.''

title: Squires Wins Again For 11th Straight
description: Pete Squires of the New York Athletic Club registered his 11th straight victory since last December by winning the Manufacturers Hanover five-borough five-mile challenge run yesterday at Clove Lake Park in Staten Island.

title: Super-Accurate Clock
description: A clock described by the Guinness Book of World Records as the most accurate timekeeping device in the world -exact to within one second per 1.7 million years - has been turned over to the National Museum of American History in the Smithsonian Institution by the Naval Research Laboratory.

title: NEEDHAM HARPER & STEERS BUYS WASHINGTON FIRM
description: Needham, Harper & Streers Inc. has acquired the Washington public relations firm of Porter, Novelli & Associates.

title: AVOIDING MISTAKES OF THE PAST
description: - Will the much-talked-about new video technologies have an effect on the advertising creative product? John E. O'Toole, chairman of Foote, Cone & Belding, not only hopes so but has some specific ideas.

title: Reed Coach Of Creighton
description: Willis Reed, who led the Knicks to two National Basketball Association titles and coached them for one season and part of another, was named today as head basketball coach at Creighton University.

title: CONNORS BEATS MCENROE, 6-4, 7-6
description: Jimmy Connors defeated John McEnroe today, 6-4, 7-6, in the final of the $250,000 Suntory Cup tennis tournament. Playing before 14,500 spectators at the Tokyo Olympic indoor gymnasium, Connors took 1 hour and 50 minutes to beat McEnroe for the second straight year in this event.

title: LEARY GOES 2 INNINGS, LEAVES WITH STIFF ELBOW,AS METS WIN, 2-1
description: UF813CHICAGO, April 12 - In the business, Tim Leary of the New York Mets is known as a ''phenom,'' implying phenomenal promise for a rookie baseball player. Sometimes the word is used literally, but often satirically to suggest that nobody could be all that good.

title: Spurs Beat Rockets; Series Is 2-2
description: San Antonio's George Gervin scored 33 points and the Spurs held off a fourth-quarter rally by Houston today for a 114-112 victory in their National Basketball Association Western Division semifinal playoff game.

title: BRINGING THE CRAFT BACK DOWN: A TIME OF HIGH RISK
description: Getting a spaceship up is a task of near-maximum risk and anxiety. All the fire, thunder and vibration carry a message of manifest peril. But getting a spaceship down can be equally risky, and never more so than in the case of the space shuttle Columbia.

title: TO PISTOEL-PACKING ISRAELIS, A GUN IS A PATRIOTIC BADGE
description: The Mignan gun shop on Ben Sirah Street draws a mixed clientele. To the glass-topped counter come well-dressed men of means, rough-handed workers, young women and rangy settlers with automatic rifles slung over their shoulders.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: In a 1981 college football bowl game, I saw a player on the receiving team signal for a fair catch on a very high, short kickoff. Is that permitted?

title: Alouettes Continue To Talk With Scott
description: The Montreal Alouettes are negotiating with James Scott, the free-agent wide receiver, but have not reached agreement with him, the club's general manager, Bob Geary, said yesterday.

title: OBOE HOLLIGER SELLS OUT HOUSE
description: WHEN an oboe recital can fill Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium to overflowing as it did Saturday evening - crowding the stage with added seating and the rear of the hall with standees - something out of the ordinary is taking place. Heinz Holliger, the Swiss virtuoso, seems to excite this kind of attention, and his generous program of old and new music showed an extraordinary control - from the declamatory fortes of Telemann's D major Fantaisie to the Romantic whispers of Saint-Saens Sonata in the same key.

title: The Police Blotter
description: Police officers shot and wounded two men who were firing shots as they fled an apparent robbery at a Bronx apartment, United Press International reported. The officers approached the suspects at 166th Street and Nelson Avenue, near a crowded park in the Morris Heights section.

title: TECHNICIANS TRYING TO ASSESS LOSS OF 13 OR MORE TILES
description: The space shuttle Columbia lost more than a dozen of its heat-protection tiles today, but space agency officials here said they were quite confident that there was no danger to the space shuttle or its two astronauts.

title: CZECHOSLVAKIA ROUTS U.S. IN WORLD HOCKEY, 11-2
description: Jiri Lala scored four goals and Czechoslovakia capitalized on power-play opportunities for four more yesterday to post an 11-2 victory over the United States on the opening day of the world ice hockey championships.

title: East Defeats West In Aloha Basketball
description: The East, led by Danny Schayes of Syracuse and Mike McGee of Michigan, ran off 15 consecutive points late in the second half last night to score a 113-97 victory over the West and win the team title in the Aloha Classic.

title: EISENHOWER PRESS SECRETARY
description: James C. Hagerty, the White House press secretary under President Dwight D. Eisenhower, died Saturday afternoon at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville, N.Y. He was 71 years old.

title: Birth Announcements
description: When the wives of baseball players have babies, the men are often the last ones to get the news. Dyar Miller of the Mets found out about his second child when he got a call in the Baltimore bullpen at the same time the news was being announced on the Oriole scoreboard.

title: WATSON SHOOTS 71-280 AND WINS MASTERS BY 2 STROKES
description: Tom Watson stood up to the pressure of the back nine today to win the 45th Masters Tournament by two strokes over Johnny Miller and Jack Nicklaus. Miller, Nicklaus and at least three others threatened Watson for varying periods of time.

title: YORTY HOPING TO FORCE MAYOR BRADLEY INTO A RUNOFF IN LOS ANGLES
