description: Although 19 persons are running for Mayor in Tuesday's nonpartisan election, only one, former Mayor Sam Yorty, is likely to give the incumbent, Tom Bradley, any competition.

title: A CURIOUS CONVOY IS SET TO GREET SHUTTLE IN CALIFORNIA
description: Four men and one woman, wearing astronaut-style spacesuits and carrying instruments to sniff the air for toxic and explosive vapors, will be the first persons to greet the astronauts John W. Young and Robert L. Crippen when they return to earth.

title: FAMILY OF TEEN-AGER STABBED AT DISNEYLAND FILES $60 MILLION LAWSUIT
description: The family of a teen-ager who was fatally stabbed at Disneyland has filed a $60 million suit against the amusement park alleging wrongful death, but Disneyland officials said that they would deny any liability.

title: THEATER: MARQUES PLAY BY PUERTO RICAN TROUPE
description: FOR 14 years, the Puerto Rican Traveling Theater, under the artistic direction of Miriam Colon Edgar, has been touring parks, streets and prisons in all the boroughs of New York City, offering plays in Spanish and English. The nomadic troupe recently moved into its first permanent indoor home in a converted firehouse on 47th Street, just off Eighth Avenue. The 196-seat theater is handsome, intimate and modern, and also has space for Mrs. Edgar's supplementary training programs. The new playhouse should help the Puerto Rican Traveling Theater consolidate its valuable activities and, because of its Broadway location, it should attract a diverse audience.

title: FILM-TV WRITERS TO STRIKE TODAY
description: Movie and television writers will begin setting up picket lines outside 20th-Century Fox Film Studios tomorrow morning and from there will move to the networks and other major producers, a spokesman for the 8,500-member Writers Guild of America said today.

title: Micki Grant's Next May Be About a Revolutionary Poet
description: Micki Grant is not a playwright who likes to talk much about her plays before they're finished, but she may have let the cat out of the bag the other night during a guarded chat about her current project.

title: An Eagle Wasn't Enough for Carol Greitzer
description: It's not that Carol Greitzer has anything against eagles, but when the Manhattan feminist and longtime member of the New York City Council spends 18 cents for a stamp, she likes to see a woman. And when Mrs. Greitzer was told that the only stamp available for invitations to a fund-raising party planned next month was the standard eagle, she took steps.

title: Striking Ohio Teachers Vote To Return to Work Today
description: Striking teachers voted tonight to return to classes tomorrow, ending the longest teachers' strike in the nation's history five months to the day after the walkout began.

title: MUSIC: A MOZART-SALIERI REUNION
description: WHAT hath ''Amadeus'' wrought? Peter Schaffer's Broadway success exploring the rivalry between Antonio Salieri and the young Mozart has suddenly made the older composer a subject of curiosity after a century and a half of complete - and, some would maintain, welldeserved - obscurity. With Salieri holding theatergoers in thrall on the great white way every night, it was only a matter of time before some enterprising musical organization decided to investigate his music.

title: CHAMBER: CENTER SOCIETY
description: WILLIAM SCHUMAN has been one of American music's most influential men for a long time. As a composer, he has contributed several significant works to the repertory. He served as president of the Juilliard School and as the first president of Lincoln Center. There is hardly an aspect of the musical arts in this country that he has not helped oversee. In fact, his industry as an administrator and educator sometimes has tended to obscure his more creative efforts.

title: Jones Takes Playoff
description: Tom Jones eased in a 6-foot putt for a par on the second hole of a sudden-death playoff and won the Magnolia Classic tournament today.

title: PEOPLE
description: Jackie End has joined the Marschalk Company as senior vice president and associate creative director.

title: GERMANY'S ECONOMY STUMBLES
description: West Germany, ''the engine of Europe,'' is in the midst of recession, and its entrenched economic problems have raised nagging questions about whether the country will ever regain its role as Western Europe's financial leader.

title: DEBORAH HART, COLUMNIST, MARRIED TO GERALD STROBER
description: Deborah Benjamin, professionally known as Deborah Hart, and Gerald Strober were married yesterday afternoon at Congregation Bnai Jeshurun, by Rabbi William Berkowitz, president of the Jewish National Fund, and spiritual leader of the congregation.

title: Spofford G. English Dead at 65; Helped Develop the Atom Bomb
description: Spofford G. English, a group leader with the Manhattan Project, which developed the atomic bomb, died last week of cancer at his home in Bethesda, Md. He was 65 years old.

title: WALCOTT, HEARNS CALL LOUIS AN INSPIRATION
description: When the news reached ringside here that Joe Louis died of a heart attack this morning in Las Vegas, Nev., Jersey Joe Walcott, his old opponent and friend, cried.

title: TV: 'SATURDAY NIGHT LIVE' IS BACK WITH NEW CAST
description: ''SATURDAY NIGHT LIVE'' on NBC-TV has somehow evolved from television's most progressive show to one of its most nostalgic. This weekend's program even went so far as to begin with the host, Chevy Chase, rummaging through a cobwebby storeroom filled with memorabilia of the Coneheads and Mr. Bill, memorabilia the audience greeted much more enthusiastically than any of the new material that followed.

title: Switch in Negotiations for an Expert Negotiator
description: Planners for the 1984 Los Angeles Olympics say they've found exactly the right man to serve as chairman of the event's Advisory Commission on International Relations.

title: ASTRONAUTS' FAMILIES GATHERED FOR LIFTOFF
description: The families of the shuttle astronauts, John W. Young and Capt. Robert L. Crippen, flew home to Houston from Florida today after watching the fiery launching of the space shuttle Columbia.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''That was one fantastic ride. I highly recommend it.'' - Capt. Robert L. Crippen, on his first space mission.

title: Texaco-Amoco Well
description: Texaco Inc. and the Amoco International Oil Company said on Friday that they had struck oil at a wildcat well they have been drilling in a remote part of northern Guatemala. They said they would drill two more wells at the site.

title: TV: 'REAL LIFE STORIES' IN SOAPS TIME
description: TELEVISION'S reality binge -covering everything from ''60 Minutes'' to ''That's Incredible!'' - staggers on this afternoon with ''Real Life Stories.'' Being shown on CBS-TV at 4 P.M. this week, Monday through Friday, these half-hours are a pilot for a regular daytime series.

title: HINCKLEY INQUIRY STUDIES ALLEGED NAZI 'FLIRTATION'
description: Michael Allen of Chicago, the 29-year-old leader of the most visible contingent of American Nazis, recalls that the first time he saw John W. Hinckley Jr., in March of 1978, there was little to distinguish the young man except his Storm Trooper's uniform.

title: 20,000 in Jersey To Pick a Union
description: TRENTON (UPI) - The State Public Employment Relations Commission has ordered a runoff election in May between two A.F.L.-C.I.O. affiliates seeking to represent nearly 20,000 state professional workers and primary-level supervisors.

title: SPORTS FANS ON THE MOVE
description: Nelson Skalbania, an entrepreneur from Vancouver, British Columbia, seems to be close to fulfilling his dream of owning a professional franchise in every major sport in the North America.

title: FIVE AGENCIES WIN $21 MILLION IN ACCOUNTS
description: Last week five accounts totaling more than $21 million in billings found new homes.

title: SUSPECT FINDS HOLE IN SYSTEM
description: They do agree that Jody Fricker dashed out of the Manhattan Criminal Courts building Saturday morning when he shouldn't have. They do not agree on who was responsible.

title: TORRE WANTS METS TO FLY AS CARDINALS DID
description: THE tins of fat pretzels will be back in Joe Torre's office tomorrow in Shea Stadium. So will the boxes of fat cigars. Tony, the faithful friend, will be handling a bunch of details. Brothers Rocco and Frank may sit on the couch and lend a family presence, and sisters Rae and Marguerite may telephone their support from the house in Brooklyn where the Mets' manager was born.

title: Pirate Homers Top Expos, 3-2
description: Dave Parker and Jason Thompson hit consecutive home runs off Ray Burris to lead the Pirates to a 3-2 victory over Montreal today.

title: 3 for Chinaglia as Cosmos Win
description: The Cosmos, playing before the smallest opening-day crowd since 1977, 40,378, defeated the Minnesota Kicks, 3-1, at Giants Stadium today.

title: BRADY MAKES CALL TO SECURITY AIDE
description: James S. Brady, the White House press secretary, who was severely wounded in the assassination attempt on President Reagan, telephoned Mr. Reagan's national security adviser yesterday for a 15-minute discussion on foreign policy.

title: A Different Tune on El Salvador
description: Bit by bit, the Reagan Administration is retreating in its El Salvador policy to a position strikingly similar - dare we say it? - to that of the Carter Administration. For weeks, Secretary of State Haig could see only one cause for violence in the tiny Central American republic: left-wing, Soviet-abetted terrorism.

title: U.S. TV Plant Set by Koreans
description: The Gold Star Company, a large South Korean electronics manufacturer, will build a $5 million television production plant in Huntsville, Ala. that will eventually produce 400,000 color television sets a year, company officials said in New York on Friday.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard GEORGE ORWELL: A Life. by Bernard Crick. Illustrated. 473 pages. Atlantic- Little, Brown. $17.95.

title: SOME WEPT, SOME SLEPT AND SOME SAW LIFTOFF AS A BIG WASTE OF MONEY
description: Much of the world joined Americans early yesterday morning in watching the space shuttle Columbia thunder away from its launching site on Cape Canaveral, Fla., and streak into the earth's orbit.

title: One Killed As Avalanche Buries 4 Skiers Near Seattle
description: An avalanche today near Snoqualmie Pass buried four of eight cross-country skiers as the party attempted to escape a severe storm in the mountains, the police said. One of the skiers died.

title: Three-Alarm Fire Sweeps Building on E. 52d St.
description: Chemical foam covered the sidewalk in front of an apartment building at 38 East 52d Street yesterday as firemen brought a three-alarm blaze under control. Residents were removed as 135 firemen and 21 pieces of equipment fought the fire. Seven persons were slightly injured.

title: SHOSTAKOVICH SON AND GRANDSON DEFECT
description: The son and grandson of the late Soviet composer Dmitri Shostakovich are seeking political asylum in West Germany, the Interior Ministry reported today.

title: TAX SERVICE DELUGED AS 15TH NEARS
description: ''You don't want to know how busy it is,'' said Millie Pitkowsky, the harried manager of an H.& R. Block office on Manhattan's Upper West Side. ''For my husband, it's been grounds for divorce,'' she said, pausing between returns in a room crowded with waiting clients.

title: Two Hostages Held Briefly In Indiana Inmates' Protest
description: Prisoners protesting living conditions at the St. Joseph County jail escaped from their cells today and held two hostages for three hours until city and county police attacked the building. No injuries were reported.

title: ADDENDA
description: Fred Gardner Company has changed its named to Fitzerald Gardner Company.

title: The U.N. Today; April 13, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Special Committee on Enhancing Non-Use of Force in International Relations - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: JOHN W. YOUNG
description: With his unlined face, his mere hint of gray hair and his sometimes wryly self-effacing manner, John W. Young doesn't exactly look or act the part. But at the age of 50 he is the chief, the astronaut's astronaut, the dean of the corps, the wise old man among spacefarers.

title: COAL MINERS WEST AND EAST: SAME PACT, CONTRARY VIEWS
description: The long valley of the north fork of the Gunnison River here, where the steeply pitched foothills block the view of distant, snow-capped Rockies, could almost be mistaken for a coal mine hollow in West Virginia.

title: VIDEODISK SALES HAVE MIXED START
description: After all the fanfare that the RCA Corporation used to introduce its SelectaVision videodisk system, the debut of the company's newest and most important product in more than 20 years has been something of an anticlimax.

title: Text of Statement
description: You go forward this morning in a daring enterprise and you take the hopes and prayers of all Americans with you. You go in the hand of God and draw on the courage of life.

title: PRESSUE BALL
description: As a freshman without a scholarship at Florida, Mike Fuentes did not make the baseball team. In his second season, he made the team, but played in only eight games and had no home runs.

title: Sex and the Selfish Gene
description: Our guess is that female academics all over the country nodded knowingly on reading a statement out of Harvard last week. A university grievance commmittee decided that Theda R. Skocpol, an associate professor of sociology, had been denied tenure because of her gender, although it was unable to find direct evidence of overt sexual discrimination.

title: SOVIET VESSEL IS WARNED AWAY
description: The Columbia spaceship's two solid-propellant booster rockets were retrieved today by two specially built ships. It was the first recovery ever made of space vehicles intended for re-use.

title: Washington Watch; Customs Study Seen as Hint
description: WASHINGTON INITIATORS of the study disavow any connection, but the recently undertaken inquiry into import entry procedures is interpreted as another form of subtle pressure being placed on Japan to agree to voluntary export restraints on car shipments to the United States.

title: SCHEDULE
description: Following are the scheduled times and events for the mission of the space shuttle Columbia on Monday and Tuesday. All times are Eastern Standard Time.

title: BLOODLESS DEER CONTROL
description: To the Editor:

title: WATSON'S BIGGEST FOE
description: AUGUSTA, Ga. HALFWAY through the 1977 Masters Tournament that Tom Watson would win, he was asked to rate his toughest opponent over the last 36 holes that year. ''Myself,'' he said. In golf, it's always that way. In a tournament of the magnitude of the Masters, anybody in contention is going to be nervous, as Tom Watson acknowledged he was yesterday in winning the Masters again. The trick is to be able to control that nervousness, as Tom Watson did so well.

title: MOTHER OF JAILED SOVIET DISSIDENT SAYS HE IS BEING DENIED VISITORS
description: The mother of the convicted Soviet dissident Anatoly B. Shcharansky said today that she had received a letter from her son informing her that he has been denied visitation rights for all of 1981.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, APRIL 13, 1981
description: Voyage of Columbia Columbia blasted into space from the Kennedy Space Center in Florida, manned by two astronauts, John W. Young and Capt. Robert L. Crippen of the Navy. The test flight of the world's first re-usable spaceship is scheduled for 36 orbits around the earth, lasting 54 1/2 hours and ending at Edwards Air Force Base in California. Soon after the takeoff, the astronauts discovered that more than a dozen heatshielding tiles on the craft's fuselage had ripped off in launching, but project officials said it would not endanger the flight. (Page A1, Column 6.) The space shuttle at least a dozen tiles, probably from the stress of its launching, but space agency officials said they were confident that the loss posed no danger to the spaceship or its crew. The tiles are designed to protect against temperature extremes in orbit and on re-entry to the earth's atmostphere. The loss was a vivid reminder of problems with the system that contributed greatly to delays in launching the first shuttle flight. Teams of technicians were gathering all possible data to assess the situation. (A1:3-5.)

title: JURY SELECTION IN RACKETEERING TRIAL ENTERS THIRD WEEK
description: The laborious process of choosing a jury in the trial of Carlos Marcello, reputedly an organized crime figure, and four other defendants enters its third week here tomorrow, with three jurors and six alternates still to be selected.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Beaumont State Bank, Dallas, has named Ronald L. Parrish chairman and chief executive officer. -Chemical New York Corp. and Chemical Bank have named Alan H. Fishman executive vice president-finance.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a transmission error, an article in Metropolitan Report on Saturday misstated the terms of a proposed sale of Lake Minnewaska and the surrounding land in upstate New York. The Marriott Corporation would pay the owners $1.85 million in cash, 1.5 percent of the selling price of each condominium built on the property and 0.35 percent of revenues for 99 years from a hotel to be built.

title: JOE LOUIS, 66, HEAVYWEIGHT KING WHO REIGNED 12 YEARS, IS DEAD
description: Joe Louis, who held the heavyweight boxing championship of the world for almost 12 years and the affection of the American public for most of his adult life, died yesterday of cardiac arrest in Las Vegas, Nev. He was 66 years old.

title: GERMAN'S SOVIET PIPE SALE
description: - Mannesmann Handel A.G., a subsidiary of Mannesmann A.G., and Thyssen Stahlunion G.m.b.H, a Thyssen A.G. subsidiary, have won an order to supply 550,000 tons of large steel pipes to the Soviet Union through March 1982, a Mannesmann spokesman said Friday. The value of the order was not disclosed, but the spokesman said it was part of a regular series of pipe deliveries to the Soviet Union, the last of which, for 700,000 tons, expired this week.

title: New Arts Festival Planned
description: According to legend, Rip Van Winkle slept away two decades in the town of Palenville, N.Y., and Joseph Frank (Jay) Pouhe is hoping to prove next summer that the community is wide awake - with the first Pine Orchard Artists Festival, sponsored by the newly formed Traverse Opera Ltd.

title: Dodgers 3, Astros 2
description: Ken Landreaux had a two-run homer and a double to lead the Dodgers to a sweep of their three-game series with Houston.

title: SOPRANO: BIRGIT NILSSON IN TWO WAGNER RECITALS
description: WHEN Birgit Nilsson is in town and wants to sing, there is only one thing to do: find the means to make it possible. That partly accounts for the two specially arranged Wagner concerts at the Metropolitan Opera over the weekend. Saturday afternon's program came about as a last-minute substitution for one of the canceled ''Fidelio'' performances, while last night's concert was planned a couple of months ago to help lend a bit of vocal glamour to an otherwise patchy season.

title: New Political Party Planned For Whites in Zimbabwe
description: Andre Holland, who served as a Deputy Minister of Information, Immigration and Tourism in the white minority Government of Ian D. Smith before Zimbabwe gained independence, announced today that he was leaving Mr. Smith's Rhodesian Front to form a new party.

title: WALTRIP IS VICTOR IN REBEL 500
description: DARLINGTON, S.C., April 12 (AP) Darrell Waltrip fended off a challenge from Harry Gant for nearly half the race today to win the $200,000 CRC Chemicals Rebel 500 at Darlington International Raceway.

title: POLISH COMMUNISTS ASSURE THEIR ALLIES THEY WILL END CRISIS
description: The Polish Communists, facing mounting pressure from their allies for speedy action, pledged here today to seek a ''political solution'' of the Polish crisis by mobilizing the party for a struggle against enemies of Communism and ''counterrevolutionaries.''

title: COLUMBIA CRWEW QUARTERS ARE 'TOURIST' FOR NOW BUT FUTURE IS 'FIRST CLASS'
description: Life aboard the space shuttle Columbia is precise, structured and sanitary, but little effort will be made on this trip to provide the kind of ordered living conditions astronauts might expect later on, when much longer flights are attempted, according to officials of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

title: KENNEDY BIDS BIDS DEMOCRATS FIGHT REPUBLICAN 'REACTION'
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy, sharing a platform with a possible Presidential rival of 1984, told former Vice President Walter F. Mondale and 4,000 other Minnesota Democrats yesterday that if the Democrats want to regain power they must forthrightly oppose Republican ''reaction'' now.

title: International
description: The West German recession raises doubts about Bonn's future as the economic engine of Europe. Economists fear that the downturn, which is expected to be temporary, has severely damaged West Germany's business structure. (Page D1.)

title: LONG-TERM YIELDS CLIMBING
description: Just a few months ago, as the Reagan Administration was moving in, some bond traders were eager to buy Treasury bonds yielding less than 12 1/2 percent because they expected yields to drop even further. They may still be right, but they will have to wait a while longer.

title: Discussions On Interest
description: Finance ministers and government bankers from the United States, West Germany, Japan, France and Britain ended a two-day meeting here Sunday, but refused to disclose details of their talks.

title: Fontana Is Winner Of Singles, Doubles
description: Tom Fontana of Matawan, N.J., won the singles and doubles titles today in the 15th annual Concord Hotel junior men's invitation tennis tournament.

title: HOME REPAIR GAINS SPUR EXPANSION AT HECHINGER CO.
description: ''If you can't find it at Hechinger, either it doesn't exist or it isn't worth owning,'' said Philip J. Mansfield, the company's executive vice president.

title: Protest at Upstate Missile Site
description: About 600 demonstrators gathered today outside Griffiss Air Force Base to protest plans to house 200 Cruise missiles at the installation. The protest was sponsored by the Cruise Control Action Project, a coalition of 18 peace groups from throughout the state. Organizers said the Cruise missile carries a 200-kiloton nuclear warhead, about 15 times the power of the bomb dropped on Hiroshima.

title: LISA BALDWIN MARRIED
description: The marriage of Lisa Baldwin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sherman L. Baldwin of Greenwich, Conn., to Louis T. Berizzi, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Berizzi also of Greenwich, took place there on Saturday in the Round Hill Community Church.

title: Bridge: Fine New York Team Loses An Argument and a Match
description: It is known that history, including bridge history, sometimes repeats itself. But for it to do so within a week is a rarity. A week ago a New York team that had four reigning national champions on it built up a big lead in a Grand National team match but lost in the last quarter to some determined opponents.

title: Average Family Pays $178.41 for Energy
description: The energy bill for an average New York City household cost $178.41 last month, 18.7 percent more than a year ago, when the cost was $150.36, the city's Consumer Affairs Department said in its monthly energy report. Based on typical March weather, this included $133.04 for space and water heating, $36.89 for electricity and $8.48 for cooking.

title: Funds Halted for A-Plant
description: President Reagan has told Energy Secretary James B. Edwards that the Federal Government will not buy or support the Nuclear Fuels Plant in Barnwell, S.C., the Charlotte Observer reported yesterday. The $362 million plant, built to reprocess spent fuel rods but never licensed for that purpose, has been operated for research since 1977.

title: JONES SEES MOVE FOR ACCORD ON TAX CUT
description: Representative James R. Jones, chairman of the House Budget Committee, said today that the White House, for the first time, appeared to be willing to compromise on its economic package by considering a one-year income tax cut instead of three successive years of tax cuts.

title: Twins Swept by A's
description: Steve McCatty pitched hitless ball for six and two-thirds innings and stopped Minnesota on three singles today as Oakland beat the Twins, 1-0, and swept their fourgame opening series.

title: CHRYSLER JOINS FORD IN FREEZING PRICES
description: The Chrysler Corporation said today that it would hold the line on prices, at least for now, thus joining the Ford Motor Company in a bid to increase sales at the expense of the industry leader, General Motors.

title: TUSKEGEE INSTITUTE GOING STRONG AT 100
description: One hundred years after its founding, Tuskegee Institute, built on a shoestring with volunteer labor, is still running on a shoestring and, in some respects, on volunteer labor.

title: Bucks Top 76ers and Tie Series
description: Bob Lanier got the best of Darryl Dawkins and Marques Johnson was simply too good for the entire Philadephia 76er front line today.

title: Quaker Oats Option
description: The Quaker Oats Company said on Friday that it had paid $3.50 a share for an option to buy, at $34 a share, the 961,700 shares of Quaker Oats common stock held by Brascan Ltd. of Toronto. The option runs through mid-June. Quaker Oats said Brascan had agreed that if the option were exercised it would not again purchase Quaker Oats shares for at least five years.

title: News Analysis
description: Caspar W. Weinberger seemed to come into his own as Secretary of Defense while in Europe last week. He had gotten off to a shaky start in January, when his ignorance of military affairs was painfully evident during his initial testimony before Congress, but with each public appearance since then, he has displayed a stronger grasp of the issues. In his swing through Britain, West Germany and Italy, he was clearly in command of the material.

title: Stanley Sets Record For Penn Marathon
description: Terry Stanley, the cross-country coach at St. Bonaventure, won the ninth annual Penn Relays marathon today, covering the course in a record 2 hours 17 minutes 34 seconds.

title: Diagnosing Nuclear War
description: The idea that a nuclear war can be ''limited'' to military targets and ''won'' by the better-prepared side has been glibly spread in recent years. Even officials who doubt both propositions, like former Defense Secretary Brown, yielded to weapons programs and targeting doctrines based on such concepts. And President Reagan has said he will pursue that path, pressing ahead with a huge, highly accurate MX missile that can carry 10 hydrogen warheads in a ''limited'' strike at Soviet military targets.

title: Reagan Aide, in Salisbury, Rules Out 'Tilt' on Apartheid
description: Chester A. Crocker, President Reagan's Assistant Secretary of State-designate for African Affairs, said today that there would be no ''tilt or endorsement of apartheid'' in South Africa by the Reagan Administration.

title: Emile Heyrman, 79, Ex-President Of Belgian Shipping Line, Is Dead
description: Emile Heyrman, former president and chairman of the board of the Belgian Line, died Saturday at St. Charles Hospital in Port Jefferson, L.I. He was 79 years old and a resident of Port Jefferson and the Caribbean island of Montserrat.

title: RESTAURATER TELLS OF '55 MARRIGE TO MRS. GOULETAS CAREY
description: ''My family in Chicago called to say that it was in The New York Times that I was dead,'' said Frangiskos Kallaniotis, the first husband of Evangeline Gouletas-Carey. ''I am not dead. I'm alive. I don't know why she would say that.''

title: WORN POWER PLANT SETS PACE FOR CONRAIL COMMUTERS
description: As his father had been for 48 years and his grandfather for more than 30, Roger A. Nichols is a railroad man on the New Haven line. This week he was back again at the Cos Cob power plant here, overseeing repairs on one of the giant generators that provide the electricity to move 40,000 commuters into and out of New York City each workday.

title: Brezhnev, Looking Fit, Casts Vote In Moscow for a Parliament Seat
description: Leonid I. Brezhnev voted today in an election to fill the parliamentary seat of the late Prime Minister Aleksei N. Kosygin.

title: Hess's Condition Said to Worsen
description: Rudolf Hess, the 86-year-old onetime deputy and private secretary to Adolf Hitler, is seriously ill with pneumonia, but the Allied powers refuse to reveal his true condition, his son said today. Wolf Hess said the condition of his father, who is serving a life sentence in Spandau Prison, had deteriorated so much that he was near death over the weekend.

title: Nassau School Study Cites Vandalism Cost
description: Vandalism in Nassau County's 57 school districts cost taxpayers $1.5 million last year, according to the County Executive.

title: Nordiques 4, Flyers 3
description: QUEBEC (UPI) - Dale Hunter, capping a surge of three consecutive goals, scored 37 seconds into overtime to even Quebec's series with Philadelphia at two victories each.

title: Ken Forsch Signs
description: Ken Forsch, the pitcher obtained in a trade two weeks ago from Houston for Dickey Thon, has signed a multiyear contract with the California Angels. Financial terms were not disclosed.

title: Commodities; Separating Futures Entities
description: ALTHOUGH the roots of most leading Wall Street brokerage houses may be traced to the commodity markets, they had until recent years kept their commodity operations in the corporate closet. The reason was that no matter how lucrative the commodity departments were, they were considered the antithesis of the prudent investment image the houses had spent fortunes to create.

title: Index; Voyage of Columbia
description: Astronauts have a constant dialogue with ground controllers A1 Launching seen as symbol of nation's prestige by many A9 Shuttle's boosters retrieved; Soviet vessel is warned away A9 The families of the astronauts are flown home to Texas A10 President Reagan watches the Columbia launching on television A11 Reaction to the liftoff ranges from pride to indifference A11 A curious convoy is set to greet shuttle in California desert A12 Thousands spread out on beaches to watch the liftoff of Columbia A13 Creature comforts are limited on first voyage of Columbia A15 International To Israelis, a gun is a patriotic badge A2 Around the World A5 Mother of Soviet dissident says he can have no visitors in '81 A8 Government/Politics Yorty strongest foe of Bradley in Los Angeles mayoral race A18 Coal miners in West differ with those in East on contract A18 Honeymoon has to wait as Carey returns to state business B3 Reporter's Notebook: Drama at Abscam trial of Williams B5 Brady phones Reagan security adviser B8 General Around the Nation A18 Neo-Nazi link is key element in Reagan shooting case A20 A suspect flees a Manhattan court and officials blame each other B3 Jury selection in trial of reputed mob figure enters third week B9 Obituaries Representative Tennyson Guyer of Ohio D10 SportsMonday Baseball: Yanks, with Guidry, lose to Rangers, 6-4 C3

title: 'THE AMERICAN DREAM'-- HISTORY OF A CLICHE
description: We don't ordinarily think of cliches as having an origin, but of course they do. Someone once said for the first time (and may the gods forgive him), ''He can't see the forest for the trees.'' Someone else first advised us to ''leave no stone unturned.'' So it is with ''the American Dream.'' This overworked phrase didn't arise spontaneously out of the primordial ooze of the American language. Someone thought it up - and this time we know whom to blame. It was the historian James Truslow Adams, and he invented ''the American Dream'' in 1931, making the phrase the theme of his book ''The Epic of America,'' published that same year.

title: Missouri to Aid Inquiry
description: University of Missouri officials say they will cooperate with an investigation into allegations that gamblers affected the outcome of two late-season Big Eight basketball games.

title: ARLEEN JAN RICHTER MARRIED TO DR. RICHARD LEVY, DENTIST
description: Arleen Jan Richter, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Emanuel Richter of Newport Beach, Calif., was married yesterday to Dr. Richard Alan Levy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sid Levy of White Plains.

title: GEORGE MANDELBAUM
description: George Mandelbaum, who specialized in corporate, matrimonial and estate law, died yesterday at St. Vincent's Hospital.

title: ISLANDERS WAIT FOR AN OPPONENT AFTER SWEEP OVER MAPLE LEAFS
description: Ending as one-sided a series as National Hockey League fans had seen in some time, the Islanders beat the Toronto Maple Leafs, 6-1, last night to complete a sweep of their three-offive-game preliminary-round playoff series. The Islanders scored a record 20 goals to only 4 for Toronto in the series, and there was little left to do except talk about how awfully the Leafs played and how good the Islanders looked.

title: REP. TENNYSON GUYER, 67, OF OHIO
description: Representative Tennyson Guyer, a Republican who had represented his Ohio district in Congress since 1972, was found dead yesterday at his home in Alexandria, Va. He was 67 years old.

title: CON ED LINKS CREATING JOBS TO RATE CUTS FOR BUSINESSES
description: The Consolidated Edison Company has proposed offering discounted electric rates to businesses that will create or expand jobs in eight economically depressed areas of the Bronx and Brooklyn.

title: Park Crackdown Set On Dog-Waste Law
description: Beginning tomorrow, special teams from the Sanitation Department will patrol New York City's parks in an attempt to increase compliance by dog owners with the city's dog-waste cleanup law, according to Sanitation Commissioner Norman Steisel.

title: SINGLE ISSUE VIEWING
description: At the annual conclave of advertising agencies, the presidents of the three commercial television networks waxed righteously indignant on a single theme: sinister forces claiming to represent morality were organizing economic boycotts to frighten advertisers from controversial programming, and were thus imposing censorship on what the mass of Americans want to see.

title: REAGAN SEES LAUNCHING ON TV AT WHITE HOUSE
description: On his first full day back in the White House since he was wounded in an assassination attempt, President Reagan arose at 6:50 A.M. today to watch the televised launching of the space shuttle Columbia on its first orbital flight.

title: Reichmanns Family Has 20% Stake in MacMillan
description: The Reichmann family of Toronto, which has major holdings in key Canadian industries, has emerged with a 20 percent interest in MacMillan Bloedel Ltd. of Vancouver in the wake of the withdrawal of the British Columbia Resources Investment Corporation from the bidding contest for MacMillan.

title: Brazil Oil Output Up 13.5%
description: Brazil's oil production rose 13.5 percent, to 19 million barrels, in the first quarter of 1981 from 1980's first quarter, a spokesman for Petrobras, the state oil company, said Friday.

title: Landslide on Mountain in Alaska Is Mistaken for Volcanic Eruption
description: A huge landslide on Mount Sanford was mistaken for a volcanic eruption by nearby residents and airline pilots passing overhead yesterday, a University of Alaska scientist says.

title: BANKS TALLY THE COST OF NOW
description: Commercial banks across the country have absorbed the greatest share of the billions of dollars that have poured into NOW accounts since the beginning of the year.

title: GIVING THE RUSSIANS A CHANCE TO CATCH UP
description: To the Editor:

title: PIANO: PERAHIA INTERPERTS BACH
description: WHETHER you love any particular one of his performances or find it frustrating, Murray Perahia remains one of the most compelling, distinctive young pianists of his generation. Mr. Perahia, who gave his only New York recital of the season Friday night at Avery Fisher Hall, has fingers that he can command to do anything he wants; his sheer, understated virtuosity is continually remarkable.

title: WOMEN IN MEDICINE FIND A NEED FOR SUPPORT
description: In what was believed to be one of the largest gatherings of women in medicine ever held in this country, female doctors were advised in New York over the weekend to become more assertive - both at work and with their husbands - to shed their traditional reluctance to join medical societies and to help stamp out the ''queen bee syndrome'' in medicine.

title: Soviet Warships to Visit Cuba
description: Three Soviet warships and a tanker will arrive at Havana Wednesday for a 10-day visit, the Soviet press agency Tass said today. The contingent includes the antisubmarine ship Nikolayev, the escort ships Svirepy and Bgitelny and the tanker Olekma, Tass said.

title: DR. ALEXANDER BUDIN
description: Dr. Alexander Budin, rabbi emeritus of Congregation Ohab Zedek in Belle Harbor, Queens, died Thursday at his home in Belle Harbor.

title: NADER OFFERS BUSINESS LEGAL-FEE TIPS
description: Ralph Nader, often portrayed as the nemesis of corporations, says he wants to help them save some money. Mr. Nader today invited exeecutives to a May 18 conference here. He said it would teach them how to reduce the cost of legal fees paid to outside law firms. These fees, he said, ''have gone through the ceiling'' in the last two decades.

title: ARGENTINE DEFENDS HUMAN RIGHTS STAND
description: Argentina's top foreign policy priority is to improve relations with the United States and Europe, but not at the expense of changing its approach to human rights, according to Oscar Camilion, the country's new Foreign Minister.

title: GREEN BERET'S GRIGRI
description: ''Just look up at the sky and see what's coming down, if there's any doubt about American support,'' said the diplomat. ''That's the spectacular answer.''

title: Red Smith; Joe Louis A Sense Of Dignity
description: WHEN Joe Louis's tax troubles were still making headlines, a man told him: ''You were 15 years ahead of your time. You should have been around today to cut in on these multimillion-dollar closedcircuit shows.''

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: DRAMA AS 1 PERCENT OF U.S. SENATE IS TRIED
description: Once more the Federal Bureau of Investigation videotapes are rolling, and once more tales of incredibly rich Arab sheiks and allegedly corrupt American politicians fill Federal District Court in Brooklyn.

title: 'YEEEOW!' AND DOGGONE!' ARE SHOUTED ON BEACHES AS CROWDS WATCH LIFTOFF
description: They came from every corner of the country and spread out by the thousands on beaches across the Indian River from the Kennedy Space Center. The sun had just risen over the Atlantic behind them and their eyes were riveted on the space shuttle Columbia, pointing straight up on its launching pad and only a moment away from a thunderous liftoff.

title: POSTHUMOUS PULITZER GIVEN WRITER WHO COULDN'T GET NOVEL PUBLISHED
description: The winners and their work, page B4. By PETER KIHSS

title: City Hurries Order Of More G.M. Buses
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey acted yesterday to speed up an order for General Motors buses that could help relieve New York City's transit woes.

title: Texas Eastern Signs Pipeline Agreement
description: The Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation of Houston has signed a letter of intent with the Transcontinental Gas Pipe Line Corporation of Houston and the Algonquin Gas Transmission Company of Boston to become a partner with them in the New England states pipeline project.

title: Politics Called an 'American Way of Life'
description: ''I don't believe 'politics' is a dirty word,'' Raymond E. Baldwin said the other day. ''It's the American way of life.'' Mr. Baldwin should know.

title: New York Lottery Passes Billion Mark
description: ALBANY (UPI) - New Yorkers have spent more than $1 billion on the state lottery since the games were restarted in 1976 after a one-year layoff, the lottery's director, John D. Quinn, reported. Mr. Quinn. who said sales for 1980-81 were $232.9 million, said the goal for 1981-82 was $410 million.

title: Talking Businesswith Freeman of First Chicago; Bank Lending And Inflation
description: Gaylord Freeman, chairman of the First Chicago Corporation from 1969 until he retired in 1975, is now its honorary chairman and a member of its international advisory committee. He holds a visitor's chair at the Northern Michigan School of Banking.

title: Bone-Collecting Ants
description: Two Johns Hopkins University scientists investigating the behavior of harvester ants in East Africa have uncovered piles of nonfossilized bones of small animals that the ants had collected. The researchers' studies, published in the journal Paleobiology, are the first recorded evidence of the collecting of modern bones by harvester ants.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, APRIL 14, 1981
description: The Voyage of Columbia Two astronauts cruised through a second day in space aboard the Columbia, enjoying the panoramas and putting the smooth-flying craft through critical tests in preparation for a planned landing early this afternoon in California's Mojave Desert. The wheeled landing is to follow 36 orbits in a journey of 54 1/2 hours. (Page A1, Column 6.) The loss of all or part of 17 tiles that protect the space shuttle from the extreme heat of re-entry into the earth's atmosphere was a subject of debate. Space officials said attempts to photograph the underside of the craft had failed, but they expressed confidence that all the critical tiles were firmly in place and posed no hazard. (C6:1-2.)

title: John Huneke, 17, an Eagle Scout; Suffered From Rare Bone Cancer
description: John Huneke, a 17-year-old student who two weeks ago fulfilled one of his life's ambitions by becoming an Eagle Scout, died Friday at Lenox Hill Hospital of Ewing's sarcoma, a rare form of bone cancer. Mr. Huneke was a resident of Mount Vernon, N.Y., where he had attended Mount Vernon High School until last year.

title: AGNEW GO-BETWEEN IS SAID TO MAKE DEAL
description: Prosecution lawyers in a $200,000 damage suit against former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew said today that Jerome B. Wolff, a confessed go-between in a scheme in which Mr. Agnew is alleged to have taken bribes from Maryland contractors when he was Governor, would testify against him when the case goes to trial next Tuesday.

title: CAROLINE GORDON, NOVELIST, CRITIC AND SHORT-STORY WRITER, 86, DIES
description: Caroline Gordon, novelist, short-story writer and critic, died Saturday after surgery in San Cristobal de las Casas, Chiapas, Mexico, where she lived. She was 86 years old.

title: KOOL JAZZ FESTIVAL WILL RUN FROM JUNE 25 TO JULY 5
description: The Newport Jazz Festival, which moved to New York from Newport, R.I., in 1972, will cut off one more vestige of its association with Newport this year by changing its name to the Kool Jazz Festival-New York. The change was announced yesterday by George Wein, founder and producer of the Newport Jazz Festival, at a news conference at the New York Sheraton.

title: Blair Television Adds On-Line Media as Client
description: On-Line Media, which operates closed-circuit TV sets at supermarket checkout counters as an advertising medium, is still a relative infant but has enough accomplishments to give it the earmarks of success. The latest is that it has become a client of Blair Television, part of John Blair & Company, which previously had served as advertising representatives only for radio and television stations.

title: 2 EFFORTS TO PHOTOGRAPH TILES ARE UNSUCCESSFUL
description: Officials at the Johnson Space Center said today that attempts to photograph the underside of the orbiting Columbia, in an effort to discover if any of its vital protective tiles were missing, had so far failed.

title: I.R.S. SEEKS 87,760 IT OWES REFUNDS
description: The Internal Revenue Service estimates that it has been unable to deliver income tax refund checks to nearly 88,000 people who have moved and left no forwarding address, according to a report released today.

title: ELITE BLACKS RECALL SEGREGATED CAPITAL
description: They were aristocrats, in education if not in wealth, so a group of black men and women who gathered here for a two-day colloquium on life as it was lived in segregated Washington recalled not the harsher peculiarities of discrimination, but lives rich in culture and community.

title: 9 Customs Workers Indicted on Auctions
description: Nine present and former employees of the United States Customs Service in Manhattan were charged yesterday with a variety of crimes relating to the service's monthly auctions of confiscated and unclaimed merchandise.

title: TIMES BOOKS NAMES PRESIDENT
description: Joseph T. Consolino, senior vice president and general manager of Simon & Schuster for the last year and a half, has been named president and publisher of Times Books, the trade-book affiliate of the New York Times Company. The former president of Times Books was Thomas H. Lipscomb, who left at the end of last year.

title: Trade Center Fire Routs 200
description: A small fire erupted in an office kitchen of the World Trade Center yesterday and was quickly extinguished. There were no injuries. Deputy Fire Chief John Rossi said 200 employees were forced to leave the third, fourth and fifth floors of 4 World Trade Center because of heavy smoke.

title: GERMAN INSTITUTES ATTACK POLICY
description: West Germany's five leading economic institutes today sharply criticized policies of both the Government and the central bank, saying the Bundesbank's restrictive monetary policy was stifling Germany's economy and that sharp cuts in Government investment were worsening the country's recession .

title: MARGIOTTA STARTS DEFENSE IN TRIAL ON NASSAU G.O.P. FEE-SPLITTING
description: Joseph M. Margiotta began his defense against charges of mail fraud and extortion in Federal District Court here today after Judge Charles Sifton denied a motion to acquit him.

title: U.N. Calls Talks on Refugees In Africa a Success
description: An emergency meeting in Geneva to raise funds for as many as five million African refugees has been called a success although contributing nations pledged only $560 million, less than half of the amount sought.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Air Products and Chemical Inc. filed with the S.E.C. $175 million principal amount of 7 percent debentures due 2011, to be sold through a Lehman Brothers group.

title: Chess: Korchnoi Takes Lone Pine And a Little Sweet Revenge
description: Viktor Korchnoi of Switzerland won the $15,000 first prize in the Louis Statham International Tournament in Lone Pine, Calif., with a 7-2 score. Three grandmasters - Yasser Seirawan of Seattle, Gennadi Sosonko of the Netherlands and Svetozar Gligoric of Yugoslavia - tied for second place a half-point back in the 61-player Swiss system event.

title: Reds 7, Padres 1
description: SAN DIEGO (UPI) - Tom Seaver allowed three hits in eight innings to record his 246th career victory, and Cincinnati's Dan Driessen, Johnny Bench and Ray Knight homered to spoil San Diego's home opener.

title: Coca Cola Prediction
description: First-quarter operating and net income for the Coca-Cola Company will likely be 6 percent to 10 percent above 1980 levels, the company said.

title: REAGAN PLANS A DRIVE TO REGAIN MOMENTUM ON ECONOMIC PACKAGE
description: The Reagan Administration, buffeted by a surprising Congressional setback last week while the President was recuperating from a gunshot wound, is gearing up now to try to recapture its political momentum when Congress returns in two weeks.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The spaceship is just performing beautiful.'' - John W. Young. (A1:6.)

title: INDEPENDENT CORPORATION WEIGHED AS ARTS AGENCY
description: A plan to replace the National Endowment for the Arts and the National Endowment for the Humanities with an independent agency similar to the Corporation for Public Broadcasting has been under discussion among White House officials. The idea, which stresses private support for the arts, comes in the wake of the Reagan Administration's proposal to cut the budgets of the Endowments by 50 per cent next year, and is still only in the talking stage.

title: Orioles 5, Red Sox 1
description: BOSTON (UPI) - Jose Morales, a pinch-hitter, singled for two runs with the bases loaded and two out in the ninth inning to start a four-run Baltimore rally.

title: American Medical Lifts Brookwood Bid
description: American Medical International Inc., locked in a bidding war with Humana Inc. over Brookwood Health Services Inc., yesterday raised its offer for the operator of hospitals and alcholism-care centers, based in Birmingham, Ala., by $10 a share.

title: PLAY AT THE PLATE
description: Manny Trillo of the Phils sliding safely into home to score on a sacrafice fly by Larry Bowa in third inning last night at Philadelphia. Steve Nicosia, Pirates' catcher, took late throw. Phils won, 5-1.

title: President for Penthouse
description: Mark J. Meagher, 49, who was president and chief operating officer of the Washington Post Company until his resignation last January, has been appointed president and chief operating officer of Penthouse International, which owns four magazines, has film and television units and is planning to build a casino in Atlantic City. Bob Guccione, 50, who founded the company when he started Penthouse magazine in England in 1965, continues as chairman and chief executive officer.

title: BAKER AND GRETZKY: YOUNG VIRTUOSOS ON ICE
description: One of the nets was fastened to the goal line as usual, but the other had been pushed forward to center ice. The puck had been replaced by a yellow tennis ball, and hostility by laughter. There was no crowd, and no need for a referee, because the only purpose for raising a stick was to celebrate a goal.

title: PORTRAIT BRINGS BEAME BACK TO CITY HALL Cuite and Joey Adams
description: An official City Hall portrait of former Mayor Abraham D. Beame was unveiled yesterday in an atmosphere of affection, jokes and a few moments of deep emotion.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 17.00-17.50 ** Current rate excludes 3 percentage-point surcharge on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: FORD PLAYS KEY ROLE IN SHUTTLE PROJECT
description: When the space shuttle crew gets in touch with its controllers at the Johnson Space Center in Houston, it uses a communications system designed by a unit of the Ford Motor Company. And the person who answers could well be a Ford employee.

title: N.A.A.C.P. ASSETS REAGAN BUDGET PROFITS THE RICH AT EXPENSE OF POOR
description: The board of directors of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People sharply attacked the Reagan Administration's budget proposals today and submitted its own ideas for combating inflation and unemployment.

title: MACDOWELL COLONY TO GIVE FIRST CORPORATE AWARD
description: The MacDowell Colony will present its first corporate executive award to J. Irwin Miller, chairman and executive of the finance committee of the Cummins Engine Company of Columbus, Ind.

title: PEKING MAGAZINE SAYS STUDENTS AND WORKERS HAVE STAGED DISORDERS
description: A Chinese magazine said today that students and workers had staged several strikes and demonstrations recently. In a prominent article by a political editor, An Zhiguo, the foreign-language weekly magazine Peking Review said that the incidents had been infrequent and involved only a tiny fraction of China's one billion people.

title: 7,500 OLD YIDDISH BOOKS FOUND IN BIN ON 16TH ST.
description: Approximately 7,500 old and out-of-print books, maps and bound periodicals in Yiddish were left in a large industrial garbage bin at the corner of 16th Street and Sixth Avenue last night, according to Eric Byron, president of the Synagogue Restoration Project, a group dedicated to maintaining Yiddish culture.

title: Sandoz Names Chief For U.S. Subsidiary
description: Max E. Link, 40 years old, has been named chief executive officer of Sandoz Inc., the United States pharmaceutical and chemical company owned by Sandoz Ltd. of Switzerland. The American corporation was responsible for about $330 million of the parent's $2.7 billion volume last year.

title: U.S. Official in Mozambique On Tour of Southern Africa
description: Chester A. Crocker, the United States Assistant Secretary of State-designate for African Affairs, arrived in Maputo, Mozambique, today on the latest leg of a 10-nation tour of southern Africa, according to the Mozambique press agency.

title: Belzberg's First City Plans Keyser Stake
description: The First City Financial Corporation, the financial services concern owned by Canada's Belzberg family, said it plans to acquire a 10 percent interest in Keyser Ullmann Overseas S.A., which operates various banks in Switzerland and France. Keyser Ullmann Overseas is a subsidiary of Keyser Ullmann Ltd., one of London's leading merchant banks.

title: HIGH SCHOOL: GRAND DREAMS HAVE FADED INTO DISAPPOINTMENT
description: TWENTY years ago, the dream of the free and universal high school seemed to have come true. By the beginning of the 1960's, virtually all American youths of high school age were actually going to high school. No other nation had ever accomplished as much. Many educators felt utopia was at hand.

title: News Analysis
description: The fierce fighting around the Lebanese town of Zahle has slowed to intermittent artillery exchanges, and the Syrian forces have emerged from this round in a more dominant position while the Christian position has been weakened both politically and militarily.

title: No Headline
description: Roland I. Gammon, a writer and lecturer on religion, collapsed and died last Wednesday near his home in Manhattan.

title: RESEARCH HELPS ISRAEL RAISE FARM EXPORTS
description: Dr. Edward Salomon, a researcher in this town's Volcani Institute, recently stumped the panel on Israeli television's version of ''I've Got a Secret.''

title: Irving Bank's Net Rises by 33.4%
description: Helped by a pretax gain of $11.1 million from the redemption of a block of Penn Central Corporation securities, first-quarter profits for the Irving Bank Corporation rose 33.4 percent this year, to $27.8 million, from $20.8 million in the first quarter of 1980, the bank holding company said today.

title: LEVESQUE IS WINNER IN QUEBEC ELECTION WITH 80 OF 122 SEATS
description: Premier Rene Levesque and his Parti Quebecois were elected tonight to a new term. About four million voters, who had rejected Quebec's separation from Canada in a referendum last year, turned around and gave Mr. Levesque a sweeping show of confidence in his ability to lead Quebec as a Canadian province. Parti Quebecois, which led from the start of the count shortly after the polls closed at 8 P.M., won 80 of the 122 seats at stake in the National Assembly against only 42 for the Liberal Party. In the outgoing assembly, which had 12 fewer seats, Parti Quebecois had 67 seats, the Liberals had 34, Union Nationale had 5, independents had 2 and 2 seats were vacant.

title: PUERTO RICO'S WAITING
description: Puerto Rico is waiting for Washington to declare its intentions. To the outside world, it may appear that it's up to Puerto Rico to decide whether it wants statehood or not. To Puerto Rico, it's not that simple.

title: Geologists View Lava Dome At Mount St. Helens
description: A dozen scientists took advantage of a break in bad weather today to fly into the crater at Mount St. Helens for a close look at the volcano's growing dome-shaped formation of hardened lava.

title: CONGRESS TO WEIGH SEVERAL GUN BILLS
description: While President Reagan was still in the hospital recovering from gunshot wounds, a spate of bills was introduced in Congress to tighten control of pistols and stiffen penalties for those caught using them to commit crimes.

title: THE CUBAN TRIANGLE
description: In the Museum of Modern Art, there is a canvas by Paul Klee showing a cat and, within its head, the bird it is hungering after. If Paul Klee were to paint a portrait of Ronald Reagan in the same manner, one would be able to see, through the transparent forehead of the President, the bird he is hungering after: Cuba.

title: COURT BACKS REPORTER IN CIVIL SUIT
description: A Federal appeals court here ruled today that a reporter had a ''qualified privilege'' under the First Amendment to refuse to disclose his sources in a lawsuit brought by two men whom he had identified as mob figures in a series of articles.

title: Control Data Up 14.5%; NCR Gains 8.2%
description: The Control Data Corporation, one of the nation's leading suppliers of computer services, large-scale computer systems and computer peripheral equipment, reported yesterday that earnings in the first quarter of 1981 increased 14.5 percent, on a sales increase of 10 percent.

title: TUESDAY, APRIL 14, 1981; The Economy
description: President Reagan told his advisers to repudiate a report by Representative James R. Jones that the Administration would compromise on the tax cut portion of his economic program. President Rea@gan said ''that he had authorized no one in his Administration to offer legislative compromises on his program for economic recovery,'' a White House spokesman stated. (Page A1.)

title: Flatulence From Flour
description: Studies of 18 healthy volunteers have suggested that many people do not fully digest the gluten in ordinary wheat flour and as a result may feed gas-producing bacteria in the lower intestinal tract.

title: IT'S BUSINESS AS USUAL AT THE SHOP IN DALLAS WHERE HINCKLEY BOUGHT GUN
description: On the east end of Elm Street stands a wellworn assortment of brick pawn shops, peep shows, bail bond offices and cheap bars, little changed by this city's boom over the last two decades.

title: Leo Burnett Loses All Revlon Business
description: Having lost part of its Revlon business last week, the Leo Burnett Company, Chicago, has resigned the rest -Formula 2, Moon Drop and Moisture Release products, and a new product called Scoundrel, a fragrance.

title: NEW TEST COULD BLOCK MANY CITY PUPILS FROM HIGH SCHOOL DIPLOMA
description: An estimated 5,000 to 10,000 of the 42,000 seniors in New York City's public high schools have not yet passed the new statewide Regents Competency Tests now required for a high school diploma, according to unofficial statistics from the city's Board of Education.

title: RESCUED FROM BURNING TENEMENT IN BOSTON
description: RESCUED FROM BURNING TENEMENT IN BOSTON: A fireman climbing up to rescue resident of three-story building that caught fire yesterday in the city's Dorchester section. No serious injuries were reported in the blaze.

title: JERSEY PANEL VOTES, 6 TO 5, FOR NEW LEGISLATIVE DISTRICTS
description: The New Jersey Reapportionment Commission approved today by a 6-to-5 vote a new map of the state's 40 legislative districts. The action insures that the June 2 primary election will be held as scheduled.

title: RETAIL SALES FOR MARCH NEARLY FLAT
description: Retail sales leveled off in March and would have shown the first decline in 10 months had it not been for auto sales, which were lifted by rebates, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: U.S. Judge Stays Execution Of a Convict in Louisiana
description: Federal District Judge Naumann Scott today stayed the execution of Dalton Prejean less than 48 hours before he was to be put to death for killing a state trooper in July 1977.

title: U.S. Control Urged In Drug Prosecution
description: Mayor Koch urged the Federal Government to take the major responsibility for combating the spread of drugrelated crimes in New York City and the nation.

title: SPANISH LEADER HOPING FOR ENTRY TO NATO IN '81
description: Prime Minister Leopoldo Calvo Sotelo is hoping to take Spain into the North Atlantic Treaty Organization before the end of this year.

title: ROLAND I. GAMMON, 86, LECTURER AND AUTHOR OF BOOKS ON RELIGION
description: Roland I. Gammon, a writer and lecturer on religion, collapsed and died last Wednesday near his home in Manhattan.

title: JAPANESE ALUMINUM PLEA
description: Japanese trade unionists have received a polite but noncommittal hearing from the American aluminum industry and its workers to their request for voluntary restraints on United States exports of aluminum to Japan.

title: SWAN REJOINS METS
description: The Mets worked out in Shea Stadium yesterday for the first time in six months, and they will open their home season there today against the St. Louis Cardinals in a rush of news - good, bad and uncertain.

title: CHINESE FARMS AND FACTORIES THRIVE ON INCENTIVES
description: With what appears to be a sense of discovery, officials and industrial and farming-commune managers here laud the virtues of a market-oriented economy and of private agriculture. At the same time, they denounce the restrictiveness of the highly centralized and planned economy that prevailed in China through the first three decades of Communism.

title: 'Crime Wave' in Kuwait; Scores of Foreigners Ousted
description: The Government of Kuwait deported scores of foreign residents after the country experienced a wave of social and political crimes, Kuwait's security chief said today.

title: Bridge: Grand National Team Final Regarded as an Anticlimax
description: After the semifinals in the Grand National Teams in White Plains on Saturday, when a highly favored team lost by 3 international match points, the final on Sunday was an anticlimax. Leonard Karp of River Vale, Michael Kamil of Fort Lee and John Suozzo of Teaneck, all in New Jersey, and David Kuenzler of Spring Valley, N.Y., won by 77 points.

title: STUDENTS ISSUE PLEA TO SPARE AID BUDGET
description: Marcus Gleysteen of New York City and about 1,200 other young Americans joined the ranks of the Washington lobbyists today, protesting Reagan Administration plans to slash loans and grants to college students.

title: 2 Indicted in Theft From Fire Victims
description: Two former employees of the Westchester County Medical Examiner's office were indicted in connection with the theft and use of credit cards taken from the bodies of two persons who were killed in a fire last December at Stouffer's Inn in Harrison, N.Y.

title: U.S. FREES MEDICAID FUNDS IN STATE AS ALBANY BUDGET FIGHT CONTINUES
description: The Federal Government gave New York State permission today to release Medicaid funds to hospitals and nursing homes without the accompanying state share. This relieved some of the external pressure felt by Governor Carey and the Senate Republican leader, Warren M. Anderson, to agree upon a 1981-82 budget.

title: HOW PARIS KEPT POSITION IN FASHION
description: Christian Dior resuscitated Paris as the world's fashion capital in 1947 when he started his New Look with its small waistlines and long, full skirts, giving women a chance to dress fancifully after the austerity of the war years. Emanuel Ungaro and Karl Lagerfeld have performed a similar service during the fashion shows for fall and winter 1981.

title: Services Friday for Joe Louis
description: Funeral services for the former heavyweight boxing champion Joe Louis will be held at 10 A.M. Friday in the sports pavilion of Caesars Palace, a spokeman for the hotel said today.

title: 3 SUSPECTS HELD IN SLAYING OF DETECTIVE'S DAUGHTER, 16
description: Three suspects in the April 3 murder of a New York City police detective's 16-year-old daughter were in custody last night. The first was arrested early yesterday in Anaheim, Calif., and the two others after surrendering in New York City.

title: MUSIC: EAST GERMAN VISITOR, GEWANDHAUS ORCHESTRA
description: THERE is always an eager curiosity when musicians of a European Communist country come to call. Americans share with such visitors roughly the same musical culture, but their two vastly different worlds of experience create fascinating opportunities for comparison.

title: PRESIDENT'S RETURN SHOWS TAXES OF $69,563 ON INCOME OF $227,968
description: President Reagan and his wife, Nancy, had an adjusted gross income of $227,968 last year and paid $69,563 in Federal taxes, according to copies of his 1980 Federal tax forms that were released today by the White House.

title: IMQUIRY IS PALNNED ON LONDON RIOTS AS VIOLENCE FADES
description: As a measure of calm returned to the Brixton section of south London today, the Government set up a judicial inquiry to investigate the causes of the weekend of looting, firebombing and violent clashes with the police.

title: Market Place; Wang Labs: Mixed View
description: WANG LABORATORIES, which in recent years established a leadership position in word processing and small business computers to become a stock market standout, may experience growing pains in the months ahead. If so, the shares could slip. They closed yesterday on the American Stock Exchange at 40 1/2, up 1/8.

title: TWO WHO FLEW IN SPACE BACK PROGRAM IN CAPITAL
description: At a time when almost every discretionary item in the Federal budget faces the severest scrutiny, advocates of strong Congressional support for manned space flight have the advantage of two specially qualified men in their camp.

title: An Appreciation; LOUIS HAD STYLE IN AND OUT OF THE RING; An Appreciation
description: On a cold night in January 1970, three men rode in a cab to Grand Central Terminal, where they would board a train for Rochester. They happened to be going to the same awards dinner. In the back seat were a baseball player and a sports reporter. In the front seat was Joe Louis, the former heavyweight champion, who stared straight ahead as the lurid city lights flashed on his broad face. He listened to the baseball player making cracks about the young cab driver, who had long hair, which was not yet the vogue among athletes.

title: TAXING AMERICANS ABROAD
description: In the competitive world of international trade, the United States can't afford to be its own worst enemy. But it is. Changes made in the Internal Revenue Code in 1976 and 1978 have greatly reduced the number of United States citizens employed abroad by American companies. Declining numbers of Americans working in foreign countries reduces United States competitiveness in overseas markets, costs billions of dollars annually in lost export sales, and aggravates domestic unemployment.

title: Hercules Net Up 5.3% for Quarter
description: Hercules Inc., a major chemicals manufacturer based in Wilmington, Del., reported yesterday that earnings in the first quarter rose 5.3 percent, to $35.5 million, or 80 cents a share, from $33.7 million, or 76 cents a share, in the corresponding three months of 1980. Sales rose 3.3 percent, to $667 million, from $646 million.

title: L.I. DRIVER BATTLES TO GET $1.95 REFUND
description: For 21 months, Frank Makara has been seeking $1.95 worth of justice. He has filed a lawsuit and appeals, argued in all-but-empty courtrooms, incurred hundreds of dollars in expenses, compiled bulging dossiers and carried his case to the threshold of the United States Supreme Court.

title: NAN TALESE MOVES TO HOUGHTON
description: Nan Talese has resigned as senior editor and vice president of Simon & Schuster to become executive editor and vice president of Houghton Mifflin, the 149-year old Boston publisher.

title: FYFE'S 'HUNCH' ABOUT POLICE OFF-DUTY GUNS
description: To the Editor:

title: CONCERT: OPERA 'LAKME' REVIVED AT CARNEGIE HALL
description: IF ''Lakme'' means anything nowadays to most New Yorkers, it is the faded memory of Lily Pons and Florence Foster Jenkins lavishing their respective geniuses on the Bell Song. Other divas than those two have tinkled through Leo Delibes's coloratura showpiece, with its high E's and other ultrasonic passagework apparently designed to be heard and relished by mice and very small dogs. But Pons and Jenkins remain the touchstones, the Either/Or, the parameters of delight Can anyone ever match them for vocal high-wire work or for sheer audience appeal?

title: AUSTRALIAN MAGAZINES SOLD BY TIMES CO.
description: The New York Times Company announced the sale of its Australian and New Zealand magazine group to the Advertiser Group of Adelaide, Australia, a communications, printing and packaging company. The Advertiser Group will publish the magazines involved under license agreements.

title: MOBIL WELL REQUESTS WITHDRAWN
description: Sixty percent of the Mobil Corporation's applications for natural-gas stripper wells since 1978 have been withdrawn either because of errors or inadequate supporting information, according to a company filing made available today by the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission.

title: PULITZER PLAY: COMEDY OF 3 SISTERS
description: Beth Henley's ''Crimes of the Heart,'' the winner of this year's Pulitzer Prize for drama, was first produced at the Actors Theater of Louisville, Ky., in 1979, a year after it was the co-winner of that institution's annual Great American Play Contest. Set five years after Hurricane Camille, it is a comic account of three eccentric sisters in the small fictional town of Hazelhurst, Miss., on the day that one of them has shot her husband.

title: STUDY LEADS TO WARNING ON TETRACYCLINE
description: Tetracycline appears to block the immune response of test animals, researchers said today, a finding that raises questions about the wisdom of long-term use of the commonly prescribed antibiotic.

title: Cila of Arrows Fined $5,000
description: Renato Cila, a defender for the Major Indoor Soccer League New York Arrows, was fined $5,000 yesterday and suspended for the first five games of next season for punching a referee in a playoff game last month.

title: JOHNNY CARSON, AS A WRITER, GOES ON STRIKE
description: The comedian Johnny Carson, a member of the Writers Guild, walked off the ''Tonight Show'' in a strike action today and NBC officials said the show would suspend production for at least one week.

title: America's Average Kind Of Day
description: ''The day the President was shot,'' says an ad of Handgun Control Inc. in newpapers across the country, ''was an average kind of day'' - meaning that more than 50 Americans were killed with handguns. The gun lobby, led by the National Rifle Association, says people kill, not guns. Polls show that most people disagree, but not enough care to argue. So the nation fails to respond to an epidemic of handgun deaths, unlike its strong reaction to the rash of deaths from toxic shock syndrome and Legionnaires' disease.

title: Miss Kirkland's Return to Ballet Company Accelerated
description: When Gelsey Kirkland was taken back into the fold of the American Ballet Theater last week, four months after she had been dismissed for chronic lateness and absence from rehearsals, it was announced that she would once again dance with Mikhail Baryshnikov, the company's artistic director, in New York on May 2.

title: Banker Views Tax Plan
description: Alan Reynolds, 38, fears that the Reagan tax proposal will not go far enough. As an adviser to David A. Stockman, director of the Office of Management and Budget, and one of the authors of the Administration's economic program, he is naturally pleased with what the President has proposed.

title: I.R.S. Criticized On Oil Tax
description: The Government is having problems collecting and monitoring the ''windfall profits'' tax on crude oil enacted a year ago, Congressional auditors said today.

title: Vast School of Krill
description: A huge swarm of krill, probably the largest aggregation of sea creatures ever measured, has been found by marine biologists in studies of the frigid ocean waters north of the Antarctic Peninsula.

title: Wrath Aroused On Braniff Pay
description: The chairman of the Braniff International Corporation, John J. Casey, found himself surrounded by controversy today because the airline decided to raise the pay of 864 management-level employees by an average of 11.4 percent.

title: AUDIT COMMITTES INFLUENTIAL
description: Just before the end of 1978, the California Life Corporation announced that it expected a 24 percent profit rise for the year, to about $2.6 million.
