title: Canada, Soviet Gain in Hockey
description: Canada routed the Netherlands, 8-1, and the Soviet Union beat Finland, 7-1, today, achieving their second straight victories and berths in the final round of the world hockey championship.

title: Water Penalty Delayed Against 82 Jersey Users
description: The Hackensack Water Company has held up prosecution of some customers accused of ignoring fines for using too much water.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Leisure Corp. said a Federal judge had approved the company's previously announced agreement with the S.E.C. settling the agency's charges of fraud in an American Leisure stock offering.

title: 2 ASTRONAUTS ENJOYING VIEW
description: The astronauts of the space shuttle Columbia cruised through their second day in space today, enjoying the view and putting their smooth-flying spaceship through critical tests in preparation for their planned landing tomorrow on the desert in California.

title: Prof. Harry Moore, 72; D. H. Lawrence Expert
description: Harry T. Moore, emeritus research professor of English at Southern Illinois University, died Saturday at Carbondale (Ill.) Memorial Hospital following a stroke.

title: Rebates Help Cut Auto Inventories
description: Rebate offers by four of the five major domestic auto makers cut the industry's supply of unsold cars to just 44 days on April 1, compared with 59 days on March 1, an industry journal reported today.

title: The Boatless People
description: There's half a point in the bitter observation that the plight of Africa's five million refugees is being ignored because they move by foot instead of boat. A conference called by 50 African states in Geneva finally commanded attention to the problem even if it failed to raise the desired $1.2 billion in emergency aid. Some good has already resulted. A contrite Reagan Administation, defensive about its careless praise for South Africa, pledged $285 million at the meeting to help black Africans who have been driven into exile by war and revolution.

title: 3 MONTHS AFTER RETURN, EX-HOSTAGES SHOW SIGNS OF SMOOTH READJUSTMENT
description: Three months after they were freed, almost all of the 52 Americans from the United States Embassy who were held hostage in Iran appear to be easing back into life's mainstream with little difficulty.

title: MERGERS DO NOT NECESSARILY REDUCE THE ECONOMIC INVESTMENT LEVEL
description: To the Editor:

title: Braves 2, Astros 1
description: HOUSTON (UPI) - A single by Rufino Linares drove in Rafael Ramirez with the winning run in the 10th inning and sent Houston to its fourth loss without a victory.

title: Mrs. Reagan's Restraint Called Handicap to Her Book
description: The author who collaborated with Nancy Reagan on her autobiography, ''Nancy,'' says that ''It's not one of my best books because Nancy didn't let herself go.''

title: 4 DEATHS IN ATLANTA CALLED 'SOLVED'
description: The slayings of as many as four of the 23 young blacks killed here since July 1979 have been ''substantially solved,'' William H. Webster, Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, said today.

title: LITTLE HELP SEEN AT PUMP
description: Four major United States oil refiners are cutting the prices they will pay for certain grades of crude oil produced in the Rocky Mountains by $1 a barrel, a move that analysts said reflected a growing world oil glut and limited local storage and refining capacity.

title: AFGHAN REBELS BRISTLE WITH NEW ARMS
description: Islamic rebels, apparently armed with new supplies, are moving openly and confidently in two widely separated provinces of Afghanistan, according to Westerners back from secret trips into the country.

title: Sports of The Times; Hockey's Disobedient Child
description: BACK in the old neighborhood, one of the mothers knew how to make her unruly child behave: she would announce ominously that she was counting from one to five.

title: Article 084233 -- No Title
description: Between now and the June 2 primary, most of the 23 candidates for Governor of New Jersey will spend about $4 million with New York City and Philadelphia television stations to reach primary voters in New Jersey. Three-quarters of that money will go to send their messages to viewers who cannot vote for them - in Connecticut, New York and Pennsylvania.

title: The Reagan Energy Slogan
description: Miraculously, the noose is loosening. Less than two years ago, angry people waited in predawn gasoline lines; now there seems to be so much gasoline that dealers are shaving prices. Nationwide, the winter just ended was 3 percent colder than last year, yet demand for heating oil went down 13 percent. When Jimmy Carter came down from Camp David to speak of national malaise, America was importing 8.4 million barrels of oil a day. Now the figure is 6 million. OPEC's grip is weakening.

title: INMATE CONVICTED IN JERSEY KILLING
description: A man already serving a life term in jail for the strangling of an elderly woman was convicted today of the murder of a Trenton social figure, Emma Jane Stockton.

title: G.M. HEAD CRITICIZES WORK ON 'X' CARS
description: F. James McDonald, president of the General Motors Corporation, says that G.M.'s popular ''X'' cars are plagued with uneven doors, shabby paint jobs and other problems that do not match the quality standards of foreign competitors.

title: Bell Argues Data Case
description: While representatives from much of the communications and computer industries waited to protest, an attorney for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company told a Federal judge today that a 25-year-old antitrust suit settlement should be reinterpreted to allow the huge company to enter the potentially lucrative computer market.

title: FORMER TREASURY SECRETARY TESTIFIES WILLIAMS DID NOT PUSH MINE TALKS
description: Henry H. Fowler, Secretary of the Treasury under President Lyndon B. Johnson, testified yesterday that as an investment banker in 1977, he was asked by Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. to advise a friend of the Senator who was seeking financing for a titanium-mining venture.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Alcan Aluminium, Montreal, has appointed J. Hugh Faulkner vice president, environment, occupational health and safety.

title: HENRY O. PATTISON JR.
description: Henry O. Pattison Jr., former chairman of the executive committee of Benton & Bowles Inc., died Thursday at his home in Tucson, Ariz., after a long illness. He was 73 years old.

title: IDEAL WEATHER EXPECTED WHEN SHUTTLE GLIDES IN BEFORE CROWD OF THOUSANDS
description: Officials here said today that they expected near-ideal weather when the space shuttle Columbia soars out of space tomorrow morning and ends its 54 1/2-hour maiden flight on a vast desert dry lake sculpted by a powerful prehistoric glacier.

title: PICNIC IN THE PARK IS RESPITE FROM TRIAL
description: Senator Harrison A. William Jr. and his wife, Jeanette, having lunch in small park behind Federal Court in Brooklyn.At Senator's Abscam trial, former Treasury Secretary Henry H. Fowler testified for the defense. Page B2.

title: GRUNFELT MAIN EVENT IN KINGS-SUNS SERIES
description: Ernie Grunfeld's past includes stardom at Forest Hills High School in Queens, all-America honors at the University of Tennessee, a United States Olympic gold medal and almost four pro seasons as a struggling, virtually forgotten forward.

title: DIGEST'S ELECTRONICS VENTURE
description: In its first year and a half of existence, the Source has infuriated its customers, run up millions of dollars in debts to hundreds of creditors, watched its two founders sue each other and hovered continuously on the brink of bankruptcy.

title: Advertising; Heublein Ads to Try Taste Tests
description: HAVING won its 10-year fight to keep United Vintners, Heublein is now mounting a highly competitive, comparative advertising campaign aimed at increasing its market share.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt DANSE MACABRE. By Stephen King. 400 pages. Illustrated. Everest. $13.95.

title: GOLD AND SILVER PLUNGE ABROAD, RECOVER IN U.S.
description: Precious metals prices gyrated wildly yesterday in response to interest rates and other economic news. Silver plunged to within 60 cents of its low during the silver crisis of March 1980, but a late rally in New York lifted silver prices into the plus column and more than cut in half the $21 an ounce that gold had lost in European trading.

title: SOUTH AFRICA HAS BECOME A STRONG U.S. ALLY
description: To the Editor:

title: ALABAMA BLACKS FEAR LOSING THE VOTING RIGHTS ACT
description: In the small, aged office of the Lowndes County Sheriff is a long, thick rubber strap. For years, it was illegally, forcefully and frequently used on the backs of black people in a county where blacks were numerically dominant but white control was absolute.

title: A.& P. Deficit Narrows
description: The Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Company, the large supermarket concern that is 49 percent owned by the Tengelmann Group retail chain in West Germany, reported yesterday that its loss in the fourth fiscal quarter of 1980 ended Feb. 28, 1981, narrowed to $4.2 million, from $11 million in the fiscal three months ended Feb. 23, 1980. Sales increased 12.5 percent, to $1.89 billion, from $1.68 billion.

title: Thousands of Coal Miners Apply to Get Food Stamps
description: By The Associated Press Thousands of striking coal miners lined up yesterday at special centers to apply for food stamps, as negotiators for the United Mine Workers and coal companies prepared to resume talks in an effort to end the walkout, now 19 days old.

title: Indonesian Exports
description: Indonesia's total exports for 1980 reached $21 billion, the highest figure in the past 15 years, Finance Minister Ali Wardhana said today.

title: 'WAR ON CANCER' STATUS REPORT: PROGRESS IS SLOW, BUT GAIN IS REAL
description: STUDYING the way in which some viruses transform cells from normal to malignant, scientists have made a series of surprising discoveries that may help explain for the first time how cancer really begins. The research, has caused much excitement among cancer biologists. In the long run it seems likely to offer new strategies for cancer treatment or prevention. At present, however, the excitement is aroused by the emerging details of the way many of the viruses that cause cancer in animals do their subversive work.

title: How To Save Billions
description: All right, David Stockman fans, here's a stunner: How could Congress have saved the taxpayers $22 billion in the last four years without cutting a single program?

title: Brenner Trial Judge Sees No Conspiracy
description: A Federal judge presiding over Teddy Brenner's $3 million antitrust suit against the World Boxing Council told Brenner's attorney yesterday that she had proved that Don King was ''a pretty bad stinker,'' but that in five days of testimony she had ''failed to show any facts that prove a conspiracy'' between King and Jose Sulaiman.

title: The U.N. Today; April 14, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Special Committee on Enhancing the Nonuse of Force in International Rela- tions - 10:30 and 3 P.M.

title: Ogilvy, Bernbach Exchange Barbs
description: Who are the most respected advertising creative people since World War II, and perhaps for this century? You would have to say William Bernbach, founder of Doyle Dane Bernbach, and David Ogilvy, founder of Ogilvy & Mather.

title: L.I. Garbage Carter Is Shot to Death
description: The owner of a garbage collection company was shot and killed in front of his home here, the Suffolk County police said.

title: MISGUIDED BLACK POLITICAL STRATEGY
description: To the Editor:

title: BRADLEY'S BODY IS FLOWN TO CAPITAL
description: A Presidential jet carrying the body of Gen. Omar N. Bradley, the nation's last five-star general, flew from his home in El Paso, Tex., today to Washington for a full military funeral.

title: HOWARD THURMAN, NOTED BLACK CLERIC
description: Dr. Howard Thurman, one of the nation's leading black clergymen and educators and an early champion of a Christianity that emphasized the needs of the poor and disadvantaged, died Friday in San Francisco after a lingering illness. He was 81 years old.

title: RIDERS SCRAMBLE AS A STRIKE HALTS SHORT LINE BUSES
description: A strike by drivers and mechanics against the Short Line Bus Company went into a third day in four states today, forcing commuters in the New York metropolitan area to scramble for alternative transportation to and from Manhattan.

title: IN ORBIT: 'THE SPACESHIP IS PERFORMING BEAUTIFUL'
description: Following are excerpts from conversations the astronauts had with Mission Control in Houston and with Vice President George Bush, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: FILLERS

title: Coke Bottled In China Plant
description: Coca-Cola, considered decadent by Government leaders during the Cultural Revolution, is being bottled in China for the first time since the Communists came to power in 1949.

title: LEILIA M. FINAN
description: Leilia M. Finan, former associate professor of physical education at Barnard College, died last Tuesday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center. She was 88 years old and lived in Butler Hall on the Columbia University campus.

title: BREZHNEV PHONE CALL SAID TO HAVE PROTECTED HARD-LINERS IN POLAND
description: The Soviet Union interceded at a Central Committee meeting of the Polish Communist Party two weeks ago to insure that hard-liners in the Politburo were not purged, reliable Polish sources said today.

title: LIBRARY ELECTS NEW LEADERSHIP
description: A new leadership of the New York Library was elected yesterday by the board of trustees, who chose Andrew Heiskell as chairman and Dr. Vartan Gregorian, a historian who was provost and a professor at the University of Pennsylvania, as president.

title: Article 084213 -- No Title
description: The alleged leader of a heroin-smuggling ring who was among the passengers on a hijacked Pakistani jetliner last month was ordered held in $10 million bail yesterday.

title: Driver Apparently Electrocuted
description: The 20-year-old son of a police captain here was apparently electrocuted yesterday as he tried to leave his automobile after it struck a utility pole, the police said today. The victim, Gregory M. Connors, was driving south on Main Street at about 3:30 A.M. when his auto struck the pole, snapping a power line.

title: Prince Charles Nurses Injury From Steeplechase Spill
description: Prince Charles continued his two-week tour of Australia yesterday with a reminder of his steeplechase spills last month still with him as he nursed a badly swollen little finger on his left hand. The finger was so swollen he's been unable to remove a ring from it.

title: F.B.I. Confirms Big 8 Inquiry
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation confirmed today that it was looking into information it had received about possible irregularities in certain Big Eight basketball games. Meanwhile, the Big Eight commissioner said the conference office ''will cooperate fully.''

title: DOCTORS GAIN IN EFFORTS TO RETAIN REVIEW PROGRAM
description: Doctors' groups are moving to thwart, or at least modify, a proposal by the Reagan Administration to kill a program that evaluates the work of physicians and hosptials treating the poor and the elderly. And the groups are reporting some success among members of Congress.

title: MRS. GOULETAS-CAREY WED 3 TIMES BEFORE, AID TO GOVERNOR SAYS
description: Evangeline Gouletas-Carey had been married and divorced three times before she wed Governor Carey last Saturday, a spokesman for the Governor said this morning.

title: COMMUNIST PARLEY CAUTIONED ON POLES
description: Italian and French Communists at the East German party congress here warned today against any outside intervention in Poland and said they were convinced that Warsaw could settle its own affairs.

title: LEGAL SERVICES ARE A SAFETY VALVE
description: To the Editor:

title: Peugeot Trucks
description: Peugeot S.A. is considering the sale of 50 percent of its Dodge truck division to Renault Vehicules Industriels, or R.V.I., the truck-building unit of the French stateowned auto maker, and a final decision is expected soon, motor industry sources said.

title: Tornado Kills 41 in Bangladesh
description: The death toll from a tornado yesterday in southern Bangladesh was put at 41 today but rescuers feared it would rise.

title: Fumes Overcome 40
description: Forty persons were overcome by carbon monoxide fumes, most of them while at work in a meatpacking plant in the West Farms section of the Bronx, the Fire Department reported.

title: REAGAN ORDERS STAFF TO REPUDIATE REPORT OF COMPROMISE ON TAX CUT
description: In his first White House meeting since the attempt on his life two weeks ago, President Reagan today ordered his staff to repudiate the report that the Administration was willing to compromise on the tax cut portion of his economic proposals.

title: Mobil Well Flowing In Gulf of Mexico
description: The Mobil Oil Corporation said that its D-2 appraisal well in the Gulf of Mexico flowed at the rate of 856 barrels of oil and 1.1 million cubic feet of natural gas daily.

title: Transactions
description: SOCCER

title: 5 Bottle Deposit Bill Signed in Suffolk
description: Peter F. Cohalan, the Suffolk County Executive, signed a bill yesterday that will make Suffolk the only county in the state to require deposits of at least 5 cents on beverage cans and bottles sold in the county when it takes effect Jan. 1.

title: An American Hero
description: Joe Louis was bigger than a heavyweight boxing champ. He was one of the few authentic heroes in modern America. Born in a ramshackle cabin in the cotton fields of Alabama, he eventually moved with his family to Detroit.

title: Leaders of Commons Decide Not to 'Expel' I.R.A. Man
description: British parliamentary leaders decided tonight not to try to ''expel'' the imprisoned Irish Republican Army guerrilla Robert Sands from the House of Commons.

title: FORMER HOSTAGES HONORED FOR VALOR
description: FORMER HOSTAGES HONORED FOR VALOR: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. pinning medal on L. Bruce Laingen, diplomat who was cited. With them is Walter J. Stoessel Jr., Under Secretary of State. Page B 12.

title: Taiwan Trade Rises
description: Taiwan's foreign trade in the first three months of 1981 grew 14.2 percent, to $10.26 billion, with a deficit of $483.3 million, official sources said today. The sources said imports in the January-March period totaled $5.37 billion, a growth of 19.9 percent, with 27.2 percent from Japan, Taiwan's largest supplier. The United States remained the island's No.1 buyer and trading partner by absorbing 32.3 percent of the export total of $4.89 billion, which represents an increase of 8.5 percent.

title: Stocks Show a Broad Retreat
description: The stock market retreated broadly yesterday, responding to a sharp increase in money supply figures and some disappointing corporate profits.

title: PHILS' CARLTON STOPS PIRATES, 5-1
description: Steve Carlton, last season's National League Cy Young Award winner, earned his first victory of the season as the Phillies defeated the Pittsburgh Pirates, 5-1, tonight before a crowd of 60,404 in Philadelphia's home opener.

title: Chemical-Plant Fire Forces Evacuation in Golden, Colo.
description: About 250 people were forced from their homes tonight by a fire at a chemical plant that leaked flammable liquid into the town's sewer system.

title: Japan Surplus Up In U.S. Trade
description: Japan posted a trade surplus of $886 million with the United States in March, in part because of a sharp increase in shipments of such products as cars and television sets, the Finance Ministry said today.

title: Q. Why does your skin puff up after a mosquito bite or bee sting?
description: A. Swelling is the normal reaction to an insect bite or sting. Chemicals in the venom result in the dilation of blood vessels, causing fluids to seep into the surrounding tissue.

title: TRADITIONAL TREATMENTS JOINED BY PROMISING WEAPONS therapy
description: RECENT gains in a patient's chances of surviving cancer reflect improvements in the traditional methods of cancer treatment - surgery, radiation therapy and chemotherapy - and new tactics in applying them to increase the probability of cure. Several promising new weapons, such as immunotherapy and hyperthermia (heat treatment), now under study are expected to extend this progress to more patients in the near future.

title: FAKERY: IT'S A PITY
description: EVERY April, perhaps prompted by April Fool's Day, professional journals buzz with disclosures about new and old scientific frauds, and this spring the spotlight seems to be on John Long, a former senior researcher at Massachusetts General Hospital.

title: SECRETARY OF DEFENSE REPORTS ON TRIP
description: SECRETARY OF DEFENSE REPORTS ON TRIP: Caspar W. Weinberger, right, who traveled to Europe last week, meeting yesterday with President Reagan and Vice President Bush in family quarters at the White House. With them were James A. Baker 3d, left, chief of staff, and Edwin Meese 3d, counselor to the President.

title: Chicago Banks' Prime at 17 1/2%
description: Three Chicago banks yesterday raised their prime lending rates to 17 1/2 percent, falling in line with a similar move last Friday by two industry leaders in New York.

title: Dodgers 4, Giants 3
description: SAN FRANCISCO (AP) - Jay Johnstone drove in the deciding run with a pinch-hit single in a three-run fourth-inning rally that gave the unbeaten Dodgers their fourth victory.

title: Chrysler Denies Pressing Ford
description: The Chrysler Corporation denied today that it was continuing to pursue a merger with the Ford Motor Company, a proposal that Ford rejected last week.

title: Six-Month Bills Down to 13.65%; Three-Month Rate at 13.78%
description: Interest rates declined slightly yesterday, although credit market participants were still uneasy about the possibility that short-term rates could increase later this month.

title: THOUSANDS OF OBJECTS OF 'SPACE JUNK' IN EARTH ORBIT
description: In addition to the Columbia, there are 1,156 other spacecraft orbiting the earth, as well as 3,419 pieces of debris, including spent rocket bodies, nuts, bolts - the flotsam and jetsam of space shots conducted not just by the United States and the Soviet Union, but by everybody else, too.

title: Alabama Utility Settles Discrimination Lawsuit
description: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission reached an agreement today with the Alabama Power Company requiring the utility to pay $2.2 million to blacks and women to settle discrimination complaints. The agreement is subject to final approval by Federal District Court in Birmingham.

title: A SMALL TOWN IN MISSOURI IS NEW CENTER OF POPULATION IN NATION
description: The center of population in the United States has moved across the Mississippi River into the limestone hills of southern Missouri, signifying that the typical American is no longer a Northerner.

title: SKETCHES OF THE NEW PULITZER WINNERS
description: Public Service The Charlotte (N.C.) Observer In a series of articles titled ''Brown Lung: A Case of Deadly Neglect,'' The Observer focused attention on byssinosis, a disease contracted by textile workers breathing invisible cotton dust, and it disclosed that regulations to limit the dust were being ignored by industry and government. After the paper published its 22 articles and eight editorials, enforcement of regulations was tightened.

title: A's 3, Angels 2
description: Tony Armas ripped a two-run homer to deep center field with two out in the eighth inning to help Oakland to its fifth straight victory.

title: ARMS AS FULCRUM OF CHINA BALANCE
description: To the Editor:

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: T HE parrot tulips were in full bloom at Grenouille last week. Rocky Cooper Converse, the former wife of Gary Cooper, was there, in pale pink and a long, California blond ponytail that cascaded to her waist. Mary McFadden was there too, whispering that her fall collection, which opens April 28, was going to be ''sexy for a change, you'll see.''

title: YANKS LOSE, 5-1, AS JAYS' CLANCY OUTPITCHES JOHN
description: Throughout spring training, Yankee scouts followed the Toronto Blue Jays, scrutinizing two young pitchers, Jim Clancy and Dave Stieb. The scouts' efforts were fruitless, though, because the Yankees were not able to pry either from the Blue Jays. And today the scouting reports could not help them beat Clancy.

title: STAGE: 'BUDDY SYSTEM'
description: IF nothing else, Jonathan Feldman has a fertile idea for a play in ''The Buddy System,'' which opened at the Circle in the Square (Downtown) last night. It is Mr. Feldman's contention that summer camp is one of the key crucibles of American adolescence - right up there with high school and the family. What former camper would dream of contradicting him? Even at this late date, I still hear my own camp's siren call on every mosquito-ridden summer night.

title: Washington State Sued By U.S. on Waste Law
description: The Justice Department filed suit today to overturn a Washington State law prohibiting the shipment of radioactive wastes into that state for storage.

title: SPREADING ELM DISEASE
description: To the Editor:

title: PYRAMIDS OF TEST QUESTION 44 OPEN A PANDORA'S BOX
description: QUESTION 44 is still being answered. The recent acknowledgment by the Educational Testing Service that a 17-year-old Florida student's ''wrong'' answer on a College Board test was correct has led dozens of students, academics and puzzle buffs to criticize the service's reasoning and propose at least two more solutions.

title: Voice Crying in Wilderness Heard at Last
description: For years Michael J. Kane has been telling New York City officials that if they'd just spend a little money he could save a lot more by cutting maintenance costs of city vehicles.

title: 13-Year High For '80 Failures
description: Commercial and industrial business failures for 1980 reached a 13-year high, rising 55 percent from 1979, to a record 11,742, Dun & Bradstreet Inc. reported yesterday.

title: DEASLY PAKISTANI ART CATERS TO AFGHANS
description: Haji Gul keeps his place open from 9 A.M. to 8 P.M. every day, including Friday, which is the Sabbath in this Moslem land. It is a question of competition, but it is also the nature of his business. Haji Gul sells guns. So does just about everyone else in this tiny village deep in the mountains of Pakistan's rugged North-West Frontier Province.

title: ARTHUR L. MAYER, FILM EXHIBITOR AND LECTURER ON MOVIE HISTORY
description: Arthur Loeb Mayer, a legendary motion-picture exhibitor, distributor and lecturer on film history, died in New York yesterday at the age of 94. For more than half a century he was an entrepreneur and then a lively voice on the vagaries of the movie business.

title: Louisiana Town Sets Curfew After Three Are Wounded
description: Riot-equipped state police were on duty in this south Louisiana town today after a white policeman and two black men were wounded by shotgun pellets in a confrontation in a predominantly black section.

title: INDIANS PLAY KEY ROLE IN KUWAIT
description: For the last 25 years, Mathunny Mathews, from India's southern state of Kerala, has lived here in Kuwait and has prospered as an automobile dealer. Another man from Kerala, N. I. Yesudasan, came here about two years ago and is making more money as a driver than he could at home.

title: 'ERRORS' FOUND IN TRIBAL OIL FUNDS
description: The Amoco Production Company, which operates oil wells on land leased from the Shoshone and Arapaho tribes in Wyoming, said today that as a result of the company's ''accounting errors'' it had not paid royalties to the tribes on substantial amounts of oil.

title: PULITZER NOVEL'S PUBLICATION IS TALE IN ITSELF
description: ''I don't like fame,'' 79-year-old Thelma Toole said. ''But I'm happy for my son.'' Her unrelenting belief in the writing of John Kennedy Toole, her late son, led to the publication last year of a manuscript over which he had toiled for years and, yesterday, to the crowning of his work with a Pulitzer Prize for fiction.

title: One Killed in South African Riot
description: White residents in the small mining town of Penge in eastern Transvaal Province fired on striking black mine workers last night when the blacks stoned homes and cars, the police said today. One man was killed and eight were wounded. The police said that the crowd of several hundred workers, who were protesting low wages and conditions in the local mine, were dispersed by tear gas.

title: FATE OF VIRGIN ISLANDS OIL REFINERY ENTANGLED IN ECONOMICS AND EMOTION
description: The revolving fans flutter like moths over the laughter and the chatter about boats and the weather, but behind the smiles there is serious concern. The world's largest oil refinery, hidden away on the south coast here, is threatening to close down.

title: Transactions
description: COLLEGES

title: Wyoming Uranium Drop
description: Uranium drilling activity in Wyoming, the nation's major producing state, declined 57 percent in 1980, the Department of Energy reported today.

title: Chemical Contamination Found In a Waterway in Chattanooga
description: Chattanooga Creek, which winds through industrial sections of south Chattanooga, is contaminated with such chemicals as the carcinogen benzene and the poisons mercury and cyanide in concentrations greater than allowed by the Federal Environmental Protection Agency, according to a study released yesterday by the Tennessee Valley Authority.

title: Accounts
description: * Copper Development Association to Marquardt & Roche, Stamford, Conn.

title: Former Brinks Guard Sentenced
description: A former guard for Brinks Inc. who admitted taking a demonstration parking meter to make a lamp was fined $1,000 and sentenced yesterday to eight weekends in jail. In sentencing the man, Anthony DeNardo of 87-29 16th Avenue, Brooklyn, Acting Justice Irving Lang of State Supreme Court said he was satisfied that Mr. DeNardo had been ''part of the group'' of Brinks guards who prosecutors contend were responsible for bilking the city of $2 million, but that his sentence must be based on the offense with which Mr. DeNardo was actually charged.

title: Down to Earth
description: It was a beautiful, exhilarating, uplifting ride. After a two-day delay to correct a computer timing problem, the space shuttle Columbia took off in a blast of color and sound from Cape Canaveral, circled the Earth 36 times and landed with majestic precision at Edwards Air Force Base in California. It gave the nation welcome reason to rejoice: Whatever setbacks have been suffered in Iran or at Three Mile Island or in Detroit's auto industry, the United States is still a master of high-technology ventures.

title: Treasury Bonds Rise Again
description: Prices of Government securities improved slightly yesterday, extending the advance that began Monday morning after yields of longterm Treasury bonds had set records as high as 13.40 percent before declining.

title: Prof. Carl L. Siegel, 84; Leading Mathematician
description: Prof. Carl Ludwig Siegel, one of this century's leading mathematicians, died April 5 in Gottingen, West Germany, at the age of 84. He made fundamental discoveries in the theory of numbers, the theory of analytic functions and celestial mechanics.

title: COOKING FOR A JOYOUS EASTER
description: Robert Farrar Capon, an Episcopal priest and food writer, is the author of ''Supper of the Lamb'' (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich). By ROBERT FARRAR CAPON

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Joseph Neubauer, 39 years old, has been named president and chief operating officer of ARA Services Inc., which provides food and other services throughout the country. He succeeds Marvin D. Heaps, 48, who resigned from the Philadelphia-based company ''for personal reasons,'' the company said.

title: INCREASE IN FOOD PRICES CLOUDS THE HOLIDAYS
description: THE average weekly cost of feeding a family of four in New York City increased by 31 cents to a record high of $103.19 in the period from March 30 to April 10, according to the market basket survey of the city's Department of Consumer Affairs. The 41-item weekly market basket cost an average of $102.88 during the two-week period ending March 27.

title: People
description: * Kathleen S. McGowan has been named director-Children's Advertising Unit for the National Advertising division of the Council of Better Business Bureaus.

title: Northrop Reports Gains
description: The Northrop Corporation, a major manufacturer of military aircraft based in Los Angeles, reported yesterday that net income in the first quarter of 1981 edged up nine-tenths of 1 percent, to $23.1 million, or $1.62 a share, from $22.9 million, or $1.61 a share, in the first quarter of 1980. Sales increased 14.6 percent, to $435.2 million, from $379.6 million.

title: ATLANTA'S OFFICIALS IN A RIFT WITH F.B.I.
description: Reaction from the Mayor and top police officials in this city was swift and stinging today after the director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation said yesterday that four cases were ''substantially solved'' and that there was a suspect in 12 to 16 of the other cases of Atlanta's 25 missing or murdered children.

title: COAL INDUSTRY REJECTS EFFORT BY UNION TO REGAIN 7 ITEMS
description: The coal industry's chief negotiator tonight ''flatly rejected'' renewed demands by the United Mine Workers for a ''better contract'' after last month's overwhelming rejection of a proposed new contract by the membership.

title: NOTES ON PEOPLE
description: Albert Finney Shorn In a hotel room at the Essex House yesterday, the actor Albert Finney gave his all for his art. He sat and had his luxuriant growth of hair shaved off, right down to the pate.

title: A FASHION INSTITUTE EXHIBITION FOR FORTUNY
description: IRENE WORTH wore a cream-colored pleated silk dress with puffed sleeves by Fortuny. But Gloria Vanderbilt wore lavender and white printed organza by Galanos because ''all my Fortunys are in the show.''

title: Jackson Runs At 'Full Tilt'
description: A Yankee spokesman reported that Reggie Jackson, who is in Florida recuperating from a torn tendon in his right calf, ran at ''full tilt'' yesterday.

title: INSURGENTS SEEK TO REMOLD CITY COUNCIL'S IMAGE
description: For years, New York's City Council has often been the branch of metropolitan government least likely to be taken seriously and it has also been called a rubber stamp.

title: MAYOR BRADLEY OF LOS ANGLES ELECTED TO THIRD TERM
description: Mayor Tom Bradley was elected to a third term today, defeating former Mayor Sam Yorty and becoming the first chief executive in the city's history to win a third term without a runoff.

title: SHANGHAI PAYS IMMENSE PRICE TO BE A MARVEL
description: The people of this city are proud of their ''10 national bests'' and bear even their ''five national worsts'' with a swagger. The ''bests,'' according to an article by Shen Dingpo of the Shanghai Academy of Social Sciences, are all the marks of economic success; the ''worsts'' are the heavy price that such success exacts in terms of a decline in the quality of life. Significantly, a group of academy members who met with a visiting reporter confessed that they had never heard the phrase ''quality of life.''

title: U.S. Plane Crashes off Okinawa
description: A United States Marine A-4 Skyhawk attack bomber crashed into the sea off Okinawa today, but the pilot bailed out and was rescued by a helicopter, a Marine spokesman here said.

title: BEIRUT GUNFIRE TRAPS PRIME MINISTER, AIDES
description: Artillery and mortar shells exploded around Parliament today as Syrians and Lebanese Christian militiamen exchanged gunfire, trapping Prime Minister Shafik al-Wazzan, four Cabinet aides and 15 legislators inside for at least an hour.

title: KLEINDIENST, EX-ATTORNEY GEMERAL, IS CHARGED WITH PREJURY IN ARIZONA
description: Former United States Attorney General - .acH . -:-???H-???C* -C ???H-*-H ???? 14 counts of perjury today in connection *. a??? ??? -C*--*???? ?- -??? ???C c-???-- scandal, State Attorney General Bob Corbin said.

title: Tolls in Connecticut Will Rise 10 Friday
description: Starting at 12:01 A.M. Friday, motorists will pay 10 cents more for tolls on Connecticut's parkways and toll bridges to help the state erase a budget deficit.

title: Article 085635 -- No Title
description: The International Finance Corporation said today that it and an international group of banks would support a $43 million loan for a Brazilian polyethylene project. I.F.C. is to lend $15 million to build a plant at Triunfo, Brazil. A loan of $28 million is to be made jointly by the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, Citibank, Union Bank of Switzerland, Amsterdam-Rotterdam Bank, Banco Sudameris Internacional, National Bank of Abu Dhabi and Abu Dhabi International Bank.

title: COPPING OUT ON THE PENNY
description: To the Editor:

title: TV: PBS'S SHAVIAN 'DEAR LIAR'
description: ''DEAR LIAR,'' tonight's ''Hallmark Hall of Fame'' presentation on WNET-TV, Channel 13, at 8 o'clock, offers the curiously diverting spectacle of two lustless lions at play. Written by Jerome Kilty in the late 50's, this theatrical piece is constructed around the correspondence over 40 years between George Bernard Shaw, described succinctly as the vegetarian and playwright, and Mrs. Patrick Campbell, the renowned actress for whom he created the role of Eliza in ''Pygmalion.''

title: Ex-Hostage Tells of Ills Suffered After His Release
description: A former hostage, Phillip Ward, said he was hospitalized for six weeks because of physical and emotional problems he developed while a captive in Iran, but he said he was well on the road to recovery.

title: Tanana, Red Sox Pitcher, Injured in Auto Accident
description: Frank Tanana, the Boston Red Sox pitcher, needed 10 stitches for a cut on his chin after he was involved in a head-on auto accident today. He was not seriously injured, a team spokesman said.

title: 9-Digit ZIP Challenged
description: The United States Postal Service's controversial nine-digit ZIP code, which has run into strong Congressional opposition, received another jolt today when the Office of Management and Budget ordered the service to justify its plan with a costbenefit analysis.

title: Economic Scene; Game Theory: Reagan's Move
description: PRESIDENT REAGAN'S decision to order his staff to repudiate a report that he was willing to compromise on the tax-cut portion of his economic plan probably demonstrates that he is a natural and gifted game theorist, better than the three sub-Cabinet officers who had led Representative James R. Jones, chairman of the House Budget Committee, to believe that the President would accept a one-year, rather than a three-year, tax cut.

title: FREE FOOD PROGRAM STRESSES CREATIVITY Armstead with low-income mother
description: DETROIT HUNDREDS of women, children beneath them like puppies, push through the old, cavernous building, placing groceries in shopping baskets. At the checkout stand, a clerk checks to see if they have all the foods they should have and helps them box the groceries. There is no cash register; the food is free.

title: BIG THREE AUTO SALES DROP 11.9%
description: Sales of new cars by the three major American auto makers dropped 11.9 percent from a year earlier in the April 1 to April 10 selling period, mainly as a result of a poor showing by the General Motors Corporation after the end of customer rebate sales promotions.

title: Merger Conditions Irk Great Western
description: The Great Western Savings and Loan Association, of Beverly Hills, the country's second largest after the Home Savings and Loan Association of Los Angeles, said today it would seek a Federal charter as a way around an unusual set of conditions imposed by the State of California upon its pending merger with Financial Federation, Inc.

title: IT'S PEAK TIME FOR SEA URCHINS
description: Sea urchins are at their peak right now and will be in the market for a few more weeks. Only the roe is edible, and it makes a delicious first course when eaten raw from the shell, accompanied by fresh French bread and cold white wine such as a Muscadet or a Chablis or a California chardonnay.

title: YOUNG DRIFTERS IN AMERICA: WHO WHERE AND WHY
description: Thousands of young middle-class and upper-middle-class Americans, reared and nurtured with the high expectations of parents and teachers, slip each year through the cracks of a conventional society.

title: OLD MAN OF THE MISSION EXCEEDS HIS JUNIOR IN JOY
description: Having made history, the dean of the spacefarers and his rookie companion stepped onto the dust of the Mojave Desert with bounce in their steps, but it was the normally unflappable veteran of five space flights and a walk on the moon who showed the jubilation of the event as he strode about, flapping his arms, to inspect the Columbia.

title: HUSBAND IS HURT SUBDUING SUSPECT
description: A 40-year-old woman was stabbed to death last night in a bathroom on the ninth floor of an office building in lower Manhattan, the police said. Moments later, her husband received head cuts as he and two other men subdued a suspect.

title: AMNESTY'S RECORDS ON TORTURE IN TURKEY
description: To the Editor:

title: SOFT-SHELL CRABS ARRIVE
description: The event did not convey quite the same sense of romantic urgency that attends the arrival of the first Beaujolais of the season, but the first soft-shell crabs of spring crept into the city last week and Gary Clauson, the executive chef of the Regency Hotel, claimed them.

title: Davis, Happy as a Yankee, Wishes Trade Talk Would Vanish
description: Ron Davis came to Toronto with the Yankees and he expects to leave Toronto with the Yankees. And he doesn't expect to visit here in the future with anybody but the Yankees.

title: Court Tells Magma Not to Discuss Bid
description: The Natomas Company said the United States District Court in Los Angeles had granted a temporary order restraining the Magma Power Company, its chairman and directors from communicating with Magma shareholders on the merits of a $42-a-share tender offer by Natomas.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Browne Vintners Co. has named David H. Rosenberg executive vice president, sales.

title: Negotiations Begun On Panama Copper
description: The Fluor Corporation said that a subsidiary had begun negotiations with the Panamanian Government and an international mining consortium aimed at developing Panama's Cerro Colorado copper ore deposits.

title: WINE TALK
description: SOUTH AFRICA, a producer of wine for more than three centuries, churns out some 200 million gallons a year, equal to West German production. But tradition and the patterns of world trade have excluded all but modest quantities from North America.

title: Market Place;
description: THE names and major holdings of some of the wealthiest individuals in the nation have come to light in a computer search for affluent potential clients for brokerage houses.

title: A SPCECK PIERCES HORIZON
description: First came the sonic boom announcing that it was near: two loud shocks that reverberated like cannon blasts across the desert floor.

title: G.&.W. Purchase
description: Gulf and Western Industries reported to the Securities and Exchange Commission that it owns 1.22 million shares, or 7.1 percent of the common stock of the B.F. Goodrich Company. The amount includes 211,800 shares purchased on the open market between March 12 and April 9, for a total of approximately $5.6 million from general corporate funds.

title: BLUES WIN IN 2D OVERTIME, ADVANCE TO PALY RANGERS
description: - The Philadelphia Flyers broke loose for three goals early in the third period tonight and defeated the Quebec Nordiques, 5-2, to win their Stanley Cup playoff series.

title: REO SPEEDWAGON FROM MIDWEST
description: THE Middle Western rock quintet Reo Speedwagon, which played to a sellout crowd at the Nassau Coliseum in Uniondale, L.I., on Sunday night, certainly qualifies for the year's outstanding pop phenomenon. ''Hi Infidelity,'' its 11th album, has sold more than 3 million copies and has been No. 1 on the album charts for two months, and this success has spurred some of the band's earlier albums back onto the charts.

title: SRI LANKA USING PATRIOTIC POMP TO STRESS ITS VALUE TO INVESTORS
description: With the same enthusiasm and pomp that most young countries display in marking the anniversary of battles or legendary events of a murky prehistory, Sri Lanka is marking 50 years of universal suffrage.

title: BETTER THERAPIES ARE HELPING THOUSANDS OF CANCER PATIENTS
description: THIS year some 815,000 Americans will face a diagnosis of serious cancer. It is the disease Americans fear most, though heart disease is by far the greater killer. It is made all the more frightening by the fact that few of us face such a diagnosis more than once in our lives, and we tend to remember those cancer patients who died tragically and painfully far more readily than we do those who fought cancer and won.

title: RESISTANCE TO PESTICIDE-SPRAYING RISES
description: With the arrival of spring and the annual state-sponsored spraying programs to protect trees from gypsy moths and other predatory insects, an increasing number of communities in the New York metropolitan area are scrutinizing the potential hazards of the pesticides, and some are electing not to take part.

title: FROM BRITISH RACIAL STRIFE, ROCK
description: WHEN the Specials first visited the United States a little more than a year ago, it was immediately evident that they were something more than an energetic new English rock band with pronounced Jamaican rhythmic influences. Some of the group's members were white and some were black, but their music was neither that of whites imitating blacks nor of blacks imitating whites. It was a vibrant dance music that combined punk rock's raw energy, pop's lyricism and the brisk, choppy syncopations of ska, the mid-60's Jamaican music that was a direct precursor of contemporary Jamaican reggae.

title: Merrick Starring in Supporting Role
description: Wayne Merrick scored only 16 goals during the regular season, and he had only 15 assists in his 71 games. He also had been benched for some games and was occasionally relegated to the Islanders' fourth line.

title: THEATER: 'IT'S ME,' BY AND WITH SYLVIA MILES
description: NARCISSISM flew into the Playhouse Theater II on Monday night in the guise of Sylvia Miles, the author, lyricist and sole performer in ''It's Me, Sylvia!'' The evening takes place in a supposed copy of Miss Miles's incredibly cluttered apartment. The set has been ingeniously designed by Eugene Lee, and that is the last kind word that should be said about the show.

title: CITY WINS SLUDGE DUMPING REPRIEVE
description: A Federal judge ruled yesterday that the Federal Environmental Protection Agency cannot stop New York City from dumping sewage sludge into the ocean unless it determines that the dumping will ''unreasonably degrade the marine environment.''

title: METS TO NURSE LEARY'S ELBOW
description: Rain fell on Shea Stadium yesterday, delaying the Mets' home opener against the St. Louis Cardinals until this afternoon and adding some gloom to the uncertain future of Tim Leary, the pitching prodigy with the sore right elbow.

title: Allied Considers Sale Of 2 Canadian Units
description: The Allied Chemical Corporation, based in Morris Township, N.J., said it is considering the sale of two of its Canadian subsidiaries, the Uno-Tex Petroleum Corporation and Union Texas of Canada Ltd., for an undetermined price. Both companies are involved in oil and natural gas exploration in western Canada and had combined afterroyalties revenues of $39.8 million (Canadian) in 1980, Allied said.

title: 1040 or Fight
description: In all the literature of money, there is no really satisfactory definition of either ''income'' or ''tax.'' Income can be earned, as in a sweatshop, or brought by angels from a distant uncle. A tax can be precisely tithed by king or Congress, or stealthily exacted by inflation and the gnomes of Zurich.

title: 3 S.I. Men Are Accused In Business Check Theft
description: Three Staten Island men were arrested yesterday on charges of stealing as much as $1 million in business checks by posing as postal workers and picking up mail bags in Manhattan's financial district. By altering the checks and using false identifications, the men were able to cash the checks.

title: Soviet Relents on Hess, Permitting Visit by Son
description: Soviet authorities relented today and allowed the son of the former Nazi leader Rudolf Hess to visit his sick father in the British military hospital in West Berlin, an allied spokesman reported.

title: TO MINISTER OF MUSIC, SONG IS 'A GIFT TO GOD'
description: Before John Weaver ever went to school, he was being boosted up to the organ console in church to press a few keys at the conclusion of the worship service led by his father. Far in advance of his high school graduation, he was a regular organist and choir director in a downtown Baltimore church.

title: B.& B. Survey Outlines Troubles Facing Cable TV
description: According to a national survey conducted by Benton & Bowles, cable TV operators will not be able to surmount the ''subscription rate barrier'' that keeps the industry at 55 percent of possible subscribers without product or marketing changes or more program diversity.

title: UNITED TECHNOLOGIES HAS A 16.4% RISE
description: The United Technologies Corporation, one of the nation's leading producers of commercial and military aircraft jet engines, reported yesterday that earnings in the first quarter of 1981 rose 16.4 percent on an increase in sales of 15.2 percent.

title: JACOBSON DENIES WILLIAMS INTERVIEWED IN '76 PROJECT
description: New Jersey's top energy official testified at the Abscam bribery trial of Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. yesterday that the Senator had not intervened with him in behalf of a 1976 proposal to build a plant to transform garbage to fuel.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN WINE MAKER DEFIES CUSTOM
description: STELLENBOSCH, South Africa The new wing of Nico Myburgh's house was built in 1776, which was 83 years after the old wing. The seven generations of Myburghs who preceded him here all made wine, but none, it seems, got fancy ideas about the wine maker's art.

title: A PASSOVER FEAST RICH IN MEMORIES AND IN CUISINE
description: Lorna J. Sass, a culinary historian, is the author of several cookbooks. By LORNA J. SASS

title: HONEYWELL UP 16.5%
description: Two of the largest United States computer manufacturers yesterday reported lackluster first-quarter earnings. Company officials and analysts indicated that the companies, the Burroughs Corporation and Honeywell Inc., would have a difficult time matching last year's earnings performance.

title: News Analysis
description: The practical dilemma that Congress faces in rescuing the Social Security System is simply stated: Almost every move that would give the financially shaky retirement program more stability involves a high political risk for those who support it.

title: AT MISSION CONTROL, EVEN EXHILARATION CAME ON CUE
description: A moment after the wheels of the space shuttle Columbia touched ground in two puffs of dust, Don Puddy, chief of the flight control team at Mission Control here, announced into the wirethin microphone at his lips: ''Room, get ready for exhilaration.''

title: DRAMA IN 'STENGELESE: YOU CAN LOOK IT UP
description: The conversation turned to languages, and the creator, expert and sole practitioner of the inimitable, sometimes inscrutable, prolix and amazin' language, Stengelese, addressed himself to it.

title: STOP ARMS FOR SAUDIS
description: The Reagan Administration is headed for a needless confrontation with the Congress, Israel, and Saudi Arabia over its arms-sales policy toward the Middle East. Despite ample advance warnings of the risks involved, the Administration has decided to sell Saudi Arabia additional military equipment that greatly enhances the offensive capabilities of that country's combat aircraft.

title: SHUTTLE PROJECT MANAGER
description: - For Mel Burke, the labors of more than three years were condensed today into 90 seconds. Mr. Burke, the 48-year-old shuttle project manager at the Dryden Flight Research Center here, was responsible for assuring that everything was ready when the space shuttle Columbia zoomed out of orbit this morning and landed on a dry lake bed at this flight test center in southern California.

title: U.S. SAYS SOVIET ACTIVITY NEAR POLAND HAS SLOWED
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that unusual military activity by Soviet and other Warsaw Pact forces in and around Poland had virtually halted.

title: 2 EMERGENCY SERVICES WILL DRAFT JURISDICTIONAL ACCORD
description: Stung by continuing disputes over who should be in charge at the scene of a medical emergency, New York City's fire and emergency medical services agreed yesterday to draft protocols governing the responsibilities of firefighters and medical corpsmen at a fire or accident.

title: A VEGETABLE STEAMER
description: IN a restaurant the vegetables often arrive at the table possessing a magnificently rich and brilliant color that is not easy to duplicate at home. One of the reasons, of course, is that professional cooks have their secrets, not all of them especially appealing when the truth is out.

title: Taiwan Airbus Order
description: China Airlines, based in Taiwan, has ordered a fourth A300-B4 Airbus with the aid of fixed-interest export loans, French bankers said today. Airbus Industrie will deliver the first $45 million plane in 1982, two more in 1983 and the fourth soon afterward, the bankers said.

title: The U.N. Today; April 15, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Special Committee on Enhancing the Nonuse of Force in International Rela- tions - 3 P.M.

title: EAST BERLIN, CITING POLSIH UNREST, TIGHTENS 'VIGILANCE'
description: In light of the labor unrest in neighboring Poland, East Germany announced today that it was intensifying political vigilance and party discipline to protect the country from either internal or external attack.

title: CARSON DENIES HE WALKED OUT
description: Johnny Carson said today that a strike by the Writers Guild of America had forced him to suspend the ''Tonight Show'' because ''this is essentially a comedy show'' and without the writers it would be just a talk show.

title: PIGEONS' FEET A LA CARTE
description: WASHINGTON When Keith Hay decided to go out for Chinese food last year, he went all the way to China. He was accompanied by 14 other welltraveled Americans of various ages, including two in their 70's, a teen-age boy and his parents and several single people. The object: to learn about and to eat Chinese food.

title: REAGAN TO SEND MORE BUDGET DATA TO G.O.P. CONSERVATIVES IN SENATE
description: President Reagan, presiding over a strategy session on his economic program today, directed budget officials to furnish additional information on future spending cuts to the conservative Republicans in the Senate who rebuffed the Administration on its budget last week.

title: Careers; This Year's Market for Executives
description: DEMAND for business executives declined 7 percent in this year's first quarter from the level of a year before, according to Executive Resource Consultants, the management recruiting affiliate of Arthur Young & Company, the nationwide accounting firm.

title: From Realty to Movies
description: Jack Singer, a 62-year-old multimillionaire Canadian real estate developer, appears to have been attracted by the lure of the motion picture industry. Mr. Singer, who has invested $3 million in Francis Coppola's over-budget, $24-million production of ''One From the Heart,'' plans to invest another $5 million and is considering the purchase of half of Mr. Coppola's Zoetrope Studios in Hollywood.

title: N.A.S.L. Rules Again Disputed
description: The rules dispute between soccer's international governing body and the North American Soccer League - an issue that had been thought resolved -took another perplexing turn yesterday when the international body denied that it had approved two league practices that make the N.A.S.L. game significantly different from the one played around the world.

title: MARRIGE IS WIFE'S FOURTH, CAREY'S OFFICE CONFIRMS
description: Governor Carey was apparently unaware of one of the three former marriages of his bride, Evangeline Gouletas, at the time of their wedding Saturday. The Governor's office confirmed early yesterday that Mrs. Gouletas-Carey had been married and divorced not twice, as had been publicly stated, but three times.

title: MASS MARKET KEY FOR LEVI'S CHIEF
description: With a relaxed, yet almost professorial, manner and a theory of marketing that shows an outright disdain for high fashion, Robert T. Grohman may seem an unlikely figure to head the world's largest apparel company.

title: Advertising; Supplement Entries by N.C.A.A.
description: THE sales force of the Pattis Group, Chicago-based magazine advertising representatives, will move out of their eight offices throughout the country tomorrow with one of their biggest assignments - selling ads for two new publications at $188,000 a page.

title: 'The Hostages' Passion'
description: ''The Hostages Passion,'' a theatrical meditation incorporating the words of the Americans who were held prisoner for 444 days in Teheran, Iran, will be presented tomorrow at 9 P.M. during an allnight Easter vigil at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue and West 112th Street.

title: THE EDITORIAL NOTEBOOK
description: The army of prisoners grows at an alarming pace, while the number of cells remains fixed. The predictable result is overcrowding, the increasingly dangerous malady that afflicts the nation's big penitentiaries.

title: Kush Says That Rutledge Was Not Run Off Team
description: Frank Kush, the former Arizona State University football coach, testified today that he ''had no personal animosity'' toward Kevin Rutledge, a former player, and ''definitely did not'' run him off the team.

title: REAGAN AIDE URGES SALT LABELS
description: Saying high blood pressure is a problem for 60 million Americans, a White House official encouraged food processors today to put salt content on labels or face the possibility of a mandatory labeling law.

title: Delay in Merger Hurt Amax Socal
description: Shares of Amax Inc. continued to come under heavy selling pressure yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange as the prospects for a takeover of the huge mining company by the Standard Oil Company of California grew increasingly uncertain.

title: BLUES WIN IN 2D OVERTIME, ADVANCE TO PLAY RANGERS
description: The Philadelphia Flyers broke loose for three goals early in the third period tonight and defeated the Quebec Nordiques, 5-2, to win their Stanley Cup playoff series.

title: ONCE NATIONAL PARKS RESOURCES ARE LOST, THEY'RE LOST FOREVER
description: To the Editor:

title: CAVIAR BLACK MARKET IN SAN FRANCISCO RESULTS IN 6 ARRESTS
description: An undercover investigation of the black market in caviar has led to the arrests of six men and confiscation of about $25,000 worth of sturgeon roe, according to the California Fish and Game Department. The black market operations threatened the Bay Area's low sturgeon population, department officials said yesterday.

title: SATELLITE TV VIEW
description: Any entrepreneur, and not just the Communications Satellite Corporation, should be permitted to broadcast television programs directly to the home via satellite tranmission, the Reagan Administration said today.

title: FISK'S SLAM PACES WHITE SOX
description: A grand slam by Carlton Fisk highlighted a six-run fourth inning and powered the White Sox to a 9-3 victory over the Milwaukee Brewers before a record home opening-day crowd of 51,560 in Comiskey Park today.

title: RED SMITH/Sports of The Times; Doc and His Toy Bulldog
description: FROM Sasabe, Ariz., which is on the Mexican border, came a letter from Teddy Hayes, who trained Jack Dempsey until Jack broke with Doc Kearns, his manager, and who then trained Mickey Walker. Teddy enclosed an old column about Walker and Kearns. Both have gone to the great speakeasy in the sky since the old piece was written, but the Hayes letter and the old column brought back treasured memories of the Toy Bulldog, who began as a featherweight and fought heavyweights on the world championship level, and the dauntless Kearns, of whom Archie Moore said, ''Give Doc a hundred pounds of steel wool, and he'll knit you a stove.''

title: COLUMBIA RETURNS: SHUTTLE ERA OPENS
description: The space shuttle Columbia rocketed out of orbit and glided to a safe landing on the desert here today to conclude the successful first demonstration of a bold new approach to extraterrestrial travel, the re-usable winged spaceship.

title: STATE RETIREES NEED PENSION RELIEF NOW
description: To the Editor:

title: Justice Dept. Urged to Seek Funds Given to 4 Charities
description: The General Accounting Office is urging the Justice Department to try to recover $3 million that Paul Bloom, a special counsel to the Energy Department in the Carter Administration, gave to four national charities to help poor people pay their heating bills.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Air Florida said it will begin service between Chicago and New York's Westchester County Airport on April 27.

title: HUFFY TROUBLED BY SLUMP IN BICYCLE SALES
description: The Huffy Corporation, the nation's leading bicycle manufacturer, has come to a skidding stop after five years of rapid growth.

title: Barbara Stanwyck Honored by Film Society
description: For a few hours, Avery Fisher Hall was turned into Hollywood-onthe-Hudson when the Film Society of Lincoln Center paid tribute to Barbara Stanwyck at its annual spring gala Monday night.

title: Atlantic City Casino Opened by Playboy
description: The $135 million 500-room Playboy hotel and casino opened yesterday after Commissioner Don M. Thomas ruled for the Casino Control Commission that four days of trial runs with ''play money'' had been completed satisfactorily.

title: DANCE: PAUL TAYLOR'S COMIC-STRIP AMERICA
description: PAUL TAYLOR is at his most serious when he is at his silliest, as the quite wonderful Paul Taylor Dance Company proved on two levels last night when it opened a three-week run at the City Center.

title: British Civil Servants Press Demands on Pay
description: More than 500,000 British civil servants struck for several hours today to press demands for a 15 percent pay increase, disrupting international air service and shutting down government offices, computers and museums.

title: ALFONS VOGEL
description: Alfons Vogel, who had been vice president of Dodge & Seymour, a former Manhattan export company, died Sunday at Lenox Hill Hospital.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''Welcome home Columbia.'' - Joseph Allen, a mission control communicator. (A1:6.)

title: DELIVERS AND PRESSMEN AGREE OM PAY IN NEGOTIATIONS WITH 2 NEWSPAPERS
description: Negotiators for the newspaper deliverers' and pressmen's unions reached agreement with The Daily News and The New York Times early yesterday on a three-year economic package.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, APRIL 15, 1981
description: The Return of Columbia A major space advance was achieved as the United States successfully demonstrated the first re-usable winged spaceship. The space shuttle Columbia rocketed out of orbit and glided to a safe wheeled landing on California's Mojave Desert. John W. Young and Capt. Robert L. Crippen of the Navy brought the powerless vehicle to a smooth touchdown at a speed of 215 miles an hour, about twice the velocity of a jetliner landing. One hour earlier, the craft was orbiting at 17,500 miles an hour. (Page A1, Column 6.) At least 250,000 people had gone to Edwards Air Force Base to watch the space shuttle glide to a landing. The spectators cheered as the Columbia touched down perhaps only 60 seconds after it was first spotted high over the horizon. (A1:1-2.)

title: Howe of Ford Foundation Going to Harvard
description: He's been everything from a principal of a junior high school to the United States Commissioner of Education, and now, after 10 years as a vice president of the Ford Foundation, Harold Howe 2d is getting a chance to pass on some of his accumulated learning about learning to a new generation of academics. Beginning next February he will become a senior lecturer at Harvard's Graduate School of Education.

title: COST OF SUBWAT EROSION PUT AT $165 MILLION A YEAR
description: Deterioration in New York City's subway service is costing businesses and commuters an estimated $165 million to $330 million a year and reducing the city's competitiveness with other areas, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York said yesterday.

title: Britain and Belize Agree On a New Constitution
description: In eight days of talks that ended here today, officials of Britain and Belize have agreed on a constitution under which the Central American colony will function after it becomes independent later this year.

title: The Economy
description: Bank regulators, seeking to aid savings and loan associations and other financial institutions, are drafting legislation to facilitate mergers and provide needed capital. John G. Heimann, Comptroller of the Currency, said a program was being devised to protect the institutions against a ''disaster scenario.'' (Page D1.)

title: Health Group Sees No Need To Ban Herbicide 2,4,5-T
description: There is no convincing evidence of human health damage from the herbicide 2,4,5-T to support efforts to ban it, a consumer health group said today.

title: Mergers Up 46% Over '80
description: The pace of corporate mergers quickened in the first quarter of 1981, rising to 599, or 46 percent ahead of the 411 in the same quarter a year earlier, W.T. Grimm & Company, a Chicago-based merger specialist said yesterday.

title: ALLY OF HONDURAN ARMY EXPECTS U.S. RIGHT-FACE
description: For over 15 years Ricardo Zuniga Augustinus has been the closest political ally of Honduras's successive military regimes. Yet when elections were held for a constitutional assembly last April, the Carter Administration pressed the army to remain neutral and Mr. Zuniga's National Party went down to defeat.

title: Mehmed A. Simsar, 78, a Scholar In Languages and Film Director
description: Mehmed A. Simsar, a scholar and teacher of Near East languages and a former motion picture director, died of heart disease Saturday at George Washington University Hospital. He was 78 years old.

title: U.S. BORROWERS TURN ABROAD
description: In a maneuver to reduce their borrowing costs, many large companies have been turning to foreign branches of American banks for their loans and away from domestic offices.

title: ROCKETS TRIUMPH, LEAD, 3-2
description: Moses Malone and Calvin Murphy, Houston's inside and outside threats, teamed up for 70 points tonight to power the Rockets past the San Antonio Spurs, 123-117, for a 3-2 edge in the Western Conference National Basketball Association semifinal series.

title: How Shall I Dear Thee?
description: A friend, as Lyndon Johnson used to say, is ''somebody you can go to the well with.'' Not for an instant would I consider going to the well with Times Square. I certainly wouldn't invite Times Square home to meet the folks. Truth is, whenever I see Times Square on the sidewalk I cross the street to avoid it.

title: No Headline
description: The Pennsylvania Engineering Corporation, a company owned by Victor Posner, the Miami Beach financier, said in a filing with the United States Securities and Exchange Commission that it had sold 200,000 shares of the Natural Gypsum Company for $4.5 million.

title: PAKISTAN SAID TO SEEK WIDE SECURITY PLEDGE FROM U.S.
description: Pakistan is expected to ask the United States for a broad pledge of support against aggression, Asian diplomats said today.

title: MISSION CONTROL: 'COLUMBIA, YOU'RE REALLY LOOKING GOOD. RIGHT ON THE
description: MONEY Following are excerpts from conversations between the astronauts and Mission Control in Houston, from the time the Columbia approached California until the two astronauts left the craft at Edwards Air Force Base, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: ARCO FORGOES COSTLY AFRICAN OIL
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company is giving up its right to 60,000 barrels a day of expensive, high-quality Nigerian crude oil, a move that oil industry sources say is illustrative of the current oil glut.

title: 2d Conrail Generator Expected by Monday
description: A generator that broke down on April 3 at Conrail's Cos Cob power station in Connecticut should be back in operation by Monday, Conrail officials said.

title: Nissan Truck Plant Spending to Increase
description: The Nissan Motor Manufacturing Corporation U.S.A. said that because of inflation and construction of a coal-fired power station, it would spend an additional $200 million on a new Datsun truck plant here.

title: SPACE TO GROW
description: America prospers on the new and the ingenious. The space program has given us both.

title: A MOTORCYCLE CLUB FOR THE EXECUTIVE
description: SAN FRANCISCO Every weekday morning, Phil deRoulet dons a gray three-piece suit, sturdy deerskin gloves and a silver helmet with a tire-tread design, then climbs aboard his BMW RF 100 motorcycle for the four-mile trek to the Transamerica pyramid in downtown San Francisco.

title: Cities Service Plans Refinery Expansion
description: The Cities Service Company said it planned to build a 2,000-tonsa-day delayed coker and a 30,000-barrels-a-day hydrocracker at its Lake Charles, La., refinery at a cost of about $338 million.

title: Bridge: Linda Sartorius Is Mourned As a Player and Organizer
description: The bridge players of New Jersey suffered a major loss four days ago when Linda Sartorius of Cedar Grove died at the age of 35. For more than a decade she had been a prominent and popular figure, both as a player and an organizer.

title: Doe Says Liberian Army Will Maintain Strict Control
description: Master Sgt. Samuel Doe, the Liberian head of state, said today that Liberia would return to civilian rule only after a newly appointed commission has drafted a constitution.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: THE French language has many spellings for the word curry. It is spelled kari, cari, carry, carri and cary. On some French menus it is also written as curry.

title: BORG IS UPSET BY PECCI
description: - Victor Pecci of Paraguay, ranked 29th in the world, scored a major upset in the $250,000 Monte Carlo tennis tournament today with a 6-0, 4-6, 7-5 victory over Bjorn Borg of Sweden, ranked No. 1 in the world.

title: Jersey to Ask Funds To Redo Mansion
description: Governor Byrne and members of the New Jersey Historical Society will meet in Newark today to begin a campaign to raise $4 million to refurbish Drumthwacket, the 40-room, state-owned mansion on Route 206 in Princeton, and make it the new official residence.

title: Kingman Brewster Becomes Counsel to New York Law Firm
description: Kingman Brewster, 61, the former president of Yale University and Ambassador to Britain, starts today in a new career - counsel to the New York law firm of Winthrop, Stimson, Putnam & Roberts. ''Counsel to'' means that a contractual relationship has been established, rather than a partnership.

title: Addendum
description: * Family Handyman magazine has increased its circulation rate base by 5 percent, to 1.05 million, from 1 million, and its advertising rates 8 percent, effective with the July/August issue.

title: A TRANSCRIPT OF STATEMENTS BY ASTRONAUTS
description: Following is a transcript of the statements made by the astronauts of the spaceship Columbia at Dryden Research Center in California, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Iran Reports 7 Persons Executed On Charges of Narcotics Dealing
description: Seven persons were executed today, six of them in public, on charges of narcotics dealing, the offical Pars press agency reported.

title: THUMPING CANNON SOUND A HERO'S TRIBUTE TO OMAR BRADLEY
description: General of the Army Omar N. Bradley served the cause of patriotism one final time today as he was accorded a military hero's funeral and was laid to rest as the last of the five star officers to command in World War II.

title: REGULATORS SEEK TO AID THRIFT UNITS
description: Federal bank regulators plan to draft a joint legislative proposal ''within the next few weeks'' designed to facilitate mergers and provide capital for troubled savings and loan associations and other financial institutions, John G. Heimann, Comptroller of the Currency, said today.

title: Winner of Harvard Suit Plans to Take Other Job
description: The winner of what is believed to be Harvard's first faculty sex-discrimination case says she will not teach at the university next fall.

title: Water Leaks at Nuclear Plant
description: About 160,000 gallons of radioactive water leaked from a storage tank into a pump room of a reactor containment building today at the Philadelphia Electric Company's Peach Bottom power station. A spokesman said that several workers in the pump room left safely and the water was contained within the room. The unit has been out of service since March 6.

title: Merrill Lynch Net Up 31% in Quarter
description: Merrill Lynch & Company, the nation's largest securities firm, said yesterday that its first-quarter earnings rose 31 percent, to $45.2 million or $1.17 a share, from $34.5 million, or 95 cents a share, in the same period last year.

title: PENNEY PLANS TO SELL 'ZERO COUPON' NOTES
description: Turning to innovative financing in the beleaguered fixed-income market, the J.C. Penney Company announced plans yesterday for the first public sale of ''zero coupon'' notes. These securities provide no interest payments to holders.

title: SHUTTLE'S LAUNCHING PAD IS A SCENE OF DEVASTATION
description: The blastoff of the space shuttle last Sunday had awesome effects on its launching pad, and as Air Force and civilian technicians returned to work here, many expressed surprise at the extent of the damage.

title: NATION REACTS WITH CHEERS AND 'WE' RE NO. 1 AGAIN'
description: The apprehension that had been building across the country for more than two days suddenly dissolved at 1:21 P.M., Eastern standard time, yesterday when the Columbia space shuttle gracefully touched down on the desert runway at Edwards Air Force Base in California. Millions of Americans were watching on television, and they broke into cheers and whistles and shouts of joy.

title: FORMER C.I.A. AGENT MAY SEEK WEICKER'S SEAT IN U.S. SENATE
description: John T. Downey, a former agent for the Central Intelligence Agency who spent 20 years in a Chinese prison, today became the first potential Democratic challenger to Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr. in next year's election.

title: CHRISTOPHER WILL LEAD GAS TALKS WITH ALGERIA
description: Three American gas-pipeline companies have engaged Warren M. Christopher, who was chief negotiator for the release of the hostages in Iran, to lead a drive to restore shipments of liquefied natural gas from Algeria.

title: DOW DOWN 4.06 ON RATE FEARS
description: Concern over interest rates sent the stock market down moderately yesterday for the second consecutive session.

title: Tri-American Offer
description: The Scottish and York International Insurance Inc. said it intended to seek all of the outstanding common shares of the Tri-American Corporation for $11.50 a share, or about $11.5 million.

title: FRENCH TRUCK MAKERS TO JOIN
description: Renault and Peugeot-Citroen, France's two automobile makers, said today that they would link their truck interests, thereby apparently completing the French Government's long-planned reorganization of the country's commercial vehicle industry.

title: CLASS TAX AND THEN THE MASS TAX
description: When Wyoming ratified the 16th Amendment on Feb. 3, 1913, no one dreamed that the income tax would become the all-inclusive complicated mess it is today.

title: Blanchette Rockefeller; FOR ASIA SOCIETY, REASONS TO CELEBRATE
description: AT noon, in midtown, no one would have batted an eyelash. At dusk, on Park Avenue, eyes were popping. For there were all those dignified but spiffy-looking men in black tie, and an equal number of chic women, long dresses trailing on the pavement. They were walking in front of and behind the Teiji Ito musicians, as exotic and noisy a group as the avenue has seen or is likely to see for many a moon.

title: Soviet Protests to U.S. on Shot
description: The Soviet Union lodged a protest today with the American Embassy over a gunshot fired at the Soviet Consulate in San Francisco three days ago, the press agency Tass reported. The protest note said it was only by chance that no one was hurt. It demanded punishment of the perpetrators.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Anatole Broyard WHAT WE TALK ABOUT WHEN WE TALK ABOUT LOVE. By Raymond Carver. 159 pages. Knopf. $9.95.

title: Briton Accused of 13 Killings Will Be Tried in London
description: The trial of a man accused of murdering 13 women during the last five years will be held in London, lawyers agreed today.

title: TEXT OF MESSAGE FROM PRESIDENT TO ASTRONAUTS
description: Following is the text of a message by President Reagan welcoming John W. Young and Capt. Robert L. Crippen, the Columbia astronauts, home today:

title: News Analysis
description: To the millions of citizens who watched the space shuttle Columbia glide to its flawless landing today, the newest space exploit was sweet vindication of American know-how.

title: 12 Challenges Resolved In National Ads
description: A 3-year-old in Dallas, having watched the Calgonite TV lady in her yellow slicker making a sales pitch from inside a dishwasher, climbed into the one in his own house. Mother was, of course, alarmed, and got in touch with the Dallas Better Business Bureau, which in turn referred the matter to the National Advertising Division of the Council of Better Business Bureaus.

title: Wartime Shell Kills 3 in Soviet
description: Three boys, all about 12 years old, were killed and two others were injured when a World War II shell exploded at their school in the Ukraine, a Soviet newspaper said today.

title: STAGE: 'TRANSLATIONS' FROM BRIAN FRIEL
description: IT'S not big news that Brian Friel, the Irish playwright, can write some of the most beautiful language to be heard in the contemporary theater. But in his new play, Mr. Friel has taken his love of words further still. Language is not just the dramatic currency of ''Translations'' - it is also the play's subject. What's more, the playwright has elevated his esthetic passion to a matter of lifeand-death importance. Though ''Translations'' is a manifestly uneven piece of theater, it has something profound to say about how words can determine the fates of ordinary people, nations and even centuries of history.
