title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Cable TV Industries filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission an initial offering for 650,000 common shares through a Bateman Eichler Hill Richards group.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: HERBERT J. WAXMAN, certified public accountant and sometime poet, has often resorted to verse to express his outrage at the obfuscation that pervades our local, state and Federal tax forms. ''One of the great goals of our age,'' he says, ''should be to put together a task force dedicated to providing transliterations of all tax regulations.'' Why? Mr. Waxman offers the following poem in evidence. He has constructed it from the actual wording appearing on the tax forms we are supposed to file today: INSTRUCTIONS FOR FORM IT-220 NEW YORK STATE AND CITY OF NEW YORK Internal Revenue Code Section 57 provides that the items of tax preference for adjusted itemized deductions and capital gains ''shall not be treated as items of tax preference for purposes of Internal Revenue Code Section 56'' (imposition of Federal minimum tax). However, these items are items of tax preference for purposes of Federal alternative minimum tax (Internal Revenue Code Section 55). Therefore, since adjusted itemized deductions and capital gains are defined as items of tax preference for Federal purposes, they are items of tax preference for New York minimum income tax purposes in accordance with the New York Tax Law. (Have I made it perfectly clear to you?)

title: IVAN GALAMIAN, TEACHER OF FAMOUS VIOLINISTS, DIES
description: Ivan Galamian, an internationally known violin pedagogue at the Juilliard School for 35 years and the teacher of many of today's best-known violinists, died, apparently of heart failure, yesterday morning in his Manhattan apartment. He was 78 years old and had been active until the end, having given his normal schedule of lessons on Monday.

title: Assignments from Allied
description: The Allied Chemical Corporation has slipped a goody from its Fibers and Plastics Company to Rumrill-Hoyt, a subsidiary of Compton Advertising.

title: Ranger Rookies Playing With Confidence
description: Craig Patrick, the Ranger coach, does not like to talk about his seven rookies. He won't single them out for praise, even though they make up a a third of the team. But he acknowledges that, without the rookies, the Rangers would hardly be preparing for the quarterfinals of the Stanley Cup playoffs tomorrow night.

title: News Analysis
description: The Republicans' deep resistance to Governor Carey's plan to take over local Medicaid costs is rooted less in substantive objections to the program than in fears that its guarantee of future aid for New York City would drastically undercut Republican bargaining power in budget negotiations for years to come.

title: Allegheny Ludlum Net Up by 37%
description: Allegheny Ludlum Industries Inc. said today that its first-quarter earnings rose 37 percent, to a record $20.8 million, or $2.27 a share, from $15.2 million or $1.55 a share, in the first three months last year.

title: FOR EASTER
description: Easter traditionally brings out flowers and eggs and rabbits - and hats. And so we have gathered up a shop full of flowery scents, a clutch of decorated eggs, some rabbits and baskets for the young and a hat to wear from Easter on. 1. Hats Come Back Not many women want an elaborate Easter hat these days. Still, hats are fun and young women, rather than dowagers, have taken them up. Two knitwear designers, Sofia Okolwicz and Anne Stillman, both barely in their 30's, believe in the hat's comeback and have made a group of hand-crocheted styles under their Sofia and Anne label. The styles are classic, but not dull; the designers have added ribbon bands, or crocheted berries or cockades to perk them up. They're in various stores around town; the sailor hat shown is $56 at Betsey, Bunky and Nini, 746 Madison Avenue (between 64th and 65th Streets).

title: Morgan Joins 17 1/2% Prime Move
description: The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, the nation's fifth-largest bank, raised its prime lending rate to 17 1/2 percent yesterday, continuing a limited move upward begun last Friday by two other New York banks.

title: U.S. Hockey Team Defeated, 4-2
description: Sweden defeated the United States, 4-2, tonight and reached the medal round of the world hockey championships. The United States, with an 0-2 mark, will play in the consolation bracket.

title: WHY SILENCE THE NORTH KOREANS?
description: To the Editor:

title: Death of a Salesman
description: ''More great Americans were failures than they were successes,'' Gertrude Stein said in ''Everybody's Autobiography.'' ''They mostly spent their lives in not having a buyer for what they had for sale.''

title: NEW OFFICE BUILDING FOR AVE. OF AMERICAS
description: It is with a touch of amusement that Seymour Durst reacts to the news that city planners are considering tinkering with the midtown zoning law to encourage new office development to move from east midtown to the west.

title: 'WELCOME HOME, COLUMBIA'
description: HOUSTON: Columbia, we show you crossing the coast now. CAPT. ROBERT L. CRIPPEN: What a way to come to California! HOUSTON: Columbia, you're out of 130K (130,000 feet) on the tracking, 6.4 Mach, looking good.

title: POLAND TO WIDEN RATIONING OFFOOD
description: Poland announced today a plan to ration butter, wheat, flour, rice and cereals, for the first time since World War II, in further emergency measures to preserve the nation's dwindling food supplies.

title: AN OIL RIPOFF HAS BEEN ABORTED
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. AIDE ARRIVES IN SOUTH AFRICA BUT PREMIER WON'T MEET WITH HIM
description: The Reagan Administration's specialist on African affairs, Chester A. Crocker, arrived here this evening on the sixth stop of a 10-nation African tour that is believed to be aimed at reviving stalled efforts to achieve independence for the disputed territory of South-West Africa.

title: LEVESQUE'S VICTORY BRINGS BOTH ELATION AND GLOOM
description: Businessmen and politicians opposed to an independent Quebec were gloomy today about the re-election of Premier Rene Levesque and his Parti Quebecois in legislative elections yesterday. Among nationalistic followers of Mr. Levesque, there was an explosion of joy and a revival of hope.

title: Submarine Name Attacked
description: Senator John Tower of Texas recommended it, and the Mayor of Corpus Christi applauded it, but the Navy's decision to name a new nuclearpowered attack submarine after the Texas city has now drawn criticism from a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Car Sales in Italy
description: Car sales in Italy rose to 478,794 deliveries in the first quarter from 459,700 a year before, Anfia, the industry's association, said today. But sales in March fell to 152,366 from February's 158,848 and from 155,676 in March 1980.

title: I.M.F. Jamaica Loan
description: The International Monetary Fund announced today that it had approved a $640 million loan to Jamaica in support of an economic program of Prime Minister Edward Seaga. The previous Government of Prime Minister Michael Manley had been unable to obtain I.M.F. funds because of disagreement over economic policies.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: LORDLY VIEWS

title: News of the Theater; 3d Play in Talley Cycle Opens June 11
description: AFTER many distractions that have kept him from doing much writing in the last year, Lanford Wilson has finally finished ''A Tale Told,'' his long-awaited new play. It will open June 11 for a fiveweek run at the Circle Repertory Company, the Off Broadway theater where the Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright opens all his new plays. The cast of 12 - which so far includes Michael Higgins, Elizabeth Sturges, Jimmie Ray Weeks and Helen Stenborg - will be directed by Marshall Mason, Circle Repertory's artistic director.

title: MARGIOTTA TRIAL TOLD A WITNESS WAS PRESSURED
description: A former member of the House of Representatives testified today that the principal Government witness in the mail-fraud and extortion trial of Joseph M. Margiotta had told him recently that he was under Government pressure ''to change the thrust of his testimony.''

title: Q&A
description: Q. I have often read that the ancient Romans used a powerfully flavored fish sauce called garum. I have heard that it is still made today. Can you tell me if this is so and how it is made?

title: F.T.C. KILLS A RULE FOR USED CARS
description: The Federal Trade Commission today effectively rejected its long-awaited rule that would make used-car dealers disclose defects in their vehicles and state plainly what warranty protection is provided.

title: JUDGE'S DECISION EXPECTED SOON IN CALIFORNIA GERM WARFRE CASE
description: The family of Edward J. Nevin, who died here in 1950, has argued in a lawsuit that his death was caused by a bacteria warfare experiment conducted by the Government off the California coast.

title: Index; International

title: PORT AUTHORITY ABANDONS PROPOSAL FOR ANY TOLL INCREASE DURING 1981
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, in a reversal of its proposal last spring to increase bridge and tunnel tolls from $1.50 to $2, said yesterday that it would not seek a toll rise this year.

title: BUSH HINTS VETO OF ONE-YEAR CUT IN FEDERAL TAXES
description: Vice President Bush said today that President Reagan ''would give the veto very, very serious consideration'' if Congress passed a one-year tax cut instead of the three-year plan recommended by the President.

title: IF GIBES HINT LEAD, KEAN'S OUT IN FRONT
description: If a politician's standing in a primary can be determined by the negative comments he attracts from his opponents, Thomas H. Kean of Livingston is the early leader in the race for the Republican nomination for Governor.

title: Around the Nation; Acquitted Rancher Is Held On Drug Charge in Arizona
description: Thomas H. Hanigan, the Arizona rancher who was recently acquitted on Federal charges stemming from the torture and robbery of three Mexican laborers, has been arrested for possession with intent to distribute 574 pounds of marijuana.

title: Yankees Set Back Jays, 6-3
description: Rudy May pitched masterly, and eight others, including the Yankees' best relievers, pitched messily tonight. As a result, May, who has not lost since last July 22, gained his second victory in two starts this season as the Yankees defeated the Toronto Blue Jays, 6-3, in 40-degree weather. For a while, Ron Davis, Tom Underwood and Rich Gossage pitched as though they would squander New York's victory.

title: Columbia's Chairman
description: Herbert A. Allen, 41, president of the investment banking firm of Allen & Company Inc., has been named chairman of Columbia Pictures Industries, effective July 1. He will succeed Leo Jaffee, a longtime Columbia executive who turns 72 next week and will become chairman emeritus.

title: THE RISKS IN USING PAINTS AND STRIPPERS
description: AMAN suffered a heart attack while stripping paint from a bureau drawer in his home. After recovering, he returned to the stripping project and soon had two more attacks, the last one fatal.

title: Villanova Dropping Football, Cites Cost
description: After 87 years and 760 games without interruption for even World War I or II, Villanova dropped varsity football yesterday in the middle of spring practice.

title: U.S. May Spur Mineral Output
description: The Government is exploring the possibility of using a law that authorized the synthetic fuels program to expand domestic production of minerals and other materials critical to the nation's defense, officials said today.

title: Levittown Nostalgia
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: My thoughts about Levittown, L.I., were triggered by Paul Goldberger's article (''Design Notebook,'' April 2). For young veterans of World War II with burgeoning families, the Levitt houses provided welcoming accommodations at a price that blue- and white-collar workers as well as beginning professionals could afford.

title: GUN LAW INDICTMENTS ABOVE THOSE FOR ALL FELONIES
description: New York State's gun law, which went into effect last August, has resulted in proportionately more indictments and convictions in the city than felonies overall.

title: GRETZKY HAS HELP ON OILERS
description: Although Wayne Gretzky of the Edmonton Oilers scored the most points in a season with 164; had the most assists with 109, and was the first player in National Hockey League history to average more than 2 points a game, he was not a one-man team. In the Oilers' closing regular-season rush, when they lost only once in their last 12 games, Gretzky had a lot of help.

title: * To the Editor:$
description: I vigorously laud your March 18 editorial ''Must MX Be a Shell Game?'' As a former SAC ICBM Launch Officer and an avid follower of strategic weapons development and procurement programs, I feel that the current deployment of the MX ICBM weapons system wherein several hundred missiles are to be shuttled among several thousand hardened and environmentally conditioned silos, as envisioned by certain defense strategists, is a disgraceful waste of human, natural and fiscal resources making the several billions spent on the nowdefunct Safeguard ABM system look like child's play. In addition, I find this deployment seriously lacking in cost-benefit analysis.

title: Dear Abby
description: I have a rather unusual problem. Last week I got married to a very nice gentleman a few years older than myself and, what with one thing and another, the wedding got a lot of publicity.

title: GAP IS WIDE AT THATCHER-GANDHI TALKS
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain conveyed to Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India today her impressions of what the United States is doing in the Indian Ocean - policies with which Mrs. Thatcher agrees and Mrs. Gandhi decidedly does not.

title: First Boston Quarter Net Up by 129%
description: First Boston Inc., the investment banking holding company, yesterday reported sharply higher net earnings for the quarter ended March 31.

title: EX-OFFICIAL DENIES WILLIAMS INFLUENCED DECISION ON CASINO APPLICATION
description: A former licensing-division chief of the New Jersey Casino Control Commission testified yesterday that neither Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. nor his wife had influenced a recommendation by the official favorable to a casino-development group linked to the Senator's wife.

title: SHOCKED EMPATHY IN HINCKLEYS' TOWN
description: The new skyscrapers that rise from the level prairie beneath downtown Denver are built by petroleum discovery money, and their silvered, sun-resistant skins have the luminescent sheen of oil.

title: Around the World; Crocker Discusses Namibia With South African Official
description: Chester Crocker, the Assistant Secretary of State-designate for Africa, met Foreign Minister Roelof F. Botha today in talks aimed at ending the deadlock on independence for South-West Africa, or Namibia.

title: 50 MILLION FRENCHMEN CAN'T BE WRONG ABOUT THE COLUMBIA'S RETURN
description: France has paid the American space shuttle a handsome compliment. It was not the message of congratulations that President Valery Giscard d'Estaing sent President Reagan this morning, saying that all humanity should be proud of the ''remarkable contribution American scientists, technicians and astronauts have made to the conquest of space and the mastery of space flight.''

title: Around the World
description: Leftist sympathizers bombed a Hamburg University building and blocked a train in Munich today in support of 26 jailed Baader-Meinhof terrorists who have been on a hunger strike for 10 weeks.

title: 15 TRAPPED BY COLORADO MINE BLAST
description: Fifteen miners were trapped in a coal mine today after an underground explosion, the authorities said.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: WHILE vinyl floor tiles have long been available in a wide range of colors and in many different styles and finishes, most of them still look like tiles; that is, they come in squares so that when put down on the floor they form a sort of overall checkerboard effect.

title: RUSSIAN BELIEVED SEIZED IN KABUL IN ATTEMPT TO DEFECT
description: Afghan and Soviet security agents intercepted and seized a man, thought to be a Russian, as he approached the United States Embassy in Kabul last Thursday, according to a Western diplomat.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Allegheny Ludlum Industries said it plans to redeem on May 18 all of its outstanding $3 convertible preferred stock at a price of $60 a share plus accrued dividends of 40 cents a share.

title: HAND TRUCKS WITH FABRICS LATEST TARGET FOR ROBBERS
description: On March 25, John Patrick, a 59-year-old deliveryman, set out with his hand truck from the Lion Fabrics Corporation on Seventh Avenue near 36th Street, pushing a load of grape-colored polyester georgette crepe material valued at $2,800.

title: Why Make Money Funds Discriminatory?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Region; X-Ray Film Thefts Laid to 13 Workers
description: ALBANY (UPI) - Five grand juries, convened to examine a statewide ''rampant pattern of fraud'' in hospital X-ray departments, have indicted 13 current and former hospital employees for stealing $330,000 worth of X-ray film.

title: MOVIE: 'GAL YOUNG UN,' TALE OF AN ODD MARRIAGE
description: ''Gal Young Un'' was shown as part of the 1979 Festival of American Independent Feature Films at the Paramount Theater. Following are excerpts from a review by Vincent Canby in The New York Times on Sept. 24, 1979. The film opened yesterday at the Art Theater, East Eighth Street and University Place.

title: CALENDAR: CRAFTS SHOW
description: Invitational 1981 Exhibition, the Crafts- man's Gallery, 16 Chase Road, Scars- dale, N.Y.

title: YONKERS FIREFIGHTERS STRIKE AFTER NEGOTIATIONS COLLAPSE
description: Firefighters in Yonkers walked off their jobs in a labor dispute late this afternoon, leaving the state's fourth largest city without fire protection.

title: Pistons Want to Convince Sampson to Join N.B.A.
description: The Detroit Pistons said today that Jack McCloskey, the National Basketball Association team's general manager, will meet with Ralph Sampson, Virginia's 7-foot-4-inch all-America center, next week to try to convince him to forego his final two years of collegiate eligibility.

title: STATE SODA-BEER CONTAINER DEPOSIT LAW PICKS UP SUPPORT ON L.I.
description: Several counties around New York City took steps this week that increased support for a controversial statewide antilitter bill that would require a nickel deposit on every soft-drink and beer container sold at retail.

title: Former Brinks Guard Sentenced
description: A former guard for Brinks Inc. who admitted taking a demonstration parking meter to make a lamp was fined $1,000 and sentenced Tuesday to eight weekends in jail. In sentencing the man, Anthony DeNardo of 87-29 16th Avenue, Brooklyn, Acting Justice Irving Lang of State Supreme Court said that he was satisfied that Mr. DeNardo had been ''part of the group'' of Brinks guards who prosecutors contend were responsible for bilking the city of $2 million, but that his sentence must be based on the offense with which Mr. DeNardo was actually charged.

title: QUOTRON MARKETING PLAN
description: The Associated Press, Dow Jones & Company and Quotron Systems jointly announced an agreement in principle yesterday for the international marketing of Quotron's financial information service.The service will be marketed through A.P.-Dow Jones, a business and economic news and information group jointly operated by the two news organizations.

title: Court Upholds Trudeau On Revising the Charter
description: In the last of three judicial challenges, the Quebec Court of Appeals today ruled, 4 to 1, that an attempt by the federal Government to effect constitutional change without the general consent of the provinces was legal.

title: TRIUMPHANT LOS ANGELES MAYOR
description: Even before Mayor Tom Bradley, with his wife, Ethel, and Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. at his side, joyfully accepted the results of yesterday's landslide re-election victory, there was talk of the former policemen's campaign for governor in 1982. ''Let me savor this for a few days, please,'' he said.

title: Accounts
description: * The Travelers Cheque division of the Chase Manhattan Bank to Kelly, Nason for the Chase Visa Travelers Cheque.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Drew Middleton THE WAR BETWEEN THE GENERALS. By David Irving. Congdon & Lattes Inc. 427 pages. Illustrated. $17.95.

title: MARGIOTTA, ON STAND, DEFENDS FEE-SPLITTING
description: Testifying in his own defense, Joseph M. Margiotta today defended the splitting of municipal insurance commissions, but said he regretted that he had accepted any money himself.

title: Louis Burial at Arlington
description: President Reagan has waived eligibility requirements to permit Joe Louis to be buried in Arlington National Cemetery Friday. Louis, who held the world heavyweight boxing championship longer than anyone else, died of a heart attack last Sunday in Las Vegas, Nev., at the age of 66.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * American Electromagnetics Corporation filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission 350,000 common shares to be sold to repay Technodyne $878,000 for amounts advanced to American Electromagnetics and for other business-related expenses, through a D.H. Blair group.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Four years ago thousands of draft evaders and others who violated the Selective Service laws were unconditionally pardoned by my predecessor.

title: Brooks, Hockey Coach, Testifies on Behalf of Kush
description: Herb Brooks, the former United States Olympic hockey coach, testified today on behalf of Frank Kush, the former Arizona State University football coach, saying that coaches, in general, physically discipline and publicly criticize their players ''as a shock therapy.''

title: Taiwan Trade Is Rising Sharply
description: Taiwan's foreign trade jumped to $3.9 billion in March, up $800 million, or 25.8 percent, from $3.1 billion in February, economic officials reported today.

title: China Is Not a Card
description: Little can be said for the idea of threatening arms sales to China every time someone in Washington feels the urge to annoy the Kremlin. And a lot can be said against it. Agreed: few other gestures would so arouse and anger the Soviet Government, which already feels compelled to keep 46 divisions stationed along its long frontier with China. But whatever the value of adding to Soviet fears would be offset by the reaction in China and in the rest of the world.

title: A WALL-STORAGE SYSTEM
description: THE Rakks shelving system is a very well thought out, attractively designed wall-storage system. Designed by Keivan Towfigh, who is president of the Rangine Corporation, which manufactures racks, the system incorporates shelves, cabinets, a folding work surface and a special bracket for holding a light.

title: Stolen Eagle Is Sought in Texas
description: The police and Federal investigators searched yesterday for an American eagle stolen from the Gladys Porter Zoo. David Thompson, deputy director of the zoo, said the 10-year-old male eagle had been stolen from a pen in which keepers had placed the bird for shipment to Florida.

title: AN ACCENT ON THE UPBEAT AT MANNES
description: NEW YORK'S Mannes College of Music and the Fontainebleau School near Paris have agreed on an exchange of students and faculty. Under the arrangement, Fontainebleau will establish an office at Mannes College on East 74th Street to recruit students for its summer programs. The Fontainebleau School, in turn, will automatically accept Mannes students into its courses.

title: SALE OF UNITS, INVESTMENTS CITED
description: The Bendix Corporation, a leading producer of high-technology, automotive and aerospace products, reported yesterday that income from the sale of discontinued operations caused earnings to soar in the second fiscal quarter of 1981, as sales increased 23.1 percent.

title: The City; Officer's Slayer Gets 25-Year Term
description: Salvatore DeSarno was sentenced to 25 years to life for the murder in January 1980 of Police Officer Cecil Sledge. Mr. DeSarno, who shouted at Justice Robert S. Kreindler during the sentencing in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, maintained that he had only been defending himself from Officer Sledge, whom he said he feared from previous encounters.

title: Acting Mayor of Annapolis Dies Of Self-Inflicted Bullet Wounds
description: Gustav J. Akerland, an alderman who stepped in as Acting Mayor of Annapolis and then repeatedly shot himself a month later in apparent despondency over city budget problems, died today.

title: Battles Said to Intensify In Iran's Khuzistan Area
description: Both Iraq and Iran reported today that fighting between their forces had intensified in the southern Iranian oil-producing province of Khuzistan.

title: CITY HALL IS CALM WHEN STATE AID FAILS TO APPEAR
description: In normal times, yesterday would have been a day when New York City could have gone to the bank with $280 million in state aid for education.

title: Spurs Beat Rockets; Suns Hold Off Kings
description: George Gervin scored 26 points tonight to give the San Antonio Spurs a 101-96 victory over the Houston Rockets and a 3-3 tie in their National Basketball Association Western Conference semifinal playoff series.

title: CHICAGO FAILS TO SUBMIT A PLAN ON DESEGREGATION
description: The deadline set by a Federal judge for the city's school board to submit a proposal to desegregate public schools passed today and the school board had no plan. Attorneys for the school board will go to Federal District Court tomorrow to ask Judge Milton I. Shadur for a delay.

title: 30% OF PUPILS SAY THEY WOULD TRY TO AVOID A DRAFT
description: Nearly 30 percent of the nation's high school seniors would try to avoid either military or civilian service if the Government made one or the other mandatory, according to a Federal report.

title: The U.N. Today; April 16, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Special Committee on Enhancing the Non-Use of Force in International Rela- tions - 10:30 A. M. and 3 P.M.

title: The City; Reputed Loan Shark Faces Tax Charges
description: Carmine Lombardozzi, described by authorities as one of organized crime's biggest loan sharks, was indicted on charges of having failed to list on Federal income-tax returns the interest collected from borrowers.

title: WEINBERGER TELLS OTTAWA REAGAN PLANS TO GO AHEAD WITH THE F-18
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger reassured Canadian officials today that the Reagan Administration supports development of the F-18 fighter jet, a program in which Canada has a large financial stake.

title: FOR UPHOLSTERY, THE COMEBACK OF JACQUARDS
description: intricately woven fabrics - and furniture retailers at the Southern Furniture Market at High Point, N.C., are showing interest.

title: 12.61 RISE PUTS DOW AT 1,001.71
description: The stock market, buoyed by lower inflationary expectations and announcements of improved corporate earnings, advanced strongly yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average rising 12.61 points, to 1,001.71.

title: THE ARCHITECT IS CATALYST IN MARRIAGE OF STYLES
description: IT'S sort of a modern design fairy tale. Two years ago, Sandy Hill, a beauty editor, met Bob Pittman, a cable television executive, on an airplane. She lived in a Greenwich Village brownstone, he in a Murray Hill high-rise. They fell in love. Six months later, they got married.

title: TV: A CHRISTIE NOVEL, 'SEVEN DIALS MYSTERY'
description: IF ''The Seven Dials Mystery'' were only half as impressive as the ad campaign heralding its arrival, television would indeed be fortunate. However, after much huffing and puffing, the Mobil Showcase Network is left with the unseemly task of bringing forth a dud. On WNEW-TV, Channel 5, tonight at 8, this two-and-a-half-hour adaptation of an Agatha Christie novel is evidently meant to be charmingly giddy. Stuffed with enough red herrings to trigger persistent visions of sour cream and onions, it succeeds only in being tiresomely silly.

title: Arnold Spector, 74, a Producer; Directed Shows at Jones Beach
description: Arnold Spector, theatrical producer and director who for 16 seasons was managing director of the Guy Lombardo productions at the Jones Beach Marine Theater, died Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 72 years old.

title: PERSISTENT MYTHS ABOUT SEX EDUCATION
description: To the Editor:

title: Honoring Stengel: Well, Thomson Was There and ...
description: The Yankees were on the road and the Mets were rained out, but when they built the American Place Theater they put a roof on, which was a good thing since it was old-timers' night for ''The Amazin' Casey Stengel'' Tuesday night and if they hadn't, where would the oldtimers go?

title: Q&A
description: Q. I am having a problem with a sluggish toilet that does not flush properly. A plumber checked the mechanism in the tank and replaced the rubber stopper. He also cleaned the bowl with acid, but we had to call him back a few days later for the same problem. He says he checked and the drain pipe is clear. Do you have any other suggestions, short of buying a new toilet? -M.D.S., Oxon Hill, Md.

title: BALLET: HOUSTON TROUPE PRESENTS SOME NEW FACES
description: THE Houston Ballet's weekend performances at the Brooklyn Academy of Music offered food for the eyes and food for thought. At two matinees conducted by James Slater, one's eyes could enjoy several cast changes, while one's mind could ponder a controversial theory.

title: SAVINGS OUTFLOW IN MARCH A RECORD
description: Savers withdrew $1.7 billion more than they deposited at the nation's 4,400 savings and loan associations last month, the largest monthly outflow ever recorded, the United States League of Savings Associations reported today.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 17.00-17.50 ** Current rate excludes 3 percentage-point surcharge on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Japanese Sight Soviet Warships
description: Japanese naval aircraft today sighted three Soviet warships moving through the international strait of Tsugaru between the islands of Honshu and Hokkaido in northern Japan, the Defense Agency said. Naval helicopters reported sighting one frigate passing through the strait from the Sea of Japan to the Pacific and one landing ship and a transport sailing from the Pacific to the Sea of Japan, it said.

title: SO MANY KEYS, SO FEW POCKETS, SUCH IRE
description: THE key question is: How do you cope with all the keys? A recent, and thoroughly unscientific, sampling of typical New Yorkers revealed that they were carrying some part of the following assortment of keys about their persons:

title: KEEPING ENGLISH NO. 1
description: Asserting that Spanish is slowly becoming the nation's ''second official language,'' Senator S. I. Hayakawa plans to propose a constitutional amendment establishing English as the country's sole official language.

title: McGraw-Hill Net Up
description: McGraw-Hill Inc., one of the nation's biggest publishing companies, said yesterday that first-quarter earnings rose 15.4 percent, to $17.2 million, or 69 cents a share, from $14.9 million, or 60 cents a share, in the same period of 1980 as the performance of the company's information services operations and the sale of a publication helped increase profits. Revenues for the latest quarter were $234.6 million, up 9.7 percent from $213.8 million a year earlier. Sharply lower borrowing costs and a gain from the sale of Medical World News in early March also contributed to improved earnings, McGraw said.

title: Antilitter Campaign Takes a New Approach
description: The ''Don't Dump on New York'' advertising campaign may have reached an important point. It might have come up with advertising that has a chance of working.

title: MAIL AGENCY ASKS UNITY BARGAINING
description: The United States Postal Service, firing the first round in labor bargaining this year, said today that it would seek to have the National Labor Relations Board intervene and designate a single bargaining unit rather than deal with all four unions.

title: AUDITOR CAUTIONS ON BRANIFF IN REPORT
description: Braniff International fell a point on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday to close at 4 1/8 in heavy trading after its outside accounting firm, Deloitte Haskins & Sells, issued an official opinion in the airline's annual report saying there were ''conditions which indicate that the company may be unable to continue as a going concern.''

title: Dun & Bradstreet Net Up
description: Dun & Bradstreet Inc. said yesterday that its net income rose 15 percent in the three months ended March 31, to $26.5 million, from $23.1 million a year earlier.

title: Pop: Carl Wilson, ex-Beach Boy
description: AS a member of the Beach Boys, that much-venerated California surf band, Carl Wilson was an important contributor to the group's soaring, ethereal vocal sound. But with the Beach Boys in decline in recent years, it was probably inevitable that Mr. Wilson should strike out on his own as a soloist, following in the footsteps of his brother Dennis Wilson and the former Beach Boy Bruce Johnston. Mr. Wilson recently put out a debut album, and on Monday he appeared at the Bottom Line with a five-piece band.

title: Exxon, Others Win Energy Price Suit
description: A Federal court in Wilmington, Del., cleared the Exxon Corporation of Department of Energy charges that it overcharged customers $100 million for natural gas liquids under price controls.

title: HOME BEAT
description: IT was the first time in 40 years that he had been in the store. No wonder the paneling was dry and in need of attention.

title: Pembroke Cracking Plans Wales Unit
description: Texaco Inc. and the Gulf Oil Corporation said a jointly owned affiliate had filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $300 million of notes and debentures, proceeds of which will be used to finance a fluid catalytic cracking unit and related facilities at Milford Haven, Wales.

title: Ashland Said to End Some Oil Contracts
description: Ashland Oil Inc. has temporarily halted daily purchases of 90,000 barrels of Mexican crude oil and 17,000 barrels from Cameroon in the face of a developing world oil glut, industry sources said. A spokesman for Ashland Oil declined to comment on the report.

title: Marsh & McLennan
description: Marsh & McLennan Companies Inc. said its C.T. Bowring & Company Ltd. subsidiary was seeking a purchaser for some of its shipping interests. A company spokesman would not disclose a target price or the number of vessels to be sold, but said they were all basically bulk carriers. He said Marsh's shipping business accounted for a relatively small percentage of the company's total business.

title: CONTINENTAL'S SOARS
description: First-quarter net operating profits plunged 16.6 percent at the Chase Manhattan Corporation, soared 30.2 percent at the Continental Illinois Corporation and rose 8.2 percent at the Bankers Trust New York Corporation, the three banking companies reported yesterday.

title: U.S. Questions Validity Of College Entrance Test
description: The Federal Trade Commission called yesterday for a reconsideration of college entrance tests, saying their validity had been called into question by findings that crash coaching courses helped improve students' scores.

title: Market Place; Calculating Price of Growth
description: PRICE/EARNINGS ratios are often used to determine relative values in the stock market, but the measure has a serious shortcoming -it does not take into account how much is paid out in dividends.

title: Three Brenner Charges Are Dismissed by Judge
description: A Federal judge knocked out three of Teddy Brenner's four charges yesterday but still left Brenner able to win the decision in his $3 million antitrust suit against the World Boxing Council.

title: Around the Nation; U.S. Budget Amendment Turned Back in Missouri
description: Missouri narrowly missed yesterday becoming the 31st state to call on Congress to summon a constitutional convention to write a constititional amendment requiring the Federal budget to be balanced. Its State House of Representatives defeated the proposal on a 77 to 75 vote.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: THURSDAY, APRIL 16, 1981; The Economy
description: U.S. industrial production rose four-tenths of 1 percent in March, reflecting improvement in auto assemblies and offsetting a similar decline the previous month, the Federal Reserve Board said. The February drop followed six straight monthly gains, but economists said the return to the plus column did not signal a strengthening rebound. The Commerce Department reported that the business inventory-to-sales ratio rose slightly in February, to 1.36 months, an apparent indication of a slowing in commercial activity. (D1.)

title: Moneyed Decorators
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: Just imagine how a middle-income hard-working interior designer feels upon reading about rich women who no longer have to fight boredom with twice-a-week visits to the hairdresser because they have found creativity? (''Decorating Among Good Friends,'' March 26). Well, those of us who studied and then struggled for years before talent and training were regarded with even a modicum of financial success can console ourselves with the smug assurance that at least we know the difference between Chippendale and Queen Anne. DOROTHY SMITH Mountain Lakes, N.J.

title: Unbeaten A's Win 7th Straight
description: Tony Armas hit a three-run homer to cap a four-run eighth inning, and Rick Langford hurled his second complete game to give the unbeaten Oakland A's a 5-3 victory tonight over the California Angels.

title: Penn Central's Profit Up 75.1%
description: The Penn Central Corporation, which emerged from bankruptcy in 1978 as the successor to the Penn Central Transportation Company, yesterday reported that first-quarter earnings rose 75.1 percent on a 47 percent increase in revenues.

title: BANI-SADR, IN BUDGET BATTLE, REGAINS OFFICE FUNDS
description: President Abolhassan Bani-Sadr, helped by a constitutional review commission, has won a budget skirmish with his fundamentalist opponents in Parliament.

title: ARSON IS FOUND IN FIRE AT BUILDING WHERE AN OFFICE TOWER IS PLANNED
description: A three-alarm blaze that heavily damaged a five-story mostly residential building off Park Avenue last Sunday was set, according to Anthony Romero, deputy chief fire marshal.

title: Gilbert Resigns From KSW&G
description: After 30 years of running advertising agencies, first Gilbert Advertising and now KSW&G, Richard L. Gilbert, 59 years old, has resigned to follow a new star. He has not picked it out yet, but he hopes it will be in the marketing end of video, the vaunted new technology.

title: COKE BRINGS 'TASTY HAPPINESS' TO CHINA
description: Its name is rendered in Chinese as ''Ke Kou Ke Le'' and roughly translated it means ''tasty happiness.'' Some Chinese say it tastes more like carbonated medicine but they note that the aluminum cans it comes in can be split lengthwise to make a spiffy red and white mudguard for bicycle fenders.

title: OME CARE IS PUSHED IN SENATE AS ALTERNATIVE TO INSTITUTIONS FOR THE AGED
description: A bipartisan group of senators, citing what they call the ''alarming escalation'' of medical costs for the elderly, has proposed a six-year experiment in care at home for the elderly and disabled as an alternative to expensive hospitals and nursing facilities.

title: Music: Orchestre Toulouse Plays Faure and Debussy
description: THROUGH its recent EMI/ Pathe and CBS recordings, which are devoted to fascinating but rarely played French scores, L'Orchestre du Capitole de Toulouse under Michel Plasson's direction has earned a high reputation as a specialist in this neglected area of the orchestral repertory. That being the case, it was not surprising to find Mr. Plasson conducting a French program with his excellent orchestra in Carnegie Hall on Saturday night.

title: Westinghouse Ends Last Uranium Suit
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation said it had settled the last of 17 suits filed against it by electric utilities in a uranium supply dispute.

title: The Region; Connecticut Upheld On Liquor Pricing
description: A Federal judge upheld Connecticut's liquor pricing law, rejecting the argument of five owners of package stores that the 20-year-old minimum-markup system violated the Sherman Antitrust Act.

title: Ruel Resigns Canadiens Post
description: Four days after they had been swept by the Edmonton Oilers in the first round of the National Hockey League's playoffs, the Montreal Canadiens announced today that Claude Ruel had resigned as coach.

title: * To the Editor:$
description: In their letter of March 31, Norman Friedman and Colin Gray argue that a land-basing mode for the MX is necessary because ''a landbased missile system has unique qualities important for deterrence.'' However, they astonishingly identify ''escalatory potential'' as one such quality.

title: CORPORATE IMAGE TIED TO SPORTS
description: ONE thing that Standard Brands has found out in the last four years is that well-known athletes can open doors. Now it is out to discover if they can also help improve attitudes.

title: SADA COWEN
description: Sada Cowen, who for years assisted promising young musicians through auditions in New York and Chicago, died on April 6 in the Elyria (Ohio) Home. She was 95 years old.

title: Ketchum New York Gets a President
description: Here's a bit of this and a bit of that from agency land:

title: CHOICES IN FRENCH VOTE ELICIT ENNUI FROM THE YOUNG
description: France's first presidential elections in seven years, by most available indications, find the young voters in a state of pessimism, and disposed somewhere between refusal and acquiescense.

title: Great Western's Chief Still Has Eye on Merger
description: James F. Montgomery, the 46-year-old president and chief executive officer of the Great Western Financial Corporation, which owns the nation's second-largest savings and loan association with $10.3 billion in assets, called off a proposed merger with the $2.4 billion Financial Federation Inc. this week. But he wants to renew the talks as soon as both of the California savings and loan holding companies convert from state to Federal charters. That would permit a merger without state government approval.

title: Synthetic Fuel Plant Delayed
description: The United States, Japan and West Germany have put off a decision on a major synthetic fuel project proposed by the Carter Administration, officials said today.

title: IN HARLEM'S ELEGANT STRIVERS' ROW
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Paula Deitz is co-editor of The Hudson Review. IN 1891, David H. King Jr., a New York builder, acquired a tract of land in Harlem on West 138th and West 139th Streets between Seventh and Eighth Avenues and commissioned three leading New York architectural concerns to design separate rows of houses for it.

title: HERS
description: AWEEK after the journalist Sally Quinn got married, a young woman who worked in the same building as Miss Quinn asked her whether she, too, should marry the man she was living with. Miss Quinn replied: ''I wanted to say 'yes, yes, yes,' because I was so happy with my own decision. But then I remembered from long, long ago in college when I was thinking about marrying a man I didn't love. I asked my best friend how you could tell if you were in love. She told me if I were in love I wouldn't need to ask that question.

title: Around the World; Turkey Arrests 49 Leftists Accused of Plotting Coup
description: The police announced the arrest today of 49 members of a leftist group on charges of trying to overthrow Turkey by armed revolution.

title: N.F.L. Trial Date Set
description: The trial of the antitrust suit in which the Oakland Raiders and the Los Angeles Coliseum Commission have brought action against the National Football League is scheduled to begin May 11 in U.S. District Court. The trial has been delayed twice, from scheduled dates of Feb. 9 and March 23.

title: PROUD APPEAL TRAINER AN INDIVIDUALIST
description: They don't call him Stanley How anymore, or even Stanley Hogg. The name is Hough, as in huff, and those who saw his colt, Proud Appeal, beat Cure the Blues in the Gotham Stakes 11 days ago are not likely to forget the name or the race.

title: BEIRUT TRIES ANEW TO SETTLE CONFLICT
description: The Lebanese Government resolved today to increase its efforts to obtain a negotiated settlement of the conflict between Syrian troops and Lebanese Christian militia forces.

title: Bridge: Partners Win Tough Hand, Then Wind Up Disqualified
description: Some news stories six months ago focused on a decision by the University Club in New York City to bar women from certain parts of its premises, including the card room, and thereby attracted criticism. A recent episode there suggests that the club is prepared, in a minor way, to discriminate against men also.

title: Two Men Are Arrested In Attempted Gem Theft
description: Two well-dressed men were arrested yesterday as they attempted to walk out of a jewelry store in midtown Manhattan's diamond district with a large amount of stolen jewels and cash, the police said.

title: SUZUKI SAYS HE WILL PRESS REAGAN ON SHIP SINKING DURING U.S. VISIT
description: Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki told Parliament today that he would ask President Reagan about the collision between an American submarine and a Japanese freighter at their meeting in Washington next month.

title: The City; Treasury Secretary Hails Fiscal Effort
description: The United States Secretary of the Treasury said he would be ''a friendly but severe watchdog'' of the city's fiscal management policies under the Federal loan guarantee program.

title: General Dynamics' Health Questions
description: A shareholders group said it intends to ask the General Dynamics Corporation to disclose at its annual meeting on May 7 all chemicals in use at its Electric Boat division in Groton, Conn., and any employee health problems there.

title: Futures Exchange: Resignation Is Seen
description: William M. Smith, 37 years old, the first president and chief executive officer of the New York Futures Exchange, intends to resign, sources close to the exchange said yesterday. The exchange opened last August as the New York Stock Exchange's subsidiary for commodity trading.

title: Cello: Neal Cary Plays Debussy
description: THE cello seemed to speak intelligently when it was played by Neal Cary on Saturday afternoon in Carnegie Recital Hall, but musical sense was often submerged under a uniform vocal style.

title: THE MX: WHAT IF BY LAND, WHAT IF BY SEA
description: To the Editor:

title: Soviet Gymnast Treated
description: Elena Mukhina, Soviet gymnast, is receiving acupuncture treatments for a severe spinal injury she suffered in a training accident last year, Tass said today. Neurosurgeons were said to be optimistic about her chances of recovery. Miss Mukhina won the world all-round title in 1978.

title: News Analysis
description: The Reagan Administration's plans for obtaining a long-term presence in Saudi Arabia through the stationing of Awacs surveillance planes have run into such criticism in Israel and on Capitol Hill that consideration is now being given to postponing the projected multibillion-dollar sale.

title: Beamon Is Named Coach Of Track at York College
description: Bob Beamon, who captured a gold medal and a world record in the 1968 Olympic long jump, has been appointed head track and field coach at York College, Milton G. Bassin, the college's president, announced yesterday.

title: 2 SALVADORANS HELD IN U.S. AIDES' DEATH
description: Two right-wing Salvadoran civilians have been arrested as suspects in the killing of the head of El Salvador's Agrarian Reform Institute and two American rural labor advisers, United States officials said today.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, APRIL 16, 1981
description: International Polish Communist radicals met and issued demands for democratic changes. The meeting of about 750 delegates from local party units said it was founding a movement for reform outside the control of the party's leadership. The delegates assailed the party leaders and called for freedom of the press and a new openness in Polish society. (Page A1, Columns 3-4.) Soviet concern about Poland, expressed in the press, made clear that Moscow's assessement of the Polish situation was unchanged. The newspapers asserted that Poland was being subverted by ''creeping counterrevolution'' from within and ''radio aggression'' from the West while the Communist workers yearned for the party to reassert its authority. (A12:3-4.)

title: THEATER: 'IL CAMPIELLO' BY THE ACTING COMPANY
description: ENTERING its 10th season, the Acting Company, that durable offspring of the Juilliard Theater Center, has covered America with a rich variety of classics and contemporary plays, as performed by a constantly replenished, youthful troupe of traveling actors. Many of our best young performers have emerged from the Acting Company; one of the pleasures of watching the group is to spot the future Kevin Kline, Patti LuPone and Frances Conroy.

title: JAMES STIRLING GETS PRITZKER ARCHITECTURE AWARD
description: James Stirling, a 55-year-old British architect who has achieved international renown but who is only now building his first works in the United States, was named yesterday as the winner of the Pritzker Architecture Prize, a $100,000 award given for a lifetime of creative achievement.

title: Puerto Rico Credit Laws
description: Puerto Rico today ordered Citibank and two local banks to discontinue by April 27 their practice of charging annual user fees for credit cards. The island consumer affairs department decreed that the annual charge by Citibank, Banco Popular and Bank of Ponce MasterCard and Visa credit cards violated Puerto Rico's interest and usury laws.

title: RAMADA INNS PLANS 13-HOTEL EXPANSION
description: Ramada Inns Inc. will spend $425 million in the next two years to add 13 large hotels with at least 300 rooms each to its worldwide chain, a company official said today.

title: Around the Nation; Nevada Speeders Getting $5 'Energy Wasting' Fines
description: Nevada Highway Patrol troopers began issuing $5 ''energy wasting'' fines today for drivers traveling between 55 miles per hour and 70 miles per hour, a day after Gov. Bob List signed a new law that eases penalties for speeding.

title: Great Chocolate Sauce Mystery Solved! Apparently
description: With a devotion worthy of a Don Quixote on a glorious quest, Julia Child, for the past year, has been seeking ''the real, genuine, authentic recipe for that famous stringy chocolate sauce served years ago at the equally famous Schrafft's restaurants.''

title: OUTPUT UP BY 0.4% ON AUTO GAINS
description: The nation's industrial production, prodded by a partial recovery in auto assemblies, rose four-tenths of 1 percent in March, the Federal Reserve Board reported yesterday.

title: CONFERENCE ON ELDERLY VOICES FEAR ON IMPACT OF REAGAN BUDGET CUTS
description: The Reagan Administration's assurances that Federal programs for older people will not suffer from its campaign for fiscal austerity have failed to persuade many representatives of that age group who met here this week.

title: WESTCHESTER'S SINGING ITS PRAISES TO INCREASE COUNTY TOURIST TRADE
description: Westchester County got its own song today, a catchy tune that local officials hope will attract tourists, doing in the 1980's what corporate growth did for the county in the 1960's and 1970's.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The ''Sports of The Times'' column reported incorrectly yesterday that the former boxing champion Mickey Walker was dead. Mr. Walker, 79 years old, lives in Marlboro, N.J.

title: THE SOUND OF ONE VOICE TALKING
description: HAVE you noticed lately that too many playwrights are suffering from monologue-itis? No fewer than four recent Broadway shows - ''The Survivor,'' ''Lolita,'' ''Rose'' and ''Fools'' -have featured central characters who insist on stepping forward and addressing the audience as if we were old chums. Because at least two of the characters in question (three, if you count the professorial narrator of ''Lolita'') are teachers, there's not much fun in their asides. If audiences really seek instruction at night, they're not so likely to go to a play as to enroll at the New School.

title: SCHOOL CLASSES FOUND UNRELATED TO SCORES IN WORLD-AFFAIRS TEST
description: A survey of American college students that was made public yesterday shows that those who study foreign languages or take courses on international affairs are no more likely to have a grasp of world issues than other students.

title: HOLDER'S SURPRISE OFFER SNAGS UA-COLUMBIA BID
description: The joint effort by Dow Jones & Company and Knight-Ridder Newspapers Inc. to acquire fast-growing UA-Columbia Cablevision Inc. hit an unexpected snag yesterday when United Artists Theatre Circuit Inc. announced a tender offer that could yield it a total of nearly 50 percent of UA-Columbia's shares, at a price $10 above the bid by the two big publishers.

title: COOPER: A STAR AT 8, BUT HAPPIER AT 58
description: LOS ANGELES AT the age of 8, Jackie Cooper was nominated for an Academy Award as best actor for ''The Champ,'' and his salary was $1,300 a week. At 18, he was Joan Crawford's lover. At 28, twice-divorced and washed up in Hollywood, he was trying to carve out a new life on Broadway. At 38, he was a television star. At 48, he had spent five years as a television mogul and was trying to earn his living as a director. At 58, as a successful television director - ''I am having fun,'' he says, ''more fun than I've ever had in my life.''

title: Toyota and Nissan Set Output Record
description: Japan's top two auto makers today reported record output for March but slower exports. The Toyota Motor Company, the nation's largest auto maker, said its output of passenger cars and trucks surpassed 307,162 units, an increase of 6 percent over March 1980.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: METS (NL) - Acquired Charlie Puleo, p itcher, from Toronto, and assigned him to T idewater of the International League. P uleo's acquisition completed an earlier d eal in which the Mets sent Mark Bomback, p itcher, to Toronto.

title: Technology; Debate Over Shuttle Benefits
description: FOR a nation that has come to doubt its technological strength, the successful flight of the space shuttle Columbia was welcome news. ''Through you, we all feel like giants again,'' President Reagan told the astronauts on their return.

title: Yastrzemski Worth the Wait
description: Carl Yastrzemski, making his 1981 debut, knocked in three runs and Tony Perez, with a homer, drove in two today in Boston's 7-2 victory over the Baltimore Orioles today.

title: AT FURNITURE MARKET, A FEW NEW IDEAS ENLIVEN QUIET SHOW
description: empty showrooms.

title:
AT YOUR SERVICE;
CHOOSING SCISSORS RIGHT FOR THE TASK
Unacceptable Deadlocks in Albany
description: New York's government has reached intolerable deadlocks because Governor Carey has run into two determined men. Warren Anderson, the Republican Senate leader, blocks the Carey budget, particularly the takeover of local Medicaid costs. Mayor Koch blocks transit rehabilitation to get a firmer promise of operating subsidies. The Governor needs to negotiate directly with both, and with quite different tactics.

title: SHARING THE PORT BARREL
description: The rush to export coal is on, with the United States' share of the world's coal market expected to more than double by the year 2000. Federal policy decisions relating to coal promise to alter the commercial standing of American ports for decades to come, with significant impacts on regional and municipal economies. The main issue is dredging: All of our ports aren't deep enough for the next generation of coal-carrying vessels, and coming Congressional votes may work to the permanent disadvantage of the port of New York.

title: GERMAN BANKS AID POLES
description: A consortium of West German banks, Poland's largest Western creditors, has agreed to let Poland postpone payments of principal due in this year's second quarter, the Dresdner Bank said today. This will give Poland time to arrange a debt rescheduling, the bank said.

title: CHAMBER: ROSENMAN'S 'FOCUS 1'
description: ''FOCUS 1,'' wrote Leonard Rosenman of his composition given its premiere by Gerard Schwarz and the Y Chamber Symphony last Saturday night, is ''like a trip down the barrel of a microscope into the worlds beyond.'' It takes an initial chord and focuses on it with increasing magnification, ''descending into sound-worlds.''

title: TREASURY BONDS SHARPLY LOWER
description: Prices slumped in the credit markets yesterday, sending yields once again to near-record levels. ''The poor performance in the Government sector was somewhat mystifying,'' one dealer said. The Treasury's longest-term bond, the 12,s of 2010, fell a point, to 96 10/ 32. At this price, it provided a 13.25 percent yield. That compared with the record return of 13.40 percent reached briefly on Monday morning.

title: Addendum
description: * Lindsay Smithers/FCB, which already has an office in Durban, South Africa, has opened another South African office in Natal.

title: BIDDING FOR PART OF CONRAIL
description: The Providence & Worcester Railroad Company is trying to prove it is the little engine that can provide profitable freight service in southern New England without governmental help.

title: By Sports of the Times; No. 7 is Also No. 68
description: HUBIE BROOKS hopped out of the Mets' dugout yesterday into the wind-chilled sun of their Shea Stadium opener and trotted toward third base with a blue ''7'' on his back. But he knew his real number.

title: MICHIGANERS EAGER FOR NEWS OF TEXAS JOBS
description: Martha Hayes and Donna Lee wore their Texas T-shirts to work at the Little Professor bookstore on Michigan Avenue here today.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: IT'S TIME

title: Janet B. Hollaman, Former Head Of East Side House Settlement
description: Janet B. Hollaman, a former president of the East Side House Settlement and a founder of the annual Winter Antiques Show, which benefits the charity, died Tuesday at her home in Sarasota, Fla. She was 88 years old.

title: People
description: * Michael Arum has joined Response Strategms Inc., the direct marketing division of Sacks & Rosen Inc., as senior vice president.

title: People Express Jets
description: People Express Airlines, a newly formed regional airline based in Newark, said it had reached agreement with Lufthansa Airlines for the purchase of three Boeing 737 aircraft for $3.7 million each, raising to 17 the number of aircraft now in its inventory. The carrier earlier announced an agreement with Lufthansa to purchase 14 Boeing 737's at the same price.

title: WARNER-LAMBERT POSTS A LOSS AFTER WRITE-OFFS
description: The Warner-Lambert Company, a medical equipment manufacturer and pharmaceutical producer, announced a first-quarter loss of $97.5 million, which it attributed to the divestiture of an optical subsidiary and other health care operations. These sales resulted in a $134.3 million write-off. First-quarter 1980 earnings were $60.7 million, or 76 cents a share.

title: Carey Defends Westway As Part of Mass Transit
description: Governor Carey showed up late last night for a panel discussion with the Governors of New Jersey and Connecticut and promptly began a vigorous defense of the proposed Westway highway project.

title: PRUNING THE ROOTS OF A CONTAINER PLANT
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Linda Yang is a regular contributor of gardening articles to The Times. By LINDA YANG

title: STORE OWNER IN JERSEY AND A WINE MERCHANT
description: Frank W. Packard, a wine merchant and retailer who was a leader in discount merchandising, died Sunday of a heart attack at an apartment he maintained in Manhattan. He was 74 years old and was a resident of Hackensack, N.J.

title: ONE KILLED IN NEWARK HOTEL BLAZE
description: A three-alarm fire raced through an aging hotel in downtown Newark today, killing one resident and forcing the removal of 125 other residents.

title: MOSCOW WARNS POLAND IS MENACED BY A 'CREEPING COUNTERREVOLUTION'
description: The Soviet press reported in worried tones today on the situation in Poland, saying that the country was being subverted by ''creeping counterrevolution'' from within and ''radio aggression'' from the West, while stalwart Communist workers longed for the party to reassert its authority.

title: CBS and Warner Profits Rise
description: CBS Inc. said yesterday that its profits for the first three months this year rose 6.9 percent, to $14 million, and another major communiations company, Warner Communications Inc., reported a 41.4 percent increase in its earnings, to $49.5 million.

title: Saudi Rail Contract
description: The Saudi Government's railroad agency said today that it had awarded a $114.3 million contract to Archirodon Ltd. of Greece to build a 94-mile, singletrack railway from Dammam to Hofuf. Sources said the contract included construction of a factory to make 600 pre-stressed concrete ties a day. The contract covers the first of three sections of a railway designed by Technicas of Italy to link Damman, on the Persian Gulf coast, and Riyadh, the Saudi capital, to the west.

title: SOVIET BEATS CANADA IN HOCKEY BY 8-2
description: The Soviet Union continued its success against Team Canada today with an 8-2 victory in the world ice hockey championships.

title: Shell in Joint Effort Off Nova Scotia
description: A $200 million oil exploration program off the Nova Scotia coast has been announced by the Shell Explorer Company of Houston and two Canadian companies, Norcen Energy Ltd. and CDC Oil and Gas Ltd.

title: THERAPY REUNION IS HELD FOR EX-HOSTAGES AND KIN
description: In closed sessions with psychiatrists today, some of the former United States hostages held in Iran said that they were worried about their marriages, their home lives and their role in helping America to recover from that crisis.

title: WASHINGTON POST GIVES UP PULITZER, CALLING ARTICLE ON ADDICT, 8, FICTION
description: The Washington Post said today that an article it printed about the life of an 8-year-old heroin addict in the slums of Washington, for which the author won a Pulitzer Prize this week, was a fabrication.

title: FITZSIMMONS, AILING, MAY QUIT UNION JOB
description: Frank E. Fitzsimmons is likely to step down soon as president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters because of failing health, several union officials said today.

title: A.T.&T. LIFTS EARNINGS 11.1%, CALLS FOR HIGHER LOCAL RATES
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company today reported an 11.1 percent increase in its first-quarter earnings, and it said local telephone rates would have to be increased sharply.

title: F.B.I. AGENT'S REMARKS ON MURDERS STRAIN BUREAU'S TIES WITH ATLANTA
description: Relations between local police officials and the Federal Bureau of Investigation were tenser today after an F.B.I agent's comments last night to a Macon, Ga., civic club that four of Atlanta's 23 murdered children had been killed by their parents because they had been considered ''nuisances.''

title: CENSUS FINDS BLACKS GAINING MAJORITIES IN BIG CITIES
description: Final 1980 census figures show that an enormous migration of whites from the nation's largest cities has left blacks or Hispanic Americans as the majority or a substantial minority in most of the cities.

title: Sydney Dance Company To Make American Debut
description: The Sydney Dance Company will make its American debut May 27 at the City Center-55th Street Theater, where it will appear through May 31.

title: 'Boat People' Exodus Increases, In Reversal of Last Year's Trend
description: The number of Vietnamese refugees arriving in Thailand and other Asian nations increased last month, in a reversal of last year's downward trend, a United Nations agency said today.

title: Texaco's Gasohol
description: Texaco U.S.A., the nation's fifth-largest refiner, said it will introduce a new higher-octane gasohol blend in selected Northeast markets this month that will replace its lower-octane, lead-free gasohol. E.W. Gunnels, vice president for marketing for the Texaco Inc. unit, said Texaco Super lead-free gasohol would be available in certain areas of Massachusetts, Connecticut, New Hampshire and Long Island. The new mixture, which is made up of 90 percent unleaded gasoline and 10 percent ethyl alcohol, will have an octane rating of 91, the company said. It did not say what the fuel might cost.

title: Around the Nation
description: Braniff Airways has settled a Federal employment discrimination lawsuit out of court by agreeing to give preferential treatment to blacks rejected as flight attendants from 1973 to 1975 and to pay each $1,000.

title: PRESIDENT REAGAN PARDONS 2 EX-F.B.I. OFFICIALS IN 1970'S BREAK-INS
description: President Reagan announced today that he had granted unconditional pardons to two former officials of the Federal Bureau of Investigation who were convicted of conspiring to violate the constitutional rights of Americans. The two men authorized Government agents to break into homes in search of antiwar radicals in the early 1970's.

title: DUGUAY, DON MALONY AILING
description: Two of the Rangers' hottest playoff scorers, Ron Duguay and Don Maloney, are injured and may not play tomorrow night when the Rangers open their National Hockey League quarterfinal series against the St. Louis Blues at the Checkerdome.

title: DRUGS SAID TO EASE MENSTRUAL PAIN
description: Scientists here reported today that several common anti-arthritis drugs could be effective in the treatment of menstrual cramps.

title: The Region; Connecticut Reports A Run on Toll Books
description: Toll stations on the Connecticut Turnpike, Merritt and Wilbur Cross Parkways and three bridges in the Hartford area were jammed with bargain-hunting motorists.

title: Pardoning the F.B.I.'s Past
description: Although Mark Felt and Edward Miller were found guilty of conspiring to violate the civil rights of innocent Americans, they deserved the executive clemency President Reagan has now extended. The equally deserving jury in their case and the nation, however, deserved better than a gratuitous revision of the record by the President.

title: REAGAN STATEMENT ABOUT THE PARDONS
description: Following is the text of a statement by President Reagan today on his pardon of two former officials of the Federal Bureau of Investigation who had been convicted of illegal procedures:

title: Borden Acquisition
description: Borden Inc. said that it was acquiring Uniroyal Inc.'s 50 percent interest in production facilities of their Monochem Inc. joint venture in Louisiana.

title: COALITION THAT SOUGHT CANDIDATE TO OPPOSE KOCH IS BREAKING UP
description: The citizen coalition seeking a candidate to run against Mayor Koch decided yesterday to disband. But the first news of its dissolution came not from the group but from the Mayor himself, in advance of the group's own official announcement.

title: REAGAN? FREE ENTERPRISE?
description: It's been less than three months since President Reagan took office but already a pattern has been set. The Japanese are being pressured to restrict their auto exports to American consumers. American grain farmers still may not deal with the Soviet Union. Nominees to regulatory agencies are unsympathetic to deregulation. The minimum wage, scourge of the unskilled and young, is to be unchanged. The Chrysler bailout continues. The Federal Trade Commission is to retain its antitrust authority. The trigger-price system for steel imports and ''anti-dumping'' measures for other goods remains in force. The oil industry still labors under a (misnamed) windfall-profits tax. Young men are still being registered for a future draft. The odd thing is that the American people were under the impression that they elected a President who believes in free enterprise and individual liberty. But considering the record so far, they must have been mistaken.

title: CITY TO REFURBISH WASHINGTON SQ. AND STEP UP PATROLLING BY POLICE
description: Plans to clean up, refurbish and provide additional police patrols for Washington Square Park were announced yesterday by Parks Commissioner Gordon J. Davis.

title: LOUISVILLE SLUGGER SUPPLY THREATENED AS WORKERS STRIKE
description: The long-brewing fear of a labor strike in major league baseball became a reality last Monday. But it was the people who make the bats, rather than those who swing them, who walked off the job.

title: Columbia College Unit Endorses a Coed School
description: A Columbia College committee on coeducation has concluded that admitting women to the college would present few practical problems and have little effect on Barnard, the women's college affiliated with Columbia Univerity.

title: Man Accused in Slaying Left State Prison Oct. 23
description: A man accused in the fatal stabbing Tuesday of a woman who was coowner of a freight business in lower Manhattan was released from prison last Oct. 23 after serving 10 years for manslaughter, the State Parole Division said yesterday.

title: A WHALE TRIES TO BEACH ITSELF
description: A 40-foot gray whale with a large gash in its side attempted to beach itself on Coney Island last night, but was apparently edged back out to sea by a police launch.

title: Naked To Mine Enemies
description: Here is how Ronald Reagan was led into doublecrossing a too-trusting Israel. Three months ago, Secretary of State Haig and Secretary of Defense Weinberger told the President that their predecessors, Muskie and Brown, had secretly promised Saudi Arabia the equipment that would make their U.S.-made F-15 fighters capable of reaching Tel Aviv. This was directly contrary to assurances given the Senate when the ''defensive'' arms were sold, as well as contrary to Carter preelection statements.

title: Harbor Pilot Is Charged In Collision of 2 Vessels
description: A Tampa Bay harbor pilot has been charged with misconduct and negligence aboard an inbound tanker moments before she collided with a Coast Guard buoy tender last year, the Coast Guard said today.

title: NATIONAL PUBLIC RADIO AT 10: EXCELLENT BUT IN DANGER
description: Next week, while National Public Radio is celebrating the 10th anniversary of its first transmission - coverage of a Senate hearing on the War Powers Act - it will provide member stations with a special 90-minute documentary titled ''Father Cares: The Last Days of Jonestown.''

title: THEATER: 'IN AN UPSTATE MOTEL' BY NEGRO ENSEMBLE
description: THERE is quite a bizarre mix of ingredients to be found in Larry Neal's ''In an Upstate Motel,'' the new offering at the Negro Ensemble Company. The playwright has taken a familiar premise -a gangland hit man and his woman on the lam - and infused it with Proustian ghosts, Pinteresque menace, even a dash of jazz. If these diverse elements are more often in conflict than in congress, there's an understandable reason for that. Mr. Neal, who died at age 42 last January, didn't have the opportunity to see and reshape his work in a full-fledged production.

title: Honda in Yugoslavia
description: The Honda Motor Company, the world's largest motorcycle maker, said it will start producing small engines for agricultural implements in Yugoslavia in 1982 in partnership with a Yugoslav concern. The company said that the $550 million venture called for monthly production of 1,500 air-cooled engines. The partner, Standard Metalska, has been assembling Honda tillers and motor pumps since 1975.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Avnet Inc. has appointed William C. Cacciatore senior vice president in charge of electronic and electrical distribution.

title: Around the World; Maksim Shostakovich To Win Asylum in U.S.
description: Maksim Shostakovich, a Soviet symphony conductor who defected in West Germany last week, will be granted political asylum in the United States, the State Department said today.

title: NASA OFFICIALS FIND THE SPACE SHUTTLE IN 'EXCELLENT' SHAPE
description: Space agency officials reported today that the condition of the winged spaceship Columbia was ''excellent'' and that it should be capable of making at least 100 round trips into orbit.

title: Guerrillas in a Balloon Shot Down by Israelis
description: Israeli troops shot down a helium-filled balloon carrying Palestinian guerrillas early today, killing several of them, the Israeli military command announced.

title: POLISH COMMUNIST FACTION APPEALS FOR MORE FREEDOM IN PARTY SYSTEM
description: Delegates from Communist Party units throughout Poland met here today to demand democratic changes in the party and a system in which power would flow upward from the people, not downward from the central apparatus.

title: Millionaire Faces Hashish Count
description: Percy Ross, a millionaire philanthropist, pleaded not guilty today to a charge of possessing hashish. A trial was scheduled for July 13 in Hennepin County District Court. Mr. Ross, 64 years old, is accused of possessing 3.5 grams of hashish seized in a raid at his office last month.

title: 76ERS DEFEAT BUCKS, LEAD BY 3-2
description: The Philadelphia 76ers were so worried about Marques Johnson they devised a special plan to stop him in game five of their Eastern Conference playoff tonight. Then they went out and defeated the Bucks, 116-99, at the Spectrum.

title: Spot Oil Trade And Prices Lag
description: Prices for gasoline and oil fell in the last week but trading in both crude oil and oil products on the spot market continued very quiet, market sources said today.

title: OPEN THE COURTROOMS TO THE LIGHT OF DAY
description: To the Editor:

title: Gannett Earnings Up 11% in Quarter
description: The Gannett Company said today that it earned $30.2 million in the first quarter this year, up 11 percent from $27.2 million in the comparable 1980 period, as profits set a record for the 54th consecutive quarter.

title: FORMER GOVERNOR OF RHODE ISLAND
description: William Henry Vanderbilt, a former Governor of Rhode Island who was a great-great-grandson of Commodore Cornelius Vanderbilt, the 19th century railroad magnate, died Tuesday night at his home in South Williamstown, Mass. He was 79 years old.

title: METS DEFEAT CARDINALS, 5-3, IN HOME OPENER
description: The Mets brought their new act to New York yesterday, opening their home season in Shea Stadium on a cool and windswept afternoon by defeating the St. Louis Cardinals, 5-3.

title: STUDY FINDS APATHY AMONG FEDERAL 'WHISTLE BLOWERS'
description: Federal employees have abundant knowledge of illegal and wasteful Government activities, but the majority do not report such activities because they believe nothing would be done to correct the situation, according to a Government study released today.

title: Conserving The Society
description: Of all President Reagan's domestic proposals one is especially significant, and revealing, in terms of political philosophy. That is his move to kill the Federally funded program of lawyers for the poor.

title: LILLIE SHULTZ, WRITER AND AN ADMINISTRATOR FOR JEWISH CONGRESS
description: Lillie Shultz, a journalist and former administrator of the American Jewish Congress, died Tuesday at her home in Manhattan after a long illness. She was 77 years old.

title: Trying to Bid a Bank Commercial Goodbye
description: A Dollar Savings Bank radio commercial heard in the New York area may sound innocent enough to most listeners, but to one Long Island man, it's been ''humiliating.'' He's obtained a court order temporarily restraining the bank from using the commercial.

title: SALES 'REPS' UNDER PRESSURE
description: The manufacturer's sales agent, commonly called ''the rep,'' has for years maintained a slippery niche in the world of merchandising. Today, reps are becoming increasingly upset by the efforts of some retailers to bypass them to cut costs.

title: American Air's Earnings Up
description: American Airlines Inc., reversing a $41.9 million loss in the 1980 first quarter, said today that it earned $3.9 million, or 3 cents a share, in the first three months of the year despite a decline in passenger traffic. Revenues rose 9.4 percent, to $952.5 million, from $871 million in the comparable 1980 period.

title: FEELINGS TOWARD JEWS FOUND MORE FAVORABLE IN A SURVEY BY GALLUP
description: While vandalism against Jewish institutions seems to be on the increase, the incidents do not signal heightened anti-Semitic feelings among Americans, according to the Gallup Poll. On the contrary, the survey reported this week that positive attitudes toward Jews have increased in recent years.

title: Samson V. Becker, 84, Architect And City Housing Authority Aide
description: Samson V. Becker, an architect and housing consultant and a design deputy for the New York City Housing Authority, died Tuesday at Sibley Hospital in Washington, D.C. Mr. Becker, who had been living in retirement in Miami Beach, was 84 years old.

title: CALM APRIL 15 FOR FUNDS
description: Another filing deadline for income tax returns has come and gone, with hardly a ripple in the 7.5 million accounts at the nation's money market funds. Investors apparently have not withdrawn large sums from the funds to pay their tax bills, most of which were due at midnight last night.

title: 'BREAKING GLASS'
description: Kate (Hazel O'Connor) is the heroine of ''Breaking Glass,'' and before we get to anything else about her, let's talk about Kate's London apartment. It has some plants, some macrame, some antique mirrors and oak furniture and hats hung folksily on the wall. There are lots of books and bric-a-brac, and the place is cozy and tidy. Very serene. Very Woodstock. Very familiar.

title: AMTRAK'S VALUE IN TERMS OF OIL
description: To the Editor:

title: SAVINGS REGULATOR CALLS INDUSTRY 'CLEARLY VIABLE'
description: The Reagan Administration's chief regulator of savings and loan associations said here yesterday that ''the industry is clearly viable'' and added that ''I think it is very unlikely that this Adminstration would be highly interested in a massive subsidy program of any type.''

title: SHEARSON STOCK UP IN MERGER CONJECTURE
description: The stock of Shearson Loeb Rhoades, one of the nation's fastestgrowing brokerage houses, surged 4 points a share yesterday, to 42 1/4, amid unconfirmed reports that the company was discussing the possibility of a takeover by the American Express Company.

title: The City; Central Park Section To Honor Lennon
description: A tear-shaped area on the western edge of Central Park was christened Strawberry Fields under a bill signed yesterday by Mayor Koch.

title: North Stars 4, Sabres 3
description: BUFFALO (UPI) - Steve Payne scored 22 seconds into overtime to give Minnesota the victory. Payne deflected a shot from the point by Brad Maxwell.

title: SENATE DEMOCRATS DIVIDED ON COURSE TO TAKE TO COUNTER THE REPUBLICANS
