description: Senate Democrats, after three months of painful adjustment to political life as the minority party, are deeply divided over the direction to take in countering Republican initiatives.

title: The Evening Hours; FLOWERS AMONG FLATWARE
description: JAPANESE double-flowering cherry trees, African daisies from Johannesburg, sprigs of quince, azaleas, tulips, hyacinths, red gingers from Hawaii, ferns and forsythias and potted amaryllis, along with the two gazebos with English ivies crawling up and through them. That was the scene when Macy's, looking like nothing less than a massive greenhouse, opened its annual Spring Flower Show with a party the other night.

title: RANGERS LOSE, 6-3, TO BLUES
description: The New York Rangers played their weakest game in several weeks tonight and lost the first game of their quarterfinal playoff series to St. Louis Blues, 6-3, at the Checkerdome.

title: NEW-HOME STARTS RISE, PERMITS OFF
description: Housing starts rose 5.8 percent in March, to a relatively weak annual rate of 1.28 million units, the Commerce Department said yesterday.

title: HARASSED MAYOR ROLLS WITH THE 'PUNCHES'
description: In jeans and a white zippered jacket, Gerald E. Loehr found himself at 2:30 this morning holding a six-inch fire hose on a blazing building along Riverdale Avenue. It was not exactly business as usual for the Mayor of Yonkers, but then there were no city firemen to do the job.

title: CARDINALS SET BACK METS WITH THREE HOME RUNS, 5-1
description: On a bright, blue afternoon, Darrell Porter, Keith Hernandez and George Hendrick hit home runs at Shea Stadium yesterday and the heady Mets slipped out of first place with a 5-1 loss to the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: A.C.L.U. Sues to Restore Los Angeles School Busing
description: While thousands of students prepared to return to neighborhood schools under a voluntary integration program next week, the State Supreme Court was urged today to keep mandatory busing alive in Los Angeles schools.

title: A NOVEL OF COMPLEX FAMILY TIES SETS OFF GUESSING
description: Nina Gore Auchincloss Steers Straight's memories of her half-brother, Gore Vidal, though fragmented, are vivid. ''A photograph of me as a teeny baby, a fat thing sitting on Gore's lap. Then I never saw him again until I was 13 or 14, a bad speller, a bad grammarian, and he started me reading. I remember him shaking his finger and telling me, 'Now I want you to read Virginia Woolf and Thomas Hardy.' ''

title: PRIVATE MUSIC AND PUBLIC SILENCE
description: In the beginning was The Box, and The Box was mostly noisy. So loud was the noise typically emanating from this bulky but portable stereophonic radio-cassette player that some who played it on subways and buses received dirty looks from fellow riders and once in a while a summons from the police.

title: Phils Top Pirates By 5-3
description: Mike Schmidt homered and Pete Rose had three hits to help the Philadelphia Phillies beat the Pittsburgh Pirates, 5-3, tonight.

title: HANDGUN CONTROL MUST NOW BE A PRIMARY LEGISLATIVE TARGET
description: To the Editor:

title: 'KNIGHRIDERS,' CAMELOT ON A YAMAHA
description: It's probably only a coincidence that George A. Romero's modestly budgeted, essentially comic ''Knightriders'' should open in New York just a week after ''Excalibur,'' John Boorman's elaborate reverential saga that examines the various legends about King Arthur and the knights of the Round Table. It's doubtful that Mr. Romero, the Pittsburgh-based director of those two hugely profitable horror films, ''Night of the Living Dead'' and ''Dawn of the Dead,'' knew what Mr. Boorman was up to or, if he did, that he had any idea that his film would be a tonic for those of us who resisted the pieties of ''Excalibur.'' Yet that is, in effect, what Mr. Romero has made.

title: P-FUNK STARTS A NATIONAL TOUR
description: George Clinton announced last year that he would no longer be performing with Parliament/Funkadelic, the remarkable black funk band he formed in the late 60's with the help of several former members of James Brown's band. He planned to devote himself to Uncle Jam records, his own custom label, and to producing Funkadelic and the other performers who have benefited from his mastery of contemporary dance rhythms.

title: HANDGUN CONTROL MUST NOW BE A PRIMARY LEGISLATIVE TARGET
description: To the Editor:

title: MUSIC: NEW NEIKRUG WORK
description: Theorectically, the event at the 92d Street Y on Tuesday night was a chamber-music concert, and it opened, in fact, with Schumann's Piano Quartet in E flat. But the main offering was the first American performance of a splendid music-theater piece by Marc Neikrug.

title: Article 087641 -- No Title
description: The assets of the nation's money market mutual funds increased nearly $1.7 billion in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

title: Let's Slay Another Sacred Tax Cow
description: The Reagan Administration's proposed budget is billed as a fearless attack on sacred cows. But some cows are still more sacred than others. This President, too, hesitates to challenge the costly and now damaging Federal subsidies for private home ownership. The omission is critical. For only by curbing these hidden subsidies - given as tax breaks on home mortgage interest - could Mr. Reagan help restrain runaway housing prices and direct personal savings toward more productive investments.

title: Delay on Rescue Device Backed
description: A Federal appeals court today supported the Government's postponement until June 21 of a requirement that a new oxygen rescue device be made available for the nation's 133,000 underground coal miners.

title: ART: 'WORKING PROCESS' AT COLUMBUS CIRCLE
description: The process by which an artist creates his work seems to be of increasing interest in our phenomenologically minded society - an interest that has impelled artists to use more skill in making their mental processes available. Seeing how a visual work is made is not always so gratifying, of course, as observing the finished product. But after all, if writers can tell us through notes and diaries how they produced their novels, why shouldn't artists be allowed to clue us in on the way they do what they do?

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, APRIL 17, 1981
description: International The prospect of preliminary arms talks on resuming negotiations to limit American and Soviet nuclear weapons in Europe was raised by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. His aides said that full negotiations were probably months away. (Page A1, Col. 1.) Israeli jets staged raids in Lebanon, striking at several suspected Palestinian guerrilla strongholds. Earlier, two teen-aged Palestinian guerrillas trying to enter Israel by balloon were shot down and killed in a gunfight with Israeli soldiers. (A3:1-3.)

title: HANDGUN CONTROL MUST NOW BE A PRIMARY LEGISLATIVE TARGET
description: To the Editor:

title: F.B.I. VOWS AID AGAINST VIOLENCE
description: William H. Webster, Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, said today that he had no desire to have the bureau become more involved in the investigation of violent crimes such as murder, robbery and rape, but he offered to support state and local police departments in any way he could.

title: EL ARISH IN SINAI THRIVES AGAIN IN WAKE IF ISRAELI WITHDRAWAL
description: Said Hussein Abdel Rahman lives with his wife and five of their 11 children in a little house on Sharia el-Geish here in Sinai beside the Mediterranean. On the outside wall are pictures of the Kaaba in Mecca, the holiest object in Islam. Mr. Abdel Rahman made a pilgrimage to the holy city last year.

title: MUSIC: LEONHARDT PLAYS HARPSICHORD IN MEDIEVAL COURT
description: GUSTAV LEONHARDT playing at his harpsichord recital Wednesday night at the Metropolitan Museum's medieval court was attractive and fluent as always, if a little more phlegmatic than sometimes in the past. But there was considerable confusion about what he actually played.

title: The Region; Two Women Killed In Building Collapse
description: NEWARK (UPI) - Two women were killed Wednesday when the ruins of a theater undergoing demolition collapsed on them, city officials said. The women - Minnie Henry, 91 years old, and a friend, Irene Haddock, 56 - were pruning flowers in Mrs. Henry's backyard when tons of concrete brick buried them, Mrs. Haddock's husband, Hardy, told the police. Mr. Haddock said he had walked to the front of the house moments before the accident. The women's bodies were later recovered.

title: Army Destroys Nerve Agent
description: The Army has destroyed 40 pounds of the nerve agent BZ and is preparing a long-range program to dispose of the entire stockpile at the Pine Bluff Arsenal.

title: Case & McGrath Ends Tie To Banquet Frozen Foods
description: Banquet Frozen Foods, a subsidiary of Conagra since last year, is an account on the loose.

title: RCA Net Off 46.7% In Quarter
description: The RCA Corporation yesterday reported a 46.7 percent drop in first-quarter earnings to $41.9 million, or 33 cents a share, from $78.7 million, or 89 cents a share, recorded in the comparable 1980 quarter. Revenues dipped slightly, to $1.95 billion, from $1.97 billion a year ago.

title: Mrs. Thatcher, in India, Defends Nationality Bill
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain, responding to charges in the Indian press that proposed new British citizenship rules are racist, said today that ''there is nothing in the proposed law which discriminates against any racial or national group.''

title: DOCTORS SAY 31 EX-HOSTAGES ARE WELL
description: Shortly after noon yesterday, a stubby military jet appeared high in the sky above the luxurious Greenbrier resort hotel that dominates this little mountain village.

title: SOCIAL SECURITY RATES NEED COOLING DOWN
description: To the Editor:

title: Edsel Ford 2d Is Named To Ford Marketing Post
description: Edsel Ford 2d, 32 years old, the great-grandson of the founder of the Ford Motor Company and the man who some Detroit sources believe may return the Ford name to the top post at the corporation, yesterday was appointed marketing plans director of the Ford division. A company spokesman in Dearborn, Mich., said that Mr. Ford would not be available to talk to the press.

title: Interest Rates Advance Slightly
description: Interest rates were slightly higher in quiet trading yesterday. Yields on long-term securities remained very near their peaks, as shown by the bellwether 12 3/4 percent Treasury bonds due in 2010, which closed at about 95 30/32 to yield 13.3 percent.

title: Auctions; American art at two houses.
description: IN sales of American paintings, drawings, watercolors and sculpture from the 18th, 19th and early 20th centuries next week at two galleries, the most important offering is Winslow Homer's ''The Dinner Horn.'' This 1870 oil on canvas depicts a young woman in a shimmering white dress standing on a path just outside a farmhouse sounding the dinner call to the men working in the fields. ''The Dinner Horn'' may bring about $1 million when it is sold next Thursday at 2 P.M. at Sotheby Parke Bernet, Madison Avenue at 76th Street. Homer painted another version of the subject three years later, in which he showed the girl on the farmhouse porch, a painting that is now in the Detroit Institute of Arts.

title: COAL BOOM CLOGGING PORTS
description: When Claire C. Chasnov, assistant director for A.T.I.C., a French association that buys coal in North America, meets with American coal executives, she typically offers them advice on how to grab a share of the growing export market for coal.

title:
RED SMITH;
Omar Bradley, Soldier and Athlete
description: ALONG with the daily assortment of publicity handouts, bills and solicitations came a letter from Red Reeder, soldier, author and athlete.

title: Schmidt Adviser Is Hopeful On Ending Salvador War
description: A senior West German politician who just returned from a tour of Latin America said today that he was convinced the fighting in El Salvador could be ended by political means. ''Weapons do not solve this problem,'' he said.

title: Index; International
description: El Arish in Sinai grows again now that Israelis are gone A2 Soviet blocks Lebanon peace plan at U.N. A3 Polish farmers win backing in Parliament on a union A3 East Germans re-elect Honecker and stress party discipline A4 Bonn braces for violence as leftist hunger striker dies A4 Eight Canadian Premiers offer constitutional plan A7 South Africans seize Bishop Tutu's passport A8 Six African leaders attack Reagan policies A8 Government/Politics South Dakota court backs state in amending $50 million tax error A10 Defense in Abscam case warned against irrelevant testimony B5 General Around the Nation A10 Doctors find 31 former hostages are ''functioning well'' A10 Cedar Rapids patiently waits for U.S. turnaround A14 GOOD FRIDAY Parking - Alternate-side parking suspended. All other rules in effect. Sanitation - Regular collections; no street cleaning. Federal, state and municipal offices -Open. Post offices - Open. Banks - Open in New York City; most closed in New Jersey and Connecticut. Stock and commodity markets -Closed. Transportation - Subways, buses and Conrail normal; some extra trains on Long Island Rail Road. Libraries - Open. Public schools - Closed.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Stock Exchange has elected Frederick B. Whittemore, managing director of Morgan Stanley & Company, vice chairman of the board of governors.

title: N.W. Ayer Toronto Office To Join Vickers & Benson
description: N.W. Ayer, which has been a presence in Toronto since 1975 and has an office with almost $5 million in billings there, will merge it into a joint venture it is starting with Vickers & Benson, one of Canada's top five agencies.

title: Restaurants; Gallic standby and new singles spot.
description: FAMILIARITY can sometimes serve as camouflage, especially with a restaurant so long at the same site that one is hardly aware of its presence. Le Bistro, on Third Avenue between 50th and 51st Streets, has been quietly, steadily and successfully serving up delicious examples of the cuisine bourgeoise for 22 years at its present address, and for 20 years before that on its original site across Third Avenue. Purchased almost four years ago by Georges Hayon, Le Bistro plays to a packed house at lunch every weekday. Less crowded at dinner, the redecorated and colorfully festive dining room offers a leisurely option for very good food at moderate prices. Service is bustling, professional and polite, and the noise level is benign.

title: IDENTIFICATION PLAN SEEKS TO COMBAT THEFTS OF TORAHS
description: Citing a recent rash of thefts of Torahs from New York City synagogues, a Brooklyn Jewish leader said yesterday that many of the sacred scrolls were apparently being stolen by, or in cooperation with, Jews familiar with their use and value.

title: Commonwealth Oil Loss
description: The Commonwealth Oil Refining Company, in Chapter 11 bankruptcy since 1978, reported yesterday a loss of $22.3 million for the first quarter of 1981, more than triple its year-earlier loss of $6.7 million. Sales for the quarter slipped to $304.6 million from $306.2 million. The company noted that the 1980 results included extraordinary credits of $2.6 million, or 17 cents a share, for a tax loss carry-forward and $6 million from an insurance claim.

title: Boy, 3, Killed in Chicago Project
description: A 3-year-old boy was found beaten to death today in his crib in an apartment in the same building of the Cabrini-Green housing project where Mayor Jane M. Byrne is living, the police said. The body of Matthew Davie was found in his 18thfloor flat by an aunt.

title: MUSIC: MACHINE AND TEITELBAUM WORK TOGETHER
description: RICHARD TEITELBAUM'S ''Colourless Green Ideas Sleep Furiously'' at the Dance Theater Workshop Tuesday evening evoked a fascinating dialogue between man and machine. For most of this rambling two-hour musical meditation, Mr. Teitelbaum's fingers introduced figures, rhythms and thematic ideas on one of four synthesizer keyboards; and in response, electronic circuitry digested them, added its own (im)personal transformations and then echoed these afterthoughts against the originals.

title: CAROLINIANS UNCERTIN ON BUDGET CUTS
description: When Representative Bill Hefner came home last night, his constituents told him to support President Reagan's economic programs - but with significant reservations.

title: The Economy
description: The dollar will be allowed to fluctuate more widely on foreign exchange markets and the Administration will intervene to support it only in emergencies. R.T. McNamar, the Deputy Treasury Secretary, said the U.S. bought $79 million worth of dollars following the shooting of President Reagan to avert any slide in the dollar, but had ended frequent market intervention. At the same news conference, Norman B. Ture, an Under Secretary of the Treasury, said he did not think it ''would be a life or death difference'' if the effective date of a tax cut was made Jan. 1, 1982, instead of July 1, 1981. (Page A1.)

title: GILLIES, POTVIN GET 2
description: The Islanders registered a convincing 8-2 victory over the Edmonton Oilers tonight at Nassau Coliseum in the first game of their National Hockey League quarterfinal playoff. The second game in the four-of-seven series will be held here tomorrow night.

title: COURT CHIDES WILLIAMS'S COUNSEL ABOUT 'IRRELEVANCIES'
description: The judge at the Abscam bribery trial of Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. criticized the Senator's attorney yesterday for introducing what the judge called ''endless detail about irrelevancies'' into the trial.

title: FALSIFICATION OF PRIZE ARTICLE PUTS A SPOTLIGHT ON HOW NEWSPAPERS CHECK
description: STORIES By JONATHAN FRIENDLY

title: TWO RESERVOIRS RUNNING OVER AS RATIONING CONTINUES
description: Reservoirs serving Jersey City, and Greenwich, Conn., are overflowing and losing millions of gallons of water daily while residents in both water-rationed areas are attempting to conserve it.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Market Place column in Busi- ness Day on Wednesday incorrectly stated the stockholdings of William L. Cary in the United States Filter Corpo- ration, Raymond F. Bentele in Mal- linckrodt and the holdings of various in- dividuals in the McDonnell Douglas Corporation. Mr. Cary holds $130.5 mil- lion worth of Filter stock as trustee for Friedrich Flick Industrieverwaltung K.G.a.A., a group of West German companies, and therefore does not share in the dividends. Mr. Bentele holds $104.1 million in Mallinckrodt stock, also as a trustee. No individual owns as much as $100 million in McDon- nell Douglas. The $100 million level was the criterion for the mention of names in the column.

title: Lawyer New Lukens Chairman
description: Frederick M. Myers, 58, a partner in the Pittsfield, Mass., law firm of Cain, Hibbard & Myers, has been elected chairman of the Lukens Steel Company. Lukens, with headquarters in Coatesville, Pa., - 1 hour 15 minutes by corporate jet to Pittsfield - is an old-line corporation that specializes in plate steels.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Bullets Tossed Onto Field During Pirates-Phils Game
description: Two bullets were thrown onto the field from the stands at Veterans Stadium -one at Dave Parker, the Pittsburgh outfielder - during the Pirates' game with the Phillies last night.

title: Judge Backs Chicago Delay On School Integration Plan
description: A Federal judge agreed today to give the school board more time to work out a plan to desegregate the city's public schools but warned that ''additional time will not make the problems go away.''

title: Bridge: Fellow Named Goren Helps Team Win in Von Zedtwitz
description: After six months of activity in the Von Zedtwitz Double Knockout Team Championship in New York, two teams, headed by Michael Becker and Alan Greenberg, remain undefeated. Thirteen teams survive after only one defeat, one of them led by Tom Abbott and including Barry Goren.

title: Notes on People; A TITLE LOST, A TITLE GAINED; A Title Lost, a Title Gained
description: Simone Duvalier, mother of the Haitian President, Jean-Claude Duvalier, had exercised a potential mother-in-law's right to disapprove of his marriage last May 27 to Michelle Bennett.

title: CELEBRATING EASTER SEASON CLOSE TO HOME
description: EASTER sets the season. Whatever the temperature or color of sky, winter as a state of mind vanishes, and the festive holiday virtually demands some celebratory activity, preferably in the open air. The possibilities this weekend abound. You can search, explore, gaze, careen, listen and even parade.

title: TRIBUTE TO VARESE, LED BY JOEL THOME, MATCHES MILIEU TO THE MUSIC
description: Tonight's all-Varese concert at the Palladium is a curious but appropriate meeting of music and milieu. Edgard Varese, one of the 20th-century's great iconoclasts, mistrusted the historical habits and habitats of ''classical music''; and the prospect of this French-American composer's explosive, spitting sonorities resounding through one of rock-and-roll's famous gathering places promises an audience almost as interesting as the music.

title: HANDGUN CONTROL MUST NOW BE A PRIMARY LEGISLATIVE TARGET
description: To the Editor:

title: Prudential Bache Bid
description: The Prudential Insurance Company of America said that its tender offer for common stock and warrants of Bache Group Inc., the big Wall Street brokerage concern, had been successful. Prudential, the nation's largest insurance company, said that a majority of the outstanding common stock on a fully diluted basis had been tendered and that all shares and warrants properly tendered had been accepted for payment.

title: ANTI-SEMITISM CHARGES CLOUD REAGAN NOMINATION
description: The Reagan Administration said today that the nomination of Warren S. Richardson to a ranking post in the Department of Health and Human Services was ''under review'' after allegations of anti-Semitism wer made.

title: Taylor Has Knee Surgery
description: Billy Taylor, the Giants' leading ground gainer the last two seasons, has undergone what a club spokesman described yesterday as ''routine'' minor arthroscope surgery on one of his knees. Afterward, Taylor said he felt fine and that he expected to be ''ready to go'' when the Giants hold their mini-camp at Giants Stadium next month.

title: THEATER: 'HEAT OF RE-ENTRY' LINKS SOVIET JEWS AND SPACE
description: ABRAHAM TETENBAUM'S new play, ''Heat of Re-Entry,'' which opened Wednesday night at the Playwrights Horizons' Capital Theater in the Park in Flushing Meadows Park, Queens, is a space-y play about the Soviet space hero Yuri Gagarin and also about Soviet Jews living in our own Brighton Beach. There is undoubtedly a good play about each of them in mind somewhere, but as a package deal, this one just does not get off the launching pad.

title: Talks About Indians At Audubon Terrace
description: Lectures and slide shows about the Indians of North America will be offered tomorrow at the Museum of the American Indian at Audubon Terrace, Broadway and 155th Street. Dr. Robert W. Venables, curator of American Indian history at the museum, is leading the lecture series, which is being given through the next six Saturdays. The topic tomorrow is ''Cultures in Conflict: Indians in the Spanish Century,'' Part I at 10 A.M., Part II at 2 P.M. Museum admission, $1.50 (75 cents for students and the elderly), includes the price of the lectures.

title: John Sotomayor Shipboard Museum to Drop Anchor in New York Mayor Koch stood in front of a 14-foot scale model of the aircraft carrier Intrepid as he announced that the ship was to become a museum berthed at Pier 86, at West 46th Street. The 900-foot carrier will be converted at a cost of $14 million to the Sea-Air-Space Museum and will include genuine aircraft among its exhibits. Joining the
description: Mayor yesterday were Borough President Andrew J. Stein of Manhattan, left, and Rear Adm. Bruce Newell.

title: The City; 2 Held in Robbery In Diamond District
description: Two New Jersey men face charges of robbery and assault in connection with a holdup attempt in Manhattan's diamond district, the police said.

title: Police Considering Action To Stop Boston Marathon
description: Police officers involved in a labor dispute here threatened yesterday to block the route of Monday's Boston Marathon. But today the head of their union said they would reconsider their plans.

title: EAST GERMANY'S COMMUNISTS, STRESSING DISCIPLINE, RE-ELECT HONECKER
description: At the close today of its six-day congress, the East German Communist Party reinstated Erich Honecker as secretary general and pledged to strengthen the country's ''internationalist role'' at the side of the Soviet Union.

title: YANKS OPTION BROWN
description: In an unexpected development that clears the way for Reggie Jackson to be restored to the roster, the Yankees placed Gene Nelson, their highly regarded right-handed starter, on the 21-day inactive list today, retroactive to April 10.

title: ART: ELLSWORTH KELLY AND RED GROOMS SHOWS
description: Ellsworth Kelly has exhibitions all over New York at this moment. There are paintings at the Leo Castelli Gallery, 142 Greene Street. There are paintings and a sculpture at the Blum Helman Gallery, 20 West 57th Street. There are drawings of plants at Castelli Uptown, 4 East 77th Street. All three shows are wonderful, in their different ways, and as everything on view is dated either 1980 or 1981, we are left in no doubt that Mr. Kelly is in his very best form. The shows at Blum Helman and Castelli Uptown can be seen through May 2, the show at Castelli on Greene Street through May 9.

title: U.S. TO LET DOLLAR MOVE
description: The Treasury Department said today that the Reagan Administration had decided to let the dollar fluctuate more widely in value in foreign exchange trading and would intervene to support it only in emergency situations, such as in the shooting of President Reagan.

title: Advertising; Bell System Brightening Ad Pages
description: BY next year, if you're living in the right town, your fingers will find much more colorful scenery as they journey through the Yellow Pages.

title: STAGE: DICKENS SINGS AGAIN IN 'COPPERFIELD'
description: AFTER sitting through ''Copperfield,'' the new musical at the ANTA, you may seriously question whether its creators have ever actually read their ostensible source material, Charles Dickens's ''David Copperfield.'' You may even question whether they've read the Classics Comics version. But there's one thing you won't question. Al Kasha and Joel Hirschhorn, who wrote this show's book, music and lyrics, have definitely, but definitely, seen lots of hit Broadway musicals.

title: Villanova to Help on Transfers
description: This coming Tuesday was supposed to be the day when spring football practice resumed at Villanova University. Instead, Villanova's coach, Dick Bedesem, will be trying to help some of his players find another school, where they can continue their careers.

title: SHOSTAKOVICH SON TO COME TO U.S.
description: Maksim Shostakovich, the son of the Soviet composer Dmitri Shostakovich, and his son Dmitri will be admitted to the United States as refugees, the State Department said today.

title: SOUTH DAKOTA COURT BACKS STATE IN FIXING A $50 MILLION TAX ERROR
description: Larry Van Emmerick, a 68-year-old retiree from Sioux Falls who lives on Social Security and disability payments, discovered in 1978 that the State Legislature made a mistake when it raised the 3 percent sales tax to 4 percent in 1969.

title: CONCERT: CRUMB'S 'VOICES'
description: THE yawning gap that separates the New York Philharmonic audience from the rest of the musical world becomes particularly clear on those rare occasions when the program contains virtually any work composed in the last 20 or 30 years. An exasperated clucking can be heard on all sides even before the piece begins. And at the first sounds, what a wagging of heads and exchange of looks. No matter how innocuous the work, several grim-faced couples are sure to get up in mid-music and stalk out.

title: Good Friday Closings
description: Stock and commodity markets in the United States and Canada will be closed today in observance of Good Friday.

title: 8 in Corsica Hurt by Bomb Just After Giscard Lands
description: A bomb injured eight people today at Campo Dell'Oro Airport minutes after a plane carrying President Valery Giscard d'Estaing of France landed, the police said. Mr. Giscard later denounced the bombing, saying it ''has scandalized Corsica.''

title: SYLVAN C. COLEMAN OF E.F. HUTTON
description: Sylvan C. Coleman, former chairman of E. F. Hutton & Company Inc. and honorary trustee of the American Museum of Natural History, died Wednesday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Asarco Sets Accord On Sale of Stock
description: Asarco Inc. said it had signed formal agreements with institutional investors covering the previously announced issuance by the company of $140 million of preferred stock.

title: 'LION OF THE DESERT,' BEDOUIN VS. MUSSOLINI
description: Money may not be able to buy happiness, but Moustapha Akkad's ''Lion of the Desert'' demonstrates that money, at least a very great deal of it - reportedly more than $30 million - can buy enough talent, know-how and extras to make a big historical movie that is at least technically respectable and occasionally spectacular in its geography. The film is the biggest piece of movie partisanship to come out of the Middle East or North Africa since Otto Preminger's ''Exodus.''

title: Japanese Warned of Car Quotas
description: Leading members of the Japanese Parliament were told by members of Congress today that Japan would face legislated quotas on auto shipments to the United States, unless their Government cut back on exports.

title: Hazel Bishop Head Attains Goal
description: When Frank S. Berger, 44, resigned two years ago as president of the House of Seagram, the North American marketing arm of Joseph E. Seagram & Sons, he said that he wanted to own his own company. This week he achieved that goal when he acquired a corporation that beginning on Monday will be known as Hazel Bishop Inc.

title: EGYPT CUTS OIL PRICES, JOINING OTHERS
description: Egypt reduced prices yesterday on various grades of oil it exports by $1 to $3 a barrel, retroactive to April 1. It thus joined the ranks of oil-producing nations that have cut prices in response to the current oil glut.

title: About Real Estate; HOME MORTGAGES WITH AN INTEREST RATE THAT CAN CHANGE
description: It will come as no surprise to most home buyers these days that lending institutions are starting to offer alternatives to the fixedrated, long-term mortgage.

title: ORLANDO, Fla., April 16 (AP) -Space officials said yesterday that the space shuttle Columbia's blastoff had done only ''minimal damage'' to launching pad 39A at the Kennedy Space Center.
description: ''Everybody at the pad and at operations is very happy about it,'' said Hugh Harris, a spokesman for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. ''They consider it minor. They expected a lot more damage than that.''

title: The Region; 2 Court Officials Die in Boat Accident
description: NEW HAVEN (AP) - Two Connecticut court officials died after their boat capsized in Long Island Sound, Coast Guard officials said. The victims were 45-year-old James Murphy of Milford and Paul Conroy, 35, of Fairfield, said a spokesman at St. Charles Hospital in Port Jefferson, L.I.

title: A REVISED LIST OF TELEPHONE NUMBERS FOR CANCER TREATMENT CENTERS
description: A list of cancer treatment centers that appeared with the ''Personal Health'' column in The Living Section on Wednesday included telephone numbers for the directors' offices instead of the centers' information services.
