title: Goodyear Profits Decline by 15%
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company said today that first-quarter profits fell 15 percent, to $43.1 million, or 59 cents a share, as a result of a sharp decline in earnings from its foreign operations.

title: Undefeated A's Win 8th in Row, 2 Shy of Record
description: Matt Keough pitched a fivehitter, and Tony Armas doubled in two runs to cap Oakland's three-run sixth inning tonight, pacing the undefeated A's to their eighth consecutive victory, a 5-1 decision over the California Angels.

title: The U.N. Today; April 17, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Special Committee on Enhancing Non- Use of Force in International Relations - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: JAZZ: LOUIS STEWART FROM DUBLIN
description: Louis Stewart, a jazz guitarist from Dublin, is making his first appearance in New York this week at Bechet's, Third Avenue between 75th and 76th Streets, where he is playing in a quartet led by the drummer Bobby Rosengarden.

title: CLIMATE AND CO 2
description: By David M. Burns

title: MEASURES OF CONTROL
description: To the Editor:

title: ART: TWO PAINTERS EXPLORE NEW WAVE
description: NOTHING is more incalculable in art - or more inevitable -than a genuine change in taste. Although taste seems to operate by a sort of law of compensation, so that the denial of certain qualities in one period almost automatically prepares the ground for their triumphal return later, its timetable can never be accurately predicted. Its roots lie in something deeper and more mysterious than mere fashion. At the heart of every genuine change in taste there is, I suppose, a keen feeling of loss, an existential ache - a sense that something absolutely essential to the life of art has been allowed to fall into a state of unendurable atrophy. It is to the immediate repair of this perceived void that taste at its profoundest level addresses itself.

title: 6 AFRICAN LEADERS CRITICIZE ADMINISTRATION POLICIES
description: The Presidents of six black African nations strongly criticized the Reagan Administration's policies in southern Africa today, and the State Department quickly responded.

title: The Pulitzer Lie
description: When a reputable newspaper lies, it poisons the community. Every other newspaper story becomes suspect. Anyone stung by a newspaper story feels emboldened to call it a lie. Facts are not only impugned but made impotent. And the tense constitutional debate about whether a newspaper must reveal its sources is irresponsibly polluted.

title: Notes on People; Oregon, Waiting for 73 Years, Presses U.S. to Pay Debt
description: The Oregon state historian, Cecil Edwards, is a man of persistence, and for years he's been guiding state efforts to dun the United States into paying Oregon a Civil War claim totaling $1.3 million.

title: 8 CANADA PREMIERS OFFER CHARTER PLAN
description: Eight of Canada's 10 provincial Premiers submitted a constitutional plan to Ottawa today that would protect their rights, but the federal Government promptly rejected it.

title: U.S. BUSINESS WON'T FOLLOW REAGAN'S GURU
description: To the Editor:

title: People
description: * Robert G. Pfundstein has been elected executive vice president and chief financial officer of Doyle Dane Bernbach International Inc.

title: BOSTON REACHES THE END OF ITS SCHOOL FUNDS
description: The Boston School Department spent the last of its $210 million annual appropriation today on the eve of a 10-day spring vacation and appeared no closer to a political compromise that would allow the system to reopen for the rest of the school year.

title: Andrus Joins United Solar
description: Cecil D. Andrus, former Secretary of the Interior, has joined the board of directors of United Solar Associates Inc., the company announced today. Mr. Andrus served in President Carter's Administration.

title: TV Weekend; MOYERS ON MYTHS, SALUTE TO ASTAIRE AND 'OMNIBUS'
description: TONIGHT and next Friday at 9 P.M., WNET-TV's ''Bill Moyers' Journal'' offers the kind of conversation that has brought richly deserved distinction to the series. For two hours, Mr. Moyers talks with Joseph Campbell, scholar and author, about the force of myths in human history. The setting is New York's American Museum of Natural History.

title: Boxing Promoter Indicted On Passport Fraud Charge
description: Ross Fields, the boxing promoter also known as Harold J. Smith, was indicted yesterday on a charge of making false statements on a passport application.

title: Dr. Richard Taylor, 94, Public Health Authority
description: Dr. Richard Moreland Taylor, a microbiologist and international authority in the field of public health, died Wednesday in Santa Barbara, Calif., where he lived. He was 94 years old.

title: Special Parking Plates Allowed For the Handicapped Using Vans
description: Handicapped people who drive specially designed vans may now get marker plates qualifying them to park in areas designated for the disabled.

title: 'Patience' on 74th St.
description: The 100th anniversary of ''Patience,'' Gilbert and Sullivan's satire of English estheticism in the 1880's, is being celebrated in a production by the Light Opera of Manhattan at the Eastside Playhouse, 334 East 74th Street.

title: Time Inc. Net Off By 5.3% in Quarter
description: Time Inc. said yesterday that its first-quarter net income fell from a year earlier despite higher earnings from continuing operations.

title: DANCE: 'ARDEN COURT,' TAYLOR SPACE-AGE BALLET
description: EVERY so often the stunningly great performance rolls around. And this time it came from the Paul Taylor Dance Company Wednesday night in the premiere of Mr. Taylor's ''Arden Court'' at the City Center.

title: 'CAVEMAN' WITH RINGO STARR
description: With all due respect to Ringo Starr, the real hero of ''Caveman'' is not a former Beatle, not the film's top-billed actor and not even a person at all. The real star is a special-effects dinosaur, one of several such creatures this cheery, playful movie has to offer. This particular dinosaur rolls his eyes, waggles his tongue, pats his tummy and has a very sweet smile. He doesn't wear himself out being clever, and neither does anyone else concerned with ''Caveman.'' But the movie is nicely whimsical, and elaborate in a way that no fantasy film this side of outer space has lately been. It's dopey, but it's also lots of fun.

title: 3 NEW UNIONS STRIKE AS YONKERS FIREMEN LET BLAZES SMOLDER
description: A strike by Yonkers firefighters that has permitted several blazes to race out of control was joined yesterday by nearly a thousand other city employees, forcing this city of 200,000 residents into a crisis.

title: At the Movies
description: Continis'' in 1971, as well as in such movies as Bertolucci's ''The Conformist'' and ''1900,'' hasn't been seen in America for several years. Now, ''Voyage en Douce,'' made in 1979, has opened at the Lincoln Plaza Cinema 2.

title: Alcoa's Net Down 29.5% in Quarter
description: The Aluminum Company of America reported today that its first-quarter profits totaled $101.2 million, down 29.5 percent from the $143.5 million earned in the first three months of last year, as revenues slipped slightly.

title: BANI-SADAR SAYS FOREIGN MINISTRY USURPS HIS POWER
description: President Abolhassan Bani-Sadr today accused the Iranian Foreign Ministry of usurping his powers and said that he would put the matter before a special commission set up to resolve disputes between Iranian leaders.

title: Books of the Times; Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard THE MIND-MURDERS. By Janwillem van de Wetering. 186 pages. Houghton Mif- flin. $9.95. FREE FALL IN CRIMSON. By John D. MacDonald. 246 pages. Harper & Row. $10.95.

title: N.F.L. Unit Investigating 3-4 Broncos for Drug Use
description: The National Football League's security division is investigating three or four members of the Denver Broncos for possible use of illegal drugs last season, the team announced yesterday.

title: Csonka Reportedly Called In Federal Drug Inquiry
description: Larry Csonka, the former Miami Dolphins fullback, appeared today before a Federal grand jury looking into marijuana smuggling but refused to answer questions on the constitutional grounds that answering them might tend to incriminate him, a television station said.

title: TRADEMARKS ADORNING APPAREL
description: At BMW dealerships, ''ultimate driving machines'' share showroom space with scarves and terry-cloth robes. Jackets and rain slickers overwhelm perfume bottles on department store cosmetics counters. Parka zippers are tagged with Salem's pine tree, and small embroidered camels turn up on sports shirts.

title: HAIG EXPECTS TALKS WITH RUSSIANS SOON ON EUROPE'S MISSLES
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said today that he expected the United States to hold preliminary talks with the Soviet Union soon on resuming negotiations to limit each side's nuclear weapons in Europe.

title: EDGY SENIORS AWAIT NEWS FROM COLLEGES
description: These are tense days at Roslyn High School as months of waiting come to an end and mountains of hope either crumble or rise as a result of a single envelope.

title: Soviet Said to Arrest Ukrainian
description: Soviet dissident sources said today that a Ukrainian lawyer who monitored Soviet compliance with human rights aspects of the 1975 Helsinki accords had been arrested. The dissident, Ivan Kandyba, was taken into custody March 24 in Pustomyny, a Ukrainian town near Lvov, according to the sources. He was arrested in 1961 for discussing Ukrainian secession from the Soviet Union and served five years.

title: Broadway; Ragged Dick to try for riches on the stage next fall.
description: RAGGED DICK, one of Horatio Alger Jr.'s typically heroic characters, who worked his way from rags to riches, will come to life on Broadway next fall in the new musical ''Shine.'' The show is the work of Richard Seff and Richard Altman, the book writers, Roger Anderson, the composer, and Lee Goldsmith, the lyricist. ''Shine'' is scheduled to go into rehearsal July 1 and try out in Philadelphia starting Aug. 17 at the Forrest Theater, with Broadway to follow.

title: Usage of Gasoline in U.S.  At 10-Year Low in March
description: United States gasoline consumption dropped sharply last month to the lowest point for any March in 10 years and, in a reversal of normal seasonal patterns, consumption was even lower than in February, the American Petroleum Institute reported today.

title: HUMANA' REPUTATION WORRIES TARGETS
description: Humana Inc., the giant Louisville, Ky., health care company that has grown rapidly in recent years through acquisitions, has a reputation for dismissing the management of companies it takes over. ''Humana takes no prisoners'' has become a widespread comment among industry competitors and analysts.

title: To Fight Crime, Fight Drugs
description: President Reagan says he wants to fight street crime, and Attorney General William French Smith has set a task force to work on the problem. But since the mugger in Chicago and the burglar in Newark operate well beyond the reach of any Federal law, Washington's role in such a fight is far from obvious - as F.B.I. Director William Webster acknowledged yesterday at the task force's first public hearing.

title: Police Work for El Salvador
description: A beam of light is finally falling on the terror and lawlessness that darken El Salvador. Effective police work has led to the arrest of two suspects in the January murder of Jose Rodolfo Viera, the director of the nation's land reform institute, and two American labor advisers, Michael Hammer and Mark Pearlman.

title: Patients Flee Bomb Threat
description: A bomb threat telephoned to St. Joseph's Hospital forced the evacuation of 31 patients last night, including three infants and some who were critically ill.

title: BankAmerica Off; Manufacturers Up
description: The BankAmerica Corporation reported yesterday that its firstquarter earnings were battered by high and sharply fluctuating interest rates.

title: HARPER WOODWARD, LAWYER, IS DEAD
description: Harper Woodward, a lawyer and business associate of Laurance S. Rockefeller for 34 years and an adviser to the Rockefeller family, died of cancer Wednesday at the Connecticut Hospital in Branford. Mr. Woodward, a longtime resident of Rye, N.Y., had most recently been living in Essex, Conn. He was 71 years old.

title: 9 MINERS DEAD AFTER EXPLOSION IN WESTERN SHAFT
description: Rescue workers early today found the bodies of nine of the 15 coal miners who had been trapped deep within the earth after an explosion Wednesday afternoon, the Pitkin County sheriff's department said.

title: Jazz at the Public
description: Amina Claudine Myers, jazz composer and performer, will perform her own works, along with the eight-member Voice Choir, tonight at 11 in the New York Shakespeare Festival Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street.

title: 'GOING APE,' TALE OF AN INHERITANCE
description: CAST three orangutans as the stars of your movie, and haven't you pretty well got it made? The orangutans will spit and gibber and bare their brown teeth, and your human players will look amusingly straightlaced by comparison. This ought to be a natural - but it isn't, as ''Going Ape'' unfortunately demonstrates. The apes should speak to their agent. They need a better property next time.

title: Economic Scene; Skepticism And Inflation
description: DOES anybody know how to stop inflation painlessly? The answer is no, according to the Group of Thirty. This group of leading economic thinkers is headed by H. Johannes Witteveen, former managing director of the International Monetary Fund. The members include such prominent figures as Otmar Emminger of West Germany, Alexandre Lamfalussy of the Bank for International Settlements, Henry C. Wallich of the Federal Reserve Board, Robert V. Roosa of Brown Brothers Harriman and Marina v.N. Whitman of the General Motors Corporation.

title: THEATER: BRECHT'S 'JUNGLE OF CITIES' IN BROOKLYN
description: Bertolt Brecht's ''Jungle of Cities'' offers a strange, chaotic view of humanity in isolation. Eschewing psychology in favor of philosophy, the play is one of Brecht's most difficult works. David Jones's BAM Theater Company production, which opened last night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, does not tie together the play's disparate elements, but it does take a serious, sometimes enlightening approach to a nightmarish subject.

title: SULAIMAN: BRENNER AVOIDED A MEETING
description: Jose Sulaiman, the president of the World Boxing Council, testified in his defense yesterday that he tried to arrange meetings with Teddy Brenner to avoid the promoter's subsequent suspension by the W.B.C. but that Brenner ignored the efforts.

title: PUBLISHING: ORWELL'S SIMPLE SECRET
description: GEORGE ORWELL has been dead for 31 years, yet in many countries his books are more popular today than ever. ''He's very widely read in Italian, German and Spanish translations, and there are thousands of Japanese Orwellians,'' said Bernard Crick, author of ''George Orwell'' (Atlantic-Little, Brown), the recent biography about the essayist, novelist and social critic.

title: Filipino Priest Slain in Monastery
description: Five heavily armed men forced their way into a monastery in the southern Philippines last night and shot and killed a Roman Catholic priest known as a critic of the local military, the authorities said today. The priest,the Rev. Godofredo Alingal, a Jesuit, was a witness last year in a rape case involving the military and was a critic of Government irregularities.

title: The Namibian Test
description: The impression has spread around black Africa, prematurely, that the Reagan Administration has tilted the U.S. toward indulgence of South Africa's status quo demands, both on its own territory and for continued control of Namibia.

title: MERCK NET RISES 10.4% IN QUARTER
description: Merck & Company Inc., a leading pharmaceuticals and chemical company based in Rahway, N.J., reported yesterday that earnings in the first quarter of 1981 increased by 10.4 percent on a sales gain of 10.7 percent.

title: Santa Anita Dispute Ends
description: A one-day boycott of racing at Santa Anita ended today when horsemen accepted the racing association's proposals, a track spokesman said. Racing will resume tomorrow.

title: T.W.A., Braniff Report Losses
description: The Braniff International Corporation yesterday reported a $23.6 million loss for the first quarter, despite an operating profit of $454,000. The Trans World Corporation, parent of Trans World Airlines, reported a $57.5 million loss for the same period.

title: AFTER 80 YEARS, PUBLISHER PLANS UNCUT 'SISTER CARRIE'
description: Theodore Dreiser's ''Sister Carrie,'' one of the landmark American novels of the 20th century, is being published for the first time just as the author wrote it 80 years ago - with the restoration of 36,000 words that had been cut out of the original manuscript. By the standards of the early 1900's - in the censorial eyes of his wife, editors and publisher - Dreiser's book was considered too sexually explicit, too rough in its language and too pessimistic in its philosophy.

title: Notes on People; An Elephant and Taxes
description: Why would a Republican Senator use the party symbol to dramatize the burden of income taxes? Because of the possibilities of pachydermic puns. That, at least, seemed to be the case on Wednesday when Senator William J. Roth Jr. of Delaware held a joint news conference with an elephant.

title: Exxon and Avondale Sign Tanker Deal
description: Exxon U.S.A. said it had signed a contract with Avondale Shipyards of New Orleans, a unit of the Ogden Corporation, to build three 43,000-deadweight-ton tankers at an estimated cost of about $100 million each.

title: CORRECTION
description: A list of cancer treatment centers in The Living Section on Wednesday in- cluded telephone numbers for the di- rectors' offices, rather than for the cen- ters' information services. A revised list appears on page B5.

title: 'Roadside Folk Art' Show
description: Photographs of painted signs, as well as actual signs, are included in ''Contemporary Roadside Folk Art,'' an exhibition by Nina Howell Starr, on display through May 16 at the Robert Freidus Gallery, 158 Lafayette Street.

title: Soviet Astronaut Shows Concern About Military Role of Spaceship
description: Maj. Gen. Aleksei A. Leonov of the Soviet Air Force, the first astronaut to ''walk'' in space, today said that this week's mission of the space shuttle Columbia was a major technical success but was financially wasteful and dangerous. He also said he was alarmed by official American statements that the mission was intended for military as well as civilian purposes.

title: Yonkers; Geography
description: The city's 18 square miles, overlooking the New Jersey Palisades, lie between the Hudson and Bronx Rivers. The borough of the Bronx is on its southern border; to the north is the Town of Greenburgh; to the east are Mount Vernon, Bronxville, Tuckahoe and Crestwood. Yonkers, a geographically divided city, has its own elegant suburbs east of the Saw Mill River, as well as the nation's first regional shopping center, Cross County. In the west are the industrial areas and the aging downtown, centered on Getty Square. Points of special interest are Philipse Manor Hall and Sarah Lawrence College, which has an 18-acre campus just west of the

title: HEIMANN STEPPING DOWN AS COMPTROLLER MAY 15
description: The Comptroller of the Currency, John G. Heimann, said yesterday that he had submitted his resignation to President Reagan, effective May 15. His term was to have run through July 1982, although rumors have circulated for more than a year that Mr. Heimann was going to leave.

title: Fluor Tender Offer
description: The Fluor Corporation announced that its tender offer for up to 20.4 million common shares of the St. Joe Minerals Corporation at $60 a share had been oversubscribed. Fluor said preliminary information indicated that about 26.3 million shares had been tendered or guaranteed for tender. It noted that this number of shares would indicate a pro-rata acceptance of 78 percent of the total tendered.

title: Notes on People; The Bills Kept Piling Up, All 2,500 of Them
description: All the family of George Blagnon of Yonkers owes Blue Cross-Blue Shield of Greater New York is a $183 premium. So it would seem, given what's happened to the Blagnons in the past 10 days, that the health-insurance company has been overzealous in its determination to collect the bill.

title: SOCIAL SERVICES' ROLE IN HOUSING COURT
description: To the Editor:

title: TRUSTING TRUSTEES
description: Are trustees trustworthy? Critics of colleges and corporate boards don't think so. The consumer advocate Ralph Nader and the public-interest lawyer Mark Green have long argued that giant corporations are tantamount to private governments and become a law into themselves. Both have called for legislation mandating not only that a majority of all corporate directors come from outside the company but also that those members represent specific constituency groups: for example, consumers, minorities, local communities, environmental interests.

title: Dulcolax Campaign Assigned to Grey
description: Dulcolax, a laxative available over the counter in this country for the last decade, is going to get its first consumer advertising - including network and spot television - from Grey Advertising, which just got the assignment. The billings could come to more than $2 million.

title: Texas Instruments Earnings Off 32%
description: Texas Instruments Inc., citing severe price declines in semiconductors and lagging demand for calculators and other consumer products, reported a 32 percent drop in earnings for the first quarter of 1981.

title: SOUTH AFRICA SEIZES TUTU'S PASSPORT
description: Two security policemen in plainclothes called at the residence of Bishop Desmond Tutu in the black township of Soweto this evening and presented him with an order to surrender his passport.

title: BOTHA HOLDS REAGAN AIDE LIABLE FOR SOUTH AFRICANS' CANCELED U.S.  VISIT
description: Prime Minister P.W. Botha said in an interview published today that he had ''certain reservations'' about the Reagan Administration's top Africa specialist, blaming him for objections raised in Washington last month to a visit by South African military officers.

title: 'THE CITY FORCED ME OUT,' STRIKING FIREMAN ASSERTS
description: ''Nobody wants this strike,'' Lieut. Warren Martin, one of this city's striking firefighters, said today as he leaned his six-foot frame against an idle fire engine at headquarters a few blocks from City Hall.

title: TO UTOPIA BY BUS AND SUBWAY
description: HOUSING in and around New York City can be described in many ways, but rarely as generous and even more rarely as idealistic. Most housing in the metropolitan area, from single-family houses in the suburbs to apartments in the center of Manhattan, was built for profit, and it tends all too frequently to be mean in its space and conservative in its design. This may be a city of innovative ideas, but one would not know it from the places in which we live because so few of them involve even the slightest degree of experimentation or adventure in design. When it comes to building lots of housing units, we seem like a city and a region of formulas, not of creativity.

title: GOULD SET TO SELL INDUSTRIAL GROUP
description: Gould Inc. announced yesterday that it had signed a letter of intent to sell its industrial group to the Reading Company for about $380 million, subject to adjustments. Reading would also assume certain liabilities of the industrial group.

title: Pop Jazz; ASTRUD GILBERTO BACK WITH A '3D LIFE'
description: SUPERFICIALLY, Astrud Gilberto still seems to be the shy, wistful fawn who first sang ''The Girl From Ipanema'' on records almost 20 years ago, a recording that sold more than 27 million copies and helped introduce bossa nova to the world beyond Brazil, where the music originated.

title: BENNY CARTER IS AT SWEET BASIL
description: IT has been Benny Carter's fate to be in the top rank in the jazz world in several areas - as an alto saxophonist, a big-band leader and an arranger - but to have proper recognition elude him. He was a model for many alto saxophonists in the 30's, yet he was not as well known as Johnny Hodges or, later, Charlie Parker.

title: 25,000 ON L.I.R.R. LINE DELAYED BY DERAILMENT LINKED TO VANDALS
description: Four cars of a Long Island Rail Road train with 150 riders aboard derailed outside the Cold Spring Harbor station yesterday afternoon after vandals apparently pried open a track switch, according to an L.I.R.R. spokesman.

title: Repayment by LaRouche Sought
description: Auditors from the Federal Election Commission are seeking repayment of more than $100,000 in Federal funds from the election committee of Lyndon H. LaRouche. According to the commission, Citizens for LaRouche received overpayments of Federal funds and should return $110,618.53 to the Treasury. Mr. LaRouche sought the Democratic nomination for President last year.

title: Gamble-Skogmo, Garfinckel Talks
description: Gamble-Skogmo Inc., a diversified retailer and financial services company, said it had notified the Securities and Exchange Commission that it has been negotiating with Garfinckel, Brooks Brothers, Miller & Rhoads Inc., the retail chain based in Washington, D.C., on the possibility of Garfinckel's buying back 927,175 of its common shares held by Gamble.

title: Dow Pushes Up 3.87; Nasdaq Sets Record
description: The stock market forged ahead yesterday in spirited pre-Easter trading. Several issues posted substantial gains as they climbed to record prices.

title: Weekender Guide; Friday; ART OF THE BOOK IN TRIBECA
description: Books and periodicals that are the work of artists and that have had an influence on the art world of the last decade will go on view tonight at 6 at the Franklin Furnace, 112 Franklin Street, in the TriBeCa section (the triangle below Canal Street). The exhibition, ''The Page as Alternative Space, 1970-80,'' includes a book by Sol LeWitt that explores combinations of arcs, circles and grids. Another book, by John Baldessari, consists of photographs from television, each with a one-word caption. Its pages pull out accordion-style, so that the captions form a sentence. There are also collaborative magazines that use graphics and typography in unusual ways. Admission is free. RAMA IN DANCE ON FOURTH ST.

title: Market Place; Reade Plan To Convert Its Shares
description: THE Walter Reade Organization, the operator of movie houses in New York whose stock was once a popular growth issue, may emerge from reorganization soon, if the shareholders are willing. On Tuesday, shareholders attending the annual meeting at Reade's 34th Street East Theatre will be asked to vote on the reorganization plan.

title: Ray-O-Vac to Stay
description: The Ray-O-Vac Corporation, which had earlier announced plans to move out of Lancaster, Ohio, has decided instead to build a new $13.2 million plant there.

title: BONN BRACES FOR VIOLENCE AS LEFTIST HUNGER STRIKE DIES
description: A convicted terrorist died today after refusing food for more than 10 weeks, leading the police to express concern about the possibility of a serious wave of terrorist violence in the country for the first time since 1977.

title: Miss Dudek, Floridian, Wins One-Meter Diving
description: Diane Dudek of Largo (Fla.) Diving won her first national title today, capturing the women's one-meter springboard finals in the 1981 U.S. indoor diving championships at Ohio State University.

title: PALACE FIGHTS TIDAL WAVE OF ROYAL WEDDING KITSCH
description: Is it beneath the royal dignity to have the faces of Prince Charles and Lady Diana Spencer peering out from souvenir T-shirts?

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Yonkers firemen prevented them from taking the hoses off their trucks.

title: Coach Ousted for Giving Injured Students DMSO
description: The Baker School Board says it has dismissed its high school physical education teacher from his head football coaching duties, partly because he treated players with DMSO.

title: DANCE: ZERO MOVING OF PHILADELPHIA
description: THERE'S nothing quite like the Zero Moving Dance Company, which appeared Wednesday night at the Theater of the Riverside Church. Its home is Philadelphia, but its heart may be in Germany.

title: PATIENT IOWANS AWAIT U.S. TURNAROUND
description: Cedar Rapids is waiting, patiently and hopefully for the most part, for something good to happen to the economy.

title: Israel Outlaws Arab Group That Supports the P.L.O.
description: The Israeli Government announced today that it had outlawed an umbrella organization of Israeli Arab leaders called the ''national coordinating committee'' because of its professed support of the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: 2 GUNMEN FLEE
description: Two police officers sitting in a patrol car were gravely wounded yesterday morning by two armed men who leaped out of a van the officers had stopped and fired 30 shots directly at them on a quiet residential street in St. Albans, Queens.

title: Algeria to Cut Gas Output
description: Algeria will limit its production of liquefied natural gas to about 95 billion cubic feet a year, the Algerian Ambassador to Belgium, Adriss Jazairy, said today. He told a meeting of the Belgian-African Chamber of Commerce that interested countries would get a share of the gas on a ''first come, first served'' basis. The low price of gas has forced exporting countries to cut back production by 300 billion cubic feet a year, equivalent in energy terms to Libya's oil production, he added.

title: The Region; Con Ed Identifies Indian Point Leak
description: A leaking tube carrying radioactive water from the Indian Point 2 atomic power reactor was identified by Consolidated Edison as the initial source of a spill outside the plant April 8.

title: Mr.  Reagan's Choice
description: Gun control is probably the most hopeless cause in American politics. Countering street violence, on the other hand, is a matter of growing concern to millions of liberals and conservatives alike. Just yesterday, Attorney General Smith's Task Force on Violent Crime held its first meeting.

title: Gunmen in Ulster Kill A Protestant Militant
description: Gunmen walked into a bar in a frontier town tonight, singled out a prominent Protestant militant and shot him to death.

title: DEOCORATIVE ARTS: MET SHOWS AMERICAN RICHES
description: splashed array of silver sauce boats, pewter tankards, ceramic jugs and iridescent glass vases from the 17th to the early 20th century dramatizes the new decorative-arts galleries opening today on the balcony of the American Wing at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The galleries are the most recent to be completed in what has been described as the single most important permanent museum facility of American art, marking the end of Phase I for the mammoth glass-enclosed wing. Still to be unveiled are seven rooms, three galleries and the study-storage areas, each of which will be opened as they are finished next year or later.

title: SPAIN'S ROAD TO A COUP
description: In his dramatic display of authority, King Juan Carlos boldly rescued Spanish democracy from the hands of putschist generals and a Civil Guard unit that stormed the Parliament on Feb. 23, but with a little help from the new Prime Minister, Leopoldo Calvo Sotelo, he may yet bring on another coup attempt.

title: RHYS CHATHAM: CLASSICAL ROAD TO ROCK
description: Rock and classical music used to be regarded as polar opposities. But in lower Manhattan, the boundaries are blurred, with a group of young composers coming from a classical background but presenting music with rock instrumentation in rock clubs, and an allied group, blending with the first, of rock performers with overtly artistic aspirations.

title: MARSHALL LEADS PLAINFIELD IN 1,600-METER RELAY MARK
description: - Plainfield, with John Marshall turning in a 47.7-second anchor 400-meter leg, set a meet record today in the 1,600-meter relayas the seventh annual Rutgers Relays opened its three-day program with high school events.

title: Flyers Defeat Flames
description: Paul Holmgren scored two goals and Rick St. Croix turned in his first shutout in the Stanley Cup playoffs, leading the Philadelphia Flyers to a 4-0 victory tonight over the Calgary Flames in the opening game of their quarterfinal series.

title: Suits Against Nigeria Upheld
description: A Federal appeals court ruled yesterday that Nigeria could not use ''sovereign immunity'' to avoid lawsuits by American companies seeking millions of dollars in a major dispute over cement contracts.

title: CONSTRUCTION OF SECOND SPACE SHUTTLE IS ON SCHEDULE FOR 1982 DELIVERY, CONTRACTOR SAYS
description: Another space shuttle, set to fly a year or so after the Columbia's test missions, stands amid scaffolding in a huge assembly hangar here and, according to the contractor, should be ready for delivery to the space agency in June 1982.

title: Reynolds Up 2.4%; Burlington Dips 7.7%
description: R.J. Reynolds Industries, the nation's leading producer of cigarettes, reported yesterday that earnings in the first quarter moved up 2.4 percent on a sales increase of 14.9 percent.

title: Argonauts Waive Metcalf
description: Terry Metcalf, the running back, has become a free agent after being released by the Toronto Argonauts and clearing Canadian Football League waivers last night.

title: SOVIET BLOCKS PROPOSAL TO SEND A U.N. AIDE TO EASE BEIRUT'S CRISIS
description: The Soviet Union today blocked a French and American plan to appoint a special United Nations representative in Lebanon charged with easing the crisis there.

title: FOUR JUDGES TAKE THE STAND AS WITNESSES FOR MARGIOTTA
description: Four high-ranking judges testified today as character witnesses for Joseph M. Margiotta despite objections by United States Attorney Edward R. Korman that the testimony could prejudice the jury.

title: A FINAL RING FOR JOE LOUIS
description: On a platform in the shape of a boxing ring, the body of Joe Louis was displayed today. The worlds of sport and gambling and expensive leisure were only a few yards from the ceremonial ring and the flowers and the Air Force guard and the thin line of visitors paying their respects to Louis, the former heavyweight champion, who died Sunday at the age of 66 and who will be buried at Arlington National Cemetery next Tuesday.

title: SEDER BRINGS WARMTH AND A BIT OF HUMOR TO PATIENTS
description: ''There's a thief in the house!'' the rabbi shouted, ''There's a ganef!'' A giggle. A chortle. A smile in the back row. And Rabbi Leonard W. Stern dutifully scanned the faces of the 30 hospital patients for the culprit, the one who made off with the matzoh, and who, according to the a tradition of the Passover seder, had the right to claim a prize for its return.

title: DeBeers to Promote Anniversary Rings
description: Ayer's biggest client in Canada has been DeBeers Consolidated Mines and that leads right into another item. The diamond people in the United States next month will begin a new sales promotion gimmick: the Diamond Anniversary Ring.

title: POLISH PANEL RECOMMENDS FARM UNION
description: The state television said tonight that a parliamentary commission had recommended legislation to permit private farmers to form an independent union.

title: Family Drama at La Mama
description: ''Flowers and Household Gods,'' a play by Momoko Iko, will be presented by the Pan Asian Repertory Theater through May 3 at La Mama E.T.C., 74A East Fourth Street.

title: BUDGET DISPUTED
description: President Reagan strolled in the Rose Garden today for the first time since his release from the hospital as his budget director led an attack against a Congressional study alleging that Mr. Reagan's economic plan would harm more than eight million low-income families.

title: FINANCING AND SALES PROBLEMS AT ADVENT
description: The Advent Corporation, the New Hampshire-based manufacturer of stereo components and large-screen television projectors, has built a solid reputation for producing quality components in its 14 years of operation.

title: COMSAT REGISTERS GAIN
description: The Inland Steel Company, a major steel producer with a strong position in large Middle Western markets, reported yesterday that higher labor and energy costs had contributed to a 20.1 percent decline in earnings in the first quarter, despite a 5.4 percent rise in sales.

title: Rejection of Arms Sale to Saudis Would Hurt Relations, Haig Says
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said today that if Congress rejected a Reagan Administration arms package for Saudi Arabia it would be ''a grievous setback in American relationships'' with the Saudis.

title: SEARCH WIDENED FOR 2 WHO SHOT 2 POLICE OFFICERS
description: Scores of detectives sought clues, pursued leads and searched for witnesses, a getaway car and the owner of an abandoned van yesterday in a widening hunt for two gunmen who wounded two police officers in an unprovoked barrage of gunfire on a Queens street Thursday.

title: Closing Arguments Heard In 2d Phase of Kush Case
description: The former Arizona State University football coach Frank Kush used ''calculated methods of physical and verbal abuse'' to persuade the punter Kevin Rutledge to quit the team in 1979, Rutledge's attorney, Robert Hing, argued today in the closing of his case.

title: JUDGE SETS JUNE DEADLINE IN I.B.M. ANTITRUST TRIAL
description: The judge presiding over the Federal Government's antitrust case against the International Business Machines Corporation set a June 1 deadline yesterday for the six-year-old trial to end.

title: Notes on People; New York Writer Getting PEN/Faulkner Award
description: The first annual PEN/Faulkner Award for fiction will be presented today to Walter Abish, a Vienna-born writer who now lives in New York and lectures at Columbia University.

title: CHILDREN'S VACATION ACTIVITIES
description: W ORKING parents who are frantically combing the city for baby sitters to care for their children during the spring holiday may be interested in recreational programs offered by the Bank Street School, the 92d Street Y and the Walden School in Manhattan.

title: LIGHT OPERA: 'PATIENCE'
description: The poet Reginald Bunthorne, an esthete with ethereal tastes, was exaltedly yearning once again for life's great Indefinables last Wednesday night, as ''Patience'' began a 12-day run at the Light Opera of Manhattan, celebrating the centennial of the Gilbert and Sullivan operetta.

title: DR. KOOP'S TALENTS
description: To the Editor:

title: Trevino Is Leader by 2 on 67-134
description: Lee Trevino posted birdies on two of the last three holes today for his second 67 and a two-stroke lead in the $300,000 MONY-Tournament of Champions.

title: STANHOUSE IS CUT BY THE DODGERS
description: The Los Angeles Dodgers announced today that they had placed Don Stanhouse on irrevocable waivers for the purpose of giving him his unconditional release.

title: 13 YEARS LATER, BEAMON'S JUMP ENDURES
description: Bob Beamon still savors the satisfaction of his astonishing world record in the long jump. ''I enjoying listening to the way people talk to me about it,'' Beamon said, recounting his leap of 29 feet 2 1/2 inches at the 1968 Mexico City Olympic Games that still ranks among the best achievments in any sport. ''Years ago, it was fresh in people's minds. Now, it will go inside but won't penetrate until one or two minutes later. Then someone will say, 'yeah, that was something.' I love it. I enjoy being a retired world record-holder. The longer it stands, the better I feel.''

title: News Analysis
description: A basic change in the attitude of the United States toward Israeli military action in Lebanon appears to have given a new flexibility to Israel's Army and Air Force, which have been busy recently with air strikes and ground assaults against Palestinian guerrilla bases in Lebanese territory.

title: 3 Vessels Fired At Near Struck Plant
description: A sniper opened fire on three vessels as they moved south on the Hudson River near Albany, the police said. Three shots were fired at two tugboats and an oil barge that had just loaded cargo at the Cibro Petroleum plant in Albany, which has been open despite a strike.

title: Reagan Names 3 To Iran Tribunal
description: President Reagan, acting under the terms of the agreement that won freedom for 52 American hostages in Iran, today appointed three members to the Iran-United States Claims Tribunal.

title: Saturday News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 26.

title: FINDING FASHIONS THROUGH THE MAILS
description: Uf918 By ANNE-MARIE SCHIRO

title: NEWARK MAYOR READY FOR RACE FOR GOVERNOR
description: Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson peered intently at a television monitor in a room in City Hall. Four Gibson-for-Governor commercials flashed across the screen. The strains of ''America the Beautiful,'' sung gospel-music style by Newark's own Cissie Houston, sounded in the background of each 30-second advertisement.

title: New Analysis; REAGAN IS NOT KILLING ENVIROMENTAL COUNCIL, BUT SOME FEAR HE IS CRIPPLING IT
description: Although it was spared the executioner's ax, the Council on Environmental Quality, the President's adviser on environmental issues, is being reduced to a fraction of its former size by the Reagan Administration.

title: MRS. THATCHER FIRM WITH INDIAN CRITICS
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher insisted today that Britain had the right to determine criteria for citizenship and that Pakistan had the right to buy arms.

title: Wood Favorite Is Giving Whiteley Touch of Blues
description: If one can believe David Whiteley, he may as well keep Highland Blade in the barn today. ''When you got a horse with the class and speed of Cure the Blues, there's nobody who can catch him,'' the 37-year-old trainer said of the favorite in the 57th running of the Wood Memorial Stakes at Aqueduct, the final New York prep for the Kentucky Derby. ''I don't believe anybody can catch him anywhere.''

title: CLASSMATE, 13, IS ARRESTED
description: A 13-year-old boy was fatally stabbed last night during an argument with a classmate, also 13, who was later charged with the murder.

title: FEDERAL JUDGE BLOCKS PLANS TO END LOS ANGELES BUSING
description: In a decision that stunned school officials here, a Federal judge today blocked plans by the Los Angeles Unified School District to end a mandatory program of busing for integration on Monday morning.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We expect full resumption of all normal city services as of right now.'' -Homer LaRue, a state mediator, in Yonkers. (1:4.)

title: REAGAN RESUMES HIS EFFORTS ON ECONOMIC MEASURES
description: President Reagan began preparations today to rejoin the fight to win Congressional passage for his economic recovery program.

title: Lay Teachers' Group Breaks From Union
description: The Federation of Catholic Teachers announced that it had severed its affiliation with the American Federation of Teachers because of differences over Government aid to nonpublic and parochial schools.

title: SATURDAY, APRIL 18, 1981; The Economy
description: The nation's basic money supply rose $4.8 billion in the week ended April 8, the Federal Reserve announced. The unexpectedly large increase, double what had been expected, could lead to a rise in short-term interest rates next week, analysts said. (Page 27.)

title: FATHER, PART-TIME
description: Under a pile of bills and advertisements for lectures on worthy subjects, I find notes left over from the last visit that my two kids made to my otherwise bachelor apartment.

title: Arts, Letters Group To Honor Hirschfeld
description: Al Hirschfeld, the artist, will be the honored guest at the art career awards dinner of the National Society of Arts and Letters, Empire State Chapter, next Friday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

title: Around the World; 1,000 Iranian Leftists Hold Rally Despite Regime's Ban
description: More than 1,000 leftists defied a Government ban on political meetings and held a rally today commemorating nine leftists executed during the Shah's rule.

title: POST EDITORS TELL OF EFFORTS TO VERIFY FICTITIOUS ARTICLE
description: Several weeks after the initial furor over Janet Cooke's article about an 8-year-old heroin addict had died down, senior editors at The Washington Post still had enough doubts about the veracity of the article that the city editor arranged with Miss Cooke to visit the boy's home with her.

title: Toll in Grain Elevator Blasts at 7
description: A seventh victim of a series of grain elevator explosions died today from the burns he suffered in the blasts. A spokesman for Memorial Hospital said Donnie Otwell, 43 years old, an elevator employee, died this morning.

title: Staub Seeking Good New Days
description: Alex Trevino, the Mets' 23-year-old catcher, sidled up to Rusty Staub near the batting cage the other day, and, with a touch of veneration in his voice, asked Staub how Shea Stadium had changed since Staub played there as a Met in 1975.

title: BABE WHO? LOU WHO?
description: The start of a new baseball season is supposed to be a moment of hope and joy. This year, however, there was only bitterness as I drove out to see the New Jersey Yankees at their new Meadowlands Stadium. I don't think I can ever become accustomed to that strange name - New Jersey Yankees - and an unfamiliar stadium built on a Jersey swamp, with no sense of history or character.

title: Textron Sells 3 Units
description: Textron Inc. said it had completed the sale of three of its units to Nucon Holdings Inc. for $66 million. Included in the sale were the Burkart polyurethane and foam unit of the Burkart Randall division and the conglomerate's Talon and Willco divisions, which make zippers and hearing-aids, respectively.

title: POLISH FARMERS WIN AUTHORITY TO FORM INDEPENDENT UNION
description: The Government acceded today to the demands of Polish farmers to create an independent union. Members of the union, Rural Solidarity, and Government representatives signed an agreement to permit the organization to come into being officially by May 10. The union will be open to the country's 3.5 million private farmers and will have the organizational structure of Solidarity, the union that now represents virtually all of Poland's industrial and office workers.

title: DANCE: ELISA MONTE AND TROUPE IN NEW 'TREADING'
description: Elisa Monte, a principal dancer with the Martha Graham Dance Company, stands out in that company for her intense dramatic presence and keenness of attack. And on the evidence of a performance by Elisa Monte and Dancers on Tuesday in the Dance Umbrella festival at City Center's the Space, Miss Monte is as fine a company manager as she is a dancer. Her young performers are well-trained, though with the exception of David Brown they lack her presence. And Miss Monte has a clear sense of what is of interest in new modern dance. Interestingly enough, however, it was Miss Monte herself, the leastknown choreographic name on the bill, who stole the show.

title: New Railroad Inflation Index
description: The Interstate Commerce Commission today adopted a new inflation index to replace existing procedures used for industrywide and individual railroad rate increases.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch from Manchester, N.H., about monastic life, published on March 23, quoted two young monks as saying that on a visit to Gethsemani Abbey in Trappist, Ky., they had observed ''everyone in business suits.'' According to the Right Rev. Timothy Kelly, abbot of Gethsemani, monks at his abbey usually wear a traditional white robe and black scapular, and for the major hours of community prayer a full-length white cowl.

title: IN FRANCE'S JOB-POOR POCKETS, MITTERRAND'S RUNNING HARD
description: Cheap wine once made Beziers rich; more recently it has impoverished it. A graceful, shabby southern town in need of paint and jobs, it is taking the general depression of the times particularly hard because its over-produced red is steadily losing out to cheaper wines from Italy and Spain.

title: INTENSE WATCH BEING KEPT ON TV PROGRAM CONTENT
description: Intensive monitoring of prime-time television by organizations concerned primarily about sex and violence may be at an all-time high.

title: Franklin Enters Not Guilty Plea
description: Joseph Paul Franklin, an avowed racist, pleaded not guilty today to two first-degree murder charges in the sniper slayings of two black joggers here. Mr. Franklin is accused of shooting Ted Fields, 20, and David Martin, 18, last Aug. 20 as they jogged with two white women near Liberty Park in Salt Lake City.

title: Bridge: Doubling Bid for Suit Slam Could Be a Drastic Mistake
description: If your opponents bid confidently to a suit slam and your trump holding suggests that they will fail, there are several good reasons for not doubling, or even contemplating a double.

title: News Summary; SATURDAY, APRIL 18, 1981
description: International An independent farmers's union was approved by the Polish Government, which thereby gave direct control over almost all areas of industrial and agrarian productivity in Poland to independent labor organizations outside the Communist Party. The new union, Rural Solidarity, will be given official status May 10. (Page 1, Column 6.) Proposed American aid to Pakistan caused sharp disagreement between Indian and American officials in Washington. India regards Pakistan as a threat to its security. Indian and American officials said that Eric Gonsalves, the senior career official in India's Foreign Ministry, expressed India's deep concern over the Administration's plans to provide military aid to Pakistan, as part of of a $1 billion assistance program that would also give economic aid, at a meeting with Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. and other American officials. (1:5.)

title: BREZHNEV HINTS HE WANTS TALKS ON SPACE ARMS CURBS
description: Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, implied today that the Soviet Union was ready to resume negotiations with the United States on banning military activity in outer space.

title: SYRIANS ALLOW FOOD INTO BESIEGED CITY IN LEBANON
description: Syrian forces that have been besieging the Lebanese Christian city of Zahle for 17 days allowed a convoy of four trucks to enter today with 40 tons of flour, other food supplies and medicines.

title: Notes on People; Mounties File Drug Charge Against Sterling Hayden
description: Sterling Hayden, the actor and sometime novelist, has been charged by the Royal Canadian Mounted Police with illegal possession of more than an ounce of hashish.

title: COURT STRIKES DOWN LAW ON DETENTION OF JUVENILES
description: A law permitting New York Family Courts to hold juveniles for up to five days without a fact-finding hearing was declared unconstitutional yesterday by a Federal judge in Manhattan.

title: Paul Wins 400-Meter Run For 46-Second Meet Mark
description: Michael Paul of Seton Hall set a meet record of 46 seconds in winning the 400-meter run today at the Rutgers Relays.

title: The Talk of Virgin Islands; GROWTH BRINGS PROBLEMS TO VIRGIN ISLANDS AS IMMIGRATION PUTS A STRAIN ON SERVICES
description: The water pipes, recalcitrant on the golf greens and nearly always dry in the housing projects, had been coughing air downtown for six days. Ann Johnson, proprietor of The Snack Box, a local lunch counter, apologized for the paper plates and cups.

title: Good Friday Closings
description: Stock and commodity markets in the United States and Canada were closed yesterday in observance of Good Friday. European currency markets were also closed, and American currency markets were open only in the morning

title: Bendix Cutback Plan
description: The Bendix Corporation is considering a plan to close portions of its automotive parts and aerospace manufacturing operations in South Bend, Ind., because of high labor costs, Bendix officials said. The officials said the company could not maintain a competitive advantage because of high labor costs in the area and was considering a plan that would eliminate about 1,000 of the 6,000 workers at the South Bend plant. A spokesman for the United Automobile Workers union said the average wage at the plant is $10 an hour, exclusive of fringe benefits.

title: EUGENE EARL M'INTOSH
description: Eugene Earl McIntosh, the founder and director of the Regent School, a private elementary school in the Bronx, died Wednesday at Montefiore Hospital after a long illness.

title: Sports of The Times; Recollections of Ollie O'Mara
description: OLLIE O'MARA remembers what Ty Cobb told him that afternoon in 1912 when O'Mara was dropped by the Detroit Tigers. ''He saw me coming out the door, and he said, 'Where are you going?' And when I told him I was released he said, 'Don't worry. You'll be back.' ''

title: AN INCINERATOR IN THE BRONX IS NOT A PIG IN A POKE
description: To the Editor:

title: GIBBERISH IN EVERYDAY LIFE
description: When I am going to use unfamiliar words during my ecology lecture, I write them on the board ahead of time. The other day, I wrote ''EPIDEICTIC.'' I turned around and there were 300 people writing ''EPIDEICTIC'' in their notebooks. Suddenly, it struck me: What power! Here they are, copying this bizarre but real word as if it were Scripture. Yet for all they knew, I made it up 10 minutes earlier.

title: YANKEES WIN, 2-1, ON JACKSON'S DOUBLE
description: Reggie Jackson, who returned to the Yankee roster this morning, won a game on his first turn at bat this season.

title: Rebels Strike Mozambican Dam
description: Rebels opposed to the Marxist Government of Mozambique claimed responsibility today for cutting power lines from the Cabora Bassa dam to South Africa, Mozambique's biggest source of foreign income. Evo Fernandes, European spokesman for the Mozambican National Resistance, said the guerrillas cut the lines a week ago.

title: ECONOMIC POST OFFERED FED CRITIC
description: Jerry L. Jordan, an economist who has criticized the Federal Reserve System for what he regards as excessive expansion of the money supply, is expected to join the President's Council of Economic Advisers as the third and final member.

title: Margiotta Judge Is Advised on Charge
description: Government and defense lawyers presented written and oral arguments yesterday on their suggestions for the charge to the jury in the mail fraud and extortion trial of Joseph M.Margiotta, the Nassau Republican chairman.

title: Race Panel Asked to Resign
description: Gov. Dave Treen asked the 10 members of the Louisiana Racing Commission to resign today, saying a ''cloud of public doubt'' hangs over the panel in the wake of allegations of fixed races.

title: SOUTH AFRICA'S NEW FOCUS ON POWER-SHARING: MONEY
description: The door is kept locked on the new complex of offices that Prof. Jan Lombard occupies here, and there is no sign to identify them. Inside, the professor toils at finding the ways and means - especially the means - to give content to a slogan that has been presented as a main plank in the platform the governing National Party is offering to the all-white electorate, which goes to the polls in two weeks.

title: Dr. Lucien I. Arditi, 53; Cardiologist and Teacher
description: Dr. Lucien I. Arditi, a cardiologist associated with the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center for more than 25 years, died Monday at New York Hospital after a short illness. He was 53 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Around the Nation; Evangelist Wins in Court On Texas Child-Care Homes
description: A state judge ruled today that an evangelist, Lester Roloff, was not required to submit his church-run child-care homes to state inspections.

title:
Patents;
Pigeons For Use in Sea Search
description: THE Navy has found a method of using pigeons to trace persons or objects lost at sea. The birds are to be carried in an aircraft and peck electric signals when they see a downed pilot or piece of equipment floating below.

title: CAPITAL STAGE FESTIVAL ATTRACTS 460 COLLEGES
description: Thirteen years ago, the first American College Theater Festival was held here in a tent on the Mall in a pouring rain. This month, the festival has been at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, which it has visited annually since the center was completed 10 years ago, with three weeks of drama, mime and musical comedy that ends tonight.

title: Turks Seize 50,000 Weapons
description: More than 50,000 weapons have been seized in six southeastern provinces in Turkey, the martial law command for the area said today. The command based in Adana said 43,591 handguns and 6,500 rifles and automatic weapons had been confiscated.

title: Notes on People; A 'New Departure' for the Ambassador to Ireland
description: He's had offers to return to journalism in Washington or take a new political appointment on Capitol Hill, but when he leaves his post as Ambassador to Ireland, William V. Shannon has decided to take his first fling at teaching, at Boston University in the fall.

title: Macklin Getting Hate Mail Over Comment on Reagan
description: Rudy Macklin, the Louisiana State basketball player who commented, ''he's no kin of mine,'' after the assassination attempt on President Reagan, says he has gotten a wave of hate mail.

title: HEDBERG SCORES ON PENALTY SHOT
description: The New York Rangers tied their Stanley Cup quarterfinal playoff series by beating the St. Louis Blues, 6-4, tonight. The Rangers scored four third-period goals after trailing by two goals early in the game.

title: Around the World; Zaire's Premier Resigns; Party Calls Him 'Cowardly'
description: Prime Minister Nguza Karl-i-Bond has resigned, the national news agency Agence Zaire-Presse said today.

title: GREAT CITY, BUT WHY WERE THE SCOTS OUT FRONT?
description: To the Editor:

title: Going Out Guide
description: GENETIC ART

title: Notes on People; Mehta and Shankar: An Intriguing Collaboration
description: When Zubin Mehta leads the New York Philharmonic next Thursday in a new concerto for sitar and orchestra, with the composer, Ravi Shankar, as soloist, it will be with some trepidation.

title: Books of The Times
description: The Journey Into Self By ANATOLE BROYARD FLOWERS OF EMPTINESS: REFLEC- TIONS ON AN ASHRAM. By Sally Bel- frage. 240 pages. The Dial Press. $10.95.

title: Japanese Act in Loss
description: A consortium headed by Mitsubishi will demand $119 million compensation from China to cover losses from a steel plant contract canceled by Peking, company sources said. The $390 million contract, canceled unilaterally by Peking earlier this year, involves the supply of plant and equipment for a hot steel rolling mill for the giant Baoshan steel project near Shanghai.

title: Top G.M. Officials Earned Less in 1980
description: Top executives of the General Motors Corporation received salary increases in 1980 but ended up with a net reduction in earnings of about 40 percent because the No.1 auto maker halted bonus payments.

title: Walter McCaslin, 57, Is Stabbed; Art Critic for Dayton Newspaper
description: Walter McCaslin, art critic for The Dayton Journal Herald, was found stabbed to death at his home today, the police said. He was 57 years old.

title: JAPAN AUOTS SOLD TO U.S. DROP BY 3%
description: Japan has told the United States that auto exports to this country were reduced 3 percent in the first quarter, Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige disclosed at a news conference today.

title: RECORD LOSS POSTED IN QUARTER AT A.M.C.
description: The American Motors Corporation, the first domestic automobile maker to report first-quarter earnings, said today that it lost $52.7 million in the period, primarily because of sharply reduced auto and Jeep sales.

title: Correction
description: A Business Day article on Thursday incorrectly reported firstquarter capital spending by the Allied Chemical Corporation. Allied spent $111 million on capital investment in the quarter.

title: U.S. SEEKS TO END DRESS CODE RULE
description: The Reagan Administration is moving to scrap a rule that allows high school students to file Federal complaints about restrictive dress codes.

title: INCOME, SPENDING SHOW RISE
description: Personal income rose eight-tenths of 1 percent last month, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of about $2,335 billion, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: FAMILIES MOURN 15 MEN FOUND DEAD IN COLORADO MINE
description: Throughout the two long nights and the intervening day that he kept his vigil beside the gravel road leading to the Dutch Creek No. 1 coal mine, 51-year-old Vince Ayala held to the hope that his ''baby brother'' John had somehow eluded the deadly explosion that ripped through the mine last Wednesday.

title: NORWALK CRACKING DOWN ON BOATS THAT AVOID TAX
description: Norwalk has one of Long Island Sound's best harbors and, by some counts, more pleasure boats tie up there than in any other port in New England. But if anyone asks, the Ragamuffin, the So Fine, the Mom's Mercedes and perhaps a third of the boats -including nearly all of the biggest, sleekest and most expensive ones - are just visiting from Delaware, thank you.

title: Around the World; U.S. Church Leaders Urge Halt to Salvador Arms Aid
description: Leaders of a dozen major Protestant denominations and top bishops of the Roman Catholic Church called today for an end to United States military aid to El Salvador and urged peace negotiations.

title: Ram and Run
description: It's hard not to feel embarrassed about that American nuclear submarine that collided with a small Japanese freighter in the busy East China Sea earlier this month. The U.S.S. George Washington is one of the most lethal of modern war machines, equipped with nucleartipped missiles and sophisticated detection gear. It sank a freighter one-third its size, ramming it below the waterline with its conning tower.

title: RELOCATION OF EMPLOYEES
description: WHEN an employee is transferred from one location to another, his company may deduct all expenses for the move, but the story is not always so bright for the employees themselves.

title: MONEY SUPPLY UP $4.8 BILLION
description: The nation's basic money supply rose $4.8 billion in the week ended April 8, a larger-than-expected increase that raised the possibility of higher short-term interest rates next week as the Federal Reserve continues its efforts to slow the growth of the money supply.

title: CAREY IS BARRED FROM BEING A GODFATHER
description: Because his marriage in a Greek Orthodox ceremony a week ago was not sanctioned by the Roman Catholic Church, the Brooklyn Diocese said yesterday that Governor Carey could not be a godfather to a state legislator's son who is to be baptized today.

title: MUSIC: GALINA VISHNEVSKAYA, SOPRANO
description: At this stage of her career, Galina Vishnevskaya should rightly be enjoying the loving indulgence of fans who know her repertory and cherish memories of her at the very top of her form. Instead, she sings to Western audiences who may deeply respect her but do not respond with the enthusiasm they reserve for more familiar prima donnas.

title: California Auto Dealer Nominated To Be Ambassador to Australia
description: President Reagan today nominated Robert Dean Nesen, an aeronautical engineer and owner of a car sales and leasing concern, to be ambassador to Australia.

title: FRACTIONATED LEBANON
description: To the Editor:

title: Yonkers Burned
description: Even though the strike of Yonkers firemen was short-lived, no one will soon expunge the memory of their picket-line behavior. Not content with refusing to work, they fought off volunteers who sought to put out fires that were destroying property and endangering life.

title: Around the Nation; Judge Gives Boston Officials Deadline on Fiscal Problems
description: A Superior Court judge today gave Boston city officials five days to end their political squabbling and find a solution to the fiscal problems that threaten to bankrupt the nation's oldest public school system.

title: Harvester Reports Gain in Refinancing
description: The International Harvester Company said today that banks accounting for more than two-thirds of the funds involved in its refinancing program have approved in principle the terms for their participation.

title: 4 UNIONS IN YONKERS AGREE TO END STRIKE DURING ARBITRATION
description: A two-day strike by firefighters and other municipal employees that threw this city into crisis and allowed fires to race out of control ended tonight. The unions agreed to go back to work while their contract dispute was submitted to binding arbitration.

title: No Headline
description: A'S WIN 9TH IN ROW, DEFEAT MARINERS,16-1

title: 15 DIE IN COLORADO IN MID AIR COLLISION
description: As many as 15 persons were killed this afternoon when a twin-engine commuter airliner and a small private craft carrying sky divers collided in clear weather over northern Colorado, spreading debris over an area of several square miles.

title: Around the Nation; Ohio Police Officials Found Not Guilty of Beating Blacks
description: An all-white jury found two city policemen and a police lieutenant not guilty today of civil rights violations in connection with the alleged beatings of three black prisoners.

title: OUTCRY OVER FIRE IMPERILS MEXICO CITY'S SCAVENGERS
description: As firemen aimed high-pressure hoses at deep piles of smoldering garbage, the scavengers, old and young, men and women, went about their chores, picking out bottles, cans, cloth, plastic bags and cartons for resale and ignoring the toxic fumes enveloping them.

title: 'Gone With the Wind' Is Back
description: ''Gone With the Wind,'' the 1939 film classic starring Clark Gable, Vivien Leigh, Leslie Howard and Olivia de Havilland, is being shown at the Regency Theater, Broadway and 67th Street.

title: Sierra Club Seeks Watt's Ouster
description: The Sierra Club today opened a campaign aimed at getting a million signatures on petitions to remove James G. Watt from his post as Secretary of the Interior. The environmental group accused Mr. Watt of ''sabotaging conservation goals supported by a vast majority of the American people.''

title: PORTRAIT OF PERSONAL PHOTOGRAPHERS TO THE PRESIDENT
description: If he is lucky, he becomes part of the furniture, an overlooked, almost invisible artist quietly freezing history in the making.

title: EARLY MORNING FIRE ROUTS 1,500 STATLER HOTEL GUESTS
description: About 1,500 guests were routed from the New York Statler Hotel yesterday by a ''suspicious'' five-alarm fire that started at about 2:40 A.M. in a third-floor ballroom and sent smoke billowing as high as the 15th floor of the 21-story building.

title: PROMOTER HINTS AT DRUG ALLEGATIONS AGAINST WELLS FARGO
description: Ross Fields, the boxing promoter also known as Harold J. Smith, said today that he had information about narcotics-related transactions at the Beverly Hills branch of the Wells Fargo Bank.

title: Louis Ceremony a Celebration; Louis Ceremony a Celebration
description: In a stirring gospel celebration, Joe Louis was praised today as a champion who lifted the hopes of Americans, particularly black Americans, when war threatened the nation and when segregation tore it.

title: Star Bars
description: Imagine a giant penitentiary orbiting the Earth at a height of 22,000 miles. Visionary? A futuristic dream? We at the Institute of Social Dynamics don't think so. That's why our engineers started planning it five years ago. We call it Sky Pen. With the successful flight of the space shuttle Columbia we now have the technology to make Sky Pen a reality. Shuttles able to take off and land at Earth bases will carry construction workers and materials readily to the site. Once Sky Pen is built, shuttle trips in rocket-powered paddy wagons will transport convicted felons to the proper orbit altitude for rendezvous with the penitentiary and return to Earth with parolees.

title: STATE FISCAL OFFICERS HAVE A HELPING HAND IN NEW YORK CITY AFFAIRS
description: To the Editor:

title: 5 FIREMEN HURT AS BLAZE FLARES UP IN 7-STORY L.I. APARTMENT BUILDING ,
description: Five Long Beach, L.I., firemen were injured and about 100 residents of a beach-front apartment house, most of them elderly, had to be taken from the building when a smoldering fire in a ground-floor storage area and sauna erupted in a rush of flame yesterday morning.

title: BONWIT'S RETURN TO FIFTH AVENUE
description: Two years after it disappeared from Fifth Avenue, Bonwit Teller's is coming home again to the corner of 57th Street and Fifth. The move is a key part of the strategy by the Allied Stores Corporation to strengthen Bonwit's image as a fashion innovator and restore the flagship of the chain to a prestigious location.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 13. 1. Coca-Cola. A bottling plant for the beverage was opened on the China mainland, the first since 1949. 2. ''Sister Carrie,'' by Theodore Dreiser. 3. Mr. Kallaniotis was the first of Evangeline Gouletas-Carey's three former husbands and Mr. Kaltezas was the second. Reports about them made headlines because Mrs. Gouletas-Carey had said she thought Mr. Kallaniotis was dead and because she had not publicly revealed her marriage to Mr. Kaltezas.

title: INDIA TELLS HAIG IT OPPOSES PLAN TO ARM PAKISTAN
description: The first high-level meetings between Indian Government officials and the Reagan Administration ended today in sharp disagreement over the Administration's plans to bolster Pakistan's armed forces.

title: 2 Held in Scheme To Sell Stolen Meat
description: Two men have been arrested and accused of having bribed a truck driver in Nebraska to turn over a load of beef valued at $500,000 and then driving to Brooklyn, where they sold the meat for one-third of its value, officials of the Federal Bureau of Investigation said yesterday.

title: 2 Yugoslavs Killed in Coal Mine
description: Two miners were killed today when they were buried by a coal slide in central Yugoslavia.

title: Transactions
description: FRIDAY; BASEBALL

title: KOCH SAYS BOTTLE DEPOSIT BILL SHOULD GET A 2-YEAR TEST
description: Mayor Koch yesterday endorsed a statewide antilitter law for softdrink and beer containers, but said he wanted it to contain a ''sunset'' provision that would cause it to expire after two years so it could be reassessed.

title: FAN F. SAMUELS DIES; CONTRIBUTED MILLIONS TO AID LINCOLN CENTER
description: When the audience attending a New York Philharmonic concert at Avery Fischer Hall at Lincoln Center opened the program Thursday night, there was an insert that read in part: ''This evening's program is being performed in memory of one of the outstanding patrons of the performing arts in our city.''

title: ANHEUSER-BUSCH TO SELL BEER IN WEST GERMANY
description: It may sound like carrying coals to Newcastle, but this week Anheuser-Busch, America's biggest brewery, announced plans to sell beer in West Germany.

title: AMERICANS TOP DUTCH IN HOCKEY
description: Dave Christian scored on a penalty shot with 11 seconds left, his third goal of the game, and gave the United States a 7-6 victory over the Netherlands today in the B pool opener of the world championships.

title: Islanders 6-3 Victors; Potvin Gets 3 Goals
description: With Denis Potvin contributing three power-play goals and two assists, the Islanders defeated the Edmonton Oilers, 6-3, at Nassau Coliseum tonight and took a 2-0 lead in their National Hockey League quarterfinal series. The four-of-seven playoff will resume at Northlands Coliseum in Edmonton, Alberta, for games Sunday and Monday.

title: WORLD PUSH BY MEXICAN BANKS IRKS RIVALS
description: Buoyed by Mexico's vast new oil wealth and a sudden surge of foreign borrowing by capital-starved Mexican companies, Mexican banks are making their entrance into international financial markets. But they are not being welcomed with enthusiasm by United States and Western European bankers.

title: EXCERPTS FROM ACCORD BY POLISH GOVERNMENT AND PRIVATE FARMERS
description: Following ar excerpts from the agreement signed today by the Polish Government and private farmers, as transmitted by the official press agency P.A.P. and translated by The Associated Press.

title: FEARFUL YONKERS RESIDENTS DECRY STRIKE
description: Sitting on his customary bench in Getty Square, James Burke did not appear to be in a state of emergency. He sat placidly at the center of Yonkers, a city of 200,000 residents that had been declared in just such a state when firemen went out on strike Wednesday.

title: THE POLITICS OF JOHN WILKES BOOTH
description: To the Editor:

title: Bay E. Estes, 70, Stricken in Car; Ex-U.S. Steel and Industry Aide
description: Bay E. Estes, a former United States Steel Corporation executive and retired vice president of the American Iron and Steel Institute, was fatally stricken Wednesday while driving his car in suburban Upper St. Clair Township. He was 70 years old.

title: Turner Cancels Public Offering
description: The Turner Broadcasting System Inc., which owns Cable News Network, a 24-hour news and feature service for cable television systems, said that it was canceling its proposed public offering of 1 million common shares.

title: TOWN HOUSE TO BE RESTORED DURING DEBATE ON USE
description: A turn-of-the century former town house off Park Avenue that suffered extensive damage Sunday in a fire caused by arson will be restored, the landlord, Lewis Rudin, said yesterday.

title: SAFETY AGENCY RE-EVALUATING CURB ON LEAD POISONING
description: The Occupational Safety and Health Administration announced today that it was reconsidering its twoyear-old regulations designed to protect workers from lead poisoning and would assess whether the cost to industry of compliance was justified by the health benefits to the more than 800,000 workers who are exposed to lead on the job.

title: Continental Target Of Texas Air's Suit
description: Texas International Airlines has filed suit against the management of Continental Air Lines and the newly formed Continental Employees Association, accusing them of conspiring to block a takeover bid by the Texas line.

title: MOST BREADS LACK 'TRUTH AND SINCERITY' THESE DAYS
description: Few foods have been endowed with more spiritual significance than bread. Whether in the form of the communion wafer (''I am the bread of life,'' Jesus told His disciples) or the matzoh, described in I Corinthians as ''the unleavened bread of truth and sincerity,'' bread plays a prominent role in the celebration of Easter and Passover, occurring simultaneously this weekend. The time seems right, therefore, to explore some of the history of bread and to consider the sad state of its quality.

title: THE STAGE: 'THE MAGNIFICENT CUCKOLD'
description: ''The Magnificent Cuckold,'' the most celebrated work by Fernand Crommelynck, a Flemish playwright who wrote in French, was heralded in Meyerhold's 1922 production in Moscow. The play deals with the author's favorite theme, the wages of jealousy, and in Jonas Jurasas's production at the Yale Repertory Theater it moves unconvincingly from winsome domesticity to farce and on to tragedy.

title: Glenn Infield, 60, Author of Books About Aviation and Nazi Germany
description: Glenn B. Infield, who wrote nine books and 300 articles dealing with aviation and the Germany of World War II, died Wednesday at the Medical Center of Beaver County, Pa. He was 60 years old.

title: North Stars Win, Take 2-0 Lead
description: Steve Christoff and Dino Ciccarelli scored two goals each to give the Minnesota North Stars a 5-2 victory over the Buffalo Sabres tonight and a 2-0 lead in their Stanley Cup quarterfinal playoff series.

title: CONGREGATIONS SHARING CHURCH COMMEMORATE GOOD FRIDAY TOGETHER
description: Two Roman Catholic nuns shared a pulpit with several priests and a female Protestant minister at St. Paul the Apostle Church in Manhattan yesterday for the traditional three-hour Good Friday service, which focuses on the words Jesus spoke from the Cross.

title: STUDENT HELD IN BLAZES AND 2 SHOTGUN DEATHS AT DORM
description: Just after 6 A.M. this morning, the police said, ''several Molotov cocktails'' exploded in the sixthfloor corridor of Bursley Hall, a dormitory that houses about 1,500 students on the North Campus of the University of Michigan here.

title: 2 Quit Trinidad Race for Premier, Leaving Post Open for Chambers
description: OF-SPAIN, Trinidad, April 17 (AP) - Two contenders have bowed out of the contest to succeed the late Prime Minister, Sir Eric E.I. Williams, leaving the way clear for Trinidad and Tobago's interim Prime Minister, George M. Chambers, to retain the post after his party meets on May 9.

title: THE HUDSON'S FISHERMEN
description: The Hudson River has many faces. There is the scenic Hudson, the cultural, historic, biologic, industrial, and embattled Hudson. A composite of these would yield yet another Hudson, that of the commercial fishermen.

title: LET THE VOTERS DECIDE
description: To the Editor:
