title: 7 Injured Las Vegas Hotel Fire
description: A small, smoky fire touched off by a welder's torch forced the evacuation of 500 guests and gamblers from the Holiday Inn on the Las Vegas Strip today.

title: Around the World; West Germans Protest Death of Jailed Guerrilla
description: Five explosions shook West Berlin last night and left-wing demonstrators took to the streets in several West German cities after a jailed hunger striker died in a 10-week fast.

title: ROCKETS OUST SPURS, GAIN WESTERN FINALS
description: The surprising Houston Rockets, led by Calvin Murphy's 42 points, defeated the San Antonio Spurs, 105-100, tonight to capture their Western Conference semifinal playoff series.

title: NEGOTIATIONS ARE BROKEN OFF IN COAL MINERS' WALKOUT
description: Negotiators for the striking United Mine Workers union and the major Eastern and Middle Western coal companies broke off renewed bargaining today, and there were signs that talks might not resume for several weeks.

title: SUMMER JOB OUTLOOK FOR YOUTHS IN NEW YORK AREA CALLED 'TOUGH'
description: Some are happy to find work pruning bushes or shuffling fast-food orders, while others are not satisfied unless they land a job with a top-ranking concern in their profession-to-be. But analysts in government, business, industry and education say that most young people in the New York metropolitan area, whatever their aspirations, will have a hard time finding summer jobs this year.

title: A Franchise Cheapened by the Dozen
description: Americans who have been celebrating political reform, particularly the public financing of campaigns and the demise of political bossism, had better take a good look at the carnival that is the gubernatorial campaign in New Jersey.

title: Chile Copper Mine Strike
description: The 8,500 workers at the El Teniente copper mine in Chile have voted to go on strike, a mine workers union spokesman said today. The strike will be effective next Wednesday.

title: Screening of 'Superman II' Will Aid Special Olympics
description: A special screening of ''Superman II'' is scheduled for June 1 at the National Theater, Broadway at 43d Street, to benefit the Special Olympics, a program of athletic training and competition for the mentally retarded.

title: Zungul Is Unlikely To Join the N.A.S.L.
description: Steve Zungul, who scored 281 goals in three championship seasons with the New York Arrows of the Major Indoor Soccer League, apparently will not have the chance to score even one goal outdoors for a North American Soccer League team.

title: CECIL B. IN A WEST SIDE WALK UP
description: In Hollywood these days, making movies means big money: Big production costs, big advertising budgets, big stars. And, all too often, big losses to match.

title: Angels Pleased With Forsch
description: Of all the changes the California Angels made in their pitching staff this winter, the last-minute move to acquire Ken Forsch may turn out to be the most rewarding.

title: BANKS TEST SECOND MORTGAGES
description: PEOPLE who have been putting money into their homes for years can now get some of it out without having to sell, under the new ''home equity'' mortgages offered by several Westchester banks.

title: TIGERS WIN 5TH STRAIGHT BY TOPPING BLUE JAYS, 4-3
description: Dan Schatzeder pitched five and two-thirds innings of one-hit ball in relief and the Detroit Tigers used a four-run sixth inning to post a 4-3 victory today over the Toronto Blue Jays.

title: A PHOTOGRAPHIC TOUR OF THE U.S., IN ALL ITS DIVERSITY
description: NEWARK AMERICA is a country of breathtaking and bewildering extremes, with seemingly endless landscapes of awesome magnitude and cities where boundaries are immediate and existence is ephemeral. Opulence flanks destitution.

title: Sandra Dyer Sorensen Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Sverre Sorensen of Atlantic Highlands, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sandra Dyer Sorensen of New York, to William Peake Henning, son of Mr. and Mrs. Basil Duke Henning of New Haven and London.

title: A DAY TO LOOK UPWARD
description: Columbia, Columbus and the Future

title: JUST ANOTHER BUDGET DEADLINE, ALBANY SHRUGS
description: The boundaries of delay, already indistinct here, seemed to dissolve completely last week as Governor Carey and Warren M. Anderson, the Senate Republican leader, refused to yield on their respective plans for New York's fiscal future. As a result, today marks the state's 20th day without a budget.

title: Lesley Wolff to Be Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Herbert H. Wolff of Roslyn, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Lesley Diane Wolff, to Robert M. Adler, son of Roslyn Adler of Brooklyn and Sidney Adler of Deerfield Beach, Fla. An October wedding is planned.

title: BASKETS: ALL SIZES, ALL SHAPES AT THE THORPE
description: THERE is a yellow brick road of sorts in Sparkill, and although it doesn't lead to the glitter of the Emerald City and Oz, it does lead to some splendor of its own. The road starts at the entrance to the grounds of the Dominican Convent complex on Route 340 and is marked by barbershop-type poles painted in bands of glowing violet, hot orange and greenish yellow. These unusual signposts lead the way through the property to the basement of one of the convent's brick buildings. The supergraphic stripes continue until they encircle the double doors of the Thorpe Intermedia Gallery.

title: Correction
description: The Follow-Up on the News column last Sunday incorrectly identified the owner of a process that a California inventor is trying to develop for a water-fueled car. The inventor, Sam L. Leach, bought back the rights in 1978 from the Presley Companies of Newport Beach, Calif.

title: Gwyn Thomas, 67, Dies; Wrote of Welsh Miners
description: Gwyn Thomas, an author who wove the ordinary people of his native South Wales into stories, novels and plays, died at his home in Cardiff, Wales, on Tuesday, The Times of London reported today. He was 67 years old.

title: A LULL IN MEAT PRICES
description: Weak demand and a surprising increase in production clobbered livestock prices during the first quarter, but consumers who enjoy red meat might be advised to stock up. Low prices and high feed costs have prompted cattle and hog farmers to reduce slaughter rates, and analysts think the cutbacks will produce higher meat prices later this spring.

title: U.S. May Shift G.I.'s in Germany
description: The United States Army may shift some of its 206,000 soldiers in West Germany closer to the East German and Czechoslovak borders, Senator Strom Thurmond, the South Carolina Repuiblican, said today. In an interview with Stars and Stripes, the unofficial Army newspaper, he said such a redeployment would help improve morale and combat readiness.

title: No Headline
description: What Herman Kahn, Lawrence W. Beilenson, Colin S. Gray and others associated with their views are saying is consistent with attitudes that do not stop in military affairs and are far from new, either in this country or in the rest of the world. It is for this reason, as well as the immediate danger of their ''rethinking,'' that serious attention must be paid to them.

title: Vanishing in Georgia
description: It was a drive that 73-year-old Charles R. Romer, a retired oil executive, and his wife, Catherine, 75, had taken many times as ''snowbirds'' -people who spend their winters in Florida and the rest of the year back home in the North. The Romers checked into a Holiday Inn in Brunswick City, Ga., on April 8, 1980.

title: PRESIDENT, COMFORTABLE AT HOME, DELAYS HIS RETURN TO OVAL OFFICE
description: President Reagan has increased his workload to four or five hours a day and is essentially able to do the same amount of paperwork he did before he was shot in the chest March 30, White House officials say.

title: NEW JERSEY STRUGGLES TO TAME TOXIC MONSTER
description: In 1977, Dr. Robert K. Tucker, a scientist at a state research office here, set out to discover links between New Jersey's high cancer rate and the haphazard disposal of thousands of tons of toxic wastes. He focused on the groundwater aquifers that supply half of the state's 7.3 million people with drinking water.

title: Home Clinic; SAFETY ON THE STEPLADDER
description: THOUGH many people who are afraid of climbing a tall ladder would not think twice about climbing an ordinary stepladder, statistics show that most injuries in the home that result from falls occur at a height of two or three feet - and many are quite serious.

title: EUROPE'S BIG GAMBLE ON SOVIET GAS
description: Soviet officials describe it as ''the largest project in recorded history.'' It is the proposed 3,600-mile natural gas transmission system from the Yamburg gas field, in the Yamal Arctic region of West Siberia, to the western border of the Soviet Union. Depending on pipeline pressure, the Yamburg field is intended to supply 40 billion to 70 billion cubic meters of natural gas a year to 10 European countries -West Germany, France, Italy, Austria, Finland, Belgium, the Netherlands, Sweden, Switzerland and Greece.

title: FINDING GOD AGAIN
description: IN the past few years, while some celebrities have chosen to kissand-tell their way onto the best-seller charts, a growing number of public figures have chosen to write about the role of religion in their lives. Among them is Leon Jaworski, the Houston lawyer best known for his role as Watergate counsel and as a prosecutor at the Nuremberg war crimes trial.

title: CHURCHILL MESSAGE STIFFENED U.S. POLICY ON JAPAN, NEW LOOK AT WAR DATA
description: HINTS By DREW MIDDLETON

title: HUMMEL'S 'TE DUM' IN U.S. PREMIERE
description: THE American premiere of ''Te Deum,'' a recently discovered 19thcentury choral work by Johann Nepomuk Hummel, is expected to draw wide attention next Sunday when it is introduced in a concert by the Rutgers University Chorale of New Brunswick and the Rutgers-Newark Orchestra.

title: THE SOUTH WITHOUT THE SCENT OF LAVENDER
description: THE COLLECTED STORIES OF CAROLINE GORDON Introduction by Robert Penn Warren. 352 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $17.95

title: DR. ISADOR CHEIN, A PSYCHOLOGIST AND N.Y.U. TEACHER, DEAD AT 69
description: Dr. Isidor Chein, professor emeritus of psychology at New York University and last year's recipient of the American Psychological Association Award, died yesterday at Beth Israel Medical Center. He was 69 years old and a resident of Rego Park, Queens.

title: Critics' Choice
description: NEW MUSIC Today, new music is a heady collage of different styles. And although no one performance group or impresario has yet attempted a really comprehensive cross-section of everything going on today, more and more of them are beginning to try.

title: OFFICIALS ON COAST ASK COURT TO TAKE 4 CHILDREN FROM FAMILY'S 'CYCLE OF CRIME'
description: More than 30 years ago, a family in Waco, Tex., and another in Prentiss, Miss., followed the same dream that lured millions of other migrants to California and moved to a predominately black neighborhood here.

title: Melanie A. Shorin, Student, Is Fiancee
description: Mrs. E. John Rosenwald Jr. of New York and Kings Point, L.I., and Joseph E. Shorin Jr. of New York and Seaview, Fire Island, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Melanie Anne Shorin, to Greg S. Feldman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Dick Feldman of New York.

title: BECKETT AT 75- AN APPRAISAL
description: As playwright, novelist and Nobel Laureate, Samuel Beckett has become a beacon of our age, offering a tragicomic vision of mankind confronting the void and then going on with the business of living. Last week, Mr. Beckett arrived at his 75th year, at the pinnacle of a career that has revolutionized theater.

title: Aide Says Miners Died Instantly
description: Concussion, not asphyxiation or fire, apparently was the cause of death for the 15 miners whose bodies were found trapped in a mine after an explosion last week, a Federal official said today. John Barton, a district manager for the Mine Safety and Health Administration, said he was with a team that found six bodies late Thursday in Dutch Creek No. 1 mine. He said they did not appear ''badly charred, disfigured or dismembered in any way.''

title: THIRTEEN RUNAWAY SLAVES AND DAVID BRADLEY
description: IN his first novel, ''South Street,'' David Bradley cast an incisive eye on the inhabitants of one of Philadelphia's more colorful inner-city thoroughfares and displayed a distinct flare for Richard Pryor's wry kind of humor. Although Mr. Bradley's second novel, ''The Chaneysville Incident,'' is by no stretch of the imagination humorous, its author, in person, exhibits the same sidelong view of life that en-livened the narrative voice of his first book.

title: TIPS BY REAGAN'S TRUST MANAGER
description: For investment wisdom, Ronald Reagan's advisers sought out Raymond J. Armstrong of the Starwood Corporation in New York and placed the President's $740,000 blind trust in his hands for the next four years. Mr. Armstrong will not breathe a word about the President's money, but he will talk about the investment strategies that guide the managing of Starwood's $400 million of pension funds and large personal holdings.

title: WAS WALPOLE WORTH IT?
description: HORACE WALPOLE'S MISCELLANEOUS CORRESPONDENCE Edited by W.S. Lewis and John Riely, with the Assistance of Edwine M. Martz and Ruth K. McClure. Illustrated. Vol. 1, 389 pp. Vol. 2, 470 pp. Vol. 3, 507 pp. New Haven, Conn.: Yale University Press. Each volume, $40.

title:
NEW JERSEY HOUSING;
UPGRADING: ALTERNATIVE TO MOVING
description: THESE days, as high home prices and interest rates discourage families from moving as often as they once might have, more and more people are discovering that, with some rethinking and a modicum of construction and outdoor plantings, happiness lies in their own back yards.

title: KURES WINS 3D TENNIS TITLE
description: Michael Kures of Willow Springs, Ill., became the first player ever to capture all three age division titles in the Easter Bowl junior tennis tournament when he won the 18 years and under championship today at the Binghamton Racquet Club.

title:
VIEWS OF SPORT;
ALAS, THEY'RE RUNNING BOSTON AGAIN WITHOUT ME
description: They'll be running the Boston Marathon again without me - though not because I didn't give it a good shot. I won't be there tomorrow but I'll be there next year.

title: EASTERN BOX TURTLE; Terrapene carolina
description: Size: Averages 4 to 6 inches; unusual to 8 inches. Color: Carapace, dark brown or black with variable pattern of yellow or orange lines, spots and blotches.

title: RANGERS BEAT YANKEES ON 2 RUNS IN 7TH, 6-4
description: Steve Comer, a 27-year-old right-hander whose pitching career last year was believed ended because of a chronic sore arm, weaved some unexpected magic for the Texas Rangers today.

title: Paula Ennis-Dwyer Plays Scriabin Piano Sonata
description: A graduate of Indiana University and currently an assistant professor of music at Williams College, Paula Ennis-Dwyer made her New York debut at Carnegie Recital Hall on Monday night. Judging from her program, Miss Ennis-Dwyer is a pianist who enjoys playing music that is both technically demanding and of a rather mystical nature.

title: SOTHEBY OPENING THIRD NEW YORK AUCTION HOUSE
description: Sotheby Parke Bernet's third auction house in New York opens Thursday at 171 East 84th Street, with an exhibition of the American manuscript collection of the late Joseph M. Roebling, great grandson of the builder of the Brooklyn Bridge.

title: INTENT AS GROUND FOR PROVING BIAS GETTING NEW EMPHASIS
description: Congress and the courts, in a subtle but important change, are moving toward re-emphasizing the need for blacks, Hispanic Americans and women to prove intentional discrimination in lawsuits alleging violations of civil rights.

title: Letter: Alive and Kicking
description: It was a shock to read on the Opinion Page of Jan. 25 that the magazine Media & Methods was dead. When I held that three-column obituary in my hand, the American Society of Educators, which I head, had just acquired Media & Methods from its previous owners.

title: Bridge; DOUBLE-DUTY 'ALERT'
description: Adecade ago the American Contract Bridge League introduced a new approach to a difficult problem. The problem was to insure that the opposition is fully informed about bidding conventions and special treatments. The solution was the ''alert'' announcement, which advises the opponents that something unusual has happened. They can inquire if they wish, but will often prefer to wait until the auction is over.

title: Lori Cohen, Glenn Nortman To Be Married in December
description: Mr. and Mrs. Terence Cohen of Lawrence, L.I. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lori Cohen, to Glenn Nortman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Nortman of Woodbury, L.I. A December wedding is planned.

title: Museum Stop
description: To the Editor:

title: Aug. 16 Bridal Set By Patricia Murphy
description: Mr. and Mrs. John E. Murphy of Mahwah, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Patricia Ann Murphy, to John William Kennelly, son of Mrs. John J. Kennelly of Wyckoff, N.J., and the late Mr. Kennelly.

title: REED'S CONTRIBUTION
description: To the Sports Editor: The Knicks' sudden and disappointing exit from the playoffs makes it easy to begin pointing fingers and summoning remembrances of the glory days of a decade ago. I would like to acknowledge the team's excellent record and vast improvement this season.

title: COLEMAN'S BAD REPORT
description: A report by James S. Coleman, a University of Chicago educational sociologist, concludes that Roman Catholic and other private schools provide a better education than public schools. He also concludes that a voucher system - a tax-supported payment for attendance at a private school - would provide poor children with a better education and promote more racial integration.

title: Art; PHOTO SCHOOL OFFERS AN ABBOTT EXHIBIT
description: NEW CANAAN THE Photo Graphics Workshop at 212 Elm Street here is unusual on several counts, not the least of which is that it is run by a mother and her daughter. The mother is Carol Ruth Shephed, the daughter, Beth. They founded the enterprise in 1971 with the late photographer Larry Colwell.

title: Critics' Choice
description: POP MUSIC Ray Charles spent more than two decades barnstorming around the United States playing for dancers before it became evident to almost everyone that he was one of the greatest popular vocalists of our time and should be heard in concert halls. That was fine for Mr. Charles, who must have been tired of playing all night every night, but those who remember hearing the singer and pianist and his first class band playing for dancers still remember these events fondly. There is something about seeing a superior popular artist playing for a dancing crowd, something special that a concert performance can never quite capture.

title: ...AND TASTELESS SALAD DRESSING?
description: Not long after last week's issue of Forbes magazine rolled off the presses, Malcolm S. Forbes Sr., the magazine's pungent editor-inchief, discovered among the ads for insurance companies and computer systems an ad for a salad dressing that was a touch out of the ordinary. It touted ''a creamy mushroom dressing'' that purported to ''melt down on your salad with a flavor explosion.'' The concoction, Three Mile Island Salad Dressing - it's actually a dry dressing mix - will make your next salad ''an historical event,'' it said.

title: Gallery View; JOHN RINGLING- THE CIRCUS MAN WHO BUILT A HOUSE OF ART
description: For several years now Wildenstein & Co. has made a habit of opening its doors to anthologies of work from outlying American museums. The anthologies in question have been chosen by Denys Sutton, the editor of Apollo magazine, who likes nothing better than to beat the bushes and come up with something that most of us have never seen before. This time around, his choice has fallen on the Ringling Museum in Sarasota, Fla., and the exhibition may now be seen at Wildenstein's, 19 East 64th Street.

title: Unearned Runs Hurt As Expos Beat Mets
description: The Mets got their first look of the year at the Montreal Expos yesterday, and saw little to dispel the notion that the Expos could bring Canada its first baseball championship.

title: Holly Myers Plans Wedding Sept. 12 To William Brooks
description: Mr. and Mrs. William A. Myers of Madison, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Harriet Lyman Myers, to William Henninger Brooks, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin P. Brooks of Wayne, N.J.

title: EXOTIC VEGETABLES
description: Spring is in the air, and the seeds are going in the ground. Early reports from two of America's oldest and largest seed companies say sales are up, in a market estimated at about $2.5 billion a year by the American Seed Trade Association. Commercial planters, of course, account for a lot of the business, but the guy next door is also shelling out more for 45-cent to $1.50 seed packets via the Post Office.

title: CHANGE IN PETITION LAWS SOUGHT
description: DURING the heat of last summer's Presidential and state election campaigns, Connecticut's statutory provisions governing candidates petitioning for a place on the ballot were challenged in Federal court as being unconstitutional.

title: THE LID COMES OFF AT AMERICAN CAN
description: A spring rain pelted the American Can Company's headquarters one day last week, softening the harsh lines of its modernistic concrete and glass construction. The 10-year-old complex, tucked away in the gentle greening hills of southwestern Connecticut, exudes an aura of corporate stability sufficient to a company with annual sales approaching $5 billion.

title: After the Deluge,; It's Still Levesque
description: Quebecers' motto appears to be: Keep Ottawa guessing. Last week, barely a year after voters decisively denied Premier Rene Levesque a mandate to negotiate independence for their province, they shook up Canada's English-speaking majority again by re-electing the Premier and his Parti Quebecois to a second five-year term.

title: NO LONGER THE FRONT-RUNNER, GISCARD RUNS FOR HIS POLITICAL LIFE
description: As journalists and polltakers know, it is a sound political tradition to behead messengers bringing bad news. In France these days, the problem is what to do with messengers who deliver a tangle of contradictions.

title: HIGHWAYS ARE CLOSED
description: Three forest fires burned out of control in South Jersey today, devastating an estimated 6,000 acres of woodland and forcing authorities to evacuate several gun club sites and close portions of highways in the area.

title: Future Events Asia to Xenon
description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated. 'The Mikado' Bows April 21 - An opening-night party, from 5 P.M. to curtaintime three hours later, will hail the arrival of ''The Mikado,'' presented in the traditional repertory manner of the Blue Hill Troupe. Festivities, at the Union Club, at Park Avenue and 69th Street, designed to aid the Youth Counseling League, will include buffet supper and a cash bar. The troupe, dedicated Gilbert and Sullivan admirers, supports a favorite charity annually, and this year's beneficiary provides mental-health services to young people. After supper and cocktails, the musically inclined may skip across the street to Hunter College at 68th Street for the colorful show. Supper tickets: $20 a person; show tickets: from $7 to $35. Call 873-6400. ''The Mikado,'' runs through Saturday at 8 P.M., with a Saturday matinee at 2). For tickets, call 722-6641.

title: Food; OXTAIL INCIDENTS
description: OXTAIL INCIDENTS Michael Geiger

title: A TIGHTROPE FOR COUNTY ATTORNEY
description: YEARS ago, when County Attorney Samuel S. Yasgur was working for Frank Hogan, the legendary Manhattan District Attorney, he took a few days off and grew a beard. ''Not bad, but no trials,'' Mr. Hogan told the young lawyer.

title: SOME VERY GOOD MASTERS
description: IT must have been the movies of the 1930's more than any other influence that got me into the habit of thinking like a writer. I wasn't a bookish child; reading was such hard work for me that I avoided it whenever possible. But I wasn't exactly the rough-andready type either, and so the movies filled a double need: They gave me an awful lot of cheap story material and a good place to hide.

title: Critics' Choice
description: ART An avowed feminist artist, Miriam Schapiro works in an aggressively decorative mode, embellishing archetypal ''female'' forms - fan, heart, kimono shapes - with cut-out fabrics, patchwork, beads, buttons, spangles and other frivolities until recently considered unacceptable in the context of ''high'' art. Her show at the Barbara Gladstone Gallery, 41 West 57th Street (through Saturday) contains four ''black paintings''; that is, shaped canvases whose deep ebony grounds are intricately patterned with painted and collaged elements that work in brilliant counterpoint.

Costikyan 8,2,371,0The Reagan Administration's efforts to reduce the Federal budget are running into a $700 billion roadblock that the Administration does not seem to understand. The $700 billion is the number of dollars that are taken out of the pockets of some Americans and put into the pockets of other Americans.

title: MARIA ANGELA FISHER TO WED
description: The engagement of Maria Angela Fisher, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Fisher of Larchmont, N.Y., to William Lawrence Pollak, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander H. Pollak of Larchmont, has been announced by Miss Fisher's aunt, Elizabeth Gelmi of Miami.

title: L.I. SWIMMERS GET A LOOK AT BRITISH LIFE
description: LONDON AT 9:55 P.M., the voice over the loudspeaker at Kennedy Airport announced, ''Last call for Flight 807 to London.'' Seven and a half hours later, as the 747 gently lowered its silver wings, bleary-eyed passengers peeked out at the sun playing hide-and-seek in the sky. Though it was nearing noon in London when the plane landed, wristwatches attested to the early hour - 5:32 A.M. E.S.T.

title: SHAKEN ONE WAY OR ANOTHER BY TENURE FIGHTTo the Editor:$
description: Forgive my genes if my head waves from side to side rather than ''nodding knowingly'' after reading the editorial ''Sex and the Selfish Gene'' (April 13). I have a recent doctorate in philosophy, a field in which only one of eight

title: FORD HAS DESIGNS ON 2-SEATER MARKET
description: THE commercial is terrific. The car sort of comes up out of the earth while trumpets tootle and a rich voice, barely able to contain itself, thrums with excitement. ''Ford EXP!'' it exults. ''Glowing with world-class sophistication and design! With handling and road command that come from front-wheel drive and four-wheel independent suspension. And a shape So subtle it slices the wind!''

title: Robin Grebe Plans Wedding on July 11
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Grebe of Cortlandt, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Robin Anne Grebe, to John H. Phillips, son of Mrs. Howard E. Phillips of Madison, N.J., and the late Mr. Phillips.

title: MERIDAN STRIVING TO HEAL ITSELF
description: MERIDEN appears to be in the middle of a painful economic transition. International Silver Company's decision in late March to close its holloware factory, which made trays and tea sets, eliminated 250 jobs and signaled a setback for an industry once so central to Meriden's economic life that it was known as the ''Silver City.'' Newer industries located in the city's eastern fringe, along Interstate 91, have not created enough jobs to hold down severe unemployment, and the city core has decayed.

title: SHAKEN ONE WAY OR ANOTHER BY TENURE FLIGHT
description: To the Editor:

title: MAN'S BEST DISH
description: Jonathan Swift, meet the Rev. John J. O'Connor. A few weeks ago, Father O'Connor made a modest proposal: If Asian refugees in the San Francisco area had a taste for dogs or cats (it had been reported that some did), why not draw on the humane society's larder? Father O'Connor, who was subsequently besieged with howls of organized protest. "I don't understand," he said, "what all the flap is about."

title: A NOVEL OF INDIA'S COMING OF AGE
description: MIDNIGHT'S CHILDREN By Salman Rushdie. 446 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $13.95.

title: James T. Glavin, 72, a Specialist In Securities and Corporate Law
description: James T. Glavin, a specialist in securities and corporate law, died Thursday at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital. Mr. Glavin, who lived in Jamaica Estates in Queens, was 72 years old.

title:
Antiques;
17TH WESTPORT SHOW
description: WESTPORT THE 17th annual Southport-Westport Antiques Show, featuring 70 exhibits, as well as added attractions, will take place next weekend at the Fairfield County Hunt club in Westport.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Christ is in Cuba. Christ will not leave Cuba. We will stay with Christ in Cuba.''

title: WILL REAGAN'S PLANS BOOST THE ECONOMY? GOOD QUESTION
description: WITH most members of Congress home for recess until April 27, hearing their constituents' views on the Administration's proposed spending and tax cuts, the White House spent the week gearing up to give them an earful, too.

title: WASHINGTON
description: BLACKS constituted 12.6 percent of New Jersey's 7,360,000 residents in 1980, forming the largest racial group in Newark and seven other cities, according to newly released details from the 1980 census.

title: Man Sues Over Photograph Identifying Him as Hinckley
description: The attorney for a man misidentified by The Associated Press in a photograph as John W. Hinckley Jr., who is accused of attempting to assassinate President Reagan, has filed a $1.5 million lawsuit.

title: NANCY LIGGETT TO WED JUNE 21
description: Mr. and Mrs. Walter C. Liggett Jr. of Wayne, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Frances Liggett, to Paul David Vinroot, son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred W. Vinroot of Ridgewood, N.J. A June 21 wedding is planned. Miss Liggett is a physical therapist at the New York University Medical Center in New York. Her fiance is program and fitness director of the Ridgewood (N.J.) Young Men's Christian Association.

title: A SHOW OF 'MADE IN NEW JERSEY'
description: BORDENTOWN THEY have not taken a count lately, but Harry and Erma Brown figure that they have more than a thousand pieces of American Belleek china made in Trenton. Their collection includes items from the 1880's through the 1940's, some of which will be on view next Saturday at the antiques show and sale at the United Methodist Church in Cranbury.

title: CATHOLICS PLAN DRIVE TO 'DEGLAMORIZE' USE OF DRUGS
description: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York is planning to consolidate its drug abuse programs into a major educational effort aimed at teen-agers and their parents.

title: ISLAND PLAN VEXES WESTPORT
description: WESTPORT A PROPOSAL to build an office complex on Gorham Island, six-acres of undeveloped land adjacent to the downtown business center here, has run into opposition from a citizens' group that fears Westport is suffering from ''overcommercialization.'' The office proposal, a spokesman for the goup said, ''represents the problems of Westport in a nutshell.''

title: OUT OF UNIFORM; Brass
description: Do the huge cuts in Federal support for the arts suggest that culture has a low priority in Washington? Of course not. In an era of guns over butter, the Reagan Administration is simply putting its arts money where it belongs: in the defense budget.

title:
DINING OUT;
A POPULAR FIXTURE AT THE SEASHORE
description: OF THE hundreds of restaurants lining the New Jersey shore, The Quay (pronounced ''key'') in Sea Bright is consistently one of the most pleasing. This casual, yet sophisticated, restaurant has been a popular fixture since 1976, when it was opened by Christine Doran and Ned Carton.

title: F.B.I.'s Loose Lips Trouble Atlantans
description: Perhaps there was a method to the Federal Bureau of Investigation's remarks last week on the search for the killers of black youths in Atlanta, but if so, city officials failed to see it.

title:
Camera;
COMMON MISTAKES MADE BY ALL PHOTOGRAPHERS
Art; SIX AT SOMERSTOWN
description: SOMERS THE Somerstown Studios and Gallery is, at the age of about 18 months, one of Westchester's youngest art centers. Directed by Leandra Pope, the enterprise occupies a large frame house on Route 100. Well-appointed galleries fill the greater part of the threefloor building, but there are workshops, too, whose amenities include a wood-burning kiln.

title: NEW LIFE FOR OLD JETS IN ENGINE JOBS
description: A fountain of youth has been discovered for the aging fleet of DC-8's owned by the nation's airlines. And the hope for prolonging the life of McDonnell Douglas's workhorse, whose days were numbered because of poor fuel efficiency and noisy engines, is spawning a new miniindustry.

title: Rebels Getting Help
description: The Afghan rebels are well-equipped and confident, two American journalists reported last week.

title: AVY B. SMITH
description: Avy B. Smith, a real-estate operator whose family-owned concern, the Jas. Jay Smith Company, had been active in the development of the Jamaica and St. Albans areas of Queens, shore property in Connecticut and in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., died Friday in West Palm Beach, Fla.

title: N.F.L. DRAFT HOLDS KEY TO RANDY RASMUSSEN'S FUTURE AS A JET
description: The draft of the best 336 college seniors by the National Football League's 28 teams each spring is a disturbing time for the veterans, many of whom feel threatened by unknown young players.

title: Giscard Ahead of Mitterrand In Last Poll Before Election
description: The final opinion poll before next weekend's French presidential election gives President Valery Giscard d'Estaing a narrow lead in the decisive second round over his socialist rival, Francois Mitterrand. Under French electoral law, no opinion polls can be published during the week preceding each of the votes, on April 26 and May 10.

title: FINE LIVING, WHERE DID YOU GO?
description: I have just received the first issue of my new subscription to Realites. Inside the front cover and prominently displayed was a letter not from the editor, but from the vice president of the parent company, Intermed Communications Inc., saying that Realites would cease to exist with this (my first) issue. Realites has as its subtitle the premise that it is ''the international guide to fine living.''

title: ANXIETY OVER APARTHEID
description: Joseph Lelyveld is the Johannesburg correspondent of The New York Times. By Joseph Lelyveld he Prime Minister enters the hall under a canopy of orange, white and blue paper flags, held aloft by outstretched arms. A carnation is pinned to his lapel, and a tiny smile plays around the corners of his mouth - the same tiny smile that can be detected on 15 posters staring down from the walls and the platform toward which he is now advancing. ''NOU, MEER AS OOIT,'' says the Afrikaans slogan on several of them. An English version of the same poster provides the translation, and it is positively Nixonian. ''NOW, MORE THAN EVER,'' it says.

title: U.S. Ensemble for Soviet Musicians
description: Enough Soviet musicians have left home to staff a symphony orchestra. So last weekend, when Maestro Maksim Shostakovich and Dmitri, his pianist son, defected in West Germany, plenty of old musical friends were waiting in the wings to embrace them.

title: MUSIC: DEBUTS IN REVIEW
description: Paul-Martin Maki's debut recital on Wednesday in Lincoln Center's Organ Interludes series at Alice Tully Hall reminded one of some of the reasons why many sophisticated concertgoers long ago gave up on organ recitals. Mr. Maki, who is organist of St. Michael's Church here and teaches at the Manhattan School of Music, brought in a program that, except for Bach's Trio Sonata No. 2 and a couple of preludes and fugues by Marcel Dupre, consisted of tedious third-rate pieces that only organists could love - the Allegro from Widor's Symphony No. 6, Reger's Fantasy on ''Hallelujah, Gott zu loben'' and Franck's ''Priere.''

title: BUS RIDERS GIVE THEIR SIDE
description: HACKENSACK FOR the second time in a year, commuters have told NJ Transit officials what they think of a new round of proposed fare increases and service reductions for the state's troubled mass-transit system.

title: Kayaking in France
description: To the Editor:

title: THE PRESIDENTIAL TROIKA
description: Hedrick Smith is chief Washington correspondent of The New York Times. By Hedrick Smith The emergency room, George Washington University Hospital: A team of doctors is bent over President Reagan in a curtained partition when Presidential aides Edwin Meese 3d and James A. Baker 3d arrive. It is only 15 minutes after the assassination attempt and Michael K. Deaver, a third key Reagan aide, who came directly to the hospital with the President, is comforting Nancy Reagan in between hurried calls to the White House.

title:
VIEWS OF SPORT;
JOE LOUIS: A MAN OF INNATE DIGNITY, INTEGRITY AND GRACE
description: Sports fans grown to maturity in the years since World War II may not realize fully the impact Joe Louis had on the mores of his times. To anyone under the age of 45 it is difficult to imagine recent sports history minus Willie Mays and Hank Aaron, Oscar Robertson and Julius Erving, Jimmy Brown and O.J. Simpson, Arthur Ashe and Althea Gibson, and, of course, Muhammad Ali.

title: CASINOS URGE JERSEY TO EASE RULES ON FREE JUNKET
description: Spokesmen for New Jersey's casino industry told the Assembly's State Government Committee today that the Casino Control Act must be amended to encourage free junkets for ''high rollers'' if the industry was to survive economically during Atlantic City's chilly winters.

title: SEARCH FOR 2 GUNMEN IN OFFICERS' SHOOTING CENTERING ON NEWARK
description: The police continued to press their search yesterday for the two gunmen who wounded two officers, one critically, Thursday in Queens. A department spokesman said the investigation was centering on Newark.

title: NEW ARTS CENTER
description: VALHALLA ON a hill overlooking woods and a creek to the north and the elegant Hartford mansion to the south, is the newest public arts facility in the county, the Academic/Arts Building of Westchester Community College. At its May 4 dedication, the key will pass from the architects to the contractor and then down the line to all those involved in planning the $7 million structure, which will provide space for dancers, painters, actors and musicians.

title: Stage View; IN 'THE FATHER,' STRINDBERG STRUCK BACK AT IBSEN
description: Obvious as it is, it hadn't occurred to me before that of course Strindberg would have resented Ibsen's idealization of women and barely suppressed contempt for men. Ibsen's women are complex, tough-minded realists, capable of looking a fact in the eye and freezing it on the spot; and they are usually right. His men, on the other hand, are obtuse, wooly-headed idealists, pompous poseurs who must be babied by their wiser wives unless they are being abandoned altogether. Ibsen's men are a laughing matter; if the world is ever going to be straightened out, his women will have to do it.

title: Miss Woodward Fiancee of Banker; July Wedding Set
description: Mr. and Mrs. M. Cabell Woodward Jr. of Rye, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Margaret Beale Woodward, to Victor Kiarsis Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Kiarsis of South Dartmouth, Mass. A July wedding is planned.

title: CUTS PERIL SCHOOL LUNCHES
description: IF the Reagan Administration's proposed cuts in the Federal nutrition assistance programs are approved as they stand now, most school districts throughout Nassau and Suffolk Counties will be forced to charge substantially higher prices for the midday meals they serve or will be asking district taxpayers to assume yet another financial responsiblity.

title:
SPORTS OF THE TIMES;
THE FINE ART OF BUNCO
description: check writer and bunco artist.'' Confessing to his true identity came hard to Smith-Fields, possibly because he is an artist. ''The stupid,'' Willa Cather wrote, ''believe that to be truthful is easy, only the artist, the great artist, knows how difficult it is.''

title: Paul Hattam Fiance Of Lauren Fierman
description: Dr. Louis B. Fierman of Guilford, Conn., and Ella Fierman of Woodbridge, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lauren Cecile Hoj Fierman, to Paul Hattam, son of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Hattam of Cramlington, England.

title: FIRST AMENDMENT HUBRIS
description: The fabricated stroy that won a Pultizer Prize has made newspaper people think about their business as nothing else has for years-and not just on the paper that printed it, The Washington Post. There is a sharpened concern about the responsibility of reporters and editors: the standards we impose on ourselves.

title: Orioles-Royals Rained Out
description: The game between the Kansas City Royals and the Baltimore Orioles was postponed today because of rain. The game was rescheduled as part of a twilight-night doubleheader to be played Aug. 4.

title: WALKING TOURS ON TAP
description: Large cities usually are the ones cited most frequently for their architectural variety and masterpieces; all too often, there are real architectural gems in smaller cities and towns that go unnoticed.

title: No Headline
description: As the mother of a 2-year-old child, I refuse to allow myself to succumb to the dissociation described by Dr. Leon Balter. The future of my child - and of the world - is too important.

title: NOW THE FOCUS SHIFTS TO WOMEN
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Annette Insdorf teaches film at Yale University and is the author of ''Francois Truffaut.'' By ANNETTE INSDORF

title: Giants 4, Braves 1
description: ATLANTA (AP) - Tom Griffin pitched a four-hitter in his first complete game since 1976, and Joe Morgan hit a two-run homer to lead San Francisco over the Braves.

title: Rethinking the Unthinkable
description: ""Rethinking the Unthinkable'' (by Wade Greene, March 15), nuclear war strategists Colin S. Gray and Herman Kahn support the view that nuclear wars are fightable and winnable. While we have no experience as a guide for how future nuclear wars will be fought, it strains the imagination to posit each side coolly and calmly destroying each others' missile forces through the detonation of thousands of nuclear warheads, resulting in millions of immediate civilian casualties and eventual radioactive fallout, and leaving the matter at that.

title: The Measured View of Crime
description: It's hardly news any more to hear that the nation is reeling from a tidal wave of crime. The networks and news magazines proclaim it with special reports and cover stories. And people feel they never had to be told; they are fearful and more than ever buying heavy locks, burglar alarms, guns. Nobody is safe; the well-known Washington physician can die as senselessly in a burglary as a defenseless grandmother in Queens. The despair shadows the nation's economy, politics and morale.

title: Realty News
description: 13 Middletown, N.J.

title: HELEN SACKLER ENGAGED
description: Dr. and Mrs. Alvin M. Sackler of Bergenfield, N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Helen Sue Sackler, to Tony Ettinger, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joel H. Ettinger of Roslyn, L.I. A July wedding is planned.

title: UTILITIES SET TO CUT NONPAYERS
description: HARTFORD BEGINNING tomorrow, 145,000 families and individuals who buy electricity and gas from Northeast Utilities but who fell far behind in their bills over the winter face loss of utility service. Thousands of customers of other utilities have faced the same threat since last Wednesday, when a winter moratorium on disconnections expired, according to utility officials.

title: UPLIFTING CAMPAIGN AGAINST A WEED
description: MY kids are the first to notice. Jason says, ''You're tense, Dad.'' Joshua adds, ''Oooo ... are you grouchy!'' And perceptive Jessica chimes, ''Must be that time of year.''

title: Cuban Refugee Is Shot In Fort Chaffee Disturbance
description: About 100 Cuban refugees threw stones and overturned cars tonight in a disturbance in which one refugee was shot and several military personnel suffered minor injuries, the authorities said.

title: Connecticut Guide; NEW HAVEN BIRTHDAY
description: Although 343 may not be New Haven's most auspicious birthday, the city is nevertheless holding a three-day celebration beginning at noon Friday with the cutting of a six-tier cake on the green. As balloons drift skyward and the Governor's Foot Guard stands by, a carillon of ''Happy Birthday to You'' will peal an accompaniment to the munching of hundreds of slices of birthday cake.

title: Margaret Lavelle Fiancee
description: The engagement of Margaret Lavelle to George Benet Bradt, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Bradt Jr., has been announced by the bride-tobe's parents, Mr. and Mrs. John Lavelle of Bayside, Queens. A September wedding is planned.

title: WINTER MEMORIES: COLD, WARM, DRY, WET
description: WITH the official end of winter on March 21 - and unofficially at the end of the month - we are inclined to look ahead to the warmth of spring and forget the cold discomfort and all the unpleasantnesses of the season past. Each Westchester winter is different, however, and each has its own unique character, which is worth remembering if only for solidifying forever a certain season in one's memory.

title: TAXPAYER SUIT AGAINST AGNEW TO BE HEARD TUESDAY
description: The long-delayed trial of a novel civil damage claim against former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew is scheduled to open here next week, without his presence but with the prospect of new details about the kickback charges that forced his resignation in 1973.

title: More on Ravenna
description: To the Editor:

title: INFLATION AS A DEFLATER OF THE MASCULINE ROLE
description: CONCERN about the sex-role stereotyping of men has been placed on the back burner as a result of the emphasis focused upon its precipitated ramifications for women.

title: Long Island Journal
description: SETTING out to raise $65,000 during its recent three-day on-the-air ''Gallery 21'' auction, WLIW, the Island's noncommercial television station, went over the top in its major fund appeal. With $74,451 bid for 300 items - and $57,000 collected within a week after the final gavel sounded - Arthur M. Gillick, president and general manager of the station, called the auction ''a great success.''

description: NONFICTION ART AND THE QUESTION OF MEANING. By Hans Kung. 9 CHARGE IT! Inside the Credit Card Conspiracy. By Terry Galanoy. 12 CIRCLE OF POISON: Pesticides and People in a Hungry World.

title: Navajos and Hopis Likely To Continue Land Dispute
description: The Navajos and Hopis officially got jurisdiction today over their shares of almost 2 million acres of Arizona's High Plains, officially ending a century-old land dispute.

title: C.G. OLINGER JR. TO WED CARLA DRAGON ON MAY 30
description: Mr. and Mrs. Carl Edward Dragan of Cincinnati, Ohio, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Carla R. Dragan, to Chauncey Greene Olinger Jr., son of Mr. Olinger of Norfolk, Va., and the late Mrs. Olinger.

title: Kicks 1, Sting 0
description: CHICAGO (UPI) - Ron Futcher scored on an assist from Ricardo Alonso to give Minnesota the victory. Phil Parkes, the Chicago goalkeeper, made only two saves, both in the second half, in the tight, defensive game. The Minnesota goalkeeper, Tino Lettieri, made seven saves, including one off a short rebound shot by Ivan Miljkovik in the last minute that preserved the victory.

title: No Headline
description: Is Lawrence Beilenson joking when he suggests that the increased incidence of cancer caused by a future nuclear war ''could be canceled out by neglecting to rebuild the cigarette industry''? I don't know about you, but the first thing I'll want after a nuclear war (''victorious'' or not) will be a good smoke. PAUL SPENCER, Annandale-on-Hudson, N.Y.

title:
Stamps;
THE NEW ISSUES SAY IT WITH FLOWERS
description: The first commemorative issue bearing the new 18-cent denomination is coming out on Thursday at Fort Valley, Ga., and the United States Postal Service is making the new higher rate more palatable by ''saying it with flowers.'' The commemoratives are a setenant block of four multicolors depicting four of the nation's most beautiful and popular flowers - the rose, the camellia, the dahlia and the lily.

title: G.O.P. SEES GOOD WORKS AS GOOD POLITICS
description: ''Republican partisans must be active in their respective communities offering volunteer service that heretofore our loyal opposition has made the province of government,'' proclaims a report to Richard Richards, chairman of the Republican National Committee.

title: MULTIPLE CINEMAS INCREASING
description: AFTER a recent showing of the Academy Award-winning film ''Ordinary People'' at the Central Triplex Theater in Cedarhurst, Lisa Klein of Woodmere felt let down. ''If I wanted to watch TV, I could have sat at home,'' she said. ''The screen was so small that I couldn't experience the movie vividly.''

title: THE EASTER BUNNY: A GOOD, BUT UNBELIEVABLE, EGG
description: MY childhood ended at age 6. By 7, I was a sneering cynic, a ''show-me'' doubter of virtually everything adults said. Disillusionment started with the Easter Bunny. Eight-year-old Tommy, the Montana ranch kid I was visiting that Easter, pointed out that the eggs I had hunted so avidly that morning were just fancily colored hens' eggs. He took me to their hen house and showed me roosting hens and their eggs, then to the rabbit hutch where Momma Rabbit was nursing many preservers of her species. The evidence and his logic seemed unassailable.

title: MUSIC: VARESE TRIBUTE
description: Ever since the 60's, people have been trying to force marriages between classical music and the rock audience. One of the more successful of such efforts took place Friday night at the Palladium, New York's principal rock emporium in the 3,000-seat range (3,400, to be precise). The occasion was a Varese concert by Joel Thome and the Orchestra of Our Time. What made it a rock event, and attracted a near sell-out crowd of predominantly rock fans (apart from some doughty if somewhat bemused classical types in the center orchestra seats) was the presence of Frank Zappa, erstwhile Mother of Invention.

title: Russian Cruise
description: To the Editor:

title: Music View; AND NOW, THE WORLD'S FIRST COMPOSING MACHINE
description: The other day as I was hard at work opening my mail while attempting to put a pin in my shirt cuff, I found myself musing about the undeniable supremacy of American technology. Talk all you like about Japanese cameras and cars, but can any nation match the efficiency of the button crusher that all New York laundries have on line? Hardly. So my eyes were naturally caught by this line, which leaped out of an announcement by the Composers' Forum of its spring concert series starting on Tuesday at Cooper Union: ''According to Composers' Forum President Joel Chadabe, 'The Sal-Mar Construction is an historically important musical event and a stunning and classical display of individual American invention. It must be seen and heard!' ''

title: North Stars Go Home 5-0 in Playoffs
description: They aren't chanting ''Break up the North Stars'' in the National Hockey League yet, but Minnesota is making another determined run at Stanley Cup playoff glory with five straight victories in the playoffs.

title: THIS CAT HAS THEATERGOERS PURRING
description: The musical at the Palace is ''Woman of the Year'' and it stars not only Lauren Bacall and Harry Guardino but also an irascible New York cat named Katz, an animated cartoon of a feline who whirls about on ingenious screens, sings, dances and talks to his creator.

description: CONSEQUENCES By SAMUEL W. LAIRD

title: REPUBLICANS SEEK BENEFIT FROM FIGHT OVER BUDGET
description: HARTFORD OUTSIDE the offices of the Republican leaders of the House of Representatives at the State Capitol is a chart that illustrates the political side of the General Assembly's scheduled debate this week on a new state budget.

title: Susan Larabee Married To Robert Levy, Lawyer
description: Susan R. Larabee and Robert M. Levy were married yesterday at the International House in Indianapolis. Judge Gerald Zore of the Superior Court of Indiana performed the ceremony.

title: HIDING FROM TAXES
description: To the Business Editor: Regarding ''How Tax Evasion Has Grown'' (March 15): Estimates that the underground economy - primarily economic activity that is itself legal, but goes unreported for tax purposes -comprises 7 percent to 10 percent of gross national product are reasonable, but the notion that the underground sector is gaining share is almost certainly incorrect.

title: BEIRUT DOCTOR SEES MANY WOUNDED, LITTLE PROGRESS
description: Whether or not a cease-fire is in force between the Syrians and the Christians or between the Christians and the Palestinians, casualties come into Barbir Medical Center every day because somebody shoots at somebody else.

title:
Gardening;
GREENHOUSES: A LUXURY BECOMES A HOBBY
description: IN past years, the private greenhouse was considered to be only for the wealthy. Their vast greenhouse ranges and conservatories were used to force exotic blooms and fruits out of season and to house vast collections of rare plants.

title: JUVENILE-JUSTICE GOALS HELD TO BE CHANGING
description: DOBBS FERRY WHEN representatives of the diverse network that makes up the county's juvenile-justice system gathered at Mercy College to discuss ''Juvenile Crime - Does the Justice System Work?'' the nearly unanimous conclusion was that it does not. But the explanations offered were varied, and the solutions proposed were scarce.

title: Arkady Aranov, Pianist, In a Program of Sonatas
description: Arkady Aranov performed widely in his native Russia before coming to the United States in 1977, but last Sunday's concert of piano music at the 92d Street Y constituted his formal introduction to New York audiences.

title: Student Held in Slayings at Dorm Is Arraigned on 2 Murder Counts
description: A University of Michigan student who is suspected of firebombing a dormitory and killing two students with a shotgun as they ran from the blaze was arraigned today on two counts of murder.

title: Jennifer Rand Sets Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Calvin G. Rand of New York have made known the engagement of their daughter, Jennifer Jewett Rand, to William Stapleton Griffis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence W. Griffis Jr. of Buffalo. The wedding is planned for Aug. 15.

title: Sato Knocks Out Abedoy
description: Johnny Sato of Stockton claimed the vacant North American Boxing Federation junior-lightweight crown yesterday by knocking out Manuel Abedoy at 2 minutes 59 seconds of the 11th round.

title: Rudolf Schoenfeld, Ambassador To 3 Nations for U.S., Dies at 86
description: Rudolf E. Schoenfeld, former United States Ambassador to Rumania, Guatemala and Colombia, died Wednesday at his Washington home. He was 86 years old.

title: BOURGES: A LIVELY CATHEDRAL TOWN
description: The industrious little city of Bourges, which lies at the geographical heart of France, could never be characterized as a sleepy cathedral town. It is, to the contrary, very much awake, as was recently demonstrated when its citizens rose to protest the construction of a convention hall that would have obstructed the view of their beloved cathedral. Gathering 17,000 signatures from among the town's 80,000 inhabitants, they forced the city to scrap its plans and, as a result, a public garden and underground parking lot now occupy the site.

description: WITH the opening of the Yale Center for British Art and with the Yale Repertory and Long Wharf Theaters going strong, New Haven has emerged over the last two years as a focal point for day trippers from all around the state.

title: Auto Regulation

Indeed, his office delayed for months the very safety proposals he complains were issued in ''one last orgy'' in January 1981. There are a number of fallacies in his article, some pointed out in Leon S. Robertson's ''Regulating the Auto'' (March 29). In addition:

description: ''Late City Edition,'' a satirical revue that made its first appearance last January at Symphony Space for a two-week run, has returned to that auditorium at Broadway and 95th Street to play late-evening performances on Fridays and Saturdays for the rest of the season.

Baldridge of Billings, Mont., and Mary G. Baldridge of Dallas. The wedding is planned for June. Miss Caulfield's father is assistant to the chairman of the Joint Industry Board in New York.

title: CABLE TV BEGINS TO MAKE BIG CHANGES IN PROFESSIONAL SPORTS
description: Cable television's arrival was predicted for so many years that people barely noticed when it finally came. But, with about 20 percent of the United States ''wired'' for cable, it has become a major factor in the way sports teams think about themselves, their fans and their future.

title: Critics' Choice
description: DANCE Asia Society goes all out this week to celebrate the opening of its new Lila Acheson Wallace Auditorium. The theater will open with performances of Kathakali, a form of highly stylized traditional dance-drama from South India, performed by members of the Kerala Kalamandalam.

title: AMERICA'S FORECAST FOR FALL
description: After trekking to showings of designer collections in Milan and Paris, the multitudes who buy and report upon women's ready-to-wear conclude their round robin this week in New York, where the bulk of the buying is done. Judging from these preview sketches and photographs taken for The New York Times, they will find America's top talents offering their usual diversity of wearable clothes. The interesting difference for fall 1981, according to the designers, is that most of the clothes are either ''romantic'' or ''opulent.''

description: The Past Comes Back

title: Leslie Alice Conway, Hamilton Alumna, Is Engaged to Robert Christopher Regan
description: The engagement of Leslie Alice Conway to Robert Christopher Regan has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Granville Elliot Conway of New Vernon, N.J. Mr. Regan is a son of Mr. and Mrs. John MacVeigh Regan of New York and Watch Hill, R.I. A June wedding is planned.

title: YONDER AND BACK
description: LATE off the drawing boards, tardy in development, delayed off the launching pad, the space shuttle Columbia was running some 24 hours behind schedule this weekend as engineers at Edwards Air Force Base in California continued their elaborate post-flight inspections.

title: Chess; A LESSON FOR SCHMID
description: Lothar Schmid discovered in this year's BBC International Tournament in London that it is harder to win a second time around. The West German grandmaster took first prize last year, but finished last this time.

title: Cutting Back In Washington
description: Responsible people want President Reagan's program to succeed (''David Stockman: The President's Cutting Edge,'' by Sidney Blumenthal, March 15).

description: ''NOW you're talking about something that hurts me very badly,'' said Dr. Gary Paparo, the County Medical Examiner, when asked about the indictments announced last week of two former employees in connection with the theft and use of credit cards belonging to two victims of last December's fire at the Stouffer's Inn.

title: Miss Stillger, D. F. Winter Will Be Wed
description: Dr. and Mrs. Walter Marcel Stillger of Muttontown, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Delphine Marie-Pierre Stillger, to Duncan Forbes Winter, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clark Burritt Winter of Garden City, L. I.

description: Mr. and Mrs. Nelson J. Leidner of Huntingdon Valley, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cynthia Ann Leidner, to Carl Anton Muller, son of Mrs. Dorothy Rinaldy Muller of Coos Bay, Ore., and Theodore Carl Muller of Westport, Conn. The wedding will take place next month.

description: Sportschannel, the cable-TV station that already has the Yankees, Mets, Islanders, Nets and Arrows among local teams, is going to add thoroughbred racing to its athletic menu.

title: Robin Diane Lustine Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. J. Gerald Lustine of Bethesda, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Robin Diane Lustine, to Dr. Bob Alan Cohn, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Cohn of Westbury, L.I. Dr. Cohn is a veterinarian. The wedding is planned for June.

description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Judy Glattstein is coordinator of the Wilton, Conn. Community Gardens and an instructor in wild flower cultivation. By JUDY GLATTSTEIN

description: Christina Campbell Thuerk and Steven Pincus were married yesterday in the clubhouse of the New York Junior League. State Supreme Court Justice Anthony T. Jordan performed the ceremony.

title: SKY DIVER, AS CRAFT COLLIDED: 'I'M DEAD'
description: John Ezequelle, one of four stunned parachutists who survived a midair plane collision yesterday that left 15 people dead, recalled today that he was sitting behind the pilot of their single-engine Cessna 206 when he saw an Air U.S. commuter plane approaching.

title: SCIENTISTS TRY TO SAVE AILING SPERM WHALE OFF L.I. SHORE
description: Marine scientists were trying yesterday to save the life of a rare sperm whale that had tried to beach itself near Jones Beach on Long Island.

title: Writer to Wed Cari Castronova
description: The engagement of Cari Castronova, widow of Paul Castronova, to Ira Kaufman, a sports writer for United Press International in New York, has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Arthur C. Smith of Lake Ronkonkoma, L.I. Mr. Kaufman is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Kaufman of Brooklyn. Mrs. Castronova is a senior clerk with the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey in Jersey City.

title: No Headline
description: A high-ranking Kremlin official spoke tonight of increased counterrevolution in Poland from forces inside the country and abroad. He reaffirmed that Moscow would not desert its ally ''in its hour of need.''

title:
Long Island Housing;
ASSESSORS, CRITICIZED, TELL WHY TAXES VARY SO MUCH
description: ''I'M the sole assessor in Smithtown,'' said Nat Amato, the Smithtown assessor, ''and that's s-o-l-e. Assessors aren't supposed to have souls.''

title: BRITAIN DISCOVERS A RACE PROBLEM, TO ITS SURPRISE
description: The bricks and firebombs that went crashing through windows of dozens of shops and police cars in South London last weekend also shattered well-established public attitudes about race relations.

title: A PENNY FUTURE IN ZINC
description: Major American producers of zinc, the metal mainly used to galvanize steel against rust, have been limping along since 1974, when a shortage spurred prices to 60 to 70 cents a pound. Last year, though major steel users like autos and construction did poorly, the price of zinc scarcely wavered from its annual average of 37 cents. However, a brighter future for producers seems in the cards.

title: Reunion in A New Land
description: Although we live in New Jersey, we frequently patronize a restaurant in Warwick, N.Y. (''Laotians in a New Land,'' by Mike Norman, March 1). We were pleased to share our copy of The New York Times Magazine with the proprietress of this restaurant, and she, in turn, with some Laotians whom she employs.

title: No Headline
description: What Wade Greene fails to mention is that the men who are in high enough positions to stage a nuclear holocaust would do so from underground shelters, in secret locations. When they dream of ''winning'' by letting only 20 million Americans die, they are toying with our lives, not their own. WILLIAM DEFOTIS, Urbana, Ill.

title: THE NATION IN SUMMARY
description: After a seven-and-a-half-week trial last November, a Federal jury decided that the tense times and national security concerns of the early 70's didn't make ''black bag jobs'' undertaken by the Federal Bureau of Investigation any less unconstitutional.

Gardening;
