description: IN past years, the private greenhouse was considered to be only for the wealthy. Their vast greenhouse ranges and conservatories were used to force exotic blooms and fruits out of season and to house vast collections of rare plants.

title: SWEDEN OPENS ITS NEW DANCE MUSEUM
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Walter Terry, dance critic for Saturday Review, is author of 20 books on the dance. By WALTER TERRY STOCKHOLM ''It is the only dance museum in the world,'' says Bengt Hager proudly. The founder-director of the prestigious Dance Museum in Stockholm adds, ''Of course there are fine theater museums with dance sections and your own Dance Collection at the New York Public Library in New York is bigger, but it's more of an archive than a museum. Here in Stockholm we have the Dance Museum but we share our treasures with visitors and our dance information with researchers and performers around the world.''

title: MILLION DOLLAR VICTORY
description: Hardly anyone ever accuses Los Angeles Mayor Tom Bradley of being a spellbinder. Going into last week's election, however, he had a few things going for him, including a high-powered media consultant from back East and $1 million to spend on his campaign. After winning his third four-year term in a landslide, Mr. Bradley, the city's first black mayor, said that he wanted to "savor this for a few days" before commenting further on his political plans.

title: THE REGION IN SUMMARY
description: After failing to put out the fire at the bargaining table, Yonkers Mayor Gerald E. Loehr was forced to battle a real blaze last week, one of several that threatened to burn out of control while 400 firefighters and 600 other municipal employees staged a two-day strike.

title: No Headline
description: Why do our retiring Presidents warn against forces over whose buildup they have presided? Wade Greene mentions, for example, that President Carter warned against the ''horrifying danger posed by the enormous stockpiles of nuclear weapons.'' And President Eisenhower, on leaving office, warned us about the ''military-industrial complex.'' Is it possible that even Presidents are powerless against the real giants? RUTH MANSBERG, Pound Ridge, N.Y.

title: Another Danger Seen In Recycling Plants
description: I trust North Hempstead Supervisor Michael J. Tully will not act hastily (''State Seeks Role in Recycling on L.I.'') in erecting a recycling plant. I have been told that this project is quite safe because plants in operation overseas have had no problems. The then Town of Hempstead Supervisor, Alfonse D'Amato, gave us the same assurances when he contemplated building the ill-fated $135 million plant in Hempstead. Mr. D'Amato told his critics that he had visited similar plants in the Midwest and could find nothing wrong with them.

title: Christopher Berg Plays Varied Guitar Program
description: Christopher Berg trained at the Peabody Conservatory of Music in Baltimore and now is chairman of the guitar department at the University of South Carolina. He made a rather cautious New York debut in Carnegie Recital Hall on Thursday night.

title:
Numismatics;
COIN DEALERS DIVERSIFY TO BROADEN THEIR HORIZONS
description: Diversification is the spice of life - or so it would appear, judging from recent activities by several of the nation's leading coin dealerships that have moved outside the numismatic field in search of new business and are laying the groundwork for even further expansion along these lines.

title: Market for Wooden Boats Is on the Rise
description: The United States Coast Guard observed, in a recent boating safety circular, that the day may be approaching when ''buyers will not be able to afford the price of fiberglass boats.'' Then, apparently, there will be a return to boats made of wood.

title: U.S. NAVAL BUILDUP IS CHALLENGING SOVIET ADVANCES IN ASIA AND AFRICA SUPREMACY AT SEA
description: As a result of the most ambitious naval deployment since the Vietnam War, the United States has become a major naval power in the Indian Ocean, challenging the advances of Soviet sea and ground forces in Africa and Asia.

title: ZEALOTS SPURN COMMON MARKET AID TO MT. ATHOS MONASTIC COMMUNITY
description: The Zealots, the most puritanical and dogmatic Eastern Orthodox monks of this self-administered monastic community, are refusing prospective financial assistance from the Common Market on the ground that the money would come from ''Catholic-dominated governments and peoples who have strayed from Christianity.''

title:
ECONOMIC AFFAIRS;
DETROIT, HOW THE MIGHTY HAVE FALLEN
description: THE rise and decline of the American automobile industry is a poignant example of the economic troubles and policy dilemmas facing American capitalism today.

title: DANCE: EIKO AND KOMA EXPERIMENT
description: Much of the work of Eiko and Koma comes close to spectacle, and ''Trilogy,'' a full-evening piece presented on Thursday at the attractive new Greene Space, a SoHo gallery, is no exception. The young Japanese experimentalists have created an hour's worth of theatrical movement that aims for startling visual effect and the blurring of normal perceptions of the body.

title: VOLUNTEER GROUPS TO PATROL ATLANTA
description: Some 200 volunteers armed only with green and white baseball caps, photo identification cards and walkie-talkies are expected to be on the streets Monday as police-sanctioned citizens' patrols watching over neighborhoods shaken by the mysterious deaths of 23 youngsters and the disappearances of two others in the last 20 months.

title: No Headline
description: Ken Williams, who was born in Jamaica and raised in England, led Prospect Heights High School of Brooklyn to a meet record yesterday in the Mobil Big Apple Relay Carnival on the John F. Kennedy track in the Bronx.

title: THE ART OF RUNNING SUBSIDIZED BUIDINGS
description: It is the basic South Bronx landscape of burned-out buildings and rubble, a scene so typical it served as the backdrop for portions of the film, ''Fort Apache, the Bronx.'' Yet down the street and around the corner is Aldus Green, 11 occupied buildings that are neat and secure. There is no graffiti or garbage, no broken windows.

title: ISLANDERS' POWER PLAY IS DOWNFALL OF OILERS
description: Leading by 2-0 in their National Hockey League quarterfinal series with the Oilers, the Islanders flew to Edmonton, Alberta, last night for Games 3 and 4 tonight and tomorrow at Northlands Coliseum. The Islanders took their power play with them.

title: TWO JOHNSONS PLAY LARGE ROLES IN BRINGING BUCKS TO 7TH GAME
description: Mickey and Marques Johnson, the Milwaukee Bucks' starting forwards, have basketball backgrounds as unrelated as they are. But both have played major roles in bringing the Eastern Conference semifinal round to a seventh and deciding game against the 76ers today at The Spectrum in Philadelphia.

title: City Council Units List Meetings for the Week
description: The following meetings by committees of the City Council have been scheduled for this week: TUESDAY - Committee on Public Safety, City Hall, 10 A.M.; Committee on Economic Development, City Hall, 1:30 P.M. WEDNESDAY - Committee on Health, 250 Broadway, 23d floor, 10 A.M. THURSDAY - Committee on Education, City Hall, 10 A.M.; Committee on Consumer Affairs, City Hall, 1:30 P.M.; Council's Public Utility Review Board, 250 Broadway, 23d floor, 3:30 P.M.

title: BAN UNLIKELY TO END BATTLE OVER URANIUM
description: TRENTON ALTHOUGH the State Legislature recently passed a bill banning mining, milling or exploring for uranium in New Jersey, the yearlong, often-emotional debate may not be over.

title: Jean Kopperud Plays Brahms Clarinet Sonata
description: Jean Kopperud, a young clarinetist who has studied and performed both here and abroad, brought energy and involvement to her solo recital debut at the Abraham Goodman House last Thursday evening. The program was an admirable mix of old and new - the Brahms F minor Duo Sonata and Bartok's ''Contrasts'' being the known commodities, and rare pieces by Leonard Bernstein, Peter Maxwell Davies, Donald Martino and Gerald Finzi adding the spice of novelty.

title: No Headline
description: Trevino Holds Lead By a Stroke on 70-204

title: Magruder Switch
description: Jeb Magruder, one of the President's men in the Watergate case, had embarked on a new life of Christian service after a short term in prison for obstructing justice. Then, in August 1979, after completing two and a half years of studies for a Master of Divinity degree at the Princeton Theological Seminary, he changed course.

title: FOR CUBAN REFUGEES, PROMISE OF U.S. FADES
description: A year ago, clinging to the rails of small boats tossing in the waterspouts and squalls of the Florida Strait, the first adventurers among what was to be a flood of 124,789 new refugees from Cuba began their crossing to the United States.

title: BRINGING A NEW DIMENSION TO BADNESS
description: He is the kind of man who can stroll into a shop, tell a lovely young salesgirl how pretty she is and that he'll be back in a moment, and then coolly blow up the building. He is the kind of man who shoots a colleague at point-blank range for making a mistake. Whether the day's work includes machine-gunning a crowd of people, charming a stewardess into letting him move in with her (needless to say, she will die for her lack of judgment), or hijacking the Roosevelt Island tramway and casually dropping people overboard, he remains at all times calm, calculating and unrelentingly sadistic.

title: Around the Garden
description: This Week:

title: FOR TUITION TAX CREDIT AND VOUCHERS
description: English WASHINGTON - Some form of tax relief for families that patronize private schools is likely in the 1980's.

title: PATERSON: STILL BEAUTIFUL RELIC TRYING HARD FOR COMEBACK
description: PATERSON FOR years, the soot-stained mills and factories around the Great Falls here churned out the engines of industrial expansion for a booming nation. Today, the bustling industrial district is a halfdeserted relic whose major distinction is historical.

title: Redistricting Along Jersey Party Lines
description: Although they agreed last year to work out a bloodless redistricting plan, members of the bipartisan New Jersey Reapportionment Commission haggled themselves into a deadlock once it became clear there could be no compromise without casualties. So, with an eye to the April 13 deadline for certification of new districts reflecting population shifts revealed in the 1980 census, the State Supreme Court appointed Donald Stokes, a dean of the Woodrow Wilson School at Princeton University, as a tie-breaking 11th member of the commission.

title: THE NEW BARYSHNIKOV: WILL HE STAR BACKSTAGE AS HE DOES ON STAGE?
description: The Mikhail Baryshnikov who steps on stage at tomorrow's opening of American Ballet Theater's 8-week season at the Metropolitan Opera House remains one of the greatest dancers in the history of ballet. But this time he is a superstar with a difference. Not only will this be his first appearance with the company in New York since 1978 but also the first time he will appear in his new position as Ballet Theater's artistic director.

title: SALE OF DREDGING SPOIL YIELDS A BONUS
description: SETAUKET WHEN the Town of Brookhaven had the channel along West Meadow Beach dredged by the Suffolk County Department of Public Works and the Cushman Dredging Company last October, about 15,000 cubic yards of dredging spoil were dumped at the shore, forming a six-foot-high slope. Homeowners along the stretch of beach complained to town officials that the mounds of sand and gravel aggregate, which reached as high as their windows, were unsightly.

title: Suspects Held in Salvador
description: The Reagan Administration has untied many of the Carter Administration's strings between human rights and foreign aid. But its support for El Salvador's civilian-military junta has been challenged in Congress because of Salvadoran security forces' reported involvement in political assassinations, in particular the killing of four American women missionary workers in December and the murder in January of the head of El Salvador's land reform program and two of his American advisers.

title: Upstaging Reagan
description: President Reagan was at the other end of the phone line, and Dan Sullivan, the drama critic of The Los Angeles Times, said that his immediate reaction was: ''Wow, the President!'' Mr. Reagan wanted Mr. Sullivan to print a good word for a foundering musical, ''Turn to the Right,'' starring Buddy Ebsen. The President's tone indicated, the critic said last month, that Mr. Reagan and Mr. Ebsen were friends.

title: MADISON
description: THE 250th birthday of Philip Mazzei, the Italian-American patriot, will be celebrated next Saturday at Fairleigh Dickinson University here.

title: Pushing a Pram And Pushing a Pen
description: My friends and I have been passing around the recent Elyse Trevers piece, ''She's Free Now - Except ...'' (Opinion Page). Even though for most of us full-time ''mommying'' is only a temporary situation, we are still experiencing many of the difficulties that she mentioned.

title: THE PRESS MUST SCRUTINIZE ITS OWN ETHICS
description: WHEN members of the New Jersey Press Association recently assembled for their annual convention to cite the best work of 1980 and consider the state of journalism, one important question was raised and quickly dismissed.

title: SICILY IN SPRING: A FLOWERING ISLE WREATHED IN ANTIQUITY
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- JAMES EGAN is a writer who lives in Connecticut. By JAMES EGAN

title: WHEN HARRIERS RUN IT'S FOR STEW AND BEER
description: CHAPPAQUA ON a recent Saturday afternoon, the quiet of Whippoorwill Park in this northern Westchester town was shattered by the sound of 20 runners flashing through the woods, shouting, ''On! On!''

title: Police in Boston Decide Not to Disrupt Marathon
description: Saying they did not want to embarrass the city, members of Boston's police union voted overwhelmingly today against disrupting the Boston Marathon as a means of protesting the layoff of hundreds of officers.

title: COMMUNIST-CHRISTIAN CONFLICT IN CUBA SEEMS TO EASE
description: At the narrow mouth of Havana Bay, a 70-foot white marble statue of Jesus, depicted as the risen Christ of Easter, looms over an embankment that drops sharply to the water. Hastily erected by the tottering regime of Fulgencio Batista days before his overthrow in 1959, it is a symbol of the ambivalence with which religion exists under the Communist Government of Fidel Castro.

title: STRIPER BILL CALLED INADEQUATE
description: There is perhaps no better indication of the difficulties facing those trying to stop the steady decline of Atlantic Coast striped bass populations than the current deliberations over proposed New York State legislation that would make the harvesting of any striper under 24 inches illegal.

title: NEW U.S. PASSPORTS TO BE ISSUED SOON
description: Americans who travel abroad will soon be issued a new passport that can be read by a machine in an effort to speed the passage of travelers through red tape at borders and to reduce fraud.

title: Donna Reimer To Be a Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. J. Squier Reimer of Bedford, N.Y., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Donna Alice Reimer, to Alexander Spotswood Hoes, son of Dr. and Mrs. John Spotswood Hoes of Rome and Cooperstown, N.Y. The wedding is planned for August in Bedford.

title: Politics; 'WAITING FOR TOBY'
description: HARTFORD DEMOCRATIC officials in Massachusetts used to play a political game known as ''Waiting for Teddy.'' A variation of that game is under way in Connecticut these days and it is known as ''Waiting for Toby.''

title: DAYLIGHT WASTING
description: To the Editor:

title: ENVIRONMENTALISTS, SEEING THREAT IN WHITE HOUSE POLICY, PLAN FIGHT
description: Although it always was much more than a group of bird watchers in tweeds and sturdy shoes, the National Audubon Society has never been known as a hotbed of political activism. But times and the society are changing.

title: Reading and Writing; REPUTATIONS DIE SLOW
description: Watching various reviewers trying to avoid saying anything unkind about Kurt Vonnegut's new book, ''Palm Sunday,'' one realizes that, contrary to public opinion, a literary reputation is the hardest thing in the world to lose. Once among the elect, a novelist is as difficult to impeach as a President. Again and again, he is given the benefit of the doubt, and since literary criticism is such a doubtful business, this is all the margin he needs.

title: N.C.A.A. IS FACING CUTBACKS IN SWIMMING
description: Sports Analysis By FRANK LITSKY

title: Carol Williamson Affianced to John Dizard
description: Mr. and Mrs. Warren Jackson Williamson of Greenville, Ala., have anounced the engagement of their daughter, Carol Williamson, to John William Dizard, son of Mr. and Mrs. Wilson Paul Dizard of Cambridge, Mass.

title: Katharine Sisson Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas K. Sisson of Concord, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Katharine T. Sisson, to George Richard Feehery Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Feehery of Atlanta. A September wedding is planned.

title: Expense Accounts
description: To the Business Editor: The implication of ''No Cuts Here: The Life on the Tab'' (March 29) is that the expense account is a John Doe taxpayer ripoff. That's curious, because when I had responsibility for approving expense accounts I looked at them as related to the production of income ... without which, needless to say, a corporation would pay no income taxes.

title: HAND FROM BUSINESS FOR CROTON REVIEW
description: THE managers of the boat supply store, the liquor store, the dry cleaner and 35 other small businesses in Croton-on-Hudson chipped in this year to sponsor a sophistifilled with free verse and avant-garde prose.

title: GOING BY PATH TO THE GROCER'S
description: Marcy Brownson and Robert W. Venables, and Bonnie Quint Kaplan and David Kaplan, good Manhattanites all, went to Hoboken the other night. They needed groceries.

title: Miss Hausman Fiancee of M. M. Holdstein
description: Elizabeth Hausman and Michael M. Holdstein of New York, graduates of Miami University in Oxford, Ohio, plan to be married in September. Their engagement has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Richard W. Sonnenfeldt of Port Washington, L. I., stepfather and mother of the bride-to-be. Mr. Holdstein, who manages the men's clothing department at Bloomingdale's in Garden City, L.I., is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Barthold Holdstein of Shaker Heights, Ohio.

title: 'Sister Carrie' In Full, At Last
description: Too sexually explicit, too rough in language, too pessimistic in outlook, said the editors, wife and publisher of Theodore Dreiser on reading the author's manuscript for ''Sister Carrie'' in 1901.

title: Connecticut Housing; REMODELING A MONEY-SAVING OPTION
description: AGHAST at the thought of giving up their low-interest, fixed-rate mortgages to move into a house better-suited to family needs or economic status, an increasing number of homeowners are remodeling instead of buying this spring.

title: Eleanor Hutzler Wed to A. B. Trowbridge
description: Eleanor K. Hutzler, widow of Charles G. Hutzler 3d, was married yesterday in Baltimore to Alexander B. Trowbridge, president of the National Association of Manufacturers. The Rev. William A. Wendt, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the home of bride's father, Sol Kann.

title: Christine Ashcraft Fiancee of Minister
description: Christine Hall Ashcraft, a lawyer in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and the Rev. Curtis Allen Larson, a Presbyterian minister there, will be married on Aug. 8 in the Abbey Church of St. Mary's on Iona Island, off the west coast of Scotland.

title: ARIANNA STASSINOPOULOS
description: When Arianna Stassinopoulos, the 30-year-old author of ''Maria Callas: The Woman Behind the Legend,'' talks about her best-selling biography, the phrase ''an extraordinary stroke of luck'' pops up again and again in her conversation. Miss Stassinopoulos is referring not to the fact that she is suddenly rich enough to pay off the debts she ran up while flying around the world to research Callas's life. Nor is she referring to the fact that her book gained instant notoriety with its intimate revelations about Callas's affair with Aristotle Onassis and the news that, shortly before Onassis died in 1975, he started divorce proceedings against Jacqueline Kennedy so he could marry Callas. Instead, Miss Stassinopoulos is talking about the remarkable circumstances, two in particular, that allowed her to write this book.

title: Mauritania Sentences 3 in Plot
description: A Mauritanian military court sentenced three men to death in absentia today on charges of taking part in an attempted coup last month, the Algerian press agency reported from the Mauritanian capital.

title: WETHERSFIELD, CONN., WHERE GEORGE WASHINGTON REALLY SLEPT
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- PATRICIA BROOKS, a writer who lives in New Canaan, Conn., reviews restaurants for the Connecticut Weekly section of The Times. By PATRICIA BROOKS

title: MASBACK ANCHORS 2 CLUB RELAY VICTORIES
description: The Rutgers Relays began seven years ago primarily as a springtime track meet for college and school athletes. Now the meet offers many races for club athletes, too, and Craig Masback, one of the better runners in the world, made the most of his opportunities today.

title: DANCE: TAYLOR'S 'RUNES' IN PREMIERE
description: The movement quality of Paul Taylor's dances is so absorbing - gasps are now heard in the City Center audience - that it is easy to overlook the ideas, themes and concepts behind his works.

title: Renita Margaret Esayian Engaged to Ronald Kechejian
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles Esayian of Huntingdon Valley, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Renita Margaret Esayian of New York, to Ronald Kechejian, son of Mr. and Mrs. Oscar Kechejian of Larchmont, N.Y.

title: Miss Griggs Plans Bridal
description: Mrs. Alexander Maitland Griggs of Boston has announced the engagement of her daughter, Mary Louise Johnson Griggs, to Harold Roland LaBonte 3d, son of Edith Mallot LaBonte of Palo Alto, Calif., and Mr. LaBonte Jr. of San Francisco.

title: Rhodeus Sericeus Off the Hook
description: The European bitterling (Rhodeus Sericeus) may now rest easy. The unusual three-inch-long fish, believed to live only in one short stretch of the Bronx River, apparently will not lose its home to Federal flood-control projects.

title: The New York Times/Neil Boenzi Joseph E. Brooks, shown here at Lord & Taylor's Fifth Avenue Store, has imposed his stamp on the expansion, exportation and Americanization of the stores he took over in 1975.; One Man's Lord & Taylor
description: ''I feel strongly that everyone should have a voice,'' said Joseph E. Brooks, chief executive of Lord & Taylor. ''But only one person makes the decision. The final decision has to be mine.''

title: PLEASANT COLONY WINNER IN WOOD
description: Lightning struck twice at Aqueduct yesterday. The first bolt hit the infield shortly after 11 A.M., and blew out the tote board circuit. The second came nearly seven hours later when Pleasant Colony whisked by favored Cure the Blues on the final turn and went on to a three-length victory in the 57th Wood Memorial.

title: Coal Talks Resume In a Bitter Mood
description: Negotiations aimed at settling the coal strike began again last week, but neither side was ready to yield even a bucket-load of ground.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: CURB ON SOVIET GRAIN PURCHASES MAY END SOON, OFFICIAL SAYS
description: Amid conflicting signals that the Administration might soon lift restrictions on grain sales to the Soviet Union, Secretary of Commerce Malcolm Baldrige said today that they might ''possibly'' be ended in a week or two.

title: OPPOSING PARKWAY EXPANSION
description: THE Association to Preserve the Hutch, an organization of residents of Scarsdale, New Rochelle and Eastchester, was formed to ''educate'' community residents, persons working or traveling in the county and government officials about the demographic, social, economic and environmental consequences of developing and expanding the Hutchinson River Parkway.

title: JAPAN's TECHNOPOLIS BUILDS FOR THE FUTURE, BUT THE PRESENT IS TOUGH
description: Yoshiaki Ohkami, a researcher at Japan's National Aerospace Laboratory, got up at 2 A.M. Wednesday to watch live television coverage of the Columbia space shuttle as it landed at 3:21 A.M. Japan time. ''A wonderful success,'' he said. ''I watched the program until 5.''But by 10, Dr. Ohkami was on his way out of Tokyo by train, heading for the Space Center here run by Japan's National Space Development Agency, where he is an adviser.

title: ZIMBABWE, A YEAR OLD, ANXIOUS OVER SOUTH AFRICA
description: Zimbabwe celebrated its first year of independence on a low key today, with its leaders expressing concern about South Africa.

title: About Long Island
description: I bought a hat the other day. Not only that, I wore it. Right out on the street, in front of God and everybody. And I didn't even care that no one else was wearing one.

title: UPSET ALTERS OUTLOOK FOR DERBY
description: The shocking defeat of Cure the Blues in yesterday's Wood Memorial not only sent the majority of Aqueduct's bettors home with empty pockets but also scrambled the outlook for the 107th Kentucky Derby on May 2.

title: OH, BROTHER, WHAT HATH GOD WROUGHT?
description: It all started in 1975 with Brother Domenic, the Xerox monk. Then Volkswagen was trying to figure out how many nuns could fit into a van. Now, one good sister can be seen munching Rice Crispies and another praising Pyrex.

title: A PRINCELY MET COLLECTION GETS THE ROYAL TREATMENT
description: When you look up the Grand Staircase in the Metropolitan Museum, the evidence is unmistakable - a dazzling mural by Tiepolo 18 feet high. It's one of three giant-scale works by the 18th-century Italian painter that newly dominate the first European Paintings gallery at the top of the stairs. Quietly, without its usual fanfare, the Met has made some significant changes in its pre-19th century European Paintings galleries.

title: ISLANDERS-RANGERS AGAIN?
description: Q UIETLY, the Islanders and the Rangers are skating on a collision course in the Stanley Cup playoffs. If each wins its current quarterfinal series, they will be matched in the semifinals as they were two years ago when the Rangers shocked the Islanders in six games and had New Yorkers talking hockey as never before.

title:
Gardening;
GREENHOUSES: A LUXURY BECOMES A HOBBY
description: IN past years, the private greenhouse was considered to be only for the wealthy. Their vast greenhouse ranges and conservatories were used to force exotic blooms and fruits out of season and to house vast collections of rare plants.

title: Notes; GUIDED TOURS FOR THOSE ON AN AMPLE BUDGET; BY SUZANNE DONNER
description: While much of the travel industry concentrates on reducing costs, a few organizations continue to specialize in the cosseting of travelers for whom luxury and convenience are more important than economy. Operators of such luxury tours also argue, however, that the services they have assembled can cost less as a package than if they are purchased individually.

title: No Headline
description: The article on David Stockman made this point for me. The rich will get richer and the middle class and the poor will get poorer.

title: WELL, WHATEVER
description: It's unusual in a business executive, but Evangeline Gouletas-Carey, Governor Carey's bride, isn't a stickler for details.

title: Chester Crocker In Darkest Africa
description: Chester A. Crocker, Assistant Secretary of State-designate for African Affairs, had the dubious honor last week of being criticized by both South Africa and the black states most opposed to its control over South-West Africa.

title: Margiotta Defense: Didn't Everyone?
description: The trial of Joseph M. Margiotta, the Nassau Republican chairman, has made possible a rare view of the workings of what the defense calls routine political patronage and the prosecution calls extortion and mail fraud. As the defense opened its case last week (its motion for acquittal having been denied), prominent witnesses said they called it patronage, too.

title: AS CONGRESSMEN TAKE UP THE ABORTION ISSUE, TWO SIDES DEBATE: WHEN DOES LIFE BEGIN
description: Eight years ago, in the landmark Roe v. Wade ruling, the Supreme Court legalized abortion during the first stages of pregnancy. Since then, opponents have been seeking a way to undo that decision, which was based on the woman's right to privacy. Since a constitutional amendment to outlaw abortion seems unattainable, abortion opponents have introduced a bill in Congress, S. 158, which declares that human life 'shall be deemed to exist from conception,' thus allowing states, if they choose, to prosecute abortion as murder. The bill is based on a clause of the 14th Amendment that gives Congress the power to enforce the Amendment's due process and equal protection guarantees. Hearings on it begin this week.

title: Miss Ashley Is the Fiancee Of J.L. Clarke
description: Dr. and Mrs. Charles Allen Ashley of Cooperstown, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Charlotte Chandler Ashley of New York, to James Lincoln Clarke, son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert L. Clarke of Pelham, N.Y.

title: THE SECRETS IN THE TISSUE OF A MOUSE
description: AN IMAGINED WORLD A Story of Scientific Discovery. By June Goodfield. 240 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $12.95.

title: KENNETH HILTON TO MARRY MEREDITH B. ADLER IN JUNE
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harold Adler of New Rochelle, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Meredith Beth Adler, to Kenneth S. Hilton, son of Dr. and Mrs. Murray M. Hilton of Great Neck, L.I. A June wedding is planned.

title:
Food;
BAKERS' CO-OP LURES RETAIL SHOPPERS
description: WEST HEMPSTEAD AROUND the corner from the West Hempstead railroad station, sacks of devil's food cake mix, pails of Bavarian cream pie filling and cans of cherries are neatly stacked in an unobtrusive warehouse, waiting to be sold. But Inter-County Bakers Inc. is not just another jobber supplying bakeries, restaurants and diners.

title: COMING TO THE DEFENSE OF 16-INCH SOFTBALL
description: To the Sports Editor: In the article, ''Unlikely Rookie Making Good'' (The New York Times, April 3) Kevin Hickey's lack of baseball experience was noted. Until a few years ago the White Sox rookie pitcher had only played 16-inch, slow-pitch softball, a game played ''almost exclusively in Chicago,'' ... and ''said to bear as much resemblance to baseball as Ping-Pong does to tennis.'' I feel that this is an unfair and misleading view.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: IT WASN'T the one used by George Washington, but Newark and Washington - Washington, D.C., that is - have buried the hatchet in what had become known as ''The Great Cherry-Blossom Feud.'' The dispute dates to 1976, when an organization known as Friends of Branch Brook Park established the Newark Cherry-Blossom Festival and issued a challenge for a contest to determine whether Washington or Newark had the most beautiful blossoms.

title: HOW TO READ THE GREAT CATHEDRALS OF EUROPE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- ALICE MARY HILTON is an art historian engaged in research on the mathematical basis of medieval art; she lectures at several institutions, among them the Metropolitan Museum of Art. By ALICE MARY HILTON

title: Czechs Defeat Canadians, 7-4
description: Czechoslovakia built a 4-1 lead in the first period, then held off Canada in the second to score a 7-4 victory in the final round of the world hockey championship today.

title:
Gardening;
GREENHOUSES: A LUXURY BECOMES A HOBBY
description: IN past years, the private greenhouse was considered to be only for the wealthy. Their vast greenhouse ranges and conservatories were used to force exotic blooms and fruits out of season and to house vast collections of rare plants.

title: D'AMATO HAS TOAST FOR MOTHER AND PRESIDENT AT BREAKFAST
description: Senator Alphonse M. D'Amato attended a Republican breakfast in Westchester last week and was full of praise for Ronald Reagan's courage under fire, describing the President's string of one-liners after the attempted assassination as ''a glimpse of the kind of man he is.''

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, APRIL 19, 1981
description: International Saudi Arabia insists that an arms deal be carried out by the Administration, allowing it to purchase five Awacs electronic surveillance planes, in addition to the previously ordered F-15 fighters. It also wants seven aerial tankers. The Saudis rejected Administration suggestions that it postpone buying the Awacs and avoid a fight in Congress, which would influenced by Israel's opposition to the plane deal. (Page 1, Column 3.) American naval power predominates in the Indian Ocean following the most ambitious mobilization of naval forces since the Vietnam War to challenge Soviet advances in Africa and Asia. Singapore, Sri Lanka, Mauritius and Kenya, among other places, are visited monthly by thousands of American sailors on shore leave, emphasizing a naval commander's view that the Indian Ocean has become ''the primary strategic concern for the United States.'' (1:4-5.)

title: Liquor Dealers Lose; Challenge on Prices
description: Connecticut liquor dealers, whose sales have dwindled in recent years as neighboring states watered down or threw out minimum alcoholic beverage pricing laws, will have to look beyond Federal District Court for a means of staunching the flow of business from their state.

title: Politics; DEBATE RISES OVER SEAGRAM AIRPORT SITE
description: TO residents of Rye, Port Chester and Greenwich, Conn., Westchester County's proposal to permit construction of a Seagram building at the County Airport has become a matter of development by stealth and is essentially unwelcome.

title: Innocence Abroad, Concern at Home
description: A Government survey in 1979 indicated that 27 percent of high school seniors believed Golda Meir was the president of Egypt; 40 percent thought Israel was an Arab nation. Dismayed by such ignorance, the Council on Learning, supported by the Endowment for the Humanities, initiated a project called ''Education and the World,'' to further students' global understanding.

title: Shroud of Turin Exhibit Is Reviewed by Scientists
description: The Shroud of Turin, for 600 years one of Christiandom's most prized relics and greatest mysteries, is not a forgery but whether its image is that of the dead Jesus is still not known, scientists said today.

title: SPACE PROGRAM FACES HURDLES DESPITE CHEERS FOR COLUMBIA
description: Two American astronauts and thousands of engineers proved last week that man could leave Earth under rocket power and return on the wings of an aircraft, a revolutionary approach to travel on the space frontier. This was the triumph of the space shuttle Columbia, which glided gracefully out of the sky and touched down here Tuesday on a dry lake bed in the Mojave Desert. Through the ground crew's post-flight jubilation, and the nation's rejoicing, ran the unabashed patriotic refrain, ''We're back in space and we're No.1.''

title: GOLD BAR FOUND IN MEXICO THOUGHT TO BE CORTES'S
description: A four-pound gold bar found on a building site in downtown Mexico City last month is believed to be part of the treasure seized from the Aztec Emperor Montezuma II by the Spanish conquistador, Hernan Cortes, in 1520.

title: MURALS BRIGHTEN CITY'S OLDER AREAS
description: NORWALK WHILE this city of 80,000 may not yet be the Ravenna of the West, as its Mayor said he liked to think of it, its arts program promoting large-scale outdoor murals has gone a long way toward restoring a bit of decorative charm to old and nondescript areas, including downtown sections and business districts, and to schools and playgrounds.

title: SAUDIS REBUFF U.S. ON POSTPONING DEAL FOR 5 RADAR PLANES
description: Saudi Arabia has rejected Reagan Administration suggestions that a political fight on Capitol Hill might be avoided if it postponed the purchase of five Awacs electronic surveillance planes and settled instead for equipment to increase the range and firepower of its previously ordered F-15 fighters, senior State Department officials said today.

title: A NOVEL OF LIFE IN A SMALL WORLD
description: THE BOOK OF EBENEZER LE PAGE By G.B. Edwards. Introduction by John Fowles. 400 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $13.95.

title: A Cooling Economy - Maybe
description: If current projections are accurate, inflation-adjusted output in the first quarter should be between 4 and 5 percent, far above expectations three months ago. Many economists expected the effects of high interest rates to rein in business activity much faster than has occurred. That impact is now being felt, some argue, and the economy will flatten out in the second quarter.

title: Corrections
description: A table with the investing column ''Low-Risk Commodity Funds'' (April 5) contained some incorrect data on the Commodity Trend Timing Fund. The fund was started in January 1980 and as of Feb. 28, 1981, the unit value was $1,336, an increase of 38.7 percent over the starting unit value of $963.

title: No Headline
description: As a Vietnam veteran, I found it particularly ironic that David Stockman, whose interest in theology was in direct proportion to his eligibility for the draft, who philosophically flimflammed his way through Harvard and baby-sat his way to Capitol Hill, is now presiding over the cutting of long overdue and only recently initiated programs to help some of the estimated 700,000 Vietnam veterans. IGOR BOBROWSKY, Upper Montclair, N.J.

title: RAPE IN MARRIAGE DEFINED
description: TWO months ago, a Connecticut man ended a violent argument with his wife over money by ripping off her clothes and sexually assaulting her in their living room. The couple's three children, aged 4 to 9, watched in horror.

title: CURING THE BLUEGRASS BLUES
description: EVERY spring, after winter has trampled my lawn into sickly submission, I stand at my front door and announce, ''This year, this lawn will be a brilliant green and beautifully lush.'' I say this aloud to emphasize the sincerity of my pledge.

title: Miss Nochlin Plans Wedding in August
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard Pommer of New York and Poughkeepsie, N.Y., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Pommer's daughter, Jessica Nochlin, to Dominic Anthony Trotta, son of Mr. and Mrs. Dominic John Trotta of New York. An August wedding is planned.

title: Practical Traveler; THE AIR TRAVELER'S OPTIONS AND RIGHTS
description: Every year, thousands of Americans fly in a commercial airliner for the first time, and many of them do not know what to expect. In letters to the Travel Section they have asked what their options and rights are, whether they will get airsick, what kind of food they will get aloft, how to avoid smokers and, conversely, how to avoid conflict with nonsmokers.

title: BRAZIL CRACKS DOWN ON ITS ONE STRONG UNION
description: Rows of new sedans shining in the sun outside South America's largest industrial complex are a somber sign for the workers on the assembly lines inside. For the first time, Brazil is building more cars than it is selling. The backup has already cost nearly 20,000 jobs. When Brazilians are given their walking papers, they face a difficult path - no unemployment pay, no promise of a callback and no union welfare funds to help.

title: THE HARDER TASK
description: To the Editor:

title: TIME RUNNING OUT FOR CONRAIL
description: Failed railroads, lost fortunes and ambitious Government programs tell the tangled tale of freight rail service in the Northeast. The bankruptcy of the Penn Central, the biggest business failure in American history, spawned Conrail in 1976. It is the nation's second-largest freight carrier, and in its short history has consumed some $3.3 billion - or $1.8 million a day - in taxpayer dollars.

title: SERVICE EMPLOYEES AND RETAIL UNION PLAN TO MERGE
description: Two big unions of service employees, both with large units in the field of health care, are planning to merge in a move that could lead to a major drive to organize hundreds of thousands of employees in hospitals and nursing homes throughout the country.

title: SEWER WORK SPEEDS UP AMID ENVIRONMENTAL QUESTIONS
description: MINEOLA WHEN critics of the Southwest Sewer District charged five years ago that the fees for the project's design engineers were too high and that the scope of the sewer system was larger than necessary, its defenders cut short the criticisms by asserting that no government agency had ever found anything corrupt or improper about the project.

title: ATOMS CLUB BREAKS THREE OF ITS RECORDS
description: The Atoms Track Club of Brooklyn revised three records it set last year by winning three events at the 27th annual Iona College Relays yesterday at Downing Stadium on Randalls Island.

title: OUT OF UNIFORM; Redress
description: The Reagan team pledges to get Washington off everybody's back. Now Education Secretary Bell proposes to do so literally. He wants to stop overseeing public school dress codes.

title: Stephanie Sine Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Philip Sine of Manhattan have made known the engagement of their daughter, Stephanie Sine, to William O. Peresman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph S. Peresman of Pittsburgh.

title: POLISH AUTHORITIES OUTLINE PLANS FOR TIES WITH UNION
description: The Polish Government published a working paper last night on its relations with the independent trade union movement Solidarity.

title: On Language; CRAFTY CRAFTING
description: ''This is a plea against the dreadful word 'crafted,' '' writes Joseph Alsop, the retired columnist. '' 'Crafted' is meant to imply that porcelain, glass, furniture or metalwork has been largely handmade by a skilled craftsman. This always is a lie, unless the thing described is one of the inferior peasant manufactures which are still cheaper than machine products.

title:
The Lively Arts;
MISS KENT IN 'SWAN LAKE'
description: ''WE'VE rented 20 swans for the second act of 'Swan Lake,' '' said Michael Vernon, ballet master of the Eglevsky Ballet Company, referring to the company's spring season next weekend at the Adams Playhouse at Hofstra University. With its rented dancers, the company looks more like the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo with its vast numbers than the small company that Long Island audiences know.

title: FIREMEN IN YONKERS ARE BACK ON THE JOB
description: Yonkers firefighters who were on strike for two days with other municipal employees were back at work today, some of them digging through the ruins of a building that an unidentified fireman is accused of setting ablaze. The walkout ended yesterday with an agreement to submit the remaining contract disputes to arbitration.

title: TRADE
description: Trade paperbacks are softcover books usually sold in bookstores and at an average price higher than mass-market paperbacks. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from 1,600 bookstores in every region of the United States.

title: Miss Zeeman Will Be Bride Of Eric Deane
description: Andrea Lily Zeeman and Eric Taylor Deane plan to be married on May 16 in Larchmont, N.Y.

title: 'WILD WORLD OF SPORTS'- SOME HITS, SOME ERRORS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- William Barry Furlong is a freelance writer who frequently reports on sports. By WILLIAM BARRY FURLONG

title: COSMOS DEFEAT TORNADO BY 3-0
description: Seninho scored his first two goals of the season tonight as the Cosmos defeated the Dallas Tornado, 3-0. The Cosmos improved their record to 3-1 and their lead in the North American Soccer League's Northern Division to 3 points over Washington, which defeated Fort Lauderdale, 1-0.

title: RACE, ETHNIC SHIFT SHOWN IN CENSUS
description: WASHINGTON,D.C. ALTHOUGH Connecticut had a modest population increase of 76,000 from 1970 to 1980, a new racial breakdown by the Census Bureau indicates a decline of 36,000 in the state's white population in that period.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: 1965), based on his correspondence and interviews with persons who knew him. Although he is shown in almost every conceivable attitude of fear, meanness, spite, indignity and rage, the author remains oddly and convincingly respectful.

title: Charlotte Bucknell Wed To Charles Kappler Jr.
description: Charlotte Wright Bucknell, daughter of Mrs. Edward C. Carter 2d of Rosemont, Pa., and the late John Addison Cobb Bucknell, was married in Villanova, Pa., yesterday to Charles Theodore Kappler Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Kappler of Washington. The Rev. Richard Hess performed the Episcopal ceremony at Appleford..

title: CATHERINE'S PEOPLE
description: RUSSIA IN THE AGE OF CATHERINE THE GREAT By Isabel de Madariaga. 698 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $40.

title: E.C. Conrad Fiance Of Susan Higgins
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Higgins Jr. of Weston and New Seabury, Mass., and Lighthouse Point, Fla., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Susan Heald Higgins, to Edward Craig Conrad, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Conrad of Riverside, Conn. The wedding is planned for August in Boston.

title: Martyn Dyke, Pianist, Plays 3 Beethoven Works
description: Martyn Dyke's debut concert at Carnegie Recital Hall Friday evening again raised the question of what virtuosity really means. Mr. Dyke, a young English pianist, is by no means the master of five-finger technique. His scales are not matched pearls; his trills are unruly; nor can he draw great rainbows of sound from his instrument.

title: Music; CHOIRS, BANDS, ENSEMBLES TO VISIT FESTIVAL
description: THEATER buffs get the best deal at the 15th Festival of the Arts. Five of the seven days will be given over to performances by troupes from Mexico, Hungary, Japan and other international centers. On the other hand, music and dance lovers will be in their element tomorrow and Tuesday as the cultural explosion gets under way at Westchester Community College in Valhalla.

title:
Dining Out;
RESTORING THE GOOD NAME OF BURGER
description: MUSTARD SEED in Elmsford, calling itself a ''pub-restaurant,'' is a particularly good example in miniature of the American hybrid of British public houses. Mustard Seed considers itself a casual place for food and drink, but it becomes rather more than that. The pleasantly cluttered cheery tunnel of a dining room holds about 14 small tables, a long bar (diners may eat at either) and a popular dart board; depending upon the time of day, it attracts a convivial clientele ranging from families out for an early dinner, businessmen in three-piece suits, elderly citizens from the neighborhood, to young and not-so-young singles and some apparently serious dart players later in the evening. They all come to enjoy some imaginative food and the gracious hospitality of the owner, Leon Siwek.

title: APPEALS COURT SAYS LOS ANGELES CAN STOP BUSING
description: A Federal appeals court said today that mandatory busing to integrate the Los Angeles public schools could end Monday, overruling a Federal district judge who had ordered the busing to continue.

title: More on Islands
description: To the Editor:

title: City Hall Notes
description: For the six years that it has been, in effect, New York City's finance agency, the Municipal Assistance Corporation has taken care of much of the city's long-term borrowing needs. Now the M.A.C. is actively considering a significant departure: It is studying, for the first time, the sale of the kind of short-term notes that New York has been able to market on its own for the last two years.

title: SALLIE FRAENKEL TO BE BRIDE OF MICHAEL ZUCH IN OCTOBER
description: Mr. and Mrs. Francis Levy Fraenkel of Rye, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sallie Fraenkel, to Michael Zuch.

title: Whites Continuing To Leave Cities
description: For all the scattered reports over the past decade of middle-class, mostly white pioneers hacking out gentrified urban homesites, suspicion remained that ''white flight'' hadn't abated all that much. Now the Census Bureau has confirmed that the exodus continued, and at a rate that many authorities found surprising.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS IN SUMMARY
description: Of all the dramas behind the Pulitzer Prizes announced last week, the tale of Janet Cooke, initial winner of the feature writing prize, was surely the most startling.

title: J.R. White to Wed Constance Bryden
description: Mr. and Mrs. John R. Bryden 3d of Bloomsburg, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Constance Bryden, to James Rutherford White, son of John D. White of New York, and Frances B. White of Merrick, L.I. A July 18 wedding is planned.

title: STAMFORD CONCERN AIDS SHUTTLE
description: STAMFORD THE shuttle is supposed to make space flight routine. But to build the first shuttle, Columbia, engineers had to advance the state of space technology in several areas, notably thermal engineering, and the step now at hand, refurbishing the shuttle to fly again.

title: Long Islanders; HIS LIFE AND LOVE BLEND HARMONIOUSLY
description: WHEN Cham-Ber Huang was a boy of 6 in Shanghai, where he was born, his grandfather gave him a Hohner harmonica. It was the beginning of a love affair with the instrument that has taken Mr. Huang around the world and made him - despite political tension - a welcome figure both in China and on Taiwan.

title: OUT OF UNIFORM; Royal to a T
description: Even before Mrs. Trollope rocketed through America in the early 19th century, people had been defining the difference between us and the English. (Mrs. Trollope said it was ''want of refinement.'') Language, it's been said, separates us.

title: Sunday Observer; MOVING AHEAD TO 1833; Russell Baker
description: BAKER HEADLINE TO COME Patrick McDonnell

title: TV View; SIGNS OF LIFE FROM THE SIT-COM
description: It could simply be that the country is desperately in need of a laugh these days, but the situation comedy is showing renewed signs of life. Just when the sit-com scene was threatening to disintegrate into endless imitations of ''The Dukes of Hazzard,'' crammed with shapely bodies and screeching automobile tires, producers apparently have decided to venture in less mindless directions.

title: BRONX RIVER FLOOD STUDY: NO U.S. AID WARRANTED
description: IN the last decade, torrential rains have swollen and flooded its streams on three occasions required Westchester County to be declared a Federal disaster area. Flood damage following a June 1972 storm amounted to more than $20 million and flood stages were two feet higher in September 1975, when Yonkers, in one example, experienced what was called the most damaging flood in its history.

title: Study Favors a Coed Columbia
description: The relationship between Columbia University and Barnard College is an affiliation to which there have been many impediments lately - and it is not likely to improve after a report released last week by a Columbia College committee on coeducation. Noting the ''well identified'' financial problems and projections of declining enrollments now facing private colleges, the committee strongly recommended admitting women to the college by the fall of 1982.

title: U.S. ROLE IN EL SALVADOR PROTESTED
description: Chanting, placard-carrying protesters converged on the United Nations yesterday to demonstrate against United States involvement in El Salvador.

title: JUST A PIECE OF CAKE
description: REAPPORTIONING the state's 40 legislative districts is like trying to cut up a large, irregular cake to please 120 snackers with different appetites.

title: Indians 5, Brewers 0
description: MILWAUKEE (AP) - Bert Blyleven tossed a four-hitter and Joe Charboneau sparked a four-run sixth with a two-run single as Cleveland dealt Milwaukee its fourth straight loss.

title: ARGENTINA'S COURTS AREN'T OPEN TO DEBORA
description: To the Editor:

title: SOME OBSERVATIONS ON MOUNT PALOMAR
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- RALPH BLUMENTHAL is a reporter for The New York Times. By RALPH BLUMENTHAL

title: 13 Arrested in Fracas at Motel
description: A confrontation between police officers and more than 1,500 vacationing youths ended with the arrest of 13 persons early today, the police said.

title: U.S.-AFRICA TIES FACE TEST OVER SANCTIONS
description: The Reagan Administration's strained relations with Africa could undergo their harshest test so far when the Security Council is faced next week with a demand for a trade boycott against South Africa.

title: THE FABULOUS BEASTS OF VENICE
description: There are times even now, if the weather is right, and the mood, and perhaps the company, when the lagoons of Venice can seem almost uninhabited by humankind. The towers of Torcello and Burano are almost lost among the reeds, the hotels of Iesolo are no more than white on the horizon, Venice itself is out of sight across the gray waters to the south, and the only living things about you are the melancholy sea birds, the little brown crabs, the loitering butterflies and the fish who plop and gasp sometimes among the rushes.

title: Margaret L. Weiss Bride of Sculptor
description: Margaret Lane Weiss, a legislative representative for Mayor Koch in Albany and New York, and Willard Boepple, a sculptor, were married yesterday. The Rev. Dr. Robert Polk, executive director of the New York Council of Churches performed the ceremony in the Riverside Church.

title: DANCE: REKA AND CO. IN HOMAGE TO BARTOK
description: Reka , a Hungarian-born choreographer, teacher and performer now based on New York, has given several concerts around the city in recent weeks to celebrate the composer Bela Bartok in his centennial. Reka and Co. performed five dances to Bartok scores on Friday at the Symphony Space. It isn't every dance concert that has such music and performances like those of the violinists Karla Boros and David Friedman and, particularly, Nancy McDill on the piano. But dance was hardly a negligible item on the program. Reka is a lowkeyed original with an eye for unusual performers.

title: Mrs. Thatcher Tells Indians Her Economic Plans Work
description: Britain's recent economic troubles have ''taught us the importance of a clear and firmly maintained economic strategy,'' Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said today during an address at Bombay's Chamber of Commerce.

title: I.R.A. Man on Hunger Strike Reported to Get Last Rites
description: Bobby Sands, the jailed Irish republican terrorist who was elected to Parliament eight days ago, received Roman Catholic last rites as he entered the 49th day of a hunger strike, he was quoted today as having told visitors. Mr. Sands is fasting to protest Britain's refusal to regard imprisoned Irish Republican Army members as political prisoners.

title: Israel Steps Up; Lebanon Attacks
description: Two teen-age Palestinians loaded a balloon with automatic weapons last week in Lebanon and floated silently toward Israel. But before they could reach the border, Israeli anti-aircraft gunners shot them down and Israeli commandos on the ground finished them off.

title: DEBORAH BOXER TO BE BRIDE OF DAVID MICHAEL MINCHIN
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Boxer of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Deborah Bran Boxer, to David Michael Richard Minchin of Bogota, Colombia, a representative there of Lloyd's Bank International Ltd.

title: Rangers' Confidence Restored After They Rally to Beat Blues
description: The Rangers, after a one-game lapse of self-assurance, are confident again that they can beat the St. Louis Blues in their quarterfinal National Hockey League playoff series. The four-ofseven-game series, tied at a game each, resumes tonight at Madison Square Garden.

title: Explorers Club Discovers Women
description: For the New York-based Explorers Club, receiving women into the ranks of the brave and daring has loomed as a last frontier. Last week, it was conquered.

title: SEAGRAM OFFICE PLAN STIRS AIRPORT DISPUTE
description: TO residents of Greenwich, and neighboring Rye and Port Chester, N.Y., Westchester County's proposal to permit construction of a Seagram building at Weschester County Airport near Purchase has become a matter of development by stealth and is essentially unwelcome.

title: THE WIFE OF THE GENIUS
description: SONYA The Life of Countess Tolstoy. By Anne Edwards. Illustrated. 512 pp. New York: Simon and Schuster. $15.95.

title: Seven Inmates Are Stabbed In New Mexico State Prison
description: Officials suspect that alcohol may have caused a disturbance in which seven prison inmates were stabbed last night in a maximum-security wing of the New Mexico State Penitentiary.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: THE WORLD IN SUMMARY
description: Polish Communists last week took up where Solidarity unionists left off. Grassroots leaders from 19 party units around the country met in Torun and demanded more party democracy, including direct elections of new leaders at a national congress to be held by July 20.

title: Blaze at the Statler Hotel Called 'Definitely Arson'
description: Fire marshals have determined that the blaze Friday that virtually closed the New York Statler Hotel was ''definitely arson,'' according to a spokesman for the Fire Department.

title: REAGAN VOICES REGRET TO JAPANESE PREMIER ABOUT SINKING OF SHIP
description: President Reagan, in a personal note sent to Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki today through the United States Embassy, expressed regret over the sinking of a Japanese cargo ship after it collided with a nuclear-powered American submarine, the George Washington.

title: WHAT LIFE IS REALLY LIKE IN ENGLAND
description: THE SECOND CHANCE And Other Stories. By Alan Sillitoe. 219 pp. New York: Simon and Schuster. $12.95. By JULIAN MOYNAHAN

title: MODERN THEOLOGY
description: JUSTICE CHURCH The New Function of the Church in North American Christianity. By Frederick Herzog. 157 pp. Maryknoll, N.Y.: Orbis Books. Paper, $6.95.

title: No Headline
description: No one bothered to mention that a program such as David Stockman's cannot succeed in an economic marketplace that thrives on inequality of opportunity for the majority of its citizens

title: Theater in Review; 'HOT'N'COLE' PRODUCES FEW KICKS
description: CAVIAR, champagne, class. Those are the things that Cole Porter's songs conjure up. You can add your own evocative words, and they will most likely have connotations of elegance, gaiety and style, with perhaps a touch of the blase thrown in.

title: Cardinals' 10-4 Rout of Reds Tarnishes Seaver's 3,000th Strikeout
description: Tony Scott drove in three runs with a pair of singles and a double today, pacing the St. Louis Cardinals to a 10-4 victory over the Cincinnati Reds that overshadowed Tom Seaver's 3,000th career strikeout.

title: PLAN TO RAZE LANDMARK STAYED
description: NEWARK MILITARY PARK, once one of the glories of this city, has all but disappeared, along with the buildings around it. But because of the threatened demolition of a last reminder of that past glory, the park still serves a purpose: It has become the focus of a heated and complicated argument about the importance of this city's urban fabric.

title:
On the Isle;
EASTER PARADE
description: Fifth Avenue may have its Easter Parade, but so does Long Island. The Island's version, though, features something more than new hats - vintage cars. Garden City's traditional Easter Sunday festivities get under way at 1 P.M. today along Franklin Avenue with the annual antique car parade, accompanied by floral displays and Easter bunnies. After the parade, the autos will be on display opposite Village Hall on Stewart Avenue for closer scrutiny by holiday strollers.CHILDREN'S HOURS

title: Sylvia Howe Engaged to Dodge Thompson
description: Mr. and Mrs. J. Murray Howe of Weston and Dennis, Mass., have announced the engagment of their daughter, Sylvia Howe, to D. Dodge Thompson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bradbury Thompson of Riverside, Conn.

title: About Westchester
description: BRONXVILLE THE occasion was billed as a tea, and woe to the person who referred to it otherwise. ''It is not high tea,'' admonished a woman in a very English accent. ''High tea means kippers, ham and eggs, treakle. It is what the working class eats instead of supper. What we have here is tea: tiny tarts, frosted cakes, cucumber sandwiches and of course, tea.''

title: CONDOMINIUMS FACE A SQUEEZE ON REPAIR BILLS
description: After years of being battered by waves, the bulkhead along the oceanfront at the 36-unit Deal Ocean Condominium in Deal, N.J., will soon need replacement.

title: Film View; FELLINI AND MALLE- BOTH IN THEIR STRIDE
description: In an interview some years ago, Federico Fellini suggested that one of the reasons many great film directors have comparatively short careers of true creativity is because commercial filmmaking does not allow a director to pause for breath, to reconsider his attitudes, to alter his style. In effect, he was saying that the director is always in danger of being gobbled up by the business of supplying theaters with movies and by his own vanity in attempting to remain popular by repeating himself.

title: Connecticut Journal
description: WITH a host of major issues still before them this spring, including a controversial set of tax increases and a new budget, state legislators are beginning to eye the calendar. Many are wondering out loud just how long this year's legislative session really will be.

title: Collision Angers Japan
description: What the Navy didn't do after the nuclear submarine George Washington collided with the freighter Nissho Maru on April 9 stirred anger in Tokyo last week. The 2,350-ton freighter sank and the captain and a sailor died.

title: FIRE DEPT. ORDERED TO HIRE MORE NONWHITES
description: A LONG discrimination dispute has resulted in a new court decision requiring the Fire Department in Bridgeport to hire more black and Hispanic applicants.

title: PINELANDS AGENCY EASE PLAN DEADLINE
description: NEW LISBON ALTHOUGH the cutoff date was officially mid-March, only 26 of the 56 municipalities in the Pine Barrens have signed agreements to have their master plans and relevant ordinances comply with the Comprehensive Management Plan that the state's Pinelands Commission has promulgated for the region.

title: IT'S HOW PRIVATE SCHOOLS ARE BETTER THAT COUNTS
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. SAID TO REVISE STRATEGY TO OPPOSE THREATS BY SOVIET
description: The Reagan Administration has begun to fashion a military strategy that would prepare the armed forces for the possibility that some confrontation with the Soviet Union might lead to a protracted conventional war, according to senior Pentagon officials.

title: HIDING FROM TAXES
description: To the Business Editor: In ''Tax Evasion,'' it is stated that ''John B.'' and ''Susan L.'' who were infuriated at the ''marriage tax,'' went through a marriage ceremony, including ''the vows at the altar and so on,'' but ''just didn't sign the papers'' so as to avoid joint filing. If they did this in New York State, however, they are probably legally married. That is so because in New York State if a couple is married by someone who is in fact a clergy person authorized to perform marriages, the fact that there is no signing of papers, or even the fact that there was no marriage license at all, does not mean that a valid marriage fails to come into effect. New York recognizes a religious ceremonial marriage by a proper clergy person even without a license.

title: MERYL GOLDSTEIN IS FIANCEE
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Goldstein of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., of the engagement of their daughter, Meryl Elyse Goldstein, to Glenn Philip Jacobs, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Jacobs of Syosset, L.I. The wedding is planned for July. Miss Goldstein, who is studying for a Ph.D. in counseling psychology at New York University, is on the staff of the counseling center at Fairleigh Dickinson University, Teaneck-Hackensack, N.J., campus. Her fiance, who has a Ph.D. in mechanical engineering from the State University at Stony Brook, is an assistant professor at Fairleigh Dickinson.

title: No Headline
description: Instead of preparing for ''the unthinkable'' with a huge buildup of armaments, which the Soviet Union will match, let Washington challege the Kremlin to join in a campaign to abolish hunger and poverty in the third world, financing it out of armament funds. DAVID M. FIGART, Briarcliff Manor, N.Y.

title: Barbara Jane Madgey Is Bride Of A. Neil Sweeny, Bank Aide
description: Barbara Jane Madgey and A. Neil Sweeny, both of New York, were married yesterday in St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Osterville, Mass. The Rev. Grant A. Morrill performed the ceremony.

title: ABOUT THE CASTLE ON THE HILL...
description: Hogwash! Carolyn Darrow (Antiques Column, April 5) has perpetuated the myth that the 1913 strike led to the decline of the Paterson silk industry. Paterson's workers have long suffered under this myth, and it's time to put it to rest.

title: A Love of Labor
description: When the Cathedral of St. John the Divine resumed building the largest Gothic structure in the world after a 38-year pause, it calculated that 22,000 stones would be needed to finish the last two towers. It could have ordered the stones machine-cut from a quarry.

title: SCHOOL BOARD WINNERS: LOOK WHAT YOU'VE WON
description: SOME of you have won. After spending your own money to get elected, losing the three friends from whom you sought campaign donations, staying up all night to address campaign literature, attending four candidate forums to speak to a total of 72 people and burning up the one personal day allowed by your employer to smile around the polling places in the hope of changing a single vote, you have been victorious in a school-board election in which 12 percent of the voters participated.

title: THRONG STAMPEDES AT EASTER EGG HUNT
description: The annual Easter egg hunt in Central Park turned into chaos yesterday when prizes were tossed up for grabs, touching off a stampede in a crowd of several thousand people. Scores were knocked to the ground, six were hurt, dozens of youngsters were separated from their parents and police reinforcements had to be summoned to restore order.

title: Mark Emerson Spangler Fiance of Sarah A. Hall
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward Hitchcock Hall Jr. of Lunenburg, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sarah Ann Hall, to Mark Emerson Spangler, son of Mrs. Arthur Stephenson Spangler of Weston Mass., and the late Dr. Spangler.

title: COUPLE CHALLENGING COURT'S RIGHT TO REMOVE CHILDREN
description: In a case now before the United States Supreme Court, an upstate New York couple is challenging the constitutionality of a New York State law that allows minor children to be taken away from their parents and made eligible for adoption by others.

title: SAVE THE EDUCATION DEPT.
description: As President Reagan and his advisers consider submitting a request to Congress to abolish the new Department of Education, it is useful to examine, and answer, arguments used against the department since it was separated in May 1980 from the Department of Health, Education and Welfare.

title: 'Victims of a Ploy' On Huntington Housing
description: When Huntington Town submitted a housing proposal for an urbanrenewal site that H.U.D. had already declared ''impacted,'' it got the lawsuit it expected from the Huntington N.A.A.C.P. and Huntington Housing Help Inc. It was as if the town had issued a manual on ''how to cut the ground from under something you didn't want to do in the first place.''

title: VILAS TROUNCES PANATTA AND GAINS MONACO FINAL
description: Guillermo Vilas of Argentina advanced to the final of the rain-delayed Monte Carlo open tournament today with a 6-2, 6-2 victory over unseeded Adriano Panatta of Italy.

title: Drugs Worth $2.5 Million Seized In Raid in Which 15 Are Arrested
description: Fifteen men believed to be part of an interstate drug ring were arrested early today in raids by the state police in northern Westchester and Putnam Counties, officials said.

title: Art View; CHUCK CLOSE'S BREAK WITH PHOTOGRAPHY
description: Of certain forms of Realist art it can truly be said that they are very largely the continuation of abstraction by other means. No matter how dominant the depictive function may seem to be in such art, and no matter how proficient it may be in sustaining a persuasive illusionism, its fundamental interests lie elsewhere - in a conception that gives to form, and the methods by which it is realized, a radical priority over the ''subject'' or image that is used in its creation.

title: Ted Turner
description: Ted Turner, the colorful owner of The Atlanta Braves and Cable News Network, received a setback last week. His Turner Broadcasting System announced withdrawal of a proposal to publicly offer a million new common shares. The company declined to say why it was withdrawing the offer, the proceeds of which would have gone toward retiring company debt. One reason might have been a recent appearance by Mr. Turner on the ''Phil Donahue Show'' in which he talked about the company - an action that could be construed by the Securities and Exchange Commission as promoting the offering.

title: RAVI SHANKAR BRINGS HIS SITAR TO THE PHILHARMONIC
description: For people who are not aficionados of Indian music, Ravi Shankar must seem like some faded icon from the 1960's, inextricably mixed in the mind with love beads, flower children and lazy clouds of incense and marijuana. As it happens, Mr. Shankar, who just turned 61, is very much active and alert, as his schedule in the next few weeks indicates. And he looks back on his fleeting years of mass popularity with a mixture of regret and resignation.

title: No Headline
description: Al Oerter, the 44-year-old four-time Olympic gold medalist, intensified his comeback effort today with a winning distance of 204 feet 9 inches in the discus throw at the rain-soaked Kansas Relays.
