title: Records Are Falling for 10-0 A's
description: The largest crowd in Oakland baseball history, 50,255, turned out last night for the A's first home opener of the post-Charlie Finley era. It exceeded by 49,602 the turnout for a game exactly two years earlier, in the pre-Billy Martin era.

title: USERS SAY BUILDING FILES NEED REBUILDING
description: A million-dollar effort to modernize the deteriorating recordkeeping system of the Department of Buildings in Manhattan is planned by the Koch administration, city officials report.

title: REPUBLICAN MODERATES ARE CAUGHT IN SQUEEZE PLAY
description: When Representative Barber B. Conable Jr., a Republican from upstate New York, is asked his position on President Reagan's tax cut proposals, he rolls his eyes, shrugs his shoulders and says with considerably less than full enthusiasm that he backs the President down the line.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Zelma Bodzin, Pianist, Offers Schumann Fantasy
description: While the pianist Zelma Bodzin did not demonstrate the carefree virtuosity and impetuous temperament needed to sweep through Schumann's Fantasy in her debut in Carnegie Recital Hall last Sunday night, in Mozart's more restrained but equally dark Fantasy and Sonata in C minor (K. 475 and 457), she demonstrated something just as important.

title: Nuclear Contamination Found in Japanese Soil
description: Radioactive waste apparently leaking from a disposal building adjacent to a nuclear power plant here has seriously contaminated soil in the area, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry said today.

title: DODGE'S BUILDING DEPRESSION
description: Although many economists who follow developments on the building front rely on a Commerce Department series for an accurate picture of work under way, an index of construction contract awards is valued as a leading indicator of what's in store for construction. The index is published by F.W. Dodge, a division of McGraw-Hill Inc.

title: A Reunion For Former Hostages
description: Amid accommodations decidedly more elegant than those at Teheran's Mushroom Inn, more than half of the 52 Americans held hostage in Iran were reunited last week at the Greenbrier, the stately West Virignia resort.

title: A NICE GUY FINISHES FIRST
description: Carey Winfrey is a former New York Times reporter who is writing a screenplay. By Carey Winfrey It's been one of those days. The Caribbean sun is playing peekaboo through the clouds, giving the exposure meters a workout and the camera men the heebie-jeebies.

title: Phillies 4, Cubs 3
description: PHILADELPHIA (AP) - Manny Trillo's two-out home run in the 10th inning gave Philadelphia its fifth straight victory. The Cubs lost their fifth straight.

title: Pieterjan Kat to Wed Lucy Look
description: Mr. and Mrs. David Townsend Look of Far Hills, N.J., have announced the engagement of Mr. Look's daughter, Lucy Look, to Pieterjan Kat, son of Mr. and Mrs. Pieter Kat of Malaga, Spain, formerly of Amsterdam, the Netherlands.

title: Antiques; JAPANESE SWORDS, ARMOR AND FITTINGS
description: It is most difficult to feel neutral about Japanese swords - those sculptured arcs of steel with the sharpest cutting blades of virtually any weapon. To some people, they are the most esthetically challenging of the decorative arts. To others, they are the most repugnant.

title: FUN IN THE SUN FOR LESS?
description: WESTPORT, Conn. The cost of fun this spring has gone up again. With the best jogging shoes selling for $75 a pair and indoor tennis court time costing $22 an hour, participation sports are adding to the inflation burden. But the appetite for fun has not abated. Most facilities are close to maximum use and equipment sales are steady.

title: KEEPING UP WITH THE PAST IN NEW HAVEN
description: One morning not long ago, a man who had spent many thousands of dollars thoughtfully renovating one of Wooster Square's brownstones noticed a fellow up the street tacking strips of aluminum over ''really fine cornicework.''

title: Linda Trownsell Betrothed to F. E. Jackson
description: The engagement of Linda Lee Trownsell to Frederick Elliott Jackson, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Jackson Jr. of Allentown, Pa., formerly of Scarsdale, N.Y., has been announced by the bride-to-be's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Donald L. Trownsell of Franklin Lakes, N.J., and Madison, Conn. The wedding is planned for June 27 in the First Congregational Church in Madison.

title:
Art;
EAST END GALLERIES GET A JUMP ON SUMMER
description: EAST HAMPTON ALTHOUGH most of the area's seasonal galleries won't be opening for another month or so, a few are getting a jump on summer. They are not only catering to the growing number of year-round residents, but also are hoping to attract the influx of weekenders that was already noticable a couple of weeks ago.

title: THOUSANDS DELAYED BY TIE-UP ON L.I.R.R.
description: Equipment failure on an eastbound Long Island Rail Road train in Queens forced suspension of service in both directions for up to 90 minutes last evening and caused lengthy delays for thousands of riders even after the train started rolling.

title: MARGIOTTA AND HIS FRIENDS
description: WESTBURY THE mail-fraud and extortion trial of Joseph M. Margiotta will probably go to the jury this week, and one central element that has emerged so far in the trial in Federal District Court here is Mr. Margiotta's relationship with the key Government witness, Richard A. Williams, and his late father, Richard B. Williams.

title: Westchester Guide; FORUM ON CIVIL RIGHTS
description: Carol Bellamy, the New York City Council President, and Dr. Michio Kaku, Nobel Prize-winning physicist, will be among those participating in a nine-day series of workshops called ''For Your Rights,'' at Sarah Lawrence College in Bronxville.

title: Jury Selection Begins Today in Met Slaying
description: Jury selection is to begin today in the State Supreme Court trial of Craig S. Crimmins, 22 years old, who is charged with murdering Helen Hagnes, a violinist, last summer at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: MENTALLY ILL ARE NOT VIOLENCE PRONE
description: To the Editor:

title: AFTER SCANT STUDY, TAXI FARES RISE BUT NOT SUPPLY
description: To the Editor:

title: P.S.C. SAYS RECORD CON ED RISE WAS VITAL TO ATTRACT INVESTMENT
description: The recent decision by New York State's Public Service Commission to give the Consolidated Edison Company the full 15 1/2 percent rate increase it had requested was shaped in large part by a growing mood among regulators that they must help bolster flagging investor confidence in the public utility industry.

title: Advertising; Travelers Check Campaign
description: WHEN you see that palomino stallion on the television screen running beautifully through the surf and along a grassy plain on behalf of the new MasterCard Travelers Cheques, it will be the work of the William Esty Company.

title: MRS. LLOYD IS LOSING PROBLEMS AND GAINING MOMENTUM AGAIN
description: CHRIS EVERT LLOYD had just defeated Regina Marsikova at the Family Circle Cup tennis tournament when a newsman asked why she had been looking at her hand during the match, which she had won, 6-1, 6-1.

title: President of Tandy To Be Chief as Well
description: John V. Roach, the 42-year-old president of the Tandy Corporation, a manufacturer of consumer electronics products and owner of the Radio Shack stores, has been named to the additional post of chief executive officer, effective July 1. He will succeed Phil R. North, 62, who will continue as chairman of the Fort Worth, Tex., company.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: A tennis player standing outside the service box is struck by the serve before it touches the ground. What is the ruling?

title: SHORT-TERM RATES EXPECTED TO RISE
description: In advance of today's auction of new three- and six-month Treasury bills, outstanding three- and six-month issues ended trading last week with rates of about 13.77 and 13.56 percent, respectively.

title: CORPORATE PROFITABILITY SURPRISING
description: With companies now reporting their first-quarter earnings, the early returns generally show a considerable, even surprising, measure of strength in corporate profitability, according to economists, Wall Street analysts and professional investors.

title: Bhutto's Son Says Hijackers Were Members of His Group
description: Mir Murtaza Bhutto, son of the former Prime Minister of Pakistan, was quoted by the British Broadcasting Corporation today as saying that members of his organization were the hijackers of a Pakistani jetliner last month. But he said he had not known that the hijacking was being planned.

title: Coal Production Down
description: The National Coal Association reported Friday that bituminous coal production for the week ended April 11 was 8.3 million tons, compared with 16.3 million tons in the comparable weekly period last year.

title: DAY IN THE LIFE OF A MONEY FUND
description: It is 9:05 A.M. and Thomas B. O'Donnell, a 28-year-old professional money shopper, is about to make his first purchase of the day. Advised that interest rates will dip as the morning ticks away, Mr. O'Donnell seeks a bargain.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''In Poland they will be celebrating Easter as they have not since 1939. It is a new spring in their lives that they weren't able to celebrate before.'' -The Rev. Stanley J. Adamczyk, pastor of the Church of the Most Sacred Heart of Jesus in Wallington, N.J. (B1:1.)

title: Quake Jolts Japanese Island
description: A moderate earthquake tonight shook part of Hokkaido, the northernmost of the four main Japanese islands. The Japanese meteorological agency said there were no immediate reports of damage or casualties. The earthquake recorded a maximum intensity of three on the Japanese scale of seven at Asahigawa and Rumoi in central Hokkaido, the agency said.

title: RIOTING URUPTS ANEW AFTER A BRITISH VEHICLE KILLS 2 IN LONDONERRY
description: Riots erupted anew in Londonderry early today as bands of youths charged through the streets after a British army Land-Rover struck and killed two youths.

title: IN ATHEIST CUBA, SOFT SPOT FOR CHURCH
description: When young Cubans raise their voices in ''The Internationale,'' the anthem of revolutionaries around the world, they usually do not sing the verse that says, ''No more saviors, no more gods, we will save ourselves.''

title: 8 Hours and 32 Innings
description: Harold M. Cooper, the president of the International League, today suspended until June 23 a 32-inning, eight-hour game between the Pawtucket Red Sox and the Rochester Red Wings. The game is the longest in the history of organized baseball.

title: Soon, Young & Rubicam May Top Japan's Dentsu
description: Dentsu, Japan's agency giant, remained the world's largest agency in 1980, but Young & Rubicam is inching up and could soon regain the title for this country, the place where the agency business started. That is what Advertising Age, the trade publication, will report today in its annual foreign agency income edition.

title: MOVIE TRAILERS: FINE ART OR ARTFUL FINESSE?
description: LOS ANGELES SINCE 1920, when a card at the end of a movie announced next week's feature, theaters have been trying to entice audiences by giving them a peek at the coming attraction.

title: Edgar Williamson, 77, a Realtor And Former Jersey Assemblyman
description: Edgar Williamson, a realtor who was a Republican Assemblyman from Essex County from 1938 to 1942 in the New Jersey State Legislature, died Saturday at his home in Lakewood, N.J. He was 77 years old.

title: 'VERY, VERY BAD,' PAKISTANI SAYS AS HE CONFISCATES LINGERIE AD
description: The gap between Islam and the West is wide, but it has its lighter moments. Since the hijacking of a Pakistani airliner in March, security at the country's airports has been strict: bags are searched three times, twice in the terminal and once on the tarmac just before one boards the plane. The guards are looking for weapons, of course, but they are good Moslems and they also look for anything contrary to Moslem law.

title: Rangers Sign Bonds For Farm Team
description: The Texas Rangers said today they they had signed the veteran Bobby Bonds for their Wichita farm team in the American Association.

title: Trevino's 69-273 Wins by 2 Shots on Coast
description: Lee Trevino shot a three-under-par 69 today and beat Ray Floyd by two strokes to win the MONY Tournament of Champions.

title: Doolittle Joins Survivors of Tokyo Raid for a Reunion
description: The military impact was negligible, but when 16 American B-25's flashed across Tokyo with their bomb doors open on April 18, 1942, it had a bell-ringing impact on the home front. Four months after Pearl Harbor, the United States had taken the war to Japan.

title: Jury to Deliberate Part 2 in Kush Trial
description: A jury of six women and two men in Maricopa County Superior Court begins deliberations tomorrow on the second phase of a $2.2 million suit against Frank Kush, the former Arizona State University football coach.

title: South African Bout For Hagler Reported
description: The world middleweight boxing champion, Marvin Hagler of the United States, reportedly will defend his world title against Ruben Pardo of Argentina here in August, The Sunday Express reported today.

title: Royal Couple Celebrate Anniversary at Sinatra's Place
description: Their wedding put the tiny Mediterranean principality of Monaco on the map, but to celebrate their 25th anniversary, Princess Grace and Prince Rainier shunned the scene of the 1956 spectacle. They toasted instead at a party Saturday night at Frank Sinatra's home at Rancho Mirage, Calif.

title: SWAN LOSES DEBUT
description: Pitching his first game since last August, Craig Swan was beset by a fielding error, a quirky play and misguided Met base running yesterday and lost to the Montreal Expos, 4-3, in the first game of a doubleheader.

title: MARCOS FOES WEIGH OVERTURE TO REBELS
description: Leading opponents of President Ferdinand E. Marcos plan to get in touch with leaders of the Moslem insurgency in the southern Philippines to discuss the possibility of joining forces in the June 16 presidential election, a former senator said today.

title: Supremacy at Sea The Race in the Indian Ocean Second of three articles.
description: The Soviet diplomat in the Seychelles was trying to show candor as he spoke with a visitor in the garden of his embassy in the island group in the Indian Ocean. ''You cannot really believe that we would disrupt Western oil flows,'' he said. ''That is not in our interest.'' The United States military attache in India struck an equally confidential tone. ''In this world, with missiles, you can't worry too much about the other fellow's intentions,'' he said. ''You have to concentrate on his capabilities, and right now, today, the Soviets have the capability to mine the Straits of Hormuz and move troops and tanks from Afghanistan to Iran.''

title: Kheel Charges Koch Set Up 'Slush Fund'
description: Theodore W. Kheel, the labor mediator charged that Mayor Koch, by continuing to collect campaign contributions in the name of his 1977 committee, had created his own $416,276 ''slush fund.''

title: News Analysis
description: It has been nearly seven months since Governor Byrne stood in the dry reservoir bed of Lake Tappan in Bergen County, declaring the northeastern corner of the state to be in a drought and ordering people and industries in 114 communities to conserve or face the prospect one day of dry faucets.

title: CASTRO DECLARES NO INVADER 'CAN GRAB OUR COUNTRY'
description: On the 20th anniversary of his victory at the Bay of Pigs, President Fidel Castro of Cuba made an emotional plea for world peace, reaffirmed his nation's solidarity with the Soviet Union and warned that no invader ''can grab our country with its guard down.''

title: Earth Tremors Rock Italian Town
description: Three earth tremors shook San Gimignano today, sending hundreds of residents and tourists fleeing into the streets of the town southwest of Siena. The police said there were no reports of injuries or damage. The seismological observatory in Prato, near Florence, said the shocks were ''more or less normal, consistent with the geological structures of the area.''

title: S.E.C. SET TO ORDER STOCK TRADING LINK
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is expected to issue an order on Tuesday that an automated computerized trading link be established between the nation's stock exchanges and the over-the-counter market, agency and industry sources said.

title: Psyche Job
description: The reputation of the Philadelphia Flyers to play brutal hockey is enough to psyche out many opponents. The team, which is currently in the quarterfinals of the Stanley Cup with Calgary, is looking for another mental edge. It has hired a psychologist.

title: Connors Tops Taroczy, Joins Vilas in Final
description: Jimmy Connors completed a 6-1, 7-6 victory over Balazs Taroczy of Hungary today in a rain-delayed semifinal of the Monte Carlo open tennis tournament.

title: STARS WIN AND LEAD SABRES, 3-0
description: Kevin Maxwell and Neal Broten scored goals 23 seconds apart in the third period tonight, sparking Minnesota to a 6-4 victory over Buffalo and giving the North Stars a commanding 3-0 lead in their Stanley Cup quarterfinal series.

title: 76ERS AND KINGS ADVANCE TO N.B.A. PLAYOFF SEMIFINALS
description: Reggie King scored 23 points, 10 in the third period, as the Kansas City Kings defeated the Phoenix Suns, 95-88, today in the seventh and deciding game of their Western Conference semifinal playoff series.

title: Blue Jays, With Bomback, Stop Tigers, 9-1
description: Mark Bomback recorded his first American League victory and Al Woods drove in three runs with a pair of doubles as the Toronto Blue Jays defeated the Detroit Tigers, 9-1, today.

title: Invitation That a Nobel Prize Winner Couldn't Refuse
description: Since he won a Nobel Prize in medicine last year, Dr. George D. Snell, has been flooded with more invitations than his schedule can accommodate. And when the letter came in from the Paracelsus Society, a new student science club at Bowdoin College, it seemed one the 77-year-old geneticist could easily pass up.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: Portland's Big-League Image

title: Euro-Advertising Mergers
description: There were two announcements in one from Paris last week, from Euro-Advertising Holdings, the J.W.T. Group subsidiary. First, it said that it had acquired a majority stake in Recla-Janssens Advertising, the largest Dutch-owned agency in the Netherlands, and second, that it had merged with Van Hees, Vlessing & Partners in Belgium. Euro-Advertising already had 12 agencies in 10 countries.

title: WILLIE DE VILLE AND BAND
description: WILLIE DeVILLE launched his band, Mink DeVille, at downtown rock clubs like CBGB in the mid-70's, but unlike the other performers who found their initial audience on that circuit -the Talking Heads, Television, Blondie - Mr. DeVille was a New York classicist. This city's most distinctive popular music has often been a mixture of street-wise realism and sheer romantic invention, and Mr. DeVille's songs and the personality he projected had both.

title: Jersey Woman Slain; Girl, 10, Calls Police
description: A woman was stabbed to death in her home, and her 10-year-old daughter called the police, authorities said.

title: NISSAN BRINGS FOREIGN WAYS TO TENNESSEE
description: The boys in Detroit are not going to believe this. Marvin Runyon, an old Detroiter, one of those real auto men who started on the assembly line, was sitting in his office, a converted Air Force barracks, and pondering management techniques:

title: ACTIVISTS FREED IN FIVE BRONX TRIALS INVOLVING PROTESTS OF BIAS IN
description: HEARING By LEONARD BUDER

title: The Hertzes Plan to Push Prime Time Magazine
description: The Hertzes are going to go public with Prime Time Communications, publisher of the fledgling magazine of the same name. They hope to raise about $3.9 million to improve the magazine's circulation.

title: Kenyan Team Leads Auto Rally in Africa
description: Shekhar Mehta of Kenya, seeking a record fourth victory in the Safari Rally, held a slim lead today when Anders Kullang of Sweden, the early leader, hit a cow and later drove into a ditch.

title: Seninho Fills Weisweiler's Order to Score
description: Coach Hennes Weisweiler of the Cosmos prides himself on his ability to get the most out of a soccer player, but until Saturday night he had failed with Seninho.

title: THE DISTRICT HEATING
description: Is the Snow Belt doomed? Should Northerners migrate to the Sun Belt? Rapidly rising heating costs could wreak economic havoc on large parts of the North. Heating oil, now about $1.35, could easily hit $2 per gallon next winter, and several times that by the late 1980's. Decontrol of natural gas will raise its home-heating cost to that of oil. What options does the Snow Belt have?

title: HOUSEHOLD FINANCE'S STRATEGY QUESTIONED
description: The Household Finance Corporation, spurred by rising interest rates and the potential collapse of the consumer loan business, undertook an ambitious diversification in recent years that put it in the leasing business, for ships, trailer trucks and computers, and in manufacturing, of barbecue grills and water coolers.

title: MUSIC: WORKS BY CHATHAM AT THE KITCHEN
description: RHYS CHATHAM'S Guitar Trio was one of the less drastically titled works on the program of ''Drastic Classical Music for Electric Instruments'' at the Kitchen on Friday night, which included ''Acoustic Terror,'' ''The Out of Tune Guitar'' and ''Wild Romance'' - but though it was simpler than the rest of the works written and performed by the electric guitarist and one-time director of the Kitchen, it was far from a classical serenade.

title: Green Light on Tudor Parks
description: Anyone who played ''red light'' as a child must have a familiar feeling about the stop-and-go negotiations over Manhattan's two Tudor City parks. For those who came in late, the game has been as follows: Harry Helmsley, the owner of Tudor City, announced an intention to build on the parks and sent in bulldozers just long enough to prove he meant it.

title: Inmates Take 10 Hostages, Then Free Them in Nevada
description: Two convicts at the Nevada State Prison took 10 people hostage today and demanded food and a helicopter. Five hours later they had surrendered and released all the hostages unharmed after gaining the promise of a transfer to a psychiatric unit.

title: FOR 20 YEARS, A RADCLIFFE HAVEN FOR FEMALE SCHOLARS
description: Two decades ago, Mary Bunting, then the president of Radcliffe College, founded a small institute for women who wanted to return to scholarly or artistic studies, after years away from academe to raise their children,

title: OBJECTS OF SOLACE FOR LIFE
description: T HE urge to cuddle a teddy bear does not appear to be one of the more popular strategies that grown-ups use in coping with the stress of existence. Nevertheless, the mechanism that lies behind a child's quest for a ''lovey'' may be an important source of comfort throughout our lives.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day Friday about Manufacturers Hanover Corpor- tion incorrectly compared the differ- ence in first-quarter net operating earnings this year and last and incor- rectly reported the rank of the bank. After-tax net operating earnings of Manufacturers Hanover, the nation's fourth largest banking organization, were $3.4 million higher in this year's first quarter than in the comparable 1980 period.

title: REAGAN TAX CUT: QUESTION OF FAIRNESS
description: Which of the following statements is true: the Reagan Administration's tax relief proposal is fair because it would give larger percentage cuts in taxes paid to lower-income wage earners than to upper-bracket taxpayers; the proposal is unfair because it would result in larger percentage rises in after-tax income for upper-income taxpayers.

title: CURE THE BLUES STILL SET FOR DERBY
description: Despite a poor effort in Saturday's Wood Memorial that may have toppled him from the favorite's role, Cure the Blues will be shipped to Churchill Downs sometime this week to prepare for the Kentucky Derby May 2.

title: CORPORATIONS WATCHING TREASURY BORROWINGS
description: The number of corporations waiting to sell long-term bonds grows with every passing week. Investment bankers say that some corporations are waiting for a cutback in Treasury borrowing this spring that would ''open a window'' and allow corporations back into the long-term markets.

title: Tiant Takes a Step On the Road Back
description: Luis Tiant may be ready to return to the major leagues. Tiant, a right-handed veteran of 17 years in the major leagues, took a step in that direction last night with a no-hitter for the Portland Beavers of the Pacific Coast League.

title: STUDY PREDICTS HARMFUL INCREASE IN USE OF COAL AND NUCLEAR POWER
description: A yearlong National Audubon Society study of the nation's energy needs concedes that it will be necessary to use more coal and nuclear power in the next 20 years, resulting in some detrimental effects on the environment.

title: FOOD STAMPS AND THE BUDGET
description: This is one of a series of occasional articles tracing the progress of one program, food stamps, through the budget process. President Reagan originally proposed cutting $1.8 billion from the program, which would cost about $12.6 billion in the 1982 fiscal year under current law.

title: THE SUPREME LAW IS STILL THE CONSTITUTION
description: To the Editor:

title: ROOTS OF YUGOSLAV RIOTS: VAGUE 'ENEMY' BLAMED
description: Even in the cold, dreary rain, women of Albanian ancestry with white headscarfs and long floral print skirts or baggy trousers strolled along the main street pausing to admire the window displays of modern dress shops, furniture stores and supermarkets.

title: Obraztsovy Scores In Rich Coast Race
description: Obraztsovy, a Kentucky-bred horse who had raced in Europe but had never won a stakes event in the United States, captured the $200,000 San Juan Capistrano Invitational Handicap over a mile and three-quarters on wet grass at Santa Anita today.

title: TEACHING AS THERAPY FOR THE WHOLE CHILD
description: Luke - not his real name - is a character in the book ''City Kid,'' by Mary McCracken. He was an angelic-looking 7-year-old who believes in the tooth fairy. He was also a thief, a burglar and an arsonist who had been arrested 24 times. In less than one school year, she says, Luke changed from dumb to bright, from crooked to honest, from sullenly silent to friendly under the tutoring of Mrs. McCracken. She says his story is true, and that he is one of many children she has helped.

title: DROP EXPECTED IN BOND YIELDS
description: Long-term Treasury bonds are yielding more than 13 percent, up from about 12.1 percent when President Reagan was inaugurated, even though the Reagan Administration is still moving toward the tax and spending cuts that are supposed to encourage lower inflation and lower interest rates.

title: City Panel Sees Need To Reverse Decline
description: New York City has entered the 1980's with its capital affairs in better order than they were a few years ago, according to the City Planning Commission's annual report, ''Capital Needs and Priorities.'' But the report said the city would still need new sources of funds to keep its physical plant from deteriorating further.

title: Losses Hit Horizons
description: The Chicago Horizons are in serious financial difficulty and owe hundreds of thousands of dollars to their creditors, club officials confirmed today.

title: Bullish Vote
description: A year ago, before the movie ''Raging Bull'' was released, Jake LaMotta was named on 80 ballots - or 74.766 percent of the votes cast - for Ring magazine's Boxing Hall of Fame. A boxer has to be on at least 75 percent of the ballots to be elected to the hall, and it seemed natural that LaMotta would make it in 1981.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Chemical Bank has named David L. Eyles to the newly created position of chairman of the credit policy committee.

title: NORANDA PERFORMANCE WINS HIGH MARKS
description: In the early 1950's, Alfred Powis, a young mining analyst with the Sun Life Assurance Company in Montreal, interviewed John R. Bradfield, then the president of Noranda Mines Ltd., for a research report.

title: A Corporal For Arlington
description: SHORTLY after Pearl Harbor, the reigning world heavyweight boxing champion, Joe Louis, defended his title against Buddy Baer on Jan. 9, 1942, at Madison Square Garden. He knocked out Baer in the first round and, as he had promised, donated his purse - $65,200 - to the Naval Relief Fund. Not long after that, on March 27, he again defended his title at the Garden for free. This time he knocked out Abe Simon in the sixth round and contributed the purse of $45,882 to the Army Relief Fund.

title: NO STOMACH FOR MEDICAID TAPEWORM
description: To the Editor:

title: TERRORISTS SOUGHT IN THE WOUNDING OF TWO OFFICERS
description: Two men who were members of the Black Liberation Army are being sought as ''prime suspects'' in the wounding of two New York City officers, one critically, last Thursday, the Police Department said this morning.

title: Gen. Charles B. Lyman; Pacific War Commander
description: Brig. Gen. Charles B. Lyman, U.S.A., retired, a combat commander in World War II in the South Pacific and the South China Sea, died Wednesday at his home in Pennsbury Township, Pa. He was 92 years old.

title: Yankees Shut Out; Cerone Has X-Rays
description: Jon Matlack, who pitched poorly in losing his first two starts this season, righted himself today with a four-hitter in a 4-0 victory by the Texas Rangers over the Yankees.

title: AUTO LIMIT IS PREPARED BY JAPANESE
description: The Ministry of International Trade and Industry has prepared a compromise plan to limit Japanese auto exports to the United States to 1.7 million units in 1981, about 120,000 fewer cars than last year, according to MITI officials quoted by the Kyodo News Service.

title: POLISH-AMERICAN EASTER HAS SPECIAL SYMBOLISM
description: A traditional Polish hymn, ''Wesoly Nam Dzis Dzien Nastal,'' which means ''A very happy day has now dawned on us,'' greeted the newly risen sun at masses in Wallington, N.J., yesterday - a day in which children in new spring clothes helped their mothers arrange dining tables with pisanki and babki, sugar lambs and ham.

title: BODY FOUND IN RIVER OUTSIDE OF ATLANTA
description: The body of 15-year-old Joseph Bell, who had been missing since March 2, was found this afternoon in DeKalb County in a tangle of debris at a bend in the South River, 15 to 20 feet from shore. He was the 24th black youth found slain in the Atlanta area in the last 20 months.

title: Bridge: Galley to Set Out on Quest To Pass His '80 Point Total
description: The record for the greatest number of master points won in a year was set in 1980 by Ron Andersen of New York and stands at 2,725. This was in the American Contract Bridge League, and similar accumulations are not uncommon since some professionals and their sponsors stay on the tournament circuit playing an average of five days a week.

title: Refugees Throw Stones In a 'Mild' Disturbance
description: About 100 Cuban refugees threw stones at their camp guards for about three hours today, but officials termed the disturbance ''mild'' compared with the uprising that left a dozen people injured last night.

title: By Jim Benagh
description: Sports World Specials Cannon's Best Shot

title: DR. MILTON P. HUNTER
description: Dr. Milton P. Hunter, who had been head of orthopedic surgery at Northern Westchester Hospital in Mount Kisco, N.Y., and at Grasslands Hospital in Valhalla, N.Y., died yesterday in Pound Ridge, N.Y. He was 84 years old and lived in Pound Ridge.

title: CITY PLAN OVERESTIMATED U.S. CUTS, REGAN ASSERTS
description: State Comptroller Edward V. Regan asserted yesterday that New York City had vastly overestimated the effects of President Reagan's proposed budget cuts on the city's 1982 financial plan.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Jane Brody THE FAMILY BOOK ABOUT SEXUALITY. By Mary S. Calderone, M.D., and Eric W. Johnson. 330 pages. Illustrated. Harper & Row. $14.95.

title: TESTING 'WORKFARE' IN SOUTH CAROLINA: FOOD STAMP USERS FIND MIXED RESULTS
description: In this rural area 15 miles upriver from Charleston, a few recipients of food stamps are working for the county to pay off the value of their benefits. One of them is Donald Griffin, an affable 28-year-old with a jail term in his past and no job in his immediate future.

title: JOBLESS BENEFIT PLAN COULD INCREASE JOBLESS
description: To the Editor:

title: A'S SPLIT BUT THEY SET MARK OF 11-0
description: The Oakland A's were defeated today for the first time this season, but not before they had established a major-league record by winning their 11th consecutive game at the start of the season.

title: Youngstown School Strike Has a Tentative Settlement
description: The 1,000 teachers who have been on strike here for the past month are to vote tomorrow morning on a tentative agreement reached today.

title: Red Smith,  On Becoming Aged in the Wood
description: IN the Churchill Downs Race Book in Las Vegas, Nev., Cure the Blues was still the favorite for the Kentucky Derby, but it was still Easter Sunday morning out there and the effects of the Wood Memorial had not been felt that far west. With Cure the Blues at 5-2, Proud Appeal was second choice at 3-1, Tap Shoes was 6-1 and Lord Avie 10-1, an underlay for a steed that isn't in the race.

title: Filipino Terrorists Kill 11 At an Easter Mass
description: Eleven people were killed and more than 155 wounded in a terrorist grenade attack on a Roman Catholic cathedral packed with thousands of worshipers at an Easter mass tonight, the authorities said. A regional military commander blamed the Communist New People's Army for the attack.

title: SAUDI OFFICIAL VOWS HIGH OUTPUT OF OIL UNTIL PRICES DROP
description: Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, Saudi Arabia's oil minister, said today that his country would not raise its oil prices or reduce its production until other petroleum-exporting nations reduced their prices significantly.

title: CBS STATION CHALLENGES ABC'S ''20 20'' ARSON REPORT
description: The CBS-owned television station in Chicago will present a onehour documentary tonight about investigative reporting that disputes a report on the ABC-TV newsmagazine ''20/20'' entitled ''Arson and Profit.'' The program won an Emmy Award last week.

title: WOODCHUCKS READY TO JOIN RITES OF SPRING
description: From now until early July - when tall pasture and meadow grasses provide them cover - woodchucks are avidly hunted throughout much of the Northeast.

title: CELLO RECITAL: SUNG EUN HONG
description: SUNG EUN HONG, a cellist from South Korea and a student at the Juilliard School, played in New York's Carnegie Recital Hall late Saturday afternoon, accompanied at the piano by Ana Maria Trenchi De Bottazzi. Two sonatas were at the core of Miss Hong's program, Beethoven's No. 3 (Op. 69) and Prokofiev's Opus 119, with shorter works by Frescobaldi, Paganini, Granados, Ravel and Cassado.

title: Steifel/Raymond
description: The First Women's Bank has chosen Steifel/Raymond Advertising as its first agency. Asked why she had not chosen an agency run by a women, Judy Hendren Mello, president of the bank, said that after a careful screening of 30 agencies to fill the bank's advertising, public relations and marketing needs, she decided that Stiefel/ Raymond was the proper one for the bank. And it has assigned two woman executives to her account

title: The Price of Order in Turkey
description: When the Turkish armed forces overthrew an elected government last September, many gave their intentions the benefit of the doubt. A weak democracy had been unable to cope with a surge in violence and a stricken economy. Turkey's military moved reluctantly, and promised a return to democracy ''as soon as possible.'' But after seven months, the ruling junta has yet to fix a firm timetable for parliamentary elections.

title: Pirates 2, Astros 0
description: HOUSTON (UPI) - Omar Moreno lofted a tie-breaking sacrifice fly in the eighth and Rod Scurry exceled in his first major-league start as Pittsburgh swept its three-game series with Houston.

title: Nonaligned Nations Appeal For Penalty for South Africa
description: Foreign Ministers from the countries professing nonalignment called on the United Nations Security Council today to impose mandatory sanctions on South Africa to force it to leave South-West Africa.

title: Ailing Sperm Whale Reported Improving
description: A 25-foot 10,000-pound sperm whale suffering from pneumonia that had been found in shallow water on the south shore of Long Island was showing marked improvement yesterday in a boat basin at Robert Moses State Park, a marine veterinarian said.

title: 76ES AND KINGS ASVANCE TO N.B.A. SEMIFINALS
description: After the end of what was probably the most disappointing and possibly last defeat in his 11-year professional career, Bob Lanier looked up at the dressing room ceiling. He saw basketballs, bouncing over his head and behind him.

title: MCDONALD'S CHEF LOOKS FOR QUALITY
description: Rene Arend, 52, who holds the unusual title of executive chef at the McDonald's Corporation, a worldwide fast-food chain with more than 6,000 units, is following with the pride of a father the success of Chicken McNuggets, a new finger-food product that he created for his company. The item recently was added at outlets in the New York area.

title: KOCH KEEPING WATCH OVER HIS IMAGE
description: Mayor Koch's political consultants have taken his ''How'm I doin'?'' question a substantial step further in a private poll that asks New Yorkers if they think the Mayor is ''arrogant,'' ''a bully,'' ''insensitive'' and ''has too much to say about everything.''

title: KENNETH BURKE TO GET LITERATURE MEDAL
description: Kenneth Burke, the literary critic and poet, will receive the National Medal for Literature at the American Book Awards ceremony at Carnegie Hall on April 30. The $15,000 award, endowed in memory of the late Harold Guinzberg, founder of the Viking Press, honors a living American writer ''for a distinguished and continuing contribution to American letters.''

title: IT CAN BE DONE
description: The view over the city and the bay from the balcony of a luxury hotel could be Miami. There are gleaming glass towers in the distance, occasionally a water-skier in the foreground, lines of cars speeding over freeways.

title: Dodgers 6, Padres 1
description: SAN DIEGO (AP) - Ken Landreaux hit a homer and drove in three runs, and Pedro Guerrero also connected as Los Angeles scored its eighth victory in nine games.

title: 3 Jersey Forest Fires Are Under Control
description: Three large forest fires in southern New Jersey had been brought under control yesterday, although they were expected to keep burning for several days within the fire lines that contained them, State Forest Fire Service officials said.

title: LOUISIANA INQUIRY URGED ON 2 JOCKEYS
description: -An angry member of the Louisiana Racing Commission said today he would ask for an inquiry on two jockeys whose charges of race fixing apparently helped prompt Gov. Dave Treen to request that the entire commission resign.

title: THE KOCH METHOD FOR WINNING AUDIENCES AND INFLUENCING VOTERS
description: It was, in most regards, a routine performance. A few nights ago Edward I. Koch spoke for an hour before 500 people who filled the lounge of the Yale Club. By the time he finished, he had demonstrated - more graphically perhaps than he had in some time - the many facets of a carefully constructed, combative political style that delights some voters and infuriates others, leaves friends wondering aloud, ''How does he do it?'' and foes asking, ''How does he get away with it?''

title: ISLANDERS BOW, 5-2 TO OILERS
description: ''This is a club that is constantly learning,'' Wayne Gretzky said tonight after having scored three goals in leading the Edmonton Oilers to a 5-2 triumph over the New York Islanders. ''Last year we learned a lot playing Philadelphia. This year we're learning from the Stanley Cup champions.''

title: GULF WAR HURTING KUWAIT'S ECONOMY
description: Frustration over the continued Iranian-Iraqi war appears to be growing here as one peace mission after another travels fruitlessly to Teheran and Baghdad and as the continued hostilities cut increasingly into the Kuwaiti economy.

title: The U.N. Today; April 20, 1981; ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL
description: Meets at 3 P.M.

title: Article 091884 -- No Title
description: Burglars wielding sledgehammers and crowbars broke into the basement of a Brooklyn bank from an adjacent clothing store Saturday night or early yesterday, then cut into a steel night depository vault with acetylene torches and fled with $150,000 to $250,000, the police said.

title: A STYLISH HOTEL LIVES TO MIRROR UGANDA'S FATE
description: The Swahili word for finished, over, ended, out or no more is kwisha, pronounced kwee-sha. The word is heard everywhere in Kampala, where food is kwisha, water is kwisha and gasoline is kwisha. Kampala is all but kwisha.

title: UNJUSTIFIED LEAK
description: To the Editor:

title: China Said to Arrest Two Political Activists
description: Chinese and foreign sources said today that the authorities had arrested two political activists, the first known political detentions in more than a year.

title: PIANIST: ISRAELA MARGALIT PLAYS BACH, PROKOFIEV AND SCHUMANN
description: ISRAELA MARGALIT offered three major works for the piano at her Alice Tully Hall recital on Friday night, three invitations to make three very different kinds of musical statements. While Miss Margalit's cultured pianism was never less than correct and wellmannered, she politely declined to turn these pieces into the sort of powerfully compelling individual conceptions these composers obviously intended them to be.

title: Four Killed as Tornado Strikes Tulsa, Okla., Area
description: A tornado struck southeastern Tulsa and the suburbs tonight, killing at least four persons, destroying dozens of houses and mobile homes and injuring several persons in a church, the authorities said.

title: Rodgers: Boston's Man on The Run
description: BOSTON AMONTH ago, Bill Rodgers awakened with the flu. ''I was weak,'' he recalled, ''washed out, sick. I was depressed. I thought Boston was gone.''

title: Coal-Gas Plant Funds Denied
description: The Department of Energy on Friday turned down a request for Federal financing to build a coal gasification plant at Oak Ridge, Tenn.

title: MONDAY, APRIL 20, 1981; International
description: Saudi Arabia will not raise oil prices or reduce production until other OPEC members lower their prices significantly, its oil minister, Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, said. His statement is seen as the opening round in what could be a tough struggle within OPEC when its members meet May 25 to discuss oil prices. (Page A1.)

title: Commodities; Rain Brings Respite to Grain Belt
description: DESPITE the renewed talk in Washington about lifting the partial embargo on grain exports to the Soviet Union, the major news in the grain belt this weekend was that it rained over much of the region.

title: A Job Search, a White House Link and a Matter of Taste
description: The client was a 28-year-old law clerk who had failed the California bar exam. But the Keith Management Company, an executive employment agency, decided he had a lot going for him, and pressed a campaign to find the young man a better position.

title: NORTH CAROLINA SUIT PITS TOBACCO AGAINST TEXTILES
description: Tobacco is North Carolina's most lucrative cash crop, and cotton textiles and apparel its largest industrial employer. Both industries are volatile, and their fortunes sometimes fluctuate and their interests sometimes collide as a result of actions by the Federal Government. Nowhere is the growing friction between textiles and tobacco in North Carolina more evident than in an industrial compensation case now before the North Carolina Supreme Court.

title: Bills' Player Charged
description: Jim Haslett, a linebacker for the Buffalo Bills, was arrested yesterday and accused of shoving a police officer who stopped the car that Haslett was a passenger in.

title: 16 KILLED IN SHELLING OF LEBANON PORT CITY BY CHRISTIAN MILITIAS
description: Christian militia forces today shelled the southern Lebanese port of Sidon, killing at least 16 residents and wounding more than 60, according to Lebanese authorities.

title: ISLANDERS BOW, 5-2, TO OILERS
description: The Rangers took a 2-1 lead in their four-of-seven quarterfinal playoff series with the St. Louis Blues at Madison Square Garden last night, thoroughly outplaying a team that had defeated them four times in four games during the regular season.

title: THE SINGING TELEGRAM BUSINESS
description: It is midmorning in a refurbished San Francisco warehouse, the home of National Singing Telegrams Ltd., as Ed Eng leafed through the 65 pages of neatly-typed song lyrics that comprise his company's telegram repertoire.

title: REHNQUIST REJECTS REQUEST TO EXTEND LOS ANGLES BUSING
description: Supreme Court Justice William H. Rehnquist tonight rejected an appeal by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People to halt the dismantling tomorrow morning of a mandatory busing program for school desegregation here.

title: FOR NEW YORK, A DAY OF PLAY AND FOR PRAYER
description: Everywhere he went in his coat of many colors on Easter Sunday, people stopped Antonio Perez to ask him questions and take his picture. At 55th Street, as a throng of people and a swirl of smoke from vendors' carts eddied down the long rich canyon of Fifth Avenue, he and Norma Lieber came together in ecumenical admiration.

title: GOODELL IS HAPPY TO RETIRE
description: BOSTON BRIAN GOODELL remembers when he wasn't the world's best swimmer. ''I learned to swim when we lived in Walnut Creek, Calif., near San Francisco,'' he said. ''There was a swim club around the corner, and all the kids in the neighborhood swam there in the summer. So I joined. I was 6 years old.

title: New Horse Drug Focus of Inquiry
description: On June 15, 1978, the Food and Drug Administration granted a German-based company the right to experiment in the United States with a new stimulant drug for treating respiratory ailments in horses.

title: Market Place; Denver Trading Of New Issues
description: DENVER A COLORADO equivalent of the Canadian penny stock market is alive and thriving in Denver, and its sponsors are eager to prove that the market is both responsible and conducive to investor profits.

title: ADMIRALS SAY NAVY LACKS SHIPS TO HANDLE NEW RESPONSIBILITIES
description: When the Chief of Naval Operations, Admiral Thomas B. Hayward, went before Congress a few weeks ago to report on the Navy's strength, he said that ''for the first time in anyone's recollection, the United States Navy is unable fully to meet its peacetime commitments.''

title: Phils Beat Cubs for 6 in Row, 7-3
description: Keith Moreland, replacing the ailing Mike Schmidt, doubled home the tie-breaking run in a four-run eighth inning today and the Phillies went on to defeat the Chicago Cubs, 7-3, for their sixth straight victory.

title: DON'T DO WITHOUT
description: To the Editor:

title: Braves 4, Giants 3
description: ATLANTA (AP) - Biff Pocoroba's two-run single in the bottom of the ninth inning ended a four-game losing streak for Atlanta. Glenn Hubbard opened the ninth by hitting a single off Greg Minton and Rafael Ramirez walked.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: LEADING MAN

title: Japan Ship Orders Off
description: Foreign orders received by Japanese shipyards in the year ended March 31 fell to 266 ships, totaling 6 million gross tons, from 294 ships totaling 7.2 million tons in the previous year, the ship exporters association said Friday. The value of export orders for the year rose 1 percent, to about $5.4 billion at current exchange rates.

title: KAMALI'S CATCHY SWEATERS
description: Just when you thought the influence of active sportswear on street fashion was running out of breath, along sprints Norma Kamali. Using the familiar fleecy sweatshirt fabric of Army-Navy store window fame, the designer has created some of the most sought-after clothes in town.

title: Teheran Admits Scandal In Attempt to Obtain Arms
description: Iran acknowledged today that it had lost $56 million in an arms swindle in Europe while trying to get badly needed supplies for its war against Iraq.

title: Lawmaker Ends Pakistan Visit
description: Representative Joel Pritchard, Republican of Washington, ended a three-day visit to Pakistan promising to advocate continued assistance for Afghan refugees, a United States Embassy spokesman said today. The United States has provided about a quarter of the $400 million being spent on refugee relief.

title: HELPED GUIDE CREATION OF CITY U.
description: Mary Shotwell Ingraham, who as a member of New York City's Board of Higher Education directed planning that led to the creation of the City University, died Thursday in the Hilaire Farm Nursing Home, Huntington, L.I. She was 94 years old.

title: Index; International
description: For U.S. and Soviet, high stakes in the Indian Ocean A1 Root of Yugoslav riots: vague ''enemy'' blamed A2 Castro regime fosters friendlier climate with churches A3 Saudis temper an Islamic rule and let men see their fiancees A4 Around the World A5 Two killed in Londonderry vio- lence after Easter marches A6 Marcos opposition plans overture to Moslem rebels A7 Hotel in Uganda wears its band- ages bravely A9 Admirals say they don't have the ships to do the job A12 Government/Politics A glimpse at how Koch wins audi- ences and influences voters B1 Federal budget cuts held overesti- mated by New York City B2 Researchers suggest ways for political parties to survive B6 General Around the Nation A16 Jersey town with ties to Poland celebrates a special Easter B1 Goldin and Fire Dept. disagree on merit of new alarm box B3 Health/Science Audubon Society study sees rise in coal use and nuclear power A14 Industry/Labor Friction develops between cotton and tobacco industries A13 Engineers are in high demand among this spring's graduates A16 PARKING REGULATIONS Because of Passover, alternate-side parking will be suspended throughout New York City today and tomorrow. All other parking rules remain in ef- fect. SportsMonday Baseball: Swan loses in 1981 debut, but Mets gain split C1

title: SAUDIS TEMPER AN ISLAMIC RULE, LETTING MEN SEE THEIR FIANCEES
description: After 14 centuries of scrupulous adherence to an Islamic orthodoxy that keeps women hidden behind veils and segregated from men in school and at work, Saudi Arabia has bent at least one of its customs.

title: The Model Assassin
description: Even as President Reagan recovers from the attempt on his life comes a startling report from California. Sirhan Sirhan, who assassinated Robert Kennedy in June 1968 is scheduled for release in the summer of 1984, and then on to asylum in Libya. How come so soon? He has been, says a prison official, ''a model prisoner'' and the parole agency is determined to treat him like any other murderer. What a false sense of fairness. What a disservice to the country.

title: BRADLEE'S WORLD
description: After announcing that its story of ''Jimmy's World'' -about a supposed 8-year-old drug addict - had been based on a nonexistent source, The Washington Post grimly printed two letters from readers that must have hurt:

title: LEBANON: MYTH AND REALITY
description: Real countries are hidden beneath layers and pretentions. The Lebanon now claiming the headlines is far different from the one we as Lebanese had constructed in our minds, from the myths we had spun about it, from the images we peddled to ourselves and to others.

title: TV: BY JONATHAN MILLER' 'ANTONY AND CLEOPATRA'
description: JONATHAN MILLER'S production of Shakespeare's ''Antony and Cleopatra,'' on WNET-TV, Channel 13, from 8 to 11 this evening, is certainly unusual, as would be expected from the man who cast Monty Python's John Cleese in ''The Taming of the Shrew'' and, for an encore, offered an intentionally controversial interpretation of ''The Merchant of Venice.'' Mr. Miller has his own unorthodox but clever ways of being memorable.

title: DANCE: JENKINS TROUPE FROM SAN FRANCISCO
description: IT was old home week at the Space at City Center on Wednesday, when the San Francisco-based Margaret Jenkins Dance Company appeared in the Dance Umbrella festival. On hand were colleagues from Miss Jenkins's days with Merce Cunningham and Viola Farber, cheering and whistling along with an exuberant lay audience. Miss Jenkins is clearly a New York favorite. But the program passed in an increasingly foggy blur for this observer, with dance that went dim sum one better by evaporating before being chewed.

title: PRIMA DONNA CRITICIZES BOLSHOI OPERA
description: a highly unusual step in a country where musicians tend either to emigrate or avoid controversy.

title: ENGINEERING GRADUATES AGAIN HIGH ON COMPANY RECRUITERS' MOST-WANTED LIST
description: This spring's college graduates are facing a job market that is both better and worse than it was last spring. Engineers are being hungrily wooed with salary offers reaching $30,000 a year, while liberal arts majors are scraping to find openings that pay $12,000.

title: 7 More Die in Colombian Floods
description: Seven more people died today as a result of floods sweeping northern and central Colombia, civil defense officials reported. A state of alert has been declared along the Caribbean coast, where 15 people have been killed and 10 reported missing in a week of flooding, the officials said.

title: STUDIES FIND FUTURE IN POLITICAL PARTIES
description: The American voter may increasingly find political parties irrelevant, but they can survive anyway by providing services to candidates that the officeseekers find essential, several studies presented this week to the Midwest Political Science Association suggested.

title: GOLDIN AUDIT AND FIRE DEPT. DISPUTE MERIT OF ALARM BOX
description: City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin urged the Fire Department yesterday to hold off further purchases of the voice-communications fire alarm boxes it first deployed, with high hopes, eight years ago. He said the boxes had ''failed to meet expectations in several important respects.''

title: Double Bragging Rights
description: The athletic board at Kansas University voted down Athletic Director Bob Marcum's novel request to move a home football game 51,500-seat Memorial Stadium to 80,000-seat Arrowhead Stadium in Kansas City, Mo., 45 miles away.

title: People
description: * John Raventos and Robert Rowley have joined Needham, Harper & Steers International Inc. as senior vice presidents.

title: Washington Watch
description: WASHINGTON SOME weeks back the Reagan Administration toyed with the notion of ''targeting'' tax breaks for depressed industries such as autos and steel. The Treasury rejected the idea on grounds that the best relief for all sectors would come from the general cuts now being pushed with renewed vigor.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, APRIL, 20, 1981
description: International Saudia Arabia will not raise oil prices or reduce its production until other petroleum-exporing nations reduce their prices significantly, Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, the Saudi oil minister, said. ''We think it went too far,'' he said. ''It's not in the interest of the international community, and therefore we want it to come down a little bit lower.'' His statements represented Saudia Arabia's most pointed threat so far in its struggle with other members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries over oil prices. (Page A1, Column 6.) A port in southern Lebanon was shelled by Christian militia forces, leaving 16 residents dead and more than 60 wounded, according to Lebanese authorities. A few hours after the shelling of Sidon, a predominantly Moslem city, Maj. Saad Haddad, the commander of the Israeli-supported Christian militia forces, suffered a heart attack.The 42-year-old commander was said to be doing ''satisfactorily.'' The shelling occurred on a day of growing violence between the Christian and the Moslem and Syrian sectors of Beirut. (A1:5.)

title: McDonnell Off 4.8%; TRW Is Up 14.8%
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation, a leading builder of fighter aircraft, announced yesterday that earnings in the first quarter fell 4.8 percent, to $41.3 million, or $1.03 a share, from $43.4 million, or $1.10 a share, in the first quarter of 1980. Sales advanced 14.8 percent, to $1.63 billion, from $1.42 billion in the 1980 period.

title: Supremacy at Sea The Race in the Indian Ocean Last of three articles.
description: The buildup of United States and Soviet naval forces in the Indian Ocean is causing growing concern among the 36 countries in the region.

title: NEWSPAPER TALKS PRESSED TO AVERT A POSSIBLE STRIKE
description: Negotiators for the newspaper unions and New York City's major newspapers pressed efforts yesterday to settle contract differences and avert a possible strike on Friday.

title: MUSIC: 20TH CENTURY GROUP OFFERS MOEVS PREMIERE
description: IN the last half century we have seen a remarkable outburst of sheer activity in Western music and yet we have also seen remarkably few new works accepted by the public during this period of melomania. This peculiar phenomenon, which no one has explained satisfactorily as yet, impelled Arthur Weisberg six years ago to found his Orchestra of the 20th Century, which is dedicated to the proposition that there exists a large body of important contemporary works that for one reason or another are ignored.

title: FIRST BOSTON'S MERGER MAKERS
description: They make an unlikely pair. Joseph R. Perella, age 39, tall, slender and dark, a son of immigrants, grew up in Newark, trained as an accountant, then entered investment banking at 30.

title: Windfall Bus Subsidy
description: To the Editor:

title: AGNEW PAID $172,000 IN 1974 ON UNREPORTED INCOME
description: A lawyer for Spiro T. Agnew said tonight that the former Vice President paid $172,000 in income taxes, penalties and interest to the Federal Government and the State of Maryland in 1974.

title: Entrepreneur for China
description: Howard S. MacAyeal, 50, has been appointed managing director of New China Investment Services, which packages the financial services required in developing industrial and commercial ventures involving the United States and China. Mr. MacA@yeal will be based at the New York office of the company, a unit of the China Trade Corporation that also has an office in Hong Kong.

title: Transit Chief Returns to Work
description: The State Transportation Commissioner, William C. Hennessy, returned to work today for the first time since he underwent surgery for a multiple heart bypass early last month. Mr. Hennessy suffered what doctors called a ''coronary insufficiency'' on Jan. 22 while in Governor Carey's New York City office. A spokesman for the Transportation Department said Mr. Hennessy planned to work two hours a day this week and would gradually increase the time.

title: TWO POETS: UNEASY FRIENDSHIP
description: THEY were an unlikely pair indeed: Ezra Pound, the flamboyant esthete, frequenting the salons of London and Paris and ministering to the talents of Eliot, Joyce and Yeats; and William Carlos Williams, the doctor, who ''never wanted to be separated from (his) fellow mortals by acting like an artist'' and who spent his life taking care of the sick in Rutherford, N.J. What they had in common, of course, was that they were two of America's finest poets, and together they remade the rules and rhythms of modern verse. Their friendship, which would survive literary quarrels and political feuds, was nurtured during their student days at the University of Pennsylvania, and on Saturday the school will celebrate the 75th anniversary of their graduation with a conference in their honor.

title: WANDERERS FIND SHELTER AND A NEW LIFE
description: A gray-bearded man with shaggy hair stood in a narrow hall, shifting slowly from foot to foot and moving his lips as if talking to himself. He was like the many homeless men in New York City who are avoided by the rest of the world, inhabiting doorways or dingy Bowery hotels. But the scene around this man was different.

title: MACHINISTS AT CANAVERAL RETURN TO WORK
description: More than 900 machinists returned to work at the Kennedy Space Center today, ending a two-month strike.

title: G.N.P. UP STRONGLY FOR FIRST QUARTER AT 6.5% YEARLY RATE
description: The nation's economy grew in the first quarter of 1981 at an annual rate of 6.5 percent, a figure that was higher than most economists had expected.

title: Carl S. Ell, 93, Educator Who Led Northeastern
description: Carl S. Ell, former president of Northeastern University, who played a key role in the development of the nation's largest private university, died Friday at Regency Hall Convalescent and Retirement Center, He was 93 years old.

title: Unbeaten Soviet Sextet Stops Czechoslovakia, 8-3
description: The Soviet Union defeated Czechoslovakia, 8-3, tonight in the world hockey championships and took a 3-point lead in the title playoff standing.

title: SUSAN B. ERNST
description: Susan Bloomingdale Ernst, the wife of Richard C. Ernst, chairman of Bloomingdale Properties, and the granddaughter of the founder of Bloomingdale's department store, died Sunday at her Connecticut home.

title: Priority Or Penalty?
description: As a House Judiciary subcommittee was completing its hearings on the future of the Legal Services Corporation, Representative Tom Railsback of Illinois asked its president, Dan Bradley, how he would ''prioritize'' its services if his budget were cut.

title: CHINA'S AIM IN ASIA: TO 'CONTAIN' SOVIET
description: China's view of Southeast Asia is dominated by implacable hostility to Vietnam's conquest of Cambodia and a conviction that the event was part of a Soviet quest to encircle China and threaten the rest of the world.

title: Norma Newman Cohen, a Leader In Group to Aid Vision-Impaired
description: Norma Newman Cohen, a leader in the national movement to help persons with impaired vision and co-founder and president of the Hollywood, Fla., chapter of Fight for Sight Inc., died yesterday at her home in Hollywood. She was 81 years old.

title: ROHATYN, 'GOING NATIONAL,' DOUBTS FREE-MARKET FUTURE
description: ''I believe in the free market,'' Felix Rohatyn said one morning, sitting in his apartment 12 floors above Park Avenue. ''But I do not believe in laissez-faire.''

title: THERE'S NO TURNING OFFICIAL BACKS ON RACISM IN JAILS
description: To the Editor:

title: CLASHES IN NORTHERN IRELAND WORSEN AS 51-DAY HUNGER STRIKE GOES ON
description: As an imprisoned Irish republican guerrilla began the 51st day of a hunger strike in Belfast, Roman Catholic youths in Londonderry today battled soldiers and the police with stones and bottles.

title: REAGAN CAN AFFIRM HIS SELF-HELP PHILOSOPHY
description: To the Editor:

title: VICTIMS SAY LIVES ECHO WITH GRIEF
description: The brief remarks of a mother whose daughter had been murdered eclipsed speeches by politicians and officials at a City Hall ceremony yesterday marking the opening of National Victim Rights Week.

title: Chess: Wilder's Big Boom Drops On Lein in Lone Pine Test
description: One may be rightly proud of the subtle exploitation of weak squares or double pawns or the relentless prosecution of a close ending, but nothing produces the thrill of the big boom, the mating combination that suddenly crashes through all obstacles. Nothing else gives such a feeling of unlimited power.

title: Pitman Potter, a Leader In International Studies
description: Pitman Benjamin Potter, an early leader in the study of international organization and a former dean of the Graduate School of American University in Washington, died Friday at his home in Washington. He was 89 years old.

title: Cuba Frees U.S. Sailors Seized During Boat Ride
description: Four American sailors were seized yesterday when they strayed into Cuban waters during a motorboat ride. The men, still carrying an ice chest full of beer, were released to United States officials at 3 P.M. today.

title: STUDENT AID THROUGH CY PRES
description: When asked what he did during the terror of the Revolution, the French intellectual Emmanuel Sieyes replied, ''I survived.'' The Reagan Administration's proposed cuts in the program guaranteeing student loans loom like the guillotine to those who run our colleges and universities, and survival has become an issue to them as well.

title: * To the Editor:$
description: The refusal by a New York City Criminal Court judge to sentence a convicted person to jail on the basis of the offender's ''... color and ethnic background'' is an affront to justice. Certainly, those unfortunates now incarcerated in city penal institutions may now view their punishment as the product of a racist and unfair criminal justice system. The motives of the sentencing judge may have been laudable, but the message he has conveyed to the community is dangerous. MICHAEL S. SACKHEIM New York, April 9, 1981

title: Beloit College Looks to the East for Eighth President
description: Beloit (Wis.) College seems to have found the formula for finding a new president - look in New York. Its latest choice is Roger H. Hull, the 38-year-old vice president for development and planning at Syracuse University.

title: U.S. ACCEPTS LIABILITY FOR THE SINKING OF JAPANESE SHIP
description: The Navy accepted liability today for the sinking of a Japanese merchant ship after a collision with a United States nuclear submarine.

title: CORRECTION
description: A chart on oil industry stocks in Busi- ness Day on Saturday gave incorrect percentage figures for performance changes. A corrected version appears on page D8.

title: CERONE OUT 6 WEEKS
description: Not long after the Yankees' spirits sagged with the news that Rick Cerone would be out for at least six weeks, a home run by Reggie Jackson in his first time at bat this season at Yankee Stadium lifted those spirits, and the Yankees, to a 6-2 victory last night over the Detroit Tigers.

title: Advertising;  Schering's Anti-Itch Campaign
description: THE Schering Corporation, one of the nation's leading pharmaceutical companies, will soon be running its first consumer advertising and will be doing it in behalf of a hydrocortisone anti-itch product, a booming new category.

title: UNCERTAINTY OVER REVENUE TIES UP $2.98 BILLION CONNECTICUT BUDGET
description: The Connecticut House of Representatives began debating a $2.98 billion spending plan this afternoon for fiscal 1981-82. But work on the revenue side of the budget has been delayed because the Democratic leadership of both houses and Gov. William A. O'Neill have been unable to agree on where the money will come from.

title: 10.36 RISE PUTS DOW AT 1,015.94
description: Amid signs that inflation might be easing, the Dow Jones industrial average climbed 10.36 points in a late rally yesterday, to finish at 1,015.94, the highest this year.

title: Blount in Venture To Build in Riyadh
description: Blount Inc., an international company involved in construction, agribusiness and specialty steel, said it and a French company, Enterprise Bouygues, had signed a contract with the Government of Saudi Arabia to build a $1.7 billion academic center at the University of Riyadh.

title: SMITHSONIAN'S NEW EXHIBITION EMBRACES JEFFERSON, THE SCIENTEST
description: By MALCOLM W. BROWNE WASHINGTON

title: NICARAGUAN JUNTA MEMBER SAYS ATTITUDE OF U.S. IS 'DISRESPECTFUL'
description: The attitude of the Reagan Administration has brought relations between Nicaragua and the United States to a ''very delicate'' point, Daniel Ortega Saavedra, a member of the Nicaraguan junta, said in Havana yesterday.

title: Poughkeepsie Skydiver Is Killed
description: A 25-year-old skydiver died last night after his parachute failed to open in a jump from 7,200 feet, according to the state police. The body of the skydiver, Paul Maguire of Poughkeepsie, was found shortly after 7 P.M. yesterday by children who heard him crash into the trees two miles southwest of the Stormville airport in Dutchess County, the troopers said.

title: Around the World; Earlier Mishap Is Revealed At Japanese Nuclear Plant
description: Investigators looking into leakage of a nuclear power plant's radioactive wastes discovered that another accident occurred last month at the same plant and was not reported, the Government said today.

title: Celtics, 76ers Renew Rivalry
description: The eighth Boston-Philadelphia playoff series in the last 17 seasons begins tonight at the Boston Garden. The circumstances are almost identical to last year, when Boston won 61 games and beat out the 76ers for the National Basketball Association's Atlantic Division title. The Celtics then eliminated Houston in four straight games and waited for the 76ers to beat Atlanta and set up a Boston-Philadelphia Eastern Conference final.
