title: MANY REPORTED HURT
description: Shells and rockets hit commercial and residential areas of the city today in the renewed fighting between Syrian and Christian forces.

title: RANCHER GETS 3 YEARS IN BEATINGS
description: A Federal judge today sentenced Patrick William Hanigan, a rancher convicted of robbing and beating three Mexican farm workers, to three concurrent three-year jail terms. The sentences were stayed pending appeal.

title: Mercury Outboards Lures Nonmotor Owners
description: With beautiful outdoor photography and the headline, ''The possible dream,'' Mercury Outboards is going to try to lure the economyshocked, nonmotor owners into becoming owners.

title: TEACHER PAY 'MORAL' ISSUE PRIEST ASSERTS
description: Rosemary Cella, who has a master's degree and has been teaching at St. Anthony of Padua School in Greenwich Village for 10 years, still makes under $12,000 a year, at least $3,000 less than her counterpart in a public school.

title: EGG HUNT SPONSOR SEES BANKRUPTCY THREATENING
description: The nonprofit sponsor of last Saturday's tumultuous egg hunt in Central Park reported last night that it was facing bankruptcy because of thefts that occurred during the melee.

title: The Police Blotter
description: A Transit Authority police officer was severely beaten on the head with his nightstick by a man he had awakened on an IND subway platform at the Second Avenue station on the F line. The officer, William Martin, 46 years old, was in critical condition at Bellevue Hospital with a fractured skull.

title: Jurors Absolve Kush In Harassment Suit
description: Citing ''a lack of sufficient evidence,'' a jury of six women and two men today found in favor of the defendants on all claims in the second phase of a $2.2 million damage suit against the former Arizona State University football coach Frank Kush and others.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It is not just the pain of losing a loved one.

title: Around the World; 33 Killed in El Salvador During Holiday Weekend
description: Thirty-three people were slain over the Easter weekend in El Salvador, authorities said today. A military spokesman said that Government troops killed five guerrillas in the war-torn province of Morazan today, but relatives said three of the men had only been returning from shopping in the market when they were killed.

title: Market Place; 2 REIT's Gain In Lease-Backs
description: IN the late 1960's, when long-term mortgage money was relatively dear, a number of shopping-center and garden-apartment developers welcomed the chance to sell and lease back land underlying their income-producing properties.

title: RAILROAD'S RECOVERY IN MICHIGAN IS LED BY POLITICAL SCIENTIST
description: Six years ago, Beth Andrus, fluent in Russian and Cantonese, was teaching political science at Lansing Community College and working on a doctorate at Michigan State University on the role of women in Soviet politics.

title: Around the Nation; U.S. and Florida in Accord On Integration of Colleges
description: The Reagan Administration today accepted a Florida plan to eliminate the vestiges of segregation in its public colleges, calling it a symbol of a new ''spirit of cooperation'' between state and Federal officials.

title: U. of Michigan Student Charged In Slaying of Two Other Students
description: A student at the University of Michigan was arraigned today on two counts of murder in connection with a dormitory shooting that left two students dead.

title: Federal Resources Chief
description: Joseph C. Bennett, the 48-year-old president of the Federal Resources Corporation, has been appointed to the additional post of chief executive officer, effective May 1, the beginning of the company's fiscal year. He will succeed Nels W. Stalheim, 69, who has headed Federal for 22 years and who will continue as chairman and chairman of the executive committee until he retires in 18 months.

title: Gerald F. J. Tyne, 81, an Engineer, Researcher and Museum Director
description: Gerald F. J. Tyne, an engineer who was a research associate of the Smithsonian Institution and the director of the New England Museum of Wireless and Steam in East Greenwich, R.I., died Saturday at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N.J. He was 81 years old and lived in Berkeley Heights, N.J.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Alcan Aluminum Ltd. said its Aluminum Co. of Canada unit and the government of Manitoba were studying the feasibility of building a $1 billion (U.S.), 200,000-ton-a-year aluminum smelter in that province.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: It was a week of embarrassing revelations and a downpour. Still, it was not without a few upbeat moments. Halston was in fine form. At his Olympic Tower retreat he was holding up one of his new sequin-and-bead-embroidered evening dresses and swaying in front of a mirror.

title: Arias Tennis Victor
description: Sixteen-year-old Jimmy Arias, a professional, won a $25,000 tennis tournament by beating Billy Martin in an all-American final today, 6-4, 4-6, 7-5.

title: ALBANY LEADER RULES OUT ANY STATE MEDICAID PLAN
description: State Senator Warren M. Anderson, whose disagreement with Governor Carey over how and when the state might assume the local costs of Medicaid has held up passage of a state budget for 20 days, hardened his position today. He rejected any Medicaid takeover as a plan ''the state can't afford.''

title: Addendum
description: * Fitzgerald Gardner Company has acquired Max Berking Advertising.

title: Japan Revises Steel Output
description: The Japan Iron and Steel Federation said today that it now expects Japan's crude steel output in the fiscal year 1981, which began this month, to total 103 million tons, down from the 105 million it estimated last December. This downward revision follows a slower-than-expected recovery in the domestic economy, it said. Export demand in the fiscal year 1981 is estimated at 33.4 million tons of crude steel, down about nine-tenths of 1 percent from the fiscal year 1980, while domestic demand will total 71 million tons, down about 5.3 percent, the federation said.

title: News Analysis
description: As an academic critic of the Carter Administration's approach to South Africa, Chester Crocker found a lot to criticize.

title: SCIENCE WATCH
description: The Dying Swans of Avon

title: Transactions;
description: BASEBALL

title: FIGURE IN WELLS FARGO CASE PLEADS NOT GUILTY TO A PASSPORT VIOLATION
description: Ross Fields, the boxing promoter who for years used the name Harold J. Smith, pleaded not guilty today to a passport violation charge. He was also given court permission to attend the burial of Joe Louis, the former heavyweight boxing champion, in Arlington, Va.

title: By Sports of The Times; Pawtucket's 32-Inning Game
description: BY the time the players left McCoy Stadium in Pawtucket from the baseball game that had begun at 8 o'clock the night before, the dawn of Easter Sunday was glowing across the Rhode Island sky.

title: EDUCATORS TELL OF TURN TOWARD PAROCHIAL SCHOOL
description: A mood of optimism prevailed as the National Catholic Education Association opened its 78th annual meeting in Manhattan yesterday amid predictions that church-related schools would attract even more students whose parents were frustrated with public education.

title: THE DOCTORS WORLD
description: WASHINGTON MEDICAL practice is full of surprises. But perhaps nothing can match that of being thrust into the role of saving the life of a President, and few doctor-patient relationships have the potential for creating more tension, even for the most disciplined surgeon.

title: SHEARSON, AMERICAN EXPRESS TIE
description: The American Express Company, confirming widely circulated reports, acknowledged yesterday that it was discussing the possibility of taking over Shearson Loeb Rhoades, the big Wall Street brokerage firm, in a transaction with an estimated value of $875 million.

title: MIRIAM HEMMENDINGER
description: Miriam Hemmendinger, a retired New Jersey probation officer, died Thursday at the Hunterdon Medical Center in Flemington, N.J. She was 66 years old and lived in Belvidere, N.J.

title: Accounts
description: * The Ladies' Home Journal to Grey Direct for subscription acquistion.

title: Group of Investors Bidding for Sun Ship
description: A group of Pennsylvania businessmen has offered to purchase for an undisclosed price the beleaguered Sun Ship Inc. of Chester, Pa., one of the prospective investors said yesterday.

title: Hospital Corp. to Buy INA Health Unit
description: The INA Corporation, reversing its strides into the health-care field, yesterday announced plans to sell its hospital unit, Hospital Affiliates International, for $650 million in cash and stock to the Hospital Corporation of America.

title: LAWYER DENIES ANY ROLE AS 'BAGMAN' TO WILLIAMS
description: A co-defendant in the Abscam bribery trial of Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. testified yesterday that he was not a ''bagman'' for the New Jersey Democrat and did not know of anybody who was.

title: Plugging the Student Loan Loopholes
description: Credit President Reagan with sicking his budget-cutters on the Federal college student aid program so cherished by his middleincome constituency. The program is plainly overgenerous; its price tag has jumped an alarming 150 percent in just three years.

title: Knight-Ridder Expands Profit
description: Knight-Ridder Newspapers Inc. said today that its first-quarter earnings rose to $20.6 million, or 64 cents a share, from $19.2 million, or 59 cents a share, in the comparable period of 1980. Successful cost-cutting was cited.

title: BLACK'S BODY FOUND IN AN ATLANTA RIVER
description: The badly decomposed body of a 23-year-old black man was discovered late this evening on a sand bar in the Chattahoochee River southwest of here.

title: BALANCING MIDEAST POLICY
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr.'s trip to the Middle East was a success in the sense that there were no major embarrassments - beyond public disagreement in Amman with the Prime Minister of Jordan over the key source of Middle East trouble: Mr. Haig's Soviet Union or Jordan's Israel - in a region traditionally accident-prone.

title: WEINBERGER PRODS NAVY LEADERS ON SUB COMMUNICATIONS SYSTEM
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger has overridden Navy reluctance to proceed with an experimental, but controversial, submarine communications system and has ordered the Navy to move ahead with caution.

title: Frank C. Love, 92, Former Head Of American Legion in New York
description: Frank C. Love, a lawyer who was a past New York State commander of the American Legion, died Friday at his home in Syracuse. He was 92 years old.

title: SAVING THE FAMILY FARMER, NOT THE ORANGES
description: To the Editor:

title: Swan Will Stay In the Rotation
description: Craig Swan said yesterday that he was feeling ordinary stiffness, but no soreness, in his right arm after a loss in his seasonal debut Sunday. He is expected to pitch in turn for the Mets on Friday or Saturday.

title: News Analysis
description: In hearings beginning this week, the subcommittee on security and terrorism of the Senate Judiciary Committee will seek to publicize theories that the Soviet Union supports and directs an integrated network of terrorist organizations and has shaped Western public opinion to its advantage through a large-scale ''disinformation'' campaign, according to a subcommittee official.

title: Giants Trade Ivie to Astros for Two Players
description: The San Francisco Giants traded Mike Ivie to the Houston Astros today for Dave Bergman, an infielderoutfielder, and Jeff Leonard, an outfielder.

title: STAGE: NISEI INTERMENT
description: IN Momoko Iko's moving new play, ''Flowers and Household Gods,'' a presentation of Tisa Chang's Pan Asian Repertory Theater at La Mama, we see a Japanese-American family over three generations indelibly influenced by the internment experience during World War II. That imprint is evident whether or not one was actually confined in a nisei camp. It distorts individual lives, deflects dreams, and it turns children against parents.

title: Woman, 29, Held in Alleged Plot To Free Convicted Jersey Slayer
description: A 29-year-old woman was held in $25,000 bail today for her part in an alleged plot to free Robert Reldan, a convicted murderer, from Trenton State Prison.

title: 9-1 DODGERS TURN BACK ASTROS
description: Steve Garvey drove in two runs and Dusty Baker had two hits and scored twice tonight as the Los Angeles Dodgers beat Houston, 5-2, their fourth victory in four games over the Astros this season.

title: EXCERPT'S FROM HAIG'S SPEECH ON HUMAN RIGHTS AND FOREIGN POLICY
description: Following are excerpts from a speech on human rights delivered by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. to the Trilateral Commission in Washington on March 31:

title: 96 IN SYRACUSE ARRESTED IN SALE OF STOLEN GOODS
description: The police today arrested 96 persons who allegedly sold more than $1 million in stolen goods, including machine guns, assault rifles and other weapons, to undercover officers who had posed as fences.

title: AMERICAN FALL COLLECTIONS OPEN
description: Bill Blass showed his familiar down-filled jackets with downfilled knickers. Stephen Burrows, who tapped some of the exuberance of the black experience in clothes when he began designing more than a decade ago, combined the rawness of ragged leather with the silky sophistication of cashmere and chiffon.

title: Texas Air Seeks Reorganization
description: Texas International Airlines, in an unusual move, petitioned the Civil Aeronautics Board today to approve an immediate reorganization so that it can obtain a measure of control over Continental Air Lines Inc.

title: Shelter Fire Kills One, Hurts 17
description: A fire attributed to arson roared through a the Kingsway Inn Shelter, a 101-room shelter for the homeless last night, killing one child and leaving 17 persons hospitalized. The dead child was as Christopher Henderson, believed to be 3 years old. The three-story building in North Broad Street was formerly the North Philadelphia station of the Reading Railroad.

title: Tibet Art Show in Newark
description: ''Tibet: A Lost World,'' a collection of more than 200 Tibetan works of art and other objects will be on view through January at the Newark Museum, 49 Washington Street, Newark.

title: 2 BLACK LIBERATION ARMY MEMBERS IDENTIFIED IN SHOOTING OF 2 OFFICERS
description: Two members of the Black Liberation Army, who were identified by their fingerprints and by five eyewitnesses, were named by the police last night as the prime suspects in last week's shooting of two officers in Queens.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, APRIL 21, 1981
description: International Opposition to human rights violations by the United States was endorsed by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. In an address in Washington before the Trilateral Commission, a private group, he said that the United States should oppose all human rights violations ''by ally or adversary, friend or foe,'' but be more critical of ''totalitarian'' governments than of ''authoritarian'' ones. Mr. Haig's aides said the Administration's human rights policy was still being reviewed. They said the Secretary's speech was authoritiative but was not necessarily the final word. (Page A1, Column 1.) Much of Beirut was under fire as fighting between Syrian and Christian forces intensified. Beirut's international airport was closed after a runway was shelled. Several people were killed, and hospitals on both sides of the Green Line dividing the city into Moslem and Christian zones reported many people wounded. (A1:3.)

title: Around the World; Three Are Named to Posts In New Zimbabwe Party
description: Andre Holland, a white farmer who was Rhodesia's Deputy Minister of Information before black majority rule here, today appointed three followers to leadership posts in his new party for liberal whites.

title: AUTO BILL TROUBLES JAPAN
description: One of Japan's top trade officials warned in an interview today that passage of a bill to restrict Japanese auto exports to the United States could lead to protectionist retaliation and said the Japanese were working to curb exports.

title: Oil Revenue Up 14% in Kuwait
description: Kuwait's revenue from crude oil exports reached $20.8 billion in 1980, a 14 percent increase over 1979, the Kuwait Chamber of Commerce and Industry said in its annual report released today.

title: Around the Nation; Coal Owners Say Proposal Of Miners Is 'Unrealistic'
description: The policy steering committee of top executives of the major coal companies in the East and Middle West today described the United Mine Workers' latest proposal to end the 25-day-old miners' strike as ''completely unrealistic.''

title: Florida Hit by Power Blackouts
description: More than 425,000 utility customers in Florida were without electricity for about half an hour today because of failures at three large generating plants in the Tampa Bay and Manatee County areas.

title: UNION SHARING OF LIABILITY IN JOB BIAS SUITS IS BARRED
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that a union could not be forced to share an employer's financial liability for illegal employment discrimination.

title: REAGAN ORDERS FREEZE ON PUBLICATIONS
description: President Reagan, asserting that the Federal Government was spending too much on publicity and advertising, imposed a moratorium today on the production or procurement of all new films, pamphlets, brochures and other audiovisual aids and publications by the executive branch.

title: Melanie Wilkes a Role Model for Miss de Havilland
description: For Olivia de Havilland, the shy and kindly Melanie Hamilton Wilkes in ''Gone With the Wind'' was ''the woman I wanted to be, the woman I was not, the woman I would like to be,'' the actress says in an unpublished brief memoir of her role.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard CORSAIR. The Life of J. Pierpont Morgan. By Andrew Sinclair. 269 pages. Illus- trated. Little, Brown. $15.

title: White Plains Gets Minority Hiring Plan
description: The Federal Government and this city agreed on a plan under which the city will ''use its best efforts'' to increase the proportion of blacks, Hispanic persons and women on its 190-member police force.

title: The U.N. Today; April 21, 1981; ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M.

title: Bridge: Deal Is Called 'Elementary'; But It's Really a Bit Difficult
description: In one respect, authors of bridge books have an advantage over columnnists: They can show the reader 13 or 26 cards instead of 52 if they choose. In the diagramed deal the reader should be looking at the North and East hands, studying the defensive problem for East in three no-trump.

title: JOINING THE COSMETICS LEGENDS
description: The cosmetics industry loves its legends about business successes that started on next to nothing. Helena Rubinstein left Poland to sell a beauty cream to the sun-parched women of Australia. Elizabeth Arden came to New York from Canada to mix up concoctions in the back of a small one-room salon, while Estee Lauder made the rounds of charity balls with samples of Youth Dew in her handbag. It is no wonder then that a young woman looking for the pot of gold at the end of the business rainbow thinks it is to be found in a cosmetics jar.

title: Arvin Names Officer To Post of President
description: James K. Baker, 49 years old, has been named president and chief operating officer of Arvin Industries, a diversified manufacturer of automotive parts and consumer goods. As president, he succeeds Eugene I. Anderson, 63, who continues as chairman and chief executive officer of the Columbus, Ind., company.

title: BELL BOND YIELDS RECORD 15.25%
description: A new triple-A-rated Bell Telephone bond issue came to market yesterday at a record yield of 15.25 percent, and short-term interest rates failed to rise as much as some analysts expected.

title: EDUCATION
description: TWO centuries ago in France it would have cost them their heads, but last week, safe in their history classroom at the Chapin School on the Upper East Side, a group of eighth-graders felt free to challenge Robespierre's explanation for the reign of terror, criticizing the reasoning of the revolutionary leader.

title: A Conrail Generator Resumes Operation
description: One of Conrail's electric generators in Cos Cob, Conn., resumed operating for the morning rush hour, after having been out of service since early this month, United Press International reported.

title: SENATE TO MOVE ON STATE DEPT. NOMINATIONS
description: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee will begin confirmation hearings tomorrow on a number of key State Department appointments that have been delayed by political opposition from Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina.

title: RANGERS AND ISLANDERS TRIUMPH, TAKE 3-1 SERIES LEAD
description: Ken Morrow banked a 50-foot shot off an opponent's skate for an overtime goal tonight that gave the New York Islanders a 5-4 victory over the Edmonton Oilers at Northlands Coliseum.

To the Editor:

title: Sindona Convicted Of Jumping Bail
description: Michele Sindona, an Italian financier convicted of fraud involving the collapse of the Franklin National Bank, was convicted yesterday of jumping bail to avoid his bank-fraud trial.

title: LOS ANGELES BUSING ENDS AFTER 3 YEARS
description: A three-year-old program of mandatory busing in the Los Angeles Unified School District ended quietly today, with about two-thirds of the children continuing to ride to schools outside their neighborhoods.

title: JUSTICES SAY CLOSING OFF STREET IS NOT A VIOLATION OF CIVIL RIGHTS
description: The closing of a street through a white area in Memphis did not violate the civil rights of the black residents of an adjoining neighborhood, the Supreme Court ruled today, though the action required the blacks to detour around the all-white subdivision.

title: SACRED SERBIAN SITE DAMAGED BY BLAZE
description: Before daybreak on March 16, the Patriarchate of Pec, which had survived invasion and occupation by the Ottoman Turks, was heavily damaged by fire.

title: MICROWAVES: ARE THEY A PERIL?
description: When Samuel Yannon, a Staten Island telephone technician, died seven years ago, pneumonia was listed as the principal cause of death.

title: AS JOHN L. LEWIS SAID: 'YOU CAN'T MINE COAL WITH BAYONETS'
description: Here in the mountains of southern West Virginia, men and women work every day gouging coal from seams often no more than three feet thick. Miles from the portal, and 400 feet below the surface, many must also crawl around in mud and water. Breathing coal dust for 20 or 30 years slowly, but inexorably, strangles miners: Their hardened lung tissue no longer transfers enough oxygen into the blood. Living this life develops the feeling inside a person that he should be permitted control over what he does. Miners harbor a strong sense of moral right, transcending legal rights that legislatures and courts choose to grant them. This deep-rooted sense is again generating confrontations, sometimes violent, during this year's United Mine Workers strike.

title: Topics; ANIMAL, VEGETABLE PANDARING, PART III; Pandaring, Part III
description: Ling-Ling has been left waiting at the church again. Chia-Chia, who as we once observed radiates virility, is revealed to lack finesse, and will be shipped home to the London Zoo.

title: Around the Nation; Boston Council Approves Plan to Save City Schools
description: The Boston City Council, facing a court deadline to bail out the city's public schools, today approved a $75 million borrowing plan that members hoped would keep classes open after spring vacation.

title: Four Major Banks Lift Prime to 17 1/2%
description: Four of the nation's largest banks, including the No.1 Bank of America, raised their prime lending rates yesterday to 17 1/2 percent from 17 percent.

title: Seko of Japan Captures Boston Marathon
description: Helped by ideal weather, a brisk early pace and competitive challenge, Toshihiko Seko of Japan won the 85th annual Boston Marathon today with the fastest time ever run in the United States, 2 hours 9 minutes 26 seconds.

title: FLAMES WIN
description: Craig Ramsay scored on a rebound with 3 minutes 28 seconds left in overtime tonight, lifting Buffalo to a 5-4 triumph over Minnesota and keeping the Sabres alive in the National Hockey League playoffs.

title: HEAD OF SECURITIES AGENCY INQUIRIES REPORTED CHOSEN AS C.I.A. COUNSEL
description: Stanley Sporkin, who has directed investigations of corporate dishonesty for the last seven years, has been appointed general counsel of the Central Intelligence Agency, according to Reagan Administration officials.

title: Around the Nation; Judge Sets Minimum Space For Texas Prison Inmates
description: A Federal judge issued a final decree today in a nine-year-old prison reform suit, ordering the Texas Department of Corrections to provide single cells or at least 60 square feet of space for each inmate by August 1983.

title: China Wins Table Tennis
description: China completed a team double at the 36th world table tennis championships tonight as the men defeated the defender, Hungary, 5-2, and the women downed South Korea, 3-0, for their fourth consecutive title.

title: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: ALONGTIME teacher of mathematics defines the purpose of mathematics as doing efficiently what it would be impossible or very laborious to do without mathematics. For example, to find the number of seats in an auditorium with rows A to T and each aisle numbered from 1 to 68, without the laborious and unreliable process of counting them, you multiply 68 by 20. This practical, time-saving response to a real situation is likely to make sense to real children.

title: Article 093013 -- No Title
description: A set of cuff links valued at $50,000 was reported stolen Saturday from the home of Federal District Judge Edward Northrop. The cuff links include a gold chain and a bar trimmed with diamonds.

title: McDonnell Douglas Studies 150-Seat Jet
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation is considering developing a new 150-seat airliner, the company's chairman, Sanford McDonnell, told the annual meeting.

title: Borg-Warner Seeks Ruling From F.T.C.
description: The Borg-Warner Corporation said it had asked the Federal Trade Commission for an advisory opinion on whether its proposed acquisition of 4.5 million common shares, or about 22 percent, of the Echlin Manufacturing Company is covered by the F.T.C.'s 1975 consent order with Borg-Warner. Under the offer, Borg-Warner would transfer its automotive after-market division to Echlin.

title: Fluor Unit's Gas Contract
description: The Abu Dhabi National Oil Company said today that it had awarded a consultancy contract for a natural gas processing plant to the Fluor Mideast Company Ltd., a British subsidiary of the Fluor Corporation. Sources said the contract was worth about $20 million. The contract covers design and supervision of the plant.

title: STRIKING WRITERS DRAFT NEW PROPOSAL
description: Motion picture and television producers will be bargaining with two Hollywood unions this week. Negotiations begin tomorrow with the Directors Guild of America, whose contract is up June 30. On Wednesday, the Writers Guild of America, which went on strike April 11, will resume negotiations, offering a new proposal on the central issue of payment for original programming for pay television, the issue that caused a three-month actors strike last summer.

title: Stock Swap Aids Goodrich
description: The B.F. Goodrich Company, helped by an extraordinary gain of $18 million from the tax-free exchange of a new series of convertible preferred stock for certain of the company's debentures, today reported a first-quarter net income of $26.3 million, or $1.41 a share, up from $20.3 million and $1.20 a share a year earlier. The diversified manfacturer of plastics, chemicals and tires said its sales for the latest quarter rose to $780.4 million from $767.5 million a year earlier. Without the gain from the securities transaction, Goodrich would have earned $8.3 million, or 43 cents a share, in the first quarter this year, the company said.

title: Migliore Starts Riding Career at the Top
description: The leading rider at Aqueduct is chauffeured to work each morning by his father. The jockey, Richard Migliore, qualified for a driver's license when he turned 17 March 14, but he has been too busy riding horses to take a road test.

title: The Awacs Won't Fly
description: If those Airborne Warning and Control System planes the Administration promised to sell to Saudi Arabia were now flown over Capitol Hill, they would send back a very clear message: Cancel this mission.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Why is it that repeated contact with an allergen sometimes gives rise to increased sensitivity, yet at other times has the opposite effect?

title: Around the World; Palestine Group Blames U.S.  And Israel for Terrorism
description: The Palestinian National Council has condemned terrorism and said it regarded the United States and Israel as those chiefly to blame.

title: Grumman Confirms Flxible Bus Delay
description: The Grumman Corporation acknowledged that New York City's Flxible bus fleet, which was ordered off the streets last December by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to undergo company repairs on their undercarriages, might not be returned to the city until late next month. This would be more than a month beyond the original target date of mid-April.

title: Tony Randall to Be Star Of a New NBC-TV Series
description: Tony Randall will portray an advertising artist who is homosexual in a new television series to be produced in New York, NBC-TV announced yesterday.

title: SMITH CASTS DOUBT ON PROSECUTOR LAW
description: Attorney General William French Smith has expressed ''serious reservations concerning the constitutionality'' of a 1978 law that provides for the appointment of a special prosecutor to investigate criminal allegations against high-ranking Federal officials.

title: Bache Tender Ends
description: The Prudential Insurance Company of America said it had received about 70 percent of the outstanding shares and warrants of the Bache Group Inc. under its expired tender offer.

title: RANGERS AND IUSLANDERS TRIUMPH, TAKE 3-1 LEADS
description: The Rangers took a 3-1 lead in their four-of-seven-game quarterfinal series with St. Louis last night, defeating the Blues, 4-1, at Madison Square Garden.

title: AS 75 MILLION TOSS AND TURN, STUDIES PURSUE SECRET OF SLEEP
description: EVERY night, millions of Americans settle themselves into bed for the sleep they feel they desperately need but they know will not come. Instead, they toss and turn and fret on their way to a bleary rising the next day.

title: Fewer Cattle In Feed Lots
description: Cattle being fed for the slaughter market as of April 1 totaled 9.76 million head, down 4 percent from a year before and 12 percent less than two years before, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Around the Nation; Teachers in Youngstown Ratify 12.5% Wage Pact
description: Striking teachers overwhelmingly ratified a new contract today, gaining a 12.5 percent wage increase over two years to end a walkout that lasted 36 school days.

title: Burlington Rail Net Rose 17.8%
description: Burlington Northern Inc., which merged last November with the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway Company to form the nation's longest rail system, reported yesterday that net income in the first quarter of 1981 rose 17.8 percent, to $90 million, or $2.33 a share, from $76.4 million, or $2.35 a share, in the first quarter of 1980.

title: REPUTATION FOR OPENNESS
description: The appointment of Stanley Sporkin to the post of general counsel of the Central Intelligence Agency may bring dismay to some in the intelligence field, but it is sure to evoke broad sighs of relief in many corporate boardrooms.

title: Topics; ANIMAL, VEGETABLE CHEERY ALIEN; Cheery Alien
description: If you park your car under a Norway maple tree now in maple-blossom time, the whole body and windshield will be spotted with sticky yellow pollen. When the winged seeds float to the edges of the lawn, you will have maple thickets where you don't want them.

title: A's 3, Twins 0
description: Matt Keough continued a streak of superior Oakland pitching with a five-hitter. The victory was the A's 12th in 13 games this season. They set a major league record for starting the season by winning their first 11.

title: HAIG FAVORS STAND AGAINST VIOLATIONS OF RIGHTS ABROAD
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. has said that the United States should oppose human rights violations ''by ally or adversary.'' But, he said, it should be more critical of ''totalitarian'' regimes than of ''authoritarian'' ones.

title: THE REGION
description: Governor Byrne announced his nomination of Daniel J. O'Hern, his chief counsel, to the New Jersey Supreme Court. In making the announcement, Mr. Byrne acknowledged he had been under pressure in recent months from ethnic groups seeking to promote a nominee and from various organizations interested in seeing a woman or a black named to succeed Justice Mark A. Sullivan, who is scheduled to retire on Aug. 11.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: CHARACTER BUILDING

title: King Reneged on Accord, Brenner Charges at Trial
description: In a pre-trial deposition read in court yesterday, the boxing promoter Teddy Brenner said that he and Don King had worked out their title fight promotional problems involving Alexis Arguello, the super-featherweight champion, but that King had later reneged on the arrangement.

title: Talking Business with Nesbit of Korn/Ferry Personnel Chief Has New Role
description: Business is seeking the ''superstar'' more than ever as a result of a tighter economy and increased competition. And, in the process, corporations are setting new criteria and priorities for the personnel officer. So important has this executive become that many companies now view him as a star in his own right, courting him and paying him accordingly.

title: TV: SERGEANT CRIBB OF SCOTLAND YARD
description: BEGINNING tonight at 9 on WNET-TV, Channel 13, the last five episodes of this season's ''Mystery!'' series on public television will be turned over to ''Sergeant Cribb,'' a detective assigned to the new Criminal Investigation Department of a Victorian-era Scotland Yard. Working without a gun in age still lacking the tools of forensic medicine, Cribb is a model of patience, painstaking investigation and sly wit. He is as British and Victorian as his bowler hat.

title: 20 PEOPLE ARE INJURED
description: Black youths hurled rocks at the police tonight during a fair in a northern London suburb, and another fair in western London was closed after about 300 blacks ''ran amok,'' the police reported.

title: SUMMATIONS OFFER JURY DISPARATE VIEWS OF MARGIOTTA
description: Summing up his case against Joseph M. Margiotta, the Nassau County Republican chairman, a Federal prosecutor declared today that the Government had proved ''what happens when government is run by the sale of office to the highest bidder.''

title: TUESDAY, APRIL 21, 1981; The Economy
description: The U.S. gross national product rose at a brisk 6.5 percent annual rate in the first quarter, a surprisingly strong advance and the biggest since 1978's second quarter. G.N.P. statistics also indicated that inflation was easing. But Administration officials asserted that despite G.N.P. first quarter growth, the economy is now weakening, and therefore Congress should approve the Administration's program for tax cuts to stimulate growth. (Page A1.)

title: Busch Ready to Test Budweiser Light
description: Anheuser-Busch Inc. said it will begin test-marketing a new brand of beer, Budweiser Light, in select metropolitan areas next week.

title: MIRO JOINS A PICASSO AT OUTDOOR ART PLAZA IN CHICAGO
description: Joan Miro's ''Chicago'' was unveiled here today, but it wasn't easy. In its own inimitable fashion, the Windy City almost gave the lie to the prouder expression of its personality, the boast that it is the City That Works.

title: The Loose Garbage Truck Deal
description: New York's Sanitation Department finds that it is not getting 12 1/2 tons of garbage into the new larger Mack trucks it bought in the hope of making fewer, heavier trips around town. The sanitation men appear to have been taken - to the cleaners, shall we say - in the same way the M.T.A was taken with its Flxible buses and R-46 subway cars. But the full facts are not yet known.

title: U.S. STATES TO WITHDRAW ALL SUPPORT FOR SOCIAL RESEARCH
description: Under pressure from the Reagan Administration, Federal agencies have begun to to weed out or drastically scale down their support for basic research in economics, sociology, psychology and the other social and behavioral sciences.

title: Insects on a Treadmill
description: By running roaches on a treadmill, three scientists at the State University of New York at Buffalo have performed what they believe is the first quantitative study of energy consumption and efficiency in a running insect, and only the second such study of an invertebrate of any kind. (The first examined the energy budget of a big land crab.)

title: JUSTICES RESTRICT A 'BILL OF RIGHTS' FOR THE RETARDED
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that a Federal ''bill of rights'' for the mentally retarded, enacted six years ago, did not oblige the states to provide any particular level of care or training for retarded people in state institutions.

title: High Court Refuses to Hear Case on $1.95 Gas Charge
description: During the gasoline shortage in the summer of 1979, Frank Makara was forced to pay $7 for $5.05 worth of gas. The extra charge was levied because there wasn't room in his tank for enough gas to meet the $7 minimum purchase regulation imposed by New York State to discourage motorists from topping off their tanks.

title: UNION CARBIDE DROPS BY 59.3%
description: Du Pont, the nation's leading chemical company, reported yesterday that net income in the first quarter of 1981 dropped 15.9 percent on a sales increase of 2.2 percent.

title: Topics; ANIMAL, VEGETABLE EXPLOITAION; Exploitation
description: A society already alert to the risks to animals obviously needs to extend its surveillance.

title: New Rochelle Teacher Gains National Honor
description: The National Teacher of the Year is Jay Sommer, a 53-year-old faculty member at New Rochelle (N.Y.) High School who speaks 10 languages fluently and passes on his expertise to his students.

title: People
description: * John F. Kelly, former manager of corporate relations at Merrill Lynch & Company, appointed Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for Public Liaison and Consumer Affairs. * William Wurtzel named to board of Hicks & Greist.

title: Sabit A. Orudzhev, 68, Minister Of Gas Industry in Soviet Union
description: Sabit A. Orudzhev, Soviet Minister of the Gas Industry, died today after a serious illness, the official press agency Tass reported.

title: Wranglers Win W.B.L. Title
description: The Nebraska Wranglers, led by Rosie Walker's 39 points, beat the Dallas Diamonds, 99-90, tonight and captured the Women's Professional Basketball League championship.

title: 2d, 4th Horses in Wood Passing Up the Derby
description: The trainers of Highland Blade and Noble Nashua said yesterday that they would not send their colts to the Kentucky Derby. David Whiteley, who saddles Highland Blade, said, ''I can't see any sense in shipping him to Louisville and finding he can't race because of the earnings duel.''

title: BALLET THEATER: GALA BENEFIT IS OPENER
description: THE kind of opening night American Ballet Theater offered Monday at the Metropolitan Opera House may not have been what its regular audience expected, but it pointed in the right direction.

title: CITY OPERA: 'MAKROPOULOS AFFAIR' FOCUSES ON INDIVIDUAL CHARACTER
description: The City Opera has been doing proudly by Leos Janacek this spring. A few weeks ago the company unveiled an enchanting new production of ''The Cunning Little Vixen,'' and on Sunday night an earlier Janacek success, ''The Makropoulos Affair,'' returned to the repertory in a stunning performance.

title: Sol Rafel, 66, Executive Director Of Jewish Center in Bronx, Dead
description: Sol Rafel, executive director of Bronx House, the largest Jewish community center in the borough, died yesterday of cancer at Montefiore Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived in Yonkers.

title: GEORGIE W. RATHBORNE
description: Georgie Winship Rathborne, a specialist in early American antiques, died Saturday at her home in Westbury, L.I. She was 97 years old and the widow of J. Cornelius Rathborne, a lumber company executive.

title: UNION CAMP UP SLIGHTLY
description: The Boise Cascade Corporation, a leading producer of paper items and building materials, yesterday reported a 12.4 percent drop in net income for this year's first quarter.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Burroughs Corporation, the office equipment manufacturer, has appointed William P. Conlin senior vice president in charge of corporate product managment.

title: U.S.-Japanese Coal Talks Set
description: Japanese coal importers and United States suppliers will hold their second set of annual talks in mid-July in California to pave the way for increasing exports to Japan. The announcement was made today by the Nippon Steel Corporation, which represents the Japanese side.

title: Tomjanovich and Lakers Reach Agreement on Suit
description: The Los Angeles Lakers' parent company has agreed to a settlement paying Rudy Tomjanovich of the Houston Rockets an undisclosed sum for a 1977 incident in which the player was punched, an attorney said today.

title: PROMPT GRAIN PRICE RISE SEEN IF SOVIET CURB SUDDENLY ENDS
description: If the curtailment of grain sales to the Soviet Union were suddenly ended, as it might be if the Russians showed they would not intervene in Poland, prices for American wheat, corn and soybeans would rise immediately, grain market analysts believe.

title: The Sporting News Seeks Agency Notice
description: Imagine a publication that frequently carries ads for DeBeers diamonds at the same time it probably carries more classified ads for baseball cards than any other publication. What would you make of that?

title: POLITICAL ALTERNATIVES IN LATIN AMERICA
description: To the Editor:

title: 3-M'S DISK DRIVES
description: The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company said its data recording products division, which has been a supplier of computer tapes and software, had entered the computer hardware business. It said it was producing three compact disk drives with storage capacities of 10, 20 and 60 megabytes, priced between $1,700 and $3,800, and available immediately.The company said it planned to continue developing magnetic recording devices and systems that would "bring about further advanced hardware products, at intervals, for a number of years."

title: Lillie Mauser, 101, an Ex-Sheriff; Grandmother of Senator Baker
description: Lillie Ladd Mauser, grandmother of the Senate majority leader, Howard H. Baker Jr., and the first woman to be elected sheriff in Tennessee, died early today at Blount Memorial Hospital. She was 101 years old and lived in Maryville.

title: POLLS ARE INDEED A FEDERAL SOCIAL SCIENCE
description: To the Editor:

title: Paine Webber Has Profitable Quarter
description: Paine Webber Inc. yesterday reported earnings of $5.8 million, or 67 cents a share, for its second fiscal quarter, compared with a loss of $10.2 million in the same quarter the year before. Revenues for the quarter totaled $253.9 million, up from $248.5 million for the second quarter of 1980.

title: TESTIMONY OF A HYPNOTIZED DANCER IS PERMITTED INTO MET MURDER TRIAL
description: The testimony of a ballerina who was hypnotized to aid her memory was ruled admissible yesterday in the murder trial of a Metropolitan Opera House stagehand.

title: Grolsch Lager Beer In 9-Market Promotion
description: Grolsch lager beer, the new Dutch brew on the American scene, will begin to get advertising promotion on May 18 when the Warwick, Welsh & Miller 30-second and 10-second TV commercials begin airing in nine major markets.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * B.F. Goodrich said its directors had approved a management recommendation to extend the expiration date of warrants to purchase common stock to Aug. 31, 1981.

title: SHOOTINGS BY POLICE ROIL NEW ORLEANS
description: A series of police shootings of blacks here in the last six months has raised fears among the authorities that the already weak rapport between blacks and the police may deteriorate even further.

title: BUDGET ROLE LIFTS DOMENICI TO HERO STATUS BACK HOME
description: Gov. Bruce King, a Democrat, says, ''We're very proud of him.'' Mayor David Rusk, another Democrat, says, ''It's great to see the role being given a senator from New Mexico.'' Del Lovato, chairman of the Council of Pueblo Tribes, calls him ''one of the most respected and well-liked senators that I've ever seen,'' and Neal Gonzalez, secretary-treasurer of the state American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, says, ''His stature has been enhanced.''

title: Addendum
description: * Money magazine will increase its circulation rate base 3 percent, to 875,000, from 850,000, effective with the July issue. Advertising rates will also increase 3 percent.

title: PORTUGUESE IN MACAO UNCERTAIN WHO REALLY GOVERNS THE COLONY
description: The gently peeling pastel walls of the 17th- and 18th-century houses and churches of Portugal's last remaining colony symbolize the waning of European control over this small piece of China across the Canton River estuary from Hong Kong.

title: U.S. EXPLORES USE OF SPACE LASERS TO COMMUNICATE WITH SUBMARINES
description: The use of laser beams from space to communicate with submerged submarines is being explored in a joint program of the Navy and the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency.

title: WILLIAM MARX
description: William Marx, a partner in the real-estate and development concern of Punia & Marx Inc., died yesterday at Brookdale Hospital in Brooklyn.

title: Richard Says Astros' Slump Dims Comeback
description: J.R. Richard, who nearly lost his life when he suffered a stroke last July 30, says his comeback attempt may be overshadowed by the Astros' early season slump.

title: MORROW: UNLIKELY ISLANDER HERO
description: Ken Morrow had scored only two goals in his role as a defensive defenseman this season, so when Monday night's National Hockey League playoff game at Edmonton went into overtime, Morrow was not considered a threat to score.

title: INTERSET RATES ADVANCE SLIGHTLY
description: Short- and long-term interest rates increased modestly yesterday on relatively light trading volume. Dealers explained that record or near-record yields for long-term bonds still attracted modest institutional buying, though the greatest buying demand was for notes due in less than five years or for money market securities due in less than a year.

title: Iraq Gets Kuwait Loan
description: Kuwait granted an interest-free loan of $2 billion to Iraq today to help finance reconstruction of areas destroyed in that country's war with Iran. The loan will be repaid over a 10-year period without interest, Kuwaiti officials said. Kuwaiti press reports said that other Gulf Arab states were considering loans for Iraq, which has been engaged in a war with Iran since last Sept. 22.

title: AIDE CALLS SEX HARASSMENT CASES 'TIP OF THE ICEBERG'
description: The head of the Equal Employment Opportunities Commission said today that sexual harassment on the job might be more frequent than his agency knows.

title: U.S. AIDES CLEARED IN BILLY CARTER CASE
description: An internal Justice Department report on the handling of the Billy Carter case has concluded that no Government official violated the law in the department's investigation of Mr. Carter's relationship with Libya.

title: New Owners Proposed For Three Mile Island
description: A New York City management consulting firm has recommended that the New Jersey Board of Public Utilities consider creating a government authority that would acquire and operate the two nuclear power plants at Three Mile Island, including the reactor that was damaged more than two years ago.

title: ANTIPATHETIC SETTLERS
description: To the Editor:

title: AT ARLINGTON, FINAL TRIBUTE TO AN AMERICAN FIGHTER
description: Joe Louis, the sharecropper's son with the knockout punch, was buried in Arlington National Cemetery today, cherished in farewells at the grave and remembrances on the street corners as the ultimate champion who smashed the myth of racial supremacy.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: IT seems to me that one of the great lacks in American cooking is a dictionary or encyclopedia that catalogues in a protracted and definitive sense the foods of this nation. There are several volumes that pretend to do so, but there are dozens, if not hundreds, of gaps in each of them. There is clearly no volume in this country that has done for the nation's kitchens what Larousse Gastronomique has done for the French.

title: NO-SHOW ON INCREASE AT BETTER RESTAURANTS
description: FOR those who dine in better restaurants, the problem is getting a reservation. But the people who run the good restaurants say that is nothing compared with their problem: People who make reservations and then, without bothering to cancel, do not show up.

title: Wine Talk
description: THE bottle was old-fashioned Bordeaux, the kind with heavy glass, slightly tapered sides and high shoulders that went out of style in the mid-1960's when shipping costs mandated lighter weights. The label said Chateau Duhart-Milon 1959, but it was the narrow sticker on the back that attracted my attention.

title: SAFETY AGENCY LISTS PAST VIOLATIONS AT COLORADO MIBE WHERE 15 DIED
description: The Dutch Creek No. 1 mine near Redstone, Colo., where 15 miners died in an explosion last week, has been cited for 1,133 health and safety violations in the last five years, the Federal Mine Safety and Health Administration said today.

title: Police in India Kill 13 Tribesmen As Angry Crowd Won't Disperse
description: The police in southern India opened fire on a mob of tribesmen last night, killing 13 people and injuring dozens of others, officials reported today.

title: 11 DIE AS SOUTH LEBANON FIGHTING WORSENS
description: Fighting between Israeli-backed Christian forces and Palestinian guerrillas in southern Lebanon intensified today, and the Lebanese authorities reported that at least 11 people were killed and 40 wounded.

title: Ailing Whale Active At Boat Basin on L.I.
description: Buffeted by high winds, a rare sperm whale spent a ''bouncy'' and active night in the Robert Moses State Park boat basin, which has become its sick bay, marine scientists said.

title: CBS-TV FINISHES FIRST IN SEASON'S RATINGS
description: TV, buoyed by the extraordinary success of ''Dallas'' and ''The Dukes of Hazzard'' and the failure of the two rival networks to produce any comparable hits, finished first in the season's primetime audience-popularity ratings race that ended Sunday.

title: U.N. OPENS CRUCIAL DEBATE ON NAMIBIA
description: The Security Council began a debate today over independence for Namibia, a move that threatens to widen the rift between the Reagan Administration and black Africa.

title: Who Should Bell A.T.& T.?
description: Would the Reagan Administration pursue the Government's seven-yearold antitrust suit against Ma Bell? the reporters asked. The new chief of the Justice Department's Antitrust Division, William Baxter, did not hesitate: ''I intend to litigate it to the eyeballs.''

title: Goldwater of California to Seek Nomination for Hayakawa's Seat
description: Representative Barry M. Goldwater Jr, today announced his candidacy for the Republican nomination to the United States Senate for the seat held by S.I. Hayakawa.

title: Citibank's Prime Joins Rise to 17 1/2%
description: Citibank, the nation's second-largest commercial bank, raised its prime rate yesterday by one-half percentage point, joining other major banks that lifted theirs to 17 1/2 percent on Monday.

title: American Express to Buy Shearson as Takeovers Transform Wall St.
description: The American Express Company will acquire Shearson Loeb Rhoades, Wall Street's second-largest brokerage firm, for about $915 million in stock, the two companies announced yesterday.

title: Irving Gilman, 65, Dies; Headed Research Group
description: Irving Gilman, president of the Analytical Research Institute in Peekskill, N.Y., and Toronto, died yesterday of cancer in Phelps Memorial Hospital in Tarrytown, N.Y. He was 65 years old and lived in Montrose, N.Y.

title: POLL FINDS MANY YOUNG CATHOLICS WHO OPPOSE DOGMA ATTEND MASS
description: While young Roman Catholics have rejected the church as a moral teacher, about 41 percent attend mass at least twice a month, feel close to God and pray quite often, according to a report delivered at a convention of the National Catholic Education Association in New York City yesterday.

title: Around the World; Japan Recovers Bodies of 2 Lost in Submarine Collision
description: The bodies of two Japanese seamen missing since their vessel was struck and sunk by a United States nuclear submarine 12 days ago were recovered today, authorities said.

title: Harness Driver Is Killed In Spill at Illinois Track
description: A harness driver was killed and another injured in a multi-horse pileup during a spill in the seventh race at Maywood Park last night.

title: S.E.C. Orders Exchange Link
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today ordered creation of a computer linkup between overthe-counter and traditional stock exchange markets by March 1, 1982.

title: IU, ASARCO PLUMMET
description: The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company, a diversified manufacturer of business products, abrasives and tapes, reported yesterday that its net earnings in the first quarter declined 14.7 percent, although sales increased by 5.9 percent.

title: BASQUE? EASY. ENGLISH? SOMETHING ELSE
description: To the Editor:

title: Around the World; Opposition Seeks to Amend Trudeau's Charter Plans
description: Opposition Conservatives today offered an amendment to Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau's constitutional proposal that could block the return of Canada's Constitution from Britain until July 1983.

title: WILLIE NILE SINGS HIS TALES
description: based singer and songwriter whose debut album last year received lavish critical praise, appeared at the Savoy on Saturday and lived up to many of the claims that have been made for him. Mr. Nile's brand of folk-rock combines deliberately elevated lyrics with a punchy folk-rock style whose influences include Buddy Holly, the Byrds and Bob Dylan, as well as some newwave rock.

title: Around the World; Greece and U.S. Defer Talks On Aid Until Next Month
description: Greece and the United States have deferred negotiations on a military and economic accord until next month, diplomatic sources said today.

title: STAGE: PAUL DOOLEY IN 'THE AMAZIN' CASEY STENGEL' AT AMERICAN PLACE
description: PAUL DOOLEY is a most appealing comic actor, but he's being asked to do the impossible in a new show called ''The Amazin' Casey Stengel or Can't Anybody Here Speak This Game?'' For almost two hours (including intermission), he must impersonate one of baseball's most eccentric figures without any help from a script. It's all so hopeless he might just as well go out to Shea Stadium and try to manage the Mets. There, at least, he would have a team to back him up.

title: No Headline
description: The Minnesota North Stars' wing, Steve Christoff, suffered a badly bruised right shoulder in Monday night's 5-4 overtime loss to Buffalo and will not accompany the team to Buffalo for Wednesday night's quarterfinal game with the Sabres.

title: Bridge: Unlike Some Team Efforts, Lawyers' League Prospers
description: Team contests based on work affiliations have had mixed success in recent years. The Metropolitan Commercial League continues to be popular, but commercial and industrial team events in tournaments, once scheduled regularly at the local and national levels, have disappeared. So has, apparently, the Bankers League, which operated sedately in New York City for many years.

title: Around the Nation; Trial Begins in Soldier's Suit Over LSD Experiments
description: A former soldier who charges in a $3.9 million lawsuit that Army LSD experiments 24 years ago made him mentally ill is still plagued by ''powerful aggressive and homicidal urges,'' a clinical psychologist, Dr. Ralph Fisch, testified today. He was the opening witness in the nonjury trial.

title: Magma Endorses Offer by Natomas
description: The Natomas Company and the Magma Power Company jointly announced that Magma's board of directors had endorsed and recommended to shareholders an amended tender offer by Natomas for any and all outstanding Magma shares.

title: Lilco Earnings Gained 18% in First Quarter
description: The Long Island Lighting Company reported today that its earnings rose 18 percent in the first quarter, to $64.2 million, from $54.4 million in 1980, or 75 cents a share, compared with 74 cents a share last year.

title: Mobil Increasing Funds For Track and Field Meets
description: The Mobil Corporation, which sponsored The Athletics Congress indoor track and field championships in New York in February, said today that it would also sponsor the outdoor championships here in June. In addition, the corporation said, it will provide money for an outdoor Grand Prix, as it now does for an indoor series.

title: The Police Blotter
description: Jewelry valued at $75,000 was reported stolen from the hotel suite of the model Cheryl Tiegs at the Carlyle Hotel. A police spokesman said that the jewels were taken from a locked metal box in a bedroom closet in a seventh floor suite on Sunday, but that the theft was not reported until yesterday. ... A partly skeletonized human head was found in a grassy area near Linden Boulevard and Lindwood Street in the East New York section of Brooklyn.

title: Nancy B. Skallerup Is Dead at 56; Was Longtime Y.W.C.A. Official
description: Nancy Baxter Skallerup, long active in the Young Women's Christian Association, died yesterday at her home in McLean, Va. She was 56 years old.

title: Prisoner Sands, Member of Parliament
description: Just what did the voters of Northern Ireland mean by electing an imprisoned nationalist guerrilla to the British Parliament? To some, the victory of Robert Sands constitutes an endorsement of the Irish Republican Army and its bloody ways. Some bitter-enders may even hope, ghoulishly, that Mr. Sands will persist to the death in his 53-day prison hunger strike. But his death would be a tragedy serving no worthy purpose, and to view his election as a mandate for violence is a shallow distortion.

title: Holmes H. Welch, 59; Specialist on East Asia
description: Holmes Hinkley Welch, a former State Department official who wrote extensively on Taoism and Buddhism, died Saturday at his home in Cambridge, Mass., after a brief illness. He was 59 years old.

title: 'SPOILED CHILDREN,' ABOUT A FRENCH DIRECTOR
description: Some films cry out to be made. Others whisper, and some just offer the tiniest, weariest shrug. ''Spoiled Children,'' which opened yesterday at the Public Theater, is one of the latter. Its main character is a film director who rents an apartment in which he plans to create his latest screenplay. While living in the apartment, he joins the tenants' committee, has a desultory affair with a woman much younger than he, pays visits to his wife that are even more desultory, and otherwise whiles away time.

title: ROCKEFELLER, CLAUSEN IN FAREWELLS
description: Shareholders paid a fond farewell yesterday to David Rockefeller, who retired as chairman of the Chase Manhattan Bank and its corporate parent, the Chase Manhattan Corporation.

title: Explosion Kills 2 in French Town
description: An explosion caused by a leaking gas line wrecked five 16th-century houses today in this town 60 miles south of Paris. The police said that at least two people were killed and that five others were seriously injured. The police and firemen searched the rubble for other residents.

title: Correction
description: The Going Out Guide yesterday incorrectly listed a performer appearing this week at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South. The correct performer is the trombonist Kai Winding.

title: REAGAN BACKS PLAN ON BUDGET BY GROUP OF HOUSE DEMOCRATS
description: President Reagan, in a move aimed at dividing Democrats in Congress on the budget issue, today embraced a $689 billion spending program for next fiscal year that is being advanced by conservative Democrats in the House of Representatives.

title: A GOLD RUSH IN NEVADA'S HILLS IS SPURRED BY NEW TECHNONLGY
description: Just about 50 miles north of this Nevada town, beneath a terrain covered by sagebrush and grass, lies what the Freeport Gold Company hopes will be one of the largest producing gold mines in the country.

title: ONE NATION'S TRUTH IS ANOTHER'S PRAVADA
description: To the Editor:

title: Iranian Paper Labels as Forgeries Bank Slips of Officials' Deposits
description: The pro-Government newspaper Islamic Republic today published photographs of what it said were forged bank slips showing that Iranian leaders had deposited millions of dollars in private accounts in foreign banks.

title: Alfred R. Shands Jr., 82; Orthopedist in Delaware
description: Dr. Alfred R. Shands Jr., an orthopedic surgeon who helped found the Alfred I. du Pont Institute for crippled children, died Monday at Cokesbury Village, a retirement center in Hockessin, Del. He was 82 years old.

title: NASSAU FEE-SPLITTING CASE GOES TO JURY
description: A Federal court jury was instructed today not to take politics into consideration and then began deliberations in the mail fraud and extortion trial of Joseph M. Margiotta, the Nassau Republican Chairman.

title: Going Out Guide
description: CLACK-CLACK

title: DOW NET FALLS 44.1%;OLIN ADVANCES 28.5%
description: The Dow Chemical Company, the country's second-largest chemical producer behind the Du Pont Company, reported yesterday that net income in the first quarter plunged 44.1 percent as sales edged up 2.8 percent. It cited ''soft demand'' in major markets.

title: FOR CORNELL HOTEL SCHOOL, A BILINGUAL PARIS BRANCH
description: A bilingual, international hotel school, organized in cooperation with the hotel adminstration school at Cornell University in Ithaca, N.Y., will open here this fall.

title: Koch Returns $13,300 Given by Police Officers
description: Mayor Koch sent back $13,300 in campaign contributions from police officers' organizations when it turned out yesterday that, contrary to what had been political practice for years in New York, such contributions were illegal.

title: By The Associated Press
description: The Mobil Corporation yesterday reported a 24.3 percent decline in first-quarter earnings from the level of a year earlier, showing the effects of high oil supplies that have reduced profit margins thoughout the industry.

title: Blackened Redfish; 3 teaspoons salt, optional 1/2 teaspoon red pepper 1/2 teaspoon white pepper 1/4 teaspoon black pepper 1/4 teaspoon dried thyme 1/4 teaspoon dried basil 1/4 teaspoon dried oregano
description: 1. Combine the salt, red pepper, white pepper, black pepper, thyme, basil, oregano and paprika in a small bowl. 2. Dip the fish pieces on both sides in butter. Sprinkle on both sides with the seasoned mixture. 3. Heat a black iron skillet over high heat about five minutes or longer (the skillet cannot get too hot) until it is beyond the smoking stage and starts to lighten in color on the bottom.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, APRIL 22, 1981
description: International A decision to sell arms to Saudi Arabia was formally announced by the White House. The multibillion-dollar sale will include five Airborne Warning and Control System planes. The formal announcement, making official a decision that actually was reached on April 2, said the ''United States has made a commitment to Saudi Arabia to move forward.'' State Department officials said that following the Administration's public announcment of its commitment to Saudi Arabia it might delay for several months its formal notification to Congress, thus opening the way to a Congressional debate. (Page A1, Column 6.) Pakistan was offered arms and economic aid by the Reagan Administration, its Foreign Minister, Agha Shahi, said after two days of talks with Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. and other officials. The assistance, to be spread over five years, is being offered to offset the Soviet threat from Afghanistan. Pakistan would get $500 million in the first year, Mr. Shahi said, though Mr. Haig said no figure had been settled upon. Last year, Pakistan rejected as ''peanuts'' a Carter Administration offer of $400 million over two years. (A1:5.)

title: H.C.A.'s MacNaughton
description: The recruiting profile stressed a strong national image and proven executive skills when the three founders of the Hospital Corporation of America reached out from Nashville in 1978 to sign Donald S. MacNaughton to head their mushrooming company.

title: CITICORP REGISTERS 16.9% GAIN IN PERIOD
description: Citicorp yesterday reported a 16.9 percent rise in its net operating earnings for the first quarter of 1981, but the gain was from an unusually low level of profitability in the quarter a year earlier, when earnings declined 34 percent below the previous year's level.

title: LED RESEARCH ON NERVOUS SYSTEM
description: Dr. Derek Ernest Denny-Brown, a researcher who carried out fundamental studies of the nervous system and its diseases, died of cancer on Monday at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 79 years old.

title: China Aids Light Industry
description: The Chinese Government is making more loans to develop a diversified rural economy, according to Li Fei, vice president of the People's Bank of China. The New China News Agency today quoted him as saying the funds were supporting light industry and the output of consumer goods, mostly bicycles, sewing machines and watches.

title: SOVIET BROADENS ROLE IN CAMBODIA AND HANOI IS REPORTEDLY IRRITATED
description: The Soviet Union is broadening its military influence and technical presence in Cambodia, and some Western analysts and unofficial Cambodian sources say the Russians' moves are irritating their Vietnamese allies, who are here in large numbers.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I have recently become quite fond of herbal teas, including rose hips and camomile. Can you tell me the origin of rose hips and what chamomile is?

title: Man Dies in Oklahoma Explosion
description: An explosion and fire at an oil well servicing company killed a man and seriously injured two other men today. The dead man was identified as Butch Hillbolt of Hennessey. The authorities said that the explosion at Big Red Well Service Inc. had apparently been caused by gasoline fumes reaching a pilot light.

title: Fred Meyer Offer
description: Fred Meyer Inc., the largest retailer in the Pacific Northwest, said yesterday in Portland, Ore., that its board has decided that ''it is not in the best interest of the company and shareholders'' to pursue further the proposal by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, to buy the company. The offer by the New York investment company involved participation by Meyer management at a price of $310 million.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Barton Valve Co. filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission 505,000 common shares at a proposed price of $17 to $20 a share in an underwriting to be managed by Instutional Equity Corporation of Dallas.

title: Careers; M.B.A.'s Vs. World Of Action
description: EVERY year management consulting firms tend to pay the highest salaries for the new harvest of Master of Business Administration degree holders, and they often get the pick of the crop.

title: CONNECTICUT JOINS SLOGANEERS
description: Connecticut came forth today with its official slogan: ''Better Yet Connecticut.'' It was created by Joseph Roy, a 45-year-old graphic artist with six children who has lived all his life in Bristol.

title: CHOOSING PRINCIPALS WITHOUT TESTS PUTS THE CART BEFORE THE HORSE
description: To the Editor:

title: Bishop Edward Dargin Dies at 82;
description: Held 2 Posts in City Archdiocese

title: U.S. STEEL TO BUILD SEAMLESS TUBE MILL
description: David M. Roderick, the chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, is expected to announce today that the company has decided to build a new seamless tubing mill to supply the boom in oil drilling that began several years ago, according to company sources.

title: Police Chief Discounts Recruits' Low Intellect
description: The city's Acting Police Chief said today that he did not care if some police recruits could not spell or drive cars because ''you don't need to be a brain, an Einstein, to be a policeman.''

title: The Pop Life; THE GODFATHER OF ROCK STILL BREAKS NEW GROUND
description: FUSIONS of rock, classical and avant-garde music may be news these days in SoHo, where young classically trained composers are breaking down musical barriers by writing music for heavily amplified rock ensembles. But such fusions are an old story for John Cale. At the age of 40, Mr. Cale, who was born in Wales and studied classical composition at London University's Goldsmith College in the early 60's, can boast an impressive list of accomplishments in rock-androll.

title: Real Estate; New Policy For Shops In Subway
description: THE Sugar 'n Spice bake shop has been a fixture in the subway station at Eighth Avenue and 42d Street since 1950. The owner for the last eight years has been Siegbert Roman, 67 years old and a baker most of his life. He has 17 employees, and the baking is done on the premises.

title: Rangers Hoping To Clinch
description: Craig Patrick, the Ranger coach, wants his team to clinch its quarterfinal playoff series against the St. Louis Blues tomorrow night. But he refuses to predict victory over a team and a city with strong emotional ties for the Patrick family.

title: BILL TO BAN ABORTIONS IS ASSAILED BY SCHOLARS AS UNCONSTITUTIONAL
description: Eleven constitutional scholars, including several prominent conservatives as well as liberals, today denounced as unconstitutional proposed legislation designed to ban abortion.

title: U.S. LOSES AS HIGH COURT BACKS ALASKA ON LEASES
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that Alaska, rather than the Federal Government, was entitled under Federal law to most of the revenue from oil and gas leases issued for Federal wildlife refuges in that state.

title: U.S. Bows in Hockey
description: West Germany defeated the United States today, 6-2, in the consolation tournament of the world hockey championships. The Americans still have a chance to win the tournament, however. Finland beat the Netherlands, 4-2.

title: NATIVE HAWAIIANS' CLAIMS
description: President Reagan has bid ''aloha'' to members of the Native Hawaiians Study Commission. Apparently disturbed by the fact that they were to receive $100 a day plus expenses and were scheduled to travel to Hawaii to conduct hearings, the President fired the nine members of the commission, who were appointed by Jimmy Carter on his last day in office.

title: Polaroid to Present New Photo System
description: The Polaroid Corporation said it planned to introduce a new amateur photographic system that will include cameras with new features, a new self-developing color film and a new battery to run the system.

title: Lobbyists Are Told To Give Fiscal Data
description: The head of the state's largest lobbying group for businesses and several clients of lobbyists were ordered to appear before the New York Temporary State Commission on Regulation of Lobbying to explain why they failed to meet the Feb. 1 deadline for filing their financial statements.

title: No Headline
description: Bob Berry has been rehired as coach of the Los Angeles Kings. After the Kings lost to the Rangers in the first round of the playoffs, there was speculation that Berry would be replaced.

title: Zero Coupon Issue Is Sold by Penney
description: Strong investor demand for the first zero coupon bonds ever issued to the public enabled underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation to increase to $200 million from $100 million an issue of A/A+-rated J.C. Penney Company notes that were priced yesterday at 33.247 to yield 14.25 percent to maturity in 1989. The issue is to be offered today.

title: WILIAMS PROSECUTOR JOUSTS WITH CO-DEFENDANT AT TRIAL
description: The co-defendant of Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr., in heated exchanges with the prosecutor, maintained yesterday that he and the Senator were pursuing a ''normal, legitimate business profit'' in their dealings with Abscam undercover agents. He said this was so even though the agents had discussed possible illegal payoffs.

title: GOLDIN URGES PENSION FUNDS TO AID BUSINESS
description: City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin, the chief investment officer for New York City's pension funds, proposed yesterday that the funds invest $260 million to stimulate new or expanding businesses in the city and the state.

title: Brady May Walk Soon With Cane And Return to Job in Few Months
description: James S. Brady, the Presidential press secretary, is healing so well from a bullet wound that he will be walking with a cane next week and may be back at the White House ''within a few months,'' a spokesman said today.

title: Around the Nation; Unidentified Company Offers to Buy Burning Town
description: An unidentified mining company is drawing interest and skepticism about its offer to pay $30 million for the anthracite coal beneath this town, a move that would allow all 1,100 residents to flee a 19-year-old, gas-spewing underground mine fire.

title: Marathon's Appeal Is Now Worldwide
description: Only hours after Toshihiko Seko of Japan had led a parade of runners past the finish line in the fastest Boston Marathon in history, vendors at the Prudential Center were hawking Tshirts that read, ''I Beat The Wall.''

title: VASQUEZ REMOVED AS CURE THE BLUES JOCKEY IN DERBY
description: Jacinto Vasquez has lost the ride on Cure the Blues in the Kentucky Derby, the colt's trainer, LeRoy Jolley, said at Belmont Park yesterday.

title: DOW OFF 10 ON RISING VOLUME
description: Some leading energy issues tumbled to their lowest levels in more than a year yesterday, and high-technology stocks also sustained losses. Meanwhile, the market erased most of its strong Monday advance that had carried the Dow Jones industrial average by a narrow margin to an eight-year high.

title: 76ERS TOP CELTICS IN OPENER
description: Two free throws by Andrew Toney, a rookie, with two seconds remaining gave the Philadelphia 76ers a 105-104 victory over the Boston Celtics tonight in the opening game of the Eastern Conference championship series.

title: Times Co. Net Up 11% on 14% Revenue Rise
description: The New York Times Company reported today that its first-quarter net income rose 11 percent, to $12.1 million, or 98 cents a share, while revenues rose 14 percent, to $195.1 million.

title: Handgun Inquiry Brings Arrests of 9 in City Sales
description: A Kentucky man accused of being a large-scale supplier of handguns illegally sold in New York City and eight city residents who allegedly sold the weapons here were arrested Monday night after a six-month undercover investigation by Federal agents and the city police.

title: Brenner Trial Near End; Jury to Get Instructions
description: Calling for $750,000 in damages as a fair estimate, the attorney for Teddy Brenner ended arguments yesterday in the promoter's $1 million antitrust suit against the World Boxing Council and its president, Jose Sulaiman.

title: PAKISTAN REPORTS U.S. HAS OFFERED 5-YEAR AID DEAL
description: Foreign Minister Agha Shahi of Pakistan said today that the Reagan Administration had offered his country a fiveyear economic and military assistance package to offset the Soviet threat from Afghanistan.

title: U.S. WILL GO AHEAD ON DEAL WITH SAUDIS FOR 5 RADAR PLANES
description: The White House announced formally today that President Reagan had decided to sell Saudi Arabia a new multibillion-dollar arms package, including five Awacs electronic surveillance planes, but that no decision had been made on when to seek Congressional concurrence.

title: No Eating, and That Includes Cashews
description: As the city administration changed hands in St. Louis yesterday, the case of Emma Harris seemed to grow more complex.

title: SOUTHERN BAPTIST ACTS TO PUT END TO DISPUTE ABOUT PRAYERS OF JEWS
description: A Baptist leader who gained wide attention last year when he said that God did not hear the prayers of Jews said last night that he would die to protect the rights of Jews.

title: Key Rates
description: Previous Year In percent Yesterday Day Ago PRIME RATE 17.50 17.50 19.75 DISCOUNT RATE* 13.00 13.00 13.00 FEDERAL FUNDS 15.83 15.60 16.65 3-MO. TREASURY BILLS 13.62 13.68 12.28 6-MO. TREASURY BILLS 13.64 13.63 11.82 TREASURY NOTES 13.95 13.81 10.91 TREASURY BONDS 13.19 13.09 10.98 BELL SYSTEM BONDS 15.07 15.00 11.75 MUNICIPAL BONDS 11.10 11.10 8.65 6-MONTH SAVINGS 13.871 CERTIFICATES * Current rate excludes 3 percentage-point surcharge on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers. Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: EXHIBITIONS OF FOOD: FEASTS FOR THE EYES
description: EVER since Andy Warhol liberated soup cans from the kitchen, food has been putting on airs. Now it shows off in museums and even restaurants as art to be looked at, not tasted. Chefs are turning into sculptors and sculptors into chefs to satisfy a new breed of food voyeurs who would rather look than eat.

title: DONALD C. STEWART
description: Donald C. Stewart, co-founder, owner and publisher of The Town Topics weekly newspaper here, died today at Princeton Medical Center of complications from leukemia.

title: Philippine Election Set June 16
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos has signed a bill designating June 16 as the date of the first presidential election in the Philippines since 1969. The Government radio announced today that Mr. Marcos signed the bill yesterday after the interim National Assembly approved it. Mr. Marcos extended the campaign period to 52 days from the originally proposed 42 days.

title: READER'S DIGEST RECEIVES AWARD FOR PUBLIC SERVICE
description: Reader's Digest won the National Magazine Award for public service yesterday for an article entitled ''The Murder of Robbie Wayne, Age Six'' by Mary Jane Chambers. It describes how a boy was tortured to death by his mother and stepfather.

title: COLD SNAP STRIKES AND LINGERS FOR A BIT
description: February was an uninvited guest early yesterday. It dropped in on April and then, like a poor relation, decided to spend the night. Suburban temperatures in the New York area hovered around freezing and sent nurserymen scurrying to cover their strawberry plants with burlap.
