The cold was not severe enough to wipe out wide areas of bushes and flowering trees, but ''frost burn'' threatened to brown the edges of new tulips.

title: ARCHBISHOP BUILDING BRIDGES FROM ENGLAND TO U.S.
description: When he was appointed Archbishop of Canterbury in 1979, Bishop Robert Alexander Kennedy Runcie worried that the highest ecclesiastical post in England might not leave him enough time to see his pedigreed Berkshire pigs.

title: Faculty Strike Ends at Wagner College
description: A 20-day faculty strike at Wagner College on Staten Island ended,with the college agreeing to recognize the teachers' union for the term of a new two-year contract. But the college kept a petition before the regional National Labor Relations Board, in which the college argued that it no longer had to bargain with the union.

title: Kitchen Equipment; POT WITH A 'GENTLE FIRE'
description: THE doufeu oven has a knack for survival. Originally this heavy, capacious pot with a broad depression in its lid was used to surround braised meat with heat. The pot sat on the fire and coals were placed in the lid's shallow well. Its name derives from that use. Doux feu means soft fire. In fact, braising refers in French to hot coals. The coals are mostly gone in these days when modern ovens can surround food with heat, but the doufeu oven remains because of a tenacious ability to adapt.

title: Pulitzer Prize Idea Tied To Newspaper Chairman
description: Roger Wilkins of The Washington Star, a member of the advisory board that recommended Janet Cooke of The Washington Post for a Pulitzer Prize in feature writing, said today that the proposal for the prize had originated with Warren H. Phillips, chairman and chief executive of The Wall Street Journal.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A caption in Metropolitan Report yesterday on the picture of an exercise class at the St. Francis Residence incorrectly identified the woman shown at the left. She is Lolly Fountaine, a dance therapist.

title: News of the Theater; NEW ROLE FOR MISS DEWHURST: DIRECTOR
description: COLLEEN DEWHURST has played a great range of roles in the theater, but never one like this: She is going to direct a play for the first time. The play is ''Ned and Jack,'' a new work by Sheldon Rosen, an American playwright living in Canada and making his New York debut. The production will open May 13 for a monthlong run at the Hudson Guild Theater.

title: MAKE CHILD-STEALING A FELONY IN NEW YORK
description: To the Editor:

title: Scout's Action Averts Death
description: Liz Rocha was floating down the Ottauquechee River near Woodstock, Vt., on a homemade raft Saturday in a race when it flipped over and she was thrown into the water. John Loftus, a 17-year-old Boy Scout, leaped into the water after her and managed to pull her toward the river bank. Spectators had improvised a rope out of clothing and pulled her and her rescuer to safety.

title: LOCAL OFFICIALS ASSAIL ADMINISTRATION'S PLAN TO CUT HOUSING FUNDS
description: Representatives of cities and counties around the nation told a Senate subcommittee today that the Reagan Administration's plans to cut housing and development aid would hurt many Americans.

title: AGNEW TRIAL OPENS IN TAXPAYERS' SUIT
description: The State of Maryland began sending witnesses into a small courtroom here today to testify that, despite his years of denials, former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew took nearly $200,000 in kickbacks from highway contractors doing business with the state government.

title: Pianist: Martha Braden Jones
description: MARTHA BRADEN JONES'S recital in Abraham Goodman House on Monday night was a friendly affair that the pianist seemed to enjoy as much as her audience did. The music on her program may not have strayed very far off the beaten track, nor did her interpretations strike any deep chords, but everything she played was characterized by a crisp efficiency, a scrupulous regard for expressive content and a sure sense for the appropriate musical gesture.

title: LONDON POLICE SEIZE 8 AS BLACK TEEN-AGERS GO ON A NEW RAMPAGE
description: A mob of young blacks rampaged through the streets of East London late today, breaking shop windows, overturning a car and threatening policemen in the second straight night of racial violence, a police spokesman said.

title: Personal Health; PAIN: FOR MILLIONS, A DAILY REALITY
description: ''Americans are probably the most pain-conscious people on the face of the earth. For years we have had it drummed into us - in print, on radio, over television, in everyday conversation - that any hint of pain is to be banished as though it were the ultimate evil. As a result, we are becoming a nation of pill-grabbers and hypochondriacs, escalating the slightest ache into a searing ordeal.'' - Norman Cousins, ''Anatomy of an Illness.''

title: Books of the Times
description: By Jonathan Friendly THE WASHINGTON REPORTERS. By Ste- phen Hess. 174 pages. The Brookings In- stitution. Cloth, $17.95; paper, $6.95.

title: Raines: 4 Steals, 4 Hits
description: Tim Raines, a rookie outfielder, tied a Montreal record with four stolen bases and had four hits as he led the Expos to a 10-3 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies today.

title: Loss at McLouth Steel
description: The McLouth Steel Corporation today reported a first-quarter loss of more than $4.1 million, widened from its loss of $2.6 million a year before. Sales rose to $180.1 million from $179.7 million. The company's chairman, Gene E. Gann, also announced the appointment of Milton Deaner as president and chief operating officer.

title: Market Place; Tristar's Drag On Lockheed
description: WALL STREET is hoping - and more than one analyst is betting - that the Lockheed Corporation will jettison its Tristar jumbo jet business soon and become significantly more profitable in the years ahead.

title: ALL EVES TURN TO PERRY ELLIS
description: PERRY ELLIS has reached that admirable stage in a designer's career where one doesn't need a score card to tell the player. It's not merely a question of turning out best sellers that are recognizably his, or of setting off what some totally secure designers call the most sincere sign of flattery: a host of recognizable copies.

title: STATE BUDGET IMPASSE STIRS CONCERN BY FISCAL AGENCY OVER CITY'S CREDIT
description: The Municipal Assistance Corporation expressed ''extreme concern'' yesterday over the state budget impasse. The corporation's board members said it could endanger New York City's hard-won improvement in its credit rating.

title: A TALK WITH BRZEZINSKI
description: The following is adapted from an interview, titled ''The Perils of Foreign Policy,'' in the May issue of the British journal Encounter. George Urban, a scholar and journalist, talks with Zbigniew Brzezinski, national security adviser under President Jimmy Carter.

title: BOSTON SCHOOL PLAN ADOPTED BY COUNCIL
description: The Boston City Council reached agreement tonight on a revised financial plan to keep the city's school system operating until June 30, but some city officials said that Mayor Kevin H. White would probably veto the plan.

title: Administration Seeks Wider Role For States on Water Resources
description: The Reagan Administration wants the states to play a larger role in developing water resources but still has not decided what its own role should be, an Interior Department official told Congress today.

title: TV: 'SHIVA,' WORSHIP OF A GOD
description: ''MANIFESTATIONS of Shiva'' is the title of an art exhibition touring the United States and of a related film produced for the Asian Society. The exhibition, at the Philadelphia Museum of Art until June 7, shows how Indian artists have conceived of the Hindu god over 2,000 years. The film, on WNET-TV, Channel 13, tonight at 10:30 o'clock, attempts to convey the very experience of Shiva worship.

title: GUILd EXTENDS DEADLINE FOR A STRIKE AGAINST NEWSPAPERS TO WEDNESDAY
description: The Newspaper Guild yesterday postponed its deadline for a strike against one or more of the city's three major newspapers from Friday to next Wednesday. It said both sides had agreed to stepped-up negotiations and would continue their talks with the assistance of a Federal mediator.

title: MISSING CHILDREN
description: Perhaps she will turn up singing to herself, oblivious on a swing, house and lost his way. Maybe there has been an argument at home - she stayed out too late, his friends are undesirables - and so a teen-ager sulks somewhere while parents agonize and the police begin the mechanics of a search. Maybe there has been a divorce and a custody battle, and one parent has taken a son or daughter from the other.

title: FREEDOM'S CAREFUL LOAN POLICY
description: Its name may not be as familiar as Citibank or Chase Manhattan, but Freedom National Bank, the only black-owned bank in New York, has turned a profit for the last 17 quarters - no small feat for a bank whose liberal lending policies had once brought it to the brink of bankruptcy.

title: YANKS AND BIRD DEFEAT TIGERS, 2-0
description: The Yankees, who have been looking for a right-handed starting pitcher for months, rediscovered Doug Bird last night. Bird, primarily a relief pitcher throughout his eight-year major league career, started against Detroit at Yankee Stadium and shut out the Tigers for six innings as the Yankees registered a 2-0 victory.

title: Harvard Stadium Damaged by Fire
description: A spectacular six-alarm fire destroyed the press section atop 78-year-old Harvard Stadium today, and a deputy fire chief said that vandals were responsible.

title: DelBello Bug Found Inoperable by F.B.I.
description: WHITE PLAINS (AP) - An electronic eavesdropping device discovered two months ago in the office of Westchester County Executive Alfred B. DelBello never worked, and it is impossible to determine who planted it, the District Attorney has concluded.

title: ALLEGED UNDERWORLD LEADER IS ASSAILED AT BRIBERY TRIAL
description: Carlos Marcello, believed to be one of the top Mafia leaders in the United States, was portrayed by a Federal prosecutor here today as the central figure in a conspiracy to obtain lucrative state insurance business by bribing Louisiana politicians and public officials.

title: Leary Out Until May 6
description: The Mets placed Tim Leary, their promising rookie pitcher, on the 21-day disabled list yesterday because of continued pain in his right elbow. Manager Joe Torre; Bob Gibson, a coach, and Lou Gorman, a club vice president, watched Leary throw for five minutes before making the decision. They said that Leary was being treated very conservatively and that his injury was not serious.

title: Business Digest WEDNESDAY, APRIL 22, 1981; Companies
description: American Express agreed to take over Shearson Loeb Rhoades for $915 million in stock. Seen in combination with Prudential Insurance's purchase last month of Bache, the takeover of America's second largest broker after Merrill Lynch is expected to lead to tough new competition on Wall Street. (Page A1.)

title: East Germans Down a Balloon
description: An East German border patrol helicopter forced down a hot-air balloon and detained the two West Germans aboard after it drifted over the border, officials here reported today.

title: Economic Scene; Good News For Consumer
description: WORRYING about Congressional action on President Reagan's proposed three-year, 30 percent tax-cut program, Administration spokesmen have been playing down the surprisingly strong surge of the gross national product in this year's first quarter. ''Real'' G.N.P. - total national output adjusted for inflation - climbed at an annual rate of 6.5 percent.

title: SUFFOCATION APPARENTLY CAUSED ATLANTA BLACK'S DEATH
description: The nude body of a young black man, found yesterday at the edge of the Chattahoochee River southwest of downtown Atlanta, was identified early today as that of 23-year-old Michael C. McIntosh, a small, slightly built former convict who, like 13 other young blacks here in the last 21 months, apparently died of suffocation.

title: Advertising;  Ad Agency Gets a New Subsidiary
description: DELLA FEMINA, TRAVISANO & PARTNERS is about to get still another ad agency subsidiary. It is KSW&G Advertising, but after May 1 it will be called Sherwood & Schneider.

title: RETURN OF STOLEN GEAR AND CREDITORS AID SAVE THGE EGG HUNT SPONSOR
description: The Epilepsy Institute reported yesterday that thousands of dollars worth of equipment stolen during the egg hunt that it sponsored Saturday at Central Park had been returned mysteriously, that some debts had been canceled and that it no longer faced bankruptcy.

title: Radioactive Water Spills at Jersey Plant
description: About 10,000 gallons of ''low level'' radioactive water has spilled into a catch basin, seeped through the walls of a building and soaked into the surrounding ground outside the Oyster Creek nuclear generating station here, authorities said.

title: Casinos Running Scared
description: What's happening to the golden goose in Atlantic City? Is it getting tired? Or is it the public that is losing interest, along with too much cash?

title: U.N. Unit Buying Rubber Boats For Rescue of Somali Refugees
description: The office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees said today that it was buying 40 inflatable rubber boats in Britain for rescue operations in flooded refugee camps in central Somalia.

title: U.N. NAMIBIAN PLAN SUBVERTED
description: To the Editor:

title: IGNORING EVENT, POLES TUNE IN TO JOHNNY CASH
description: Today is the 36th anniversary of the Polish-Soviet Friendship Treaty and Poles remarked that relations between the two countries were so terrific that a soccer match between them was called off recently with an explanation that the Soviet players were busy with more important things.

title: COURT WIDENS CURB ON SEARCH OF HOME
description: The Supreme Court today expanded the constitutional protection against searches of private homes by the police. The Court ruled, 7 to 2, that even when the police have a valid arrest warrant they also need a search warrant to enter the home of someone other than the person they want to arrest.

title: Abu Dhabi Hotel Blast Kills 2
description: Two persons were killed and a third injured today in a bomb explosion at the Hyatt Regency hotel, a police statement said.

title:
RED SMITH;
The Boys Who Play Billy Ball
description: IMPERISHABLE Luis Tiant, knocked out by an eight-run attack in his first two innings as a pitcher for the Portland Beavers, throws a nohitter in his second start. Bobby Bonds, years younger than Luis but also an exile from the major leagues, is signed by Texas to try a comeback in Wichita. Seven teams -the Yankees, Orioles, White Sox, Royals, Phillies, Twins and A's -draw record opening-day crowds, proving that baseball is healthier than ever, or else that the public is rushing to see some games before the season ends with a strike on May 29.

title: Violinist: Earl Carlyss Plays Sonatas of Mozart, Copland
description: THE very term ''second fiddle'' stands in our slang as a symbol of inferiority. This must not make second fiddlers feel very good, but they would have been heartened by Earl Carlyss's violin recital Monday night at the Juilliard Theater. Mr. Carlyss has been the second violinist of the Juilliard String Quartet since 1966, and his recital had nothing inferior about it at all.

title: Queen Elizabeth Is 55, Unofficially and Quietly
description: Her birthday won't be celebrated officially until June 13, when, presumably, the English weather will be more dependably fair and suitable for the ceremonial Trooping the Color, but yesterday Queen Elizabeth II observed her actual 55th birthday.

title: FRENCH CHEF, NEW ORLEANS STYLE
description: a celebrated, internationally known chef who just happens to have been born in the United States. With his wife Kay Hinrich, Mr. Prudhomme is the owner of K. Paul's Louisiana Kitchen, which in just two years has be-come one of the most popular eating places in New Orleans. Mr. Prudhomme came to New York recently to prepare Cajun and Creole foods, his specialties, for an assembly of more than 150 French chefs who were on a 10-day visit to America. He made jambalaya, chicken gumbo, crawfish bisque and an etouffee of crawfish, all as part of an all-American feast. He also visited my kitchen to demonstrate numerous Louisiana specialties, including the jambalaya and chicken gumbo, dirty rice (also known as rice dressing), red beans with rice and his own invention, a specialty of specialties, blackened redfish.

title: Ida Bennett, 66, Winner Of Many Titles in Bridge
description: Ida Bennett of Staten Island, one of the country's most successful woman bridge players, was killed near here yesterday in a one-car accident on the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway. She was 66 years old.

title: JAZZ: CURSON AND MELBA LISTON
description: TWO of the more promising jazz groups of the last few years -Melba Liston and Company and Ted Curson Big Eight -shared two concerts at Town Hall on Saturday evening in which both groups indicated that they are losing the quality that gave them promise.

title: SAUDIS CUT SOME OIL $2
description: Amid growing evidence of an oil glut, Saudi Arabia has intensified its campaign to lower world oil prices by cutting the price it charges for some of its oil exports by $2 a barrel.

title: Around the Nation; Mistrial Motions Rejected In Case of Ex-Governor
description: The corruption trial of former Gov. Ray Blanton opened today with assistant United States Attorney Bob Lynch vowing to prove that the people of Tennessee were deprived of their right to have public offficials perform ''fairly, honestly and free from corruption.''

title: SOVIET SAYS ZIONISTS STRIVE TO UNDERMINE POLAND
description: The Soviet press, which has been accusing American labor unions, West Germans, Western radio stations and Western imperialism of interfering in Poland, today added Western Zionism to its list of subversive meddlers.

title: TEXT OF THE FINAL JUSTICE DEPARTMENT REPORT ON ACTIVITIES IN THE BILLY
description: Following is the text of the final Justice Department report, made public today, on the investigation into Billy Carter's relations with Libya: Introduction

title: UTILITY RETURNS TO RIVER POWER TO CUT OIL BILLS
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill and Lelan F. Sillin Jr., chairman of the board of Northeast Utilities, pulled the switch, stood back and waited for the electric bulb to light.

title: MRS. THATCHER REBUFFS IRISH M.P.'S ON ROBERT SANDS, JAILED I.R.A. LEADER
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said today that she would refuse to meet three members of the Irish Parliament who had hoped to discuss the case of Robert Sands, a 27-year-old prisoner on a hunger strike who is reported to be approaching death.

title: Doctor Of the Interior
description: A Mrs. Mullens of Trenton, N.J., writes that she is in a quandary and wants advice. My advice, Mrs. Mullens, is to stay there and see what happens. Robert Benchley once spent 10 years in a quandary and afterward became very successful in Hollywood.

title: Benton & Bowles Names A Second Vice President
description: Meanwhile at Benton & Bowles, which has only one president - John S. Bowen - the executive vice president population was doubled with the naming of a second one.

title: Appointment to Mint
description: President Reagan intends to appoint Donna Pope, a veteran member of the Ohio Legislature, to serve as director of the United States Mint, the White House said today.

title: FORMER AIDE SEEKS TO CHALLENGE KOCH
description: Criticizing his former boss, Mayor Koch, as a ''show biz'' official who has ''no program for this city's future,'' Bernard Rome declared his candidacy yesterday for the Republican nomination for Mayor of New York.

title: CASTRO ACCUSES U.S. OF BUILDING TENSION
description: President Fidel Castro said today that the threatening language and the military maneuvers of the Reagan Administration are turning Central America and the Caribbean ''into a hotbed of tension similar to that of the Persian Gulf, the Indian Ocean, the Middle East and Europe.''

title: PLANT IN MARYLAND MAY END OIL ERA
description: In most ways Chalk Point No.4, now nearing completion in the tobacco-growing flatlands of southern Maryland, is a quite unremarkable electric generating plant.

title: Dr. Clarence J. Schein, a Teacher And Chief of Surgery at Einstein
description: Dr. Clarence J. Schein, a member of the faculty of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine and of the surgical staff of Montefiore Hospital and Medical Center for 33 years, died Friday after a long illness. He lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: CONGRESSIONAL SURVEY FINDS BIOTECHNOLOGY A KEY TO FUTURE ENERGY AND
description: MATERIALS NEEDS By HAROLD M. SCHMECK Jr.

title: Rights Group Challenges Pact for Religious Cable TV
description: The American Civil Liberties Union sued the city today, challenging its cable television contract with the Warner Cable Corporation as an unconstitutional establishment of religion.

title: Pistons Are Said to Offer Sampson Top Rookie Pact
description: Jack McCluskey, the Detroit Pistons' general manager, was said today to have offered Ralph Sampson, Virginia's 7-foot-4-inch center, the richest rookie contract ever in the National Basketball Association if he chose to leave school and turn pro.

title: BASQUE? EASY. ENGLISH? SOMETHING ELSE
description: To the Editor:

title: Discoveries; THOUGHTS OF MAY AND SUMMER, AND GLITTER AND AFRICAN CRAFT; 1. Hooray for May!
description: In Chaucer's England, the first of May was celebrated with the gathering of flowers and decorating doorways with baskets of blossoms. For centuries, British children made May baskets and left them on friend's doorsteps. And now, at Westhampton Beach, L.I., the charming custom of May baskets is being revived by Jeanne Block and Miriam Gallacher, who own a flower business called Westhampton Greenery. The women tuck spring flowers such as narcissus, freesia, grape hyacinths and budding branches into twig-handled baskets and will deliver them to the friend of your choice on May 1. The charge is $25, including delivery to Manhattan only. Since each basket is made to order, the partners advise ordering early. They can be reached at (516) 325-0426.

title: Uniroyal in Black Despite Sales Drop
description: Uniroyal Inc., the tire, chemical and plastic materials manufacturer, reported net income of $7.6 million, or 24 cents a share, for the first quarter, in contrast to a loss of $11.7 million in the 1980 first quarter. However, sales slipped to $541 million from $580 million.

title: AWACS: A MODIFIED 707 WITH A COMPUTER THAT CAN TRACK 400 PLANES
description: The Awacs electronic surveillance planes that the Reagan Administration has decided to sell to Saudi Arabia are modified Boeing 707's that can fly for 72 hours with refueling.

title: Notes on People; Holland Doesn't Necessarily Mean the Netherlands
description: Back on Feb. 19, when John Murphy, a Rockland County legislator, sent a note to the County Clerk, Joseph Holland, he made only one mistake. He put the note in a white official envelope rather than a brown interoffice envelope.

title: U.S. SEES CAR INDUSTRY SHORTFALL
description: The United States has told Japan that American auto makers will be $12 billion short of the $80 billion they plan to spend over the next three years to carry out a vast retooling effort to become more competitive, Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige said today.

title: ROCKETS SET BACK KINGS, 97-78
description: Moses Malone scored 29 points and led a second-half surge that carried the Houston Rockets past the Kansas City Kings, 97-78, tonight in the opener of their Western Conference championship series.

title: Military Anlaysis
description: MacDILL AIR FORCE BASE, Fla. -A review and perhaps a realignment of the armed services unified command system is one of the urgent issues facing Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger once he has shepherded the military budget through Congress.

title: BALLET THEATER: GALA OPENING NIGHT
description: THE kind of opening night American Ballet Theater offered Monday at the Metropolitan Opera House may not have been what its regular audience expected, but it pointed in the right direction.

title: ROAD FATALITIES AMONG BLACKS WORRY PRETORIA
description: South Africa's National Road Safety Council regularly buys space in newspapers intended for black readers in order to publish a comic strip called ''The Crazy Adventures of Bobo.'' The hero is a black who is extremely naive about the mortal peril he is in whenever he approaches roads and highways.

title: The U.N. Today; April 22, 1981; ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL
description: Advisory Committee for the Interna- tional Year of Disabled Persons - 10 A.M.

title: WOMEN ON BOARDS: A NEW PERSPECTIVE
description: WOMEN on corporate boards are growing in numbers - up almost 25 percent in less than three years. And although they still represent only 1.8 percent of total board membership, there is a marked shift in the corporate chairman's perception of the contribution women can make to a board, according to Felice N. Schwartz of Catalyst, a national nonprofit organization that promotes the active participation of women in corporations and the professions.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: HOUSTON (NL) - Purchased contract of J oe Pittman, infielder, from Tucson farm. METS (NL) - Placed Tim Leary, pitcher, o n disabled list until May 6; activated Bob B ailor, infielder-outfielder.

title: U.S. ACTS TO EXPAND TEAMSTER FUND SUIT
description: The Reagan Administration moved today to broaden allegations in a Government civil suit accusing former trustees of mismanaging the Central States Pension Fund of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''As for Billy Carter, although we remain of the opinion that he lied to Government agents investigating his Foreign Agents Registration Act responsibilites, the decison to initiate criminal prosecution in such cases is made within the Criminal Division.'' - A Justice Department report. (A20:6.)

title: Love Story
description: People we know in the country celebrate spring by picking wild leeks in the woods for salads and soup. In Greenwich Village, a man with a conch shell walks out on the Bank Street Pier and blows his greetings to the QE2 as she slides down the Hudson, hoping she'll answer with an ocean-deep toot.

title: 2 Straight 117's a First For New York's Lottery
description: For the first time in the history of the New York State lottery, the same number was chosen in two consecutive drawings, officials said yesterday. But the Saturday and Monday drawings of the number - 117 - did not discouraged bettors, who still wagered on the number yesterday, the officials said.

title: ADVERTISING
description: In his first real organizational move since taking over the helm of N.W. Ayer from Neal O'Connor, Louis T. Hagopian, chairman and chief executive, announced seven changes of status at the international agency yesterday.

title: Paramount Fills Post
description: Donald C. Simpson, 35 years old, was named yesterday to the new post of president of Paramount Productions for the Motion Pictures division of Paramount Pictures Corporation. Mr. Simpson, who was formerly senior vice president in charge of worldwide production, has been with Paramount Pictures since October 1975 and was named to his last post in April 1980.

title: Around the Nation; Oil Slicks Off Florida Keys Called No Immediate Threat
description: Seven patches of spilled oil floated at sea today off the lower Florida Keys, but officials said that most of the oil was moving away from land and did not pose an immediate threat to the island chain.

title: AMERICAN EXPRESS TO BUY SHEARSON AS TAKEOVERS TRANSFORM WALL ST.
description: The American Express Company will acquire Shearson Loeb Rhoades, Wall Street's second-largest brokerage firm, for about $915 million in stock, the two companies announced yesterday.

title: Effa Manley, 81, Who Originated Newark Eagles of Negro League
description: Effa Manley, onetime owner of the Newark Eagles, a Negro league team that developed Monte Irvin, Larry Doby and Don Newcombe for the majors, died Saturday in a nursing home at the age of 81.

title: Notes on People; When a Couple of Musicians Get Together Sparks Fly
description: Although two members of his trio are married to each other, Joseph Kalichstein says he doesn't really feel like the odd piano player out.

title: Chrysler to Convert Missouri Car Plant
description: The Chrysler Corporation said today that it will stop building rear-wheel-drive cars in the United States on May 1.

title: HOW TO DECANT WINE: TWO SIMPLE PROCEDURES
description: Perhaps the most ingenious method of decanting red wine is practiced at Chateau Grancey, the home of Louis Latour, outside the village of Beaune in the Burgundy region of France. The method involves decanting the sediment from the bottle rather than decanting the wine.

title: Illinois Player Is Denied Permission to Play in '81
description: The attorney for Dave Wilson, the University of Illinois quarterback, says the Big Ten Conference has rejected a request that would have allowed Wilson to play football again in 1981.

description: Tony Hendra, the Manhattan humorist and bicycling bon vivant, has a truly eerie ability to sense the imminence of an emerging trend. Once again, he is first in identifying a forthcoming craze: 70's nostalgia.

title: Continental Airlines
description: Continental Airlines said that Texas International Airlines was violating the independence of the trust which holds a 48.5 percent interest in Continental. Continental asked the Civil Aeronautics Board, in a petition, to withdraw its approval of the trust and to order Texas International to divest itself of Continental stock. Continental also asked the C.A.B. to instruct the trustee, the First Jersey National Bank, to cease its ''delay tactics and to abide by the terms of the C.A.B.-mandated voting trust agreement.''

title: Best Buys; 'TIS THE SEASON FOR VEGETABLES AND FRUITS
description: THE high prices we've seen recently for fruits and vegetables that were hit by the winter freeze in Florida continue to wane as the new crop arrives. Cucumbers, grapefruit, peppers, tomatoes, zucchini and eggplant are all considerably lower this week.

title: Article 094249 -- No Title
description: Democrats in the Connecticut House of Representatives settled their differences today and pushed through a $2.99 billion state budget that had been defeated earlier in the day.

title: MARCH RISE IN DURABLES PUT AT 1.3%
description: New factory orders for durable goods, an economic index intended to foreshadow future trends in industrial production and employment, rose 1.3 percent in March, the Commerce Department reported yesterday.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Albany Savings Bank plans to absorb Newburgh Savings Bank in a merger.

title: REPUBLICAN WINS STOCKMAN SEAT
description: Mark Siljander, a conservative Republican, tonight won election to the Congressional seat vacated by David A. Stockman, now director of the Office of Management and Budget.

title: A.& P. to Buy Niagara Frontier
description: The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company has agreed to buy Niagara Frontier Services Inc., owner of several chains of food stores, in a deal worth about $84 million, the companies announced today.

title: 31 Treated in Fire In Subway Tunnel
description: Thirty-one passengers were treated for smoke inhalation and minor bruises after a smoky electrical fire erupted under a subway train in Queens, the Transit Authority said.

title: BASQUE? EASY. ENGLISH? SOMETHING ELSE
description: To the Editor:

title: HOLLYWOOD FIGURES BALK AT U.S. STUDY OF DRUG USE
description: Despite assurances from a Congressional aide that there was no intention of asking people to name names, Hollywood resistance is threatening to scuttle an investigation of drug abuse in the entertainment industry.

title: SATELLITE TELEVISION FOR HOMES
description: The Federal Communications Commission opened a new avenue for television today by endorsing direct broadcasting from satellites to homes. It also accepted for expedited consideration a plan by Comsat to begin such service as early as 1985.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, a dispatch from Havana on Monday about Roman Catholicism in Cuba misstated the church's attitude toward revolutionary social change. As a result of papal encyclicals and the Second Vatican Council, the church, while still opposing Communism, has become more tolerant toward socialism.

title: BEHIND SENATOR HELMS, A CHERUBIC ASSISTANT REIGNS
description: His name does not appear on any of the walnut doors that line the corridors of the two Senate office buildings, nor has he ever voted ''yea'' or ''nay'' in the Senate chamber.

title: Around the World; Japan Says Nuclear Mishap Exposed 56 to Radiation
description: Fifty-six men were exposed to contaminated waste during a nuclear power plant accident last March 8 on the Sea of Japan, the Government announced today.

title: Transit Policeman Shot at M.T.A. Offices
description: A Transit Authority police officer on duty at the executive offices of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, on Madison Avenue between 44th and 45th Streets, was shot in the left thigh yesterday during an exchange of gunfire with an armed intruder.

title: 300 SALVADOR REBELS FAIL IN ATTACK
description: Three hundred guerrillas backed by light artillery, bazookas and grenade launchers were repulsed yesterday in one of their largest attacks in the last month, a military commander said today.

title: A Chief Economist At Commerce Dept.
description: Robert G. Dederick, Harvard-trained senior vice president and top economist of the Northern Trust Company of Chicago, is the Administration's choice to become chief economist at the Commerce Department.

title: BLOCKING THE DISABLED
description: To the Editor:

title: Turkish Military Court Sentences A Pro-Albania Editor to 19 Years
description: A military court has sentenced the former managing editor of a banned leftist weekly to 19 years in jail on charges of supporting Communism, making separatist propaganda and lowering the prestige of the armed forces, martial law authorities said today.

title: Puzzling Out the Secret of Conservative Success
description: Since last fall's Republican victories, developing alternatives to conservative thought has become a thriving industry among some politicians. The latest is Mark Green, a Democrat whose program is known as the Democracy Project and is designed to appeal to ''progressives.''

title: Driver for a Slain Crime Chieftain Gets Eight-Year Term for Perjury
description: John Stanfa, who was sitting in the driver's seat of the car in which Angelo Bruno, the reputed crime leader, was shot to death 13 months ago, was sentenced today to eight years in prison for lying to a grand jury investigating the murder.

title: RECRUITERS SHOP FOR VILLANOVA BARGAINS
description: Representatives of more than 40 colleges and universities, trying to improve their own football teams, solemnly gathered at the Villanova Field House all day today, a week after the university's board of trustees had voted to abolish its 87-year-old program.

title: BRETONS WHO HAVE GONE HOME AGAIN
description: Two elderly ladies met recently on the main street of this tiny village in a remote corner of Brittany. ''That is a lovely coat,'' one said. ''It's like one I bought in Bloomingdale's years ago.''

title: TRANSCRIPT OF AN INTERVIEW WITH THE PRESIDENT ON HIS WOUNDING AND
description: Following is the official White House transcript of an interview with President Reagan today by James Gerstenzang of The Associated Press and Helen Thomas of United Press International:

title: TO THE HOME SECTION: Mary Kay Blakely presented a passionate, biased description in the ''Hers'' column of the anti-abortion group that she opposes. In fact, she rendered so distorted a picture, in such a mean-spirited manner, that she did nothing so much as exhibit a myopic misinterpretation of the issue and a disregard for any argument to be offered by the pro-life faction.
description: ''Pro-lifers'' are not as she portrays them. They're not an unfeeling mob of extremists bent on punishing women for the crime of possessing the reproductive capacity.

title: Bethlehem Steel Details Payments
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation has filed documents with the Securities and Exchange Commission to settle S.E.C. complaints that the company had made inadequate disclosures of improper payments in its shipyard business.

title: ILL-ADVISED NEW YORK BUDGET CUTBACK
description: To the Editor:

title: People
description: * Alan Chaiet has been named a senior vice president of J. Walter Thompson U.S.A. Inc.

title: Down the Slippery Slope
description: Soviet officials from Ambassador Dobrynin on down are buttonholing other foreign diplomats to ask: ''Do you think the Americans will talk?'' The Russians seem desperate to arrange a forum for the discussion of disarmament.

title: CELTICS TROUNCE 76ERS
description: In what Coach Bill Fitch of Boston called a ''typical Larry Bird game,'' the second-year forward scored 34 points, grabbed 16 rebounds and had five assists tonight in the Celtics' 118-99 victory over the Philadelphia 76ers that evened their Eastern Conference championship series at a game apiece.

title: Notes on People; Reischauer, at Harvard, Gives Farewell Lecture
description: When he began his graduate studies at Harvard half a century ago, Asian affairs was a substantially undernourished area of academic concern. But yesterday, when Edwin O. Reischauer delivered his farewell lecture at the university's Yenching Institute, interest in the field seemed to be booming.

title: Home Improvement
description: At this time of year homeowners spend a lot of time mowing, trimming and pruning and doing other chores that involve working with power-driven yard equipment. While the mowers, trimmers and other tools can go a long way toward transforming drudgery into a pleasant outdoor chore, they may also cause serious injury if they are carelessly or improperly handled.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, APRIL 23, 1981
description: International U.S. commitment to Israel's security was reaffirmed by the Reagan Administration after protests from the Israeli Government and Israeli diplomats in Washington over the Administration's announcement that it would sell arms to Saudi Arabia. Israel is especially against the proposed sale of five Awacs surveillance planes. After a meeting in Jerusalem with the United States Ambassador, Samuel Lewis, Prime Minister Menachem Begin said ''the Government of Israel expressed deep pain and unqualified opposition'' to the arms deal. (Page A1, Column 6.) Senator Jesse Helms was challenged by the White House in his efforts to have a person of his choice named assistant secretary of state for inter-American affairs as the Senate Foreign Relations Committee began confirmation hearings on key State Department appointments. The White House nominated Thomas O. Enders, a career diplomat and economic specialist with no Latin American experience. Senator Helms, who indicated he would oppose Mr. Enders, has put forward Louis Tambs, a professor at Arizona State University and a former contractor in Latin America. (A1:5.)

title: STAGE: 'MERTON OF MOVIES'
description: town sales clerk who wants to become a movie star. Merton was a prototypical Kaufman hero -nice, gullible and destined to outsmart all the supposedly shrewder types who were so eager to take advantage of him.

title: Notes on People; Goldwater Voices Alarm Over Nation's Defense
description: The assignment was to discuss some aspect of aviation, but Senator Barry Goldwater seemed to stretch the point a bit yesterday when he addressed the Wings Club, an organization of senior aviation executives, at the Biltmore Hotel.

title: 2 BIG FOOD CONCERNS PLANNING TO MERGE
description: Nabisco Inc. and Standard Brands Inc., two of the country's largest producers of packaged foods, announced yesterday that they would merge into a new company to be known as Nabisco Brands Inc. The transaction will involve an exchange of stock with an estimated value of more than $2 billion.

title: Judge Extends Deadline For Boston School Plan
description: Expressing reluctance to intervene, a judge today gave city officials two more days to find a way to keep the insolvent Boston school system open.

title: RADIO: JONESTOWN TRAGEDY DOCUMENTED ON TAPE
description: The power of pure sound is demonstrated dramatically tonight in a National Public Radio documentary titled ''Father Cares: The Last of Jonestown.'' Devised and written by James Reston Jr., the 90-minute program is constructed around tape recordings made by the Rev. Jim Jones and more than 900 of his followers in the 18 months preceding their deaths in Guyana on Nov. 18, 1978.

title: Finish the Financial Revolution
description: ''It's amazing,'' said the man from the Wall Street brokerage house to the reporter. ''We've gone from being the ugliest girl on the block to the most beautiful in town.'' Last month Bache, the sixth largest brokerage company, was acquired by Prudential Insurance. Now American Express has plunked down $915 million for Shearson Loeb Rhoades, the fourth largest. And other giant financial institutions are said to be looking for a stake on the Street.

title: Conoco Cites Good Oil Flow Rate
description: Conoco Inc., one of the nation's large oil companies, said that flow tests from a second well at Milne Point on the North Slope of Alaska indicated a commercially feasible oilfield.

title: MUSIC: 2 CARTER WORKS AND FILM
description: AS he pointed out Tuesday night, Elliott Carter is not so unperformed a composer as the stereotype of ignored contemporary music might suggest. And given the frequency of Carter performances, it cannot be said that the evening devoted to his work at Cooper Union was a great success.

title: BUDGET OFFICE SAYS SPENDING CUTS HIT ALL REGIONS EQUALLY
description: An analysis by the Office of Management and Budget has found that the impact of President Reagan's proposed budget reductions will fall equally on each region of the country and not disproportionately on the Northeast and Middle West, as some Congressional critics are contending.

title: Montana's Senate Upholds Veto Of Bill to Limit Curb on Evidence
description: Montana's Senate came within a vote yesterday of passing a bill design to eliminate the United States Supreme Court's ''exclusionary rule'' in this state.

title: DANCE: MISS BENITEZ'S SPANISH TROUPE
description: THE program presented by the Maria Benitez Estampa Flamenca on Tuesday at the City Center's The Space, under the auspices of the Dance Umbrella festival, wasn't at all the familiar Spanish dance concert. Miss Benitez is typically fiery and exotic in an earthy way. She is accompanied by two predictably sensuous male dancers, a singer and a guitarist. But the 11 dances she presented were not at all the expected survey of Spanish dance forms. Their influence was evident, as were the stylized expressions of passion, the proud, arched backs and the beautifully articulated foot beats of traditional Spanish dance. But Miss Benitez has made of these elements her own brand of generalized contemporary Spanish concert dance.

title: OHIO STANDARD UP, INDIANA STANDARD OFF
description: First-quarter earnings of the nation's major oil companies, as reflected in three reports released yesterday, appear to be living up to earlier projections that the spectacular profits gains of recent years could not be sustained.

title: OF STOOPS AND STEPS, SALONS OF THE STREET
description: The way our porch looked in winter was the way they all looked: tarpaulin on the glider, wicker chairs turned to face and lean on the wall, a few snow-coned flower pots. In late April, but never earlier because spring is elusive in New England, the tarp was taken to the attic, the chairs were righted and windowsill plants were carried out for sunbaths.

title: MEDICAID TAKEOVER AT HEART OF CAREY-ANDERSON IMPASSE
description: At the center of the squalls generated by the Senate majority leader and Governor Carey over the state budget, now 22 days late, stands the issue of Medicaid, the expensive healthcare program for the poor.

title: NAMIBIA PLAN GAINS AT TALKS IN LONDON
description: Five Western governments made substantial progress at a meeting here today toward formulating new proposals for the independence of South-West Africa, diplomatic sources reported.

title: UNITED ARAB EMIRATES WILL BUY 30 MILITARY PLANES FROM BRITAIN
description: The United Arab Emirates told Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher today that it would purchase British training aircraft that can also be used for ground support attacks.

title: Young & Rubicam Shift
description: James H. Cobb, a senior vice president and management supervisor at Young & Rubicam and a 17-year veteran of the agency, is transferring out to Kansas City, Mo., to become president of Y.&R.'s Brewer Advertising. He is 55, as is Richard W. Dodderidge, the chap he is replacing. Mr. Dodderidge, who has spent 35 years with Brewer and nine years as its president, will remain on the Brewer board.

title: SHOW HOUSES
description: Designer show houses in New Jersey and Pennsylvania and on Long Island are also open for spring fund raising. April 27-May 31. ''Welwyn,'' the site of Designer Showcase '81, is a Georgian-style country estate in Glen Cove, L.I., that stretches over 200 acres of woodlands, sweeping lawns and boxwood gardens. This 35-room waterfront mansion on Crescent Beach Road will showcase the talents of more than 30 of the foremost interior designers in the metropoliltan area. Proceeds from the monthlong event will benefit the Family Service Association of Nassau County.

title: CHICAGO IS PUZZLED BY CHARGE THAT AIDE WAS BUGGED
description: Chicago is accustomed to the politics of the unusual, if not the bizarre. When Mayor Jane M. Byrne, at the end of March, moved into the Cabrini-Green housing project, a violence-scarred, predominantly black project, aficionados of politics, Chicago style, whatever their interpretation of her motives, smiled and applauded her act as bold and innovative.

title: DANCE: DANA REITZ PERFORMS
description: What helps make the choreography of Dana Reitz so remarkable is its protean nature. Just as one thinks one has perceived the basic shape of a movement, that movement immediately becomes something else. Miss Reitz's choreography is a choreography of perpetual metamorphosis.

title: Cooney Exhibition Is Attacked
description: John Condon, president of Madison Square Garden's boxing department, attacked Gerry Cooney yesterday for planning to fight a four-round exhibition match Sunday in Canton, Ohio.

title: A JUDGE ASSAILS COUNSEL FOR CITY IN DAMAGE CASE
description: A trial judge in the Bronx has accused the office of the New York City Corporation Counsel of ''atrocious conduct'' and a ''gross miscarriage of justice'' in the defense of a million-dollar lawsuit that charges the city with malicious prosecution.

title: Sadat to Visit the Sudan
description: President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt is to visit the Sudan next month, his first trip to an Arab nation since Egypt's peace with Israel in March 1979, the Sudanese news agency reported today.

title: The Region; State University Fees To Rise $150 a Year
description: ALBANY (AP) - The State University Board of Trustees voted to raise undergraduate tuition at 29 campuses by $150, to $1,050 a year.

title: Spot TV Ads Up in '80
description: The Broadcast Advertisers Reports, independent tabulators of television advertising activity, reported that national spot television advertising rose 13.2 percent last year over 1979 to $2.5 billion. The Television Bureau of Advertising, which released the data, said that the spending was done by 2,598 companies to promote 10,612 brands.

title: AROUND THE WORLD
description: The Greek Government today rejected a Turkish protest over an anti-Turkish demonstration by Armenians living here. A spokesman for the Foreign Ministry said the contents of the Greek reply would not be made public but that Athens regarded the protest as ''unjustified.''

title: Bridge: Becker's Brilliance in Como In '58 Title Match Recalled
description: Casual conversations sometimes change lives. B. Jay Becker, whose Vanderbilt victory last month at the age of 76 set a new age record for that famous event, was managing the New York Bridge Whist Club in 1950. To one of the members, a quiet man known as ''Gorty,'' he mentioned that he was interested in writing about the game.

description: In India, there's a protest for every occasion A2 Dozens killed and wounded in Bei- rut fighting A3 United Arab Emirates will buy British military aircraft A4 Around the World A5 U.N. delegates stage walkout at Namibia debate A6 Member of Soviet Politburo criti- cizes U.S. on arms linkage A6 New Namibia plan gains at Lon- don talks A7 Decision to end curb on grain sales to Soviet reported near A11 East Germans renew criticism of events in Poland A14 Poles charge West exaggerated size of Pact maneuvers A15 Government/Politics How reapportionment affects one Senator in New Jersey B2 General Around the Nation A16 Anchorage and New York among costliest U.S. cities, report says A16 Chicago puzzled by school aide's charges that she was bugged A17 Some Cuban refugees finding U.S. a land of opportunity B3 More brain surgery is ordered for B13< Health/Science Doctors divided on symptoms and cure of toxic shock syndrome A20 Education/Welfare Catholic educators hear attack on tuition tax-credit plans B10 Features/Notes Issue and Debate: Deeming when life begins and abortions stop B9 Notes on People C20 News Analysis Tony Schwartz discusses ethics of investigative reporting on TV C20 Home Section Home Kips Bay show house: Contrasts and flourishes C1

title: The City; The Police Blotter
description: More than three dozen people were treated for irritations caused by gas fumes that seeped from a basement of a five-story apartment building at 1770 East 172d Street in the Parkchester section of the Bronx. Five persons were held for observation at the Bronx Municipal Hospital Center. ... A teen-age boy was being sought after the clothes of two 50-year-old sleeping passengers were set afire aboard an IND F subway train near the Carroll Street Station in the Prospect Park section of Brooklyn. One passenger, Carmelo Martinez, was burned on the arm, while the other, Abraham Simmons, escaped injury.

title: 2,500 British Air Traffic Workers Vote to Begin 5-Week Job Action
description: About 2,500 British air traffic controllers seeking higher pay voted today to start five weeks of disruptive action next Monday.

title: NEW OIL FUTURES MARKET BOOMS
description: Since the first price for heating oil futures contracts was shouted on the floor of the International Petroleum Exchange's headquarters in Cereal House, Mark Lane, in the heart of London's financial district, business has been better than the most optimistic forcasts.

title: IN INDIA, THERE'S A DEMONSTRATION FOR ANY OCCASION
description: Just as Eskimos have more than a hundred words for snow and Arabs have dozens of expressions for sand, so it is entirely fitting that people in India have many ways of saying demonstration.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article yesterday about a group of constitutional scholars who criticized proposed legislation to ban abortion omitted one member and incorrectly identified another. The group included Prof. Paul Brest of Stanford University Law School. Erwin N. Griswold, now a Washington lawyer, is a former dean of Harvard Law School.

title: RANGERS HALTED, 4-3, AS BLUES FIGHT BACK
description: The Rangers failed to clinch a position in the National Hockey League semifinal playoffs tonight, losing to the St. Louis Blues, 4-3, after giving up a two-goal second-period lead.

title: Jersey Post for Coghlan
description: Eamonn Coghlan, one of the world's leading middle distance runners, will serve as an indoor track consultant to the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority. Coghlan will be an adviser at the Meadowlands Arena, which will host the Vitalis-United States Olympic Invitational Track Meet next January.

title: Scali, McCabe, Sloves
description: Scali, McCabe, Sloves is the new agency for Showtime Entertainment, suppliers of Showtime programming to cable system operators.

title: Turner Broadcasting Gets General Foods Advertising
description: In what could be the biggest advertising deal on cable television so far, General Foods yesterday signed a $40 million contract with the Turner Broadcasting System, Atlanta, to advertise on its WTBS Super Station. The advertiser refused to say how long the contract would run.

title: Bottle Strikes Pitcher in Eye
description: Dennis Martinez, Baltimore pitcher, was struck above the right eye with a beer bottle thrown by a spectator at Comiskey Park before tonight's scheduled game between the Orioles and the White Sox was rained out.

title: The U.N. Today; April 23, 1981; SECURITY COUNCIL
description: Meets on Namibia at 11 A.M. GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Canada Ties Soviet, 4-4, In World Title Hockey
description: Mike Gartner scored midway in the third period to give Canada a 4-4 tie with the Soviet Union tonight in the world hockey championships.

title: TOP WEST BERLIN COURT REINSTATES CONVICTION IN 1913 REICHSTAG FIRE
description: West Berlin's highest court today reversed an earlier decision that had posthumosly acquitted Marinus van der Lubbe, a Dutchman, of involvement in the 1933 burning of the Reichstag.

title: CALENDAR OF EVENTS: A BENEFIT BOOK SALE
description: Friends of the 67th Street Library Book Sale, 328 East 67th Street.

title: SCIENTESTS DIVIDED ON THE SYMPTOMS AND CURE OF TOXIC SHOCK SYNDROME
description: As scientists reportedly draw closer to isolating the agent in the bacterium Staphylococcus aureus that causes toxic shock syndrome, they remain divided as to what the spectrum of symptoms may be, what women may do to minimize the risk of getting the disease and what the best treatment may be.

title: NORTH CAROLINA FUND PLAN AIDS LOCAL HOME MARKET
description: North Carolina introduced a landmark financing yesterday that will enable the state's pension funds to channel more funds into the local housing market.

title: Honesty and Grace in City Hall
description: Nobody should call Mayor Koch dishonest because, long after his election, his 1977 campaign committee sold about $13,000 in benefit tickets to police organizations, a practice the State Board of Elections deems to be forbidden by the election laws. But what people might call Mr. Koch is graceless.

title: EAST GERMANY, SWITCHING COURSE, RENEWS CRITICISM OF EVENTS IN POLAND
description: Just a few days after party leaders here signaled their confidence in Poland's ability to solve its own problems, the East Germans today renewed their attacks on counterrevolutionaries and said the situation in Poland had worsened again.

title: The Region; Mayors Threatened On Drought Plans
description: The mayors of 24 communities can be sent to jail unless they submit plans describing how they would distribute water if their water systems failed, state authorities said.

title: BRADY HAS SURGERY FOR BRAIN PRESSURE
description: James S. Brady, the White House press secretary who was shot in the head three weeks ago in the attempt to assassinate President Reagan, underwent nearly six hours of cranial surgery last night after his doctors discovered that an air leak was putting pressure on his brain.

title: BEIRUT STRIFE LEAVES 23 DEAD, STREETS EMPTY
description: Twenty-three people were reported killed here today in fighting between Syrian and Christian forces and in gun battles between factions of Moslems.

title: PAPER'S FALSE ARTICLE IS A MAJOR TOPIC AT A CONVENTION ON NEWSPAPER EDITORS
description: Benjamin C. Bradlee, executive editor of The Washington Post, went before fellow newspaper editors today to explain and defend his newspaper's handling of what turned out to be a fabricated article about an 8-year-old heroin user.

title: STATE REDISTRICTING POSES PERIL TO SOME LEGISLATORS
description: When the map makers finished drawing new district lines for the New Jersey Legislature this month, they separated the patrons of Eddie Harrington's candy store from their favorite State Senator.

title: Japan Oil Imports Fall
description: Spurred by the Government's energy substitution program, Japan's petroleum imports in the fiscal year ended in March dropped 10.1 percent from the previous year, official figures released today showed.

title: CIVIL LIBERTARIAN WINS $400,00 IN SUIT FOR LIBEL
description: A jury here awarded $400,000 in damages today to a prominent civil libertarian in the retrial of a 12-year-old libel case that became a constitutional landmark in 1974.

title: DETERMINING WHEN LIFE BEGINS AND ABORTIONS STOP
description: Nine years after the Supreme Court ruled that women have a constitutional right to an abortion in at least the first three months of pregnancy, a highly emotional Congressional battle is shaping up over efforts to bypass the Court's decision.

title: PAINFUL COMPARISON WITH THE HOLOCAUST
description: To the Editor:

title: Trackman, Struck on Head By Hammer, Dies of Injury
description: John Tucker, a 24-year-old track star who was critically injured Saturday when he was hit by an errant hammer throw during warmups for the Illinois Classic track and field meet, died last night.

title: Notes on People; Saroyan in Hospital Recovering From Stroke
description: ''I'm here, I have been all the intervening years,'' says William Saroyan's entry in Who's Who in America. Yesterday the 72-year-old author was reported hanging in gamely following a stroke that felled him Monday at his home in Fresno, Calif.

title: Accounts
description: * Velcro USA Inc. to Grey, Conahy & Lyon.

title: IT'S NOT MACHIAVELLIAN TO OPEN YOUNG MINDS
description: To the Editor:

title: 27 FELLOWS INVOLVED WTH NURSING HOMES
description: Twenty-seven persons who have been convicted of felonies continue to operate or receive revenue from nursing homes in New York State because of legal requirements that allow hearings and court appeals in state efforts to displace them.

title: ROTHMANS TIE TO PHILIP MORRIS SET
description: Philip Morris Inc. announced yesterday that it had agreed to buy a large stake in Rothmans International Ltd. in a transaction valued at $350 million, beating out its archrival in the United States, R.J. Reynolds Industries, which was also after Rothmans.

title: Books of the Times
description: By John Leonard MIDNIGHT'S CHILDREN. By Salman Ru- shdie. 446 pages. Knopf. $13.95.

title: Field of 10 in Blue Grass
description: A trace of heresy has reared its head in this horsy locale, where nearly everything, from the local truss company to the artificial-limb company to the finance company, is named Blue Grass. Proud Appeal, the Florida-bred colt whose racing home has been New York, is the likely favorite tomorrow over Kentucky-bred Tap Shoes at Keeneland.

title: Tenneco Gas Yields
description: Tenneco Inc. said it had started production from two new platforms in the Gulf of Mexico, moving 95 million cubic feet of natural gas daily through its Tennesee Gas Pipeline Company division.

title: QUEST MAGAZINE PUT UP FOR SALE BY WORLDWIDE CHURCH GROUP
description: Some three months after its top editors resigned in a dispute over editorial interference from its owners, Quest magazine has been put up for sale by the Ambassador International Cultural Foundation.

title: JAZZ: KAI WINDING AT SWEET BASIL
description: born trombonist who made his first major impression in jazz as the lustiest of Stan Kenton's braying trombonists in the late 40's and later teamed with J.J. Johnson in the trombone duo known as Jay and Kai, is making his first club appearance in New York in almost a decade this week (through Saturday) at Sweet Basil.

title: A Windfall Falls
description: Connecticut's cities and towns are continually engaged in a tug-ofwar over formulas for dividing state education aid. Until this year, it turns out, the poorer central cities have been unwitting winners over their more affluent neighbors.

title: Going Out Guide
description: HOW TO CHARM SNAKES

title: The City; G.M. Plans to Sell Fifth Ave. Building
description: The General Motors Corporation announced yesterday that it was putting the 50-story white marble General Motors Building at 767 Fifth Avenue on sale. However, the company will keep its corporate offices in the building.

title: DECISION TO END SOVIET GRAIN SALE CURB REPORTED NEAR
description: The Reagan Administration was reported tonight to be close to a decision to lift restrictions on grain sales to the Soviet Union in stages, according to White House officials.

title: ARE WE DEMEANING LIFE'S VALUE
description: To the Editor:

title: NL GAINS 63% AND AVON, 5.9%
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation, one of the nation's largest producers of data-processing equipment, reported yesterday that net income in the third quarter of its fiscal year, ended March 28, soared 49.8 percent on an increase in revenues of 35.3 percent.

title: REAGAN TELLS OF INITIAL PAIN AND PANIC AFTER BEING SHOT
description: President Reagan, in his first public discussion of the attempt on his life last month, recounted today how an initial feeling that he had not been hit by the gunfire gave way to ''the most paralyzing pain'' and then a sense of panic over being unable to breathe.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Aluminum Corporation of America is selling $250 million in 7 percent debentures at a price of $48.362 to yield 14.7 percent at maturity in 2001 through an underwriting group managed by the First Boston Corporation.

title: Some Refining Units Shut Down by Arco
description: Reacting to the current oversupply of oil products, the Atlantic Richfield Company, the nation's ninth-largest oil producer and refiner, said it had closed unneeded crude oil distillation units at its Philadelphia and Houston refineries, reducing its total crude refining capacity to an average of 741,000 barrels a day from the 1980 average of 826,000 barrels, for a production cut of almost 10 percent.

title: SHUTOUT HIS 3D
description: Unbeaten Fernando Valenzuela scattered seven hits en route to his fourth victory and third shutout of the season and drove in a run with a single as Los Angeles beat the Astros, 1-0, tonight.

title: THE OLD RAIN BARREL MAKES A COMEBACK
description: ONCE upon a time, before water ran in pipes, people used barrels to collect rain as it slipped off their roofs. Now, when scarcity renews our appreciation of rain, people are regarding their downspouts with new respect. For even when a small amount of rain eases the drought, good quantities of water can be tapped for later use in watering gardens, lawns and, in a severe arid spell, cooking and drinking.

title: U.S. Steel to Build With Customer Help
description: The United States Steel Corporation said that it would finance construction of a 600,000-ton seamless-pipe mill through an arrangement in which part of the money would be put up by customers for the mill, which would be built and operated by the nation's largest steel company.

title: Union Carbide Plans $1 Billion in Outlays
description: The Union Carbide Corporation, which earlier this week reported that its first-quarter profits fell 59.3 percent, announced that it plans to spend more than $1 billion on capital projects this year including funds redeployed from its divestiture program. Last year the company spent about $1.1 billion on capital projects.

title: Arizona Bank Is Robbed
description: Of About $2.5 Million

title: Stocks Gain a Bit; Dow Up 1.08
description: The stock market overcame interest-rate jitters yesterday to push slightly higher with airline and brokerage-house issues leading the way. Selected high-technology stocks also posted gains.

title: 317 Vietnamese Refugees Saved By U.S. Navy Ships in 24 Hours
description: An American destroyer today picked up 71 Vietnamese refugees from a boat drifting in the South China Sea, bringing to 317 the number of refugees rescued by United States Navy ships in the last 24 hours, a Navy spokesman said.

title: SHOEMAKER TO RIDE CURE THE BLUES IN DERBY
description: Bill Shoemaker, who has ridden three Kentucky Derby winners, will ride Cure the Blues in the Derby May 2, LeRoy Jolley, the colt's trainer, announced at his Belmont Park barn yesterday.

title: News of Music; 2 HALLS TO CO-PRODUCE 4- CONCERT SERIES
description: CARNEGIE HALL and Lincoln Center, genteel and amicable rivals for New York music audiences since the latter's opening 15 years ago, will co-produce a series of four concerts next season. The players for this unprecedented cooperative venture will be the St. Paul Chamber Orchestra under its new music director, Pinchas Zukerman, with Itzhak Perlman, violinist, and Erie Mills, soprano, as soloists. The music is by Mozart, and the programs will include his complete works for violin and orchestra.

title: Kuwait in Hawaiian Energy Venture
description: Pacific Resources Inc., a Honolulu-based company, and the Kuwait Petroleum Corporation, a company owned by the Government of Kuwait, have formed a joint venture to pursue energy-related activities, mainly in the Pacific Basin area.

title: TO THE HOME SECTION: It is so easy to imply that ''pro-lifers'' care nothing for the quality of the lives of unhappily pregnant women, but Mary Kay Blakely would do well to research the extensive damage done psychologically to women who have had abortions. Guilt is carried for the rest of their lives, and present for good reason. It has nothing to do with morality. Abortion is so clearly an abominable assault on natural law that guilt is an instinctual reaction.
description: The facts are that abortion has led to flippant moral decisions.

title: Utah Senator Reproves Environmental Agency
description: Saying he was ''sick and tired of bureaucracy,'' Senator Jake Garn threatened today to make drastic cuts in funds for the Environmental Protection Agency if it did not go easier on business and industry.

title: Kimber Smith, a Painter Of 'Lyrical' Abstractions
description: Kimber Smith, an Abstract Expressionist painter, died on Tuesday in Southampton (L.I.) Hospital. He was 59 years old and lived in East Hampton, L.I.

title: BALLET: TAYLOR'S 'AIRS' AND 'SYLPHIDES'
description: American Ballet Theater's second program at the Metropolitan Opera House Tuesday night again stressed those aspects that its new director, Mikhail Baryshnikov, is bringing to the fore this season. It was an evening of exclusively plotless ballet, and the accent was on ensemble work. Nonetheless, there were definite and even exciting novelties.

title: German Strike Specter
description: An estimated one million metalworkers in West Germany staged warning strikes today as union and industry negotiators met in an effort to break a deadlock in wage talks and avert a nationwide walkout.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Airborne Freight Corporation, Seattle, has named Tom Rooney vice president-Europe.

title: Wall St. Journal Magazine Sample Set for Research
description: Dow Jones is moving steadily toward a magazine to complement its flagship publication, The Wall Street Journal. And it has just printed 15,000 copies of a slick-looking prototype of The Wall Street Journal Magazine that will primarily be used for extensive reader research over the next few months.

title: Home Beat
description: THE statues came from the movie-studio properties shop in Rome complete with fig leaves, as did the torso that found its place on the mantel of the Florentine room, one of the new model rooms opening today on Bloomingdale's fifth floor. The classical statues are only one of the entertaining tours de force by Fred Palatinus, the store's director of furniture design and presentation.

title: Balboni Sparks Yankees
description: Steve Balboni, who speaks softly when he speaks at all, carried his big stick to the major leagues last night, and walloped a triple in his first time at bat. It was his third time at bat, though, that decided the game.

title: LEFTISTS IN BERKELEY LOSE CONTROL OF THE CITY COUNCIL TO MODERATES'
description: The political tilt to the right manifested by the election of Ronald Reagan as President and the defeat of leading liberal United States senators last year has shown up at the grass roots in this city that is almost a synonym for radicalism.

title: 2 Americans Among 6 Dead In Sinking of Nile Tour Boat
description: A Nile tourist vessel ran aground yesterday in a rain storm and sank, causing the death of six persons and injury to 12, a Cairo official said today.

title: YOUTH BATTLE TROOPS IN FIVE CITIES IN NORTHERN IRELAND
description: Groups of youths battled British troops and the police in Londonderry, Belfast and three other cities today after an emotional funeral for two teenagers killed in disturbances Sunday in Londonderry.

title: Technology; Complexities Cloud Interferon
description: INTERFERON, which is naturally produced by the body in minute quantities, is believed to fight cancer and such viruses as rabies, hepatitis, shingles and herpes. Some have called it the potential ''silver bullet'' in the war on cancer.

title: Nuclear Accident Exercise Is Held in Nevada Desert
description: The fictional hamlet of Wahmonie, Calif., was blanketed today with emergency teams acting out a nuclear accident.

title: ANCHORAGE MOST COSTLY U.S. CITY FOR TYPICAL FAMILY ,STUDY FINDS
description: A survey of major American cities shows that Anchorage, Honolulu, Boston, New York and Washington are the costliest places for a family of four to maintain a moderate standard of living, the Labor Department said today.

title: CHILDREN'S ADS V. QUEBEC
description: The authorities in Quebec have taken a toymaker to court after he tried to sell ''Strawberry Shortcake'' dolls to little girls.

title: FLORENCE JOSEPH
description: Florence Joseph, a psychoanalyst and social worker who was long a director of the National Psychological Association for Psychoanalysis, died yesterday at her Manhattan home. Mrs. Joseph would have observed her 81st birthday today.

title: HOUSE OPENS DRUG HEARING ON COAST
description: Despite press releases that the House Select Committee on Narcotics Abuse and Control would focus ''on drug abuse in the Hollywood entertainment industry,'' the committee opened two days of hearings here today by getting an overview from state and Federal officials on California's prominence as a leading marijuanaproducing and drug-consuming state.
