title: Rights Leader Says CORE May Arrest Atlanta Killer
description: Roy Innis, chairman of the Congress of Racial Equality, said today that he believed he knew who was responsible for the slayings of at least six of Atlanta's young blacks and vowed that if the police did not make the arrest within 72 hours his group would do so.

title: TO THE HOME SECTION: Mary Kay Blakely's piece on abortion is one of the best I've read.  She has done us all a service by putting the positions so clearly.  SUSAN ANTHONY
description: Manhattan

title: Dowell and Godunov Hurt, Off Ballet Bills
description: Because of a foot injury, Anthony Dowell has been forced to cancel his appearances with the American Ballet Theater, which has just opened at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: NIGHTMARE BROUGHT TO LIFE
description: Two months before the Rev. Jim Jones took his followers to their gruesome end in 1978, Jonestown had a visitor from the United States who praised the settlement and its paranoid leader. People in the United States knew there had to be a better way of life, he said, ''and it is here.''

title: U.S. SAYS SAUDI DEAL WILL NOT ENDANGER SECURITY OF ISRAELIS
description: The Reagan Administration, faced with a critical reaction from Israel and its American supporters, pledged today that it remained ''firmly committed'' to Israel's security and contended that the proposed sale of military equipment to Saudi Arabia did not endanger the Israelis.

title: U.S. Said to Press for Inquiry Into El Salvador Killings
description: The United States will continue to press El Salvador to investigate the murder of four American missionaries, Roman Catholic Church officials said today.

title: What Reagan Compromise?
description: The President meant what he said when he got out of the hospital: no, he has not made any deals to compromise his economic program, and he has no plan to do so.

title: TO THE HOME SECTION: In my professional life as a social worker in the city's settlement houses in Brownsville and on the Lower East Side, I have met many women who had to choose between painful and shameful alternatives through no fault of their own. Many risked health and life at the hands of unqualified, illegal abortionists.
description: Thank you for printing Mary Kay Blakely's column. Her passionate and beautifully written article defends a woman's right to life. MILDRED BRODY Rockville Centre, L.I.

title: MERRICK IN CLASH OVER OPENING OF PLAYS
description: David Merrick announced yesterday that he would open Oliver Hailey's new play, ''I Won't Dance,'' on May 10 at the Helen Hayes Theater. May 10 also happens to be the opening-night date of another new Broadway play, Renee Taylor and Joseph Bologna's ''It Had to Be You,'' at the Golden Theater.

title: E.P.A. DIESEL STANDARDS UPHELD
description: A Federal appeals court, rejecting arguments from both the automobile industry and environmentalists, today upheld the Environmental Protection Agency's proposed pollution standards for vehicles that have diesel engines.

title: TIRED OF LAWN MOWING? RENT A SHEEP, ONLY $35
description: A former New York City transit policeman who was tired of mowing the lawn has come up with a better way of keeping his yard trimmed and wants to share his plan with other homeowners. Louis R. Valente will rent a sheep for the summer for $35.

title: Q&A
description: Q. The porcelain in my kitchen sink is worn out and has long dark scratches on the surface. Clorox won't whiten it anymore. To avoid buying a new sink, is there a paint that can be used that will make the sink white again? - B.C., Philadelphia.

title: News Analysis
description: This week WBBM-TV, the CBS-owned station in Chicago, broadcast a hard-hitting documentary that raised questions about certain controversial techniques of investigative reporting on television, including selective editing, the confrontation interview, undercover reporting and the preoccupation with dramatic pictures at the potential expense of accuracy and fairness.

title: TO THE HOME SECTION: ''Do they really agonize enough?'' asks an unknown Midwestern priest of women who choose abortion. (''Hers,'' Mary Kay Blakely, April 9). Yes, we do agonize. I personally have agonized for three years. I have not gone a week in those three years without wondering if I was right, if my child would have been a boy or girl, if he would have had blue eyes. I cannot see a 3-year-old without asking myself if I have the right to study at a private university while his mother pushes a stroller and lives on welfare. The answer is always yes.
description: My decision was not a flippant one nor was it painless.

title: By Sports of The Times; Yanks' Johnny Oates Is in Good Spot
description: IN the hours before Tommy John starts for the Yankees against the Toronto Blue Jays tonight, Johnny Oates will stop at the pitcher's locker for perhaps 15 minutes.

title: Rep. Winn Guilty in Driving Case
description: Representative Larry Winn Jr., Republican of Kansas, pleaded guilty today to a charge of driving while intoxicated and under the influence of prescription drugs. The 61-year-old Representative entered his plea in Douglas County District Court and paid a $175 fine and court costs. He was also placed on probation for the term of a 30-day jail sentence.

title: KIPS BAY SHOW HOUSE: CONTRASTS AND FLOURISHES
description: NEITHER late deliveries, un-upholstered chairs nor the late cold snap that kept the white doves away deterred the decorators from the completion of their appointed rooms - and the Kips Bay Boys' Club Decorator Show House opened on schedule yesterday. And, as usual when designers are asked to decorate a house to benefit a charity, there was a magical quality in the transformation of empty spaces into rooms completed down to the last detail. Nineteen of the city's interior design firms participated.

title: PIANO RECITAL: BYRON JANIS
description: When music is not allowed to breathe on its own, when its lines pulse with an imposed eccentricity and its drama is appropriated with disregard for sense, a hypnotic world can still be created if the musician himself is arrogant enough and forceful enough to make his will as interesting as the music's.

title: Five Tornadoes Strike Missouri,
description: Injuring More Than 30 Persons By United Press International

title: The City; A Rival for Koch
description: Jim Smith, a Brooklyn man who owns a printing shop in lower Manhattan, announced that he would seek the Democratic nomination for Mayor. ''I'm a bit of a novice here, but I'm not afraid of taking on the Mayor,'' Mr. Smith, who is 33 years old, said as he stood on the steps of City Hall.

title: INA Reports Gain
description: The INA Corporation, which owns the Insurance Company of North America, reported yesterday that its first-quarter operating income rose to $68.5 million, or $1.70 a share, from $64.3 million, or $1.66 a share, a year earlier. Revenues climbed to $1.4 billion from $1.2 billion.

title: Executive Movements In the Interpublic Group
description: James D. Kuras, 41, a senior vice president of the Interpublic Group of Companies, parent of McCann-Erickson, is moving over to be executive vice president and general manager of the New York office of McCann. He replaces Stephen W. Norcia, 40, who will move to Interpublic until he is assigned to another agency in the group.

title: 2 PUBLISHERS CABLE BID ADVANCES
description: Rebuffing a higher offer for a portion of the shares, the board of UA-Columbia Cablevision Inc. approved a definitive agreement yesterday that brings the fast-growing cable company a step closer to being acquired by Dow Jones & Company and Knight-Ridder Newspapers Inc.

title: CHAIRMAN IS NAMED AT NATIONAL STEEL
description: Howard M. Love, 51 years old, has been named chairman of the National Steel Corporation, succeeding George A. Stinson, 66, who retired from the nation's third-largest steel producer. Mr. Love will remain president and chief executive officer.

title: CHAMBER CONCERT: THE NEW YORK WOODWIND QUINTET
description: The tone of the New York Woodwind Quintet had a bright precision about it at the Abraham Goodman House on April 13. Donald MacCourt's bassoon and Ronald Roseman's oboe provided the reedy texture, with glints of metallic thrust from William Purvis's horn and Samuel Baron's flute; David Glazer's clarinet was at the center of the spectrum, merging the woods with the metals.

title: N.H.L. LISTS SEMIFINAL DATES
description: The National Hockey League's semifinal playoff series will begin Sunday or Tuesday, depending on the outcome of the quarterfinals, the league said yesterday.

title: GREEN REVOLUTION II: $
description: There is a new Green Revolution coming to America, and its promises are many and high-sounding. We are told that a dazzling new cornucopia of miracle crops and genetically engineered substances will set farmers free of expensive fertilizers, yield cheap and abundant foods, and enable the United States to feed the world's hungry. Last month, Forbes magazine proclaimed ''Green Revolution II'' the growth industry of the 1980's. Indeed, this new agri-genetic revolution has turned the head of Wall Street and big business.

title: CATHOLIC EDUCATORS TOLD TAX-CREDIT PLAN WOULD ENDANGER FREEDOMS
description: Tuition tax credits for families sending children to private schools would open the door to Government regulation of those schools, a spokesman for public schools told the annual convention of the National Catholic Educational Association yesterday.

title: ANALYSTS SPLIT ON RATE DIRECTION
description: Interest rates were little changed yesterday while analysts remain sharply divided between those expecting interest rates to increase and those expecting them to decline.

title: An Appraisal
description: Everyone knows that the World Trade Center is taller, and that the Chrysler Building has that extraordinary Art Deco top. But somehow the Empire State Building remains the most glamorous symbol of the tall building New York has ever seen.

title: SPRING CREDIT FLOW AWAITS ALBANY THAW
description: To the Editor:

title: A WESTWAY TRADE-IN IS NO WAY TO HELP MASS TRANSIT
description: To the Editor:

title: Design Notebook; BONWIT TELLER: LIVELY INTERIOR ON 57TH STREET.
description: WHEN the new Bonwit Teller store on East 57th Street was still abuilding, it was covered by a seven-story-high billboard bearing the store's celebrated trademark of purple violets. Such a huge sign might ordinarily seem to be a vulgar commercial intrusion on genteel 57th Street, but somehow this sign was special - it was a breath of fresh air and color on the street, a surprise element at enormous scale that enlivened its entire block.

title: The Cityz; 2 Policemen Seized As Bribe-Takers
description: Acting on information provided by another police officer, authorities arrested two New York City policemen on charges that they had demanded and had taken payoffs from an alleged West Side policy operator.

title: Trout & Reis Campaign
description: Trout & Reis Advertising, Western Union's agency, has been assigned to do the first campaign for its telex service, a $300 million business never advertised before. There is a $1.5 million budget that will put ads about ''The most underpriced message service in the world'' into The Wall Street Journal and trade publications.

title: Flyers 9, Flames 4
description: Brian Propp scored three goals in a span of just over eight minutes during the opening period tonight as the Philadelphia Flyers routed the Calgary Flames, 9-4, to remain alive in their quarterfinal series.

title: SOME CUBANS FINDING U.S. A GOOD LAND
description: Nearly a year ago, seasick in a 40-foot lobster boat in the crossing of Cuban refugees from Mariel to Key West, Gaspar Fernandez spoke hopefully of the opportunities for him in the United States.

title: Marshall Islanders Sue U.S.  For Atomic Test Injuries
description: Hundreds of Marshall Islanders sued the United States today for injuries and damages that they said were caused by 12 years of atomic testing in the United Statesadministered archipelago in the Western Pacific.

title: Market Place; SCM: Growth In Book Value
description: THE SCM Corporation, the typewriter company that over the years has added Proctor Silex appliances, Durkee foods, Allied paper and Glidden paints and chemicals, has dismayed some shareholders with this diversity.

title: ENERGY CHIEF OULTINES APPROACH ON OIL RESERVE
description: Energy Secretary James B. Edwards indicated today that the Administration would soon choose a combination of methods, including the use of large amounts of Alaskan royalty oil, to fill the nation's Strategic Petroleum Reserve.

title: Kleindienst Denies Charges Of Perjury in Arizona Case
description: Richard G. Kleindienst, the former Attorney General accused of lying in an investigation of his dealings with a convicted swindler, pleaded not guilty today to 14 counts of perjury.

title: The City; L.I.R.R. Cars Derail
description: The last two cars of an eastbound Long Island Rail Road train derailed just beyond the station at Jamaica, Queens, at 5:30 P.M. yesterday, a railroad spokesman said.

title: Pitney-Bowes Deal
description: Pitney-Bowes Inc., a maker of postage meters and mailing systems, said it had made an agreement with the Ricoh Company Ltd., the largest maker of office copiers in Japan, to import and market a Ricoh medium-volume, table-top, drytone, plain-paper copier in North America. The copier is a compact desk-top type designed for customers who need an average of 8,000 to 12,000 copies a month. Pitney-Bowes said it will begin limited sales of the copier in September and will expand distribution throughout North America in the first quarter of 1982.

title: Thinking
description: Thinking something through is like untying a knot: You search for the start of the tangle, negotiate an occasional detour and finally emerge with a straight and single strand. But untying knots is a matter of touching - the fingertips probe for tension or the telltale slack - whereas thinking requires the mind alone.

title: Martin Taylor Is Dead; Expert on Constitution
description: Martin Taylor, an authority on constitutional law, died Tuesday at the Smithtown (L.I.) General Hospital. He was 95 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: AGENTS BEGIN SEIZING LIVESTOCK IN PRELUDE TO RELOCATING NAVAJOS
description: In a prelude to the resolution of a bitter century-old land dispute, the Bureau of Indian Affairs today began seizing livestock belonging to Navajo Indians living on land recently ceded by Congress to the rival Hopi tribe.

title: WILLIAMS DENIES EVER USING POWER FOR PROFIT
description: Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. took the witness stand at his trial on Abscam bribery charges yesterday and declared that at no time in his long public career had he tried to influence a Federal agency for his personal profit.

title: SUBMARINE SAID TO HAVE LEFT CRASH AREA BECAUSE SKIPPER SAW NOTHING AMISS
description: Naval and diplomatic reports on the collision of an American submarine and a Japanese freighter two weeks ago show that the submarine left the scene shortly after the accident because the American captain saw nothing amiss, Pentagon officials said today.

title: Notes on People; Anthony Quinn, 66, Dances On as He Marks Birthday
description: He was born in Mexico, lives in Italy and is perhaps best known for his portrayal of Zorba the Greek, but when it came time to celebrate his 66th birthday Tuesday night, Anthony Quinn found himself in New York and didn't seem to mind. Indeed, the actor seemed right at home during a party at the Sirocco restaurant and nightclub.

title: OFFER MADE FOR FIGI'S
description: The American Can Company has agreed to acquire Figi's Inc of Marshfield, Wis., a major mail-order distributor of cheese and other specialty foods with annual sales of $35 million.

title: SINGLE WOMEN AS HOMEOWNERS REFLECT FEMINIST GAINS
description: Nedra Sims, who makes $25,000 a year in an investment consulting concern, recently bought a condominium apartment on Chicago's South Side for $25,000. ''I bought it for investment, for a tax break and for the pleasure of owning a home,'' she said. ''I was sick of throwing money away on rent. I had no problem getting credit.''

title: KINGS WIN, TIE SERIES, 1-1
description: The Kansas City Kings, led by Reggie King's offense and a defense that held the Rockets to 31 points in the second half, defeated Houston 88-79, tonight. The victory evened the four-of-seven-game Western Conference championship series at one game apiece.

title: Ft. Benning Soldier Faces Inquiry In Slaying of Buffalo-Area Blacks
description: Two officers representing the Erie County District Attorney and the Buffalo and state police went to Fort Benning, Ga., today to question a soldier about the murders of seven black men in the Buffalo area since last September, a Buffalo police detective reported.

title: TO THE HOME SECTION: While it is true that there will be many situations in which abortion will seem to be the answer, nevertheless it ought to be seen as truly the death of an innocent human infant, even though unborn.
description: Is there then any reason, no matter how serious, to justify taking innocent human life? If we reject capital punishment, how can we justify for any reason, no matter how compassionate, the death of an innocent infant. MSGR. HENRY P. COSGROVE Our Lady of Lourdes Church

title: Margiotta Case Jury Retires for 2d Night
description: The jury in the mail-fraud and extortion trial of Joseph M. Margiotta, the Nassau County Republican chairman, recessed last night without reaching a verdict after 18 hours of deliberations over two days.

title: REAGAN NAMES 2 OVER OPPOSITION OF CONSERVATIVES
description: The White House nominated Thomas O. Enders today to be Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs over the opposition of Senator Jesse Helms.

title: METS RAINY NIGHT ENDS AT 2-2
description: The Mets and Pirates played for 2 hours 39 minutes tonight, then waited for 1 hour 29 minutes after a game-long rain became too intense. At that point - with the score tied, 2-2, and the Pirates prepared to bat in the bottom of the ninth - the umpires halted play for good, meaning that the game will have to be replayed from the beginning, but the team and individual records will count. No replay date was announced.

title: Critic's Notebook; EXOTIC WORKS ENLIVEN OPERATIC REPERTORY
description: Operatic repertory used to be depressingly predictable, but that's changing. Throughout the world in recent decades, there has been an ever-greater emphasis on unusual revivals. At first sight, this might seem all to the good. Our responsiveness to even the greatest masterpieces can be dulled by overfamiliarity, and there are surely lesser works by great composers and near-great works by lesser composers that we would all do well to encounter occasionally.

title: BIRTHDAY 'CANDLES' TO LIGHT JUBILEE FOR EMPIRE STATE CELEBRATING HALF A CENTURY
description: It is still, after 50 years, one of the most dazzling views in the world. To look down from the 86th-floor terrace of the Empire State Building is to see the mighty city as if in a dream - the streets shorn of all shabbiness, the noises muted, the rivers glistening and the beginnings of an ocean far off in the distance. Never mind that the World Trade Center is taller. It just enhances the view.

title: U.S. ARMS AND ANGOLA
description: The Administration has asked Congress to repeal its statutory restriction against providing covert military assistance to internal factions in Angola. The law, enacted in 1976, was recommended unanimously by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee and passed overwhelmingly in both houses of Congress. Angola had required a commitment too large to remain a secret, and Congress determined that any further aid should be openly sought and openly debated.

title: TO THE HOME SECTION: Yes, the abortion decision is the ''most profoundly personal decision of a lifetime,'' but, whose decision - and whose life?  We cannot solve our socio-economic problems by taking life. We worry about the pain of young seals being clubbed to death, but nary a word about fetuses being cut to pieces or burned alive by a saline solution.  MARION TUTTLE
description: Ringwood, N.J.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Asarco Inc. expects to spend about $200 million in 1982, compared with $150 million in capital expenditures this year.

title: Hers
description: THE two boys were several feet ahead of me, these affable escorts leading the way to the park. I'd been reluctant to take a break from the work I was doing, but the day, and the boys, were a compelling distraction.

title: Norwegian Sets Record In Penn Relays Decathlon
description: Gudmond Olsen, a senior at Mount St. Mary's College in Emmitsburg, Md., and a native of Norway, used a strong second-day performance to set a Penn Relays record of 7,823 points today in winning the decathlon competition. Olsen broke the record of 7,821 points set by Ron Evans of Connecticut in 1973.

title: Books of The Times
description: It is impossible to resist a novel that contains the sentence ''My sister the Brass Monkey developed the curious habit of setting fire to shoes.'' Or one that will pause to observe, as it considers an unhappy India, ''Sacred cows eat anything.'' According to ''Midnight's Children,'' guilt is a fog, optimism is a disease, freedom is a myth, fried spiders cure blindness and ''Gandhi will die at the wrong time.'' Nevertheless, Salman Rushdie chortles.

title: ISRAEL EXPRESSES 'PROFOUND REGRET' OVER PLAN TO SELL AWACS TO SAUDIS
description: Israel today protested the Reagan Administration's decision to supply sophisticated weapons, including Awacs electronic surveillance aircraft, to Saudi Arabia.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I don't think I'm going to hurdle any tables in the room here for a while.'' -President Reagan. (A1:2.)

title: Reynolds Metals Net Off 36.7%
description: The Reynolds Metals Company, the nation's second-largest aluminum manufacturer after the Aluminum Company of America, said yesterday that its first-quarter net income fell by 36.7 percent, to $33 million, or $1.69 a share, from $52.1 million, or $2.70 a share, in the same period last year.

title: 9 COUNCIL MEMBERS QUIT NAMIBIA DEBATE
description: The leaders of nine Security Council delegations walked out of a debate on the future of South-West Africa today as a representative of South Africa warned that his country would not take sanctions ''lying down.''

title: Stock Swap Helps Lockheed Gain
description: A large gain on the exchange of convertible preferred stock for debentures enabled the Lockheed Corporation to earn $2.33 a share in the first quarter, up from 71 cents a year ago.

title: G. O. P. Fails to Upset Redistricting in Jersey
description: In a ruling that Republican leaders said destroyed their party in Essex County, a Superior Court judge today rejected their challenge to new legislative district lines adopted last week by the State Reapportionment Commission.

title: Offer for Sands Casino Backed
description: Inns of America Inc., won a recommendation from the Nevada Gaming Control Board today to acquire the Sands Hotel Casino on the Las Vegas ''Strip'' from the Summa Corporation for $85 million.

title: Government Offices Planned for Yonkers
description: YONKERS (UPI) - New York State and Westchester County announced plans to spend up to $18 million in downtown Yonkers through investment in new and existing office space.

title: THEATER: 'ANIMALS,' TRIO OF COMEDIES
description: CAN there be any doubt we've reached the silly season on Broadway? Just when it seemed that ''Fools'' was safely behind us, along comes ''Animals,'' an evening of three one-act comedies that makes ''Fools'' look like a model of civilized humor by comparison. What's next? Just possibly a mental collapse for those theatergoers who are exposed to too much of this nonsense in too short a period of time.

title: The Gun Culture
description: From a recent item in the Times: ''An eighth-grader at Intermediate School 210 in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn was grazed by a bullet fired from a .22 caliber revolver that another student was showing him.

title: Insider Reports for Exchanges
description: The New York and the American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges. NEW YORK EXCHANGE

title: Jersey Police Watching For Joanne Chesimard
description: The police in New Jersey were alerted last night after an anonymous caller said that a 1981 Oldsmobile with Joanne Chesimard, the fugitive leader of the Black Liberation Army, was in the state.

title: POLES SAY WEST EXAGGERATED 'MODEST' MANEUVERS
description: The Polish Communist Party, offering its first detailed commentary on the recent Soviet-bloc maneuvers held in and around Poland, said today that the exercises had been ''exceptionally modest.'' It charged that the West had exaggerated their size to make them seem a threat to Poland's sovereignty.

title: FLYERS TRIUMPH, 9-4
description: The Minnesota North Stars defeated the Buffalo Sabres, 4-3, tonight to win their quarterfinal series, 4 games to 1.

title: OILERS TURN BACK ISLANDERS BY 4-3
description: The Edmonton Oilers kept the Islanders from clinching their Stanley Cup quarterfinal series tonight by scoring a 4-3 victory at Nassau Coliseum. The Islanders still lead the four-of-seven-game series, 3-2, with the sixth game in Edmonton, Alberta, Friday night.

title: Fire Kills Man at British Hotel
description: A fire at a hostel for the homeless called Booth's Hotel killed a man and injured 11 people in this southern coastal town today. the authorities said. It was the latest in a series of fires at British homes for the destitute.

title: DANCE: KEI TAKEI OFFERS 6 PARTS OF 'LIGHT'
description: ''LIGHT'' returned to New York on Tuesday night and, as usual, ''Light'' was harsh. This ''Light'' was the ongoing and apparently never-ending cycle of dances that for the last 11 years Kei Takei has been choreographing for her company, Moving Earth. ''Light, Part 15'' receives its premiere on Saturday night. But Tuesday's performance at Larry Richardson's Dance Gallery offered the first six installments of ''Light,'' created between 1969 and 1971.

title: SHIFT AT APPLE COMPUTER
description: Wil Houde, 44 years old, has been named general manager of the personal computer systems division of Apple Computer Inc. He replaces Thomas Whitney, 41, who resigned earlier this month. An executive committee had asked Mr. Whitney to step down because of differences involving management style, according to a company spokesman.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Mild Quakes Hit California
description: A series of mild earthquakes shook the Imperial Valley of California last night, but no damage or injuries were reported. A spokesman for the California Institute of Technology seismology laboratory said the biggest of the quakes measured 3.4 on the open-ended Richter Scale and was recorded at 10:28 P.M. local time.

title: Miro Recovering From Cold
description: Joan Miro, who became 88 years old Monday, is in good health after suffering from a slight cold earlier in the week, the artist's wife said today. Pilar Miro said her husband had resumed his normal schedule of working eight hours a day in his studio overlooking the Mediterranean.

title: Gardening; SUCCESSFUL ROSES, BY ANY NAME
description: THE rose is perhaps the most perfect flower to grow. For beauty, color and fragrance, it has few peers. Garden centers and even supermarkets have potted roses on sale now. Many bushes will be sold to first-time rose growers. Others will be additions to present gardens. A number will be replacements for bushes killed last winter, although bushes kept vigorous and healthy usually come through tough winters unscathed.

title: CASUAL LUXURY IN ADRI'S NEW COLLECTION
description: ADRI, the sportswear designer who has always had her special following, has catapulted into the top echelon of fashion makers. Halston continued to build the Halston mystique, which boils down to an uncomplicated theorem: clothes should be simple by day, extravagant by night. Vera Maxwell celebrated her 80th birthday with a show eulogizing Ultrasuede (''my customers won't let me get away from it,'' she said). Caroline Simonelli revitalized the Mollie Parnis boutique and, all in all, it was a great day for American fashion.

title:
Helpful Hardware;
Wireless Intercoms
description: WIRELESS intercoms that plug into existing electrical outlets make it possible to set up a communications system in a house or apartment without the expense and difficulty of special wiring. They are particularly useful for monitoring the room of a baby or a sick person and for talking to people in distant rooms.

title: Advertising;  The Selling Of a New Fragrance
description: KURTZ & TARLOW, a three-and-a-half-year-old agency, has been named to do the advertising for a new fragrance line called Vanderbilt, due out in about a year and supposedly the talk of the fashion industry.

title: Notes on People; Buckley, in Arizona Speaking on Violence, Struck by Pie
description: The coconut cream pie hit William F. Buckley Jr. in the face. It was Tuesday night in Tucson and he had just spoken about violence in American society to a Young Republican forum at the University of Arizona.

title: Correction
description: An article in Metropolitan Report yesterday on the National Magazine Awards omitted two of the three short-story writers who won the fiction award for the North American Review. The two are Ward Just and Maria Thomas.

title: MOSCOW ACCUSES U.S. OF USING OTHER ISSUES TO AVOID ARMS TALKS
description: A high Soviet official accused the Reagan Administration today of seeking to avoid new talks on strategic arms by linking the issue to other international problems.

title: Business Digest; THURSDAY, APRIL 23, 1981; Companies
description: Nabisco and Standard Brands announced a $2 billion merger plan that would create a new company to be known as Nabisco Brands Inc. Robert M. Schaeberle, Nabisco's 58-year-old chairman, would head the new company, which would rank as the nation's third-largest producer of processed foods. (Page A1.)

title: Youth Held on Firing at Officer
description: A 16-year-old Newark youth has been arrested and charged with shooting at a police officer, authorities said today. The police said the youth, who was not identified because of his age, had fired at the officer when he intervened on Tuesday when he found the teen-ager shooting at another boy.

title: MUSIC: SEQUEIRA COSTA, PORTUGUESE PIANIST, PLAYS
description: Sequeira Costa, the Portuguese pianist, brought a firm technique and a clear musical head to a largely conventional program of solo music at Carnegie Hall Wednesday evening. His approach to such wellworn material as Beethoven's ''Appassionata'' Sonata and the Chopin Sonata in B minor was always honorable and often sensitive; but Mr. Costa was at his most appealing within the more delicate dimensions of Ravel's Sonatine and the labyrinthine textures of ''El Puerto'' and ''Triana,'' both by Albeniz.

title: SAFEWAY STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to march 31
description: B-Including $1.6 million gain for the latest first quarter and $300,000 loss for the previous first quarter from foreign curre translations

title: CITY OPERA:A NEW TIMELINESS FOR MOZART'S 'CLEMENZA DI TITO'
description: MOZART'S ''La Clemenza di Tito,'' which came back into the New York City Opera repertory Wednesday in a production first seen in the fall of 1979, has a libretto based on a Metastasio text, which means it is stilted in the manner of most 18th-century Italian court operas. But the libretto has a curious timeliness just now, in the wake of ''Masada'' on television.

title: AMERICAN SHIPBUILDING CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ENTEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
GRANITEVILLE CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
PULITZER PRIZE BOARD MEMBERS SAY THEY WEIGH CHANGES IN PROCEDURE
description: Members of the Pulitzer Prize Board said today that they were considering changes in the procedures they follow for selecting and announcing the winners of the nation's most prestigious journalism award.

title: MCDONALD'S CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
AMERICAN FILTRONA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Quotation of the Day
description: ''The church is vital to the community. I'm not a member of the church, but it's important to a lot of people who are important to me.''

title: PRESIDENT SAID TO PLAN STUDY OF ENDOWMENTS
description: The White House is expected to announce shortly the appointment of a group to study the structures of the National Endowments for the Arts and the Humanities. The panel will also determine how more money can be generated for the arts from other than governmental sources.

title: SENATE BEGINS HEARINGS ON BILL TO OUTLAW ABORTIONS
description: Senate conservatives opened their drive to outlaw abortions today as five doctors appeared on Capitol Hill and testified that human life begins at conception.

title: ASHLAND OIL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: B-Includes $16.5 million gain from the sale of operations

title: Tibet in Newark
description: ''Tibet: A Lost World,'' a collection of more than 200 Tibetan works of art and other objects will be on view through January at the Newark Museum, 49 Washington Street, Newark.

title: 3-DAY RENAISSANCE FAIR ON PARK AVE.
description: One of the more heartening trends on the early-music scene in recent years has been a tendency for groups to combine forces. The trend is heartening because for various reasons - economics, the logistical feasiblity of small ensembles, personality clashes within the confines of the early-music world -most of these groups tend to be small. That's fine for intimate works. But it distorts our view of the past, which like today offered music ranging from intimacy to grand display.

title: Books
description: C.I.A. Thriller By Eric Pace SPECTRUM. By David Wise. 370 pages. Viking. $13.95.

title: PACIFIC RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Advertising; Armstrong Theater Rebirth
description: covering manufacturer becomes a network advertiser once again. Now, however, the client is Armstrong World Industries, not Armstrong Cork.

title: SECURITIES INDUSTRY ACTS TO SOFTEN RULE ON CAPITAL RESERVES
description: Few stockbrokers are inclined to look on Securities and Exchange Commission regulations as grist for provocative cocktail conversation. But the uniform net capital rule may prove an exception.

title: Schlumberger Increases 41.9%; Curtiss-Wright, Rockwell Rise
description: Schlumberger Ltd., the nation's second largest oilfield service company after the Halliburton Company, announced yesterday that earnings in the first quarter of 1981 soared 41.9 percent on an increase in sales of 25 percent.

title: STEEL MILLS COMPLAIN ON EXPORTS OF SCRAP
description: Gerard Bonomo, president of the Shiavone-Bonomo Corporation, watched a giant 6,000-horsepower shredder take a wrecked car and in a few seconds convert it into strands of scrap, which were then carried by conveyor to the top of a towering 60,000-ton pile.

title: Walking Tours Sunday In Brooklyn and S.I.
description: The early architecture and history of Brooklyn Heights are the subjects of a walking tour to be led Sunday by Joseph Hores of Pace University. The tour, which includes a look at Plymouth Church of the Pilgrims and the former residences of the writers Hart Crane and Arthur Miller, begins at 2 P.M. Meeting place is Pace University, across from City Hall, in Manhattan; the fee is $4.

title: ARTIFICIAL SKIN FOR BURN VICTIMS IS REPORTED DEVELOPED IN BOSTON
description: Artificial skin made from cowhide, shark cartilage and plastic has been successfully used by doctors at the Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston to replace skin destroyed by burns, the doctors reported yesterday. They said that the new skin successfully performed many of the functions of real skin.

title: PROUD APPEAL, $3, WINS BLUE GRASS
description: Keeneland, unlike most major tracks, has no race-caller for the fans. But they didn't need one today to follow the Blue Grass winner.

title: Bridge: Ida Bennett's Quiet Manner Concealed Her Will to Win
description: The bridge players of Staten Island lost their leading citizen Monday when Ida Bennett was killed in an auto accident near Syracuse. She was accompanied by her regular partner, Ethel Keohane of Wellesley Hills, Mass., who was seriously injured.

title: MEMOIRS BY SADAT FRIEND TIE FORMER OFFICIAL TO FINANCIAL MISCONDUCT
description: Publication of the autobiography of President Sadat's closest friend has created an uproar here because it contains allegations of financial misconduct by a former Prime Minister and by two daughters of Gamal Abdel Nasser.

title: RYAN HOMES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CLOPAY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
HOSPITAL GROUP'S RAPID RISE
description: In a 1979 strategic planning meeting, the Hospital Corporation of America established the goal of doubling its revenues, which then totaled $797 million, within six years.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Edward J. McMahon, 56 years old, has been named president and chief operating officer of the St. Regis Paper Company, a big forest products company with large market shares in the fields of paper and packaging. As president of the company, which has headquarters in New York and had sales last year of more than $2.7 billion, he succeeds William R. Haselton, 56, who was appointed chairman and continues as chief executive officer.

title: ROYAL TRUSTCO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Why Give Away the Granary?
description: The Reagan team invites ridicule as it wiggles and wriggles on the President's campaign promise to end the embargo on Soviet purchases of American grain. After proclaiming that ''food is a weapon'' and that the Soviet Union cannot be trusted to keep its word, the Administration now hints it may lift grain sale restrictions. What does it want in exchange? Some sort of promise that Moscow won't invade Poland. Imagine the scorn a fellow named Reagan would have unleashed had a fellow named Carter even contemplated so credulous a deal.

title: MILTON ROY CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ALLEGHANY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: B-Includes $8.2 million pre-tax gain on the sale of investments C-Includes $4.9 million pre-tax gain on the sale of investments

title: THE FILMS OF OLIVIER REVISITED
description: In 1933 when Laurence Olivier, then just 24, was replaced by John Gilbert as Greta Garbo's leading man in ''Queen Christina,'' Miss Garbo reportedly sent the English actor packing from Hollywood with the wan observation that ''life's a mess anyway.''

title: FRIDAY, APRIL 24, 1981; The Economy
description: Consumer prices rose last month at an annual rate of 7.5 percent, the Labor Department reported. The increase was the smallest advance since July. The small advance reflected the slowing of energy price increases and an apparent imporovement in the inflation picture overall. (Page A1.)

title: Reds 5, Astros 4
description: HOUSTON (UPI) - Dan Driessen singled to score Ken Griffey with two out in the 10th inning, enabling Cincinnati to snap a four-game losing streak. Dickie Thon, Houston's shortstop, misplayed Griffey's leadoff single in short left field, allowing Griffey to move to second. Two outs later, Driessen lined a single to right off Dave Smith (0-2)

title: CANADA PERMANENT MORTGAGE reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: B-Includes $907,000 special gain...C-After $15,000 special char

title: MILLIPORE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Nigeria Bars Oil Price Cut
description: Nigeria will not cut its oil prices in response to the present glut on world markets and does not foresee any shortage of buyers, a Government official said today.

title: Economic Scene; Claremont Sees Inflation Drop
description: THE Claremont Economics Institute, which stirred up a fuss at the start of the Reagan Administration with its highly optimistic forecasts, is still predicting that the annual rate of inflation, currently at 7.5 percent, can be brought below 6 percent by the middle of next year if Congress enacts the President's tax and spending cuts.

title: COMMONWEALTH EDISON CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SHAW INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 28
ORIOLE HOMES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 10 percent dividend paid in January

title: KRATOS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Auctions; Native wares for many tastes.
description: in the form of folk paintings, period furnishings, autographs and manuscripts, and the art of the Indians - will be in the spotlight in six exhibitions and subsequent auctions over the next nine days at all three New York galleries of Sotheby Parke Bernet. The action begins tomorrow at 10:15 A.M. and 2 P.M. at Sotheby's York Avenue galleries (72d Street), with the sale of American Indian art. The four most important lots are a Tlingit wood-and-steel knife, with wooden handle carved in the shape of a beaver (up to $30,000); a Haida rattle, its bear-shape shaker embellished with a smiling human figure sprawled on its forehead; a raven-shape Northwest Coast Tlingit helmet decorated with a frog's face on the breast, and a Haida wooden chief's chair, carved with two bear masks (all are estimated to sell for up to $25,000 each).

title: GF BUSINESS EQUIPMENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CARNEGIE'S '81-82 SEASON TO OFFER BEETHOVEN FESTIVAL, BACH SERIES
description: A Beethoven festival with the Orchestre de Paris conducted by Daniel Barenboim will be a highlight of Carnegie Hall's 1981-82 season, the hall's executive director, Stewart J. Warkow, announced yesterday. The Beethoven concerts will be given from Feb. 8 through Feb. 19 and the six programs will include all nine symphonies as well as the Violin Concerto with Itzhak Perlman as soloist.

title: SPS TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CELTICS FIND A NEEDED CATALYST IN BIRD
description: Toshihiko Seko sprinted the final 100 yards, and Larry Bird couldn't believe it. ''How can you run 26 miles and still be able to run that fast?'' he asked. Bird finished drying his hair, pulled a bench closer to the television set in the Boston Garden locker room and stared in disbelief.

title: PSA INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results include a portion of the gain related to the exchange o the shares of a subsidiary

title: NEW HAMPSHIRE BALL BEARINGS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective Dec 1

title: AAV COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28

title: CONCERT: MARTIRANO AND HIS MACHINE
description: Proponents of electronic music have been promising us great things for a generation or more, but so far the major result of their experimenting has been to refine and ramify the technology. Results that would be recognized as musical outside the parochial borders of the electronic community have been extremely skimpy. And musical skimpiness characterized the performance of Salvatore Martirano last night at the Cooper Union, where he improvised for 50 minutes on his Sal-Mar Construction, as he calls the electronic instrument that he and others at the University of Illinois have been building since the late 60's. Mr. Martirano claims that the instrument, which resembles a doomsday machine out of a NASA technician's fantasy or something a boy might dream after consuming too many issues of Popular Electronics, is "the world's first electronic sound generating composing machine." It embodies computers as well as synthesizing equipment, a pairing that allows the performer to improvise in "real time"-that is, on the spot, without tape-in tandem with the automated sounds previously programmed into the machine. It is designed to produce more complex textures than are available on ordinary music synthesizers and to permit, in theory, an "interaction" between performer and machine. There are 291 touch-sensitive switches, functioning as input devices, and 24 speakers that hang about the hall to to spread the output. A television monitor, apparently conveying some visual messages that could not be made out from the audience, sat on a chair beside the instrument.

The Evening Hours
description: A FRIEND spotted Thomas Lee Jones at the Seventh Regiment Armory the other night, exclaimed ''Oh my God!'' came to attention and gave him a snappy military salute. And no wonder. Mr. Jones was glorious in a bright red uniform (''I'm supposed to be a British field marshal'') pinned with the Order of St. John and the blue sash of the ancient Russian order of St. Sergius. If the uniform was a bit mixed up, it was because it was a copy of one Edward II wore and was made by a Brooklyn tailor named Nelson Arriaga. The medals and sash were borrowed from a friend who collects old decorations. Except that he kept tripping over his sword, Mr. Jones had a wonderful time swaggering in his boots and returning the salutes of other would-be Victorians.

Miss Grant's is the more inspiring film, and also the more uncomplicated. In Miss Schreiber's film, life is a bit more ironic and quirky. title: Sharing the Bill for a Bill of Rights

If Congress wants to legislate better care, the Court said, it has an obligation to spell out what that means, so that the states know exactly what they are getting into when they accept Washington's help. title: 1 MAN, 1 8 VOTE
description: Yes, some are more equal than others. Congress in 1971 passed the Federal Election Campaign Act providing for public financing of Presidential elections. As amended in 1974, the law placed limits on the amount of money individuals and organizations could contribute to Presidential and Congressional candidates. On the ground that the amended law violated free-speech rights, a consortium of plaintiffs that included liberals and conservatives brought suit. The Supreme Court, in a 1976 ruling, let stand the principal of public financing combined with limits on direct contributions. However, it struck down limits on outside expenditures by individuals or organizations on the ground that these restricted free speech. In allowing rich individuals to spend more money to influence elections, it confirmed the essential inferiority of the citizen of modest means in the exercise of one of his most fundamental rights. Short of becoming rich himself, he could never hope to equal the amount of free speech enjoyed by the well-to-do.

title: 203 AGENCIES AND PUBLIC HEALTH'S FUTURE
description: The Reagan Administration's proposed elimination of the country's 203 health systems agencies, created by Federal law in 1974, is a real boon to the public: It will save each of us the cost of a pack of cigarettes every year. We would be wise to spend the pennies saved on vitamins rather than cigarettes because, according to projections by the American Health Planning Association, eliminating the agencies, which were set up to control health-care costs, will push the average price of a day in the hospital to $1,300 in less than 10 years.

ECLECTIC APPROACH BY RALPH LAUREN
description: The Indians didn't appear until the Ralph Lauren show at the Hotel Pierre was more than half over. First there was his mannish tailored look, clothes that make pretty women look ultrafeminine. Tweedy trousers with pleats at the waist, cuffs casually turned up. Above them, the models wore tailored shirts, ties and knitted cardigans in glowing colors such as canary yellow. Sometimes they slipped into mannish topcoats and sauntered down the runway with their hands in their pants pockets. Some of them wore, instead of trousers, plus fours - the kind the Duke of Windsor donned for a run around the golf course. With Argyle socks, of course.

description: The trial of Raymond L.S. Patriarca, charged with being an accessory to murder, was postponed for four months today because of the 73-year-old defendant's health. His attorney said Mr. Patriarca would undergo surgery next week.

title: 'THE BOAT IS FULL'
description: The best films in the New Directors/ New Films series, co-sponsored by the Film Society of Lincoln Center and the Museum of Modern Art, are those that qualify as discoveries. ''The Boat Is Full'' is something more, something in the neighborhood of a revelation. Markus Imhoof, who wrote and directed this Swiss-German-Austrian co-production, works with such grace and assurance that he in no way seems to be a novice, notwithstanding the series' title. His film is fresh, purposeful and surprising at every turn.

title: Business Digest; SATURDAY, APRIL 25, 1981; The Economy
description: President Reagan lifted the 15-month curb on grain sales to Moscow but warned that his Administration was not lessening its determination to stop Russian ''acts of aggression wherever they take place.'' The action also lifted a ban on shipment of phosphate fertilizers to the Soviet Union. But Russian fishing privileges in American waters remain curtailed, as do the limitations on trade of high-technology products. (Page 1.) title: THIS 'DON JUAN' IS A PARABLE OF EVIL
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Benedict Nightingale writes on theater for The New Statesman. By BENEDICT NIGHTINGALE LONDON The National Theater has recently been taking more than passing interest in the Don Juan story, and especially in its odder permutations. In 1978, it disinterred ''Don Juan Comes Back From the War'' by the Hungarian dramatist Odon Horvath, a play that transformed the sexual predator into a repentant army veteran, anxious only to rediscover and propitiate the girl he had long ago seduced and abandoned. Earlier this year, the National revived Bernard Shaw's ''Man and Superman,'' complete with the rarely performed dream-debate ''Don Juan in Hell,'' which takes mythological revisionism still further. Its hero is the lover who never found satisfaction in love, a crusading intellectual not unlike Shaw himself.

title: COLLECTING ON A GRAND SCALE
description: There is a very good reason why architecture has never been thrown under the umbrella of that currenly trendy term "collectibles": It is no simple matter to collect architecture in the way that one collects bottles or seashells or even Rembrandts. Buildings do not fit very easily into cases or onto shelves, and they cannot be stacked up in garages or basements. Lovers of architecture who have been bitten by the collecting urge thus tend to seek solace in substitutes - in gathering architectural drawings a pastime that has become so fashionable in recent years that it has led to the opening of galleries specializing in the marketing of architects' sketches; in acquiring architectural models, something not as popular as architectural drawings but clearly on the rise; or in collecting architecture books, prints and folios, probably the oldest type of architectural collecting of all. But there have always been a few determined souls who have managed against all odds, to collect real buildings. It is a sport that takes as much money as polo and probably a great more commitment. Buildings cannot be found through a regular, reliable dealer, as prints or toy turtles can, and the buildings a collector may want to collect are not very likely to be found in one convenient location. A building collector must be willing to travel, then, and he or she must also be willing to spend a lot of money, not only to acquire--or to commission--his or her collection, but to keep it up.

title: WHEN THE MAJOR PIANISTS INTERPRET CHOPIN AND LISZT
description: Chopin and Liszt stand as perhaps the pre-eminent examples of the worldly, mid-19th-century piano virtuoso-composer - and a steady flow of recordings attests to their continued pre-eminence today. Idolized by Parisian and European high society, they wrote music that also reached out to the newly-aware middle classes, and epitomized both the intimate fantasies and the bold, nationalist pride of that time. Both men were roughly contemporary, Chopin born in 1810 and Liszt a year later, although Liszt outlived Chopin by 37 years. Both were among the first to bring the modern concert grand to its full artistic potential, and both can be credited with harmonic advances that belied their images as purveyors of showy display pieces.

The article omitted the one major factor in extending the life of the moving image on celluloid: All film requires hand inspection, total wet immersion in cleaning solution, chemical impregnation of both the emulsion (picture) side and cell side, foot by foot, on a regularly scheduled basis.

title: LACROSSE BOOMING AT HIGH SCHOOLS
description: YORKTOWN HEIGHTS INTEREST in public high school lacrosse, born quietly in this northwestern Westchester community in 1966, continues to grow in a surprising manner. Whereas there was only one varsity team in the county then, there are now about 25 interscholastic rivals.

title: DESERT WARFARE THE WAY IT REALLY WAS, CIRCA 1930
description: ''Lion of the Desert,'' a new two-and-three-quarter-hour film about the Libyan resistance against Italian imperialism in the early years of this century, has been given a lukewarm reception by the film critics. That may or may not be deserved. Nevertheless, from a military historian's point of view Rod Steiger and Anable, respectively, as Benito Mussolini and the Libyan resistance leader, Omar Mukhtar, and - more importantly - ''Lion of the Desert'' is one of the triumphs of military movie making.

title: CONSUMER RATES
Can Those Alligators Find Happiness in Liberaldom?
description: Patrick Blesty (Speaking Personally, April 12) has clearly let the little reptile get the better of him. Although perhaps at one time the sighting of an embroidered alligator would instill fear in liberal hearts, such is no longer the case.

title: SOCIALIST WORKERS, AT TRIAL, ALLEGE U.S. HARASSMENT
description: Two leaders of the Socialist Workers Party have testified that Federal agents used false charges, anonymous letters and undercover provocateurs to disrupt their political activities.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Frits de Jonge, a Violist, In Program of 4 Sonatas
description: Frits de Jonge is a violist from the Netherlands now teaching at the University of South Carolina, and on Thursday night he made his New York debut in Carnegie Recital Hall. Mr. de Jonge's program consisted of sonatas by four diverse composers: Brahms's Op. 120, No. 2; Hindemith's Op. 11, No. 4; Bach's Gamba Sonata No. 2, and Schubert's ''Arpeggione.''

title: 3 Men Who Hijacked Pakistani Jet Are Said to Travel to Afghanistan
description: The three men who hijacked a Pakistani jetliner to Syria last month and 25 of the political prisoners whose release they won have gone to Afghanistan by way of New Delhi, police sources said today.

title: Home Clinic; ELIMINATING ERRORS IN APPLYING PAINT WITH A ROLLER
description: PAINT rollers are probably one of the simplest tools you can use for coating large flat, surfaces such as walls and ceilings. Even so, there are some tricks of the trade that will help the amateur do a neater, quicker job of painting without misses or runs and drips.

title: A CITY SCHOOL ON THE UPBEAT SIDE
description: A BIG, furry tarantula named Milady de Winter sits on the desk of the assistant principal for biology at Benjamin N. Cardozo Jr. High School in Bayside, Queens. All around this departmental mascot, individual students are doing original research into algae, milkweed bugs, the poisonous secrets of mushrooms and other explorable territory.

title: STAMFORD RENEWAL NEARING COMPLETION
description: WITH the announcements last week that Saks & Company will open a store in Stamford's sprawling shopping mall and that construction will begin shortly on the final two of six buildings in an adjacent office complex known as Stamford Forum, the city's ambitious urban redevelopment program appears to be nearing completion.

title: ECONOMY UP ON EXPORTS
description: The size of the first-quarter increase in gross national product, which rose at an adjusted annual rate of 6.5 percent, took many economists by surprise. A partial explanation lies in the fact that exports, unexpectedly, surged.

title: DANCE: INDIAN KATHAKALI
description: As its first performance, on Friday night, at the Lila Acheson Wallace Auditorium in the Asia Society's new building at 725 Park Avenue, the society's performing-arts division presented a program of Kathakali dance-drama - one of India's richest classical art forms.

Gardening;

To clinch the sale, the photos are always accompanied by a caption that says you can grow all the fruit you can eat in your own backyard.

title: FOR SEEING AND READING
description: MAYBE there is a nice, direct, scientific way of judging a picture book. Something we can graph and collate. On my desk is a ''device that provides a simple way to determine the appropriate grade level of a book or article.'' It is called a Readability Rater and it looks like a slide rule. First ''randomly select a 300-word passage ...'' Next, ''determine the average number of syllables and average number of sentences per hundred words.'' Where those two numbers meet there is another number that ... oh, never mind. Some of these books don't even have 300 words, and it won't work with pictures anyhow. How about the stealthy, old-fashioned approach? Absorb the rhythm of the words, judge how well they lead the pictures and how the two pace and illuminate each other. Burrow beneath the surface of the art for ideas, a kernel, that singular voice saying something old in a new way, something new in an old way. Something. Go graph that.

title: TAX-EXEMPT STATUS OF HOTCHKISS STUDIED
description: SALISBURY A RESIDENT'S demand that Salisbury officials place certain facilities at The Hotchkiss School on the town tax rolls has raised a legal question that may have implications for other tax-exempt schools in the state.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
AT HOME

With an hour to kill before meeting a friend for dinner, I lingered, with other passersby, at the shop windows. In my town at this hour, most shops are closed and pedestrians walk purposefully toward predictable destinations and occupations: House and family, cocktails, dinner, the evening news, bed.

title: Auto Regulation
description: To the Business Editor: Concerning Leon S. Robertson's ''Regulating the Auto'' (March 29): It would seem that Mr. Robertson is totally enamored with air bags, but he makes some statements that are erroneous.

description: To the Sports Editor:

title: THE HIGH COST OF KIDNEY CARE
description: Statistically, the number of Americans suffering from serious kidney diseases may not loom large, but certainly for them - and also the nation -their survival is becoming a serious economic problem, and possibly a moral one.

title: SYMPHONY'S WOES HELP SMALLER GROUPS
description: THE New Jersey Symphony's canceling its season because of financial problems has resulted in a windfall for the state's parttime orchestras. Spokesmen for several regional and community orchestras report not only a dramatic rise in attendance, but also that tickets for remaining concerts this season are selling at a brisk pace.

description: The case of a small, quiet black man last seen on his way to sell old coins was reviewed by the Atlanta police today as volunteers scoured tree-lined roads for clues to the murders and disappearances of 26 other young blacks.

title: TEACHERS LEARNING ABOUT FAMILY CRISES
description: FOR Carole Meehan, a sixth-grade teacher at the Intermediate School in White Plains, teaching the school curriculum has become increasingly difficult. ''Before I can get to the work, the children will bring up a family problem and say how much it distrubs them,'' she explained during a recent conference of educators. ''They'll say things like, 'I wish I didn't have to live with my mother only,' or, 'Why can't my father visit me?' When one starts talking, it's like a chain reaction - a whole barrage of things. I feel what the children are saying really is, 'Please listen to me.' ''

description: Howard Phipps, philanthropist and horticulturist, died Friday at his estate in Old Westbury, L.I. He would have been 100 years old on May 23.

Colorful new T-shirts with the Wipty logo are on order for all members (at only $2.98 each) and our founder-president, Margi, has worked out a deal with a distributor to get visiting teams' caps and pennants at reduced prices. And, as she said at our meeting last month, ''We're coming off a great 1980 season. In games we attended as a group, our teams won 12 of 19.''

description: When Joe W. Freelon sits in his mayoral campaign headquarters here, where food on the shelf and vote tallies on the wall imply that the April 7 election is not yet over, supporters sometimes stop in to ask, ''Are they trying to steal it from you?''

title:
Dining Out;
GOOD NEWS, BAD NEWS IN ARMONK
description: FIVE years ago, Flower Dragon in Armonk was a delightful and welcome addition to Northern Westchester's paucity of Chinese restaurants; in fact, it is still a gastronomical landmark of some distinction, if erratic. And although stiff competition in this cuisine thrives farther south, Flower Dragon remains almost without serious alternatives in the county's northern region. The restaurant's isolation is both lucky and unlucky for neighborhood residents - lucky to have a good Chinese restaurant within striking distance; unlucky to be obliged to pay somewhat higher prices for food that can be inconsistent in quality. After sampling about 40 dishes from the extensive menu, we must report that the hand that stir-fries the wok cannot always be relied upon.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Protected 'Forgery'
description: The case against Charles Briggins, a New York City detective who lived in Freeport, L.I., appeared airtight. He had opened a bank account under an assumed name, had cashed checks using the assumed name and had presented for identification a driver's permit issued to his assumed identity.

title: Golf's Senior Circuit Is No Easy Reward
description: ''The nice thing about these senior tournaments,'' Gene Littler was saying, ''is that you're finding out how old some of these guys honestly are.''

title: 'OKLAHOMA!' ENCORE AIDS MOLLOY
description: ROCKVILLE CENTRE IF it were up to Joan Roberts, she'd probably never sing the songs from ''Oklahoma!'' again. It's not that she doesn't admire the historic musical that in 1943 made her a star at the age of 21; she does.

title: DISARTICULATION
description: Scholars who are seriously studying the contemporary United States have come to recognize the limitations of ''theories'' they offer to explain our current difficulties. Moreover, many thoughtful analysts admit that ''scientific'' approaches frequently are ideological justifications for political goals of particular pressure groups. It is time to realize that universities have entered directly and excessively into the stalemated political process. The public would be better off if the experts concentrated on helping the public understand how society actually operates, and on stimulating political leaders to sharpen their sense of their own - and society's - enlightened interests.

description: ''I'M not a Jewish historian,'' said Werner T. Angress. ''I'm a German historian. I am dealing as a historian of Germany with what came to be known in the 19th century as the so-called Jewish question - how to adjust to a minority which had lived in Germany since the time of the Romans.''

title: Music View; MASTERPIECES THAT CALL FOR MIRACLES
description: James Joyce called them epiphanies, those moments in Everyman's life when mystic understanding seems to come flooding in, momentarily transfiguring an everyday scene and transporting him to another plane of existence. Stephen Dedalus's realization that God is ''a shout in the street'' was just such a fleeting insight, at least for him. The reader of ''Ulysses'' may dimly grasp the concept even though it would not yield easily to rational explanation. If an epiphany could be easily explained, after all, it would not qualify as an epiphany. If Stephen had announced that God was the answer to a geometrical theorem, that might be a theological or philosophical conundrum, but probably not an epiphany. The essence of an epiphany is its refusal to be captured by the lawmen of logic. It is a hitand-run miracle.

title: No Headline
description: Colette Dowling maintains that ''the ultimate change is personal.'' Not true. The ultimate work is societal. Women can take it from there.

title: INFLATION REACHES THE TOLL BOOTHS
description: WHEN the state finished financing the Connecticut Turnpike, it set a passenger-car toll of 25 cents and figured that it would take until 1997 to pay for the road. That was in 1958, and since then, the turnpike has seen drastic increases in operating costs, a prolonged gas crisis that has cut traffic, and now, an increase in the tolls, all of which may cause motorists at the eight toll plazas to wonder when the road will finally be paid for.

title: No Headline
description: Men have always had ''dependency needs,'' the fulfilling of which has been women's traditional primary duty. The needs of working men to be cooked for, cared for, listened to, sympathized with, advised, admired and loved have not been called ''hidden'' or denigrated as psychiatric symptoms. They have been regarded as basic human needs, the meeting of which is essential to functioning in a complex, competitive, demanding world. MARY DEUTSCH EDSALL, Washington

title: Poker Player Killed Over 5th Ace

The victim was Arthur Ellison, a 36-year-old resident of the West Atco section of this South Jersey community. Dennis Wixted, assistant Camden County prosecutor, said the police had charged James Lewis, 54, at whose home the game was held, with murder and weapons offenses.

title: Headliners; A Word Too Many
description: The magazine's first mistake was to assert as fact what was, at best, only an American Opinion. Its second mistake was to make the assertion about Elmer Gertz, a longtime civil libertarian and a lawyer. Mr. Gertz went to court, charging that American Opinion, the John Birch Society monthly, had libeled him in a 1969 article in which he was described as a ''Leninist'' and a ''Communist-fronter'' who helped frame a Chicago police officer for murder. The case led in 1974 to a landmark Supreme Court decision on libel law and, last week, to a Chicago jury's award of $400,000 in damages to Mr. Gertz.

title: ROSETTA STONES FROM SPACE
description: David Abrahamson is a freelance writer. By David Abrahamson On the night of Feb. 8, 1969, a large meteorite crashed to earth near the Allende Valley in northern Mexico. More than two tons of material in thousands of pieces were scattered over 100 square miles, and the meteor's fireball was visible as far away as Texas and New Mexico. The Allende ''fall'' was the largest sample ever recovered of one of the rarest types of meteorite and, in the words of Dr. Martin Prinz, chairman of the department of mineral sciences at the American Museum of Natural History, it was both ''the most primitive and the most complex'' meteorite ever found - so complex that it is still being studied today by an emerging new generation of astrogeologists.

title: PLAY ON COSMONAUT LANDS IN SEA OF VACUITY
description: If plays were adjudged on topicality alone, "Heat of Re-entry" would be a winner. In it, the playwright attempts to explore the life and death of the first cosmonaut. The timing is uncannily right: The play opened at Playwrights Horizons at the Theater-in-the-Park in Queens the night after the space shuttle Columbia's return, and just three nights after the 20the anniversary of man's first space flight. But nearly everything else about "Heat of Re-entry" (the title refers to the high temperature of the space capsule during the return to earth) is wrongheaded. Mr. Tetenbaum is writing about a playwright (the fictious Lev Malchikov, a Russian Jewish emigre, living in Brooklyn) who is writing a play about the first man to travel in space (the real Yuri Gargarin). In the play, the playwright comments upon his play in process and converses with this central character, who assumes a life of his own, making demands and intruding upon his creator's domain, playfully, capriciously at first, and then more and more insistently, as the nature of his death is speculated upon. (we have been told that Gagrin dies durong a test flight; the playwright suggests that he invited death by hunting animals from a low-flying jet.) We are led, all too emphatically, into the playwright's struggle to finish his own play, and figure it out: "I'd say it's turned into a tragedy," he concludes. I'd say it never got out of the typewriter. Mr. Tetenbaum types in your basic sitcom style with delusions of tragedy and pretensions toward poetry.

title: COLLECTING CLASSIC DESIGNS
description: It is not necessary for a piece pf furniture or a household object to have the patina and pedigree of age to be collectible. In fact, many of the designs currently being manufactured are worthy of collecting because of the classic integrity of their design. Many of these objects will probably be desireable in future years as they are now. And because they are intended to be part of a collection that almost everybody has-home furnishings-they do not have to be collected in multiples. Classic design has an inherent quality to it, a quality that is achieved through the intelligent resolution of all its elements, purpose, design inspiration, material, proportion, construction and finish. It is not faddish, and there is little danger that in future years its purchaser will bemoan the fact that he fell for fashion of the moment and is now stuck with it, like an immovable albatross. Some fo these designs, such as handosme tea cart of ALvar Aalto, a Finnish architect, have been in continuous production since the 1930's Others, such as the 1920's smoked-glass and steel table designed by Eileen Gray, have been revived and re beginning to be manufactured again. Still others, such as a portable word processor that fits inside a small attache case, are brand new. The value of these classic is not that they are going to increase monetarily, although they may well, but rather that their design is so timeless that it should never go out of style.
