description: Some of the most interesting dishes on the menus of Italian restaurants in America are of uncertain or dubious origin. They bear Italian names but are commonly supposed to have been created in this country. Three of these dishes are clams Posillipo, chicken scarpariello and veal francese. One will rarely, if ever, find recipes for these dishes in standard or traditional Italian cookbooks, either regional or classic.

title: Reiko Kamata in a Concert Of Pieces for the Koto
description: The koto, a six-foot-long zither with 13 strings that is the national instrument of Japan, is seldom heard in concerts here, but Reiko Kamata came to Carnegie Recital Hall last Wednesday night to play it.

title: TERESA TALENTO, NURSE, IS FIANCEE OF MICHAEL B. DUNCAN
description: Teresa Talento, a nurse at the New Rochelle(N.Y.) Medical Center plans to be married in June to Micheal Bevan Duncan, a sail designer and production manager at Sobstad Sailmakers, Inc. in Mamaroneck, N.Y.

title: YANKS BOW TO BLUE JAYS, 7-2
description: For Danny Ainge of the Toronto Blue Jays, each successful swing of the bat vindicates a decision he made to play major league baseball instead of accepting the riches of the National Basketball Association.

title: THE BROKERING OF TEACHER CREDITS
description: NEARLY 5,000 New Jersey and Pennsylvania teachers take continuingeducation courses at an unaccredited institution of which some of the highest state education officials have never heard. The records of those teachers, though, make no mention of that institution; instead, they list two fully accredited colleges, Monmouth and Marywood, which have awarded credit for courses neither held on their campuses nor taught by their faculty.

title: LIVING WITH COLLECTIONS
description: One out of three Americans does it, according to authorities. It has been called a passion, a compulsion and even an addiction. But by whatever name, collecting now appears to be thriving pastime enjoyed by many. There are more than 30 periodicals, 12 publishing houses and at least 100 books in print offering advice and information on acquiring everything from barbed wire--these enthusiasts even have their own newspaper--to fine art. What are all these people collecting, why do they do it and, perhaps more importantly, once acquired, how do they live with their collections? In America, collectors once meant either the amassers of stamps or coins, or 19th- and early 20th-century millionaires who, with the help of experts such as Bernard Berenson and Lord Duveen, acquired the work of European masters as much for the aura of cultivation it lent their owners as for its beauty and value. Today, while stamps, coins and fine art still enjoy tremendous popularity, the majority of collections are now composed around either more mundane or more exotic themes. In fact, almost anything, it would appear, can be a collectible. By and large, today's collectors do not choose their acquisitions for their potential increase in value through the years. If they do appreciate, their owners say, it is a bonus. Many are motivated by nostalgia for simpler times and gather together sentimental objects such as Victorian valentines, but most seem driven only by a strong fascination for their specialty, whether it is salt-glaze pottery or objects covered shagreen, or shark skin.

title: Marcos's Party Unanimous In Naming Him a Candidate
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos was nominated unanimously by his party today to seek re-election June 16, probably as the only candidate.

title: THE N.F.L. DRAFT: THE 'IMPACT PLAYERS' ARE THREE LINEBACKERS
description: The National Football League's annual draft of college players, to be held Tuesday and Wednesday, is not unlike a display of gifts beneath the tree on Christmas morning. There will be worthy presents for all 28 teams right into the seventh round, according to Frank (Bucko) Kilroy, the general manager of the New England Patriots.

title: 'COCKTAIL MOLOTOV,' COMEDY
description: For reasons that probably only a sociologist could explain, French film makers make more intelligent films about the problems of growing up bourgeois than the film makers of any other country. It may have something to do with the peculiar love-hate feelings that French artists have always felt for the bourgeoisie since the ultimate, mid-19th century triumph of the middle classes in the revolution that had begun in 1789, and that finally discredited not only the ancien regime, but also the ferocious lower orders.

title: PUTTING INTERFERON TO THE TEST
description: In March 25, 1980, a small parcel arrived in Glasgow on a routine commercial flight from Denmark. It looked like nothing so much as a small wrapped trinket, a souvenir for the folks back home. Yet it was rushed from the plane with haste, spun past customs and hurtled through the narrow, gray streets of the dour Scottish city. It was interferon - a minuscule amount, enough to treat two small boys for an insignificant length of time.

title: AMTRAK CHIEF LOOKS TO CONGRESS FOR AID
description: Budget-cutters in the Reagan Administration say Amtrak's time has come and gone, but Alan S. Boyd, president of Amtrak, says that historical tides and the sentiment in Congress are running with the national passenger railroad.

title: FLYERS MAKE A RECOVERY
description: The Philadelphia Flyers have played their last two games as if they were their last. Now the Calgary Flames have a chance to experience that feeling.

title: THE NEW UNDERGROUND
description: They live completely apart from the Bill Blasses, the Halstons and the Oscar de la Rentas of this world. Not that they necessarily would mind being a part of that rarefied subtext, of course. But, at the moment, they've got one of their own.

title: Rising Salaries and Bonuses
description: The 28 players to be selected on the first round of the National Football League draft can expect first-year salaries of $80,000 to $125,000 and signing bonuses from $140,000 to $750,000. The higher the draft selection, the larger the contract; the longer the contract, the larger the bonus.

title: 12 Railroad Workers Shaken Up As Locomotive Jars Amtrak Cars
description: At least 12 railroad employees were hurt when an Amtrak train that was being put together at the Sunnyside rail yard in Queens was bumped hard by a switch engine yesterday afternoon, the police said.

title: Jury in Margiotta Case Recesses Till Tomorrow
description: A Federal jury this evening recessed its deliberations in the mail fraud and extortion trial of the Nassau County Republican chairman until Monday morning.

title: INVENTING A LITERARY SELF
description: EVERY literary generation has its myths. For American writers in the 19th century, it was the myth of the common man, of democracy, of what F.O. Matthiessen in ''American Renaissance'' called ''the union of labor and culture.'' For the so-called Lost Generation of the 1920's, it was bohemian Europe, adventure abroad, the escape from philistine America. For a good many contemporary writers, the myth is made of their own careers: how they came to be writers, their influences, the vicissitudes of their imaginative lives. The literary myth of our time is the myth of literary vocation.

title: Magic Hours
description: As children, we always felt the arbitrary change to daylight saving time much more powerfully than the equinox. Overnight, it gave us magical evenings after dinner, with fireflies in the yard, Good Humor desserts and hide-and-seek between the houses as the shadows finally came down.

title: Antiques; A WITTY AUTOGRAPH IS PRIZED AND PRICEY
description: Autographs that are humorous are among the most desirable missives for collectors. And when the writer is not known for his humor, the letter is even more eagerly sought. That, in any case, may be tested Tuesday when an uncharacteristically spirited letter written by George Washington in 1782 comes up for sale at Sotheby Parke Bernet's new 84th Street Galleries, 171 East 84th Street.

title: Overlook Terrace Sold
description: A 171-unit moderate-income, eight-story apartment building at 100 Overlook Terrace in the Washington Heights section of Manhattan was purchased by David Kupperman, a real-estate investor.

title: SOME DIPLOMACY, PLEASE
description: G. K. Chesterton once said that ''if a thing is worth doing, it is worth doing badly.'' What he meant was that if something deserved doing, it should be done, even if it could not be done well. Perhaps this is how we should view the Reagan Administration's conduct of foreign affairs. The Administration surely is not doing well what should be done.

title: Royals Top Brewers on Gura's 3-Hitter, 4-2
description: Willie Aikens hit a two-run homer in the first inning and Larry Gura hurled a three-hitter today to enable the Kansas City Royals to snap a four-game losing streak with a 4-2 victory over the Milwaukee Brewers.

title: Tiant Just Misses No-Hitter
description: Luis Tiant came within one out of pitching his second straight no-hitter last night, leading the Portland Beavers to an 8-0 victory over the Spokane Indians in the first game of a Pacific Coast League doubleheader.

title: Mrs. Thatcher, in Qatar, Backs U.S. on Gulf Force
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain, ending a tour of four oil states, today called the Russians ''the new imperialists'' and reiterated her support for a United States plan to establish a rapid deployment force for use if a Persian Gulf crisis threatened oil supplies.

title: THE REAL BUDGET DANGER
description: In the five years between 1965 and 1970, as Lyndon Johnson poured men and money into Vietnam, the level of annual American military spending rose by just over $24 billion. In today's money that is $53 billion.

title: ALGREN ENTERING THE EAST END RING
description: SAG HARBOR ALTHOUGH not one to back away from a good fight - he is, after all, an intense devotee of the ring - Nelson Algren, nonetheless, finally withdrew from the fierce 30-year battle he waged with Chicago and, after six years of wandering through urban New Jersey, has settled down in this historic village.

title: IS GUNG-HO THE WAY TO GO?
description: As Congress prepares to debate the largest defense budget ever, a group of civilian and military planners are challenging the basic thinking on strategy and tactics underlying some of the enormously expensive new weapons.

title: INFALLIBLE, HARDLY
description: Last week's report that the economy grew at an unexpectedly robust 6.5 percent annual rate during the first three months of 1981 left many economists grasping for explanations. Most of their economic models had predicted a much smaller figure - one to three percentage points lower.

title: SAUDIS SHIELDI ISLAM FROM 'ALIEN VALUES'
description: Saudi Arabia's economic planners believe they can successfully link the West's technology and the Islamic faith without rending society, but acknowledge they face a challenge.

title: Acid Rain Costs Money
description: Aside from worries about environmental hazards, participants at this week's U.S.-Canadian conference on acid rain are likely to focus on a growing body of information about the costs created by what analysts call an external diseconomy.

title: Allstate Acquisition
description: Allstate Insurance Company has acquired Harrison Corporate Park in Harrison, N.Y., from Robert Dubofsky and Jerome Artsis for $13 million. The two structures include a newly built 135,000-square foot office structure and an older, 20,000-square-foot facility, both situated on a site overlooking the Cross Westchester Expressway.

title:
THE HIGH SCHOOLS TODAY;
ANTIDOTES FOR 'SENIORITIS'
description: SCHOOLS across the country are devising a variety of new programs to combat high school ''senioritis,'' a malaise that educators say is marked by student lassitude, lack of motivation, inability to concentrate, anxiety about the future, and, consequently, lowered class attendance and sinking grades. The long-standing advancedplacement courses, designed to introduce college-credit courses for students unchallenged by the customary high school offerings, are being supplemented by some unusual alternatives.

title: No Headline
description: As a woman who chose to leave her marriage after 29 years, I can tell Colette Dowling that what enrages me is not that I might ''have to work,'' but that what I spent my life doing was not and is still not considered ''work.'' The women who fulfill the role into which society channels them, who nurture their husbands and children rather than themselves risk ending up with no assets of their own, no Social Security benefits of their own, no pension guarantees and very dim job prospects. That can make you angry! Until the system which fosters, rewards and feeds on women's dependency is changed, women will continue to distort themselves to make that fragile glass slipper fit. LAURA CONTE, Binghamton, N.Y.

title: A Sensible Ecotopian
description: To the Editor:

title: G.O.P. LEADER SEEKS CHANGES IN CAMPAIGN SYSTEM
description: Richard Richards, the Republican national chairman, wants his party to start changing the mechanics of Presidential campaigns, especially to shorten them and to curb ''independent expenditures'' by anyone other than candidates or parties.

title: G.A.O. AGRICULTURE STUDY ASSAILS U.S. SYSTEM FOR PRESERVING SEED
description: The General Accounting Office has issued a report criticizing the Agriculture Department's management of a system used to collect and store seeds and other genetic crop material.

title: I.R.A. HUNGER STRIKE REFUSES TO SEE 2 RIGHTS ENVOYS
description: 814BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 25 (AP) - Two envoys of the European Human Rights Commission tried to meet with Robert Sands in prison today to persuade him to end his hunger strike but were rebuffed because he was dissatisfied with Britain's conditions for the meeting.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Mendelssohn Strings Present Varied Quartets
description: A debut concert that sounded very unlike one was played by the Mendelssohn String Quartet in Goodman Concert Hall on Tuesday night. This ensemble of apparently recent origin played Haydn's Quartet in A (Op. 9, No. 6), Schoenberg's Quartet No. 2 and Dvorak's Quartet in E flat as though it had been doing so for years.

title: REAGAN MILITARY PLAN ENVISIONS UP TO 250,000 ADDITIONAL RECRUITS
description: The Reagan Administration is considering the addition of up to 250,000 people to the armed forces over the next five years or so, a 12 percent increase that would be costly and could revive the issue of a peacetime draft.

title: HEARNS BEATS SHIELDS AS REFEREE HALTS BOUT AT START OF ROUND 13
description: Thomas Hearns, the World Boxing Association welterweight champion, used his reach and superior punching power to score a 13th-round knockout over fifth-ranked Randy Shields in a scheduled 15-round title bout today.

title:
NEW JERSEY HOUSING;
THE HASSLES OF WORKING AT HOME
description: IT MAY be true, as prognosticators like Alvin Toffler tell us, that we are about to enter a new era characterized by ''cottage industries'' of people working at home to produce society's goods and services. If this is so, these people may have a rude awakening as they bump against 25- and 30-year-old zoning ordinances.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
MOLDING A MIND THAT CAN FACE THE SEASONS TO COME
description: ''I WANNA be an aminal when I grow up, Mama.'' I ask him, emphasizing the correct pronunciation of the word, what kind of animal he wants to be when he grows up.

title: APPALACHIA NATIVES SAY YOU CAN GO HOME AGAIN
description: On a slope outside Pikeville, the earth-moving machines of the Chapperal Coal Corporation have left one isolated remainder of the past: a small, cedar-shaded cemetery filled with monuments to hard-bitten mountain people who died before their time.

title: The Learning-Disabled And Coindre Hall Plan
description: As a citizen and a social worker at the Lowell School, a school for learning-disabled children, I was quite concerned by statements reported in the recent article ''Special School Due at Coindre Hall'' on the proposed opening of the Eagle Hill School in Huntington.

title: Stage View; TWO NEW MUSICALS, POLES APART
description: Ithink I do understand why such lavish praise has been heaped upon a very small, very short, two-flights-up entertainment in the workshop space at Playwrights Horizons, William Finn's ''March of the Falsettos.'' Some of the reasons for the little musical's sudden, sellout success are of course intrinsic. Mr. Finn's crossfire of melodies - now agitated, now serene - perfectly mirror a thoroughly confused world in which happiness and chess and psychiatry and homosexuality and the tingling touch of a lovely woman's hand are all most enthusiastically, then bitterly, intermingled.

title:
A DEMOCRAT'S COMMENT;
IT'S VOODOO TO ME
description: ''We're going to stay with the President and gamble it is going to work.'' -Howard Baker, Senate Majority Leader, speaking of the Reagan economic program on April 1.

title: DEVELOPERS EYE HORSE-SHOW GROUNDS
description: STONY BROOK THE Old Field Horse Show grounds, considered hallowed turf by Long Island horse fanciers, are up for sale, and their future as a home for some of the oldest horse shows on the East Coast is in doubt.

title: About Westchester
description: IN the brightly lit, peach-and-brown apartment, coffee is percolating, a small gray dog named Pepper is shuffling about for handouts of cherry cheesecake and Judith Mandel is talking about Auschwitz.

title: U.N. Debate Is Oil On Namibia's Fires
description: The United Nations sometimes serves the cause of compromise, but perhaps as often it sharpens conflict. That happened last week when the Security Council again took up the issue of independence for South-West Africa.

title:
Numismatics;
NO MORE COPPER CENTS?
description: f913Barring unforeseen developments the United States Mint will introduce a new kind of one-cent piece - a coin consisting mostly of zinc, instead of copper - before the end of this year. That became likely at the end of last month when the Treasury Department got the green light from the House Subcommittee on Consumer Affairs and Coinage.

title: PIGGOTT OUT OF HOSPITAL
description: Lester Piggott, top British jockey, left a hospital last night after surgery on his right ear. The ear was damaged in an accident Thursday at Epsom.

title: JOHANNESBURG
description: IN the days when South Africa's lawmakers were busy piecing together the structure of racial separation known as apartheid, which now seems ever so slowly to be coming unstuck, they displayed a genius for euphemisms. Sometimes these seemed to carry an edge of mockery, as when they passed a law in 1959 that was intended to bar black students from universities attended by whites and named it the Extension of University Education Act.

title: A Lament For Vietnam
description: I can understand Doan Van Toai's disillusionment very well, but I would not conclude, as he suggests, that the failure is one of ideology (''A Lament for Vietnam,'' March 29).

title: SURVIVING IN AFRICA
description: MARY LACEY By Maureen Connell. 277 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $11.95.

title: Publishers Face the Future
description: Representatives of the American Newspaper Publishers Association convene in Chicago this weekend with a chaotic year behind them and major challenges ahead.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: The Suffolk Democratic and Republican chairmen - Dominic J. Baranello and Anthony Prudenti, respectively - are close to agreement on the creation of new judgeships for the county and a bipartisan split of the judicial spoils.

title: TWO TASTEFULLY OPULENT RELEASES
description: At a time when minimalist esthetics dominate rock and funk, the latest albums by Deniece Williams and Quincy Jones go against the grain by flaunting a near-symphonic opulence. ''My Melody'' (Columbia/ ARC 37048), Miss Williams's fourth solo album, is an inspired collaboration with Thom Bell, the Philadelphia songwriter and producer whose hits with the Stylistics and the Spinners in the early 70's epitomized pop-soul elegance. Quincy Jones's ''The Dude'' (A&M SP-3721) is a light romantic entertainment featuring a number of top session musicians and singers. As Mr. Jones's records usually do, ''The Dude'' incorporates the latest trends, in this case, rap records, into a high-gloss, pop-soul format.

title: POLIICAL SEMINAR OF A COLORADAN INVOLVES VOTERS IN GOVERNMENT
description: After 46 years of teaching, 81-year-old A.G. Waldrop became a student, one of about 250 people attending what has become an annual event in the nation's capital, the Wirth Washington Seminar.

title: B. SAKOWITZ LED FASHION CHAIN
description: Bernard Sakowitz, retired chairman of Sakowitz Inc., a Houston-based chain of fashion specialty stores, died yesterday in this Phoenix suburb, company officials said. He was 74 years old.

title: WASHINGTON
description: IN its first three months, the Reagan Administration has sounded an almost daily alarm about the Soviet threat. Preoccupation with the Russians has dominated foreign policy and has also produced some of the Administration's first discernible difficulties. ''Moscow is the greatest source of international insecurity today,'' Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said last week. ''Let us be plain about it. Soviet promotion of violence as the instrument of change constitutes the greatest danger to the world.''

title: TWO NOVELS
description: DALE LOVES SOPHIE TO DEATH By Robb Forman Dew. 217 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $11.95.

title: Hungary Plans 5-Day Workweek, Joining All in Bloc but Rumania
description: The Government of Hungary, evidently seeking to avert labor unrest, has taken its first step toward instituting a five-day workweek.

title: MYSTERIES, JUNIOR DIVISION
City Council Redistricting Panel Chooses Officers Before Hearing
description: The City Council Redistricting Commission has elected Marvin Markus, a financial analyst from Brooklyn, as chairman.

title: KEEPING SPACE PEACEFUL
description: To the Editor:

title:
PERSPECTIVES;
THE CASE AGAINST REAGAN'S CUTBACKS
description: THE fundamental stance of both Democratic and Republican Administrations on education since the mid-1960's has been to put the leverage of the Federal Government behind equal opportunity for those most frequently denied it - the children of poor people, racial and cultural minorities and the handicapped. That stance is weakening fast under leadership that would rather save a buck than save a child and that prefers the easy flow of unrestricted and reduced Federal funds to states and school districts to the inherent difficulty of focusing its money on national problems.

title: COUNTING CHICKENS IN THE POLITICAL ROOST
description: SOME political chickens came home to roost last week when State Senator Eugene J. Bedell, Democrat of Keansburg, told Governor Byrne he intended to block the Governor's appointment of Daniel J. O'Hern to the State Supreme Court. Mr. O'Hern, currently Counsel to the Governor, is a former Mayor of Red Bank.

title: SOCCER VICTORY PERKS UP SPIRIT OF TORRID CAIRO
description: For days now Cairo has been in the sweltering grip of a hamsin, a furnace of still air from the desert that has had sweltering Egyptians cursing the premature arrival of summer.

title: TRIBE REFUSES TO GIVE UP BATTLE FOR BIG HORN RIVER
description: The Crow tribe has not given up its fight for ownership of a 50-mile section of the Big Horn River, despite a ruling last month by the United States Supreme Court that the river belonged to the state.

title: A HEATED RACE FOR SUPERVISOR
description: TOWN Supervisor elections are often routine, issueless and predictable, but that won't be the case in East Hampton this year. The contest for Supervisor shapes up as one of the most interesting and one of the most heated election contests on the Island this year. The candidates - Mary Fallon, the Republican incumbent, and Larry Cantwell, a Democratic councilman -are both formidable vote-getters. Neither has lost an election yet.

title: FRANCE, ON ELECTION EVE, ANNOUNCES GRAIN SALE TO SOVIET
description: The French Government, in an announcement certain to appeal to farmers on the eve of a presidential election, said today that it would sell 600,000 tons of grain to the Soviet Union.

title: Bundles of Energy In Microbiology
description: Mankind is often accused of squandering energy, but what it lacks in foresight it may once again make up in 11th-hour ingenuity, according to a study released last week by Congress's Office of Technology Assessment. The report says that biological technologies - including gene-splicing and synthetic creation of microorganisms - could dramatically reduce American dependence on oil and coal for energy and raw materials.

title: Cosmos, Rowdies Renew Keen Rivalry
description: The Cosmos and the Tampa Bay Rowdies play at Giants Stadium in the New Jersey Meadowlands today, renewing one of the fiercest rivalries in the North American Soccer League.

title: FOR THE LOVE OF MUSIC
description: Ever since they stopped being nomads and settled into permanent dwellings, people have collected objects linked to their interests and affections. For some reason, a collector's passions seem most easily aroused by artifacts that combine a utilitarian function with decorative merit, as witness old collections of ornate pottery or weapons, or-more recently-collections of "antique" motor cars, period clocks and watches or old tools. So it is not surprising that, as the phonograph rounds out its first century, old record players of all kinds are being eagerly sought by collectors. After all, for many people, the love of music is one of their strongest and most durable emotional commitments, and if their musicality is matched by a penchant for fine mechanical contrivances, they are likely to find the collection of musical automata most rewarding. Some of these mechanical music makers actually precede the phonograph by yet another century or more. There has been, for example, an an active collector's market for music boxes ever since they gained , popularity among the well-to-do in the latter 1700's. Both the earlier kind, which work with tuned tines plucked by a studded roll, and the later sort, which employ slotted metal disks, now command prices ranging into the thousands of dollars, and several shops are devoted exclusively to these tinkling mementos of yesteryear. As for the phonograph collectors, they seem ti fall into groups of specialists. Some are interested only in models using the original Edision cylinders rather than flat records.

title: HOW TO START AN AIRLINE: PEOPLE EXPRESS POISED TO FLY
description: NEWARK There it goes now,'' said Gerald L. Gitner. The Boeing 737 roared on takeoff past the second-floor corner office window at Newark Airport's North Terminal. Mr. Gitner and Donald C. Burr watched like proud fathers. The gleaming jet, the first in their proposed fleet, was undergoing tests last week by a team from the Federal Aviation Agency. Mr. Burr, 39, and Mr. Gitner, 36, plan to give birth to an airline this Thursday.

title: CARDINALS WIN 7TH STRAIGHT
description: Gene Tenace hit a three-run home run and Bob Shirley and Bruce Sutter combined on a four-hitter today to lead the St. Louis Cardinals to their seventh straight victory, a 5-1 decision over the Pittsburgh Pirates.

title: INDUSTRIAL AREAS IN MIDWEST HIT HARD BY HOUSING SLUMP
description: Bruno Pasquinelli, a major Chicago-area home builder who has also developed land in Florida and Colorado, used to employ 130 carpenters in the mid-70's. By late 1979 he employed five and now he employs about a dozen. A builder of houses that sell for $40,000 to $50,000, he managed to break even in 1979 but experienced substantial losses in 1980. He is now engaged in joint ventures with savings and loan associations. He is doing more building in Colorado than in Illinois because the demand for his houses in the Chicago area has decreased from 500 homes a year to 80.

title: Mary Patricia Guck Bride of Robert Lane, Accountant
description: Mary Patricia Guck, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John Kelly Guck of Forest Hills Gardens, Queens, and Quogue, L.I., was married at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola yesterday to Robert Lawrence Lane, son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond L. Lane of Oradell, N.J. The Rev. Thomas Ambrose performed the ceremony.

title: Caroline Rockefeller, Duke Alumna, Bride Of David Spencer, Architectural Restorer
description: Caroline Parker Rockefeller, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Godfrey A. Rockefeller of Gibson Island, Md., was married there yesterday to David Robert Spencer, son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert C. Spencer of Petersburg, Ill. The Rev. Myron Bloy, uncle of the bride, performed the Episcopal ceremony at St. Christopher's by the Sea.

title: CATHOLIC SCHOOLS EXPECTING A TURNAROUND IN FORTUNES
description: The mood at the annual convention of the National Catholic Educational Association in New York last week was markedly different from that of the past few years. Gone were the unhappy faces and expressions of frustration. For the first time in about a decade, principals and teachers in Catholic schools were facing the future with optimism.

title:
THE CAREFUL SHOPPER;
Outdoor Gear Discounted At Fairfield Trading Post
description: Spring fever has prompted one reader to recommend a favorite source of outdoor equipment, the Fairfield Trading Post, opened in 1956. It calls itself a ''supermarket of marine and camping supplies'' with discounts of 20 to 40 percent.

title: LIFE WITH 'ANNIE' BECAME A FULL-TIME JOB
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Thomas Meehan wrote the book for the Broadway musical ''Annie.'' By THOMAS MEEHAN

title: BIG HOUSING PROJECT OFF
description: The plan to convert the abandoned 1.1 million-square-foot factory formerly occupied by the Aluminum Company of America into a luxury housing project was heralded two years ago as the largest factoryto-housing conversion ever attempted in the country. What's more, the project would have been a symbolic first step forward for Edgewater, N.J. - a backwater borough along the Hudson River that for decades was ignored as its neighbor, Fort Lee, was courted by developers.

title: FANEUIL ADAMS
description: Faneuil Adams, a retired partner in the law firm of Hill & Barlow of Boston, died Thursday in Boston.

title: B. W. Cart Fiance Of Sarah Austell
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Rhett Austell Jr. of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sarah Austell, to Benjamin Whaley Cart, son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Whaley Cart of Pamplico, S.C.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: GOVERNOR CAREY'S appearance last Wednesday in County Executive Alfred B. DelBello's office attracted more than a dozen political figures who had something to say about Mr. Carey's proposal to assume the local costs of Medicaid in the state budget.

title: AN AGENDA FOR ISRAEL
description: To the Editor:

title: Chess; TO BE GOOD- OR LUCKY?
description: If it were really better to be lucky than good, this sentiment would not be expressed just by bitter losers. But no one would deny that there are times when it is best to be both lucky and good.

title: Violinist Wins Prize
description: Ralph Evans, a violinist, won the first prize of $5,000 in the Young Artist Auditions Contest on Wednesday in Birmingham, Ala. The contest is sponsored by the National Federation of Music Clubs.

title: LONG-TERM EFFECTS OF CHEMICALS SOUGHT
description: TRENTON ALTHOUGH thousands of firefighters and dozens of specially trained state employees are regularly exposed to hazardous chemicals on the job, suprisingly little is known about the immediate or long-term health effects of such exposure.

title:
Camera;
SUMMER WORKSHOPS
WINE FANCIERS FIND RACKS IN BIG SIZES
description: SYOSSET GOING public seems to be the trend on the Island, especially when it comes to food products and equipment. First, High Bar Wholesale Foods of Oceanside and Inter-County Bakers of West Hempstead made their products available to the retail market, and now Kedco of Syosset, which sells display racks to liquor stores and restaurants, has found that opening its doors to the public is to its advantage for several reasons.

title: No Headline
description: Proud Appeal, winner of the Blue Grass Stakes and Kentucky Derby favorite, arrived at Churchill Downs today from Keeneland Race Course near Lexington.

title: THE ANATOMY OF A TRIUMPHANT MODERN DANCE
description: Paul Taylor has created a new work. That's something he does with a fair amount of regularity and predictably good results. But ''Arden Court'' has had its dancers beaming, the critics sharpening their superlatives and audiences roaring with delight at City Center, where the Paul Taylor Dance Company performs through next Sunday.

title:
SPORTS OF THE TIMES;
PROSPERITY IN THE FIGHT GAME
description: D AVE WINFIELD is 29 years old and this is his ninth season in professional baseball. If he plays into his 40th year, he will earn something more than $20 million, a tidy sum in the estimation of ribbon clerks, garbage collectors and sportswriters. To Sugar Ray Leonard, it is a fish cake. It is altogether possible that by Feb. 5, 1982, the anniversary of his first pro fight, the proprietor of the World Boxing Council's welterweight championship will have collected twice that much in five years.

title: DINAH, AGELESS, IS REVELING IN HER 60'S
description: Dinah Shore has gotten used to it by now. When most people meet her for the first time, it is not her nine gold records they remark about or her distinguished 30-year television career or how she has appeared several times on the annual Gallup poll of the 10 most admired women in the world.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
LOCAL CONTROL OF SEX EDUCATION IS A MYTH
description: AS THE state's educational bureaucracy attempts to quell the rising tide of opposition to its compulsory sex-education program, one keeps hearing a catchy little phrase: Local control.

title: NEW CLASHES SEEM TO SMASH LEBANON TRUCE
description: Syrian forces mounted heavy artillery and helicopter attacks today on Christian militia forces around the eastern town of Zahle and several other areas in the strategic Bekaa Valley.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN BATON ROUGE?
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- FRANCES FRANK MARCUS is a writer who lives in Louisiana. By FRANCES FRANK MARCUS

title: FOREIGN POLICY BY HINDSIGHT
description: DEBACLE The American Failure in Iran. By Michael Ledeen and William Lewis. 256 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $14.95.

title:
Stamps  stamp;
STREAM OF U.S. ISSUES
description: When the United States needs new postage stamp designs in a hurry the first impulse most often has been to ''Rally Around the Flag,'' and once again it is the Stars and Stripes, with more stars than stripes, and some patriotic embellishments.

title: BRIXTON BAROMETER
description: The Brixton pub I frequent is a block away from where the recent rioting took place. From the atmosphere in the pub, I knew last November that trouble was brewing in the London ghetto. Like certain Harlem bars in the 1960's, the pub acts as a barometer for the local racial weather, but to be able to read it accurately you need some historical perspective.

title: SPERM WHALE RELEASED FROM BOAT BASIN ON L.I.
description: A 25,000-pound sperm whale that had been given little chance of surviving just two days ago was released yesterday afternoon from the western tip of Fire Island. It went with an escort of 11 boats, the high hopes of the marine biologists who had nursed it back to health and the cheers of more than 5,000 people who watched it head for the open sea.

title: DEVELOPERS ALLOWED TO SUE PLANS BOARD
description: STATE Supreme Court Justice Charles R. Thom has granted developers the right to sue the Huntington Planning Board for damages because the board, according to the justice, ''pursued a plan to prevent the company from developing their property'' and was ''guilty of bad faith and abuse of their powers.''

title: STATE U. FORMS ROCKEFELLER UNITS
description: The State University of New York has established a Nelson A. Rockefeller College of Public Affairs and Policy on its Albany campus and a universitywide Rockefeller Institute of Government as a ''living memorial'' to the late Governor.

title:
VIEWS OF SPORT;
ADVICE FOR THE HIGH SCHOOL COACH WITH A STAR ATHLETE
description: It is a matter of fact that every high school coach will become involved in the recruiting process if he or she stays in the coaching profession long enough. It is also a matter of fact that not every coach is prepared to deal with this, nor do all high school coaches fully understand recruiting from the college coach's point of view. This frequently causes serious problems with misunderstandings that lead to bad feelings on the part of high school coaches toward a recruiter or the college represented.

title: SOME ARE VERY MICE INDEED
description: Name a very mice drama that won a Pulitzer Prize. The Mice Man Cometh. Where does a rabbit go to have an operation? To the Ether Bunny. What do you call a mouse's coat? A Mickey Mantle.

title: Jane Sammis is Bethroed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Quentin B. Sammis of Huntington, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Jane Howell Sammis, to William Kelly Stuart, son of Mrs. Charles E. Stuart of Durham, N.C., and the late Dr. Stuart.

title: REAGAN'S FIRST 100 DAYS
description: Steven R. Weisman is a White House correspondent for The New York Times. By Steven R. Weisman n a mild winter morning nearly 100 days ago, Ronald Reagan took his oath of office as the

title: FUEL AID EXPEDITED
description: TRENTON STATE officials are finally reporting progress in reducing the backlog of requests by lower-income families for up to $300 in Federal aid to offset heating costs.

title: Gallery View; 19TH-CENTURY GERMAN MASTERS
description: uf920One of the more reputable phenomena in a world that has lately got somewhat out of hand is the reemergence of 19th-century Germany as a subject for rational discussion. That reemergence is about to be celebrated at the Metropolitan Museum, where an exhibition called ''German Masters of the 19th Century'' opens to the public next Saturday. Organized by Stephan Waetzoldt, general director of the Berlin museums, this is a selective anthology - 96 paintings, in all, and 54 drawings - that contains a remarkably high proportion of the works from that particular period that any enthusiast for the subject would most want to see.

title: THE REGION: In Summary; It's 'Hideous' but; Try to Change It
description: Taxes may be as inevitable as death, but they don't have to be as unfair as life. In New York City, according to a study reported last week, property tax assessments are ''hideously inequitable'' and even ''savage'' in the way they favor wealthier areas over poorer ones and private homeowners over apartment dwellers.

title: Opinion Writer Is Accused Of Distorting a Quotation
description: In the article, ''Must Developers Wear Black Hats?'' (Opinion Page, April 5), Prof. John Sinton of Stockton State College quotes from my testimony before the state's Division of Water Resources in a hearing concerning the Smithville development.

title: Georgian's Porsche Earns Pole Position at Riverside
description: John Paul Jr. of Lawrenceville, Ga., drove his Porsche round the 3.25-mile Riverside International Raceway track at 121.199 miles an hour to earn the pole position for tomorrow's Los Angeles Times Grand Prix of Endurance.

title: GLADWYN HILL
description: Last Sunday morning, as millions of people were leisurely celebrating Easter, 60 men and women from several continents met in a hotel conference room for an intense three-hour colloquy entitled ''The Behavior of Large Corporations.'' The colloquists were not business people, economists or public officials. They were among the 2,000 participants at the annual convention of the 77-year-old Association of American Geographers.

title: NORTHSTAGE SHIFT TO VARIETY FORMAT
description: GLEN COVE AFTER today's closing of ''Man of La Mancha'' - one month sooner than scheduled - the Northstage Theater Restaurant will focus on presenting weekend variety entertainment (''dinner and concert'' packages) instead of producing full-scale Broadway or Broadway-bound musicals for extended runs.

title: A FRIEND'S GOODBYE: 'A TOUCH OF GREATNESS'
description: When I was a sophomore in high school, William Ken Neilson was the boy I wanted to be. He was curly haired, cool, charming, even charismatic. He was a senior at the time and, undoubtedly, the most gifted high school athlete I'd ever seen.

title: The Exterminators
description: Few magazine articles have transfixed so many readers as Jacobo Timerman's prison memoir in The New Yorker of April 20. Understandably. There is no more devastasting account of Argentine repression, and no more vivid depiction of the vermiform creatures who inhabit that country's murderous security forces.

title: Film View; THE STORY IS THE SAME BUT HOLLYWOOD HAS CHANGED
description: In all three American renderings of ''The Postman Always Rings Twice'' - James M. Cain's 1934 novel; the then-racy, now relatively decorous 1946 movie that starred Lana Turner and John Garfield; and Bob Rafelson's intense, impassioned new version, with Jack Nicholson and Jessica Lange - a pet cat is accidentally electrocuted during the course of a murder scheme. ''Ain't that a shame? Killed her deader than hell,'' laments a cop in Mr. Cain's novel. In the 1946 movie, this same cop is so saddened by the cat's death he very nearly cries. In Mr. Rafelson's version, the dead cat is tossed to the ground and nobody bats an eye. Mr. Cain's story, hard-boiled to begin with, is a lot more hard-boiled now.

title: MOUNT VERNON, N.Y.
description: A''MAGNET'' school formed here five years ago in the wake of a Federal desegregation order has a problem: It can't keep up with the demand.

title:
Gardening;
CARE OF FRUIT TREES HAS REWARDS
description: THE ads are pretty convincing. Those photos of trees so heavily laden with fruit that they bend to the ground make you want to go right out and buy one of each kind. To clinch the sale, the photos are always accompanied by a caption that says you can grow all the fruit you can eat in your own backyard.

title: YOUNG SCIENTIST FACING CHALLENGE
description: FOR the past year, David Mitzi, a 17-year-old senior at Westhill High School in Stamford, has spent much of his time in his laboratory, experimenting with one of his many projects.

title: EXPLORING CAREERS IN HUMAN SERVICES
description: WHEN Jody Lehrbaum, a music therapist at St. Agnes Hospital children's unit in White Plains, was a student at White Plains High School, she knew she wanted to use her music training. ''But I did not know what career options were available,'' she recalled.

title: LIBERAL GROUP TO WORK TO KEEP DEMOCRATS IN CONGRESS
description: The National Committee for an Effective Congress, which once enthusiastically financed some liberal Republican candidates for the House and Senate, has cast itself in the role of helping to preserve the Democratic Party as a national force in the 1982 elections.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
GOING THE WRONG WAY BY RAIL
description: THE years of promises of improved service for the half-million people who commute to work by rail in the Northeast are no closer to being kept now than they were a decade ago.

title: Lauren Mitchell Wed to H.S. Rauschenbach
description: Lauren Mitchell, daughter of Mrs. Louis Hauptfleisch of Summit, N.J., and the late Don W. Mitchell, was married at the Episcopal Church of the Holy Spirit in Orleans, Mass., yesterday to Henri Simon Rauschenbach, son of Dr. and Mrs. Paul E. Rauschenbach of Paterson, N.J. Retired Bishop George E. Rath of the Episcopal Diocese of Newark and the Rev. Arlan Baillie performed the cermony.

description: 1 8 3 GORKY PARK, by Martin Cruz Smith. (Random House, $13.95.) A triple murder in Moscow leads to a chase across two continents. 2 2 15 MASQUERADE, by Kit Williams. (Schocken Books, $9.95.) A fantastic tale about the Sun, the Moon and a lost treasure. 3 1 27 THE COVENANT, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $17.95.) Fifteen thousand years of South African history. 4 6 4 CREATION, by Gore Vidal. (Random House, $15.95.) title: Jersey Jail Is Damaged In a Protest by Prisoners
description: About 100 prisoners at the Monmouth County Correctional Center here broke through a dormitory wall in a two-day disturbance that ended tonight, officials said.

title: by Peggy Schmidt
description: Lisa Fredericks, an English major who will be graduating from Marymount Manhattan College this spring, is looking for a research or reporting position in the news media. She is hopeful that she will have an edge over other liberal arts graduates because in addition to her writing credentials she has developed a basic understanding of business. As a participant in her school's Women in Management Honor Track, Miss Fredericks took practical courses in marketing, economics and public relations and interned for a television network and a publishing firm.

title: FOR ISRAEL AND ITS FOES LEBANON IS LESS A NATION THAN A BATTLEFIELD
description: There is peace across the Sinai Peninsula, along Israel's border with Egypt. There is peace along the Jordan River and the stretch of desert that straddles the Israeli-Jordanian frontier. There is even peace in the rolling Golan Heights, on the border with Syria. But across Israel's border with Lebanon, there is a nasty little war that has furnished a breeding ground for terrorism and has provoked Israeli retaliatory and pre-emptive strikes.

title: THE CELTICS REGROUP AS THE 76ERS RELAX
description: While the Philadelphia 76ers made jokes and dressed for a practice session today at The Spectrum, Coach Billy Cunningham was saying, ''If they don't beat us tomorrow, they are in trouble. There is no way we're going to lose three in a row.''

title: Body Language; For Burn Victims
description: The fundamental problem, said Dr. John F. Burke, was to create a substance that would ''talk'' or ''interact'' with the rest of the body as if it belonged to it. It took 10 years of labor -down to assuring that the distance between pores approximated the normal distance of 50 microns - but last week Dr. Burke announced the development of an artificial skin that, in tests on human burn victims, proved better than grafts from human donors.

description: To the Editor:

description: In analyzing their dependency needs, women should avoid comparing themselves unfavorably with men, who clearly hold no monopoly on mental health (''The Cinderella Syndrome,'' by Colette Dowling, March 22).

description: A Camaro that runs on nitrous oxide will be shown by its owner, Scott Shafiroff, in a display of road racers, stock cars, rally cars, go-karts, formula cars, funny cars, antiques, vans and radiocontrolled cars from noon to 6 P.M. today in the parking lot of Victoria Station Restaurant at Water Street and Lexington Avenue in White Plains.

On the contrary, it taught him fundamentals about painting - drawing, formation of the figure through steady modulation of color, light and shade, and compositional arrangements - that too many artists never learn. They don't have the patience and sometimes they don't have the ability. Now in his ninth decade, Mr. Csoka has both.

title: No Happy Birthday
description: Amtrak, the national passenger railroad service, celebrates its tenth anniversary this week. However, if proposed cuts in Federal subsidies are approved, the milestone could be its last.

description: The nation's newest attack submarine was launched here today as more than 1,000 demonstrators protested the use of nuclear arms and the naming of the vessel the Corpus Christi.

title: Sara A. Rasmussen, Dr. Richard Fraser Married in Suburbs
description: Sara Anne Rasmussen, a candidate for a doctorate in comparative religion at Harvard University, was married yesterday to Dr. Richard Alexander Ross Fraser, a neurosurgeon. The Rev. Edward Johnston performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Rye, N.Y.

title: Scattered Sunshine Clutters Reagan's Economic Outlook
description: A sense of urgency is one of the strongest things Ronald Reagan has going for his untested economic revitalization program. That is hardly what last week's economic news lent. Not only was growth surprisingly strong. Inflation had slowed. Murray L. Weidenbaum, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, led the charge to strip the sheep's clothing from the wolf at the door.

title: BUSINESS PUTS GRADS IN THE ARTS ON HOLD...
description: THE greater emphasis on liberal arts that is sweeping college campuses - despite the scarcity of jobs for professors of history or literature - is raising questions about where liberal-arts students will work after graduation.

title: Mary M. Cross Is Married
description: Mary Moore Cross, daughter of Mrs. James F. Cross 3d of South Orange, N.J., and the late Mr. Cross, was married yesterday to Peter Griswold Exline, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Paul Gettis Exline of Tulsa, Okla. The Rev. Shannon Bernard of the First Universalist-Unitarian Church of Essex County performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's mother. Mrs. Exline is an assistant story editor at Columbia Pictures in Burbank, Calif. Her husband is creative-affairs director of Neufeld-Davis Productions in Beverly Hills, Calif.

title: DECORATORS' SHOWCASE
description: A 37-room, turn-of-the-century mansion in Englewood will become a decorators' showcase next Sunday. The house, which sits on nearly four acres on East Hill, was built in 1903 by Oscar Sewall, a member of a ship-building family. Except for its use as a soldiers' convalescent home during World War I, it has always been a private residence.

title: NEW YORK TOLD TO CORRECT NUCLEAR EMERGENCY PLANS
description: Deficiencies in the mandatory plans for coping with accidents at nuclear plants in New York State have been found by the Federal Government, which is giving the state and counties four months to correct them.

title: May 24 Bridal Set By Carmen Suardy
description: Carmen Solano of Queens Village, Queens, and Julian Suardy of Santo Domingo, Dominican Republic, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Carmen Suardy, to James Wasserman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Wasserman of Marblehead, Mass. A May 24 wedding is planned in New York.

title: WINNETKA, Ill.
description: NESTLED comfortably among the mansions of this community, where success stories are wrapped up in neat packages of $250,000 homes, half a mile from Lake Michigan where white sails billow against Chicago's winds, is New Trier East High School, whose image is a shining reflection of Chicago's North Shore. This image perpetuates itself with glittery graduates such as Ann-Margret, Rock Hudson and Charlton Heston; with the likes of W. Clement Stone traversing the lake drive in a limousine; and with publicity from the movie ''Ordinary People,'' filmed a few miles away, portraying the price some pay for success and maintaining its appearances..

title: COLUMBIA UNIVERSITY SEKS TO BE A BETTER NEIGHBOR
description: Columbia University, whose dominance as an educational institution and landlord in Morningside Heights has often led it into conflict with its neighbors, has embarked on a new effort to improve its community and government relations.
