title: Charles H. Spilman Is Dead at 70; Ex-Editor of Providence Journal
description: Charles H. Spilman, retired executive editor of The Providence (R.I.) Journal-Bulletin, died here Thursday. He was 70 years old.

title: TECHNOLOGICAL PROMISE
description: To the Editor:

title: UNUSED RAIL RIGHTS OF WAY BECOMING SCENIC TRAILS
description: ONE OF New Jersey's most abundant resources, and one that has started to be recycled, is its abandoned railroad rights-of-way. More than 1,000 miles of old, unused tracks and roadbeds traverse some of the most scenic landscapes in the state, and they are being adapted for recreational uses such as hiking and bicycling.

title: ANGLICAN UNITY TO BE A MAJOR ISSUE AT BISHOPS' FIRST U.S. CONFERENCE
description: In their first conference in the United States, about two dozen Anglican bishops and archbishops from around the world will begin to consider tomorrow how much unity is to be desired in the far-flung, multicultural Anglican Communion, an issue as old as King Henry VIII's differences with the Pope.

title: Dani Shapiro Plans Wedding in August
description: Mr. and Mrs. Paul H. Shapiro of Hillside, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Daneile Joyce Shapiro, to Dan Mitchell Storper, son of David Harrison Storper of Whitestone, Queens, and the late Natalie Reichlin Storper.

title: Chicago School Chief Told To Stay Out of Politics
description: Mayor Jane M. Byrne today warned Superintendent Ruth B. Love of the city's schools to stay out of politics. Mrs. Byrne, apparently angered over last week's uproar over reports that Miss Love's office, conference room and car were rigged with illegal electronic surveillance devices, said the incident, which resulted in the resignation of Miss Love's top aide, should be a lesson to the schools chief.

title: LITTLE WINNERS
description: MAGAZINE CHILD ATHELETES OPENER PAGE 59 Emily Greenspan, a staff writer at Self Magazine, is a former professional figure skater. By Emily Greenspan The Playland Ice Casino in Rye, N.Y., is unheated and beer cans lie crumpled under the empty bleachers after last night's hockey game. A blue haze of stale cigarette smoke hangs over the ice. There is silence, except for the occasional scrape of steel blades, as 20 of us kids ''with potential'' trace and retrace our figure eights.

title: RINGING CHANGES ON JAMAICAN REGGAE
description: Dub is an increasingly popular and influential subspecies of reggae, Jamaica's popular music. Dub records often start out sounding like conventional reggae - a singer intones an opening phrase, keyboards and guitars begin clickclacking against each other in percussive counterpoint, bass and drums lock into step, a horn section contributes an anticipatory fanfare. But almost immediately, the music begins to unravel. The singer and horns vanish, leaving only a ghostly, shimmering electronic echo. Bass and drums crunch dutifully onward as snatches of guitars, keyboards and other instruments appear out of nowhere, repeat themselves for a measure or two, and then evaporate. Sometimes the instruments fall in together for part of a verse and the music's texture thickens. Sometimes almost everything disappears and one hears a single drum beat, a bass note, then nothing, nothing at all.

title: 100 Days
description: Ronald Reagan's first hundred days have not been, as he once hoped, like Franklin Roosevelt's. Even before an assassin stole thirty of them, the new President came to understand that he could not electrify the country with one legislative surge. Like FDR, Mr. Reagan aims to restore American strength and confidence. But he faces a different economic crisis, confronts a different Congress and brings a different concept of revival. Unlike any recent President, he thinks Federal power should not be wielded to shape America's economy or society. So by recent standards of Presidential leadership, he has not done much - even as, by his lights, he has accomplished a great deal.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Catskill Brass Quintet In Wide-Ranging Program
description: The Catskill Brass Quintet played a program of Elizabethan, Baroque and 20th-century music at Carnegie Recital Hall on Tuesday. The most interesting pieces came toward the beginning and the end of the evening - namely, a Canzona in the style of Gabrieli by Samuel Scheidt, transcriptions of three dance pieces by Anthony Holborne, an attendant at the court of Elizabeth I, and a Quintet for Brass Instruments by Alvin Etler, an American who died in 1973.

title:
Photography View;
A HARROWING WORLD VERSUS THE GOOD LIFE
description: It is hard to imagine two photographers more different in outlook and feeling than Roland L. Freeman and Joel-Peter Witkin. Yet both have produced substantial bodies of unusually interesting work which they are now showing in one-man shows in New York. Freeman is a photojournalist whose book and exhibition ''Southern Roads/City Pavements,'' at the International Center of Photography, 1130 Fifth Avenue at 94th Street, is a warm, straightforward portrayal of real life that transforms reportage into poetry. Witkin, who is showing at the Robert Samuel Gallery, 795 Broadway between 10th and 11th Streets, through May 11, is more overtly artistic in his approach to a harrowing world that exists primarily in his own imagination. Both, however, have something of value to say about the world we all live in.

title: APPROVAL OF ONCE-REJECTED PACT ENDS 15-DAY STRIKE AT SHORT LINE
description: A 15-day strike against Short Line-Hudson Transit Lines Inc., a bus company that primarily serves parts of New Jersey and New York, ended yesterday as drivers and mechanics accepted a three-year contract that they had rejected on Thursday, a company executive said.

title: Music; BASICALLY BAROQUE FOR THE BASS AND ORGAN
description: ''THE spirit of the baroque was one of great spontaneity,'' says Gary Karr, the virtuoso who has almost single-handedly given the double bass widespread credibility as a solo instrument. ''I think the fact that I play a lot of new music, and thus have to struggle through contemporary thought processes, makes me more creative when I do get back to pieces from earlier periods.''

title: ON THE LEGITIMACY OF COBB'S RECORD
description: o the Sports Editor:

title: PAUL JONES PLAYS PIANO RECITAL
description: Paul Jones began his piano program at Carnegie Recital Hall on Friday evening with promise, capturing the dance styles of Bach's B minor French Suite with an absolute rightness of tempo and a straightforward, unpretentious musicality. Mr. Jones chose clean, pedal-free textures and preferred terraced dynamics and echo effects over Romantic arcs of crescendo and decrescendo. In short, the piano became an effective surrogate for its Baroque counterparts, not an orchestral instrument.

title: RECALLING A GENTEEL GREYSTONE STATION
description: COMMUTING isn't what it used to be. Take stations, for instance. During the 1940's I commuted to New York City from a New York Central Hudson Division station in north Yonkers called Greystone. The station building was a small, neat structure, made - appropriately - of gray stone and separated from the Hudson River only by the platforms and the four main-line tracks. The sidewalks were always swept, or shoveled, and the windows were always clean. It was a cozy haven in winter and a cool retreat in summer.

title: ISLANDERS EXCITED OVER ALL-NEW YORK PLAYOFF ENCOUNTER
description: F OR the third time in the seven years that the Islanders have qualified for the National Hockey League playoffs, the Rangers have become their opponents in one of the series. As clubs that share the New York label, and with fans of each constantly urging on their favorites, they could hardly have been prevented from turning a natural rivalry into a hotbed of emotion and excitement.

title: Fairfield County Chorale To Sing Dvorak's Requiem
description: The Fairfield County Chorale and the Amor Artis Orchestra will perform Dvorak's Requiem tonight at 8 o'clock in Carnegie Hall.

title: Video Display Terminals Pass Tests for Radiation
description: New radiation tests indicate that video display terminals, the computerized typewriters used at work by about seven million Americans, emit ''little or no harmful radiation under normal operating conditions,'' the Government has reported.

title:
HISTORIC SCHOOL, MODERN PROBLEMS;
ALBUQUERQUE, N.M.
description: STUDENTS in Menaul School's 11th-grade English class were asked one recent afternoon to find the mistake in this sentence: ''Dorm life keeps the student away from things that are not so good for them.'' After spotting the error, students talked about the composition that followed, as well as other essays on topics such as integration through busing and care for the elderly.

title: A BROOKLYN COUNCILMAN IS ON TRIAL IN LARCENY CASE
description: A New York City Councilman, Vincent A. Riccio, has spent the last three weeks weeks in a courtroom here, fighting charges of grand larceny and conspiracy in a case that, according to his lawyer, never had the Councilman as its main target.

title: Use Reason, Not Passion, On Airport Expansion
description: The Opinion Page piece about the Westchester County Airport (''Westchester Airport: A Safer Course,'' April 5) is based on much of the same misinformation and misconceptions as previous articles. To its credit, however, this recent article does recognize the fact that the airport is not going to go away, and the problems it generates must be dealt with reasonably.

title: BATTLING NUTRITION OGRES
description: WESTBURY ''HOW can I get my child to eat vegetables?'' ''My son takes medication for hyperactivity. Are there foods he should avoid?'' ''Is honey better than sugar?'' ''Can a child get a balanced meal at one of those fast-food places?'' ''My daughter says she's not hungry. Should I force her to eat?''

title: JERSEY BAR UNIT WEIGHS ASKING PLACE FOR WOMEN ON SUPREME COURT
description: The New Jersey Bar Association has set the stage for a possible vote next month on a resolution asking Governor Byrne to appoint a qualified woman to the State Supreme Court.

title: THE CORPORATE TAX BITE
description: While the April 15 deadline for individual income taxpayers is recent enough to still cause nightmares, most of America's major corporations went through it all with a month-earlier deadline, and some results are in.

title: Follow-Up on the News; 'Hot' Spy in the Cold
description: When Cosmos 954, a crippled Soviet spy satellite carrying a nuclear reactor, re-entered the earth's atmosphere and disintegrated over northern Canada in January 1978, it set off a frantic search for its fragments. The reactor, which had provided electrial power for the satellite, contained 100 pounds of uranium 235, which can give off deadly radioactivity for hundreds of centuries.

title: WOODY ALLEN'S NEW BROADWAY PLAY MIGHT JUST BE ABOUT WOODY ALLEN
description: This is how it began: Woody Allen sat in the back bedroom of his apartment one morning (''In September or something, approximately,'' he explains; he is not being flippant, only vague) addressing himself to a typewriter. Prose he writes in longhand. A play he types. This play he finished in six or seven weeks, revising it many times after that, and even fooling around with a few lines here and there last week. Tomorrow night the play, ''The Floating Light Bulb,'' opens at the Vivian Beaumont at Lincoln Center.

title:
ON THE ISLE;
TO THE DOGS
description: Today is the day all good dog lovers can come to the aid of their favorite canines - by cheering them on, at least. At Eisenhower Park in East Meadow, Norwegian elkhounds will go on show at Parking Lot 8 at 10 A.M. At Cantiague Park in Hicksville, the Newfoundland Dog Show gets under way at 11 A.M. At Nassau Beach Park in Lido, an All-Breed Obedience and Trial Match Show begins at 7:30 A.M. All three are free to spectators.THE FRENCH WAY

title: HASSAM'S ENDURING POPULARITY
description: EAST HAMPTON OF the many American artists who developed their own version of Impressionism in the late 19th century, Frederick Childe Hassam (1859-1935) is among the most celebrated. His career was marked by singular critical and popular success, and his canvases and prints enjoy continued favor with the general public and the collector. Guild Hall's current exhibition, surveying Hassam's long and prolific career and including some works only recently rediscovered, clearly shows why.

title: CRAFTS
description: ''SINEW, Bead and Quill: The Making of Design,'' a new addition to the American Indian Gallery at the Newark Museum, calls attention to an important decorative tradition in native American artifacts. For those who can concentrate on buckskin leggings with recorded lamas' chants in the background, this display offers a quiet change of pace from the ceremonial splendor of Tibetan art that now dominates the museum.

title: LIFE IN THE BURROW
description: As a child, I had a clear picture of what a pack rat looked like. He was was small, brown, with a furry tail, and carried a trampish red bandanna over his shoulder. He spent his days collecting objects which he took to his burrow at night to pore over and arrange. I was probably heavily "Wind in the Willows" because I was conviced that pack rats wore waistcoats on chilly days. But what I did not realize was that I was living in an active nest of them. That my family, and those before them were accomplished packrats, and the suburban burrow I grew up in was filled with their accumulations. Four generations of thrifty households run on the principle of "Save it-- it might just come in handy someday" made for crowded rooms. No minimal funiture arrangements for us. Dining-room chairs pressed closely against each other; there were more sofas in the living room than floor space. The Steinway upright loomed in the library corner flanked by papiermache whatnots that tripped up the music teacher every Wednesday afternoon. Unless one knew the territory, going about in the house at night was frankly hazardous. Every so often, an unwary guest would try for the bathroom in the dark with predictable collisions. If he made it over the six slippery Oriental rugs, he was bound to crash into the walnut pipe organ, whose keyboard cover fell silently open in damp weather, or fa over the two rocking chairs.

title: NEW VIENNA SUBWAY IS SMOOTH AS A WALTZ
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- PAUL HOFMANN, formerly a Times correspondent, lives in Rome. By PAUL HOFMANN

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
FEAR, TOO, IS A FORM OF POLLUTION
description: ''PLEASE, Mr. Bruckman!'' The woman's voice broke as she cried into the telephone. ''Please do not let the Hempstead Resource Recovery Plant reopen! I have small children. Don't let anything happen to them!''

title: POLICE CONTRACTS EMBROIL COUNTIES
description: THE salary dispute between Nassau County and its Patrolmen's Benevolent Association - believed to have been settled after an arbitration panel's award -appears to be heating up.

title: Art; SCULPTOR FAVORS 'MOVING' WORKS
description: SOUTH SALEM WHEN people compare Sterett-Gittings Kelsey's sculptures to the work of Degas, she doesn't mind in the least. ''It's not a bad association to have,'' she says. But the only thing Miss Kelsey has in common with the French Impressionist is a partiality for portraying dancers. The work she does in her studio here is very much her own, and her ballerinas, athletes and animals are studies in motion.

title: AROUND THE NATION: In Summary; Los Angeles Pupils Get Busing Choice
description: Does a school board commit an intentional act of segregation by eliminating a busing program designed to correct unintentional segregation? A United States Supreme Court Justice pondered last week, while 7,000 Los Angeles schoolchildren, exercising an option offered by the Board of Education, abandoned the city's three-yearold busing program.

title:
Art;
A CEREBRAL GAME AT THE HUDSON RIVER
description: YONKERS THE Hudson River Museum provided this reviewer with a number of surprises in its current exhibition of sculpture by Siah Armajani. First, he had thought surrealism was dead as an art movement. Second, he never expected to eat lunch on or hang his coat on a work of art. Finally, he had thought that Richard Koshalek, the museum's brilliant former director, was safely off in Los Angeles and that the Hudson River Museum's radical, innovative exhibitions would be coming to a close.

title: Editors' Choice
description: seller description. AN IMAGINED WORLD, by June Goodfield. (Harper & Row, $12.95.)

title: 45 JAPANESE WORKERS ARE REPORTED EXPOSED TO NUCLEAR RADIATION
description: Japanese officials disclosed today that as many as 45 workers were exposed to radiation in January during repairs of the chronically defective Tsuruga nuclear power plant.

title: BRIGHTER OUTLOOK FOR AIRLINE STOCKS
description: Over the years, the airlines, with their, if you'll pardon the expression, repeated downdrafts and altitude gains, have shown themselves to be a classic example of a cyclical industry - much as the retail industry, which tracks the economy, is considered cyclical, while the food industry, which is needed in good times and bad, is not. Both business and pleasure travel rise in good economic times, while they are fall off during recessions.

title: No Headline
description: In choosing my present career, I did not choose ''not to work'' nor did I choose to become dependent.

title: Abolition of Legal Aid Opposed
description: The deans of 143 of the nation's 168 accredited law schools have issued a statement opposing President Reagan's plan to abolish Federal financing for legal aid for the poor. Substantial financing for legal aid ''is essential if we are to make progress toward meeting the goal of equal justice under law,'' said the statement, which was issued Thursday and circulated in Congress. The President asked Congress last month to eliminate all Federal financing for legal aid and abolish the Legal Services Corporation.

title: David Shafer, Miss Schecter Will Be Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jerrold L. Schecter of Washington have made known the engagement of their daughter, Evelind Anne Schecter, to David Michael Shafer, son of Prof. Paul R. Shafer of Enfield, N.H., and Betty H. Shafer of Somerville, Mass. A June 21 wedding is planned at the Schecter home.

title: SPORKIN
description: Stanley Sporkin, 49, corporate policeman at the Securities and Exchange Commission for the last seven years, is leaving to become general counsel of the Central Intelligence Agency. Mr. Sporkin, whose pursuit of companies in payoff cases as head of the S.E.C.'s enforcement division earned him some enmity, will rejoin William J. Casey, director of Central Intelligence. The two worked together when Mr. Casey was S.E.C. chief from 1971 to 1973. The new S.E.C. head, John Shad, is thus free to pick his own enforcement chief.

title: ARGENTINA SUFFERING A SHORTAGE OF POLITICAL OPTIONS
description: Sixty political activists gathered for dinner recently and released a statement asserting that Argentina was undergoing ''one of the most difficult and dramatic moments'' in its history. Military rule, they added, ''has run out.''

title: THE REGION: In Summary; Abscam Jurors Hear Williams
description: Defense attorneys for Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. have argued throughout his Abscam bribery trial that the Senator did not mean what he was recorded as saying. Last week the New Jersey Democrat added the weight of his own testimony to that argument, but he appeared to gain little by it.

title: SCHOOL STUDY DIDN'T PUSH KEY POINT, COLEMAN SAYS
description: James Coleman, the author of a controversial study that found that students learn more in private and parochial high schools than in public ones, now says that the document published two weeks ago did not emphasize the most significant conclusions of his study and that the data on which it was based were flawed.

title: MYTHICAL RULER AN EASY WINNER
description: Mythical Ruler, the second choice at 2-1, beat Classic Go Go, the even-money favorite, in the Stepping Stone Purse for 3-year-olds today at Churchill Downs.

title: THE WORLD: In Summary; The French Decide Their Differences In Voting Today
description: French voters tend to be a dour lot who generally gripe their way to the polls. But although France is one of the few countries where wages have roughly kept ahead of inflation, voters' discontent focuses on economic issues today as they choose among 10 candidates for President in the first round of balloting.

title: CHARLES COHEN TO MARRY ALEXANDRA GILBERT IN JUNE
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward Gilbert have announced the engagement of Mr. Gilbert' daughter, Alexandra Gilbert, to Charles Steven Cohen,son of Mr. and Mrs. Sherman Cohen of Greenwich, Conn.

title: CRITICS' CHOICE
description: THEATER Barnard Hughes was a superb, if less than famous, character actor for years before he became a star as the quirky Irish father in Hugh Leonard's ''Da.'' Now Mr. Hughes is returning to the New York stage for the first time since that triumph - and who is he playing? Another quirky Irish father, in Brian Friel's ''Translations'' at the Manhattan Theater Club.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: CUBAN SHOWCASE
description: Many of Havana's apartment houses and office buildings could use some sprucing up, but otherwise the city of two million people is well kept. Streets are swept and safe for pedestrians. Service is courteous and crowds orderly.

title: Soviet Moves to Offset End Of U.S. Aid to Nicaragua
description: The Soviet Union and its allies are apparently moving quickly to compensate for the suspension of aid to Nicaragua by the Reagan Administration.

title: LLOYD-NAVRATILOVA DUEL RESUMES ON CLAY TODAY
description: Chris Evert Lloyd had little trouble with Virginia Ruzici of Rumania, and Martina Navratilova defeated Mima Jausovec of Yugoslavia today to set up a showdown in tomorrow's final of the $250,000 Murjani clay tennis tournament.

title: Connecticut Housing; PLANNING AHEAD FOR MOVING DAY
description: NOBODY likes to move. In a new book on the subject, called ''The Moving Experience,'' the author, Geraldine H. Davis, points out that ''everyone will feel, at least part of the time, lost, lonely, ugly, angry, frustrated, anxious, insecure, exhausted, jumpy, exhilarated, depressed. Comfort yourself and each other with the fact that these conditions are normal.''

title: No Headline
description: Oklahoma's sprint medley relay team set an American and collegiate record, and Mel Lattany of Georgia won a fourth straight title in the 100-meter dash at the 72d Drake Relays today.

title: STUDENTS REACH OUT TO AID ALCOHOLICS BUT MEET DISTRUST
description: HE knocked gently on the door and a little girl answered. Beyond her, a dazed, naked man lay across a bed, a hand covering his face. The man motioned to the girl to close the door, and Tony Cipolla, a graduate student in social work, was shut out. As Mr. Cipolla walked back down the hall, he heard the man hit the child, who began to cry. Mr. Cipolla was not sure what to do.

title: CRITICS QUESTION $200,000 STATE STUDY FOR ARTS COMPLEX
description: DOES the Island need - and can it support - a cultural arts complex on the scale of Lincoln Center? A New York State agency, the Urban Development Corporation, is currently studying the feasibility of building such a center, backed by a $200,000 appropriation. The money was not sought by elected officials of Nassau or Suffolk County, but was proposed by local arts and business leaders, endorsed by Governor Carey and shepherded through the State Legislature by Arthur J. Kremer, the Democratic-Liberal Assemblyman from Long Beach.

title: CITY STUDIES RULING ON BIAS IN CITY PENSIONS
description: A lawyer for New York City said yesterday that Mayor Koch and the city's Corporation Counsel would make no ''rash'' decision on whether to appeal a Federal judge's ruling that the city's largest employee pension plan discriminated against women by assuming they lived three years longer than men.

title: PORTRAIT OF THE ARTIST AS SON, LOVER, ELEGIST
description: THE SOURCE OF LIGHT By Reynolds Price. 318 pp. New York: Atheneum. $13.95.

title: NEW YORK HAS REASON TO POUR $2.7 BILLION INTO A HOLE IN THE GROUND
description: Sometime next month, workers 525 feet beneath upper Manhattan are to begin lining with concrete a dank, manmade cavern. This step in the construction of New York's third water tunnel will not represent a milestone for the project, but it will be the sort of visible progress that public officials have lately become impatient to see.

title: AMERICAN ICON
description: The Empire State Building was already the eighth wonder of the world when King Kong swung from the top, Fay Wray struggling in his arms. The building, which turns 50 this week, has become one of the most famous shapes in American iconography.

title: No Headline
description: employment (page 8) ELIZABETH: NOT GREAT, BUT BETTER THAN MOST By DANIEL AKST ................................. THE CITIES - This is the fourth article in a series on the decline of the state's major cities and their prospects for recovery ................................

title:
THE HIGH SCHOOLS TODAY;
NEW CURRICULUMS SOUGHT
description: ENORMOUS pressure to overhaul the high school curriculum is being applied throughout the nation these days by a variety of critics who charge that the curriculum is too ambitious, unorganized, overloaded and frivolous.

title: Susan Elizabeth Cogger Wed to Norman E. Mitchell 3d
description: Susan Elizabeth Cogger, daughter of Ruth Loomis Banks of Clearwater, Fla., and the late Carroll Cogger, was married yesterday to Norman Edward Mitchell 3d, son of Colonel Mitchell 2d, U.S.A.F., retired, and Mrs. Mitchell of Pawling, N.Y. The Rev. Donald McKinney, assisted by the Rev. Gordon Powell, performed the ceremony at the First Unitarian Church in Brooklyn Heights.

title: AN INDEX TO GETTING AHEAD
description: IT'S springtime at old Gillyflower U., and the faculty promotion committee is hard at work separating the academic wheat from the chaff, deciding who will and who won't. In one close race for promotion, the two candidates are neck and neck, but the one whose name is mentioned 21 times in a certain bulky bibliography defeats the rival with 19 mentions.

title: FUN AND GAMES AND DARK IMAGININGS
description: JUMANJI Written and Illustrated by Chris Van Allsburg. Unpaged. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $9.95.

title: Practical Traveler; GETTING THE MOST OUT OF AN UNLIMITED-MILEAGE TICKET
description: Despite the steadily increasing cost of transportation, a lot of money can be saved with tickets that allow an unlimited amount of travel within a specified time on airlines, railroads and buses. Some illustrations:

title: Christine D'Andrea Wed To Kevin Joseph Mulvey
description: Christine Elizabeth D'Andrea, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. D'Andrea of Rye, N.Y., was married there yesterday in the Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection to Kevin Joseph Mulvey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen W. Mulvey, also of Rye and of Juno Beach, Fla. The Rev. Francis P. Rowley performed the ceremony.

title: HAMMARSKJOLD TOWER PLANNED
description: Dag Hammarskjold Tower, a 40-story structure offering 250 luxury condominium units, is planned for construction on property being used as a parking lot fronting on the western side of Second Avenue between 46th and 47th Streets in Manhattan.

title: Lynn Eriksen Married To Gorden McKinna Jr.
description: Lynn Michele Eriksen, daughter of Dan Eriksen of New York and Mrs. Theodore R. Bashkow of Katonah, N.Y., was married yesterday to Gorden K. McKinna Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. McKinna of Charlotte, N.C. The Rev. Dr. Richard Monkman performed the ceremony at the Pound Ridge (N.Y.) Community Church.

title: Janice L. Seidel Married To John F. Nieman Jr.
description: Janice L. Seidel, daughter of Mrs. Harry G. Seidel of Washington and the late Mr. Seidel, was married in New York yesterday to John F. Nieman Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Nieman of St. Louis.

title: Sound; THE BEST LOUDSPEAKER FOR THE MONEY
description: When a product is intended to sell at a modest price, it is often necessary to make design compromises to keep the cost down. The intelligence excercised in choosing and balancing those compromises makes the difference between a good cheap product and a product that is merely cheap.

title: STOCKTON COLLEGE: A BOON OR BANE?
description: POMONA WHEN Stockton State College opened 10 years ago in the rickety old Mayflower Hotel in Atlantic City, its campus was the Boardwalk of that decaying city. Within a year, though, it moved 10 miles north to this quiet, rural northern Atlantic County community at the edge of the Pine Barrens. Its gleaming glass and cement buildings were the largest and most striking development in Galloway Township, and the school quickly became the county's dominant cultural institution.

title: RECENT HOME SALES
description: A Random Selection Bergenfield 205 Church Street 4-bedroom, 2-bath split-level $94,000 Finished basement, attic fan. Taxes: $2,108 Demarest 40 Bogert Road 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath Colonial $170,000 Two sun porches, fireplace in living room.

title: A STATE MOVE FOR THE REVITALIZATION OF YONKERS
description: GOVERNOR CAREY has placed New York State behind the long-standing local and county efforts to bring new life to downtown Yonkers. County Executive Alfred B. DelBello announced at the Yonkers City Hall last week that the Governor had committed the state to study the feasibility of installing state offices in a new building to be financed by the county in the Getty Square area.

title: PHILIP BENNETT FIANCE OF ELIZABETH VALENTINE
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Henry Valentine of Carlisle, Mass., and Holderness, N.H., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Hudson Valentine, to Philip Davies Bennett, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Franklin Bennett of Greenwich, Conn. An August wedding is planned on Church Island, Squam Lake, N.H.

title: Sarah Davis To Be a Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Graham Davis of New Canaan, Conn., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Sarah Hulme Davis, to Thomas Hartley Davidson, son of Mrs. Clement Olmsted Davidson of Madison, Conn., and the late Mr. Davidson. An Aug. 8 wedding is planned in New Canaan.

title: BRENNER IS WEIGHING POST-VERDICT MOVES
description: Jose Sulaiman awoke yesterday after ''my first good night's sleep in three weeks,'' and prepared to return home to Mexico City. Teddy Brenner said he was trying to relax at home and temporarily put out of his mind the loss of his antitrust suit against the World Boxing Council.

title: STUDENTS, WRITER TRADE VIEWS ON PLAY
description: WATERFORD DALE WASSERMAN, who wrote the book for ''Man of La Mancha,'' and launched it from the Goodspeed Opera House in East Haddam in 1965, has been at the Eugene O'Neill Theater Center here for a week refining his new musical for possible sale to a regional theater. College students participating in the National Theater Institute, one of the programs at the center, play the roles, do the technical jobs and form the audience.

title: SOARING PENSION COSTS TERMED KEY FACTOR IN PROPOSED LAYOFFS ON COAST
description: City officials here have been predicting for almost a decade that the rising cost of pensions for police officers and firefighters was leading the city toward a major fiscal crisis.

title: LOGIC SAYS THAT PLATO'S ABOUT TO PAY OFF
description: THE gamble has been more than $750 million since 1962 - one of the largest corporate investments ever in an unproven product. But to date the Control Data Corporation has yet to make a penny on its foray into the design and production of computer-based instruction.

title: A LIGHT NOTE IN WINES...
description: Never satisfied with the booming growth in wine consumption by Americans, vintners are going on a health and diet kick to draw an even larger segment of the population to the delights of wine.

title: THROUGH A LENS LIGHTLY
description: These Masai warriors are members of a nomadic tribe that has existed for about a thousand years on the plains of East Africa. In GROWING UP MASAI (Macmillan, $8.95), Tom Shachtman (text) and Donn Renn (photographs) capture the primitive world of two Masai children by following them through a typical day.

title: GIANTS AIMING TO REDUCE GAP
description: The Giants expect this draft will begin to close the enormous gap between themselves and the teams at the top of their division, the Philadelphia Eagles and Dallas Cowboys. George Young, the general manager with background as a scout of college players, points out that the Cowboys and Eagles will be drafting 26th and 27th on every round; the Giants will be second, third or fourth.

title: CANCER IN CHILDREN: HELP FOR THE PARENTS
description: ''THE child is a trouper. Despite her treatments, it was she who sustained us until we found a group that offers support to parents. Now she's gained some weight, and when we see her looking so beautiful, we can feel better about the chemotherapy. You can understand how happy we are to have her.''

title: YALE REP: AN 'ADVENTURE'
description: WHEN an electrical wire short-circuited during a performance of Peter Handke's play ''They Are Dying Out'' at New Haven's Yale Repertory Theatre last season, the theater's staff evacuated the building.

title: FRANCE'S PRESIDENT FACING 9 OPPONENTS IN TODAY'S ELECTION
description: The 10 candidates in France's presidential race were silent today for the first time in weeks as the nation entered the one-day campaign recess that precedes tomorrow's round of voting.

title: Reading and Writing; A CRITIC'S ADVENTURE
description: A couple of weeks ago in the Book Review, Geoffrey H. Hartman raised the question of how creative literary criticism could or should be. Should the critic be theoretical or intuitive, formal or emotional? Do critics dehumanize the work of art or do they intrude, putting too much of their own humanity into it? Can the response to fiction or poetry be a work of art too, or is the critic only a teacher at best, what T.S. Eliot called a corrector of taste?

title: CHINA REPORTS OPIUM IS BEING SMUGGLED TO HONG KONG AND TAIWAN (Reuters) -
description: Raw opium grown for medical purposes in China is being stolen and smuggled out of the country to dealers in Hong Kong and Taiwan, according to a senior Chinese judicial official.

title: POEMS AS MEETING PLACES
CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: BIRD CONFERENCE

title: FANCIFUL WORLDS
ETHICS COURSES ARE MAKING SLOW INROADS
description: WHEN medical students start practicing in hospitals, they will face situations where they must decide whether to use the ''no code'' to indicate that critically ill patients should not receive emergency resuscitation. In commenting on such a situation, Dr. Arthur L. Caplan, associate for the humanities at the Hastings Center Institute of Society, Ethics and the Life Sciences, said, ''What we are really dealing with is how many times a patient should die and who should be involved in the decision.''

title: Susan M. Reynolds Is Wed to a Banker
description: Susan Mary Reynolds, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Hess Reynolds Jr. of Mantoloking, N.J., and Stowe, Vt., was married yesterday to Andrew Lucas van Pragg, son of Louis van Praag of Ewelme, England, and Angela van Praag of Athelington, England. The Rev. Robert Redmond performed the ceremony in Holy Cross Roman Catholic Church in Rumson, N.J.

title: MARTINU'S 'THE GREEK PASSION'- A COMPOSER IN SEARCH OF EPIC TRAGEDY
description: Indiana University's School of Music has devised an ambitious New York showcase for its various performing ensembles this week, and the highlight of the visit takes place tonight at the Metropolitan Opera House with the American premiere production of Bohuslav Martinu's final opera, ''The Greek Passion.'' The rest of the country will also have an opportunity to experience this unusual event, for Bravo, a cable television service devoted to the performing arts, has taped the production and it will be shown nationally next month.

title: Team Handball Set For Championship
description: Team handball is often described as water polo without the water, hockey without sticks or soccer using the hands. One thing is certain: It is quite different from the brand of handball with which most people are familiar.

title: LEARNING TO LOVE A LONG DELAY
description: I'm in a solitary confinement cell which is Mexico's version of a Pullman couchette. A door leads to a dark and silent corridor. A scratched and dirty window looks out on a few wooden shacks. What am I doing here? The train has been stopped for six hours and is showing no interest in moving. Paciencia, senor, the porter keeps telling me. He's right. Maybe I'll try some of the tequila I bought to fight off the wolves.

title: Dr. Gerhard Schmidt, Biochemist
description: Dr. Gerhard Schmidt, a research scientist who was a professor of biochemistry at the Tufts University School of Medicine, died Friday at the Tufts-New England Medical Center in Boston. Dr. Schmidt, a resident of Brookline, Mass., was 79 years old.

title: IDEAS AND TRENDS: In Summary; Rights of Retarded Too Vague to Apply, High Court Decides
description: A ''bill of rights'' for the mentally retarded, approved by Congress six years ago, was effectively repealed last week by the Supreme Court, which ruled that it was too vaguely stated to be enforceable. By a 6-to-3 majority, the Court overturned a decision of the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit that had brought a Pennsylvania state mental institution under virtual court management.

title: ABOLISH THE STATE DEPT.
description: Cyrus R. Vance, Zbigniew Brzezinski, and Edmund S. Muskie have left the cast, but the feud between the White House and the State Department has settled in for another four-year run.

title: Panel on Terrorism Makes Its Debut
description: Senator Jeremiah A. Denton, Republican of Alabama, has promised to invite people with varied views of Soviet behavior, including advocates of unilateral disarmament, to testify before his new subcommittee on security and terrorism. The witnesses at the committee's first hearing last week all declared that Moscow is a key supporter of terrorism, and Senator Denton strongly endorsed their view.

title: AROUND THE NATION: In Summary; Wall St. Enforcer; Among the Spooks?
description: However else his tour at the Central Intelligence Agency is remembered, William J. Casey will be recalled as a director who wasn't reluctant to sign on independent-minded subordinates. First, there was Admiral Bobby R. Inman, who was chief of the National Security Agency and, it was said, wanted to run the C.I.A. himself; Mr. Casey made him deputy director.

title: At Home
description: IT is twilight as I stroll along the labyrinthian streets of New York City's West Village. With an hour to kill before meeting a friend for dinner, I linger with other passers-by at the small shop windows. In my town at this hour, most shops are closed and pedestrians walk purposefully toward predictable destinations and occupations: house and family, cocktails, dinner, the evening news, bed.

title: HOW MANDATES BURDEN THE LOCAL GOVERNMENTS
description: THE Reagan Administration is pressing to make cuts in the Federal budget. The State of Connecticut is grappling with major expenditures and revenue problems, which will be further affected by Federal cuts. The results of both the Federal and state actions will ultimately affect local governments.

title: Julia Denny Bride in Darien Of Thomas Miller, Executive
description: Julia C. Denny, daughter of Mrs. Edward Arnold Denny of Harrogate, England, and the late Mr. Denny, was married yesterday in the Noroton Presbyterian Church in Darien, Conn., to Thomas H. Miller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Charles Miller of Darien. The Rev. Edward Danks performed the ceremony.

title: Cable TV System Fined $20,000
description: In a clear expression of its concern, the Federal Communications Commission fined a Michigan cable TV system $20,000 yesterday, the maximum possible, for causing interference on radio frequencies used by air traffic controllers.

title: ALL AGOG OVER JIM AND SANDY
description: The conference room on the 40th floor of the American Express building is sweltering as the afternoon sun over the Hudson River streams into the the room, but Jim Robinson and Sandy Weill are grinning like the cat that ate the canary.

title: Ship Fire Imperils Egyptian Port
description: A tanker in Alexandria harbor was engulfed by flames today, touching off eight tons of explosives in its cargo, the police reported. A state of emergency was declared and the area was evacuated. The tanker, carrying 3,000 tons of petrochemicals, was identified as the Eastfloat, of Panamanian registry.

title: LOOKING FOR MOM
description: RAINBOW JORDAN By Alice Childress. 142 pp. New York: Coward, McCann & Geoghegan. $8.95. (Ages 13 and Up)

title: A POCKET-SIZED DIGITAL RECORD FOR THE FUTURE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Allan Kozinn writes frequently about music and recordings. By ALLAN KOZINN

title: J.J. O'Toole 3d, Suzanne Black To Wed in Fall
description: Mr. and Mrs. Hiram Day Black of New York and Nantucket, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Suzanne Black, to John James O'Toole 3d. He is a son of Mrs. James Lewis Hewitt of Bucks County, Pa., and Mr. O'Toole Jr. of Fredericksburg, Va.

title: RANGERS SHOWING QUIET CONFIDENCE FOR SEMIFINAL TEST
description: M OST of the Rangers, preparing for the Stanley Cup semifinal series against the Islanders, seemed stricken in their locker room by infectious understatement, a condition their coach, Craig Patrick, has been quietly spreading for weeks.

title: Indiana's Little 500 Speeds Into The Big Time
description: ''Breaking Away,'' the movie that made Indiana University's Little 500 bicycle race not more than a local event, was playing at a theatre here this week as a reminder of what that race, held today, once was. The race and the shiny new $3 million stadium that housed it were a reminder of how the financial success of big-time colege athletics has been mimicked by an intramural event.

title:
PERSPECTIVES;
'THAT TEST WASN'T FAIR, TEACHER!'
description: HOORAY for Daniel Lowen! This splendid Florida youth, armed only with the sword of keen intelligence and the shield of his loving father, coolly challenged the giant Educational Testing Service and, in a single reasoned stroke, raised the scores of 240,000 high school students on the most recent Preliminary Scholastic Apitude Test. That is no mean achievement, but the wider significance of Mr. Lowen's determined effort is the ringing blow he has struck for truth-intesting.

title: Marimekko Linens A Buy in Larchmont
description: Postcards have gone out to customers on a pair of sales at the newly renovated Motif Designs in Larchmont. The first is a closeout sale that drops prices on Marimekko comforters, sheets, pillowcases and towels 50 to 75 percent off suggested retail prices. The second, which begins May 28 and ends June 15, is the annual window-treatment sale at 40 percent off catalogue prices on Levelors, verticals, woodweaves, balloons and Austrian, Roman and laminated shades.

title: A FAMILY SAVORS THE OUTDOORS AMONG FLORIDA'S MIDDLE KEYS
description: Most people know two things about the Florida Keys, that string of coral islands stretching for more than a hundred miles west of the mainland. They know about Key Largo, the northernmost island, mainly because of Maxwell Anderson's play, ''Key Largo,'' and the movie with Humphrey Bogart. And they know about Key West, at the tip, because Ernest Hemingway, Tennessee Williams and other colorful types lived there on and off. Lately, Key West has been in the news as the receiving point for thousands of refugees from Castro's Cuba, although the locals insist that the Cubans were all put on buses and transported to processing centers far away.

title: Cook Turns Back Couture In Firestone Bowling Final
description: Steve Cook rolled 10 straight strikes before leaving a 6-7 split as he defeated Pete Couture, 287-183, tonight in the final match of the $150,000 Firestone tournament of champions.

title: FLOOD OF ETHIOPIAN REFUGEES INTO SUDAN CONTINUES
description: Alganesh, a slim, bright-eyed 26-yearold Ethiopian nurse, fled when she found out that some of her fellow students in Asmara were being imprisoned and tortured by the regime of Col. Mengistu Haile Mariam. She walked 275 miles in broken plastic sandals to the safety of this refugee camp 40 miles over the border.

title: PLAY IT AGAIN: 'NEW YORK, NEW YORK'
description: WHEN the Rangers stunned the Islanders two years ago in the Stanley Cup semifinals, it was the most meaningful moment for New York intramural sports since the Yankees and the Dodgers tangled in all those World Series three decades ago. And all that emotion is about to boil over again, beginning Tuesday night at the Nassau Coliseum in the opener of another best-of-seven showdown.

title: Purchase Rights
description: To the Editor:

title:
FORUM;
ENGINEERS SHOULD RUN THE AUTO BUSINESS
description: As an engineer who spent the first 20 years of his professional life designing automobiles and their components, I have very strong feelings that the control of our industry must return to the technical side. It is clear from the events of the past few years and the dire economic situation of so many of the automobile companies, that the financial and marketing people in charge today have failed.

title: Peat Moss a Winner Under 145
description: The telephone rang in the office of the racing secretary Lenny Hale around noon yesterday at Aqueduct. ''No, lady, we are not running any steeplechase races here today,'' an assistant to Hale said with some annoyance.

title: Theater; HIGH-SCHOOL DAYS REMEMBERED
description: MUSICALS that ask a question deserve an answer. The answer to the Hartford Theater Company's latest production - ''Is There Life After High School?'' - is yes and no. No, not really for the eight performers involved. The five men and three women, all of whom portray many people, have gone on since their high school years, but their emotions are still hung up in locker rooms, proms and adolescent anguish. From the audience's point of view, however, there definitely is life after high school. The musical, in its worldpremiere engagement, reaches out continually to jolt you into recognition and remembrance.

description: Size: Female 25 inches; male 23 inches. Color: Mottled brown, black and white, with underparts barred.

title:
SCHOOLS IN CAPITAL TOUGHEN STANDARDS;
WASHINGTON
description: THE much-battered District of Columbia public-school system has taken a stand against ''social promotion'' - at the first-grade level. After six years of developing and putting into effect a homegrown ''competency-based curriculum,'' the school system this year decided to promote only those children in the first through third grades who could prove that they had learned what the curriculum proposed to teach.

title: Students of human behavior have long speculated about why some people seem irresistibly drawn to collecting.  "The salient characteristic of this mania," claims Thomas Wiseman in his book "The Money Motive" (Random House, 1974), "is the bestowal of one's love on something nonliving; it is the deflection of eros from a a human object to an inanimate one." And who is the archetypal collector?  Freud described him as miserly, pedantic, stubborn and obsessively tidy.  Can these characterizations be true?  Can the child's seemingly harmless stamp collection actually be the object of deflected eros?  Can the reckless specualtor who has just dropped a bundle on a Captain Video lunch pail be gripped by parsimony?  Has the former sportsman who has taken to spending his precious weekends at auctions gone pedantic on us?
description: Probably the noblest and rarest form of collector is the Patron. A connoisseur, he puts his private gain to enduring public good. Though he is not an artist, he is artistic: His collection is his creation, product of an original and compelling vision. History's classic example of the Patron: the Medicis of 15th- and 16th-century Florence, who enriched Western civilization by indulging their exquisite tastes through enlightened patronage of, among others, Botticelli and Michelangelo. A far more ubiquitous but no less impassioned collector is the Fan. The Fan's enthusiasm for a particular sport or artist exceeds the more usual means of expression, such as attending games or concerts, so he seeks an outlet in collecting allied memorabilia. Often he is a frustrated artist. In his eyes, the next best thing to being a gifted composer owning Beethoven's letters and manuscripts. Or, on a different scale, the next best thing to being able to hit one out of the park is owning the 1954 Topps Chewing Gum card of the Milwaukee Braves' Hank Aaron. The Clutterer is a very different sort of collector, one whom purists, such as Fans, often fault for lacking focus. This sort collects without perceptible effort--objects just seem to attach themselves to him the way barnacles do to ships. He tends to have a bit of this, a bit of that, and, as a consequence, his collection usually lacks depth. The key to the Clutterer conundrum: a tendency to anthropomorphize.

title: OAKLAND REJECTS TAX INCREASE DESPITE RISING CRIME
description: The defeat of a local ballot proposal on property taxes may have left Oakland, a largely black, workingclass city of 338,000 people, with the problem of trying to cope with California's highest crime rate while it has the state's most seriously understaffed police department.

title: OFF TO SUMMER CAMP
Dance View; 'ARDEN COURT' AND VIRTUOSIC DANCING
description: At the recent premiere of Paul Taylor's ''Arden Court,'' the choreographer stepped aside in favor of his dancers as few choreographers have ever done. And he did so by making it possible for them to give the unusually great performance they did at that initial shviewing, the dancing seemingly superseded the depth and quality of the work as a whole. And yet it is just as obvious that no group of dancers could perform so exceptionally without something to dance that could bring them up to this level.

title: Jane Warner Cumber Wed To Peter William Allen
description: Jane Warner Cumber, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Warner G. Cumber of Hadlyme, Conn., and Peter William Allen, son of Mr. and Mrs. John S. Allen of Manhasset, L.I., were married yesterday. The Rev. Rex L. Burrell performed the ceremony at the Zion Episcopal Church in Douglaston, Queens.

title: Ann Taylor Savage Is Bride Of Stephen Skinner in Queens
description: The marriage of Ann Taylor Savage, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John C. Savage of Forest Hills, Queens, to Stephen Paul Skinner took place yesterday at Our Lady Queen of Martyrs Roman Catholic Church in Forest Hills. The Rev. Francis X. Mulhall performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass.

title: AN ISSUE OF COMMUNITY COMPATIBILITY OVER THE COUNTY AIRPORT
description: IN 1956, Congress began the Federal Interstate Highway System Program by agreeing to pay 90 percent of the costs of a national network of high-speed limited-access highways.

title: No Headline
description: Beth Solomon birdied the 18th hole today to tie Jane Blalock for the lead in the $100,000 Birmingham Classic.

title: DO THE ARTS INSPIRE VIOLENCE IN REAL LIFE?
description: In film as in other media, violence has long since become commonplace, with people dismembered, impaled, incinerated, blown up, machine-gunned or otherwise annihilated with numbing regularity. Social scientists have long debated the effects of such depictions of violence upon viewers, and recently the controversy flared anew with reports that Federal investigators believe John Hinckley, who has been charged with the attempted assassination of President Reagan, was influenced by the 1976 movie ''Taxi Driver.''

title: TALK WITH A WINNER
description: ''CHRISTIAN MISSIONARY'' jumps out from Katherine Paterson's biography, suggesting inveterate goodness, cannibal jokes and the picture of a sugar-voiced 1950's mom, like the one on reruns of ''Leave It To Beaver,'' who serves up constant comment on ''the problems of our young people today'' along with tea and cookies. In Mrs. Paterson's case, the image is reinforced by her setting. The Paterson home is a big white frame house on a quiet street in Norfolk, Va., that looks like an Andy Hardy movie set, strewn with a comfortable clutter of bicycles and children's woodworking projects -a seashell-outlined ''P'' on a wooden plaque and a plywood horse with the word ''Paterson'' burned into it. As the visitor waits on the porch, the sounds of dogs barking somewhere inside underscore the expectation of an aggressively wholesome children's book author.

title: Spanish Network News To Begin on TV on June 1
description: The National Spanish Television Network has annouced that it will begin what it calls the first national Spanish-language news program ''produced by and for Hispanics in the United States'' on June 1.

title: BIG STEEL ON THE LONG ROAD BACK
description: What Churchill said of Dunkirk is now true for U.S. Steel: Wars are not won by evacuations. For the last year and a half, Big Steel has put itself through a painful scaling down, sloughing off thousands of workers, slashing capacity and producing the largest write-off in American industrial history.

title: No Headline
description: There are those who might respond to Colette Dowling by saying: Why should women bother to strive for achievement in the world of work? Why shouldn't they stay at home and be housewives like their mothers?

title: The New Way to Find the "Right" Districts
description: MOVING from San Francisco to the East Coast last November, Ann Vasquez wanted to avoid buying a house in a neighborhood from which her 9-year-old daughter would be required to take a long bus ride to school each morning.

title: GALAMIAN- A GREAT VIOLIN TEACHER
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Judith Karp, who writes frequently about music, spent a summer studying violin at Meadowmount. By JUDITH KARP

title: CAMPS SPREAD FOR PUPILS THINKING THIN
description: ''IWAS afraid to go to parties,'' said 13-year-old Alex Sachs, describing her life before she lost 17 pounds at a weight camp. Mark Troupin, 15, who lost 30 pounds last summer, recalled: ''Every night I'd go to bed saying to myself, 'This time I'm going on a diet.' Nothing ever lasted more than 48 hours. But at camp I relearned my eating habits, and it worked.''

title: Sunday Observer; THE ENGLISH MAFIA
description: Sunday ObserverBy Russell Baker Patrick McDonnell

title: Marguerite Cowles Is Bride
description: Marguerite Jane Cowles was married yesterday to Warren Beardow. The Rev. John Genzel performed the ceremony at St. Peter's Lutheran Church in New York.

title: TURKISH 'HAZAL,' 20TH-CENTURY FOX TALE
description: OLD ways die hard, and some movies about old ways dying hard are harder to take than others. Such a film is ''Hazal,'' a 20th-century Turkish folk tale set in a rural village where custom is breached at great risk.

title: SPECIALISTS PLAY ROLE IN RIVALRY OF U.S. REGIONS
description: In the economic rivalry between the North and the South, the leaders of the South have been employing some relatively new resources in the political arena: the economists, social scientists and others who have emerged as a result of the region's growing system of universities and colleges.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: THE CIVILIZING INFLUENCE

title: CABARET: DEBBIE SHAPIRO
description: DEBBIE SHAPIRO, a young singer who won some excited critical notices for her performance last December in ''Perfectly Frank,'' the Broadway revue based on Frank Loesser's songs, introduced a nightclub act Thursday evening at Les Mouches, 11th Avenue at 26th Street, that explained why the response to her on Broadway was so favorable.

title: New Sunday Paper for Scotland Is the First of Its Kind in 60 Years
description: Scotland's first new Sunday newspaper in 60 years, The Sunday Standard, began publication today, and a spokesman said the reaction from readers was good.

title: SAVINGS OUTFLOWS AT RECORD
description: Federal regulators said today that customers of savings and loan associations withdrew a record $2.3 billion more than they deposited in March, but a Federal banking official cautioned against overstating the savings association industry's problems.

title: 'PORTRAIT OF TERESA' AT THE MODERN
description: ''PORTRAIT OF TERESA,'' a Cuban entry in the ''New Directors/New Films'' series sponsored by the Film Society of Lincoln Center and the Museum of Modern Art, bears a glancing resemblance to ''Norma Rae,'' because it's the realistic account of a woman struggling with the overwhelming demands of family and her job in a textile factory. To be sure, Teresa (Daisy Granados) is no activist or militant. But she is beginning to long for a change in her cirumstances. The film might more accurately have been titled ''Portrait of Teresa and Ramon,'' because the troubles of Teresa's husband are explored almost as thoroughly as her own.

title: Volcano Releases More Steam
description: Mount St. Helens shot steam and ash about 15,000 feet into the air for the third consecutive morning, spotter pilots for the United States Forest Service reported today. The steam plume shot up from the 8,400-foot volcano at 8:21 A.M. in a cloud that could be seen clearly from Portland, Ore., according to the Forest Service.

title: RESULT OF INQUIRY ON SLAYINGS OF 7 AWAITED UPSTATE
description: The Erie County District Attorney, Edward C. Cosgrove, said yesterday that he would decide shortly, perhaps today, whether to seek an indictment against a 25-year-old white Army private listed as a suspect in the slaying of seven black men in Buffalo last year.

title: Sutherland Disputes Stopping Bout in 9th
description: Murray Sutherland said ''a very fast count'' prematurely stopped his fight yesterday against Matthew Saad Muhammad, the World Boxing Council light-heavyweight champion.

title: GOVERNMENT PENALIZES BOAT OWNERS IN CUBAN FLOTILLA
description: Hundreds of small boats are piled together here, rusting and rotting on a Government dock. They are the boats of the so-called Freedom Flotilla, which brought more than 127,000 Cuban refugees across the treacherous Florida Straits to this country.

title: Reporter Slain in Iran Is Honored
description: The Nieman Foundation's award for conscience and integrity in journalism was awarded yesterday posthumously to Joe Alex Morris Jr., a Los Angeles Times reporter, who was shot in the chest and killed while covering the Iranian revolution. Mr. Morris, a longtime Middle East reporter who had worked for United Press, The New York Herald Tribune and Newsweek, died Feb. 10, 1979. The Louis M. Lyons Award was presented to Mr. Morris's widow, Ursula.

title: A Recuperating Hess Marks His 87th Birthday
description: Rudolf Hess, Hitler's deputy chancellor, quietly marked his 87th birthday yesterday in a British military hospital in West Berlin, where he has been recuperating from pneumonia since April 6.

title: Bronx Youth, 18, Is Slain for Radio
description: An 18-year-old Bronx youth was shot to death last night after he resisted two assailants who told him to hand over his new transistor radio, the police said.

title: WEIGHING THE IMPACT OF A JOINY CUSTODY LAW
description: When California's controversial joint custody law took effect in January 1980, legal experts there were predicting that one out of every two custody contests would end with both parents being granted equal rights to and responsibilities for the child after a divorce or separation.

title: F.B.I. DIRECTOR SEES NO EVIDENCE SOVIET FOSTERS TERRORISM IN U.S.
description: William H. Webster, Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, said today that there was ''no real evidence'' to suggest that the Soviet Union was sponsoring or instigating terrorist activity in the United States.

title: SEXUALITY AND BREAST SURGERY
description: ON Jan. 8, 1980, Barbara Glenn's left breast was removed because a biopsy confirmed the presence of a malignant tumor. On Jan. 12 her right breast was removed when a frozen section taken during the first operation disclosed cancer cells there.

title: SIGN OF SPRING IN WILD ALBERTA: SOGGY 'ROADS'
description: Spring is coming to the northern tier of Canada, far from the tidy population concentrations strung along the border with the United States.

title: THE RIDERS ARE JOCKEYING FOR KENTUCKY DERBY MOUNTS ,
description: LOUISVILLE Ky. THE Queen of the annual Derby Ball here is selected from five finalists by a spin of the wheel. If riding assignments for the Kentucky Derby were chosen this way, many owners, trainers, bettors and even jockeys would have no less idea than they do now of how Saturday's 107th Derby will turn out.

title: INFLATION MAKES ARGENTINES GAMBLERS IN RISKY GAME
description: People the world over are trying to cope with inflation. And then there are Argentines. In the last 30 years many countries have risen and fallen in the inflation ranks, but Argentina has remained near the top. The rate of increase in consumer prices peaked at nearly 450 percent in 1976. Last year, it was under 90 percent, and some Government officials crowed success. But this year many economists expect the rate to shoot back up.

title: PLAY: WELLER'S 'FISHING' REVIVED AT SECOND STAGE
description: WHEN Michael Weller's ''Fishing'' first appeared at the Public Theater in 1975, it was regarded as an unofficial sequel to the playwright's ''Moonchildren.'' Looking at it now, in a lovely revival at the Second Stage, ''Fishing'' seems more like a warm-up for Mr. Weller's ''Loose Ends.'' Either way, this is a transitional play, about 60's children who are themselves in transition: The characters are turning 30, and their lives are on the brink of confusing change. It's not empty poetry that much of the second act takes place, quite literally, in a fog.

title: COSMOS ON TOP, 4-1, AFTER SLUGGISH START
description: The Cosmos awakened after a lethargic first half and scored four goals in the second to defeat the Tampa Bay Rowdies, 4-1, at Giants Stadium today.

title: MUSIC: J.J. CALE'S COUNTRY BLUES
description: based singer, songwriter and guitarist, who made a rare New York appearance at the Bottom Line on Thursday, is an able craftsman of short-form Southern blues songs. Mr. Cale's smoky drawl, combined with his gently rolling blues guitar style, evokes an idyllic Southern landscape.

title: ISRAELI JETS ATTACK TARGETS IN LEBANON
description: Israeli air force jets struck targets in southern Lebanon today, and Lebanese authorities said that 15 people were killed and 30 wounded in the attacks.

title: Father and Son Die In Flatbush Blaze
description: A Brooklyn man and his 6-year-old son died after an electric blanket caught fire and spread flames through the top floor and roof of their home in Flatbush, according to fire and police officials.

title: Chemistry Lesson
description: When Nancy Lopez-Melton replaced her regular caddie, the out-going Roscoe Jones, last fall and replaced him with the low-key Gary Snyder, she said that women pro golfers let their male caddies push them around too much and that Jones ''made me mad.''

title: MGM Purchases Estate For Casino in Massachusetts
description: MGM Grand Hotels Inc. has bought a 58-acre estate in Hull for a $78 million gaming casino and resort, the company said yesterday, expressing confidence that the State Legislature will pass a bill allowing the seaside community to license the establishment.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Sure, I would move if I could find a job, but with what? Where are we going to go with no money?'' - Steve Ristoski, a laid-off automobile worker. (A1:2.)

title: Coast Rider Wins
description: Despite the pain from an injured hand, Randy Mamola of California easily won the Austrian motorcycle Grand Prix today, the first event in the 1981 5,000-cubiccentimeter world championship series.

title: Chinese Sweep Titles In Table Tennis
description: China today became the first country to win all seven world titles in table tennis.

title: BEGRUDGINGLY, THE BRITISH SUBMIT TO THE CENSUS TAKER'S QUESTIONS
description: The centuries-old English belief that a man's home is his castle was cited here again this month as Britons grudgingly completed their 1981 census forms.

title: TV: THE SWEDE WHO SAVED JEWS
description: BEGINNING last Thursday and continuing through tomorrow, WNET-TV, Channel 13, has been presenting ''Days of Remembrance of the Holocaust,'' a collection of programs and one-minute messages associated with the anniversary of the 1945 liberation of the Dachau concentration camp and with the Jewish Holocaust memorial holiday of Yom Hashoah this Friday.

title: Moses Wins 58th Straight Race
description: Edwin Moses had to come from behind to keep his winning streak intact, and James Sanford won the 100-meter dash today in the 22d Mount San Antonio Relays.

title: Mrs. Lloyd Routs Miss Navratilova By 6-0, 6-0 in Final
description: Top-seeded Chris Evert Lloyd easily defeated Martina Navratilova, 6-0, 6-0, today to win the $250,000 Murjani tennis tournament.

title: 3 Islander Rookies Are Doing Their Share
description: Although the Islanders say that their playoff experience and a solid core of veterans should enable them to withstand the exuberance of the Rangers in their National Hockey League semifinals starting tomorrow night at Nassau Coliseum, they may be overlooking the three rookies on their roster.

title: 'JUDGES DESERVE RESPONSIBLE CRITICISM'
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising; Creativity Is a Force At Richards
description: TRUE creativity, it would appear, can be as difficult to control as atomic fusion. It can thrust success upon its possessor. Stan Richards, the Philadelphian who went West to find his fortune and is now being sought by the Eastern establishment, could certainly attest to that.

title: ULSTER IS BRACING FOR FRESH TUMULT AS IRISH HUNGER STRIKER NEARS DEATH
description: With all avenues of compromise apparently closed, Northern Ireland's Roman Catholic militants and the British Government are again at the brink of a possibly violent showdown.

title: TIME FOR A BREAK
description: To the Editor:

title: BROKERS DIVIDED ON MERGERS
description: Wall Street leaders appeared divided about the recent wave of brokerage house mergers as they gathered here today for the semiannual convention of the Securities Industry Association.

title: CYNTHIA GREEN AND ELIOT JAY KAPLAN, EDITORS, MARRIED
description: Cynthia Elaine Green, regional editor of The Courier-News, a Gannett newspaper in Bridgewater, N.J., was married in Princeton, N.J., yesterday to Eliot Jay Kaplan, associate editor of Family Weekly magazine, the CBS-owned Sunday supplement. Superior Court Judge J. Wilson Noden performed the ceremony in the Prospect Gardens on the Princeton University campus.

title: Leakage of Raw Sewage Puzzles California Town
description: Officials are expressing bewilderment over what could have happened to millions of gallons of raw sewage dumped since 1978 in this northern California community.

title: Air and Sea Hunt Ends For Exiles Cuba Deported
description: The Coast Guard ended a two-and-a-half-day search tonight for six small boats carrying 40 Cuban exiles who reportedly returned to their homeland from the United States last year only to be jailed and later cast adrift at sea.

title: GIFTS TO NONPROFIT GROUPS RISE TO A RECORD BUT LAG BEHIND INFLATION
description: Charitable contributions to the country's 300,000 nonprofit organizations from individuals, foundations and corporations reached $47.74 billion, a record, last year, but that was still not enough to keep pace with inflation, according to the American Association of Fund-Raising Counsel.

title: Bridge: Human Dimension Missing In the Accounts of Bidding
description: A printed account of the bidding and play as they have taken place tends to omit the human dimension. In many deals a player must pick up vibrations from the opposition. He does so at his own risk, and must do his ethical best to ignore similar indications from his partner.

title: Channel 13 Auction This Week
description: Channel 13's fourth annual on-the-air auction of art and antiques will run from Thursday through Sunday. The WNET auction begins weekdays at 5 P.M. and Saturday and Sunday at 1:30 P.M. and ends each night at 1:30 A.M.

title: Bonds's Homer Scores 3 in Minors
description: Bobby Bonds hit a three-run homer in the third inning today to help Wichita to an 8-6 American Association victory over Evansville.

title: TRANSIT AUTHORITY AGREES TO PROPOSAL FOR EXECUTIVE HELP
description: After two weeks of sensitive negotiations, the Transit Authority has agreed to let a team of private business executives try to improve the management of New York City's faltering subway and bus systems, but the authority has turned down the executives' offer of help in seven key areas.

title: Elizabeth H. Gossett, a Trustee Of Barnard College, Is Dead at 73
description: Elizabeth Hughes Gossett, a trustee of Barnard College and founder of the Supreme Court Historical Society, died Saturday at Harper-Grace Hospital in Detroit. Mrs. Gossett, who lived in Bloomfield Hills, Mich., was 73 years old.

title: SISTER EDITH MARIE MARTIN
description: Sister Edith Marie Martin, language professor, chairman of the French department and academic dean at the College of Mount St. Vincent, died yesterday at the Convent of Mary the Queen in Yonkers after a long illness.

title: Dollar Falls Against Yen
description: The dollar dropped against the Japanese yen today in early moderate trading on the Tokyo foreign exchange market, opening at 214.50 yen before recovering a bit to 214.60. It had closed Friday at 215.35.

title: BANK EARNINGS UP, BUT WEAK
description: Most of the nation's major banking companies experienced relatively weak earnings in the first quarter, even though 12 of the 15 surveyed reported increases in their net operating earnings from a year earlier.

title: TWO FAMILIES ADJUST TO NEW ROUTINES
description: While legal experts in California debate the pros and cons of joint custody, divorced couples such as Beverly and Marvin Philo of Sacramento and Chuck and Joan Mathison of Long Beach are living with it - after a few adjustments.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption in some editions of the Times on Saturday incorrectly identified a man with Governor Carey and Mayor Koch. He is Francis T. Purcell, the Nassau County Executive.

title: Friday's Rates On Treasury Bills
description: In advance of today's auction of new three- and six-month Treasury bills, outstanding bills closed late Friday at rates of about 13.97 percent for three months and 13.88 percent for six months.

title: Grey Subsidiary Wins Huffman-Koos Account
description: Grey, Conahy & Lyon, which began last week winning the Velcro account, ended it announcing the landing of the Huffman-Koos business.

title: Ferragamo Signing Expected Today
description: Vince Ferragamo, the quarterback who led the Los Angeles Rams to the 1979 Super Bowl, is expected to sign with the Montreal Alouettes of the Canadian Football League tomorrow. The club has called a news conference at 5 P.M. tomorrow.

title: BROCK TO VISIT JAPAN FOR AUTO TALKS
description: The Foreign Ministry, in a surprise announcement, said today that Bill Brock, the chief United States trade negotiator, would visit Japan later this week to discuss limiting Japanese auto exports to America.

title: Archbishop Says Mankind Must Explore Inner Space
description: The Archbishop of Canterbury, while hailing the space shuttle's flight into outer space, said today that mankind needs to explore ''inner space.'' Inner space, he said, ''harbors the fears and the desire to dominate, which are the sources of the violence and the divisions which disfigure the world.''

title: Dearie to Seek Post Of City Comptroller
description: John C. Dearie, a State Assemblyman from the Bronx, will announce his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for City Comptroller today, an aide to the Assemblyman said yesterday.

title: Agent Rule Violated, Dallas Paper Claims
description: Two University of Houston football players apparently violated National Collegiate Athletic Association rules when they signed agreements with agents before the start of the 1980 season.

title: O'Hare Said to Remain World's Busiest Airport
description: Despite an 8.8 percent decline in air traffic, O'Hare International Airport in Chicago was still the world's busiest airport last year, with nearly 43.7 million passengers, the Airport Operators Council International says. O'Hare has held the lead for more than a decade.

title: DETROIT DESPAIRS OF REGAINING JOBS
description: Time and the money have run out for Steve Ristoski and for tens of thousands of other jobless automobile workers here.

title: CONCERT: GUARNERI QUARTET PLAYS EVENING OF ODDITIES
description: ALTHOUGH there is a real and honorable audience for the great classics, many famous soloists and chamber groups can still be accused of playing it safe. Season after season, they serve up their Haydn and Mozart, their Beethoven, Schubert and Brahms, sometimes slipping in a safe little oddity just before the intermission but otherwise sticking to the familiar. For some, this is true art - avoiding the dross, communing exclusively with the masters and striving always to deepen already profound interpretations. For others, it is timid, lazy and boring.

title: Link of Salvador Soldiers To Killing of 4 Reported
description: CBS News said tonight that evidence evaluated by the Federal Bureau of Investigation pointed to six members of the Salvadoran National Guard as the killers of four United States churchwomen in El Salvador last December. The F.B.I. denied the report.
