title: Washington Watch; Looking Back At Kennedy Cut
description: WASHINGTON 'THE purpose of cutting taxes is not to create a deficit but to increase investment, employment and the prospects for a balanced budget.'' These are words, not of President Reagan, but of an earlier supply-sider, President Kennedy, drawn from his special message to Congress on Jan. 24, 1963 - which laid the foundation for the 1964 general tax cut and investment tax credit.

title: Head of Retail Division At Batus Adds 2 Posts
description: Robert J. Suslow has been appointed chairman and chief executive officer of Batus Inc.'s retail division, effective Sept. 30, when Allan R. Johnson retires. The 47-year-old Mr. Suslow, a native New Yorker, will also remain president of the division and a member of the board of Batus Inc.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, APRIL 27, 1981
description: International In the French election's first round, President Valery Giscard dEstaing took a slight lead over Francois Mitterrand, the Socialist leader. Jacques Chirac, the Gaullist candidate, and Georges Marchais, the Communist candidate, lagged far behind. The preliminary vote that eliminated eight other contenders from the May 10 runoff was so close that it was impossible to give either the President or Mr. Mitterrand a decisive lead. (Page A1, Column 6.) Israeli planes raided suspected Palestinian bases in southern Lebanon, while Syrian forces heavily shelled Christian villages and military positions in the strategic Bekaa Valley and around Jebel Sannin, a mountain east of Beirut. Lebanese authorities reported that 15 people were killed and 30 wounded in the Israeli attack. A Syrian military spokesman said that Syrian planes shot down two Israeli craft and that a Syrian plane was hit. Israel denied that there had been an air fight. (A1:5.)

title: TIME FOR A BREAK
description: To the Editor:

title: Golden Eggs
description: Easter traditionally has been a time when youngsters go on egg hunts. At the annual Olympus Easter Bowl junior tennis tournament, held at Edgewater, N.J., a week ago, many youngsters seem more interested putting all their eggs in one basket - pro careers.

title: BATTLE OVER 1982 BUDGET TO CONTINUE IN HOUSE AS CONGRESS ENDS RECESS
description: President Reagan's economic package is to face a crucial test in the House of Representatives this week when Congress returns from its Easter recess and two alternative budgets for the next fiscal year reach the floor for a vote.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: A player in a National Basketball Association game is dribbling the ball. As he reaches midcourt, his left foot crosses the line but the ball is still in the backcourt. Can he bring his left foot back over the center line? Also, when a player inbounds the ball, can one of his feet be over the end line if it is up in the air?

title: Dr. Charles Hogan, 74, Former Official at U.N.
description: Dr. Charles A. Hogan, who had been with the Secretariat of the United Nations for 25 years and had been chief of sections on freedom of information and press and nongovernmental organizations, died last Thursday at Mount Zion Hospital in San Francisco. He was 74 years old and lived in San Francisco.

title: AFGHAN REGIME MARKS THREE YEARS OF MARXIST RULE
description: The Moscow-backed Government in Afghanistan marks three years of Marxist rule tomorrow, with Moslem rebels as determined as ever to fight the Soviet military presence.

title: A Short Story Is Born on Fifth Avenue
description: ''Many people,'' Harlan Ellison was saying the other day, ''have the idea that writers are strange magicians who work on far mountaintops.''

title: TAMING HOMEOWNER'S SUBSIDY
description: To the Editor:

title: Soviet to Sell Wheat to Afghans
description: The Soviet Union agreed today to sell Afghanistan 300,000 metric tons of wheat, the Kabul radio said. The broadcast, monitored here, did not mention the terms of the sale.

title: Career Soldier Takes Over As Premier of Mauritania
description: Mauritania has announced that its civilian Prime Minister, Sidi Ahmed Ould Bneijara, has been ousted and replaced by a career soldier, Lieut. Col. Maaouya Ould Sidi Ahmed Taya, who will also be responsible for defense.

title: WATSON VICTOR BY 2 SHOTS AT NEW ORLEANS
description: Tom Watson made five birdies in an eight-hole stretch and pulled away with a four-under-par 68 to win the $350,000 New Orleans open today.

title: Kemp-Roth: Too Large and Too Small
description: Act I of the drama over the Reagan economic program has centered on proposed reductions in spending. Today, as Congress returns from Easter recess, attention will shift to the tax changes Mr. Reagan wants. It should be a lively Act II, for there is much to fight over. The Administration's tax proposal is both wishful and risky; and a major part of it should be rejected by Congress.

title: Iran's Newest Victims
description: Iran is no longer in the spotlight; its war with Iraq drags on indecisively and a now-indifferent world shrugs off its unending internal wrangles. This apathy perfectly suits Iran's clerical zealots as they silence newspapers, jail their opponents and bloodily settle old scores. Especially ominous has been their systematic execution of adherents of Baha'i.

title: MRS. CATALANO WINS, PAIRED WITH LINDSAY
description: Just six days after finishing second and setting an American record in the Boston Marathon, Patti Lyons Catalano teamed with Herb Lindsay yesterday to win the third annual Trevira Twosome 10-mile run in Central Park.

title: MORTGAGE RATE HEARINGS DUE
description: The chairman of the House Banking, Finance and Urban Affairs Committee said that the committee would hold hearings on last week's decision by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board to permit unrestricted variable rate mortgages tied to an index.

title: Porsche Turbo Wins
description: John Fitzpatrick of England and Jim Busby of Laguna Beach, Calif., driving a Porsche Turbo, won the tightest duel yet in the Los Angeles Times-Toyota 6-Hour Enduro today at the Riverside International Raceway. The winners averaged 109.217 miles an hour in edging John Paul, Jr., and his co-driving father, both of Lawrenceville, Ga., by 32.982 seconds after leading by more than three laps with less than 30 minutes to go.

title: Freed Whale Sighted 7 Miles Out to Sea
description: A 25,000-pound sperm whale, having recovered from a near-fatal case of pneumonia, spent its first full day back in its natural habitat - the Atlantic Ocean -after being released Saturday from the western tip of Fire Island.

title: 2 Women Suspended For Using Steroids
description: Two female athletes, an Austrian runner and a Soviet shot-putter, were suspended from competition for 18 months today for taking banned anabolic steroids at the European indoor track and field championships in February.

title: Sweden 2d in World Hockey
description: Sweden, scoring all its goals on power plays, defeated Canada, 4-3, today and clinched second place in the world hockey championships.

title: White Motor Picks A New Chairman
description: Wallace B. Askins, the 50-year-old executive vice president and chief financial officer of the White Motor Corporation, has been named chairman and chief executive officer. He succeeds Cruse W. Moss, 55, who resigned as head of the Farmington Hills, Mich., manufacturer of heavy-duty trucks, farm equipment and fork-lift trucks.

title: THE CINDERELLA PULITZER PRIZE NOVEL RECONSIDERED
description: IT makes for a powerful Hollywood script synopsis - the story of how John Kennedy Toole's ''A Confederacy of Dunces'' got published by Louisiana State University Press and went on to win fame and fortune and the 1980 Pulitzer Prize for fiction: lonely genius writes satirical novel, submits it to crass, commercial New York publisher, who strings lonely genius along for a while, then rejects satirical novel on ground it will never sell. Heartbroken over this rejection, the young novelist ends his life.

title: Harvard Joins Critics of I.B.M.
description: Harvard University announced today that it would vote in favor of an International Business Machine's stockholder resolution to restrict the company's ability to sell or service computers for the South African Government.

title: Red Smith;  Thespian Quarterback
description: TERRY BRADSHAW, it says here, will be back in pads throwing passes for the Pittsburgh Steelers when the 1981 professional football season opens. This is the opinion of a self-appointed television critic.

title: Liberal Iranian Paper Reappears With a Pledge on Press Freedom
description: Mizan, Iran's leading liberal newspaper, was back on sale today after a two-week ban, and promised its readers to defend freedom of the press and independence of the courts.

title: Market Place; The Outlook For Polaroid
description: WALL STREET analysts converged on the Polaroid Corporation at Cambridge, Mass., last week with sugar plums dancing in their heads. When they emerged, the sugar plums had turned a bit sour.

title: AT 19, THOMAS MAKES HIS DECISION
description: IT was Draft Day in the ghetto. That's what everyone there called it. On a few days each year, chieftains of the notorious Vice Lords street gang appeared at certain homes on the West Side of Chicago to take recruits. On this summer night in 1966, 25 Vice Lord chiefs stopped in front of the home of Mary Thomas. She had nine children, seven of them boys, ranging from Lord Henry, 15 years old, to Isiah, 5. The Thomases lived on the first floor of a two-story red brick building on Congress Street, facing the Eisenhower Expressway.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard GOD EMPEROR OF DUNE. By Frank Her- bert. 411 pages. Putnam. $12.95.

title: 'Released Is Not Deceased'
description: TWO years ago Don Stanhouse was the Baltimore Orioles' late-inning relief and comic relief. His nickname told it all - Stan The Man Unusual. On his way into the Orioles' clubhouse after batting practice, he often stopped in the dugout and let out a scream that curdled the blood of early arrivals at the ball park. And when he took off his Orioles cap, his hairdo startled people, too.

title: Klan Leader Is Arrested
description: The Imperial Wizard of the Ku Klux Klan, Bill Wilkinson, was arrested yesterday at a Klan march and rally in Manchester, the police said. The police said that Mr. Wilkinson had been charged with soliciting without a permit.

title: FLAMES OUST FLYERS IN 7TH GAME
description: The Calgary Flames got power-play goals by Willi Plett, Ken Houston and Kevin Lavallee as they beat the Philadelphia Flyers, 4-1, tonight and advanced to the semifinals of the National Hockey League playoffs.

title: COLUMBIA SEMINARS TO STUDY THE PRESS AND SOCIETY
description: Columbia University has announced a three-year seminar program on the press and its relationship to such issues as crime and violence, race relations, foreign policy, the justice system and business and government.

title: TIME FOR A BREAK
description: To the Editor:

title: Israel Repeats Its Opposition To Awacs Sale to the Saudis
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin's Cabinet repeated its opposition today to the proposed United States sale of radar reconnaissance planes to Saudi Arabia, but stopped short of authorizing measures to try to block the deal.

title: MASTERING FLY FISHING IS NO SIMPLE TASK
description: To one reared in a countryside that was blessed with excellent trout ponds and streams, the idea of attending a fly-fishing school seems strange; I improved my angling skills by skipping school.

title: The U.N. Today; April 27, 1981; SECURITY COUNCIL
description: Meets at 11 A.M. GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: SOVIET CALLS HAIG SPEECH 'WARLIKE'
description: The official Soviet press agency, Tass, accused Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. today of showing what it characterized as excessive belligerence unsuited to his job as America's top diplomat.

title: 'KING PENGUIN' PETERSON LEADS RACE TO AID AUDUBON SOCIETY
description: King Penguin, dressed for the day's marathon in khaki jump suit and jogging shoes and rakish field hat, peeked out the door of his room at the Ramada Inn at 4 A.M. In New England, he's called Osprey. But in most of the United States and around the world, he is King Penguin: Roger Tory Peterson, recognized at the age of 72 as the premier bird watcher on the planet.

title: LITTLER, ROSBURG WIN LEGENDS GOLF
description: Gene Littler and Bob Rosburg watched their five-shot lead cut to one on the back nine today before they went on to win the Legends of Golf tournament.

title: LONG-TERM BOND SEEN IN TREASURY FINANCING
description: While the backlog of proposed, but unsold, corporate debt issues continues to grow, many experts do not think the Treasury will curb its long-term borrowings much.

title: The Economy
description: Wall Street appeared divided over the wave of brokerage house mergers as industry officials gathered for a meeting of the Securities Industry Association in Bermuda. Many are unhappy over the recent takeovers of major houses by big financial institutions and expect more such actions to follow. (Page D1.)

title: Wallin Helps Spur Rangers' Late Drive
description: ''Wallin is a good player, but he's a jerk,'' said Ulf Nilsson, the Rangers' gifted center. Peter Wallin, a Swedish player who joined the team March 8, stared in puzzlement for a moment in the Ranger locker room, then both players smiled. It was Nilsson's way of letting anyone within earshot know, on the eve of the playoffs, that Wallin had been accepted as a valuable teammate not only by the other Swedes, Nilsson and Anders Hedberg, but by all the Rangers.

title: Baltimore Loyola, Hobart Top Polls
description: Baltimore Loyola regained the top spot in Division II and Hobart remained the unanimous choice for No. 1 in Division III today in the respective coaches' polls of the United States Intercollegiate Lacrosse Association.

title: DERBY HOPEFULS STEP UP PACE
description: Horatio Luro says he doesn't believe in working on Sundays. Never has. But Luro, an 80-year-old Argentine trainer, was loping along on his stable pony this morning.

title: MAKING IT HARDER
description: Renewed United States efforts to settle the festering Namibian issue, the key to relations with Africa, have been palpably set back by a series of often off-hand remarks in Washington. The tour by Assistant Secretary of State-designate for African Affairs, Chester A. Crocker, stirred an outpouring of argument from major African spokesmen that showed clearly the way the Administration's review of African policy is being taken in black countries.

title: Suspects Named in Robbery Of $3 Million at Tucson Bank
description: A man wanted for fleeing jail and three others wanted in a $1.5 million jewel theft in Phoenix are being sought in connection with the $3.3 million robbery of a bank here last week, the police and the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today.

title: Burned
description: Chairman Dyson of the New York State Power Authority and Commissioner Steisel of New York City's Sanitation Department have rallied to the defense of their plan to build a $245 million garbage incinerating plant in the Bronx. It would support itself, they say, partly from charges to the city for taking in its garbage, and partly by using the heat to run a steam generator to produce electricity for sale.

title: Rockets Triumph, Lead, 3-1
description: Houston's Moses Malone scored 42 points and took 22 rebounds today as the Houston Rockets defeated the Kansas City Kings, 100-89, in a National Basketball Association Western Conference final playoff game.

title: NABISCO MERGER CALLED KEY TO GROWTH
description: When Robert M. Schaeberle accounced the marriage last week of his company, Nabisco Inc., and Standard Brands Inc., he termed it ''a merger in every sense of the word.''

title: CRIMMINS GOES ON TRIAL TODAY IN OPERA KILLING
description: A jury of seven women and five men will begin today to hear the case of Craig S. Crimmins, a 22-year-old stagehand who is accused of murdering Helen Hagnes, a 31-year-old violinist, at the Metropolitan Opera House last summer.

title: A CHALLENGE TO CONGRESSIONAL CREATIVITY
description: To the Editor:

title: DROP FORESEEN IN ENERGY USE
description: The nation is expected to use slightly less energy this year than it did last, according to a report from the Department of Energy.

title: RONI PAITCHEL, A TEACHER, BRIDE OF JEFFERY DENHOLTZ
description: Roni Susan Paitchel and Jeffrey Robert Denholtz were married yesterday in Temple Emanuel in Livingston, N.J. Rabbi Peter Kasden performed the ceremony.

title: Monmouth Jail Calm Following Protests
description: The Monmouth County Correctional Center was relatively calm after two days of violent protests in which inmates set fires, broke windows and used a makeshift battering ram to knock down an interior wall.

title: MARGOT S. SLADE, EDITOR, WED TO NICHOLAS BAXTER
description: Margot S. Slade, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin S. Slade of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday in Manhattan to Nicholas St. Clair Lund Baxter, son of Brig. Gen Harry J.P. Baxter, British Army, retired, and Mrs. Baxter of County Down, Northern Irleand.

title: Rules on Sponsor Credits Relaxed by the F.C.C.
description: The Federal Communications Commission decided last week to relax some of the rules covering sponsor credits on public television.

title: JOHN SCULLY: MIND OVER MATTER
description: JOHN SCULLY, 6 feet 5 inches tall, 250 pounds, 22 years of age, has a thick neck supporting a discriminating mind. Around noontime tomorrow Scully is expected to be drafted late in the first round of the National Football League's annual selection of the best college football players. One of the league's 28 teams will make the selection and this act will in turn immediately value the Scully body and mind at about $500,000.

title: Miss Solomon Ends Drought
description: Beth Solomon beat Jane Blalock on the third hole of a sudden-death playoff and won the $100,000 Birmingham Classic golf tournament today. It was her first victory in seven touring years.

title: YAMANI OR YA LIFE
description: On March 5, 1975, in Los Angeles, a Palestinian Arab showed up unexpectedly at the Wilshire Boulevard offices of Ronald Reagan. He was Sadat Hassan, permanent P.L.O. observer at the United Nations, and Mr. Reagan agreed to see him.

title: Baldrige Says the U.S. Got No 'Quid Pro Quo' on Grain
description: Secretary of Commerce Malcolm Baldrige said today that there was no ''quid pro quo'' for ending the restrictions on grain sales to the Soviet Union and that United States politics played only a minor part in the decision.

title: JOSHUA C. TAYLOR, ART HISTORIAN AND SMITHSONIAN CHIEF
description: Joshua C. Taylor, an art historian and the director of the National Museum of American Art of the Smithsonian Institution in Washington, died yesterday at Georgetown University Hospital there after a brief illness. He was 63 years old.

title: AT MOCK AUCTION, CHILDREN LEARN HOW TO COLLECT
description: The starting price of $9,000 for President Lincoln's autograph seemed to intimidate the bidders at first, and the hall was silent. After all, considering that their sole income was a weekly allowance from their parents of about $1.50, the autograph was a bit out of range.

title: ELIZABETH TAYLOR PREVIEWS A PARTY
description: ''Hi, I'm Tondelayo Schwartz,'' said Elizabeth Taylor Warner to Lillian Hellman, who sat leisurely smoking a cigarette seeming for all the world like Lewis Carroll's caterpillar with hookah. ''Say,'' continued Miss Taylor, ''what is all this?''

title: FACING AN URBAN DESERT
description: The Reagan Administration's proposed budget promises a land of milk and honey. As a mayor, my concern is that it may turn out to be a desert of rocks and dust for the older central cities of the United States.

title: with BELGRADE -----; Croatia Dissident Reported Held
description: Dr. Marko Veselica, a prominent Croatian dissident, has been arrested in the northwestern city of Zagreb on suspicion of antistate activities, legal sources said today. Lawyers for Professor Veselica said that an investigating judge ordered him to be detained Friday ''because of new evidence which pointed to links with Yugoslav emigres abroad.''

title: ORIGINATOR OF BRAZIL'S CHICKEN EXPORTS
description: There seems to be something about the chicken business that breeds salesmen with a bent for showmanship. Brazil's answer to Frank Perdue is Nunzio Quraitem, a fast-talking former organ technician in Middle Eastern Catholic cathedrals who struck his first deal by forging a telexed order from Iran for 5,000 tons of frozen poultry five years ago.

title: POLITICAL PURIFICATION IN NEW JERSEY
description: To the Editor:

title: INDIAN SEES A NEED FOR A-BOMBS
description: A high-ranking Government military adviser said today that India had to build a nuclear bomb not only to achieve military superiority over Pakistan but also to insure that India was not ignored by the United States.

title: McEnroe's Trinity Legacy
description: The tennis captain at Trinity School was ''gifted in math and science - and his Latin master still remembers his good work,'' said Robin Lester, headmaster of the 270-year-old school on the Upper West Side. ''Already competitive, yes, but the temper? No - just a person who drove himself relentlessly but also had a tremendous sense of humor.''

title: West Point Cadet Killed on 9W
description: A senior West Point cadet was killed in an auto accident last night when he was ejected through the car's rear window, the state police said. The cadet, Richard Sobotik, 22 years old, of Houston, was driving south on Route 9W at a high speed when he failed to make a curve, hit a guardrail and was thrown through the window into a rock embankment, the police said.

title: GREEKS MARK EASTER WITH SERVICES AND LAMB FEAST Rye
description: Eyes blinked against the bright sun yesterday morning - Easter for the world's Eastern Orthodox Churches -at the neat three-story brick house of Soulis Drakoularakos in Astoria, Queens. The Resurrection of Christ had been celebrated in churches at the stroke of midnight the night before, and it was already 12:30 in the morning by the time traditional Greek parties all over Astoria got going seriously. Soulis Drakoularakos and his wife, Voula, and their three children were up late, some until 5 A.M.

title: NEW YORK CURRENCY TRADE EBBS
description: WHILE foreign-currency trading may be dormant on the New York Futures Exchange, the market in the ''ultimate commodity'' is alive and booming in Chicago.

title: Gene McCabe, Designer Of Cartier's Monogram
description: Gene McCabe, a well-known display director and interior designer who created the interior design of Cartier at 52d Street and Fifth Avenue, died Saturday at New York Hospital after a brief illness. Mr. McCabe, who was a resident of Manhattan, was 51 years old.

title: TO REDUCE CRIME, ELIMINATE CASH
description: We are witnessing a barrage of news-media concern and debate about violent crime and its effect on the quality of life in the United States. In sheer monetary loss, the cost to society runs into the hundreds of billions of dollars, a substantial fraction of the total Federal budget. Yet there is a simple - or, better, simply stated, solution that would instantly result in a drastic reduction in crime and, incidently, in our taxes.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Avatar Holdings Inc. has appointed Thomas E. Lewis president and chief operating officer, succeeding Peter Sharp, who continues as chairman and chief executive officer.

title: Golf Legend
description: Among the thousands who attended the funeral service for Joe Louis in Las Vegas, Nev., was Charlie Sifford. It had been known over the years that some black athletes, Jackie Robinson being one, had credited Louis with being the inspiration for their breakthroughs into big-time sports. Sifford added his name to that list, and he said he got his help from Louis in person in his quest to become the first black golfer to play on the professional tour.

title: JONES IS HERO AS 76ERS TAKE 3-1 LEAD
description: Bobby Jones, with the instincts of a defensive back in football, intercepted a pass with two seconds left and insured the Philadelphia 76ers' 107-105 victory over the Boston Celtics at the Spectrum today.

title: Sports World Specials By Jim Benagh The Sunshine Boys
description: Sunshine Mary has not raced in the past couple of weeks, and for good reason. In 10 races, Sunshine Mary, a 3-year-old filly, has yet to beat another horse, holding up the rear to 94 opponents.

title: LED EWINGS IN DALLAS'
description: Jim Davis, the gravely-voice character actor best known as the tough patriarch of the Ewing family in the television series ''Dallas'' died yesterday in his home in Northridge, Calif. He was 65 years old and had recently undergone surgery for a perforated ulcer.

title: METS DROP 2 TO EXPOS
description: The Mets dropped a doubleheader to the firstplace Expos today and got a further setback when Craig Swan injured his right shoulder.

title: THEATER: PINERO'S 'A MIDNIGHT MOON'
description: MIGUEL PINERO's new play, ''A Midnight Moon at the Greasy Spoon,'' at the Theater for the New City, begins like a four-alarm blaze. The late-night Times Square diner that is the scene of the evening's adventure is bursting at the seams with prostitutes, junkies and punks, shouting and competing for attention. For a moment it appears as if we are in for a characteristic Pinero study of what he calls ''the underclass,'' as in his prize-winning prison drama ''Short Eyes'' or his barroom passion play ''The Sun Always Shines for the Cool.'' However, as tempers subside and individual identities emerge, we realize that the author has something quite different - and refreshing - in mind. ''Greasy Spoon'' is a sympathetic slice of working-class life, a play about idealism and disillusionment.

title: THOUSANDS JAM NEW BONWIT'S FOR PREVIEW
description: ''To all of Bonwit Teller's special friends,'' the lavender type on the invitation read. ''It is my privilege, in this most blooming and exciting of our springs, to invite you to a private preview of the new Bonwit Teller.''

title: POLISH ARCHBISHOP IS SAID TO NEED LONG MEDICAL CARE
description: Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski, leader of Poland's Roman Catholic Church and a voice of moderation in the labor trouble, is ill and will require long medical treatment, the church announced today.

title: WASTE NOT WANT NOT FOR TREES
description: To the Editor:

title: CONGRESS EXPECTED TO SEEK SAVINGS ON SOCIAL SECURITY FOR SHORT TERM
description: A group of pension experts will urge President Reagan to defer attempts at long-range changes in Social Security for the present and concentrate on the solvency crisis faced by the retirement program in the immediate future, according to Congressional staff members.

title: POSTAL UNIT'S PLANNED MOVE UPSETS 2 COMMUNITIES
description: The United States Postal Service is planning to move its Stamford, Conn., mail-processing center to Rye, but the decision doesn't sit well with any of those concerned - neither Stamford nor Rye, nor even the Postal Service itself.

title: INTERIOR SECRETARY SAYS HE WON'T TRY TO DROP ANY PARK LANDS NOW
description: James G. Watt, whose actions in his first months as Secretary of the Interior have been condemned by conservationists and cheered by developers, said today that he would seek no major changes in the nation's land use and protection laws, nor would he try at this time to drop any units from the National Park or Wildlife Refuge systems.

title: FRANCE'S PRESIDENT GAINS NARROW LEAD IN PRELIMINARY VOTE
description: President Valery Giscard d'Estaing and the Socialist leader, Francois Mitterrand, emerged last night from the first round of the presidential election as neck-and-neck contenders in the runoff in two weeks.

title: COAL EXPORTERS ARE SEEN FACING PROBLEMS AT PORTS
description: The long-range problem in the coal export business may well turn out to be excess port capacity, rather than the inability of ports and other transportation companies to handle the expected boom, according to some rail and coal experts.

title: OPERA: FLOYD'S 'WILLIE'
description: HOUSTON ROBERT PENN WARREN'S ''All the King's Men'' is in many ways the basic American novel, dealing as it does with such apple-pie topics as demagoguery, social ideals run amok, political chicanery and, ultimately, the assassination of a public figure. The work moved easily onto the movie screen many years ago, with Broderick Crawford as the corrupt hero of the downtrodden, and now it has been transported to the opera stage, in Carlisle Floyd's ''Willie Stark.'' Mr. Floyd's work was given its world premiere Friday night by the Houston Grand Opera in a production that, under Harold Prince's direction, retold Mr. Warren's many-leveled tale in a one-dimensional Broadwaymusical style, which relied for most of its appeal on period flavor and tricky staging ideas. The music was pushed into the background rather effectively.

title: DEAD STOCKS REVIVE IN SALES TO INVESTORS
description: The Philadelphia & Lancaster Turnpike Company went out of business almost 300 years ago, but there is still a booming market for its stock. One share sold this weekend for $320, triple its value just two years ago, and market analysts feel the stock will hit $400 soon.

title: BOND YIELDS HIGH AS TRADERS REMAIN SKEPTICAL ON INFLATION
description: The response of the credit markets to President Reagan's economic program has been negative so far, despite ardent hopes for its success. Long-term interest rates are at record highs, and the credit markets are in disarray, with analysts sharply divided about the likely course of the economy.

title: A Night of Mutual Attraction at Xenon
description: The operators of the new Legends model agency didn't need much of an excuse to celebrate at Xenon the other night. ''They asked if they could give a party for us, and we said yes,'' said Kay Mitchell, the president of the three-month-old Manhattan agency.

title: 55 PROBLEMS FACING NEW YORK CITY MASS TRANSIT
description: After two months of looking over the spectrum of Transit Authority operations, from headquarters to subway tracks to maintenance yards, the Economic Development Council issued a 72-page report, supplemented by more than 100 pages of memorandums and performance charts, listing 55 problem areas.

title: TRADITIONS FLOURISH ON RUSSIAN EASTER
description: Today was Russian Easter, and from early morning the crowds began streaming out of subway stations and streetcar stops, forming a solid, broad mass to the gates of Vagankovo Cemetery in northwestern Moscow.

title: Shepherd Is Victor In Virginia 500
description: Morgan Shepherd of Conover, N.C., won his first Grand National race today with an easy victory in the $169,000 Virginia 500.

title: 6 Valuable Torahs Are Stolen in Jersey
description: Six holy scrolls, worth about $20,000 each, were apparently stolen from a synagogue in this Ocean County community over the weekend, according to the police.

title: STATE STUDYING USE OF 38 LANDFILLS FOR GETTING POWER FROM GARBAGE
description: After finding that a Staten Island landfill can supply enough methane gas from decomposing garbage to run a small power plant, New York State is studying 38 landfills across the state to see if the gas can be recovered from them for commercial use.

title: Yet Another Tumble for the 'Accident Prone' Prince
description: Britain's best-known horseman took another tumble yesterday, the third time in six weeks that Prince Charles has fallen off a galloping horse. The first two falls, including one that bloodied the royal nose, occurred during steeplechase races in England. Yesterday's fall came during a polo match in Sydney, Australia.

title: New Parliament Elected, By Vietnamese Voters
description: Vietnamese voters elected a new Parliament today. The 496-seat assembly will be the seventh since Ho Chi Minh declared Vietnam an independent country in September 1945, but it will be the first to be chosen in nationwide elections since the unification of North and South Vietnam in 1976.

title: Chain Bracelet Wins Top Flight Handicap
description: Chain Bracelet put away the favored Weber City Miss turning for home yesterday and scored an easy victory in the $107,800 Top Flight Handicap at Aqueduct.

title: YEAR LATER, 1,800 CUBANS WAIT IN U.S. JAILS
description: Jorge Morales Alfonso says he has thought about the moment a thousand times, worrying over each detail of it at night in his cell at the Federal Penitentiary here.

title: Paper Offers Car Rebates
description: The Oakland Press, a 75,000-circulation newspaper in Oakland County, has announced that it will offer $100 cash rebates to subscribers who buy new foreign or domestic 1981 cars, trucks or vans advertised in its pages. According to guidelines announced Friday, participating car dealers will identify specific vehicles and advertise them in the newspaper. New cars, trucks and vans must already be in the dealer's stock to be eligible for the rebates, which run through May 31.

title: YUGOSLAVS, SHAKEN BY RIOTS, FEAR PLOT
description: Nearly a month after the rioting in a southern province of Yugoslavia, it is still unclear what the troubles were all about.

title: White Sox Win Sixth Straight
description: Bob Molinaro, a left-handed hitting outfielder, was signed by the Tigers in the free-agent draft of June 1968. He then spent almost 10 years in the Detroit minor-league system before he was traded to the Chicago White Sox in 1977.

title: MCKELLEN STARS AT GALA FOR SHAKESPEARE'S GLOBE
description: The gilded, the talented and the rich joined last night to help rebuild Shakespeare's Globe Theater. In the presence of Princess Grace of Monaco, who was the ''honorary patron,'' they paid as much as $250 a ticket to hear the actor Ian McKellen in a benefit performance of ''Acting Shakespeare'' at the Broadhurst Theater. The evening was organized primarily by Sam Wanamaker, the American actor and director, who now lives in Britain.

title: Shift at Top of Bausch & Lomb
description: Six months after being named president of Bausch & Lomb Inc., Daniel E. Gill, 44 years old, has been elected to the additional post of chief executive officer. He succeeds Daniel G. Schuman, 64, who will continue as chairman of the Rochester company until retiring at the end of the year.

title: TUCSON PROTEST GROUP LINKS BIBLE TO EL SALVADOR
description: As employees leave the Federal Building here each Thursday afternoon, they encounter a group of some 50 people quietly demonstrating against United States involvement in El Salvador.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: THE START

title: ATWOOD OCEANICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

title: MUSIC: CHICAGO SYMPHONY
description: LISTENING to the Chicago Symphony Orchestra play Mahler's Ninth Symphony can be a thrilling experience, that we know by now. But it can also be a strange one simply because in this imperfect world we do not expect to hear such a fiercely difficult work performed with so little sense of peril, let alone perceptible error. The quality of orchestral playing, both soloistic and ensemble, that Sir Georg Solti drew from the Chicagoans Monday night at Carnegie Hall was so consistently high that an air of unreality settled over the entire evening. The listener could virtually forget that mundane, fallible instruments and musicians were mediating between him and the music; direct contact of a rare sort was made possible.

title: Mysterious Disease Near Mountain

Over the last 10 years, a broad national consensus has emerged that we must increase energy security by reducing the amount of oil that the United States imports from abroad. This agreement on policy was forged through three Administrations - two Republican and one Democratic -and has been the cornerstone of our national energy policy.

description: There are signs that the Administration's supply-side economists are banking increasingly on regulatory reform and less on the combined impact of certain tax and less-certain expenditure cuts. title: U.S. May Raise EE Bonds to 9%
description: The interest rate on United States savings bonds may be raised to 9 percent from 8 percent, starting Friday. Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan said yesterday that the Administration was giving ''active consideration'' to a rise of one percentage point.

POLICE IN BUFFALO SAY TESTS OF SOILDER'S JACKET SHOW HUMAN BLOODSTAINS
description: As an investigation continued today into a possible link between a white Army private at Fort Benning, Ga., and the slaying of seven black men in this city last year, police and Federal officials said that preliminary tests on a jacket confiscated from the soldier showed human bloodstains.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, APRIL 28, 1981
description: International A foreign-policy difference between President Reagan and Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. was disclosed by White House officials. They said that Mr. Haig did not reflect the President's views when he said Saturday that Washington would impose a total trade embargo against the Soviet Union if it invaded Poland. A spokesman called an embargo ''one of many options'' that the President could choose. (Page A1, Column 1.) The Administration was rebuffed in an attempt to end Congressional restrictions on American military aid to insurgents in Angola. By a 7-to-0 vote, a House subcommittee backed retention of the restrictions. (A3:3-6.)

title: PARDONING A BLACK-BAG JOB ON THE CONSTITUTION
description: To The Editor: Your April 16 editorial pairs the pardoning of Mark Felt and Edward Miller with the out-of-court settlement favoring five individuals - I am one of them - whose phones were illegally tapped and homes illegally broken into by F.B.I. men. The editorial suggests the settlement prompted and partly justifies the clemency granted to Felt and Miller. This argument uses a victory of law to excuse an abuse of it.

It was the first step in her 75 years of volunteer work; at the age of 90, she is now a Union Settlement board member.

title: PERU YIELDS EVIDENCE OF OLDEST VILLAGE IN HEMISPHERE

title: 'GUINEA PIGS' LOOKS INTO FAILURES AT THREE MILE ISLAND
description: ''WE ARE the Guinea Pigs,'' which is playing at the Public Theater on weekends, is a documentary consisting mainly of interviews. It might seem talky, if the things that were being said were not so horrifying. The film's grim message is that the repercussions of the nuclear accident at Three Mile Island are by no means over, and that the results will be far more catastrophic than has been generally known.

title: PROFITABLE HANDGUN INDUSTRY FACES THREAT
description: For the manufacturers of handguns across the country, these are profitable, but difficult, times. Pistol and revolver sales in 1980 amounted to more than $221 million, a 26 percent jump over the previous year and about one and three-quarter times the 1976 figure of $127.4 million. But despite the highly favorable business outlook, handgun manufacturers are facing a political challenge that some believe threatens the whole industry.

title: TV: DRAMA OF YOUNG CRIME-FIGHTER
description: THE facts: The Guardian Angels were founded a couple of years ago by Curtis Sliwa, a former newsboy working out of an apartment in the Bronx. Wearing a uniform of red berets and white T-shirts, the Angels ride New York's crime-ridden subways as self-appointed defenders of the law, making citizen arrests on their own initiative. They have clashed with certain law-enforcement agencies, especially the Transit Police, and have been accused of being unschooled in certain areas of policing.

ROE SPURNING STATE HELP IN JERSEY GOVERNOR RACE
description: In 10 regional campaign offices around the state, volunteers for Representative Robert A. Roe are organizing cake and cookie sales, film festivals on college campuses, a hayride, dances, horse races and $1 buffet lunches in a campaign for Governor that is unusual this year because it is old-fashioned.

title: Mocking ZIP + 4
description: Three things Americans like to ridicule are (1) the increasing number of numbers in modern life, (2) the length of time it takes a letter to arrive, and (3) the cost of Government. All are involved in the bargain proposed by the Postal Service that a Senate subcommittee will examine tomorrow. The Service believes that, in exchange for making 1 a little worse, it can make 2 and 3 a good deal better. Despite some Congressional mockery, there's nothing at all ridiculous about that; ''ZIP + 4'' is well worth a try.

title: 100 Flee Railroad Chlorine Leak
description: More than 100 residents were evacuated today when deadly chlorine gas leaked from a Sante Fe Railroad tank car loaded with hydrochloric acid, but firefighters said the gas cloud was quickly and safely dispersed. No injuries were reported.

title: Earnings at A.& S.  Highest Since 1977
description: Abraham & Straus, the Brooklyn-based store chain, raised its earnings in the last fiscal year to the highest level since 1977 despite low margins and ''substantial inventory shortages,'' some of them resulting from thefts.

title: Lakers Re-Sign Sharman
description: Bill Sharman received a three-year extension of his contract as general manager of the Los Angeles Lakers today.

title: Alouettes Sign Ferragamo, Scott
description: Vince Ferragamo, the former quarterback of the Los Angeles Rams, and James Scott, who played out his option with the Chicago Bears, signed multiyear contracts today with the Montreal Alouettes of the Canadian Football League.

description: Agriculture in the United States has evolved into a large-scale, specialized, highly mechanized system, heavily dependent upon petroleum and relying upon certain regions to provide the bulk of the nation's food needs - California, the produce; the Great Plains, the hogs, and the Corn Belt, the corn, for example.

title: HERSHEY, SINGER UP
description: Norton Simon Inc., the parent of Avis Inc. and one of the nation's leading manufacturers of foods, cosmetics, distilled spirits and other consumers products, reported yesterday that earnings in the third fiscal quarter of 1981 dropped 40.4 percent, while revenues advanced by 6.3 percent.

title: DEMOCRATIC PARLEY URGED IN EARLY '82
description: Charles T. Manatt, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, is trying to move up the date of the party's 1982 national conference, scheduling it before the 1982 election, with the number of delegates cut in half.

title: REVISED 'HEAVEN'S GATE' COLLAPSES AT BOX OFFICE
description: Public judgment of the re-edited version of Michael Cimino's ''Heaven's Gate,'' the approximately $40 million movie, which opened in slightly more than 800 theaters across the country last Friday, was quick and decisive. Although United Artists, the movie's distributor, refused to give out any box-office figures this morning, it was clear that the movie was a disaster.

title: CITY WILL APPEAL RULING THAT PENSION PLAN IS BIASED AGAINST WOMEN
description: New York City's Corporation Counsel said yesterday that the city would appeal a Federal court ruling that its largest employee pension plan discriminated against women.

title: A Rodin Fan to Share His Sculpture Collection
description: ''Machines that think'' are no novelty in World Trade Center offices, but B. Gerald Cantor shares his 105th-floor space with ''The Thinker,'' a 1,200-pound bronze casting of the Auguste Rodin sculpture. It arrived Saturday by freight elevator, with the help of eight workmen.

description: Stiff competition for timber resources will spread across the world in the next several decades, according to an expert on wood fuels.

description: Israeli fighter-bombers struck Palestinian areas of southern Lebanon this afternoon and evening as fighting increased between Israeli-backed Lebanese Christian militiamen and their enemies, the Syrian and Lebanese Moslem and leftist forces.

title: OIL, DRUG ISSUES AID STOCK RISE
description: The stock market moved slightly higher yesterday, aided by improved prices for major oils, drugs and other selected blue chips such as General Electric and Du Pont.

description: The Spring Nationals of the American Bridge Association ended Sunday in Las Vegas, Nev., in a familiar fashion. For the third straight year victory in the Swiss teams on the final day went to the New York partnership of Jim Garcia and Luz Chandler.

description: About 100,000 farmers from all over Italy drove their tractors or marched through the streets of Rome today to protest the agricultural policy of the European Common Market, which they say favors northern European countries.

description: Madge Evans, a popular actress who frequently portrayed the cleancut, decent American woman in films and on stage during the 30's, died of cancer Sunday night at her home in Oakland, N.J., where she had lived for many years with her husband, the playwright Sidney Kingsley. She was 71 years old.

description: Steel production rose to 2.6 million tons in the week ended last Saturday, an increase of seven-tenths of 1 percent from the previous week's 2.58 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

description: INVESTORS sometimes turn to gold in an effort to avoid the hazards of holding currencies in times of worldwide inflation. But there are problems: Gold must be stored, the holder must pay for costly appraisals on purchase and sale, and investors cannot get the wholesale price unless a kilogram is purchased at a minimum cost of about $15,000.

Manager Billy Martin of the Oakland A's, having noticed something unusual about the batter's box before Saturday night's game against the Seattle Mariners at the Kingdome, asked Bill Kunkel, chief of the umpires crew working the series, to investigate.

description: Calling Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin ''the most investigated elected municipal official in the recent history of New York City,'' Assemblyman John P. Dearie announced yesterday that he would run against Mr. Goldin in the Democratic primary in September.

description: The Xerox Corporation yesterday introduced a product intended to overcome a major obstacle in the path toward the automated office - the reluctance of white-collar workers with no computer experience to use electronic terminals.

The buyers loved it, the photographers shot more film than they had to and the fashion editors fairly swooned.

description: ''The team that capitalizes on its breaks usually wins. That's what we did tonight, and that was the difference.''

title: Xerox Up 7.5%; MacMillan Falls 74.3%
description: The Xerox Corporation, the nation's leading producer of copying and duplicating machines, reported yesterday that earnings in the first quarter of 1981 rose 7.5 percent as sales increased 10.8 percent.

title: Top Anglican Urges Talks On Limiting Atom Weapons
description: The Archbishop of Canterbury, the Most Rev. Robert K. Runcie, called nuclear warfare the ''lunatic unthinkable'' today and urged negotiations among the great powers to limit nuclear weapons.

title: REBUILDING OUR TRANSIT
description: Governor's Carey's $5.6 billion legislative program for purchasing new capital equipment for New York City's subway and bus systems is a disaster for mass-transit riders. It is fiscally irresponsible and provides no real long-term solution to the system's needs. Most business and citizen groups, as well as legislative leaders in the city, share this view, but, amazingly, have decided not to fight the Governor's bill. They are glad that something -anything - is being done about the collapse of the transit system. This is a very bad mistake.

title: Faction in Polish Party Will Monitor Big Meeting
description: Some Communist Party members have set up an unusual system to monitor the deliberations of a Central Committee meeting tomorrow and relay the information to party members throughout Poland.

SUZUKI SAYS U.S. DID NOT CONSULT ON ENDING GRAIN BAN
description: Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki, who will visit Washington next week, criticized the United States today for not having consulted with Japan before ending the 15-month curb on grain shipments to the Soviet Union.

title: HOUSE PANEL TRIMS FOOD STAMP BUDGET
description: For almost two decades, the agriculture committees of Congress have steadily expanded the food stamp program, to the point where it now reaches 22 million Americans. Today it took a House subcommittee less than two hours to trim about $1 billion out of the program for the fiscal year 1982, and the lawmakers are not through cutting. The session of the panel on domestic marketing, consumer relations and nutrition marked the formal beginning of legislative efforts that will eventually produce a revised food stamp program later this year. But the meeting clearly demonstrated how President Reagan has already won many of the basic economic battles on Capitol Hill and reduced his liberal critics to fighting rearguard actions against a few of his more drastic budget-slashing proposals.

title: Lucrative Alouette Pact Is Hailed by Ferragamo
description: Vince Ferragamo said yesterday that he had turned aside repeated appeals from his former teammates and signed a contract with the Montreal Alouettes of the Canadian Football League because they made him an offer he could not refuse.

title: Los Angeles Is Wild Over 5-0 Valenzuela
description: One newspaper calls him ''Fernando Koufax.'' Another calls him ''Unbelievable!'' The Los Angeles Dodgers fans? They don't know what to make of Fernando Valenzuela, an emigre from rural Mexico.

title: Lumber Output Off 8.8%
description: Lumber production in February, at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 32.1 billion board feet, was 8.8 percent under the January rate and 13.4 percent below the rate of February 1980, according to the National Forest Products Association. Shipments were also lower, running at an annual rate of 29.8 billion board feet, down 11.7 percent from January and off 18.1 percent from the February 1980 rate.

description: In the first major legislative action on the new Administration's proposed military budget, the Senate Armed Services Committee decided today to give President Reagan all but a sliver of what he requested for next year.

title: News Analysis
description: With a flair for the dramatic moment, President Reagan sought tonight to provide irresistible momentum for his budget package by capitalizing on what his lieutenants regard as a rare ''second honeymoon'' with the American public after the attempt on his life 29 days ago.

description: Proud Appeal, the probable favorite for Saturday's Kentucky Derby, galloped an easy two miles today at Churchill Downs.

title: FORD AND CHRYSLER REPORT BIG DEFICITS
description: Both the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation reported today that they had larger-than-expected losses for the first quarter of this year, and each attributed the results to sluggish sales and rising costs.

title: BETHLEHEM OFF 52.3%
description: The United States Steel Corporation, the nation's largest steel producer, reported yesterday that its earnings in the 1981 first quarter more than doubled, to $270.9 million, or $3.06 a share, compared with $126 million, or $1.45 a share, during the similar period a year ago. Revenues for the quarter advanced 6.3 percent, to $3.4 billion from $3.2 billion.

title: NOTES ON PEOPLE
description: Despite All Appearances, Woody Allen Wasn't There

title: FOOTE BELTS HOMER
description: After 22 trips to the plate without a hit as a Chicago Cub, Barry Foote lofted the second pitch thrown to him as a Yankee into the left-field stands for a home run in the third inning tonight. Willie Randolph, ending an 0-for-10 slump, added a three-run homer in the fifth and Tommy John pitched a six-hitter as the Yankees beat the Tigers, 4-1, at Tiger Stadium.

title: GOLD FIELD GETS 7% OF NEWMONT
description: The Newmont Mining Corporation came under a surprise takeover attack yesterday with the disclosure by Consolidated Gold Fields Ltd. of London that it had purchased a 7 percent interest in the huge American mining company for $108.2 million and planned to buy substantially more.

title: Market Place; Preservation Of Capital
description: STOCK prices have been soaring for some time now and, as often happens in bull markets, Wall Street is beginning to soft-pedal the idea of preservation of capital to worship at the altar of performance.

title: Northwest Banking Shift
description: John W. Morrison, 58, has been named chairman and chief executive officer of the Northwest Bancorporation, effective Oct. 1. He will succeed Chester C. Lind, 62, who will retire from the Minneapolis bank holding company, the lead bank of which is the Northwestern National Bank of Minneapolis.

title: WEINBERGER URGES JAPAN TO TAKE MORE RESPONSIBILITY FOR ITS DEFENSE
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger said today that ''Japan would find it exceedingly difficult to defend itself with current forces'' and should ''provide much more for its own self-defense.''

title: OPERA: LEHAR'S 'COUNT'
description: FRANZ LEHAR followed his spectacular early triumph, ''The Merry Widow,'' with some 30 other operettas, none of which have ever proved quite so enduring. ''The Count of Luxemburg,'' first given in 1909, just five years after ''Merry Widow,'' is nonetheless full of charming music in a similar vein, a fact that the Village Light Opera underscored in its revival of the work Saturday night at the Fashion Institute Theater - the first New York performance in more than 50 years.

title: A MOTHER HOPES AND TRIES TO UNDERSTAND
description: In the long hallway outside Courtroom 928, Dolores Higgins finds solace in her cigarettes, the Blessed Virgin Mary and a manila envelope full of photographs. She smokes and prays, prays and smokes, and sometimes she takes the pictures out and looks them over, as though to convince herself that there was indeed a time when her son sat on Santa Claus's lap, attended first grade and smiled into the camera with his arm around her shoulder.

title: SCHMIDT RULES OUT ARMS SALE TO SAUDI ARABIA FOR NOW
description: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany told the Saudi leadership today that it was ''not feasible'' at this time for Bonn to end its policy of not selling arms to any Middle East nation.

description: B-Including $402.3 million gain on sale of the company's intere in Belridge Oil

title: MICKEY WALKER, WHO CAPTURED 2 WORLD BOXING TITLES, DIES AT 79
description: Mickey Walker, who won the world welterweight and middleweight boxing titles and also fought some of the sport's top heavyweights, died yesterday morning at Freehold Area Hospital in Freehold, N.J. He was 79 years old.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Brascan Ltd. has fully placed its $100 million offering of $25 par 10.75 percent cumulative redeemable 1981 series A preferred shares through an underwriting group lead by Dominion Securities Corporation group.

title: Wills Suspended 2 Games
description: The American League said yesterday that it had suspended Manager Maury Wills of the Mariners for two games for ''doctoring the batter's box'' before Saturday night's game against the Oakland A's in Seattle.

title: ISRAELI JETS DOWN TWO SYRIAN COPTERS IN CENTRAL LEBANON
description: Israeli jet fighters shot down two Syrian helicopters over east central Lebanon today in what was officially described as a warning that Israel would not allow the Syrians to defeat the Lebanese Christians in the fighting that has flared in recent weeks.

title: Economic Scene; Clash Over Gold Standard
description: IN seeking to reconcile the main ideas of his two principal groups of economic supporters, the supply-siders and the monetarists, President Reagan set aside one of his own economic beliefs: that the country should go back to the gold standard to end inflation.

title: ICE CREAM MAKER
description: AN acquaintance of mine once owned an ice-cream maker and then gave it away. Too much trouble, he said. I disagree. The ice-cream machine is one of those superb designs that was invented in the mid-19th century and really has not had to change much since then because it works so well. And, my friend's experience aside, once you use a good machine a few times, the trouble it requires is virtually invisible compared with the sensual delights that almost invariably issue from it.

title: POSTPUNK ART OF JOHN CALE
description: ON his excellent new album, ''Honi Soit,'' John Cale, one of the godfathers of new-wave music, has accomplished the seemingly impossible feat of reconciling the ferocity of postpunk rock with the stateliness of European classicism. Listening to the record, one wondered if Mr. Cale and his four-piece band could reproduce in person the album's resoundingly evocative music. Saturday's performance at the Ritz proved, beyond expectation, that they could.

title: Trade Gap Narrower For March
description: A sharp decline in imported oil, combined with a surge in American exports, shrank the nation's merchandise trade deficit to $451.4 million in March, the smallest in more than five years, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Note of Earthly Reality Deters a Science Fiction Writer
description: Rather than tangle with Darth Vader, Robert Moss said, he has changed the title of his next spy novel from ''Death Star'' to ''Death Beam.''

title: PHILLIPS OFF 4.8% AND SUN 52.2%
description: Texaco Inc., the nation's third-largest oil company, reported yesterday that its first-quarter operating profits increased 9.6 percent, while the Phillips Petroleum Company, the 10th largest, posted a 4.8 percent decline.

title: Luce to Quit as Chief Of Con Ed; President Will Take On Duties
description: Charles F. Luce, who has withstood rate wars, consumer protests over nuclear plants and a blackout in his 14 years with the Consolidated Edison Company, said yesterday that he would step down as chief executive of the utility on Aug. 1. Mr. Luce said he would also relinquish his position as chairman of one of the nation's largest private utilities when he reaches the company's mandatory retirement age of 65 in August 1982.

title: Ginnie Mae Appointment
description: President Reagan today named Robert W. Karpe, chairman of the board of Karpe Real Estate Center in Bakersfield, Calif., as president of the Government National Mortgage Association. Mr. Karpe, 50 years old, was commissioner of the California Department of Real Estate during Mr. Reagan's second term as governor.

title: 2 ARMY NURSES TO TESTIFY ABOUT KILLINGS IN BUFFALO
description: Two Army nurses left Fort Benning, Ga., for Buffalo today, reportedly to testify before a grand jury about comments that a white Army private allegedly made to nurses that he had killed blacks here and in New York City.

title: Voting for Women
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: I was delighted to see Enid Nemy's article on ''Women on Boards: A New Perspective''(April 22). Her optimism - or that of Mr. Eklund, chief executive officer of the Equitable Life Assurance Company, that there is no reluctance to women anymore, is belied by the fact, as she also notes, that only 1.8 percent of total board membership is female.

title: Q & A
description: Q. You recently wrote of the virtues of a Mexican vegetable called jicama. Can you tell me more precisely what this is?

title: Panel in House Rejects Reagan Dairy Proposal
description: A House Agriculture subcommittee rejected the Reagan Administration's four-year dairy proposal today, approving instead a bill that would cost $2 billion more than President Reagan's alternative.

title: THE U.S. AND ZAIRE
description: At the risk of distorting the complexity of international affairs, the Reagan Administration in shaping foreign policy has emphatically re-established the primacy of the Soviet threat. The limitations of this view are exemplified in Zaire, where American temptations to cry ''The Russians are coming!'' has long been strong.

title: Science Academy Sees No Way To Absolutely Define Life's Start
description: The National Academy of Sciences, addressing a key issue dividing antiabortion forces and those who favor permitting abortions, today passed a resolution asserting that it was not possible to answer the question of when human life begins in clear-cut scientific terms.

title: 1. Tucking Away Time
description: Whether you're off for a business trip, a vacation or just a weekend in the country, you'll probably need a travel clock. One of the easiest to pack is a new clock by Seiko that is built into a neat, leather-like case that looks like a folded wallet when closed and is small enough to tuck into a handbag. Open, the clock props up and is easy to read. There's an alarm, of course. The case comes in beige, black, brown or red. Saks Fifth Avenue has it in the main floor jewelry department for $59.50.

title: Rangers Offer Praise And Avoid Excuses

title: BOTHA VOWS REBELS WON'T GET NAMIBIA
description: Prime Minister P.W. Botha, in his final speech of the election campaign, promised last night that the disputed territory of South-West Africa would not be allowed to fall into the hands of the insurgent movement that is backed by South Africa's black neighbors and the Organization of African Unity.

title: BY MICHAEL STRAUSS
description: The Pirates made the opener of a 13-game Mets home stand an inglorious one last night with an 8-0 victory at Shea Stadium. A five-run burst in the third inning and some steady pitching by Rick Rhoden were the key ingredients for Pittsburgh. The defeat was the fourth in a row for the Mets, who made four errors.

title: Real Estate; Promoting Office Use In Jersey
description: SOUTH HACKENSACK, N.J. OTHER builders have taken the same turns that Alfred Sanzari has taken in northern New Jersey. He began as a home builder in the 1950's, shifted to garden apartments and then went into commercial construction. For the 1980's, a project getting into construction in Teaneck marks another phase.

title: Livestock Project to Resume In Navajo-Hopi Dispute
description: The Bureau of Indian Affairs will resume a program of removing Navajo livestock from land that has been assigned to the Hopi tribe, bureau officials said today.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Executive Changes column in Business Day on Monday incorrectly reported promotions at R.H. Macy & Company. Herbert Friedman was named chairman and chief executive officer for the Davison's division of Macy and Harold D. Kahn was named president of the division.

title: Tokyo Stocks Soar
description: The Tokyo Stock Exchange average climbed to another record today on active buying by foreign investors, who the Government said poured $6.15 billion into the market in the 1980 fiscal year. The average on the exchange, the world's biggest after the New York Stock Exchange, has been rising steadily this year on buying by Middle East countries mainly and by Western pension funds attracted by Japan's basic economic strength.

title: PHILLIPS PETROLEUM CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: SOME time ago a reader asked me why I never printed a recipe for frogs' legs. There are two reasons. The first is that frogs' legs, which are relatively scarce, are a premium and generally costly item in America; the second is because, for some reason, frogs' legs fall into the food prejudice category. It is hard for me to understand why the latter is true, for frogs' legs are as tasty and tender as chicken (and the diet of frogs is equally if not more clean than that of chickens).

title: PRODUCTION OPERATORS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
WINE TALK
description: THE affliction known among oenophiles as auction fever usually arrives in the spring and sets off frenzied bidding for table wines at astronomical prices. This year is proving to be no exception. A jeroboam, equal to six single bottles, of Chateau Petrus 1961 sold for $13,000 at an auction held by Christie's last Saturday in Chicago.

title: TECHNICOLOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 28
HARVEY BRIGHT
description: Harvey Bright, a former furniture manufacturer and professional boxer, died Sunday at the Sarah R. Neuman Nursing Home in Mamaroneck, N.Y. He was 82 years old and had resided for 50 years in New Rochelle, N.Y., where he was active in community affairs.

title: POUSSIN WORK BOUGHT BY GETTY AND SIMON MUSEUMS
description: A painting by the 17th-century French artist Nicholas Poussin, which brought a record price of $3.6 million at a Christie's auction in London on April 10, has been bought jointly by the J. Paul Getty Museum in Malibu, Calif., and a foundation established by Norton Simon, the West Coast industrialist. The painting, ''The Holy Family,'' done in 1651, will be shown alternately at the Getty Museum and at the Norton Simon Museum in Pasadena.

description: United States Tobacco Company

title: U.S. Reports an Apparent Decline In Toxic Shock Syndrome Cases
description: The Food and Drug Administration said today that there appeared to have been a marked decline in the incidence of toxic shock syndrome since its link to tampon use was reported.

title: JETS CHOOSE RUNNERS
description: The Jets, who for years have had one of the worst defenses in pro football, startled the draft yesterday by selecting a running back on not only their first pick but also their second, thus putting together what could become a new tandem in the backfield.

title: ACTIONS ON GRAIN AND AWACS SALES ASSAILED SHARPLY IN HOUSE HEARING
description: Members of a House subcommittee today sharply criticized the Reagan Administration's decisions to end the curbs on grain sales to the Soviet Union and to sell Awacs electronic surveillance planes to Saudi Arabia.

title: Tanzania Starts Withdrawal Of Its Troops from Uganda
description: Tanzania announced today that it had started withdrawing its force of 10,000 soldiers from Uganda despite appeals from the Ugandan Government.

title: Revenge of the No-Shows
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: Perhaps the increase in no-show reservations at restaurants (''No-Shows on Increase at Better Restaurants,'' April 22) is the revenge of the restaurant goer? Nowhere in the article is mention made of the person showing up for a reservation and being told that there is no record of his reservation, a sort of no-show on the part of the management.

title: 'AN ITALIAN WOMAN'
description: MARTA is bored. Oh, god, is she bored. Marta has a faithful but dull husband who attempts to anticipate her every wish. She has a daughter who is young and small. She has a passionate lover, a whiteon-white apartment and a wardrobe full of couture clothes. Marta is bored as only rich, beautiful, upper-class women can be bored in Italian films, especially in Italian films of the pre-Red Brigade 1960's. But Marta is not in a 1960's movie. She's in ''An Italian Woman,'' which was directed in 1980 by Giuseppe Bertolucci, the younger brother of Bernardo, and written by him and three other tireless scavengers of other people's movies and emotions.

title: DRIVE ON PARKING HELPING TO SPEED MIDTOWN TRAFFIC
description: A campaign against double parking that began five weeks ago in the mid-Manhattan business and theater districts has substantially eased traffic in the 100-block target area, according to the city's Department of Traffic.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: PHILOSOPHERS have sometimes suggested that pain is ennobling to the human spirit. However, it is safe to say that most of those who share this view in the abstract would seek relief in the face of actual pain.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: THE SKY IS FALLING

title: POP LIFE
description: POP music is generally considered a bastion of liberalism, but it has its own invisible racial barriers and they are barriers most artists will cross only at their own peril. Ask Garland Jeffreys, a 37-year-old black rock singer and songwriter from Brooklyn who has been making accessible, critically acclaimed albums since the early 70's, only to watch each record disappear into a kind of commercial limbo.

title: Margiotta Judge Bars Jury Dismissal
description: A Federal jury declared yesterday for the second time that it was deadlocked in the mail-fraud and extortion trial of Joseph M. Margiotta, the Nassau County Republican chairman, and that ''further deliberation is pointless.''

title: TV: ROONEY IN 'LEAVE ' EM LAUGHING'
description: ''LEAVE 'EM LAUGHING,'' on CBS-TV tonight at 8, is that oldfashioned theatrical commodity: a vehicle for a star. The chief product is a bravura performance surrounded by a good deal of capable but not distracting support. In this instance, the star is Mickey Rooney and, despite some uneven moments, he delivers the emotional goods.

description: A prosecutor charged yesterday that two arms merchants tried to sell machine guns and ammunition for $3.3 million ''to supply terrorists for profit.''

She answers the claim of widespread sexual harassment with a non sequitur and throws in a load of emotional eyewash about the male being the ideal breadwinner, with a dependent wife sitting at home.

title: CONCERT NEW ARTS TRIO PLAYS NEW MOEVS WORK
description: THE New Arts Trio is just four years old but it is a precocious toddler. The group, formed in 1977, won last year's Walter W. Naumburg Foundation's Chamber Music Award, and its concert last night at Alice Tully Hall abundantly showed why. This prize does not normally go to untried ensembles, however promising, but is a laurel wreath placed on the brow of a group that is fully fledged and already highly professional. The New Arts Trio, a piano trio, fulfilled those criteria nicely.

title: 3 APPOINTEES, OPPOSED BY HELMS, CONFIRMED BY SENATE COMMITTEE
description: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee confirmed today by a 16-0 vote the Administration's nominees for three State Department posts who were opposed by Senator Jesse Helms, a member of the panel.

title: BEST BUYS
description: THE average weekly cost of feeding a family of four in New York City fell 68 cents to $102.51 during the two-week period from April 13 through April 24, according to the city's Department of Consumer Affairs. The 41-item shopping basket cost $103.19 for the two-week period ending April 10.

title: Expos Snap Phils' Streak at 4
description: Chris Speier had a single, double and triple, and knocked in two runs, as the Montreal Expos snapped the Philadelphia Phillies' four-game winning streak with a 6-3 victory tonight.

title: Arizona to Hold a Hearing On Drugs Given to Shields
description: The Arizona Athletic Commission will hold a special hearing into reports that Randy Shields was injected with pain-killers last Saturday before he lost to Thomas Hearns here in his bid for the World Boxing Association welterweight title.

title: HAWAIIANS FIGHT TO SAVE PRISTINE AREA
description: The bulldozer's growl, the hammer's tap and the condominium salesman's suave pitch have reached this island of Kauai 15 years after those forces began to reshape Waikiki, Maui's western beaches and the Kona district of the island of Hawaii.

title: 76ers See Lesson in '68 Series
description: The 1967-68 Philadelphia 76ers were the first team in National Basketball Association history to lose a playoff series after taking a 3-1 advantage. Billy Cunningham was the sixth man on that team, which lost to the Boston Celtics.

title: Webb President Is Chief
description: Robert K. Swanson, the 48-year-old president of the Del E. Webb Corporation, has been appointed to the additional positions of chairman and chief executive officer, effective at the annual meeting in July. He will succeed Robert H. Johnson, 65, who will retire.

title: BOY MENTIONED IN TALK SLEEPS THROUGH IT ALL
description: Peter James Sweeney, the 8-year-old boy from Rockville Centre, L.I., who sent a get-well letter to President Reagan, was already asleep when Mr. Reagan read his message aloud in his speech last night.

description: Investor jitters over rising interest rates, along with some profit taking, sent the stock market into a broad decline yesterday in accelerated trading.

title: FAR RIGHTISTS FIGHT IT OUT IN SOUTH AFRICAN ELECTION
description: In a tale by a writer named Herman Charles Bosman, who was South Africa's most entertaining and endearing storyteller, a group of Afrikaner farmers in this sparsely settled area of the northern Transvaal gather for a meeting of their debating society. The schoolmaster announces that the subject of the debate will be ''That the Bantu should be allowed to develop along his own lines,'' whereupon a farmer protests that ''the subject was too hard to understand.''

title: TOO MANY SIDES AND SURROGATES IN CHAOTIC LEBANON
description: To the Editor: The April 9 editorial, ''To the Last Lebanese,'' is more illuminating in the omissions than in its now standard condemnation of violence by all parties in the Lebanese crisis.

title: Alabama Bill Will Allow Bryant to Coach Past 70
description: The Alabama Legisature passed a bill today allowing Paul (Bear) Bryant, the University of Alabama football coach, to coach beyond the state's mandatory retirement age of 70.

description: * American Public Energy Company, Dallas, has named Paul R. Jackson vice president and exploration manager.

title: Advertising; Foundation President Is Chosen
description: MICHAEL J. NAPLES, whose background includes experience with most major facets of marketing research, was named president yesterday of the Advertising Research Foundation by its board.

title: Go Quietly, Spiro Agnew
description: A civil court in Annapolis, Md., has found that Spiro Agnew took $147,500 in bribes as Governor of Maryland, collecting the last $17,500 of it even after becoming Vice President in 1969. That judgment, which comes to nearly $250,000 with interest, confirms the allegations of corruption that have remained in the air since his forced resignation in 1973. It should also put an end to Mr. Agnew's nattering negations of guilt.

title: MOYNIHAN LINKS BUDGET VOTES TO LIFTING OF GRAIN CURB
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan said today that the Administration's lifting of the curb on grain exports to the Soviet Union was ''clearly related'' to its efforts to win the votes of three Republicans on the Budget Committee who voted earlier this month to defeat President Reagan's budget in committee.

title: Two Killed in Rio Mishap
description: Two passengers were killed and at least 50 injured today when a Rio streetcar jumped the tracks, flipped over and slammed into a retaining wall, the police said. The open-air antiquated streetcar was shuttling through the hilly Santa Teresa neighborhood when the cable connecting it to the overhead electric line broke, throwing passengers into the street, the police said.

title: FOR BEENE, A TURNING POINT
description: THE Geoffrey Beene collection is like a complex but rewarding book: not simple to comprehend but worth the effort. The designer has reached another of his turning points. Having decided about five years ago that contemporary clothes must be primarily easy to move in and not constricting, he stuck by his guns while other designers were in hot pursuit of novelty with football shoulders, slinky skirts and other manifestations of tawdry sexiness.

title: POPE'S SECRETARY SEES ULSTER HUNGER STRIKER
description: Pope John Paul II intervened today in the hunger strike of a Roman Catholic militant in Northern Ireland, sending his private secretary to the province in the hope that he could ease the rapidly mounting tensions there.

title: News Analysis
description: The decision by the City Council this week to reduce some of the benefits available to real-estate developers in Manhattan marked the biggest step taken by New York City in its efforts to redesign an array of often-criticized tax incentive programs.

title: American League; White Sox 8, Orioles 6
description: BALTIMORE (AP) - Doubles by Bill Almon and Tony Bernazard of Chicago keyed a six-run, second-inning.

title: British Recession Report
description: Britain's recession is flattening out, according to a report published today of a survey of 1,893 companies by the Confederation of British Industry. The survey showed that output and demand continued to fall over the past four months, but slower than previously. The employers' organization said it had found a new optimism among exporters but that there might be a further small decline in the next four months.

title: TO THE LIVING SECTION: To the midtown maitre d'hotel of that 60-seat restaurant: Tell me, how do you arrive at your assumption that it is the bridge and tunnel crowd who are your Saturday night no-shows? Logic would indicate that people who have to drive an hour each way would be advance planners -subscriptions obtained, baby sitters booked, restaurant reservations secured and respected. For the bridge and tunnel folks, the Saturday night trek is not a casual drop-in occurrence. It is a solid commitment to be taken quite seriously.
description: For suburbanites to be referred to as the sort of people who don't know is condescending. As for those savvy weekday businesspeople and restaurant goers the maitre d'hotel admires, I would be willing to bet that a full 44 percent of them run to catch the 5:44 home. How does he know who's city and who's country anyway? This is one suburbanite who would love to tell him a thing or two - once she gets the hay out of her hair and the fertilizer off her shoes! JUDITH SLOAN Manhasset, L.I.

title: NORTH STARS TRIUMPH OVER FLAMES BY 4-1
description: Short-handed goals by Gordie Roberts and Al MacAdam broken open a tight game and carried the Minnesota North Stars to a 4-1 victory over the Calgary Flames tonight in the opener of their semifinal series.

title: The 'Kulchur Queen' and Her Literary Progeny
description: Kulchur was the avant-garde magazine Lita Rothbard Hornick, a Barnard graduate and wife of a manufacturer, founded in the 1960's soon after she received her Ph.D. from Columbia. But ''Kulchur Queen,'' the title of her 1977 biography by one of her poet proteges, John Giorno, ''shocked me at first, and then I got to like it,'' Mrs. Hornick recalled Monday night at the Gotham Book Mart.

title: Britain's Gift to Bobby Sands
description: On the question of principle, Britain's Prime Minister Thatcher is right in refusing to yield political status to Bobby Sands, the Irish Republican Army hunger striker. But this dying young man has made it appear that her stubbornness, rather than his own, is the source of a fearful conflict already ravaging Northern Ireland. For that, Mrs. Thatcher is partly to blame. By appearing unfeeling and unresponsive, she and her Government are providing Bobby Sands with a deathbed gift - the crown of martyrdom.

title: Mobil Canada Abandons Well
description: Mobil Oil Canada, Ltd., a unit of the Mobil Corporation, said it had abandoned its G-88 wildcat well on the South Tempest structure off the Grand Banks of Newfoundland after a series of tests in five zones.

title: SCHOOLS IN BOSTON TOLD TO STAY OPEN
description: A Superior Court judge today ordered Boston's insolvent school system to remain open for the rest of the academic year after last-minute attempts to reach a political solution to the city's school financial crisis failed.
