HOUSE PANEL URGES LEDERER'S EXPULSION
description: The House ethics committee today urged the House to expel Representative Raymond F. Lederer, Democrat of Pennsylvania, the only Congressman convicted in an Abscam case who was re-elected last fall.

title: Blue Jays 6, Brewers 2
description: Ken Macha, making his first start since being purchased from Montreal in January, drilled a two-run double in a four-run, sixth-inning rally that sparked the Blue Jays.

title: Chacon Gets Title Shot
description: Cornelius Boza-Edwards, a Ugandan based in Britain, will defend his World Boxing Council superfeatherweight title against Bobby Chacon of the United States here May 30, Don Chargin, matchmaker for Azteca Promotions, said today.

title: U.S.-Japanese Auto Talks Set
description: High Japanese and American officials are voicing optimism that a solution to the problem of Japanese auto imports will be reached this week, initiated by a trip to Tokyo by the United States special trade representative, Bill Brock.

description: Perhaps it is because he has had nothing but courtroom victories as chief Abscam prosecutor, or perhaps, as he himself indicates, time has eased the pressures of his role. Whatever it may be, Thomas P. Puccio is clearly a more relaxed man these days.

description: With only one month to go before baseball's May 29 strike deadline, negotiators continue to make no progress toward a settlement of the compensation dispute.

title: TURN HOMEMAKING INTO A SECURE OCCUPATION
description: Family. The word evokes memories of comforting hugs, and mom in the kitchen, and also of the White House Conference on Families last year, which had trouble even defining the term.

title: ADDISON BINGHAM
description: Addison Bingham, a former vice president of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, died Monday at his home in Manhattan.

title: 'OH, BROTHER!' MUSICAL SATIRIZING OIL, DUE IN FALL
description: ''OH, BROTHER!'' will open on Broadway on Sept. 23, and presumably become the first big musical of next season. It is based on ''The Comedy of Errors'' - the 1938 ''Boys From Syracuse'' was based on that, too - but it will be based on it only loosely. ''Oh, Brother!'' takes place in an unidentified country in the Middle East; one of its songs is ''OPEC Maiden,'' and the two sets of twins who want to be reunited (this seems to be where ''The Comedy of Errors'' comes in) were originally separated when a plane was hijacked to Cuba.

READING DATA INDICATE DECLINE IN REASONING ABILITY
description: New evidence of lower achievement in schools throughout the country was provided yesterday by the National Assessment of Educational Progress, which found that the inferential reasoning of 13-year-olds and 17-year-olds declined on reading tests in the 1970's.

title: INTERIOR SECRETARY DECLARES U.S. NEEDS AN INVENTORY OF RESOURCES
description: Interior Secretary James G. Watt, speaking in behalf of his own conduct in office as well as in support of easing policies on offshore oil exploration, told a House subcommittee today that the nation must undertake a full inventory of all its natural resources, including offshore oil and gas.

title: Ex-Lineman Charged
description: Billy Don Jackson, former U.C.L.A. defensive lineman, pleaded not guilty yesterday to a murder charge. The charge stemmed from the stabbing death of a man last year in what the police said was a violent argument over a small amount of marijuana. Jackson, 22 years old, was free on bail.

title: U.S., SUMMING UP, SAYS WILLIAMS PEDDLED INFLUENCE
description: Denouncing Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. as someone who had engaged in the ''use of his influence to fill his pockets,'' a Federal prosecutor yesterday called for his conviction on bribery and conspiracy charges stemming from the Abscam investigation of political corruption.

title: CONTRACTORS EXEMPTED FROM RECORDS-ACCESS RULE
description: The Reagan Administration announced today that it was exempting construction contractors from a job safety standard that required employers to give workers access to records detailing their exposure to hazardous substances.

title: MASSEY-FERGUSON TO SHUT IOWA PLANT
description: Massey-Ferguson Ltd. of Toronto has announced the closing of its four-wheel-drive tractor plant at Des Moines as the company seeks greater efficiency to reduce costs.

title: Service for John A. Roosevelt
description: A funeral service will be held tomorrow at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue and 90th Street, for John A. Roosevelt, a retired New York investment banker and the youngest son of President Franklin D. Roosevelt. Mr. Roosevelt died Monday at the age of 65. The service will be at 1 P.M. Interment, at the family burial site in Hyde Park, N.Y., will be private.

title: 2 QUIT LEBANON'S CABINET TO PROTEST SYRIAN SHELLING
description: Syrian forces tonight heavily shelled the Lebanese Christian town of Zahle 30 miles east of here, and Lebanese officials reported that at least 12 people were killed and more than 45 wounded.

description: MUSTARD used to be thought of as something to be smeared on hot dogs. Not any more. Now there is a vast choice of French, German, English and American mustards on the market, in every category and price, and suitable for a multitude of uses, from sauces to coating roasts, from marinades to salad dressings. For those who want to travel further afield, there are now anchovy mustards, peanut mustards, sherry mustards, lime mustards, pink and green peppercorn mustards.

title: Earnings Up 3.8% At BBDO International
description: Yesterday, BBDO International released its first-quarter earnings and they were up - a little. Net income rose 3.8 percent, from $2.6 million, to $2.7 million, or $1.02 a share, compared with 99 cents a share last year. revenues increased 7.1 percent, to $42.2 million, from the $39.4 million in the same period last year.

title: Amnesia Victim Returns Home With Her Parents

title: WHERE TO GO FOR RELIEF OF PAIN

An internist or family practitioner is generally the best person to consult initially. The doctor will determine the likely cause and, if possible, treat that directly or refer you to a specialist.

title: Witness Says She Saw Fatal Blow in Miami Riot
description: The prosecution and defense rested after a black woman testified today that she saw Nathaniel Lane raise ''a big rock'' and smash it down on the head of one of three young whites beaten to death during the first night of racial violence here last May.

description: Cliff Battles, a halfbackquarterback in the National Football League Hall of Fame, died today in a hospital where he had been treated for a heart condition. He was 70 years old.

description: Navy Secretary John F. Lehman Jr. said today he had concluded that the General Dynamics Corporation shipyard in Groton, Conn., had the necessary work force and plant to meet the Navy's schedules for deliveries of submarines.

Reneker, former chairman and chief executive officer of Esmark Inc. of Chicago, a holding company for diversified concerns that include the meat producers Swift & Co., died of a heart attack Monday at Presbyterian St. Luke's Hospital in Chicago. He was 68 years old and lived in Chicago.

title: Careers
description: IN John P. Marquand's 1949 novel, ''Point of No Return,'' the hero and another assistant vice president stage a quietly desperate battle for a vice presidency of an important New York bank. One loses (not the hero) and apparently must resign. The president, expressing wonderment, says there was never a doubt in his mind that the hero would be chosen.

Calhoun, and other directors, seeking to halt an allegedly unlawful plan to prevent Hecla's acquisition of Day Mines at a substantial premium.

title: FEDERAL AGENTS HUNT FOR SUSPECT IN GEORGIA O'KEEFFE FRAUD CASE
description: Federal agents were searching yesterday for a 34-year-old man accused of illegally arranging for thousands of lithographs to be made of paintings by Georgia O'Keeffe.

title: The Willowbrook Watchers
description: Several years ago the Willowbrook Development Center, a New York State institution for the retarded on Staten Island, became a national symbol of social neglect. A Federal judge found conditions so inhumane as to violate the constitutional rights of patients and ordered the state to clean up.

title: STEEL AND AUTO AT THE BACK DOOR
description: When I.B.M. builds a new factory, the Federal Government picks up part of the tab by crediting up to 10 percent of the cost against the corporation's tax bill. But when Bethlehem Steel makes a similar investment, Uncle Sam turns tightwad. The tax credit is virtually valueless to Bethlehem because it doesn't have enough taxable profits to offset.

title: '21' NOW SERVING ELITE IN TEXAS
description: Two captains of industry, seated on a banquette, are pressed up against the restaurant's walls like a pair of pinstripe-suited icons. The powers that be in communications are seated at a table nearby. Downstairs, Random House huddles with CBS; ABC dines alone.

description: Negotiations between the Newspaper Guild and The New York Times and The Daily News continued past midnight in an effort to avert a strike against The Times that had been scheduled for 12:01 A.M. today.

title: Ship's Crew Saved in Java Sea
description: Fire engulfed an oil supply ship in the Java Sea yesterday, and another vessel rescued its six crewmen, who had abandoned ship, officials said today. The cause of the fire aboard the Panamanian-registered Catherine Tide was not known.

title: NORTHEAST UTILITIES reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31

description: When a group of Manhattan women started Consumer Action Now 11 years ago, they had little more than a catchy acronym and a lot of nerve.

description: ''Instant Oral Biographies,'' a 96-page book that looks like a reporter's notepad, describes how to record on tape the life stories of relatives and friends by using basic interviewing techniques.

title: Libya and Soviet Differ On What Qaddafi Said
description: A Libyan spokesman said today that the Soviet Communist Party newspaper, Pravda, changed the wording of a speech given by the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, at a Kremlin banquet last night.

title: HOCKEY RIVALRY SPLITS LONG BEACH
description: As the New York Rangers and the New York Islanders prepared for the opening game of their ''Parkway Series'' tomorrow night, fans in this Long Island suburb had already joined the battle. They donned their team's colors, engaged in spirited arguments and occasionally resorted to fist fights, a popular tool of debate among many hockey fans and players.

title: A ROOKIE COOKIE IN THE BIG CUSINE LEAGUE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Clark Whelton, who is out of his league in the kitchen, is Mayor Koch's speechwriter. By CLARK WHELTON

title: STAGE: 'TASTE OF HONEY' REVIVED AT ROUNDABOUT
description: ''WE don't ask for life - we have it thrust upon us,'' says Jo, the impoverished, abandoned 18-year-old heroine of Shelagh Delaney's ''A Taste of Honey.'' True enough, but then what does one do? According to Miss Delaney, you don't feel sorry for yourself, you don't cry, you don't even rage at the heavens. You just keep going on, from dark night to dark night, trying to preserve your sense of humor and dignity as best you can.

description: The Commodity Exchange in New York yesterday announced reductions in margin requirements for trading futures contracts in gold, silver, copper, two-year Treasury notes and Government National Mortgage Association certificates.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: THIS week the Empire State Building will officially mark its 50th anniversary, and Metropolitan Diary is concerned that - amid all the parties, the speechmaking and the nostalgic hoopla - someone may be overlooked.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, APRIL 29, 1981
description: International Israeli jets moved against Syrians in central Lebanon for the first time in the recent heavy fighting. The jet fighters shot down two Syrian helicopters in what was described as an official warning that Israel would not allow the Syrians to defeat the Lebanese Christians. (Page A1, Column 3.) No sale of Bonn arms to Saudi Arabia is possible now, according to Chancellor Helmut Schmidt. He told Saudi leaders in Riyadh that differences among West Germans over the issue of exporting weapons to the Middle East were intense. (A13:1-3.)

title: Foster Wheeler Fills Two Top Positions
description: Louis E. Azzato, 50 years old, has been elected president and chief executive officer of the Foster Wheeler Corporation, an engineering, manufacturing and construction company.

title: Coal Tax Loss Called Peril To West Virginia Schools
description: By The Associated Press Gov. John D. Rockefeller 4th said yesterday that the nationwide strike by 160,000 United Mine Workers members was beginning to have ''devastating'' effects in West Virginia, with the state losing $500,000 a day in tax revenue.

title: Some Nuclear Waste Leaked Into Sewer of Town in Japan
description: Officials of the Japan Nuclear Power Company said today that the atomic plant here leaked radioactive waste into the town sewer for four years.

title: CHRYSLER CHANGES
description: The Chrysler Corporation plans to close its Detroit Universal division plant by the end of the year and transfer operations to an engine plant and a stamping plant, both in the Detroit area, and a machining plant in Toledo, Ohio. It said that most of the unit's 300 workers would be offered jobs at the other plants. The move reflects a rapid change-over to the output of front-wheel-drive cars from the rear-wheel-drive units, in which the Universal division plant specialized.

title: CANADIAN HEARING ON CONSTITUTION OPENS IN SUPREME COURT IN OTTAWA
description: Before nine scarlet-robed justices of Canada's Supreme Court, the federal Government and six provincial governments began their arguments today on whether Ottawa could act without general provincial consent to establish a new constitution.

title: The Economy
description: President Reagan urged Congress to approve his economic plan, saying his package of spending curbs and tax cuts were ''the only answer we have left'' to inflation and unemployment. Addressing a joint session of the House and Senate in his first major public appearance since the attempt on his life a month ago, Mr. Reagan asked Democrats to reject proposals by their leaders. (Page A1.)

title: WESTERN FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31

Lee B. Macht, Harvard Professor And Leader in Mental Health Field
description: Lee B. Macht, a nationally known mental health leader and professor of psychiatry at Harvard Medical School, died at his home Sunday after a short illness.

title: SAINTS SELECT ROGERS AS NO. 1
description: It took the New Orleans Saints only 32 seconds yesterday to make good their predictable selection of George Rogers, the South Carolina running back, as the No. 1 choice in the National Football League's annual draft of the top college players.

title: MOVE TO REJOIN LABOR ALLIANCE GAINS IN U.A.W.
description: The United Automobile Workers, in a significant step toward rebuilding unity within the house of labor, announced today that its rank-and-file convention delegates had voted overwhelmingly to authorize the union's reaffiliation with the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations.

title: Klan Leader Released From Jail
description: Bill Wilkinson, Imperial Wizard of the Ku Klux Klan, who had been jailed here since Sunday for parading and soliciting funds without a permit, paid $100 in fines today and was released. Mr. Wilkinson, head of the Invisible Knights of the Klan, was one of 22 Klansmen taken to jail in a school bus after staging several rallies and marches last weekend.

title: By Sports of The Times; N.F.L.'s Dangerous Trend
description: PERHAPS the most opinionated species in sports is the football draftnik, that seer who specializes in gristle, bone and brain. Especially opinionated is the New York subspecies, which has suffered through more than a decade of disappointment.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Anatole Broyard LIVING ALONE. By John Givens. 178 pages. Atheneum. $11.95.

title: Sony Introduces New Video System
description: The Sony Corporation introduced in Tokyo a prototype of a highdefinition video recording and playback system that it believes will take over major new markets from 35-millimeter film in both the movie and television industries.

title: G.E. Is Shifting Some TV Output
description: The General Electric Company, citing stiff competition from imports of Taiwanese and South Korean television sets, announced that it will stop production of black and white sets by 1983 and shift production overseas.

title: MEDICAL EXAMINERS SAY LATEST BLACK VICTIM IN ATLANTA DIED OF ASPHYXIA
description: Jimmy Ray Payne, the 26th young black to be killed in a baffling series of slayings here over the last 21 months, died of asphyxiation like 14 others before him, medical examiners said today.

description: Citing a military threat from Libya and Soviet penetration of Africa, Lieut. Gen. Mohammed Abdel Halim Abu Ghazala, Defense Minister of Egypt, has asked the Reagan Administration for a substantial expansion of arms sales to Cairo over the next few years.

description: After what it called a ''long and tortuous'' proceeding, the Federal Trade Commission today dismissed its 10-year-old antitrust case against the American General Insurance Company.

description: African nations unsuccessfully pressed Western powers today to spell out how they now expect South-West Africa to achieve its independence, African diplomats disclosed.

description: A ''significant profit decline'' for the ABC television network eroded the first-quarter earnings of American Broadcasting Companies Inc. to 45 cents a share from 86 cents a share in the same period of 1980.

title: Court Rules Schoolgirls Can Play on Boys' Team
description: A Federal appeals court ruled today that an Ohio High School Athletic Association rule barring girls from competing on boys' teams in contact sports should be eliminated.

description: ATLANTA (UPI) - Don Sutton and Dave Smith combined on a threehitter, and Jose Cruz hit a double and a homer for Houston.

description: The discovery of television has certainly made big advertising spenders out of those brokerage people. The Merrill Lynch total budget will be up this year by 10 percent, to $20 million, with 40 percent going to the tube.

title: ACCORD ON BUDGET REACHED IN ALBANY TO END STALEMATE majority leader Warren Anderson
description: The monthlong impasse on the state budget was broken today as Governor Carey and the State Senate Republican majority leader, Warren M. Anderson, reached agreement on a $16.6 billion budget for New York State. It does not include a state takeover of the local costs of Medicaid that had been sought by Mr. Carey.

title: FRENCH COMMUNISTS TURN TO MITTERRAND
description: Francois Mitterrand, the Socialist candidate, received important support in the presidential race today when the Communist Party instructed its members to vote for him against President Valery Giscard d'Estaing in the runoff election May 10.

description: A New York City businessman was sentenced to 30 days in jail for assaulting the actress-model Melonie Haller, a former star of the ''Welcome Back Kotter'' TV series.

title: DEMOCRATS IN CONGRESS WEIGHING A PROPOSAL TO BALANCE THE BUDGET
description: House Democratic leaders, eager to capture momentum on the budget issue, today considered supporting a balanced budget for the fiscal year 1982 as a means of outflanking President Reagan and House Republican leaders.

description: Frank J. Ritger, vice chairman of the Trust Company of the West, a Los Angeles-based concern with offices in Manhattan, died Monday at his home in Short Hills, N.J. He was 66 years old.

description: Eastern Airlines reported yesterday that its first-quarter net income rose 17.1 percent, to $4.1 million, from $3.5 million a year earlier. But the earnings were not enough to cover full payment of dividends on its preferred stock, the Miami-based carrier said. Making this payment left the equivalent of a loss of 4 cents a common share. This was in contrast to a profit of 8 cents a share in the 1980 quarter.

description: Federal agents arrested 10 reputed mercenaries preparing an an armed invasion of the Caribbean island of Dominica, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today.

title: REGAN BARS MONEY FUND CURBS NOW
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan said today that the Administration opposed adopting any specific measures at this time to help ailing savings banks and savings and loan associations, including curbs on high-yielding money market mutual funds.

description: The deal is off. Charles D. Peebler Jr., president of Bozell & Jacobs, said yesterday that, although he had been having conversations with Louis Van Leeuwen about taking him in with some of his accounts from the troubled Van Leeuwen & Partners, conversations with those clients indicated that most had other plans.

title: U.N. COUNCIL GIVEN PLAN TO AVERT CLASH ON SOUTH AFRICA SANCTIONS
description: An 11th-hour effort was made here today to avert a threatened confrontation between the Reagan Administration and African nations over sanctions against South Africa.

title: SAFES AS COMBINATIONS OF ART AND SECURITY
description: and early 20th-century ones, even when they were kept out of sight in the back rooms of homes or offices, would often be covered with elaborate scrollwork and detailed metal work. They were a far cry from the solid gray cubes that are common today.

title: BOSTON'S RUSH-HOUR TRAFFIC BLOCKED IN PROTEST OF POLICE AND FIRE L AYOFFS
description: Hundreds of demonstrators protesting the layoff of police officers and firefighters formed a human blockade against rush-hour traffic today as Boston's penniless public schools stayed open under a court order and the city reeled one day closer to insolvency.

title: C.B.O.E. Plan Contested
description: The Chicago Board of Trade asked a Federal appeals court in Chicago to invalidate the Security and Exchange Commission's approval of a new proposal by the Chicago Board Options Exchange to trade nonstock options.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Natural Resources Company, Detroit, has elected to its board Robert W. Stewart, president of the Michigan Consolidated Gas Company.

title: No Headline
description: The Israeli air attacks in Lebanon were described here today as potentially useful diplomatically. The raids that downed two Syrian helicopters were said to have been tailored to be a precise and limited slap, vivid but on a small enough scale to avoid provoking full-scale battle.

title: Mortimer B. Smith, Writer, Dies; Stressed Basic Education Skills
description: Mortimer Brewster Smith, a writer and association executive who devoted much of his life to urging that the public schools place more stress on the mastery of basic skills, died Sunday in Scottsdale, Ariz. He was 75 years old.

title: SCREEN: 'ROSIE,' WORLD WAS II AND WOMEN
description: ''Rosie the Riveter'' was shown as part of last year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from a review by Vincent Canby in The New York Times on Sept. 27, 1980. The film opened yesterday at the Art Theater, Eighth Street, east of Fifth Avenue.

title: New Delhi Aide Doubts Survival Of Nuclear Agreement With U.S.
description: Foreign Minister P.V. Narasimha Rao cast doubts today about the survival of the 18-year-old agreement between India and the United States on the American-built nuclear power station at Tarapur, near Bombay.

title: Piano Recital: Marya Marlowe
description: MARYA MARLOWE plays the piano with a coloristic touch and lovely musical instincts, but she does not use these talents wisely. Her recital at Alice Tully Hall Saturday evening frequently crossed the line between freedom of expression and rhythmic misrepresentation - the note values in Chopin's B-flat minor Scherzo and Debussy's great ''Hommage a Rameau'' too often treated as toys.

title: Foreign Reporting Cited By Overseas Press Club
description: The Overseas Press Club honored the foreign reporting of 17 broadcast and print journalists last night at the club's 42d annual awards dinner. Six of the awards, presented in ceremonies at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, were given for coverage of events in Iran and Afghanistan.

title: NEW METHOD TO DETECT A DEADLY SKIN CANCER REPORTED BY SCIENTISTS
description: Researchers said today that they had used the techniques of genetic engineering to develop a possible method for early detection of an often fatal skin cancer that strikes about 7,000 Americans a year.

title: COMMITTEE ROLL-CALL VOTE ON SALVADOR ISSUE
description: Following is the roll-call vote by which the House Foreign Affairs Committee today approved an amendment to the foreign aid bill establishing conditions for military assistance to El Salvador for the fiscal year 1982: FOR THE AMENDMENT - 26 Democrats - 18 Zablocki, Wis.

title: OIL BOOM AROUSES HOPE IN RURAL LOUISIANA
description: James Silverstein, a 30-year-old black construction worker, was sitting on the front steps of a tin-roofed shack watching his two young children play with a rusty bicycle.

title: Around the World; Iran Wins Paris Suit On Uncompleted Arms Deal
description: Iran won a lawsuit today to freeze a company's bank account in connection with a $56 million arms deal that was never completed.

title: Addenda
description: * Vision Publicidad, a Peruvian agency, has formed an affiliation with Ted Bates & Company and will be called Vision/Ted Bates Publicidad.

description: ON the face of it, the major event of the New York City Ballet spring season, which opened Tuesday night at the State Theater, should be its June Tchaikovsky Festival.

description: To the Editor:

title: LED EPISCOPAL DIOCESE
description: Bishop Austin Pardue, who retired in 1968 after serving as Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Pittsburgh for 28 years, died yesterday at his home. He was 81 years old.

title: Islanders Show Balance and Versatility
description: In winning the first game of their semifinal playoff series, the Islanders proved again how versatile they have become since their elimination two years ago by the Rangers.

title: Around the Nation; Witness Tells of Paying A Blanton Campaign Debt
description: The Government's chief witness in the trial of former Gov. Ray Blanton testified today that he used $23,000, or 20 percent of a year's profits from his liquor store, to help pay a debt incurred by Mr. Blanton.

title: Hers; THE BLURRED PROFILE OF THAT CERTAIN WOMAN; by Mary Kay Blakely
description: WHETHER anybody else believes her or not, conservative politicians do, and in Indiana she's quoted constantly. She's the remarkable woman who's ''never been discriminated against.'' Who is this amazing woman?

title: RULING SOUTH AFRICA PARTY HOLDS DOMINANCE IN SPITE OF DEFECTIONS
description: Prime Minister P.W. Botha's National Party was maintaining its overwhelming dominance in Parliament early today in the all-white general election despite significant defections by Afrikaner voters to extremist parties that accuse the National Party of endangering white rule.
