title: BILLIE JEAN KING IS SUED FOR ASSETS OVER ALLEGED LESBIAN RELATIONSHIP
description: A woman who alleged that she had had a lesbian relationship for seven years with Billie Jean King, the professional tennis player, filed a lawsuit here yesterday contending that she was entitled to share in Mrs. King's assets because of the relationship.

title: Doctor, Once a Murder Suspect, Gets Probation on Drug Charge
description: Dr. Raymond La Scola, a prominent Los Angeles physician who was once a suspect in a heavily publicized murder case, has been sentenced to three years' probation for issuing a fictitious prescription.

title: SCHMIDT SEES P.L.O. ROLE IN EUROPE TALKS
description: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt said today that the Palestine Liberation Organization would participate in a meeting this fall between foreign ministers of the Arab world and the Common Market countries.

title: HOUSE STUDY SAYS PUBLIC IS MISLED ON PRIME RATE
description: A study by the staff of the House Banking, Finance and Urban Affairs Committee on bank lending concludes that major banks and news organizations have misled the public in the information they provide on the prime lending rate. Often, the study says, announcements of changes in the rate do not reflect actual rates that banks offer their commercial customers.

title: Notes On People; Ladies' Home Journal Getting New Editor in Chief
description: The new editor in chief and vice president of The Ladies' Home Journal, come May 18, will be Myrna Blyth. She is now executive editor and vice president at Family Circle, which she joined in 1973. Mrs. Blyth succeeds Lenore Hershey, recently named president and editorial director of a new multimedia subsidiary of the Journal's parent company, Charter Publishing Company.

title: TRUCK DRIVER IN BRITAIN CONFESSES AT HIS TRIAL TO KILLING 13 WOMEN
description: Peter Sutcliffe, a 34-year-old truck driver from Bradford in northern England, confessed today to killing 13 women and admitted that he had attempted to murder 7 others.

title: Spot Oil Prices Drop
description: The glut in world oil supplies and reduced consumption have reduced the spot market price for Arab light high-sulfur crude oil by about $1 in the last two weeks, to below $35 a barrel, traders said today. Arab light is now quoted at around $34.80. North African low-sulfur crudes are also weaker, at $37 a barrel or lower, they said.

title: CAMPO ADDS NEW YORK FLAVOR TO SCENE IN QUEST OF FIRST DERBY
description: Johnny Campo is New York. He's subway graffiti, he's Coney Island, he's a Nathan's red hot. The actor Jack Klugman, in trying to describe Campo at a horsemen's dinner here last night, said, ''He's by Damon Runyon, out of a Don Rickles mare.''

title: Around the Nation; Atlanta Curfew for Children Linked to 4 Adults' Slayings
description: Fear and a strict curfew affecting children may be the reasons adults have been the victims in the four most recent slayings of 26 young blacks here, Public Safety Commissioner Lee Patrick Brown said today.

title: DOW SLIDES BY 12.61 ON RATES RISE
description: Rising interest rates, pushed up even further by the announcement of higher prime rates at severl major banks, sent stock prices tumbling yesterday. The setback included recently popular blue chips and technology high-fliers, along with most other stock groups.

title: CONTINENTAL AIR: FIGHT INTENSIFIES
description: THE fight for Continental Air Lines grows more intense. At the moment, Texas International Airlines is stymied. It cannot vote its Continental shares under Civil Aeronautics Board rules. Yet it is faced with a reduction in its ownership interest to 26 percent from the current 49 percent as a result of Continental's plan to issue 15.4 million new shares to its employees.

title: N.F.L. Draft; ATLANTA FALCONS
description: Bobby Butler, db, Florida State; Lyman White, l b, L ouisiana State; Scott Woerner, db, Georgia; J ohn S cully, c, Notre Dame; Eric Sanders, ot, N evada- R eno; Harry Stanback, dt, North Carolina; M atthew T eague, dl, Prairie View; Clifford Toney, db, A uburn; C alvin Fance, rb, Rice; Bob Murphy, db, Ohio S tate; K eith Chappelle, wr, Iowa; Mark McCants, db, T em- p le. BALTIMORE COLTS Randy McMillan, rb, Pittsburgh; Donnell T hompson, dt, North Carolina; Randy Van Divier, ot, W ash- i ngton; Tim Sherwin, te, Boston College; Bubba G reen, dt, North Carolina State; Obed Ariri, k , Clem- s on; Ken Sitton, db, Oklahoma; Hosea Taylor, d t, H ouston; Tim Gooch, dt, Kentucky; Greg Gerken, l b, N orthern Arizona; Trent Bryant, db, Arkansas; H olden Smith, wr, California; Eric Scoggins, l b, South- e rn California. BUFFALO BILLS Booker Moore, rb, Penn State; Chris Williams, d b, L ouisiana State; Byron Franklin, wr, Auburn; M ike M osley, wr, Texas A&M; Robert Geathers, dt, S outh C arolina State; Calvin Clark, de, Purdue; R obert Holt, w r, Baylor; Steve Doolittle, lb, Colorado; Rob R iddick, r b, Millersville State; Justin Cross, ot, W estern Colora- d o; Buster Barnett, te, Jackson State; Keith C lark, lb, M emphis State.

title: HIROHITO AT 80: FOCUS OF EFFORT TO BRIDGE A GAP
description: A forest of tiny Rising Sun flags fluttered in the hands of well-wishers who gathered before the Imperial Palace today to greet Emperor Hirohito on his 80th birthday.

title: Mr. Reagan's Form, and Faith
description: It was formidable politics and an impressive show. Ronald Reagan, still wan and hoarse from his gunshot wound, stirred a rare joint session of Congress and a large television audience as no recent President has or could. The man, the politician and the actor were one. But his message, almost lost in the thunderous applause, was still facile. The President wants Congress to pass his economic program as is, at once. Why? Because ''there are no more alternatives left.'' But there are alternatives, or at least significant modifications, and good reasons to consider them.

title: TURKEY ASKS DEATH AT RIGHTISTS' TRIAL
description: The death penalty was asked today for 220 members of the right-wing Nationalist Action Party, including its leader, Alpaslan Turkes.

title: AN INDUSTRY POLL FINDS LANDLORDS EXPECT 'WAVE' OF ABANDONMENTS
description: More than a third of the landlords in New York City said in a recent survey that, barring changes in the city's rent stabilization laws, they each would be forced to abandon at least one apartment building within the next five years.

title: Prince Abdel-Aziz, 26, at Oxford; Heart Attack Is Given as Cause
description: Prince Abdel-Aziz al-Faisal, a 26-year-old nephew of King Khalid, has died at his home near Oxford University, where he was a graduate student, the police said today.

title: GENERAL MOTORS DROPS EFFORT TO IMPROVE AIR BAGS
description: The General Motors Corporation has abandoned its effort to improve the air-bag passenger protection system, saying that it makes more sense to encourage people to use their manual safety belts.

title: RANGERS BEWAIL LACK OF AGGRESSIVENESS
description: Last night, after they had given up an early 2-1 lead and lost, 5-2, to the Islanders in their Stanley Cup semifinal series opener, the Rangers were mostly morose and introspective.

title: THEATER: 'DISROBING THE BRIDE,' THREE WOMEN ON WEDDING DAY
description: ''DISROBING THE BRIDE'' is described as ''a work in progress'' that can be taken literally or any way you want. So far as the work at the Cubiculo is concerned, it is a voyage into a series of monologues that have pretensions of saying something but that go nowhere at all.

title: Way Promoted To American Express Post
description: Alva O. Way, 52, who joined the American Express Company in 1979 as vice chairman, has been elected president. Louis V. Gerstner Jr., 39, will succeed him as vice chairman.

title: Net Income Falls 39% At Interpublic Group
description: The Interpublic Group of Companies reported that its first-quarter net income was down 39 percent, to $865,000, or 19 cents a share, from $1.4 million, or 32 cents a share, in the comparable period last year.

title: Construction Contracts Rise
description: Paced by strong commercial building, new contracts for construction in March were 27 percent above a year ago when credit controls had a severe impact, the F.W. Dodge division of McGraw-Hill reports, but a strong recovery is not likely this year.

title: SAVINGS BOND YIELDS INCREASED BY 1 POINT
description: The Treasury Department announced today that it was raising by one percentage point the interest rates it pays on $70 billion of United States Savings Bonds held by 23 million households.

title: Security Increased After 3 Rapes; At Schools in; Jacksonville, Fla.
description: Security was increased today at schools throughout the city after the rape of a third girl at knifepoint in a school lavatory.

title: WORKERS' RALLY DISRUPTS SERVICE FOR 25,000 CONRAIL RIDERS
description: Thousands of New York commuters were inconvenienced by canceled trains, crowding and delays yesterday when employees on Conrail's Hudson and Harlem lines took the day off to join a protest in Washington against the Reagan Administration's proposed budget cuts and plans to split up the government-run railroad and sell it to private bidders.

title: NEXT IN OFFICE AUTOMATION
description: THE office has been gradually filling up with sophisticated electronic machinery - word processors, intelligent copiers, printers and computers. The next step is to connect the machines to each other, using a local network. Most of the major office equipment vendors have developed or are believed to be developing their own local networks or are lining up behind the standard bearers in what is shaping up as the next big battle in the office automation industry.

title: Notes On People; 2 Astronauts Plan Terrestrial Wedding, in Hawaii
description: Although they could very well be the first husband and wife in outer space, Dr. Margaret Rhea Seddon and Lieut. Cmdr. Robert Lee Gibson, both astronauts, will settle for a trip to Hawaii by conventional jet following their marriage May 30 in her home town of Murfreesboro, Tenn.

title: CALENDAR OF EVENTS: BROOKLYN HOUSE TOUR
description: Prospect Lefferts Gardens 12th Annual House Tour, Church of the Evangel, Bedford Avenue and Hawthorne Street, Brooklyn.

title: TWO WORKERS ADDED TO POLISH POLITBURO
description: At a meeting that lasted almost 22 hours, the Central Committee ousted two longtime politicians from the ruling Politburo today and replaced them with two rank-and-file workers. The move was intended to make Polish workers feel they have a voice in the higher echelons of the party.

title: Around the World; Rudolf Hess Back in Prison After Hospital Stay
description: Rudolf Hess, Hitler's former deputy, was moved back to Spandau Prison today after three weeks' hospital treatment for pneumonia, British military authorities announced.

title: WEINBERGER AIDE ORDERS MILITARY TO CUT COSTS BY REVISING BUYING POLICY
description: The Reagan Administration today began its first extensive effort to cut military costs as Deputy Secretary of Defense Frank C. Carlucci ordered the Pentagon ''to make major changes both in acquisition philosophy and the acquisition process itself.''

title: Steelworkers Keep Leadership
description: Lloyd McBride, president of the United Steelworkers of America, and the union's four other international officers will stay in office for a second four-year term, the union announced today. The union, which has 1.4 million members, said that all five were unopposed for a May 28 election of officers and directors.

title: Senator Helms Pledges Not to Block Nominees
description: Senator Jesse Helms said today that he would not obstruct confirmation by the Senate of key State Department nominees after receiving a personal assurance from President Reagan that they would carry out White House policies.

title: Around the Nation; 39 Cubans Are Ordered Sent From Miami to Spain
description: A Federal judge yesterday ordered 39 Cubans deported from Miami to Spain, where lawyers for the Cubans say they will face persecution.

title: G.&W. Buys 5% Of National Steel
description: Gulf and Western Industries has notified the Securities and Exchange Commission that it has purchased 980,200 shares of the National Steel Corporation, or 5.17 percent of the common stock, for $25.7 million.

title: Danny Kaye to Lead Concert
description: The comedian Danny Kaye will conduct a special Pension Fund Benefit concert of the New York Philharmonic at Avery Fisher Hall on Sept. 23. The event will be telecast as part of the ''Live from Lincoln Center'' series.

title: U.S. RULES ON COAL PLANTS UPHELD
description: A Federal appeals court today upheld the Government's air pollution standards for new coal-fired power plants in a case that could affect national environmental policy into the mid-1990's.

title: PITNEY BOWES TO BUILD MAIN OFFICE IN DEPRESSED SECTION OF STAMFORD
description: Pitney Bowes, the world's largest manufacturer of postal equipment, announced today that it would build a $100 million corporate headquarters on 10 acres in the heart of this city's most depressed area.

title: KODAK GAINS 29.1%; SPERRY CLIMBS 6.2%
description: The Eastman Kodak Company, the world's largest producer of photographic products, reported yesterday that earnings in the first quarter climbed 29.1 percent on a sales increase of 7.9 percent.

title: No Headline
description: To the Eidtor:

title: WINFIELD CLOUT TOPS TIGERS, 3-2
description: Dave Winfield paused between first and second base to watch the ball sail over the to watch the ball sail over the field watch the ball sail over the field fence at Tiger Stadium today. He Yankee. a two-run shot in the third inning that sparked New York to a 3-2 victory over Detroit, the 10th loss in a row Tigers.

title: Kansas Auto Plant Delayed by G.M.
description: The General Motors Corporation, the only American auto maker to show a profit in the first quarter this year, said yesterday that slumping sales have forced at least a one-year delay in planned construction of a $500 million auto plant here.

title: DANCE: TAYLOR COMPANY
description: PAUL TAYLOR'S dances could be categorized as dark grotesqueries, sublimities of light and outpourings of purely physical comedy. On Tuesday at City Center, the Paul Taylor Dance Company presented a program that included all three. The rounded bodies and buoyant attack that unmistakably mark his choreography ran like a thread through the evening. But this was an evening of remarkable variety in mood and theme.

title: Barton Silverman Peter Sweeney, 8, at left, holds a copy of his get-well letter, which President Reagan read in a speech to Congress Tuesday night.  Yesterday, Peter shared the limelight with classmates at the Riverside School in Rockville Centre, L.I.
description: Letter to the President Makes a Pupil a Star

title: U.S.-Japan Auto Talks
description: Bill Brock, the special United States trade representative, arrived in Tokyo today to try to convince Japanese officials to lower their self-imposed car export quotas to the United States even further.

title: Mexican Gas Rise Cleared
description: American importers have been authorized to pay $4.94 per 1,000 cubic feet for Mexican natural gas, a price the Mexican state oil company demanded to match the latest Canadian price increase, the Energy Department said today.

title: JULES C. STEIN, 85, FOUNDER OF MCA, DIES
description: Jules C. Stein, who built a band booking agency with $1,000 capital into MCA Inc., a billion-dollar force in the world of mass entertainment, died yesterday of heart failure in the University of California at Los Angeles Medical Center. He was 85 years old.

title: CAREYS TO SEEK CATHOLIC MARITAL RULING
description: Evangeline Gouletas-Carey said last night that she would ask a Roman Catholic marriage tribunal to nullify her first three marriages so that Governor Carey could seek dispensation from the church for his recent marriage.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: by Florence Fabricant
description: CHOCOLATE has become very popular for wedding cakes and has been used to flavor the icing and decorations as well as the cake and filling. Nut cake, Grand Marnier cake and mocca, carrot and cheese cakes are also vying with white or yellow pound cakes and the traditional ''bride's cake'' made of dark fruit cake.

title: Around the World; U.S. and South Korea Resume Security Talks
description: The United States and South Korea today resumed regular consultations on security that were postponed by the Carter Administration after the military seized power in Seoul in December 1979.

title: Duplicate Desk
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: On behalf of Riverside Furniture Corporation, Fort Smith, Ark., for which our company is the public relations counsel, I would like to clear up some confusing information in your Southern Furniture Market story, ''A Few New Ideas Enliven Quiet Show'' (April 16).

title: Milwaukee Jinx Follows Umpire
description: The umpire Lou DiMuro, hospitalized the last time he came to Milwaukee - in a 1979 home-plate collision with Cliff Johnson - was injured again last night.

title: Design Notebook; HOUSES OF STRENGTH AND SERENITY BY ARATA ISOZAKI
description: ARATA ISOZAKI has never built a building in the United States, but his work in Japan has made him a figure of considerable interest in American architectural circles. And he is about to move into even more prominence: he has begun work on the Los Angeles Museum of Contemporary Art, a new institution that will rise in downtown Los Angeles.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Air Florida System plans to offer 2 million common shares.

title: French Oil Pact in Brazil
description: Ste. Nationale Elf Aquitaine said today that its subsidiary, Ste. Elf Aquitaine Bresil, had signed contracts with Brazil to explore for oil in the central Amazon region.

title: FLOW OF ARMS TO SALVADORAN REBELS IS SAID TO INCREASE ALONG NEW ROUTES
description: After a lull, the flow of arms to rebel forces in El Salvador has increased and has changed routes, senior Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: FARMERS ELATED OVER END TO CURB ON GRAIN FOR SOVIET
description: A warm wind swept across the rolling hills and rich bottomlands here in eastern Iowa, big green tractors churned across the black fields, and farmers walked with a renewed spring in their steps, for it was time to begin planting corn.

title: Wurlitzer Chief Quits Suddenly
description: Wiliam N. Herleman, the 57-year-old chairman of the Wurlitzer Company, resigned suddenly yesterday. His resignation from three corporate posts - he is president and chief executive, as well as chairman - becomes effective today, according to a brief statement from the company's Dekalb, Ill., headquarters late yesterday afternoon.

title: DEMOCRATS IN HOUSE ADD MILITARY FUNDS TO PROPOSED BUDGET
description: House Democratic leaders agreed today to restore money for the military in an attempt to win the support of party conservatives for their budget plan in what is shaping up as a close vote on President Reagan's budget.

title: by Bob Cary
description: If a fleet of tank trucks loaded with waste sulfuric acid slipped across the border into Canada and dumped the poison into a number of lakes, killing all the fish, the outcry from both sides of the border would be immediate and loud.

title: CONTRADICTORY AMERICAN AND SAUDI POLICIES
description: To the Editor:

title: A Pedestrian Is Killed As Auto Jumps Curb
description: One pedestrian was killed and another was critically injured last evening after they were struck by a speeding car that jumped onto a sidewalk at 17th Street and Seventh Avenue, the police and witnesses said.

title: Governor of California Sues U.S.  To Block Oil-Drilling Lease Plan
description: Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. and a coalition of environmental groups filed suits today against Interior Secretary James G. Watt in an effort to block his plan to issue oil drilling leases off the California coast.

title: A Classic 'Hers'
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: Concerning the ''Hers'' column by Mary Kay Blakely (April 16): This is a classic! It should be required reading for every person who questions why society in general and marriage in particular appear so fragile today. It represents the absolute ultimate (so far) expression of the narcissist.

title: People
description: * Horace Malfa, executive vice president, named to the additional post of general manager of Cunningham & Walsh's Eastern region, and Arthur Meranus, a senior vice president, has been named director of creative services.

title: Algerian Oil Levy Stands
description: Algeria has not dropped a $1.50-abarrel oil levy it charges Western oil companies to cover research and technical assistance, Energy Ministry sources said today.

title: Polaroid Product
description: The Polaroid Corporation said it would introduce in the next few weeks an authentication material enabling manufacturers, retailers and customers to protect themselves from counterfeit products offered as brand-name merchandise. The material, which Polaroid said was virtually impossible to counterfeit, may be attached to products such as designer clothes, jewelry, recording tapes, records, wines and spirits or cosmetics. It can be examined in normal light, without use of a special viewing device, to verify authenticity of a product, Polaroid said.

title: A REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: MOTHERS' VIGIL IN ARGENTINA
description: A march last Thursday by mothers demanding an accounting of their missing children was larger than most of their recent demonstrations. The 100 or so women walked quietly in a circle for about a half an hour around an obelisk in the Plaza de Mayo, a small park of water fountains and neat flower beds.

title: TO THE HOME SECTION: Mary Kay Blakely's essay on Agnes's ice cream in the ''Hers'' column has touched a raw nerve in me and probably every woman who read it.
description: You seem to think that marriage is doing whatever you did before you were married, except having someone doing it with you. I see this as a sterile, self-centered and one-sided definition of marriage.

title: QUALITY WOES BEDEVIL DETROIT
description: Robert Quarti of Kensington, Conn., decided to take advantage of a $500 rebate offer last month to buy a new Chevrolet Citation, one of the ''X'' series of cars sold by the General Motors Corporation. As he drove home from work a few days later he noticed a rattle in the dash panel. When he investigated, the whole panel slumped toward him.

title: NEWLYWED CHINESE DANCER HELD ON VISIT TO HIS CONSULATE IN U.S.
description: Li Cunxin, a Chinese ballet dancer, was freed Wednesday evening from 21 hours' detention at his country's consulate, where he had gone to explain that he wanted to stay in this country with his American wife of three days.

title: U.S. JURY STARTS ITS DELIBERATIONS ON WILLIAMS ABSCAM CHARGES
description: After a month of testimony, a Federal jury in Brooklyn began its deliberations last night in the Abscam bribery trial of Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. of New Jersey.

title: GETTING MARRIED: NO PLACE LIKE HOME
description: ''IT'S 10 minutes after 4 - we'd better get started,'' Elena Prohaska said. So she and Burton S. Glinn took their places in front of the flower-bedecked mantel in their living room, and Richard W. Wallach, Justice of the New York State Supreme Court, pronounced them husband and wife in a simple ceremony.

title: THE PLIGHT OF THE EMBASSY WIFE
description: It used to be so easy. The embassy tea parties. The native dancers on the front lawn. The shopping trips to quaint bazaars.

title: Golfers Reject Move To Divide Pro Tour
description: A proposal to divide the professional golf tour into two segments, with a player draft supplying talent for each circuit, was overwhelmingly rejected tonight at a meeting of 100 players who are here for the Houston open.

title: Merck and Astra In Drug Venture
description: Merck & Company and AB Astra, a Swedish pharmaceutical company, announced an agreement in principle to establish a joint venture in the United States for the development and marketing of certain pharmaceuticals discovered by Astra.

title: Advertising; ProClinica's Unusual Approach
description: YOU do not find too many ad agency presidents taking pictures in operating rooms, not even the ones specializing in health care accounts.

title: BECHTELS GET CONTROL OF DILLON, READ
description: The Bechtel family of San Francisco, which controls the Bechtel Group, one of the world's biggest engineering companies, has bought a controlling interest in Dillon, Read & Company, the Wall Street investment banking house, the two announced jointly yesterday.

title: Insider Reports for Exchanges
description: The New York and the American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges. NEW YORK EXCHANGE

title: BRIEFS
description: * Atlantic Oil Corp. plans an $18 million joint oil and gas venture with Heafitz, Widmann, McMahon & Gardener Ltd. Approximately half of the cash will be provided by American Gas and Oil Investors.
To the Editor:

title: Peoples Drug Pact
description: Peoples Drug Stores Inc., a self-service chain based in Alexandria, Va., announced the signing of a definitive agreement for the purchase of 21 retail drugstores in Iowa and Minnesota operated by Drug Fair Inc. of Iowa City. Peoples said that the transaction, effective June 1, was for an undisclosed amount of cash and Peoples common shares. It added that Carroll Lust, founder and president of Drug Fair, would continue as chief operating officer of what would be a new division of Peoples.

title: Holiday Inns: Profit Up 19.4%
description: Holiday Inns Inc. today reported a record first-quarter profit despite a decline in the occupancy rate at the company's hotels and motels.

title: LAG BY CITY CITED IN ROAD BUILDING AND SEWER WORK
description: New York City is losing the struggle to repair its streets, bridges and sewer system and lacks a comprehensive plan to stop their deterioration, according to City Council President Carol Bellamy.

title: Cubs 6, Cards 1
description: CHICAGO (UPI) - A double by Bill Buckner with two out was the key blow in a five-run eighth, as Chicago ended a 12-game losing streak in the opener of a doubleheader. The Cards had won eight in a row.

title: THE WAR ON DRUGS BADLY NEEDS A SHOT IN THE ARM
description: To the Editor:

title: A'S WIN 18TH, TIE A RECORD
description: Mike Norris pitched a five-hitter to help the A's snap a two-game losing streak in a fightmarred 6-4 over the California Angels today. The A's, leaders in the American League West with an 18-3 record, tied the major league mark for victories in April.

title: LTV to Divest Itself Of Wilson Food Unit
description: The LTV Corporation announced yesterday that it would spin off its Wilson Foods unit through a distribution of the latter's stock to holders of LTV.

title: Circulation Aide Named by Times
description: Russell T. Lewis, 33 years old, was named director of circulation sales yesterday for The New York Times. Mr. Lewis, who joined the newspaper as a copy boy in 1966, has been a staff attorney for The Times since January 1977.

title: ARGENTINA CLOSES BORDER WITH CHILE AFTER 2 ARRESTS
description: Argentina closed its border with Chile today after the imprisonment of two Argentine army officers inside Chile.

title: Home Improvement; HOW-TO BOOKS ON REMODELING AND REPAIRING YOUR HOME
description: DUE to the tremendous increase in the cost of housing and the shortage of mortgage money, many people who are dissatisfied with their houses are more interested in remodeling or repairing than in trying to buy new ones.

title: Rangers 5, Red Sox 0
description: Danny Darwin allowed one hit, a bloop single to Rick Miller leading off the fifth, to give Texas three straight shutouts for the first time in its 10-year history.

title: Around the World; Senate Approves Treaty On Sea Border With Canada
description: The Senate voted 91 to 0 today to approve a treaty with Canada under which a panel of international judges would be asked to settle a dispute over maritime boundaries in the Gulf of Maine.

title: Choice Backed On 9-Digit ZIP
description: Postmaster General William F. Bolger told a Senate subcommittee today that he supported a bill that would keep the nine-digit ZIP code voluntary and dispel ''lingering fears'' about the plan.

title: Lowenstein Reports Talks on Takeover
description: Robert Bendheim, chairman of the M. Lowenstein Corporation, said that discussions were being held with an American company for the possible acquisition of Lowenstein for $49 a share. The price offered by the unidentified buyer surprised analysts, since it was almost double the current value of Lowenstein's common stock.

title: 600 YEARS OF GLASS OF CZECHOSLOVAKIA
QADDAFI ENDS A VISIT TO MOSCOW WITH ACCORD ON GENERAL POLICIES
description: The Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, today ended a three-day visit that was marked by displays of friendship and agreement on generalities.

title: MARGIOTTA EXTORTION CASE ENDS IN A MISTRIAL
description: The trial of Joseph M. Margiotta, the Nassau County Republican chairman, ended in a mistrial this evening. The jury, considering charges of mail fraud and extortion, remained deadlocked after 64 hours of deliberations over eight days.

title: News Analysis
description: The simmering suspicions dividing India and Pakistan are again becoming inflamed, this time raising the prospect of the first nuclear arms race between countries that are not superpowers.

title: VW's 1980 Net Fell 51.9%
description: Volkswagen A.G. said today that its earnings fell 51.9 percent last year, to about $177.3 million, largely because of losses at several foreign auto making units and its Triumph-Adler office machine division.

title: Notes On People; A Jazz Singer Has Something Cheerful to Sing About
description: Chris Connor insists she has nothing against rock, and says she even likes listening to it. But Miss Connor sings jazz, and for a while, she acknowledged, the rock revolution made it hard for jazz singers to get bookings.

title: PAPERS AND GUILD RENEW TALKS ON DUAL PAY SCALE
description: Negotiators for the Newspaper Guild and The New York Times and The Daily News renewed contract talks last night and continued to negotiate early this morning to resolve a difficult issue relating to dual minimum wage scales for new and older employees.

title: FREE SPEECH IS VITAL TO FOREIGN SERVICE TOO
description: To the Editor:

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, APRIL 30, 1981
description: International Concern about the fighting in Lebanon was expressed by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. The Reagan Administration did not criticize Israel for its shooting down of two Syrian helicopters Tuesday, but it sought to dissociate the United States from the Israeli action, apparently in an effort to maintain some leverage as a possible intermediary. (Page A1, Column 6.) Syria moved antiaircraft missiles into eastern Lebanon in apparent response to Israel's downing of the two Syrian helicopters there. But the Syrians were said to have suspended helicopter attacks on Christian positions near the tacks on Christian positions near the town of Zahle. (A3:1.)

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on Monday about the role of specialists in the economic rivalry between the North and the South incorrectly identified the affiliation of three professors. John Rees, Bernard L. Weinstein and Donald A. Hicks are faculty members at the University of Texas at Dallas.

title: WITNESS IS SLAIN ON BROOKLYN STREET HOURS BEFORE DRUG CASE TESTIMONY
description: A retired truck salesman who had helped investigators break up an international drug smuggling ring was shot and killed yesterday on a Brooklyn street hours before he was scheduled to testify in Federal court.

title: SYRIA MOVES MISSILES TO COUNTER ISRAELIS
description: Syria moved antiaircraft missiles into the Bekaa Valley of eastern Lebanon today in apparent response to the Israeli downing of two Syrian helicopters yesterday.

title: Q&A
description: Q. My aluminum awnings are about 20 years old. The finish is fading, so I want to paint them this summer. Is a primer is needed, and what type of paint I should use? - A.W., Pittsburgh.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 17.50-18.00 ** Current rate excludes 3 percentage-point surcharge on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Poletown Wrecker's Ball
description: Detroit is hurting. Unemployment in the Motor City is up to 18 percent and benefits are running out. Nowhere in America is economic depression more a reality.

title: Sunpapers' Publisher
description: Reg Murphy, the 47-year-old publisher and editor of The San Francisco Examiner, plans to concentrate on the editorial product in his new job as publisher of The Baltimore Sunpapers. He will assume the position after July 1, succeeding Donald H. Patterson, 64, who will continue as president of the A.S. Abell Company, which owns the newspapers.

title: PIRATES POUND METS AGAIN IN A 10-1 ROUT
description: Actually, it was the electricians at Shea Stadium who were the real culprits last night in the Mets' 10-0 loss to the Pittsburgh Pirates.

title: By Sports of The Times; The Islanders' Former Ranger
description: SKATING around during the warmup before the opener of the Stanley Cup semifinal, Mike McEwen never even glanced back at the team he was with two years ago.

title: Britain Lowers Oil Estimate
description: The Department of Energy said today that it had lowered its estimate of recoverable reserves of oil on Britain's continental shelf by about 1 percent. At the same time, it said it had raised its estimate of gas reserves slightly.

title: PAPAL ENVOY SEES ULSTER AIDES ON HUNGER STRIKERS
description: A personal represenative of Pope John Paul II held urgent talks with Government officials today in his effort to halt hunger strikes by four leaders of the Irish Republican Army.

title: 3 New Keyboards
description: Honeywell Inc. introduced three membrane-type keyboards for wordprocessing machines and electronic data terminals. The keyboards would cost 25 to 65 percent less than current solid-state and electromechanical keyboards and permit faster and more accurate operation of keyboard machines, according to William L. Spivey, marketing director of mechanical products for Honeywell.

title: Hamburg Offices Firebombed
description: Firebombs hurled through the windows of two Social Democratic Party offices and a land registry building here today caused several thousand dollars' damage, the police said. No one was injured. The police said they did not know whether the attacks were connected with similar incidents in the last two weeks protesting the death of Sigurd Debus, a jailed terrorist, after a two-month hunger strike.

title: Tidewater Purchase
description: Tidewater Inc. said it had signed a letter of intent with the Hillman Manufacturing Company of Pittsburgh to acquire a Hillman subsidiary, R.L. Frailey Inc., of Tulsa, Okla., engineers and constructors of natural gas processing plants. Tidewater, which supplies marine support services to the petroleum industry, said the proposed acquisition called for an exchange of stock and was subject to a purchase agreement and approval by regulatory authorities and the boards of both company. Tidewater did not disclose the number of shares to be exchanged.

title: Film Rights to 'Gorky Park' Sold for $250,000
description: Screen rights to ''Gorky Park,'' the No. 1 fiction title on The New York Times Best Seller List this week, have been purchased for more than $250,000 by Howard Koch Jr. and Gene Kirkwood. John Schlesinger, the director of ''Midnight Cowboy'' and ''Sunday, Bloody Sunday,'' has been signed to direct the movie.

title: Acting Now to Relieve 1984
description: Raise a cheer for Richard Richards of Utah, the new chairman of the Republican National Committee. He has made the prospect of 1984 look a little brighter. Not the 1984 of Orwell's gloomy anticipation; we have in mind the next Presidential campaign.

title: Kenyon & Eckhardt Wins All of Turtle Wax Back
description: After the briefest of flings as a two-agency company, Turtle Wax Inc. of Chicago has consolidated back to one again.

title: STAGE: W.S. GILBERT'S 'ENGAGED'
description: The soap opera is a relatively new, and perhaps deplorable, kind of entertainment. The parodies of soap operas are not just perhaps deplorable; they are absolutely deplorable, and you may think they have scarcely any honorable antecedents at all. You are wrong. In 1877, W.S. Gilbert, Arthur Sullivan's misogynous partner, wrote ''Engaged,'' a comedy about marriage that flouted everything that other eminent Victorians were saying about it. The Manhattan Punch Line is treating this curious antique as farce, and offering it one of its customarily energetic and skillful productions.

title: by Terry Robards
description: ONE of the classic moments for Champagne is the toast at a wedding reception, a tradition that no wedding should be without. Champagne is equally appropriate served throughout the reception, for it is the quintessential wine of celebration. It adds a special touch that no other beverage can impart.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: VOWS: JUDGES AND CLERGY
description: FIRST things first. If you want to be married at home, start by getting someone to officiate. Roman Catholic and Greek Orthodox priests do not perform marriages in homes, and Congregationalist ministers, too, would normally refuse.

title: Gardening; WHAT TO DO THIS MONTH THE CITY GARDENER; by Linda Yang
description: Plant Purchases To achieve a full garden quickly, buy mature shrubs and trees with roots that are balled and burlapped or in nursery containers. These plants have feeder roots intact and there is minimal shock from moving. Bare root plants are less expensive but slower growing and harder to start in poor soil or on roofs. Bare root plants will do better if the roots are well soaked in a solution of water and diluted fertilizer.

title: IN SOUTH AFRICA, SOMETIMES THE SOUND OF LAUGHTER
description: JOHANNESBURG FOR all the efforts of its official publicists, the impression of itself that South Africa conveys to the world is compounded of fear, suffering and, above all, conflict. It might seem to follow that the South African scene is bleak and joyless. Often it is, but sometimes, especially when the Market Theater here is going full force, it can be vibrant with life and more than a little hilarious.

title: Socal Net Up 6.2% In First Quarter
description: The Standard Oil Company of California reported yesterday that its first-quarter net income increased by 6.2 percent from the comparable quarter last year, further confirming an oil industry trend of slower growth in earnings.

title: EARTH SHUTTLES WANTED To the Editor:$
description: While the successful voyage of the space shuttle captures the headlines, some of us Earthlings are far more concerned with the possibility of losing the safest, most energy-efficient, noncongesting, non-air-polluting mode of travel yet devised: the passenger train.

title: LEDERER QUITS CONGRESS OVER CONVICTION IN ABSCAM
description: Representative Raymond F. Lederer, faced with almost certain expulsion from the House of Representatives because of his conviction in the Government's Abscam investigation, resigned from Congress today.

title: NICARAGUA AND HONDURAS CLOSE BORDER AFTER CLASHES
description: Honduras and Nicaragua have closed their common border and sent troop reinforcements to the area after a number of minor clashes that the Managua Government says have been provoked by Nicaraguan exiles operating from inside Honduran territory. But after an exchange of gunfire across the border last night, Honduran and Nicaraguan military commanders reportedly met today in the hope of reducing tensions and reopening the frontier.

title: JUSTICES UPHOLD RESTRICTIONS ON RIGHT TO VOTE FOR WATER DISTRICT OFFICIAL
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that the right to vote for directors of a public water district, a local government unit that is common in the Western states, can be restricted to owners of property in the district.

title: REAGAN SCHOOL AID PLAN UNVEILED
description: The Reagan Administration today unveiled its legislative proposal to consolidate 44 Federal school aid programs into two block grants to the states.

title: Careys Agree to Accept Conflict of Interest Rules
description: Governor Carey and his wife agreed today to abide by a set of guidelines for avoiding conflicts of interests stemming from Mrs. Gouletas-Carey's condominium business, the Governor's press office said.

title: Going Out Guide
description: STEPPING LIVELY

title: EX-BUSBOY CHARGED IN STOUFFER'S BLAZE
description: A 25-year-old former busboy at Stouffer's Inn in Harrison, N.Y., was arrested this morning and charged with arson and 26 counts of murder in a fire that swept the inn last December, killing 26 business executives.

title: INDICTMENT ISSUED IN BUFFALO AREA SLAYINGS
description: A grand jury in Erie County today issued a sealed indictment against a suspect in three of seven murders of black men in this area last year, according to District Attorney Edward C. Cosgrove.

title: TAYLOR SAYS GIANTS MADE HIM WELCOME
description: Lawrence Taylor is 6 feet 3 inches and 245 pounds, has an 18 1/2-inch neck and is strong enough to bench-press 395 pounds. But he is low key and smiles easily, and he describes himself as ''a as ''a

title: REAGAN LOSES ON GRAIN PLANS
description: The Senate Agriculture Committee today abruptly dropped President Reagan's plan for more flexible price supports on next year's wheat crop and voted to continue the grain subsidies that he wanted to eliminate.

title: The U.N. Today; April 30, 1981; SECURITY COUNCIL
description: Meets on Namibia at 5 P.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL

title: Astros 5, Braves 4
description: ATLANTA (UPI) - Jose Cruz singled to score Craig Reynolds from third in the ninth inning for Houston.

title: Foreign Policy Chaos
description: One of candidate Reagan's most telling campaign arguments was against what he called the disarray of the Carter foreign policy. It was time, he said, for the United States to stop sending conflicting signals to our friends and adversaries abroad. He promised policies that were clear, strong and above all consistent.

title: Around the Nation; 2 Kentucky Truckers Shot In a Clash With Coal Miners
description: By The Associated Press Two men were shot in a confrontation between striking coal miners and independent truckers in Kentucky yesterday, and the police dispersed 75 pickets at a coal mine in southern West Virginia in the 34th day of the United Mine Workers' strike.

title: REAGAN PLEASED BY REACTION TO HIS SPEECH
description: On his 100th day in office, President Reagan spent three hours in the Oval Office as his staff issued schedule announcements showing that he was increasing his workload.

title: TO THE HOME SECTION: A column titled ''Hers'' isn't likely to attract many hims, but you did gain my attention with your column a week ago on marriage and what can happen to a woman when she becomes a wife. It is sufficient to say that the column touched me personally.
description: So I tried ''Hers'' again this morning. You should be a fencer.

title: BOND YIELDS SET NEW HIGHS
description: Rising short-term interest rates and a lack of investor demand combined yesterday to raise yields in the credit markets to record levels for securities due in more than three years.

title: TV: PAULIST DRAMA ON TEEN-AGE PREGNANCY
description: ''GIRL on the Edge of Town,'' on WNEW-TV tonight at 9 o'clock, is a modest and well-intentioned, but irritatingly inept, drama about teen-age pregnancy, abortion and adoption services. The hourlong program merits attention primarily because it comes from Roman Catholic sources, specifically Paulist Productions. The executive producer is billed as Elwood Kieser, Paulist. Written by Jim McGinn, the production is part of a Capital Cities series of ''Family Specials.'' Past presentations have treated such issues as teen-age alcoholism and suicide.

title: Owners Reject Latest Proposal
description: Ray Grebey, chief negotiator for baseball's club owners, formally rejected yesterday the players' latest proposal in the free-agent compensation dispute, saying it was still up to the players to make a move that would avert a threatened strike May 29.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: The Ford Motor Company said today that it planned to raise the price of its average equipped 1981-model car by 2.1 percent, or $178, effective Friday. The increase lifts the average price of a Ford car to $8,817, up $456 during the 1981 model year, a company spokesman said.

title: SOME DEMOCRATS ACCUSE O'NEILL OF A LACK OF STRONG LEADERSHIP
description: As Democrats grope to find a way of resisting President Reagan's legislative assault on Capitol Hill, several of them are openly grumbling about their party's leadership, and particularly about the Speaker of the House, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr.

title: PRIME RISE TO 18% LED BY CHASE
description: Amid unsettled conditions in the money markets, several leading banks increased their prime rates yesterday to 18 percent from 17 1/2 percent.

title: Mrs. Frontiere Becomes Sole Owner of Rams
description: Georgia Rosenbloom Frontiere formally became the sole owner of the Los Angeles Rams today when a Superior Court judge approved the sale of her son's stock.

title: There's No Blinking at Medicaid
description: New Yorkers can be grateful that Governor Carey and the Senate majority leader, Warren Anderson, are talking again, at least enough to pass a budget that is a month overdue. Their petty and even vituperative brawl served no one; it also proved costly. Millions of dollars were lost while hospitals, nursing homes and schools were forced into makeshift borrowing to meet expenses. And for all that, it's not even clear yet who won this battle.

title: Helpful Hardware; SHELVING CONNECTORS; by Barbara Isenberg and Mary Smith
description: FOR designing and assembling your own movable storage or shelving configurations, we have found some special clips that will do the job without carpentry.

title: Gardening; WHAT TO DO THIS MONTH THE COUNTRY GARDENER
description: Lawns May will be the critical month. Ample rainfall should complete the comeback of drought-ravaged lawns and establish rooting of those newly seeded or sodded. Apply pre-emergent crabgrass controls early, before lilacs bloom. If your lawn was not fed last month apply fertilizer. Consider application of granular 2,4-D/Banvel combination where broad-leafed weeds and chickweed are problems. Mow often so clippings are short; do not rake them up since they replenish nitrogen.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard THE MEETING AT TELGTE. By Gunter Grass. Translated from the German by Ralph Manheim. Afterword by Leonard Forster. 147 pages. Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $9.95.

title: Business Digest; THURSDAY, APRIL 30, 1981; The Economy
description: The prime lending rate was raised to 18 percent by several leading banks following a sharp rise in key short-term interest rates. Some banks rely heavily on short-term Federal funds to finance loans, and these funds surged as high as 24 percent yesterday from 17 1/2 percent on Tuesday. Chase Manhattan initiated the move in the prime from 17 1/2 percent. Bank of America and Citibank, however, stayed at 17 1/2 percent. (D1.)

title: RISE IN U.S. OPTIMISM ON ECONOMY BOLSTERS REAGAN SUPPORT, POLL HINTS
description: The optimism of the American public about personal economic prospects appears to be rising and helping President Reagan hold widespread popular support, even among critics of his tax plans and among those who think his proposed spending cuts will hurt them personally, according to the latest New York Times/ CBS News Poll.

title: Kuriles Volcano Erupts
description: The Atlasov volcano in the Kuril Islands off the Pacific coast of the Soviet Union erupted last night, the press agency Tass reported today. The eruption, off the southern tip of the Kamchatka Peninsula, covered the settlement of Severokurilsk on nearby Paramushir Island with ashes up to 10 inches deep.

title: LEADING INDICATORS UP BY 1.4%
description: The Government's index of leading indicators, which seeks to assess the future course of the economy, rose by 1.4 percent last month, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Philip Morris Plans To Raise Spending
description: Capital expenditures by Philip Morris Inc. are expected to rise to about $950 million this year from $756 million in 1980, George Weissman, chairman and chief executive officer, told the annual meeting in Richmond. The tobacco and beverage producer will spend a further $2.5 billion in the four years beginning in 1982, he added.

title: News Analysis
description: There may be a bittersweet message in a report released yesterday showing improvement in reading skills in the early grades of school and a worsening in the high school years: Learning to read is very different from reading to learn.

title: HOUSE PANEL LINKS AID TO SALVADOR TO CURB ON 'INDISCRIMINATE' KILLING
description: The House Foreign Affairs Committee voted today to impose restrictions on United States military aid to El Salvador that would require President Reagan to provide assurances that ''indiscriminate torture and murder'' by Salvadoran security forces is being brought under control.

title: HOME SALES UP BY 0.6% FOR MARCH
description: Sales of new single-family houses rose six-tenths of 1 percent in March, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 511,000, despite continued high mortgage interest rates, the Government reported today.

title: McNeil Is Confident He Can Benefit Jets
description: His mother brought him up by the Bible, the Jets' No. 1 draft choice said yesterday. And then he added his little yesterday. And then he added his little joke: ''If they give to me, then they'll receive.''

title: FLOWERS: A FESTIVE NOTE
description: THE first thing to be said is that it's perfectly legal to get married without flowers and that a blossomless wedding will have no appreciable effect on the quality of the marriage.

title: CLAM COMEBACK BEGINNING ON L.I.
description: ''Just like picking up nickels and dimes,'' said Jim Wood, planting his long-handled clam tongs in the shallow bottom around his boat and hauling up muddy forkfuls of dark-shelled chowder clams, cherrystones and a few prized littlenecks. One clam each 36 seconds, he calculated, was 100 clams an hour; at about $50 per 500 wholesale, that's $10 an hour.

title: HIGH FASHION: DAZZLING DAY
description: NOBODY ever accused Oscar de la Renta of designing quiet, unassuming clothes, but this time the voltage was high enough to light a ballroom. Pauline Trigere was at the top of her form with clothes that managed to be calm and ladylike as well as elegantly attractive. (''I hope they're nice, but practical and wearable, too,'' she said as she introduced her show.)

title: BRITISH NEWS MAGAZINE SHUTS AFTER 18 MONTHS
description: The arrival of Now!, a lavishly printed news magazine, stirred the British publishing scene 18 months ago, although it had little effect on advertisers. Reporters' salaries at Now! averaged more than $35,000 a year, much higher than the going rate at London newspapers.

title: by Paul Craig Roberts
description: It used to be that if a person was against a policy, he said it was ''un-American.'' Today, if you are against a policy, you say it causes deficits and is inflationary.

title: Coast Man to Purchase San Francisco Magazine
description: Another deal that never did come off was Knapp Communications' buying San Francisco magazine.

title: SIMPATICO SEATING
description: IT'S a chair, it's a chaise and it was one of the most talked about pieces of furniture in Milan last fall. The strange-looking seating unit is by the Milan-based Japanese designer Toshiyuki Kita.

title: Con Edison Head Committed to Coal
description: Arthur Hauspurg, the new president of the Consolidated Edison Company, who will also become chief executive officer when Charles F. Luce steps down on Aug. 1, has an extensive background with coalburning utilities. He is therefore determined to increase Con Edison's use of coal to help produce electricity.

title: Bridge: Long Island Regional Play Begins at Hofstra Tonight
description: For enthusiasts in Nassau and Suffolk Counties the high point in the tournament year is the Long Island Regional, which begins tonight at the Hofstra University Physical Fitness Center, Hempstead, L.I.

title: PRESS AIDE'S RECOVERY PROGRESS SET BACK, WHITE HOUSE REPORTS
description: James S. Brady, the White House press secretary, has been confined to a reclining position in his hospital bed for the next 10 days to two weeks because of renewed leakage of air into his brain, the White House reported today.

title: TRIAL IS TOLD CRIMMINS LEFT POST NIGHT OF MET SLAYING
description: The man who supervised Craig S. Crimmins's work the night a violinist was slain at the Metropolitan Opera House testified yesterday that the 22-year-old stagehand disappeared from his assigned post after 9 o'clock and did not return to work until the next day.

title: Celtics Win to Force a 6th Game
description: Just when it appeared the Celtics were headed for a second-straight five-game defeat in the Eastern Conference championship round, the Philadelphia 76ers faltered tonight, and Michael Leon Carr became an instant hero.

title: Texaco Finds Gas Off California Shore
description: Texaco Inc. said today that a wildcat well in Federal waters of the Santa Barbara channel had yielded natural gas, proving that the Pitas Point gas field extended farther to the west than had been known.

title: HAIG SAYS FIGHTING IN CENTRAL LEBANON IS 'VERY WORRISOME'
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr.said today that the situation in Lebanon was ''very worrisome'' because of the increased dangers caused by stepped-up Syrian and Israeli military activity there.

title: PARSONS IS GIVEN A GRANT TO SET UP DESIGN CENTER
description: ATEACHER from the Parsons School of Design was wearing his usual black tie, but over one shoulder he had draped a plaid shawl. Next to him stood a woman in top-to-toe sequins. And standing next to her was Perry Ellis in a simple navy blazer.

title: SCREEN: 'IN FOR TREATMENT,' ABOUT DUTCH HOSPITALS
description: THE beginning of ''In for Treatment'' almost has the ring of black comedy, as a man embarks on a series of medical tests at a hospital where he is babied, denied information and eventually refused permission to leave. Although Mr. de Waal (Helmert Woudenberg) seems perfectly healthy when he enters the hospital, the nurses are soon annoyed to find him walking instead of using a wheelchair. The aides who administer tests that de Waal doesn't visibly need assure him, ''Don't worry, it's all done by computer.''

title: Carlton, Victor, Gets His 3,000th Strikeout
description: Steve Carlton became the first lefthander in baseball history to surpass 3,000 strikeouts, as he beat the Montreal Expos tonight, 6-2, for his fourth victory.victory.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I want to make it fully clear that the United States has not given a green light to Israel to undertake any military actions in Lebanon.'' - Dean Fischer, State Department spokesman. (A1:6.)

title: BLACK COLLEGES SLIP AS A SOURCE FOR DRAFT
description: The National Football League's draft ended yesterday with the final six of the 12 rounds of selections, and conspicuous by their small numbers were players drafted from Southern colleges with predominantly black student bodies, such as Grambling, Jackson State, Morgan State and Tennessee State.

title: CONCERT: INDIANA U.
description: THE Indiana University Philharmonic Orchestra had a good time breaking down musical manners in Avery Fisher Hall on Monday night. The brash American assertiveness of Charles Ives's Fourth Symphony never degenerated into modernist bombast.

title: COMPLETED INTEGRATION PLAN APPROVED BY CHICAGO BOARD
description: The Chicago school board submitted to a Federal court today a completed school desegregation plan that severely restricts and delays busing and would leave hundreds of schools predominantly white, all black or all Hispanic.

title: SOWETO BLACKS TRY TO IGNORE WHITE ELECTION
description: There were no last-minute efforts to get out the vote in a neighborhood called Mapetla this evening. That's because there was no voting there in today's South African election.

title: Notes On People; Congratulations and Champagne From Nixon
description: ''Justice,'' said the note, ''ultimately prevails.'' It was just one of hundreds of such messages of congratulations received last week by two former officials of the Federal Bureau of Investigation after they received Presidential pardons for their role in illegal F.B.I. break-ins.

title: Around the Nation; Court to Be Asked to Back People's Temple Settlement
description: A lawyer said yesterday that he would ask a state court to approve a $1.4 million settlement of the Government's claims against the People's Temple to cover burial expenses for more than 900 members of the cult who died in mass murders and suicides.

title: WILLIAM MEIKLEJOHN, TALENT SCOUT
description: William Meiklejohn, a talent agent who ''discovered'' such Hollywood figures as Mickey Rooney, Judy Garland and a young radio announcer named Ronald Reagan, died Sunday at St. Joseph Medical Center in Burbank. He had been receiving treatment for a perforated ulcer. He was 78 years old.

title: Gimbel and Saks Had '80 Gain
description: The Gimbel Brothers and Saks Fifth Avenue stores, units of the Batus Retail division, had gains of 85.6 percent in net income and 11 percent in sales in the fiscal year 1980 over levels a year earlier, the parent company reported yesterday. The 1980 fiscal year, ending Jan. 3, had 53 weeks, the 1979 year, 52.

title: News of Music; COLLEGE NAMES DIVISION FOR COPLAND
description: AMERICA'S musical community has been straining its collective imagination to figure out new and different ways to honor Aaron Copland, celebrating his 80th year. Queens College came up with a particularly original and enduring one this week when it renamed its music department the Aaron Copland School of Music.

title: President of Somalia Expels 10 Of Ruling Council's 17 Members
description: President Mohammed Siad Barre has dismissed 10 members of the country's 17-member ruling Supreme Revolutionary Council from top Government and political posts, the Somali news agency reported today.

title: HARVARD GROUP VOTES A PLAN FOR MINORITIES FOR THE LAW REVIEW
description: Faculty members of the Harvard Law Review voted a compromise today to support in principle a student effort to increase the number of women and members of minorities on the Harvard Law Review but asked editors of the publication to delay putting their plan into effect for one year.

title: Tool Orders Fall Below 1980
description: Machine tool orders continued at lower levels in March, running 34 percent below March 1980, although there was an increase from the levels of February.

title: BYRNE MAKES DEGNAN AD
description: New Jersey's Secretary of State, Donald Lan, withdrew from the campaign for the Democratic nomination for governor yesterday, while Governor Byrne appeared to drop his professed neutrality in the race by making a campaign commercial in Trenton for John J. Degnan, his former Attorney General.

title: ABC-TV WILL REPLACE 8 SHOWS IN 6 1/2 PRIME-TIME HOURS IN FALL
description: ABC Television announced yesterday that it would drop eight programs from its prime-time schedule for the fall, including the Friday night movie and four long-running series that have fallen into decline - ''Charlie's Angels,'' ''Soap,'' ''Vega$'' and ''Eight Is Enough.''
